column2: A GROUP of Black Shirt artillery officers, and the writer, were sitting in a rudely constructed mess tent on the heights overlooking the No Man's Land of the valley of the Gabat, when some one mentioned the fact that the colonel was a colonial veteran who had lived and fought in East Africa for many years.

Serene and steady, on her overseas voyage to Rio, the largest airship yet constructed, the yon Hindenburg, again demonstrates the capabilities of the rigid lighter-than-air craft soundly built and rightly handled. In this latest product of the Luftschiffbau Zeppelin the Germans have embodied a degree of passenger comfort heretofore unattained in any vehicle of the air.

To impart a truly Springtime motif to the Spring Festival and Ball on April 17 at the Waldorf-Astoria, a decorations committee headed by Mrs. Walter Becker, with the assistance of Mrs. Conrad Buhler, has devised an elaborate decorative scheme which will give the grand ballroom and its foyers the appearance of an outdoor garden.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- Specializing in secular folk songs and dances, the plantation singers of Coastal Georgia, under the sponsorship of Mrs. Maxfield Parrish, will hold their first annual song festival on Thursday evening at the Sea Island Casino.

Following your interesting and accurate article on Charles Martin Hall's discovery of the electrolytic process for producing aluminum there appeared in THE TIMES on March 2 a letter from James A. Clark which conveyed some incorrect impressions about the connection of Romaine Cole with Charles Martin Hall.

An appeal to employed workers to support as far as their means would permit the forthcoming campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for a minimum of $1,500,000 was made yesterday by Matthew Woll, a vice-president of the American Federation of Labor, who is serving as a member of the Citizens Committee.

Fifty-two Saturdays ago yesterday 560 little brown trout pitted their indifference and wariness against the lures and cunning of three times as many local anglers in the meandering murkiness of the Bronx River.
TOKYO, April 4 (AP). -- Lieut. Gen. Juzo Nishio, installed today as vice chief of the Japanese Army general staff, declared a conviction that a war with Soviet Russia was impossible.

THE conflict between dictatorships and representative constitutional governments has for several years been claiming a steadily larger place in the minds of thoughtful people. It is in no way surprising, therefore, that an increasing number of able authors have become engrossed with the subject.

ASMARA, Eritrea, April 4. -- Emperor Haile Selassie's Imperial Guard is reported to have been completely smashed today in the greatest disaster that has yet befallen Ethiopia. His men are declared fleeing in disorder south of Lake Ashangi, pursued by every available plane of the Italian northern forces.

SIGNS of Spring: No more blasts of superheated air from the foyers of "de luxe" houses. . . . The presence on Broadway of Dexter Fellows, greatest living master of overstatement (not excepting the motion picture advertisers).

VATICAN CITY, April 4 (AP). -The emptiest Holy Week Rome has had for many decades will begin tomorrow, when Pope Pius receives the decorated palms from the Bresca family of San Remo. They have supplied the Pontiff's palms for the Sunday before Easter since 1585.

LONDON, April 4. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today told the French Charge d'Affaires, Roger Cambon, and the Belgian Ambassador, Baron de Cartier de Marchienne, that the British could not arrange for a conference of the Locarno powers in Brussels next week, which the French have been insisting upon ever since Adolf Hitler's latest peace proposals were received in London last Wednesday.

THE United Kingdom's move to renew, with modifications, its Royal Charter that controls and finances radio has stirred discussion on both sides of the Atlantic, possibly because of the British recognition that "the constitution has worked well and has served as a model elsewhere."

THERE is an element of contradiction in "It Won't Be Flowers." One of those taut, fragile, supersensitive novels, its theme is unexpectedly substantial. For all the delicacy and frequent preciousness of her style. Miss Kelly tackles a real problem and tackles it honestly if naively.

YAQUI Indians, who fled from cruelties in Mexico years ago, carry on in the alkali flats of Arizona a species of Passion drama that is strange to all except Yaquis and not well understood by them. Mummers call themselves Fariseos (Pharisees).
Stories of the Canadian Northwest in which huskies, otters, beavers, moose, wolves and other animals are the central figures, while lumbermen, engineers and Indian guides furnish the human element.

Generally higher prices for furniture and floor coverings were considered a certainty in the home-furnishings market yesterday as producers completed surveys of flood damage and other factors which will affect Spring and Summer showings.
Flood relief contributions sent yesterday to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross amounted to $9,461.11, bringing the chapter's total fund to $523,294.41 to date.

WHEN rustling became rampant on several spreads clustering around Buffalo Wells, Utah, most of the ranchers looked to young Ace Gilbert to head a committee of vigilante. But Ace, owner of the Lazy 9, saw that there was more to the problem than Sheriff or committee realized.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Sentiment among Republican leaders who came here today for the regional conference called by Chairman Fletcher of the National Committee seemed to favor the nomination of the Western Presidential candidate with the greatest strength in his own section, with the Vice Presidential candidate to be selected from the East.

SINCE Eden man has searched for his lost simplicity, and since Rousseau his literary prospectors have found it among the most poorly paid, the closest to the soil. The comfort that discovery brings (in books) is an unfailing delight.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 4. -A study of social problems in Providence is being pushed ahead rapidly this Spring in the Department of Political Science and Sociology at Brown University. The work is designed to give students and members of the departmental faculty new data for sociological studies and, secondly, to assist local social work and other agencies with their planning.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Frank Knox, Illinois candidate for the Republi can Presidential nomination, tonight outlined a six-point program for his party to advocate for "clearing up the wreckage of the New Deal" and speeding recovery.

IN Mystic, Conn., there is a statue of Major John Mason, a resolute figure alertly drawing a sword, that looks like a cross between Cotton Mather, famous Puritan divine, and Captain Morgan, famous pirate. But Major Mason was like neither of these, although the story of his long and beneficent life shows that he had some of the better qualities of each.

ALTHOUGH cold weather and snow cut down retail sales in the West, volume continued to run substantially ahead of a year ago as trade drew close to the holiday. The increases could be explained, of course, by an early Easter, which brings peak buying of the season more than a week ahead of last year.

AN alcoholic party in Paris ends in a murder over which no one appears to be greatly perturbed except for a few persons whose grief, if it may be so called, arises from perfectly selfish reasons. So far as the law is concerned, the death of Jose Fernandez is held to be suicide, but there are several of those present at the party who have the best of reasons for believing that he was murdered.

THE Dorothy Paris Gallery, 56 West Fifty-third Street, is celebrating its fourth anniversary with a group show that will be current until April 25. A special effort appears to have been made to secure representative work.

ROME, April 4. -- The Italian Government has ordered the expulsion of Giovanni Giglio, a British subject born in Malta and for many years the correspondent here of The Daily Herald, London's Labor party organ.

Several debutantes, headed by Miss Lynne R. Russell, will act as flower girls at the annual gift horse party for the benefit of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work which will be held the afternoon of April 15 at the Exchange Restaurant, 541 Madison Avenue. Serving with Miss Russell are the Misses Janet Olcott, Barbara Hope Gatins and Pamela Prime.

Ed Kleiner and Walter Callahan combined in striking out thirteen men and gave only four hits between them as the strong Abraham Lincoln High School baseball team routed St. Michael's of Brooklyn, 12 -- 4, yesterday at Lincoln Field in one of the leading schoolboy games played in the metropolitan area.

ALBANY, April 4. -- The Legislature so far has turned a deaf ear on the earnest admonition of Governor Lehman in his annual message that the lawmakers no longer put off the task, required of them by the Constitution, to reapportion the State for Congressional as well as Senate and Assembly districts.

MOUNT EVEREST awaits a fresh assault from man; a new climbing expedition pushes out of India into Tibet, watched by the world. Some day man will be the subject of opening sentences about Everest and the mountain will take a subordinate place; but not yet. Everest, unconquered, must still be named first.

WHEN he was at the University of Wisconsin as exchange professor in 1923, Nobel Prize Winner Professor The Svedberg of the University of Upsala had a bright idea which he proceeded to work out with Dr. J.B. Nichols.

AN expedition into the files unearths the copy of a letter dated London, April 8, 1932. Emanating from one of the European companies, it answers a Middle Western correspondent's question as to when a renewal of the ancient practice of issuing Wagnerian sets -- "whole acts or slices from the operas" -- might be expected.

THE campaign biography of a Presidential candidate has made a place for itself as one of the more staid and dignified measures of the high-powered publicity that has developed around the central figures of the Presidential election year. But "staid" and "dignified" must be taken in that connection as merely relative terms.

The Ingersoll-Rand Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1935 a net income of $3,560,360 after Federal taxes, depreciation and other deductions. After dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the income was equal to $3.50 each on 974,130 shares of common stock, excluding 25,130 shares held in the treasury.
PORTSMOUTH, Va., April 4. -With 2,000 hardy fans braving the Wintry weather to see a bit of big league baseball today, Casey Stengel's Dodgers obliged by putting on display a creditable brand.

American and English period furniture and decorations, Oriental rugs and carpets, a Flemish verdure tapestry dating from about 1700 and other furnishings, property of Peterborough Estates, Inc., removed from East Hill, Peterborough, N.H., former residence of Mrs. William H. Schofield, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday afternoon.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 4. -- The opening of the New York trout fishing season attracted only a sprinkling of the faithful to the waters of Westchester and Putnam Counties today. The turnout of anglers was the smallest in years, but the fishing, surprisingly enough, was of a quality to compensate for the rigors that generally attend inaugural expeditions.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 4. -- Eighteen participated in the skeet event at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. The major winner was C.H. Sayre, who broke 49 out of 50 targets. It gave him the high scratch cup. A.S. Bayles had the same total, but was shooting for targets only.

Three captains of the Cunard-White Star Line staff will be assigned to the bridge of the new super-liner Queen Mary when she pulls away from Southampton in May on her maiden transatlantic voyage to New York.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, as well as in the whole week, was restricted in anticipation of details regarding the cotton the government will release yet this season. Fluctuations in old and new crop deliveries held within the narrowest range in several weeks, to end with losses of 1 to 3 points.

Miss Virginia Crocheron Gildersleeve will be honored at a reception and dinner by members of the Barnard Alumnae of Westchester County on Wednesday evening at the Hotel Gramatan, Bronxville, in observance of her twenty-fifth anniversary as Dean of Barnard College. Mrs. J. Anthony Schwarzmann is president of the alumnae group in Westchester and has been active in arrangements.

LEE DUNCAN'S story of his life as a criminal and a convict raises some psychological questions in the reader's mind that lift it out of the ordinary ruck of revolting criminal reminiscences and give it a distinctive value. The first of these is the question, What made him a criminal?

A FUNERAL dirge of wreckers' blows will soon be sounded for the Britannia, the yacht owned and raced by the late King George. She was launched on the Clyde in 1893 for the Prince of Wales, later King Edward VII, and passed on to his son.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 4. -- Vermont defeated the Naval Academy today, 3 to 0, Beadle striking out an even dozen and allowing the Cadets three hits, two of which came in the last inning.
The United States Military Academy at West Point will be the scene of the opening event on the senior schedule of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association for 1936, as given out yesterday.

A PART from the fact that Dr. Williams's biography of George Eliot contains several hitherto unpublished letters, the book would be impressive for its freshness and treatment alone, since the letters are, in the main, relatively unimportant.

Mrs. Ives Washburn will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at her home, 411 East Fifty-seventh Street, for members of the junior committee aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "Parsifal," Wednesday night, at the Metropolitan Opera House, for the benefit of the Hospital and Music Committees of the New York City Visiting Committee.

ARCHAEOLOGISTS have been penetrating the layers of darkness that have surrounded the origins of the New Testament until they have almost arrived at the actual source. With the aid of palaeographers, successively unearthed pieces of papyrus have been identified, and last year the invasion proceeded into the second century.

AIKEN, S.C. -- The leading sport event of the coming week in Aiken will be the first annual dog show of the Aiken County Kennel Club, which is planned for Saturday afternoon at Eustis Park. The club, headed by George N. Owen of Great Neck, L.I., is affiliated with the American Kennel Club and expects to stage a colorful show.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The selection of national convention delegates in five States this week calls attention not only to intra-party struggles but also to the diverse methods of choosing the men who will name the next candidates for President.

LONDON, April 4 (AP). -- Cambridge's beer-drinking oarsmen breezed to victory over Oxford's milk-fed huskies today in the eighty-eighth contest of Great Britain's blue-ribbon intercollegiate rowing classic.

OUR colleague and co-worker, Mr. Orrin Dunlap Jr., radio editor of THE TIMES, contributed to the issue of last Sunday, March 29, an article of special interest to lovers of music. This article discussed the general tenor of the correspondence received by the National Broadcasting Company about its broadcasts on Saturday afternoons of performances by the Metropolitan Opera Association.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 4. -Twenty-nine senior foresters and twelve two-year rangers at the Pennsylvania State College will hold their final college banquet on Monday night. They all expect to be gone from college when formal graduation is conducted in June.

In the dining room of their unfinished new house Mr. and Mrs. Percy Stone find the corpse of a total stranger. Whereupon Amos Petrie makes the unfeeling suggestion that they call the house "Homicide Haven." So much for the title.

BERLIN, April 4. -- The letters of reassurance exchanged by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and the French and Belgian Ambassadors to London provoked great resentment in official quarters here as well as in the more moderate non-Nazi press.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- With election of officers of its Undergraduate Publications Association, Temple University has just completed a project planned several years ago of bringing about full cooperation among The Temple University News, a thrice-weekly newspaper; The Owl, a monthly humorous and literary magazine; The Templar, year book, and the Annual Handbook.

Out-of-town players entered in the preliminary tournament for the United States chess championship continued to hold their own against metropolitan experts in the fourth-round matches at the rooms of Manhattan, Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Clubs, yesterday.

ALTHOUGH born in England, large, kindly Stephen Leacock came to Canada at the age of 6 and his mind and appearance bear the stamp of the New World. He loves his adopted home and its proximity to the United States and, in his own words, "will rock it out to sleep right here."

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Although the Supreme Court administered what was regarded as the coup de grace to an NRA already moribund in May, 1935, that sprawling organization did not really give up the ghost until this week.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 4. -- Vermont defeated the Naval Academy today, 3 to 0, Beadle striking out an even dozen and allowing the Cadets three hits, two of which came in the last inning.
The United States Military Academy at West Point will be the scene of the opening event on the senior schedule of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association for 1936, as given out yesterday.

A PART from the fact that Dr. Williams's biography of George Eliot contains several hitherto unpublished letters, the book would be impressive for its freshness and treatment alone, since the letters are, in the main, relatively unimportant.

Mrs. Ives Washburn will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at her home, 411 East Fifty-seventh Street, for members of the junior committee aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "Parsifal," Wednesday night, at the Metropolitan Opera House, for the benefit of the Hospital and Music Committees of the New York City Visiting Committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 4. -Canadian and American orchardists are becoming greatly interested in research on the development of apples which Miss Mary MacArthur of Nova Scotia is carrying on for her doctor's thesis in the Radcliffe Graduate School.

Resolutions urging endorsement of the American Student Union and the April 22 student strike against war were adopted at the closing session of the two-day Brooklyn intercollegiate anti-war conference which was held at Brooklyn College yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Although the Supreme Court administered what was regarded as the coup de grace to an NRA already moribund in May, 1935, that sprawling organization did not really give up the ghost until this week.

Spring is here with all its familiar signs and delightful portents. For lo! the hooded brothers have appeared -- those hardy anchorites, the skunk cabbages. What recked they of the cold? The pussywillows, too, have braved the caprices of the weather, but they have prudently donned fur coats for the occasion.

Lincoln Ellsworth returned to New York yesterday from his flight across Antarctica with no plan for a new exploration venture, but with a strong desire to return to the southern polar region and fly over the unseen reaches of Enderby Land, south of Africa.
AUSTIN, Texas, April 5. -- The fine points of distinction between a literal, anatomical nude and an abstract nude today appeared destined for a decision by the Federal Centennial Commission.

NEW HAVEN, April 4. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.5, which compares with 82.6 the week before, 82.5 two weeks before, 82.4 three weeks before and 82.8 four weeks before.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Administration forces are expected to rebound this week to business criticism of President Roosevelt's new tax plan by pressing harder than ever for the full program as outlined in his message of March 3.

Although no individual is devilish enough to desire war, nations push themselves into a panic of hostility toward one another that inevitably results in conflict, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said in a sermon yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 5 (AP). -- The marriage six months ago of Harry Bannister, former husband of Ann Harding of the films, and Leah Welt of New York was disclosed here tonight by the bride's sister, Mrs. Leo Kern.
" Broadway sailors" -- complete from white caps to bell-bottomed trousers, and even equipped with liberty cards -- are arousing the navy's ire, it was revealed yesterday.

Plans were announced yesterday by the WPA, to give employment on projects to 5,000 physically handicapped persons in this city. Mrs. Dora H. Crampton, director of the newly created Bureau for the Physiically Handicapped, explained that in addition to providing employment for this group a program of social rehabilitation would be devised to help them find permanent adjustment in the community.
ALBANY, April 5. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill by Assemblyman Steingut, Democratic minority leader, designed to speed up rate cases before the Public Service Commission.

The 104th Field Artillery, National Guard, moved its headquarters yesterday from the garage at 172d Street, near Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, to the new $1,500,000 armory at 168th Street and Ninety-third Avenue, Jamaica. Lieut. Col. Redmond Kernan was in command in the absence of Colonel Charles G. Blakeslee of Binghamton, N.Y., regimental commander.

LONDON, April 5. -- Germans in Tanganyika, Africa, have believed for some time that this mandated colony is to be handed over to Germany by Britain. Their predictions are set forth in an airmailed dispatch to The Times of London from its correspondent in Dar-es-Salaam.

BERLIN, April 5. -- Nazi punishment was visited swiftly upon industrial workers who failed to vote in the March 29 Reichstag elections, it was disclosed today. They were summarily dismissed from their jobs yesterday.

The church needs "young men who can see visions, rather than old men with their dreams," the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland, for nearly a quarter of a century rector of historic St. George's in Stuyvesant Square, declared there yesterday in announcing that he had asked to be relieved of his parochial duties after next Oct. 1.

Permits for new buildings and alterations to existing ones issued in the five boroughs of this city amounted to $153,765,000 last year, according to News and Opinion, the bulletin of the Building Trades Employers Association. The total includes $4,446,000 for projects of the Federal Government on its own land, which are not ordinarily included in building permits.

Albert Proudfoot White, 31-year-old Scottish medical student who had just completed a month's tour of the United States, met instant death on a crowded sidewalk in Seventh Avenue near Fifty-first Street, in front of the Hotel Taft, about 2 P.M. yesterday when he fell or jumped from a room on the fifteenth floor.

The bubble of Oiler invincibility burst before the magnificent ball-handling of the Universals in Madison Square Garden last night as the Hollywood quintet upset the famed McPherson combination to win the final Olympic basketball tryout, 44 to 43.

PARIS, April 3. -- Some surprise may have been caused by the latest Bank of France's return showing that withdrawals of gold for the week ended on March 27 totaled only 114,000,000 francs, which is much too small an amount to explain the bank's decision on March 21 to raise its rate from 3 1/2 to 5 per cent.

HAVANA, April 5 (AP). -- The Government College, composed of the Cabinet and the Council of State, voted a concession tonight to a concern known as the Banco Cuba to establish a daily lottery paying the government $300,000 yearly, which will be divided among beneficent institutions.

Formal announcement will be made today of the offering of $62,545,500 of National Dairy Products Corporation 3 3/4 per cent debentures due on May 1, 1951, with common stock purchase warrants attached, at 100 1/2 to security holders of the corporation by the corporation and a nationwide banking group of seventy members headed by Goldman, Sachs Co.

ROME, April 5. -- Italians believe the main East African campaign in the north is virtually finished. Operations now probably will develop into a number of minor expeditions to take possession of the territory that is already at Italy's mercy, to round up remnants of the defeated Ethiopian armies, suppress brigandage and establish law and order.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 5. -- Two team triumphs today gave the Bermuda one-design craft the lead in their annual Spring series with Long Island Sound's Interclub Class yachts. The series now stands three victories for the home skippers against two for the visitors, the local sailors needing one more to clinch the four-out-of-seven race event.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- Senator William E. Borah of Idaho, arriving here today to start his campaign for support in Illinois and Wisconsin for the Republican Presidential nomination, was asked what he would do at the national convention and he made this cryptic reply:

Seven of the city's leading civic associations joined yesterday in expressing surprise at Mayor La Guardia's failure to support the Baldwin-Hill bill, giving the city complete control over what are now mandatory salary schedules. The bill would restore control of $50,000,000 of annual city appropriations now fixed by State statute.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- On the nineteenth anniversary of America's entry into the World War, the army will turn out in force tomorrow to lead the country in observance of the day.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (AP). -- Announcement was made today that the Francis Wayland Ayer Cup for typographical excellence had been awarded to The New York Herald Tribune, giving it permanent possession of the trophy.

The German Consulate General announced yesterday that coupons of the Dawes loan bonds due on April 15 would be bought in the same manner as were the coupons due on Oct. 15 last. The statement follows:

Considering the packed houses which greeted Artur Schnabel during the recent series of Beethoven recitals here, the small size of the audience gathered at Town Hall yesterday afternoon to hear the Austrian pianist and Bronislaw Huberman in a program of violin and piano sonatas seemed rather surprising.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has just acquired and will place on exhibition this morning a rare painting by Joachim Patinir (circa 1480-1524), one of the earliest landscape painters of the Netherlands. The picture is a triptych, the central panel depicting St. Jerome and the wings portraying the baptism of Christ and the temptation of St. Anthony.

Harry W. Laidler, city chairman of the Socialist party (the Left Wing group, which won the primary fight in the city), issued yesterday an appeal for harmony and urged that all elements of the party, Left Wing and Old Guard, join in building up a democratic, inclusive organization to make a vigorous campaign for the Socialist nominee for President.

In many respects the most striking of last week's sidelights on the financial attitude was resumption of the forward movement on the Stock Exchange. During the early stages of Germany's Rhineland demonstration, stock-market averages had declined 7 1/4 points, and had recovered only slowly.

International rules, which differ considerably from tournament regulations in this country, will prevail in the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship scheduled to start on Thursday evening at the New York Athletic Club. An announcement to that effect was made last night by Edmond Soussa of Egypt, former world's champion and a New York resident at present.

At 11 o'clock yesterday morning the circus was a sprawling array of sleepers, box-cars, shiny red-and-silver cages mounted on flat-cars, and scattered hay in the railroad yards at the Bronx end of the 135th Street-Willis Avenue bridge.

The steady expansion in retail sales throughout the country of Spring apparel and other merchandise was reflected in the wholesale markets here last week, as manufacturers and distributers pushed deliveries of goods for Easter. In addition to placing last-minute reorders for rush shipments, retailers made purchases of regular apparel lines for delivery after Easter.

Brown Brothers, Harriman Co., private bankers, report total deposits of $43,898,704 as of March 31, compared with $43,733,519 on Dec. 31 last. Loans and advances increased from $12,336,196 to $16,181,732. Cash amounted to $9,853,953, against $10,334,741. Holdings of United States Government securities were $9,330,074, compared with $12,943,101.

LONDON, April 3. -- A development which it is hoped may prove to be the turning point for the security markets and the beginning of a renewed advance came after the middle of this week when the City took the view that Germany had made a helpful reply to proposals by the Locarno powers.

Few days pass without uncovering some new defect or complication in the proposed tax on undistributed corporation profits. On the first page of our financial section yesterday GODFREY N. NELSON pointed out how complex a mathematical calculation the corporation would have to make to determine precisely what its tax was.

The Long Island University Blackbirds turned back the St. John's University nine, 8 -- 2, yesterday for their fourth straight victory of the season. A crowd of 2,000 attended the contest at Dexter Park, which ended after seven innings by agreement.

A formal protest, addressed to the Mayor and the Board of Estimate, against the franchise to the New York Omnibus Corporation to operate a bus route near Gramercy Park has been prepared by the Gramercy Park Association.

During the early part of the Roosevelt Administration much was heard of the necessity of "pump-priming." The theory was that the contraction of private spending had crippled business and that the Government must substitute its own spending if business was to be revived.

DETROIT, April 5 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin instructed officers of his National Union for Social Justice today to set aside all plans, "if there be any," to establish another major party and "diligently set forth to destroy the present leadership and the current philosophy which dominate both major parties."

SOME like the Red Sox. Anyway, they are the talk of the towns. The way Uncle Tom Yawkey squandered his money attracted more than passing notice and there is a general hope that his expensive purchases will give him a good run for his money.

There must be a spirit of functional unity among all the Protestant denominations in our city if the religion of Christ is to show a united front against the neo-paganism of today, Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney for New York and president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, said yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, Sixth Avenue at Twentieth Street.

Mario Chamlee, tenor, and Ruth Miller, soprano -- she is Mrs. Chamlee in private life -- appeared in a joint recital at the Town Hall last night. Mr. Chamlee began with songs by Beethoven and Brahms, and Miss Miller followed with music by Schubert and Brahms.

BALTIMORE, April 5. -- Can a horse with a strong heart but weak knees win the Kentucky Derby? This is the question which occupies the veteran J.J. Greeley, trainer of the Shandon Farm's Bright Light, which was practically left at the post yesterday in the Rowe Memorial Handicap at Bowie but still went on to an impressive victory over other Derby eligibles.

The Detroit Tigers and Chicago Cubs are named as the favorites to retain their American and National League pennants in the new set of odds for the coming major league baseball races announced yesterday by Jack Doyle, Broadway betting commissioner.

Cotton futures moved irregularly last week. They were influenced early to some extent by the weather in the Cotton Belt and later by plans for marketing government-financed cotton. At the close on Saturday, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week ranging from 10 points decline on the May contract to 2 points advance on the January delivery.

Offering will be made to the public today by a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., of a new issue of $40,000,000 of 3 3/4 per cent secured sinking-fund bonds due on April 1, 1946, of the New York Central Railroad Company. The bonds are priced at 98 and accrued interest, to yield about 4 per cent to maturity.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 5. -- The Arkansas vacation of Charles (Lucky) Luciana, a fugitive from New York justice, tonight definitely was scheduled to end tomorrow afternoon following the active participation of Federal officials in the legal battle that brought a week's postponement of his departure for New York.

MEXICO, D.F., April 5. -- A spirit of tolerance and conciliation on the part of President Lazaro Cardenas was evidenced this morning by a visit to more than forty Catholic churches, in which Palm Sunday was being observed by more persons than in many years.

Robert E. Weadock, 32 years old, son of a prominent family of Saginaw, Mich., was found sitting dazed yesterday on the steps of a building in West 112th Street, a few doors from Broadway, and was taken to Bellevue Hospital to be treated for amnesia.

Several thousand persons, including Borough President James J. Lyons and 200 representatives of American Legion posts from the Bronx and Manhattan, yesterday afternoon attended memorial services in observance of Army Day at the north entrance of the Bronx County Court Building, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, under the auspices of Unknown Soldier Post No. 1,124, American Legion.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 5. -- In a fresh Spring breeze from the south and a chop of water in the harbor, twenty-three dinghies sailed today in the regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman last night gave the second performance of Miss Humphrey's two-part work consisting of "Theatre Piece" and "New Dance" at the Adelphi Theatre before a large and cheering audience. The performance was under the auspices of New Theatre Magazine, which is entitled to a vote of thanks for making possible a second seeing of one of the most significant choreographic achievements of the day.

DETROIT, April 5. -- A joint conference of public officials and executive representatives of private organizations interested in the promotion of highway safety win be held under auspices of the Safety Traffic Committee of the Automobile Manufacturers Association here tomorrow.

MOSCOW, April 5. -- Convinced that Great Britain has adopted an equivocal attitude toward Adolf Hitler's violation of Locarno, which can result only in a rearmed and ambitious Germany that will have her own dangerous way, the Soviet Union appears to have washed its hands of the matter and for the time being lapsed into a concerned silence.
Banks were among the sellers of Manhattan properties under contract in deals announced over the week-end. Most of the structures will be modernized by the new owners.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 5 (AP). -- Pabst Blue Ribbons of New York and their leading 3,065 total were the targets tonight as a dozen of the nation's crack five-man teams lined up in the American Bowling Congress tournament. The New Yorkers have been leading since March 26.
THE NEW YORK TIMES'S editorial today. "The Surplus Tax," proves only that the proposed new tax law is a maze. But I think none will deny that the tax laws of any year are a maze.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The employment of 1,600,000 men in various capacities was shown today by Robert Fechner, director of Emergency Conservation Work, as a result of the Civilian Conservation Corps relief and reforestation program during three years.

All the good old quadrennials are blossoming early. The keynoters are being picked amid the usual rumoring and guessing. Sterling editorial articles that might have been "kept standing" for four, twenty-four, forty-eight years once more delight the eye and refresh the memory.

P. Garino and L.F. Sanman, Class A gunners, tied for the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, each breaking 95 out of 100 targets. Garino took the extra string with 25 straight, Sanman carding 23.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 5. -- A warning that the American university, especially the endowed institution, is threatened through the revolutionary trends of thought of the present day was sounded in the annual report of Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale University, issued today.

Plans for a poll of secondary school students in 1,000 "key" communities throughout the country to discover what they consider their most important problems were announced yesterday by Dr. James E. Mendenhall of Lincoln School, Columbia University.

Eighteen men, all of whom were said by the police to have criminal records, were taken into custody by detectives of the Poplar Street and Classon Avenue stations in Brooklyn over the week-end, it was disclosed yesterday. They were held on various charges ranging from assault and robbery to grand larceny.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Two ceremonies will be held tomorrow to honor the late Senator Robert M. La Follette for opposing United States entrance into the World War. The day is the nineteenth anniversary of this country's declaration of war.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 2 pointed to the achievement of Great Britain in ending her fiscal year for the third successive time with "a real surplus." "The whole record of British finances during the depression," THE TIMES explained, "is instructive.

Offering to the public of a new issue of $13,500,000 of first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1966, of the California Oregon Power Company will be made today by an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds are priced at 97 1/2 and accrued interest.

Palm Sunday services held in churches throughout the city yesterday with the religious pageantry and color customary on that day, were described as an occasion when the falsely religious often mingle with the true followers of God, by the Very Rev. Milo Hudson Gates in his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

DETROIT, April 5. -- Getting a quick jump on their rivals, the Detroit Red Wings conquered the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, 3 to 1, in the first game of the series for the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- The prosecution and defense brushed up arguments tonight for the start tomorrow of the Senate's twelfth impeachment trial in 137 years -- the case of the House against Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter of Florida.

LONDON, April 5. -- The financial editor of The Times, reviewing the recent report of the German Kredit Gesellschaft, says it leaves the general impression that the revival of German economic activity under the Hitler regime, "which is necessarily mainly domestic as in other countries," is not such as to lead one to expect it will continue.

BERLIN, April 3. -- The Reich Bureau of Statistics predicts the armaments fever and improving industry will sustain the world market for raw materials and prices in the coming month. The survey says, however, the movement of the cereals market is unpredictable.

MADRID, April 5 (AP). -- A public announcement of "imminent revolutionary events" was made today by Fernando Carrollo, a prominent leader of the Anarcho-Syndicalist Federation of Catalonia at a regional convention of extreme Leftists.

Three of the recommendations of the National Association of Basketball Coaches were adopted, another was shelved and the fifth was voted down as the National Basketball Rules Committee of the United States and Canada concluded its session at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, April 5. -- A Rome report that Empress Menen of Ethiopia received a message from Emperor Haile Selassie saying "There is nothing left for you to do but pray for me," was formally denied today by Foreign Minister Belaten Gheta Herrouy.

LONDON, April 3. -- Belgium has returned to the gold standard as from the end of March by stabilizing the gold value of the belga with a 28 per cent reduction from the former value of that unit, fixed in 1926. This event is in a strange and significant contrast with the position that is now facing the French franc.

The world stock of United States cotton on Feb. 29 was 1,266,000 bales smaller than at the end of February, last year, while the world stock of foreign growths was 377,000 bales larger, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. Stocks of all cottons were 889,000 bales smaller than on Feb. 28, 1935.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- Power obtained from the work of ordinary bacteria was suggested today as a possible addition to man's store of reserve energy by Dr. A.M. Partansky and Dr. H.K. Benson of the University of Washington at Seattle.

Of the nation's $14,000,000,000 annual crime bill, $125,000,000 represented the cost of maintaining inmates of penitentiaries, reformatories, jails and institutions for juvenile delinquents, William B. Cox, executive secretary of the Osborne Association, Inc., estimated in his annual report made public yesterday.

I note in THE TIMES this morning that Controller Taylor is happy because all records for the first day of the real estate tax-collecting period were broken by the receipt of almost $40,000,000. This apparently indicates to the Controller that "better times are coming back with a rush."

Four million pounds of steel -- the floor and girders of the superstructure of the lift span of the Tri-Borough Bridge connecting East 125th Street with Randall's Island -- were floated up the Harlem River to the bridge yesterday afternoon in a three-hour voyage from Weehawken, N.J., where the cargo was assembled.
Random notes on the trout opening:
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- A sustained improvement in home building and financing in recent months was hailed today by two Federal agencies dealing with the subject.

Two more units of the city's independent subway system will be put in operation at midnight Wednesday. They are the ten-mile Fulton Stret line in Brooklyn and the East River tunnel link, which will carry the Houston-Essex Street line to a connection with the Brooklyn lines at Jay Street.

PITTSBURGH, April 5. -- All steel mills in the flooded areas were in normal operation at the end of last week and most of them ran normally throughout the week. With those that lost several days of activity, normal operation means a rate higher than before the flood so as to catch up with orders.

The appointment by the New York State Chamber of Commerce of a committee to study national fiscal problems was announced yesterday by Richard W. Lawrence, chairman of the executive committee. Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the chamber, is chairman of the committee.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 5. -- One hundred and fifty-six Brown University upper classmen have been placed on the dean's list for high academic standing this semester, Dean Samuel T. Arnold announced tonight. The total is larger than for the second semester last year.

Markets for commodity futures last week were generally quiet, with price changes mostly small. Sugar, however, was an exception, the 1937 months touching new high marks for the year on Saturday as a result of news from Washington bearing on a Sugar Control Bill pending in Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Payments under the invalidated AAA production control programs of more than $1,000,000 in three checks to a Florida sugar corporation, $123,747 in one year to a large cotton plantation operator and $157,000 to the world's largest hog farming company were shown today in a report by Secretary Wallace to the Senate Agriculture Committee.

Fellowships have been awarded to two seniors showing most promise of distinction, it was announced yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College. The George Welwood Murray Fellowship, which includes the fields of social science, literature and other fine arts, has been awarded to Miss Fukami Sate of Japan.

Jesus with his leadership could have made Jerusalem the capital of the world, the Rev. Frank Oliver Hall, pastor of the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity at Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street, said yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- Investigators for the Communications Commission said today that they were making a thorough study of patents owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to determine whether this ownership makes possible a "telephone monopoly."

On the eve of the funeral of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, executed murderer of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey took the offensive last night in a lengthy statement against criticism scheduled to be publicized before the State Assembly tonight.

Controller Taylor called attention yesterday to a bill he has introduced in the Municipal Assembly, under which 221 acres of land, now under the jurisdiction of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, would be transferred to the Park Department and converted into playgrounds.

Veteran of many disputes in which he championed the liberal viewpoint within the Protestant Episcopal Church, the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland is perhaps best remembered for the storm provoked in 1930 by his invitation to non-Episcopal clergymen to conduct services in St. George's Church.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the winners in the department's inter-precinct safety competition for the six-month period ended last Dec. 31. He said prizes would be awarded to the winners later by Mayor La Guardia.

One of those rare occasions -- a theatrical reunion -- took place last evening on the stage of the Majestic Theatre, where a benefit was held for the Jewish Theatrical Guild. Pat Rooney and his wife, Marion Bent, and their son, Pat Rooney 3d, were the participants.

LONDON, April 5 (AP). -- British statesmen, with Europe bristling with new armament and crises and the danger of another war admittedly increased, have renewed their semi-official drive to bring the United States into the League of Nations.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York County, moved yesterday to invoke against Charles (Lucky) Luciana, a fugitive held in Arkansas, a Federal statute specifically passed to help State authorities bring back offenders.
PITTSBURGH, April 5. -- The Democrats, for the first time since the Civil War, form the majority party on the Pittsburgh poll lists.
Pray, who, attached to the New York Public Library, is responsible for the use of the pedestals of the lions as signboards for library announcements and samples?

The three openings that had been scheduled for next Thursday night now stand at two, for S.M. Chartock yesterday postponed "The Mikado" to the following evening at the Majestic (and, by the way, added George Hiroshe to its cast). . . . That leaves "Summer Wives" and the Federal Theatre Project "Macbeth" to compete on Thursday for the first-night trade.

Foreign dollar bonds in default as to interest at the end of 1935 amounted to $2,810,000,000, or 37.5 per cent of all the foreign dollar bonds outstanding, according to a bulletin to be issued today by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance.

Members of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce received over the week-end a bulletin warning them against Mayor La Guardia's proposed charter amendment to provide for a Department of Commerce and Labor. "Extreme vagueness" was said to be the "chief threat" of the measure.

ADDIS ABABA, April 5. -- Thousands of Addis Ababa residents streamed into the surrounding hills today, fearing another air raid on the capital. The tension subsided by midday, when the effect of heat and high altitude on gas consumption hampers long flights by the Italians. Raids are usually made just after dawn.

A weighty and formal petition to the Legislature of New Jersey has been presented to it by the president and members of the faculty of Princeton University and other prominent citizens. It asks for a legislative inquiry into the facts alleged concerning unwarranted and illegal meddling with the processes of criminal justice in that State.

Political clubs of any kind should not be tolerated in New York high schools, Dr. George G. Sullivan, editor of Wisdom, official publication of the Trinity League, said yesterday at a meeting of the New York province of the Federation of Catholic College Clubs, at the Hotel Commodore.

The Atlantic City Horse Show Association announced last night that on May 12 Mrs. Florence Dibble, Boston sportswoman, would attempt to break the 35-year-old speed record for the coach-and-four drive between New York City and Atlantic City, N.J.

ARLINGTON, N.J., April 5. -- The cake was being frosted in the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Andrews at 287 Stewart Avenue. On a table near by were fourteen candles, but that was just a family joke. Today Mr. Andrews celebrated his fortieth birthday.

Maxwell Anderson, receiving the first annual award of the New York Drama Critics Circle for his poetic play "Winterset," last night at a dinner in the Hotel Algonquin, criticized the Pulitzer Prize as lacking the authority of the critics' award. Two years ago Mr. Anderson received the Pultizer Prize.
HAVE you forgotten what happened in Faneuil Hall on a Friday night in May, 1854? Or did you never know?

NEWARK, N.J., April 5. -- Admission of sisterhoods, brotherhoods and youth leagues to membership was voted today by the New Jersey Association of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations at Temple B'nai Jeshurun at its annual conference on promoting religious endeavor among the laity.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- Light receipts last week advanced hog prices 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight to a top price of $10.90, the highest in two weeks. At the same time shipping orders were the lightest in six weeks. Light hogs were wanted by the trade, with 1,500 bought by shippers at $10.65 to $10.90.

ASMARA, Eritrea, April 5. -- Italian troops entered Quoram, at the southerly end of Lake Ashangi, today while Emperor Haile Selassie's forces continued their wild flight, scattering so wide that pursuit became virtually impossible.

FREDERICKSBURG, Pa., April 5. -- A big twin-motored army bombing plane, apparently far off its course and flying through a heavy rainstorm, smashed into steep Blue Mountain tonight, killing its crew of five.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

CLINTON, N.J., April 5. -- Nepken Carolina Bill sang his field trial swan song today, celebrating his retirement by winning the open all-age stake of the Jockey Hollow Club which started its annual Spring meeting this morning on the State grounds.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5. -- A proposal that news of happenings at meetings of the Philadelphia Presbytery be given to newspaper reporters only through the stated clerk is attacked as "a very dangerous insult" to the press by the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, writing in the current issue of The Presbyterian Guardian.

Many reservations have been made for the annual dinner dance under the auspices of the Almoners, to take place April 13 in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital. Proceeds will aid the charities of the hospital, which was founded in 1860 by the Sisters of Charity, and which depends chiefly on private contributions to maintain its foundling home, clinics and wards.

The Townsend Plan's proposed 2 per cent transaction tax would yield annually only $4,106,000,000, or about 16 per cent of the $24,000,000,000 needed yearly to pay old-age pensions of $200 a month, it was estimated yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund.

Opposed views as to the justice of the appeal of employes of the Board of Education for salary increases were expressed last night by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, and Abraham Lefkowitz, legislative representative of the Teachers Guild.

Cardinal Hayes blessed the palms, presided on his throne, was the central figure in the "Procession of Palms" and bestowed his blessing upon the more than 3,500 worshipers yesterday morning at the Palm Sunday high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

NORFOLK, Va., April 5. -- After spotting the Norfolk Tars to a 5 -- 0 lead in the first two innings, while a highly partisan crowd of 4,000 local fans offered numerous noisy and uncomplimentary suggestions to Casey Stengel, the Dodgers finally found the dynamite in their bats to overwhelm the opposition, 12 to 5, today.
ASMARA, April 5. -- Following yesterday's defeat of the troops under Emperor Haile Selassie, the Ethiopians are retreating rapidly toward Dessye.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- The corn situation continues to puzzle traders here, both in cash and in futures, particularly the former. The action of the market is a great disappointment to those who have been friendly to the buying side and who have taken advantage of all weak spots to add to commitments.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 5. -- According to the Brno newspaper Tagesbote, the newly appointed chairman of the Austrian Phoenix Life Insurance Company, Peter von Reiningshaus, has submitted his resignation. It has not yet been accepted and the Vienna Government hopes that at a general meeting fixed for tomorrow he may be persuaded to withdraw it.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 5 (AP). -- Experiments which suggest an unexpected value to humans in vitamin D were made public today at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

A prayer for peace was offered last night by Helen Keller, who despite the handicap of blindness became a woman of many accomplishments. She spoke at the seventh anniversary celebration of the New History Society at 110 East Fifty-ninth Street.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 6. -- M.G. Despain, general manager of the Public Service Company at Tupelo, Miss., told The Associated Press here by telephone tonight that the death toll in the tornado there tonight may run into hundreds.

BERLIN, April 3. -- While financial circles early this week showed reserve pending the outcome of Berlin's proposals to London, publication of these proposals led on Thursday to a sharp advance in stocks. The Boerse here believes the situation is due to change to Germany's advantage, inasmuch as Chancellor Hitler's comprehensive peace plan would obscure the question of remilitarization of the Rhineland.

One thing which the radio news announcers have yet to learn is the dramatic value of silence. One evening last week when a vast audience sat tense before the radio waiting for an important news flash, there were announcers who felt it incumbent to fill up the pause with a line of talk that it would be mild to describe as painful.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- In an analysis of the Supreme Court's decision declaring AAA unconstitutional the American Liberty League today upheld the majority opinion as legally sound and severely criticized the minority opinion as "contrary to established constitutional law."

The Fusion administration of Mayor La Guardia was attacked last night by Senator Abraham Kaplan, chairman of the unsuccessful O'Brien Mayoralty campaign in 1933, while Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the Fusion party, defended it during the forum hour of Radio Station WOR.

Freed from the restrictions of office and of office-seeking, ex-President HOOVER has become one of the most arresting speakers on public affairs in the United States. His address at Fort Wayne, Ind., on Saturday night marked one stage more in his acquiring this new reputation.

Scoring her fifth consecutive victory in the finals and completing a series of fourteen straight for the entire tournament, Mrs. Adele Rivero of Manhattan yesterday won the women's championship at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club.

Charles L. Ornstein, one of the leaders in the fight for the boycotting of the 1936 Olympic Games, was dropped from the American Olympic Committee at its meeting at the New York A.C. yesterday over his protest and in spite of his refusal to turn in a last-minute resignation.

PARIS, April 5. -- After four weeks of negative action and a negative attitude the French Government has started to take a positive view and make positive proposals for getting out of the dangerous situation into which Europe was plunged by the denunciation of the Locarno pact and the reoccupation of the Rhineland.

In his letter "The Value of Courts," appearing in THE TIMES of March 15, Mr. Reed objects to a proposed statute which would make necessary a vote of seven judges in the United States Supreme Court in order to render a law unconstitutional.

The resources of the New York Community Trust rose to $8,419,742 at the end of 1935, compared with $8,024,688 the year before, according to its annual report to be made public today. The trust now ranks fifteenth among foundations in the United States, based on size of capital, and seventeenth in volume of appropriations, according to the Twentieth Century Fund.

April continues its active pace and the local galleries have much to offer this week. There is a considerable list of group and one-man displays, made up of work both contemporary and belonging to the past.

Two scenes from Richard Rohman's "Power of the Press" arrived last night at the Civic Repertory, to be greeted by an audience forewarned that here was no Hollywood saga of romantic newspaperdom. For Mr. Rohman's story is as far from glamour as a strike can take it, and his Hildy Johnsons are involved not in scoops and deadlines but a struggle for security.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- Filing of a formal petition by a group of Eastern railroads for an eighteen-month delay in new low passenger fares scheduled to go into effect on June 2 was disclosed today by officials of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Shipyards have received tenders from the Norwegian America Line Oslo, for the construction of a combined passenger and freight liner for the Norway-New York service.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- The pointer Ch. Nancolleth Marquis owned by the Giralda Farms of Madison, N.J., and handled by McClure Halley, was named the best in show at the close of the thirty-fifth annual exhibition of the Chicago Kennel Club at the Coliseum tonight. The judge was Theodore Offerman of New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Creation of a Federal interdepartmental highway safety coordinating agency, headed by a Cabinet officer, was urged by the automobile industry upon Secretary Roper today as one means of coping with the increasing numbers of deaths and injuries resulting from automobile accidents.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- Asserting that the $4,000,000,000 work-relief fund "is being used to help buy the election," the Republican Congressional Committee asked the public today to make its own investigation of WPA activities.

One Jewish annual observance of the Feast of Passover, commemorating the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt more than 3,000 years ago, will begin at sundown today. The Passover will be observed for eight days by Orthodox and for a week by Reform Jews.

General American Investors, Inc., reports net assets as of March 31 of $32,324,782, after deducting $2,253,000 for taxes which would be payable at present rates if the appreciation on the value of securities over cost were realized. This is equivalent, after providing for the outstanding debentures at par, to $321.56 a share on the preferred stock and to $13.63 each on 1,300,220 shares of common stock, without giving effect to the exercising of outstanding warrants.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- No. 2 white oats in the sample market at the close here last week were 3 to 3 1/2 cents a bushel over the May; No. 3 white 1 to 2 cents over, and No. 4 white 1/2 to 2 1/2 cents under the May. Sales, track Chicago and transmississippi billing, were at 25 1/4 cents for No. 4 white.

MIAMI, April 5. -- At the close of two weeks of fishing and cruising in the Atlantic Ocean east of Florida, President Roosevelt still was at sea tonight undetermined as to the exact time he would land and return to Washington.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (AP). -- The sixteen passengers of the burning Norwegian motorship Tricolor were transferred to the British tanker Yarraville in the North Pacific today, the liner President Grant reported to Globe Wireless here.

Vv'I-IITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Na., April 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Luce gave a luncheon today in the Tangerine Room of the Casino at the Greenbrier for Mr. and Mrs. Lucius M. Boomer. Mr. and Mrs. Basil O'Connor were dinner hosts in the Colonnades tonight efore leaving for New York.
SMITHTOWN BRANCH, L.I., April 5. -- Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon was injured here soon after 4 P.M. today when the automobile in which he was riding was forced off the road and into a tree.

Charging that the value of endorsements is being dissipated by irresponsible vendors, the Association of Consulting Chemists and Chemical Engineers has proposed a plan to raise the level of the reliability of "approval," "certification" and "listing" systems used in the marking of consumer goods.

LONDON, Monday, April 6. -- Although political circles here have been inclined to accept it as probable that Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin would resign from the Prime Ministership after the coronation of King Edward in May, 1937, it is asserted by Viscount Rothermere's Daily Mail today that he has decided to resign around Whitsunday, next May 31.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., April 5. -- The United States destroyer Manley, rushing to intercept vessels allegedly smuggling ammunition to Honduran revolutionaries while flying the American flag, made today what was believed to be a record transit of the Panama Canal.
CHICAGO, April 5 (AP). -- "Shots" of alcohol were offered to physicians today as a possible cure for pneumonia.

To "revitalize" faith in the Christian Gospel among ministers, twenty educators and religious leaders have been appointed to conduct meetings in twenty-five cities next Fall under the auspices of the National Preaching Mission.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 5. -- Manager Joe McCarthy is convinced at last that the elements have conspired against him and his Yankees.
Members of the Boys Club of New York would prefer any one of a half dozen jobs to that of President of the United States, it was announced by the club yesterday, on the basis of a questionnaire.
MOSCOW, April 5 (AP). -- Reports from Outer Mongolia indicated a dangerous situation still prevailed today in the Manchukuoan border region, although at the moment there was no fighting.

Limited budgetary appropriations and restrictions on the number of qualified teachers have made the Italian language "the educational foundling of New York City," Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, Fusion member of the Board of Education, charged yesterday.

Count Hkarion Woronzoff-Doschkoff, Colonel M.A. Carlisle-Crowe and Major Gordon Ingram are among the passengers sailing today for Ireland, France and England on the Cunard White Star liner Britannic. Others sailing on the ship include W. Stanley Lloyd, Miss Daphne Lloyd, W.C. Price, Alan Dunning, Derek Williams and Glenn Tryon.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 5. -- With Colonel Bill Terry back in active service again after a three-day lay-off, the Giants clapped down on the Memphis Chicks with a vengeance today and swiftly settled the question of supremacy which was sort of left hanging in the balance overnight as the result of yesterday's thirteen-inning tie.

VIENNA, April 5. -- A preliminary censorship has been secretly instituted over foreign newspapers entering Austria. Newspaper dealers find that certain newspapers, especially those from Czechoslovakia, are being held back a couple of hours for careful examination by the censors before being released for sale.

Eight of New York's leading foilsmen qualified for the national championship yesterday in the divisional bouts on the strips of the New York Athletic Club under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America. The home club placed three men, this achievement being equaled by the Fencers Club. The Salle d'Armes Vince and University F.C. shared the remaining berths.

The twenty largest banks in the United States increased their holdings of United States Government securities from Dec. 31 to March 4 by $255,323,000, so that on March 4 they held $5,970,913,000 of them, according to The American Banker. This is about one-fifth of the national debt.

Byrnes MacDonald, director of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the New York Police Department, in an address on the "Juvenile Crime Problem'' yesterday at the thirty-ninth annual communion breakfast of the New Amsterdam Council 217, Knights of Columbus, at the Capitol Hotel, urged the Knights to aid his bureau in its efforts to combat juvenile delinquency.
Two women were killed and a man and another woman seriously injured in an automobile crash early yesterday on Victory Boulevard near Willowbrook Road, Bullshead, S.I.

I cannot too vigorously applaud Dr. John L. Tildsley's stand and comment relative to the demand of Dr. George D. Sullivan for more laws to fight both communism and atheism and proscribe the right to proselyte for these doctrines, to fight, in this instance, meaning what it usually means -- to suppress by force or fiat.

Mayor La Guardia told school attendance officers yesterday that he would move to close any establishment catering to high school students where liquor was served. The Mayor's threat was couched in forthright and inclusive terms.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- Liquidation last week reduced the prices of most grains to around the lowest levels of the season. The volume of business was liberal, feeling was bearish and there was considerable short selling.

NORFOLK, Va., April 5 (AP). -- Many of the idioms of the "American language," as distinguished from pure English, have been traced to a Virginia origin, says Sir William Craigie, internationally known lexicographer.

A 17-year-old high school student, Lloyd Lewis of Plattsburg, Mo., was named last night the winner of a $5,000 scholarship in any American college or university for writing the best essay on the subject, "How Can America Stay Out of War?"

American shipyards are building 119 vessels of 165,870 tons, more than double the number and five times the tonnage under construction a year ago, according to the monthly report of the American Bureau of Shipping

Samuel Factor of Chicago, G.N. Treystman of Manhattan and Harold Morton of Boston triumphed again in their respective groups yesterday, remaining undefeated in the United States chess championship preliminaries. Matches in four divisions were played at the Grover Cleveland Club and the Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Clubs.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 7. -- Suppression of political movements in the army is the subject of a conference of divisional commanders that General Count Juichi Terauchi, the War Minister, will open today.

An intensive drive by peace organizations for the inclusion of anti-war planks in the platforms of political parties was forecast yesterday by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, honorary chairman of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War.

An old woman with three fingers missing from her right hand, dressed in man's garb -- and very tattered, grimy garb, at that -- was found dead in the rain in front of the tenement at 343 Broome Street, just off the Bowery, at 4:30 A.M. yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 6. -- Discussing the ruling by Secretary Wallace tonight that "packers have violated the Packers and Stockyards Act," J.P. Swift Jr., vice president of Swift Co., in charge of sales, said:
Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York County, issued this statement last evening:

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Acting in the New York "mushroom synagogue" controversy, the Supreme Court today continued in effect an interlocutory injunction obtained by Sara Mr. Wachs in a dispute with Police Commissioner Valentine and District Attorney Foley of the Bronx.

LONDON, April 6. -- After having worked for eight and a half years, a committee of noted accountants and lawyers who had the task of making the income-tax laws intelligible to despairing British taxpayers, who must surrender from 20 to 60 per cent of their incomes, made public tonight a suggested "Codifying Bill."

Furthering his policy of appointing "career men" to advanced posts in the city administration, Mayor La Guardia named Matthew J. Troy yesterday as a city magistrate to succeed the late Magistrate Thomas Casey in Brooklyn, and promoted Andrew J. Galligan of the City Chamberlain's office to Deputy City Chamberlain.

It seems to me that it is not fair to put all the blame for the disgraceful condition of the streets on the Sanitation Department. It is clear that if it had more cooperation from police and teachers things would be much better.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French frano on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

KEY WEST, Fla., April 6 (AP). -- Here to greet the 43-foot schooner Water Witch as she won the Class A honors in the Havana-Key West sailing race today were members of the crew from the yawl Sea Call which dropped out of last week's St. Petersburg-Havana haul when deserted by the winds.

To eliminate "fixes" and all other forms of political "chiseling," Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., chief city magistrate, introduced into the Brooklyn Traffic Court yesterday a system whereby all traffic violators get an open hearing. At the end of the day it was reported the system had worked very smoothly.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 6. -- Ben Chapman joined the Yankees here today, signed his contract and was all set to play his first game in center field, but enjoyed a day of rest instead.

ALBANY, April 6. -- Believing that the home State of President Roosevelt will be the most hotly contested battleground in the national campaign, Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee, will set his party machinery in motion earlier this year than has been the practice in former campaigns.

Use by the majority of the House Judiciary Committee of the report made in 1932 by the Economists' Committee on Anti-Trust Policy, and signed by 125 leading economists in such a way as to infer that the professors who signed it favor the enactment of the present Robinson-Patman "price discrimination" bill was labeled as "sophistry" by Congressman Emanuel Celler, in a statement issued last night.

BALTIMORE, April 6 (AP). -- First efforts to reorganize the Townsend old age pension group saw a demand tonight by directors of the national organization for the retirement of the head of its largest unit, Club 93, at Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission sent letters today to a number of the larger banks in the country, calling attention to the fact that where as trustees, or in other circumstances, they hold 10 per cent or more of securities of a public utility company, they must make certain reports to the commission if they are to be exempted as holding companies from provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

Price changes among bonds were narrow and mixed and trading was routine yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. But the market maintained a generally firm undertone, although trading interest drooped in favor of interest in the large volume of new obligations to be placed or the market this week.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora denied yesterday an application to punish Park Commissioner Robert Moses for contempt of court for causing trees and shrubbery to be dug up around the Central Park Casino after Justice Carew had granted a temporary injunction restraining him from doing so.

ROME, April 6. -- It appears probable that the first contact between the Italian Government and the League of Nations conciliation committee of thirteen to clear the ground for the discussion of Italo-Ethiopian peace will be established, not by the Italian delegates at Geneva, but by Salvador de Madariaga, Spanish chairman of the committee, in Rome.

An indeterminate sentence of not more than three years in the penitentiary was imposed by Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday on Morris Melman, 23 years old, of 346 East Seventeenth Street, vice president and one of the organizers of the Allied Printing Helpers Union.

SHEFFIELD, Ala., April 6. -- The Giants and Indians joined forces here today in the wake of a tornado which cracked down on the surrounding country with devastating force last night and, while the twister did not exactly flatten the pennant hopes of either Bill Terry or Steve O'Neill, it inspired in both a profound respect for the elements.

Initial public financing for the Phillips Packing Company, Inc., has been arranged with the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers, which will offer today, by means of a prospectus, 10,000 shares of 5 1/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock and 75,000 shares of common stock of the company. The preferred stock will be priced at $100 a share and accrued dividends and the common at $15 a share.

Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., reported yesterday net sales of $22,084,314 for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1936, compared with $21,848,061 in the preceding year, the best showing since the year ended on Jan. 31, 1932, while Abraham Straus, Inc., reported for the same period, net sales of $20,962,266, compared with $20,228,682 the year before, and also a high since the 1931-1932 period.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Eleven of the country's largest packers were ordered to cease and desist from price fixing, apportioning territories and other merchandising practices in contradiction to the Packers and Stockyards Act, in orders issued by the Department of Agriculture today.

CHICAGO, April 6. -- Offerings of hogs here today were unusually light for a Monday and somewhat below trade requirements, resulting in an advance of 10 to 25 cents a hundred weight. The top price was lifted to $11, or 10 cents above Friday's level, while the day's average of $10.70 showed a gain of 15 cents.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad reduced its loan from the Railroad Credit Corporation to $915,963 in 1935, according to the report for last year issued yesterday by E.E. Loomis, president. The Lehigh Valley paid $1,210,093 to and borrowed $1,500,000 from the corporation.

Readers who have to do with kindergartens, or other educational or playtime activities of children, may be interested to know that approved play blocks may now be obtained from a non-commercial source.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The Supreme Court refused today to interfere with a lower court decision holding unconstitutional a provision of the 1934 Revenue Act imposing a processing tax on coconut oil, which is produced chiefly in the Philippines.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 6. -- Smith Wildman Brookhart, twice elected Senator from Iowa and from 1933 until early this year on the New Deal payroll as "special adviser" on foreign trade, today entered the Republican primary against Senator L.J. Dickinson and four other aspirants for the party nomination in June.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Acting under instructions from President Roosevelt, Secretary Roper has begun investigation of reported sabotage on several American freighters and passenger ships, manned largely by foreign crews.

Leasing of midtown space to the National Safety Council, and renewals and new contracts for large commercial quarters downtown by several business houses, featured the business rentals announced yesterday.

The response of home and foreign financial watchers to the various stages of the Rhineland dispute has been an interesting incident. When the newspapers talked of "the imminent clash" and of the impending European war, financial markets were virtually unmoved in Europe, and in this country merely receded slightly, recovering quickly all of the lost ground.

Formation of a new general management investment trust of the "open-end" type, National Fund, Inc., was announced yesterday by its sponsors and distributors, William H. Davis Co. of Jersey City. Registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, of 1,000,000 shares of the trust's common stock and 244,230 warrants became effective yesterday, it was stated.

Lacking a transcript of the opinion, Wall Street authorities on the Securities Act of 1933 were unwilling yesterday to comment upon the United States Supreme Court's decision establishing the right of an issuer of securities, in this case J. Edward Jones, to withdraw a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Differing from the majority of the court, Justice Untermyer of the Appellate Division held yesterday that false testimony could not be considered as a refusal to answer a questioner and that, therefore, punishment for contempt, would be "a dangerous innovation."
INDIANAPOLIS, April 6 (AP). -- Two outstanding individual series and a sixth place all-events total featured today's bombarding in the minor events of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Vadim S. Makaroff entertained colonists at Louwana tonight with a dinner, with music and entertainment later. With them for a few days are Mrs. G. Grant Mason Jr. and Martin L. Scott, who came from Miami.

TRENTON, N.J., April 6. -- Public school expenditures in New Jersey have decreased 20 per cent in the last three years, Governor Harold G. Hoffman said today in analyzing a special report of Charles H. Elliott, Commissioner of Education.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 6. -- A bribe of $50,000 was offered this morning to Attorney General Carl E. Bailey to help effect the release of Charles (Lucky) Luciana, fugitive New York racket chief wanted in that city for trial on charges of compulsory prostitution.

Continuation of recent improvement in the steel business will result gradually in the attainment of a normal basis of production, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, predicted yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Hoboken.

BOSTON, April 6 (AP). -- Federal Judge George C. Sweeney withheld today final approval of reorganization of the Arnoskeag Manufacturing Company pending his consideration of petitions objecting to the plan, including one from Frederick H. Prince of this city.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Washington observed Army Day today to the strains of martial music as soldiers, sailors and veterans' organizations paraded from the Capitol down Constitution Avenue to the White House.
