Completion of the new passenger-freight ship Batory, Poland's newest addition to her merchant fleet, was announced here yesterday by officials of the Gdynia America Line, the official Polish governmental line which will operate the vessel between New York and the port of Gdynia.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP). -- The Republican National Committee disclosed today that on the complaint of supporters of Senator Borah it had acted to prevent the use of Republican campaign funds against the Idaho Senator in the Wisconsin Presidential primaries tomorrow.
LONDON, April 6. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden hinted today that sanctions might have to be intensified if Italy did not agree to end the Ethiopian War within a definite period.

By unanimous decision the Circuit Court of Appeals upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the Gold Reserve Act of 1934 as it applies to gold held here by aliens. The court, also ruling there could be no market for the gold because its private ownership was outlawed, demolished the other basis of the suit, "unique value," by which the complainant would have made $850,000 profit.

With three recently acquired canvases by Canaletto serving as a nucleus, M. Knoedler Co. has arranged an exhibition of eighteenth century Venetian painting, some of the pictures from the gallery's own stock, some borrowed from collectors and museums.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Disbursements in March by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation amounted to $164,974,050, but of this total $100,000,000 was an allocation from its funds under the Emergency Appropriation Act of 1935 and $45,175,345 went to purchase from the PWA marketable securities which the RFC expects later to sell at a premium in the investment market, a statement revealed today.

There is, on the wooden float alongside the handsome Gould Boathouse from which Columbia rows, a better spirit prevailing this Spring than there was a year ago. Last year Columbia rowing had reached a point where there were not even enough men out to make two varsity boatloads and there was no junior varsity.

Today seven distinguished scientists will do honor at Harvard to a Zoroaster of our time. He is Dr. GEORGE ELLERY HALE, director emeritus of Mount Wilson Observatory. The sun has been his particular study. He was the first man to look deep into it and see its whirlpools of hydrogen -- whirlpools so huge that the earth would disappear in one of them like a cinder in a furnace.

LONDON, April 6. -- Allyn B. McIntire, president of the Boston Advertising Club, today extended on invitation to the British Advertising Association to send delegates to the annual American advertising convention, which will be held in Boston on June 29.

Discrimination against Negroes in Harlem Hospital and other city in institutions was charged in a report sent to Mayor La Guardia last Tuesday by the committee he appointed to investigate conditions in Harlem after the rioting of March 19, 1935.
ABOARD STEAMSHIP YARRAVILLE, April 6. -- We were five days out of Yokohama when fire was discovered in the No. 5 hatch, in the aft of the Norwegian motorship Tricolor.
Robert Derck, an outsider, provided almost all the excitement in the metropolitan badminton championships at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night.
Let us give a thought to the enlisted men of the army who have been disabled in the performance of their duty.

The 1,462 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $44,255,014,146 par value as of April 1, had a total market value of $41,807,142,328, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of March 1, there was the same number of issues, aggregating $43,015,263,454 par value, which had a total market value of $40,624,571,422.

LONDON, April 6. -- Hector Bywater, naval expert of The Daily Telegraph, asserts that Italy, in a move to control the Mediterranean, has planned a larger and stronger navy and that blockade tests already have been carried out with the view of obtaining mastery of the Suez Canal.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., April 6. -- At least 187 persons were killed, more than 300 were injured and property was damaged to an estimated extent of $5,000,000 by a tornado which struck this mill town early today.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on April 1 shows a decrease for the week of $217,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations largely offset by increases in other loans and investments, and decreases of $169,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $142,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- As a formal step to salvage as much as possible from the assets in the Kreuger Toll bankruptcies that followed the suicide of Ivar Kreuger in March, 1932, the two protective committees for secured bondholders today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a joint definitive plan of readjustment.

Benny Friedman, the former Michigan All-America quarterback who has coached City College's varsity football team for the past two years, has signed to guide the Beavers again in 1936, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- A Republican move to confound the administration by confronting it with the many dire predictions made last week as to the results of its new tax plan proved a boomerang today, when, instead of creating embarrassment, it brought forth the most vigorous defense of the program yet delivered before the Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- As a "sequel" to the Social Security Act, Joseph B. Eastman, transportation coordinator, recommended to Congress today enactment of a large unemployment compensation program for the 1,564,000 workers in the rail, motor, water and air transportation industries.

LONDON, April 6. -- The stock markets here were firm but quiet today because of the approaching holidays. There was an outstanding rise in international issues, following the improvement in Wall Street. British funds remained firm.
LONDON, April 6. -- The French peace plan is being awaited with some trepidation in London for fear that it will be too harsh in tone and too legalistic in substance to appeal to the British public.

CHICAGO, April 6. -- Hailing the army's services to the nation at a dinner marking the nineteenth anniversary of the United States' entry into the World War, George H. Dern, Secretary of War, asserted here tonight that there is "ample justification for the belief that in the past and probably at the present time it is dangerously small."

PHILADELPHIA, April 6. -- The militant Fundamentalist faction in the Presbytery of Philadelphia received a setback today at the annual election, at which the Rev. Dr. George Emerson Barnes, pastor of Overbrook Presbyterian Church, and widely known as a liberal, was made Moderator.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP). -- Decision to press a demand for immediate hearings on the Commodity Exchange Bill was reached today at a secret session of Republican and Democratic Senators in the office of the majority leader, Senator Robinson of Arkansas.

Charles L. Ornstein, who was expelled from membership on the American Olympic Committee at its meeting on Sunday, issued a statement yesterday in which he charged that the A.O.C. "is representative not of the sporting spirit of American tradition, but that it has adopted the color and tactics of Nazi Germany."

The trial of Henry C. Steneck and his brother, George W., charged with falsifying a report on the financial condition of the closed Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken in 1931, was halted for a period yesterday in Jersey City when it was disclosed that two jurors had been approached, and one offered a bribe.

" One Flew East" is the latest title of that new play by Douglas Gilmore and Kay Kenney which has been variously known as "Straight From the Hartz" and "The Canary Man." And the news about it this morning is that it may turn up in May, which can always find room for a premiere.
WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The Text of the minority opinion of the Supreme Court in the case of J. Edward Jones against the Securities and Exchange Commission is a follows:

A poll of New Yorkers who ventured into the arctic reaches of the Catskills for the trout season opening reveals that the casualties to the fish were trivial, but that the toll of anglers who succumbed to frost-bite and chilblains assumed devastating proportions.

RICHMOND, Va., April 6. -- His immediate plans disarranged by a downpour last night and this morning in Norfolk which washed out the second game with the Tars, Manager Stengel of the Dodgers today had time to consider and comment upon other things more directly bearing upon possible Brooklyn progress in the National League race.

Two attempts to start an investigation of the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, one directed primarily at Governor Harold G. Hoffman and the other designed to review the acts of all officials, were voted down last night by the New Jersey Assembly.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- A Supreme Court review of the New York State Mortgage Moratorium Law of 1983 became a virtual certainty today when the court noted probable jurisdiction in the attack against the law by Joseph and Angelina Loporto, holders of a second mortgage on a tenement house at 39 Henry Street, New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 6. -- Playland, the $9,000,000 amusement park of the Westchester County Park Commission at Rye, operated during 1935 at a net loss of $280,240, although in the commission's official report it was said the park had made an "operating profit" of $179,188 last year, the commission reported today.
This statement was issued yesterday by J. Edward Jones after he was informed of the decision of the Supreme Court:

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- While expressing the belief that the decision of the Supreme Court in the J. Edward Jones case would put some difficulties in the way of labeling fraudulent promoters as such, Chairman James M. Landis of the Securities and Exchange Commission said tonight that the administration of the Securities Act of 1933 was not otherwise affected and that the commission's efforts to suppress fraud would go on.
CAIRO, Ill., April 6 (AP). -- Fed by the drainage of heavy week-end rains, the Ohio River moved upward tonight and sent the Mississippi toward new heights.

A NUMBER of writers have been ranging the country lately interviewing everybody in overalls who could be persuaded to talk. They have coaxed comments on the state of the nation as reflected in town dumps from dump pickers. They have gathered emigration statistics from filling-station men. And, coming after Caldwell, have picked up fascinating tales of tenants eaten by hogs in the Cotton Belt.

TRENTON, N.J., April 6. -- The New Jersey Legislature began the thirteenth week of its annual session today. Again both houses sidetracked the relief issue and adjourned until 1:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The Senate opened the trial of Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter of Florida. The Agriculture Committee reported favorably Senator Vandenberg's resolution for publication of the large benefits paid under the AAA.

The General Sugar Corporation filed yesterday in the United States District Court for the District of Delaware a petition for permission to reorganize under the provisions of Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act. This action followed the promulgation of a joint reorganization plan for Vertientes Sugar Company and Camaguey Sugar Company, subsidiaries, by the bondholders' protective committee headed, respectively, by Thomas L. Chadbourne and Arthur W. Loasby.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP). -- The man behind the Kentucky Derby for the last thirty-five years, Colonel Matt Winn, became seriously Derby-minded tonight as he packed his gripsack to get away for Louisville tomorrow to take charge of America's most famous horse race.
CINCINNATI, April 6 (AP). -- Heavy rains and damaging hailstorms over the Ohio Valley brought a threat of new floods tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- By a vote of 6 to 3 the Supreme Court held today that the Securities and Exchange Commission bureaucratically invaded the constitutional rights of J. Edward Jones, New York oil-company financier, by attempting to force him to testify before it concerning a securities-registration statement he had filed and then withdrawn when its accuracy was challenged.

MILWAUKEE, April 6. -- Warning the voters not to leave the selection of a candidate for President to trading and bartering by uninstructed delegates behind closed doors, Senator Borah urged Wisconsin to choose at tomorrow's election Borah-instructed delegates to the Republican convention.

BASLE, April 6. -- The American Neutrality Law is among the factors working toward upsetting the de facto monetary stabilization the world precariously has enjoyed since May, 1935, it came out here in informal exchanges of views on the future of the French franc and the gold bloc which dominated the monthly session of the board of the World Bank today.

Officials of May's Department Store in Brooklyn were held responsible for the strike there in a report made public yesterday by the Mayor's committee named to investigate the walkout. The committee recommended "that shoppers of Brooklyn make their purchases where a sense of justice controls employment policies."

Contesting the right of the Securities and Exchange Commission to make public figures of sales and other confidential data of corporations, the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation has filed a suit in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second District in which it contends that the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is unconstitutional.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 6. -- Dr. C.E. McGuire, economist, of Washington and New York, and chairman of the board of the National Bank of Nicaragua, left today on a Pan American airplane for the United States. Dr. McGuire arrived here last week from Venezuela where he studied exchange conditions and the monetary and fiscal systems at the request of the Venezuelan Government.

The pamphlet report of the American Power and Light Company shows a consolidated net income of $7,512,476 for 1935, equivalent to $4.24 a share on 793,581 shares of $6 and 978,444 shares of $5 preferred stocks, combined, against $3,959,929, or $2.23 a share on the combined preferred stocks, for 1934.
GAINESVILLE, April 6. -- The Dixie Hunt Hotel, largest in the city, was wrecked by today's tornado, but an official said the guests escaped without injury.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP). -- Help for hundreds of injured and thousands of homeless in tornado-torn Tupelo, Miss., and Gainesville, Ga., was marshaled today by the American Red Cross, with doctors and nurses sent to both areas.

Mrs. H. Pelham Curtis will give a reception this afternoon at her home, 126 East Sixty-second Street, for members of the executive and debutante committees aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe the night of April 13 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Society for the Relief of Half Orphan and Destitute Children.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday appointed three lawyers familiar with real estate problems as trustees for the reorganization of the $24,300,000 issue of guaranteed mortgage certificates known as Series C-2, the second largest issue sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts yesterday awarded a new issue of $4,000,000 of notes to the Bankers Trust Company of New York on a 0.19 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $21. The notes, dated April 15, will become payable on April 2, 1937. Four other bids were submitted.

The City of New York will possess, before the end of the year, the first micro-ray beam radio link for regular service in this country, it was announced yesterday by Frederick J.H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures.

TUPELO, Miss., April 6. -- Tupelo's list of identified dead from last night's 100-mile-an-hour tornado reached the 134 mark tonight as a fleet of ambulances, trucks and motor cars streamed to hospitals and morgues with the victims.

The New York State Public Service Commission has authorized the Consolidated Edison Company, Inc., to issue $70,000,000 of debenture bonds, consisting of $35,000,000 of ten-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures due in 1946 and $35,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1956.
Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, gave credit to his faculty last night for the abolition of the credit system at the institution over which he presides.

A contract deadline set by the Public Works Administration forced the Board of Education last night to revoke contracts for the construction of two Bronx schools and re-award them at an increased cost of $36,300 to the city and Federal Government.

Thirteen of the country's leading basketball players were selected yesterday to represent the United States in the Olympics at Berlin as a climax to the nation-wide tournaments which ended Sunday night in Madison Square Garden with the Universal Pictures of Hollywood nosing out the McPherson (Kan.) Oilers, 44 to 43.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The House passed today a bill putting employes of air lines under the Railway Labor Act and setting up a National Air Transport Adjustment Board to deal with labor disputes in that industry.

Joseph A. Solovei, an attorney, testified again yesterday before the extraordinary grand jury in Brooklyn that is investigating charges of bribery in the murder of Samuel Drukman. Solovei did not sign a waiver of immunity.

The award to LLOYD LEWIS of Plattsburg, Mo., by the judges in the Eddie Canof essay contest in which 212,000 American high school students 17 years of age took part, was deserved, for no one of this multitude of youth could have written a better paragraph than that which was embodied in his essay.

EDMONTON, Alta., April 6. -- Alberta's social-credit government introduced today in the dying hours of the session of the Legislature two bills which will bring comfort neither to its American creditors nor its Canadian critics.

When a barrister almost tears his wig in court to express his surprise and horror at the law's want of delay, the layman feels like ordering his ascension robe, provided he can get it on tick. In the King's Bench Division of the High Court Mr. ST. JOHN FIELD, K.C., asking postponement of the hearing of an action, said mournfully and almost incredibly:

John Carlson, who was awarded the Altman Prize for the best landscape in the Academy Annual painted by an American-born citizen -- and then lost it on the technicality of not having been born in the United States -- is holding his first one-man show of canvases in several years, opening today, at the Grand Central Fifth Avenue Galleries.

THE last of the notable baseball holdouts has let go and come in, thus surprising nobody at all. The esteemed Clark Griffith, the silver-thatched owner of the Senators, peered out from under his shaggy eyebrows in the thick of this Spring's holdout campaign and put it about right when he said:

MIAMI, Fla., April 6. -- President Roosevelt has set Wednesday for the termination of his fishing cruise after spending two weeks in the waters east of here. He announced through his temporary offices today that he would arrive in Washington about noon on Friday.

Nathan Strauss, organizer and for many years president of the Federal Grand Jurors Association of the Eastern District, and once owner of a large chain of provision stores bearing his name, was found dead of gas poisoning in the bedroom of his home at 401 Park Place, Brooklyn, a little before noon yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
Indications of construction revival were contained in building reports for two city boroughs and the southern section of the United States made public yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., April 6. -- The best effort Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt could make to take the feature today, named the Sagamore Handicap in honor of his farm, was frustrated by the speed of Felix Spatola's Wise Prince, which got home first by half a length.

LONDON, April 6. -- George Lansbury, former leader of the Labor party, who is sailing for the United States April 15 to participate in a big emergency peace movement in that country, spoke tonight at a farewell meeting given him by peace advocates of Britain. He said that perhaps he would he the first man to go to America without asking that country for money, men or armaments.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Representative Deen of Georgia, rising in the House for the first time this session, today defended his constituents from the slurs he said are cast upon them by "Tobacco Road." a "most infamous, wicked and damnable play."

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- In a third change of mind, the Senate Agriculture Committee reported favorably today the Vandenberg resolution calling on Secretary Wallace to furnish a list of benefit payments in excess of $10,000 under the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Solicitors for the Postoffice Department rested their case today against Mrs. Oliver Harriman's $60,000 prize contest which they charge is a lottery because the exercise of judgment on the part of the contestant has little effect, "if any," on the award.
G.N. Treystman of this city, competing in Group C at the Empire City Chess Club in the United States chess championship preliminaries, tallied his sixth consecutive victory last night.
WASHINGTON, April 6. -- High points in the Supreme Court majority decision in the Jones case were as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Testimony concerning alleged fee-splitting marked a story of the aftermath of the Florida real estate boom furnished to the Senate today as the impeachment trial of Halsted L. Ritter, United States district judge for Southern Florida, was begun.

BALTIMORE, April 6 (AP). -- The blood of a dozen young men of Perryville was tested today against the possibility that a blood transfusion might be needed for Mrs. Emily Fisher, critically wounded at her Perryville home in the "community gossip" shooting.

Louis Waldman, State chairman of the Socialist party (Old Guard) replied yesterday to the suggestion of Harry W. Laidler, city chairman of the Socialist party (Left Wing) for party harmony by saying that the Old Guard group always had sought peace but required as a prerequisite to peace that the Left Wing leaders drop all proposals for united action with the Communists.

Starting with one non-sliceable mashie and an old tin cup, the United States Golf Association yesterday began looking for exhibits for a golf museum and admitted it might even accept clubs like, say, Bobby Jones's "Calamity Jane."

LINDEN, N.J., April 6. -- Lawrence Starkey, 21 years old, of 431 Mallory Avenue, Jersey City, was killed and eight other persons were injured when a sedan sidewiped another car. swerved and crashed into a truck and a second auto on State Highway Route 25 here early today.

VIENNA, April 6. -- The ministers of the three Little Entente powers -- Rumania, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia -- today presented to Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg identical notes of protest against the Austrian proclamation of universal service, which action they describe as a violation of the disarmament clauses of the Treaty of St. Germain. The Austrian Government tonight published the text of the notes.
ALBANY, April 6 (AP). -- Up-State cities, aroused by six week-end automobile fatalities and 248 auto deaths in January and February, pushed a vigorous safety drive tonight.

ALBANY, April 6. -- The conference committee appointed by the Senate and Assembly will meet tomorrow afternoon in an attempt to reach an agreement on controversial items in Governor Lehman's Budget Bill and one of his revenue measures and thus break the deadlock between the Democratic Senate and the Republican Assembly which has held for more than a month.

As near month contracts on the Cotton Exchange have been selling about $2 a bale below the average Southern Spot market, announcement of the administration's plan for releasing 1,000,000 bales in the balance of the current season caused little change in prices yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 6 (AP). -- Belief that an ancient Egyptian tomb cut from solid rock to a depth of thirty feet dates back more than 7,200 years was expressed today.

GENEVA, April 6. -- Three possible courses of action are open to the Committee of Thirteen at its meeting Wednesday. The one that is believed to have British backing is to ask Premier Benito Mussolini for a yes or no answer with a time limit attached as to whether he will negotiate peace "in the framework of the League and the spirit of the covenant."

PARIS, April 6. -- Alteration of the unanimity rule on the Council of the League of Nations to a two-thirds majority is believed to be among the provisions of the French peace plan submitted today to the Cabinet by Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin.

A generally firmer tone was in evidence in most futures on the local commodity markets yesterday. On the cash markets, rye, butter, eggs, Straits tin, wool tops and rubber advanced, while corn, cotton, standard tin, silk and cocoa declined.

WASHINGTON, April (AP). -- The authority of the House Military Committee to elicit information from a newspaper reporter regarding the background of a story was challenged today by Elisha Hanson, counsel for Frank C. Waldrop, writer for the Hearst newspapers.

How Italy is faring under sanctions is indicated in the weekly commerce reports for April 4 of the Department of Commerce. It brings the situation up only to the end of February but records these summations of conditions:
BOSTON, April 6 (AP). -- The Massachusetts House of Representatives lined up overwhelmingly today in favor of the Teachers Oath Law.

Two anti-war meetings were scheduled to be held yesterday at the Eternal Light in Madison Square as a contrast to Army Day celebrations in other parts of the city, but after one organization had laid a wreath at the monument, a second group learned that the Park Department had refused to grant it a permit.
Bernard DeVoto has begun work on a new novel, "Mountain Time," which Little, Brown plan to publish in the Spring of 1937.

PITTSBURGH, April 6. -- A sharply critical attack on Herbert Hoover as the leader of a "do-nothing administration" which chose, after the economic crash of 1929, to help the "bankers and the investing classes" while the "people starved" was made tonight by Secretary Ickes.

ALBANY, April 6. -- Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., Assistant Health Commissioner, was nominated tonight by Governor Lehman as Health Commissioner to succeed Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., who has resigned to become Surgeon General of the United States.

The Beethoven Association concluded its eighteenth season with a concert at the Town Hall last night. A group of fourteen instrumentalists took part in the program, which included works by Vitali, Beethoven and Saint-Saens. A large audience gave evidences of pleasure throughout the evening.

Tony Canzoneri must defend his world's lightweight championship against Lou Ambers of Herkimer, N.Y., on or before July 15, the New York State Athletic Commission ruled at its meeting yesterday. The boxing solons instructed Sammy Goldman, Canzoneri's manager, and Al Weill, Ambers's pilot, to appear before them within fifteen days with signed contracts for such a bout.

ANDERSON, S.C., April 6. -- This textile city, storm-conscious as the result of tornadoes that have taken lives in the past, saw another such storm whirl out of the West today and later counted thirty persons injured, several seriously, but no dead.

Miss Rhode Low gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mrs. Moses Taylor Campbell, Mrs. Albert Gould Jennings, Mrs. Dudley P. Gilbert, Mrs. John Hone Auerback and Mrs. LeBrun Rhinelander.

The scope of "obscenity" as understood by the law was limited yesterday in a decision handed down by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals when it was decided that the reaction of the "prurient" would be no commentary on the ultimate value of an artistic or scientific production.

BERLIN, April 6. -- The Boerse opened weak, with typical Monday inactivity. Heavy industrials were quiet, showing a tendency to fall at the close. Vereinigtestahl losing 1/4 point and Rheinstahl, 1/8. Electricals were inactive with the exception of A.E.G., which gained 5/8 point.

WITH THE SOUTHERN ITALIAN ARMY IN ETHIOPIA (by courier to Mogadiscio, Italian Somaliland), April 3 (AP). -- Italian air squadrons broke up strong entrenchments and destroyed an anti-aircraft battery at Sasa Baneh today.

Miss Rhode Low gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mrs. Moses Taylor Campbell, Mrs. Albert Gould Jennings, Mrs. Dudley P. Gilbert, Mrs. John Hone Auerback and Mrs. LeBrun Rhinelander.

The scope of "obscenity" as understood by the law was limited yesterday in a decision handed down by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals when it was decided that the reaction of the "prurient" would be no commentary on the ultimate value of an artistic or scientific production.

BERLIN, April 6. -- The Boerse opened weak, with typical Monday inactivity. Heavy industrials were quiet, showing a tendency to fall at the close. Vereinigtestahl losing 1/4 point and Rheinstahl, 1/8. Electricals were inactive with the exception of A.E.G., which gained 5/8 point.

WITH THE SOUTHERN ITALIAN ARMY IN ETHIOPIA (by courier to Mogadiscio, Italian Somaliland), April 3 (AP). -- Italian air squadrons broke up strong entrenchments and destroyed an anti-aircraft battery at Sasa Baneh today.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 6 (AP). -- The American whose racquet beat Fred Perry, England's No. 1 player, in the United States singles final last year, has a hunch the United States will regain the Davis Cup.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 6. -- Six lettermen were among the sixty-one candidates for the 1936 Princeton football team who reported to Head Coach Fritz Crisler today at the opening of the annual four-week Spring practice session. Thirty-four of the candidates were members of last Fall's freshman eleven.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 6. -- Bermuda's four-boat team of one-design yachts won one race today against Long Island Sound's interclub class knockabouts and with it the annual Spring series. The competition ended with four triumphs for the home skippers against two for the visitors.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 6. -- A new basis for the assessment of corporation real estate for tax purposes was advanced today by William H. Hall, appearing as counsel for Clinton L. Bardo, a trustee of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway, when he informed Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley that railroad property should be assessed with a view to the financial condition of its owners.

CLINTON, N.J., April 6. -- Allegheny Baconrind, white and liver pointer dog owned by Captain R.H. Clemmer of Waynesboro, Va., and handled by E.M. Farrier, won first honors today in the open junior all-age stake, second event on the program at the Spring meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club.

Detectives of the East Sixty-seventh Street station arrested two men last night in connection with the theft of $56,000 worth of jewelry and furs from the apartment of Dr. Kurt Simon, 888 Park Avenue, on March 10 during the building service employes strike.
BALTIMORE, April 6. -- Three men, crew of the 200-foot oil barge Anthony Groves Jr., were burned to death or drowned today when the barge was swept by flames in Chesapeake Bay following an explosion.

Last-minute requests for Easter merchandise were numerous in the wholesale markets here yesterday as retailers sought to spur deliveries on both apparel and accessories, deliveries of which have been delayed. It is expected that this week's trade at retail will strongly emphasize dress accessories and juvenile wear, although major apparel will continue to sell in volume.

Dusk last evening brought to Jews throughout the world the beginning of the holiday period of Peseach, or Passover, commemorating the storied exodus from the Egypt of the Pharaohs more than 3,000 years ago.

By their votes today Wisconsin Republicans will decide whether the State's twenty-four delegates to the Cleveland Convention shall have a free hand or be pledged to support Senator BORAH. The uninstructed slate was made by caucuses in the districts and a State conference.

Plans for daily conferences in an attempt to speed transit unification negotiations were announced yesterday by William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commission, at the close of the first general transit conference held by the commission in a month.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6. -- After one of the greatest putting exhibitions ever seen on any golf course Horton Smith, angular Chicago professional, today edged his fellow-townsman, Harry Cooper, out of what appeared to be certain victory in the masters' tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club.

The Madison Square Hotel, surrounding the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, and the old Fifth Avenue Theatre, at the northwest corner of Broadway and Twenty-eighth Street, were among the ten Manhattan properties bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday, as follows:

LONDON, April 6. -- Rudyard Kipling, whose books outsell all others in this country, left an estate in Britain valued at 155,228 gross and 142,488 net, according to his will, which has been filed by the widow.

For the previous failure of the AAA to publish the facts regarding the recipients of large benefits, Secretary WALLACE has made two explanations. One of these is the amount of clerical work it would have involved, the other the fear of the "exploitation to which "farmers, by such a practice, would "have been exposed."

Emily C. Williams sold a four-story flat at 230 East 102d Street to a client of Crandall, Grant Williams. The property is assessed at $12,000. The sale, for all cash, was arranged by William Cruikshank's Sons.

Resplendent in a miniature policeman's uniform -- a gift from his mother to hasten his recovery from scarlet fever -- Peter J. Farrell Jr., 7 years old, sauntered from his home at 339 West Forty-third Street at noon yesterday and, stationing himself at Eighth Avenue and Forty-third Street, proceeded to direct traffic with all the gusto of a regular bluecoat.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 6. -- A thirty-cent red hot rivet caused $10,000 damage and endangered sixteen of the workers building the Bay Bridge today by igniting a wooden pier fender soaked with creosote.
The total of contributions received for flood relief by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross rose to $532,282 yesterday, General Robert C. Davis, executive director, announced.
WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Following is the text of the majority opinion of the Supreme Court in the case of J. Edward Jones against the Securities and Exchange Commission:

With the preponderance of the day's news favoring the side of the advance, the stock market responded accordingly yesterday but showed no inclination to overdo matters. Steel and automotive issues resumed leadership at the outset, and brisk gains were recorded in the forenoon.

MOSCOW, April 6. -- Soviet realism in world politics took the form today of advocacy of complete equality for Germany and a strong collective system of security under a strengthened League of Nations.

DES MOINES, N.M., April 6 (AP). -- Into the depths of Devil's Wash Basin, a hidden lake, State police today took up a trail revealed by a strange story of how Ray Sutton, missing for six years, was murdered in gangster fashion by bootleggers.

ADDIS ABABA, April 6. -- A vigorous repudiation of suggestions that he has been decisively defeated and is suing for peace is the first point in Emperor Haile Selassie's reply to a request today for a statement after the Italian claim of victory.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 6. -- Yale's opening football practice on Anthony Thompson Field today, held between showers and on a muddy field, brought out fifty candidates. Fifteen more notified Head Coach Ducky Pond that they expect to report tomorrow or Wednesday and complete the squad that will drill five days a week for five weeks this Spring.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Governor Myers of the Farm Credit Administration announced today that approximately $185,000,000 principal amount of 4 1/2 per cent individual bonds of the Federal Land Banks would be called tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The philosophical division in the Supreme Court continues to be the most interesting, probably the most important, thing in Washington. Whenever it comes to the surface of events it is revealed as a fundamental difference over what latitude this court shall allow a governmental agency in the discharge of a function which both sets of justices agree may be an honest attempt to implement the law that created the agency.

Proficiency certificates stating that they had satisfactorily completed the required study were received yesterday afternoon by the first thirty girls taking the household training course, given under the direction of the women's division of the WPA, of which Mrs. Sarah S. Dennen is director.

Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, whose plan for recapitalization of the Radio Corporation of America was approved by the directors of the company on Jan. 31, will attend a special meeting of the company today.

A prediction that New York City would rank first in safety among the cities of the nation in 1936 was made yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine at a luncheon meeting of the New York Advertising Men's Post of the American Legion at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.
In your editorial today you refer to the fact that present unemployment is fully as great as it was in March, 1933. If we disregard relief and public works employment, that is probably true.

The elevation of ghost-writing from a sporadic and somewhat shamefaced occupation to a recognized trade is signalized by the appearance of newspaper advertisements of a ghost-writers' bureau. "Any topic, any purpose, any length," reads the copy.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,873,900 barrels, compared with 2,876,200 the week before, a decline of 2,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 18,650 barrels in Oklahoma and a gain of 9,350 in Louisiana were the important changes.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- For the first time the Internal Revenue Bureau, in regulations issued today, recognized the write-off of bank debts by supervisory authorities, as deductible from income for Federal tax purposes.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Closer working arrangements between the United States and China on financial problems involving silver were contemplated today as representatives of the Chinese Government and this country conferred in Washington.

CHICAGO, April 7. -- The West won its first national open indoor polo championship tonight when Steve Hammond, hard-riding member of a selected high-goal Western trio, drove home a final second goal which downed an all-star team from the East, 7 to 6 1/2, in the concluding match of the East-West tournament.

CHICAGO, April 7. -- The First National Bank of this city formally notified the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today of its intention to retire the remaining $15,000,000 of its preferred stock still held by the RFC. The bank retired $10,000,000 of the original $25,000,000 issue last December.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Wednesday, April 8. -- Borah candidates for delegate at large to the Republican National Convention had an increasing lead over an organization uninstructed slate in returns early today from yesterday's balloting.

Sir Arthur Munro Sutherland, former Lord Mayor of Newcastle-on-Tyne, a shipowner; Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bostwick and Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius V. Whitney are among the passengers due today from the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

Playing off his postponed game from the sixth round in Group A at the Manhattan Chess Club, Samuel Factor of Chicago, Illinois State champion, yesterday tied the score made by G.N. Treystman, a contestant in Group C at the Empire City Chess Club, in the United States chess championship preliminaries.

The State of Rhode Island yesterday awarded a new issue of $500,000 of relief bonds to B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., at a price of 100,456 for 1 1/4s. The bonds are dated Sept. 16, 1935, and mature on April 15, 1940. They will be reoffered today to yield 1 per cent to maturity.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP). -- A joint move to create a system of coordinated truck lines to supplement railway service was made today before the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Union Pacific, the Chicago North Western and the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroads.

We were flying in thick weather. The engines were roaring along smoothly. When it seemed as if enough time had elapsed for us to be nearing Pittsburgh, I went forward and asked the pilot when we were due. Captain Ferguson leaned back and said over his shoulder.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 7. -- Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, fighting to convince Captain Wilmer Allison of the American Davis Cup team that he deserves the No. 1 singles spot on the squad, defeated Allison today to win the River Oaks tennis championship.

Probability of opposition to the re-election of Mrs. Robert L. Bacon as vice chairman of the Republican State Committee was indicated yesterday when the newly elected women members of the committee from New York County met at county headquarters, 469 Fifth Avenue, on the call of Kenneth S. Simpson, county chairman.

SHANGHAI, April 7. -- A categorical denial of rumors that China had concluded a secret treaty with Russia was given this afternoon at Nanking by General Chang Chun, Foreign Minister, when Yakichiro Suma, the Japanese Consul General, called on him to draw attention to the conclusion of a mutual assistance protocol between Outer Mongolia and the Soviet.

Two checks for $3,000 were the subject yesterday of examination by Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor investigating charges of bribery in connection with the murder of Samuel Drukman in Brooklyn on the night of March 3, 1935.
LONDON, April 7. -- The embargo on foreign capital issues in London, which has been in force more than four years, is to be examined by an expert committee that was appointed by the government.
Manhattan realty deals yesterday included sales of several properties which will be renovated by the new owners. Multi-family housing on the upper West Side also figured in some of the transactions.

The Whitney Museum, delving into a not-so-very-distant phase of America's past, brings forward this week two Pennsylvania artists -- David G. Blythe and Joseph Boggs Beale -- examples of whose work are displayed in the galleries on the first and second floors.

Yesterday's share market followed the recent pattern, in that it turned dull on recessions. The strength on Monday and on Saturday induced profit-taking yesterday, and as declines ensued, the volume of trading diminished. Recent favorites in the industrial list closed lower on the day, as did the railway issues, as the utilities and some of the specialty stocks in the industrial group pointed higher.

BERLIN, Conn., April 7. -- Politely holding the door of the Berlin savings bank open to allow Miss Anna Tinti, 18, to enter, three bandits then used her as a shield while they held up employes of the bank and made their escape with $5,811 at 2 P.M. today.
Completion of reorganization of the Emergency Relief Bureau has resulted in a saving of approximately $7,700,000 annually, Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the bureau, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, April 7. -- Bills recommended by Thomas F. Dewey and Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutors, and designed to aid them in their drive against racketeers and gangsters in New York City were passed today by the Senate and sent to the Governor for his approval.

The Philadelphia Orchestra ended its New York season last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Stokowski conducted, and never has he given a more convincing and engrossing example of his wholly exceptional powers than in his interpretation of the three excerpts from "Parsifal," which opened the program.

Formal offering will be made today of an issue of $180,000,000 of Federal Land Banks 3 per cent consolidated Federal Farm Loan bonds, due on May 1, 1956, and not redeemable before May 1, 1946. The bonds are priced at 99 1/2 and interest, to yield about 3.03 per cent.

Captain Ralph E. Fleischer, Quartermaster Corps, United States Army, who was recently found guilty at a court-martial of embezzlement of government food and cash, has petitioned President Roosevelt to order a court of inquiry on the circumstances leading to the charges on which he was tried, it was announced yesterday by Lewis Landes, his associate counsel.

While business failures in the retail group showed an increase in the United States in the week ended April 2, compared with the previous week, the total was below the average for the division so far this year, it was reported yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

That the Metropolitan Opera audience at large prefers French and German opera was evidenced yesterday afternoon when the Metropolitan Opera Guild announced the results of its recent ballot. Mrs. John DeWitt Peltz, chairman of the ballot committee, disclosed the results at the first annual meeting of the guild at the Hotel Pierre.

Continuing its program of consolidating its operating subsidiaries, the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that the properties and activities of the American Sheet and Tin Plate Company would be merged with those of its principal operating unit, the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

SENATOR BORAH probably would rather be known as a "great moral force" than be President. This is just as well. The Senator himself has been violently mistreating whatever Presidential aspirations he may have for some thirty years. By now to make an orthodox play for that office would seem to run against his entire nature, both inborn and developed.

THE sun-tanned president of the National League, Mr. Ford Christopher Frick, was seated at his desk and looking a bit lonely in his large office. Maybe it was the weather. It was bad baseball weather.

CLEVELAND, April 7. -- Mrs. Cecelia Challinor and her two children got the greatest thrill they have had or ever will have, probably, at 8:30 o'clock tonight. Informed shortly after noon that her husband, Charles G. Challinor, 33, was one of the persons killed in the airline crash at Uniontown, Pa., she told a reporter:

Announcement was made yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, of the opening of playgrounds throughout the city for the use of children after school hours. Playgrounds connected with the public schools will be available to the children immediately.

Although steel operations rose sharply in the first quarter of this year to the highest rate since 1930, earnings of the leading producers probably were not as satisfactory as the quantity of production would indicate. Keen competition for business and heavy price-cutting took their toll of profit margins.

CLINTON, N.J., April 7. -- Through rain-soaked covers of the State shooting grounds today a large field contested in the final event of the annual Spring meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club. Although rain fell during the early morning, there was a let up by the time the first brace was put down in the shooting dog stake and the event was run through to a conclusion.

BERLIN, April 7. -- The National Socialist sport authorities are boycotting plans for a German excursion to the Max Schmeling-Joe Louis fight in the United States in June. A protest against the project appears in the Reich Sport Journal, the regular organ of the German Olympic committee and of the centralized German sport bureaucracy headed by Hans von Tschammer und Osten, Reich sport leader.

Henry C. and George W. Steneck, former president and vice president respectively of the closed Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, were convicted yesterday by a jury in the Hudson County Court in Jersey City of falsely reporting the value of the bank's assets to the State Banking Commissioner for 1931.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark. April 7. -- Charles (Lucky) Luciano succeeded late today in frustrating for at least ten days the efforts of New York authorities to force his return there to face charges of compulsory prostitution. Out of their bag of legal tricks his attorneys drew a manoeuvre giving the fugitive ten days of grace.
TUPELO, Miss., April 7 (AP). -- Tupelo settled itself to a gigantic rehabilitation task tonight after burying many of its 192 storm dead in hurriedly prepared graves.

A warning that the present trend to taxation of undivided profits might easily lead along the road of easy spending to taxation not only of capital reserves of corporations but also of the savings of individuals, was given last night by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

LONDON, April 7. -- Trading continued quiet but with prices firm today on the London Stock Exchange. British funds formed one of the best sections of the market, with the war loan standing out. Internationals were again active, although trading lessened in the afternoon.
I read with interest the dispatch in THE TIMES headed "Britain still asks United States to join League."
Women leaders in social and civic life met at the Colony Club yesterday and agreed to support the $1,500,000 campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 7 (AP). -- Alfred Gaudreau of Saginaw, Mich., provided the only change among leaders in the American Bowling Congress today when he blasted 699 in the singles. In missing the 700 mark by one pin, Gaudreau hit games of 236, 241, 222 to take eighth place.

BERLIN, April 7. -- In the absence of authoritative indications of the nature of the French peace proposals, German political comment is wholly speculative. The prevailing view is that the diplomatic battle now being waged between London and Paris has resolved itself into a conflict between Locarno and Chancellor Adolf Hitler's peace proposals.

Showing an all-around mastery of the game that practically sets him in a class by himself so far as local badminton play is concerned, Kenneth J. Ridgway of Garden City won the metropolitan singles championship for the third successive year at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night.

The alertness of a motorist driving in Fifth Avenue last Monday night in acting on a police alarm for a missing boy resulted yesterday in Saul Lubin, 17 years old, of 324 East Ninth Street, being held in $1,000 bail by Magistrate McKinery in the Felony Court on a kidnapping charge.

A charge of malicious mischief preferred by the Rev. Frank D. Svoboda, pastor of the Jan Hus Presbyterian Church, 347 East Seventy-fourth Street, was responsible last night for the appearance of Daniel Smith, a 16-year-old public school student, in Night Court.

LONDON, April 7. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden left this afternoon for Geneva for tomorrow's session of the League of Nations Conciliation Committee of Thirteen to consider the possibility of Italo-Ethiopian peace negotiations and the question of Italy's violation of treaties by killing African noncombatants with poisonous gas dropped from planes.

CINCINNATI, April 7 (AP). -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company asked the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today to review an order of the Federal Trade Commission directing the company to desist in a practice of granting special price considerations to Sears, Roebuck Co.

MIAMI, Fla., April 7. -- After studying reports on the Southern tornado disasters, President Roosevelt tonight allocated $2,500,000 to the Works Progress Administration funds for emergency work in the affected areas to supplement Red Cross relief.

MADRID, April 7. -- Niceto Alcala Zamora, president of the Spanish Republic, was removed from office tonight on a Socialist motion that was carried in the Cortes, or Parliament, by a vote of 238 to 5. The Right abstained from voting.

In defending the salary paid to him by the International Business Machines Corporation, Thomas J. Watson, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that, although his compensation had averaged $184,154 a year, he now must pay the government in taxes "a little over 60 per cent" of his yearly income.

The Union Pacific Railroad will undertake today a refunding transaction said to be unique in its history through the offering of $26,835,000 of 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund thirty-five year debenture bonds due in 1971. The coupon rate was described as the lowest for an unsecured issue of this kind.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP). -- Prompted by storms dealing death and destruction in the South on the heels of floods in the East, the Senate today agreed to take up tomorrow legislation to authorize the RFC to lend $50,000,000 for rehabilitation work.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- American business, this time through the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, aimed another attack at President Roosevelt's new tax program, as the Ways and Means Committee brought its hearings to a close at a late night session.
Sermons on the first day of Passover were based generally on the theme that many Jews face a situation paralleling that of the sufferers under Pharaoh more than 3,000 years ago.

In the prosaic setting of a downtown office building, the head of a large corporation last night invoked the aid of modern exponents of the sonnet and iambic pentameter "to build back into the minds of American people the love of the home" and to promote a "boom" in dwelling construction which he believes already has started.

Production of steel ingots totaled 9,363,731 tons in the first three months of this year, the largest tonnage for a first-quarter period since 1930, says a statement by the American Iron and Steel Institute to be published today. The amount was 10 per cent larger than the 8,517,437 tons made in the first quarter of last year.

Steps taken by the Hitler regime to insure truth and accuracy in advertising copy have greatly increased the German public's confidence in advertising, Christian A. Kupferberg, chairman of a group of thirty-four Reich industrialists and advertising executives declared yesterday at a luncheon tended to the delegation by the Advertising Club of New York.

A New Jersey State-owned automobile, assigned to an inspector for the Department of Motor Vehicles, was linked by District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn yesterday to the events which led to the disclosure of Paul H. Wendel's "confession" to the Lindbergh kidnapping.

ALBANY, April 7. -- The conference committee appointed by the Legislature to compose differences between Republicans and Democrats over Governor Lehman's principal budget bill and one of his revenue measures held its first meeting today but failed to agree.
ELIZABETHTON, Tenn., April 7. -- The Giants and Indians carried their Spring struggle into the hills today, but only Steve O'Neill's hardy tribe profited by the manoeuvre.

Jack Frye, president of TWA, declared yesterday afternoon that the pilot, Otto Ferguson, was far off his course when the company's airliner crashed near Uniontown, Pa. He said that the plane was following the new type airway beacon which is being developed by the Department of Commerce.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals granted a temporary injunction yesterday to prevent the showing of "Captain January," a motion picture based on the novel of that name, pending trial of a suit for accounting and a permanent injunction against the Fox Film Corporation and its subsidiary, Rural Pictures Corporation.

BUDAPEST, April 7. -- Premier Julius Goemboes and Tibor Eckhardt, leader of the Peasants party, fought a bloodless pistol duel today in the tanbark-covered ring of the Francis Joseph cavalry barracks. They parted without a reconciliation.

A dispute between the Australian and Cuban tennis associations as to the site of the first-round Davis Cup tie between their teams has resulted in the withdrawal of Cuba from the international matches, it was announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- A permanent organization of the unemployed, no matter what their political faith, with a program and policy "for an unknown period of time in the future," was the goal set today at a "unity" meeting of delegates from a group of unemployed associations which began a three-day convention here today.

EDMONTON, April 7. -- The world's first social credit Legislature ended its first session today after breaking all records for brevity, since it lasted only nine weeks, and for business done because 114 bills were introduced and 102 were passed.

CLEVELAND, April 7. -- Urging elimination "of all those things which do not properly belong in the sphere of government action," James P. Warburg. New York banker, told the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce today, however, that opposition to the New Deal faces two dangers.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP). -- Louis Brooks of New York, a cotton broker and former chairman of the business conduct committee of the New York Cotton Exchange, told a Senate Agriculture subcommittee today that the Department of Justice should investigate operations on that Exchange.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 8. -- The text of the mutual assistance pact signed by the Soviet Union and the Mongolian People's Republic follows:

BASLE, Switzerland, April 7. -- Central bankers believe that if France abandons the gold standard she will go to a floating level as the British pound did but fixed in relation to the pound so as to allow moderate pressure for stabilization and to bring gold gradually back to France.

The Frick Collection, 1 East Seventieth Street, has acquired the rare and valuable panel by the early Italian master Piero della Francesca, which was discovered recently in Austria. The panel will be placed on exhibition this morning in the lecture hall of the Frick Collection.

Strong opposition to any move by WPA authorities to reduce the number of workers on school relief projects was voiced yesterday by Associate Superintendent of Schools Stephen F. Bayne, Assistant Superintendent Benjamin B. Greenberg and Professor Arthur I. Gates of Teachers College, Columbia University.

It begins to look as if every European nation, or group of nations, is about to issue proposals for a revision of the Covenant of the League of Nations. That document, like the Constitution of the United States, provided for its own amendment, and perhaps after seventeen years of trial some changes are desirable.

Sales in March for Montgomery Ward Co. were the largest for that month in the company's history. As reported yesterday, the total for the month was $24,844,596, without consideration of the change in the number of stores in the year, compared with $22,783,089 for the corresponding month in 1935, an increase of 9 per cent.

Mae Scheible and Joseph Ryan, her handyman and "bouncer," were found guilty yesterday in Federal court of having violated the Mann Act when they moved her vice operations from Pittsburgh to New York in the Fall of 1934.

LONDON, April 7. -- Special prayers were offered for German Jewry and an appeal for the 1,000,000 fund to aid Jewish emigration from Germany was made in every synagogue in Britian today, the first day of Passover.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 7. -- The sun shone for the Yankees today, the first bright rays the squad has seen since leaving Florida, but it cast only shadows for Joe McCarthy and his band. The joy of an otherwise perfect day was lost in the gloom of accident and illness which overtook the club and added two players to the hospital list.

Moses L. Parshelsky, president of Parshelsky Brothers, Inc., manufacturers of glass and builders' supplies at 131 Morgan Avenue, Brooklyn, was named in an indictment handed by the Federal grand jury yesterday to Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court.

The only real defenders of the proposed tax on undistributed corporation profits that have appeared before the Ways and Means Committee have been three representatives of the Treasury, a lawyer requested by the Treasury to appear, and a representative of the Communist party.

VIENNA, April 7. -- Yesterday's protest by the Little Entente nations against Austria's alleged violation of the Treaty of Saint Germain in proclaiming universal military service evoked today a government-inspired attack of unusual violence on Yugoslavia and to a lesser extent on Czechoslovakia and Rumania, the other members of the entente.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 7. -- Revision of the entrance requirements of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology permitting greater flexibility in the choice of subjects and requiring fewer examinations has been announced. The changes effect particularly those students who cannot qualify under the plan which permits students in the highest fifth of their class to enter technology without examination.

Secretary ICKES has renewed his attack on the Hoover Administration with a thrust which does not do him credit. Speaking at Pittsburgh he said that Mr. HOOVER, "while sternly denying "Federal relief to starving men and "women," did not hesitate about "generously handing over" millions of dollars to banks, insurance companies and other corporations.

Shipments of all types of hosiery in February totaled 8,662,068 dozen, an increase of 2 per cent over those in January, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. The total was almost unchanged from that of a year ago, the association reports.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- President Roosevelt's re-election was declared extremely probable, although not certain, by Norman Thomas, former Socialist candidate for President, during a press conference here today. Mr. Thomas revealed in the course of his talk that he was considering running in the November election for the House of Representatives from some New York City district, instead of for the Presidency.

Modes that emerge gracefully into the limelight after the lapse of a hundred years and others that now range from grotesque to burlesque fascinated an audience of more than 1,000 women and more than a few men in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Continued improvement in banking conditions was seen today by officials in a notice received by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation from the First National Bank of Chicago that it desired to retire the balance of the preferred stock which the government corporation purchased.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $3,730,785 after all deductions for the year ended on Feb. 29. This was equal after preferred dividends to $1.45 each on 1,743,658 common shares and it compared with $2,901, 644, or 98 cents a share, for the preceding twelve months.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 7. -- A hospital is not liable for the negligence of nurses while they are "exercising their profession and calling," according to a decision today by Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close when he set aside a $4,500 jury verdict against the New Rochelle Hospital.

MEXICO, D.F., April 7. -- Eight persons were killed and fourteen injured, some of them perhaps fatally, in the bombing of last evening's express train from Vera Cruz to this city on a bridge near Paso del Macho, according to the latest figures of railway officials.
WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Rain forced Casey Stengel's Dodgers to ignore their scheduled engagement with the Richmond Colts today. The team left the Virginia capital at noon.

Postmaster General James A. Farley said yesterday that he had no intention of resigning either his Cabinet post or his job as chairman of the Democratic National Committee. He departed for a brief vacation in Bermuda, sailing at 3 P.M. on the Monarch of Bermuda with Mrs. Farley and their children, Betty, Ann and James A. Jr. Mrs. D.H. McKetrick, a friend, also accompanied them.

John Barbirolli, 36-year-old British conductor, who is comparatively unknown in this country, has been chosen to direct the first ten weeks of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society next season, it was announced yesterday by the board of directors.
Housing and business properties were included in the Queens realty turnover reported yesterday.

Commodity futures were slightly easier yesterday in all the markets here. The trading was listless, except in wool tops where advances occurred. On the cash markets, wheat, rye, cotton, wool tops, butter and eggs gained, while flour, cocoa, silk and tins declined.

DETROIT, April 7. -- A vigorous, smooth-working attack that rarely faltered enabled the Detroit Red Wings to turn back the Toronto Maple Leafs in the second game of the Stanley Cup round for the world's hockey championship tonight by the score of 9 to 4.

A first trip in an airplane, the reward granted by parents for attaining a high scholastic average, proved fatal to Crawford T. Kelly, 18-year-old son of Dr. and Mrs. John C. Kelly of McKeesport, a victim of the crash near Uniontown yesterday.

Sponsors of the proposed tax-limitation amendment to the State constitution have made further changes in the bill now before the State Legislature to meet objections that the plan would injure municipal credit.

Resentment against toy green pigs as emblematic of St. Patrick's Day and the Irish race caused the United Irish Societies of Brooklyn and Long Island, meeting at 81 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, to adopt unanimously a resolution requesting the German Consul, the German Trade Commissioner in Washington and German importers to take steps to stop their manufacture and sale.

Thomas Ewing Jr., president of the Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company of Yonkers, who died Feb. 8, 1933, left an estate appraised yesterday at $7,778,187 gross and $6,772,493 net, which included property previously taxed valued at $6,662,539.

Melville C. Rosch, secretary of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, reported yesterday that an eight-pound brown trout was caught in Kensico Reservoir, north of White Plains, on the opening day of the season. Records of the association fail to disclose a larger trout of the brook, brown or rainbow varieties ever having been taken from the waters of Westchester County.

The United States cannot isolate itself from the disastrous consequences of another world war, but by cooperating with the collective efforts of other nations it could prevent the outbreak of such a catastrophe, Sir Arthur Salter said last night in an address before a distinguished audience at the Town Hall.

Having tried almost everything else in his Circus on Sixth Avenue, Mr. Rose has now devised a new scheme for "Jumbo's" last week. During all the matinees, including Sunday, each ticket bought will enable the purchaser to bring along with him free one child.

Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post told the young women's organization of the Women's National Republican Club yesterday that 78 per cent of the old-law tenements standing in 1900 were still standing, despite the demolition, since he took office, of slum properties with five miles of front footage.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, April 7. -- According to reliable information received here from South Tyrol, a "banishment commission" for South Tyrol, sitting in Bolzano [formerly Bozen] under the Italian prefect Mastromattei, has passed heavy sentences of banishment on eight South Tyrolese to Southern Italy.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 7 (AP). -- Carolina rivers, already out of their banks at some points, rose slowly toward flood crests today as small tributaries, swollen by a four-inch rainfall, disgorged.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Dismissal of lottery charges against Mrs. Oliver Harriman's $60,000 prize contest was moved by her counsel today on the ground that nothing in the Postoffice Department's citation nor the subsequent hearings had shown a violation of postal regulations justifying its exclusion from the mails.

Discussions of the proposal of the intercoastal ship line to organize a conference with power to regulate and administer the affairs of the intercoastal trade were resumed yesterday at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street. The conferees met several times last week at the Hotel Barclay, but failed to reach an agreement.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers will offer today 281,914 shares of common stock of the Flintkote Company at $47.25 a share. This financing will mark the passing of control of the company, a leading American producer of asphalt shingles and sidings, roofings and emulsions, from foreign interests to investors here.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., April 7. -- Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of Newark arrived here soon after dark tonight and immediately went to the Uniontown Hospital to see his wife, one of the three survivors of the air-liner crash near here today.

On Nov. 15, 1935, Mr. ROOSEVELT announced the appointment of LAMAR HARDY as United States Attorney and JOHN J. KELLY as Marshal for the Southern District of New York. The intruding hand of Mr. FARLEY was suspected. After long opposition, the appointment of Mr. HARDY was confirmed last week.

CHATTANOOGA, April 7 (AP). -- Rain driven in torrents over the South by week-end tornadoes sent many creeks and rivers far beyond flood level tonight and raised a new threat to life and property in half a dozen States.

Dana Pond, the artist, gave a reception for Mr. and Mrs. Arnall Hodges yesterday afternoon in his studio in the Hotel Des Artistes, 1 West Sixty-seventh Street. The host and his guests of honor were assisted in receiving by Mrs. Hendrick Vanderbilt Duryea and Mrs. Edwin Swift Balch of Philadelphia.

How many people realize that, in contradistinction to the League of Nations centered in Geneva, there is developing another League of Nations outside? True, they are not banded together as yet, being tremendously out of sympathy with each other in all respects but one.

Organization of a board of thirty or forty nationally known economists, charged by the President with the duty of "jealously safeguarding majority interests of consumers," was recommended yesterday by Ward Melville, president of the Melville Shoe Corporation and of the National Council of Shoe Retailers, Inc.

David A. Moscovitz, regional attorney for the National Labor Relations Board, sought yesterday to prove that The Associated Press was an organization engaged in interstate commerce and therefore subject to the National Labor Relations Act.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- The propriety of Judge Halsted L. Ritter's refusal to grant the plea of the plaintiff for dismissal of the foreclosure suit against the Whitehall Building and Operating Company and his insistence on appointing a receiver became an issue today at the Senate impeachment trial of the Florida Federal jurist.

MADRID, April 7. -- Five years to the month after he bad driven King Alfonso from the throne, Niceto Alcala Zamora was ousted by a vote of the Cortes tonight from the presidency of the republic he had helped to create. His term still had one year and eight months to run.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Following its policy of dealing with each case separately, the Securities and Exchange Commission today, after denying applications that it be held confidential, made public data reported to it by several corporations under the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Mrs. Joanna de Tuscan, the Middle West's outstanding swordswoman, rose to unexpected heights last night as she emerged victorious from a field of seventeen candidates in the fifth of the series of Olympic tryouts conducted on the strips of the Fencers Club.

BALTIMORE, April 7 (AP). -- Directors of the Townsend Plan reorganized the national movement today and at the same time challenged the Congressional investigation of its affairs as being "unwarranted and unconstitutional."

BOWIE, Md., April 7. -- There was a New York victory and a surprising one through the heavy footing today when Townsend Martin's Balkanese got up to win by a head from John Hay Whitney's Tall Oak, the favorite. The race was the four furlongs of the Salisbury Purse, a prep for the Kindergarten Stakes, and it seems pretty sure now that the Martin juvenile will be one of the choices in Saturday's feature.
TOKYO, April 7. -- Evidently inspired from a common source, all evening newspapers reported today that Nanking had concluded a secret agreement with the Soviet directed against Japan.

Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, received a fee of $150,000 for devising the plan of recapitalization of the Radio Corporation of America, he said at the special meeting of stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- From the areas stricken by flood and wind comes nothing but praise for the work of the American Red Cross. Once more there is brought to mind the difference between the atmosphere in which governmental and private relief are administered.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP). -- Dining and dancing in the name of Jackson and Jefferson have been adopted by the Democrats as a source of revenue.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 7. -- Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S.C., who defeated Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare and Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews on her way to winning the recent women's tournament at Belleair, Fla., tied with Miss Deborah Verry of Worcester, Mass., for medal honors today in the women's North and South golf championship.

GENEVA, April 7. -- Declaring "Ethiopia's independence is not alone at stake," her Paris Minister, Wolde Maryam, made a strong appeal to the League of Nations today for something more from tomorrow's meeting of the conciliation committee of thirteen than "a platonic invitation to the two belligerents to accept negotiations."

A ten-year period of activity in real estate was forecast by Joseph P. Day in an address before the Lions Club of New York at the Hotel Astor yesterday. With the present country-wide interest in home ownership and anticipated credit inflation, the real estate market would gather momentum and workers would fall away from relief rolls and be reabsorbed in gainful occupations, Mr. Day predicted.

PARIS, April 7. -- France's and Great Britain's Foreign Ministers are traveling tonight to Geneva to discuss in different committees Italy's broken word in Ethiopia and Germany's broken word in the Rhineland.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., April 7. -- Eleven of fourteen persons aboard the California-bound "Sun Racer" of Transcontinental and Western Air were killed today when the airliner crashed on a mountain-top not far from the hamlet of Fairchance, near here.

Mrs. Maud Millette, mistress of the women's wardrobe of the circus, beamed almost tenderly last night over a long table-load of soft feathered hats, each shaped like a complicated lyre in a room in Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, April 7. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade fluctuated today in an erratic manner within a range of around 1/2 cent a bushel, showing relative firmness as the result of continued dry weather reports from parts of Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas, and closed with net gains of 1/8 cent.

An advance party of the joint American expedition to Siberia to study the total eclipse of the sun on June 19 will sail today on the Washington of the United States Lines. The party, sponsored by the Harvard College Observatory and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is in charge of Dr. Donald H. Menzel, Associate Professor of Astronomy at Harvard.

CHICAGO, April 7. -- The demand for hogs here today was much less aggressive than yesterday and prices declined 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight, with final sales at the bottom. The top price was off 10 cents at $10.90, while the day's average was off a like amount at $10.60.

KANSAS CITY, April 7 (AP). -- Nellie Granger, who stumbled into a farmhouse near Uniontown today with word that eleven persons had been killed in a TWA plane crash, was chosen from among 2,000 applicants, six months ago, as a flying hostess for the airline.
MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, April 8. -- If Mayor Hoan is re-elected he probably will be the only survivor of the Socialist city administration, unofficial returns indicated early today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP). -- The International Joint Commission decided today to hold public hearings late next Summer on a proposed deep seaway from Montreal to New York, linking the St. Lawrence River, Lake Champlain and the Hudson River.

Mixed trends ruled the bond market yesterday in continued dull trading. While the higher grade issues, including United States Government loans, held steady to slightly higher, the most conspicuous price movements were on the down side and confined almost exclusively to the speculative bonds in the industrial group.

In deciding on Monday a case arising under the Securities Act of 1933, the Supreme Court took occasion to warn against the irregular and oppressive practices to which agencies of the Government have been too often tempted to resort. The court did not pass at all upon the constitutionality of the Securities Act itself.

The number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday, because of the proximity of Easter, was the smallest for any week this year. The total was also well below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Four adults and seven children were carried down ladders from a burning building at 413 Nostrand Avenue, at Jefferson Avenue, in the Bedford section of Brooklyn, about 10 o'clock last night. Two other tenants escaped over the roof of an adjoining building.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., April 7. -- Rescue crews, working in a swirling snowstorm, trudged over seven weary miles through thick underbrush and deep mud tonight to take the bodies of the victims of the airliner crash to a Uniontown morgue.
James Lavall, 40 years old, a Negro, of 63 West 143d Street, was held in $500 bail yesterday for Special Sessions by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio on a petit larceny charge.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Joining forces, the National Geographic Society and Georgetown University scientists said today that they would attempt to make the first true color photographs of an eclipse of the sun on June 19 in Siberia.

An improvement occurred in both old and new crop positions on the Cotton Exchange yesterday which carried May to 11 1/4 cents a pound and all late months above 10 1/4 cents, with a gain of 5 to 9 points on the day. As cotton in the 12-cent loan has not yet been made available to consumers and the supply of desirable grades is rapidly diminishing, trade demand for near months affected prices.

Members of the Dramatists Guild, both active and associate, will meet this afternoon at the Hotel Shelton, at which time the proposed amendment to the minimum basic agreement, which would substitute a straight 60-40 split of "picture money" for the present sliding scale, will be presented to the voting members for ratification.
