GAINSVILLE, Ga., April 7. -- The storm-lashed South compiled a list of 421 known dead today from sporadic Spring tornadoes, as flooded rivers threatened new disaster over a widespread area.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 7. -- Educational institutions of this country, with the exception of the University of Virginia and Yale University, were criticized for turning out "men as money-makers" in the will of James Anderson Hawes of Harrison, for more than twenty years general secretary of the national council of the Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity.

Labor conditions in this State furnish a basis for real estate stability, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday in a letter to Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 7. -- Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch entertained with a luncheon today at the Greenbrier Casino for Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien, Miss Ann Brokaw and Mrs. Lucius M. Boomer.

GARY, Ind., April 7. -- Cocker spaniels were the first breed to be judged this morning at the opening of the second annual all-breed show of the Calumet Kennel Club, which is being held in the Hotel Gary. The judge of the cockers was Harry Osborne of Chicago.

Twenty-five years of travel that took me into every State in the Union and into all the Canadian Provinces convinces me that the New Yorker is the most self-centered individual in the United States. I am one, so I feel I can freely express my opinion.

An injunction to prevent a New York restaurant from using the name of a Parisian restaurant was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the Maison Prunier against Prunier's Restaurant and Cafe, Inc.; Prunier de Paris, Amelio and Calimero Ronchetti and Myron Colbert.

The Combustion Engineering Company, Inc., has leased the seventeenth floor in 200 Madison Avenue, adding 13,450 square feet to the four floors now occupied by the company. The Cross Brown Company was the broker. Other rentals reported yesterday were as follows:

Reports of a "face-lifting" operation promised for Washington Square this Spring by the Park Department and protests against "inadequate" police supervision at night were heard last night at the thirtieth annual meeting of the Washington Square Association, held at the Hotel Brevoort.

Reports of a "face-lifting" operation promised for Washington Square this Spring by the Park Department and protests against "inadequate" police supervision at night were heard last night at the thirtieth annual meeting of the Washington Square Association, held at the Hotel Brevoort.

Shafts of criticism were thrust at the New Deal yesterday by Bruce (Buster) Hoefer, 10-year-old Sheboygan, Wis., editor with three years' experience, who is publishing his Sheboygan Weekly in New York this week during a visit. Blond, slight of build and in the fifth grade at the Ulysses S. Grant School at Sheboygan, Buster, who is reporter, copyreader, editor, printer -- and who writes his own advertising copy -- had this to say:
News of the destruction wrought by tornadoes in the South brought the contributions to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross for disaster relief to $547,541 yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 7. -- The home-and-home series of football games between the University of Pennsylvania and Princeton, resumed last Fall, will suffer a one-year lapse in 1937, according to the eight-game Nassau schedule for that season released today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- The Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection has requested operators of freighters and passenger ships of American registry to keep it informed of all cases of insubordination among their crews, so that corrective measures may be taken in the interest of greater safety of life and property at sea.

The annual award of the Hundred Year Association, composed of business houses established here a century or longer, will be given to John D. Rockefeller Jr. for his gift to the city of Fort Tryon Park and the Cloisters, museum of medieval art, it was announced last night at the eighth annual dinner at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza.

GARY, Ind., April 8. -- General D, English setter owned by George F. Henneberry of LaGrange Park, Ill., and handled by Joseph Viner of Chicago, won the best in show award at the Calumet Kennel Club's fixture, which closed tonight.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 8 (AP). -- Falls City Hi-Bru of Indianapolis smashed into first place in the team standings of the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight with a 3,089 total.

Tom Kelly scored a no-hit, no-run victory in hurling Jamaica High to a 1-to-0 triumph over Richmond Hill at Dexter Park yesterday in the opening game of the season for both teams. The contest figured in the Queens Division P.S.A.L. competition.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, in a letter received yesterday by Senator Copeland urged the Senate Commerce Committee to investigate labor conditions in the merchant marine with a view to eliminating the causes of unrest and sabotage on American ships.

Captain Ernest A. Hoff, for nine years leader of the City College R.O.T.C. band, struck a note of discord yesterday when he brought suit in the Supreme Court to regain his job and recover back pay on the ground that he was forced out a year ago last September as the innocent victim of a "pacifist-military" conflict at the college.

The Roosevelt administration was charged yesterday by Bernarr Macfadden with creating a "new depression" after adhering to Jeffersonian principles during the first five months of the New Deal. The publisher spoke at a luncheon of the New York Board of Trade in the Hotel Astor.
WASHINGTON, April 8. -- An nouncement that the Senate Air Safety Committee has started an investigation of the airliner crash near Uniontown was made here today by the chairman, Senator Copeland.

BERLIN, April 8. -- It was announced today that Germany and Poland had reached an agreement on the principle whereby their dispute regarding German transit traffic through the Polish Province of Pomorze, known as the Polish Corridor, would be settled.
WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The Senate heard further witnesses in the impeachment of Judge Halsted L. Ritter of Florida and recessed at 6 P.M. until 11:30 A.M. tomorrow.

BERLIN, April 8. -- German official quarters made only perfunctory comment on the French counter proposals to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's peace plan today, explaining that a reply must await a closer study.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

LONDON, April 8. -- The British Government went into its diplomatic archives of the past twenty-one months today to show that Germany had evaded or rejected incessant attempts to limit the air armaments of Europe and also had broken repeated pledges by sending troops into the Rhineland.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Brushing aside Republican resistance, the House majority today passed and sent to the Senate the Kerr bill authorizing States to enter into compacts to regulate the production of tobacco. The roll call vote, which was forced by the Republicans in a last attempt to defeat the measure, was 189 to 117.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 8 (AP). -- For the second time this year residents in low-lying sections of Chattanooga were moving to higher ground tonight as the swelling Tennessee River poured a fresh flood into the city. Twenty-seven families were moved out today.

Detective Thomas P. Mason of the narcotic squad, who had posed as a soldier since February to find out who was supplying drugged cigarettes to the soldiers at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, charged yesterday in Bay Ridge Court that James Brakfield, 24 years old, of 377 Eighty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was a purveyor of the narcotics.

A few months ago a friend asked me to wish her good luck in a business transaction which she had undertaken. I agreed to send her my good wishes every day at noon until the deal was put over. I kept my promise and prayed for my friend. While I was doing this I thought I might just as well wish a few more friends good luck.

LONDON, Thursday, April 9. -The tone of British editorial comment on the French proposals seems uniformly critical, the proposal for an international police force being roundly condemned. The Times says editorially:

Edgar Appleby defeated Bruno Klerings, 300 to 93, in nineteen innings last night in the Poggenburg Memorial Cup 18.2 balkline tourney at the Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy. Appleby had an unfinished run of 97. Klerings made 17 in his best turn.

The State of West Virginia yesterday awarded a new issue of $1,200,000 of road bonds to a banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. at a price of 100.03 for $432,000 as 3 1/4s and $768,000 as 2 1/4s. The bonds are dated Sept. 1, 1935, and mature on Sept. 1, 1936 to 1960.

Mr. ARTHUR KROCK'S article of yesterday, reviving the suggestion of LEWIS W. DOUGLAS that administration of relief be turned over to the Red Cross, is a reminder that there are several alternatives to the present relief program which are worth more attention than they have received.

Harry E. Lawrence, 32-year-old electrical engineer employed by the National Broadcasting Company, was killed by an electric shock shortly after 4 P.M. yesterday while experimenting with a charged condenser in the broadcasting company's experimental television transmitting station on the eighty-fifth floor of the Empire State Building.

MERRICK, L.I., April 8. -- Phillip John Schaffner, 11-year-old son of Dr. and Mrs. P.M. Schaffner of Byron Place, this village, who left home March 30 to be a detective with a tin badge and a book of rules obtained from the sponsor of a commercial radio program, was found early this morning in McCarren Park in Brooklyn by police.
Trade Price-Fixing Absorbs All Near-Month Contracts at Around 11.30c a Pound.

Throughout the entire controversy over remilitarization of the Rhineland, HITLER'S first demand has been for full "equality" for Germany. It was, in fact, for the purpose of asserting such equality that he claims to have sent troops into the Rhine Valley. If this is in reality his goal, he now knows the terms on which France is willing to aid him in achieving it.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York, at its monthly meeting yesterday, expressed its objection to a proposal to amend the Shipping Act on the ground that shippers would be subjected to penalties for making certain agreements with ship lines while the lines would not be affected.
William Lockhart, apartment house superintendent with "a pride in his work" and a special aptitude for cleanliness, attracted the attention of civic groups yesterday and was rewarded for his efforts.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
ATLANTA, April 8 (AP). -- The task of erasing the scars left by the South's worst tornado season was accelerated today as clearing skies lessened the fear of destructive floods.

ST. PAUL, April 8 (AP). -- Sentiment for Governor Landon of Kansas as the Republican party's Presidential candidate predominated today at seven district conventions which named fourteen uninstructed delegates to the national convention at Cleveland.
Dispersion of a gambling syndicate that has been preying on young matrons and men in political clubhouses in Manhattan and the Bronx was disclosed yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

Four Easter cruise ships are leaving today for Bermuda, Nassau and the West Indies and four others for Southern and Eastern ports with 5,500 passengers. In addition, two ships are departing for Europe.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Pell gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. M. Taylor Pyne, Mrs. Augustine L. Humes, Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend and Mrs. Henry B.H. Ripley. Another luncheon there was given by Mrs. William S. Haskell for Mrs. John Insley, Mrs. Chester Billings and Mrs. Elliman Knapp.
HOUSTON, Texas, April 8 (AP). -- A cold rain kept the United States and Mexican Davis Cup practice on a conversational basis today.
The sixteenth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York will be held on June 15 at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, it was announced yesterday by Ralph T. Crane, president of the club.
A textile firm which has occupied store space on lower Broadway for many years yesterday bought a downtown site for improvement with a building for its exclusive use.

HICKORY, N.C., April 8. -- The Giants carried the Indians to a higher elevation today and on a ball field situated on the crest of the picturesque Blue Ridges smacked down Steve O'Neill's Tribe in a manner that left little to be desired.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee today virtually deserted the committee when it started to draft the new Tax Bill, declaring they would be permitted no voice in the process. They will absent themselves until the measure is ready for presentation to the House, probably next Tuesday or Wednesday.

Most commodity futures were firmer in more active trading on the local markets yesterday. Sugar, coffee and tins were easier. On the cash markets tins and silk declined, while gains appeared in wheat, corn, rye, oats, cotton, lard, butter, hides, wool tops and cocoa.

Dr. Harold R. Mixsell and William Rand, former rivals in squash tennis, stand opposed to each other in the final of the handicap doubles court tennis tournament for the Appleton Cup at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP). -- The Chief of Army Engineers, it was learned today, has submitted to Congress his disapproval of a plan to construct a ship canal across New Jersey from Raritan Bay to Bordentown on the Delaware River.

The public will get its first chance today to judge the achievement of sculptors for the Federal Art Project, WPA, in this city, when an exhibition of their work is opened at 10 A.M. at the Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street. A preview was given yesterday.

Sales last month of General Motors cars to consumers in the United States set a new record for a March at 181,782 units, compared with 126,691 in March, 1935, and with 96,134 last February, it was announced yesterday. The total exceeded that of any other month since May, 1928.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The District of Columbia Court of Appeals took under advisement today the appeal of the North American Company and the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., from a District Supreme Court order staying injunction suits which they had brought against the "death sentence" provisions of the Wheeler-Rayburn Act.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public fifty-two new registration statements for securities involving $164,153,329 in proposed issues. They are described as follows:

CHICAGO, April 8. -- Short covering induced by continued reports of dry weather and dust storms in the Southwest and marked strength in Liverpool and Winnipeg lifted prices of wheat 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel today on the Board of Trade, and the final quotations were near the top.
What a farce it is when nations say that war should be carried on under "civilized" rules! They repeat smugly: "Don't use poison gas. It's barbarous and not allowed."

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- By a vote of 129,958 to 21,413 the convention of the Workers Alliance of America today accepted the report of the national executive board which recommended uniting with the National Unemployment Councils, the National Unemployment League and independent organizations of the jobless and of WPA workers.

Tomorrow is the Salvation Army's "Founders' Day." Throughout the world all-day services will be held as they have been held every year on Good Friday since the day in 1912 when General BOOTH, the founder, made his last public appearance in London.
PARIS, April 8. -- Following is the reply of the French Government to the German memorandum of March 31 concerning the Rhineland controversy:
PARIS, April 8. -- Following is the text of the declaration of the French Government containing a peace plan communicated today to representatives of three Locarno powers:

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The two radio beacons operated at Pittsburgh by the Bureau of Air Commerce were "flight checked" immediately after the crash of the TWA air liner yesterday near Uniontown and found to be working satisfactorily, Secretary Roper declared today.
GENEVA, April 8. -- An agreement was reached today regarding the form of the memorial to Woodrow Wilson that is to be a conspicuous feature of the new League of Nations building.
TORONTO, April 8. -- Glum indeed is the outlook for the Toronto Maple Leafs, as they contemplate their third game with the Detroit Red Wings for the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship.

LONDON, April 8. -- Ivor Novello tonight made one of his rare appearances in a play not of his own authorship, when he took the part of Lord George Hell in a delightful adaptation by Clemence Dane of Max Beerbohm's fantasy, "The Happy Hypocrite," at His Majesty's Theatre tonight.
TOKYO, April 8. -- Count General Juichi Terauchi today declared that his mission as War Minister was to restore discipline, promote armament and renovate the national policies.

Al Roth, Bronx lightweight star, gained a unanimous decision over Bat Battalino of Hartford in ten rounds at the Star Casino last night. Many in the crowd of 2,500 disapproved of the verdict. Battalino weighed 139 and Roth 136 3/4.

As persons of small income as well as several of the city's largest corporations opened their purse strings, contributions to the fund being sought for disaster relief by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross yesterday reached the total of $558,369.78.

So that it would not interfere with Race Week, the Larchmont Yacht Club's ocean race out around Long Island and Fire Island lightship and back will start on July 15 instead of on the seventeenth. The historic Brooklyn Yacht Club Challenge Cup also will be a prize in the event.

G.N. Treystman of New York kept up his winning streak in the United States chess tourney preliminaries last night, scoring his seventh consecutive victory in Group C at the Empire City Club. Samuel Factor of Chicago experienced a slight setback when his game with Samuel Silberman of the Bronx in Group A at the Manhattan Club resulted in a draw after 49 moves.
MADRID, April 8. -- Refusal to accept the resignation of Premier Manuel Azana and his government was among the first important acts taken by provisional President Diego Martinez-Barrio today.
The Transcontinental and Western Air has appointed a board of inquiry with two regular air line pilots as members to investigate the wreck near Uniontown.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8. -- Valley Forge Military Academy will hold a funeral service Friday for one of its cadets and a memorial service for three others who were among those killed yesterday in the crash of an airliner near Uniontown.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Prefacing his remarks with the observation that "American ships are absolutely safe," Secretary Roper of the Department of Commerce disclosed for the first time officially today that he had laid before President Roosevelt and the Cabinet several reported cases of sabotage and insubordination aboard vessels of American registry and that an informal inquiry was being conducted by his department.

Representatives of American financial, business and industrial concerns welcomed the visiting commission of Polish business leaders which arrived here on Monday at a dinner last night aboard the Gdynia-America liner Pilsudski under the auspices of the American-Polish Chamber of Commerce.

MASSENA, N.Y., April 8. -- Fifteen fathers who believe Uncle Sam should help in the support of large families decided today to get the advice of a committee of local business men before further effort to put their proposal before the Federal Government.

John Warne Herbert, lawyer, manufacturer and New Jersey politician, who died Aug. 26, 1934, a resident of Helmetta, N.J., left an estate appraised yesterday at $4,687,034 gross and $3,679,337 net. The bulk of the estate was in securities worth $4,454,090 which included 10,000 shares American Snuff Company stock appraised at $637,500 and 9,708 shares International Business Machines Corporation valued at $1,329,996.

A protest against the "shocking reported Italian use of gas and bombs against defenseless Ethiopian villagers and the Red Cross" was cabled yesterday by twenty-one leaders of religious and welfare organizations, representing the American Committee on the Ethiopian Crisis, 8 West Fortieth Street, New York City, to Salvador de Madariago, chairman of the Committee of Thirteen of the League of Nations.

In the face of continued support by the British Equalization Fund, the franc again weakened yesterday. It fell to 6.59 3/8 cents and closed at 6.59 5/8 cents, off 5/8 point. Sterling fell 5/8 cent to $4.94 1/2, and all other important foreign exchanges lost ground.

Work on 5,000 vegetable gardens which soon will be turned over to as many families, chosen for their need rather than their farming ability, was begun yesterday in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. In Richmond plowing on another 1,000 gardens was postponed because of unfavorable weather.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 8. -Nothing that really could be called an upset occurred in the first round of match play in the women's North and South golf championship today.

William R. Hayward, suspended principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, was formally reinstated by the Board of Education last night in accordance with a ruling of Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education.

Wagner's "Parsifal" received its second performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House and as usual packed the auditorium to capacity. The consecrational festival play, which was presented as a benefit for the New York City Visiting Committee, again had a profoundly impressive interpretation, with Artur Bodanzky conducting.

ROME, April 8. -- Premier Mussolini told a Cabinet council this morning that Italy would continue her military operations in East Africa until Ethiopia was completely crushed. The first objective of the campaign, he said, is security for Italian colonies.

At a special meeting of the board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday the request of John H. McFadden Jr., president of the Exchange, that a committee be appointed "to initiate an exacting, thorough and impartial investigation of the activities of himself and his firm on the Cotton Exchange" was granted.
ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., April 8. -- One man was killed and two others were critically injured this afternoon when the two planes in which they were flying collided.

Fears of Connecticut fishermen that the opening of the trout season might be delayed because of the recent floods have been set at rest by the State Board of Fisheries and Game. The board announces that there will be no postponement and the season will open next Wednesday as scheduled.

Mrs. Lillian Mae Bartholomew, mother of Freddie Bartholomew, 10-year-old boy actor, who is earning $1,500 weekly in the movies at Hollywood, arrived yesterday in the third-class on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to claim her son, whom she has not seen for two years.

George H. (Pete) Bostwick, amateur steeplechase rider, who rode his own horse, Castle Irwell, in the Grand National at Aintree last month, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, accompanied by Mrs. Bostwick.

GENEVA, April 8. -- With the British and the French apparently further apart both on Germany and Italy at the end than at the start of the first day of its meeting here, the Committee of Thirteen of the League of Nations Council decided to gain another day's time as regards both the questions of an armistice and of gas warfare in Ethiopia.

Spring football practice at Manhattan College ended yesterday, Coach Chick Meehan discharging the squad until next Fall at the conclusion of a brief drill at Van Cortlandt Park. While the session lasted only two and a half weeks in all, this short period was deemed sufficient in view of the team's fine showing in scrimmages with Columbia.

New York University's baseball team captured its third straight game in as many starts yesterday, but it had to come from behind three times before it could turn the trick. A small crowd at Ohio Field saw the Violet subdue an aggressive St. John's University nine, 8 to 7, on a two-run rally in the last half on a ninth.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- From information obtained from several Federal bureaus, it was disclosed today that Thomas Campbell, Montana "wheat king," received more than $50,000 from the AAA for not planting a full crop on land rented from the Indians at "bargain prices."

MOSCOW, April 8. -- The Soviet Government, in a note by Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff today, rejected as ill-founded the protest of the Chinese Government against the protocol of mutual assistance signed by the Soviet and Mongolia on March 12 and declared it to be in the interests of both the Mongolian and the Chinese people.

Complete ownership of all rapid transit lines by the city and their operation under its direct control provide the only means of escape from hopeless and costly confusion in rapid-transit affairs, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at a luncheon held in Kismet Temple, Brooklyn, to celebrate the opening of the $55,000,000 four-track Schermerhorn-Fulton Street subway linking downtown Brooklyn to East New York.

Counsel for Charles (Lucky) Luciano threatened yesterday to carry his fight against extradition from Arkansas here to the United States Supreme Court if necessary, an Associated Press dispatch from Little Rock, Ark., reported last night. Meanwhile the reputed head of the vice ring here remained in jail in Little Rock.

PEORIA, Ill., April 8. -- Senator Borah of Idaho thundered against reciprocal trade treaties, against monopoly in business and against any entanglement in European affairs, in the opening address tonight of his Illinois campaign to win the State's Republican preferential primary vote for President next Tuesday.

An increase in wages from $71.50 a month to $85 for 6,000 clerical workers employed by the WPA was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, works progress administrator. On a weekly basis, figured on the time actually put in, the workers will receive $79 a month.

An amendment to the minimum basic agreement of the Dramatists Guild which eliminates the disputed sliding scale for the distribution of "film money" between playwright and manager, and substitutes instead a straight 60-40 split, with the playwright getting the larger share, was approved by the voting members at a general meeting of the guild yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Shelton.

Arthur Hartmann, free-lance writer and playwright who used the pen name Arthur Barton, was found dead early yesterday in his two-room apartment at 309 East Twenty-third Street, between First and Second Avenues. He was 32 years old.

ALBANY, April 8. -- A new drive to win legislative ratification for pari-mutuel machines at the New York tracks by a program providing for both mutuel and open betting has been launched by Democratic Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan, it was learned today.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 8. -Senator Borah of Idaho, apparently gathering some strength from the footloose voters of the new La Follette Progressive party, yesterday made almost a clean sweep of Wisconsin's twenty-four delegates to the Republican National Convention.

PARIS, April 8. -- In her plan for the organization of European security France declared today that there could be no prosperity without peace, but that once peace had been established "an economic organization of peoples" should be established.

As was expected, Wisconsin was kind to Mr. BORAH. He seems to have run remarkably well in the primary of Tuesday; and it would be ungracious to lay too much stress upon the hospitable character of that institution in that State. Whatever the La Follettian Progressives did for him he has earned by those aberrancies from the straight Republican path that have made the invariable regulars gasp.

The first two sessions of the sale of first editions, autograph letters and manuscripts collected by the late Harry B. Smith, librettist of more than 200 comic operas, brought $16,061.50. They were held yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, where the final sessions will be held this afternoon and evening.

The public using the air for transport has grown amazingly, and largely because of the assurances of the air lines that absolutely nothing in the care and conduct of their planes is left to chance. We have grown also to believe that passenger planes will not be flown in dangerous weather.

H.D.R. Burgess, banker of this city, and C.H. Wang of Shanghai have been appointed joint managers of the New York Agency of the Bank of China of Shanghai, it was announced yesterday by Thomas E. Huser, counsel for the bank here.

Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange moved within a narrow price range yesterday in featureless trading. Dealings were routine as traders focused attention on the task of absorbing the huge amount of new bonds placed on the market this week. Total transactions amounted to $10,092,900, compared with $10,222,100 on Tuesday.
Four foreign billiard stars arrived here yesterday aboard the French liner Paris to take part in the world's amateur three-cushion tournament that starts tonight at the New York Athletic Club.
BRUSSELS, April 8. -- The Belgian Parliament, which has been dissolved until the elections of May 24, adjourned this afternoon. It can be convoked again at any time between now and May 22.

The Republic Steel Corporation operated at 60.7 per cent of capacity in March and should run at a little more than 60 per cent this month, T.M. Girdler, chairman, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Jersey City. He said he saw no reason why operations should fall below 60 per cent in May and June.

Fifteen applications for listing of securities, the largest number to be acted upon at one time in several years, were approved yesterday by the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange yesterday.

PARIS, April 8. -- France's peace plan and the reply of the French Government to Germany's Justification of her occupation of the Rhineland were issued today for publication at the same time that they were handed to representatives of the interested governments.

IT was all right for Joe DiMaggio to beat the other Yankees to town. Joe was a little lame, so they let him start on ahead of the rest. But the early arrival of Frank Crosetti with a broken nose and Pat Malone with tonsillitis is ominous. When the casualties begin coming in two at a time the outlook for the club is none too healthy.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, April 8. -- Deeply tanned and with energies restored by his most restful vacation since he entered the White House, President Roosevelt today ended a sixteen-day fishing cruise, spent mostly in the Bahamas, when he landed at Fort Lauderdale and entrained for Washington.
ADDIS ABABA, April 8. -- An inspiring effect was produced here by the publication of an Ethiopian communique radioed this afternoon from Quoram, which town the Italians claim they have occupied.

HIGHPOINT, N.C., April 8. -- The Yankees did not do much hitting today when they faced Binghamton, Class A minor league link in Colonel Jacob Ruppert's farm system, yet they romped to a 10-to-6 victory before 1,000 fans, the largest turno the team has attracted on the current junket.

The Dollar liner President Garfield docked at her Jersey City pier yesterday minus four of her crew. Captain Gregory Cullen, master of the liner, said he refused to bring two of the "black gang," or engine-room crew, any further than Genoa on the ship's round-the-world passage, and he left another man behind for insubordination and radical activities.

VIENNA, April 8. -- A new series of ordinances was issued late tonight by a Cabinet Council concerning the affairs of the Austrian Phoenix Life Insurance Company, whose difficulties had already provoked in the last two weeks government decree laws that sought to make up a deficit in the company's reserve fund amounting to about $50,000,000 by the imposition of special fees on Austrian insurance companies and policyholders.

Damages sustained by the Western Union Telegraph Company from the recent floods in Pennsylvania and New England did not amount to more than $200,000, Roy B. White, president, said at yesterday's brief and sparsely attended annual meeting of the company. Newcomb Carlton, chairman, presided.

MILWAUKEE, April 8 (AP). -- Voters of Milwaukee, Sheboygan and a group of Lincoln County communities rejected referenda proposals for government ownership of utilities and those of Madison approved a municipal bus system, returns from yesterday's election showed tonight.
BOSTON, April 8 (AP). -- The Massachusetts Supreme Court described burlesque today as "a place to display good-looking girls in unappropriate dress -- sometimes in nudeness."

The spectacle presented by the Republicans at Albany in their sustained controversy with the Governor over the budget is one to make the gods that preside over the State Capitol shake with mirth. For years they have been denouncing successive Democratic Executives -SMITH, ROOSEVELT, LEHMAN -- for extravagance.

First to announce results of operations for the first quarter of this year, the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company reported yesterday a net profit of $1,996,967 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to 79 cents a share on 2,503,505 shares.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 8 (AP). -A middle-aged housewife, a youthful appearing carpenter and two Negroes are in jail here charged with a plot to wreck a Louisville Nashville Railroad passenger train in an effort to kill the woman's 70-year-old husband, the train's engineer.

Rosa Ponselle sat in the sunroom of her apartment at 90 Riverside Drive yesterday, holding her arm in a sling in painful memory of her final performance of the season as a soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company.

The buying of stocks continued yesterday to be selective, some groups, such as the steels and the rubbers, gaining substantially, while others weakened. The closing was irregular, a trifle lower, perhaps, on the average. The day's news bearing on the market was replete with cheerful industrial and trade reports, so that the waves of profit-taking were neither insistent nor prolonged.

CHICAGO, April 8. -- The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway has just placed an order for a streamlined light-weight stainless steel train which it will put on a schedule of 39 hours and 45 minutes between Chicago and Los Angeles late this year, S.T. Bledsoe, president, announced today.

The report issued recently by the Securities and Exchange Commission of changes in the holdings of officers and directors of their own companies' securities has shown a rather heavy amount of liquidation on balance. The inference obtainable from this information is that the "insiders" were selling while the uninformed public was buying.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Testimony that one Federal judge in Florida thought $15,000 a sufficient fee for the legal services for which Judge Halsted L. Ritter later awarded an additional $75,000 to A.L. Rankin, his former law partner, was introduced in the impeachment trial of Judge Ritter before the Senate today.

Although she failed to save her mistress's jewelry, worth $5,000, according to the police, Sarah McKay, a maid employed at Essex House, forty-story apartment hotel on Central Park South at Seventh Avenue, made a plucky attempt yesterday to keep two armed hold-up men out of the room where Mrs. Henry Rosenstein was ill in bed.

The Executive Department Reorganization Act (Economy Act) of 1932 was upheld as constitutional yesterday when a Federal statutory court refused an injunction to the Isbrandtsen-Moller Company, Inc., which had refused to report its cargo freight rates to the Commerce Department.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., April 8. -- Investigators for the Department of Commerce, the Senate Committee on Air Safety and the TWA company worked throughout the day at examination of the scattered wreckage of the big transport plane that crashed on Chestnut Ridge yesterday, but indicated by their silence that the cause of the tragedy which claimed eleven lives was an unsolved mystery.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 8. -- The Rev. Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman is busy preparing for the largest demonstration thus far of the Oxford Group movement at the Danish Gymnastic High School at Ollerup as the culmination of a year's work. About 30,000 persons are expected at Ollerup on Easter Sunday.

RENO, Nev., April 8. -- Frank Foster, who was tried and acquitted of the murder of Jake Lingle, Chicago Tribune reporter, in 1931, was seized here today by Department of Justice agents and Detective Christopher Carroll of the New York Police Department on a charge of participating in a $138,000 jewel robbery in New York City.

UNIONTOWN, April 8. -- A doctor rushed seventy mile in two hours from Steubenville, Ohio, expecting to treat his best friend, Stanley Bayersdorfer, for broken ankles. Instead he found him dead, victim of the air crash.

Myron Colbert, president of Prunier's Restaurant and Cafe, Inc., which has been sued by Maison Prunier, Parisian restaurant, to prevent the use of the name at 121 East Fifty-second Street, declared before Supreme Court Justice Walsh yesterday that the reputation of the Paris Prunier's, which is more than fifty years old, will be enhanced rather than damaged by the use of its name for the defendant's restaurant.
A French youth arrived here yesterday with an elaborate program laid out for him, including a visit to Washington, on which he is expected to meet the President.

Nature started a swirl in the Southern atmosphere two days ago. As cold and warm winds passed each other at high altitude they were twisted into a funnel. Spinning at perhaps 500 miles an hour on its vertical axis, the funnel dipped to the earth. A partial vacuum at the center wrought havoc.

LONDON, April 8. -- The British Government's policies in regard to both the Italo-Ethiopian war and the Rhineland crisis were severely attacked in a debate on foreign affairs in the House of Lords today by Lord Snell, a Labor member.

Ernest von Hefner of Germany and Big Chief Sanooke of North Carolina toppled out of the ring and were counted out by Referee Hughie Riley after 21 minutes 32 seconds of grappling in the feature finish wrestling exhibition at the Ridgewood Grove last night.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The administration is taking steps to assure a quick transfer from work relief to some system of direct relief if Congress should decide against continuation of the work program in whole or part, it was revealed today at closed hearings on President Roosevelt's request for $1,500,000,000 to continue the WPA program began before the House Appropriations Committee.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey assumed "full responsibility" yesterday for the use of a State-owned automobile in connection with the Paul H. Wendel "confession" and invited a thorough Federal investigation into the entire Lindbergh kidnapping case.

MUSSOLINI is certainly a hard man to bargain with. Whenever the parties of the second part are ready to strike hands with him he changes his mind, shifts his ground, and wants to start everything over again. One has but to recall the vacillating and changing statements which he has made about his purpose in warring upon Ethiopia.
BUENOS AIRES, April 8. -- The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for March 31 shows the following changes, in paper pesos:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 8. -Yale, making its baseball debut today, lost to a powerful batting and good fielding Springfield College nine, 8 to 2. The game attracted a fair sized crowd, which dwindled to a mere handful as brilliant sunshine gave way to almost freezing weather conditions as the battle progressed.

This evening, which set out to have three premieres, now has none at all. The Messrs. Linder and Wolfson yesterday postponed "Summer Wives" from tonight until next Monday at the Mansfield. That leaves "The Mikado," tomorrow evening at the Majestic, and "On Your Toes," Saturday night at the Imperial, as the week's only incoming shows.

WASHINGTON April 8. -- Following is the text of the opinion of Chief Justice Wheat in the District of Columbia Supreme Court denying an injunction to William Randolph Hearst against the Senate Lobby Committee:

Charles E. Clark, Dean of Yale University's Law School, sitting yesterday as trial examiner for the Labor Relations Board, declined to dismiss the complaint filed by the American Newspaper Guild against The Associated Press over the dismissal of Morris Watson, an editorial employe.

While they found some American advertisements couched in too "folksy" or slangy language and others objectionable because of emphasis on personal failings or ailments, spokesmen for the German group of business and advertising executives who have been visiting here considered the general standard of newspaper and magazine copy fairly high.

A profusion of major and minor phenomena went on view in Madison Square Garden yesterday as the circus opened for the benefit of several thousand children either too young to go to school or old enough to figure out a way not to have to.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Plans of the New York Central Railroad to refinance $62,900,000 of demand loans on a definite time basis as a part of a broader program to save $66,722,150 by 1946 through refunding and retirement of obligations were approved formally today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 8. -- Here alongside the Raritan River, which lives in the song of the college, Rutgers is carrying on the experiment started by several colleges in recent years that it is not necessary to find wealth before you find a crew.

A quick reorganization of the Western Pacific Railroad was predicted yesterday by Thomas M. Schumacher, president, following a meeting with Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The RFC is to provide $3,000,000 in the reorganization through the purchase of trustees' certificates from the company.

Sales of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation in the first three months of this year were 30 per cent larger than those in the corresponding period of last year, Clarence M. Woolley, chairman of the board, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting.

A missing link in art history has been found in excavations in ancient Antioch, according to Dr. Charles R. Morey, chairman of the Department of Art at Princeton and vice president of the College Art Association, who was a speaker yesterday at the twenty-fifth annual convention of the College Art Association at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP). -- Income tax receipts from the six districts of New York for the first three months of 1936 were $28,811,466 greater than in the corresponding period last year, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Plans of the New York Central Railroad to refinance $62,900,000 of demand loans on a definite time basis as a part of a broader program to save $66,722,150 by 1946 through refunding and retirement of obligations were approved formally today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
LONDON, April 8. -- The London Stock Exchange was cheerful today with only one trading day before the Easter holidays begin. British funds continued firm and the war loan was again in demand.

Jeff Dickson, European sports promoter who hails from Jackson, Miss., arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa and proceeded to the offices of Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, where he announced he was here to sign Joe Louis for a series of exhibitions in eleven European countries.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 8. -Complimenting her sister, Mrs. H. Ray Dennis, Mr. Dennis and their son, H. Ray Dennis Jr., of Morristown, N.J., who are her guests, Mrs. Francisco Terry entertained with a cocktail party for thirty-five today at her villa.

BERLIN, April 8. -- The collapse of the neopagans' attempt to develop their religion and the degeneration of Nordic paganism into a purely anti-Christian revolt are symbolized by the retirement today of Professor Jacob Wilhelm Hauer of Tuebingen University as head of the German Faith Movement.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Slow thinking in the Department of Agriculture is what really gave the jump to Senator Vandenberg and the Republican National Committee in the matter of the AAA payments. If the Senator's resolution for publicity had been differently handled, the advantage up to this point would not be so one-sided.

CHICAGO, April 8. -- Local packers and city butchers were good buyers of hogs here today and more than offset a lack of shipping demand. The market was quoted as steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher. The top was advanced 5 cents to $10.95, or within 5 cents of the recent high point, while the day's average was unchanged from yesterday at $10.60.
Buses replaced trolley cars yesterday on another of the important thoroughfares of Manhattan -Twenty-third Street -- as another step in the motorization of the city's surface transportation.
BERLIN, April 8. -- The Boerse was slightly firmer today, although activity, as usual, was strictly limited. Genuine trading continues to be carried on privately.

Although the Long Island Railroad's rent at Pennsylvania Station is based on the number of cars entering and leaving the terminal, the Long Island is charged for station improvements that are for the exclusive use of the Pennsylvania Railroad, it was brought out at yesterday's hearing on the application of the Long Island for an increase in commutation rates.
Investors were active in acquiring apartment and taxpayer properties in the Bronx yesterday.

" A-men," an original musical comedy, written and composed by undergraduates, will be presented tonight by the City College Dramatic Society in the auditorium of the School of Business and Civic Administration, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

BOWIE, Md., April 8. -- Jockey Georgie Watson, 18 years old, was seriously injured when he was unseated from his uncle's horse, Reigh Tetrarch, as he brought the 3-year-old charging into the home stretch in the fourth race today at Bowie.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8. -Admittedly unimpressed by the recent progress in construction of the Randall's Island stadium, William J. Bingham, chairman of the Olympic track and field committee, today nevertheless formally awarded the final tryouts on July 10 and 11 to that site in New York.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 8 (AP). -Joseph E. Widener's Brevity, 13-to-5 Winter-book favorite for the Kentuckly Derby, arrived from Florida today aboard a special car hooked to a fast passenger train.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Chief Justice Alfred A. Wheat of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia today denied the application of William Randolph Hearst for an injunction restraining the Senate Lobby Committee from making any use of telegrams, subpoenaed from the files of the Western Union Telegraph Company, exchanged between Mr. Hearst and his editorial employes.

ALBANY, April 8. -- Governor Lehman announced his approval today of five measures designed to promote the better enforcement of criminal law, including one providing for a statutory felony court in the magistrate's court in New York City.

Hard and timely hitting by City College, coupled with ineffective pitching and loose fielding by the losers, gave the Lavender baseball team a 17-3 victory over Savage Institute in a seven-inning game at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The contest was cut short because of the Beavers' big lead and the cold.

Mrs. Marjorie Post Davies, daughter of the late Charles W. Post, whose trade-marked cereal products earned him a fortune earlier in the century, was elected to the board of directors of General Foods Corporation yesterday, as the first woman so chosen in the history of the company.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- A majority of the special House committee investigating the American Retail Federation reported today that the federation was a "super lobby," although not engaged in "improper lobbying." The minority filed a report praising the federation and asserting that it might be of much benefit to consumers.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Van Lingle Mungo took to the mound today and was opposed by a rival of his semi-pro days in South Carolina, Buck Newsom, and Van was returned the victor. The Dodgers banged out sixteen hits to defeat the Senators, 10 to 2.
Steel ingot production this week is at 66 per Gent of capacity, the highest level since the second week of June, 1930, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by the magazine Iron Age.

A statement I made in a delegate assembly meeting of the United Parents Associations, apropos to the controversy over last year's peace demonstration in the high schools, was to the effect that school regulations seem quite flexible, inasmuch as Boy Scout and other organizations have no difficulty in getting their boys excused from school for functions having nothing to do with school activities.

The sharp division of opinion which has been manifest in recent design piracy developments will be strongly in evidence today at the hearings which begin in Washington on legislation to afford design protection. The National Retail Dry Goods Association will oppose the Vandenberg amendment to the Duffy bill.

Lieutenant Frank McCarthy of the police safe and loft squad returned to police headquarters yesterday with three prisoners and a photographic record of their re-enactment of a loft robbery. The picture angle was a new device, designed to prevent crime victims from backing down in the face of intimidation.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 9 (AP). -- Night and day patrols were set up on some levees in the Mississippi Valley today as the big river continued its steady rise.

Miss Louise Wood Eastman, a graduate nurse on the staff of the Willard Parker Hospital, was to have been married yesterday. On the eve of her wedding, however, she learned that her fiance was already married, so took her own life by poison.

A visible audience of more than 1,000 persons who filled Town Hall, and those who listened in on the NBC-WJZ network, last night heard Governor James M. Curley of Massachusetts, and Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council and former vice president of the United States Steel Corporation, debate the value of the tariff to American prosperity.

The city of St. Louis, Mo., failed to receive any bids yesterday for the proposed sale of $2,250,000 of bonds, the proceeds of which were to have been used for the construction of a Jefferson Memorial Park. The refusal of banking groups to submit bids resulted from litigation started by a group of taxpayers protesting the sale of these bonds.

The objections raised by the residents of Gramercy Park against the routing of the buses through this restricted section of the city is highly justified. Not only do they mar this beautiful residential area, but accidents are sure to result when these enormously large vehicles turn the corners through the narrow lanes of Gramercy Park.

" Bury the Dead," Irwin Shaw's one-act anti-war play, will open a regular Broadway run next Thursday night at the Fulton Theatre. Received with considerable acclaim at its two special performances on March 14 and 15 at the Forty-sixth Street, it is now to be presented by Alex Yokel.

Telephone operating companies controlled by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation report a net gain of 8,982 telephones on their lines for March. compared with gains of 6,447 in the corresponding month a year ago and 4,342 in February, 1936.

The French franc continued yesterday to weaken in foreign exchange under pressure of the flight of capital from France, while publication of the Bank of France's statement, showing further heavy losses of gold and increases in bills discounted and note circulation emphasized the growing pressure of the crisis in the franc.

Frederick T. Daniels, executive director of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, indicated yesterday that if the Lyons Residence Bill was passed by the Board of Aldermen and enforced, the State contribution of 40 per cent of the administrative costs of the Emergency Relief Bureau would be withheld.

ROME, April 9 (AP). -Italian dispatches from the Northern Ethiopian front today said only a lack of roads prevented the occupation of the city of Dessye. Roads are being constructed as speedily as possible, the dispatches added.
LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The American Association of Port Authorities urged the Department of Commerce yesterday to promulgate regulations restricting the operation of oil tankers with a view to protecting the lives and persons aboard them and property which is endangered by their proximity.

Operations of Libby, McNeill Libby, packers and canners, and subsidiaries for the year ended on Feb. 29 resulted in a profit of $1,920,832 after depreciation, interest, amortization, loss on disposal of fixed property, expenses in connection with recapitalization plan, Federal income taxes and other charges, it was reported yesterday.
Annual physical examinations for the city's 90,000 employes are being considered by the Municipal Civil Service Commission, James E. Finegan, president of the body, announced yesterday.

Edward Van Baerle drives a taxicab for a living; has done so for more than twenty-five years of his life. His cab supplied the wherewithal to support his wife and two children in their home at 409 West 129th Street, and it also has been a sort of rolling gallery in which he has shown water-colors and pencil drawings.

BOSTON, April 9. -- The directors of the Calumet and Hecla Consolidated Copper Company today declared a dividend of 25 cents a share, payable on June 1 to stock of record of May 1. This is the first dividend since 1930, in which year the company paid $1.50.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 9. -- Three candidates for the vacancy as alumni fellow of the Yale University Corporation caused by the refusal of Vance C. McCormick of Harrisburg, Pa., to accept renomination, were today announced by William S. Moorhead of this city, chairman of the Yale Alumni Board.
Behind Warren Maurer's pitching the John Adams High School baseball team opened its Quens division P.S.A.L. schedule with a 7-to-2 victory over Far Rockaway High on the letter's field yesterday.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The Community Trust again reports an advance. The cumulative disbursements in the decade 1925 to 1935 have risen beyond $1,500,000. And it is able to report that apart from real estate securities and one additional item of less than $75, every investment in every fund of the trust now applicable to charitable purposes paid its 1935 interest on time and in full.
PARIS, April 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

RALEIGH, N.C., April 9. -- Rutgers was defeated, 4 -- 2, today by the North Carolina State nine. The game was called in the seventh because of rain and cold. Ray Lens, Rutgers pitcher, limited State to two hits, a triple and a double, but his wildness kept him in trouble.

Stream conditions are likely to be no better for trout fishing this week-end than on the opening day of the season last Saturday. The continued cold weather and rains have lowered water temperatures, and in regions where the precipitation was heavy, streams are slightly discolored.

ALBANY, April 9. -- The Niagara Falls Power Company has asked authority of the Public Service Commission to issue $32,493,000 of general-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds to be called first-mortgage bonds upon the discharge of existing mortgage indentures. The proceeds of the bonds, which are to be sold at par, are to be used for the refunding of obligations.

Unless there was a collapse of the railroad industry, there was little likelihod of government ownership, Robert V. Fletcher of Washington, vice president and general counsel of the Association of American Railroads, said yesterday in an address at a luncheon of the New York University Men-in-Finance Club at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Admitting that he was baffled as to a decision in the case of a young member of the Naval Militia who was found guilty in February in connection with a $7,700 hold-up. General Sessions Judge Rosalsky postponed the case until April 17. At that time he will decide whether to grant the young man a new trial, quash his conviction or let the jury's verdict stand.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 9. -- Two humane errands, concerned with a fight against crippling disease and with suffering caused by the tornado which swept parts of this State early Monday, occupied President Roosevelt today while he halted his trip to Washington from Fort Lauderdale.

Two sisters, one 14 years old, the other 12, who live in a tenement on Third Avenue near Fifty-seventh Street, were arrested yesterday afternoon as they were about to enter a motion-picture theatre at Third Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street to see a double feature.

Residents and property owners of Gramercy Park adopted unanimously last night a resolution authorizing the Gramercy Park Association to move aggressively to persuade the Board of Estimate to put an end to motor bus operation on the streets surrounding the park.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today broadened its inquiry into alleged manipulative activities in the stock of Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange by Charles C. Wright of New York, a stock broker, to include the firm of Wright Sexton and others and postponed the hearing called from April 20 to May 11, to permit further time for preparation of the case.

Failure of Byrnes McDonald, director of the Police Juvenile Aid Bureau, to fill out a form listing his qualifications for the $5,500-a-year post he holds resulted yesterday in an announcement by the Municipal Civil Service Commission that it would refuse to certify his name on the city's April 15 payroll.

Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley and Public Service Commissioner George R. Van Namee yesterday warned lawyers for the various interests in the proceeding to increase the commutation fares on the Long Island Railroad against any further delay in the presentation of evidence.

BERLIN, April 9. -- The semi-official response of the German Foreign Office to the French peace plan, appearing today in the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, was almost conciliatory, compared with the vindictive comments in this morning's press.

A 100-acre tract in Jamaica, now occupied by the Hillcrest Golf Club, has been purchased by St. John's University in Brooklyn to serve as the new site for the university, it was announced yesterday by the Very Rev. Dr. Edward J. Walsh, president.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- A counter-attack on Republican criticism of large AAA benefit payments is being planned by Representative Jones, chairman of the Agriculture Committee. He is preparing a resolution directing the Tariff Commission to report to Congress the names of all corporations who have benefited from existing protective tariffs by $100,000 a year or more.

Following discovery of a $1,545.85 shortage in his accounts, John Collins, chief clerk of the First District Municipal Court in the Bronx, was arrested yesterday and booked on a charge of grand larceny.

Further weakness in grains, cattle and beef sent The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices to 124.2 on Tuesday from 124.4 the Tuesday previous. The index is now the lowest since July 23. The decline, under way since the beginning of the year, reflects largely the prospects of increased grain and livestock supplies, as the losses from the drought are gradually recovered.
An order again suspending William R. Hayward, principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, was issued yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. C. Douglas Dillon gave a dinner tonight at their residence.

A permanent Federal agency to meet the vocational and educational needs of youth was proposed yesterday by Arthur J. Jones, Professor of Secondary Education at the University of Pennsylvania, in an address opening the thirty-ninth annual convention of the Eastern Commercial Teachers Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

An Easter basket filled with chocolate bunnies and brightly colored eggs proved a stronger lure yesterday than the combined ministrations of psychology and psychiatry for Frankie, 4 years old, the shyest little fellow who ever came under the care of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

The proposed dissolution of seven firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange and the formation of six were announced yesterday by the Exchange. Transfer of the membership of P. Christopher Mohrman to Joseph J. Magrane for an undisclosed consideration and the admission of the latter to Biggs, Mohrman Co., effective yesterday, also were announced.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The joint bills by Senators Barbour, Republican, and Moore, Democrat, both of New Jersey, calling for preliminary flood control examinations of the Passaic and Delaware Rivers in New Jersey were reported favorably to the Senate today by the Commerce Committee.
The opinion of Chief Justice WHEAT in the District of Columbia Supreme Court, denying an injunction to WILLIAM RANDOLPH HEARST against the Senate Lobby Committee, was based on three grounds:
Good Friday will be more widely observed than ever in the city today with special services in the churches.

A banner Winter cruise season is approaching its climax this weekend with the largest number of Easter cruise passengers ever recorded on the books of local steamship companies, they said yesterday. In the last four days of this week at least seventeen liners are being used by Easter vacationists.

A PRETTY sociological fable, which should become extremely popular if given half a chance, is "The Roofs of Elm Street" (Putnam, $2.50), by William McNally. The first three words of the title appear to be a sort of bow to Sinclair Lewis. The natural title is "Elm Street."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 9. -- For the first time in a number of years the Yale navy is faced with a dearth of first-rate material and the varsity is less advanced at this stage than it has been for some time. Ed Leader, starting his fourteenth season as head coach, is tackling with typical concentration as hard a job as he has had for years.

NEW HAVEN, April 9. -- Roman Kwiecden, Acting Consul General of Poland, said today at the dedication at Yale University of a memorial bas-relief of Colonel House that Colonel House and President Wilson symbolized the noblest qualities of the American people, particularly their true democracy and humanitarianism, their deep sense of justice, their sympathy and readiness to help the persecuted and oppressed.

Despite adverse weather and severe flood damage in New England and the Ohio Valley district, chain store sales in March made the best relative showing since December, according to the monthly survey issued yesterday by Hammons Co., Inc., and Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.

Ten properties in Manhattan were put up for bidding at auction stands yesterday. All the parcels were struck down to the plaintiffs who brought about the foreclosure actions, nine of the properties going to banks.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Senator Borah is well aware of the importance of the stake for which he is now contending in Illinois. Upon the showing he makes there will depend in great degree his influence as a Warwick of the Cleveland candidate and platform. The test is being made by Mr. Borah under rather adverse conditions.
TOKYO, April 9. -- En route to London, Sir Alexander Cadogan, British Ambassador to China, visited Tokyo today and found the Japanese Foreign Office metaphorically in the hands of caretakers.

The case of Paul H. Wendel moved toward a solution last night as the police prepared to arrest an ex-convict identified by the former Trenton lawyer as one of the four men who held him a prisoner in Brooklyn and forced him to "confess" the Lindbergh kidnapping.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Formation of what amounts to a "brain trust" to end "brain trusts" was announced today by Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee. A group of nine college professors and instructors has been chosen, with a working staff of fifty, to analyze the New Deal, "expose its fallacies," and furnish material for Republican campaign orators.

The Joint legislative Committee on the World's Fair appointed by Governor Lehman made an inspection tour yesterday of the proposed site on which the fair is to be held in 1939 at Flushing Meadows Park in Queens. Mayor La Guardia and other city officials and incorporators of the World's Fair project acted as guides for the committee, which was headed by State Senator John J. Dunnigan of the Bronx as chairman.

Although showers occurred at several points in the Southwest, the relief proved inadequate and prices on the Cotton Exchange again reflected unfavorable weather conditions. Compared with light precipitation at widely scattered stations in the Western States, heavy rains added to the already excessive moisture east of the Mississippi River.

Showing an increase of 10.9 per cent over a year before, bank clearings for twenty-two leading cities in the country for the week ended on Wednesday, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., amounted to $5,768,053,000, compared with $5,202,948,000 for the same week of last year.
Alfred Lagache of France, the defending titleholder, met defeat last night as the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship opened at the New York Athletic Club.

Postmaster General FARLEY has sailed for a short vacation in Bermuda, leaving word that he has no intention, when he returns, of giving up either his Cabinet office or his position as chairman of the Democratic National Committee. The only people who object to his holding two jobs, he told the ship news reporters, are those who would rather he didn't hold any.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- House prosecutors in the impeachment trial of Federal Judge Halstead L. Ritter of Florida, under way now before the Senate, rested their case late today after having examined only thirteen out of the twenty-eight witnesses they had summoned.

TORONTO, April 9. -- Staging a dramatic rally that sent a crowd of 14,000 persons into a burst of almost hysterical acclaim, the Toronto Maple Leafs remained in the running for the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship by defeating the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

Disaster relief contributions sent yesterday to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross amounted to $10,037, bringing the chapter's fund to $568,406. The funds are being sought for relief of flood and tornado victims.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Representative Celler, who filed a dissenting report yesterday on the Anti-Price Discrimination Bill introduced by Representative Patman, declared today that Dr. Nathan Isaacs, Professor of Business Law in the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, agreed with him that "some of the most vicious features of NRA in disguise would be foisted upon American industry" by enactment of the Patman bill.

Major league owners, optimistic to the last, agreed yesterday that Tuesday, opening day, will be one of golden sunshine and estimated that 200,000 persons will be in the stands. In the event of inclement weather they will settle for 150,000, they admit.

Plans of two six-story apartment houses to cost $175,000 each were filed in the Bronx and Brooklyn yesterday, together with another Brooklyn project of similar height to cost $216,000. Details of the filings were as follows:

Lashing out at his Philadelphia critics, Roy E. Moore, chairman of the American Olympic women's gymnastic committee, declared yesterday no place on the team "can be bought" and insisted that the members of the Philadelphia turngemeinde's team would have to "take their chances" against other candidates May 9 in the national tryouts.

A youth who refused to say anything about himself, except that he was Jeffrey King, 19 years old, was committed to Elmira Reformatory yesterday in General Sessions, after Judge Rosalsky had denounced him as "the toughest defendant I've had before me since Gerald Chapman, the mail-truck hold-up man, many years ago."
About 400 persons attended the opening yesterday of the first exhibition, at 7 East Thirty-eighth Street, of sculpture done under the Federal Art Project, WPA, in this city.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation in March amounted to 783,552 tons, compared with 676,315 tons in February and with 668,056 in March, 1935, according to an announcement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- A plea for moderation and good temper during the period between now and election was made tonight over a nation-wide radio hook-up by Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

The description in Salome Germaine's letter of the noise made by the Department of Sanitation trucks is not exaggerated, and it is surely time that something was done to prevent those of us who are unfortunate enough to live on their main routes of travel from being wakened at intervals through the night and early morning by what seems like a series of earthquakes.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Officials here, scanning France's peace proposals, were encouraged to see that, like the German, they recognize Secretary of State Cordell Hull's views that no permanent peace can be established unless economic fetters hampering trade are loosened.
PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- The first Folklore Festival here will be given on May 2 in the Irvine Auditorium under the auspices of Bucknell University.

Warned that curtailment of work relief may create the enormous problem of caring for millions of unemployables for decades to come, 400 welfare leaders attending a meeting sponsored by five civic organizations appealed yesterday to President Roosevelt to reconsider the proposal to reduce WPA staffs.

ALBANY, April 9. -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Orange Republican, demanded tonight that the proposal for ratification of the Child Labor Amendment, and bills to permit women jurors and to allow unemployment insurance, be brought to the floor of the upper house for a vote.

Republicans are evidently preparing in this campaign to make great play with charges that the vast outlay of money by the Democratic Administration has been marked not only by waste and extravagance but by political abuses. Chairman FLETCHER long since asserted that the billions of relief money were in reality a huge campaign fund for the Democratic party.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 9. -- The riddle of extending the span of human life will be attacked from a new angle, that of diet in the last half of adult life, in a six-year experiment begun today at Cornell University.

Although most of the games in the eighth round of the United States chess championship preliminaries, scheduled to be played last night at the rooms of the Manhattan, Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Clubs, were postponed until tonight, several important changes took place in the standing of the competitors and notably so in Groups A, C and D.

The Appellate Division ordered a new trial yesterday for Howard S. Velleman, who was convicted of grand larceny in the second degree before General Sessions Judge Cornelius F. Collins on the ground that he did not receive a fair trial. The Appellate Division decided, however, that the "evidence was sufficient to warrant a finding of guilt."
PARIS, April 9 (AP). -- Pershing Hall, landmark of the American Legion in Europe, will close its doors on April 30, its treasury empty, the board of directors announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The controversy between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation over what material filed shall be treated as confidential took a new angle today when the corporation filed, as of Nov. 20, 1935, an application for exemption as a holding company from the holding-company provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

Large disbursements by the Treasury of funds previously acquired lifted member-bank reserves sharply in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve statement published yesterday showed. The Treasury spent $112,000,000 net in the week and member-bank reserves rose $84,000,000; but the excess of member-bank reserves over legal requirements rose $110,000,000 to $2,420,000,000, indicating that reserve requirements of the banks must have been reduced in the week through a decline in their deposits.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Vigorous opposition to the amendment proposed by Senator Vandenberg was presented by manufacturers of textiles and large retail interests today before the House Patents Committee at a hearing on the design-protection provision of the Duffy bill to revise the Copyright Law.
LONDON, April 9. -- King Edward VIII, who would like to be known as the poor man's King, distributed alms at Westminster Abbey today in his first public ceremony since his father's funeral.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, defended his administration against charges of politics in relief before a House appropriations subcommittee today.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- More than seventy-five delegates to the congress of the Workers Alliance of America were ejected from the corridors of the House of Representatives today when police construed their demeanor to indicate that they were about to rush the House restaurant.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Democrats of the Ways and Means Committee formally affirmed their determination today to stand by President Roosevelt's plan for an undistributed corporate profits levy when they voted down a proposal to continue the present corporation income tax with a rate of 22 1/2 per cent.

The pamphlet report of the International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $1,131,259 after all deductions, equal, after dividend requirements on the $3.50 series preferred stock, to 76 cents a share on 845,159 shares of Class A stock.

PITTSBURGH, April 9. -- Spectacular rebound from flood levels is revealed in the rise of business activity in the Pittsburgh district in the week ended April 4, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., April 9 (AP). -Investigators studying the crash of the TWA's giant plane, Sun Racer, expressed the opinion tonight that Pilot Otto Ferguson realized he was lost a few minutes before the ship plunged into a desolate mountain side, killing eleven persons.
CHICAGO, April 9. -- The Western Golf Association dragged one of the ancient game's oldest arguments into the open again today by abolishing the stymie.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange continued in the doldrums, traders being unable to shake off the lethargy that spread through the market early in the week. Interest had been switched to the distribution of the record volume of new bonds placed on the market this week.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- "This is a research staff," Chairman Fletcher said at a press conference on the new Republican "brain trust," "not a group of politically ambitious college professors with preconceived ideas, who look forward to getting on the Federal payroll in the hope they can reform the universe."

PARIS, April 9. -- Breaking a long silence on the subject of the French debt to the United States, former Premier Edouard Herriot, in an election speech at Lyons today, told his fellow-countrymen without mincing words that their refusal to pay in 1932 was the reason why America was now "on another planet" so far as help for France was concerned.
BERLIN, April 9. -- Despite the growing financial stringency, National Socialist Germany has been able to resume the battle against unemployment this Spring with considerable success.

RUMSON, N.J., April 9. -- The two-way-amplifier system in the new Rumson High School, by which the Superintendent of Schools could listen in at his office to every sound in any of the dozen classrooms in the building, was discontinued today by order of the Town Board of Education after teachers and pupils had protested.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- An order by Governor Earle to the State Liquor Control Board not to buy any more whiskies, brandies or rums from the Joseph S. Finch Company of Pittsburgh until the company has paid a balance of $5,292,322 plus interest alleged to be due as liquor floor taxes had a repercussion today in the Federal District Court here.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Between 300 and 500 "interruptions to the operation of American merchant vessels" have been reported to the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection by steamship companies since Jan. 1, 1935, Director Joseph B. Weaver announced today in a formal statement suggested to him by Assistant Secretary of Commerce Johnson.

An amendment to one of the rules of racing which will deny to jockeys and trainers under suspension the privilege of attending the races was adopted yesterday by the Jockey Club at its regular monthly meeting.

Columbia University received $38,085 in gifts last month, it was announced yesterday. This included $10,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for research in poliomyelitis, speech disorders and other neurological problems.

The district qualifying round for the national epee championships, held at the New York Athletic Club last night, was featured by the unexpected elimination of Lieutenant Fred R. Weber as eight fencers from a field of nineteen earned the right to enter the title competition on April 26-29.

GENEVA, April 9. -- Italy plans to follow Japan's example in Manchukuo by setting up a puppet regime in Ethiopia, Baron Pompeo Aloisi of Italy intimated late tonight in a talk with Pierre-Etienne Flandin, French Foreign Minister.

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas for the week ended April 4 showed an increase of 19 per cent, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure is believed to represent the pre-Easter peak.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 9. -- There will be a new North and South women's golf champion crowned in the current tournament, as none of the four survivors after today's second-round matches ever has held the title. The defending champion, Miss Estelle Lawson of Chapel Hill, N.C., was eliminated by Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S.C.
