Real estate activity in Manhattan yesterday consisted largely of contracts of sale on housing properties in scattered sections of the borough.
BERLIN, April 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The sharp guns of undergraduate satire were turned against politics, crime, university life and the professionalism of football last night in "A-Men," the annual varsity show presented by the City College Dramatic Society in the auditorium of the School of Business and Civic Administration, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt inspected yesterday three centers in Manhattan where the work of the National Youth Administration is being carried on, and expressed her satisfaction with the project, whose sponsors are seeking additional appropriations to carry on the work after June 30.

NEWARK, N.J., April 9. -- A statement of disapproval issued here today by D. Frederick Burnett, State Commissioner of Alcohol Beverage Control, called attention to a bill now pending in the State Legislature that would virtually prohibit New Jersey consumers from buying liquor, wine or beer from any but New Jersey retail dealers.

CHICAGO, April 9. -- Scattered showers were reported today over part of the dry area in Kansas, and while they were regarded as too light to be of material benefit to the wheat crop, they induced many scattered longs on the Board of Trade to get out of their holdings, and at no time were prices as high as yesterday's final quotations.

LONDON, April 9. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were irregular today, with business restricted because of the approach of the Easter holidays. British Government stocks weakened after their recent sharp rises. Excepting renewed buying of United States Steel, trading in international issues was uneventful.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- An Easter program conducted by Leopold Stokowski this afternoon climaxed the Philadelphia Orchestra's thirty-sixth season. It will be repeated on Saturday night. The orchestra will leave on Monday afternoon on a special train for its thirty-five-day transcontinental tour, which will end in Madison Square Garden, New York, on May 18.

The Hansa of the Hamburg-American Line will arrive today from Hamburg, Bremen and Channel ports, bringing among her passengers Baron Adolf von Fuerstenberg, Dr. Artur Oster, attached to the German Foreign Office in Berlin; Hans Brockstedt, Mrs. Maria Hopf, Mrs. Gertrud Thyssen, Mrs. Justin A. Zender, Joseph R. Dolan, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Miller.

The Easter week-end pause in the principal security and commodity markets of the world will be inaugurated today, in some cases to be extended into a three or four-day holiday. In observance of Good Friday all leading domestic and foreign exchanges will be closed today, although banks will be open as usual.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- Attorney General Cummings said today that charges of price fixing in the oil industry would be put before a special grand jury for investigation.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- Testimony that War Department officials had intimations in 1931 of a conspiracy to obtain army surplus goods ostensibly for charitable purposes and divert them to the private market was given today to the House Military Committee by Lieut. Col. William R. Gruber.

BERLIN, Friday, April 10. -- The Zeppelin Transportation Company's radio station here reported, early today that the von Hindenburg was over the Mediterranean off the Spanish coast at 2 A.M. [8 P.M. Thursday, Eastern standard time].

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and a leading spirit in the newly formed Labor's Non-Partisan League for the re-election of President Roosevelt, opened the league's campaign in New York last night with an address in Webster Hall before a meeting of the cutters' organization of his union.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 9. -- Eldon Trimingham sailed his new Norwegian-built yacht Saga today to a second straight victory in the series between the United States and Bermuda "sixes" for the Prince of Wales Cup. Saga, of the Bermuda team, led from start to finish over the ten-mile course.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 8, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,480,000,000, a decrease of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $19,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Negotiations between the railway managements and the labor unions were broken off yesterday after the managements declared they could make no further concessions for the protection of employes displaced by consolidations. The labor group then announced it would press for legislation to bring about their demands.

SHANGHAI, April 9. -- Further steps toward consolidation of his military position in Shansi Province vis-a-vis Japanese encroachment in Hopei and Chahar is seen in the departure of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek today from Nanking for Hankow.

DECATUR, Ill., April 9. -- If the Republican party attacks the problem of monopoly and convinces the people that it will keep the economic path open and free to individual initiative, that party will win in November, Senator Borah asserted tonight in the second address of his campaign for the Republican Presidential preference vote of Illinois at next Tuesday's election.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York yesterday gave concrete evidence of its desire to have American music performed by its orchestra next season. It announced a competition for new works by native composers, a first prize of $1,000 for a major work and a second prize of $500 for a shorter work.

Recent events in Europe reveal that the forces making for organized peace have not kept pace with the forces making for war and should focus American attention on the problem of neutrality, according to Allen W. Dulles.

The final session of the sale of first editions, autograph letters and manuscripts collected by the late Harry B. Smith, librettist, at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries last night, brought $8,707.50. The total for the four sessions was $29,231.

Mrs. Crawford Hill Jr., chairman of the executive committee, gave a tea yesterday at her home, 530 East Eighty-sixth Street, for members of the executive, gift and men's committees for the third annual gift horse party to be given Wednesday afternoon at the Exchange Restaurant, 541 Madison Avenue, for the benefit of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work.

Most futures were easier in generally quiet trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, reflecting the arrival of a three-day holiday for most of the Exchanges. On the cash markets, lard, butter, wool tops, Santos coffee, cocoa and rubber advanced, while wheat, rye, cotton and tins declined.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 8. -- With five British men-of-war of the American-West Indies squadron and Canadian fleet and President Roosevelt's Potomac, under escort of two United States warships, being seen at Mayaguana within a week, the inhabitants of the island must have thought that the recent rumors of wars had crystallized into international conflict.

The esthetic element in American life promises to become dominant at no distant date, John Shapley, chairman of the art department of the University of Chicago and president of the College Art Association, told the members of the organization yesterday morning at its twenty-fifth anniversary meeting, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
ALBANY, April 9. -- Governor Lehman announced today that he had signed two bills urged by Special Prosecutors Hiram C. Todd and Thomas E. Dewey to aid in the drive against racketeers and gangsters.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- Testifying today before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, which is considering the Wheeler anti-basing-point bill, Harold M. Scott, president of the Keystone Portland Cement Company of Philadelphia, said that enactment of the measure would greatly restrict markets for the entire cement industry.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 9. -- Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien entertained at luncheon today at the Greenbrier for Mrs. Vanderbilt Smith and Miss Elinor Bronaugh. Dinner hosts there were Mrs. Edwin Norman Hickman, Mr. and Mrs. George Mercer and Mrs. Henry C. Luce, whose party included Miss Ann Brokaw, Dr. and Mrs. J. Bentley Squier, Mr. and Mrs. Donaldson Brown and Alexander J. Pagel.

Several hours ahead of their original schedule, the Brooklyn Dodgers arrived home from their Spring training activities in the South early last night. Their slated game with the Senators having been rained out at Washington yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 9. -The further extension of Princeton University's policy of giving curricular privileges to outstanding undergraduates was announced here today by the board of trustees at the Spring meeting. The appointment of eight men to the faculty also was announced and four degrees awarded.

LONDON, April 9. -- Great Britain "downed tools" tonight for the annual four-day Easter vacation. Parliament has adjourned, government officials have scattered to their country retreats, and few business offices will open again before Tuesday morning.

RICHMOND, Va., April 9. -- The most discouraging Spring exhibition tour of a Yankee ball club in years ended in the despondency of a rainstorm today. It forced cancellation of a skirmish with the Richmond Colts of the Piedmont League.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- A moderate decline in the wholesale price index was recorded in the week ended on April 4, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The decrease put the bureau's figure, based on the 1926 average as 100, at 79.2, the same as a year ago.

Trading in the share market yesterday assumed most of the characteristics of a pro-holiday session. Prices moved narrowly most of the day in quiet dealings, save for a small pick-up in activity in the final hour. The closing was steady, with industrials off irregularly and railway issues slightly higher.

BOWIE, Md., April 9. -- A contender for the Harford Handicap, Monday's opening-day feature at Havre de Grace, loomed out of the mud and rain at Bowie today when Night Play won the featured Single Foot Purse despite wretched weather conditions.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 9. -- Strongly favored tennis stars of the United States will begin a campaign to regain the Davis Cup from Europe tomorrow as they enter first-round matches with Mexico. Experts give the youths from the neighboring republic little chance to win even one of the five matches.

OTTAWA, April 9 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada increased $1,704,554 and those of chartered banks declined $1,911,328 in the week ended yesterday. The statement follows:

Racketeering in the furniture industry has become an increasingly serious problem. This was the finding of the March grand jury, which had before it evidence submitted by District Attorney DODGE and his assistant, JAMES J. WILSON. One of the favorite devices is the "stuffed flat," where a fictitious tenant offers to dispose of household goods at prices which are by no means a "bargain.

Dr. F. Homer Curtiss of Washington, founder and head of the Order of Christian Mystics, has been sued in the Supreme Court by Herbert R. Stevens, broker, for $200,000 damages for alienating the affections of Mrs. Eleanor Chapman Stevens whom the defendant employed in the work of the religious cult, it was learned yesterday.

What may be the world's champion hitch-hiker walked into the office of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. He is a singing pedestrian and since 1926 has traveled more than 150,000 miles around the world and visited thirty-four countries, financed entirely by his singing as a modern street corner troubadour.

THEY have played for the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship at Rheims, Amsterdam, Barcelona, Algiers and points east and west and now they are having a go at it right here in New York City under the hospitable roof of the New York Athletic Club on Central Park South.

The committee on bonds of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that, effective on next Monday, all commission orders for the purchase or sale of 195 of the 199 issues in the foreign and domestic "free crowds" must be sent to the floor of the Exchange for execution except under certain specified conditions. The "free crowd" issues are the more active bonds on the Exchange as distinguished from the inactive or "book bonds."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 9. -- Ed Ingalls, sophomore right-hander, set down 14 on strike-outs as Harvard opened its home season on wind-swept Soldiers Field today with a 12-to-0 triumph over neighboring Northeastern University.
CHICACO, April 9. -- Reports that the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company would undertake its first refinancing operation since 1932 were confirmed tonight by George A. Ranney, chairman.

The following film programs, which have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools, will be shown over the week-end:

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Stephen Raushenbush, former chief investigator for the Senate Munitions Committee, charged today that three weeks ago, acting as chairman of the Pennsylvania Security League, he informed Mr. Hopkins that Edward N. Jones, Pennsylvania WPA Administrator, had placed in WPA pay envelopes statements accusing Mr. Raushenbush of promoting a third political party, terming him a "would-be political boss" and characterizing him as a "political gigolo."

Samuel D. Schwitzer wrote you with regard to the program of the Federal Housing Administration, stating that the interest charge generally carried by loans up to $50,000 made under the modernization credit plan varies between 10 and 12 per cent. Mr. Schwitzer has evidently been misinformed.

Tony Canzoneri, lightweight champion of the world, gained a decisive victory over Johnny Jadick of Kensington, Pa., in their ten-round fight at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 4,500 saw the little titleholder give Jadick a terrific lacing throughout the ten rounds and twice come close to scoring a knockout.

The rate at which apparel-class wool was consumed in February was the highest for any corresponding period since 1923, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers. Foreign wool consumed in February, the report states, accounted for 23 per cent of the total for the period, as compared with 18 per cent in January and an average of 8 per cent for the year 1935.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- Over objections of the New York State Public Service Commission, the Federal Power Commission proceeded today with a hearing on applications for the consolidation of four public utility companies serving Southern and Central New York.

Max Silverman, labor adjuster for the Flour Truckmen's Association, is being sought for questioning in the investigation into the bribery phase of the Drukman murder case in Brooklyn, it was said yesterday by J. Edward Lumbard Jr., chief assistant to Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor of the case.

Max Wockenfuss, trombone soloist of the Metropolitan Opera Company orchestra and a former member of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, died from a heart attack last night while driving with his wife from the home of a friend in Queens. He was 55 years old.

MOSCOW, April 9. -- The full legal right of the Soviet Government to send troops to Outer Mongolia on the request of either the local Mongolian or the Nanking authorities was asserted today by the newspaper Pravda in an editorial amplifying the reply of Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff yesterday to the Nanking government's protest against the Soviet-Mongolian treaty.

ALBANY, April 9. -- Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported that the number of industrial building plans submitted to the State Department of Labor during March increased 100 per cent over February, reaching a new high record for the month during the twelve years such plans have been required. The normal increase for March over February is 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Assertions that the collapse of child labor standards since the Supreme Court invalidated the codes of fair competition makes it necessary to take some form of action to maintain former code regulations on child labor are contained in a report of the NRA division of review, made available today.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP). -- A subsurface House rebellion against voting $10,000 for fighting the Senate lobby committee's legal battles menaces the adoption of a resolution to provide such a fund.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Electrical energy for rural sections of this country on a permanent basis was assured today when the House, without a record vote, passed and sent to the Senate the Norris-Rayburn bill implementing a ten-year program for the Rural Electrification Administration, created temporarily by President Roosevelt on May 11, 1935.
PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- Delegates to the Democratic National Convention here in June will not only decide upon a Presidential nominee but may also watch the selection of a beauty queen.

CHICAGO, April 9. -- Hogs weighing under 250 pounds were in good demand here today and some sales showed an advance of 5 cents a hundredweight ever yesterday's levels, while heavier kinds generally were steady to 10 cents lower. The top was lifted 5 cents to $11, equaling the best price of the season, while the day's average was 5 cents lower at $10.55.

The Nash Motors Company reported yesterday a net profit of $72,372 for the quarter ended on Feb. 29 after all taxes, administrative and other expenses. This compared with a net loss of $405,905 in the corresponding quarter last year. The net profit for the quarter was the first reported by the company for any corresponding period since 1932.

The regular New York County grand jury for March has investigated the so-called furniture racket, and has made a report and certain recommendations for new legislation to curb this nefarious business.

Brooklyn celebrated joyfully this week the opening of the new Fulton Street subway running eastward almost to the boundary of Queens. This line should serve to rehabilitate a large area of homes and business which in recent years has suffered from the lack of modern rapid transit facilities.

A private showing of films of original musical manuscripts was exhibited yesterday afternoon at the New York Public Library. The invitation to the exhibition was by Countess Mercati, who is sponsoring a collection of such films for the library.
BERLIN, April 9. -- The Boerse maintained today its course of establishing new records for inactivity. All genuine trading is carried on privately.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., April 9. -- President Roosevelt stopped in this storm-stricken city tonight, expressed his sympathy with its citizens and praised the spirit with which they had met the problem of last Monday's tornado and its devastation.

LONDON, April 9. -- In debate on miscellaneous matters, which is allowable on a motion to adjourn the House of Commons for the Easter recess, there was an indication this afternoon that the members no longer considered war impossible.

Damage to stocks and loss of production on installed equipment due to the floods in March will amount to more than 6,000,000 pounds of rayon yarn, it was estimated yesterday by the Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.
Included in leases of business space reported by brokers and renting agents yesterday were several rentals of quarters in the lower Manhattan section of the city.

RICHMOND, Va., April 9 (AP). -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today denied a motion of Greenwood County, South Carolina, and the Public Works Administration to vacate a stay of mandate granted the Duke Power Company in connection with the court's denial of the company's petition for an injunction to prevent construction of a proposed power plant at Buzzard Roost.

BLUEFIELD, W.Va., April 9. -- The touring Giants and Indians halted here today en route from Pulaski, Va., where their scheduled game had been rained out, to Weirton, W.Va., final port of call before they move into Cleveland to close the series Saturday and Sunday.

Stanley Norton's sharp single over second base with the bases filled in the seventh and final inning gave the unbeaten Brooklyn College nine a 5-4 victory over St. Peter's College of Jersey City at the Manhattan Beach diamond yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- In directing new criticism at Secretary Wallace today in his fight for publication of big AAA payments, Senator Vandenberg asserted in the Senate that the Agriculture Secretary had corrected himself in making public what information he had on the big benefits.

BALTIMORE, April 9. -- Dr. Robert W. Wood, Professor of Experimental Physics at Johns Hopkins University, tonight aided Baltimore detectives in their attempt to solve the mystery surrounding the explosion of a dynamite bomb on the lawn of the home of Mayor Howard W. Jackson in the Homeland Guilford section a few minutes after he had entered it at 1:30 A.M. today.

IROME, April 9. -- Usually well informed circles in Rome today openly accused the League of Nations conciliation Committee of Thirteen of pursuing the double purpose of throwing on Italy the blame for delay in getting peace negotiations started and of hampering further Italian operations in East Africa.
Bishop William T Manning yesterday issued the following Easter message to the Episcopal Diocese of New York, of which he is the head:

INDIANAPOLIS, April 9. -- Another 1935 American Bowling Congress champion fell by the wayside today when Ora Mayer, all-events titleholder last year, failed in his effort to retain the crown in this year's tourney.
The perennial fight of the Young Republicans for recognition within the party has now affected the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, it was disclosed yesterday.
GAINESVILLE, Ga., April 9 (AP). -- Cold rain poured down upon tornado-stricken Gainesville today, chilling refugees and relief workers and interfering with the burial of many of the 180 dead.

PARIS, Friday, April 10. -- Early this morning the German dirigible von Hindenburg, returning from her maiden trip across the South Atlantic, was fighting strong head winds over the Mediterranean with one of her engines crippled, but the fact that she was steadily progressing at the rate of some fifty miles an hour indicated that the trouble was not serious.

A net loss of $3,323,432 for 1935 was reported yesterday by the International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries, excluding the International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries, after all charges, reserves, taxes and full preferred dividend requirements of subsidiaries, compared with a net loss of $3,359,716 for 1934.

In a test case of the law making it a misdemeanor for a creditor to make a demand upon a debtor with a paper which simulates a legal process to frighten him into payment, Henry Schwartz, president of the Globe Jewelers, Inc., at 507 Fifth Avenue, and the corporation itself were found guilty in Special Sessions yesterday of violating Section 551 of the Penal Code.

Dr. Lois H. Meek, director of the Child Development Institute of Columbia University and member of the board of directors of the National Federation of Day Nurseries, urged yesterday that a national program of nursery education be developed to meet the problems of the pre-school child.
LONDON, April 9. -- Priceless Chinese art treasures recently on exhibition here, convoyed by British destroyers almost like a troopship in wartime, left tonight aboard the steamer Ranpura for China.

The New York shad fishing season, which began April 1, was rapidly approaching its peak last night with 200 fishermen pulling in larger and larger hauls from their nets in the Hudson River between North Bergen and Newburgh twice daily.

TORONTO, April 10. -- The Detroit Red Wings are confident they will be crowned the hockey champions of the world tomorrow night when they meet the Toronto Maple Leafs in the fourth game of the current Stanley Cup series.

CLEVELAND, April 10. -- Forced into idleness again today by rains which made the ball park at Weirton, W. Va., unfit for play, the Giants and the Cleveland Indians arrived here on their special train several hours ahead of the original schedule.

MOSCOW, April 10. -- Charges that the Japanese police had been maintaining a "virtual blockade" of the Soviet Embassy in Tokyo were made by the government organ Izvestia today in an editorial denouncing the raid by four extremists on the Tass News Agency offices in Tokyo on Wednesday.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 10. -- The third race of the yachting series between the United States and Bermuda "sixes" for the Prince of Wales Cup will be sailed tomorrow.

ALBANY, April 10. -- The question of the State's right to violate a local ordinance was put before Justice Francis Bergan in a special term of the Supreme Court today. He heard arguments on a motion for an injunction to prevent the town of Smithtown, L.I., from enforcing a local law against dumping of sewage into the Nissequogue River.

TAMPA, Fla., April 10 (AP). -- Disinclination of hot-house frogs to multiply to the extent the literature said they would is the basis of a Federal court equity suit here asking an accounting of the activities of Southern Industries, Inc., operator of a cooperative frog "dude ranch."

ROME, April 10 (AP). -- The unusual spectacle of decorous, black-garbed priests banging their prayer books violently on their kneeling benches in St. Peter's tonight climaxed Rome's Good Friday observance.

DANVILLE, Ill., April 10. -- Pushing his Illinois campaign in two addresses, Senator Borah today charged that "hundreds of thousands of dollars, half a million if not a million," were being spent in this State to defeat him in the primary vote next Tuesday.

In a brief filed yesterday with the House Committee on Patents, now holding hearings on proposed copyright revision legislation, the Fashion Originators Guild of America urged that wearing apparel designs be included "as an absolute economic necessity for the protection of the best interests of labor, capital and the consuming public."
GENEVA, April 10. -- Following is the text of the communique issued by the Locarno powers here tonight:
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP). -- Vigorous, alert and bearing more than his share of court work, Chief Justice Hughes will celebrate his seventy-fourth birthday tomorrow.

WINDSOR, Ont., April 10 (AP). -- The Detroit Olympics came from behind tonight to score a 4-3 victory over the Windsor Bulldogs for their second straight triumph in the International Hockey League final play-offs for the Teddy Oke trophy.

" If America wants to sell to Poland in increased quantities it must learn to buy increased quantities from us," said Josef Jakubowski, director of the Warsaw Chamber of Industry and Commerce, in an interview yesterday at the Hotel Commodore. He is heading a commission of Polish businessmen who are here to make a survey of our foreign trade.

THE word "sharecropper" is a queer one. Most dictionaries, even the latest, pass it completely by. The great Oxford Dictionary, in a supplementary volume, finds that not until 1929 was it used in respectable circles. Offhand, I can think of no parallel construction in English; we have "boatbuilder," not "buildboater"; "cardplayer," not "playcarder."

More than 10,000 persons swarmed about the Central Hanover Bank branch at Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street at 4 P.M. yesterday as policemen leaped from a dozen radio cars and reports spread that two men had been caught robbing the bank.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- A reciprocal tariff plank was proposed today by Robert Lincoln O'Brien, chairman of the Tariff Commission, for inclusion in the Republican platform. Leading Republican members of Congress indicated strong opposition to the proposal, however, several assorting that tariff reciprocity was Democratic doctrine and that the Republican party must oppose continuance of the trade agreements negotiated by the present administration.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- With the world's leading grain markets closed for the Good Friday holiday, few traders appeared on the local Exchange to comment on the government's estimate on the Winter wheat crop issued late today. The total of 493,000,000 bushels was far below expectations, and showed 44,000,000 under the average estimate of Chicago statisticians which was issued last week and was only 60,000,000 bushels in excess of last year's harvest.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The Interior Department's action in awarding an $835,159 cement contract for dam construction on the Colorado River to the Republic Portland Cement Company of San Antonio, although it submitted bids identical with those of three other companies, was criticized today by Senator Wheeler in a statement in which he asserted that "the cement industry has penalized the taxpayers of this country in excess profits an unbelievable sum."

GENEVA, April 10. -- The Committee of Thirteen of the League of Nations today instructed its president, Salvador de Madariaga of Spain, to ask Italy and Ethiopia to send delegates here Tuesday to discuss with him and Joseph A. Avenol, secretary general of the League, how to open armistice negotiations.

Although retail sales this week came close to a six-year peak for the period, Easter buying was under expectations, clue to cold and rainy weather in many districts, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Sales for the country as a whole were estimated at 12 to 18 per cent ahead of those for the comparative 1935 week.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Members of the Democratic subcommittee seeking to translate President Roosevelt's proposal of an undistributed corporate profits tax into law admitted today they had found a loophole which threatened to drain off, so far as the immediate future is concerned, much of the revenue which the President so urgently requested to balance the regular budget.

BOSTON, April 10. -- A walkout of deckhands, stewards and engine-room crews of the Eastern Steamship Company liners, Acadia and New York, was settled this afternoon by a compromise in which the strikers gained restoration of a $10 per month pay cut.

Industrial and trade occupations rather than office work will lure the majority of school and college graduates of the future, according to an opinion expressed yesterday at the annual convention of the Eastern Commercial Teachers Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BOSTON, April 10. -- Carlos Chavez, the young Mexican musician who will appear next season in New York as guest leader of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, conducted performances of two of his compositions with the Boston Symphony Orchestra this afternoon in Symphony Hall.

The 1936 Medal of Honor of the Institute of Radio Engineers has been awarded to Dr. George A. Campbell, inventor of the electrical wave filter, who recently retired from the Bell Telephone Laboratories, it was announced yesterday by the institute.

PARIS, April 10. -- Edouard Herriot in an election speech in Lyons tonight took a strong stand against devaluing the franc. The former Premier declared that only international speculators stood to gain thereby and that it would only mean a new devaluation of the pound and the dollar and the beginning of a currency race "toward zero."

LONDON, April 10. -- Aroused over the absence of word from his wife, Cecil Llewellyn Bartholomew said today he was "convinced my wife has been kidnapped in an attempt to prevent us from regaining Freddie."

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP). -- C.W. Kellogg of New York, chairman of the board of the Engineers Public Service Corporation, told a Senate committee today that possibilities of inflation and high taxation have acted as brakes on power rate reductions.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- President Roosevelt returned, held a Cabinet meeting and began work on the speech he is to deliver in Baltimore Monday night in connection with the Jefferson Day dinner dance sponsored by the Young Democrats.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Testifying before a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Labor and Education today, James J. Mullen, a former employe of the Clairton, Pa., plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company, asserted that George F. Ruck, assistant to the president of the H.C. Frick Coke Company and for eight years prior to 1922 an employe of the Department of Justice, participated in the organization of an espionage system in the Clairton plant.

Plutarco Elias Calles, for many years the "strong man" and virtual dictator of Mexico, obtained his first important official position as Secretary of Industry, Commerce and Labor in the Carranza government. Before that, however, he had espoused the revolutionary cause in the revolt against Porfirio Diaz, which resulted in the overthrow of that Dictator-President in 1913.

Traditionalists planning to participate in the annual Easter parade on Fifth Avenue tomorrow morning would do well to include an umbrella in their Spring accoutrement, for, according to the Weather Bureau, the week-end will be marked by cloudy weather.

Byrnes McDonald, director of the Police Juvenile Aid Bureau, who was informed Thursday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission that he would not be on the April 15 payroll, declared yesterday that he did not know "what will happen."

A study of the operating ratios of member banks of the Federal Reserve in the New York District, which has just been prepared by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, shows that on the average charge-offs exceeded net earnings from current operations last year, resulting in a net loss equal to 2.5 per cent of capital funds, or 0.3 per cent of the total available funds of the banks.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The Senate will be asked to consider ratification of the recently signed treaty with Panama in executive session behind closed doors, Chairman Pittman of the Foreign Relations Committee indicated today. The military and naval aspects of the treaty's provisions would be the reason for such procedure, which has no precedent in recent years.
TOKYO, April 10. -- Shigeru Yoshida today was appointed Ambassador to London, succeeding Tsuneo Matsudaira, who became Imperial Household Minister after the recent assassinations.

Her throat tightly circled with two double-knotted garments, Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, 34-year-old author, book reviewer and wife of Lewis H. Titterton, a National Broadcasting Company executive, was found murdered, late yesterday, in the bathtub of her home at 22 Beckman Place.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- The statement that overthrow of the New Deal is vital if the country's economic system is to be prevented from collapsing was made by Paul Robey, economist and lecturer on banking at Columbia University, at a luncheon of the Executives Club of Chicago today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 A. -- Predicting an increased sugar consumption, Secretary Wallace today announced high import quotas for offshore producers. The quota changes developed from revisions in the original 1936 estimates.

MEXICO, D.F., April 10. -- General Plutarco Elias Calles, former President of Mexico and one of the greatest personalities in Mexico since the time of Dictator Porfirio Diaz, was arrested and deported to the United States this morning by order of President Lazaro Cardenas.

ROME, April 10. -- Well-informed circles in Rome continue to say very positively that Italy is quite willing and ready to establish contacts with the League's Committee of Thirteen as a preliminary to peace negotiations and as proof of good faith.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 10. -- Mrs. H.W. Burkhart's Legal Gamble scored by a length dyer Mrs. A.M. Creech's Crout Au Pot in the fifth and feature race today at Arlington Downs. Flag Cadet of the B. Hernandez stable was third in the mile and one-sixteenth affair.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 10 (AP). -- Another light scoring session marked the doubles and singles events of the American Bowling Congress today. South Bend, Ind., bowlers accounted for the top scores in both divisions.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has amended its rules covering the filing of documents under the Holding Company Act of 1935 to require that all applications other than those for which special forms and instructions are prescribed and all formal statements of fact filed with the commission be verified.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 10. -- Uncle Sam's two young tennis stars, Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta and Donald Budge of California, bore down today to give the American Davis Cup team two singles victories over Mexico's courageous youths in opening matches of the North American interzone play.

In THE TIMES of April 4 Jamboree is included among the entries for the Rowe Memorial Handicap. That's wrong. Jamboree completed his racing career on the Latonia track in 1897, for I was there and I saw his finish. It was like this:
SAVANNAH, Ga., April 10 (AP). -- Marie Dressler's butler and maid, who inherited $50,000 under the actress's will, are opening a night club and tourist camp for Negroes near Savannah.

That the Republican National Committee should, according to the announcement of Chairman FLETCHER, have organized a committee of economists to "analyze the New Deal," to criticize, in the light of economic science, the principles or programs of action adopted by the present Administration, is in many respects entirely logical.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 10. -- Whizaway lived up to her name today when she flashed through her field to carry off first honors-and cash in the open junior all-age stake at the annual meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club, which opened this morning on the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club.
CAIRO, Ill., April 10 (AP). -- New thousands joined the exodus from the Mississippi lowlands tonight as the swollen river spilled the Ohio's flood waters over sections of a half dozen States.

Harold Morton of Boston, New England chess champion and also the present Rhode Island and Massachusetts State titleholder, continued his successful career in Group D of the United States chess championship preliminaries at the Queens Chess Club in Woodside last night.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 10. -- Bombs and fire spread terror today throughout the Wyoming Valley anthracite district.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Sixteen architects and draftsmen living in or near New York won eleven of the forty-six awards in a national home-design competition conducted by Pencil Points magazine and sponsored by the Portland Cement Association. The results of the contest were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Sales by department stores increased from February to March by considerably more than the usual seasonal gain, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The board's index, which makes allowance for seasonal changes, advanced from 80 per cent of the 1923-25 average to 88 per cent.

Charles (Lucky) Luciano, reputed head of a vice ring in this city, who is in jail at Little Rock, Ark., has until 2 P.M. Monday to make any application for an appeal from his extradition to New York, under an order yesterday by Federal Judge Kimbrough Stone, sitting in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Kansas City, Mo.

The relief fund of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross for the benefit of sufferers in the recent flood and tornado disasters reached a total of $571,326.34 yesterday, it was announced by General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the organization, at 315 Lexington Avenue.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- Hogs were in good demand with prices ranging from steady to 10 cents a hundred- weight higher than yesterday. The lighter kinds showed the most strength, although local packers were more interested in lard types. The top was unchanged at $11, while the day's average was also unchanged at $10.55.

With a customary flurry of bunnies and brightly painted eggs, the nocturnal nabobs will welcome, this coming week, the joyous Easter holidays and the reasonable anticipation of a post-Lenten boom in trade. It is a gratifying season for the boys -- almost as good as Christmas week -- and they have made their own preparations for it.

ADDIS ABABA, April 10. -- The use of gas by the Italians in Ogaden Province Wednesday was reported in today's dispatch from Ras Nasibu at Harar. Aircraft dropped gas bombs on Daggah Bur and Sasa Baneh, he reported, and eighty persons were severely burned or otherwise injured.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP). -- The United States and Great Britain were engaged today in a survey of Anglo-American trade, which may result in negotiation of a reciprocal trade pact with this country's biggest customer.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP). -- A possible revival of the question whether Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, or Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, should administer public works funds developed today as a group of House members urged the earmarking of $700,000,000 for PWA.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- A Winter wheat crop of 493,166,000 bushels, compared with 433,447,000 bushels last year and a preceding five-year average of 618,186,000 bushels was forecast today by the government Crop Reporting Board. At the same time the AAA announced plans to disburse $40,500,000 to Winter wheat farmers who had agreed to curtail their planting by 5 per cent before the invalidating Supreme Court decision on Jan. 6.
LOS ANGELES, April 10 (AP). -- Jimmy McLarnin concluded preliminary training today and prepared to leave for New York, where he has a ten-round engagement May 8 with Tony Canzoneri.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- After adopting "a program of action" today, the convention of the Workers Alliance of America formulated plans to march past the White House tomorrow despite a police veto which provided for a "walk past the rear" of the Executive Mansion.
MONTE CARLO, April 10. -- Prince Pierre, former son-in-law of Prince Louis, ruler of Monaco, today denied he had received 800,000 francs annually since his separation from Princess Charlotte.
Playing smoothly and accurately, Edward Lee of New York captured two games in the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 10 (AP). -- Governor Wilbur L. Cross, 74 years old today, blamed a "Daemon" for driving him into public life. This daemon, the Governor explained, resembles one described by Goethe as "something of a god who influences one's life."

Opposition to the Lyons residence bill, which will come before the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly on Tuesday, be organized at 3 o'clock this afternoon when the 382 relief employes affected by the bill meet at the Russell Sage Foundation, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-second Street.

LONDON, April 10 (Canadian Press). -- Humbling Birmingham by 2 -- 1 at Roker Park, Sunderland gained further ground in the race for the English Soccer League championship today. The famous Northern club, with 52 points, now has a lead of 9 over Derby County, its nearest rival.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The Pittsburgh West Virginia Railroad today asked the permission of the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $2,000,000 of equipment trust certificates covering equipment valued at $4,071,516.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 10. -- Orlando and Tampa may have produced most of the spectacular kidnappings, floggings and tar-and-feather parties in Central Florida recently, but St. Petersburg, the "Sunshine City," has its own unsolved case of terrorism that, like many of the others, is laid to members of the Ku Klux Klan.
COHASSET, Minn., April 10. -- A country physician climaxed twenty-eight years of ministering to the ills of this community today by a Good Friday cancellation of unpaid accounts totaling $50,000.

Although I don't remember any details of the 1888 baseball games mentioned by Old Timer, H.S. Barnes and T.J. Hughes in recent letters to the sports editor, I am sure that the New Yorks were called Giants in those days.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Promoters of the Grand National Treasure Hunt were barred from the use of the mails under a fraud order issued today by Acting Postmaster General W.W. Howes on the recommendation of Karl A. Crowley, solicitor for the Postoffice Department, based on evidence produced at hearings held here last week.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, April 10. -- A grave attack which violates our constitutional guarantees has been made upon the undersigned. The only reason given by the government for expatriating us is the anarchical conditions which prevail in the country.

In a letter accompanying notice of the annual meeting, called for May 20, H.F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, yesterday advised shareholders that they would be asked to rescind authorization previously given for the issuance of $100,000,000 of secured bonds and to authorize not more than $50,000,000 of bonds or other securities.

ISTANBUL, April 10. -- Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdu Aras announced to the council of the Republican People's party in Angora today that the Turkish Government had decided formally to request the powers signatory to the Treaty of Lausanne to agree to modification of the convention relating to non-fortification of the straits and the demilitarized zones.

GENEVA, April 10. -- The Locarno powers, Great Britain, France, Italy and Belgium, agreed late tonight that the German Government in its recent note to Britain "has not made the contribution to re-establishment of confidence indispensable'' for the negotiation of a new Locarno treaty and for the opening of "immediate general negotiations."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 (AP). -- To the thunder of hoofbeats and cheers of 20,000 fans, Top Row and Azucar, Santa Anita Handicap winners, will hook up in another turf duel tomorrow -- the $10,000 added mile and a furlong Marchbank Handicap at Tanforan. Seven thoroughbreds will go postward in the first running of the event, named in honor of John W. Marchbank, owner of Tanforan.

In his New Republic gallery of possible Republican nominees for President Mr. JONATHAN MITCHELL has reached Senator VANDENBERG. That Senator has long been an admirer and a worshiper of ALEXANDER HAMILTON. Whether or not we accept JEFFERSON'S statement that HAMILTON'S "system "flowed from principles adverse to "liberty," it is mere observation of contemporary fact to say that with all their annual lip-service to JEFFERSON the Democrats are now far more Hamiltonian than HAMILTON ever was.

General and Countess Adalbert de Chambrun, Baron and Baroness Raymond de Luze, Countess Guy du Bourg de Bozas, and son Vicomte Bertrand du Pontavice de Heussey, and the Duke de Richelieu are among those sailing today for Havre on the French liner Paris.
PITTSBURGH, April 10. -- Nellie Granger, the hostess of the Sun Racer, knew before it happened that her ship was going to crash.

New bond financing announced this week amounted to $427,666,500, including $180,000,000 of Federal Land Bank 3 per cent bonds and $62,545,500 of National Dairy Products 3 3/4s, the latter offered to holders of securities of the corporation before the public offering. This total compares with $62,942,000 placed on the market last week, and with $263,310,000, also including a Land Bank issue, in the corresponding period of last year.

To determine the relation between consumption and newspaper expenditure in the gasoline industry, the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday released an analysis of advertising pressure and sales possibilities in that industry, under the title "Gasoline and Newspapers."

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Representative Treadway, ranking Republican of the House Ways and Means Committee, let it be known that if he has his way R.L. O'Brien will not receive so much as a hearing on his reciprocal tariff proposal at the Cleveland convention.

ASMARA, Eritrea, April 10. -- That the Italian campaign in Africa is almost over is the firm conviction of this writer, reached in the past two days as a result of flights in bombing planes to and from Sardo in the heart of Aussa Sultanate in Ethiopia.

Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator, welcomed yesterday "constructive criticism" of the relief organization, pointing specifically to the protest registered Thursday by five leading civic and welfare organizations of the city. The groups had asked that reduction of WPA rolls be canceled.
Miss Nellie Granger, hostess of the airliner Sun Racer, which crashed on a Pennsylvania mountainside with a loss of eleven lives, won promotion yesterday for her courage in rescuing two passengers.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP). -- Evidence that an Assistant Secretary of War and other army representatives knew that army surplus goods intended for charitable purposes were diverted to private sales channels was read today into the record of the House Military Committee.

The Labor Nonpartisan League is poorly advised in supporting President Roosevelt for re-election, as urged by Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, Dr. Harry W. Laidler, chairman of the public affairs committee of the New York Socialist party (left wing), declared yesterday.

LONDON, April 10. -- Dr. Leopold Gustav Alexander von Hoesch, German Ambassador to the Court of St. James since November, 1932, fell dead of heart disease while dressing in his bedroom at the embassy at 10 o'clock this morning.

A recent report to VICTOR RIDDER, WPA Administrator for this city, indicated that about 60 to 70 of normal industrial efficiency was all that could be expected, under present conditions, on projects under his control. Measured by that standard, the author of the report declared, the results obtained here have been on the whole "very satisfactory."

Easter may fall anywhere between March 22 and April 25. This range of thirty-five days is disturbing to teachers who fix the terms of school classes, department-store managers who think of Spring styles, time-table compilers who consider the desires of tourists, and nearly all business men who reckon with seasons.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 10. -- A memorial plaque to Adolph S. Ochs, late publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Chattanooga Times, was unveiled tonight by the Mizpah Congregation of the Julius and Bertha Ochs Memorial Temple.

Few persons realize that a "similar struggle" to that which has preserved the lives of the Dionne quintuplets "has been going on at our very doors," the Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart says in his annual report, to be made public today, as director of the Children's Division of the Catholic Charities of New York.

William Fox, former motion picture producer, who recently was adjudged in contempt of court for his failure to submit to examination in a suit brought against him by the Capitol Company, a California corporation, appears to have been "playing tag with the courts for months."

BOWIE, Md., April 10. -- Juvenile and older horses will have their main opportunities of the Bowie meeting tomorrow, when the Kindergarten Stakes and the Southern Maryland Handicap are decided as the features on the concluding program.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Far-reaching proposals for expanding the peace system of the Western Hemisphere have been made to President Roosevelt by Guatemala and Chile in their replies to his suggestion for an inter-American conference to be held at Buenos Aires for the purpose of consolidating the agencies of peace in the Americas.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation will open bids on April 23 on forty-one issues of municipalities, counties and school districts of twenty-two States aggregating $5,183,700, which it is offering to the private investment market.

When the curtain rose on the first scene of the Metropolitan's annual Good Friday presentation of Wagner's "Parsifal," yesterday afternoon, the auditorium was packed to capacity with an eager multitude of serious music-lovers, who came, not to be amused or entertained, but to absorb devoutly the consolatory message conveyed by this unique creation.

Art has become a valuable therapeutic agent in the treatment of mental cases, according to speakers at the twenty-fifth annual convention of the College Art Association, which closed its three-day meeting yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 10. -- Batsmen of the Albany club of the International League hit the ball around the lot this afternoon to win from the Naval Academy by 11 to 1. Centerfielder Marion led the onslaught with a brace of triples and a double, and scored four of the visitors' tallies.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Alarmed at the recent disastrous air crashes that have resulted in the loss of lives and destruction of mail, Representative Mead of New York, chairman of the Postoffice and Post Roads Committee, today called that committee to meet Tuesday to consider the transfer of the Bureau of Air Commerce from the Department of Commerce to the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Police Lieutenant James J. Coy, who several years ago was police dramatic censor, retired last midnight after more than twenty-five years in the department.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- A return to direct relief "except for worth-while and necessary work on a basis of cost competitive with contemporary public construction," was urged by General Hugh S. Johnson in a report made Oct. 26, soon after his retirement as New York City WPA Administrator, to Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress chief.

SACRAMENTO, April 10 (AP). -- Governor Frank F. Merriam has issued a statement concerning the coming primary election on May 5. It was in reply to the criticism by the Republican Assembly of methods by which the Landon slate was put in the field.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Returning to Washington early this afternoon from his holiday in the South, President Roosevelt applied himself to the task of gathering information on developments during his absence.

DALLAS, Texas, April 10 (AP). -- General Plutarco Elias Calles declared here tonight that Mexico was on the brink of a revolution and expressed the belief that his exile would aggravate the situation.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- An attempt to show that the Farmers Independence Council of America is connected with the American Liberty League and financed in part, at least, by men who are influential in the league was made today by the Senate Lobby Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Polka dots and daisies, strap sandals, and period and modern furniture figured in the arguments today for and against design copyright proposed by the Vandenberg amendment to the Duffey bill. The bill was up at a hearing before the House Patents Committee.
A preliminary report of the Pennsylvania Board of Game Commissioners on the 1935 hunting season offers some interesting statistics on the take of game birds and animals in that State.

SHERBURNE, N.Y., April 10 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, State Republican chairman, heard his leadership extolled last night at a testimonial dinner arranged by the Sherburne Young Republican Club and attended by 300 partisans from the Sixth Judicial District.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 10. -- Control of the Jersey Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company, 280 North Broad Street, with outstanding guarantees amounting to $4,901,363, was taken over yesterday by Carl K. Withers, State Banking and Insurance Commissioner, on petition of the company's board of directors.

In reply to Richard Rochester's query about the origin of the term fungo, which appeared in your very engaging "Letters to the Sports Editor" columns, I would like to hint at the etymology of the word. I do not believe it belongs in the same category as "flied out," but rather that it has a perfectly legitimate background.

Paul H. Wendel identified yesterday the second of four men who, he says, abducted him and forced him to "confess" to the Lindbergh baby kidnapping. This man and another whom Wendel identified by a photograph on Thursday are being sought by the police.

Persons subject to the New York State income tax were reminded yesterday by Wesley M. Dawson, district supervisor here of the Department of Taxation and Finance, that Wednesday is the last day for filing returns. Payment of the tax may be made either personally at local offices or by check to 80 Centre Street or to Albany.
THE husky young man in the far corner of the luncheon nook paused in his destruction of a mushroom omelette to look up and remark with evident satisfaction:

ADDIS ABABA, April 10 -- An Ethiopian communique said today three Italian divisions had been repulsed after attacking Sasa Baneh and Daggah Bur on the southern front by the armies of Ras Nasibu and Dedjazmatch Makonnen.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 10. -- An automobile powered by natural gas instead of gasoline was demonstrated on the streets here today by officials of the Minneapolis Gas Light Company.

Among post-war diplomats few faced a more difficult task than Dr. Leopold von Hoesch, who for eleven years represented Germany in Paris, first as counselor and Charge d'Affaires and later as Ambassador. When he became Ambassador to London in 1932, he had won the confidence of the French to a large extent and had contributed greatly to better relations between France and Germany.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- Directors of the First National Bank of Chicago at their regular meeting this afternoon voted to buy back the $15,000,000 of preferred stock sold to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation two years ago and to sell 50,000 additional shares of $100 par common stock at $200 a share to provide $10,000,000 to cover this retirement.

I have read letters to the editors of several metropolitan dailies from correspondents who have professed to find New York a most inhospitable and unfit city in which to live and make social contacts.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Saturday, April 11. -- The District Attorney's office announced early today a "good" suspect in the "Easter gift" bomb outrages was being questioned.

The admission of the Seas Shipping Company, operator of the Robin Line, to membership in the conference of freight lines operating between the Atlantic seaboard and ports of South and East Africa, was urged yesterday in a report submitted to the Shipping Board by John A. Russell, examiner.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 10 (AP). -- Another base hit at precisely the right spot last May 18 could have given Harvard a baseball victory over Dartmouth and sent the Crimson into a much closer finish with the Green in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race.
A first-aid corps of 1,600 employes of the Works Progress Administration is being formed to supervise accident emergencies on construction projects, it was announced yesterday.
HOW can this country stay out of war? Very simple; by fulfilling the destiny dictated alike by history and geography.
BROWNSVILLE, Texas, April 10. -- Surrounded by an armed guard of six Mexican soldiers, the exiled General Plutarco Elias Calles arrived here by airplane from Mexico today.

RICHMOND, Va., April 10. -- Jimmy Thomson of Ridgewood, N.J., gained a three-stroke lead today at the halfway mark in the $3,000 Richmond open-golf tournament at the James River course of the Country Club of Virginia.

More than forty museums of the country have already agreed to cooperate with the Museum of Modern Art here, it was disclosed yesterday, in an attempt to obtain an amendment to Federal laws which now permit customs officials to assess heavy duties on "abstract" sculpture as "not art," while admitting "abstract" painting duty-free as "art."

ALBANY, N.Y., April 10 (AP). -- Edwin C. (Alabama) Pitts, who rocketed to baseball fame last year when he jumped from the Sing Sing prison nine to an International League berth with the Albany Senators, was transferred today to York of the New York-Pennsylvania League.

Members of the Salmagundi Club who wouldn't like surrealism in art even if it were good were conspicuous by their absence last night at a gathering at the clubhouse, 47 Fifth Avenue, at which the entertainment committee, in friendly cooperation with the art committee, sought an answer to a self-propounded challenge, "Can the Salmagundi go abstract?"

PRINCETON, N.J., April 10. -- The Princeton varsity crew today spotted the jayvee eight four lengths over a mile and three-quarter course and came through in the last half mile at a high 38 stroke to win by two lengths. A strong head wind made the time for the distance slow.
The sale of a large multi-family building on Washington Heights featured a good demand for housing properties in Manhattan yesterday.

GENEVA, April 10. -- The conciliation Committee of Thirteen, snubbed by the International Red Cross today, decided to open its own investigation of charges and counter-charges that both Italy and Ethiopia have violated international rules of warfare.

A double week-end holiday and the Easter festivities are leading most Europeans to turn their thoughts away from the international crisis. But it exists in an acute form, and we may be sure that responsible statesmen will be giving their minds to it more intensely than ever during the short interlude.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, April 11. -- The Nanking Foreign Ministry, finding Moscow's reply to China's protest over the mutual assistance protocol between the Soviet Union and Outer Mongolia entirely unsatisfactory, is now planning a second demarche soon and probably an eventual appeal to the League of Nations if Moscow's second reply fails to give satisfaction.

Apparently on the theory that any matter it happens to think about is a fit subject for Federal legislation -- one more law won't do us any harm -- Congress now has before it a bill "to prohibit the use of the mail for the solicitations of the procurement of divorces in foreign countries."

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Following issuance today of a "fraud order" against the Grand National Treasure Hunt, Inc., and the Association for Legalizing American Lotteries, Inc., it was indicated by postal authorities that early rulings were likely on the Golden Stakes Advertising Company, of which Alfred E. Smith Jr. is vice president and counsel, and on the National Conference for Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., of which Mrs. Oliver Harriman is president.

Harry Meyers, 38 years old, of 949 Third Avenue, an ex-convict, pleaded not guilty in Felony Court yesterday to a charge that he coached his two daughters, aged 14 and 12, in a series of apartment thefts on the middle East Side. The little girls are suspected of taking more than $5,000 in money and jewelry in recent months through thefts of purses from the occupants.
The Pennsylvania State Police sent a warning to Manhattan Police Headquarters at 2 P.M. yesterday that bombs similar to those received at Wilkes-Barre may have been mailed to New York City addresses.

Citing a clause of the Treaty of Versailles, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook refused yesterday to recognize the "sovereign immunity" claimed in the courts of this country by the Reichsbahn (German State Railroads). The decision was in a suit for $98,000 brought by a former employe, who claimed that amount because of his discharge as a "non-Aryan" and his internment in a concentration camp in Germany.

CLEVELAND, April 10. -- The White Motor Company delivered 2,483 trucks and buses in the first quarter, compared with 1,261 in the corresponding 1935 period, up 96 1/2 per cent and reported a profit for the first time in five years, Robert F. Black, president, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Money in circulation at the end of March amounted to $5,877,042,037, compared with $5,845,959,668 at the end of February and $5,493,137,741 on March 31, 1935, the Treasury announced today.

Four sales were negotiated by J. G. Mulford of Plainfield during the past week. A new house to be built by Carl Nelson on a 60-foot lot on Shackamaxon Drive at Westfield Was sold from the plans to Charles H. Calquist of Perth Amboy. A fifty-foot lot on Field Avenue was sold for Howard Mitcheltree of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Evidence to sustain Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter's contention that the $4,500 he accepted from A.L. Rankin, his former law partner, represented part payment of a debt resulting from the dissolution of their partnership was presented by defense counsel in his impeachment trial before the Senate today.

The United May Day Committee will demand of the police this morning the right to hold its annual May Day parade on Fifth Avenue from Fifty-ninth Street to Union Square, it was announced yesterday by Amicus Most, executive secretary of the committee.

Good Friday was observed yesterday with cathedrals and churches throughout the city crowded. There was no official pause here as in some foreign cities, but there was as solemn hush over New York, particularly in the financial and commercial districts, where thousands gave up their luncheon to attend some nearby service.
MEXICO, D. F., April 10. -- General Calles, while waiting at Santa Barbara for a military escort to take him to the Central Airport, told The Associated Press correspondent:

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Sir John Maffey, Under-Secretary for the Colonies, who recently concluded an official tour of the British West Indies, was received at tea at the White House today by the President. The British Ambassador accompanied Sir John, who, with Lady Maffey, is a guest at the embassy here.

WILDWOOD, N.J., April 10 (AP). -- Walter Cantley, veteran Philadelphia golfer, shot a 73 today to win the medal in the qualifying round of the fourteenth annual Easter golf tournament of the Wildwood Golf Club.
U. S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

The question raised by Hitler's use of the word "Alsbald" and its correct translation is brought up again by the translation of the French memorandum in answer to Hitler and of France's plan for European peace, both of which are published in today's press.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, national chairman of the $3,500,000 campaign of the United Palestine Appeal for the settlement in Palestine of a maximum number of the Jews of Germany, Poland and other lands, has received messages endorsing the drive from Governor Paul V. McNutt of Indiana, Representative Schuyler Merritt of Connecticut, Governor Tom Berry of South Dakota and Governor Harold Hoffman of New Jersey, it was announced yesterday.

A proposal to liquidate the Western Power Corporation, a subsidiary of the North American Company, will be presented to stockholders at a special meeting on Thursday, April 30. It is necessary first to provide funds to pay off the preferred stock on dissolution, says the letter sent to security holders of the corporation yesterday.

PRAGUE, April 10. -- The latest Arbeiter-Zeitung, organ of the Austrian Socialists, published at Bruenn, Czechoslovakia, devotes four pages to analyzing the "Phoenix crash." The paper attributes the losses to the fall in the dollar and speculation in municipal bonds.
ALBANY, April 10. -- The Esquirol bill widening the powers of the Domestic Relations Courts in New York City was signed by Governor Lehman today.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $15,753,091, to be represented by one State and fifty-one municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $29,695,225 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $24,019,876.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 10. -- Two New England stars gained the final round of the women's North and South golf championship by defeating South Carolina rivals today. Miss Deborah Verry of Worcester, Mass., subdued Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, 2 up, and Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., eliminated Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, 1 up.
BERLIN, April 10. -- In the sudden death of Dr. Leopold yon Hoesch, her Ambassador to London, Germany loses one of her most capable diplomatists.
The Albright Art Gallery of Buffalo has acquired for its permanent collection a pair of portraits by the American portrait painter Ralph Earl from M. Knoedler Co., Inc.

The celebration of the Passover, which began at sundown last Monday, will be continued today and tomorrow, coming to a close Monday in the Reform temples and Tuesday in the Orthodox synagogues. Some of the services include:

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 10. -- Although his friends stayed away from his home and there were frequent occasions when he felt the urge for a steak smothered in onions, the Rev. William H. Alderson, district superintendent of the Methodist Episcopal Church, greeted the end of the Lenten season tonight with the satisfaction of having proved to himself that a family of five can at least exist on a relief food allowance of $8.20 a week.

SHANGHAI, April 10. -- A ChinoRussian conflict of interests on China's northwestern frontier, where the Soviet Union is said to be opposing Chinese authority and spreadingits inTluence, was revealed today when the Nanking government issued an order closing the greater part of Kokonor (Tsinghai Province) to foreign travel.

I should like to extend my sympathy to Lewis Belmore. But he forgot to add in his letter that New York has an anti-noise campaign which chooses to ignore the worst offenders inside of dwellings, and we also have a Health Department which accepts complaints against obnoxious neighbors but does not seem interested enough to correct their practices.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 10. -- The First International Congress for Musical Education, which closed here today, was attended by 700 delegates, representing eighteen countries.

New York will get another musical show this evening, a gesture to Spring on the part of Dwight Deere Wiman. Call it "On Your Toes" and say that in it Ray Bolger has the part of a vaudeville hoofer suffering aspirations toward the art of ballet.
Stationed in roomy individual box stalls, twelve polo ponies slated to see action during the London season were shipped to England yesterday aboard the American Merchant liner American Farmer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 10. -- Harvard's three varsity crews, as they worked in a wintry setting on the Charles River Basin today, gave evidence of power and more finished rowing than the Crimson eights of last year at this stage.
CLEVELAND, April 10 (AP). -- Bill Terry, manager of the Giants, today picked the Cleveland Indians to win the American League pennant.
For the third time in five months, gunmen were routed last night by the use of champagne bottles in the liquor store of Meyer D. Nitzburg, 1,108 Park Avenue, near Eighty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- An increase in United States exports for February to $181,838,000 from $162,999,000 in February, 1935, an increase of $18,839,000, was reported today by the Department of Commerce. Exports were larger to all but fifteen foreign markets for the month this year and showed increases over last year's value in February to all but one of the major geographic divisions, Asia.

The Masters' Bridge Tournament, conducted by the American Bridge League, will be held in the Park Lane, Park Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, beginning Monday afternoon and concluding Sunday, April 19, it was announced yesterday.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

Easter will be celebrated in the churches of the metropolitan area tomorrow. Thousands of Protestants will attend Easter dawn services. In the Roman Catholic churches there will be masses beginning early in the morning. Early morning celebrations of Holy Communion also will be held by Episcopalians, Lutherans and other denominations.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, April 10. -- The von Hindenburg, the new luxury Zeppelin, landed here at 7 o'clock this evening with only two of its four motors, running. The ship made more than one-third of the voyage from Rio de Janeiro to its home port driven by two motors.
The Consulate General of Mexico and the Fiscal Delegation of the Mexican Government have leased offices in Sixty Wall Tower on Pine Street.

ALBANY, April 10. -- Nine of the eleven main industrial groups in the State reported increases in employment and payrolls for the period from the middle of February to middle of March, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

Columbia will open its campaign in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today when it faces Cornell at Baker Field at 3 P.M. Captain Johnny De Bettencourt is scheduled to pitch for the Lions, while Cornell will send Jack Batten, ace moundsman, against the Blue. Cornell has played one league game, losing to Penn.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 10. -- A large Easter crowd arrived at the Homestead this morning. Charles Hayden of New York played the Homestead course with the Princess Miguel de Braganca, and both afterward joined Mr. and Mrs. Beverly Bogert and Miss Margaret Steward at luncheon in the Colonial Room.

The little Norwegian tramp freighter Elfi, her smudgy stack salt-encrusted from encounters with many oceans, warped slowly into the Atlantic Basin in Brooklyn yesterday and tied up at Commercial Wharf not far from the Hamilton Avenue ferry.

PASADENA, Calif., April 10. -- Apparently safe and sound after its cautious journeying from Corning. N.Y., the 200-inch eye for the world's largest telescope rested in the optical shop of the California Institute of Technology tonight. Whether the huge lens escaped damage on the railroad trip will not be definitely known until after a thorough check.

College rowing in the East will make its debut at 3 o'clock this afternoon when the crews of Columbia and Manhattan meet on the Harlem River. The four-race regatta was scheduled as an informl affair, but this status has not decreased interest in the meeting, which is expected to serve as an index of what may be expected of the Lions and Jaspers in their regular campaigns.

While weather conditions were not of the best, Easter trade in the metropolitan area was well maintained during the week. Some department stores used the pre-Easter figures of last year, when Easter came nine days later, and they were able to "beat" these figures this week by 10 per cent or so.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10. -- It pays, and well, to be the legal guardian of a child movie darling.

Jo Davidson, American sculptor, who will leave today for his home in Paris, made two confessions yesterday afternoon in the studio at 1 West Sixty-seventh Street where he has been staying. First, he intimated, he may hold his first show of water-colors and oils soon, Second, President Roosevelt has prevailed on him to contribute his skill to the forthcoming Democratic campaign.

" The Mikado" that blooms in the Spring opened at the Majestic last evening. Let appropriate expressions of joy rise from the Winter-beaten populace. For this, as you probably know, is "The Mikado" which William Danforth, Frank Moulan and Herbert Waterous are more likely than not to spread across some Gotham stage at about this time of year as the forerunner to a Gilbert and Sullivan festival.

The return of the Yankees and Dodgers to the metropolitan sector yesterday was attended by some 4,000 frigid baseball fans, who saw the Brooklyn team score a sensational triumph in the first game of the Ebbets Field series.

BELIOT, Wis., April 10. -- A curious stone pipe unearthed by two farm boys from a huge Indian mound near Fort Smith, Okla., has been identified by Professor Paul N. Nesbitt, head of Beloit College's department of anthropology, as of Mayan or Inca origin.
Metropolitan newspapers, especially THE NEW YORK TIMES, have shown such an interest in Rugby football that undoubtedly a word or two on its development and present status will be of interest.

New advances in the study of the correlationship of speech defects to brain injury were reported last night by Dr. Samuel T. Orton, Professor of Neurology and Neuropathology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University.

MADRID, March 6, 1936. THE most typical regional music heard in Vasconia this season was a choral program given in Donostia (San Sebastian) by the celebrated Orfeon Donostiarra of that city, presenting two new works by Eduardo de Gorosarri, prize-winners in its last contest held for Basque folksongs harmonized for various mixed voices, in pursuance of this society's systematic cultivation of the local lyric lore.

THE prolonged growl and the quick, sharp splash of breakers on the beach are again music to the ears of New Yorkers. Easter week is the curtain-raiser for many shore resorts, and this year -- for reasons connected with accelerating business recovery -- for more than the usual number.

WILDWOOD, N.J., April 11 (AP). -- James (Sonny) Fraser, defending champion, advanced to the semi-final round of the fourteenth annual Wildwood Easter golf tournament today, defeating Bill Firth of Old York Road, Philadelphia, 3 and 1, in a match in which he held the lead throughout.

MIAMI, Fla., April 11 (AP). -- The Puerto Rican Clipper, which collided with a launch while it was taking off from the harbor of Port of Spain, Trinidad, today, left here Thursday on the regular passenger, mail and express flight of six days down South America's east coast to Buenos Aires.

DALLAS, April 11. -- The week before Easter has been marked by satisfactory gains in all lines of business throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District. A few dust storms of only moderate intensity and unseasonably low temperatures over much of the district lasting for the greater part of the week hampered sales somewhat, but, on the whole, the volume of retail and wholesale buying has been well up to expectations.

KEREN, Eritrea. IN this city, approachable by railway from the Red Sea coast, there are, as in all African cities, a market and a bazaar. In the former the usual pitiful stock is displayed -- three or four different kinds of spices, tea, coffee and bright-colored beads from Czechoslovakia.
EL PASO, Texas, April 11 (AP). -- General Plutarco Elias Calles declared today he had been banished by a "country swept with chaos," as he paused in his hurried air trip to a California exile.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- A plan for cities to sentence traffic violators to a school to learn how to drive safely will soon be suggested by the President's Accident Prevention Conference.
BERLIN, April 10. -- The fundamental difference between America and Europe, politically speaking, is that America is wrapped up in domestic politics while Europe is wrapped up in foreign politics.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 11 (AP). -- Counsel for Charles Luciano, alleged New York vice operator, rejected today a proposal that they appear in St. Louis Monday to seek an appeal from a decision of Federal Judge John E. Martineau denying a habeas corpus plea of Luciano, who is fighting extradition to New York.
