WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Indications are that the Securities and Exchange Commission, except in connection with its bill dealing with unlisted trading in securities on the national securities Exchanges, will not press for legislation in the present session of Congress.

Because police radio patrol cars searched in the vicinity of Prospect Park for nearly an hour last night to thwart what at first was believed to be a double kidnapping, Anthony Visignoli Sr. of 489 East New York Avenue can enjoy Easter today. Detectives said he even might take his family for a ride in his automobile, the indirect cause of all the trouble.

A gunman, deserted by his companion after robbing the Fox clothing store at 2,099 Second Avenue yesterday afternoon, attempted to kidnap a policeman who stood in his way, and failing in this, engaged in a gun battle with three others who came on the scene.
THE title of this book is happy: the Ireland of today is quick with economic and social change, and the eight plays in this book reflect it.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Departing in one important particular from the action of other Eastern roads on the passenger fare decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Long Island Railroad asked the commission today for authority to establish basic passenger fares of 3 cents a mile in both Pullman and day coaches.

CHICAGO, April 11. -- The government report on Thursday showing a probable yield of 493,000,000 bushels of Winter wheat, or 44,000,000 under the returns of earlier in the month, was construed today by the trade as bullish. A rush of short covering resulted, sweeping prices up 2 cents a bushel from the previous close.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- In preparation for the bonus payment, the Treasury has begun its shipments of adjusted service bonds to Federal Reserve Banks. Approximately two and a half million applications, out of some three and a half million certificates outstanding, have already been filed with the Veterans Bureau, and each day adds thousands to the total.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Judge Halsted L. Ritter of the Southern District of Florida made a detailed denial today of the articles of impeachment brought against him by the House as he took the stand at the conclusion of the defense testimony before the Senate.

MOSCOW, April 11. -- The evolution of the Young Communist League into a trained military reserve, every member of which, man or woman, will have mastered some specialty useful in war, was presented as the major and immediate objective to delegates meeting in the Kremlin tonight at the opening session of the tenth congress of the league.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 11 (AP). -- One-hit relief pitching by Don Brennan held the Tigers in check over the last five innings today and gave the Reds a 5-5 tie with the world champions in a game called at the end of the eleventh inning on account of rain.

The thirty-third annual meeting of the National Catholic Educational Association will open Tuesday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Two thousand delegates are expected for the three-day convention, which will represent a cross-section of all branches and phases of Catholic education and scholarship.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 11. -- The evolution of American drama from 1760 to the present day has furnished to the Playshop Laboratory at Mount Holyoke College this year a rich fund of material for experimentation and study. Results of this theatrical survey, undertaken by students in three different courses, will take definite form in the productions scheduled for April 20-21 and April 28-29.
Recreational facilities in Central Park will show a great improvement this year, compared with past seasons, a survey yesterday of projects under way in the park disclosed.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP). -- Finding Larry French for all their runs in the third and fifth innings, the White Sox defeated the Cubs, 5 to 1, before 4,500 fans, at Wrigley Field today as the teams resumed their annual Spring city series that was started in Los Angeles last month.

NEWARK, N.J., April 11. -- David M. Hammer, 70-year-old grocer of 235 Lafayette Street, was in a critical condition at St. James Hospital tonight with a bullet wound in the head, while a Negro, alleged to have shot him when Hammer resisted a hold-up, is being held at police headquarters.

GORDON NICHOLSON, a football player from Alabama, went north to college. One of the other freshman football candidates was a Negro. The first day of scrimmage they were named on opposing squads. All Gordon's ingrained prejudices came to the surface.

ALWAYS FAITHFUL, the speediest homing pigeon in the United States Army, has received a gold medal for outstanding performance in the year 1935. He won the recent Chattanooga national pigeon race, against 1,114 other racers, flying 715 miles at an average speed of 47 miles per hour.

Patrolwoman Mary Shanley ordered two suspicious characters, neither of them weaklings, into the lobby of the Longacre Building in Times Square shortly after 10 o'clock last night. They complied, for everything in the policewoman's mien indicated determination -- even the firm grasp of her right hand on her service pistol.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 10. -- The La Follette-controlled Progressive party, footloose and with a free hand, dominated this week both the Democratic and Republican election of delegates to the national conventions of the two old parties. La Folletteites, with no national convention of their own, threw votes around in merry fashion.
REMINDERS: He probably doesn't need them, but last Monday brought three reminders of the World War to General John J. Pershing, retired commander of the A.E.F.

The "passive resistance strike" recently staged by the crew of the California has probably contributed more toward stimulating public interest in marine affairs than anything ever before. As a master mariner and an eyewitness, I had opportunity to study and follow the events that led to the so-called "mutiny" aboard that ship.

MILAN, March 9, 1936 ITALY'S illustrious museum of nineteenth-century operatic art -- few would dispute that such is La Scala's chief function today -- has just added another wreath to its venerable collection of laurels for one more of the brilliant revivals that constitute its most envied specialty.

Eleazar Lopez Contreras, Provisional President of Venezuela, will be elected unanimously when Congress meets at Caracas this month, according to Dr. J.J. Mendoza, newly appointed Minister to Washington. The envoy, who arrived here Tuesday on the Empress of Australia, is at the Waldorf-Astoria with his daughter, Miss Helen Carmen Mendoza, and an attache of the legation.

THERE are certain principles in this undertaking to be observed, which as yet do not seem to be as clearly grasped as they must be. I make no apology, therefore, for reiterating these principles now as emphatically as possible.
HAVANA, April 11. -- Two 10-year-old boys were killed by the explosion of a bomb in a vacant lot near Santa Iglesia Cathedral in the city of Santiago this morning.

ACTIVITY in London is engaging the local lads. With minor exceptions the town's connection with England has heretofore been largely conversational, but now an alliance is assuming tangible form. From its earliest days the cinema has been internationally minded, but the problems that have confronted the business of late in foreign territory have made the industry acutely conscious of the need of production outside of Hollywood.

A thorough handbook on planning and creating a garden, this volume by Richard Sudell is splendid in all but one particular, and the point on which the book falls short is not the fault of the author, who has done an excellent job. The text is absorbing, the diagrams and illustrations of high merit, and the lists of plants extensive and carefully compiled.

ABROAD rustling river of big and little money which The Economist estimates at "perhaps more than 500,000,000" pours into betting every year in Britain. Every few years some offshoot of that never-ending river its banks and goes cascading in some new direction toward the pots of gold at the end of some new rainbow.

PEGGY WOOD, writer as well as actress, devotes her first novel to an amusing history of the experiences of a young couple in the throes of Hollywood. Tessa was a New York actress with a natural gift for comedy and an unquenchable yen to play tragic feminine Hamlets.

THE competition for the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge prize of $1,000, offered under the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation by the Division of Music of the Library of Congress, will close Sept. 30. The competition, open to composers of all nationalities, is for a chamber-music work for four stringed instruments (without piano).

THE NEW YORK TIMES printed recently an article from Dar-es-Salaam, East Africa, in which it was stated that "the average native here has little desire for return to German rule under which matters like holding the country in trust for its inhabitants would receive scant consideration."

ALL of the Easter eggs are not going into baskets for the children this year; instead it begins to look as if a goodly number of them would find their way into beverages for the grown-ups. The old custom of serving eggnogg at Easter is being revived.

THE Easter egg-rolling festival began a bit early this year and, much as it embarrasses me to admit it, an unconscionable number of the eggs were rolled, hurled or kicked in my direction. This morning, when the drama department is serenely out on parade, this corner presents a spattered and scrambled appearance.

BURLESQUE: Because a Boston burlesque theatre displayed her photograph in the lobby -- although she would never think of playing burlesque -- Miss Fofo Louka, dramatic actress from Athens, won $2,500 for damage to her reputation. In upholding the award last week, the Massachusetts Supreme Court made clear the distinction between tragedy (in which Miss Louka specializes) and burlesque.

THE beginning of the end may have come for Ethiopia, but not for the consequences of the end of Ethiopia. The repercussions of her passing may outlive the memory of her independence. For more has been at stake in Africa than the survival of the last unconquered nation on that continent.

KWEISUI, China, Sunday, April 12. -- The princely descendants of the mighty thirteenth century Mongol conqueror, Genghis Khan, gathered early today for annual prayers to their ancestor. They journeyed from throughout Suiyuan Province and Inner Mongolia to meet at his shrine.

The 'British freighter Welcombe left the Robins Erie Basin plant of the Todd Shipyards Corporation yesterday, completely recovered from an operation for a broken back which had caused her detention for three weeks.

Civic and mercantile organizations strenuously objected yesterday when the United Labor May Day Committee applied for a police permit to hold its annual May Day parade on Fifth Avenue. Police Commissioner Valentine will consider the application, also the alternate routes suggested, and announce his decision at police headquarters within a few days.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., April 11. -- A Spring supper dance will be held next Saturday at the Ardsley Country Club. Edwin W. Fiske Jr. heads the committee on arrangements. He will be assisted by Mrs. T. Wylie Kinney, Mrs. J.W.M. Richardson, Mrs. Kenyon B. Conger, Mr. and Mrs. H.M. Grout, Mrs. J.V. Dillon, Mrs. Gordon L. Harris, Carl A. Miller, Stuart Peabody and Dr. Bayard Williams.

EVERY one going to see the Bignou exhibition of modern French tapestries, I decided that I also must go, not that I had anything to add to the discussion -- by no means a muted discussion -- aroused by the exhibition. So much said and so well said, you know.

MOSCOW, April 11. -- An important step toward weaning Soviet industry from the bottle of State aid was taken in a government decree, announced today, abolishing subsidies in several branches of heavy industry and the timber industry.

CLEVELAND, April 11. -- The Glidden Company has filed a registration statement with the Securities Exchange Commission covering 200,000 shares of $50 par 4 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock. The company proposes to use this issue to retire, by call or exchange, 65,000 shares of $100 par 7 per cent prior-preference stock callable at $105.

Five of the leaders in the United States chess championship preliminaries, who, with only two more rounds to go, have excellent prospects of earning places in the finals beginning on April 25, were winners in their respective divisions yesterday.

IT seems rather a pity that Albert Frisch, the policeman who makes two important discoveries in the early chapters of this story, drops completely out of the picture after he has started Inspector McKee off on the trail that leads to the apprehension of a cold-blooded and utterly unscrupulous murder.

CHICAGO, April 11. -- Headquarters for Colonel Frank Knox announced today pledges of support from National Committeeman Frank L. Smith, National Committeewoman Bertha Baur and Chairman John Searing of the State central committee.

Professor Albert Einstein, in a message read to 2,000 persons attending the annual dinner of the National Labor Committee for Jewish Workers in Palestine last night at the Hotel Commodore, expressed the opinion that a public protest would prevent the British Government from approving additional restrictions in Palestine, which are being considered.

THIS year marks what may not too extravagantly be called a centenary in the history of the theatre. It was in 1836 that Elisabeth Felix, the 15-year-old daughter of a Jewish peddler, gained admittance to the Paris Conservatoire, with a scholarship, to study for the Comedie Francaise and to play occasional small parts.

TEXAS born and bred, young Branch Dilliard did not think much of California (whither he had gone with a trail herd) until he caught a glimpse of the lovely Senorita Mariposa Castameto. Just before that, in a cantina, he had overheard two drunken "yellow-backs" plotting to kidnap the girl.

Colonel Fred V.S. Chamberlain, commanding officer of the Reserve Officers Training Corps at New York University, announced yesterday the promotions of cadet officers in the university unit. General orders were also issued assigning officers to various duties in the R.O.T.C. infantry regiment.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee with offices at 7 Hanover Street contemplates substantial allotments for relief work among the Jews in Poland in 1936, it was announced yesterday by Joseph C. Hyman, secretary of the committee.

ADDING its modest "click-click" to the swelling chorus of Spring sounds, the camera is increasingly in evidence these days. On city streets laughing crowds, new Easter hats, flower vendors, grinning policemen, children and well-scrubbed dogs make excellent targets; away from the city there are budding hillsides, winding roadways, rustic scenes.
DETROIT, April 11. -- The twenty-first annual show of the Detroit Kennel Club opened this morning with an entry of 935 dogs representing fifty-two breeds.

Eugene P. Connolly, president of the Association of Knickerbocker Democrats of New York City, announced yesterday the formation of a citizens' committee for striking seamen, to aid the "rank and file" strike of members of the International Seamen's Union.

Cherry-blossom time in Washington, for the past six years the occasion of a week-end pilgrimage to the national capital by members of the Catholic Young Women's Club, is exercising its annual lure. Miss Anne Golden, club director, will lead the first of two groups of more than 200 each that are making the trip this week-end and next.

Behind the scenes in a circus is enchanted ground to boys and girls, who are fascinated by accounts of what goes on in the elephant lines, how animals are trained and what the acrobats do when they are not performing double somersaults from one trapeze to another.

An old-time Caucasian fete will be revived on Friday night at the Plaza when the annual Allaverdy Ball will be given by members of the Societe Caucasienne-Allaverdy. This organization was formed to unite Georgians and Circassians of mutual interests and traditions and to promote and establish closer social and cultural relationships between them and Americans.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April -- Administrative officers and alumnae of thirteen Eastern colleges for women will counsel future college students at the third annual Pre-College Guidance Conference, which will be held here April 23, 24, 25 and 26.

The new classic features of Alice, whose adventures in Wonderland were chronicled by Lewis Carroll in 1865, were not always so "bright, delicate and radiant," according to Professor Harry M. Ayres of Columbia University, whose critical study, "Carroll's Alice," has just been published at the university.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- William Green advised labor today to support those candidates in the coming campaign who were "pledged to the responsibility of finding how social welfare legislation can be made the law of the land unchallenged by the judiciary."

LONDON, April 11 (Canadian Press). -- Interest in English football is at a high pitch as the various teams in the four divisions of the league go into the final drive of the long season that ends May 2. Although Sunderland is practically certain of the championship of the First Division, the struggles for promotion in the other leagues are intense.

SPAIN enters into a third phase of her republican life. It is not lacking in dramatic touches. A complete reversal of the political and parliamentary situation is lit up with the flares of churches and convents set afire by riotous crowds, and in towns and villages the strife of ideals leads to armed brawls and loss of life.

Labor difficulties and the trend toward radicalism in Mexico, which for some time have caused much concern to executives of American companies operating in the Southern republic, show no signs of improvement, according to those familiar with developments there.

PORTSMOUTH, England, April 11. -- In a bleak northeast wind and a choppy sea, Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup class sloop Yankee left her moorings off Gosport today to return unescorted to the United States.

THAT it is possible for any young man of average ability and serious intent to work his way through college in four to four and one-half years is the conclusion of Dr. Earl Joyce Miller, dean of men on the Los Angeles campus of the University of California.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- At next Tuesday's primary Senator Borah try to win from Colonel Frank Knox enough delegates to the National Republican Convention to keep him in the race for the Presidential nomination. Colonel Knox has wooed the electorate in a thorough campaign which carried him into every, Congressional district.

BOSTON, April 10. -- The campaign for the repeal of the Teachers Oath Law has failed for this year. The only real surprise was the magnitude of its defeat. The vote by which the House refused the repeal bill a third reading was 133 to 88. As the committee on education had reported seven to six for repeal the opponents of the oath act looked for the adoption of their bill by a narrow margin.

ROME, April 11. -- Marshal Pietro Badoglio reported today 400 Ethiopians were killed in a battle between Emperor Haile Selassie's regular troops and rebellious Azebo and Galla native tribesmen on the Northern front. He telegraphed:

As a part of the city's "Out of School Activities," Mayor La Guardia was informed yesterday, the Board of Transportation, in cooperation with the Board of Education, has provided free transportation for students on the city subway to museums, parks and other points of interest.

BALTIMORE, April 11. -- With thousands of steeplechase fans roaring "come on" to their favorites, Sporting Print and Justinian II thundered across the finish line in a dead heat in the twenty-eighth annual running of My Lady's Manor point-to-point race today near Monkton.

AT 4:30 o'clock in the morning of April 12, 1861, watchers on the waterfront of Charleston, straining their eyes seaward toward Sumter in the gloom of the hour before sunrise, saw a streak of fire "rise high in air and, curving in its course, burst almost directly over the fort."

ANDREW SMITH is a former Communist who with his wife went to Russia in 1932 to throw in his lot with the Soviet Republics, and who in 1935 returned to the United States completely disillusioned. Naturally Mr. Smith has provided excellent ammunition for the enemies of communism and has been impolitely assailed by his former comrades as a traitor to his "class."

ALBANY, April 11. -- Governor Lehman announced today the veto of the Crews bill which would have made mandatory an eight-hour day and forty-eight-hour week for all employes of the New York City subway system and fix a schedule of overtime pay.

GENEVA, April 11. -- One more week of diplomacy -- this time at Geneva instead of London -- and how does it leave the prospects of peace and collective security and how hopeful or otherwise are those who are in the thick of it?

College rowing made its 1936 debut in the East yesterday on the Harlem River with Columbia defeating Manhattan in all four races of an informal regatta. It was informal in name only, however, for the competition was keen and several hundred spectators lined the Speedway wall to watch the races.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 11 (AP). -- The Prophet, handsome bay gelding owned by Flying Horse Farms and ridden by Jack Skinner, had enough in reserve to beat off the challenge of five of America's best steeplechasers and win the Middleburg Hunt Cup, feature event of the Spring races held over the Glenwood course today.

THE Dramatists Guild's proffered basic agreement is an edict, not an agreement. The words are those of Arthur Hopkins, a wiser, more temperate observer than most of us. They express succinctly the feeling of the most radical of the embattled producers.

NEVER before has there been such a wealth of travel literature as confronts the tourist this season. Not only steamship companies and travel bureaus, but educational associations, peace foundations and student bodies are offering programs of events in foreign lands, with directions of how best to get there.

FAIRFIELD, Ill., April 11. -- Senator Borah, who enlivened his Illinois campaign yesterday by charging that the great corporate interests were spending perhaps as much as a million dollars to defeat him in the State's Presidential preference voting Tuesday, reiterated this accusation today.

IT is the purpose of Drs. Haggard and Fry to present in this book an analysis and description of the structural elements of personality, to the end that the reader, thus learning out of what roots and under what determining conditions his character has been formed, can with wisdom and understanding undertake the task of improving it.

AMINIATURE model city, complete from jail to Y.M.C.A., was recently built in thirteen weeks at a total outlay of 60 cents by 125 boys of the Stamford (Conn.) High School. The boys were of a group who disliked academis studies and were lingering in school more or less under legal compulsion up to the 16-year school-leaving age.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 11. -- Spring at Vassar College has brought more than a change of weather. Already the extensive gardens are attracting the attention of students, and as the grass grows greener, the trees, deciduous and evergreen, again dominate the landscape.

On my return after a short absence from the city I have before me your editorial of March 29 in which you comment on the increase in motor vehicle fatalities, and the need for proper compensation for the victims of accidents. Compulsory liability insurance, tried in Massachusetts and elsewhere has, as you rightly point out, never been successful.

Next Wednesday, the day on which the eleventh and final round of the United States championship preliminaries will be played at the Manhattan, Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Clubs in this city, will witness the start of the international masters' tournament at the second annual Easter chess congress of the Kent County Chess Association at Margate, England.

Despite the continued business and industrial improvement of the past year, a survey of the relief situation in New York City shows that Federal, State and city taxpayers are supporting about 25 per cent more persons at a cost of about 50 per cent more than before WPA went into effect.

The more Michael Tolleroy delves into the mystery of the death of Theodore Stonebridge the more he wonders just how the man died. There are several possibilities, but the only thing that is certain is that Stonebridge is very dead indeed. Inspector Daugherty of the Atlantic City police thinks he knows who did the killing, but Tolleroy is not so sure.

A large luncheon and fashion show will be held Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Emergency Shelter. More than 250 persons of prominence in society are expected to attend the function, which will take place before an interesting stage decoration representing a Spring rock garden.

The pamphlet report of the Alabama Power Company for 1935, issued yesterday, shows that net income after all deductions was $3,023,384, equal to $8.23 each on 367,178 combined shares of preferred stock, compared with $2,760,269, or $7.52 a share, in 1934.

THERE will be no place in the 1936 national political campaign for the old-time spellbinder, according to Dr. Thomas H. Reed, chairman of the Committee on Civic Education by Radio, who asserts in a report to the Radio Institute of Audible Arts that one of radio's greatest achievements has been "to put leather lungs out of business."

IN any gathering, even of fairly distinguished persons, there is often some one figure which stands out with special distinction. That was the impression Bertha Kalich made on me, suggesting the name of a Judith, Queen Elizabeth, Maria Stuart, Rachel, Sarah Bernhardt.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 11. -- Two hundred investigators, working in fourteen squads, intensified their search late today for the sender of the "Easter-gift" bombs, when the finding of fingerprints on four unexploded packages opened up a new line of inquiry.

DUBLIN. -- On Easter Monday the minds of Irishmen will go back to the day, twenty years before, when Patrick Pearse and six others issued their proclamation declaring an Irish republic and set in motion the train of events that was to lead to the establishment of the Irish Free State.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- A "yes" and "no" answer was given to the House Military Committee today to the question whether the War Department knew in 1932 about plans to divert surplus supplies from charity to business.

THIS new study and interpretation of the personality, life and times of the famous mistress of Henri II is not merely another of the yellowish scandal chronicles which too many authors are given to writing when they turn their attention to the light o' loves that have decorated the paths of European kings.

Unless an amendment to the Clayton Act to curb unfair trade practices is passed at the present session of Congress, leaders in the food industry, it was indicated here yesterday, will attempt to achieve the same ends by the voluntary observance of the rules recommended by the National Food and Grocery Conference Committee.

Josef B. Foerster's latest opera, "Bloud" ("The Fool"), based on Tolstoy's folk-tale "The Pilgrim," was given its world premiere recently at the National Theatre in Prague. The Czech composer has become more and more mystic in his more recent operas, and he proved to be especially so in this new work, which exploits the idea that the unswerving faith of a fool -- that is, a person with clouded mentality -- leads directly to God.

Pedals flying, 100 enthusiastic cyclists sped up and down the Mall in Central Park yesterday morning as the Park Department's opening of its first bicycle path was marked with a colorful parade portraying the history of the two-wheeled, foot-propelled vehicle.

New York State delegates to the Republican National Convention were urged yesterday in letters sent to them by the Committee on Public Affairs of the UnionLeague Club to support a declaration on "sound money," meaning a currency based on the gold standard, for inclusion in the party platform.

NO people on earth, probably, appreciate more than the Chinese a sympathetic understanding of their civilization and a knowledge of their language and literature. Louis Laloy is well equipped in both respects, and in addition already had a wide circle of Chinese friends before making what was apparently his first visit to China.

As the eighth biennial convention of the National League of American Pen Women opens this afternoon with a reception in the Burlington Hotel in Washington, a full delegation of thirteen members and alternates is in attendance from the New York branch to further the candidacy of Mrs. Clyde Robertson for the office of national president.

A NEW annual book award has been instituted by the American Booksellers Association, to be given at the annual convention of the association. It is called the National Book Award, and the judges will be the booksellers in all parts of the country, who will make their selections from a list compiled by a central New York committee of seven members and revised by a national committee of fifteen booksellers in different cities.

THE Fifth Annual Narcissus Show of the Garden Club of Virginia will be held in the armory at Alexandria, Va., on April 15 and 16. On April 16 and 17 the Thirteenth Annual Daffodil Show of the Maryland Daffodil Society, under the auspices of the Federated Garden Clubs of Maryland, will be held at the Guilford Community Church at Baltimore.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Early disposition of the case of Major Gen. Johnson Hagood was indicated today after the general talked with the President for the second time within three weeks.

A group of educators has just completed the organization of a national association to develop art education in public, parochial, private and professional schools, colleges and universities throughout the country. It will be known as the National Association for Art Education.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 11. -- Individual brilliance stood the New York All-Star rugby team in good stead as it pounded out a 10-3 triumph over a well-rounded Montreal All-Star fifteen today at the Nassau College of N.Y.U. grounds.

The final surge of pre-Easter buying pushed retail sales figures to high levels in most of the Federal Reserve Districts throughout the country last week, although rainy and unseasonably cold weather had a retarding effect on trade in some sections.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- At the end of the next three weeks the nature of the Republican convention at Cleveland will probably have been foretold.

HAVING spent hopeful days spreading maps over the dining room table, the New York motorist and his family are ready to start the annual road parade -- eager to forget the drab city scenes of Winter in the bright landscapes of early Spring in the country.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 11. -- Setting a pace during the morning running that none of the others could approach, Gray Rock Flash captured first money late today in the open all-age stake, chief event of the twenty-fifth anniversary meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Association, which is being held in the covers of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club.

Bitter and sweet are adroitly mixed in "Such an Enmity." A charming villa on the Riviera is the setting for a cleverly mysterious murder plot which wavers between success and failure. The wealthy and aristocratic guests assembled at this seaside paradise are an ill-assorted group, bristling with animosities, open and secret.

An entirely new-fashioned set of sails is to be used on the America's Cup defender Rainbow when she is brought out in June to race the Yankee during a Summer campaign. It really will be an experimental dress for her in view of the expected challenge from T.O.M. Sopwith for an international match next year with his new Endeavour II.

ALTHOUGH in his writing John Galsworthy, because of his objectivity of approach and treatment, and his frequently satiric purpose, seems one of the least autobiographical of novelists, this admirably executed book by H.V. Marrot shows that often the tie between Galsworthy's life and works was a very close one.

An illustration of the harmful taxes being levied by Congress is provided by the Social Security Act. Justification for this act encounters a dilemma. As a means of creating a reserve against future troubles, its operation should be deferred until current expenses can be met.

P. Garino and A.S. Cornhill tied for the High-Over-All Cup in the registered shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each finished with a card of 97 out of 100 targets. Garino won the extra string, 24 to 23.

KANSAS CITY, April 11. -- The flying hostess may well expect a career of romance and adventure, for it is a fascinating life that goes along with the hazards strikingly illustrated in the experience of Nellie Granger, plucky heroine of the recent crash of the big transport plane on a mountain near Uniontown, Pa.

In your article in THE TIMES of April 5 on the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts you characterized as "drivel" the "ad lib comment and interviews" during the intermissions. Yet it seems to me that you have overlooked an important point or two.

HAMILTON, N.Y., April 11. -- To give Colgate students a more rounded education and fit them for actual careers the university will try next Fall the experiment of having combination majors in social science.

PITTSBURGH, April 10. -- Whatever is to be the final judgment on the Roosevelt New Deal, it seems destined at least to be credited with restoring the two-party system to Pennsylvania, which for many years was one-sidedly Republican.
TOLEDO, April 11. -- Pioneering with the idea of settling labor disputes within its own confines, Toledo has decided to finance its own Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- About 600 "hunger marchers," members of the newly formed Unemployed Workers Alliance, singing, shouting and waving banners, paraded for miles through the capital today under heavy police guard.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 11. -- The Town Club of Scarsdale took its stand this week with those who have been urging that the Westchester Commission on Government, headed by Carl H. Pforzheimer, should not attempt complete reorganization of county and local governments in one step.

THE Secretary of Agriculture, Henry A. Wallace, has recently approved the use of $1,300,000 for the purpose of stimulating field tests for new uses of cotton in highway construction. Two programs are planned. The first provides for the diversion of manufactured cotton fabric for use as a reinforcement membrane in bituminous surface-treated highways and the second for the diversion of cotton for use in cotton mats for the curing of concrete pavements.

EVERY country has its horse folklore. In Nuremberg you are shown imprints in the castle's stone parapet and are told they are the hoof marks of the steed of a certain bandit baron of the Middle Ages, who escaped by jumping his horse off the battlements and galloping away safe and sound, notwithstanding a sheer drop of more than a hundred feet.

The Rhine -- A European river which last week was very much in the thoughts of Foreign Minister Flandin of France; it rises in Switzerland; part of it forms the Franco-German frontier, part of it is wholly German, part of it is wholly Dutch; once it was the fortified boundary of the Roman Empire; always it has been a battleground.

THE Cord front-drive car, which was announced by the Auburn company at the Automobile Show last November, is now in regular production, it was reported last week, and accumulated orders for it are being filled as rapidly as possible.

LONG neglected, the Finnish cranberry growers of Cape Cod seem to be edging their way into fiction. Over a year ago Elizabeth Eastman described their way of life in a competent, accurate novel called "Sun on Their Shoulders"; now they figure again in another and very different story.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., formerly Health Commissioner of New York State, became guardian of the entire nation's health this week, taking up the duties of Surgeon General which Dr. Hugh S. Cumming had laid down after sixteen years of service.

THE Boy Scouts of America, an entity in themselves, are also a link in a far-flung international chain. That chain runs through seventy-three lands and is forged by more than 2,500,000 boys who subscribe to similar ideals and engage in a similar program.

A large stained and painted glass window of the early sixteenth century, depicting scenes from the life of the Virgin Mary, was sold in eleven sections yesterday afternoon at Rains Galleries, 12 East Forty-ninth Street, for a total of $10,375.

"America must make an effort for better understanding of the culture, civilization and psychology of Oriental people to get along in trade relations and international intercourse in the Pacific," said Dr. David L. Crawford, president of the University of Hawaii, in an interview last week at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- Temple University lost a hard fought game to the Penn Athletic Club nine today, 5 to 2.
PARIS, April 9. -- The Duchess of Kent, who recently flew to Belgrade, looked very chic as she stepped out of the plane at Le Bourget. She was wearing Schiaparelli's famous black wool valentine suit.

The philanthropies furthered by the New York Women's Auxiliary Bible Society will be aided by an illustrated talk on Brittany and the Bretons by Mrs. Hewitt Bailly the morning of April 29 in the main ballroom of the Pierre. Mrs. Bailly will wear several original Breton costumes.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The Ways and Means subcommittee drafting tax legislation reached a tentative agreement today to tax stock dividends where those dividends are paid in such a way that the payment changes the relative interest of the stockholders in the corporation concerned.

THE salt marshland on which old Fort Pulaski of Georgia was constructed is being changed into sweet soil through the efforts of the National Park Service. Built on an island and once considered impregnable, the historic fortress is now being restored for tourists.

A collection of American period furniture and decorations, including Duncan Phyfe examples, English and French porcelains, early American and decorative silver and other objects, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Saturday afternoon.

THE turn of the wheel of fashion in gardening is bringing back into use many flowers long neglected. The "modernistic'' trend in landscaping, particularly, is increasing the use of flowers of one kind in solid masses for block color effects.

The national lawyers committee of the American Liberty League, in upholding the Supreme Court's majority opinion invalidating the AAA as legally sound, cites as one fundamental proposition on which that opinion rests, "that Congress has not the power to take from one private group for the personal benefit of another private group."

GENEVA, April 11. -- The League of Nations received today from the Turkish Government the text of a note urging revision of the Straits Convention signed at Lausanne in 1923, providing for freedom of transit through the Dardanelles and their demilitarization.

A trout breakfast is the latest project for a philanthropic cause to have enlisted the interest and support of a group of younger members of society. Taking as their inspirational note the opening of the New Jersey trout-fishing season on Wednesday, a special committee of arrangements has planned a fishing party for the season's opening, to be followed by the breakfast next Sunday at the Lombardy.

I deplore a growing tendency on the part of newspaper columnists to cite long lists of short, unrelated facts about the height of the Washington Monument, blackstrap molasses, or the breakfasts of movie actresses.

Another sailorman has gone in for motor boating, at least part of the way. George Ratsey of City Island, known on two sides of the Atlantic wherever canvas fills in a breeze, has bought a new Richardson cruiser, painted her blue, installed some extra accessories and has christened her Zaidette.

CHICAGO, April 11. -- I confidently believe the American League will enjoy an exciting and interesting race in 1936. I know the baseball public will agree with me when I say there are four clubs -- Detroit, New York, Boston and Cleveland -- that figure they have a chance to win the championship.
RADIO'S amateur hour "craze" has spread across the sea as evidenced by the fact that the British Broadcasting Corporation has relaxed its ban on programs provided by singing and dramatic societies.

TIENTSIN, China, April 11. -- The fact that another staggering reduction in the Chinese Central Government's finances and a further blow at its control in North China are impending was revealed here today by Major Gen. Hayao Tada, commander of the Japanese forces in North China.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The United States will urge other nations of the world to re-examine and restate the rights of neutrals under international law, Secretary of State Cordell Hull told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee during secret hearings on neutrality legislation at the beginning of this session of Congress, according to an expurgated report of these proceedings made public today.

Marriage is no barrier to insanity, but it serves as an indicator against the probability of latently developing mental disorders and, when successful, is a sign of good mental health, it was declared yesterday at the seventh Spring meeting of the New York branch of the American Psychological Association, held at Fordham University.

ONE of the vernal symbols in New York's restaurants is Spring lamb and mint sauce; with it one brackets broiled chicken, young and tender, and the new crop of roast ducklings. The seasonal consumption of these foods stirs the markets and the butcher shops into new activity, for New York has a keen appetite for the meats of early Spring.

Officials of oil companies operating in Venezuela, who have returned recently from that country have reported that although groups of professional agitators took advantage of the excitement following the death of General Gomez to endeavor to incite class strife and hatred of foreigners, all indications now point to a continuation of Venezuela's policy of protecting foreign investments and of stimulating the development of its natural resources, particularly oil.

THE temporary set-back caused by cooler weather, frosty nights and cold rains is likely to bring a false sense of security to gardeners who feel that there will be, as a result, an extension of time for accomplishing early Spring work.

BEL AIR, Md., April 11. -- More than 700 men and women, including WPA workers and members of New York organizations, clashed with State police at Bel Air, Md., today in a dispute based largely on refusal of cafes in that place to serve Negro members of the delegation, which was on the way to attend a convention of unemployed at Washington.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 11. -- President Conant of Harvard, who completed this week a revolutionary reorganization of the university's methods of training secondary school teachers and educational administrators, announced tonight that a number of scholarships, with maximum stipends of $1,000 each, would be given this Spring to college graduates who enter next Fall on the course of study for the new degree of Master of Arts in Teaching.

Heart-throb fiction can be brightly written, amusing, and fairly human. In "It's You I Want" Allene Corliss does a good job of handling heavy romance with a light touch. Her theme deals with the pangs of young love among the moderns of Boston and New York.

After weeks of intensive drilling, during which the weather was never up even to average but for which enthusiasm never lagged, professional baseball's sixteen major league clubs will toe the mark this week with the opening of the National and American League pennant races.
MANILA, P.I. (AP). -- New York and Chicago have their fleets of taxicabs; Japan and China have their thousands of rickshaws and Manila has her carromatas.

The interest burden under which many railroads faltered and some lapsed into bankruptcy in recent years is being steadily lightened. Interest on the aggregate of railroad debt began to decrease as far back as 1933. This reduction is now proceeding rapidly as a result of low money rates.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 11. -- Two thousand chemists and industrialists will participate in the ninety-first meeting of the American Chemical Society, which will be held here next week from Monday until Friday. More than 300 papers and addresses reporting new research and showing chemistry's expanding influence will be presented.

CARBONDALE, Ill., April 11. -- Senator Borah delivered the final speech of his Illinois campaign before a large audience at the Southern Illinois Teachers College here tonight. He reiterated his charge that the heart of his opposition for the Republican Presidential nomination is "the monopolistic and plutocratic rich, who are destroying economic freedom and political liberty in the United States."

The possibility of the passage at this session of Congress of an amended Federal Pure Food and Drugs Act became more favorable last week than it has been in months, sponsors of the legislation declared here yesterday, as a special subcommittee of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee began intensive work on a revision of the Copeland bill.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- Sharp dissension among members of the special House committee investigating the Townsend old-age pension movement was disclosed today from within the committee.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 -- Embracing an estimated total of 9,000,000 words on topics ranging from the chemical composition of old coins to New Deal measures, the annual deluge of theses by Princeton University seniors began to flood the desks of faculty members this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10. -- Bad luck follows Herbert Hoover with ironic persistency as his carefully worked out plan for an uninstructed delegation from California to the Cleveland Convention runs head on into the ambitions and whims of Governor Frank F. Merriam and William Randolph Hearst.

ON May 13 last year there was sold at public auction in London the important collection of Walt Whitman manuscripts, letters and books formed by his close friend, biographer and literary executor, the late Dr. Richard Maurice Bucke.
Scoring an average of a point an inning, Edward Lee, New York contender in the world's amateur three-cushion bililard championship, captured his third victory in the tourney last night.
WAINWRIGHT, Alberta, April 11. -- To all appearances, "Social Credit" is actually to be tried out in Alberta within the next six weeks.

If the predictions of the Weather Bureau are correct, participants in the traditional Easter Day parade on Fifth Avenue today will display the latest styles in raincoats, umbrellas and other rainy weather accouterments instead of the preferred Spring attire of top hats, striped trousers and morning coats for the men and dainty, flowery creations for the women.

MEYRIC R. ROGERS, in his catalogue introduction, estimates that the life of aristocratic Venetians in the eighteenth century was "a continuous round of entertainment." Since the republic was "finished" as a world power, there may well have appeared little use in bothering about "problems of state, or what might lie in the future."

Easter week is bringing once again a party that for many years has been one of the important events of the Spring season -- the annual Butterfly Ball in behalf of the House of Rest. The entertainment will take place on Tuesday night in the main ballroom and Oval Restaurant of the Ritz-Carlton and for the third successive year it will be held as a dinner dance.

IN order to dramatize a new trend in art education, thirty-two public school of Greater New York, New Jersey and Long Island -- together with public, private and parochial schools throughout the country -- will take part in an exhibition of paintings by children, to open here on Tuesday.

More than 2,000 bundles of merchandise have already been exchanged for tickets of admission to the Thrift House formal dance Thursday evening at the Hotel Astor. The benefit celebrates the third anniversary of the founding of the original shop by Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, and will be also the first entertainment given for the chain of shops into which it has been expanded.

PATERSON, N.J., April 11. -- In several hundred shops in Paterson men and their wives, their children and their relatives, who used to work for wages as silk weavers, are now discovering that it is catastrophic to be owners of their own looms.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Thanks to its "rainstormer," a machine recently developed by the Forest Service to produce artificial and controllable rain, new light has been thrown on the causes of floods.

Private family welfare agencies gave individualized aid, including "planning for tomorrow," to 37,732 of the city's distressed families last year, it was disclosed yesterday by Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee's campaign for a minimum of $1,500,000 for the support of the private family welfare agencies.

LONDON, April 10. -- The International situation has become so horribly, so almost incredibly, grotesque that the British Cabinet is indulging in the desperate faith that something must happen soon to awaken Europe out of its nightmare and restore a sense of reality.

AN unusual exhibition has been arranged (through April) at the National Arts Club. Selected work by neighboring organizations is on view. The Greenwich Society of Artists, the New Rochelle Art Association, Scarsdale Woman's Club, Silvermine Guild of Artists, Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild, Westfield Art Association and Yonkers Art Association are represented.

FAR on the horizon there are signs that a youth movement, long prophesied, is making its appearance upon the American scene -- more insistent, gaunt-faced, eager-eyed young people press the claims of their baffled generation upon the nation.
OHIO State University, a pioneer among the educational institutions that have extended their influence by aid of the radio, reports success with two new departures in this field.

Bulb gardeners will want this new book on their pet subject. The author deals comprehensively with all the true bulbs, even including among these the Western native bulbous plants for use in Eastern gardens. He has provided less exhaustive material on most of the tubers and corms, the dahlia, gladiolus, iris, , and has added even native orchids and a chapter on indoor Winter gardening.

MOST of the recent novels of farm life -- and we have had a plethora of them in the past few seasons -- have been dedicated to the development of a point of view. Their authors, on the one hand, portray for the reader the ugliness and hardship of the farmer's life, the bitterness of his struggle to wring a livelihood from his debt-burdened acres.

SOMETHING to rattle the breakfast table cups this morning should be the news that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought the American rights to the R.C. Sherriff-Jeanne de Casalis "St. Helena." Specifically, M-G-M has acquired it for production here next season by its own little Napoleon of West Forty-second Street.

THIS is the first statement we have issued on the managers' reception of our new contract. We have kept quiet for a whole series of reasons. The publicizing of any argument between playwrights and producers is bad for the public's interest in plays.

Despite somewhat unfavorable weather, last-minute Easter shopping was heavy in the metropolitan area last week. Most department stores here showed substantial gains over the corresponding week last year and also over the sales figures for the pre-Easter week of 1935.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, April 11. -- The Petty family was torn in a political split today as a result of the decision of Charles Petty, the father, to run for the Democratic nomination for Congress, while Emery Petty, the son, county chairman, is strongly supporting Representative Otha D. Wearin for re-nomination.

I do not believe that any fears should be felt upon the part of the traveling public about American ships. Our safety standards certainly are equal to the requirements of any other nation. This does not mean that we are not endeavoring constantly to bring about greater standards of safety and efficiency of seamanship.

MEDFORD, Mass., April 11. -- The Graduate Society of Tufts College, a unique dramatic group composed mostly of those who were members of the Thespians in their student days, will present its annual Spring production next Friday evening in Jackson Gymnasium.

Six persons were injured shortly after 7 o'clock last night in Brooklyn when a westbound Bay Ridge Avenue trolley car left the tracks at Eighty-sixth Street and Twenty-third Avenue and crashed into a pillar of the West End elevated line.

With the aid of a grant of $42,500 by the Rockefeller Foundation Drs. L.A. MAYNARD, C.M. MCCAY and S.A. ASDELL of Cornell are to discover what effect diet has on longevity. For years they have been collecting evidence which show that if white rats grow slowly they live longer.

MOSCOW, April 11. -- The Soviet Government lately has been paying subsidies of more than 10 rubles per ton of coal and more than 20 rubles per ton of pigiron produced. A decree issued today withdrawing the subsidies promised the current year would see a further reduction in production costs.

SUGAR has played a singularly romantic part in the drama of industry and commerce. Nations have waged war to establish sugar monopolies or to avoid paying tribute to such monopolies. Territories have been seized, colonies founded, piracies encouraged, tariffs imposed and bounties offered, with strife and bloodshed as an all-too-frequent result.

LONDON, April 11. -- Edgar Wallace seldom wrote melodrama with more shivers and suspense in it than "The Frog," the spectacular thriller that came to Prince's Theatre tonight, adapted by Ian Hay from Mr. Wallace's novel, "The Fellowship of the Frog."

CAIRO, Ill., April 11 (AP). -- United States engineers asserted that "there is nothing to worry about" as the swollen Ohio River gave evidence tonight of a definite check in the rush of its flood waters into the broad Mississippi.

IF the Philharmonic-Symphony directors had deliberately intended to surprise their constituents, they could not have made a more unexpected choice of a new conductor than John Barbirolli. To a few persons who read the English papers the name was vaguely familiar.

COLLECTORS of antique weathervanes value them not only as quaint reminders of the life of Colonial days but as authentic examples of the folk art of the period. In the days when farmers and seafaring people made up the greater part of the population, these vanes imparted information on which to base important forecasts.

The New York racing season on Jockey Club tracks, greatest and most important in the country, will be launched on Wednesday with the running of the Paumonok Handicap at Jamaica, and ending Oct. 31 at Empire City. In all 171 days of racing are scheduled, the programs of the five associations being studded once more with renewals of the rich and historic stakes which are the most famous on this side of the ocean.

THE prevalence of tailored suits this season has called into being many sorts of false fronts to wear with them, in place of blouses. Some of these false fronts, held in at the waist with a belt, can also be worn with light wool or silk dresses.

LONDON Is trying to eliminate the cockney accent from its schools. "Cockney'' is said to be one of the worst handicaps a boy can have after leaving school. Phonographs and records have accordingly been installed in the schools in order to teach pupils correct diction, in the hope that the cockney pupil will presently disappear into the past as the cockney teacher has done.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 11. -- Captain Wilmer Allison took an hour off from his golf game today and teamed with John Van Ryn as the United States Davis Cup doubles team to clinch the North American zone series with Mexico, three matches to none.

This new volume by John C. Wister is not, as the title might indicate, a beginner's handbook or a seasonal garden narrative It is a well thought-out and admirably executed book for the use of the more advanced gardener. Unusual material for the finest effects in every type of garden is given special attention.

More than 500 teachers of speech in Eastern schools and colleges are expected to attend the annual convention of the Eastern Public Speaking Conference Friday and Saturday at the Hotel New Yorker. Speakers will include Dr. Alfred Adler and Professors W. Cabell Greet of Bernard, John Theobald of Amherst, William S. Howell of Princeton, James A. Winans of Dartmouth, Norman Mattis of Harvard, W.M. Parrish of Pittsburgh and Dr. Lyman Bryson of Teachers College, Columbia.

Marking the second year of sustained improvement in trade, the net profits in 1935 of most leading retail concerns showed substantial gains over 1934, according to analysis of the annual reports thus far made public by these companies.

Believing that the Sugar Institute decision has given trade associations a broader base on which to operate, the Trade Association Executives in New York City will this week appoint a committee to study the decision and its implications thoroughly and to make recommendations to the membership as a whole.

WASHINGTON. DESPITE the controversy that has continued these many years as to whether Robert E. Lee was ever in fact offered command of the Union Army by President Lincoln, the men and women who seek to perpetuate the memory of this great soldier will soon take another step to establish the making and refusal of this offer as one of the episodes in American history.

PITTSBURGH, April 11 (AP). -- A radio operator repeated today the last words of worry heard from Pilot Otto Ferguson before the TWA's Sun Racer crashed on a mountainside near Uniontown on Tuesday killing eleven persons and injuring three.

Young Graham Trench, an American archaeologist, was in China heading an expedition to do some deep digging in the Gobi Desert. Somehow he got sidetracked. With the Boxer rebellion brewing, Trench found himself romantically drawn into a plot to restore the Buddha Seal to its rightful keeper, the young emperor.
PARIS, April 10. -- During the past week another French Government has in the name of the French people presented to the world a picture of what they would like Europe to look like.

TOKYO, April 11. -- Japan will not sign the new London naval treaty, it was reiterated here today in reply to foreign intimations to the contrary. On the other hand, she will not contravene the treaty.

AT last we are able to get at the truth about Senator Borah. He is the moralist in politics, and, more than that, a moral force. Such is the impression that steadily takes form in following this skillfully compiled account of everything he has done or, equally important, prevented from being done.

MENTALLY retarded children in Newark's "Binet classes" are coming into their own, thanks to the lowly harmonica. The Binet teachers decided last year to build up the confidence of their backward pupils by musical work. Casting about for inexpensive instruments, they hit upon the harmonica and now the pupils of whole schools are learning to play.

OMAHA, Neb., April 10. -- Iowa politics took a turn for the picturesque this week with the return of Smith W. Brookhart, former lieutenant colonel in the United States Army, crack rifle shot, ballistics expert and former United States Senator, to his home State and the Republican party.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Army engineers have found that the exclusive use of tidal power for the $36,000,000 Passamaquoddy project will run to a higher cost than original estimates indicated and are understood to have recommended that a Diesel power plant be constructed to pump some of the water.

PARIS, April 10. -- Coming to Paris from Berlin has never been a longer journey, now that all that is German in Germany and all that is French in France are accentuated and intensified. The physical distance is constantly shortened by planes and non-stop trains, but the spiritual distance increases.

APPARENTLY the authorities in Russia are not inclined to treat serious traffic offenses lightly. In a recent dispatch from Moscow, it was reported that one K. Urazov had been sentenced to be shot for driving while intoxicated and causing an accident in which a horse was killed and three persons injured.

Winding up his campaign for Republican votes in next Tuesday's primary in Illinois, Senator BORAH emerges as the champion of three issues. He is against "entanglements" with Europe. He is against "monopoly" in industry. And he is against reciprocal trade treaties.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 11. -- George Bean is getting out circulars for the auction sale of the furniture that Calvin Coolidge bought when he married Grace Goodhue, the blithe young teacher from the Clark School and took half a house on Massasoit Street.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 11. -- Mid-year examinations and semester grades in full-year courses will be eliminated at Brown University next year as another step in a series of readjustments in the university's program.

A drive to obtain 1,000,000 books for redistribution to New York City hospitals, prisons and charitable institutions will culminate with Book-Sharing Week, next Thursday through April 23. This was announced yesterday by the Book-Sharing Week committee, headed by Warden Lewis E. Lawes Sing Sing prison and Mrs. Sherman Post Haight as co-chairmen.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 11. -- An attempt at Yale to frame new requirements for membership election to the Phi Beta Kappa Society Chapter is attracting widespread attention. If an amendment, to be submitted at the chapter meeting next Tuesday, is passed, high scholarship ratings will no longer be the sole requirement in the election at the end of the senior year.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP). -- L.A. McLean, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said today that the nation's banks were forced into an unsound investment policy under operation of Title 11 of the National Housing Act.

TO my son Gustav," opens father Max Born, the grand savant of our times and father in a spiritual sense to many an outstanding genius in physics. Thereupon follows a book in which every effort has been made to talk down kindly, wittily, but with a set purpose to educate.

LONDON, April 11. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned from Geneva today well satisfied with having averted a deadlock over the Rhineland, but troubled and discouraged over the immediate outlook in the Italo-Ethiopian struggle.

What will Hitler's next move be? Though only a month has gone by since German troops, contrary to treaty obligations, marched into the Rhineland, Europe is less interested in punishing the Nazi leader for that move than in preventing his next one.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau will entertain at dinner tomorrow evening in honor of K.P. Chen, head of a delegation of Chinese bankers and government officials now in this country. Mr. Chen is managing director of the Shanghai Commercial and Savings Bank and a member of the standing committee of five of the Currency Reserve Board of China.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- A full investigation of the charges and practices of railroads, their carloading and freight-forwarding business, was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to determine whether present methods were "inconsistent with honest, economical and efficient management."

HILDEGARDE HAWTHORNE has made Longfellow a living figure in this book. She writes of him with sympathy and understanding, presenting him in relation to his times and the circle of friends and acquaintance that surrounded him.

Charges that American ships are manned by a large percentage of foreign seamen were denied yesterday by ship operators. Every ship serving as a carrier of the mails and thus benefiting by the government's subsidizing policy is required by law to carry a crew made up of Americans to the extent of at least two-thirds of its personnel, it was pointed out.

UNIVERSITY EXTENSION at Columbia University celebrates a double anniversary this month. Professor James C. Egbert is being honored for his long service as dean of the department, which began with its inception twenty-five years ago, and also for having been affiliated with the university for half a century.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 11. -For the first time in the history of the women's North and South golf championships, the title has been won by a Massachusetts player. Miss Deborah Verry of Worcester, Mass., captured the honors today in a final-round victory over Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., but only after they had battled over the regular eighteen holes and one extra.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 11. -- One of the largest events of the week was the cocktail party Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr. gave today at their home.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10. -- The terms company police and coal and iron police recurred frequently in dispatches from the anthracite region relating to rioting late last week between coal company guards and bootleg coal miners.

AMERICA is lining up for the noisy game of party politics. The leaders are out in front calling for supporters. Soon the contest will begin in all earnest. But what does it all mean? Politics in America has always been confusing, and often it might be said: "Scratch a Democrat and you'll find a Republican."

THE hatless hidalgo, Don Vernon Gomez of the Yankees, came swinging along with a brown overcoat draped like a Castilian cape over his left shoulder, thus protecting his valuable left arm from the inclement weather. Except for the uniform cap that he wears, under injunction, on the field of play, Senor Gomez never bothers to protect his head with a hat, no matter what the weather or the season of the year.

The National League has every reason to launch into the 1936 baseball season with enthusiasm. It's the league's sixtieth birthday year and in each city we plan a "birthday celebration" which will bring together the players and fans of all the decades that have passed into history since the National League was organized in 1876.

DANIELSVILLE, Ga., April 11. -- A Negro farmer accused of an attempt to assault a white girl was rescued from the Madison County jail today by National Guardsmen after a mob had stormed the place in an effort to get him.

THE sky was rosy with the promise of sunrise on a Summer morning in 1825 when a wagonette drawn by a single horse set forth from Boston carrying Samuel A. Worcester and his bride, Ann, on their wedding journey to their future home among the Cherokee Indians.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., April 11. -- Heirs of Senator Bronson M. Cutting of New Mexico, who was killed last Summer in an airplane crash, have presented his collection of 4,000 phonograph records to Swarthmore College.
PIERRE, S.D., April 11. -- The South Dakota State coal mine, a venture into private business, has been finally eliminated, after more than three years of effort to dispose of it at any price.

The "Great Luciano," droop-eyed and unwholesomely dark, stared in disbelief when a dapper young operative on the staff of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey broke in on his meditations in Hot Springs, Ark., a few days ago and thrust a warrant at him. Anger flooded his face a deeper shade.
I cannot tell you with what interest I read your article in last Sunday's TIMES regarding the al most circus performance which goes on in the intermission of the opera broadcasts.

OUR various museums continue to contribute in generous measure to the panorama of art world activities. Before taking up new shows that enliven the roster it may be well to allude for a moment to certain recent accessions.

Four speakers survived preliminary trials in Manhattan College's traditional oratorical contest for the Grady Memorial Medal last week, thus qualifying for the finals of the forty-eighth annual competition, to be held as part of the Campus Day exercises, Sunday, May 3.

PRAGUE, April 11. -- Two years of protracted negotiations between the underground leaders of the Austrian Socialist and Communist movements finally have resulted in the formation of a united front, the latest Arbeiter Zeitung announced. This action is not a fusion of parties but "war comradeship."
BOWIE, Md., April 11. -- Irrepressible, Purple Knight and Good Harvest enabled Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, owner of the largest string of thoroughbreds in America, to sweep both stakes here today.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The divided decision of the Supreme Court of the United States pronounced this week in the controversy between J. Edward Jones and the Securities and Exchange Commission again revealed the characteristic cleavage of opinion between the members of the court on problems arising out of the relation of government to the individual.

BERLIN, April 11. -- The institute founded by Chancellor Adolf Hitler for rewriting German history, notably modern history, according to National Socialist ideas announced today that its grant from the government had been substantially increased and that it will now expand its program.

Asserting the Securities and Exchange Acts of 1933 and 1934 represented constitutionally valid control of stock sales in interstate commerce, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday issued a preliminary injunction prohibiting Torr Co., Ellery W. Mann and thirteen other defendants from trading in the stock of the TransLux Daylight Picture Screen Corporation.

EUROPE is in a race to build powerful long-range verbal radio "guns." Words are the ammunition, kilowatts the powder, statesmen and propagandists are the men whose tongues release the electrified "shells." That is the picture American radio engineers bring home from recent trips to the Old World.

Major Gem Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area of the United States Army, announced yesterday that 2,520 reserve officers from New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Puerto Rico would be assigned to active duty for fourteen-day periods this Summer.

SHE is a vision in lace, the Spring bride, whose wedding party is developed in a symphony of azalea pinks. Her gown is entirely of Alencon lace, sheer as a cobweb; even her veil is of the same. Its delicate thread pattern shadows her face with an illusive mystery when, as she walks up the aisle, it is worn down.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 10. -- Attendance at Townsend meetings in the Northwest is as large and apparently as enthusiastic as ever, but area and district leaders of the Old Age Revolving Pension movement are said to be worried over the manner in which the flow of nickels and dimes in many districts is dwindling to a mere trickle.

When the Spanish Conquistadors led by Hernando Cortes subdued the Aztecs of Mexico in the sixteenth century they set up a two-class system; a small privileged class of landowners and a large unprivileged class of laborers and semi-serfs, the peons. That condition slumbered through the centuries until the French Revolution stirred echoes in New Spain.

Sixty-five New York City public junior high schools began last week final preparations for their elimination round in the teachers' contest on the Constitution which is being conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Their entries closed on April 1, and Benjamin Veit, district superintendent, announced yesterday the five districts into which he had divided these schools for purposes of final judging.

Bridal gowns of bygone eras as well as those of the present time will be worn by women of society in a novel fashion revue, "Brides of Two Centuries," to be a feature of the luncheon hour on Tuesday, at the formal opening of the Garden Room of the Park Lane, with the Goddard Neighborhood Center as the beneficiary.

Early season yachtsmen who instead of getting their boats into water during May are speeding their work to go to sea in April will find some weird sights among the buoys, spars, beacons and other aids to navigation. Throughout Eastern cruising waters the February and March floods destroyed hundreds of markers.

Excitement pervaded the lower East Side yesterday afternoon as 500 boys, from 5 to 13 years old, engaged in a feverish and noisy search for 3,800 eggs of the natural, candy and jelly bean varieties. It was the third annual Easter Egg Hunt of the Gramercy Boys Club, 535 East Sixteenth Street.

Whether the membership of the United States in the International Labor Organization is worth while is a question recently raised in Congress by Mr. McMillan, chairman of the Appropriations Committee of the House. In presenting H.R. 12098, which provides appropriations for the Departments of State, Justice, Commerce and Labor.

Many dinner and supper parties will be given at the formal opening of the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria on May 7, from which the Humane Society will benefit. During the evening there will divertissements by professionals.

Both national advertisers and retailers should cooperate to select the strong points in each other's sales and advertising systems and borrow these good points without delay, Kenneth M. Goode, president of the Sales Executive Club of New York, declared yesterday, in commenting on the speech of Paul M. Murphy, advertising manager of Frederick Loeser Co., before the club last week.

COMPLETED plans indicate that the annual convention of the National Council of State Garden Clubs, to be held in Dallas, Texas, April 20, 21 and 22, will be of unusual interest to visiting garden club delegates from other States.

Sororities at Hunter College pledged seventy-eight new members this term, thirty-four fewer than received bids last Spring, according to an announcement today by Miss Selma Goldstone, chairman of the Pan-Hellenic Association of Hunter. Miss Goldstone attributed the 30 per cent decrease to the "rush" fee and increased scholastic requisites, introduced this season for the first time.

It is time indeed that a book should appear dealing exclusively with the versatile tuberous-rooted begonia. Gardeners with shady locations in which they hope for Summer bloom will welcome this excellent little book by George Otten, who has been a practical student of this plant for more than fifty years.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The first local golf tournament of the season, the sixth annual Old Dominion golf championships, will be played on the Cascades and Homestead courses during the coming week, commencing tomorrow.

ACCORDING to news dispatches and communications sent direct to this department of THE TIMES, the Russian composer Shostakovich has been ordered by the Soviet Government to take in the future an entirely different direction than the one he took in his opera, "Lady Macbeth of Mzensk."

This is a practical handbook for the use of the gardener who wishes to grow delphiniums successfully. The author, who is the editor of The American Delphinium Society Bulletin, and who has devoted the past few years of his life to solving the cultural problems of this lovely plant, is eminently qualified to convey the information presented here.

The Archbishop of Canterbury renews a request which he recently made to a conference of Christian communions of England, Wales and Scotland, but to which he would give wider appeal at this season in the face of the world's difficulties and dangers.

Sandwiched between a holiday and a Sunday, the short trading session in the share market yesterday was one of the most listless and colorless in recent months. Many of the larger traders remained away from the Street to stretch the Good Friday pause into a three-day holiday, which, together with the complete cessation of trading in foreign markets, tended further to dull activity here.
PARIS, April 11. -- This Easter lull has been received in Paris with the feeling that it presages a climax in international affairs at Geneva next week.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 11. -- The Summer session at Rutgers University will open June 29 and continue until Aug. 8, with an anticipated enrollment of about 1,000, Dr. Clarence E. Partch, dean of the School of Education, announced today.

This volume stands alone as a standard work on the subject. Invaluable to the scientist and the commercial grower, the text has been carefully planned to make all its information available to the layman. No technical language is employed in the main body of the book.

IN some sections Easter trade was pronounced the best in six years as the holiday peak was passed last week. Weather conditions in other areas held clown volume so that it was just about even with a year ago. While the bulk of the business was done upon apparel and dress accessories, the expansion of giftware buying was commented upon, and the season is beginning to take on some of the aspects of Christmas trade.

For the testing of flying boat hulls, seaplane floats and kindred objects, a towing basin will be opened at the Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics, New York University, at 12:30 P.M., Tuesday, Dr. Alexander Klemin, director of the school, said yesterday.

Brooklyn police continued their search yesterday for two men identified from photographs by Paul H. Wendel, Trenton (N.J.) attorney, as members of the group whom he accuses of kidnapping and torturing him to obtain a false "confession" of the kidnapping of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The Association for the Legalizing of American Lotteries, Inc., and the Grand National Treasure Hunt, Inc., applied today to the District of Columbia Supreme Court for an injunction to restrain Postmaster General Farley from enforcing a fraud order issued yesterday against them in connection with a $100,000 cartoon contest.

Miss Betty Morris, daughter of the late Mrs. Lewis Gouverneur Morris, who for many years was active in the interests of the New York Women's League for Animals, heads the group that has charge of the sale of tickets for the song recital to be given Wednesday afternoon at the home of James Speyer, 1,058 Fifth Avenue, for the benefit of the league.

ROME, April 11. -- Great emphasis is laid here on the unsatisfactory nature of the reply made by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Great Britain to the query of Baron Pompeo Aloisi at Geneva yesterday as to whether Italy's participation in the Locarno powers' deliberations was welcome.
