Charging that there had been an "illegal" delivery of $1,250,000 par value United States Treasury bonds and notes to two high officials of the War Department about the time of the Maryland banking holiday of 1933, the Baltimore Trust Corporation sued in Federal court yesterday to recover the value of the securities from the Chase National Bank of New York City, through which they were sold.

A large group of horticulturists, whose names are to be found in Mr. Seymour's introduction to the book, have written this impressive garden encyclopedia, which, considering the amount and the wide range of the subject matter, sells at an amazingly low price.

If our mystery writers do not stop writing about murders in hospitals patients are going to be more nervous than they already are. It is bad enough to worry about one's appendix, or whatever it is that the doctors are going to remove, without lying awake nights wondering whether some fiend in human form isn't slinking along the corridors with murderous intent.

JAMAICA is now at the height of the most prosperous Winter tourist season in its history, with hotels filled to capacity and steamship and air lines unable to accommodate the demand for transportation to that island. Hitherto known chiefly as a port of call for cruise ships, this largest of the British West Indies islands has suddenly taken a favored place on the tourist map.

THE "fatal generals" about whom E.V. Westrate writes in this book are those who lost in contact with the enemy an appalling number of combatants, not necessarily those who failed to carry the enemy's lines and achieve victory.

Dr. Francis E. Townsend, author of the Townsend old-age-pension plan, declared last night that the movement had been strengthened by the withdrawal of R.E. Clements, co-founder of the organization, and Representative John S. McGroarty of California, Congressional sponsor of proposed Townsend plan legislation.

Admittedly without a direct clue to the slayer's identity, the police turned to science yesterday to help them track down the man who on Friday criminally attacked and strangled Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, 34-year-old author and book reviewer, whose body was found in the bathtub of her apartment at 22 Beekman Place.

More than a score of band leaders discussed plans of aiding the strike of arrangers, copyists and proofreaders against music publishing houses of New York City at a conference called yesterday morning by the Musicians Union, Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, 1,265 Sixth Avenue.
RICHMOND, Va., April 11. -- Jimmy Thomson, Shawnee-on-the-Delaware pro, who learned to play golf here ten years ago, returned to win the $3,000 Richmond open today with a sub-par 285.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 11. -- The University of Southern California track and field team took its first step of the Olympic year to defend coast and national championships by overwhelming the University of California today, 93 to 38.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 11. -- With the plans completed, Lehigh University will greet the host of wrestlers who will converge here next week for the Olympic mat team finals. The tests are slated for Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11. -The Navy lacrosse team today downed the Princeton ten, 8 -- 5, on Poe Field. It was the first defeat in collegiate competition for the Tigers in twenty-one games over a period of three years.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Shipments of tear gas, pistols and munitions to large corporations coincided with strike activities and union organization drives, according to witnesses who testified today before the La Follette subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Education and Labor.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- By 1942 the United States Navy will have reached its full treaty strength and will be on a par with that of Great Britain, second to none in the world, according to present plans.

Forecasts of the chances of their teams were made yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the managers of the three local major league baseball clubs. The statements of Bill Terry of the Giants, Joe McCarthy of the Yankees and Casey Stengel of the Dodgers follow:

AFTER a year or two of indecision and mediocrity the Theatre Guild is concluding one of its brightest seasons. "If This Be Treason," "The Taming of the Shrew," "Porgy and Bess," "Call It a Day," "End of Summer" and "Idiot's Delight" -- that is a pretty notable program.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- A sharp increase in business activity took place in the week ended on April 4, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

A NATIONAL highway safety program which, by means of wide educational activities, will attempt to reduce automobile accidents and deaths is now in operation. It is being promoted by a group of national organizations, including the International Association of Chiefs of Police, General Federation of Women's Clubs, National Congress of Patents and Teachers, American Legion and American Automobile Association.

RICHMOND, April 11. -- Weather conditions this week were unfavorable, but pre-Easter retail business in the Fifth District broke all records for the last six years, and wholesale houses also report a heavy demand.

In the death last Friday of LEOPOLD VON HOESCH, German Ambassador to the Court of St. James since 1932, Germany and the whole of Europe suffers loss. A gentleman trained in the best traditions of the old diplomacy and immune to the contagion of violent, swashbuckling nationalism, he devoted his life to easing the relations between his country and its Western neighbors.

Echoes of Chancellor HITLER'S record-breaking 98.7 per cent plebiscite continue to be heard. The Berlin reports speak of doubts asserting themselves in the Nazi camp. The more intelligent leaders now wonder if the victory was not too big and may not yet turn out to be a boomerang.

BERLIN, April 11 (AP). -- Military pomp and splendor reminiscent of the heyday of the former Emperor Wilhelm will for the first time attend Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's forty-seventh birthday anniversary April 20.

Members of the Middle Atlantic Division of the Association of Bank Women and their guests, the women's committee of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking, will be entertained Friday at a tea at the head office of the Chase National Bank at 18 Pine Street.

MADRID, April 10. -- In an atmosphere of highly contradictory opinions, Niceto Alcala Zamora's abrupt dismissal from the Presidency of the Spanish Republic by a Cortes vote on a Socialist motion is still producing heated polemics here. It was an event of much importance in the life of the young republic.

THERE are signs at last of a concerted movement to protect authors from the risks to which they are exposed through the present unsatisfactory state of the law of literary libel. A powerful plea for drastic reform has been published in The Times over the signatures of thirty-four of the most distinguished living English writers -- novelists, poets, essayists and critics.

ALTHOUGH Mr. Gerald Yorke says in his introduction that because of his comparatively short stay in China he is not yet fully qualified to write seriously about the country, this is not the impression that one is likely to carry away after a reading of the book.

DODGE CITY, Kan., April 10. -George E. Farrell, who will administer the soil subsidy plan enacted to replace the invalidated AAA in the Western and Midwestern States, came to the hard-wheat country this week to sell the "doubting Thomases" on the plan.

MISS JOHNSON is Associate Professor of English at Wellesley College, and it should be said at the very beginning that her professorial attainments are of the right kind. She informs, yet holds our attention while doing so. Scholarly throughout, and basing many of her conclusions on original research, she retains enough humanity to make her book a thrilling one not alone to the faithful Elia but almost to any lover of critical biography.

Nineteen houses of the City College House Plan held elections during the Easter vacation naming fifty-seven undergraduate leaders. Officers of the central governing council were also elected by the members of the extracurricular activity center. Solomon Chaiken was named president; Edward Schecter, vice president; Frederick Udall, controller, and Kay Michelson, secretary.

Increasing traffic on the nation's air lines and the use of larger airships will necessitate an outlay by the aviation industry this year of about $20,000,000 for new manufacturing and air-terminal facilities, W.J. Austin, president of the Austin Company, estimated yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 11. -- Herman F. Whiton's new six-meter yacht Indian Scout today won the third race of the international series for the Prince of Wales Cup. Raymond Hunt's Silroc, one of the Boston boats, came in second, giving the United States team the first two places.

Mrs. Harry Fargo Ostrander of Seattle, who is at the St. Regis, gave a dinner last night in the King Cole Room and a supper later in the Maisonette Russe to celebrate the birthday of her daughter, Miss Alice Fargo Ostrander, which occurs today.

However conservative or reactionary one may be, it requires a mind of even unusual narrowness and sourness not to appreciate high mental and moral distinction when it is found in opponents of one's cherished fundamental notions of politics, legislation and government.

This English book on garden design will be of great value to landscape architects and to those who have country estates which must be landscaped. It will prove of interest, too, to many others. Though there is one chapter on small gardens, the main text of the book and most of the fine photogravures deal with the gardens of great English estates.

HOLLYWOOD. ON the eve of launching commercial television in England -- an event of considerable import to Gaumont-British and other United Kingdom film concerns -- the American cinema industry, as represented by Hollywood, continues to view the possibility of competition in the home with detached interest, almost with apathy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 11. -- The Westchester Music Festival Association, which succeeded the Westchester County Recreation Commission as sponsor of the annual song festivals, today announced programs for the festival which will be held on May 8 and 9 at the County Center.

ST. LOUIS, April 11. -- Unseasonable weather, with disastrous storms in its trade area, have had a decidedly retarding effect upon many business lines in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week. Retail trade has felt the lack of demand for Spring goods, delayed by cold weather, and in many instances is running close to last year's total.

AMONG the difficult problems confronting the amateur who wishes to construct a rock garden or a wild garden is the elemental one of "laying out" the plot. To make a plan for such a garden is a task entirely different from planning a formal garden or a hardy border.

PARIS. THE opening of the Horse Show affords the first opportunity of seeing the new Spring daytime fashions as they are actually worn. At the Auteuil races the elegance displayed depends upon the weather; at the Horse Show there is an outdoor atmosphere combined with indoor protection.

Net profits in 1935 of the Mead Corporation and subsidiaries, book paper and fiber board manufacturers, amounted to $501,607 after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal and State income taxes and other charges. After allowing for annual dividend requirements on the $6 preferred stock on which accumulated dividends at the end of the year amounted to $19.50 a share, the earnings were equal to 51 cents each on 588,450 no-par shares of common stock.

That time-honored slogan of this land of opportunity -- every boy a potential President -- doesn't take into account the wishes of the boys. If statistics made public last week are representative, less than 10 per cent of them dream about the White House.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The Denver Stock Exchange has requested permission to withdraw its registration as a national securities Exchange, the Securities Exchange Commission announced today. The commission made known, too, that the Exchange had reserved the right, subject to certain conditions stipulated by the SEC, to ask for reinstatement at some time in the future.

The relief fund of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross for the benefit of flood and tornado victims reached $574,152.63 yesterday, it was announced by General Robert C. Davis, executive director.

Candidates for the $250 scholarship of the Barnard-in-Bergen Club must have their applications in by Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Arthur Roth of Rutherford, N.J., chairman of the scholarship committee. Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College will address the club that evening at 8:15 o'clock in the lounge of the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood at a joint meeting with the Northern Valley Chapter of the A.A.U.W.

LIEUT. COL. JUSTROW (retired) of the German Army has a low opinion of the German steel helmet and expresses it in Die Umschau. He thinks the helmet has fine, severe, soldierly Roman lines, but that it is a poor thing.

MR. TATE'S book is partly on the correspondence of poetry and ideas, and partly on their distinction. It is a mixed book of essays that roves from a fairly academic note on Donne to a polemic on Humanism, from "The Profession of Letters in the south" to Emily Dickinson and her New England background; but it comes back to a point that is suggested by the title word, reactionary.

As the Ethiopian question becomes critical again in the League of Nations, the Italians are apparently determined to seize all of Ethiopia, as Mussolini threatened last August before the campaign actually started. He said last week that all Ethiopians bearing arms must be annihilated; and his armies move south at accelerated speed.

More than 1,400 Jewish children have been transported from Germany to Palestine and settled, mostly in agricultural colonies, through the Youth Aliyah, a movement for the transfer of Jewish children between the ages of 15 and 17 from Germany, according to Mrs. Ilse Warburg, formerly of Berlin and now of Haifa, Palestine.

ALONG the Atlantic seaboard visiting Westerners have long bristled to the phrase that "many good men have come out of the West, but the sooner they come, the better they are." Mr. McNally's second novel should do a good bit toward restoring the West's dignity.

ALBANY, April 11. -- While the battle over Governor Lehman's executive budget bills has been in progress at the Capitol, the controversy over his anti-crime program has been temporarily hushed. Some of the most important measures of his program for the better enforcement of the criminal law either have been defeated or else are still awaiting final action by the Legislature.

Fashion shows of varied character have been arranged for the near future in behalf of charitable organizations. Under the auspices of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House a parade of styles entitled the Golden Wedding Fashion Show will take place tomorrow afternoon in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the flood sufferers.

The French franc continued to decline in the foreign exchange market yesterday, although dealings here were restricted by the influence of the general holidays abroad. Quotations fell to 6.58 11-16 cents and closed at 6.58 7/8 cents, off 1/8 point net.

LUDOVICO ROCCA'S "The Dybbuk," one of the most successful of new operas, will be given its New York premiere May 13 in Carnegie Hall, when it will be performed, under the sponsorship of the Detroit Civic Opera Company, with Franco Ghione as conductor.
PARIS, April 11. -- Advance glimpses of hat and dressmaking ateliers disclosed today what chic Parisiennes will wear in tomorrow's Easter parades.

LUCKNOW, India, April 11 (AP). -- Tens of thousands of members of the Indian National Congress camped in temporary shelters on the outskirts of Lucknow tonight, awaiting the opening of the annual session tomorrow.

The 1936 Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament schedule has just been released by Miss Josephine Windle, chairman. There are a few changes on the program and several indications, such as more handicaps, an increase in club dues and several new trophies, that this year is going to be better than ever for the association.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- The administration's tax program and WPA appropriations were assailed tonight by Senator Hastings as political moves designed to further the New Deal in the campaign.

The American Merchant Marine Library Association, of which President Roosevelt is honorary president, will begin its fifteenth annual drive, Seamen's Book Week, on April 20 with a dinner at the River Club. The campaign will continue through April 25 in an effort to obtain 50,000 books urgently needed to replenish libraries now in use in ships of the merchant marine, among stations of the United States Coast Guard and lighthouse keepers.

ROANOKE, Va., April 11 (AP). -- Virginia Republicans meeting in convention today refrained from instructing delegates, expressed "confidence in the fitness" of Governor Landon of Kansas for President, declined to oppose Senator Carter Glass, veteran Democrat, and cheered and applauded two attacks on the Roosevelt administration.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 11. -- Will Gallop, Mrs. Julius Bliss's aged chestnut gelding, took the jumping championship at the Round Hill Club Stables' ninth annual Spring Horse Show tonight after close competition.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The organization of Labor's Non-Partisan League, which has for its "1936 purpose" the re-election of President Roosevelt, is regarded here as a significant undertaking that may be the precursor of an American labor party or a third party of labor, farmer, Liberal and Progressive elements.

POTSDAM, N.Y., April 11 (AP). -- Representative Bertrand H. Snell, House minority leader, said today that he was confident that the St. Lawrence River treaty would be ratified at the next session of Congress.

MANY men came under the influence of Adolphus Washington Greely during his fruitful life, which began on March 27, 1844, when Tyler was President, and ended last October, a span of nearly ninety-two years. One of Greely's disciples was William Mitchell, who as a lad of 18 sat in the Senate gallery and listened to the declaration of war against Spain.

Once more Mrs. Hill uses her well-tried formula of story-telling and religion. In "April Gold" she demonstrates how a family down on their luck win happiness and wealth by living clean, thinking right and trusting in God. The Reeds lost their father, their house and their money almost simultaneously.

President Roosevelt's annual escape to southern waters, where he fishes, swims and enjoys the sun, was postponed this Spring until March 23 by the flood disaster in the North. The last days of his cruise, which ended on Wednesday, were clouded by news of another disaster, the tornado which took more than 400 lives in the South.

THE transport crash at Uniontown, Pa., last Tuesday has raised the question of the proper functioning of the radio beam on that part of the Newark-Pittsburgh Airway. The facts will be determined by official investigation.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- President Roosevelt's scheduled speech to be delivered Monday night under the auspices of the Young Democrats of America, on which he began serious work today with the realization that it would be broadcast over the nation-wide radio networks, is expected by persons closest to him to be the forerunner of a campaign for re-election more active than that waged by any other President with the possible exception of Woodrow Wilson.

English garden books are welcomed by American readers even though they know that climatic conditions here are so different that much of their information must be discounted for American use. In the present volume a chapter has been added by J.E. Spingarn on Clematis in the United States and to this extent at least cognizance has been taken of the needs of American readers.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- The year-old contest between Harold Ickes and Harry Hopkins over the handling of relief funds headed for the White House again tonight in a new form.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony, under the baton of Arturo Toscanini, will present an all-Debussy program this week, with the assistance of Bidu Sayao, Brazilian soprano; Rose Bampton, contralto, and fifty-six women from the chorus of the Schola Cantorum of New York.

Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas leads in a poll of members of the New York Young Republican Club on their preference for a Presidential candidate, Paul Y. Williams, president of the club, announced yesterday. The position of the club will be determined by the result of the poll, which is not yet complete.

UNIQUE among graduate schools is the Institute of Paper Chemistry, affiliated with Lawrence College, Appleton, Wis. Established five years ago to prepare students for research and production work in the pulp and paper industry, it represents an original attack upon the age-old effort to bridge the gap that separates educational institutions from industry.

ALTHOUGH it is a regional novel in the narrowest sense of the word, wholly dependent on its unusual and flavorsome background, "Rain on the Just" evokes freshly and forthrightly the folk-ways of a vanishing race. The Brushy Mountains district of North Carolina is the setting of Mrs. Morehouse's story.
Your article in today's TIMES on "Comment for Opera Broadcasts" struck a very true note. Undoubtedly there are many who could reveal to you similar between-the-acts harmful broadcasts.

Due to the brilliant performance which it enjoyed, with Mishel Piastro as soloist, Goldmark's violin concerto, though musically none too exciting, proved the outstanding feature of last night's Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concert in Carnegie Hall.

ROME, April 11 (AP). -- Easter Eve brought Rome only faint memories tonight of the profitable days of yore, when thousands of tourists and Pilgrims flocked here to participate in the colorful and joyous commemoration of the Resurrection.

TOYOHIKO KAGAWA must be accounted as being one of the greatest and most powerful men in Japan, if spiritual power and exceptional achievement are admitted as valid criteria. His marvelous, it might almost be called miraculous, story was published in the United States several years ago and some of his books have appeared here in translation.

THE current exhibition at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee serves to raise distinctly the average of exhibitions at that institution. Among the more widely known artists represented are John Sloan and A.S. Baylinson, the former with "Semi-Nude, Red Hair" and "Bonfire in the Snow" and the latter with two typical canvases -- "Ethiopian Belle" and "Flower Composition."

The petroleum industry must curtail the amount of crude oil run to refinery stills if it is to liquidate the surplus gasoline now in storage by the end of the Summer season, according to the American Petroleum Institute's committee on supply and demand.

Joe McCarthy's Yankees finally won a decision over Casey Stengel's Dodgers when they emerged from the semi-darkness and fog at Ebbets Field yesterday, after two and a half hours of drab baseball, on the long end of a 6-3 score.

On the grounds in old Bedford Village, N.Y., on Friday the Southern New York Field Trial Club will open its ninth annual Spring field trial meeting, contestants to be worked on liberated quail. Entries will close on Thursday and drawings will be held that evening at 8 o'clock in the City Hall at White Plains, N.Y.

The nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange will present to the membership tomorrow its official slate of officers to be voted upon at the annual election on May 11. Whereas in 1935 the incumbent failed of renomination for the presidency after a pre-election contest which split members into factions, this year it is generally conceded that Charles R. Gay will be selected again as president without opposition.

NEW ORLEANS, April 11 (AP). -- Colonel Robert B. Watts, associate general counsel for the National Labor Relations Board, filed a petition today in the Fifth United States Circuit Court of Appeals requesting enforcement of the board's order to the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh to cease interference with union activities of its employes.

A city-wide search for Mrs. Sophia Macht, 35 years old, of Baltimore, undertaken in an effort to prevent her from making an attempt at suicide, failed late last night when she plunged from a 25-foot wall upon the pavement of the Sunken Gardens in the Plaza of Rockefeller Center.

LONDON. -- In the first two years of the World War, on the blood-soaked fields of Flanders and in Gallipoli, the seed was sown of the crisis now afflicting the Conservative party in Great Britain. For there went to their death in thousands the youths who, in the normal course of events, would have become the leaders of politics and business today.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 11 (AP) -The last of the 1935 titleholders entered the domain of past champions, today when the doubles team of Clyde Sumerix and Harry Souers of Akron, Ohio, rolled a weak 1,031 series in the American Bowling Congress tournament. They won the doubles at Syracuse last year with 1,348.

At the conclusion of the hearings held by the House Ways and Means Committee on the projected plan to tax undistributed corporate earnings it was announced that the proposal to substitute a flat rate of tax for graduated rates had been defeated and that certain members of the committee, to the exclusion of others, would proceed with the drafting of the bill along the lines of tax reform as originally outlined by President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes was 74 today, but took only little note of it.

Julia Cummins has done all in her power in this book to instruct the beginner in methods which will produce successful results. In addition to the rudiments of home flower-growing she has included chapters on the creation of the simpler types of gardens.

MUCH construction work will be done this year on the Eastern State Parkway, one of the principal routes radiating from the metropolitan area. At the present time it extends from its connection with the Bronx River Parkway Extension, in the vicinity of Yorktown, northerly to the Cold Spring-Carmel Road, State Route 301.

Police officials in charge of the Titterton murder investigation yesterday announced that they were using the most modern scientific methods known to criminology in searching for clues to the identity of the killer.

When you go to a tackle store to buy a new fly rod, how do you test its action? You probably grab the grip, hold the rod out at arm's length and give it a few tentative wiggles. If it "feels" right -- depending on whether you are looking for limberness or stiffness -- and the price fits your purse, you tell the salesman to wrap it up.

Once again Great Britain has assumed the role of conciliator between Paris and Berlin. Undaunted by the discouraging results of his previous efforts to get concessions from Chancellor Hitler, the British Foreign Minister has undertaken to question the German Government on a series of points and to report back to the other Locarno powers next month.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- A peek at some of the costs in a major Supreme Court case, usually not disclosed, was provided today by the protest of the Sugar Institute against paying about $5,000 for printing extra court exhibits.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- In his classic treatise, "Physics of the Air," published some years ago, Dr. W.J. Humphreys of the United States Weather Bureau writes of the tornado: "We infer that there are adjacent, presumably superjacent, currents of air of different sources where and whenever tornadoes are likely to occur."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 11. -- Boston College won from the Naval Academy on the diamond today, 10 to 6. Each team made four errors and the hitting was practically even but keener work in the field and on the bases gave the visitors the margin.

THE eyes of many travelers are turning this season toward the Pacific. The great drawback to Eastern travel -- although one goes west to get to the Eastern lands -- always has been the expense of long journeys.
ROME, April 10 -- One of the curious things about the Italo- Ethiopian controversy is that Premier Mussolini has never come out in the open and stated clearly what he wants in East Africa.

AVIATION note: In a pretty, new Stinson four-seater cabin plane Pilot Ruth Chatterton -- the Amelia Earhart of Beverly Hills -- landed at Roosevelt Field, L.I., late one afternoon last week on her third day out of Los Angeles.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 11. -- Two Cornell University seniors from the New York metropolitan area took leading honors in the 1936 Forbes Heermans prize contest, just awarded for the third year, for the best original one-act plays on an American theme.

Several hundred delegates representing 200 clubs with an aggregate membership of 35,000 will compose the assembly of the tenth biennial convention of the New York State Federation of Music Clubs, opening Wednesday. The occasion will mark the retirement from the presidency of Mrs. Etta Hamilton Morris of Brooklyn, who has held office for eight years.

If it may be said that last week's markets were generally under holiday influence, exception must be made in the case of new bond financing. Approximating $425,000,000 new flotations bulked larger than in any week on record, Treasury financing excluded, even surpassing the busy period of 1928-29, when it seemed that the supply of new corporations and new parts of the globe to be financed was limitless.

This English book by Clarence Elliott is a comprehensive list of rock garden plants alphabetically arranged, with full descriptions and directions for propagation and culture. The several varieties of each species are carefully described with their special uses in the rock garden.
THIS is a book that is stimulating, provocative of thought and courageously honest in every line. As to form and style, it would take a critic with a grouch to find anything to carp

The prelude, if any, is a very brief one, for the first murder in this book is recorded in Chapter One. But perhaps the author considers that killing merely a prelude to the others that are to follow. Be that as it may, there are murders enough and to spare, and the Sheriff of Lakeview County almost gives up in despair.

PITTSBURGH, April 11. -- John A. Young, president of the Federal Laboratories, Inc., said tonight that gas equipment and guns were sold by the laboratories to industrial organizations "at the time riots were occurring," that "equipment wasn't used," and that "there hasn't been any buying since."
I am filled with admiration for your so-right article in yesterday's TIMES with regard to the radio commentary between acts on the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts.

Pan-American Day will be celebrated on Tuesday as a joint observance of historic anniversaries and mutual friendship of the nations of the Americas. On this day the peoples of the Americas reaffirm their faith in the enduring bonds of American solidarity.

There cannot be world peace until the United States abandons its policy of isolation and agrees to cooperate in some form of internationalism. If the League of Nations is not a satisfactory medium, another way must be found to include in a binding covenant all the great military powers, the seven dangers of the world.

NOW that the trout season is open many an angler is able to enjoy a double hobby: that of landing a wary trout -- and with an artificial lure of his own manufacture. To deceive the trout, the artificial insects cast before it must closely resemble the natural flies, nymphs and moths it habitually feeds upon.

The gold-bloc countries must choose either radical remedies to force down their entire level of costs about 20 per cent or a suitable devaluation to bring their level of costs into equilibrium with conditions in Great Britain and the United States, according to Bertil Ohlin, Swedish economist, who discusses the relative position of the gold and sterling blocs in The Index, the quarterly publication of the Svenska Handelsbanken of Stockholm.

THE first annual Print Series of the American Artists School will be available to the public this week. Since Kuniyoshi, Harry Gottlieb, Stuart Davis, Eugene Fitsch and Raphael Soyer are donating their work to the series, the school is able to offer the prints at an unusually moderate price and all proceeds will revert to the school's maintenance fund.

That retailers enjoyed the best Easter business since 1929 was indicated in reports received last week from stores throughout the country by Kirby, Block Co., resident buying office here. Percentage increases were far ahead of planned sales, the office notes in its summary of market conditions prepared especially for THE TIMES.

TO a generation like our own, which is witnessing a rebirth of the American spirit of rebellion against existing social conditions and a revival of the passion for reform, Theodore Parker should be a sympathetic figure, and Professor Commager's book an interesting study.

Fifteen thugs straggled into the fur manufacturing establishment of Weiss Barnett on the fourth floor of 122 West Twenty-seventh Street at 12:50 P.M. yesterday. Their hands bristled with clasp and fur knives, lengths of lead pipe jutted from their pockets.

All members of groups affiliated with the State Federation of Women's Clubs are eligible to attend the Spring conference of the department of fine arts on Friday at the Hotel McAlpin. Mrs. Julian Olney of White Plains, chairman, will have charge of the program, which will consist of addresses during the morning session, a luncheon and an afternoon devoted to conducted tours through Rockefeller Center.

Congressional approval of The Hague rules, providing for uniform bills of lading on ships of nations signatory to the agreement, was obtained last week after fifteen years of effort on the part of traders, shipping companies and others interested in foreign trade.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Members of the national council of the Garden Club of America will be entertained here Friday by the Sand Hills Garden Club, coincident with the annual flower show.

WASHINGTON, Tpril 11. -- With President Roosevelt holding the trowel, the cornerstone of the $12,000,000 Interior Department Building will be laid with appropriate ceremonies on April 16. This will be the first important Federal building in Washington authorized, designed and constructed under the present administration.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 11. -- Indian Broom raced to a new world record and a smashing victory over Top Row in the first running of the $10,000 added Marchbank Handicap at Tanforan today.

In answer to questions raised by Senator Vandenberg, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, reported last week the payment of total AAA benefits of more than $1,000,000 to a Florida sugar corporation, $961,000 to a Puerto Rican sugar producer, $1,022,000 to a Hawaiian sugar concern, $123,000 to a cotton planter, $157,000 to a hog raiser and more than $50,000 to a wheat grower.

When Charles H. Dougherty, 82 years old, heard last September that Congress had voted him the back pay that was owed him for work he had done in a navy yard fifty years earlier, he promised that he would do a "dance" when he received the money.

The American Society for the Relief of Russian Exiles is to benefit from a dinner dance typical of Easter feasts in Czarist Russia on Wednesday in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis. A ribbon decorative scheme, reminiscent of the refectory walls of churches and monasteries in Russia, will enhance the spirit of the old Russian Easter to be celebrated that night, and other observances of the old regime will be in effect.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa. -- A labor colony plan for teaching the "won't-works" the dignity of labor and for training them to be useful members of society will soon be put into operation by the Department of Labor.
Teams in the southern half of the International League are to open their campaigns at home on Thursday, when the circuit's fifty-third season is scheduled to get under way, a day later than usual.

COOPERATION between the heavier and lighter than air factions in aeronautics was indicated in the announcement last week that American Airlines, Inc., and the operators of the new Zeppelin von Hindenburg would cooperate in the handling of dirigible passengers between New York City and Lakehurst, N.J., during the transatlantic demonstration service by the dirigible next Summer.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 11. -- Preparations for the annual departure of the salmon packing fleets from San Francisco and other Pacific Coast ports is affording employment to hundreds of workers loading supplies. The glamour marking the departure of the cannery ships in the days of sail has given way to a strictly business atmosphere.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 11 (AP) -- Marynell, outsider, broke from the barrier with lightning speed in the $5,000 added Texas Frontier Handicap at Arlington Downs today and defeated a fine field, crossing the wire a good length ahead of F.A. Griffith's Sarada.
SINCE the advent of broadcasting, radio announcers have frequently been accused of "talking through their hat." Today an experiment during New York's Easter parade will prove it is entirely possible.

CLEVELAND, April 11. -- Only one member of Bill Terry's Giants traveled as far as third base today against some very fancy flinging by three of Cleveland's first-string pitchers, and the next-to-closing game of this long series went to the Indians, 4 to 0. The victory was the seventh for the American Leaguers, against six for the Giants, with one more to play.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Here are extracts taken from the transcript of Judge Halsted L. Ritter's oral statement to the Senate today concerning the Whitehall Hotel receivership case:

While opposition to the Robinson-Patman Price Discrimination Bill became more vocal and more general among retailers last week, the view was held that the prospects for passage of the measure have not been greatly reduced. Observers here yesterday said the bill stands about an even chance of being enacted into law at this session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- Two publicity agencies tangled today in a dispute over whether Republican National Committee workers were posing as newspaper men to gather information about New Deal affairs.

OUT of the West have come many good ornamental plants. Years ago horticulturists of England and the Continent sent their scouts to America to gather new plants for gardens already rich in varied flora from the Old World and the Orient.

"Garden Variety" is the product of an erudite mind, and in Winter when the lover of the out-of-doors must sit by the fire and look forward to the coming of Spring, it is a pleasant thing to have at call such a volume as this by Sir Arthur Hort.

This volume by four popular English authors is a book to what the gardener's appetite for outdoor activity. The fact that American readers cannot accept all the advice of these British flower growers will not militate against the book's popularity, for after all, "How Does Your Garden Grow?" is a cozy fireside volume -- not a garden manual.
LOS ANGELES, April 11 (AP). -- Defiant in exile, General Plutarco Elias Calles tonight accused the government that banished him of attempting a dictatorship in Mexico "on the Russian plan."

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT is scheduled for two broadcasts this week; tomorrow from 10:30 to 11 P.M., when he speaks before the Young Democratic Clubs of Maryland at the Fifth Regiment Armory, Baltimore. The broadcasters say Mr. Roosevelt "is expected to discuss issues of the forthcoming campaign."

After the strange disappearance of Lord Cobbleigh years pass before it is discovered what has become of him. As one reads Mr. Snaith's narrative, the time seems even longer. The years might well have been decades. In the meantime the reader improves his acquaintance with Wolfgang Amadeus Mumm, the Viennese detective genius; with Thorp Devereux, who is in charge of Mumm's London office, and with Thorp's wife, Mizzi, formerly secretary to the Viennese detective.

AFTER a tour of six months, which included performances in more than a hundred cities, the De Basil Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo returns to New York tonight to open its second engagement of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House.
ATLANTA, April 11. -- Retail trade advanced to new high levels in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The Senate spent all of last week trying a Federal judge for high crimes and misdemeanors in office. It had nothing else to do.

On the eve of the Continental Congress of the D.A.R., scheduled for next week in Washington, young girls from every State in the Union are converging on the capital as winners in the organization's good-citizenship pilgrimage. Their program of entertainment will start Friday and will close on April 21, the second day of the convention.

IN this twentieth century, disease has become the last frontier. The adventurers of today go forth not with axe and rifle but with microscope and test tube, fighting their way amid "invisible and unknown perils" to an unknown goal.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va. -- The Easter parade held at high noon today in the Colonial corridor at the Greenbrier fulfills a tradition of early days, when belles and beaux of the old South gathered here for the seasonal festivities.

TORONTO, April 11. -- Detroit's Red Wings added another championship to the long list boasted by the automobile city in winning the Stanley Cup tonight. The smooth-skating Wing sextet defeated the gallant Toronto Maple Leafs in the fourth game of the cup series by the score of 3 to 2 in what was the best-played contest of the entire round.
THE wedding ceremony is over; rose petals and rice are showering on the bride; she has donned her going-away outfit -- one of the most important items in her trousseau.

An exhibition of antiques and fine arts worth more than $2,000,000 will be shown in the Whitelaw Reid house at Purchase, N.Y., May 16 through May 31, for the benefit of the Westchester County Children's Association, it was announced yesterday.

IT is now more than ten years since Mr. Hackett published his other novel, "That Nice Young Couple," during which time he has achieved for himself a very considerable reputation as a biographer. In the present case his return to fiction may be judged as something of a sentimental journey, for he has returned as well to the Ireland of his youth and used it as something beyond mere background.

THE Garden Dictionary -- which is really an encyclopedia rather than a dictionary -- is so named because it has been admirably planned to be an index to itself. In addition to all the subjects generally included in such a volume, there are numerous exclusive features of great importance.

MAMMOTH CAVE, KY. MAMMOTH CAVE, under the operation of the State and National Governments, and of the public who raised funds with which to purchase this subterranean wonderland, eclipsed all its attendance records for 100 years in 1935, with a registration of 63,852 visitors.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Miami, which in previous years has honored Venezuela, Mexico, Cuba and Colombia, will this season pay tribute to Chile during the city's annual observance of Pan-American Pay on Tuesday. Bayfront Park is to be the scene of a historical play-pageant entitled "O'Higgins of Chile," written for the occasion by Dr. Barbara Ring of Arlington, Mass., and Miami.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Apri 11. -- Three persons were killed early today when the big flying boat Puerto Rican Clipper grazed a launch in the harbor while taking off and "ground looped" on the surface of the water.

ON Easter Monday thousands of children will gather on the south lawn of the White House grounds in Washington to take part in the annual national egg-rolling festival. Some time during the day the President, is expected to step out on the balcony and watch the scene for a few minutes.

At this season, the calendar, both secular and religious, brightens the outlook of mankind. With the Spring men feel that like the earth they are wakening to new life. The joyful celebration and solemn associations of Easter lead to renewed thoughts upon the life everlasting. It is a time of quickened hope.

WITH increased size and range of aircraft and with the risk of fire -- which frequently is a dread aftermath of aircraft accidents even though the ratio of accidents to miles flown continues to decrease -- interest is heightened in the development of oil-burning engines.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11. -- Led by Jimmy Salsich, who counted a try and a conversion, the undefeated Princeton Rugby Club today won its fourth start of the season, downing the New York Rugby Club, 11 -- 5, on a muddy Bedford field.

THE American Bridge League's annual tournament for master players -- those who have previously won contract bridge championships -- is scheduled for this week at the Park Lane Hotel. There is one event for teams of four, and another in which the entrants compete as individuals.

REPORTS are persistent in Manila that a large-scale merger is in the offing whereby aviation services in the islands would be unified and a plan of training evolved for officers of the Philippine Army.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP). -- Inaugurating something new in professional baseball, a Sunday opening, the American Association will start its thirty-fifth championship campaign tomorrow with the same eight clubs that opened the initial race back in 1902.

After a series of weekly meetings held over a period of more than two months, final arrangements have been completed for the Junior League Jubilee to be held on Friday night at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

PALM BEACH. -- Although the thin trickle of departures, now beginning, will rise to full stream in the next few weeks, leaving the majority of villas deserted by June 1, Palm Beach will present anything but its usual tranquil aspect this Summer.

The Pennsylvania Company, a subsidiary of the Pennsylvania Railroad, which holds controlling interests in the Lehigh Valley and Wabash railways, reported for 1935 a net income of $4,791,952, excluding $334,069 net profit from the sale of securities, credited to profit and loss.

In marked contrast with the large volume in the preceding week, the number of separate lots of bonds called last week for payment before maturity was small. The announcements, except for two sizable foreign issues and one large block of Federal Land Bank bonds, were principally for small parts of municipal and public utility loans.

LONDON, April 11. -- Much interest has been aroused in the city by the government's appointment of an expert committee to advise the Treasury regarding the present restrictions on foreign borrowing in London. It is clear from the statement of the Chancellor of the Exchequer in announcing this step that no immediate relaxation in the restrictions is contemplated.

A new regulation reducing the daily creel limit and setting for the first time a season catch limit on State-controlled waters will go into effect when the trout fishing season opens in Connecticut on Wednesday.

Eight saber wielders from this district qualified for the national championship yesterday in the tests conducted under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America on the strips of the New York Athletic Club. A field of twenty candidates started in the competition.

In the tenth and semi-final round of the United States chess championship preliminaries yesterday the leaders generally held their own in their respective sections. The games were played at the Manhattan, Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Clubs.

The de Basil Ballet Russe returned to New York last night for a final Spring season of two weeks at the Metropolitan Opera House, after an arduous six months of touring which included more than 200 performances. Certainly the company must be made up of phenomenal "troupers," for they appeared none the worse for wear, and danced as freshly as if they had never heard of such wearying things as railroad schedules and one-night stands.

TORONTO, April 12 (Canadian Press) . -- Imperial Oil, Ltd., controlled by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, in 1935 had net earnings of $25,229,850, equal to 93.56 cents a share, compared with $25,771,653, equal to 95.73 cents a share, in 1934, according to the annual report issued today.

The Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, had to close its doors yesterday after they had been open to the general public for exactly twenty-five minutes. More than 3,700 persons heard the morning sermon of the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, 1,000 of them being forced to listen over the amplifying system, since seats in the church were filled before the services began.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 12. -- In a heavy fog, a cold wind and a drizzle of rain, nearly 10,000 persons early this morning attended an annual Easter sunrise service here on Eagle Rock. A large number of the congregation listened to the service on automobile radios, while they witnessed through car windows the movements of the speakers and musicians.
DUBLIN, April 12. -- Many persons were hurt here today as Republican extremists honoring the dead of the Easter Week rebellion of 1916 clashed with Communists.

JENA, La., April 12. -- The Paul J. Greens will not have to take turns as "plow horses" this Spring. They have a real horse now, supplied by the Rural Settlement Administration after the family had acted as its own work animal for three years.
Thirty-six awards to men who helped trace Bruno Richard Hauptmann are listed among 313 citations of meritorious police work made public yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12. -- Mrs. J.T. Reynolds, this city's oldest resident, observed her 103d birthday anniversary today by playing the piano and reciting for two-score visitors who called on her at her home, 316 Parker Street.

I wish to compliment and endorse the article written under date of April 7 by your Washington correspondent, Arthur Krock, in which he revived and analyzed the Lewis Douglas proposal for the administration of relief through the technique and in the structure of the Red Cross.

The sixth annual cumulative New York Times Index is now on sale at The Times Annex, 229 West Forty-third Street, it was announced yesterday. The volume, consisting of 2,951 pages, covers all news events of 1935 in summarized form.

A report issued yesterday by David R. Morris, meteorologist of the Federal Meteorological Observatory in Central Park, showed the amount of soot in the air over New York City in March averaged 1.33 tons a cubic mile, which was .22 of a ton less than in February but .10 ton more than in March, 1935.

Seventy-four 3-year-olds have been named for the Preakness Stakes, Maryland's greatest horse race, to be run at Pimlico on May 16, according to an announcement from M.L. Daiger, secretary of the Maryland Jockey Club, which organization is the turf's link between racing of the present day and that of the period of the Revolution.

Real estate continues to hold the ground it has gained and is improving at a steady pace, according to a report on title abstracts issued yesterday by Harry Fromkes, president of the City Abstract Corporation of 42 Broadway. Mr. Fromkes said his organization had prepared titles on properties having a total assessed valuation of $161,140,707 during the first quarter of 1936.

ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP). -- The standout pitching of Earl Caldwell and a three-run rally in the ninth inning gave the Browns of the American League a 7-to-4 exhibition victory before 9,000 fans today in the first of their two-game city series with the Cardinals.
HOUSTON, Texas, April 12. -- In top form, the United States Davis Cup team completed the rout of the Mexican troupe today with the loss of only one set in five matches.

Negotiations about to be closed with the city's bankers will make possible the refunding of outstanding 3 per cent revenue notes on July 1 with securities bearing a 2 per cent rate, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. He estimated that the refunding operation, affecting notes issued on Jan. 1, 1935; July 1, 1935, and Jan. 1, 1936, would result in an interest saving of $500,000 during the life of the notes.

New commitments for finished steel products are in lighter volume than in March, which suggests the leveling off of production, according to the magazine Steel. The publication finds, however, that last week's operations advanced sharply, rising 3 points to 66 1/2 per cent of capacity, the highest rate since June, 1930, when the rate was 68 per cent.

ALBANY, April 12. -- Voicing strong objection to legislation making mandatory additional expenditures by cities, Governor Lehman has vetoed a bill under which custodians and janitors of public buildings in New York City would receive extra pay if the buildings were used for election purposes.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan proposed yesterday that a six-lane bridge to connect mid-Manhattan with Queens and Brooklyn should be built instead of the projected four-lane $58,000,000 vehicular tunnel.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Congress, whose adjournment goal is now set for some date during the first six days of June, starts tomorrow what really amounts to another week of marking time while awaiting a chance to act on the $799,000,000 tax and $1,500,000,000 relief bills, still in the process of formation.

A recommendation that legislation be enacted to permit the incorporation of legitimate labor unions in this State has been forwarded to Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and members of the Legislature by the West Side Association of Commerce in the City of New York, it was announced yesterday.
ALBANY, April 12. -- Legislative leaders are discussing the advisability of submitting a new unemployment relief bond issue to the voters at the Fall election, it was learned tonight at the Capitol.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 12. -- Ranging from the first folio of 1623 to the new Cambridge edition, a special exhibit of Shakespeare's works will be on display in the Princeton University Library for the remainder of April, James Thayer Gerould, librarian, announced today.

Colonel Henry Breckinridge issued a statement yesterday in which he said President Roosevelt had lost "his moral right" to the vote of New Jersey's delegates at the coming Democratic National Convention through his failure to enter the preferential primary in that State.

PITTSBURGH, April 12. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 66 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the preceding week. The rate seems accurately to measure actual ultimate consumption of steel. What little arrearage was caused by the flood had been made up.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 12. -- President Roosevelt has sent word to this city that he will send three Federal investigators to help solve the bomb outrage taht fatally injured two persons and maimed three others Friday.

DELHI, India, April 12. -- A program of advanced socialism was put forward today by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru in his presidential address to the Indian Nationalist Congress party meeting at Lucknow. He praised the Russian economic system and linked the Congress party's policy with the world clash between the ideas of socialism and imperialism.

Several group shows are among the score or more of exhibitions on the calendar for the week following Easter. The New York Water-Color Club will hold its annual show at the American Fine Arts Building, opening with a reception Wednesday evening and to the public on Thursday.
LAWTON, Okla., April 12 (AP). -- About 100,000 persons in a giant natural amphitheatre near here today viewed a sunrise depiction of the nativity, death and resurrection of Jesus.
The Brookhattans defeated the Scots-Americans by 3 to 2 in an American Soccer League game at Starlight Park yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 12. -- Joining in the traffic which makes the Charles River Basin take on the appearance of a national regatta in the late afternoons are the crews of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, moving along, shepherded by the gray-painted coaching launch from the front of which one of the famous veterans of the sport, white mustachioed Bill Haines, roars at them through his coach's megaphone.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., April 12. -- More than 2,000 persons braved the chilly drizzle at dawn this morning to attend the Easter service in the picturesque setting of the hills of Beth Page State Park. The direct result of the interest shown in the service is that it will become a fixture.

What the world needs today is not merely the Golden Rule or the Sermon on the Mount but "the divine authority and the living power of Jesus Christ," the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday in his Easter Day sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.
MOSCOW, April 12. -- A solitary church bell of all the hundreds that used to peal on Russia's pre-revolutionary Easter rang today within hearing of the Kremlin.

The Municipal Art Committee of this city will conduct its first national exhibition of American art this Summer. It will be held in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, from May 18 to July 18.

GENEVA, April 12. -- The Italian and Ethiopian replies to the note of the League of Nations Committee of Thirteen urging the belligerents to observe the conventions of international warfare were made public by the League today.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday expressed support of the campaign to be conducted by the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for a minimum of $1,500,000 to help accredited family welfare agencies meet the extraordinary, demands for help being made upon them.

LONDON, April 11. -- The Bank of England bought a further 300,000 of gold his week, making a total of 1,099,000 of the metal purchased since the beginning of the year. In resuming these operations on a fairly substantial scale, the Bank evidently has in mind the probability that, some time in the current year, the record note circulation of 424,500,000, reached at Christmas time in 1935, may be exceeded.

Marshal BADOGLIO has been ordered by MUSSOLINI to issue a military decree freeing all slaves in Ethiopian territory under the control of the Italian armies. This is no doubt intended to be taken as a part of the civilizing mission which the Italian Government nominally set out upon when it invaded Ethiopia.

MADRID, April 12. -- Exactly five years after the municipal elections that overthrew the monarchy in Spain, political interest is focused today on the various candidacies for President of the republic -- as yet not officially announced.

NEW ORLEANS, April 12. -- There was a somewhat improved volume of trading in the cotton contract market here last week, with rather more trade buying and the usual short covering and evening-up of commitments for the Easter holidays.

JOHN REED was born in a mansion in Oregon and died thirty-three years later in Moscow. Any schoolboy can figure out the linear distance between this start and this finish; it is for those who aspire to end their days amid familiar surroundings, a vast and uncomfortable distance. In the case of John Reed, however, the miles themselves are hardly half the story.

Advertising and merchandising campaigns for Summer will get under way in the liquor industry late this week, distillers and wholesalers agreed yesterday. In many respects, they added, the coming Summer will be the most interesting from a competitive standpoint since the repeal of prohibition.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Liquidation and pressure by bearish interests carried grain prices on the Board of Trade last week to almost the lowest of the season on most deliveries, with low records set in September corn and all deliveries of oats. Weak holders were well shaken out, and a large accumulated short interest placed the markets in an unsettled condition.

Commodity futures markets generally were slightly firmer at the end of the four days of trading last week. Silk futures, however, were moderately easier. A few of the staples were quite strong, principally wool tops, rubber and copper.
Despite rain which continued intermittently until late in the afternoon, more than 7,500 persons were estimated to have attended Easter services on Staten Island yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, April 12 (AP). -- Reserve manpower totaling 300,000 warriors moved into defensive positions across Northern Ethiopia under the personal direction of Emperor Haile Selassie, the government announced today.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Samaria due to arrive today includes Captain R.C. Brown, port warden for Montreal; Mr. and Mrs. Frank Binns, Major and Mrs. F.M. Green, C. Cheever Hardwick, Dr. R.G. Mason, George H. Hemingway, A.S.M. Marshall, Mr. and Mrs. G.C. Krell and F.A. Slack.

MOSCOW, April 12. -- Figures made public today at the Young Communists Congress indicated there had been a great decrease in the observance of religious rites among youths, a decline in the number of early marriages and a noteworthy improvement in the physique of young men called for army service.

LIMA, Peru, April 12 (AP). -- Colonel Ernesto Montagne formed a new Peruvian Cabinet tonight after the ministry headed by Premier Manuel Rodriguez had resigned because of the forthcoming Presidential elections.
M. M. Caretti, as an American, is much perturbed that a "foreign parade" should block Fifth Avenue on St. Patrick's Day, while the Army Day parade is shunted to other routes.
LOS ANGELES, April 12 (AP). -- Defiance of a Congressional subpoena was voiced today by an attorney for Townsend Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., as the inquiry shifted here from Washington.

CLEVELAND, April 12. -- Two home runs by Joe Moore, one of them with the bases filled, carried the Giants to a one-sided conquest of the Indians today before a gathering of 5,000 spectators. The score was 7 to 0.

ALTHOUGH he is as pleased as Punch about the whole thing, Mr. Ike Falk managed to maintain an air of great solemnity in telling the strange tale of how he obtained a season baseball pass, a National League pass signed by President Ford C. Frick, No. 180 on the league list and most assuredly made out to "Mr. Ike Falk and one."

ALBANY, April 12. -- The total number of new stock corporations formed in this State in the first quarter of 1936 was 5,119, it was reported today by the corporation bureau of the office of the Secretary of State. This total is twenty less than the first quarter figure last year.

A 16-year-old Erasmus Hall High School pupil was saved, and another, the grandson of a Brooklyn physician, was reported lost when their canoe capsized shortly after noon yesterday in Jamaica Bay, off Beach 124th Street, Rockaway Beach.
Deals involving houses in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens were announced by real estate brokers over the week-end.

HAVANA, April 12. -- In a unanimous resolution of the Supreme Court, made public today, the administration and lower courts are taken sharply to task for the numerous incidents of the past few months in which prisoners have been killed after their arrest.

Test tubes bubbled, microscope experts bent over slides and a group of police research men pondered possibly important notes yesterday in a laboratory quest for a clue to the person who strangled 34-year-old Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton in her apartment at 22 Beekman Place last Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- James M. Beck, eminent constitutional lawyer, Solicitor General from 1921 to 1925 and member of the House of Representatives from 1927 to 1934, died suddenly at his home today of coronary thrombosis. He would have been 75 years old on July 9.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12. -- About 50,000 persons, many of whom waited several hours in semi-darkness, assembled in the Temple University Stadium here today to hear the story of the Resurrection related at an Easter sunrise service.

MADRID, April 12 (AP). -- The marital happiness of Juan Ignacio Pombo, young Spaniard who flew the Atlantic to win a bride, was menaced by legal difficulties today. The filing of a suit by his mother-in-law to annul the marriage was reported.

An automobile bore down on two Brooklyn girls as they crossed Ocean Avenue at 1 A. M. yesterday, bowled them off their feet and dragged one, a 17-year-old continuation school student, 150 feet along the rain-swept roadway before another motorist forced the driver to the curb by cutting in front of him.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 12 (AP). -Bowlers did their Easter parading with strikes today in the American Bowling Congress tournament and two new names appeared among the leaders.

Greatly improved over their initial showing on Saturday, the Montreal All-Stars terminated a brief invasion here with a well merited 5-3 victory over the French Rugby Club at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, thrilling a small turnout with a remarkable display of aggressiveness.

Cotton futures advanced moderately in last week's abbreviated market, largely under the influence of adverse crop developments supplemented by a belief in the trade that the government selling program for loan cotton was not so bearish as it was first thought in some quarters.

A card party will be held under the auspices of the Service Club of St. Thomas Church tomorrow afternoon in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Church Mission of Help. Already many tables have been reserved for the games.

The influence of Christ is as potent today as it was on the lives of His disciples, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street. He decried the increasing use of alcohol and narcotics, declaring that we have now "a generation of neurotics with broken health and shattered lives."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 12. -The discovery of the existence in the living body of a vast network of hitherto unsuspected power systems, which supply brain, nerve and muscle with the electrical current involved in the translation of messages between mind and body, was reported here today by Professor Edwin J. Cohn of the Harvard Medical School on the eve of the opening of the ninety-first meeting of the American Chemical Society.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP). -- The Kansas City Blue and the Indianapolis Indians furnished the fireworks today as the American Association opened its thirty-fifth season before more than 36,000 fans.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Action in the provision market here last week was influenced largely by the nervousness in the hog market as well as in those for cotton and corn. Speculative buyers absorbed liberal offerings of lard futures, and the cash trade in meats and lard was fair.

The older generation must see that youth gets the facts during the coming Presidential campaign, James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company, declared yesterday in a letter to Robert H. Thayer, chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee for New York City.

Doubtless because the week's favorable industrial news had been anticipated and "discounted" by the advance in stocks which had occurred already -- particularly the rise of 14 points in the "averages" since New Year's Day -- last week's financial markets were all but inanimate.

DETROIT, April 12. -- Herewithem Moscow's Ghost, liver and white pointer owned by R.F. Maloney of Pittsburgh, won the special for best in show today at the close of the twenty-first annual all-breed show of the Detroit Kennel Club in Convention Hall.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Corn traders on the Board of Trade were somewhat surprised last week by the government's report on farm holdings aggregating 776,112,000 bushels, or 40.3 per cent of last year's crop, compared with 436,337,000 bushels, or 39.5 per 'cent, a year ago and 757,030,000 bushels, or 35.6 per cent, two years ago.

Several dinners will be given in advance of the performance of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Society for the Relief of Half Orphan and Destitute Children.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 12. -- The eighteenth annual Easter egg hunt, participated in by the children at the Greenbrier, was held this morning.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 12. -- More hart 350,000 men and women walked up and down the Boardwalk here today in one of the largest Easter parades in recent years. Hotels were crowded to capacity as special trains, buses and motor cars brought visitors from points as faraway as Alabama and Saskatchewan.

The thirteenth annual Easter dawn service under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches was held yesterday morning between 7 and 8 o'clock in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. Bad weather prevented the service from being held from the steps of the univerity library on 116th Street, as had been planned.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Labor unions must decide for themselves what elected officials are to represent their views and the National Labor Relations Board has jurisdiction only to demand recognition by employers of the workers' right to bargain collectively through representatives of their own choosing, the board held in a ruling made public today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 12. -- A fifty-foot section of the boardwalk here collapsed this afternoon, injuring seven women and a boy in a crowd of about 3,000 persons who had gathered in front of a grandstand to see the award of fashion prizes.

LONDON, April 12. The British Government faced today the first real test of its sincerity in having urged discontented nations for the past two years or more to seek redress of their grievances by legal and peaceful methods instead of by force.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 12. -- One week of Spring football practice at Cornell has hardly scratched the surface of the reconstruction job undertaken by Carl Gray Snavely, the new head coach. There's no occasion as yet for predicting the Ithacans will climb out of the "Ivy League" cellar next Fall, particularly as Snavely's first team will tackle the hardest schedule Cornell has had since pre-war days.

Lowering the income-tax brackets, the addition of selective excise taxes if the income tax increase does not yield sufficient revenue, and the imposition of a flat withholding tax on non-resident alien income are proposed in a substitute tax plan offered by the Merchants Association of New York to the House Ways and Means Committee, in place of the proposed revenue bill now under consideration.
CINCINNATI, April 12 (AP). -- Bunching three runs in each of two innings, the world champion Tigers defeated the Reds today, 8 -- 7, before 6,800 fans out to get their first glimpse of the home team.

Your editorial "Not Corruption But Polities" is fine and I agree with all of it except when you say "there is not the slightest reason to question his [President Roosevelt's] sincerity in taking this position [that partisan politics be kept out of relief work].
AKSUM, Ethiopia, Monday, April 13. -- Italian troops have reached the shores of Lake Tana in force. This correspondent saw them today from an airplane.

A 3-year-old boy was rescued at 8:45 o'clock last night from a blazing apartment on the second floor of 430 East Fifty-eighth Street, near Sutton Place, when he was dropped from a window into a coat held by a patrolman and a passerby in the rear yard twenty feet below.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 12. -- Representatives of many foreign nations today joined Danes in a demonstration at Ollerup on the Island of Funen to celebrate the first anniversary of the coming of Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman's Oxford Group movement to Denmark.

MEXICO, D.F., April 12. -- Twenty thousand members of the Confederation of Mexican Workers marched to the National Palace today in demonstration of their gratification over the exiling to the United States of former President Plutarcho Elias Calles.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 12. -- Bill Inslee, who has always been up in the running of the dinghy racing with his boat Smoke, made her go a little faster today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. So doing, he made a clean sweep of four contests for the Class B One-Design boats. He ran up a total of 20 points to 13 for Harry Hall, in second place with his Squaw.
That mentor of aspiring stars, that harker-back to the unforgotten glory of vaudeville's "two-a-day," Gus Edwards, is on Broadway again.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Denial of fifteen applications for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market, in ten instances because the applicants could not be found at the addresses they had given, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The "high cost" of participation in the international labor office has prompted the House Appropriations Committee to recommend that Congress review the entire question of American membership with a review to withdrawal.

St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street, attracted yesterday morning the traditional Easter throng to the 11 o'clock service and an overflow congregation lined four-deep along the avenue despite the damp, cold weather.

The City Affairs Committee and the Welfare Council sent letters yesterday to Timothy J. Sullivan, President of the Board of Aldermen, and leaders and members of the board protesting against the Lyons Residence Bill under which 372 executives and administrative employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau would be dropped.

PITTSBURGH, April 12. -- A new safety glass, a new razor blade, and a forthcoming scientific analysis of the perfect shave, as well as "promising" anti-pneumonia compounds, are among the fourscore developments of the past year listed today in the annual report of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research by E.R. Weidlein, director.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,318,532,100. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

With the view of assuring the future of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra by placing its 1936-37 season "on a sound and permanent basis of increased audiences," the committee on subscription tickets of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society will conduct a large meeting tomorrow morning at Steinway Hall, it was announced yesterday by the society.

CHICAGO. April 12. -- The condition of the Winter wheat plant in the Southwestern States is reported as poor to good, a large percentage of the acreage poor to fair. A little rain has fallen in spots, but more is needed to prevent deterioration.

Pleading for the entry of the United States into the League of Nations, Mrs. Catherine Law Colwell writes to THE TIMES: "In England today, and to a lesser extent on the Continent, the man in the street believes in and wishes to strengthen the League."

Peter Garino took the high-gun cup for the third successive time and the second day in a row at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, breaking 99 out of 100 targets. He carried off the honors in shoot-offs Saturday and last Sunday.

Playing under gray skies, on a swampy field and in a temperature of around 40 apparently was no handicap to the Yankees at Ebbets Field yesterday as they closed out the exhibition series by beating the Dodgers again, 7 to 4. The victory gave the McCarthymen two triumphs in the five games.

ROME, April 12. -- After a rainy night, Easter Sunday dawned bright, sunny and warm, to the delight of the many thousands of visitors who had flocked to Rome, drawn by the spell of the Eternal City at this festive season.

Colonel Roger D. Black, 53-year-old retired army engineer and until recently acting chief of the management branch of the housing division of the local Public Works Administration, was found dead yesterday in his room in the Hotel Woodstock, 127 West Forty-third Street, under circumstances that the police believed warranted a full investigation.

Cardinal Hayes sang the Pontifical Easter Mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. The service began at 11 A.M. and ended at 1:15 P.M. Just before its close the Cardinal, standing at the high altar and facing a kneeling congregation of more than 6,000 persons, lifted his right hand and imparted the Papal Benediction as he made the sign of the cross.

The University of Nebraska should be sending to KARLIS ULMANIS of Latvia another pennant, unless one will serve for the two offices of Prime Minister and President of the republic of his native country, both of which he has now assumed pending the putting into effect of a reformed Constitution.
Concluding Passover services commemorating the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt more than 3,000 years ago began at sundown yesterday. They will continue today and tomorrow morning.
PARIS, April 12. -- France passed a troubled Easter today. The bleak, uncertain Paris weather fairly reflected the national state of mind following last week's session at Geneva.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 12. -- At the end of ten hours of running today in the open amateur all-age stake, the final competition in the twenty-fifth anniversary meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club, the winner was announced as Rosedale Jimmie, a white and lemon pointer dog owned and handled by Harry B. Hollins Jr. of Islip, L.I.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP). -- Vern Kennedy and Rookie Red Evans held the Cubs to three hits as the White Sox defeated the National League champion, 7 to 1, before 14,500 at Comiskey Park today to retain their Spring series supremacy, three victories to two.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Fat lambs for the Easter trade were in brisk demand most of last week. Fresh, shorn lambs, averaging around 82 pounds, were sold at $9.15, a new high price for the crop. Lightweight lambs were preferred by shippers, who paid $10.85 to $11 for those weighing 75 pounds, with some averaging 95 pounds at the same prices.

An old political hand in Washington declares that no Presidential campaign within his recollection ever included such a puzzle as that of the growing movement for the nomination of Governor LANDON. Here is a man who has not even publicly avowed that he is a candidate.

LONDON, April 11. -- The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices in Great Britain for March, based on the average for 1930 as 100, is 91.7, unchanged from February. It compares with 86.9 for March, 1935.
