WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Cordial acceptance of President Roosevelt's proposal for an inter-American conference at Buenos Aires to consolidate peace in the Western Hemisphere and suggestions for a wide variety of subjects for the agenda are contained in replies from heads of Latin American States, which were made public tonight by the State Department.

TRENTON, N.J., April 12. -- Dr. John F. Condon, intermediary in the Lindbergh kidnapping, was requested late today to appear before the Mercer County grand jury which is investigating the "confession" and alleged kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, disbarred Trenton attorney.

The total stock of United States cotton in domestic hands at the end of March was approximately 8,722,000 bales, compared with 9,973,000 on the corresponding date last year, a 1,251,000-bale drop, and 10,734,000 two years ago, according to an analysis of the statistical situation of the staple by the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12. -- Miss Rhoda Krause, 28 years old, of 1,918 Halstead Street, East Orange, was killed and three other young women were injured, two of them seriously, early today when an automobile in which they were riding crashed into a safety isle in front of the City Hall at Broad and Franklin Streets.

A rather surprisingly busy week begins tonight at the Mansfield with "Summer Wives," which emerges from the workshop of Jack Linder and D.S. Wolfson. Mark Linder and Dolph Singer wrote it, and it finds the team of Smith and Dale as a couple of Broadway boys in the Catskills, where their play-i mates include Helen Charleston, ] Morgan Conway, Miriam Battistaf and ]dlton Douglas.

LONDON, April 12. -- Another case of a patient who "died" on the operating table only to be brought back to life again by heart massage and injection of adrenalin is described in the current issue of The British Medical Journal.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ashley T. Cole's dinner party tonight included James J. Hoey, the Misses Jane and Anne Hoey, Ashley T. Cole Jr. and Hugh Cole.

For the first time in four years a score of Bowery veterans in tatters partially covered by top hats, cutaways and spats took part in the Easter parade yesterday. The 1936 procession was unique in that almost every man was crippled.

LONDON, April 11. -- The Easter holidays greatly restrained business on the Stock Exchange this week, but there has been no loss of the confidence which has been maintained throughout the current European crisis. Because of the manner in which this is dragging along, there is a growing disposition to ignore it, or at least to belittle its dangers, and once more to pay attention to the still rising curve of home industrial activity.

The action of the late President Wilson in permitting America to enter the World War was denounced last night by former Supreme Court Justice Daniel F. Cohalan, speaking at a Clan-na-Gael meeting held in the Hotel Astor, to commemorate the twentieth anniversary of the Irish Revolution of 1916.

Beginning on May 1 about 15,000 employes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company will receive an increase of 2 per cent of their basic wage rates, Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the company, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, April 12. -- The smaller communities of New York State have the highest proportion of liquor licenses in relation to population, Captain John B. Judson, executive officer of the State Liquor Authority, disclosed today. New York City has the smallest number of licenses in proportion to population.

What is significant about the growing criticism of the relief program is that so much of it is coming from those who have administered the program. To the recent statement of ROBERT MOSES that local executives are "sick and tired of work relief" must now be added the colorful words of General JOHNSON, in the report suppressed by the Administration, that "60 per cent" of this invented work is a needlessly "expensive and fatuous gesture."

BERLIN, April 11. -- The markets here this week refused to discern in the Rhineland complications any threat to industry and trade, and the Boerse, after an irregular opening on Monday, soon resumed its advance. Thus there is the apparent paradox that in the four weeks following the shock of Hitler's Locarno denunciation, the stock market has experienced its best rise of the last two years.

Although an Easter dawn service was conducted as scheduled on the ramparts at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn at 5:35 o'clock yesterday morning, the lowering weather later forced several hundred worshipers to abandon plans for the annual service of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation in Prospect Park.

Commemoration of the centenary of Mr. Pickwick couldn't come more happily than in this year of a Presidential campaign. When tempers get heated and invective is virulent, it is useful to remember that old custom is repeating itself. All this political slap-stick stuff should be taken in a Pickwickian sense. The vocabulary of name-calling is pitifully narrow.

Foreign exchanges settled quietly again last week, continuing a movement which has been running for the last month and ascribed to the political situation and the precarious state of the French financial position.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP). -- In a gray and sometimes drizzly capital, tourist-crammed, a sun-browned President and his wife today joined in the nation's Easter worship and style parade.

An exhibition of 300 pictures by school children will be opened at 8:30 tonight in the mezzanine galleries of the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. The show is of unusual interest, not only because the pictures illustrate new departures in the art teaching of public schools but also because they are executed in two new media, finger paint and dry paint.

A joint plea for the "religious cooperation" of the principal faiths of the world in a united front against persecution, intolerance and hatred was made last night by a Catholic priest, a Jewish rabbi and an Episcopalian rector.

One of the fields in which successive State Legislatures always run true to form is home rule for cities. There is no subject on which politicians love more dearly to orate. On occasion, carried away by their enthusiasm, they may even approve some such broad grant of municipal home rule as that contained in the New York State constitutional amendment of 1923.
With that mordant wit for which he is famous, George Bernard Shaw once said: "Those who can, do; those who can't, teach."

The appointment of Charles Harwood, attorney, as an additional special assistant to the United States Attorney General in the prosecution of indictments returned here by Federal grand juries against officers and directors of so-called guaranteed mortgage companies was announced yesterday.

Eighteen hundred homeless men filled a large meeting hall at the Gold Dust Lodge of the Salvation Army, Corlears Street and the East River, for an Easter service at 8 A.M. yesterday. The service, which was to have been held in Corlears Park, was forced indoors by the inclement weather.

Being under the impression that Spring is one of four seasons when laughing is pleasant, some of the town humorists have staged a comic musical show, "On Your Toes," which was put on at the Imperial Saturday evening. They are humorists with a gift for neat satire and cunning ribaldry -- bookmakers, tune vendors and monntebanks alike, for the most remarkable thing about "On Your Toes" is i the uniformity of its viewpoint.

BERKSHIRE HILLS, Mass., April 12. -- The Berkshire Hills were snow-covered today, and Colonel Arthur D. Budd enjoyed his first Easter skiing at his estate in Windsor. There was snow three inches deep on Mount Greylock, near Williamstown.

Sunless and shivery, but echoing with the deep diapason of the organ and the clangor of church bells, yesterday morning brought the traditional Easter pageantry into motion once more up and down Fifth Avenue.
TOKYO, Monday, April 13. -- The Soviet Union's new mutual defense agreement with Outer Mongolia, which region China claims, is about to be answered by Japan in another area of China.

BERLIN, April 11. -- The loss of 5,000,000 marks in gold, shown in the Reichsbank's return for April 7, of which all except about 1,000,000 marks was actually exported, was primarily due to the need for payment for food imports. The present 67,000,000 gold reserve is 28,000,000 less than the highest in 1935.

PARIS, April 12. -- Discussion of the Franco-British deadlock at Geneva continued unabated in the Paris press today, while government circles remained silent on the course to be adopted. A final decision on that question has been put off until Wednesday, when Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin will return to Paris for a conference with Premier Albert Sarraut and Joseph Paul-Boncour, French League delegate, and perhaps for a Cabinet meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (AP). -- Connie Mack's Athletics, displaying unexpected strength, defeated the Phillies, 4 to 3, today in the only game of the 1936 city exhibition series. Rain halted the contest after five and a half innings had been played, making it the shortest city series on record.

More than two thousand people attended the Easter services yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. The bleakness of the day was brightened by the gay Easter attire of the crowd. Red roses and tall Easter lilies were massed about the altar.

MIAMI, Fla., April 12 (AP). -- A smaller Pan American airliner carried southward from Trinidad today most of the passengers who had been aboard the big flying boat Puerto Rican Clipper yesterday when an accident in Port of Spain harbor brought death to two passenger and the steward.

NEW HAVEN, April 11. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commidity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.5, which compares with 82.5 the week before, 82.6 two weeks before, 82.5 three weeks before and 82.4 four weeks before.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 12. -- Despite a cloudy morning several thousand people took part in the annual sunrise service at the western portico of the Kenciso Dam of the New York City Water Department at Valhalla, the beginning today of Easter services throughout Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- President Roosevelt must be restricted to a relief program specifically laid down by Congress, and "waste, inefficiency and politics" must be eliminated from the relief program, the American Liberty League declared today an a statement attacking the President's request for $1,500,000,000 to supplement the $4,800,000,000 provided an the 1935 Emergency Relief Act.

Following the terrible disasters that have swept this country from various directions, there has come a gratifying demonstration that the old-time ability to rise superior to trouble and destruction still exists in America. An example of this is given in a personal letter received today from Charles M. Ketchum, secretary of the Greensboro (N.C.) Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas will be nominated for President by the Republican National Convention in June, "probably on the second, surely on the third ballot," John M. Hamilton, his manager, predicted today after a survey of the pre-convention situation and a conference with his Western associates.

BOSTON, April 12 (AP). -- The Bees, using regular pitchers, defeated the Red Sox, 8 to 4, today to gain the city's major league title before a chilled crowd of 6,500 at Fenway Park. Rain washed out the first two games of the series.

Wholesale apparel and accessory markets here experienced a normal slackening in activity last week as retailers concentrated on their Easter business. While open orders for coats and suits declined considerably, many special orders were received by manufacturers.
PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (AP). -- The Pennsylvania Railroad, which had its beginning with thirty miles of track and $3,000,000 worth of capital stock, will be 90 years old tomorrow.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, a group appointed by Secretary of Commerce Roper, announced yesterday he had written a letter to the Secretary of the Treasury urging approval of increases in the appropriation as requested by the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection for 1937.

Six hundred persons, united in a common enmity to British rule in Ireland, gathered at Town Hall last night to mark the twentieth anniversary of the Irish Rebellion of 1916. They met under the auspices of the American Association for the Recognition of the Irish Republic and political differences were proscribed for the evening.

FORT LEE, N.J., April 12. -- The trustees of the Union Church of Palisade here decided that, since it was Easter morning, they would remove the padlock from their church doors to allow brief services today, despite the fact that they have kept the church closed on legal advice during the five weeks since they ousted their pastor.

TORONTO, April 12. -- The Stanley Cup, silver trophy emblematic of the world's hockey championship which finally has come into possession of the Red Wings, left here this afternoon en route to Detroit. It was proudly and jealously guarded by James Norris Jr., vice president of the club.

In an effort to clear up the numerous entanglements in the heavyweight wrestling situation the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday requested Dick Shikat, recognized here as the champion, to appear before the board next Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- President Roosevelt proclaimed May 1 as Child Health Day and conferred with Norman H. Davis, head of the delegation to the recent London Naval Conference, Secretary Ickes, H.L. Hopkins and other officials.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A large issue, for refunding, was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today when Oklahoma Natural Gas Company of Tulsa registered for the issuance of $20,000,000 first-mortgage bonds, Series A, 4 1/2 per cent, due on May 1, 1951; $10,000,000 of convertible debentures due on May 1, 1946, and an undetermined number of shares of $15-par common stock for conversion of the debentures.

The Copeland bill to revise the Federal Food and Drug Act of 1906 was praised by four speakers last night at a meeting of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at the Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- A sharp clash between Chairman McSwain and Representative Maverick, who contended witnesses were not getting a "fair deal," prompted a sudden adjournment today of the House Military Committee investigating the disposition of surplus army goods.

Following a conference with State and insurance company officials yesterday District Attorney Dodge disclosed that twenty arrests had been made thus far in his investigation of fraudulent accident claims. Most of those arrested have pleaded guilty, he said.

COMING up to the start, this observer can hazard only a few feeble guesses on what will be the order of finish in the big league races. The Cubs and Tigers led their respective circuits last year and still look good enough to repeat -- if!

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 13. -- Yale today defeated the Wesleyan University nine, 3 -- 1, in a game begun and ended in rain but with seven dry innings between, and with chilling temperature prevailing throughout.

Representatives of New York and New Jersey in Congress were asked yesterday by the Shippers' Conference of Greater New York to oppose legislation sponsored by Senator Copeland which provides penalties for shippers accepting rate concessions from ship lines in the foreign trade.

No one can say that "Summer Vives" is sailing undex' false colors at the Mansfield, where it was put on last evening. It is a helter-skelter collection of gags and smalltime vaudeville numbers with Smith and Dale cuffing their way through the leading parts.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- When the Senators inaugurate the local baseball season tomorrow at 3 o'clock in a game with the Yankees President Roosevelt will be in his usual box to toss out the first ball.

New Jersey has 1,475 miles of public trout waters. The State Fish and Game Commission stocks the streams with an average of 350 legal-sized fish to the mile. Some of the larger and more heavily fished waters are allotted between 500 and 1,000 trout per mile.
BALTIMORE, April 13 (AP). -- A torchlight parade, the blare of bands and the flutter of flags and pennants gave a carnival setting tonight to President Roosevelt's speech here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13. -- Flying under an assumed name after eluding searchers in New York, Mrs. Lillian Mae Bartholomew slipped into Los Angeles today to begin a court battle for regaining the custody of her son, Freddie Bartholomew, child actor, from his aunt, Miss Myllicent Bartholomew.

The National Committee on Folk Arts of the United States opened yesterday, with a reception in its galleries at 673 Fifth Avenue (entrance on East Fifty-third Street), a new show called "Colonial Folk Arts and Customs Pertaining to Plant Life."
ALBANY, April 13. -- Due mainly to the prevalence of respiratory diseases in New York City, the death rate for February in the State was the highest for the month since 1929.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 13. -- Production of a new synthetic fiber, one-third thinner than the finest natural silk, was announced here today by Dr. Ernest B. Benger of the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., before the opening general session of the ninety-first meeting of the American Chemical Society.

The city of St. Louis, Mo., will receive bids on Friday on an offering of $4,667,000 of public building and improvement bonds, to be dated May 1, 1936, and to mature on May 1, 1951 to 1956. Bidders have been asked to specify the rate of interest.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Major Gen. Johnson Hagood, who was disciplined for criticism of the relief program, was ordered restored to active duty today following two personal appeals to President Roosevelt.

With rubber and wool top futures moderately firmer, the commodity futures markets here yesterday were either depressed or in the doldrums, with the holidays in foreign countries a factor in the dullness. In the cash markets cotton, corn, butter, eggs, Straits tin and rubber advanced, while wheat, oats, pork, cocoa, antimony and silk declined.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- Cottonseed crushed in the eight-month period, Aug. 1 to Mar. 31, was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 3,534,771 tons, compared with 3,184,776 in the same period a year ago.

Amid the boos and cheers of more than 500 persons, an effigy of Adolf Hitler was hanged above the platform in the Central Opera House, Sixty-seventh Street and Third Avenue, last night at an anti-war meeting conducted by the League Against War and Fascism.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 13. -- The memory of Thomas Jefferson was honored today at the University of Virginia, which he founded in 1819, and later at Monticello, his home on the mountain that rises above the Albemarle County farm, Shadwell, where he was born 193 years ago today.

WILKES-BARRE, April 13. -- Dynamite used in the construction of the "Easter gift" bombs which caused two deaths and serious injuries to three other persons in this area Friday was traced tentatively today to the Buttonwood Colliery of the Glen Alden Coal Company.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The House Appropriations Committee prepared today to present to the House a deficiency bill carrying about $2,318,689,840 for relief and other administration needs. This includes $1,500,000,000 for relief, $246,000,000 for the CCC, $479,689,840 for social insurance funds, $50,000,000 for a public building program and $43,000,000 for the TVA.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- Communications Commission officials said today that President Roosevelt probably would be asked to decide whether more funds should be sought to continue the $750,000 investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

These are very prosperous times for THOMAS JEFFERSON. Everybody has a kind word for him. Nearly everybody writes a book about him. Every political party and faction in the land calls him father. It is a remarkable recovery, compared with which the recovery in automobiles or electric current is trivial.

In his more than fifty years at the bar JAMES M. BECK argued many important, and no small number of famous, civil and criminal cases. As United States District Attorney, Assistant Attorney General, Solicitor General and in a lucrative private practice, he had a wider experience than falls to most lawyers.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Any world conference for adjusting European conditions should include problems of the Far East, Sao-Ke Alfred Sze, the Chinese Ambassador, asserted today in an address before the eighth biennial convention of the National League of American Pen Women.

Mail orders received here yesterday for women's apparel and accessories were fair, leading to the view that the good Easter trade in most sections will be followed by active replenishment of stocks. It was held doubtful that heavy purchasing would set in this week, but the arrival of buyers here next week is expected to be heavy.
ATHENS, April 13. -- Premier Constantine Demerdjis died of heart disease this morning. He was 59 years old. George Metaxas, Vice Premier and War Minister, succeeded him as Premier.

Count and Countess Rene de Chambrun, Alanson B. Houghton, former United States Ambassador to Great Britain, and ex-Governor Frank C. Lowden of Illinois and Mrs. Lowden will be among the passengers sailing tonight for Europe on the North German Lloyd liner-Europa.

Mae Scheible, who was convicted last week in Federal court of having violated the Mann Act when she moved her $100,000 a year vice operations from Pittsburgh to New York in the Autumn of 1934, was sentenced yesterday to serve four years in prison and was fined $5,000.

The attempt to build a wall around New York, to protect it not from barbarian hordes but from invasion by a few men and women of superior intelligence and capacity, will reach its climax today when the Board of Aldermen votes on the Lyons bill "To pro- "vide for the residence within the con- "fines of the city of employes of the "Emergency Relief Bureau."

Sentence was suspended on Edward A. Glennon, 45 years old, of 55 South Greenleaf Avenue, Westerleigh, S.I., dismissed chief keeper of Harlem prison, in General Sessions yesterday on his plea of guilty to the theft of $3,095 of the prison's funds between last July and February.

C. Lionel Marcus paints landscapes for "relaxation." He is a business man who four years ago took up painting at the age of 43. He will open his first exhibition on Saturday and it will continue until May 2 at Jacques Seligmann Co., 3 East Fifty-first Street.

Charges that the City Projects Council, an organization of WPA workers with a reported membership of 9,000, is a Communist "innocents' club," directed and controlled by Communists, were made in a report submitted yesterday to Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator.
Donoho, Moore Co. announced yesterday that the offering of 55,000 shares of Haloid Company common stock had been sold and the subscription books closed.

Negotiations looking to the sale by the United States Steel Corporation of one of its Canadian subsidiaries, the Canadian Steel Corporation, Ltd., to R.S. Rider, former vice president of the Canadian concern, are being carried on, it was announced yesterday.
The New York Federation of Music Clubs will open its tenth biennial convention tomorrow at the Hotel Astor. The sessions will continue through Saturday.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- Colonel Knox made a last-minute thrust at the New Deal in a speech tonight as his headquarters was asserting he would achieve a sweeping triumph in the first man-to-man test of lepublican contenders and would not lose one of the fifty convention delegates to be named by the party's electors Tuesday.

The Chesapeake Corporation was listed as holder of 3,297,774 shares of Chesapeake Ohio Railway common stock in the report of the C. O.'s largest stockholders at the end of 1935. This compared with 2,325,439 shares held at the end of 1934.

The British Empire's plans for a world-wide promotion of wool, of which it is the leading producer, were outlined yesterday by Lord Barnby, war-time head of the Wool Control Board and affiliated both here and abroad with wool organizations, at a luncheon sponsored by the Associated Wool Industries at the Empire State Club.

The Rev. Dr. J. Valdemar Moldenhawer, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, was elected unanimously as Moderator of the Presbytery of New York yesterday at the annual meeting of that body in the parish house of the Fifth Avenue Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., April 13 (AP). -- C.G. Challinor, 34 years old, died tonight, the twelfth victim of the TWA Sun Racer's crash on Chestnut Ridge near here last Tuesday.

BALTIMORE, April 13. -- In a speech before a cheering audience of 15,000 persons gathered here President Roosevelt tonight pictured the administration's social program as the only satisfactory answer to the questions asked by young people of America who have gained "scars of disillusionment" from the economic depression.

Charles R. Gay and Benjamin H. Brinton were renominated yesterday as president and treasurer, respectively, of the New York Stock Exchange. The nominating committee also recommended the reelection of eleven of the fourteen other incumbents whose terms expire next month.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Next week, after months and years of study and conference, Senator Wagner will present for public discussion the debutante among his legislative children -- the Housing Bill. Like most other members of the Wagner legislative family, this proposal has social welfare as its object.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Contacts totaling $1,000,457.72 were awarded by the War Department today for engineering projects, as follows:
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed May 1 as Child Health Day. His statement read:
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Conferences will be held tomorrow to consider Treasury and Veterans Administration plans for distribution of the soldiers' bonus, which is expected to start June 15.

Questioning the economic soundness of work relief, Bailey B. Burritt, general director of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, suggests in the ninety-second annual report of that organization, made public yesterday, that a better method might be to reward employers for increasing employment.
Dr. William J. Schieffelin, for the past twenty-eight years head of the Citizens Union, will celebrate his seventieth birthday today with his eight children and twenty grandchildren.

Efforts of men employed as guards during the building strike to obtain time cards showing wages still due them caused a hearing yesterday in the State Office Building before Abraham S. Wechsler, deputy chief of the Division of Licenses, to break up in wild confusion.

The Federal Government is providing the only opening this evening, the WPA and Harlem together. For up at the Lafayette Theatre they will be putting on "Macbeth," in Orson Welles's new version, which shifts the action from Scotland to Haiti. Curtain at 8:40.

John S. Sumner, secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, felt that the public exhibition of pictures in a book on nudism would have a demoralizing effect on the public, he testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman and a jury.

Philadelphia dispatches call attention to the fact that yesterday was the ninetieth anniversary for the chartering of the Pennsylvania Railroad. Beginning its career in April, 1846, the Pennsylvania was not the first of American railroads to enter the field. The present Delaware Hudson was chartered in 1823, the Baltimore Ohio in 1827.
Matthew J. Troy, former Assistant Corporation Counsel, was sworn in yesterday as a city magistrate by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.

NEWTON, Mass., April 13 (AP). -- Gilmour (Gloomy Gil) Dobie, 57-year-old coaching veteran, suffered a fractured collar bone when three of his Boston College backfield candidates crashed into him during today's Spring football practice session.

New life insurance production for March showed the first gain for 1936 with an increase of 1 per cent over the same month of 1935, according to figures made public yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents. In January and February there were decreases of 17.4 per cent and 7.6 per cent, respectively, with the first quarter showing decline of 8.2 per cent from a year before.

ASMARA, Eritrea, April 13. -- Italian troops today occupied the Ethiopian side of Gallabat on the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan frontier, literally in the same town with British troops of Sudan and the British Royal Air Force.
Details of the conference of the mutual savings bankers of the country to be held at the Hotel Traymore, Atlantic City, N.J., on May 13 to 15, were announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 13 (Canadian Press). -- Sunderland made sure of its sixth English Football League championship today despite the fact that the season has three weeks to run. The strong northern club clinched the soccer title by trouncing Birmingham, 7 -- 2, on the letter's ground.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 13 (AP). -- The Falls City Hi-Bru team of Indianapolis became the 1936 world's champion bowling team tonight as competition closed in the five-man event of the American Bowling Congress.

MILWAUKEE, April 13 (AP). -- Heywood Broun, New York columnist and president of the American Newspaper Guild, was convicted in District Court today on a charge of interfering with a police officer in connection with the strike of editorial employes at The Wisconsin News.
ROME, April 13. -- The commander-in-chief of the Fascist forces in East Africa announced in a communiqu.

An exhibition of school art work called "Young America Paints" was opened last night in the mezzanine galleries of the R.C.A. Building, Rockefeller Center. The show consists of some 300 pictures produced by young persons between 8 and 18 years of age in schools throughout the country.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 13. -- Charles J. Paine, an aviator en route from Florida to his home in Weston, Mass., had a miraculous escape this afternoon when his biplane, in a forced landing at Wallack's Point, somersaulted into Long Island Sound.

VIENNA, April 13. -- Perhaps on account of the secrecy maintained in British diplomatic quarters here, unusual importance is attached by Austria to the present visit of Sir Austen Chamberlain to Vienna. He arrived Friday to be guest of the British Minister, Sir Walford Selby, for ten days.

The demand for stocks continued selective yesterday, with the railway, copper and rubber groups and a scattering of other issues pointing higher as the balance of the list moved irregularly. The fact that the European and Canadian markets were closed for the Easter Monday holiday, and that the Supreme Court again delayed in passing judgment on the constitutionality of the Guffey Coal Act, made for quiet trading here.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 13 (AP). -- Without contests for its Presidential preference vote, the Nebraska primary campaign ended tonight with more than 500 candidates seeking places on State, Congressional and legislative tickets of the two major parties tomorrow.

The Schenley Distillers Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March 31 a net income of $1,739,200 after depreciation, interest, contingencies and Federal-income and capital-stock taxes.

ROCHESTER, April 13. -- An inquiry by the State Board of Regents, which is expected to prove helpful in shaping the State's future policy toward public school construction, was started here today by a group headed by Barnett Braslow, architect, of New York.

Additional common stock of two companies which recently voted split-ups were among the issues of four concerns approved for listing yesterday by the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange.

Restrictions against religious activities of Catholics and adherents of other faiths in Mexico are being rapidly removed, Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, Secretary of the Committee on Cooperation in Latin America, said yesterday on his return from a tour of the northern part of that country.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- The broad outline of a plan for municipal purchase of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company for $34,000,000, to be paid in installments over a fifty-year period, was agreed upon today by Mayor S. Davis Wilson and P.R.T. officials.

Today's voting in Illinois will signify much more than the election of delegates to the Republican National Convention. It will demonstrate whether malefactors of great wealth, who live in fear of Senator BORAH, will be able by the use of the unlimited and corrupt expenditure of money to defeat him.
TRENTON, N. J., April 13. -- After being warned to forget politics and care for the State's needy, the Assembly tonight voted down for the eighth time this session the "Luxury" Tax Bill.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on April 8 shows an increase for the week of $148,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations, a net decrease of $38,000,000 in other loans and investments, and increases of $312,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $47,000,000 in time deposits and $186,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

KALGAN, China, April 13 (AP). -- The Japanese Army, apparently disregarding the nominal Chinese sovereignty in Inner Mongolia, has installed military equipment at strategic points, informed sources said today. This equipment includes landing fields and wireless stations.

Solemnly, and not a bit perturbed by the fact that their elders did their parading Sunday, 100 youngsters from the metropolitan area held their own Easter parade of dolls yesterday afternoon at Bloomingdale's.

A mass demonstration and all- star benefit concert are scheduled for May 3 in Madison Square Garden by the Committee for Relief and Liberation of Victims of Persecution in Europe, maintained by the American Federation of Labor in association with the Labor Chest and the Central Trades and Labor Council.

Plainclothes patrolmen of Police Commissioner Valentine's confidential staff raided a two-room suite in the Hotel Cadillac, 153 West Forty-third Street, about 4 P.M. yesterday and arrested fourteen men. Harry Evans, 37 years old, of 2,016 Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, was charged with keeping and maintaining a gambling house.

HAVANA, Tuesday, April 14. -- Dr. Carlos Marques Sterling, a member of the Liberal party and son of the late former Secretary of State and Ambassador to Washington, was elected President of the House of Representatives last night.

The report of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York for 1934 was numbered the ninetieth, but since its issuance documents have been discovered which establish 1834 as the year of its founding. It thus finds itself in a new century of its existence, the report for 1935 being the 101st. But incidentally it has missed a celebration of its centenary, leaping as it has done across the threshold of the new century.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The Prudence Company, Inc., of New York City lost today in the Supreme Court a $10,000 anti-climax to its $400,000 victory in February against the Fidelity and Deposit Company and the American Bonding Company, both of Baltimore.

GENEVA, April 13. -- Italy is understood to have requested a postponement until Wednesday of the preliminary armistice talks that were scheduled to begin here tomorrow with Salvador de Madariaga and Joseph A. Avenol, respectively chairman of the Committee of Thirteen on Conciliation and Secretary General of the League of Nations.

The Industrial Corporation, management engineers, has opened an office at 115 Broadway, G. Harvey Porter, vice president announced yesterday. The company has other offices in Philadelphia, Baltimore and Richmond.
Harry W. Kouwenhoven, 52 years old, Brooklyn lawyer specializing in the management of estates, was arrested last night on a charge of grand larceny.

Referring to M.M. Casetti's inquiry as to why the Army Day parade is shunted outside the business zone, I may say that the route, down Fifth Avenue from Ninetieth to Sixty-second Street, was not forced upon the committee but chosen by it.

AIKEN, S.C., April 13. -- Mister Gingo, a chestnut gelding owned by Howell H. Howard of Dayton, Ohio, captured the hunter championship in the twentieth annual Aiken Horse Show today. The exhibition, deferred six times since April 1 on account of rain and wet grounds, was finally held under perfect conditions.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, which recently suspended from April to Nov. 1 the proposal of railroads of the Eastern territory to begin free pick-up and delivery service, pending an investigation by the commission, was asked today in a petition filed by the American Trucking Association, Inc., to extend the scope of its inquiry to cover services which are now in effect on railroads of the South and West.

" New York is the natural theatre of the nation's racing, and the year 1936 should be a banner one for the sport in this State," was one of the declarations yesterday by Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, who spoke at a luncheon at the Jamaica race track.

Billy Celebron, a sharp-shooting youngster from Rockford, Ill., forged to the front in the welterweight division last night as he recorded a technical knockout victory over the Italian veteran, Cleto Locatelli, before 4,000 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace.
The National Industrial Conference Board made public a report yesterday showing an increase of 5,413,000 in the number of persons employed in the United States between March, 1933 and December, 1935.

PHILADELPIA, April 13. -- "Red Rhumba," a musical show with a Cuban background, was presented at the Forrest Theatre tonight as the forty-eighth annual production of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP). -- A cheering crowd of more than 2,000 supporters of Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old-age pension chieftain, heard Western Townsend leaders "welcome" Congressional investigators to the Coast today.
CHICAGO, April 13. -- Close friends of Major General I-Iagood said here today that he planned to retire soon and take an important l executive office with a Chicago mall-order firm.

Destruction of several types of highly malignant cancers in animals by injections of a diluted filtrate of the typhoid bacillus is reported today in the current issue of The American Journal of Cancer by Dr. Mendel Jacobi of Beth-El Hospital, Brooklyn.

Despite the insistence by Robert Moses as head of the Triborough Bridge Authority that the forty-hour week should be adopted in order to complete the project as scheduled on July 10, Arthur S. Turtle, Acting State Director for the Administration of Public Works, indicated in a formal statement last night that the thirty-hour week would not be changed.

Legal action to restrain the Emergency Relief Bureau from dismissing nearly 400 employes affected by the Lyons Residence Bill was begun yesterday, according to Hyman N. Glickstein, attorney, who said he had obtained an order from Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag requiring the ERB to show cause why it should not be so enjoined at 10 o'clock this morning.

ST. LOUIS, April 13 (AP). -- A fifth-inning batting punch that put the skids under the Browns' second pitcher, Mike Meola, gave the Cardinals a 6-3 triumph in the second of the two-game Spring city series today. The Browns won yesterday.

A drunken automobile driver in Brooklyn knocked down two young women and dragged the body of one of them a distance of 150 feet before he was forced to the curb by a passerby in a car. In his defense he said that he was not aware he had hit anything. Half an hour earlier he was not aware that he had knocked down three traffic stanchions.

One of the last and most important paintings by Paul Gauguin (1848-1903), French artist and a pioneer in the Post-Impressionist movement, has been acquired by the Marie Harriman Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, and will be shown for the first time in this country on April 22 for the benefit of the Public Education Association.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The Retail Furniture Dealers Association of St. Louis, its officers and forty-two merchant members were named today in a complaint by the Federal Trade Commission alleging violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act through combination and conspiracy to monopolize the sale and distribution of furniture and allied products in the St. Louis and East St. Louis trade areas.

WILDWOOD, N.J., April 18 (AP). -- Ray Mangrum of Los Angeles completed the thirty-six-hole qualifying round in the Wildwood Golf Club's second annual open tournament today with a total of 143, four strokes better than his nearest opponents.

MOOSE RIVER, N.S., Tuesday, April 14. -- Miners blasting and digging through rock in an attempt to rescue three Toronto men trapped 151 feet down in the Moose River gold mine by a cave-in reported early today that they had reopened a disused shaft forty-five feet below the surface.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Amendment of the Duffy Copyright Bill to provide for retention of a statutory damage fee for infringement and for the printing in the United States of copyrighted work of American authors for distribution in this country was urged today by publishers of books and maps before the House Committee on Patents, which is considering proposed revision of the present Copyright Law, enacted in 1909.

BETHLEHEM, Ba., April 13. -- In addressing the Engineers Club of the Lehigh Valley at Lehigh University tonight on "Transportation," Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, expressed the opinion that railroads would improve as would the water carriers and the motor carriers and the air carriers in the future.

TOKYO, April 13. -- The existence of a movement seeking Mongolian unity and independence with Russian backing instead of under Japanese auspices was disclosed today by the Kwantung army's announcement that six high Mongolian officials of Manchukuo had been arrested.

In emphasizing the case for a monetary unit the purchasing power of which remains constant Professor Fisher overlooks the fact that the 1929 crash and subsequent depression occurred in the face of a period of comparative price stability.

With the principal European markets still closed in observance of the Easter holidays, dealings in foreign exchange here yesterday again were in small volume. A better tone, however, prevailed. The French franc rose 1/8 point to 6.59 cents and the pound sterling was up 1/8 cent to $4.94 1/4.

TRENTON, N.J., April 13. -- The New Jersey State Assembly voted down tonight a new resolution calling for an investigation into the conduct of Governor Harold Hoffman and other officials in the Bruno Richard Hauptmann case.
Business, apartment and dwelling properties were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 13. -- A foretaste of combat at 300 miles an hour was given here today when the first plane in the new competition for single-seater pursuit airplanes, opening on Wednesday, flew over Wright Field. This was the Vought V-1-41, the first of four planes which are expected to take part in the competition.
Alton The first railroad to report for Earch, the Alton, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, showed a larger deficit for the month. The statement follows:

The opening of the week yesterday failed to dislodge the bond market from its quietude with trading at an even slower pace than the last full day's session. Although bonds on the New York Stock Exchange displayed a firm undertone, the price changes were irregular.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The necessity for cooperation in the public and private fields to combat the illicit traffic in narcotics was stressed by Secretary Hull in a message read today at a luncheon of the World Narcotic Defense Association.
Mayor La Guardia received a telegram yesterday from Israel Amter of the Communist party demanding that labor organizations be permitted to use Fifth Avenue for a May Day parade on May 1.

Mrs. G. Umberto Ferulli, 59 years old, whose husband is a commander of the Order of the Crown of Italy, jumped from a bathroom window of their fifth-floor apartment at 270 West End Avenue, on the southeast corner of Seventy-third Street, shortly before 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a decision issued today suspending temporarily the registration of Gerald Owens of New York as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market, presented a carefully prepared statement of the procedure it had followed in employing the powers given to it under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to exercise such control.

Guy A. Thompson, trustee in reorganization proceedings for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, began suit here yesterday in Federal Court to recover $3,200,000, which the railroad has paid under a 1930 contract for the purchase from the Van Sweringen interests of terminal properties in Kansis City and St. Joseph, Mo.

The President is to be commended for restoring Major Gem HAGOOD to active duty. That plain-spoken soldier was doubtless technically guilty of a breach of army discipline when, testifying before a subcommittee of Congress several months ago, he gave evidence characterized by the Chief of Staff as "designed to bring ridicule "and contempt upon civil agencies of "the Government" (notably WPA and CCC).

Walker D. Hines, lawyer, and director general of American Railroads in the last year of Federal wartime control, left a net estate of $499,892 when he died in Merano, Italy, on Jan. 14, 1934, it was shown in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. In addition, there was $77,153 in real and tangible personal property in Connecticut, not included in the taxable estate in New York.

MOSCOW, April 13. -- Emphasizing that the country strongest in the air will be invincible in the next war, A.V. Kosarieff, secretary of the Young Communists League, urged its congress today to train 8,000 aviators this year.

Three lumps of mud were regarded by the police yesterday as possibly affording a solution of the mysterious murder of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, 34-year-old novelist and book critic. The body of Mrs. Titterton, who had been criminally attacked and strangled, was found last Friday afternoon in the bathtub of her apartment at 22 Beekman Place.

The sensibilities of thirty-six of the nation's premier bridge players were affronted yesterday by the smell of fresh paint and the clatter of an electrician's ladder as they settled down at the Park Lane for the opening of the American Bridge League's individual championship tournament.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- One of the so-called pivotal States holds its primary tomorrow, with Senator Borah of Idaho and Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago newspaper publisher, as rivals in the contest for Presidential delegates. The outcome of their contest is expected to have an important bearing on the selection of the Republican candidate at the national convention.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- The demand for hogs was fairly active here today with prices steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher. Weights under 300 pounds sold quickly with reports of a better demand for fresh pork having some effect. The top was unchanged from Saturday at $11, while the day's average was 5 cents higher at $10.60. Most sales were at $10.40 to $10.90.

A joint exhibition of work by Rudolf Jacobi and his wife, whose brush name is the brief and easily remembered Annot, opened yesterday in the galleries on the thirty-third floor of the Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue. It is a large show, containing nearly a hundred pictures, and will be current until April 25.

The quarterly statements of investment trusts that have appeared within the last two weeks show that the managers of these companies believe that the basic trend of business and of stock prices is still upward. Holdings of cash showed little change; and while there was some switching of the common stock holdings, the total amount invested in junior securities was increased.
CONCORD, N.H., April 13. -- Governor Bridges of New Hampshire has forwarded to Col. Frank Knox this telegram:

ALBANY, April 13. -- The Legislature entered tonight upon its second week of arrested activity with ten-minute sessions in the Senate and Assembly. Only eight of the fifty-one Senators and as many of the 149 members of the Assembly were in attendance.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- The action of the new crop deliveries of wheat is dominated by weather conditions in the Southwest. Reports indicating absence of moisture there over the week-end and record-breaking temperatures for this season of the year brought buying from commission houses today and lifted the July 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade.

BOSTON, April 13. -- A remarkable similarity between a murderous assault upon a Quincy woman ten years ago and the circumstances surrounding the murder of Mrs. Lewis H. Titterton, New York writer, led New York and Quincy police on a new man hunt today.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 13. -- Jay Jay, 3-year-old gelding in the silks of Howard Bruce of Baltimore, surprised some 12,000 fans when he outran eight smart rivals in the twenty-fourth Harford Handicap, six-furlong fixture that topped the Harford Agricultural and Breeders Association's opening program today.

A special committee of directors of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, appointed by the full board to review the prospects of bringing the company out of receivership if the proposed unification plan fails, has worked out a tentative plan, accordingly to Theodore S. Watson of Watson White, one of the Manhattan Railway representatives on the Interborough's board.

Continuing his brilliant play, Edward Lee of New York won his fourth game in the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship at the New York Athletic Club last night to remain the only unbeaten competitor.

In a combined organization meeting and Jefferson Day celebration, with United States Senator Albert W. Barkley of Kentucky as the principal speaker, John J. Dorman, former Fire Commissioner, was reelected last night as chairman of the Kings County Democratic Committee.

Lloyd Lewis did not seem to understand yesterday why folks Were so put out by the fact that his essay on "How Can America Stay Out of War?" which won a $5,000 scholarship in a radio contest, was copied from a magazine article written for the December issue of Peace Digest, by Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of the University of Newark.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A hope that the United States Government "will find it possible to intervene on behalf of the Jews in Poland" to prevent their persecution was expressed to Secretary of State Cordell Hull today by a committee representing members of the American Federation of Labor and 350,000 Jewish citizens of this country.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 13. -- Sangreal, star campaigner of the Milky Way Farms, today equaled the feat performed Saturday by The Fighter, his stablemate, and tied the track record of 1:42 in the mile and seventy yards to take the $1,000 James Bowie Purse event at Arlington Downs.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Another New Deal law, the Municipal Bankruptcy Act of 1934, will be tested in the Supreme Court, as a result of a decision by the court today to hear arguments in a Texas suit involving constitutionality of the law.
LONDON, April 13. -- Discussions of war and peace loomed large at Easter conferences of various organizations today.

A dispatch from Washington which you published states: "Foreign-born citizens will be reminded during the forthcoming campaign 'that the Roosevelt administration is closely following that road by which many of their homelands have lost their cherished liberties.'"
LONDON, April 13. -- Discussions of war and peace loomed large at Easter conferences of various organizations today.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 (AP). -- E.W. Day Jr., pilot for Central Airlines, testified before a Federal investigating committee here today that the Pittsburgh Airport's radio beam worked properly a few minutes before the TWA's Sun Racer crashed on Tuesday.

ROME, April 13. -- Well-informed circles here confirm that Baron Pompeo Aloisi or another Italian representative will be in Geneva at the appointed time to place himself in touch with Salvador de Madariaga, according to the wish expressed by the League of Nations Committee of Thirteen on conciliation.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- A pay increase from $68,504 in 1934 to $74,714 in 1935 to Robert W. Schiff, president of the Schiff Company of Columbus, Ohio, was listed today in a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Metropolitan All-Stars, composed of leading players on local college basketball teams during the past season, conquered Kate Smith's Celtics, 46 -- 34, before 2,500 persons at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night. Reuben (Rip) Kaplinsky, St. John's luminary, and Willie Rubenstein of N.Y.U. shared scoring honors for the winners with fifteen points apiece.

ALBANY, April 13. -- A school teacher has the same right to punish a child as the parent, the limitation being that the punishment may not be immoderate in degree or unreasonable in manner, Dr. Frank F. Graves ruled today in sustaining an appeal of Mrs. Carrie M. Hynie, dismissed teacher in the Union Free Teacher at Highland Falls.
Several leases to chain-store groups for expansion of their retail operations were included in the business space rentals announced yesterday.

Bruce Hoefer, 11-year-old editor of The Sheboygan Weekly in Wisconsin, interviewed Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday on his political future, but could not report much success with the Mayor's answers.

Within the last year more than 500,000 school children of Greater New York have become acquainted with the works of standard and classic composers through concerts given by the Musicians Emergency Fund, Mrs. Yolanda Mero-Irion, its executive director, announced yesterday.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, April 13. -- B. Iden Payne, director, gave a vivid, bustling opening to the twenty-fifth annual Shakespeare Festival here today with his presentation of "The Taming of the Shrew." The festival will last twenty-four weeks, a fortnight longer than last year, and the theater has been enlarged by the addition of 150 seats.

PARIS, April 13. -- What is being called here "Europe's decisive week" opened without the French Government making known the stand it will take at Geneva either with regard to the Anglo-French conflict of views on Europe's future or as to the League itself.

CHICAGO, April 13 (AP). -- Edward E. Blake, chairman of the Prohibition party's national committee, announced today the choice of D. Leigh Colvin of New York, favored by Illinois prohibitionists for the Presidential nomination, as keynoter for the national convention which will select the party's standard bearer next month at Niagara Falls, N.Y.

CHICAGO, April 13 (AP). -- Manager Jimmy Dykes of the White Sox warned his pal, Mickey Cochrane, today that another slow start this season would just about cost the world champion Tigers a third straight American League title.

The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, one of the leading yacht clubs on Long Island, sought permission yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn to reorganize under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Law.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 13. -- President Angell of Yale University said at the annual banquet of The Yale Daily News board tonight that unless chaos intervened, the university would find a way to realize its ideals of more than two centuries and live within its income.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP). -- The American Olympic Committee "needs money and needs it soon," Avery Brundage said today.
BALTIMORE, April 13. -- The text of President Roosevelt's address tonight was as follows:

President ROOSEVELT'S happy suggestion of a Pan-American Peace Congress has had a cordial response from most of the countries to which he sent the proposal. The State Department has made public a bare outline of their replies and suggestions. These contain several orders of business, but a committee of which Secretary HULL is chairman will prepare the agenda in advance of the conference.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The National Sheltered Workshop Com mittee, created under the National Recovery Administration to supervise factories and workshops maintained by charitable institutions, was commended today in an NRA-Department of Commerce report as a successful innovation which should be continued as a separate agency or under an established department.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 13. -- Saga, the new Norwegian-built six-meter yacht owned by Eldon and Kenneth Trimingham of Bermuda, carried off the Prince of Wales Trophy today as the international sailing series came to an end.
LONDON, April 13. -- The British Government is determined not to have anything to do with military or naval sanctions against Italy, such as, for example, the closing of the Suez Canal.

The New York City Housing Authority and the Housing Division of the PWA have received nearly 7,500 inquiries for apartments in the $12,500,000 Ten Eyck slum-clearance project in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- Thousands of boys and girls, dressed in their best, rolled Easter eggs over the broad White House lawns today, pausing only long enough to hear greetings from the President himself.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced today that special agencies to facilitate loans to sufferers from the recent floods and tornadoes would be set up in Tupelo, Miss.; Hartford, Conn., and Springfield, Mass., as soon as Congress adopts the bill allotting $50,000,000 of RFC funds for that purpose.

CHICAGO, April 23. -- Sharp reductions and some elimination of fees and expenses in connection with reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company were recommended today by attorneys for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in a brief filed with Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A prediction was made today by Speaker Byrns that President Roosevelt would insist that Congress provide new taxes to restore his budget in full to its status before the Agricultural Adjustment Act was invalidated and the veterans' bonus enacted over his veto.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 13. -- Headed by Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., member of the Davis Cup team, a field of forty-six players started out under azure skies in the eighteenth annual North and South tennis championship today on the clay courts of the Pinehurst Country Club.

About 2,000 Catholic educators, representing more than 10,000 colleges, seminaries and schools throughout the country, assembled here yesterday for the thirty-third annual meeting of the National Catholic Educational Association in the Waldorf-Astoria. It is the first convention of the association here since 1920.

Capital stock of the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway (Gulf Coast Lines) jumped 17 points in odd-lot trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The company, which is in bankruptcy, is a subsidiary of the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

Milton Hanauer and G.N. Treystman, both of New York, qualified last night for the grand finals of the United States chess championship after results were recorded at the Manhattan, Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Clubs, where adjourned and postponed games were decided.
The re-election of all four officers of the Republican State Committee at the meeting of the committee on Thursday at the National Republican Club was said yesterday to be virtually certain.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Deportation of 7,500,000 aliens so that "our own people should have jobs" was demanded before the National Sentinels today by Mrs. Jesse W. Nicholson of Maryland, president.

TOKYO, April 13. -- The Japanese Army, after seizing six high Mongolian officials of the State of Manchukuo, charged tonight they were involved in a plot "apparently the result of Outer Mongolia's campaign against Manchukuo at the instigation of Soviet agents."

Public School 120 on Barren Island, where about 100 children of residents go to school, will soon be a thing of the past. It will be abandoned by the Board of Education after the graduation exercises on June 30, it was announced yesterday by John E. Wade, Associate Superintendent of Schools.

CHICAGO, April 14. -- Upon his arrival here from Washington tonight Major Gen. Johnson Hagood, critic of the New Deal, who was restored to active duty on Monday and assigned to command the Sixth Corps Area, announced that in addition to his army duties he would become "efficiency engineer" with a national mail-order house.

The first sale since 1923 of locomotives and cars to reimburse holders of defaulted equipment trust certificates is to be held on April 29, in St. Augustine, Fla., a committee for Florida East Coast Railway certificates announced yesterday. Although many equipment trust obligations have been defaulted in recent years, until now the holders have been enabled to obtain some return on their investment without taking title to miscellaneous lots of rolling stock.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The opening of the professional baseball season is always a day of political armistice in Washington. Members of Congress and executive and judicial dignitaries rush to the ball park, some because they particularly enjoy this outdoor form of commercial entertainment and on such a day are privileged by custom to drop their work, some because they think their presence convinces their constituents that they are lovably human.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP). -- Curt Davis limited the Bees to four hits as the Phillies defeated them, 4 to 1, before a National League opening-day crowd of 9,000 today.

LONDON, April 14. -- Just before British, French and Belgian army and navy chiefs gather here tomorrow for consideration of measures to meet a German attack, the funeral of a German who opposed the remilitarization of the Rhineland will be held.

Following passage of the Lyons Residence Bill yesterday by the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly, Mayor La Guardia ordered the immediate suspension of the measure, acting under Section 5, which he said gave him that power.
A written civil service examination for police sergeant will be held today in the DeWitt Clinton and Evander Childs High Schools with 5,400 patrolmen paying $5 fees to take part.

In THE TIMES of April 7 Herman Oliphant of the Treasury is reported to have told the House Ways and Means Committee that he could not give "one honest reason for treating a corporation tax-wise any differently from an individual or a partnership across the street."

New York's 171-day racing season, which will see almost $2,000,000 distributed to horsemen, will start this afternoon at Jamaica, where the opening-day card will be featured by the renewal of the $5,000 added Paumonok Handicap, first run in 1906. A field of seven has been named for the test.
BERLIN, April 14. -- The Boerse showed only scattered signs of activity today and for all practical purposes was completely stagnant.

LONDON, April 14. -- On its political side, tomorrow's conference here of the general staffs of Britain, France and Belgium will serve as a reminder that Germany did not tear up the Locarno treaty when she marched her troops into the Rhineland but only transformed it into a defensive alliance among Britain, France and Belgium.

GENEVA, April 14. -- Salvador de Madariaga, chairman of the League of Nations Committee of Thirteen, received word today that Baron Pompeo Aloisi of Italy would arrive here tomorrow for preliminary armistice talks.

Consolidated net profit of the National Cash Register Company and subsidiaries in the first quarter of this year amounted to $341,750 after deducting depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. The profit is equivalent to 21 cents each on 1,628,000 shares of no-par capital stock.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- A permanent organization under the civil service system could more properly supervise and regulate air commerce than the "political" organization now vested with control, Frank McManamy, Interstate Commerce Commissioner, told the House Postoffice and Post Roads Committee today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 14.-- The dean of American rowing, starting his thirty-third year as head coach of the Syracuse crews faces one of the hardest tasks he has ever had in that long span of service with the Orange. To the usual difficulties of Spring rowing here has been added flood with the result that, to date, Jim Ten Eyck has yet to follow either of his varsity crews in his coaching launch.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The tong-expected "show-down" in the maritime labor situation on the Pacific Coast is regarded here as imminent as the result of the breaking off of relations between the San Francisco Waterfront Employers Association and the San Francisco local of the International Longshoremen's Association, of which Harry Bridges, left wing leader, is president.

Today Newark commemorates the hundredth anniversary of her existence as a city. Her life as a community began in 1666. She too is a product of that year of wonders, so memorable in London Few marvels can be greater than her rise to the crowded cosmopolis that she has become.

Will there be a successor to The Great THURSTON, who came after HOUDINI, who came after KELLAR, who came after HERRMANN the Great? Is there room, in a world crammed with the veritable miracles of science, for the mystifiers of a simpler age?

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 14. -- Five men who executed a daring daylight burglary at the home of Joseph Love, New York dress manufacturer of 88 Fanshaw Avenue, Yonkers, on Oct. 10, and escaped with $16,000 in jewelry, were sentenced today by County Judge Gerald Nolan and Acting County Judge James W. Bailey.

Formation of a committee of former Kansans now living in the East to run an Eastern regional headquarters for the Presidential candidacy of Governor Alfred M. Landon was announced yesterday following a luncheon of the group at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

Robert Moses, chief executive officer of the Triborough Bridge Authority, accused Arthur S. Turtle, Acting State PWA Director, yesterday of ignoring entirely his basic reason for requesting a change from the thirty-hour week to one of forty on the bridge project.
MOOSE RIVER, N.S., Wednesday, April 15 (AP). -- Mining experts had almost abandoned hope early today for the rescue of three men imprisoned 140 feet below the surface in the Moose River gold mine.

CLEVELAND, April 14. -- Lynwood Rowe, the tall Arkansas schoolboy, put the Tigers on the road that they hope will take them to their third straight pennant when he pitched the Indians into submission before 18,200 opening-day fans today, 3 to 0.

A special resolution urging action by Congress on the Ellenbogen bill introduced on Monday in the House permitting FHA loans to include advances for restocking merchandise in addition to the rehabilitation loans authorized in the Flood Relief Bill was passed yesterday by the trustees of the American Retail Federation following the annual meeting of the organization at the Hotel New Yorker.
Boston, Mass., will enter the market tomorrow with an issue of $2,500,000 notes, dated April 21 and maturing on Nov. 6.

Controller Frank J. Taylor announced last night that he had submitted to the Sinking Fund Commission, for consideration today, a report suggesting a radical change in the city's dock rental policy to the end that shipping concerns that have left the port may be persuaded to return.

The third performance in the Spring season of the de Basil Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was marked by a complete change of bill. "Lac des Cygnes," the one-act version of the old Petipa-Tchaikovsky "choreographic poem," was restored to the program for the first time this season, with Alexandra Danilova and Paul Petroff in the leading roles and Efrem Kurtz conducting.

Eleven parcels, comprising fifteen buildings, were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan for foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Most of the structures were houses, the largest being a twelve-story apartment building at the southwest corner of West End Avenue and Seventy-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Impassioned closing arguments rang out in the Senate today in the impeachment trial of Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter of Florida, and votes of guilty or not guilty will be taken tomorrow at noon.

Shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon a gray-haired woman dressed completely in black, but with a large fresh rose at the clasp of her cape, appeared at the door-way of the three-story brick rooming house at 61 Washington Square South.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, tentatively approved yesterday the plan of reorganization for the James Butler Grocery Company of Long Island City, operators of 483 retail stores in the metropolitan district. Judge Byers dismissed several objections to the plan and recommended several minor changes in it.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The fact that James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has not yet asked for a renewal of the leave that has been granted to him each year by Harvard College and which would expire in September led to published reports today that he may retire from government service.

Two WPA workers, pouring cement for an anchorage of the Triborough Bridge, were killed yesterday afternoon when they lost their balance on a scaffold and fell to the ground near Twenty-third Street and Van Alst Avenue, Astoria, Queens.

The Hazel Atlas Glass Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange of the election to the board of directors of J.S. Jones and Samuel O. Laughlin Jr., both of Wheeling, W.Va., to succeed D. Allan Burt and Benjamin J. Neuhardt.

Daulton Mann, vice president of the Grace Steamship Line, said last night that the action of the ship lines meant the stripping of the Pacific Coast longshoremen's leaders of their powers as far as recognition by the lines was concerned.

Emphasis on organized promotion to increase an industry's sales will become one of the leading activities of trade association work within the next few years, according to comments yesterday by several trade group executives. Practically every industry is being more or less forced into such work and. while the memory of many failures in the past has served as a deterrent, more successful attempts recently have been encouraging.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- War Department officials professed ignorance tonight Of the reported intention of Major Gen. Johnson Hagood to act as an "efficiency" engineer for Sears, Roebuck Co., while also serving as commander of the Sixth Corps Area at Chicago.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Elmer F. Andrews, New York State Industrial Commissioner, in a memorandum placed before the national conference on silicosis, held here today upon the call of Secretary Perkins, said that an emergency situation existed in silica dust hazard industries in New York State.

Cooper Union carried yesterday to the Appellate Division its fight to win tax exemption for the Chrysler Building and the land it occupies at Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street. John W. Davis, appearing for Cooper Union, told the Appellate Court that imposition of the city tax on the property deprived the institution of part of the revenue it requires for carrying on educational work in New York City.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 14. -- The Milky Way Farms Stable, which has saddled winners consistently at Arlington Downs, scored impressively again today when Sir Gawaine put seven lengths between him and the field in the John Booth Purse.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 14. -- Bermuda's first pictorial issue of postage stamps, placed in circulation today, created an immediate widespread demand. Collectors, including many Americans, buying complete sets, thronged the Hamilton postoffice, eager to take advantage of the authorities' offer to impress envelopes posted today with a dated "first-day cover" rubber stamp.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 14. -- The proposed unification of the three largest branches of American Methodism will be debated at the 137th annual New York Methodist Church Conference which opens here tomorrow.

A new plan for financing installment buying of electric refrigerators is under discussion among the Consolidated Edison Company, the National City Bank and leading dealers in electrical equipment. Although full details have not been worked out, the plan as contemplated would operate along lines similar to those employed for modernization loans under the Federal Housing Administration.

Because a well-to-do Brooklyn executive neglected to mention the existence of an infant he adopted after making his will, the child will inherit more than $90,000 of his estate instead of receiving only $7.13 which her foster-father had deposited in a trust account for her benefit.

PALO ALTO, Calif., April 14 (AP). -- Former President Hoover said tonight that President Roosevelt's newest advocacy of shorter hours to increase employment was "a most desirable end" but that it had failed two years ago as an emergency measure.

The Police Department "has to keep step" with the march of science if it is to outwit the underworld, which rapidly is taking advantage of scientific progress, Grover A Whalen, former police commissioner, said yesterday.

LONDON, April 14. -- The Independent Labor party, the once-powerful Left Wing organization that produced such stalwarts as Ramsay MacDonald, Viscount Snowden and other notable Labor leaders, closed its annual conference today "split on every issue" as one speaker put it, and financially apathetic.

In the face of the opening of the baseball season yesterday, it took a firm stand by officials of the American Bridge League to keep the proportion of ailing grandmothers among the thirty-six bridge experts participating in the league's individual championship tournament at the Park Lane from reaching that among office boys in other parts of the city.
For fifteen fleeting minutes, minutes that must have thrilled him far more than the mightiest home run he ever crashed over the distant ramparts, Babe Ruth was baseball's idol and hero yesterday.

Owen D. Young, chairman of the Thomas Alva Edison Foundation National Committee, announced yesterday that the quota for the New York regional area in the nation-wide campaign to provide a "living memorial" to the inventor would be $1,800,000.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quota-! tions for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

LINCOLN, Neb., Wednesday, April 15 (AP). -- Terry Carpenter, former Representative in Congress, jumped into a surprise lead for the Democratic nomination to the Senate in Nebraska primaries today, with the other three candidates bunched close behind him.

A letter has been addressed to Congressman Sirovich, chairman of the House Committee on Patents, by the Fashion Originators Guild, dealing with the objections raised to pending design protection legislation by the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The communication was made public here yesterday by Albert M. Post, executive director of the guild, who signed the letter.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- President Roosevelt opened the baseball season here today by tossing out a wild first ball in the opening game between the New York Yankees and the Washington Senators. He then sat through nine exciting innings, with a rose in his lapel and a bag of peanuts in his lap, until the Washington team scored the only run, in the last half of the ninth.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- The Rev. Dr. George Emerson Barnes, newly elected Moderator of the Philadelphia Presbytery, came under the fire of militant fundamentalists today during an adjourned meeting which dealt further with reorganization of the Presbytery's rules.

A festival spirit accompanied by Hollywood floodlights and a brass band of eighty pieces came to Harlem last night to celebrate the opening of the most ambitious venture of the Negro division of the Federal Theatre Project -- a transplanted version of Shakespeare's. "Macbeth," with an all-Negro cast.

Further provision for Gold Star Mothers by Federal and State authorities was advocated yesterday by speakers at the fourteenth biennial State convention of the American War Mothers, which opened at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Monday.

Demands for adoption of the American Legion's three-point program for adequate national defense and legislative provision for the widows and orphans of World War veterans were made by Ray Murphy, national commander of the Legion, last night at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Testimany tending to show an interlocking relation of industrial espionage and strike-breaking agencies with a company selling tear-gas bombs and munitions to break strikes and the lawyers for the American Liberty League, who drew up a brief against the constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Act, was presented to the LaFollette Subcommittee on Education and Labor today by Heber Blankenhorn, industrial economist for the National Labor Relations Board.

A letter from John Holley Clark objects to constitutional change. "Many superficial thinkers believe that they are much wiser than that wonderful body of patriots and statesmen who framed the American Constitution, and they fail to recognize that there is a great difference between material things and things of reason and principle," he says.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14. -- The reappointment of Dr. Abraham Flexner as director of the Institute for Advanced Study here and the re-election of other officers was announced today at the institute's offices at 20 Nassau Street.

Shareholders of the Union Bag and Paper Company at their annual meeting yesterday approved the recommendation of directors to increase the authorized capital shares of the company from 200,000 to 300,000 and to issue rights to common shareholders for the purchase of additional shares in a ratio of one new share for each three held.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 14. -- With ideal Summer weather prevailing and large galleries in attendance at both the morning and afternoon sessions, play in the North and South tennis championships came down to the quarter- final round today in the men's and women's singles at the Pinehurst Country Club.

Following the example of perfume importers, large liquor importing houses are filing their trade-marks at custom houses to prevent unauthorized importations of their merchandise from abroad, Arthur A.
