Kestler, general counsel for the New York State Organization of Retail Liquor Store Associations, Inc., and the Long Island Wine and Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., announced yesterday.

ROME, April 14. -- Baron Pompeo Aloisi, accompanied by only a very small delegation, will leave for Geneva tonight to place himself in contact with Salvador de Madariaga, chairman of the League of Nations Committee of Thirteen.

TRENTON, April 14. -- The New Jersey Assembly late tonight passed the "Luxury Tax" Bill in the tenth vote taken on the measure this session. Passage was made possible by the votes of three Democratic members who cast their ballots for the bill after voting against it when it was moved earlier in the evening for the ninth time.

The great paradox of American recovery is the rise of relief expenditures in the face of consistent and continuing improvement of the economic situation. Consider the changes of the last two years. Using in each case Government figures for the latest date available, and comparing them with corresponding figures of two years ago, we find:

Gross production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 2,890,050 barrels daily, compared with 2,873,900 in the preceding week, a rise of 16,150, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Upturns of 22,300 and of 11,700 barrels, respectively, in Oklahoma and Texas and a decrease of 10,250 in Louisiana were the important changes.

Like its principal characters, "Bury the Dead" refuses to stay put. First it was to open at the Fulton on Thursday, then it was Friday. Now Impresario Yokel says Saturday, with the location keeping step with the march of progress and shifting to the Barrymore.
HAVANA, April 14. -- The House of Representatives failed to reach an agreement today concerning the election of a president of that body as the split in the three-party coalition widened.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 14. -- In an apparent attempt to obtain a larger share of the estate of the late Colonel Henry H. Rogers, Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers, his widow and third wife, petitioned Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau here today to set aside a waiver she signed agreeing to the provisions of Colonel Rogers's will.

Daylight Saving Time will go into effect at 2 A.M. on April 26 in more than 300 cities, towns and villages in this State, according to a survey by the Merchants Association of New York, made public yesterday. It will end at 2 A.M. Sept. 27.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission was urged yesterday by representatives of a dozen or more women's groups to discard its plan to limit to men an examination soon to be held as a preliminary to the setting up of a civil service eligible list for court attendant posts.

The share market suffered its widest decline yesterday since March 13 when the European "war scare" induced active selling. Many leading stocks dropped 1 to 5 points yesterday in trading that amounted to 1,936,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, the heaviest since April 6.

The New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, which has steadily improved in its concerts given this season, concluded its season under Antonia Brico's leadership last night in Carnegie Hall. The concert began with a suave and sensitive performance of Mendelssohn's "Italian" symphony, a work which makes its main demands upon the strings but also asks finished playing of wood and horns.

The Northern Pacific Railway is considering refunding at a lower rate of interest $105,959,000 of refunding and improvement 6 per cent bonds due in 2047, Charles Donnelly, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

GIBRALTAR, April 14. -- With Chinese art treasures valued at about $50,000,000 aboard her, the British liner Ranpura tonight lies firmly wedged in sand in the Bay of Gibraltar. She went aground this morning in a gale and day-long efforts of the most powerful Admiralty tugs have failed to refloat her.

Attorney General Homer S. Cummings filed suit for $1,081,298 in Federal court yesterday against the estate of the late Johann Friedrich Hackfeld, sugar factor of Honolulu, alleging that the latter had offered fraudulent proof of citizenship to recover money and property seized under the Trading With the Enemy Act at the time of the World War.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- An attack on the Social Security Act as an evasion of the immediate problems of unemployment and as a costly and cumbersome measure based upon outworn social insurance models was made today by witnesses at a hearing on the Frazier Workers' Social Insurance Bill before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor.

The Goddard Neighborhood Center was the beneficiary of a garden fete held yesterday during the tea and dinner hours to mark the formal opening of the Garden Room of the Park Lane. After dinner there were divertissements by theatrical, radio and motion picture performers.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Two million veterans of the World War will receive checks and 3 per cent bonds through payment of the soldiers' bonus on June 15, Secretary Morgenthau told a conference of veterans' organizations' officials today.

Amid the gay and festive setting of a flag-bedecked arena and a crowd of 56,000, one of the largest inaugural gatherings in the history of the Polo Grounds, Colonel Bill Terry's Giants opened the National League's 1936 pennant race in New York yesterday in gaudy, if not exactly precise, fashion. They thrashed Casey Stengel's Dodgers, and so sent half the vast assemblage home pretty well satisfied with the outlook in general.
ALBANY, April 14. -- Following are the texts of two decisions today by the Court of Appeals relative to the powers of the Mortgage Commission:

The most immediate fear of inflation comes from the unbalanced Federal budget and unwillingness to levy taxes and to decrease expenses so as to balance the budget, Orrin G. Wood, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, told investment bankers at a luncheon yesterday in the Bankers Club arranged by the association's New York group.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP). -- Boston's high-priced Red Sox offset wabbly pitching and ragged fielding with lusty slugging today to gain a 9-4 opening-day triumph over the Philadelphia Athletics before an official crowd of 29,100.

Captain George Eyston, English auto racer second in fame only to Sir Malcolm Campbell, arrived aboard the Cunard-White Star Aquitania yesterday, accompanied by a co-driver, an engineer and two mechanics, and bringing with him two crated racing machines.

There was a Motor Fuels Symposium yesterday at Kansas City, Mo., where the American Chemical Society is meeting to review the accomplishments of chemists in many fields. The symposium is of national interest because the friends of the farmer, not content with the distribution of largess by the Government, advocated what amounts to the compulsory blending of gasoline with alcohol distilled from surplus or waste farm products.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 14. -- The launching of the government's sugar program as a part of the island reconstruction plan was revealed this afternoon when the purchase of the Lafayette Central from its French owners was announced by Carlos Chardon, acting administrator of the Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration.

LONDON, April 14. -- The London Stock Exchange, after the holiday, reopened quiet today with prices irregular owing to the continued political uncertainty, although the undertone was firm. British funds were steady.

With the open-air boxing season about to begin, Minority Leader Thomas J. Curran introduced a local law in the Aldermanic branch of the municipal Assembly yesterday requiring promoters either to pay a 10 per cent city tax on tickets or to mark the location of seats plainly on tickets.

Midnight tonight is the deadline for filing State income tax returns and making at least a part payment. Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, warned taxpayers yesterday that returns postmarked after 12 midnight would be liable to penalties.

LONDON, April 14. -- As is customary in these times of open diplomacy, the conference of the general staffs of Great Britain, France and Belgium, the preliminaries of which have now begun in London, possesses an inner meaning.

MONTREAL, April 14. -- With output of newsprint paper by Canadian mills last month setting a new all-time record for March, production for the first quarter of 1936 reached a total of 693,424 tons, by far the largest volume for any quarter in the Canadian industry's history and an increase of nearly 18 per cent over production in the first quarter of 1935.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The Inter-American Peace Conference, which is to be held in Buenos Aires at the suggestion of President Roosevelt, offers an opportunity for the American nations "to set an example to the world of friendly cooperation and enlightened internationalism," Secretary Hull said tonight in an address to the Pan American Union during a program to celebrate "Pan-American Day."

STRATFORD, Conn., April 14. -- Two world altitude records were claimed for a Sikorsky S-43 amphibian plane after it had soared to 27,950 feel with a 500-kilogram pay load here today, with Chief Test Pilot Boris Sergievsky at the controls.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 14 (AP). -- The thirty-sixth annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress closed its 37-day run today with new champions crowned in every division.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The House today adopted the conference report and completed legislative action on the bill authorizing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to lend up to $50,000,000 for repairing industrial damage done by the floods in the Eastern part of the country last month.
WASHINGTON, April 14. -- A ninth-inning attack on Lefty Gomez gave the Senators a 1-0 victory over the Yankees today in the first game of the American League championship season at Griffith Stadium.

CALGARY, Alta., April 14 (Canadian Press). -- Charles Cockroft, Alberta Provincial Treasurer, revealed that the Social Credit government is going forward with its proposed refunding of the Province's debt of $160,000,000.

The Duchess of Manchester, the Count de Moustier, Lady Jean Dundas and Sir James and Lady Calder are among the persons leaving tonight for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania. Others leaving on the ship include Mr. and Mrs. Martin Beck, C.J. Lyttleton, Mr. and Mrs. F.R. Guinness, Mr. and Mrs. J. Ward Seabury, Captain J.M. Cobbald, Mrs. P.G. Milne-Mitchell, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond von Hofmannstahl, Captain A.W.L. Paget and Miss Auriol Lee.

Although the dry sections in the Western belt continued without rain the improved weather east of the Mississippi River caused an easier trend on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices lost 1 to 12 points. With trade covering of May obligations and houses doing government business still inactive, the near month held around previous closing figures, and a final quotation of 11.34 cents a pound compared with 11.70 cents at the eight delivery markets.
LONDON, April 14. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden will leave for Geneva tomorrow on what appears to be one of the most hopeless missions of his career.

Herbert Morrison, one of the leaders of the British Labor party, arrived on the Aquitania yesterday morning to make his first visit to the United States. If there is another Labor Prime Minister in England, Mr. Morrison is in line for the office.

NANKING, April 14 (AP). -- Chinese official sources said today the activity of Japanese military agents in North China, allegedly directed toward seeking independence for that region, had suddenly been renewed.

MANILA, Wednesday, April 15 (AP). -- Two destroyers of the United States Navy's Asiatic fleet collided last night during manoeuvres forty-five miles northwest of Negra Point, at the northwestern tip of Luzon Island, navy officials announced today. They said no one was injured, but the ships were reported badly damaged.

The Tri-Continental Corporation and its affiliated investment trusts -- Selected Industries, Inc.; the Capital Administration Company, Ltd., and Broad Street Investing Company, Inc. -- reported yesterday increases in their net assets for the first quarter of this year.

The most important movement in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange developed in the more speculative domestic corporate issues, which, influenced by the weakness in the stock market, sustained substantial reactions. Meanwhile, high-grade investment bonds, including United States Government loans, held firm to slightly better in quiet trading.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- John Kelley held Penn to three scratch hits today and Boston College won its second game on the Southern trip, 4 to 1. Two of the hits were made by Jim Hauze, who drove in Joe Bienstein with Penn's only run.
BUENOS AIRES, April 14. -- An Argentine polo team will visit the United States this year to play for the Cup of the Americas, the Argentine Polo Association announced today.

MADRID, April 14. -- The celebration of the second Spanish Republic's fifth anniversary today was marred by death and violence in Madrid and several provincial capitals. One person was killed and four were injured here, and about fifty arrests were made. There were disorders in Jerez de la Frontera, Segovia and other towns, but the rigid press censorship enforced by the Azana government has made it almost impossible to obtain details.
CINCINNATI, April 14 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates batted Cincinnati's No. 1 pitcher, Paul Derringer, from the box in the third inning today and won their initial National League contest, 8 to 6.

Offering to the public by means of a prospectus will be made today by C.B. Ewart Co., Inc., of 35,000 shares of preferred stock and 17,500 shares of common stock of San-Nap-Pak Manufacturing Company, Inc. The preferred stock will be offered with 10,500 shares of the common stock in units of ten shares of preferred and three shares of common at a price of $100 a unit.

While business failures declined in the manufacturing division in the week ended April 9 as compared with the previous week, there was a slight increase in the retail group, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

MONTREAL, April 14. -- Opinion here is inclined to favor the proposed Lake Champlain seaway canal, which has been approved by representatives of thirteen chambers of commerce, members of the Northern New York Federation, at their meeting at Potsdam, N.Y.

Holding that the Chase National Bank was not liable for damages in a $10,000,000 suit brought against it by holders of securities of a former Insull company, Supreme Court Justice Samuel I Rosenman declared yesterday that modern trust indentures, covering investments of billions of dollars, were "utterly unjust to the investing public" and possessed "all the potentialities of fraud upon innocent investors."

Morris High School's nine topped Commerce, 4 to 3, at Sterling Oval, in the opener for both teams in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division P.S.A.L. race yesterday. The battle was a postponed affair, and it was one of nine struggles in which local teams figured.

ALBANY, April 14. -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Orange, denounced today the plan to construct the Midtown Tunnel under the East River to Queens and declared that he was preparing a bill to substitute a bridge at a saving he estimated at $36,000,000.

Frank V. Kelly was re-elected Brooklyn Democratic leader yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the Democratic State Committee members in the Jefferson Building, 4-5 Court Square. About the same time the Republican district leaders were re-electing John R. Crews as their county chieftain at a meeting at Republican headquarters, 160 Montague Street.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14 -- Scoring heavily in the early innings, Princeton's baseball team gained an 8-0 victory over the Panzer College nine on University Field today. It was the second triumph in six starts for the Tigers.

A laboratory experiment which went awry has brought about the development of a new photographic emulsion for coating films, plates or paper. It functions in a directly opposite manner from emulsions in common use. The new solution, with the use of ordinary developing materials, prints positives from positives and negatives from negatives instantly.

John S. Sumner, secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, testifying yesterday in Supreme Court, gave a clean bill of morality to the statue of Civic Virtue, the often criticized "Tough Guy" of City Hall Park, but said he could not pass judgment on nude statues in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, as he had not visited the museum in twenty years.

This day seventy-one years ago is vivid in the mind of Isador Lewi, veteran New York newspaper man now approaching his eighty-sixth birthday. On the night before, April 14, 1865, Abraham Lincoln had been shot at Ford's Theatre and after living through the night he died on April 15.

Ralph (Indian) Hurtado, newest lightweight sensation from Panama, gave another cool and workmanlike performance at the New York Coliseum last night as he punched his way to a technical knockout victory over Irish Eddie Brink of Scranton, Pa., before a crowd of 7,000.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, April 15. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, was leading Senator Borah of Idaho in returns early today in yesterday's Illinois preferential vote on candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 14. -- Although Eldon and Kenneth Trimingham's Saga of Bermuda once more demonstrated her superiority over the other six-meter sloops, the United States team of four boats took the lead today as the series for the Governor Cubitt Cup got under way.

Mrs. Marie Belloc Lowndes, sister of Hilaire Belloc, and herself a noted English novelist Who has written thirty books, arrived yesterday on the Cunard ,White Star liner Aquitania on her annual visit to the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Evidence that one of the objectives of the Farmers Independence Council of America was the "elimination" of the New Deal was produced by the Senate Lobby Committee today as is sought to prove that the council is an ally of the Republican party.

The Mercer County grand jury at Trenton, N.J., abandoned yesterday all efforts to obtain the testimony of Dr. John F. Condon in connection with its investigation of Paul H. Wendel's "confession," later repudiated, that he and not Bruno Richard Hauptmann, executed on April 3, kidnapped Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

William F. McGuinness, an assistant district attorney of Kings County, and Joseph Cummings, an auditor on the staff of William F.X. Geoghan, District Attorney, appeared yesterday before the extraordinary grand jury which is now investigating charges of bribery and police brutality in connection with the Samuel Drukman murder case in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The House bloc demanding that $700,000,000 of the new $1,500,000,000 relief appropriation requested by the President be set aside for public works was left to its own resources today when Secretary Ickes denied any connection with the move.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S speech to the Young Democrats of Maryland must have been a surprise to the political sugurs. They had predicted that he would begin his campaign for re-election with a fiery summons to his party, and a defiance of all the foes of the New Deal. In fact, he did nothing of the kind.

An exhibition of paintings by Jean-Louis Forain has opened at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until May 2. Forain's prints are shown much more frequently than are his oils and for that reason the present display should prove especially welcome.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- President Roosevelt's reference to shorter hours for labor in his first campaign speech in Baltimore last night aroused much criticism today among Republicans, who held it looked like an attempt to ignore the NRA decision of the Supreme Court.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14. -- The San Francisco Waterfront Employers Association today suspended relations with the Stevedores Local 38-79, International Longshoremen's Association, after the dock workers refused to handle cargo of the Grace liner Santa Rosa when the ship arrived here this morning from New York.

A gala luncheon and fashion show were held yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin to aid the work of the Emergency Shelter of this city. The stage setting for the function represented an English garden with flowering cherry trees, formal boxwood and a marble statue of Pan.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- While the Republicans in Congress, led by Senator Vandenberg and others, sought today to get together for a united fight on the administration work-relief program, the division among Democrats over earmarking for the PWA $700,000,000 of the $1,500,000,000 asked by President Roosevelt for work relief to be administered by the WPA gave heart to the opposition.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 14. -- Benefited by the advantage of Florida competition and stronger handling, Mrs. R.H. Heighe's Zay defeated Alfred Gwynne Venderbilt's Good Gamble by a head in the featured Belair Purse today at Havre de Grace.

CHICAGO, April 14. -- The scholastic ranking of the Massen family was realigned today to read like this: First, John Massen Jr.; second, Mrs. Massen; third, Alderman John Massen Sr., the former champion.

CHICAGO, April 14. -- Consumer resistance to paying what is regarded as a high price for fresh pork led to less aggressive buying of hogs here today and prices were quoted as steady to 15 cents a hundred pounds lower, with lard-type offerings showing comparative strength.

ST. LOUIS, April 14. -- Sinking Dizzy Dean with a blistering bombardment of base hits, the champion Cubs of the National League opened the season today with a 12-7 victory over their chief rivals, the Cardinals.

Communism and the movement for government control of education in the United States were roundly condemned yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Catholic Educational Association, which opened formally with a pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral and continued with sessions at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed in March was reported today by the Census Bureau at 548,913 bales Of lint and 60,811 of linters, compared with 516,649 and 53,565, respectively, in February this year, and 482,373 and 65,810 in March of last year.

A PROFILE view of Congress, obtained by standing sufficiently far to the Left so that the confusions of traditional partisanships and sentiments are avoided, and every blemish is clear and all weaknesses obvious, is offered by Ernest Sutherland Bates in "The Story of Congress, 1789-1935" (Harper, $3).

A leaning toward support of President Roosevelt in the coming campaign, but hesitancy in so doing now because of the fear that the President may yield to conservative pressure from within his own party, is evinced by Mayor La Guardia, in an article in the current issue of Liberty, entitled "What Will the Republican Progressives Do?"

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP). -- The White Sox, picking up momentum in the sixth and eighth innings, when they scored five times, whipped the Browns, 7 -- 6, today to open the American League season before 12,000 fans.

If it is "Macbeth" that the WPA folk are staging in Harlem at the Lafayette Theatre these evenings, we shall have to wear a schoolmaster's frown. If it is a voodoo show suggested by the Macbeth legend, we can toss a sweaty night-cap in the air.

ALBANY, April 14. -- Three important decisions upholding the powers of the State Mortgage Commission were handed down by the Court of Appeals today. One fixed the right of the commission to reorganize mortgage issues in the absence of dissent by certificate holders Another ruled that the commission may borrow money to pay taxes in arrears and other taxes not immediately due, and for foreclosure expenses.

Registration of visiting buyers in town during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the preceding week and over the corresponding period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. During the week the total number of buyers listed was 745, as against 657 in the previous week and 556 in the same period last year.

Turkey declines to follow the Nazi precedent of repudiation of treaties and negotiation afterward, and apparently is to be rewarded for its appeal to reason rather than to force. Last Friday the Turkish Foreign Minister announced his Government's decision formally to request the Powers signatory to the Treaty of Lausanne to agree to the modification of the convention relating to the demilitarization of the Straits and the zone of the Dardanelles.

WILDWOOD, N.J., April 14 (AP). -- Ray Mangrum of Los Angeles won the Wildwood Golf Club's second annual open tournament today and carried off $500 first prize money, but he was forced into a ten-hole play-off with Leonard Dodson of Pembine, Wis., who overcame a six-stroke deficit at the three- quarter mark to tie Mangrum at 294 for the seventy-two holes.

Sugar futures yesterday scored the broadest advance since Jan. 7 and overshadowed the trading in all other futures on the commodity markets here. In the cash markets wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, silk, eggs and wool tops were higher, while cotton and tin were lower.

Leasing of several large apartments was reported yesterday. Among these was a duplex of eighteen rooms and eight baths in 740 Park Avenue, leased to Marshall Field by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., for Douglas Gibbons Co., agents.

Support of the Wagner Housing Bill, now pending in Congress, was pledged yesterday by Mayor La Guardia after he had shoveled the first concrete for the Ten Eyck Houses, the $12,500,000 PWA low-rent housing project covering twelve city blocks in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn.

Deaths of infants under one year declined sharply last week to a total of only eighty-four, 'the Department of Health reported yesterday. The rate per 1,000 live births was 43.7, compared to 49.9 a year ago and 50.4 in the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Purchase by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of $3,840,000 of 4 per cent equipment trust certificates of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

NEWARK, N.J., April 14. -- A meeting of the City Commission at 2 P.M., the exact hour at which the first Mayor and Common Council met 100 years ago tomorrow, will mark the opening of the celebration of Newark 100 years as a city.

WHEELING, W.VA., April 14.-- Champion Milson O'Boy, Irish setter owned by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York and handled by Harry Hartnett, won his forty-first best of breed award today at the opening of the second annual dog show of the Tri-State Kennel Association.

A new era in the relations between Japan and the United States, based upon policies that arise from the "common sentiments'' of Both nations, is envisaged in a message to Premier Koki Hirota of Japan, signed by twenty-seven men prominent in financial, educational, journalistic and church circles in this country.
In the midst of the higher mathematics involved in calculating their State income tax, citizens of New York may have paused to speculate upon some abstruse questions of fiscal theory:

The undefeated Long Island University nine staged a four-run drive in the sixth frame to down Providence College, 7 -- 2, in the second game of a twin bill at Dexter Park yesterday. In the opener Providence won from St. John's, 4 -- 3.
Scene, Jamaica, April 14, day before opening. Weather clear; track fast.
Investment housing purchases in three boroughs featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

The formation of Lobdell Co. and changes in several other firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange were announced yesterday by the Exchange. Partners of the new firm will be David S., Charles E. and Janet E. Lobdell, Clayton Snyder, John G. Hopkins, David A. and Ida R.

Random ramblings: A bouquet for the Ramapo Rod and Gun Club of Suffern, N.Y ... E.N. Price, secretary, tells us that the club is sponsoring a junior organization. ... Members will take boys fishing, teach them fly and bait casting instruct them in fly tying, and will stage casting contests for the youngsters ...

ALBANY, April 14. -- The legislative conference committee appointed to break the deadlock between the Democratic Senate and the Republican Assembly over Governor Lehman's budget and revenue program held its second meeting today and adjourned for a week without agreeing on any question before it.

New York City is losing hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of retail business annually to other communities because of the 2 per cent sales tax levied for unemployment relief, Lee J. Eastman, president of the Packard Motor Car Company of New York, told 650 members of the American Arbitration Association and their guests at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

Edward Lee of New York won his fifth straight game in the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship last night, further entrenching himself in first place. He defeated Edmond Soussa of Egypt, former champion and present national amateur balkline titleholder, 50 to 31, in sixty-four innings.

While disclaiming any intention to encourage formation of organizations of WPA employes in opposition to the City Projects Council and others characterized as Communist, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, said yesterday that should such opposition organizations be formed he would accord them recognition in so far as they were really representative of the WPA.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP). -- The Automobile Manufacturers Association, trade organization of the motor industry, has resigned from the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Describing unification of courts as "the most necessary improvement in our judicial system," Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division, First Department, suggested last night that all New York City courts be merged into three general tribunals.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The law which permitted the City of New York to reduce the pay of the policemen, firemen and others and thus save some $18,000,000 was not repealed by a concurrent resolution of the Legislature, the Court of Appeals ruled today in denying a mandamus order asked by Joseph P. Moran, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

KANSAS CITY, April 14. -- Warfare between large industrial interests over the merits of high-proof alcohol as a blend with gasoline for use as a motor fuel burst out into the open for the first time today at the meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Ultra-violet rays, effective as a detecting medium where other methods had failed, brought out yesterday stains on the skirt, bathrobe and bedspread taken by the police from the apartment of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, at 22 Beekman Place, after she had been murdered last Friday.

The Rev. Leopold J. Tibsar was elected president of the Catholic Anthropological Conference at the eleventh annual meeting of that organization yesterday at Fordham University. The Rev. Francis P. LeBuffe was named vice president and Dr. John M. Cooper secretary-treasurer.

Spring leasing in the commercial field has taken a spurt following the Easter holidays. Brokers reported long lists of new contracts for store and office space, many of these rentals involving quarters in the Fifth Avenue shopping district.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Preservation in the proposed revision of the copyright law of the present statutory damage penalty of $250 for infringement was urged today before the House Patents Committee for the protection of the motion picture industry and of theatre owners by Gabriel L. Hess, representing the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., and Edward P. Kilroe of Fox Film Company and Movietone Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- The cost of the recent floods in property damage to the Pennsylvania Rail-road may amount to $8,500,000, exclusive of an additional loss of about $4,000,000 in traffic revenues, A.J. County, vice president of finance, told stockholders at the annual meeting today.
The annual Butterfly Ball, given for the third year as a dinner dance, took place last night in the main ballroom and oval restaurant of the Ritz-Carlton. Several hundred persons attended.

Successful in drawing his last game against one of his chief rivals for the place, Sidney Bernstein of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday completed his schedule in Group C of the United States chess championship preliminaries at the Empire City Chess Club and, having made sure of second place in that division, qualified for the grand final, which will begin at the Hotel Astor on April 25.

I am writing to inquire whether something cannot be done about Sol Bloom. He got into the newspapers by disclaiming the ability of our illustrious G. Washington to hurl a silver coin of rather indeterminate value across a certain river. A certain Big Train, hero of a million boys, pricked that bubble.

Merchant shipbuilding in the last three months increased 276,961 tons, or nearly 20 per cent, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, published yesterday. The total under way in the shipyards of the world on March 31 was 1,820,114 tons, as compared with 1,543,153 tons at the start of the year.

Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, intimated in a speech last night that the time would soon come when the Metropolitan season would run from eight to ten months. He added that he could see "no reason why New York cannot have Summer Metropolitan Opera."

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- American entrance into the International Copyright Union through adherence to the Berne convention was urged today by Dr. Wallace McClure of the Department of State, and opposed by Nathan Burkan on behalf of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, and Gabriel L. Hess, for the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., at the final hearing on the Duffy Copyright Bill before the House Patents Committee.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 15. -- No protest was made by stockholders of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad at the annual meeting here today against the reorganization proceedings started several months ago.

A weekly weather report showing the year thus far had been the driest on record in much of the Western cotton belt, with conditions the last week decidedly unfavorable, brought a recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. While holders of the May continued to reduce their interest in advance of first notice day, an increased demand for new crop contracts caused an improvement of 3 to 9 points on the day.

CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP). -- Paced by Hal Trosky and Bruce Campbell, the Indians squared the series with the Tigers today, scoring eight runs in a wild third inning, knocking the world-series hero Tommy Bridges from the box and coasting to a 14-7 victory.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The House rejected today a joint resolution to permit the Senate Lobby Committee to pay counsel, in its litigation with William Randolph Hearst over the seizure of telegrams, at a rate far above that allowed by existing law.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP). -- The Boston Bees, in a fourth-inning scoring rampage, sent nine runs across the plate and defeated the Phillies, 12 to 4, today.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Regular flights over a period of six months beginning in May will be carried out by the dirigible Hindenburg from Frankfurt-am-Main to Lakehurst, N.J., under a schedule completed by the Zeppelin Company with the Navy Department and announced today.

Arthur Livingston, editor and co-translator of Pareto's "Mind and Society," is the translator of Octave Aubry's "Saint Helena," which Lippincott will publish in the Autumn. Part of the book, which is said to establish Mr. Aubry as the greatest living French authority on Napoleon, was published in serial form in the Revue des Deux Mondes.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 15. -- The St. John's nine snapped its three-game losing streak today at the expense of the Upsala College team, 9 to 5.

Local offices of the State Department of Taxation and Finance were crowded yesterday with persons who had waited until the last minute to file their income-tax returns. Wesley M. Dawson, district supervisor, estimated that 25,000 persons had visited the office at 80 Centre Street between 9 A.M. and 9 P.M., when it closed.

Representatives of the intercoastal freight lines, who have been in session nearly three weeks in an attempt to reconcile their differences, agreed yesterday to recognize a single rate classification in their trade and to effect a new organization to settle operative controversies.

The Park Department completed plans yesterday for welcoming, the sixth millionth visitor to the Central Park Zoo, an event which is expected to take place some time Sunday afternoon. Last night the total had reached 5,891,033.

Multi-family buildings formed the bulk of foreclosed real estate in Manhattan yesterday. Auctioneers were kept busy at thirteen, sales in the borough, all the parcels being struck down to the plaintiffs, who instituted the court actions to protect their liens.
KANSAS CITY, April 15 (AP). -- Oscar S. Stauffer, chairman of the Landon-for-President Committee, said in a statement today:
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quota{dons for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

More than 500 persons, most of them representing various groups which form the Joint Committee of Participating Army and Navy Organizations, attended a testimonial dinner and dance last night in honor of Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, and Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., commander of the Third Naval District, both of whom will retire from service at the end of' this month.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Additional registration statements covering twelve separate stock and bond issues by as many corporations have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, that agency announced today. They were summarized by the commission as follows:

Liquidation of accumulated dividends on the preferred stock and resumption of regular payments, as well as dividends on the common shares, must await the retirement of $5,500,000 of debenture bonds which are not due until May, 1940, H.S. Wilkinson, chairman, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting of the Crucible Steel Company of America.
Miss Arrietta Smith was elected president of the Junior League of Brooklyn yesterday at the annual meeting of the league, held at the Hotel Bossert. Miss Althea McCammon is the retiring president.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 15. -- What was described by the inhabitants as the first real day of Spring-like weather brought leaves out along the banks of Carnegie Lake this afternoon and produced eight-oared crews on its surface in almost as great a number.

Cycle, 12-1 shot from the Howe Stable, captured the $7,400 Paumonok Handicap as Jamaica opened yesterday for the beginning of the New York racing season, which will continue until the end of October. The favored King Saxon, last year's winner and record holder, as well as the Futurity victor, Tintagel, which is eligible for the Kentucky Derby, could do nothing with the son of Sickle, which scored by five lengths.

TRENTON, April 15. -- The Mercer County grand jury completed here tonight its two weeks' investigation into the "confession" by Paul H. Wendel, 51-year-old disbarred lawyer, that he kidnapped and murdered the Lindbergh baby. It voted no indictment.

Continued record high payments of real estate taxes for the current year, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced last night, will make it possible for him to redeem today the $5,000,000 balance of a $25,000,000 revenue bill issue borrowed in anticipation of tax collections.

Deploring secular trends in modern education, the Rev. William J. McGucken, regent of the school of education of St. Louis University, urged yesterday that institutions preparing parochial school teachers be "Catholic in tone" in every subject.

CINCINNATI, April 15 (AP). -- Singles by Forrest Jensen and Paul Waner in the ninth inning, combined with an error by Ival Goodman, gave the Pirates their second consecutive victory over Cincinnati today, 7 to 6. The Reds filled the bases in the ninth but George McQuinn, whose triple scored two of the four runs in the Reds' big fifth inning, struck out.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15. -- Results of stratosphere studies which may help to penetrate further the mystery of the cosmic ray and its possible effect upon the future of the universe were reported tonight by Dr. W.F.G. Swann, director of the Bartol Research Foundation of the Franklin Institute.

There is a deep trench in Walter Muller's front yard at 36-22 Thirty-fourth Street, Astoria, Queens, which looks as though workmen had left open a sewer excavation. But to Muller it is the possible end of the depression for him. It is his own private gold mine within the city limits.

GENEVA, April 15. -- The following statistics, made public today by the League of Nations, show the value of Italian imports and exports for the first four months after sanctions went into effect, as compared with the respective months a year previous, as well as the value of imports from and exports to Italy by individual countries during those months. All figures are computed in gold dollars of the pro-devaluation rate.

Predicting that the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Bill will become a law at this session of Congress, Representative Wright Patman told the New York Pharmaceutical Council last night that a rule which will provide for immediate consideration of the measure is expected to be adopted by the House within the next ten days.

PARIS, April 15. -- In a fighting speech delivered before editors and correspondents of French provincial journals here tonight, Premier Albert Sarraut said France was strong enough to protect her interests by force.

Although it is with regret one learns that the young student Lloyd Lewis, originally adjudged winner of the Cantor peace essay award, lifted his material from a published article by Dr. Frank Kingdon, yet it does not seem to me to be so extraordinary or shocking.

Criticism of the Federal Communications Commission's methods at public hearings on its investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was voiced yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president of the company, at the annual meeting of stockholders, attended by about 400 persons.

Slightly firmer prices prevailed in most staples on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Cottonseed oil and raw hide futures eased moderately. Trading in general was dull. On the cash markets all them grains, wool tops, standard tin, Rio coffee and rubber, the latter at a new high, showed gains, while cotton, butter, eggs, cocoa and silk declined.

One earnest lady would solve the unemployment problem by deporting 7,500,000 aliens and giving their jobs to "Americans." Actually the results may be even more gratifying than she anticipates. For instance, sending 7,500,000 people out of the country means a great many new jobs in shipping and shipbuilding and land transportation of all kinds.

Pointing out that the current picture offers little indication of a reaction in the rate of steel production for at least another month, The Iron Age says that a leveling off around the 70 per cent level would not be surprising. It adds, however, that the strong and diversified character of current demand would seem to preclude any tendency toward a decline.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 (AP). -- Orders to omit scheduled stops here were given to several steamships by line officials today in the wake of a waterfront labor crisis which already has tied up a large intercoastal Uner.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP). -- With its own nationwide investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company continuing, the Federal Communications Commission was reported today to be cooperating with States and cities in their local inquiries into telephone rates.
A fairly evenly balanced array of eight teams will swing into action today, weather permitting, in the opening of the International League's fifty-third season.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Representatives of the six New England States and New York, advocating passage of the Citron resolution authorizing the States to enter into compacts for flood control of streams where drainage basins lie within two or more States, were assured of Federal assistance when they appeared before a House Judiciary subcommittee today.

Seven men were arrested on charges of "conspiring to defraud" in a raid a little after noon yesterday on the offices of the Church Bulletin Calendar Guide at 1 Hudson Street. The raid was led by Americus Delli Paoli, Assistant District Attorney, and Detective Sergeant William J. Quaine of District Attorney Dodge's office.

LONDON, April 15 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade's figures for March: Total imports, 68,050,000; exports of British products, 36,510,000; re-exports, 5,900,000; total exports, 42,410,000; excess of imports, 25,640,000.

CHICAGO, April 15. -- Late returns today indicated a plurality of 80,000 for Colonel Frank Knox in yesterday's primary for the Republican Presidential preference vote of Illinois, but Senator Borah apparently had carried thirteen of the fifteen down-State Congressional districts.

Albert C. Simonson of the Manhattan Club, a member of one of the victorious United States international teams, and Arnold S. Denker of the same club, erstwhile Bronx champion, were added last night to the candidates who will compete in the finals for the United States chess championship which will begin in New York a week from Saturday.

The French Government, French hotels and railroads have joined forces to stimulate American travel in France, according to Ernest Peyromaure-Debord, deputy commissioner of the French Bureau of Tourism. Mr. Peyromaure-Debord, who is also a member of the Council of State, arrived in New York last week and is returning to France on the Lafayette, which sails Saturday.

Two large store properties were reported sold yesterday in Queens, where dwelling and apartment house construction has been proceeding at a brisk pace and in which the city subway soon is to be extended.

The management of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway announced yesterday that a plan for refunding dividend interest to loosen the grip of the Van Sweringen interests on the line was under consideration. The plan would increase the influence of the Taplin interests in the company.

BUENOS AIRES, April 15. -- Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas has sent President Roosevelt a draft treaty for consideration at the forthcoming peace conference at Buenos Aires designed to implement the good-neighbor policy by putting teeth Into already existing anti-war pacts and prohibiting by an inter-American treaty those policies of former United States Governments which have caused irritation in Latin America.

Contributions totaling $113,616.29 were reported yesterday by campaign workers at the first luncheon meeting of the annual Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army. The drive to raise $500,000 for the work of the Army here began ten days ago and will continue through May.
In THE TIMES article "Disorders at Sea Laid to Red Tape," F.L. Adams writes:
WASHINGTON, April 15. -- No more money will be allocated to the Passamaquoddy "tide-harnessing" power project or the Florida Ship Canal from present funds, President Roosevelt said today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15. -- Dr. Arthur A. Mitten, ousted from the chairmanship of the board of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company at the annual meeting of stockholders on March 18, was restored to the position today by Federal Judge George A. Welsh.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 15. -- Donald Budge and Gene Mako of the United States Davis Cup team finally arrived at Pinehurst from Houston, Texas, at 3 A.M. today and by nightfall the former was occupying a bracket in the semi-finals of the North and South championship tennis singles, while Mako found the ordeal too much and went down in the quarter-finals.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Officials here learned today that members of the House Appropriations Committee had questioned Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, at length on the white-collar part of the WPA program during closed hearings last week.

A foreign news agency headed its account the other day of European troubles by saying that the outlook for peace is "hopeless." One is reminded of the remark of an Austrian statesman at a time of crisis who, when asked what he thought of the situation, replied that it was "hopeless, but not serious."

The New York Cotton Exchange, through Perry E. Moore, chairman of its legislative committee, yesterday forwarded to the Senate Committee on Agriculture a letter reciting that E.A. Crawford was expelled from the Cotton Exchange on Sept. 8, 1933, on three charges, all of which he had admitted at his trial before the supervisory committee of the Exchange.

MOOSE RIVER, N.S., April 15 (AP). -- Provincial mining officials, clinging to a faint hope of rescuing three Toronto men trapped since Sunday in the Moose River Gold mine, began a new approach tonight.

CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP). -- The greatest boxing carnival in the history of the A.A.U. got under way tonight as 286 boys from all sections of the country swapped punches in quest of the national championships in eight divisions. Practically every State as well as Hawaii was represented.

MARGATE, England, April 15. -- Jose R. Capablanca of Havana and Salo Flohr of Prague were the winners in the first round of the international tournament of the Kent County Chess Association, play in which was begun today at the Grand Hotel in Cliftonville.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 15. -- Delegates began arriving here tonight for the two-day session of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers' convention, with a program devoted to consideration of the industry's problems.
WASHINGTON, April 15. -- "Knox carried Chicago but I carried Illinois" was the comment today of Senator Borah.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 15. -Scoring four runs in the final three innings, Lafayette's baseball team downed Princeton, 5 -- 3, on University Field today.

Fifteen group meetings, including a sales executives conference, will be held at the thirty-second annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America in Boston on June 28 to July 2. The sales meeting will be an innovation for the convention and will be organized by the International Association of Sales Executives of which Allen Zoll is president.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 15. -- Three thousand spectators saw Mrs. Marion du Pont Somerville's chestnut gelding, Oliver C., ridden by Noel Laing, capture the Glenwood, a timber race that featured the closing program of the Middleburg hunts meeting today.

CHICAGO, April 15. -- Receipts of hogs fell below trade expectations today, and while the shipping demand was slow, butchers and small packers were after supplies and prices were steady to 5 cents a hundredweight higher. The top was 5 cents higher than yesterday at $10.95 while the day's average was up a like amount at $10.60. Most sales were at $10.35 to $10.90.
UNION, N.J., April 15. -- Behind the effective hurling of Johnnie Morris, who did not allow a hit until the eighth inning, City College defeated Panzer at the tri-city stadium today, 6 -- 1.

The city of Yonkers, N.Y., awarded yesterday an issue of $1,265,000 of various bonds to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including Darby Co., Inc.; B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc.; Schlater, Noyes Gardner, Inc., and Burr Co., Inc., at a price of 100.046 for $962,000 of 3.30 per cent bonds and $303,000 of 3.10s.
Mayor La Guardia appealed to the public yesterday to support the drive for $1,500,000 conducted by twelve private relief agencies to carry on their work.

Two men were drowned yesterday when a ten-foot boat in which they were sailing off Execution Light in Long Island Sound capsized. Two others who set out in a boat from the S.S. Lorenz, bound for New York from Canada, tried to save them but could not reach them in time.

The New York branch of the American Pharmaceutical Association announced yesterday that Edmund N. Gathercoal, Professor of Pharmacognosy at the School of Pharmacy of the University of Illinois, will be the recipient of the Remington Honor Medal for 1936.

Stripped of all inaugural trimmings, but with a goodly sized gathering of 10,000 on hand to see the sport, the Giants and Dodgers settled down to some real fighting at the Polo Grounds yesterday and forthwith put on a rousing exhibition.

Undergraduates at City College will not be prohibited from holding an anti-war strike next Wednesday, although the assembly will not be recognized by the faculty, Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men, announced yesterday. Classes will continue as usual at 11 o'clock, when the meeting will be held, but no extra penalty for staying away from classes will be imposed by the administration, he said.
ALBANY, April 15. -- Following is the text of the prevailing opinion of the Court of Appeals declaring the Unemployment Insurance Law constitutional.

Leon Fischbein, a lawyer of 26 Court Street, Brooklyn, admitted yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook that he had written in a second name on a court order entitling him to see a prisoner in the Tombs. He explained that he had intended merely to correct a mistake by the court clerk from whom he had obtained the order.

More than 1,400 art teachers from educational institutions throughout the Eastern section of the country attended the opening session of the annual four-day convention of the Eastern Arts Association, held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

" Legislative leaders," we are not told of what stripe, are reported from Albany to be discussing the advisability of submitting another sizable unemployment relief bond issue to the voters at the Fall election. Republican anxieties on that score would be easy to understand.

DOVER, N.J., April 15. -- Sunny skies and Summer weather ushered in the North Jersey trout season today, but fewer anglers flocked to the shores of rushing streams, and as a result the trout fared much better than their brethren who were hauled out of the waters last year.

AUGUSTA, Me., April 15. -Through the announcement of Governor Louis J. Brann of his candidacy for United States Senator, the Democrats of Maine have greatly improved their chance of making a good showing in the September election, accepted throughout the country as a "political barometer" indicating the trend for the Presidential election in November.

LOS ANGELES, April 15. -- Dr. William Daniel Moriarty, 59, Professor of Economics at the University of Southern California, who exploded a bomb in a small sedan last night, killing himself and his wife, 55, and seriously injuring two friends, had "rehearsed" the act less than two weeks ago, driving the same group of friends to the same lonely spot where the tragedy occurred, police learned today in their inquiry.

PITTSBURGH, April 15. -- The Department of Commerce was warned today to "get to work" at once on its radio beam at the county airport if airplane tragedies like the crash of the Sun Racer were to be averted.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15. -- Latin may be a dead language; but classical farce, if it is properly produced, can still be counted among the lively arts. With a spirited gesture to the past, the Harvard Classical Club has revived the "Mostellaria" of Plautus as its contribution to the tercentenary celebration of the college, with masks, costumes and settings as nearly as possible like those of the theatre in the age of Cicero.

George Messersmith, United States Minister to Austria, and Mrs. Messersmith; George A. de Gripenberg, Finnish Minister to Great Britain, and Mrs. de Gripenberg; Alexander Woollcott, Princess Lowenstein and Captain H.M. Smyth are among the passengers due today from Europe on the Manhattan of the United States Lines.

A comprehensive ten-year program to modernize and add to the city hospital system at an estimated cost of $53,300,000 has been submitted at the request of Mayor La Guardia to the Mayor's Committee on City Planning, Hospital Commissioner S.S. Goldwater announced yesterday.

Arthur G. Kuney and Edward A. Sauter, president and treasurer, respectively, of the defunct Commonwealth Bond Corporation, were found guilty by a General Sessions jury late yesterday afternoon of the theft of about $4,600 of the corporation's funds that should have gone to bond and certificate holders.

MADISON, Wis., April 15 (AP). -- Complaints of price fixing and other alleged unfair trade practices in the oil industry will be presented to a special grand jury that will convene here on May 4, Attorney General Cummings today notified the office of the United States Attorney here.

ATHENS, April 15. -- The Turkish Minister to Greece has called at the Foreign Office to request enlightenment regarding Greece's attitude toward his government's decision to fortify the straits. It is expected Greece will not oppose the Turkish demand but will simultaneously propose changes in the Treaty of Lausanne that will permit Greece to fortify the islands of Lemnos, Chios, Samos and Mytilene, off the coast of Asia Minor.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- After nearly five hours of deliberation behind closed doors, the Senate was unable to reach a decision today on the articles of impeachment brought by the House against Judge Halsted L. Ritter of the Southern District of Florida.

Martin J. Deitz of Weehawken, Grand Master of Masons in New Jersey, addressed 800 members of Bluestone and Warren G. Harding Lodges of West New York, N.J., and the Mystic Tie Lodge at the latter's clubhouse in Union City, N.J., last night, while nearly 65,000 members in Masonic lodges throughout the State were meeting simultaneously to hear Mr. Deitz's address read to them.

Bunching ten hits effectively behind the flawless pitching of Pete Blumette, Manhattan's baseball team got off to a flying start on its 1936 campaign by overwhelming Brooklyn College, 11 to 1, at Manhattan Field yesterday.

There was a large gathering yesterday afternoon at the recital given by Queens Mario and Emanuel List of the Metropolitan Opera at the home of James Speyer, 1,058 Fifth Avenue, for the benefit of the New York Women's League for Animals.

The share market resumed where it left off before its setback on Tuesday, in that profit-taking was sporadic and the demand selective. The groups that met with most favor yesterday were the rubbers, the packing issues late in the day, and a scattering of leading issues in other classifications.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15. -- Showering lefts and rights, Leroy Haynes, Philadelphia Negro heavyweight, tonight knocked out Natie Brown of Washington in the second round at the Arena before 8,000 spectators. Haynes, recent con queror of Primo Camera, scored his sixth straight knockout when Referee Joe McGuigan counted out Brown 2 minutes 48 seconds after the round started.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Until there is a breakdown by counties of the vote in the Illinois Republican Presidential primary, the number of Illinois delegates who will support Senator Borah at Cleveland will be undetermined. But enough of the result is known to establish the fact that in the section vital to Republican success in November he has a remarkable personal following which must be reckoned with by the convention Warwicks.

Growing opposition to the dictatorships in Italy and Germany and a drift of Christians away from pacifism were cited yesterday by Dr. Daniel A. Poling, editor of The Christian Herald, as the main tendencies he had observed abroad on a recently completed ten-month tour.

HAVANA, April 15. -- The American scooner Fleetwood, with nine persons aboard, was forced to put into Cortes, a port on the south coast of Pinar del Rio Province, owing to illness of the navigator, Johan Johanson, according to Maurice Allard, head of the party, which had set out to found a Utopian colony at St. Thomas, Virgin Islands.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP). -- A group of Eastern railroads made a new move today before the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to provide more extensive pick-up and delivery service.

Mr. and Mrs. John V. Bouvier 3d of this city and East Hampton and Mr. and Mrs. John J. Ryan Jr. of Hewlett jointly gave a dinner and dance last night at the Bouvier home here, 740 Park Avenue, for two engaged couples whose marriages will take place soon.

LONDON, April 15. -- The defensive entente between Britain, France and Belgium became a reality at 11:30 o'clock this morning as a direct consequence of Germany's repudiation of the Locarno treaty and her remilitarization of the Rhineland.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 15. -- Weather extremes that ranged from frigid sleet in the early morning hours to Summer-like thunderstorms at midday, provided a dismal trout fishing inaugural for Connecticut anglers today. The turnout of fishermen was small in comparison with other openings.

March construction figures showed a 40 per cent increase over the figures for February and a 62 per cent increase over those for March, 1935, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. Construction contracts in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains totaled $199,028,300 last month, as compared with $142,050,200 for February and $122,940,500 for March, 1936.
An annual stockholders meeting which had continued for two days of fourteen hours each, ended last midnight in the main office of R. Hoe Co., Inc., at 138th Street and the East River.

Mr. and Mrs. John W. Bray gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 118 East Fifty-fourth Street, for Miss Itie Selleck Mac-Gregor of Washington, daughter of the late Judge and Mrs. Rob Roy MacGregor of Yankton, S.D., and Norman J. Beaudrias, whose marriage will take place this afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

THE battery for the rich Red Sox on opening day was W. Ferrell and R. Ferrell and this led to a little extra-inning discussion on family ties on the diamond. No one in the circle had anything except a reading knowledge of George and Harry Wright of ancient days, nor could the gathering furnish any eyewitnesses to speak up for the Delehantys.

When John Mulligan, 39 years old, of 502 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, received a one-day sentence to the city prison in Tombs Court yesterday on a charge of "public intoxication," he revealed that the horse attached to the bakery wagon he drives is expertly familiar with the city's traffic system.

The voice had the genial quality and the phrases, the mellow Victorian flavor, you would expect from the Squire of Green Escape, but it was the hoarseness that excited suspicion. It didn't sound quite like Christopher Morley.

The world economic outlook continued obscure in February, according to the monthly review of foreign conditions in the Second Quarter Review and Forecast Number of The Annalist of April 17. Industrial activity seems to have been fairly well maintained, outside of the United States and Canada, and international trade showed little change.

LINCOLN, Feb., April 15 (AP). -- Senator William E. Borah won a five-to-one victory in the Nebraska Republican preferential primary in which he had no official opposition but the "write-in" vote for Governor Alf M. Landon.

More than 5,400 veterans of the city's police force crouched for four hours yesterday in the little desk seats of three public schools working over examinations which will qualify some of them for promotion to the rank of sergeant. A few, who were too big for the small desks, got little tables in a "general science" classroom, where they labored under the eye of a young woman monitor.

Columbia's baseball forces turned the tables on N.Y.U. yesterday at Baker Field, but it was none too deft an operation. The Lions glided along smoothly behind a 5-0 lead most of the way, but at the finish just managed to stagger through to a 6-4 victory as the tying run was perched on second base.

In his recent letter to THE TIMES Mr. Whipple is evidently sincere in his convictions about the teachers' oath. He gives evidence in his own person of his belief that the best citizen is the one who knows least about government and economics. He does this by speaking of the totalitarian State and Marxism as synonymous, when they are, of course, the two extremes, between which lie all other known forms of government.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP). -- George M. Harrison, chairman of the railway labor executives committee, and John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, today expressed widely divergent views on the Wheeler bill to protect rail workers displaced in coordination projects. Both appeared at a Senate hearing on the measure.
Motorization of the street-car network of the New York Railways Corporation in Manhattan will be completed on Monday with the substitution of buses for trolley cars on the Fourteenth Street line.

LONDON, April 15. -- Wrapped in a Nazi swastika flag, the body of Dr. Leopold von Hoesch, German Ambassador to Great Britain, left Dover aboard a British destroyer today on its way to the family vault at Dresden.

Representative JONES, chairman of the Agricultural Committee, wants to retaliate. If they are going to make public the large AAA benefit payments, he wants them to make public the names of all corporations who have benefited from existing protective tariffs by $100,000 a year or more.

By an agreement among processors, overprinted designs or those achieved through so-called flock printing will now have to be registered, it was announced yesterday by Miss Irene L. Blunt, director of the Industrial Design Registration Bureau of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP). -- The White Sox belted Jack Knott and Russell Van Atta for eleven hits, including home runs by Mike Kreerich and Vernon Washington, to defeat the Browns today, 6 to 3, and make it two straight in the season's opening series.

Herbert L. Morrison, Laborite party leader and chairman of the London County Council, attacked the communism of the Third International last night as a step in the direction of fascism in an address at the Mecca Temple, West Fifty-fifth Street.

Robert A. Nesbit, associate aquatic biologist of the United States Bureau of Fisheries, reminds salt water anglers that they can be of assistance to the bureau in its investigation of the weakfish, a species which in recent years has shown such a marked decline in numbers as to create serious concern for the future supply.

The 382 relief employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau who are affected by the Lyons Residence Bill were still in possession of their jobs yesterday, enforcement of the bill having been suspended by Mayor La Guardia as soon as it was finally passed on Tuesday by the Board of Aldermen.

MADRID, April 15. -- Premier Manuel Azana tonight made his long-delayed ministerial declaration to the Cortes announcing his government's program. He admitted that the economic situation is causing grave concern and that maintenance of law and order is proving to be an extremely difficult problem.

The experience of settlement houses in the two and one-half years since repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment has produced divided opinions as to whether drinking has increased or decreased, according to replies to a questionnaire sent out by the State Liquor Authority to forty settlement house heads.
LONDON, April 15. -- Outstanding in the trading today on the London Stock Exchange was the renewed demand for British funds, which generally were higher. Elsewhere the list was quiet but mostly firm.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 15. -- Declaring that "It is idle for either young or old to assume a tribal hostility one to the other," because "both are essential to the progress of humanity," Walter W. Price, financier and author, today attacked President Roosevelt's Baltimore address.

First listed corporations to comply with the request of the New York Stock Exchange for twelve months' earnings reports at quarterly intervals were the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, which rendered their first-quarter statements yesterday.
ASMARA Eritrea, April 15. -- An Eritrean Army Corps today occupied Dessye, the only important town that had remained between the Italians and Addis Ababa.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15. -- Portentous calm prevailed in the waterfront labor crisis today as both sides apparently jockeyed for position in the dispute which threatens to tie up the shipping industry of the port and perhaps the entire West Coast.
Fingerprints have been found on a bedstead in the apartment at 22 Beekman Place in which Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, 34-year-old writer, was strangled last Friday, it was learned last night.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1936 a net profit of $3,732,454, equal to $1.40 a share on its combined preferred and common shares, compared with $2,326,496, or 87 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1935.

ALBANY, April 15. -- The Democratic campaign was opened in President Roosevelt's home State at a dinner here tonight at which 450 party leaders heard Postmaster General Farley predict the President's triumphant re-election and Governor Lehman extol the achievements of the party in the State during his administration.

The Roxy Theatre Corporation, which "could not have been sold for junk" when it went into receivership four years ago, is now earning a considerable operating profit, according to Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey, who granted yesterday a $62,000 allowance to attorneys for the receiver, Howard S. Cullman.

The Southern Railway estimated its net income in 1936 would be $3,851,000 in statements filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. This would compare with a net income of $2,773,136 in 1935. The company estimated it would have $4,000,000 on hand at the end of this year after payment of interest, taxes and equipment trust obligations.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- A Roosevelt First Voters League, which aims to win 5,000,000 of the 9,000,000 who, it is estimated, have come of age since the last Presidential election, was formed here today with the blessings of the Democratic National Committee.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 15 (AP). -- A.G. Vanderbilt's Postage Due, with Johnny Bejshak up, qualified handsomely for his engagement on Saturday in the mile and a sixteenth Chesapeake Stakes by running six furlongs in 1:12 1-5 today in the Grade A Handicap.

Frank H. Goodfellow, 56-year-old member of the Salle Santelli, won the first veterans' three-weapon competition of the Amateur Fencers League of America last night, in one of the most successful and entertaining events ever to be staged at the Fencers Club.

Wendell L. Wilkie, executive of one of the large utility holding companies, declared last night that the utilities could re-employ "tens of thousands of people" if they were relieved from government attacks and restrictive and hampering legislation.
For the second time this year New York led the big cities of the country in its automobile safety record in February, Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Nicholas Montemarano, a 10-year-old public school student, narrowly escaped death by electric shock early last night when a wire he was holding while playing with several companions came into contact with a high-tension wire of the Long Island Railroad at Fort Hamilton Parkway and Sixty-second Street, Brooklyn.

Recent labor disputes have again focused attention on safety at sea. As a former American seaman who found the going too tough in our ships, I can only urge a most careful and impartial investigation to clear the entire matter. Anything less will result in worse rather than better conditions.

The Navy Department, through Commander Wallace B. Phillips, intelligence officer for the Third Naval District, ordered alterations yesterday in the uniforms of the four guards at the exhibition of anti-New Deal murals at 5 East Fifty-seventh Street, on the ground that they closely resembled the uniform of enlisted men in the United States Marine Corps.

Yesterday, as Italian troops poured into Dessye -- 145 miles in an airline from Addis Ababa -- the League of Nations published a report on the operation of its sanctions. This report shows that many countries which participated in the application of sanctions have made vigorous efforts to enforce them.
ALBANY, April 15. -- The speech of Postmaster General Farley at the dinner of the Democratic State Committee tonight was as follows:

The New York Water Color Club opened its forty-seventh annual exhibition with a reception last evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, where the work goes on public view today. This show will be current until the end of the month. There is no admission charge.

LONDON, April 15. -- George Lansbury, the grand old man of the British Labor party, the leadership of which he resigned because of his strong pacifist views, sailed on the Berengaria today on an American peace crusade.
Sherwin A. Hill of Detroit has been elected a director of the Motor Products Corporation, succeeding D.B. Lee, resigned.

WHEELING, W.Va., April 15. -- Champion St. Margaret Magnificent of Clairedale, Sealyham terrier owned by the Clairedale Kennels of Riverhead, L.I., won the best in show award at the second annual all-breed fixture of the Tri-State Kennel Association which closed tonight.

A permanent research and fellowship is to be established at the New York Botanical Garden through an additional gift of $15,000 from Dr. Alexander P. Anderson of Red Wing, Minn., it was announced yesterday.

The eight members of the American women's golf team Sailed last night on the Hamburg-American liner Hansa bound for England to meet the British team in the Curtis Cup matches and then compete in the British championship.

BERLIN, April 15. -- Max Schmeling received a shabby send-off from his Fatherland when he left today aboard the Bremen to train in America for his fight with Joe Louis in June. There was no crowd at the boat train last night and practically no well-wishers at the boat today.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Members of State regulatory commissions in the railroad and public utility field today came to the support of the Interstate Commerce Commission in its demand that basic railroad passenger fares be reduced from 3 to 2 cents a mile.
PARIS, April 15. -- Following are the parts relating to foreign relations of the address of Premier Albert Sarraut today to provincial editors who were visiting Paris:

The Republican State Committee will meet at 1 o'clock today at the National Republican Club to elect officers for the next two years. Indications last night were that the meeting would be peaceful, despite the undercurrent of friction within the party in this State.

Veterans and youngsters, athletes of the past and of the present gathered in the gymnasium of the New York A.C. last night for the fifth annual All Sports dinner as nearly 1,000 of them paid tribute to the vast army of Winged Foot athletes in general and the national champions of the year before in particular.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The Yankees are still trying to win their first game of the new season. They seemed to have today's second skirmish with the Senators safely tucked away for six innings, but the pitching collapsed then and the game passed beyond recall.

NEWARK, N.J., April 15. -- Newark began today a month's celebration of its 100 years as a city. A special meeting of the City Commission was held in the City Hall at 2 P.M., which was the hour the first City Commission met.

A half-million-dollar theft, so adroitly executed that police at first doubted that it had occurred, was solved by announcement here and in Washington last night that Federal agents have arrested eight men and recovered $310,000 of the loot.

No less a statistician than Walter Hampden's press agent has figured that Mr. Hampden will give his 991st performance as Cyrano de Bergerac on Saturday night, May 9. That date, it had been understood, would mark the end of Mr. Hampden's forthcoming, limited stay at the New Amsterdam.

Hearings before the Transit Commission on the application of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway for permission to curtail its daily train service within the city limits were adjourned yesterday until April 29 because of a dispute over the commission's jurisdiction.

The Shawinigan Water and Power Company reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1936 gross revenue of $3,290,847 compared with $3,118,975 in the corresponding period of 1935, and net operating revenue of $1,791,537, after expenses, ordinary taxes and reserve for exchange losses, compared with $1,746,161 a year before.

Dennis Woods hammered on an indoor aerial yesterday afternoon and his wife, Florence, mended a couch cover, but they had their minds on something else. On Saturday two of their seven children will be 4 years old, and the occasion is likely to be exceptional.

Dr. Jacques P. Alper, 37 years old, who operated a loan shark business while secret physician to the Nick Montana vice ring, was sentenced to an indefinite term up to three years in the penitentiary yesterday in General Sessions for malpractice.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Charges that coal operators and their "privately paid deputy sheriff system" were responsible for denial of freedom of speech, freedom of assemblage and freedom of political rights in Harlan County, Ky., were made today by Thomas C. Townsend, counsel for the United Mine Workers of America.

KANSAS CITY, April 15. -- Evidence of the existence in the lower stratosphere, fifteen to twenty miles up, of a vast reservoir of "heavy oxygen," which keeps pouring down into the air we breathe, was presented today at the meeting of the American Chemical Society.

BERLIN, April 15. -- The Boerse failed again today to develop anything even vaguely resembling a tendency and continued to operate as merely an official market, genuine trading going on privately as usual.

Thomas F. Flynn, an independent Democrat of Brooklyn, threw the Sinking Fund Commission meeting yesterday into turmoil by charging that he was losing the city as a tenant in his warehouse because he had supported Joseph D. McGoldrick for District Attorney last Fall.

GENEVA, April 15. -- The first official figures showing the effect of sanctions on Italian trade and that of other countries during their first four months were issued today by the League of Nations. Although incomplete, especially for February, they indicate that sanctions after a slow start have been very widely and drastically applied and have been increasingly reducing Italy's imports and even more rapidly reducing her exports.
