WASHINGTON, April 15. -- President Roosevelt announced at his press conference that no more work relief funds would be allotted either to the Passamaquoddy project or the Florida Ship Canal, but that Congress must appropriate money if work is to continue.

A ceremony typical of Easter feasts in Czarist Russia featured a dinner dance and entertainment held last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for the benefit of the American Society for the Relief of Russian Exiles. Mrs. Landon K. Thorne is president of the organization, which aids destitute Russians.
WASHINGTON, April 15. -- President Roosevelt interpreted yesterday's capacity crowd at the Senators-Yankees opening game as an indication that baseball this year will have a banner season.

Public offering of the first 3 1/4 per cent bond issue of a telephone operating company will be made today by a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. The issue is $30,000,000 of Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company refunding mortgage 3 1/4 per cent Series B bonds due on April 1, 1966.

Waldemar von Zedtwitz became the American Bridge League's "champion of champions" yesterday by emerging at the top of a list of thirty-six experts in the individual masters' tournament at the Park Lane.

A Supreme Court jury returned a verdict of $500 yesterday in favor of Nathan Freedman, bookseller, in his $50,000 suit for false arrest against John S. Sumner, secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, and the society. Mr. Freedman was arrested in 1932 for displaying in his shop window pictures in a book on nudism, but was freed in magistrate's court.

Book-Sharing Week was opened officially last night at the Biltmore Hotel with a request from Mayor La Guardia, chairman ex officio of the Book-Sharing Week Committee, that citizens give books to city hospitals, prisons and charitable institutions.
ST. LOUIS, April 15. -- Leroy Parmelee and Frankie Frisch of the Cardinals today combined their efforts to win a 3-2 decision from the Cubs in the second game of the inaugural series.

Whatever may be the distribution of delegates, the division of the Republican vote in the Illinois "advisory" Presidential primary is unflattering to Colonel KNOX. He had the support of the organization. He carried on a campaign which from the first has been more persistent than that of any other aspirant.

Gene Deardorff of St. Louis, runner-up for the last two years in the national tourney, yesterday accounted for his third triumph in the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship at the New York Athletic Club and moved into a triple tie for second place.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 15. -- An expansion program involving $8,000,000 was announced today at the annual stockholders' meeting here of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company. Of this sum $1,000,000 will be used for enlarging the Libby Glass Manufacturing Company's plant here, it is understood.

ADDIS ABABA, April 15. -- As a result of the long silence of the northern headquarters of the Ethiopian army alarming rumors about the situation at the front flourish in fertile ground here. Nevertheless, according to apparently reliable information just arrived from Dessye, the Ethiopian forces, although at a disadvantage in consequence of reverses in the past two months, retain a position capable of strong defense.

The revival of the old-fashioned hymn sing which once characterized evangelical church services, and the discussion of the educational value of church music, marked the opening yesterday at the Hotel Astor of the tenth biennial convention of the New York Federation of Music Clubs.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Government officials, diplomats and high officers of the army and navy tonight heard Lincoln Ellsworth lecture on his recent Antarctic trip before the National Geographic Society in Constitution Hall.
ALBANY, April 15. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's address tonight at the dinner of the Democratic State Committee:

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- John J. Raskob, former Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Pierre S. du Pont of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., were disclosed before the Senate Lobby Committee today as the principal financial backers of the "grass roots" anti-New Deal convention held at Macon Jan. 29, at which Governor Talmadge of Georgia was endorsed as an anti-Roosevelt candidate for the Presidency.

The male choristers of the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West Seventy-first Street, last night gave their annual benefit concert in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The ensemble, composed of forty-five voices, was under the direction of Warren A. Foley, who has been choirmaster of the church for the last twelve years.

Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican lightweight, returned to the Star Casino, scene of his first American bout, last night to knock out Lou Jallos of Cleveland. It was the thirteenth triumph in succession for Montanez, who carried the fight from the start, never letting up his pounding.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- President Roosevelt said today that he would make no definite plans for long trips or visits until after Congress adjourns. He made this statement at a press conference when asked about reports that he had been invited to visit Canada late in the Spring. The President left the question open.

ROME, April 15. -- With a timing that suggests an almost deliberate striving after dramatic effect, Italian troops occupied Dessye, formerly Emperor Haile Selassie's headquarters, this morning on the very eve of the meeting in Geneva of the League of Nations Committee of Thirteen, which is to explore the possibilities of making peace between Italy and Ethiopia.

MOSCOW, April 15. -- The Soviet Union will second any steps taken by Turkey before the League of Nations looking to restoration of Turkey's full sovereignty over her straits, it is indicated authoritatively.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, announced yesterday his willingness to accept the nomination for President this year on The Socialist ticket if the party insisted on it, although he would prefer to run for Congress.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 15. -- Winning the first race in the international series for the Governor Cubitt Cup by 20 points to 16 1/4 may have spurred on the United States team of six-meter yachtsmen. At any rate, they took the second and third contests today, which were the final ones.

ATLANTA, April 15. -- Overriding wishes of President Roosevelt's followers for an earlier date, the State Democratic Executive Committee, dominated by his critic, Governor Talmadge, today set a Presidential primary for June 3 and fixed the entrance fee at $10,000 for each candidate.

BERLIN, April 15. -- The differences between Dr. Hugo Eckener and the Propaganda Ministry over his opposition to having the giant new Zeppelin Hindenburg used in the recent election campaign apparently were all satisfactorily threshed out today.
Benjamin Caro, builder, has assembled a corner plot in the Marble Hill section of Manhattan for improvement with a large apartment house, it was announced yesterday.

Armed with proxies for 950 shares of stock, most of them owned by Mrs. Hamilton Fish Armstrong of New York, a dozen members of the League of Women Shoppers invaded the annual stockholders' meeting of the Borden Company at 15 Exchange Place, Jersey City, yesterday in an unsuccessful attempt to commit the company to dealing with its employes in collective bargaining and to arbitration of labor disputes.

Fordham's unbeaten baseball team did a complete job of routing the University of Newark nine yesterday at Fordham Field as four righthanded twirlers divided the task of mowing down the opposition, yielding only one single while recording a 15-0 shut-out.

CHICAGO, April 15. -- Former Senator George H. Moses of New Hampshire said today that, including returns from the Illinois preference primary, he estimated that Colonel Knox had substantially 130 delegates to the Republican convention formally committed to his Presidential candidacy.

United States Government loans led an advance in the bond market yesterday, responding to a broad demand which carried sixteen of the long-term issues to new high levels since their issuance. Trading in Federal issues was the heaviest since March 20. Sales were $2,484,400, against $489,700 on Tuesday.

John Cronin, 74 years old, will be taken to Sing Sing this morning from the Tombs prison, which he helped to rebuild in 1898, to serve a two-year term on a plea of guilty to second-degree manslaughter. The sentence was imposed on him yesterday by General Sessions Judge Collins.

CHICAGO, April 15. -- With production difficulties largely eliminated, only the threat of "overburdening" taxation and government interference cloud an otherwise favorable outlook for the oil industry, Edward G. Seubert, president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, asserted in his annual report to stockholders, given out today.
In an effort to attract more shipping to this port the Sinking Fund Commission voted yesterday to reduce the rentals of city-owned piers by about 13 per cent.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 15. -- Yale scored a 6-to-5, tenth-inning victory over Williams today when Pitcher Walt Fuchs threw Dexter Blake's bunt over third base in an effort to halt Dick Marcus who had walked and taken second when Walt Klimczak was hit.

For the first time since the passage of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 an underwriting group yesterday openly notified dealers participating in distribution of a security that the group had supported and might continue to support the market for the issue in the period of public distribution.

A resolution decrying "the rising tide of militarism in this country" and voicing opposition to any war except one of defense was adopted unanimously yesterday by 500 women at a meeting of the women's division of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery at the Hotel Commodore.

A detective story from real life, involving whispered telephone messages, mysterious women, villas in Monte Carlo, a street murder, yachts, high-priced motor cars and all the trappings of lurid fiction was disclosed by the police here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP). -- The $1,067,665 payment by the AAA which Secretary Wallace recently reported was said in responsible Congressional quarters today to have gone to the United States Sugar Corporation.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- Further returns from down-State counties in the Presidential preference primary contest between Senator Borah and Colonel Knox, Chicago publisher, still indicated today that Mr. Borah had carried 13 districts, with 26 national delegates, out of the State's 25 Congressional districts.

BOSTON, April 16. -- An increase in popular sentiment for the nomination of Governor Landon for President on the Republican ticket and a slackening of opposition to President Roosevelt have been the most notable developments in Massachusetts in the last few months, according to impartial observers.

MARGATE, England, April 16. -- Salo Flohr of Prague went into the lead in the international chess masters' tournament as the second I round was contested at the Grand Hotel in Cliftonville today. The famous Czechoslovak, who defeated Brian Reilly of Ireland yesterday, won from Sir George Thomas, champion of the City of London Chess Club and former British titleholder.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 16. -- Thomas Maloney, former president of the disbanded United Anthracite Miners of Pennsylvania, died in the Wyoming Valley Homeopathic Hospital today, increasing to three the death list from the Good Friday bomb explosions.

Fifty-nine honor awards to students of Cooper Union were announced yesterday. They were for participation in extra-curricular activities and were listed in the year book of Cooper Union Engineering Schools.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- A warning by J. Edgar Hoover that any slash in appropriations requested by the Justice Department's Bureau of Identification might result in a new "wave of kidnapping" was made public today by a Senate Appropriations subcommittee.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for this year.

The Bank of France, publishing yesterday its statement as of last week's close, reported loss from its gold reserve during the week amounting to 945,000,000 francs, making loss of 2,729,000,000 during three successive weeks; the outgo in American values equivalent respectively to $62,300,000 and $180,100,000.
BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP). -- The Orioles beat the Buffalo Bisons, 15 -- 11, today to open the International League season. The Flock took its victory in a big eighth inning good for eight runs.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Organization of a national housing advisory council to encourage the building of 250,000 new houses this year by coodinating the activities of more than 100,000 members of trade associations throughout the country, was announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 (AP). -- San Francisco longshoremen, facing prospective idleness in the current waterfront labor battle between employers and left-wing union leaders, received assurances of support today from the Pacific Coast International Longshoremen's Association.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- President Roosevelt called upon the American people today to give renewed and vigorous support to the policy of conserving national resources. He made his appeal in an address at the laying of the cornerstone of the new $12,000,000 Interior Building.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., April 16. -- Roaring on a deeper note, both on the test block and in the air, than had ever been heard from an American aircraft engine, a new fourteen-cylinder, twin-row motor was demonstrated here today at the plant of the Pratt Whitney division of the United Aircraft Corporation.

With a bank check as their principal clue, three detectives rounded up four men in Queens yesterday morning, charged them with robbery, raided the Jamaica bungalow of one of them in the afternoon and seized a small arsenal.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16. -- With a bullet wound in her head, Nancy Haines, 13 years old, was found dead at 6:30 this evening in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Haines Jr. of Meadowbrook, a suburb. A .32-caliber revolver belonging to her father, a hosiery manufacturer here, lay beside her body.
PARIS, April 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Sales of housing properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn featured real estate activity in this city yesterday. A business property in lower Manhattan changed hands with the purchase of a John Street building.

The 1936 appeal for funds for the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York was begun yesterday when more than 100 members of the Catholic clergy and laity attended the first "report" luncheon of the special gifts committee at the Hotel Biltmore.

Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley reprimanded all the lawyers involved in the application for an increase in the commutation fares of the Long Island Railroad yesterday for their failure to speed up the taking of testimony. He set June 1 as the deadline for the completion of the case.
LONDON, April 16. -- Trading was quiet today on the London Stock Exchange, but prices were firm as a result of encouraging trade figures and Wall Street's recovery. British funds continued in demand.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Federal court, Brooklyn, approved yesterday the sale of forty-two retail stores of the James Butler Grocery Company of Long Island City, which is in reorganization proceedings under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Governor Lehman will go on the air on Sunday night in an attempt to rally support for his eight-point social security program, which Republicans have been blockading in the Legislature.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 16 (AP). -- New impetus for the movement to return the veteran lawmaker, George W. Norris, to his Senate seat came today as a result of Tuesday's primary, in which he did not seek renomination.

Much needed showers over several counties in Texas and in some section of Oklahoma brought sufficient reselling of contracts on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday to ease the market, which ended 1 point higher to 4 points lower. While some recent buyers were liquidating new crop months, covering by shorts in the May position held the near month around previous closing figures.

MADRID, April 16. -- Political passions in Spain are growing intensity and are dividing the country into two hostile camps. Before the debate in the Cortes on Premier Manuel Azana's ability to maintain order ended tonight with a vote of confidence for the government fresh outbreaks in Madrid, Seville and Jerez caused five deaths and the wounding of more than fifty persons.

LONDON, April 16. -- The secret conference of the general staffs of Britain, France and Belgium practically concluded its work today. A concise summary of results achieved is now being drafted for signature tomorrow before the delegations disperse.

So successful has been the free industrial art school established in January by the Federal Art Project of the WPA that more than three times as many students have applied as can be accommodated, according to a report made last night to the advisory board by Gilbert Rohde, director.

Weaver W. Adams of Boston completed his schedule in Group B of the United States chess championship preliminaries at the Marshall Chess Club last night, adding 2 points to his total and thereby making sure of second place, below Arnold S. Denker of New York, who finished first.

The report of the Pennsylvania Railroad for January and February, 1936, shows net income of $2,212,754, equivalent to 17 cents a share on the outstanding capital stock. This compares with a revised net income for the first two months of the preceding year of $1,999,297, or 15 cents a share.

A parade dramatizing the history of surface transportation on Fourteenth Street, with its transition from horse car to electric car to motor bus, will be a highlight of ceremonies Monday celebrating the substitution of buses for trolley cars on the thoroughfare.

THE railbirds and the turf officials seemed to think that the metropolitan racing season was off to a fine start at Jamaica on Wednesday. Bright weather, fine crowd, good races and all that sort of thing.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 16. -- The furniture manufacturing industry is beginning to show a profit, though small, for the first time in seven years, Dr. A.P. Haake, managing director, National Association of Furniture Manufacturers, declared at the semi-annual convention of the association here today.

CAIRO, April 16. -- News from Ethiopia via Anglo-Egyptian Sudan confirms the belief that Emperor Haile Selassie's northern armies are in full retreat with little hope of their being rallied unless the rains end Italian air attacks.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., April 16. -- Critics of the Roosevelt administration were challenged by Postmaster General Farley tonight to specify what part of the New Deal they would abolish.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 16 (AP). -- Johnny Goodman of Omaha and Jack Davison of Long Meadow, Mass., will fight it out tomorrow for the championship of the 1936 Mason-Dixon golf tournament.

The Hudson Motor Car Company will report for the first quarter of this year net earnings exceeding any first quarter since 1930, A.E. Barit, president and general manager, said yesterday. The total, he said, would be well in excess of earnings for the first quarter of last year, when the amount was equivalent to 15 cents a share for the common stock.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Friday, April 17. -- Charles (Lucky) Luciano, reputed New York City vice racketeer, was turned over to three New York detectives at 12:01 o'clock this morning and immediately taken away in secret.
BERLIN, April 16. -- The German Air Ministry announced today trial flights for a transatlantic air service between Germany and the United States will be started within a few months.
LONDON, April 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP). -- The name of Dean had another black mar', albeit a protested one, against it today.

United States Government loans were carried to new high levels since their issuance yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Net gains, however, were not unusually large, ranging from 1/32 to 4/32 point. Sales of Federal issues amounted to $1,960,300, compared with $2,484,400 on Wednesday.

FRANKFURT - AM - MAIN, April 16. -- Dr. Gerhard Wagner, Reichsfuehrer [leader] of German physicians, emphasized in an article published today the importance of the first meeting of the Reich Cooperative Organization for German Medical Science that will be held in Wiesbaden Saturday, Sunday and Monday.

Having practically made a career of "Tobacco Road" for most of the past three seasons, Henry Hull will appear next on Broadway under Arthur Hopkins's management in a new play by Sophie Treadwell. Mr. Hull has definitely been signed, and when the time comes (next October) he will be starred.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- Removal of hedges against sales of cash wheat to the government and to mills gave the May delivery a strong undertone on the Board of Trade today, but the prospect that the parched Winter wheat area in the Southwest might receive some moisture overnight led to free selling of new-crop contracts.

Sir Granville Bantock, British composer and conductor, and Dr. and Mrs. W. Greenhouse Allt are among the passengers due today from the Channel ports on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland. Other passengers include Martin Schlimport, German Consul at Montreal; Mr. and Mrs. James W. Murray, Mr. and Mrs. C.I. Tillman, P.M. Nicholson, A.E. Grieve, Mrs. Eugenie K. Cunningham, Daniel Dreyfus, Dr. Heinrich von Stein, Mrs. Else Bos, Miss C.M. Oliver, William Forbes-Watkins and Albert P. Matthews.

The pamphlet report of the United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries for 1935 shows that gross operating earnings rose $4,285,518, or 5.8 per cent, compared with gains of 8.44 per cent in electric and 9.57 per cent in gas sales, while total expenses rose $3,762,023, or 7.01 per cent, compared with 1934.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Having denied applications that the material be held confidential, the Securities and Exchange Commission today made public salaries and other data filed with it under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 by the American Car and Foundry Company and several other companies.

BERLIN, April 16. -- Prices on the Boerse were somewhat weaker today. Heavy industrial issues fell on a small turnover, Rheinstahl losing 1 7/8 points. Berlin Karlsruhe declined 1 1/4 points as the machine list sagged. Chemical shares softened, I.G. Farben receding a point.

Manhattan's hard-hitting nine enjoyed a field day at the expense of St. Francis College yesterday. Reaching the Franciscan pitchers for thirteen safeties, including three home runs, the Jaspers romped to an 18 -- 6 triumph in a blustery setting at Brooklyn's Parade Grounds.

President ROOSEVELT is right about the nature of the effort to preserve natural resources. It is a "battle," and a continuing one, which "must be "carried forward with renewed vigor "if future generations are to receive "the full benefits that are their due." Special objectives may differ from generation to generation.

One hundred and sixty-four yachtsmen attended a dinner in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, last night, which was tendered to George A. Cormack, who has been secretary of the club for thirty-five years and will have been a member fifty-one years on May 20.
Plans of a $180,000 six-story apartment house for Fourteenth - and Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, were among the building projects filed yesterday as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Argentine suggestions for discussion at the projected Pan-American Peace Conference, contained in the form of a draft treaty sent to President Roosevelt by Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas, on the whole were well received here.

Albert Ottinger, former Attorney General of New York State, announced yesterday that he was about to finish the work of his "voluntary" Landon-for-President committee, which he established with headquarters at the Hotel Astor two months ago.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 16. -- Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and Hal Surface, Kansas City, Mo., qualified today for the final round of the North and South tennis-championship at the Pinehurst Country Club.

Further large disbursements by the Treasury out of balances previously accumulated in the Federal Reserve Banks helped to raise member-bank reserves $172,000,000 and to lift the excess of reserves over requirements $130,000,000 to a total of $2,550,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve reports issued yesterday.

Textile High launched its campaign in the Lower Manhattan-Richmond Division of the P.S.A.L. baseball championship yesterday by turning back Port Richmond, 11 -- 2, at Dyckman Oval. John Leznick, who relieved Lou Morales in the first inning, shut out the losers in the last six frames.

Only twenty-two out of a total of 793 member banks of the Federal Reserve in the New York Federal Reserve District had reserve balances and deposits with correspondents amounting to less than 25 per cent in excess of their requirements at the end of last year, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its annual report for 1935, to be published today.
BIRMINGHAM, England, April 16 (AP). -- A 34-year-old mother of five was hanged in Winson Green prison today while a crowd of 3,000, kneeling on the streets outside, prayed and sang hymns.

Henry C. Steneck, 56 years old, of 20 West Seventy-seventh Street, New York, president of the defunct Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, and his brother, George W., 52, of 350 Central Park West, New York, also an officer of the bank, were sentenced to prison terms yesterday by Judge Kinkead in the Jersey City Court of Common Pleas on their convictions last week of making false reports to the State Banking Department.
Many local governments in New Jersey, especially in the industrial sections, faced a crisis yesterday in providing funds for the relief of their unemployed.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 16. -- John Davison, who tomorrow will enter the finals with Johnny Goodman in the Mason and Dixon golf tournament being played this week on the old White championship course, entertained tonight with dinner in the rustic room at Kate's Mountain Lodge.

Repeated comments are made on the increased return of Federal and New York State income taxes, and the deduction is drawn therefrom that the country is prospering. The real reason, of course, is quite different -- both Federal and New York State taxes having been stepped up by two and two and a half times what they were last year.

Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Lowell gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Their guests were Count and Countess Riccio, Mr. and Mrs. George Parkinson, Mr. and Mrs. John Hone Auerbach, Mr. and Mrs. William Roosevelt Thompson, Mr. and Mrs. David Lowery, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E.C. Roelker, Mr. and Mrs. Julius W. Noyes, Mr. and Mrs. Justin O'Brien Haynes, Miss Edna Brokaw and William Floyd-Jones.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 16. -- Revised and final charter recommendations were filed this afternoon with the Westchester Board of Supervisors by the commission which has been studying reorganization plans for county and local governments for more than two years.

Statements proclaiming a right to academic freedom and opposing government interference with education were approved unanimously yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the National Catholic Educational Association here.

Business conditions improved slightly last month despite the temporary depressing influence of the floods, according to The Annalist Index of Business Activity. The preliminary index is 88.2, as against 87.8 for February and 91.3 for January.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16. -- With Governor Harold G. Hoffman making wild pitches to Deputy Mayor Dennis Kelly before nearly 11,000 fans, the Bears today opened the International League season here and proceeded to dissipate an early lead to lose in the ninth inning to Toronto, 7 to 5.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- A plan for a grant of concessions on an "installment" basis for debt-ridden corporations under the proposed tax on undistributed corporate profits was written into the tentative draft of the new Revenue Bill today as the Ways and Means Democratic subcommittee again took charge with a view to rushing the measure to the House floor next week.

Applications to list the securities of twelve corporations have been received by the New York Stock Exchange and may be acted upon at the next meeting of the stock list committee, the Exchange announced yesterday.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 16. -- Within a few days the Federal Cabinet subcommittee investigating methods whereby specific action can be taken to redress the unfavorable trade balance between Australia and the United States will make its proposals.

MEXICO, D.F., April 16. -- To promote industrial development and free newly established industries from the vicissitudes of private money, whether foreign or Mexican, President Lazaro Cardenas issued today a decree under which a fund of 15,000,000 pesos will be set up in the National Mortgage, Urban and Public Works Bank.
WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The President laid the cornerstone of the new Department of Interior Building and met with the Cabinet in regular weekly session.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., April 16. -- Metallurgists and editors of trade and scientific publications from all parts of the country today witnessed the opening of Bethlehem Steel Corporation's new Bethanized wire and sheet mill.

Eight crack bridge teams applied themselves yesterday at the Park Lane to the task of winning the team-of-four championship of the American Bridge League and the right to represent the United States in the international matches for the Olcott-Pate Trophy.
WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The text of President Roosevelt's address today at the laying of the cornerstone of the Interior Department Building was follows:

EDMUND WILSON, a prominent member of the New Republic group of writers, spent six weeks with scarlet fever in an Odessa hospital last year. From this attack he seems to have happily recovered, if one may judge by the grace and vigor of his account in The New Yorker.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase of 28 per cent for the week ended April 11, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase, covering deliveries for the pre-Easter week, is the largest for any weekly period since July 6, 1935, the organization reported.

Proposals for the extension of music study in the public school system were presented yesterday at a luncheon of the New York Federation of Music Clubs, now holding its tenth biennial convention at the Hotel Astor.

With one brisk workout to his credit already, Mayor La Guardia will wind up his trusty right arm at 3:15 this afternoon and fire away in the general direction of Catcher Bill Dickey, thus opening the home season for the Yankees at the Stadium.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 16. -- "Yankee imperialism and despotism" were denounced today in speeches by Pedro Albizu Campos, Nationalist party president, at the annual observance of the birthday of the late Jose de Diego, independence advocate.

The "grass roots convention" which was held at Macon, Ga., several months ago professed to represent Southern Democrats in seventeen States and endorsed a candidate for the Presidency. In so doing it entered the field of national politics, and the Senate Lobby Committee is accordingly within its rights in inquiring into the sponsorship of the movement and the financial contributions made to it.
The Dodgers very definitely appeared to have the Giants licked in the third and concluding game of their series at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

BOSTON, April 16 (AP). -- Manager Joe Cronin stopped short-stopping for two and possibly three weeks today when he fractured his right thumb while his Red Sox pounded the Philadelphia Athletics for a 10 -- 4 victory.

Five of the seven Manhattan properties offered at foreclosure sales by auctioneers yesterday were bought in by savings banks. One parcel was taken over by a hospital and another scheduled sale was adjourned.

Life from the days of Pharaoh to that of modern civilized nations was portrayed in a sequence of tableaux enacted by 1,000 Manhattan Girl Scouts in a "Pageant of World Understanding and Friendship" yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

Declining the first time since Jan. 15, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday in twenty-two leading cities totaled $5,072,985,000, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reports. This compares with $5,321,213,000 for the same week in 1935, or a decrease of 4.7 per cent. In the preceding week a gain of 11.1 per cent was registered.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 15, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,486,000,000, an increase of $6,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $10,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1935.
The behavior problems of children are frequently due to the emotional problems of their parents, a special committee of the National Federation of Day Nurseries reported yesterday.

Charles Feld of 82-20 Caldwell Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, president of the Feld Dairy Company, testified as the State's first witness yesterday at the General Sessions trial of four officers and members of the Council of Independent Milk Dealers on charges of conspiracy, coercion and restraint of trade.
PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP). -- The Phillies checked attacks by the Bees in the closing innings today and won, 7 to 5, before fewer than 500 fans. The Phils had a 7-1 lead in the seventh.
Edward Lee of New York became the first American to win the crown when he clinched the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship at the New York Athletic Club last night.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Forty of the sixty-five detectives working on the murder of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, after discussing the case for two hours at a conference yesterday, were compelled to confess that they were at a loss for definite clues.

New York is rapidly becoming one of the greatest art centers in the world, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday morning at the opening session of the second day's meeting of the twenty-seventh annual convention of the Eastern Arts Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- While the demand for hogs was not brisk and fresh pork was said to be moving slowly, prices at the yards here today were steady to 5 cents a 100 pounds higher, the top moving up 5 cents to $11, equaling the best figure since Feb. 13.

KANSAS CITY, April 16. -- A new process which makes possible for the first time large-scale commercial production of a new type of super-explosive from corn was reported today before the closing sessions of the American Chemical Society.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16. -- Pennsylvania's crews, braving sandbanks and a gale which made navigation of the double bridges on the Schuylkill something of a job, worked out today on some stretches of good water they found up along the race course and managed to get in a session of paddling that lasted almost ten minutes.

Advisory Presidential preference primaries seem rather curious playthings. What, for instance, can be learned from the display of these toys in Nebraska Tuesday? There was nobody to oppose Mr. ROOSEVELT in the Democratic primary. All the delegates were for him. It was known they would be.

A new plan of reorganization for the Lawyers Mortgage Company was revealed yesterday when a group known as the guarantee holders reorganization committee filed a motion in the County Clerk's office of New York County asking for consideration of its proposal.

Among various rentals of business space reported in Manhattan yesterday was a contract for a large unit of space in Rockefeller Center with the Berlitz School of Languages of America, Inc. The institute will move from its Thirty-fourth Street location to the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue, where it will have fifty-three classrooms.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 16. -- A protest against the use of the name, "Methodist," by the Methodist Federation for Social Service, of which the Rev. Dr. Harry F. Ward of Union Theological Seminary, New York, is chairman, was adopted unanimously tonight by the laymen of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley, Bronx Democrat, said yesterday that at the next meeting of the Board of Aldermen he would introduce an amendment to the Lyons Residence Law depriving Mayor La Guardia of power to suspend the law.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- George H. Gannon has been dropped as Washington State WPA administrator by Harry L. Hopkins, chief of the agency, for responsibility in connection with the "collection of funds for political purposes."

The ice is clearing gradually from most of Maine's far-flung chain of lakes, recent reports indicate. Spring salmon and squaretail trout fishing already is under way in a number of the southerly lakes, and by May 1 it is expected that most of the northern waters will be open.
ROME, April 16 (AP). -- Italy today began a daring 170-mile thrust through the heart of Ethiopia toward the capital city of Addis Ababa, Rome newspapers reported.

The Downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street, which says it has a membership of 3,500 in the financial district, filed a petition in Federal court yesterday for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act. Its assets were reported to be $4,936,447.60 and its deficit $1,410,144.62.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- When the Black committee and its chairman are not ignoring the Fourth Amendment or threatening courts in which citizens are seeking protection of their constitutional guarantees, much good and interesting material is produced by the investigations.

Most commodity futures were slightly easier yesterday in average trading on the local Exchanges. Cocoa was active and higher, and wool tops advanced in light trading. On the cash markets, cotton, cocoa and silk were higher, while rye, oats, butter, eggs, lard, tins and rubber declined.

A Spring display of slot machines on three floors of a remodeled brownstone house at 453 West Forty-seventh. Street, near Tenth Avenue, was broken up abruptly at 6:30 o'clock last night by a squad of detectives who arrested two men, dispersed 400 prospective customers and confiscated 300 machines of various styles.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 16. -- A six-run rally in the sixth inning gave Rutgers an easy victory over Boston College today, 10 to 2. The Scarlet garnered nine hits off Harry Lane, including a home run, a triple and three doubles before he retired in favor of Don Kelley in the seventh.

In celebration of its fifteenth anniversary, the Art Directors Club opened yesterday afternoon in the fifth-floor gallery of B. Altman Co. an exhibition of contemporary and historic advertising art, which will be on view to the public from this morning until May 9.

WASHINGTON, April 16 . -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today exemption from provisions of the Holding Company Act of 1935 to the Standard Oil Company of Indiana and to the Southern States Power Company of North Carolina and permitted the Kentucky-Tennessee Light and Power Company and the Bruceton Light and Power Company to withdraw exemption applications.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Officials of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers charged today that private detective agencies had specialized in planting labor spies in the ranks of its workers and declared that the union had found it necessary to retaliate by placing some of its men in the employ of several detective agencies to "fight fire with fire."

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP). -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors sat down tonight in an "off-the-record" discussion with President Roosevelt, after the organization had heard its own president discuss a "national administration policy which is far less concerned with the freedom of the press than an American Government should be."

Arturo Toscanini was never more a high priest of art than when he officiated last night in Carnegie Hall, with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, in a program consisting entirely of representative orchestral and choral compositions of Debussy.

PALMER, Alaska, April 16 (AP). -- The Matanuska Colony, nearing its first birthday, May 10, has promulgated a "second-year plan" aimed at equipping this modern pioneer settlement to bid for Alaska's $400,000 a year agricultural export trade.

LONDON, April 16. -- With record speed and with the utmost politeness the British Government accepted today Turkey's request for a discussion of revision of the Lausanne treaty and refortification of the Dardanelles.

THE TIMES published several readers' letters criticizing the new buses. The writers display very proper resentment toward the obnoxious fumes. It is well known, however, that the deadliest constituent of these gases is carbon monoxide, colorless and odorless. Its insidious lethal nature has caused numerous tragedies familiar to all of us.

A bondholders' protective committee has been organized to oppose the Prudence-Bonds Corporation's plan of reorganization for the first mortgage collateral bonds of the sixth series. The committee consists of Adam Metz, president of the Bakers' Mutual Insurance Company of New York; Charles S. Oakley of the Cross Brown Company, and Edward W. Smith, vice president of the Clinton Trust Company.
PHILADELPHIA, April 16. -- E. H. Taylor, an associate editor of The Country Gentleman since 1920, has resigned to join the forces of Governor Landon of Kansas as a campaign adviser.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

BRUSSELS, April 16. -- The police charged tonight that Nicholas Elsen, 31 years old, a former convict, was the author of letters to King Leopold in which the monarch was threatened with death and his three motherless children with kidnapping.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 16. -- A daily double pay-off of $596 on Bender First, victor in the opening event, and Ampersand, winner of the third; three finishes close enough to bring calls from the placing judges for photographs; and four mutuel returns in a row of more than $20 for $2, marked the program presented today at the Havre de Grace track.

BERLIN, April 16. -- A good part of the class of 1922, that is, the 14-year-old boys and girls just leaving grammar school, will report tomorrow at camps all over Germany to start serving their "land year," which they will spend in work, sport and play in the country.

After drifting aimlessly during most of the day, stock prices sold off in the final hour and closed generally lower. The trading pace was the slowest of the month and the third slowest of any day this year thus far. The day's volume on the Stock Exchange was only 1,146,000 shares, compared with 1,318,000 on Wednesday.

Victor H. Abbott, a district superintendent in the Sanitation Department, was dismissed from the city service yesterday by Commissioner Hammond after Abbott, a member of the department for sixteen years, had been found guilty at a departmental trial of having flouted an order of the Budget Director.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, April 16. -- Representative Fred L. Crawford of Michigan has urged Virgin Islands organizations to protest to Washington against the stand of Dr. Ernest Gruening, Director of the Division of Territories and Island Possessions, against the Franchise Bill drafted in the islands.

ALBANY, April 16. -- The conviction of Farmer Miller, Charles Cranides and Joseph Kiley, charged with operating lottery in their Winthrop Theatre in Brooklyn, was upheld by the Court of Appeals in a unanimous decision, announced today, which declared their custom of giving patrons slips calling for prizes was in violation of State gambling laws.

The part of Governor LEHMAN'S speech to the Democratic State Committee which will most interest politicians is his reference to his possible candidacy for another term. On that subject all sorts of rumors and predictions have been published. The Governor said that all of them were unauthorized.
Reports of reacquired securities made yesterday to the New York Curb Exchange by listed companies follow:

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 16. -- A surprise victory by Curtis Ford of the Allentown Y.M.C.A. and a thirteen-second triumph by Orville England of Weatherford, Okla., both of them recorded tonight, stood out among the principal performances registered during the opening day's competition in the final American Olympic wrestling try-outs at Lehigh University.
Covici, Friede will publish on May 15 C.J. Bulliet's work on modern artists, "The Significant Moderns and Their Pictures."
ALBANY, N.Y., April 16 (AP). -- Montreal, using extra base hits, defeated the Albany Senators, 9 to 3, in the opening game of the International League season today.
Control of the Republican organization in New York State passed quietly yesterday into the hands of a group who might be called the "Young Turks" of the party.

Eight men accused of being members of a gang that stole $590,000 in United States Treasury notes in December, 1934, were held in bail totaling $325,000 yesterday by Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner.

An increase of nearly 50 per cent in the number of men employed in shipyards in the United States was recorded last year was reported yesterday by H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, at the annual meeting of the directors.

LWOW, Poland, April 16. -- Refusal of workers in this city to bury one of their comrades in a remote corner of the municipal cemetery led to serious disorders and street fighting with the police. According to official reports three were killed and more than a hundred injured.
WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Dixie Walker launched his 1936 career as utility fly-chaser for the Yankees today just in time to save the McCarthymen from their third straight setback by the Senators.

LONDON, April 16 (AP). -- Confronted by new anti-British editorial attacks in Rome and increasing uncertainties in Geneva, the British Admiralty took additional precautions tonight in the Mediterranean.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 16. -- The extreme right anti-Semitic Fascist movement reached its height today when leaders of the government party demanded that the government immediately severely suppress radical agitation among the peasantry, which, they said, must in the long run lead to general bloodshed.
LONDON, April 16 (AP). -- The Hon. Moya Beresford, daughter of Lord Decies and granddaughter of George Jay Gould, was married today to the Hon. Patrick Bellew, brother of Lord Bellew.
ROME, April 16. -- Italian attention was concentrated today on Geneva, where the League of Nation's Committee of Thirteen on concilation was meeting to decide whether any prospects of peace existed.
Receipts from the city's 2 per cent sales tax for the first quarter of the year, with late returns in Queens untabulated, total $9,242,220.18, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced last night.
The exhibition of water-colors by John Whorf, at the Milch Galleries, has been extended to April 25.

Calling for reduced governmental expenditures, a balanced budget, increased taxes and a firm statutory gold standard, Dr. Edwin W. Kemmerer of Princeton University, in a speech yesterday before the fifteenth annual meeting of the National Council of American Importers Traders, Inc., at the Hotel Astor, said that such steps were the only means of avoiding the serious inflation now threatening the country.

CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP). -- President Ford Frick of the National League served notice today that his non-fraternizing rule for players on the field carried no license to the athletes to swing their fistS freely.

The State Court of Appeals is expected to hand down a decision within the next week or two which may result in carrying the fight over the question of the constitutionality of Section 2 of the State Fair Trade Act to the United States Supreme Court, it was announced yesterday by Merwin Lewis, attorney.

The country will welcome the accumulating signs that Congress intends more frequently to exert its constitutional power. A new spirit of independence is stirring among the members, so that they even vote against minor measures advocated by the leaders of the majority party.

MOSCOW, April 16. -- Current rumors that present barriers to travel abroad by Soviet citizens will gradually be lifted received a measure of support today in a statement by Maxim Litvinoff, Foreign Commissar, to a group of Young Communist delegates who visited him at the Foreign Office.

Follies and fashions, in a light whimsical vein, featured the Spring bundle party given last night in the roof ballroom of the Hotel Astor by the joint Thrift Houses, with an attendance of about 1,500 guests.

Recovery in the private building industry is still several years distant, Charles L. Eidlitz, managing director of the Credit Association of the Building Trades of New York, predicted yesterday. Mr. Eidlitz, addressing builders at a luncheon in the new offices of Brown's Letters, Inc., construction reports, in the Architects Building, 101 Park Avenue, also analyzed the ethical standards of contractors, discussed the qualifications of credit men and warned against creation of good-will by unpaid work.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP). -- An extension of the list of manufacturers, exporters and importers of arms, ammunition or implements of war who must register with the State Department is made in a new proclamation issued by President Roosevelt, effective June 1.

Federal liquor control is based on the proposition that the government must protect the consumer and society in general, as well as the industry, in its rights and privileges under the law. Wilford S. Alexander, Administrator of Federal Alcohol Control, said last night in an address at the Hotel Biltmore.

Alumnae of the Spence School and many of their relatives and friends comprised the throng of more than 700 persons which attended the Silver Spoon dinner and supper dance given last night at the Plaza by the Spence Alumnae Society and its sub-organization, The Spinsters, to support the Spence Adoption Nursery at 232 East Sixty-second Street.

PITTSBURGH, April 16. -- Business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week reached a new high level in the recovery period, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's index of business, in which allowance is made for the usual seasonal changes and for long-term trend, stood at 84 (preliminary) per cent of normal, the highest point reached by this index since the week ended Nov. 15, 1930.
CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP). -- Long-range hitting off big Jim Weaver brought the Reds their first victory of the year today as they defeated the Pirates, 7 to 4.

The American Rolling Mill Company reports a net profit for 1935 of $4,310,129, equivalent, after deducting preferred dividend requirements, to $2.41 a share on the average number of outstanding shares of common stock. This compares with $966,566, or 49 cents a share, in 1934.

The principle of the provision in the New York milk law which requires that well-advertised milk be sold through retail stores at a price 1 cent a quart higher than milk, not well advertised, "is economically unsound and places a harmful restraint upon the freedom of competition," according to the Advertising Federation of America.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The German Government made application today for the permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of the Dawes loan of 1924 and of the Young loan of 1930, thus leaving only Great Britain, Chile and Brazil on the list of foreign governments which have not met the requirements for such registration as fixed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

While I am disposed to agree with Whidden Graham that Professor Williams of Harvard has a defective understanding of his subject, "Monetary Stabilization and International Flow of Capital," I cannot agree that "there is no such thing as an international flow of capital."

ALBANY, April 16. -- The new Democratic State Committee, chosen at the Spring primaries, reelected Postmaster General James A. Farley as chairman today, chose sixteen delegates at large to the Democratic National Convention and an equal number of alternates.

The New York Junior League will open its clubhouse to the public tonight for a gala entertainment in behalf of a welfare fund that supports the three main philanthropic projects of the league. The event has been in preparation for almost three months and will be known as the Junior League Jubilee, marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of the organization.
ROME, April 16. -- Drafts of Italian methods for governing 'conquered Ethiopia" are already on paper and are being studied by the Ministry of Colonies, informed sources said tonight.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday for 1935 a consolidated net income of $18,594,330, after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation, depletion and amortization, equal to $1.42 a share on the 13,102,900 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $18,327,807, or $1.40 a capital share in 1934.

The decision of the Court of Appeals upholding the constitutionality of New York State's Unemployment Insurance Act removes both an immediate uncertainty and what might otherwise have become a serious political issue. Previously Supreme Court Justice DOWLING had held one provision of the law unconstitutional, while Supreme Court Justice RUSSELL had held the entire act invalid.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Citation of Kurt Grunwald, an organizer for the Farmers Independence Council, for contempt of the Senate because of his refusal to answer questions of the Black Lobby Committee was being considered by the committee tonight and its decision is expected when hearings are resumed tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Pickford-Lasky Productions, Inc., of Hollywood filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of 20,600 shares of no par value preferred stock and 12,750 shares of no par value common stock. The preferred stock is to be offered at $100 a share and common stock will be offered to purchasers of preferred at $1 a share on the basis of one share for each four shares purchased.

Surrogate James A. Foley denied probate yesterday to a six-line penciled piece of paper which was offered as the will of Mrs. Ida E. Wood, Herald Square recluse and widow of Benjamin E. Wood, former Representative in Congress and New York newspaper publisher.

I feel that, in his efforts to place the proper historical markers on the sites of certain old New York landmarks, Commissioner Moses is overlooking one so labeled forty-six years ago by the Holland Society and probably forgotten by most New Yorkers.

The Long Island University nine was hard pressed to overcome the St. Peter's College team, 3 -- 1, at Dexter Park yesterday. The pitching of Kenneth Norton was the outstanding feature. He fanned nine and permitted only two hits in his first start of the season.

CLEVELAND, April 16. -- Thirty-two of the nation's finest amateur boxers fought their way into the semi-finals of the national A.A.U. championships tonight, each winning two bouts in the ninety-six-event program.

The first step always is the most important, and it was with a good deal of satisfaction that Mr. and Mrs. Morton L. Schwartz watched Bold Venture successfully begin his 1936 campaign at Jamaica yesterday. It is hoped he will go on to the Kentucky Derby and other big 3-year-old tests.
HAZLETON, Pa., April 16. -- Parading youngsters of Hazle Township, reinforced by men and women, laid a noisy siege to eight schools today and called for marches on seven more tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Wholesale prices rose moderately in the week ended on April 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on 1926 averages, now stands at 79.5, compared with 79.2 a week before and 79.9 a year ago.

The General Motors Corporation has re-entered the radio industry through the purchase of the Kokomo division of the Crosley Radio Corporation at Kokomo, Ind., effective May 1, it was announced yesterday. General Motors will produce automobile radios at the plant. The price paid for the plant was not announced.

GENEVA, April 16. -- Italy gave the League of Nations today her conditions for even discussing an armistice and peace in Ethiopia. They amounted to a dictation ignoring the League. Ethiopia promptly rejected them and asked the League to apply all the sanctions of Article XVI, military as well as economic and financial.

With the painting of the forty-eighth star in the corner of a large American flag yesterday afternoon, a three-week venture in mural decorating, representing the "collective" work of thirty members of the Art Department of Teachers College, Columbia University, was completed and the murals placed on view.

With the exception of poor results on Monday, department-store trade here was active during the week, particularly on main-floor lines. However, this week last year was the one immediately preceding Easter and the comparison of sales for the two periods would show a drop of about 20 per cent, according to estimates in well-informed quarters.

GENEVA, April 17. -- Italian sources here contended today that Wolde Mariam Ayeleu, the Ethiopian League of Nations delegate, did not have the right to represent the Ethiopian Government, claiming regular communications had stopped and the central authority at Addis Ababa had toppled.
A "hunger march" on the New Jersey capitol at Trenton was being planned last night as hundreds of towns and cities struggled to find a means of caring for the needy without State funds.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP). -- Chicago's National League champion Cubs received a cold reception from the Reds in their opening home game today, going down to a 12-3 defeat before 10,000 fans who shivered in 40-degree weather.

Federal Judge Patterson appointed yesterday George Frankenthaler, an attorney of 120 Broadway, receiver of all real and personal property of William Fox, former motion-picture producer, who has been adjudged in contempt and who was accused last week of "playing tag" with the courts to avoid examination.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 17. -- Two Princeton University professors, burned by the explosion of a radium-berylium mixture, were being examined hourly here today for radium poisoning while laboratory assistants searched for $400 worth of the radium lost in the blast.

While retail distribution showed the usual post-Easter decline this week, buying at wholesale widened as commitments were placed for early Summer needs and reduced stocks brought hurried reorders for goods for current sellings events, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Both favored teams-of-four emerged victorious from the semifinal round of the American Bridge League's championship tournament yesterday and last night at the Park Lane. The team to survive the ninety-six deals in the finals today and tomorrow will represent the United States in the international matches for the Olcott-Pate Trophy.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- The whole banking system of the United States is definitely on trial, John N. Riddle, economist of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, declared today in an address before the Eastern Regional Conference of the Robert Morris Associates at the Manufacturers and Bankers Club here.

It is not always easy these days to find things to which one can confidently "point with pride." Many Americans must be just a trifle ashamed of the trade reports from the League of Nations reflecting the efforts of other nations to curb aggression. OGDEN MILLS cannot be very proud of his recent contribution to the fertilization of the political grass roots.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Senate roll-call vote on which Judge H.L. Ritter of Florida was convicted follows:

NEWARK, N.J., April 17. -- After deliberating three hours and twenty-three minutes, a jury in Common Pleas Court before Judge Richard Hartshorne found City Commissioner Reginald Parnell not guilty today of a charge of malfeasance in office. The trial began Monday.
Progress was made yesterday in tracing the source of the 13-inch cord found under the body of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton.

" Tunnel vision," or the narrowing of the field of vision, has been found to be a source of motor accidents, Dr. Theodore W. Forbes, lecturer in psychology in Barnard Collegt, Columbia University, told a group of business men, social workers and physicians yesterday at the afternoon session of the two-day institute on the conservation of vision, in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

What is said to be the first and only biography in English of Friedrich Engels will be published on May 11 by Knopf. The author is Gustav Mayer, until 1933 Professor of Social Democratic History at the University of Berlin.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, chairman of the National Sponsoring Committee of the Emergency Peace Campaign, will be a speaker at the opening mass meeting of the campaign Wednesday evening in Carnegie Hall. Other speakers will be Kirby Page, author, and George Lansbury, British Labor leader, who is due to arrive Tuesday on the Berengaria.

At last peace has come to the Republican State Committee of New York. Let squabbles and shindies past be all forgotten. Certain down-State and up-State leaders took the seats of power. Chairman EATON, center of so many storms, was re-elected to serve until the candidate for Governor is found.
Charles (Lucky) Luciano, extradited from Arkansas on a charge of compulsory prostitution, is scheduled to arrive at the Grand Central at 8 o'clock this morning.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 17. -- Nine persons were killed in the Croatian village of Kerestinitch last night in the fatal climax of a series of clashes between Serbian Fascists and Croat peasants, which began with the assassination of two Croat leaders on April 10.

The New York price for foreign silver was raised yesterday 1/4 cent to 45 cents an ounce by Handy Harman, bullion brokers, after a sharp rise in silver's price in London. The change here was the first since Jan. 20 last and the first advance since Aug. 23 last year.

The problem of correct word usage crops up in the settlement house reports on drinking since repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. The welfare workers feel that temperance education today is not what it should be.

The French liner Lafayette, sailing today for Plymouth and Havre, will have among her passengers Ernest Truex, actor; Artur Schnabel, pianist; Emanuel List, basso of the Metropolitan Opera Association; Sir Alfred Zimmern, Professor of International Relations at Oxford University; Lieut. Col. Vincenzo Coppola, air and military attache at the Italian Embassy in Washington, and Charles F. Noyes, New York realty man.
DETROIT, April 17 (AP). -- The White Sox cast gloom over an opening-day crowd of 32,000 chilled fans today by defeating the Tigers, 5 to 3, behind the seven-hit pitching of Johnny Whitehead.

In his Easter pastoral letter, which will be read tomorrow at all masses in the 370 parishes of the New York Archdiocese, Cardinal Hayes appeals for continued support of the 212 agencies of Catholic Charities. His letter sets the week of April 26 to May 4 aside for support of private charitable work by agencies "alert to changing conditions."

GENEVA, April 17. -- The League of Nations Committee of Thirteen agreed informally this afternoon to report to the League Council on Monday that it had failed in its effort to end the Italo-Ethiopian War.

Paul H. Wendel, disbarred Trenton attorney whose repudiated "confession" to the Lindbergh kidnapping has resulted in an intensive police search for the four men who he charged abducted him and forced him to make the false confession, arrived shortly before 11 o'clock last night at the office of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan in Brooklyn.
ALBANY, April 17. -- Charges seeking the removal of Buffalo's Democratic Mayor, George J. Zimmermann, were filed with Governor Lehman today by George C. Riley, Democratic attorney of that city.

The Long Island Railroad completed yesterday its arguments for an increase in commutation rates before Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, and Leon G. Godley, Transit Commissioner. It was the twenty-third day of taking testimony since the proceedings started on Sept. 30.

Yesterday Secretary HULL named envoys of Argentina, Mexico and Guatemala as a special committee to draw up a preliminary list of subjects for consideration at the forthcoming inter-American peace conference. The Governments of these three nations have already forwarded useful suggestions.

The City of St. Louis, Mo., awarded yesterday a new issue of $4,667,000 of the public building and improvement bonds to a banking group headed by the Chase National Bank at a price of 100.289 for $3,020,000 as 2 1/2s and $1,647,000 as 2 3/4s. The bonds will be dated May 1, 1936, and will mature on May 1, 1951 to 1956.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (AP). -- Jimmy DeShong conquered the Athletics in their home opener today, holding Connie Mack's men to two hits as the Senators won, 3 to 2, before 2,500 spectators.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 17. -- Facing rough and turbulent water, the crews of Columbia and the Navy went out tonight for the final workout before the opening of the Eastern rowing season tomorrow.

More than six acres of toys, the largest showing since 1929, will be displayed at the American Toy Fair which opens Monday at the Hotel McAlpin and the Toy Center, 200 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by H.D. Clark, manager of the trade exhibit, which is sponsored by the Toy Manufacturers of the United States.

Prices were mixed in narrow and dull trading yesterday on the local commodity futures markets. On the cash markets the grains, cotton, butter, eggs, rubber and tins advanced, and cocoa and silk declined.
LONDON, April 17. -- Reports received here tonight that Turkish troops had occupied the demilitarized zone along the Dardanelles were doubted by British officials.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- President Roosevelt, at his press conference, expressed his disapproval of proposals to earmark $700,000,000 of the proposed $1,500,000,000 relief appropriation for PWA projects of the "heavy construction" type and voiced the hope that ship subsidy legislation will be enacted at this session.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 17. -- Mrs. Helen Kiefer, 29 years old, wife of Charles Kiefer of Vernon Valley Road, Northport, was sentenced today to 180 days in the Suffolk County jail and fined $50 after her conviction on a charge of leaving the scene of an accident in which two 16-year-old schoolgirls were killed at Commack, March 14.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said here today that a definite expansion in bank credit was under way for the first time since the bank panic of 1933. The growth in demand for credit is more noticeable in the smaller towns than in the large cities, he said.
BALTIMORE, April 17 (AP). -- Bill Harris of Buffalo held Baltimore to three hits and no runs today and the Bisons captured the second game of the season, 11-0.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- Congratulating the 1,500,000 present and past members of the Civilian Conservation Corps, the first camp of which was set up three years ago, President Roosevelt said tonight that they deserved "the admiration of the entire country."

Frigid weather yesterday did not affect the pitching of Long Island University's Larry Burger, the Blackbirds' hurler turning in a one-hit performance in blanking the Boston College nine, 1-0, at Dexter Park.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Senate lobby investigators said today that an exchange of letters between Vice President Garner and John Henry Kirby, chairman of the Southern Committee to Uphold the Constitution, had been put into the committee's files.

An impressive Spring festival and ball took place last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria among seasonal blossoms and greenery. The event was given under the auspices of the German-American Charities, Inc.

The American Confidential Bureau, Inc., an agency which supplied guards and strikebreakers to many of the city's largest real estate firms during the building-service strike in March, virtually was taken over and run by a gang of underworld characters during almost the entire period of the strike.

The harassed Casey Stengel was able to get his first night's sleep since his Dodgers began losing to the Giants last Tuesday after the Flatbush athletes yesterday rewarded an opening-day crowd of nearly 8,000 by outlasting the Phillies to win in the tenth inning, 4 -- 3.

MARGATE, England, April 17. -- Paying the former world champion, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine, the compliment of adopting the defense named after him, Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia today gained his third consecutive victory, defeating Erich Lundin of Stockholm in the third round of the international tournament.
" We don't give the trout fishermen what they want, but what is good for them."

Mrs. Fay Webb Vallee is entitled to receive only the $100 a week provided in her separation agreement with Rudy Vallee, singer and orchestra leader, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday by a three-to-two decision. The court upheld Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo in refusing to set aside the separation agreement.
BERLIN, April 17. -- The news from Geneva is not pleasing to Germany. It is deplored in official and unofficial circles alike.
Customs of the old Caucasian province in Russia were revived last night at the annual Allaverdy ball given by the Societe Caucassienne-Allaverdy in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- National banks of the United States showed net earnings of $158,491,000 in the calendar year 1935, compared with deficits for the fiscal year 1932, 1933 and 1934, Controller of the Currency J.F.T. O'Connor announced today.
Architects filed plans yesterday for altering a large number of buildings in Manhattan. Two new structures planned in the borough were a one-story store building and a small garage.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Associate Justice Willis Van Devanter, dean of the Supreme Court, in an interview on his seventy-seventh birthday, revealed today that a third AAA benefit payment check had been offered him "a few days ago" and refused.

MADRID, April 17. -- Another revolutionary general strike for political motives was declared in Madrid today. The U.G.T., or Socialist labor union, unwillingly joined the strike, which was forced by a rival organization, the. C.N.T., or Syndicalist labor union.

We are indebted to Governor James Curley of Massachusetts for the announcement that it was Captain John Sullivan, an Irishman, who fired "the shot heard round the world." This shooting occurred at Portsmouth, N.H., on a day in December, 1774, during the capture of Fort William and Mary.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 17. -- Max A. Schulz, 51 years old, a German-American newspaper writer, committed suicide early this morning by inhaling carbon monoxide gas while seated in his automobile in the garage behind his home on Emerson Lane in New Providence Township, six miles from here.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Authority was given the Hibernia Safe Deposit Company, 261 Fifth Avenue, New York, to change the location of its principal place of business to 57 William Street, the State Banking Department announced today. It was also authorized to open a branch office at 295 Fifth Avenue, conditional upon the closing of the one now at 261 Fifth Avenue.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts is only $9,730,645, to be represented to eighty-six municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $19,783,091 for the current week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,755,077.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, April 17. -- Four Jews were seriously wounded, thirty were badly beaten and many were arrested in a clash with the police here today.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Grave uncertainties as to the probable yield of President Roosevelt's new tax program as revised by the Ways and Means subcommittee on taxation arose today as administration leaders planned to shove the measure to the floor of the House by the middle of next week.

Cardinal HAYES in his message to be read at all the Masses tomorrow morning, asking for the support of the many works of mercy under the leadership and guidance of Catholic Charities, announces that all who either work or contribute will be especially remembered in the offering of the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass during the year.

Although more rain occurred in Texas, intensified drought conditions in Oklahoma brought about a recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and the list advanced 1 to 6 points. More active covering of the outstanding May interest stiffened the near delivery as houses doing government business failed to release contracts.
legal fees and $2,000 for accountants' fees.
Except for the weather and the Yankees, everything was all right at New York's second major league baseball opening of the week yesterday in the Stadium.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- An overwhelming Democratic victory in November was predicted by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in a statement today. He based his conclusion on the heavy vote cast for President Roosevelt in the primaries in Illinois and elsewhere and the increased registration in California, Pennsylvania and other States.

It isn't often that any one comes to the defense of the greatly maligned, but very necessary, officials in sports. So much has been written -- but not in THE TIMES, I'm glad to say -- of track officials, swimming officials et sic ad infinitum getting free trips to Germany and the Olympic Games this year that the truth of the matter should be presented.

In commenting on the recent paragraph concerning trade association promotion in this column, Ernest C. Morse, general director of the Associated Wool Industries, said yesterday that, "in my opinion, the promotion of an industry involves a balanced program which may be divided into four major items.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Informed tonight of President Roosevelt's disapproval of earmarking $700,000,000 for the PWA, Representative Better, Democrat of New York, head of the bloc making the demand, said:
SHANGHAI, April 17. -- A report that Japan is preparing to send six additional divisions of troops to Manchukuo because of the tension with Russia was circulated here today.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Pegging operations which do not violate the anti-manipulation provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are not illegal, John Burns, general counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, stated in a letter sent recently, in reply to an inquiry, to counsel for Lehman Brothers, head of underwriters distributing a block of stock of Flintkote Company.
Investors were active yesterday in the purchase of Brooklyn houses, some of which will be modernized.

A contract bridge party and supper dance was held last night at the Plaza for the benefit of the St. Ambrose Mission. Among those who had guests were Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Tuttle, the Rev. and Mrs. Gilbert Darlington, Mrs. James Roosevelt, Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw, Mrs. Lewis Latham Clarke, Mrs. Robert Gardiner, George Lippincott Brown and George L. Bagby.

Dave Feinman, a sidewalk spieler at Morris Klar's clothing store, 47 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, showed every evidence last night that he was regaining the oratorical form that seemed to have deserted him last week.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- While the demand for hogs here today was rather slow, offerings under 260 pounds sold at steady prices. Heavier kinds, however, were off as much as 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight in spots, easiness in lard being a factor.

While workmen labored on the construction of the ring itself and statisticians pored over the huge charts of seating arrangements for the Joe Louis-Max Schmeling fight at the Yankee Stadium on June 17, Promoter Mike Jacobs received a visitor yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- Invasion of State's rights by the Federal Government is being halted by a new governmental agency, the Council of State Governments, Henry W. Toll, executive director of the council, pointed out today in an address which opened the second annual general assembly of the council's Commissions on Interstate Cooperation.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- The report of the city of Chicago, made public today, showed that in the first three months of 1936 the city met current obligations, redeemed $8,853,000 in tax warrants, borrowed $4,850,000 and diminished the city's funded debt by $2,000,000.

The schedule of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association, as announced yesterday by Mrs. Kenneth S. Hogg, chairman of the tournament committee, reveals that the 1936 championship will be played at Wee Burn, June 15 to 19.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on April 4 amounted to 312,974,000 barrels, according to the Federal Bureau of Mines. This was a rise of 1,805,000 barrels over the week before, comprising an increase of 1,685,000 and 120,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

The policy of the recently organized German-American League, the former Friends of the New Germany, was outlined last night at a meeting at the New York Turnhall, Eighty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue. Organization of labor groups, training schools for speakers, extension of the Ordnungsdienst, education of youth, and strong interest in American politics were the main points of a program as announced by Fritz Kuhn, national leader of the league.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- A statement that former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York made his famous speech at the American Liberty League dinner in Washington because the league "needed him to clear it of its financial taint" was put in the records of the Senate Lobby Committee hearings today.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Americans in Addis Ababa are not expected to be in great danger from an occupation of the Ethiopian capital by Italian troops.
