Slow trading and narrow price movements characterized the stock market yesterday. Generally favorable trade and corporate reports failed to shake the market from its lethargy, and the latest European political news was too little understood to be of influence.

ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP). -- The Indians fell on Mike Meola in the tenth today as they had on his three predecessors, scored three runs and defeated the Browns, 13 to 10. The Browns sent the game into extra innings in the ninth.

The Junior League of New York was host last night in its clubhouse, at 221 East Seventy-first Street, to nearly 1,800 persons for a gala jubilee marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of the league. As a benefit for the three main philanthropic projects of the organization, the jubilee was the first occasion on which the building had been opened to the public since its official inauguration in 1929 as headquarters of the Junior League.

PARIS, April 17. -- Bernard Klein, one of the two men arrested here in connection with the $1,456,000 bond theft from the Bank of Manhattan Company in New York, told the police today that the $440,000 of stolen bonds found in his possession had been given to him in London last February by a man who promised him 40 per cent commission for selling them.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- An alleged plot to "rub out" Francis J. German, leader of the general textile strike of 1934, was read into the record of the La Follette subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today by John Edelman, research director of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers.

MOSCOW, Saturday, April 18. -- The Soviet Government has expressed complete accord with the Turkish desire to regain sovereignty over the Straits in a note from Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff delivered Thursday to the Turkish Ambassador here and published early this morning.
" I Married a Doctor," with Pat O'Brien and Josephine Hutchinson, opens this morning at the Strand. It is based on Sinclair Lewis's novel, "Main Street."

A total of $41,068,000 of new bonds was placed on the market this week, compared with the record volume of $427,666,500 last week. In the corresponding week a year ago only $19,590,000 in new bonds was offered for public subscription.

The $80,000,000 investment of the Alleghany Corporation in the Missouri Pacific Railroad has had its outlook obscured by the proceedings in bankruptcy to reorganize the railroad, according to the report on the holding company for 1935, issued yesterday by O.P. Van Sweringen, president.

BERLIN, April 17. -- Prices on the Boerse continued to fall today, although the turnover, as usual, was very small. No more significance is attributed by the business community to a falling than to a rising market in view of the Boerse's entirely official and carefully controlled operations.
You give a very poor example to explain your Topic of The Times item on "Numbers Not Everything." The last sentence reads:

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 17. -- With Leo (Skinny) Fallon of Baltimore in the pilot house, Swashbuckler, 8-to-1 shot from Mrs. Janon Fisher Jr.'s stable, flashed a clever performance at Havre de Grace today to win the Griffwood Purse, six-furlong test for 3-year- olds.

This department finds itself in the enviable position of being able to make a declaratory statement this morning without having its fingers crossed. The statement is this: the daffiest, most sublimely risible performance to be seen in any night club these evenings is that of Willie and Eugene Howard, on parole from the stage for the nonce, at the Versailles Restaurant.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- A varied editorial page, carrying conflicting views on controversial subjects, was offered to the American Society of Newspaper Editors today as a means of giving a newspaper added "reader appeal."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (AP). -- Indications of a break in tension on the labor-troubled waterfront appeared tonight when district officials of the longshoremen's union and the waterfront employers agreed to meet tomorrow.

In a recent letter to THE TIMES Mrs. Helene De Diveky argues against the entry of the United States into the League of Nations, voicing her belief that the European peoples have largely lost their faith in its potency. She bases a part of her own skepticism upon the fact, which she thinks generally disregarded, that between 1870 and 1914, eight conflicts raged abroad "in spite of all diplomatic efforts."

BOSTON, April 17. -- Stung to action, not so much by the Bees as by a biting gale that swept off the historic Charles with unrelenting fury, the Giants flattened Bill McKechnie's erstwhile Braves in their own hive today and thus brought about a complete frost to the opening of the National League season in Boston.

After falling from the roof of a seven-story building at 272 Manhattan Avenue into a basement court yesterday, Ralph Cesteros, 5 years old, of 282 Manhattan Avenue, brushed himself off and started to walk out of the court.

The results of the work to date of the Municipal Art Committee, appointed by Mayor La Guardia in September, 1934, "have already proved the value and need of this Fine Arts Division of the city and its right to reasonable financial support by the city in order that its work will not continue to be hampered," according to a statement by Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, chairman, in the first annual report of the committee, issued yesterday.

In THE TIMES of April 16 the news article "Welfare Groups Differ on Drinking" indicated that there was no consensus of opinion among the groups as to increase or decrease. As I view the matter, all are correct.

CLEVELAND, April 17. -- Eight youngsters fought their way to amateur fistic fame tonight, capturing national A.A.U. championships in the greatest boxing carnival the organization has sponsored in forty-nine years.

NUTLEY, N.J., April 17. -- A bank train of the Erie Railroad was held up here this morning by seven robbers who rifled the strong box in the baggage car and sped off in an apple-green sedan with money bags containing $958.35, a much smaller haul than they had expected to get.
NEWARK, N.J., April 17. -- The Newark Bears evened their series with the Toronto Maple Leafs at one game each today when they pounded out a 13 to 9 victory over their opening day conquerors.

Singing in the bathtub and chanting around the family breakfast table are highly desirable habits which tend to remedy the defects of a "subway voice," from which most New Yorkers are suffering as a result of competition with the roar of traffic, Professor Jane Dorsey Zimmerman said yesterday.

Legislation will be introduced in Albany early next week, it was learned yesterday, whereby the Bankers' Agreement will be revised to allow the refunding of $102,674,500 of the city's short-term debt to save approximately a million dollars a year in interest.
ROME, April 17. -- Rumors of the impending abdication of Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia have been circulating in Rome, but official quarters declare them unfounded or at least premature.

Buddy Kammer, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High star, struck out eleven and yielded only three hits as his team subdued Adelphi Academy, a Brooklyn rival, 5 -- 2, yesterday at the Parade Grounds. A four-run assault in the first sealed victory for the winners.

Temple University's baseball team, forced to come from behind three times, put on a four-run drive in the ninth inning to defeat New York University, 8 to 4, yesterday at Ohio Field for its third triumph in five starts this season. A crowd of 500 shivering supporters saw the Violet meet its second straight setback of the week.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- President Roosevelt made clear today his intention to resist all efforts to earmark a substantial portion of the proposed $1,500,000,000 work-relief appropriation for "heavy construction" projects of the Public Works Administration.

Plans for a new apartment house on Washington Heights and modernization of various existing structures were announced in connection with realty deals in Manhattan yesterday. A Bronx parcel also was acquired for improvement with a new multi-family building.

A so-called little stock exchange, members of which deal entirely in stolen securities, exists in New York, George R. Pfann, Assistant United States Attorney, charged yesterday before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson, in opposing a writ of habeas corpus sworn out for Earl Frederick Palmer, accused as a member of the "exchange."
For the second time within the last two months, four men accused of operating an artichoke trust in violation of the Sherman Act, waited last night for a jury to decide their innocence or guilt.

Three adjoining theatres at the northwest corner of Broadway and Forty-fifth Street were bought in at a foreclosure auction sale yesterday by Robert E. Dowling, as president of the City Investing Company. The playhouses are the Astor, at the corner, the Bijou at 209 West Forty-fifth Street and the Morosco at 217.

Scoring the winning run with one out in the ninth inning, the St. John's University baseball team repulsed the St. Francis College nine, 7 to 6, at Carey Field yesterday. It was the third victory in six games for the Indians this season.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Plans by President Roosevelt to go on to Hyde Park for a brief visit at his mother's home following the delivery of a speech in New York City before the National Democratic Club on the night of April 25, were indicated at the White House today.
BERLIN, April 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

An exhibition of art work by students in elementary and secondary schools throughout the Eastern section of the country was held yesterday morning at the third day's session of the annual convention of the Eastern Arts Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 17 (AP). -- The decathlon crown tottered precariously on the brow of Clyde Coffman of Topeka tonight after the first five events of the stern test of all-around track and field skill held in connection with the fourteenth annual Kansas relays.

SEATTLE, April 17 (AP). -- The rowing world will get its first glimpse of the competition it will buck in the Olympic tryouts this Summer when the champion University of California crew and the always formidable Huskies of Washington clash here tomorrow. The event is the thirty-third annual Pacific Coast intercollegiate regatta and Lake Washington is the scene.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Prudential Insurance Company, functioning in the newly established capacity of acceptable assignee, has made its first purchase of Federal Housing Administration insured mortgages by acquiring more than $100,000 of these securities from the Franklin Mortgage and Guaranty Company of Newark, Stewart McDonald, FHA Administrator, announced today.

I noted with interest your editorial on the higher mathematics involved in the New York State income tax. I would, however, like to point out that your question, "Why is the income from the sale of securities or other property subject to the 'normal tax' but exempted from the 'emergency tax'?" should be amplified.

The triumph of the Left parties in the Spanish general election has brought the predicted political evils in its train. The extremists are attacked by the more extreme. Communists, syndicalists and anarchists seem to think that their day has come. A complete "social revolution" has long been advocated in Spain by agitators in various parts of the Peninsula.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Under highly dramatic circumstances the Senate today removed Halsted L. Ritter from office as judge in the Southern District of Florida, after finding him guilty of "high crimes and misdemeanors in office" under one of the seven articles of impeachment brought by the House of Representatives.

LONDON, April 17. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange remained quiet today because of the approaching budget figures, with prices ending around the overnight levels. Foreign bonds continued quiet, European issues marking time pending international developments.

The will of Marilyn Miller, musical comedy star, who died on April 7, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, named her mother, Mrs. Ada Thompson Miller of 1,525 North Van Ness Avenue, Hollywood, Calif., as the principal beneficiary. The will, which was drawn April 23, 1931, several years before her marriage, did not mention Miss Miller's husband, Chester L. O'Brien of 46 East Sixty-fifth Street.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 17. -- Unification of the Methodist Church was recommended today by the lay delegates at the 137th New York Methodist Episcopal conference. The step was advocated as a forerunner of Protestant solidarity. solidarity.

The steady development of Robert O'Connor's playing, from season to season, brings that earnest pianist's performances constantly nearer the high goal he obviously has in view. Last night, at his recital in the Town Hall, a decided gain in dynamic range was to be noted in his keyboard proclamations, enabling him to produce vivid contrasts hitherto lacking in his work.

Interference by parents in the normal development of motor faculties in children, particularly by attempting to force a naturally left-handed child to acquire the more common habit of right-handedness, is frequently the basis of serious developmental disorders which affect the mind, Dr. Samuel T. Orton, Professor of Neurology and Neuropathology of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, declared last night.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 18. -- Shigeru Kawagoe, Consul General in Tientsin, was the Japanese Army's choice for the China Embassy and his selection by military influence over Vice Foreign Minister Shigeru Shigemitsu and other senior diplomats who were proposed has moved the press to unusual freedom of criticism.

To the performance of several industries in the first quarter of this year, the old slogan "profitless prosperity" could be applied with a good deal of justification. Price cutting in steel and building supplies apparently reached a point where profit margins dwindled rapidly.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The issue whether the Public Works Administration may finance publicly owned and operated hydroelectric plants to compete with private enterprises was laid before the Supreme Court today when the Duke Power Company and the Southern Public Utilities Company appealed from the lower court decision in the Buzzard Roost case.

With another sterling game marking his play, Edward Lee of New York, who clinched the title Thursday, remained unbeaten as the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship ended last night at the New York Athletic Club.

BUFFALO, April 17. -- The Left Wing in the Socialist party won control of the State organization here tonight when Max Delson of New York was elected temporary chairman of the State committee over August Claessens of New York, Old Guard candidate, by a vote of 55 to 43.

On the night of Dec. 9 WALTER LIGGETT, publisher of The Midwest American, was murdered in the alley in back of his home in Minneapolis. He had just stepped from his automobile and was reaching for some groceries; his wife and his 10-year-old daughter were with him.

The Johns-Manville Corporation and subsidiary companies reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a net profit of $2,095,044, following allowance for depreciation, income taxes, depletion and other charges. After preferred dividend requirements, the profit is equal to $2.09 a share on 750,000 common shares.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The issue whether the Public Works Administration may finance publicly owned and operated hydroelectric plants to compete with private enterprises was laid before the Supreme Court today when the Duke Power Company and the Southern Public Utilities Company appealed from the lower court decision in the Buzzard Roost case.

" Bury the Dead," Irwin Shaw's anti-war play, will open a Broadway run this evening at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre. Put on some weeks ago for two special performances, it won considerable attention and, finally, the sponsorship of Alex Yokel.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The President has never insisted that the proposed tax on undistributed corporation profits must be enacted. On the contrary, his only message on this subject put the proposal forward merely as one worth considering. "I leave, of course," he said, "to the discretion "of the Congress the formulation of "the appropriate taxes for the needed "permanent revenue.

The Johns-Manville Corporation and subsidiary companies reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a net profit of $2,095,044, following allowance for depreciation, income taxes, depletion and other charges. After preferred dividend requirements, the profit is equal to $2.09 a share on 750,000 common shares.

The last of the special Olympic tryouts, held at the Fencers Club under the auspices of the Amateur Fencing League of America last night, resulted in another surprise victory for Mrs. Joanna de Tuscan, the much-improved Detroit fencer who has been training here this season at the Salle Santelli.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

In recent articles on the Olympic Games it has been stated that the marathon run was an ancient contest. This is a mistake. The race was-absolutely unknown to ancient Greek sports, it not being instituted until 1896 at the restored Olympic Games held in Athens.

WILTON, Me., April 17. -- Wilton's "trick road" on which automobiles seemingly coast uphill backward drew its quota of the curious tonight despite a statement by highway officials that the apparent reverse grade was an "optical illusion."

A friendship of more than twenty years, cooled in recent months by a series of alleged wrongs, ended yesterday in the slashing of Arthur J. Sullivan, 41 years old, vice president of Frank B. Hall Co., Inc., insurance brokers.

If the reader, who wrote to you about the origin of the word "fungo," as applied to batting, can get hold of one of the old Spalding Baseball Guides prior to about 1895, when it always was edited by Father Henry Chadwick, he will read a lot about fungo batting.

A resolution authorizing Mayor La Guardia to seek the consent of the War Department and of Congress for the construction of a bridge across the Narrows from Brooklyn to Staten Island was adopted unanimously yesterday by the Board of Estimate, reviving a proposal for linking the boroughs which has been discussed for years.
ADDIS ABABA, April 17. -- The Ethiopian Government charged tonight that two Italian airplanes fired on the city today during a flight over the capital.

For his pioneering work as pilot of Pan American Airways clipper ships in the Pacific service, Captain Edwin C. Musick has been named to receive the Harmon Trophy for 1935 as the "world's outstanding aviator."

ALBANY, April 17. -- A plea for enactment of Governor Lehman's eight-point social security program was put forward today through the Social Welfare Department by Victor F. Ridder, president of the State Board of Social Welfare and WPA director in New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- A new government policy foreshadowing a "permanent cure" for unemployment may result from a comprehensive study of the technological causes of joblessness, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, declared today.

(Controlled by the Atlas Corporation) -- As of March 31, 1936, net assets were $20,244,052, after allowing for a reserve of $1,006,200 for Federal income tax on unrealized appreciation in the value of investments. This was equal to $85.94 a share on 235,573 shares of first-preferred stock, after the payment in the quarter of $3 a share on account of accrued dividends.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 17. -- The directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company received today a six months' extension within which to file a plan of reorganization. The order was signed here by Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks, giving until Oct. 23, for the filing of proposals.

MOST of the Fenway Millionaires bustled off to the Bronx at an early hour yesterday. They didn't want to miss any part of the opening celebration at the Yankee Stadium, including the time allotted to the batting practice of the visiting team. But Robert Moses Grove, the long left-hander from Lonaconing, Md., clung to a heavily upholstered chair in the lobby of the Red Sox caravanserai as long as possible.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 17. -- A spectacular triumph by Joseph Parkey, Oklahoma Southwestern State Teachers College featherweight, achieved in 18 seconds over a veteran champion whom he had never faced before, featured the second day's contests in the final American Olympic wrestling tryouts at Lehigh University.
PITTSBURGH, April 17. -- I. Lamont Hughes, abruptly and without explanation, today resigned as executive vice president of the newly created Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 17. -- The largest tennis gallery Pinehurst has known in years saw Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., carry off the title in the eighteenth North and South championship today with an exhibition that was little short of awe-inspiring.

Racing between the America's Cup yachts Yankee and Rainbow will start on June 12, it was decided yesterday. Gerard B. Lambert, who owns Yankee and sailed her against the English yachts last year, and Harold S. Vanderbilt, who owns Rainbow, the last cup defender, agreed upon the opening date.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Wisconsin Gas and Electric Company has filed an amendment to its registration statement for the issuance of $10,500,000 of 3 1/2 per cent series first-mortgage bonds due in 1966, giving the offering date as April 20.

ROME, April 17. -- Public attention here is now concentrated not on Geneva but on the Somaliland front, where, according to current reports, partly confirmed by war bulletins, heavy fighting has been in progress in Ogaden Province of Ethiopia for several days.

Many visiting clergymen and many assistant pastors will preach in the city's leading Protestant churches tomorrow, as the pastors are away on a brief vacation to recuperate from the extra Lenten and Easter activities. Some of the pastors who have not left town will preach on the topic "The Aftermath of Easter."

New York and Paris police worked together by cable and wireless yesterday to round up members of an international gang, after the arrest of three men and the recovery of $440,000 out of $1,456,000 in bonds belonging to the Bank of the Manhattan Company, stolen in January, 1935.

The National City Bank of New York, one of ten banks of the New York Clearing House Association involved in the suit brought by the United States Government to compel them to make good the losses suffered by the depositors of the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, has agreed to pay $725,000 in settlement of claims against it.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 17. -- A nine-day celebration of the semi-centennial of the University of Chattanooga, to be marked by a far-reaching symposium on education, opened here today with addresses by General James G. Harbord, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, and Dr. James R. McCain, president of Agnes Scott College and the Association of American Colleges.

" A musical journey in song and piano for young people of all ages" was what Dorothy Gordon and Guy Maier called their joint recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The entertainment which they afforded their decidedly interested audience had, indeed, the merit of absorbing the attention of the grown-ups in the house as completely as it did that of the large number of youngsters for whom the program was primarily intended.

Mr. and Mrs. James A. Thomas of Homeside, White Plains, gave a reception and dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Lillias P. Dulles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Foster Dulles, who is a student at Bennington College.

ELIZABETH WYNNE was the daughter of one Richard Wynne, an Englishman of Welsh descent. In 1789, at the age of 11, she conceived the idea of starting a diary. With a fidelity unusual at any age she recorded her movements and thoughts nearly every day continuously for sixty-eight years.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Democrats of the Ways and Means tax subcommittee gave final approval late today to the new Tax Bill, but still lacked complete estimates as to its prospective yield.

LONDON, April 18. -- While art lovers were relieved at the refloating of the liner Ranpura, returning to China with treasures worth $50,000,000 that had been shown at the Royal Academy here, China's Ambassador, Quo Tai Chi, opened another great exhibition of Chinese art yesterday at the Victoria and Albert Museum, where the world-famed Eumorfopoulos collection is on view.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18. -- The Princeton Theatre Intime, in collaboration with the Dramatic Art Department of the Finch School of New York, will present Henrik Ibsen's "Peer Gynt" in McCarter Theatre on the evenings of Friday, May 1, and Saturday, May 2. A third performance will be held in the Lenox Little Theatre in New York on Monday, May 4.

ADDIS ABABA, April 18. -- The Ethiopian military situation is extremely grave. The government, like that of Emperor Menelik before the Battle of Adowa forty years ago, is praying for intervention -- this time, however, not by heaven, but by the League of Nations.

THIS unassuming and entirely human study of one of the most beloved figures of early sixteenth-century England is an outstanding exception to the rule that biographical novels are less satisfying, from historical and scholarly viewpoints, than straight biography.

Your recent editorial on the National Labor Relations Act and the decision of Judge Barnes provokes me to offer a more sympathetic statement of the objects and working of the law. Incidentally, the decision of Judge Barnes represents a distinct minority view.
LOS ANGELES, April 18. -- Charles J. Fitzgerald, 60, was arrested without a struggle by Federal agents here.

Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander gave a luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre. Pier guests included Mr. and Mrs. Ashley Chanler, Mr. and Mrs. Frederio W. Rhinelander, Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Pierrepont Gilbert, Princess Pignatelli di Montecalvo, Mrs. Moses Taylor Campbell, Miss Anne Stuyvesant, G. Creighton Wehb, George MacDonald, William NIatheus Sullivan, Laurence Atterbury and W. Francklyn Paris.

LONDON, April 9. THEATRICAL taste changes very slowly and, if any important alteration is to be remarked, it is necessary to turn away now and then from the new plays of the week and to see what pieces that might ordinarily be considered to be outside the commercial run have nevertheless established themselves in public favor.

LOOK TO THE LIGHTNING" was Gilbert Maxwell's first book of poems and it was a book praised by the critics. "Stranger's Garment" is a better book technically and a book showing more maturity of thought. This poet writes in the conventional forms about the usual subjects, love, loss and his own feeling for nature, his evaluation of the different persons he has known.

Celebrities of the club world and of radio, eager to learn the winners of the second annual awards of the Women's National Radio Committee, will crowd into the ballroom of the Hotel Astor Wednesday for the luncheon at which the announcements will be made.

The extensive work of the child placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association will benefit by a children's Spring party and fashion show on the afternoon of April 30 at the Park Lane. Mrs. C. De Wolf Gibson is chairman of arrangements for the fete which will offer a wide variety of diversions for children and elders accompanying them.

LAURENCE KIRK has swung a wide arc from his clever and original horror story, "The Farm at Paranao," with a Brazilian setting, to his new novel, a bright froth of romance and shady dealing, staged in London. "Rings on Her Fingers" concerns the breach-of-promise racket as it can be legally worked in England.
ALBANY, April 18. -- Governor Lehman will go on the radio tomorrow to ask the people of the State for support of his eight point social security program.

A century before the polar regions actually were explored by air a scheme for such an undertaking was advanced by Citizen Genet, one of the storm centers of post-Revolutionary American history, according to an unusual letter by him which has come to light.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Appointment of eight health officers to an advisory board which will aid in formulating a standard public health code was announced today by the United States Public Health Service. The aim is to assure the cooperation of cities and towns in a project sponsored by the Treasury Department.

THE Highway Education Board has announced its eleventh national safety contest in which children and teachers of elementary schools will participate. Cash prizes and medals totaling $6,500 will be distributed among the winners. Pupils of the fifth to the eighth grade are eligible to enter, writing essays on "A Definite Program for My Community to Prevent Highway Accidents and to Promote Highway Safety."

MANHASSET, L.I., April 18. -- Showing absolutely no respect for sentiment or age, 28-year-old Ogden Phipps, national amateur singles court tennis champion for the past three years, administered a sound licking to the man who taught him the fundamentals of the sport many years ago, the 51-year-old Walter Kinsella, in a $5,000 challenge match today on the spacious Greentree court.

MOOSE RIVER, N.S., Sunday, April 19. -- Three men imprisoned in the Moose River gold mine for a week sent their voices up through a 100-foot steel tube early today to say they had survived imprisonment and exposure. Earlier rappings had been heard through the tube.

PARIS, April 16. -- Boot-makers here are featuring fabric shoes in the material of the dress or suit with which they are to be worn. Tweed, flannel or broadcloth shoes for town wear are trimmed on the heel and toe pieces with patent leather.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 18. -- Trinity recorded a 6-to-5 victory over the Wesleyan nine today.

Seven former presidents of the Westchester County Federation of Women are expected to attend the fifteenth anniversary meeting on Friday at the Contemporary Club, White Plains. They are Mrs. Edward Lyman Bill, Mrs. George S. Harral, Mrs. Julian C. Chase, Mrs. William E. Breckenridge, Mrs. John G. Anderson, Mrs. Gridley Adams and Mrs. A. Emerson Hadlock. Mrs. Kenneth Norton is the retiring president.

City College's baseball team scored its third straight victory at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, triumphing over the Providence College nine by 8 to 2. It was the first diamond victory ever registered by the Lavender at the expense of the Rhode Islanders.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 18. -- The White Plains branch of the National Urban League will sponsor a concert by Roland Hayes, Negro tenor, on Friday in the County Center here.

NOT yet six months old, the American Student Union moves swiftly toward the national spotlight as sponsor of the country-wide students' peace strike to be called on April 22. Educators on several hundred college and high school campuses have already had a good look at this youngest among national student organizations.

SCOUTING, of course, is fun for its participants, but it is an educative fun, carefully taught by more than 232,000 adult leaders, of whom less than a thousand are professional. In their turn these teachers must be trained, and for this task the movement has developed an extensive program directed by the Educational Service of the New York National Office through the 543 local councils scattered throughout the country.

Miss Jane McLean has enlisted the assistance of several young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons in the sale of boxes and seats for the recital by Jascha Heifetz, violinist, on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Cecilia Music School of the Madonna House Settlement.
WASHINGTON, Pa., April 18. -- Henry Ford himself indulged in a "wisecrack" about his own product during his brief visit here yesterday.

BERLIN, April 18. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller has joined the leaders of the National Church movement who have undertaken to overthrow the Protestant and Catholic churches and establish a single German church with a strictly national character.

The Italians are marching on Addis Ababa, the capital of Ethiopia. They are sending flying columns south from Dessye, troops which are supplied only by airplanes. It is a spectacular, almost convincing proof that the resistance of Haile Selassie has broken down under overwhelming military power.

WATER, the essential needed to entice tourists to the recently completed Telescope Peak Trail in Death Valley National Monument, has been discovered half a mile from the route and close to the famous Telescope Notch.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 18. -- Three men hunted for almost three years as participants in the $100,000 kidnapping of William Hamm Jr., brewer of St. Paul, have been arrested, officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed here today.

JOHN REED was born in an elegant mansion in Portland, Ore., and was buried thirty-three years later, with "thousands of workers walking behind his coffin," beside the wall of the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia. That simple statement would of itself suggest that a life worth looking into lay between the two almost fantastically opposed poles of its beginning and its end.

Like Mr. Leeming's "Things Any Boy Can Make," this volume will provide excellent entertainment for boys, and for girls, too, from 8 to 12. Mr. Leeming can be trusted to make his directions sufficiently clear and simple for children to follow them unaided, and he has been careful to suggest only such material as can be easily obtained.

Continuance of birth control by the healthy and intelligent, and with population increases coming from the mentally and physically unfit will soon lower the average intelligence of the United States to less than 10 years of age, Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, former Commissioner of Health of New York City, warned yesterday.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 18. -- Youngstown's first dog show in ten years opened this morning for a two-day session under the auspices of the Mahoning-Shanango Kennel Club at the Rayenwood Auditorium. It is sponsored by the Youngstown Hospital Association and 341 dogs are entered.

WAUPUN, Wis., April 18 (AP). -- Leslie Homer, one of the last of John Dillinger's gang of terrorists, was shot off the wall of the Wisconsin State prison today while leading four men in a desperate attempt to escape.

NOW, when making up seed lists, is the time for one to arrange for that most subtle and alluring quality that can animate a garden -- fragrance. Many persons do not possess an "eye" for color or for form, or do not appreciate rarity in plants.

The gigantic task of fitting out and launching the thousands of expensive boats which have been hauled out in the many yards of the metropolitan area during the Winter got under way earlier this year than in past seasons. In most cases the owners have requested earlier deliveries of their craft, officials declare.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Within two months the mail men will begin delivery to World War veterans of checks and neat $50 bonus bonds, 6 1/2 by 7 3/4 inches, printed on crinkly green currency paper and bearing the likeness of the soldier-President, Andrew Jackson.
The Duchess just glanced at the headlines over Alice's shoulder.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to postpone the effective date of its recent order that reduces railroad passenger fares throughout the United States and reaffirmed its mandate that, after June 2, fares would be unlawful if they exceeded 2 cents a mile in coaches and 3 cents a mile in Pullman cars.

ST. PAUL, April 18 (AP). -- Four delegates at large to the national convention, uninstructed and unpledged, were elected by the State Republican convention today after it had adopted a platform and listened to speeches attacking the administrations of President Roosevelt and Governor Olson.
GENOA, April 18 (AP). -- Mgr. Tito Crespi, auditor of the papal nunziature at Madrid, was found hanged in his cabin aboard the steamer Merano when it docked today from Barcelona.

Declaring that uniformity of purpose and action is needed to deal with the problems confronting drug manufacturers and distributers, Frank A. Blair, president of the Proprietary Association, announced yesterday that the organization will lead a movement to coordinate some of the activities of the various trade groups in the industry.

With typical football weather prevailing, the Columbia University and Lafayette College gridiron squads engaged in a two and one-half hour scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field. The Pennsylvanians, who are being coached for the first time by Ernie Nevers, former Stanford star, started with a line-up composed entirely of last year's freshmen eleven with the exception of Ernie Kanzler, senior, who was at right end.

OFF the westernmost cape of Africa in the latitude of Bermuda there is a group of seven Spanish islands which, their residents claim, possess the most equable climate in the world. The voyage from New York is pleasant Winter and Summer and vessels flying the Stars and Stripes, equipped with passenger accommodation, call regularly at Santa Cruz and Las Palmas, which are thriving cities having busy United States Consulates.

Although retail distribution moved at a slower pace last week, following the final rush of Easter buying in the previous week, the trend of business in general continued favorable in most of the Federal Reserve Districts. Buying in the wholesale markets gathered new momentum as retailers made commitments for early Summer needs and placed a substantial volume of reorders for goods for current selling.

ADDIS ABABA, April 18. -- The members of the Belgian military mission, employed for the last five years by Emperor Haile Selassie to train soldiers and police, were reported reliably today to have resigned again.

Speaking at Albany last Wednesday evening, Chairman FARLEY, in his large and tolerant way, described the Republican party as now only a thing of shreds and patches. Its leaders cannot meet without quarreling. The former rank and file is hopelessly divided and can never be wrought into a united party again.

WITH the purpose of instituting an American music festival of which the performances shall have a rank and significance equal to those of the best-known festivals given in Europe in the Summertime, the committee of the Berkshire Festival to be held during the week of Aug. 9 at Anna Farm at Stockbridge has secured by special agreement the services of Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

ROME. -- The anti-sanctionist campaign, one of the principal points of which is that Italy must buy the raw materials and products she needs, such as gasoline, copper, iron, trucks and the like, only from non-sanctionist countries, is expected to result in the placing of large orders for coal in the American market.

A RAILROAD, says Mr. Firestone, "may become two streaks of rust and a right of way, a highway may go bad, a canal fill up with bulrushes and bullfrogs, a forest get into history as fallen timbers, a mining city fade into a ghost town. But rivers are eternal thing.

The leading New York banks showed an average decline of 0.8 per cent in deposits and 0.74 per cent in total resources in the first quarter of this year on the basis of reports issued by sixteen clearing house institutions. In the last twelve months their deposits have increased an average of 18.2 per cent and their resources 15.5 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP). -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled the consolidation of four oil companies into the Transcontinental Oil Company in 1919 was not a taxable transaction and ordered the Board of Tax Appeals to enter a judgment of no deficiency.

CONGRESS has recently been asked to incorporate the Military Order of the Purple Heart, which was founded by General George Washington more than a century and a half ago, and was revived by President Hoover on Feb. 22, 1932, the bicentennial of Washington's birth.

In today's Magazine there is a piece in the right vein about GEORGE LYMAN KITTREDGE, who has taught English at Harvard since '88. He hasn't repented of his decision to quit his job. He should have waited till '38 but, like certain verbs, he is strong and irregular. He won't wait for his ritual half-century.

THE purpose of Dr. Maude Glasgow in this book is to show from authoritative sources the important and beneficent part the Protestant Scotch-Irish who themselves or whose ancestors were born in Northern Ireland have played in Anglo-Irish and American civilization. The reader expects, quite naturally, since she herself was born there, that her volume will hold a brief for the Scotch-Irish. Nor will his expectation be disappointed.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP). -- The Indians pounded three St. Louis pitchers today to take their second game in the series, 7 to 2, and send the Browns to their fourth straight defeat.

BEER, orchids and food are Nero Wolfe's major passions -- and probably in that order. Our reason for this surmise is that once in the course of the events narrated in this story Wolfe permits himself to be deprived of his rightful share of certain favorite dishes, and once he neglects his beloved orchids, but there is no record of his failing to consume his liberal quota of beer.

WHEN an Englishman has been in the habit of looking on the New York stage as a kind of annex to the London stage, a few weeks of theatregoing in this city are bound to produce a happily disillusioned man.

Two hundred and eleven dissertations were accepted last year by Columbia University from candidates for the doctor's degree, it was announced yesterday. They range in length from eight pages to two thick volumes, and in subject matter from Mooganaykankote Siddalingaiya's "Reconstructing Elementary Education in Mysore, India," to one candidate's "Kinship System and the Forms of Marriage."

Thank you for your comment on the cheap, undignified and amazing talks presented during the intermissions of the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts. It may surprise you to know that, in general, they have been of higher quality this Winter than previously.

THE reign of philip II of Spain, writes the French historian Batiffol, is the story of the Catholic Reaction. Rather unfortunately for the modern student, however, it is a story without art, without unity of action, full of cross-purposes and anticlimax.

WASHINGTON. -- A bibliography of the hill folk is Uncle Sam's latest contribution to the cause of social justice. It lists 830 books and articles on the mountaineers of the Southern Appalachians. Subjects include adult illiteracy, Auman pottery, baptizing, courting, drinking, folklore, feuds, handicrafts, individualism, midwives and Scotch ballads.

A fair proportion of the feminine executives comprising the membership of the International Association of Altrusa Clubs will turn over their desks during the next six days to youthful aspirants, and analyze their professions for girls who believe they would like to sit at the one and to practice the other.

IT sometimes seemed odd to Americans that English women were so active in politics before they got the vote; it has always seemed odd to Americans and English that French women should, through the centuries, have been so active and influential in all spheres of national life without ever having the vote at all, or, indeed, in mass, taking any interest in it.

HONOLULU, T.H., April 18. -- Indications that the Pan American Airways is preparing for early inauguration of its passenger service across the Pacific were seen with the arrival today by the China Clipper of K.A. Kennedy, division traffic Manager for the Pacific Coast.

BALTIMORE, April 18. -- In one of the closest finishes seen during the thirty-seven years of the Grand National Point-to-Point, J.W.Y. Martin's bay gelding, Inshore, crossed the line a half length in front of Arthur I. Meig's Preparedness today.

Sweeping aside German debt moratorium laws as non-existent for American investors in German bonds issued here, Judge Robert P. Patterson of the United States District Court ruled yesterday that German corporations issuing such bonds had subjected themselves to American courts and therefore must meet their obligations in this country.

A.P. HERBERT is a gallant warrior in the cause of correct speech. With the shafts of wit and irony and of ordinary common sense, he strikes out at those enemies of the language who insist on saying everything in the most obscure, muddled and difficult fashion.

IT is always a matter of interest when a man of reputation in one field tries his hand in another, and Dr. Johnson's first novel accordingly deserves a touch of special attention. "Spring Storm" is in the good sense of the word a modest book, born somewhat less of a creative than of a commemorative impulse, for its author has recalled here the scenes and sensations of his youth in Nebraska.

The peoples of twelve nations joined last night in a folk festival at the Seventh Regiment, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue. It was sponsored by the international department of the Twenty-third Street Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, with the Folk Festival Council cooperating.

BERLIN, April 18. -- It stands to reason that social and labor matters have to occupy a prominent place in the reconstruction work done by the National Socialist Government. About the most urgent as well as the most difficult of the problems here concerned is that of unemployment.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 18. -- The senior class at Vassar College gave its annual promenade tonight in Students Building. Nearly 200 students and their guests began the program this afternoon at a concert by the college sextet. A formal reception and dinner preceded the grand march, traditional part of the prom program.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan's campaign for a new bridge across the East River at Forty-second Street in place of the projected $58,000,000 East River vehicular tunnel won the support yesterday of Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 18. -- The Nassau Colege of N.Y.U. scored a rugby upset today by defeating Long Island University, 13 -- 9, at the Hofstra Memorial Field.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Continued drought in the Southwestern Winter wheat belt and the government forecast holding out little hope of relief in the coming week increased public interest today on the Board of Trade. Prices advanced sharply to a new high mark on the current upturn, the September reaching fresh ground for the season.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- With the first performance of a new play, "Behold Your God," by Richard Houghton Hepburn, brother of Katharine Hepburn, the Hedgerow Theatre will celebrate its thirteenth birthday on Tuesday night at the little playhouse in Rose Valley, thirteen miles southwest of Philadelphia.
With the yachting season just around the corner, one's thoughts naturally turn to paint and varnish and should likewise be directed to the yacht's interior.
For the second consecutive year, Hunter College carried off the Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish Trophy, emblematic of the women's intercollegiate team fencing championship, last night.

THERE will be opera as usual during the coming Spring season with Wagner as the mainstay at Covent Garden and Mozart at Mr. Christy's Glyndebourne Theatre. But the projected visit of Toscanini has come to nothing, and the last hope of such another symphonic festival as that of last year has now died.

Final preparations are being made by several committees for the Spring dinner dance to be held on Friday at Sherry's to aid the work of the social service and occupational therapy departments of the Reconstruction Hospital. The event has received a large advance patronage and many younger members of society are active in arranging details for it.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Next week, from April 27 to May 2, is "Garden Week" in Virginia. Pilgrimages will be made to all parts of the State. Special motor excursions will be arranged from Hot Springs to enable those interested to visit all the exhibition gardens within a reasonable distance.

DESPITE the fact that rhododendrons were long considered, by the small property owner, as belonging to those plants suited only for large estates, they have gradually become so popular and so generally available that now no one who has a suitable location for a few plants need do without them.

KARACHI, India. -- After a lapse of ninety years, the Province of Sind again assumes its geographic and political status as a province under the charge of Sir Lancelot Graham as Governor. This part of the lower Indus valley has been subjected to more invasions than any other part of India.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 18. -- One world record was broken, the Olympic decathlon mark bettered and an intercollegiate standard tumbled as 10,000 spectators watched a preview of United States track and field hopefuls in the fourteenth annual Kansas Relays today.

With enrollment of more than 2,000 volunteer workers nearly completed, the Citizens Family Welfare Committee announced yesterday that it would launch its campaign for a minimum of $1,500,000 for the support of private family welfare agencies at a meeting at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, on Tuesday afternoon at 4:45 o'clock.

The Edward, G. Budd Manufacturing Company reported yesterday for the March quarter a net operating profit of $346,250 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges Including income of $638,000 from the Budd International Corporation as a result of that company's sale of its interest in the British Pressed Steel Company, there was a net profit of $984,250 for the quarter.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 18. -- Seventeen sailing dinghies went out this afternoon in the first session of the two-day regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and a number of them had their troubles in a northwest breeze which was still hard with Winter weight.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 18. -- Reaffirming the church's policy that total abstinence, not moderation, was the only safe course to pursue, the New York Conference of the Methodist Church today unanimously adopted its temperance committee's report denouncing the liquor traffic.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- The Senate Commerce Committee became mired today in a new dispute over whether it should ask State and local governments to put up $100,000,000 to match nearly $400,000,000 of Federal money in a nation-wide flood control program.

WITH the best will in the world it is hard to understand the processes which led the powers of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra to their choice of conductors for next season. It is generally agreed today that the fewer the conductors to whom an orchestra must submit itself in the course of a season the better.

VIENNA, April 17. -- A general collapse of disarmament provisions seems to have been started by Austria's introduction of compulsory military service. Although Germany set the evil example a year ago, it had no immediate reactions in Central and Southeastern Europe while the Little Entente remained the watchdog of the treaties and the greater powers were not too preoccupied to hold the smaller States to their bond.

MOTOR tourists who have a historical bent may find the Epic of America written for them with axe and spade, with trowel and hammer, on a thousand hills and valleys of the continent when the National Park Service completes the vast program for the preservation and rehabilitation of historic sites and monuments now under way.

Refusing to endorse the nationwide student peace strike set for 11 A.M. Wednesday, the Student Council of Hunter College has called a peace mobilization within the college for the same time. Characterizing the strike as an "emotional outburst," student leaders voted against participation, 23 to 10.

New York University announced yesterday the finding of what may be the oldest clock in working condition in existence. The finder, Dr. Daniel W. Hering, 86-year-old curator of the James Arthur collection of clocks and watches at the university, declared that the clock had stood on a West Street dealer's shelves for twenty years and was passed as rubbish by hundreds of visitors, including collectors.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 17. -- Twice rejected by Congress, Florida's cross-state ship canal project has resolved itself into an economic and political enigma in which public interest has waned rapidly during the last few days. But it doubtless will be a conspicuous issue in Washington again soon.

BELIEVING that the misconceptions of diplomacy render its work less efficacious than it should be, Graham H. Stuart, Professor of Political Science in Stanford University, has prepared this book to place it in a more revealing light.

Although the mystery in this novel is transparent enough to the reader, it is not so to the young American artist, Cassie Mather, who is one of the principal characters. We first meet Cassie on her way to Paris on a French steamer.

NOW that Britain is rearming with all its might and main, Sir Thomas Inskip, to his own and the general surprise, has become the man of the moment. A few weeks ago his round and intensely serious countenance, looking dourly Pickwickian behind his spectacles, was framed in the full-bottomed gray wig of the law.

PITTSBURGH, April 17. -- With the charge that many deaths resulted from silicosis (silicate dust disease) contracted in the digging of a three-mile tunnel at Gauley Bridge in the neighboring State of West Virginia, the industrial State of Pennsylvania received an added stimulus to the investigation of its own conditions in this respect, and the results of a survey just completed by the Department of Labor and Industry are causing a stir.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- The A.C. Spark Plug Company of Flint, Michigan, a General Motors subsidiary, appealed to the Supreme Court today to free it from a $1,000,000 damage claim based on a lower court ruling that it had engaged in "unfair competition."

TORONTO, Ont., April 18. -- In 1931 the Dominion of Canada had only approximately thirty gold plants of all sizes in operation, but the last five-year period has witnessed a remarkable expansion in development, and a recent survey of mining operations showed more than 120 gold mills in operation and many others under construction.

DALLAS, April 18. -- Favorable weather has prevailed over the Eleventh Federal Reserve District during the current week, and has been attended by satisfactory gains in most lines of business. With the passing of the pre-Easter season there has been a slight let-down in retail buying of wearing apparel, but merchants report business has held up better than they had expected.
HAVERFORD, Pa., April 18. -- Lafayette overwhelmed the Haverford nine today on a cold, windswept field. The score was 23 -- 7.

NANCY HALE is a writer whose performance so far has been baffling and who has certainly not yet crystallized in any mold. Her first novel, of which the least said the better, made gestures in the direction of brittle sophistication; her second, "Never Any More," was so surprisingly superior, so different in setting and mood, that the two books seemed to have little in common.

THERE are, broadly speaking, two schools of directors working in motion pictures today -- the school which appeals to the audience intellectually, and the school whose appeal is emotional. In the picture whose appeal is primarily intellectual, the picture is essentially the director's picture.

A survey last week among the stock-boat plants, brokers and distributors found optimism over the 1936 yachting season genuine and enthusiastic. The good old days of predepression 1928 and 1929 appear to be back.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Blanket seizure of private communications, whatever the authority used, was denounced today by the American Society of Newspaper Editors as a violation of constitutional rights.

TROY, April 18. -- The cast of "Trojan Women," by Euripides, to be presented by Russell Sage College on May 30 at the Crossways, has been chosen and rehearsals are now under way. Production of a Greek play is a traditional part of the commencement activities of the college.

France's attitude in the face of the Rhineland crisis was described as an example of admirable self-control by Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye, French Ambassador to Washington, in an address yesterday before the thirty-fourth annual luncheon of the Federation de I'Alliance Francaise aux Etats-Unis et au Canada at the Hotel Plaza.
MOSCOW, April 18. -- The ancient Romans liked caviar, too, and salt herring from the entrance to the Sea of Azov was a delicacy along the whole Mediterranean littoral in classical times.

Because prolonged sessions of Congress and the New York State Legislature would make it impossible for many public officials to attend, the executive committee of the Grover Cleveland Memorial Committee announced yesterday through its chairman, Gustavus A. Rogers, that it had postponed until a later date the ceremonial dinner which was to have been held on April 29.

FATHER DUDLEY'S thrillers bear a superficial resemblance to Chesterton's Father Brown tales, but they have a narrow range, and their appeal seems limited to Catholic readers. The present volume deals with the struggle of the Masterful Monk, Anselm Thornton, against Anti-Christ in the modern world, his activities against boleshevism in England and his assistance in leading a young Englishwoman to the faith.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP). -- Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, cracked the whip at his official family today to start sending home definite reports on the $350,000 fund necessary to get the United States athletes to Berlin in August.

THE wooded campus of Wellesley College, in Massachusetts, will resound from late June to mid-July with a many-sided discussion of international and national affairs. From June 23 to July 2 it will be the scene of the fifth annual New England Institute of International Relations, conducted under auspices of the American Friends Service Committee and the Congregational Council for Social Action.

PERSONS who incline to the view that New York is "just a small town after all will probably see in the growing popularity of old-fashioned parlor games another argument for their case. But the players of "Murder," of "Coffee Pot," of "Sniff" and "Ghosts" and "Conversation" will not mind; let scoffers scoff and viewers-with-alarm do just that.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The Zeppelin Company announces that the dirigible Hindenburg will take off on her first flight to the United States on May 6, as originally planned, instead of May 14, for the work of overhauling her four Diesel motors has been almost completed. Their re-examination at the Daimler-Benz factory at Stuttgart made only slight alterations necessary.

PARIS, April 18. -- Trading on the Bourse for the week ended calmly today, with yesterday's advance well held. Rentes were strong, but a small volume of business was done, giving the market an appearance of fragility.

Young women headed by Miss Katherine Farley are active in arrangements for the dinner and supper dance in behalf of the Humane Society which will mark the formal opening on May 7 of the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE "railroad problem" is not so very difficult to understand, with the aid of a few facts. In 1920, something like $20,000,000,000 had been invested in railroad property. Since that time, a like amount has gone into other forms of transportation competitive in one way or another with the railroads, and about $6,000,000,000 more into the railroads.

PIERRE, S.D. -- Twenty years ago when the Non-Partisan League, under the management of A.G. Townley, was sweeping North Dakota with its "New Day" program, the indications were rather strong that the same movement would roll down over the prairies of South Dakota.

MADRID, April 18. -- Although a bill sponsored by the Azana government to dissolve the Falange Espanola and all similar Fascist organizations has not yet been enacted by Parliament, more than 800 members of the Falange were arrested here and in the provinces today. The organization is headed by Antonio Primo de Rivera, son of the late Spanish dictator.

RECENTLY an order went to the police to search diligently for the mothers and fathers of abandoned infants and foundlings as these are discovered. About 200 babies are abandoned in this city every year, many of them at holiday times when unfortunate mothers seem to despair as they contrast their plight with the happiness of others who are buying for themselves and their children.

Joe Besselmann, German middleweight, made his first appearance in American boxing circles at the Ridgewood Grove last night and scored a three-round knockout over the veteran Williamsburg campaigner, Larry Marinucci, before 3,000 persons.
PITTSBURGH, April 18. -- Mayor McNair, during his stay in jail today, laughed and joked with the prisoners, ate an apple and smoked a stogie.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Government pencils, slide rules and adding machines have been worked overtime this week, following President Roosevelt's suggestions on compulsory education for all persons up to the age of 18 and retirement of all workers at age 65.

WHATEVER the late depression has done or failed to do to the farmer, at least it has contributed something to the social security of the farmer's daughter. The traveling salesman -- whose name has always been connected, however mistakenly, with deviltry and prankish accident in rural households -- has so far faded from the scene that it is years since the last joke was coined at his expense.

A major reason for the lack of effective promotional tie-up between producers of nationally branded merchandise and department stores, which has been the subject of recent complaint, is the fact that the set prices on many of the branded items of merchandise leave these stores insufficient mark-up.
ROME, April 18. -- Today's war bulletin confirms rumors prevalent in Rome for several days that General Rodolfo Graziani has launched his offensive from the south against Harar.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- An assured total of 130 votes in the Republican National Convention was claimed today by Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, on his arrival for a brief visit in the capital. To capture the Presidential nomination 501 votes are needed.
Two tries by Harry Cohen enabled the French Rugby team to beat the Yale fifteen, 6 -- 5, in a spirited game at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

MEXICO, D.F., April 17. -- The deportation of former President Plutarco Elias Calles, the labor leader Luis Morones and Luis Leon, both former Cabinet officers, and Melchor Ortega, former Governor of Guanajuato, has gone far toward calming Mexico's political atmosphere.

A group of clergymen from the United States will preach in Great Britain this Summer and thirteen clergymen from overseas will come here to occupy pulpits. This exchange will be under the auspices of the Committee on Interchange of Preachers and Speakers, the headquarters of which is at 70 Fifth Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18. -- The Harvard baseball team maintained a ten-year tradition when it opened its Eastern intercollegiate league season today by defeating Princeton, 9 -- 2. Not since 1926 has a Tiger nine managed to take a diamond contest from its Crimson rival.

THE aromatic odor of cedar shavings mingles with the musty smell of tarred lines and salty canvas and the pungency of turpentine. There is a sound of tapping mallets and the rasp of scrapers on bilge strakes. Fathoms of anchor rope are hauled out for inspection and a myriad of cylinder-head bolts and valve springs are spread in oily array. Spring outfitting and re-rigging for the boat lover begins in April.

Nathan Milstein's violin recital before a large audience in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon must be chronicled among the outstanding artistic events of the passing season. In its brilliancy, accuracy and technical perfection the playing he put forth was unsurpassable by any violinist of the day.

HAROLD LLOYD, the comic, who is in town for a brief playgoing holiday, and incidentally to keep an eye on several story possibilities, isn't being secretive or mysterious when he tells you he just doesn't know what story he is likely to do next for Paramount.
LONDON, April 18. -- The British and Italian Governments threw charges at each other in a series of notes just made public concerning the recent bombings of British ambulance units in Ethiopia.
WHAT are our schools doing to prepare children for participation in the economic order?

THE Gibson Girl is back again, in a whirl of shirtwaists and puffed sleeves, veils and lacy jabots and severely tailored suits. She comes accompanied by enthusiasm for dachshunde and spotted coach dogs, the whir of bicycles, the applause of debutant and the reminiscent sighs of matrons who once were Gibson Girls themselves and never have forgotten how beautiful they were.

Both the doubles and the distance championships of the New York Athletic Club were decided at the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. T.H. Lewis took the doubles title by breaking 96 out of 100 targets, the second prize going to A.F. MacNichol, who had 91. The winner of the third and last scratch cup was T.H. Lawrence. He carded 87.

Under unusual circumstances a Federal jury that had been out since 2 P.M. Friday reported a disagreement yesterday in the trial of four men accused of having operated an artichoke trust in violation of the Sherman act. The jury at their first trial seven weeks ago also disagreed.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18. -- Scoring four runs in the first three innings, the University of Richmond defeated the Naval Academy nine today, 5 to 2.

Ben Fidd, the veteran watchman of the Chelsea Piers, made a trip yesterday afternoon to the foot of West Fiftieth Street to inspect the new pier being completed for the accommodation of the Queen Mary. He was accompanied by his favorite grandson who is named after him -- Ben Fidd Jr.

Once again the pollution of New York's atmosphere by smoke has been called to attention statistically. David R. Morris of the Federal Meteorological Observatory in Central Park has issued figures for March showing an average of 1.33 tons of soot per cubic mile of air, a gain of .44 tons over a seven-year March average, and a gain of .10 tons over March, 1935.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The German Calisthenics Association to appears have reversed the ruling of the Reich Sport League that no Jew may belong to a German sport organization. The association has issued a ruling forbidding the expulsion of any member of a local calisthenics group merely on the ground that he is a Jew.

CHEMISTRY'S expanding influence was shown in more than 300 papers read at the ninety-first meeting of the American Chemical Society, held last week in Kansas City, Mo. Two thousand chemists, agriculturalists and industrialists participated in sessions lasting five days and showed how chemistry strengthens national self-sufficiency, alters the conditions of everyday life, stimulates industrial progress and provides tools for research in all branches of pure science.

Final plans for the sixth annual convention of the Women's State Republican Club of New Jersey, which will convene at Haddon Hall, Atlantic City, on Friday and Saturday, have been announced by Mrs. Clarence Blair Mitchell, general chairman.

Total revenues of the electric light and power industry for February amounted to $171,219,500, compared with $162,469,900 in the same month last year, a gain of 5.4 per cent, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. Total sales were 13 per cent larger at 6,999,033,000 kilowatt-hours.

Credit, collection and exchange conditions in Latin-American markets showed marked improvement in the first three months of this year, compared with the closing quarter of 1935, the quarterly survey compiled yesterday by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men discloses.

THERE is not much in this tribute to Governor Landon of Kansas to suggest that the man and the hour are met. Perhaps Mr. Palmer is to blame. Perhaps he has not studied his hero carefully enough, and so does not do him full justice. Yet a panegyric is probably never a good source of information.

Paul H. Wendel, disbarred Trenton attorney who charged that he was kidnapped and tortured into "confessing" the murder of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr., picked a house at 3,041 Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday as the place in which he believes he was held captive.

WELLESLEY, Mass., April 18. -- Students of medieval art at Wellesley College have converted one of the studios in the Farnsworth Museum into a monastic scriptorium of eleventh century South-Italy, in keeping with the college theory that they should project themselves into an authentic historical atmosphere properly to understand and appreciate the accomplishments of a period.

MEXICO, D.F., April 18. -- Although there is some prospect that today's conferences between the owners and workers may result in a settlement of the bakers' strike, which for forty-eight hours has closed upward of 500 bakeries here, the situation continues tense.

THE twentieth annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists will open at Grand Central Palace on Friday evening. More than a thousand guests are expected to attend the preview at that time. The show will open to the public on Saturday morning and continue through Sunday, May 17.

Completing the schedule of the Connecticut-Eastern New York Field Trial Circuit and concluding the field-trial season in this section of the country for the Spring, the annual meeting of the Sport and Conservation League will open on Friday morning and end on Sunday at Middletown, N.Y.
Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were little changed in number from the reduced volume in the preceding week.

With the demand for stocks continuing to lack vitality, prices drifted lower again yesterday. Leading issues at the closing were down fractionally to 3 points. The trading total on the Stock Exchange for the half-day session amounted to 809,000 shares, compared with 798,000 the Saturday before.

OTTAWA, April 18. -- It is unwritten law that the Governor General of Canada is never interviewed or quoted in the press on matters of State. It is probably more true of the present occupant of the office, Lord Tweedsmuir, who was born plain John Buchan at Perth, Scotland, sixty years ago, than of any man who has held it in the past.

In a general circular to school principals and superintendents, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, has announced that the current term will end June 30. He also calls attention to Child Health Day, May 1, and Parents' Day, May 10, and requests that appropriate exercises and special emphasis mark the observances.

Since the French replied on April 8 to Germany's justification of her occupation of the Rhineland the world has again directed its attention to the problem and rules of treaty revision. Among other things, France's new peace plan proposed the establishment of a "European commission" under the League of Nations which would act by a two-thirds majority in regulating the revision of treaties.

The French franc rose 1/4 point yesterday to 6.59 1/2 cents, where it showed a net gain of 5/8 point for the last week. Sterling declined 3-16 cent to $4.94 1-16, which was down 1-16 cent net in the week. In other directions the foreign exchange market maintained the quiet that characterized the week's business.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 18. -- Concluding three hectic days of competition, Westerners -- more specifically Oklahomans -- captured the laurels in six of the seven classes as the final American Olympic wrestling tryouts came to a close tonight before a capacity crowd of 1,500 fans in Taylor Gymnasium at Lehigh University.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 18. -- Chile will lift its sanctions against Italy in the near future, according to the newspaper Trabajo which points out that Minister of Finance Gustavo Ross, now in France, has received instructions from his government to proceed to Italy and Spain at once on a special mission.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- An open battle among administration leaders over methods of raising $976,000,000 for a four-years' slum clearance program developed today, with the fate of housing legislation at this session of Congress depending on the outcome.

STATION WJZ will become one of the Stentors among American broadcasters if the Federal Communications Commission sanctions a power increase from the present 50,000 to 500,000 watts. Plans specify new apparatus coupled to a lofty steel tower rising 640 feet above the transmitter site, at Bound Brook, N.J., thirty miles from New York.

The New York State Unemployment Insurance Law, which had been successfully attacked in several cases in the lower courts, was held constitutional last week by the highest judicial body of the State, the Court of Appeals. "I can see nothing unreasonable or unconstitutional in the legislative act which seeks to meet the evils and dangers of unemployment in the future by raising a fund through taxation of employers generally," wrote Chief Justice Frederick E. Crane.
SAN JOSE, Calif., April 18 (AP). -- Herbert Hoover told the Young Republicans of California today that the Republican party must become "the true liberal party of America."

RICHMOND, April 18. -- Another big spurt in building was made in the Fifth Federal Reserve District in March, the total being $6,587,201 against $3,416,265 in the same month a year ago. In the first quarter the amount of new construction work was near that in for all of 1935.

BOSTON, April 17. -- The old campaign slogan, "As goes Maine, so goes the nation," has not always held true. But the old tradition that what Maine does in the September State election the country will do in the Presidential test in November has been so generally accepted that both parties strive mightily to make the best showing possible in the earlier election.

The principal New York banks which became involuntary owners of the stocks of public utility operating and holding companies during the depression have almost completed their schedules of, or have filed reports on, such holdings as required by the Securities and Exchange Commission under authority of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18. -- In an effort to stimulate undergraduate interest in public problems, The Daily Princetonian, The Harvard Crimson and The Yale News, student publications of the three universities, are planning a series of annual conferences at which leaders in government and business and faculty members of the three universities will meet for informal discussions with students.

FOR more than fifty years, off and on, the place that "big business" is to play in our national life has been an issue. It promises to be an issue in the campaign just beginning, although the battle lines are harder to draw than they were when Theodore Roosevelt was smashing "bad" trusts and hurling fiery invectives at "malefactors of great wealth."

STATISTICS indicate that per 64 cent of all fatal traffic accidents happen on rural roads or in cities with a population of less than 10,000. In 1924, only about one-half of such accidents were in rural areas. It is clear, therefore, that conditions on rural roads should be investigated to determine why the accident rate on them has increased so steadily.

THE twenty-first birthday of the English Folk Dance Society of America will be celebrated by the New York branch in its annual festival in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, on Saturday afternoon and a special "birthday ballet" composed for the occasion will be presented as a feature of the celebration.
CHICAGO, April 18. -- Clarence Darrow, the central character in a long list of court room dramas, was 79 years old today.

Delegates to a conference of New York State Negro Republicans criticized the attitude of both national and State administrations toward their race yesterday in a resolution unanimously adopted in the building of the Association of Trade and Commerce, 2,370 Seventh Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- Stroked by W. Chattin Wetherill Jr., the Pennsylvania sophomore class eight rallied in the last half-mile to defeat the seniors by six feet over the wind-swept Henley course on the Schuylkill today and gain a leg on the Penniman Bowl.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18. -- Retail and wholesale interests reported spotty conditions during the week, but, in the main, satisfactory. Earnings reports, banking, security trading and similar statistics were encouraging.

A NEW book by Bernhard Kellermann always arouses high expectations. For Kelermann is a master of the novel. Whatever the topic he selects, his story is developed with true creative power, and words, in his hands, become an instrument with which he lures his readers into a world and a life to which his mind has given form.

Charles Lucania, whose Winter visit to Hot Springs, Ark., was interrupted by indictments here charging him with compulsory prostitution, was held in $350,000 bail yesterday and locked up in Raymond Street jail to await trial with his henchmen.

It is a mistake for parents to chide their children for stuttering, Dr. Alfred Adler said yesterday in an address at the twenty-seventh annual Eastern Public Speaking Conference, which closed after a two-day meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

The "dressmaker swagger" coat in new short lengths is rapidly becoming an important Summer fashion, according to a style summary prepared especially for THE TIMES by Tobe, consultant to more than 100 leading stores throughout the country.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 18. -- Holy Cross opened its college baseball season today by defeating Dartmouth, 12 to 11, in a hard-hitting and loosely played game. Weather better suited for football kept the attendance down to 3,500.

CITY dwellers who take for granted electrical "spectaculars" seven stories high and flamboyant billboard stickers that can be read for half a mile may find it difficult to imagine a day when a diminutive wooden horse, a slight hand-carved figure holding forth a bunch of grapes, or even a Life-sized wooden Indian in war paint and feathers could make an impression on the commercial life of the town.

THE relations between art and experience have been the subject of much discussion in and out of fiction.
