Is it necessary for the artists to have had personal knowledge of emotions in order successfully to portray them? Mr. Hichens replies in the affirmative, though he does make one significant reservation.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The volume of industrial production in the first half of April was considerably above that in March, although usually there is little change from March to April, the Department of Commerce reported today on its weekly survey.

A profusion of flowers transforming the ballroom into a picturesque garden setting will be the dominant motif of the Blossom Ball to be held on Friday night at the Plaza. Anticipating one of the gayest parties of the Spring season, the committees working toward the success of the event expect an attendance of more than 1,500.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- Two of the most important events of the intellectual life of Philadelphia are scheduled for this week.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Uncle Sam's clipping bureau is busier than ever keeping tab on what the newspapers in cities of 50,000 and over are saying about the New Deal and its works. Four hundred dailies are being read and clipped for news items, bouquets and brickbats; the clippings are sorted by subject matter, and a list of headings is distributed each day among Cabinet officials and bureau chiefs.
ISTANBUL, April 17. -- During the last two years the question of fortifying the Dardanelles has been a dark cloud on the horizon promising to bring a deluge over the political world at any moment.

ROBERT GRAVES raps Kipling's literary knuckles by way of saluting this old soldier's indecorous memoirs. One trouble with the tales about Ortheris, Learoyd and Mulvaney, Mr. Graves complains, is that Kipling was a civilian. He had never had a full share in the barrack rooms and the ballads.

RECENT reports have indicated that an effort to detect habitual traffic law violators and, by punishment or persuasion, correct their motoring manners, is making headway in Connecticut. Michael A. Conner, the State's Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, was asked about it and, in a letter received last week, he first cited the following provision in the general statutes of the State relating to the violation of motor vehicle regulations:

Negotiations for a new contract in the anthracite field were continued yesterday and will be resumed tomorrow by the joint negotiating committee of the United Mine Workers of America and the anthracite operators. The union has served notice that its members will not work after April 30 if a new contract is not signed.

Purchasing of Summer merchandise was the chief concern of buyers, whose number increased in the market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

COLORADO SPRINGS. PLANS have been completed for the formal opening of the just completed Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center tomorrow. One prominent feature of the week of festivities will be an exhibition of work by French artists, among them Cezanne, Renoir, Van Gogh, Picasso and Matisse.

The membership of The Associated Press increased from 1,340 daily newspapers in 1934 to 1,359 at the end of 1935, it was announced in the annual report of the board of directors of that organization, published in connection with the annual meeting of members at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow.

Can we have expert administration with popular government? President DODDS of Princeton put this question to those who heard him deliver the Jefferson Day address at the University of Virginia on the future of democracy. For a people without a talent for self-government, the speaker held, the answer must be in the negative.

MARGATE, England, April 18. -- Unable to circumvent his chief rival in the fourth round today, Jose R. Capablanca of Havana had to content himself with a draw in his encounter with Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia in the international tournament of the Kent County Chess Association at the Grand Hotel.

The reorganization through bankruptcy of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad has aroused the hopes of bondholders for the first important Western railroad consolidation to be undertaken since the proposal to merge the Great Northern and Northern Pacific.

FIVE parties under the guidance of the Trail Riders of the Wilderness will explore nearly 600 miles of Western wilderness this Summer. The Trail Riders, organized three years ago by the American Forestry Association, with headquarters at 1,713 K Street, N.W., Washington, D.C., sponsor expeditions of persons looking for "something different" in vacations.

GENEVA, April 18. -- The League of Nations Committee of Thirteen today put on formal record yesterday's informal decision that its efforts to obtain Italo-Ethiopian peace had ended in failure. A report to the Council by Salvador de Madariaga, chairman of the committee, implied Italy was responsible for this failure.

BUENOS AIRES, April 17. -- It is safe to say the South American nations have never awaited any other international conference with so much hope and enthusiastic optimism as they display in awaiting President Roosevelt's pan-American peace conference at Buenos Aires.

FOR the space of a few weeks, everybody will be at home again. The Southern trippers are back. The Summer vacationists are not yet ready to start their trekking. Easter has lifted the Lenten ban on parties. All is gay once more. Sunshine and warm days are in the offing, and it is high time to think about that ensemble or sheer suit which one will want for wear about town.

OXFORD is confronted by one of the perils of the twentieth century. This citadel of learning has become a victim of the flood of motor traffic that courses through the main highways of England and swallows everything in its path.

Merchandising methods which proved successful for refrigerator, washing machine and other major appliance producers during the depression are being utilized this year by the gas appliance industry to win a larger share of consumer home expenditures, J.F. Donovan of the gas merchandising division of Williams Saylor, Inc., merchandising counselors, said yesterday.

BARTOW, Fla., April 18. -- Sinister methods of the Ku Klux Klan raised their heads today behind prosaic arguments by the batteries of lawyers for State and defense over admissibility of evidence in the first of the Tampa flogging and murder cases to go on trial in this quiet county seat.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- Pennsylvania and Yale divided honors in an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header on Franklin Field today. The Red and Blue won the first game, 8 to 2, and the Ells took the second, 11 to 2. About 800 saw the two seven-inning contests.

In preparation for model housing and other improvements, relief workers demolished 637 old buildings covering an area of more than nineteen acres in New York from Aug. 1, 1935 to April 10, 1936, according to the Works Progress Administration.

THIS yarn of the operations of our wartime sub-chasers in the Adriatic is too slight and sketchy (and its author too credulous) to be of particular historical value, but its very informality and its restricted scope -- limited by the horizon of one man's observations -- make it interesting, and sometimes exciting, reading.

THE optimism which usually marks the attitude of producers in formulating the new season's program was dampened this week when several theatre chains insisted that they be allowed to see more than three or four samples of the 1936-37 product before signing contracts.

ROME, April 18. -- Although official reports were lacking, the best informed Rome sources said General Rodolfo Graziani, commander of Italy's southern army, had engaged the forces of Ras Nasibu in a battle on "the Harar line," but that the Italians still were a long distance from Harar itself.

In the letters reproduced in the music section of yesterday's TIMES on the subject of material for intermissions of Metropolitan Opera broadcasts the absence of one element was notable throughout -- that of the abounding gratitude which we all owe to the National Broadcasting Company for the radio presentation of these operas, and which should be the first expression from all of us in making any comment whatever about the programs.

PATRICK CARLETON'S last novel "One Breath," was a distinct advance on his earlier work. It was, also, a more finished and rounded performance than the present volume. But "Saturday to Monday" reaches out further.
The Woods twins had their birthday yesterday and, despite advance notices of girl-trouble between the 4-year-olds, the occasion passed smoothly.

In excess of $300,000,000 annually "is being lifted from consumer purses" through State and local retail sales taxes throughout the country, the National Retail Dry Goods Association reported yesterday, following a survey made by the organization.

WASHINGTON. -- As part of its program to provide more complete current business statistics, the Department of Commerce will soon increase the number of States covered by its monthly summaries of sales by independent stores. Figures are now available for Texas, Oklahoma, New Mexico, Massachusetts, Indiana, Illinois and Wisconsin. Colorado, Wyoming, Ohio, Iowa, Nebraska and Arkansas soon will be added to this list.

AS Mark Twain once said, "Everybody complains about the weather, but nobody does anything about it." The gardener soon learns that nothing can be done about it; but he also learns that by adjusting his plans in accordance with its vagaries he can do much to overcome, or at least sidestep, many of the inconveniences it is likely to cause him.

LONDON, April 11 (By mail) -- No greater safeguard has been devised against an outbreak of war, at least in Western Europe, than the formidable systems of frontier defenses constructed by France and Belgium. The great sums spent on them have been well invested.

THE masters' individual tournament, conducted last week by the American Bridge League at the Park Lane, came close to setting a record for the number of out-of-town participants. Of the thirty-six players who took part, twelve were from other cities -- six from points in Ohio, four from Philadelphia, one from Chicago and one from New Jersey.

ST. LOUIS, April 18. -- A sharp upturn in employment is noted in the Eighth Federal Reserve District and the demand for workers in certain lines exceeds the supply. It is estimated that 200 persons are being placed in permanent jobs each week in the St. Louis area.

IT'S beginning to look as though no Max Gordon production were authentic without Francis Pierlot in the cast. Starting with "The Band Wagon," a musical imbroglio to which he contributed nine separate impersonations, Pierlot has appeared under the Gordon aegis as a chauffeur in "Her Master's Voice," as a canawler in "The Farmer Takes a Wife," and as a handy man in "Ethan Frome."

Led off by the National Society, Daughters of the American Revolution, which will open its forty-fifth Continental Congress tomorrow night in the national capital with an address by President Roosevelt, a series of important assemblies of ranking organizations of women will take place during the next two weeks.

TO maintain a mood of blended fantasy and reality throughout the pages of a full-length novel is not an easy thing to accomplish While to all imaginative people the mental life is made up of just such a blend of hard fact and glittering fancy, setting it down so that it seems neither foolish nor overstrained is something rarely done.

IN a few more weeks Harvard will be holding another commencement, at the same time looking forward to the tercentenary of its creation as the first institution of higher learning in the American colonies. Marching in the academic procession for the last time as an active teacher will be a tall, straight figure with a Shavian beard, George Lyman Kittredge, A.B.M.A. and Litt. D. to the seventh power.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 18. -- America's two top-ranking tennis teams, rivals for the Davis Cup doubles assignment against Australia, met on the clay courts of the Pinehurst Country Club today and again the verdict was returned in favor of Donald Budge and Gene Mako over Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn, the national champions.

HOLLYWOOD, April 18. -- The controversy over the custody of Freddie Bartholomew, talented 12-year-old film actor, reached a new phase today when his mother, Mrs. Lilian Bartholomew, filed a court petition here for removal of Miss Myllicent Bartholomew, his aunt, as his guardian.

A DEVELOPMENT of the depression, neighborhood sales and service stations operated by automobile dealers have grown rapidly in numbers in the last three years. They constitute a challenge to the traditional Automobile Row which long has existed in every city.

MONKEY business is good. Our simian population is increasing by leaps and bounds. In the last five years tens of thousands of the little beasts have left their savage haunts in Asia, Africa and South America and have come to live in the United States.

The last of the Knickerbocker Assemblies for this season was held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The dances are arranged for debutantes of former years. The guests were received by members of the committee, headed by Mrs. Frederick W. Longfellow and including Mrs. Thatcher M. Brown, Mrs. Lansing P. Reed, Mrs. Adrian V.S. Lambert, Mrs. Lyman Delano, Mrs. F. Kingsbury Curtis, Mrs. Frederick H. Osborn and Mrs. J. Howland Auchincloss.

Here is something new in murder mysteries. When the story opens, Lucian Myrand is in Joliet prison serving a life sentence for murder. There is no question as to his guilt; his own confession and the circumstances of the killing preclude any other explanation.

A complete revision in the relationship between the American Trade Association Executives and its local organizations will be recommended at the association's semiannual convention starting in Washington on April 27. The aim of the proposed suggestions is to achieve greater cooperation and coordination between the national body and the local groups, and to create greater interest in trade associations.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Having played host to the eighteenth annual united North and South tennis tournament, Pinehurst is settling down for a week of shooting. The eighteenth annual united North and South amateur handicap has been combined this year with the North Carolina State championship, and both will be contested all week at the Pinehurst Gun Club.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The study begun by the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine what, if any, legislation it should recommend to the next Congress for Federal regulation of investment trusts gives promise of developing into one of the most important it has undertaken.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Administrative modifications in the new soil conservation program which give Secretary Wallace complete veto power over benefit payments to farmers, regardless of their "technical eligibility" for the grants, were announced today by the farm administration after a study of recommendations offered by State farm leaders.

THE storms which have whirled and whistled through the New Deal agencies during the past year have left one -- the one of which the President is probably proudest -- intact. Despite hurricanes, whether political and figurative or shockingly real, the TVA's banners still wave over the ramparts of great dams from Norris, on the Clinch, above Knoxville, to Pickwick Landing, in Southwestern Tennessee.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Bureau of Investigation, today gave an official account of the Harem kidnapping as follows:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 18. -- The most extensive debate program in the history of Rutgers University, which included a long Western tour, closed with a record of seventeen victories and seven losses in decision contests, Professor Richard C. Reager, debating coach, announced today.

PENNSYLVANIA'S Highway Department is planning an "all-weather" superhighway, extending from Harrisburg over the roadbed of the old South Penn Railroad, which cost its owners millions although there was never a rail laid.

FROM Hobe Sound, Fla., comes Philip Barry tomorrow, bearing the finished script of his new play for Jed Harris. But it is definitely not for production this Spring, though Mr. Harris had toyed with the idea of a May premiere. No title yet.

Retail trade was fairly active during most of the week in the metropolitan area. However, the comparisons of department store sales figures was with the pre-Easter week a year ago, and estimates here indicated volume ran about 20 per cent under the 1935 figures.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Colonel Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to President Roosevelt, died in his sleep at Naval Hospital tonight after an illness of more than a year. He was 65 years old.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., April 18. -- Official questioning of Miss Nellie H. Granger, heroine of the wreck of the plane Sun Racer, was broken off abruptly today when the young woman was frightened by a photographic flashlight exploding just outside her hospital room.

MR. BATES announces with exultation that he is the first who "has troubled to write a history of Congress." There was one attempt in 1893, he says, but it was so "thoroughly uncritical" as to be of no use today "even if it were available."
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 18. -- A plea for housing legislation on a nation-wide scale featured today's session of the Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians.

NORRIS HOUGHTON, who held a Guggenheim Fellowship, went to Russia to spend six months observing its theatre. Being serious about it he first learned the language -- many latter day investigators never bother -- and being honest he kept an open mind.

TO understand the attitude and state of mind of the French in the present international crisis, one must recall the last twenty years of their history. In 1918, after a long and terrible war during which, for the second time in less than fifty years, her territory was invaded, her towns destroyed, her countryside devastated, France with her allies gained a complete victory.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange touched high levels of the week yesterday, when May sold within 3 points of 11 1/2 cents, while two of the new-crop months rose above 10 1/2 cents, and the list ended with a 2 to 7-point improvement.

The destroyer Dunlap, built for the United States Navy at a cost of about $4,000,000, was launched at 5:15 P.M yesterday at the plant of the United Dry Docks, Inc., Mariners Harbor, S.I., under the sponsorship of Mrs. Robert H. Dunlap, widow of Brig. Gen. Robert H. Dunlap of the United States Marine Corps, for whom the vessel was named.

MOSCOW, April 17. -- In no field, not even in their creation of a gigantic industrial structure and a strong army, have the Bolsheviki been cleverer or more successful than in their cultivation of youth.

OMAHA, Neb., April 17. -- Taking one thing with another, Senator Borah did not do so well in the Nebraska Presidential preference primary as might have been expected of a candidate entered without formal opposition.

Mayor La Guardia started a new policy in the appointment of city magistrates yesterday, naming Gustav W.M. Wieboldt, Queens attorney, to serve out the unexpired term of the late Magistrate Guy Van Amringe of Manhattan.

LONDON, April 18. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin emerged today from his recent sphinxlike role and for the first time in several weeks gave some public indication of the way his mind is moving on the problems of British foreign policy.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 18 (AP). -- Public-spirited citizens, to the number of about 40,000, are planning to join with the Federal forces tomorrow as special police to prevent disorders when the unpopular Congress meets for the election of a new President of Venezuela.

THE resounding title of this novel is drawn from a couplet by George Santayana -- "To trust the soul's invincible surmise Was all his science and his only art." "Invincible Surmise" is the work of a new novelist from South Carolina.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- The Knox-Borah contest in the Illinois primary has resolved itself into a controversy over delegates. The Borah managers argue that under the State law their candidate is entitled to the delegates in every Congressional district where he received a preference majority.

Recording a total of 25 points, the Lawson Branch mermen of Chicago captured the team championship as the fourteenth annual International Y.M.C.A. swimming competition was completed last night in the Brooklyn Central pool.

Scores of diners were toppled from their seats and persons in adjacent amusement places and shops were shaken when an explosion of a heater rocked the Rectors Cafeteria at 1,627 Broadway, near the southwest corner of Fiftieth Street, last night, while about 100 customers were at the counters and tables.

MISS AYN RAND is the latest addition to the long list of authors who have looked at Soviet Russia through glasses of one color or another and lived to tell their stories. She is distinguishable chiefly in that she, a native Ruasian, has acquired a remarkably fluent English, and in that she has chosen to record her hatred of communism in the form of a novel.

VILLANOVA, Pa., April 18. -- St. John's of Brooklyn lost a hard-fought game to the Villanova nine today, 10 to 9. A five-run rally in the eighth gave Villanova the triumph. The Wildcats are undefeated in the college ranks.

English and French period furniture and decorations, tapestries, Oriental rugs and objects of art will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

As a needed adjunct to its land airport, the busiest in the world, Newark disclosed yesterday that a seaplane base, financed with WPA funds, was under construction adjoining the inshore channel of the Port of Newark.

STRONG representation of pilots and aviation leaders make up the new contest board of the National Aeronautic Association, made public in Washington last week by Charles F. Homer, president of the N.A.A. As chairman of the records committee is Colonel John H. (Jack) Jouett, who organized the Randolph Field of China for the Chinese National Government.

EASTPORT, Me., April 17. -- Maine is pondering today over the fate of the New Deal's $36,000,000 Passamaquoddy tidal power development, situated on its easternmost tip, at Eastport, which President Roosevelt apparently has left high and dry.

For seven innings yesterday Casey Stengel and an Ebbets Field crowd of 7,500 fans were hopeful that the Dodgers would make it two straight over the Phillies and were buoyed up by the brilliant playing of the young Brooklyn infield and a miracle catch by Randy Moore, starting his first game in right field.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 18. -- The destroyer Selfridge, one of the newest additions to the navy, glided into the Delaware River at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation yard here at 11:10 o'clock this morning while more than 6,000 persons cheered.

It is an impressive contrast that B.M. ANDERSON Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, made yesterday at New Haven between "economic planning" by government and the automatic control exercised over production by the play of prices in a free competitive market.

IN view of the vast sums of money expended weekly for relief purposes by government agencies in New York City, the question is often raised as to the place of the private welfare agencies in the relief picture. The question is peculiarly pertinent at this time, for next Tuesday the Citizens Family Welfare Committee will launch an appeal for support to carry on the work of the city's twelve private welfare agencies.

The Four Aces, defending champions in the American Bridge League's championship tournament for teams of four at the Park Lane, had the keenest competition of their careers yesterday at the start of their final-round match with Waldemar von Zedtwitz, Edward Hymes Jr., Sam Fry Jr. and M.D. Maier.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 18 (AP). -- Studies by a young Air Corps flight surgeon in the field of human reactions to high-altitude flying led today to plans for establishment here of what he described as the only physiological research laboratory of its kind in the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 18. -- The Nonpartisan League, the new organization formed by George L. Berry and other American Federation of Labor leaders to further labor's political interests and to aid in the re-election of President Roosevelt, as well as the candidacy of Mr. Roosevelt, was endorsed today by the executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, which has a membership of 120,000.

ERRED: For twenty-three years New York's publishers, booksellers, movie managers and stage producers have known the vigilant eye of John Saxton Sumner, secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice. Most emphatically Mr. Sumner does not approve of "Let's Go Naked" in shop windows.

TRADE had the high pre-Easter sales figures of last year to make comparison with last week and general results, of course, were sizable declines in most sections. Some areas reported volume as better than usual after Easter, others told of steady business but the majority noted decreases.

ATHENS, April 18. -- A prisoner named Marinos in the State prison at Synagros, near Athens, who had been sentenced to life imprisonment for murder, today alarmed the whole Greek capital for more than half a day and even caused a special meeting of the Cabinet before he was killed by a prison guard.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The five London schoolboys who died from exposure in the blizzard in the Black Forest yesterday are to be given by the Hitler Youth all the honors accorded by Britain to Ambassador Leopold yon Hoesch. Tonight their bodies lay in state in the chapel at Freiburg, watched over by a Hitler Youth guard.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa. -- Protectionists in South Africa, who have been carrying on a campaign in favor of higher duties on foreign -- chiefly American and Japanese -- goods, received a setback with the publication of the Customs Tariff Commission's report to Parliament.

The circus, with all its traditional accoutrements, added a joyous note to the dull routine of hospital life yesterday morning as the thirtieth annual "big show" of Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey was performed on the waterfront lawn at Bellevue Hospital.

BUDAPEST, April 18. -- A barbarous ceremony in the town of Oroshaza today marked a new step in the development of the recently revived Turanian pagan and racial religion. It closely resembles Erich Ludendorff's German paganism.

Registrations are coming in rapidly for the seventh annual conference of the New Jersey Committee on the Cause and Cure of War. Two sessions will be held, one on Friday and one on Saturday, in the McCarter Theatre, Princeton, on the general topic, "The Future of International Cooperation."

NO one, says the British Broadcasting Company in its new edition of "Broadcast English," can pronounce correctly all the, place names in the United Kingdom. Not even its announcers, who are sometimes called upon to speak out such puzzlers as Ulgham, Garboidisham, Hardenhuish, Hautbois, Puncknowle or Meois.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 18. -- Colgate shut out Army at baseball today in a cold-weather game, 3 to 0. It was the opening game of the cadets' season. Wright, a tall left-hander, pitched well for the up-Staters, keeping the Army's seven hits well scattered, no two of them coming in an inning.

HE'S gone. Maybe he will bob up again. For years they had him on the edge and gave him a pushing around. When he was pushed off one major league bench he quietly moved over to another and sat there as large as life in a new uniform. But the other day when they opened the gates of the Brooklyn ball park and invited everybody in, they shoved him out.

In Baltimore's Fifth Regiment Armory in 1912 the Democrats, on the forty-sixth ballot, nominated Woodrow Wilson for the Presidency. At the same time they indirectly gave Franklin D. Roosevelt a leg up on his career, for Mr. Roosevelt became Assistant Secretary of the Navy and, later, one of the heirs to the Wilson liberalism.

Robert Fechner, director of Emergency Conservation Work, announced at Washington yesterday that twenty-eight CCC camps had been established or approved to aid in waterfowl restoration projects along the four principal flyways in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Works Progress Administrator Hopkins told the House Appropriations Committee early this week that 3,853,000 heads of families or unattached persons were receiving a livelihood for themselves and their families from the Federal Government as of Feb. 29, 1936.

IN joint commemoration of the hundredth anniversary of the completion of historic Fort Macon and the formal opening of the State park which surrounds the battle-scarred fortress recently restored by government relief workers, North Carolina is planning a gala Summer celebration.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Following announcement by the Department of Justice of arrests in the kidnapping of William A. Hamm Jr., J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Bureau of Investigation, said that "there will be more arrests soon," in addition to those of Edward C. Bartholmey, Charles J. Fitzgerald and John P. (Jack) Peifer of St. Paul.

WE are not going to wait until midsummer to venture forth in big hats. Nor are we going to reserve them for "best"; we are going to set them jauntily on our heads when, in the morning, we leave home, whether it be for business or pleasure.

SO many omnibuses have appeared this year that a new one makes one question, "Why another?" For the latest addition, however -- "An Eighteenth Century Miscellany" -- edited by Louis Kronenberger (G.P. Putnam's Sons, $3), there seems adequate reason -- a reason implicit in the literature of that century.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 18. -- Ten 3-year-olds, nine of them Kentucky Derby candidates, tried their mettle in the Chesapeake Stakes today, and the lone filly of the lot, William du Pont Jr.'s Gold Seeker, won the mile and a sixteenth test in a great finish from nine colts.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- States must clear up complications and conflicts in their laws if the modern criminal is to be suppressed, Judge Richard Hartshorne of the Court of Common Pleas of Newark, N.J., told the assembly of Commissioners on Interstate Cooperation at their meeting here today.

BERLIN, April 18. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's forty-seventh birthday, it now appears, is to be celebrated with Napoleonic ceremonies Monday. A whole infantry division and a tank battalion are to parade before him. From 7 o'clock in the morning until 1 in the afternoon literally the whole central section of Berlin is to be closed to traffic and occupied by the troops, which will be summoned from their garrisons throughout the Mark of Brandenburg.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP). -- The Athletics put on a four-run rally in the ninth today, but fell a run short and lost to the Senators, 5 to 4. The Mackmen have lost all four games of the season.

Headquarters of the National Board of the Y.W.C.A. at 600 Lexington Avenue are buzzing with preparations for the fourteenth biennial convention of the association, to be held April 29 to May 5 at Colorado Springs. Mrs. Harrie R. Chamberlin of Toledo, president of the convention, and Mrs. Frederic M. Paist of Wayne, Pa., president of the National Board, are among the executives who have assisted in the preliminaries.

WITH the addition to the Palisades Interstate Park of 203 acres across the summit of Storm King Mountain, the great playground owned jointly by New York and New Jersey enters the new season crowned by a scenic vantage point unsurpassed anywhere along the entire stretch of the Hudson.

The New York Diet Kitchen Association will be the beneficiary of a luncheon, card party and Spring fashion show which has been arranged by young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons for May 5 at the formal opening of the Gardens of the Park Lane.

NEW YORK, with its miles and miles of streets, hundreds of skyscrapers, intricate underground electrical system and thousands of automobiles sputtering through the lattice-steel canyons, has been selected as the ideal proving ground for television on ultra-short radio waves.

RADIO sets of the future may be flat, not more than two or three inches thick, according to O. H. Caldwell, editor of Radio Today, who points out that compact receiver-chassis layouts are made possible by metal tubes and new space-saving loud-speakers.

BERLIN, April 18 (AP). -- A strict censorship "in the interests of safety and the State" has been imposed on star-chamber proceedings against political offenders estimated to number between twenty-five and 150.

Detective Henry P. Oswald of the New York Police Department sailed yesterday on the steamship Lafayette to question two men arrested in Paris in connection with the theft of $2,000,000 in bonds from the Bank of the Manhattan Company and the United States Trust Company about a year ago.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 18. -- Boosting his Kentucky Derby prospects, The Fighter, gallant Milky Way Farms' colt, scored a stretch drive triumph in the $15,000 added Texas Derby at Arlington Downs today before 23,000 fans.
WHEN the new Zeppelin Hindenburg crosses the Atlantic to the United States in May, American broadcasters plan to rebroadcast several programs, at least one daily, from the big airship.

SO many plants are advertised these days as "patented" that the amateur gardener wonders just what this term implies, and whether there is any advantage in purchasing a patented variety. A clearing up of some current misconceptions concerning this matter may serve a useful purpose.

Father Knickerbocker's "Sh-h-h!" uttered hereabouts in tones of paternal admonition during the last six months is soon to take on the firmer tone of legislative command. Alderman Murray Stand, an interested observer of the Mayor's anti-noise campaign, has picked out twelve among the city's most bothersome noises and drawn up a bill to abate them.

BEDFORD, N.Y., April 18. -- After a long day of running, which was enjoyed by the largest gallery of the ninth annual meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club, the judges announced late today that the white and black pointer dog John Gay had gained highest honors in the amateur shooting dog stake.

While awaiting the arrival of an elevator in which to make a leisurely escape after having robbed the Numethod Matrix and Plate Company of a $772.11 payroll, the two hold-up men scorned convention yesterday by twice revisiting the scene of their crime, a washroom outside the company offices at 460 West Thirty-fourth Street, where they had tied up four employes, one of them the payroll messenger.

SUPERINTENDENT Harold G. Campbell's call on New York City's school teachers to emphasize in the classrooms the importance of peace has focused attention on other efforts to promote international good-will through education in public and private schools.

A couple of football heroes, Andy Palau and Bill Ladroga, perfectly at home in the chill November-like air that swept over the Ram diamond yesterday, led the unbeaten Maroon to its fifth consecutive baseball victory as Fordham handed Temple a sound 7-1 defeat.

Among the thousands of visitors to the New Jersey section of the Palisades Interstate Park at this time of year are hundreds of boat owners and boat-minded persons who are convinced that at last Spring is here. The boat owners are busy reconditioning their craft which have been stored on shore for the Winter, renewing friendships of last season and making plans for the coming one.

Within the next few weeks scores of the large steel yachts which have been cruising in southern waters during the Winter will return to the metropolitan area. The first of the larger craft to arrive here was Julius Fleischmann's 225-foot yacht Camargo, which slipped into the Tebo Basin of the Todd Shipyards Corporation in Brooklyn recently for a refitting preparatory to a northern cruise.

In the final figure skating event of the season at the Ice Club yesterday, Miss Katherine Durbrow and Roland Janson, both of the Skating Club of New York, emerged as the new Middle Atlantic champions. For the first time the event was open to entrants from New Haven and Philadelphia, and the result was a larger and more keenly contested competition than ever before.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Two men and a woman were being questioned by police tonight in an effort to solve the mystery of the killing of Arthur J. Hewitt, 59, prosperous resident of Wheaton, a suburb, who recently resigned as head of the Midwestern Company, an engineering firm.

With the eagerly sought elimination of the processing tax having proved a boomerang in the last three months, the cotton textile industry must undertake immediate curtailment, if a general breakdown of prices is to be prevented, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by selling agents and distributors.
ST. PAUL, April 18. -- The disclosure by the Department of Justice today that the Hamm kidnappers were members of the Alvin Karpis gang, was the first definite identification of the abductors.
The movement to establish a Federal Department of Education with Cabinet portfolio has met strong opposition from Catholic educators. It has many proponents, however, among other groups.

BERLIN, April 18. -- German Wehrwirtschaft, or military economy, which began to dominate German life and business when the National Socialist regime came into power, is apparently determined to steer a middle course between "the international principle of individualism'' and Premier Benito Mussolini's nationalization of Italy's key industries.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., April 18. -- False fire alarms, incendiary blazes which start mysteriously near the full of the moon and the order of a determined police judge all had a bearing here tonight on whether a fire engine would be polished.

EXHIBITION of American etchings in the dear dead days, which on a few counts are quite blessedly beyond recall, almost invariably brought to the searching-and-not-finding mind the pleasant Gallic phrase to the effect that the more things change, the more they are the same thing.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18. -- New York came back into the rowing picture this evening when a crew that carried the pale blue of Columbia defeated the Navy in the varsity race of the regatta on the Severn by a little more than a length.

GLASGOW, April 18 (Canadian Press). -- Winners of the Scottish Football Cup for the third successive season, the Glasgow Rangers celebrated the equalling of a record that has stood for more than a half-century. When the colorful Light Blues triumphed, 1 -- 0, over Third Lanark at Hampden Park today they joined Queen's Park and the Old Vale of Leven Club who accomplished the feat in the early days of the competition.

COLLECTORS of antiques are always athirst for knowledge, though often they build up their store of information by gathering bits of miscellany rather than by systematic searching in libraries and historical records.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 18. -- Launching the 1936 horse show campaign in Westchestsr County, Mrs. Gordon Wright's bay gelding, Sonny, won the jumping championship at the Saxon Woods Hunt Club today. The rosette was awarded on the basis of points scored throughout the competition and Sonny, with a total of eleven, gained the top honors.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Painted against a background of the coming political conventions and campaign, the Spring dinner of the Gridiron Club was held tonight with President Roosevelt, Vice President Garner, Chief Justice Hughes and four other members of the Supreme Court, members of the Cabinet, Congress and the diplomatic corps among the more than 500 present.

The course of least resistance in a typically dull week-end session in the bond market yesterday was toward moderately lower prices. Influenced by a renewed decline in stocks, the convertible and more speculative industrial loans were the most vulnerable to pressure and several substantial declines were recorded.

BOTH Republicans and Democrats may do well to turn their eyes to Harrisburg, Pa., next week-end. There for three days, from April 24 to 26, students from thirty-four colleges will hold a "model political convention" and demonstrate the making of a presumably ideal party platform.
Savage broke into the winning column for the first time this season by conquering the Brooklyn College nine, 6 -- 2, at the Manhattan Beach diamond yesterday.

In connection with the much-discussed intermission interviews during the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts, I wish to say that I feel very grateful for these broadcasts, not being one of the fortunate persons living in New York City or vicinity who have the opportunity to attend the opera, and to see and hear the artists in person.

TWO good reasons exist for air traffic control -- to avoid collision in the air; to improve reliability of service by enabling operation of aircraft in bad weather. Control of aircraft at terminals may be likened to control of trains, boats or buses at their terminals, except for one very aggravating feature -- an airplane cannot remain stationary when it is necessary to do so, and in this respect it differs from all other conveyances.

THE relations between architect and client, with emphasis on the client's responsibilities in making his choice and then not interfering in the carrying out of the architectural work proper, form the subject of a paper translated from the German of Walter Kurt Behrendt in the April issue of The American Magazine of Art.

An admirable book, for it not only includes necessary rules and practical information for keeping an aquarium but successfully demonstrates that a hobby pursued intelligently brings far more satisfaction than one that is carried on carelessly and with intermittent interest.

TOMORROW marks the seventy-fifth anniversary of one of the dramatic episodes in aeronautical history. It demonstrated the existence and effects of air currents at high altitudes and led the aeronaut, Professor Thaddeus S.C. Lowe, after a startling flight, to pursue scientific investigations the results of which are now being realized in national and transoceanic aerial navigation.

Yielding only five hits and striking out thirteen in his first varsity start, Ray Volpi pitched Manhattan's baseball team to an 8-to-1 victory over the Seton Hall College nine of South Orange, N.J., at Manhattan Field yesterday. It was the third straight triumph for the undefeated Jaspers.

Thoroughbreds carrying the colors of The Jockey Club members, John Hay Whitney and Marshall Field, won the principal races before 15,000 persons at Jamaica yesterday, Court Scandal and Tintagel being the respective victors. The former is expected to cut some figure in the 2-year-old ranks following a decisive four-length victory in the $4,700 Youthful Stakes, which was the scheduled feature.

A glance at the cast of characters in the front of this book may possibly give the reader the impression that there are too many Higleys in the story. But that has been attended to; there are not so many when the story ends. One of them has already been eliminated when Inspector Schmidt arrives on the scene accompanied by his ghost writer, George Bagby.

ABOUT the importance of these books there can be no question. In London and Moscow we may be very sure that every word will be scrutinized. For mankind as a whole the significance is no less obvious. Facts, figures, quotations, opinions, forecasts -- pertinent and up to date -are mobilized around an issue of increasing urgency.

Social, literary and dramatic circles are cooperating in plans for the Mark Twain Memorial Ball to be held on May 5 at the Ritz-Carlton. The event is to be given under the auspices of the Mark Twain Memorial Association, which was formed for the purpose of erecting a national monument to the memory of the famous author.

GENEVA, April 17. -- Of all the weak points in the League of Nations there seem to be three to which most attention has been called here by its present difficulties. These concern its membership, its machinery for reaching agreement and the combination of these which allows a nation to fill simultaneously the roles of condemned lawbreaker in one case and judge and Sheriff in another.

PASADENA, April 18 (AP). -- A tiny instrument, weighing less than a pound, which will automatically radio the temperature, humidity and barometric pressure at altitudes to 90,000 feet, is shown at the California Institute of Technology's "open house."
Plans for a city welcome to Lincoln Ellsworth's ship Wyatt Earp on her return from Antarctica this morning have been completed by a committee named by Mayor La Guardia to head the reception.

THE many faceted Mr. Dexter Fellows, who has devoted many, many years and considerable hyperbole to keeping alive the spirit of Phineas Taylor Barnum, sat down sharply on one of Colonel Timothy John Fitzgerald McCoy's ten-gallon hats at Madison Square Garden the other day and expelled his cigar butt and an explosive "Faugh!" through the well-gnawed whisps of his walrus mustache.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP). -- Twenty-seven students of physical education from all sections of the nation will go to Berlin next Summer as guests of the German Government at the Olympics.
I wish I could beat a big bass drum to emphasize my approval of your article last Sunday on the Metropolitan broadcasts.

PARIS. THE vogue for suits for every type of occasion has given an enormous importance to blouses. From morn to midnight they play a premier role in composing the Smart-style picture. Boyish shirts, pre-war shirtwaists, ruffled babyish blouses, jacket-blouses, peasant smocks buttoned in back and tunics, all make a veritable wardrobe of a single tailleur, and set the tone of the whole ensemble.

A resolution pledging "approval and active support" of the newly formed National Association for Art Education was unanimously passed yesterday morning by nearly 1,400 delegates at the closing session of the twenty-seventh annual four-day convention of the Eastern Arts Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

OUR VOICES: New Yorkers who must make themselves understood in noisy places frequently develop strident tones which may be described technically as "the subway voice." Professor Jane Dorsey Zimmerman, who teaches speech at Teachers College, Columbia University, discussed the matter last week at the Eastern Public Speaking Conference, held in this city.

SEATTLE, April 18. -- Riding in the tail of a stiff southerly wind, the University of Washington rowing fleet scored a smashing, triple triumph over the Bears of California today, breaking the Lake Washington course record in each race.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed formation of Edward J. Duffy Co., by Edward J. Duffy, Alfred Poole Duffy, Michael J. Donovan, Lawrence J. Clarke, Edward W. Rejaunier and George R. Swift.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- If no formidable opposition develops during hearings to be held this week on the Wagner-Ellenbogen Housing Bill, now pending in both houses of Congress, the Federal Government is due to tackle the housing problem in a new way.

The ever-colorful and fast-moving panorama of the Penn Relays will be unfolded on Franklin Field's new cinder-path this week-end when approximately 3,000 athletes from 500 schools and colleges match strides on Friday and Saturday. As a show the Penn Relays have few, if any, equals.

A FEW days are still left of Book Sharing Week, April 16 to 23, during which the Book Sharing Week Committee hopes to secure 1,000,000 books for distribution to hospitals, institutions and charitable organizations of Greater New York.

The share market plodded through another uninteresting week. Business developments were favorable enough, notably in the steel, automotive and construction industries, but in general the news of the week failed to produce anything that could be counted on to give prices a fresh start.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 18. -- Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank of New York, declared today that causes of the "greatest evils of the present national and world disorder are to be found in the interferences by governments with markets."

ALTHOUGH the current drama season has been one of the finest in years, it has discovered very little new talent. It represents the gradual perfecting of talents with which we have been familiar for some time. The present is excellent.

PROVIDENCE, April 18. -- Brown's baseball team repulsed Amherst today, 12 to 3. Epple was batted out of the box after Brown had found him for seven hits, which, combined with poor support, netted 10 runs.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 18. -- International relations and peace were discussed tonight in the University of Chattanooga's chapel by Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, and Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State. The addresses were at the university's semi-centennial celebration.

NO event in the art galleries this week could hope to rival in barbaric splendor the transmogrification of "Macbeth" by members of the Negro Theatre (a PWA project), which excited the populace and gathered in its bouquets of footlight flowers up in Harlem last Tuesday night.

With the return of three members of the American Wolfe-Noel squash racquets team last week, the oft-discussed question of the differences between the English and American-type of game cropped up again in connection with our loss of the trophy.

Members of the Todhunter School Alumnae Association, of which Miss Katherine Holmes is president, have arranged a card party and fashion show for next Friday at Sherry's to raise funds for the Puerto Rican branch of the New York Kindergarten Association.

This week has been designated as "Seamen's Book Week" by the American Merchant Marine Library Association, which opens its fifteenth annual book drive tomorrow to replenish the libraries of seamen on American commercial and government ships and the keepers in lighthouses.

RAYMOND MASSEY, found in his dressing room at the National Theatre, should have been bubbling over with inside stuff on the filming of "Things to Come," the H.G. Wells antiwar, civilization of the future, wings over the universe film spectacle.

CANTON, N.Y., April 18 (AP). -- Austin MacCormick, New York City Commissioner of Correction, told 700 St. Lawrence University students today that "we can control crime not only by armed force, hut by social forces."

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- A nation-wide vote of confidence in the leaders of their movement, a vote inspired and directed by national headquarters of Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., is being taken among the Townsend clubs.
Wigs and Cues, the dramatic association of Barnard College, presented four original one-act plays last night at Brinckerhoff Theatre at Barnard.

With the added information that paint, rather than mud or dirt, caused the stains found on the bed cover in the apartment at 22 Beekman Place, where Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton was slain April 10, detectives continued yesterday in their efforts to track down the murderer.

SPRING, somnolent Spring, appears to have had the opposite effect on the Broadway screen. Casting off the sluggishness and banality which, with minor exceptions, characterized it in recent weeks, the Times Square midway has begun to twinkle again.

The Bearns prizes for original music, awarded annually by Columbia University in a nation-wide competition, were announced yesterday. Three prizes were given this year, one more than usual, because the 1935 jury made no awards, holding that none of the entries was of sufficient merit.

KALIMPONG, India, March 24 (By Air Mail to London). -- As our advance party gets under way, I have looked into our expedition store book for the nth time to satisfy myself that nothing has been forgotten or mislaid. And I was amazed, also for the nth time, by the multiplicity of things which a party bound for Mount Everest seems to require.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Bayfront Park, on the shores of Biscayne Bay, which last week was the scene of events in celebration of the Dade County centennial and the observance of Pan-American Day, has been selected as the locale of the fortieth triennial conclave of the grand encampment, Knights Templar, to be held during the week of July 17, 1937.

BOSTON, April 18. -- Not even the sun came out to help the cause of the Bees today and as this made it slightly more disagreeable than it was for yesterday's National League inaugural in the Hub, the management of the Boston club lost little time making a swift survey of the weather and calling off the second game of the series with the Giants.

Terminal cities are divided in their views on the proposal to amend the Interstate Commerce Act by revising its fourth section, a survey by the Conference on Port Development of New York reveals. The proposal is the principal feature of the Pettengill bill, which is before Congress.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 18. -- Dr. Francis G. Benedict, director of the Carnegie Nutrition Laboratory at Washington, has discovered that when elephants lie down their heart beats are some nine counts higher than when they stand up. All other animals and human beings have higher heart rates when standing.
The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

The New Year Book and Racing Rules of the American Power Boat Association, indispensable to all regatta officials and yacht-club committees, has this year been expanded to 354 pages. It was put in circulation last week from the A.P.B.A. headquarters, at 424 Madison Avenue, where President George W. Sutton Jr. and Executive Secretary William Edgar John have their offices.

BUFFALO, April 18. -- With the control of the State organization definitely in the hands of the left wing as the result of its victory at last night's meeting of the new State committee, delegates representing the Norman Thomas faction held a convention here today at which they perfected their party machinery preparatory to the official recognition of the left wing as the Socialist party of the State by the National Executive Committee.

According to the few observations given out during the past week by Representative Samuel B. Hill of Washington, chairman of the taxation subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, with reference to the forthcoming "Revenue Bill of 1936," there appears to have been no major change in the proposed plan to tax the undistributed earnings of corporations.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

RAYMOND MASSEY, found in his dressing room at the National Theatre, should have been bubbling over with inside stuff on the filming of "Things to Come," the H.G. Wells antiwar, civilization of the future, wings over the universe film spectacle.

CANTON, N.Y., April 18 (AP). -- Austin MacCormick, New York City Commissioner of Correction, told 700 St. Lawrence University students today that "we can control crime not only by armed force, hut by social forces."

IN his book on Shakespeare Mr. Middleton Murry returns to his best field -- literary criticism, after some curious excursions into the Life of Jesus, the Necessity of Communism, the biographical interpretation of D.H. Lawrence, and the like.

Two hundred social workers and members of organizations keenly interested in the Minimum Wage Law for Women have scheduled a luncheon conference at the Hotel Commodore for tomorrow, just a week and a day before the United States Supreme Court is to review the verdict of the Court of Appeals which quashed the legislation in New York State.

A large committee of young matrons and debutantes of this season and former years has been appointed to serve as a junior committee for the three-day Spring Flower Festival marking the opening of the Gardens of the Nations in Rockefeller Center on April 27, 28 and 29.
DANBURY, Conn., April 18. -- Teachers in the public schools of Danbury are spending their week's vacation without their pay check for the current month.

When Dr. Samuel Guy Inman speaks as an expert upon conditions in the Latin-American republics -- as with ample warrant and experience he is entitled to do -- his utterances merit serious and respectful consideration, at least as expressions of opinion that are not lightly or baselessly thrown off.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Until a fortnight ago the AAA was one New Deal agency that had an almost perfect record for beating the opposition at its own game. With the aid of a highly developed public relations department it had successfully weathered every challenge.

Rapt concentration prevails within the whitewashed walls of three narrow, unpretentious rooms on the top floor of the old Brooklyn police headquarters at 72 Poplar Street. Here, for a year, the police and science have been working together to detect perpetrators of crime.

After a ten-day visit to this country during which he saw "most everything worth seeing" and talked with leading citizens of New York and Washington, including President Roosevelt, Bernard Main de Bossiere, 15-year-old Boy Scout from France, sailed for Paris yesterday on the French liner Lafayette.
The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

The New Year Book and Racing Rules of the American Power Boat Association, indispensable to all regatta officials and yacht-club committees, has this year been expanded to 354 pages. It was put in circulation last week from the A.P.B.A. headquarters, at 424 Madison Avenue, where President George W. Sutton Jr. and Executive Secretary William Edgar John have their offices.

BUFFALO, April 18. -- With the control of the State organization definitely in the hands of the left wing as the result of its victory at last night's meeting of the new State committee, delegates representing the Norman Thomas faction held a convention here today at which they perfected their party machinery preparatory to the official recognition of the left wing as the Socialist party of the State by the National Executive Committee.

According to the few observations given out during the past week by Representative Samuel B. Hill of Washington, chairman of the taxation subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, with reference to the forthcoming "Revenue Bill of 1936," there appears to have been no major change in the proposed plan to tax the undistributed earnings of corporations.

ALBANY, April 18. -- The truth of the old saying that hard times make high taxes is being brought home this year to taxpayers of all categories and in all sections of the State; particularly it was brought home this week to the payers of personal income tax who last Wednesday deposited with the State Tax Commission, either in whole or in part, the tax assessed against them on their 1935 incomes.
DENVER, April 18 (AP). -- Governor Johnson declared martial law today in a strip 316 miles long and a mile wide along the southern border of the State to keep out aliens and indigents.

Appearing as a member of the working press as well as in her official capacity, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be guest of honor on Friday night at the fourteenth annual Front Page Ball of the Newspaper Women's Club at the Hotel Astor.

The recent presentation of a picture portraying the discovery of America by Leif Ericsson to Congress by a Norwegian delegation seems to have aroused misgivings among your readers. Letters from two of them have appeared in THE TIMES in which the writers have characterized the achievement of the Norsemen as legend, setting forth the claims of other discoverers, both before and after Leif sailed to the "western land" in the year 1000.

There was pouring rain in Geneva Thursday evening, but in spite of it Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, took a walk in Mon Repos Park, which stands at the end of the Quai Woodrow Wilson and looks forth upon the lake. Mr. Eden appeared worried; he had reason.

THOUGH it must be seven years since The Mystery of the Missing Brandenburg Concertos kept this department busy, the memory of it still rankles. It started when letters, circulars and advertising in European periodicals pointed to the early release by the Decca Company of all six concertos recorded by a body of eminent artists, hand picked and rehearsed within an inch of their lives.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Cold weather and the passing of the Easter shopping season brought a sharp decline in retail trade during the week. With the exception of an outlying group featuring a heavily advertised special sale, sales averages were from 5 to 10 per cent below last year with the larger department stores.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18. -- Joe Patterson, Navy captain, left the hospital this morning to take firsts in two events against Princeton and help the Middie track team win its opening meet, 67 to 59. Jack Dalton, son of Navy's famous football back of a generation ago, led the way in both dashes.
When Franklin D. Roosevelt made his first public utterance as President-elect, just after the returns showed that he had been elected by an overwhelming majority, he declared:

THE calm resourcefulness displayed recently by Miss Nellie Granger, Transcontinental and Western Air Line hostess, when she rescued two survivors from the wreckage of her plane on a mountain top near Uniontown, Pa., and then made her way down the mountainside to report the accident and summon aid, serves to emphasize a new profession for women which has sprung up with the growth of aviation.

PITTSBURGH, April 18. -- Mayor William N. McNair went to jail today because he refused to obey an order by Judge Frank Pierkarski directing him to repay to Samuel Collinger a $100 numbers fine imposed by Magistrate Turets.
George Selkirk struck one solitary blow in the Yankees' behalf yesterday at the Stadium, but it carried solid significance.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended April 15, which included five business days in some of the reporting cities, aggregated $8,404,000,000. The total reported is approximately the same as was reported for the preceding week and 6 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

More than 500 of the leading newspaper publishers, editors and business managers of the United States and Canada will gather in New York this week for the annual meeting of The Associated Press and the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
VATICAN CITY, April 18 (AP). -- Pope Pius today gave the first indication that he felt himself approaching the end of his span of life.

BERLIN, April 17. -- While the Nile, one of the oldest of mankind's battlegrounds, has again become a center of world politics, all is quiet along the Rhine, one of Europe's oldest battlegrounds. Moreover, it is likely to remain quiet as long as Great Britain has not made up her mind whether to choose France or Germany as her sword-bearer on the Continent to check the latest challenger to her world rule, Fascist Italy.

Those who discussed recently in Congress and the press the army and navy appropriations often referred to the need for a national defense policy -- some standard to measure the demands of the navy and army authorities. The sums being considered for the two arms total more than $1,000,000,000.

Mrs. Anson McCleverty of England, who will exhibit one of the finest collections of air-mail stamps in the coming New York international philatelic exhibition opening in the Grand Central Palace May 9, arrived in the city last week with her husband, Colonel McCleverty.

First editions and autograph letters and manuscripts by famous modern authors, including the Rudyard Kipling collection formed by the late Arthur H. Scribner of this city, together with an assemblage of books illustrated by Arthur Backham and a few original drawings collected by the late Isabel Whitney Sage, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries Wednesday evening and Thursday afternoon and evening.

AS THE voyager sails into the panoramic harbor of San Juan, Puerto Rico, it is the Luquillo Mountains, looming up to the south, that make the greatest appeal to the imagination. Long inaccessible, the scenes of wild beauty in these heights now may be viewed by the tourist over highways built by the CCC.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, April 18 (AP). -- The Paraguayan Government made public tonight a decree whereby it will rigidly supervise production and prices of foodstuffs and other articles of basic necessity. The decree also authorizes nationalization of industries that make the products directly affecting the necessities of the people.

VIENNA, April 18. -- A strongly worded answer has been given by the Chief Rabbi of Vienna, Dr Feuchtwang, to recent anti-Semitic attacks. The Jews, he said, were in the situation they had been centuries before on the banks of the Red Sea when they had an enemy behind them and the waves ahead.

THIS very interesting and very subjective book leaves no doubt that Charlotte Wilder has the sensibility of a poet. The collection contains two lyrics in strict form. All of the other poems are in a form comparable only to that used by Marianne Moore, a kind of heightened prose with certain of the effects of verse.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 18. -- A critical drought situation is developing in a widening area of the Southwest. This has resulted in another advance in wheat prices, but obviously had a depressing influence on general trade conditions. One big department store, through special sales efforts, held close to the pre-Easter volume, but the general average of retail trade was off 15 per cent from last week and 10 per cent below a year ago.

NOW that trees and shrubs are opening their leaf buds and perennials and bulbs are sending up shoots, gardeners give way to the urge to stir up the soil and begin to get their garden equipment ready. There are this Spring some improved gadgets designed to make gardening a more comfortable occupation for women.
LONDON, April 17. -- The openings for next week -- always subject to last-minute changes -- are these:

WASHINGTON. -- With the addition of Connecticut to the list, thirty-nine States are now practically free from bovine tuberculosis, one of the great scourges of the cattle industry. Tuberculosis eradication work began in Connecticut more than twenty-five years ago, and since 1918 has been carried on with the active cooperation of the Federal Government.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18. -- Many persons do not know that the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is a co-educational institution. Yet when Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the institute, hands out Technology's degrees seven weeks hence he will give a substantial number of them to young women.
Permit me to congrulate you upon your recent article criticizing the preposterous interviews featured during the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts.
LONDON, April 17. -- Every mile of the Italian Army's advance toward Addis Ababa this week has brought Britain closer to an awkward and possibly dangerous turning point in her foreign policy.

LONDON, April 18. -- Throwing a huge wash that broke in twelve-foot waves on the Isle of Arran a mile away, the new liner Queen Mary successfully carried out her speed trials today off the Scottish coast.
GOUROCK, Scotland, April 18 (AP). -- The new British liner Queen Mary established an official speed of 30.4 knots in speed trials off the Isle of Arran today.

FOR forty-odd years those substantial red buckram records of American auctions have been issuing from the press at regular annual intervals. They review the big parade of books, books, books, moving up and down again, and as the sole index to price fluctuations they offer invaluable aid to collectors.

There may have been difficulties in applying the Stakhanoff method to get more coal, textiles or automobiles, but in one respect Soviet production is now increasing at a pace which Germany and Italy undoubtedly watch with envy. Within the last twelve months, four millions have been added to the population.

MOSCOW, April 18. -- The prospect that Soviet railways, one of the essential enterprises the State has been supporting by subsidies, will soon be able to pay their own way was held out yesterday after the closing meeting of a conference of leading railway workers at the Kremlin under the presidency of Lazar M. Kaganovitch, Commissar for, Railroad Transportation.

THERE can hardly be another activity now being carried on in this country for the furtherance of international peace that holds such potentialities of beneficent influence as does this series of little "World Affairs Book," of which this booklet by Mr. Duggan is the fifteenth number.

PARIS, April 17. -- The warning that France may come to consider leaving the League of Nations is being given repeatedly in the French press these days and was strongly hinted at as even more than a possibility by Premier Albert Sarraut in a public speech in Paris last Wednesday.

SOMETHING is happening to one of San Francisco's seven hills -- the one below which millions of world travelers have boarded or left their ships. Glaring modernity is breaking out over the rugged perch in a rash of boldly jutting apartment houses, reared from the tilting ground that once supported a genial hodgepodge of Bohemian architecture.

TOKYO, April 18. -- A member of the Japanese Parliament sitting next to a Russian at dinner a few nights ago said the Japanese feared that Russia might attack now while her forces were superior and Japan's defense program was uncompleted. The Russian answered that the Soviet's military power would be still greater a few years hence.

A plea for cleaner and more attractive cities, with the suggestion that civic pride is a valuable asset, was made by J.C. Nichols, vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards to the delegates from the South Central States attending the recent regional convention in Tulsa, Oklahoma.

Diplomatic sallies alternate with reconnoitering raids on the Mongolian-Manchukuoan-Siberian borders, but both are designed to the same purpose. Each side is jockeying for position. The weapons of alliances and treaties have for the moment supplanted cavalry, machine-guns and airplanes, but the unofficial struggle goes on nevertheless.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The succession of nearly perfect days, promising to continue indefinitely after an unusually cold Winter, is serving to hold many colonists here long after villas and hotels customarily close.

SPRING'S sunny days bring the housewife out, basket on arm, to do the family marketing in person. The season's vegetables and fruits are in the stalls. Some of them are sun-ripened, fresh and succulent -- their very appearance is inviting; others are wilted, obviously not of the first class.

The Engineers Public Service Company announced yesterday that it had given notice of intention to exercise on April 28 its option to buy 92,119 shares of common stock of the El Paso Natural Gas Company at $25 a share.

The Foreign Commerce Club of New York announced yesterday the election of Charles E. Dougherty as president, succeeding Thomas F. Baker, who held the office two years. Mr. Dougherty is vice president of the Carter Weekes Stevedoring Company and has been active in the affairs of the club for ten years.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 17. -- Changes affecting more than forty of 120 courses in the Williams College curriculum are revealed by an administrative bulletin. Fourteen courses not offered this term are announced for next year, while more than fifteen others have been so drastically changed in content that they may be considered new.

PARK lakes in the city's five boroughs will be dotted next Saturday and Sunday with the sails of a vast fleet of miniature racing yachts. The trim craft will be "sailed" from the shore by boys and girls all under 16 years of age in the preliminaries to the twelfth annual model boat races for the championship of the city, which will be held May 9 on Conservatory. Lake in Central Park.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18. -- The Grace liner Santa Rosa arrived Tuesday with the largest passenger list it has carried to open the Summer tourist season in the three years since the line established the service.
NEWARK, April 18. -- The Newark Bears defeated Toronto, 3 to 2, in eleven innings today to gain a 2-to-1 verdict in the first series of the season.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Driving Lon Warneke from the mound with a three-run rally in the eighth, Cincinnati edged out the Cubs, 5 -- 4, before 5,000 shivering fans today. It was the Reds' second victory in a row over the league champions.

Evander Childs High School, winner of the Public Schools Athletic League indoor track and field championship last month when it captured the mantle worn by New Utrecht for ten years, opened its outdoor campaign yesterday with an impressive victory against fifty-three high and prep schools in the twenty-eighth New York University interscholastic meet at Ohio Field.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Electrical manufacturers and contractors should benefit largely from sales of equipment to beneficiaries of the government's rural electrification program, Morris L. Cook, Rural Electrification Administrator, has assured the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

The pamphlet report of the United Gas Corporation for 1935, issued for today, says that subsidiaries have extensive holdings in the Rodessa Field, in Caddo Parish, La., and in Cass County, Texas, which promises to be a major oil reserve, and are busy developing them.

At the very time when the United States has as much to gain as any other country from the strengthening of the International Labor Organization, which it entered less than two years ago, the House of Representatives Appropriations Committee recommends that Congress consider our country's withdrawal.
The Rev. Randolph Ray conducted the services yesterday at the Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street, marking his thirteenth anniversary as rector of the church.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- If the luck of the draw means anything, the track teams from North Texas Teachers, Maryland and Manhattan can be congratulating themselves tonight on the spots they have picked for the University of Pennsylvania relay carnival next week-end.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The American Liberty League is a "nonpartisan organization founded to defend the Constitution and defend the rights and liberties guaranteed by that Constitution," a statement approved by the league's executive committee declared today.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 19. -- Contrary to the feeling of indignation that a snatch-thief generally arouses, Princeton esthetes were genuinely relieved today when it was revealed that one of the canvases included in an exhibition of abstract painting by modern American and European artists had been stolen from the gallery of the Antioch Court in McCormick Hall.

TEL AVIV, April 19. -- After several days of tension serious Arab attacks on Jews occurred in the Tel Aviv-Jaffa district this morning, resulting in the deaths of nine Jews and two Arabs, and the wounding of fifty, including about ten Arabs and several Britons.

Foreign exchanges idled through a listless week so far as business and rate fluctuations were concerned. For a pattern it followed closely that of the preceding fortnight of routine requirements at almost stable prices. The nominal character of the market was ascribed to the lessening of the tension surrounding the Rhineland incident, although at the week's close there was fresh apprehension over the Italo-Ethiopian affair.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which launches its campaign for a minimum of $1,500,000 for the support of private family welfare agencies tomorrow afternoon at a meeting at Town Hall, has added twenty-two prominent business and professional men and fifty women, prominent socially and in civic affairs, to its divisional groups, it was announced yesterday by Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the committee.
That housing properties continue to prove attractive to investors was demonstrated again over the week-end when sales of various flats in Manhattan and the Bronx were announced.
PARIS, April 19. -- French officials charged tonight that Germany was secretly constructing a naval base on a Portuguese island off the west coast of Africa.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- Cash interests which have sold May oats as a hedge are said to be transferring supplies from private to public elevators with expectations of delivering the grain on May sales. Crop reports are regarded as generally favorable and the cash demand is only fair.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The markets here were not affected by the international uncertainty this week, for, although the advance of stocks ceased, the declines did not exceed a profit-taking reaction, which was to be expected after five weeks of bull trading.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 19. -- Champion St. Margaret Magnificent of Clairedale, the Sealyham terrier owned by the Clairedale Kennels of Riverhead, L.I., and handled by Leonard Brumby of Hicksville, was named the best in show at the close of the first annual exhibition of the Mahoning-Shenango Kennel Club tonight.
PITTSBURGH, April 19 (AP). -- The Cardinals bunched their hits opportunely today to defeat Pittsburgh, 7 -- 3, and spoil the twice-postponed home opening game for approximately 17,500 Pirate fans.

Sweatshop labor, including child labor, is responsible for the grave conditions of competition offered by certain Southern States with Northern industrial States, the National Child Labor Committee reported yesterday in citing the widespread use of child labor as "a compelling argument for the ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment."

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox, with their galaxy of former Mackmen and with Pitcher Wes Ferrell at top form, beat the Athletics in a hurlers' struggle, 2 to 1, today. The defeat was the fifth straight for Philadelphia, which has yet to break into the victory column.

Presidents and chancellors of several colleges and universities in this country were on record yesterday deploring a decree promulgated in Germany shortly after Easter excluding Jewish children from German public schools.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 19. -- Monkeys were perched on the rails and rigging, decks were laden with cages of tropical birds, animals and reptiles, while specially constructed watertanks were crowded with hundreds of specimens of rare fish when Vincent Astor's yacht Nourmahal dropped anchor at St. George's Harbor at 7:30 A.M. today.
