MOSCOW, April 19. -- In view of the present strained relations between Germany and the Soviet Union, foreign diplomats here are waiting with considerable interest to see whether either State will denounce the Treaty of Berlin, signed when they were extremely friendly, or allow it to continue in force. Only six days are left in which to decide.

The four-story apartment house at 245 Sullivan Place, Brooklyn, was sold by Shure Kaplan, operators, to Shirley R. Irgang and Doris Siegel. There are forty suites in the building, which was sold for cash over a $90,000 first mortgage and a $6,000 purchase money mortgage. Philip L. Dworetz, attorney, represented the sellers.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP). -- The Cubs, led by Chuck Klein, who rifled his second and third home runs of the season into the right-field bleachers, did a thorough job of salvaging the final game from Cincinnati today, pounding three Red pitchers for sixteen hits and a 16 -- 6 victory.

A further report on the Townsend plan was made public yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund. The report, it was said, was based on "careful and sympathetic consideration of the specific claims for the plan, recognizing it as a matter of national importance that the founder and several millions of well-organized members sincerely believe it would be possible to pay monthly pensions of $200 to citizens over 60 years of age."

BOSTON, April 19. -- With Hal Schumacher turning in a high grade piece of pitching which, in fact, threatened for quite a spell to string out into the season's first no-hitter, the Giants gave the Bees a final polishing off today and scurried back to New York eminently satisfied with affairs as far as they have gone.
ADDIS ABABA, April 19. -- Jijiga, former Ethiopian headquarters on the southern front, is reported to have fallen and there are also unconfirmed rumors that Harar has been taken.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- A summary of reports submitted by officers, directors and the principal stockholders covering their transactions and activities in securities in February and earlier months was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

THE world is still too much with us, it seems, and of doctors and saints to say so there is no lack. Today in Times Square, unless tradition fails, an apathetic noon-hour crowd will gather about an earnest sidewalk speaker, while on the pavement itself, scrawled in blue chalk, will run the day's written exhortation. Repent, repent! By evening the speaker and his audience will have disappeared, and the very chalk-marks will have vanished.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 19. -- A theory that religious education is the only defense against governmental systems such as communism and fascism, which deny liberty and dignity of the individual, was advanced at the University of Chattanooga today by three men representing the Jewish, Protestant and Catholic faiths.

The Daniel Guggenheim memorial concerts by the Goldman Band, under the direction of Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, which will be again the gift of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, will begin Wednesday, June 17, and end Sunday, Aug. 16.

The gradual upward movement in cotton futures that has been under way since the first of March continued last week on the New York Cotton Exchange. Although the rise in the last six weeks has met with some interruptions, it has been persistent and substantial.

A 16-year-old youth, arrested after detectives had traced, a bowling pin with which a middle-aged storekeeper had been bludgeoned to death in Brooklyn holdup, confessed to the crime yesterday, according to the police, and was help on a charge of homicide.

Evans Ward of Port Chester has been asked to become treasurer of the Republican State Committee to fill the place left vacant by the refusal of Henry Root Stern to accept re-election, it was learned yesterday, Mr. Ward, a son of the late William L. Ward, for many years the party leader in Westchester County, is considering the matter.
DENVER, April 19. -- National Guardsmen moved southward tonight to enforce Governor Johnson's martial law order to turn back all indigent laborers and aliens entering Colorado along a 360-mile strip.

It is doubtful if American political history could furnish an exact parallel to the relation which existed between President ROOSEVELT and his chief private secretary, Colonel LOUIS HOWE, who died on Saturday. Other Presidents have had their familiars and advisers.

The National Federation of Textiles, Inc., trade association for the silk and rayon industry, announced yesterday that it had pledged support of the proposed National Textile Act to set up a "Little Federal Trade Commission" for the control of the textile industry.

Protestantism is maintaining its strength in the nation, the Rev. Dr. J. Sutherland Bonnell declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad spent $3,140,692 on new roiling stock in 1935, according to the report for that year by Daniel Willard, president. Among the purchases were the Royal Blue, an air-conditioned streamlined train of aluminum alloy placed in operation between New York and Washington, and a similar one of light-weight steel put in service between Chicago and St. Louis.

In the last five years the average weight of children between the ages of 6 and 9 has decreased and malnutrition has increased, particularly among children in that part of the population affected adversely by the depression, Dr. Elda Robb of Teachers College, Columbia University, asserted in a report published yesterday by the National Federation of Day Nurseries.

Free concerts under the auspices of the Federal Music Project will be presented today by the Gotham Little Symphony at the Educational Alliance by the Lenox Chamber Trio at the Seamen's House Y.M.C.A. and by the Chatham Chamber Trio at the Seamen's Branch Y.M.C.A. in Brooklyn.

In most respects, both general trade and financial markets last week duplicated their action of the week before. On the Stock Exchanges, both at home and abroad, resumption of business after the Eastertide interruption was marked merely by a pause in the movement either up or down.
ST. LOUIS, April 19 (AP). -- Cleveland defeated the Browns, 13 -- 6, today, to sweep the three-game series. It was the fifth straight setback for the Hornsbymen.

Trunk line railroads, ferry boats and the Hudson Manhattan tubes combined carried about 2,500,000 fewer passengers to and from the city in 1935 than they did in 1934, according to a compilation made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19. -- Mayor La Guardia of New York flew into San Francisco this morning, was greeted by Mayor Rossi and went immediately to his hotel to rest for day-long conferences tomorrow on the relief problem of American cities, which is the chief topic before the regional meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors here.

The Conference on Port Development of the City of New York announced yesterday that an impartial survey to determine the attitude of business throughout the nation on the Pettengill bill, which has passed in the House of Representatives, shows that most commercial associations are opposed to the measure.
KANSAS CITY, April 19. -- Associates here said today Frederick H. Harvey flew East a week ago to meet his wife in New York on her return from a European trip. She had been visiting in England.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin charged the major political parties today with waging "a gigantic sham battle" and predicted that the program of his National Union for Social Justice would "march on to victory, if necessary, over the corpses of both of them."

NEW HAVEN, April 18. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.6, which compares with 82.5 a week ago, 82.5 two weeks ago, 82.6 three weeks ago and 82.5 four weeks ago.

PITTSBURGH, April 19. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 68 per cent of capacity, up 2 points in a week and 4 points in two weeks, and one-fourth above the average rate in the fourth quarter of last year.
Earl Whitehill insisted on taking himself off Washington's hospital list and pitching against the Yankees yesterday in the first visit of the Senators to the Stadium this year.

PARIS, April 18. -- The Bank of France's return for April 10 shows a fresh loss of 945,000,000 francs in gold. Loans against securities, government bonds and bullion show an aggregate decrease of 320,000,000 francs. Bills discounted rose 244,000,000 francs, on the other hand, to a record figure of 13,374,000,000 francs.

LONDON, April 18. -- The feature of British foreign trade in recent months has been the rapid growth of imports and a diminution in the rate of the increase in exports. Imports in March exceeded those of a year before by 7,545,000, while for the first quarter they rose almost 22,000,000, compared with an increase of only 2,500,000 in exports.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- As a means of reducing Federal expenditures for relief, balancing the budget and preventing inflation, the National Economy League suggested today a return to cooperative efforts between Federal, State and local governments.

An intensive police search was started yesterday afternoon for a mysterious marksman who shot and seriously wounded an 18-year-old girl who was sitting at an open window in her second-floor apartment at 329 East 122d Street, and narrowly missed hitting with another bullet a woman in an apartment two houses away.

TRENTON, N.J., April 19. -- Municipal officials throughout New Jersey and 270,000 needy persons are looking to the Senate to pass the so-called "Luxury" Tax Bill tomorrow night so the State Relief Council may resume its functions.

Daughters of the Cincinnati attending their annual service in St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, yesterday afternoon were told by the Rev. Dr. Joseph P. McComas, vicar of the church, that the people of this country should build anew in the face of great world changes if they would remain secure in the possession of freedom.

The Four Aces won the Nate B. Spingold Trophy, emblematic of the team-of-four championship of the American Bridge League, for the second consecutive year yesterday by defeating Waldemar von Zedtwitz, Edward Hymes Jr., Sam Fry Jr. and M.D. Maier at the Park Lane. The margin of victory was 1,880 points.

BOSTON, April 19. -- As the hour of noon tolls across the wooded New England countryside at rural Hopkinton tomorrow, George V. Brown will raise his ancient but potent revolver, a shot will ring through the air and the fortieth annual Boston marathon will be under way.

The motor ship Wyatt Earp, base ship of the Lincoln Ellsworth Antarctic Expedition, arrived in New York yesterday from the Bay of Whales, Little America, after a trip of more than half the distance around the world.

In a dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning it is stated that "the $1,067,665 payment by the AAA which Secretary Wallace recently reported was said in responsible Congressional quarters today to have gone to the United States Sugar Corporation * * * for reducing sugar cane acreage."

Offering to the public will be made today of 106,312 shares of cumulative preferred stock, $1.25 series, of Associated Telephone Company, Ltd., by an underwriting group composed of Bonbright Co., Inc.; Paine, Webber Co.; Mitchum, Tully Co. and Blyth Co., Inc.
To encourage "unrecognized authors,'' the Book-of-the-Month Club announced yesterday that it would award annually four fellowships of $2,500 each.

The twentieth annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists, at Grand Central Palace, opening with a reception and preview on Friday evening and to the public on Saturday, is the most striking event of the week in the local art world. The week, however, has more than a score of other shows on the calendar, many of them with special points of interest.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- The world's grain markets have changed for the better in the last two weeks. Trading has increased and there are indications that unless something unforeseen develops soon higher prices are likely.

Governor Lehman appealed last night for popular support for the State Social Security Bill, which, enacted, would enable the State to share in the benefits of the Federal Social Security Act. The bill, although passed unanimously by the State Senate, is held up in the Republican-controlled Assembly.

ATHENS, April 19. -- The truce in the politico-religious difficulties between Italian authorities and Greek inhabitants of the Dodecanese Islands has been broken by the conviction of fourteen women on Calymnos Island, who were sentenced to three months' imprisonment and fined 800 lire for secretly burying the bodies of relatives without permission.

MOSCOW, April 19 (AP). -- That the Soviet State must for the time being carry on with certain traditions inherited from the bourgeoisie was among important announcements contained in a statement on the governmental and social development in Soviet Russia published today.

Long Island University, Fordham and Manhattan remained unbeaten in metropolitan college baseball circles as New York University and Brooklyn College dropped from the ranks of the select during the past week.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., April 19. -- Frederick H. Harvey, vice president and general manager of the Harvey system of eating houses of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad, and his wife, Elizabeth Eda Harvey, were killed instantly at 1:45 o'clock this afternoon when their biplane in which they were flying from New York City to their home in Kansas City crashed in the Alleghany Mountains twelve miles east of here.

After a preliminary showing about five weeks ago, Irwin Shaw's harrowing war drama, "Bury the Dead," has moved into the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, where it opened on Saturday evening, under the management of Alex Yokel. It ought to be boycotted by militarists, ammunition vendors and saber rattlers.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 19. -- Mrs. Albert Parker gave a dinner tonight at Kate's Mountain Lodge for her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paterno Jr., students in the University of Virginia. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paterno Sr., who were in this party, were honored last night on the occasion of Mr. Paterno's birthday by this same group.

LONDON, April 19. -- The report of Cunard White Star, Ltd., issued tonight, indicates Britain's new Atlantic shipping merger is swiftly cutting its losses and may soon be earning a profit for the first time.
PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- Ellis A. Gimbel of this city has resigned as chairman of the board of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., a post to which he was elected in May, 1935.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 19. -- A large portrait of King George II of England has been presented to Princeton University by a group of four alumni to replace the portrait which was pierced by a cannon ball during the Revolutionary Battle of Princeton, it was announced tonight by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university.
Martin Schlossman, 30 years old, of 3,041 Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn, was booked at the Parkville police station at 12:45 o'clock this morning charged with the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel.

The Sunday morning social season, already notable for a bicycle caravan down Fifth Avenue, a roller skating race during a snowstorm and a huntless hunt breakfast, provided its first "English Spring-Breakfast Ride" yesterday.

Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York expended $1,257,670 during the fiscal year ended Feb. 29, it was disclosed in a statement yesterday by the Very Rev. Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, executive director. Of this total, $649,932, or more than 50 per cent, was devoted to family care, while $383,212 was used in the care and supervision of children.

"Sophisticated writers" and "two-week scientists" who make flying visits to the South Sea islands and report that missionary work is of no avail were ridiculed yesterday by the Right Rev. Thomas J. Wade, Vicar Apostolic of the North Solomon Islands.

SO far the heavyweight tournaments sponsored or encouraged by J. Dempsey, Esq., have failed to produce any fighter calculated to make Shufflin' Joe Louis turn pale or James J. Braddock give up his crown without a struggle. Even Mr. Dempsey shakes his head slowly and sadly when the net results of his well-meant campaign are up for discussion.

John F. Thomas, 29-year-old household appliance salesman, of 142-20 116th Road, South Ozone Park, Queens, was held without bail on a charge of homicide yesterday by Magistrate Anthony Savarese in the Jamaica Magistrate's Court. He will receive a hearing tomorrow in the Rockaway Beach Court.

Christian fellowship and willing service to one's fellow man were i seen as a means to international i amity and collective salvation yesterday morning by the l~ev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox in his sermon at St. Paul's Chapel. Columbia University, where he is chaplain. "

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, April 19 (AP). -- Unborn babies hear sounds for the last four months before birth, and noises which do not disturb their mothers may speed the infants' heart rate fourteen beats a second.

MUNICH, April 19. -- Juan Carlos Zabala of Argentina, the marathon victor at the Los Angeles Olympic Games in 1932, today broke Paavo Nurmi's world's record for the twenty-kilometer run, which was established by the Finn on Sept. 3, 1930.

Four persons were injured, two of them seriously, in an automobile crash that piled up five cars on Sunrise Highway near South Jamaica, Queens, at 8 o'clock last night, tying up heavy home-bound Sunday night traffic for nearly two hours.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 19 (AP). -- General Eleazar Lopez Contreras, who has guided the country through the trying days since the death of the Dictator-President Juan Vicente Gomez, ended his term as provisional chief magistrate today.

If Captain Christ Johnson, 50-year-old master of Barge 20 of the Nassau Sand and Gravel Company of Port Washington, L.I., was drowned Saturday night, it was in the milk of human kindness and the honey of good fellowship, and not, as the police thought yesterday, in the cheerless waters of the Flushing River.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that it had written to all New York members of Congress urging that they oppose the Wheeler-Crosser bill, which is intended to establish rigid restrictions on the discharge of employes by the railroads and the continued payment of salaries to those who might be discharged in the event that the railroads were consolidated or abandoned.

Persons interested in the Dalton School have taken over the boxes and a portion of the orchestra section of Madison Square Garden for the concert on May 17 to be given by the Philadelphia Orchestra under the direction of Leopold Stokowski in behalf of the school's scholarship fund.

It is to the "men of honor" that civilization must look for its salvation, asserted the Rev. Minot Simons yesterday morning in his sermon at All Souls' Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

GENEVA, April 19. -- Out of a two-hour conversation on Friday between Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain and Joseph Paul-Boncour, French Minister of State, there has come a change in the European diplomatic situation that promises much, but must await confirmation until May 11, after the French elections, when statesmen of France and Great Britain will meet here again at a meeting of the League of Nations Council.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Congressional interest will focus on the House this week, with the administration tax program coming up Wednesday, according to present plans, and the leadership starting a drive for adjournment, now planned for about June 1.

ROME, April 19. -- An official war bulletin today gives the first authentic news of the fighting on the Ogaden front for possession of Harar, of which greatly magnified and distorted echoes have been reaching Rome for the last few days.

PARIS, April 19. -- A total of 4,807 candidates have inscribed their names for the election next Sunday, in which 11,500,000 voters will cast votes to elect the candidates for 618 seats in the French Chamber of Deputies. This number of candidates constitutes a record, being nearly 1,000 more than the number presented in 1932.

BERLIN, April 19. -- Contemplating the tangle of European politics after an absence in one of those quiet places where world echoes penetrate but faintly and health is the only thing that matters, this returning observer finds two points about the present situation outstanding.
Changes in the 1936 waterfowl shooting regulations have been recommended to the United States Bureau of Biological Survey by the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission.
Coming from behind in the ninth, the St. John's University baseball team staged a two-run rally to nip the Brooklyn College nine, 8 -- 7, at Dexter Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Control of the Republican National Convention may be decided at the meeting of the committee on arrangements in Cleveland next Tuesday, with the Landon forces fighting for Colonel C. Wayland Brooks, Republican nominee for Governor in Illinois, as the keynote speaker.

NEW DELHI, India, April 19 (Canadian Press). -- The Marquess of Linlithgow took over the duties of Viceroy for a five-year term that will see the far-reaching Constitution reforms of the Government of India Act put in effect.

WARSAW April 19 (AP). -- Rumors of a Polish Cabinet crisis circulated tonight as Premier Marjan Zyndram Koscialkowski canceled a trip to Budapest, where he was to return a visit by the Hungarian Premier, Julius Goemboes, who was in Warsaw in 1934.

Impressed with the means by which wholesalers here have under taken to regulate advertising and merchandising practices, liquor jobbers in other sections of the country have asked for information regarding the formation of the Wholesale Board of Trade of the Institute of Wine and Spirit Distillers, Inc., John F. Connolly, executive secretary, said yesterday.

Five fires started under wooden staircases in old-law tenements in the Bronx between 2:17 A.M. and 5:11 A.M. yesterday by some one the authorities believe may be an alcoholic pyromaniac, the most dangerous of all types, almost cost the lives of twenty families.

The largest purchase to be made by the Port of New York Authority in connection with the new tunnel to uptown Manhattan took place last week when it acquired four homes in the High Bluff section of Weehawken. The dwellings acquired were those of Mrs. Clara Frances Trager, Mrs. Lillian Schuster, Mrs. Pansy B. Klie and John Eisele.

LONDON, April 18. -- Although the last three weeks have been the quietest period the security markets here have experienced in a long time, an undertone of confidence has prevailed, and the markets are steadily shaking off the apprehension felt in the early days of the European crisis.

LONDON, April 18. -- Aimee and Philip Stuart, authors of "Nine Till Six" and "Birthday," increased their reputation further with "Indian Summer," originally entitled "The Unquiet Heart," which was tried out at the Arts Theatre tonight.

BALTIMORE, April 19 (AP). -- Behind first-class pitching on the part of Jim Bivin and Cliff Melton the Orioles defeated Toronto today, 3 to 2 and 11 to 7. Bivin, making his bow to local fans, held the leafs to four hits in the opener, while Cliff Melton and Bill Lohrman allowed only three in the nightcap.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 19 (AP). -- A disappointed, lame little girl, for nine years a sufferer from infantile paralysis, sat in her modest home tonight wondering if she would ever get her chance to "run and play like other girls."

ALBANY, April 19. -- A bill amending the New York City Tunnel Authority Act, passed earlier this year, to permit the construction of a bridge over the East River instead of a tunnel, will be introduced tomorrow night by Senator Desmond, Orange Republican.

Four players, headed by Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley, Calif., women's national champion, were named as members of this country's Wightman Cup team yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association. The squad will defend the international trophy against England at Wimbledon on June 12 and 13.

There is no longer any doubt about business recovery but still considerable doubt about the political future, according to soundings taken here yesterday among about 500 publishers, editors and business managers of the leading newspapers of the United States and Canada.

Mayor William N. McNair of Pittsburgh, who spent three hours in a Pittsburgh jail Saturday afternoon when he refused to obey an order of a judge to repay a $100 fine imposed in a numbers game case, was the star performer last night on Major Bowes's radio amateur hour.

Without God, the human race and the world in which it lives would be inexplicable, Bishop Herbert Welch, missionary bishop in the Orient for the American Methodist Episcopal Church, asserted in a sermon yesterday morning. He spoke at the Metropolitan Methodist Episcopal Temple, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

Captain Ronald Cheyne-Stout, director of the zoo in Central Park, awarded yesterday afternoon to his 6,000,000th visitor a huge key to the zoo. The recipient, Cynthia Cogswell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cogswell of 161 East Seventy-fourth Street and granddaughter of Supreme Court Justice Morgan J. O'Brien, is 5 years old.

Winners in the seventh annual nation-wide contest to determine the cities that are carrying on the most effective community health programs were announced yesterday by Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
There will be rejoicing in the Municipal Building today -- even if it happens to he a jubilation delayed for some twenty-four years.

Gambling and prostitution have been "practically eliminated and are at a minimum in the city," Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine informed Mayor F.H. La Guardia yesterday in the annual report of his department showing a 5 per cent drop in the number of major crimes reported in 1935, as compared with 1934.

MONTREAL, April 19. -- The bondholders' protective committee representing the first and general mortgage 6 per cent gold bonds of the Canada Steamship Lines, Ltd., has forwarded to the bondholders particulars of a general plan of reorganization formulated by the committee.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 19. -- In the best day's sailing dinghy racing in a year, with hair-breadth finishes and a class victory scored by a single point, the Larchmont Yacht Club's two-day regatta ended this afternoon.

An interesting situation arises as a result of the decision handed down by Judge PATTERSON of the United States District Court to the effect that German moratorium laws cannot be legally recognized here. The decision occurred in a suit brought by an American trust company, acting as trustee for American bondholders, against several private German corporations.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 19. -- Since the Italians have reached the shores of Lake Tana in Ethiopia two meetings have taken place between Premier Aly Maher Pasha and the Italian Minister, Pellegrini Ghigi. On the subject of these meetings some Cairo newspapers now announce that the Italian Government is prepared to negotiate with Egypt regarding eventual use of the lake as a reservoir in an Egyptian irrigation scheme.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- Supplies of hogs here last week increased about 2,000 head over the week before and were about 4,000 over the corresponding week last year. Eleven markets handled 205,000 hogs in the five-day week, or 4,000 more than in the week before and 16,000 over a year ago.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 19. -- The government is not taking a leading part in any negotiations for or against a change in African mandates, a high authority said today. Rumors current in Europe that the Union of South Africa would apply for mandates relinquished by others or was organizing a common African front against the German demand for colonies was described as "purest fiction."

TOKYO, April 19. -- Public anxiety regarding Japan's future naval expenditure will find expression during the budget discussions next month. Foreseeing a swarm of interpellations, naval authorities have agreed to answer with a policy of moderation which Nichi Nichi outlined this morning.

Finishing with a total of 97 out of a possible 100 targets, A.L. Burns won the final regular shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In Class A, H. Thoens and E. B. Horwath each had a full card, the prize going to the first-named gunner.
PORTLAND, Ore., April 19. -- Owen W. Matthews 3d was afraid "some one was kidding me" when told today that he was the winner of the Cantor $5,000 scholarship.

With ceremony and fanfare equal to that bestowed on the bluebloods of their world, the common run of canine and feline pets adopted from the stray department of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals came into their own yesterday afternoon and proudly competed for blue ribbons at the seventh annual pet show of the hospital, held at the Hotel Roosevelt.

One of the most significant and probably enduring results of the depression in the political field has been the approach of the cities to the Federal Government. In the old days they sat around the table with the counties and the towns and spent a good deal of their time visiting the State capitals, but they had few, if any, close relations with Washington.

Bertha Kalich's career in the English and Yiddish-speaking theatres was honored last night at a testimonial benefit at the Majestic Theatre, where her friends and admirers all but filled the house to pay her homage. On the other side of the footlights her theatrical colleagues assembled in a long program that began at 9 P.M. and had not ended at midnight.

MOOSE RIVER, N.S., Monday, April 20. -- The three men entombed in the Moose River gold mine sent word that one of their number was dead today, after flood waters rose rapidly in the pit where they had been imprisoned a week.

One minor but sufficient reason for keeping this country a union of sovereign States is that it makes Presidential politics so much more picturesque. Wipe out the States, and what becomes, once every four years, of the Favorite Son, the Native Son, the Adopted Son, and other varieties of the species filius politicus?

President Roosevelt sent a personal letter yesterday to Robert E. Sherwood, circus raconteur, on the occasion of his eightieth birthday and the twenty-ninth revival of the lollypop festival. More than 100 children and an equal number of adults heard "Uncle Bob" read the felicitations from Washington as he stood on his lawn at 775 Westminster Road, Brooklyn, beside a fabricated lollypop tree.

To the non-technical observer, English influence has rendered great service to the world in postponing the meeting of the Locarno signatories and counseling mature consideration of the German plan of a new Franco-German alignment.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 (AP). -- This port fell back into the paralyzing grip of a labor dispute tonight just when a settlement seemed near.

Two dance events divided last night between them when Senorita Montalva made her debut at the Town Hall, and a new version of "Public Gardens" was presented by the de Basil Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Plans are rapidly nearing completion for the Lucky Number Supper Dance, which will be given at the Ritz-Carlton on Friday evening for the benefit of the Louise Eltinge Memorial Fund. The fund was organized by the Alumnae Association of the Gardner School to provide scholarships for graduate study and to assist the unemployed.

To the non-technical observer, English influence has rendered great service to the world in postponing the meeting of the Locarno signatories and counseling mature consideration of the German plan of a new Franco-German alignment.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 (AP). -- This port fell back into the paralyzing grip of a labor dispute tonight just when a settlement seemed near.

Two dance events divided last night between them when Senorita Montalva made her debut at the Town Hall, and a new version of "Public Gardens" was presented by the de Basil Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Plans are rapidly nearing completion for the Lucky Number Supper Dance, which will be given at the Ritz-Carlton on Friday evening for the benefit of the Louise Eltinge Memorial Fund. The fund was organized by the Alumnae Association of the Gardner School to provide scholarships for graduate study and to assist the unemployed.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,806,574,200. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- The reunion of two Naval Academy classmates ended today in an automobile collision in which three persons were killed.

Many readers of yesterday's TIMES were doubtless struck by one pleasant item reported in its financial pages. This was the fact that THE TIMES index of business activity -- a figure based on the production of steel, electric power, automobiles and lumber, together with freight carloadings -- has entered new high ground for 1936.

Spring and Gilbert and Sullivan continue tonight at the Majestic to the tunes of "The Pirates of Penzance,'' successor this week to "The Mikado." The old favorites are on hand again, of course -- William Danforth, Frank Moulan, Vera Ross, Herbert Waterous, Vivian Hart, et al.

With the Kentucky Derby less than two weeks off, and eighteen eligibles having been tested Saturday, the outlook is that only about a third of the 102 nominess have any chance for the mile-and-a-quarter test May 2 at Churchill Downs.

Called upon unexpectedly to do something really entertaining for 13,500 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday, Van Lingle Mungo responded by holding the Phillies to six hits and pitching the Dodgers out of the cellar, a spot promptly occupied by the Bees.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust, a general management investment set-up, reports net assets of $94,203,915 as of March 31, equal to $25.52 each on 3,691,376 shares outstanding, after allowing for taxes on unrealized appreciation of securities.

LONDON, April 18. -- Discussion of the note circulation situation of the Bank of England again is becoming general. The current week's figure is almost 422,000,000, only slightly less than the record of last Christmas and 29,500,000 above the Easter total a year ago.

Wearing regulation field uniforms, 350 officers and men of Squadron A, now the Manhattan Units of the 101st Cavalry Regiment, paraded yesterday afternoon to the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, where they participated in annual memorial services to their dead.

A man arrested on charges of possessing narcotics and a pistol early yesterday morning at 79 Macdougal Street in the company of two ex-convicts out on parole, was found last night to be wanted by the police of Washington, D.C., as a bank robber.

BERLIN, April 19. -- The glorification of Chancellor Adolf Hitler in connection with his forty-seventh birthday tomorrow is assuming extraordinary proportions even for the Third Reich. Tonight his Propaganda Minister, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, eulogized him in a world-wide broadcast in many languages as the political and social savior of Germany and as the man future historians will recognize as the savior of "senile Europe" and, by inference, the whole world.

Peace was Christ's whole mission on earth and the divine commission. He entrusted to His apostles, aiding them in fulfilling it by His institution of the Sacrament of Penance, the Rev. Thomas L. Graham declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 19. -- Many hundreds of grappling fans in this vicinity who left Lehigh University's Taylor Gymnasium late last night virtually resigned to the fact that none of Lehigh's mat heroes had made the American Olympic wrestling squad are rejoicing today.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Directed toward flood control on a national basis, appointment of expert consultants to assist State and regional planning organizations in the country's fifteen major drainage basins was announced today by the National Resources Committee, of which Secretary Ickes is chairman.

With sugar, rubber, silk and wool-top futures moderately firm on a fair trading volume, other staples reflected weaker trends in the local commodity markets last week. Nevertheless, only a few severe declines appeared. In the cash markets wheat was 4 5/8 cents higher and gains were scored by other grains and by cotton, lard, eggs, rubber, copper and standard tin.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Senator Norris, the liberal veteran of the Senate, today advocated the reelection of President Roosevelt in a statement endorsing the "First Voters Movement" of Paul Best, former president of the District of Columbia Young Democrats.

Mrs. Clarissa Benditto, who had a temporary Winter domicile at 27 Scholes Street, an abandoned and unheated shack that backs up against one of the city's most impressive experiments in model tenement housing in Brooklyn, has become the object of a police inquiry.

LONDON, April 18. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average for 1927 as 100, on April 15 stood at 71.1, compared with 70.9 three weeks before, 70.8 five weeks before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

While it is no "Bury the Dead," the Barrymore's curtain raiser has the distinction of being exactly what it says -- a "Prelude." Mr. Shaw's play is of the war that is to begin tomorrow, and so the Actors Repertory Company first shows a bit of what happened in the war that ended yesterday.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP). -- Schoolboy Rowe pitched Detroit back into the victory column today with a five-hit, 5-to-0 verdict over the White Sox, his second successive shut-out of the season. He is the only Tiger pitcher to win a game thus far.
NEWARK, N.J., April 19. -- The Newark Bears defeated the Buffalo Bisons, 5 to 2, in the first game of a series today before 7,000.

NEW ORLEANS, April 19. -- After opening rather quietly as a result of the Easter holidays, the last week developed a slightly better volume of trading in cotton here, because of the anxiety caused by the late start of the new crop, continued unfavorable dry weather in the Western belt and uncertainty as to the disposal of what is termed the 10-cent loan cotton in the hands of the government.

GENEVA, April 19. -- Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, was preparing here today a speech to be given before the League of Nations Council tomorrow that promises to be unusually important. It aims at upholding against Italy the League pledges to Ethiopia. The feeling of France is running high against this.

TORONTO, April 19. -- Toronto was thrilled and newspaper offices were deluged by telephone calls from all over Ontario when word came today from Moose River, N.S., that Dr. D.E. Robertson, Herman Magill and Alfred Scadding had spoken with rescuers and friends on the surface of the mine where they are entombed.

Offering to the public will be made today of a new issue of $10,500,000 of first-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due 1966, of Wisconsin Gas and Electric Company by a banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds will be priced at 101 1/2 and accrued interest.

CHENGTU, Szechwan Province, China, April 19. -- Wholesale suicides and "mercy" slayings were reported today in Szechwan Province, which is suffering the worst famine in China's history. The authorities fear 15,000,000 will die unless the entire resources of the nation are devoted to relief.

The Most Rev. Anthony Bashir was consecrated Archbishop of the Syrian Orthodox Church of North America yesterday morning at St. Nicholas Cathedral, 347 State Street Brooklyn, succeeding the late Archbishop Victor Abo Assaly, who died last Fall.

Unable to raise the $350,000 bail fixed by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook as the price of his freedom, Charles (Lucky) Lucania languished yesterday in the Brooklyn city prison, to which he was committed pending his trial with eleven other defendants on four indictments charging him with compulsory prostitution.

ALBANY, April 19 (AP). -- Customary increased Spring activity Z brought a 26 per cent employment i~ncrease in Blew York State's coni struction industry last month, State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported tonight.

BEDFORD, N.Y., April 19. -- Samuel Faile of White Plains, whose Rosedale prefix has been carried by many noted winners in the East, captured another important event today when his Rosedale Judge was placed first in the open all-age stake of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.

Masters of the art of living in the woods with only a knife and a hatchet, experts at signaling with smoke, flag or swinging arms, keen students of nature and campers without peer in all Borough Park, Brooklyn, are the twenty-three members of Boy Scout Troop 326 of 114 Remsen Street.

Mr. Baum's analysis of juvenile delinquency in his letter to THE TIMES showed commendably that improper education and environment are fundamental causative factors. It will pay to study this serious problem from a strictly scientific viewpoint.

The attention of buyers in the wholesale markets here last week was centered chiefly on Summer merchandise lines. Wholesalers and manufacturers were preparing for the arrival of a large number of buyers this week to cover their requirements for the Summer season, particularly in the women's apparel division.

While not agreeing with many of the things Chairman Fletcher has undertaken to do in the name of the Republican party, I think it is a gross injustice to both the party and him to view in the recently appointed economic research committee any attempt to establish a counterpart to the Brain Trust of Washington.

PARIS, April 18. -- The gold which left the Bank of France last week went almost entirely to the British Exchange Equalization Fund, which bought francs and immediately converted them into gold, as usual, to prevent the pound from rising. Only a trifling amount went to the central banks of Europe.

PARIS, April 18. -- The general wholesale price average in France for March was 379, compared with 377 in February and with 344 in March, 1935. The retail average price was 452, compared with 454 in February and with 447 in March, 1935.

Lower prices ruled yesterday among bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading was in moderate volume. Pressure again was most evident against the convertible and more speculative issues, reflecting the weakness in stocks, while narrow and mixed price movements characterized exceptionally dull trading among the higher grade investment bonds.

EASTON, Pa., April 20. -- One hundred and fifty mechanical engineering students from a score of Eastern colleges gathered at Lafayette College today for the annual Eastern student conference of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers under the auspices of the Lafayette student branch.

Early erection of a memorial in Times Square to the Rev. Francis P. Duffy, wartime chaplain of the 165th (old Sixty-ninth) Infantry, seemed assured yesterday, after several years of debate as to the suitability of the memorial and the site.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The death of Dr. John Henry House, founder of the American Farm School, Salonika, Greece, is the passing of an "international servant" whose services have demonstrated the elemental foundations of peace. For sixty-four years Dr. House served the stormy Balkans and established there the essentials of community life that, on the long view, are the only guarantees of peace and progress.
Three big Atlantic liners will arrive today from Europe, the Cunard White Star Berengaria, the French liner Ile de France and the Bremen of the North German Lloyd, all with large passenger lists.

Frederick Bristol, who gave a piano recital at the Town Hall last night, cannot be accused of following the familiar paths of program arrangers. His program began with six short pieces by Debussy, and then came Scriabin's rarely heard first sonata.

William L. Ransom, president of the American Bar Association, assailed the centralization of power in government last night in an address before the New York Society of Certified Public Accountants in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Harriet Eells, mezzo-soprano, who was obliged to postpone several dates for her recital earlier this season because of illness, appeared in concert at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Her program began with an aria by Nicola Piccini. A group by Schubert and Brahms and one in French by Faure, Debussy and Ravel followed.

ALBANY, April 20. -- The Court of Appeals ordered today that a writ of mandamus be issued to Dr. Ira Fink compelling the Civil Service Commission of New York City to rerate an oral test taken by him in an examination for medical examiner.

The majority of the Ways and Means Committee announce that debate on the new Tax Bill, which it is expected will be laid before the House tomorrow, will be limited in time, but that no "gag rule" will be enforced. This means that amendments may be offered and pressed to a vote.

Many parties were given in connection with the supper darfee under the auspices of the Russian Nobility Association last night in the Russian Eagle of the Sherry-Netherland for the benefit of sick and destitute Russians in this country.

ADDIS ABABA, April 20. -- For the last three days a steady stream of soldiers has been moving from Central Shoa to various points on the possible line of the Italian advance from Dessye. Reserves have been called from the provinces, such as Wollega, whose resources thus far have only been tapped, as replacements for Ras Makonnen's army which fought near Makale at the end of February.
ALBANY, April 20. -- Former Mayor James J. Walker received an ovation in the Senate chamber tonight as, breaking all precedents, he stood in the middle aisle and recalled other days.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on April 15 shows increases for the week of $65,000,000 in total loans and investments, $164,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve' Banks, $106,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and $193,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

The support accorded share prices yesterday was as cautious and uncertain as that of last week, and when heavy selling appeared in the final hour, the list weakened rapidly. Many leading issues were down 1 to 5 points from Saturday's closing; a few, as much as 6 to 8 points.

An attempt to terrorize a State witness last Sunday brought a guard of twenty detectives and uniformed patrolmen yesterday to supplement an increased force of court attendants at the General Sessions trial of seven men and three women, members of the so-called "arsenal gang," for keeping a machine gun in their West Ninetieth Street rendezvous.

The General Sessions trial of four officers and members of the Council of Independent Milk Dealers on a conspiracy and coercion indictment had to be adjourned by Judge Wallace after a brief session yesterday because of the non-appearance of the principal State witness, Charles Feld, head of a small dairy concern.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent letter to THE TIMES Miss Caroline M. Platt describes the League of Nations as "man's first attempt to provide a clearing house for all international problems."

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The General Capital Corporation of Boston has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, under the Securities Act of 1933, for issuance of 300,000 shares of no-par value common capital stock to be offered to the public at the "determined asset value" plus such premium, but not exceeding 6 per cent of the gross selling price as the underwriter, Capital Managers, Inc., may fix.

Some sort of highway connection between Brooklyn and Staten Island has long been under consideration. It had an honored place on the map of future developments put out some years ago by the Regional Plan Committee. It was approved by DAY ZIMMERMAN, Mayor WALKER'S special consultants.

Joseph M. Schenck, now chairman of the board of Twentieth Century Fox, and formerly chairman of the United Artists Corporation, was a witness yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McCook in defense of the $500,000 suit by William S. Hart, who charges that Mr. Schenck and the late Hiram Abrams conspired to force him out of the production of Western films.

NEWARK, N.J., April 20. -- The Bears registered their fourth straight victory today, defeating Buffalo, 6 to 1, behind the fine pitching of left-banded Marvin Duke. Duke allowed only four hits, one of which was a single by Marvin Olson with two out in the fourth inning to score Elburt Fletcher, who had walked and advanced on an infield out.

To the outspoken satisfaction of employes, tenants, and visitors in the Manhattan Municipal Building, seven new automatic elevators went into service yesterday morning, replacing an equal number of rather eccentric cars whose records in vertical mileage dates back twenty-four years.
Grover A. Whalen received yesterday the "endorsement" of former Governor Alfred E. Smith as a candidate for Mayor. In fact, Mr. Smith might be held to have publicly urged Mr. Whalen to make the race.

ST. LOUIS, April 20. -- Unsound legislation based on the "theories of academic non-producers" is the greatest single threat to the present comeback of American industry, T.M. Girdler, chairman and president of the Republic Steel Corporation, told 110 members of the American Zinc Institute tonight at their eighteenth annual convention here.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- Underweight hogs were scarce and in good demand here today, with sales generally showing 10 cents a hundred-weight above the close of last week. Stock under 170 pounds showed the most strength. Other weights were generally steady, but the demand was not aggressive and some weakness was noted in the later trading on weights above 250 pounds.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- Four Senators, including Senator Borah, explained today that they voted to convict Judge Halsted L. Ritter of House impeachment charges because they felt the evidence "established beyond doubt the want of 'good' behavior."

HAZLETON, Pa., April 20 (AP). -- Housewives deserted their washtubs today to take a hand in a mele at the Stockton School, where striking pupils of Hazle Township besieged their children. Raiding pickets from Ebervale swirled around the little red schoolhouse at Stockton.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The problem of keeping out of foreign wars hinges primarily upon the proper conception and forthright application of the principle of neutrality.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 20. -- Harvard strengthened its hold on first place with its second straight triumph in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by beating Cornell, 8 -- 6, in the opening game on Hoy Field today.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The suit by Robert A. Taft, son of the former President, to make the government pay $1.07 in gold as interest on a $50 Fourth Liberty Loan bond started on its way to the Supreme Court today when the justices of the Court of Claims presented five questions to the high tribunal.

QUEBEC, April 20. -- Formal transfer of Price Brothers Company bonds to Pacona, Ltd., the New York syndicate which recently made a $20,000,000 offer for assets of the company, will be effected in Montreal tomorrow. Acquisition of bonds that have been deposited is expected to clarify the situation as to Pacona's intentions.

LONDON, April 20. -- Official quarters here think it unlikely that foreign residents of Addis Ababa will be endangered unless there should be a period between the end of effective Ethiopian authority and the arrival of Italian troops. Such a period, if the municipal officials and police were not left at their posts, might last two or three days, during which there would be risk of looting and other disturbances.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 20. -- Led by Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, the national titleholder, the field in the Mason and Dixon tennis championship advanced two rounds without a major casualty today as the tournament got under way on the clay courts of the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

In the Senate yesterday Mr. Hastings of Delaware, pursuing his role as the political gadfly of the administration, taunted the Democrats for obstructing a general Congressional inquiry into "this business of relief." That was good as far as it went. But it did not fill the aching void into which a new and sounder relief plan must eventually be fitted if government housekeeping is ever to be put in order.

Paintings by the well-known English artist, Rod Procter, are being exhibited at the Carl Fischer Galleries, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street. This is Mrs. Procter's first one-man show in America, although examples of her work have frequently been included in large group displays.

The Mercer Street detectives are looking for 28,000 nickels. They have a suspect in custody, arrested before they knew that $1,400 worth of nickels had been stolen from the Horn Hardart Automat at 632 Broadway, near Bleecker Street. It did not take much searching to discover that the suspect did not have the nickels, because 28,000 nickels make a sizable bundle.

For giving the first American performance of Bronislava Nijinska's choreographic version of Stravinsky's "Les Noces" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, the de Basil Ballet Russe should be given a rising vote of thanks by the entire dance community, for here is assuredly one of the great works of our time.

Mrs. Warner M. Van Norden was re-elected president, for the fifteenth successive year, of the Bible and Fruit Mission to the Public Hospitals of New York City at the sixty-first annual meeting of that organization held yesterday afternoon at her home, 7 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ALBANY, April 20. -- The practice of permitting prisoners in the Tombs Prison to have money in their possession is frowned upon by the State Commission of Correction, which has just adopted an inspection report of Commissioner John L. Schoenfeld and James McC. Shillinglaw, senior inspector.

Offering to the public of Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit refunding bonds, originally scheduled for this week, will be delayed until early next week, probably on Monday, it was learned yesterday. A change in the total amount and revisions in the coupon rates also became known, and instead of a total of $109,000,000, the amount has been lifted to $110,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- President Roosevelt conferred with the Maine delegation in Congress, Governor Brann and Army engineers regarding the Passamaquoddy project, and discussed with Admiral Standley the latter's proposal to begin construction of two new battleships in the next fiscal year.
LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP). -- Three weary students overslept today while class bells rang at the University of Southern California. They had a perfect excuse.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- An additional list of applications for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets, including twenty-five from New York City, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The National Union for Social Justice, the political group headed by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Royal Oak, Mich., filed today, for the first time, an accounting of its expenditures and receipts in conformity with the Corrupt Practices Act.

From the pinnacle of a lifetime career in the military service of his country, Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, who will retire because of age on April 30, looked back yesterday to the days before the World War and discussed America's present needs in the way of preparedness.
MADRID, April 20. -- Scores of priests and Conservative Catholic newspaper men were arrested today at Oviedo and other Asturian communities and at Alicante, Granada and elsewhere in the South.

George Washington High School had a foretaste yesterday of the national anti-war strike which is expected to take 500,000 college and high school students from their classes at 11 A.M. tomorrow. The strike has been disapproved by the Board of Superintendents of the city school system and penalties have been prescribed for participating students.

HALIFAX, N.S., April 20. -- The best we can hope for is that the Draeger crew of expert coal mining rescue men will get through to the two men trapped in the Moose River gold mine some time tonight. We are keeping in close touch with the scene by radio but the only announcement we want is that they have broken through.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- In the first action instituted in connection with solicitation of proxies, the Securities and Exchange Commission authorized today a public investigation to determine whether A.C. Kehaya, a director, and the Standard Commercial Tobacco Company protective committee had violated the proxy regulations adopted by it under Section 14 (a) of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934.

A $40,000,000 financing operation for the Saguenay Power Company, Ltd., to provide funds for refunding Purposes will be carried out today in the United States and Canadian markets with the offering of $30,000,000 of first mortgage 4 1/4 per cent bonds, $5,000,000 of 2 1/4 to 4 per cent serial notes and $5,000,0Q0 of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred shares.

Rear Admiral Harris Laning assumed command of the Third Naval District yesterday morning at the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, when a full guard of marines accorded him the traditional flourishes and a thirteen-gun salute was fired from the U.S.S. Seattle.

MARGATE, England, April 20. -- Defeating E.G. Sergeant of London in the fifth round, Jose R. Capablanca of Havana today gained his second victory in the international tournament at the Kent County Chess Association's Easter congress.

The names of Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, retiring commander of the Second Corps area, and Edward Corsi, former director of home relief and now Deputy Welfare Commissioner, were mentioned yesterday in WPA circles as possible successors to Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, who retires on June 30.

An extension, in modified form, of the three-year debt adjustment plan for external bonds of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia, which provides for full service of the bonds after October, 1937, has been arranged between the government and representatives of the bond holders, Radoye Yankovitch, Consul General in New York, announced yesterday.

Paine, Webber Co. and their partners control the largest block of common stock of the Kansas City Southern Railway, according to the list of the twenty largest stockholders made public yesterday. All told, the firm and its members held nearly 80,000 shares in April, 1935, according to the list.

Frankie Klick, veteran lightweight from San Francisco, brought to an end the long winning streak of Ralph (Indian) Hurtado when he decisively outpointed the young contender from Panama in the ten-round feature at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

The hearing into charges by the Federal Trade Commission that the American Safety Razor Corporation violated the Clayton Act by making special sales arrangements to large wholesale houses was resumed yesterday before Examiner Edward M. Averill at 45 Broadway.

An attempt by the National Labor Relations Board to obtain an order from the United States Circuit Court in this district enforcing a ruling of the regional board in Richmond, Va., was described as a trick yesterday by Federal Judge Learned Hand.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Senator John J. Dunnigan, acting at the request of the Board of Estimate, introduced tonight a bill under which interest rates of New York City loans under the bankers' agreement would be reduced from 4 to 2 per cent.
Another tall apartment house for the East Side of Manhattan was in prospect yesterday as the result of the purchase of a large site on Twenty-fourth Street, close to Fourth Avenue.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- Testimony of Joseph P. Rend, Chicago coal merchant and financier, taken in the form of a deposition on May 16, 1934, a year before his death, was read to a Federal court jury today as the opening of the suit by which Mrs. Agnes E. Rend, his widow, seeks the recovery of $1,500,000 from the old National City Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Although Franklin D. Roosevelt has been Washington's good-luck fan, Owner Clark Griffith of the Senators today ranked Woodrow Wilson and Warren G. Harding as tops among the Presidential baseball enthusiasts.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

TROY, N.Y., April 20. -- Charging leaders who talk and write about "economic security" with being guilty of thinking emotionally and with pitifully hoaxing great numbers of people, Dr. William Otis Hotchkiss, president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, tonight declared that in the generation ahead the world would need, as never before, the kind of mental discipline that characterizes the engineer and scientist.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Assembly this evening announcing that to break the deadlock over his Budget Bill and hasten final adjournment he would not insist upon restoration to the budget of an $11,160,000 debt service item which the Assembly, Republican-controlled, had eliminated, incidental to a $15,000,000 reduction in the tax on gasoline.

THOSE who willfully feel that plenty has already been said about the Bounty and Pitcairn Island are about to miss a peculiarly interesting book, "The Heritage of the Bounty" (Simon Schuster, $3). This is, in a way, a clean-up job, After this the deluge probably will be over.

MOOSE RIVER, N. S., Tuesday, April 21. -- Rescue workers hacked desperately early today at a wall of rock separating them from two men entombed for eight days in the Moose River Gold Mine, after H. K. MacDonald, Halifax physician, said the pair could live another twenty-four hours.

The New York price for foreign silver was advanced 3/4 cent an ounce to 45 3/4 cents yesterday by Handy Harmon, bullion brokers. This was the second successive advance in price, the brokers having lifted the quotation on last Friday to 45 cents from 44 3/4 cents, a figure that bad been unchanged since Jan. 20.

Recommendations of the steering committee of the Medium Price Coat Associates that preliminary showings of regular lines be held instead of preparing special groups of garments for August sales was approved last night at a meeting of manufacturers and wholesalers at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Just before the PWA entered into negotiations with six Alabama towns to allocate funds to construct municipal lighting plants, the Alabama Power Company, largest utility in the State, offered to sell its local plants to the towns, the District of Columbia Supreme Court was told today.

The Federal Government began trial of a suit here yesterday in the State Supreme Court to recover $2,000,000 from nine New York banks. It is intended to complete the payment of 10,000 depositors who had $16,400,000 in the Harriman National Bank when it failed to emerge from the inaugural moratorium of 1933.

ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP). -- A booming double in the ninth inning by Manager Frankie Frisch that sent three runs across the plate, followed by an error, and a single by Ducky Medwick for two more scores, gave the St. Louis Cardinals an 8-to-7 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

Henry, C. Turner, Mayor La Guardia s first appointee to the Board of Education, will become its president when the term of Dr. George J. Ryan expires next month. The unanimous backing of the board's Fusion majority will be thrown behind Mr. Turner at the annual meeting on May 12, it was learned yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., April 20. -- Opposition to support by the church of any war involving the United States was voiced by the seventy-ninth annual Newark Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at its closing session at St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church here today.

TRENTON, N.J., April 20. -- After again failing to pass legislation which would supply funds for relief, the New Jersey Legislature adjourned tonight. The House will reconvene at 11:30 o'clock tomorrow morning and the Senate at 1:30 P.M.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 20. -Holy Cross won its second baseball game of the season today,, defeating Brown, 4 to 2, before a holiday crowd of 3,000.
Civic Virtue has a son.

ALBANY, April 20 (AP). -- Legislative leaders were reported tonight to be "agreed in principle" on a bill aimed to provide for State cooperation with the Federal Government in a flood-control program for Central-Southern New York.

With 50,000 volumes as its goal the American Merchant Marine Library Association yesterday inaugurated its fifteenth annual drive for books and magazines to be distributed among American seamen traveling to all parts of the world and for Coast Guard crews and lighthouse tenders in waters extending from Alaska to Florida.
Two lawyers conferred yesterday with Charles Lucania in Brooklyn city prison, where he is being held on indictments charging him with compulsory prostitution.

FREEPORT, L.I., April 20. -- Sixteen fishermen aboard the party boat Dawn, owned by Captain Madison Pearson of 29 Sportsmens Avenue, Freeport, were rescued by means of a carrier pigeon Sunday, it became known today. It is said to be the first rescue of its kind on record in this section.

Net income of the Electric Bond and Share Company for the first quarter of 1936 amounted to $2,180,936, equal, after preferred dividends, to 11-3 cents a share on 5,267,147 common shares. This compares with $2,213,566, or 2 cents a share, on the common stock in the first quarter of last year.

LONDON, April 20. -- What Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin described last Saturday as "the black shadow of fear" over Europe will darken the budget picture for 1936-37 that Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, will unveil to the House of Commons tomorrow.

The members of The Associated Press at their thirty-seventh annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday voted unanimously to amend the by-laws increasing the board of directors from fifteen to eighteen, and providing that the additional three directors be elected from members representing newspapers published in cities of less than 50,000 population.

Following is text of the arbitration award announced by Ferdinand A. Silicox in the Building Service Employes Union wage dispute, as made available last night by William D. Rawlins, executive secretary of the Realty Advisory Board:
PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- President Roosevelt's support of the Ellenbogen bill was sought in a message sent from here today by the convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers.

Most futures declined yesterday in average trading on the commodity markets. Sugar advanced and coffee was steady. On the cash markets eggs alone advanced, while cotton, lard, butter, wooltops, cocoa, hides and silk and all the grains, except corn, declined.

Pounding out sixteen hits, including seven extra-base smashes, the St. John's University baseball team had an easy time defeating Northeastern University, 11 to 7, at Dexter Park yesterday. The Redmen made five doubles and two triples. The three-baggers were hit by Paddy Joyce, St. John's catcher, who led the attack with four safeties in five attempts.
The United States will defend the Walker Cup, prized team trophy of amateur golf, against Great Britain's challenge this Summer with one of the youngest squads in the history of cup competition.

Three stores in the building at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and East Fifty-ninth Street have been rented by the S. Leasing Company to the Childs Restaurant Company. The latter plans to alter the space for a new restaurant.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 20. -Estimated Federal and State estate taxes of $13,138,115 are to be apportioned against the estate of i Colonel Henry H. Rogers, oil man,' and a trust fund created by 'his father, I=Tenry l:f. Rogers, according to the terms of a decision handed down today by Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau.

BERLIN, April 20. -- National Socialist Germany in the full pride of her newly acquired strength celebrated today the forty-seventh birthday of Adolf Hitler, who has led her to that strength. The celebration was universal and had every earmark of spontaneity and popular enthusiasm.

A proposed plan of reorganization for the Home Title Insurance Company, which was taken over by the State Superintendent of Insurance for rehabilitation three years ago, was submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Brewer in Brooklyn by a committee headed by George E. Warren, vice president of the Chase National Bank.

Allen L. Lindley, a governor of the New York Stock Exchange and chairman of its business conduct committee, who was not renominated by the nominating committee last week, was nominated yesterday by a petition signed by more than 100 members.

BALTIMORE, April 20 (AP). -- District headquarters of the Townsend old-age pension organization announced today its second national convention would be held July 3, 4 and 5 at Kansas City, home of Chairman Bell of the Congressional committee investigating the movement.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Efforts are being made to induce Senator Borah to be a delegate to the Republican National Convention and to sit as a member of the resolutions committee, which will draft the platform.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- One hundred and ninety-nine years in prison was the punishment decreed today by Judge Joseph Burke for two of the four 'teenage gangsters indicted for murdering Dr. Silber C. Peacock on Jan. 2.

BOSTON, April 20. -- In the strangest finish that the Boston Marathon has had in thirty years Ellison (Tarzan) Brown, 22-year-old Narragansett Indian from Providence, was the surprise winner of America's distance running classic today, virtually clinching himself a place on the American Olympic team.

NEWTON, Mass., April 20. -- The Fordham baseball team pounded out its sixth straight victory of the season at Alumni Field today, routing the Boston College Eagles, 14 to 3. The Rams collected a total of sixteen hits at the expense of four Maroon and Gold pitchers.

BERLIN, April 20. -- Despite all the difficulties of Economic Minister Hjalmar Schacht's new plan of export and import control, German foreign trade continues to improve according to the figures for March, issued today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20. -- A charge that it was necessary to "register as a Democrat" in Santa Barbara in order to get on work relief was made as a regional meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors opened here today.

It is definitely Max Gordon who will present the Dietz-Schwartz musical "Between the Devil," for which Lee Shubert also had been mentioned as a possible sponsor. As already noted, it will be an intimate show. There should be more news about this when Mr. Gordon and Mr. Dietz return from the Coast tomorrow and Sunday respectively.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Committee for Industrial Organization, of which John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers, is president and Charles P. Howard secretary, has offered to cooperate with the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers and to finance to the extent of $500,000 a campaign to organize the steel industry along industrial union lines.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, April 20. -- Five more Jews were killed by Arabs today and thirty more were injured as outbreaks continued in the Jaffa area. Two Arabs were killed and thirty-two wounded in clashes with the police.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 20. -- The annual session of the New York conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church closed its meeting this afternoon with Bishop H. Lester Smith announcing assignment of pastors to churches.

GENEVA, April 20. -- The Council of the League of Nations adopted tonight a resolution reaffirming that Italy is an aggressor and that sanctions will continue and may be increased, but saying this much more softly than when Italy was further from Addis Ababa.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 20. -- Four bandits held up the Morningside State Bank here today, kidnapped four bank officials and employes, and escaped with about $1,600. The four kidnapped were released unharmed a mile from the bank.

Profits of the General Foods Corporation for the first quarter of 1936 were larger than for any other three months since the first quarter of 1932, according to a report issued yesterday by C.M. Chester, chairman. Net earnings for the three months ended on March 31 were $4,067,150, equivalent to 77 cents each on 5,251,440 shares of common stock outstanding.
Ten properties were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan auction sales yesterday. Most of the parcels were apartment houses. Results of the sales were as follows:
Thomas Hunter, unattached, scored two knockout victories in taking the 135-pound class honors at the amateur boxing show held by the New York Athletic Club at its city clubhouse last night.

If there were an automobile accident on South Cecil Street, Lexington, S.C., where Will Briggs lives, it would create considerable excitement -- but certainly not as much as the one in which he figured yesterday at Essex and Delancey Streets, probably the most excitable intersection of that part of the city.

With the four men accused by Paul H. Wendel of kidnapping him and torturing him into a "confession" that he murdered Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., in jail or being sought by detectives, District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan bent his efforts yesterday toward identifying the arch conspirator for whom they acted.

GENEVA, April 20. -- Following are the main points in the speeches before the League of Nations Council today by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and Joseph Paul-Boncour, French League delegate:

Jamaica High School's nine took first position in the race for the Queens Division P.S.A.L. crown yesterday by downing Newtown High, 10 to 5, at the Jamaica Stadium. The victory was the second in a row for Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Internal revenue collections for the first three quarters of the current fiscal year amounted to $2,657,090,083, an increase of $186,320,214, despite a reduction of $334,504,600 in the processing taxes, the Treasury announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- In a message to the Daughters of the American Revolution, President Roosevelt asserted tonight that the United States would continue to press for an international arms reduction agreement and would not increase armaments unless forced by other nations to do so.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Nearing completion of almost two years of investigation, the Senate Munitions Committee submitted today its third report, in which four of its seven members favored outright government ownership of sufficient munitions plant capacity to supply the army and the navy. The minority of three favored stricter regulation but not nationalization.

Speaking at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, Sir Wilmott Lewis, Washington correspondent of The London Times, warned 500 leading publishers, editors and business managers that the chief danger to the freedom of the press in English-speaking democracies came from within, rather than from without.

The last few days have witnessed an upward revision in the interest rates on two large bond issues in registration with the SEC. This is contrary to the trend some months ago, when on one or two occasions the coupons on registered issues were reduced one-quarter of 1 per cent prior to the offering date.
ROME, April 20. -- Fascist officials prepared tonight for a nationwide celebration of prospective victory in Ethiopia as Rome's 2,689th birthday anniversary drew near.

The engineers who built the Holland Tunnel undoubtedly were fine men in their chosen profession, but in planning that great project they apparently never realized that some day some one might wish to bring a giraffe from Jersey City to New York.

Commissioner VALENTINE'S statement that commercialized gambling has been "practically eliminated" here is perhaps too sweeping. The police have, however, carried on a vigorous campaign against the slot-machine racketeers, policy men and wire-room operators with considerable success.

The /Iuseum of odern Art has temporarily closed its doors, to reopen April 29 with an exhibition of work by modern painters and sculptors who, while best known for accomplishment in other fields, have figured also in the realm of filustration.

BERLIN, April 20. -JAlttiough. the Boerse was open. tday,: fhere' was l virtually no trading..Th Exchange was within the district: shut offI from traffic and given over 'to troops and most of the.' banking ! and commercial houses'were closed or operated only' with skeleton staffs throughout the morning in any case.

PITTSBURGH, April 20. (AP). -- Pittsburgh's fiddle-playing Mayor, William N. McNair, was cleared of embezzlement and nonfeasance charges today after he capitulated to a court order restoring a fine to a man arrested in raids on "numbers" writers.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Democratic and Republican leaders in the House agreed today upon the time and method of consideration of the tax bill, indicating that it would be taken up Thursday and acted upon by May 1.

PARIS, April 20. -- Jean Dupuy, famous outboard racer and donor of the Spreckels Trophy, named in honor of his wife, the former Miss Dorothy Spreckels, set a new world's record for Class X outboard motor boats on the Seine this morning with an official average speed of 119 kilometers 718 meters an hour.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP). -- Gus Suhr, captain and first baseman of the P/rates, put a story-book finish to a free-hitting game today with a home run that gave Pittsburgh a 9-to-8 victory over the Cubs.

Mrs. M. Leach Shepherd entertained at dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Count and Countess Adolphe J. von der Palen-Klar, Dr. and Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop, Colonel and Mrs. H. Murray Jacoby, Mrs. James T. Lee, Mrs. Henry Dater, George Keim, Julian Detmer and Charles E. Thorn.

The Wood Memorial at a mile and seventy yards, with $10,000 added, to the run at Jamaica on Saturday, will provide an excellent line on the Kentucky Derby, according to the list of probable starters announced yesterday. Of thirteen now likely to go to the post twelve are eligible for the Bluegrass classic, Mr. Bones being the single exception.

The Delaware, Lackawanna , Western Railroad reduced its loan from the Railroad Credit Corporation by $419,263 in 1935, bringing it to $680,736, according to the report for that year issued yesterday by J.M. Davis, president. The loan originally was $1,500,000. Offsetting the present indebtedness are advances of $721,319 due the railroad by the corporation.
