CHICAGO, April 20. -- Liquidation by holders of May wheat contracts in leading American markets and a forecast of possible moisture in the dry section in the Southwestern States brought to a halt the bull movement in wheat today. Stop-loss selling developed in the May immediately after the opening.

Abandoning its recent campaign for the substitution of cumulative twelve-month reports of earnings for quarterly statements, the New York Stock Exchange committee on stock list yesterday urged listed companies to continue to publish the usual quarterly reports.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- Henry Sturgis of New York told the Interstate Commerce Commission today approval of the Van Sweringen plan for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad would destroy the credit of all railroads. He called the plan a "sham."

Arturo Toscanini has decided to include music by Mendelssohn on his first program with the new Palestine Symphony Orchestra, which he will conduct in Palestine next October, it was announced yesterday by Bronislaw Huberman, the violinist, who is the founder and organizer of the orchestra.

Wage increases substantially the same as demanded by the Building Service Employes Union in the recent strike of elevator operators and other service workers were granted yesterday by Ferdinand A. Silcox, Chief Forester of the United States, in an arbitration award resulting from settlement of the strike.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 20. -- A silencer designed to make noise "commit suicide" before it has a chance to mar radio reception, has been incorporated in a novel receiving set, built by James J. Lamb of the American Radio Relay League laboratory.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 20. -- Mrs. Helen B. Kiefer of Northport, L.I., who was sentenced a few days ago to 180 days in the county jail and fined $50 for leaving the scene of an automobile accident in which two 16-year-old girls were fatally injured, was indicted on a charge of second degree man-slaughter by a Suffolk County grand jury here today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Charges amounting to more than $13,000,000 annually for services to operating companies by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were attacked today by Samuel Becker, special counsel for the Federal Communications Commission, when the commission's inquiry into the affairs of the corporation was reopened. A prompt defense was made by Walter S. Gifford, president, and other A.T. officials.
Business property deals featured the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 20. -- The Board of Supervisors adopted a report this afternoon from its special government committee which put the attitude of the supervisors toward government reform in a new light and left the charter question still undecided.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 20. -Investigation of the forgery of the sigha ture.of the Under-Secretary of the Foreign Ministry on documents that served to obtain permission from theUnited States Government for a shipment of arms and ammunition to Chile during the Chaco l conflict between Bolivia and Paraguay has caused a stir in official and commercial circles here.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- In a sharp contrast with his previous policy in the field of slum clearance and low-cost housing, Secretary Ickes, testifying today before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor, endorsed in general Senator Wagner's bill for Federal assistance to local communities, laying particular stress on the provisions for maximum decentralization of Federal authority and increased local authority.

BARTOW, Fla., April 20. -- The gruesome description of a flogging and tar-and-feathering was told in the little rustic court house here today by one of the three victims of the Tampa flogging of Nov. 30, 1935, which brought death to Joseph A. Shoemaker.

Arab nationalists now threaten to apply in Palestine against the Jews the weapon they have been using so effectively in Syria against the French -- the general strike. Quick to capitalize the riots and bloodshed of the last few days in the Jewish city of Tel Aviv and in the neighboring predominantly Arab city of Jaffa, the Arab leaders now demand that the British authorities halt Jewish immigration.

Victor Emanuel's Miss Merriment, one of the best sprinters in this section, easily captured the Briarwood purse for fillies and mares, which featured the racing at Jamaica yesterday. She fully justified the hopes of her backers who had the courage to support her at 1 to 3.

The humble flounder achieved a new dignity last Sunday when the Long Island Railroad for the first time ran an excursion train to Peconic Bay and Montauk for the convenience of admirers of the bottom-feeding flatfish.

Jimmy Wilson's Phillies, wearing a lot of New York cast-offs but a jaunty air notwithstanding, made their debut at the Polo Grounds yesterday and forthwith made considerable trouble which eventually cost the Giants the ball game by a score of 7 to 6.

MOSCOW, April 20. -- A new search for Sannikoff Island, north of New Siberia, which explorers have long been unable to find, though it has been marked on polar charts for more than a century, will be made by the Soviet icebreaker Sadko on its thirty-sixth voyage through northern seas, which is soon to begin.

NEW HAVEN, April 20. -- President Hutchins of Chicago University said today in opening the Storrs lecture course at Yale University that confusion existed in higher education in the United States, that the advanced university degree has lost its meaning, that future teachers are put through the same work as those aiming to be scholars, and that the classes, the content and aims of graduate work are as confused as those of the high school.
BOSTON, April 20 (AP). -- The Senators and the Red Sox split a two-game holiday bill today, Boston winning the first game, 6 -- 5, and dropping the second, 6 -- 2, before 44,700 persons.

Saro Corso, 6 years old, was shot and critically wounded yesterday afternoon by his 4-year-old brother, Samuel, while playing "cops and robbers" in the hallway of the house in which they live at 314 First Street, Hoboken, N.J.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- An army air corps of 4,000 combat airplanes and a reserve personnel of 1,350 fliers on active duty for not to exceed five years, was approved in the House by unanimous vote today, while Admiral William H. Standley, chief of naval operations, visited the White House to ask President Roosevelt's approval to begin construction of two battleships during the next fiscal year.

The United Hospital Fund will receive the remainder of a trust fund that was worth $847,660 on Sept. 28, 1929, after the payment of $120,000 in specific bequests. This was ascertained yesterday when the will of Mrs. Elizabeth A. Kathan, widow of Reid A. Nathan, publisher of Shepard's Citations for Lawyers, was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.
MOOSE RIVER, N.S., April 20. -- "Charlie, I want to tell you how I happen to be in this mess."

Colonel KNOX is a candidate of wide circulation, Senator BORAH of moderate, Governor LANDON of none. The Governor is stationary. He won't come East. He won't go West. So thousands go to Topeka. The price of living has gone up. There is talk of building a special hotel for correspondents.

Alumni of Notre Dame University gathered last night in 109 cities throughout the country to observe the thirteenth annual universal Notre Dame night. The principal dinner was at Washington and the speeches of President John O'Hara, Bishop John M. McNamara of Baltimore, and Bernard J. Voll, national alumni president, were broadcast over the National Broadcasting Company network to the meetings in other cities.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Eighty banks and investment banking houses received allotments today ranging from $200,000 to $1,600,000 of the $50,000,000 short-term notes which are to be issued tomorrow by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller. The notes bear interest at the rate of three-tenths of 1 per cent.

While mail reorders for fill-ins on late Spring merchandise did not increase appreciably in the market here yesterday, there were signs of a sharp upswing of interest in Summer garments and accessories. A larger number of buyers is expected today to view the showings of Summer dresses in the higher-price brackets that will start this week.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 (AP). -- San Francisco longshoremen voted tonight to resume working relations with waterfront employers under the 1934 strike arbitration award.

Anonymous Fascist threats have been sent to Sir WALTER CITRINE, British trades union leader. Internal evidence casts just a shadow of doubt on their authenticity. The symbols are Fascist and Nazi, but the language is startlingly otherwise.

The night of Thursday, June 18, was set yesterday as the date on which Joe Louis will meet Max Schmeling. In making the announcement Promoter Hike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club revealed that the battle will take place at the Yankee Stadium.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20. -- Tampering with the Supreme Court is not the way to force uniform legislation needed to meet present economic and social problems, Mayor La Guardia of New York told the Commonwealth Club today.

A quintet of former Dodgers invaded Ebbets Field yesterday disguised as Bees and before the long afternoon's business had been concluded partially convinced some 4,500 fans that last Winter's Brooklyn-Boston trading wasn't all for the best.
DETROIT, April 20 (AP). -- The St. Louis Browns scored three runs in the seventh and six in the eighth today to defeat the Detroit Tigers, 9 to 6. It was the Browns' first victory of the season.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 20. -- Upsets and more upsets occurred today. The program lacked a race of true feature proportions, but the place of honor was awarded to a six-furlong sprint for 3-year-old fillies.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Maine delegation began drafting legislation tonight for submission to Congress looking toward authorization for the $36,000,000 Passamaquoddy tidal power project, following two conferences on the subject at the White House.

Bound and garroted, the body of a man identified early this morning as Tony Gubitosi, 21-year-old petty racketeer of 290 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, was pulled from the Gowanus Canal at the foot of Bond Street, Brooklyn, a few minutes before 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Communists and Socialists combined in a united front May Day committee, under the chairmanship of Norman Thomas, will march in Fifth Avenue on May Day despite protests by eleven business men's organizations, if a recommendation made by Deputy Inspector Edward A. Bracken is approved by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and Chief Inspector John Seery.

With predictions of showers over western sections of the Cotton Belt, a weak stock market and government-financed cotton coming on the market, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 9 points yesterday under increased selling pressure.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- The Yankees' first meeting of the early season with the Athletics today was a weird occasion indeed.

SCHENECTADY, April 20. -- Questioning whether the specialized training which is the American conception of engineering education does not actually warp the outlook of our engineers, Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, speaking tonight as the Steinmetz memorial lecturer, recommended broadening the base of technological education according to the pattern set by European universities.
With a record number of new games for grown-ups shown at the American Toy Fair which opened here yesterday, adults promise to take over a large slice of the toy market in this country.

The American Merchant Marine Library Association makes its fifteenth annual appeal this week for books for seamen. Last year 250,000 books of its gathering went to sea and 50,00 are "urgently needed" to replenish the libraries already in place. There must be at least this number now on crowded land shelves that are as eager for the change, even after there has been a sharing with neighbors (individuals and institutions) on shore this past week.

A change in the trend toward powerful, highly organized national governments is necessary if the world is to achieve lasting peace, City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. declared last night in a debate conducted by the Foreign Policy Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

MANCHESTER, England, April 20. -- Alfred Duff Cooper, War Secretary, in a speech here tonight called upon the leaders of the Church of England to denounce "the insidious doctrine of pacifism" as heresy. He was addressing a territorial recruiting meeting of 3,000 in the Free Trade Hall.
Improvements in the city's hospital system were listed yesterday in the annual report of the Hospitals Department for 1935, made public by S.S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 21. -- Strategic as well as commercial importance is attached to a project to be presented to the Diet in May for construction of a new railroad between Fusan, the Korean port nearest Japan, and Keijo (Seoul), the capital of Korea.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- After a week of enforced silence during the Ritter trial, political partisans in the Senate loosed their pent-up oratory today and the chamber rang with denunciations of the New Deal, Democrats, Republicans and opponents of the Roosevelt policies.

The local Savoyards, getting a firm grip on the Spring season, last evening led the faithful into "The Pirates of Penzance" at the Majestic. It was Item 2 in the Gilbert Sullivan Festival, which began ten days ago and moves, in the due processes of festivals, through the popular numbers of the album.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told the Advertising Club of New York yesterday that the depression was over but that, with the unemployed to care for, the government would find it difficult to bring its expenditures within its income until work was provided for all, either by "more work or a better distribution of that which is available."

Consumer understanding and appreciation of professional standards must be raised along with standards of advertising, Bernard Lichtenberg, president of the Institute of Public Relations, declared last night at the annual scholarship dinner of the Advertising Women of New York at the Advertising Club.

Joseph M. Schenck, former chairman of United Artists, was cross-examined yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McCook and a jury in the $500,000 breach of contract suit by William S. Hart, former actor, on the ground that Mr. Schenck and the late Hiram Abrams, president of United Artists, conspired in 1925 to force him out of producing his own Western films.

Once more the British Chancellor of the Exchequer has submitted a balanced budget to the House of Commons. To make it balance, however, he has had to resort this time to additional taxation -- and in this respect the situation differs from that of a year ago, when the Chancellor was able to break the happy news that income taxes could be somewhat reduced.

Net income of the Continental Can Company, Inc., for the twelve months ended on March 31, as reported yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange, amounted to $15,829,206, which, after providing $4,583,808 for depreciation and Federal taxes, left net earnings available for the common stock of $11,245,398, equal to $4.22 each on 2,665,191 outstanding common shares of $20 par value.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Exports of American merchandise in March were valued at $195,336,000 in the monthly foreign trade review of the Commerce Department today. This increase of 7 per cent over the preceding months was accompanied by a 4 per cent rise in import values to a total of $200,295,000.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Spokesmen for Catholic, Protestant and Jewish social welfare organizations appeared today before the La Follette subcommittee of the Committee on Education and Labor and urged a comprehensive investigation of violations of civil liberties.

The New York A.C. softball water polo team yesterday struck its first successful blow in defense of the National A.A.U. senior indoor championship by defeating the St. George Dragon Club six, 24 to 6, in the home pool.

F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen from a three-month hunting trip in India, accompanied by Mrs. Davison.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation reported yesterday for the thirteen weeks ended on March 28 a net profit of $1,239,760, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 59 cents each on 1,226,530 1/2 shares of common stock outstanding.

With the join legislative Committee on the World's Fair reported ready to recommend next week that the State appropriate $2,100,000 for basic improvements this year, the directors of the fair corporation are expected to vote today to provide representation on the board for the city, State and Federal Governments.

LONDON, April 21. -- "Uncle David," King Edward, sent a note of apology today to soften the disappointment of Princess Elizabeth, who had expected him to attend her tenth birthday party. He said he was prevented by state affairs from attending the celebration.

Giving high praise to the reciprocal trade treaty for effecting a complete reversal in the economic situation of Cuba, M.M. Watkins, export manager of the Brown Instrument division of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Company, told the Export Managers Club of New York yesterday that years of profitable trade with the island republic lie ahead.

When Frank E. Carstarphen, Assistant District Attorney, rested the State's case yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Vincenzo Tisbo, former banker, for the alleged theft of $8,890 from one of his depositors in 1923, Judge Freschi took under advisement a motion by the defense lawyer, Michael R. Matteo, for a directed verdict of acquittal by the jury.

A "flameless fire," which was extinguished without water but after which a score of persons were treated or examined by ambulance surgeons, occurred yesterday afternoon in a six-story loft building in 120 Wooster Street, near Spring Street.

Despite further sales of 12-cent-loan cotton and rains in parts of Texas, prices on the Cotton Exchange here strengthened yesterday to end with gains of 4 to 7 points. As first May notice day, next Tuesday, approaches, mills with engagements to fix prices by that date have become increasingly active, and the demand for May carried quotations to 11 1/2 cents a pound.

The $98,085,708 refunding operation of the Chicago Park District was officially declared effective yesterday by the district and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., refunding agent, after announcement that more than 85 per cent of all bonds of the twenty-two superseded park districts, comprising 224 separate issues, had assented to the proposal or were in process of doing so.

The National Labor Relations Board resorted to no trick when it filed a petition with the United States Circuit Court of this district seeking an order to enforce a ruling of the regional board in Richmond, Va., J. Warren Madden, chairman of the board, informed Judge Hand in a telegram sent yesterday from Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP). -- Increased margin requirements were recommended today to the Senate Agriculture Committee as a substitute for the administration bill to bring all commodity exchanges under Federal control and restrict the amount of trading in futures.

With an increase of 45,150 barrels in the daily average, gross production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 2,935,200 barrels, compared to 2,890,050 in the preceding week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

When the principal State witness again failed to appear yesterday in General Sessions for cross-examination in the trial of four members of the Council of Independent Milk Dealers on a conspiracy and coercion indictment, Judge James G. Wallace denounced his conduct as "ridiculous."

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, President-elect of Cuba, arrived here late today for an official visit of two days, and with Mrs. Gomez was a guest of Secretary of State and Mrs. Cordell Hull at dinner this evening at the Sulgrave Club.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has adopted a short form of application for issues whose listing involves only a change of the company's name, the par value of its stock or other technical alterations. The new form was used for the first time this week by the Pittsburgh Terminal Coal Corporation and the Federal Mining and Smelting Company.
Refinancing of one of the largest store properties in New Jersey at a low interest rate was reported yesterday by the Paul Hammond Company, broker.

MOSCOW, April 21. -- The Soviet State has now largely achieved the first goal in its march toward communism, Andrei Andreieff, secretary of the central committee of the Communist party of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, told the Young Communist League [Comsomol] conference here today.

A quick resale in Hudson County, N.J., was reported yesterday involving the Schweinert property at 214-26 Palisade Avenue, Union City, about 150 by 200 feet. The new owners are reported to be Planning an eight-story apartment house there for 112 families at a cost of between $350,000 and $400,000.

A decision by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court, First Department, that compensation liens do not have to be recorded to be effective was hailed yesterday by Assistant Attorney General Joseph A. McLaughlin, in charge of the Labor Bureau of the Attorney General's office, as being of vital importance to thousands of workmen's compensation claimants.

The Kings County grand jury spent all of yesterday afternoon listening to Paul H. Wendel's bizarre story of how four men kidnapped him, forced him to confess falsely that he murdered Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., and then handed him over to Ellis Parker Sr., chief of Burlington County detectives.

A study of the record and of the Senate's action in the impeachment trial of Federal Judge Ritter of the Southern district of Florida, which resulted in his removal from the bench, does not warrant an assumption that this action belongs to the New Deal chapter of executive and legislative conflict with the judiciary.

The second annual dinner of the Order of Colonial Lords of Manors was held last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre. Major Montgomery Schuyler, president of the organization, presided and the principal speakers included Brig. Gen. John Ross Delafield and W.D. Schuyler Lighthall of Montreal.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 21. -- Neil Takala's home run with two men on bases in the fifth-inning featured the Montclair State Teachers College 8-3 victory over Panzer College of East Orange, today. It was the fourth straight triumph for the Montclair Indians, who have only lost to Rutgers.

Declaring that every one in America is "credit-minded" now, James A. Dingivan, general manager Of Arnold Constable Co., told the Associated Retail Credit Men of New York City, Inc., at a meeting at the Governor Clinton Hotel last night, that they have a golden opportunity before them.

Public offering of $110,000,000 of bonds of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation will be made next Tuesday, it was announced officially yesterday. Further changes in the proportionate amounts of bonds and serial bonds to be issued were made and the final amendment to the registration statement is expected to be filed on Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Oxford will publish on April 30 "The Poetical Works of Robert Bridges," containing everything of importance written by the former poet laureate except "The Testament of Beauty."

The decline in business failures in the United States in the week ended April 16 was most evident in the retail division, which showed a drop of 26.3 per cent below the average for the classification for sixteen weeks, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun and Bradstreet, Inc.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- A story of how the late Joseph P. Rend was induced to buy 1,000 shares of National City Bank stock at the high price level of Nov. 1, 1929, was told on the witness stand in Judge Charles E. Woodward's court today by W.R. Boyer, former salesman in Chicago for the National City Company of New York.

The Long Island University. string of baseball victories was stretched to eight yesterday when the Northeastern University nine was overpowered, 9 to 2, at Dexter Park. The contest marked L.I.U.'s last home appearance until May 2.

Preparations were begun yesterday by the Realty Advisory Board and the Building Service Employes Union for putting into effect without delay the wage award of Ferdinand A. Silcox, Chief Forester of the United States, affecting elevator operators and other building service workers in Manhattan.
ALBANY, April 21. -- Governor Lehman called upon the Legislature in a special message today to ratify the child labor amendment to the Federal Constitution "in fairness to the children of America."

ROME, April 21. -- Air reconnaissance has not revealed the presence of any appreciable Ethiopian force between Dessye and Addis Ababa. The Italians, therefore, believe they could without much danger organize a flying advance by motor truck and be in the Ethiopian capital in a few days.

BERLIN, April 21. -- Adolf Hitler by a declaration of Air Minister Hermann Goering became today not only Fuehrer of the Reich but also its Supreme War Lord, a title the Kaiser used to hold. In view of the Fuehrer's own insistence on his supreme devotion to peace, this is a little puzzling, but the Nazi leaders' speeches are not infrequently at cross purposes.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Senator Borah declined today to be drawn into any kind of coalition with the forces supporting Governor Landon of Kansas for the Republican nomination for President. The suggestion had been advanced by William Allen White, the Emporia publisher.

VATICAN CITY, April 21. -- An earnest appeal for elevation of the general tone of motion pictures was made by Pope Pius today in an address to thirty delegates from various countries to the recently ended congress in Rome of the International Federal Cinematographic Press.

A Squad off thirty-four athletes has been entered by Manhattan in the Penn relays at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, Friday and Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Coach Peter L. Waters. The Jaspers will bid for seven relay titles and will be represented in nine individual events.
BUENOS AIRES, April 21. -- The regular fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for April 15 shows the following changes, in paper pesos:

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Senator Wagner's $976,000,000 Low-Cost Housing and Slum Clearance Bill was endorsed by secretary Perkins and William Green today when they appeared before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- "Behold Your God," an "economic satire" in ten scenes by Richard Houghton Hepburn, brother of Katharine Hepburn, the actress, was presented tonight by Jasper Deeter and his Hedgerow Theatre Company in Rose Valley in celebration of the company's thirteenth birthday.
Manager Bill Terry of the Giants announced yesterday that for the 1937 campaign the New York club would do its training in Havana, Cuba.

With an air of confidence, Max Schmeling, former world's heavyweight champion and the next man who will face the Detroit Bomber, Joe Louis, arrived from Germany yesterday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.
Cyril Rosenberg pitched the Boys High School nine to a one-hit 8-1 victory over Brooklyn Tech at Boys High Stadium yesterday. The contest was in Section A of the Brooklyn Division of the P.S.A.L.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- In contrast to yesterday's uproarious ses sion, the Senate settled down to legislative duties today, passed two bills and watched a one-man fili- buster fizzle out.

Three generations of achievement in merchandising since Gimbel Brothers, Inc., was formed by Adam Gimbel in 1842, and the character of the managers and directors who are now guiding the affairs of the huge department store system were praised at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday by Louis J. Horowitz, director and chairman of the advisory committee of the company.

LOUISVILLE, April 21 (AP). -- The cards Colonel E.R. Bradley hopes will win the Kentucky Derby's $40,000 added pot on the Saturday after next will be shown face up tomorrow when Banister and Bien Joli have their first real work since coming to Churchill Downs from the Idle Hour Farm.

The outlook for the American Locomotive Company is the best in five years, William C. Dickerman, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. He reported orders on hand for fifty engines on April 18, of which thirty-eight were for delivery in this country and twelve for delivery in Canada, compared with fourteen engines, all for domestic delivery, a year previously.
By a vote of fifty-nine to three, the Board of Aldermen adopted yesterday the anti-noise ordinance providing penalties for unnecessary noise in this city.

MOOSE RIVER, N.S., April 21 (Canadian Press). -- This village mushroomed rapidly with the arrival, all last week and over the week-end, of mining officials, relatives, engineering experts, volunteers, newspaper men and spectators interested in the rescue work at the Moose River mine.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Services by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to its associated companies were the basis for lively exchanges between A.C. Heiss, A.T. and T. controller, and Samuel Becker, special counsel for the Federal Communications Commission, at today's session of the investigation of the telephone company.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 21. -- Six furlongs in 1:11 4-5 -- the fastest time of the Harford Agricultural and Breeders Association's meeting and of the Maryland season to date -- was the accomplishment today of Major Ral Parr's Star Porter, 6-year-old chestnut gelded son of The Porter and Starella.

Although there will be no change in the plans to lay off 42,000 WPA workers by June 15, as ordered by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal WPA Administrator, more care will be exercised in picking those to be dismissed, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator here, said yesterday in revealing that the WPA was behind schedule in the lay-off program.

A dozen policemen were called to restore order at the first meeting of the recently elected Queens County Democratic Committee in Jamaica High School last night after some of the members had charged the platform and taken possession of it, halting the proceedings.

MOOSE RIVER, N.S., April 21. -- Mrs. R.E. Robertson, still fearing to be too hopeful as to the success of the efforts to save her husband, walked nervously today from shaft to shaft, from diamond drill to boiler room on weary rounds.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

Details of an intensive study of the nation's consuming habits at various income levels, undertaken by economists and statisticians of the Department of Labor, were made public here yesterday by Miss Ruth M. Ayres, director of the New York division.

THIS sudden blooming of Dr. Alvin Johnson as a novelist carries with it a rather enduring surprise. There was surprise in the fact that Dr. Johnson had written a novel, and more surprise that it should be the sort of novel which it is. For in "Spring Storm" (Knopf, $2.50) the distinguished director of the New School for Social Research and associate editor of the Encyclopedia of the Social Sciences lets passion flare.

A pre-opening tea, in the interests of the benefit showing of the famous Gauguin painting, "D'ou Venons Nous -- Que Sommes Nous -- Ou Allons Nous?" will be given today at the Marie Harriman Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street. After the preview, the picture will be on display for two weeks as a benefit for the Public Education Association, a civic organization maintained by citizens in the interest of the improvement of the public schools.

BERLIN, April 21. -- The apparent determination on the part of the German Olympic committee to use the Berlin Olympics for purposes of international political propaganda has again come to the fore in an active campaign to assure worldwide circulation for the Reich Sport Journal, which carries on its cover the subtitle "Official Olympic Journal."

A Six-story apartment house to be built at the northwest corner of 199th Street and Valentine Avenue will cost $200,000, according to plans filed yesterday with the Bronx Department of Buildings by Charles Kreymborg, the architect. The owner is the Olop Corporation, A. Giordano, president, of 2,488 Grand Concourse.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in an address prepared for delivery tonight in the Emergency Peace Campaign to Keep the United States Out of War, said that "by and large the vast number of our individual citizens still shirk their responsibility."

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP). -- The cotton-spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during March at 108.1 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 105.2 per cent for February this year, and 92.9 per cent for March last year.

Westchester County won first prize in the Northeastern division of the second annual interchamber rural health conservation contest, conducted by the United States Chamber of Commerce and the American Public Health Association for the best county or district health work and administration in 1935, it was announced yesterday at the office of the association in Rockefeller Center.

MARGATE, England, April 21. -- Defeating the world women's champion, Miss Vera Menchik of London, representing Czechoslovakia, in the sixth round today, Jose R. Capablanca of Havana tied Salo Flohr of Prague, his chief rival, for first place in the international tournament of the Kent County Chess Association at the Grand Hotel.

Last Sunday was "Humane Sunday" and this is "Be-Kind-to-Animals Week." In this day and age both appellations should be superfluous. The zealous work of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has done much to curb willful mistreatment of horses and smaller creatures in this city.

GENEVA, April 21. -- Italy by April 1 had lost almost half the gold and foreign exchange reserve that she had last Oct. 20, Karl Gustaf Westman of Sweden, chairman of the League of Nations committee of Experts on Sanctions, told the committee today in a report emphasizing the accumulating effect of sanctions.

Flashing an effective body attack Lou Camps, promising Bronx featherweight, won a decision from Joey Archibald of Providence in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 4,000 saw Camps register his twenty-eighth victory in thirty professional starts.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Following is the text of the report on the Tax Bill presented by the minority of the Ways and Means Committee:

Lee Pattison, city and State director of the Federal Music Project, yesterday announced plans or a six-day festival of American music, which will be presented by the New York units of the project in conjunction with the country's observance of music week beginning May 3.

Of interest to sportsmen who are planning trips to Canadian fishing waters is the announcement of the Quebec provincial government that the seven-day tourist license inaugurated last year again will be available this season.

BOSTON, April 21 (AP). -- Bob (Lefty) Grove held the Senators to three scattered hits today in a one-sided game that found the Red Sox leading, 8 -- 1, when rain halted the action in the first of the seventh inning. It was the veteran southpaw's second successful start of the season.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 21. -- San Francisco longshoremen will return to work tomorrow under peace terms signed this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- A summary of the new Tax Bill introduced today by Representative Doughton of North Carolina and officially reported by the Ways and Means Committee, with the important additions to the present law textually, follows:

ALBANY, April 21. -- Prompt action by the budget conference committee of the Senate and Assembly this afternoon resulted in agreement on a compromise which it is expected will meet the Governor's views and end the deadlock between the two houses on the main Budget Bill.
ADDIS ABABA, April 21. -- The Ethiopian Government telephoned this morning to various points rumored to be the immediate objective of the Italian forces.

Bud Mignault, clever light heavyweight from Brockton, Mass., stepped out of his class against Ralph Barbara in the feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night, but managed to gain a draw with the hard-hitting Brooklynite before a crowd of 2,500.

The Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates reported yesterday a net income of $10,077,542 for the twelve months ended on Feb. 29, after Federal income taxes and before depreciation, depletion, retirements, interest, amortization of debt discount and expense of recently liquidated subsidiaries, minority interests and surplus adjustments.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Revenue Bill of 1936, designed primarily to effect a comprehensive reform in the Federal system of taxing corporations and incidentally to plug two gaping holes left in President Roosevelt's budget by invalidation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act and enactment of the bonus payment measure, was introduced in the House today by Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., April 21. -- The annual Pleasantville music festival opened tonight in the auditorium of Pleasantville High School with a concert by the fifty-three-piece high school band under the direction of Frederick F. Quinlan.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company today, in an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933, set Thursday of this week as the offering date for $60,000,000 of first-mortgage sinking fund 4 per cent bonds, Series C, due on May 1, 1961, and $30,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent convertible debentures due on Feb. 1, 1951.
The Westchester County Golf Association yesterday announced its schedule of championships and tournaments for the coming season.

Lincoln Ellsworth, the explorer, who has just returned from his flight across the Antarctic Continent, received last night, at a meeting of the American Geographical Society, the David Livingstone Centenary Medal.

Samuel Shipman, the playwright, and Clara Lipman, who helped him write a play entitled "Depends on a Woman," which has never been produced, began suit yesterday in Federal court against R.-K.-O. alleging that the motion picture "I Dream Too Much" is simply a musical version of their own work.

LONG BEACH, L.I., April 21. -- The City Council, meeting here tonight, voted to fence off the public beach for its entire length of five miles and charge admission fees to all who wish to enter upon it. More than 500 taxpayers attended the meeting.
BALTIMORE, April 21 (AP). -- The Orioles made it three straight in their series with Toronto today.
With seeming bad strategy the railroads in the East are protesting the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission in the matter of passenger-rate reduction.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 21. -- At the end of the third round of competition in the Mason-Dixon tennis championship at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club today, eight of the leading players of the country were occupying the quarter-final brackets, holding out the promise for the morrow of one of the best days of tennis seen here in recent years.

BERLIN, April 21. -- The People's Tribunal, created by the National Socialist regime to deal with "traitors" in abbreviated fashion irrespective of legal court procedure, was made permanent by a decree issued today and signed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Dr. Franz Guertner, Minister of Justice; Count Lutz Schwerin and Krosigk, Finance Minister, and Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, War Minister.

LONDON, April 21. -- The grim meaning of rearmament was driven home to every man and woman in the kingdom today when Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced increases in taxation to pay for Great Britain's vast defense program.

Granville, from the stable of William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, indicated at Jamaica yesterday that he was a real threat for the Kentucky Derby when he scored a smashing victory in the Bridgehampton Purse, at a mile and seventy yards, and defeated Willis Sharpe Kilmer's highly regarded Ned Reigh by five lengths.

RICHMOND, Va., April 21. -- Although economic conditions in the Southeast continued to improve in 1935, reductions in rates to meet competitiOn by motor truck and steamships, higher prices for coal and supplies and increased wages adversely affected the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad last year, George R. Elliott, president, said at the annual meeting here today.

DETROIT, April 21 (AP). -- Joe Louis, the dark star to which the boxing industry has hitched its money, said today he hoped to stop Max Schmeling in less than the four rounds he needed to knock out Max Baer.

Following a debate on whether the Federal child labor amendment should be ratified by the States, a group of women, meeting under the auspices of the child welfare division of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs yesterday, in the Hotel Astor, voted 28 to 23 against the measure.

MOOSE RIVER, N.S., Wednesday, April 22 (Canadian Press). -- Driving rain added its discomfort to difficulties of the surface workers at the mine during the night. The boiler room was packed with men, officials making it headquarters from which instructions were being issued.

Governor LEHMAN speaks of the dangerous fiscal precedent set by the Republicans when they insisted on eliminating from the pending State budget an item of $11,000,000 for debt service. It may turn out to be an even more dangerous political precedent. By giving in to them and refusing to "oppose obstinacy with obstinacy" the Governor has placed the responsibility for enacting an unbalanced budget where it belongs.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The main points of the new Tax Bill introduced today in the House were as follows:

Remington Rand, Inc., resumed payment of common dividends yesterday with the declaration of a regular quarterly dividend of 15 cents in cash and 1 per cent in stock. This places the stock on a 60 cents cash and 4 per cent stock annual basis.

Five hundred thousand students in high schools and colleges throughout the nation are expected to leave their classes at 11 A.M. today to demonstrate their abhorrence of war. Parallel demonstrations will take place in France, Belgium, Spain and Puerto Rico, according to word received by the American Student Union, sponsor of the movement.

ROME, April 21. -- Premier Benito Mussolini added his voice today to the paeans of triumph being sung all over Italy, not only for the conquest of Ethiopia but also for the favorable turn of events at Geneva. He shouted to a crowd of thousands of his followers cheering themselves hoarse in the Piazza Venezia this morning that he now held victory firmly in his grasp.

Selected by artists as the best poster among 240 entered in a city-wide contest conducted by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, a design of a bird feeding from a huge hand received high praise for both its humane and its artistic appeal at an awarding of prizes yesterday afternoon in the society's headquarters, 50 Madison Avenue.

The large Gauguin painting, "D'ou Venons Nous -- Que Sommes Nous -- Ou Allons Nous?" recently acquired by the Marie Harriman Gallery, has just been purchased from this gallery by the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. The previously announced plan of exhibiting the picture for the benefit of the Public Education Association will, however, be adhered to.

A net profit of $7,086,830 was reported yesterday by the General Electric Company for the first quarter of 1936 after depreciation, charges and Federal taxes. This was equal to 25 cents each on 28,845,927 common shares. It compared with $5,390,930, or 19 cents a share, in the same period of 1935.

For the first time in three months the weekly registration of buyers reached the thousand mark. This high total was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week ended yesterday 1,094 arrivals were reported, the highest since the week of Jan. 15, when 1,206 were listed.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 21. -- President Angell announced today the appointment of Professor Samuel W. Dudley, Strathcona Professor of Mechanical Engineering at the university, as dean of the Yale School of Engineering, succeeding Dean Robert E. Doherty, recently elected president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology.

Mrs. Andrew Carnegie will sail today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to spend the Summer in Scotland. Also on board the ship will be Lord and Lady Burgh, Lady Elizabeth Lindsay, Sir Arthur Munro Sutherland, Lady Sutherland, Sir Duncan and Lady Hay, Colonel W. Stewart-Roddie, Captain O.D. Winterbottom, Dr. and Mrs. Archibald Stewart, Sax Rohmer, author, with Mrs. Rohmer; Dwight Taylor, playwright; Miss Leslie Howard, actress, and J.W. Hicks Jr.

If any uneasiness is felt over the foreign political situation, or over the possible devaluation of the French franc, it is being translated into selling of American securities by citizens of this country rather than by foreigners. A canvass yesterday of brokerage offices with branch offices in London, Paris and Amsterdam showed that in general foreigners still are buying our stocks on balance, although the volume of trading has declined sharply.

Tracked down by means of a thirteen-inch strand of twine that he had left inadvertently at the scene of the crime, John Fiorenza, 24-year-old ex-convict and upholsterer, confessed yesterday morning the strangling of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton in her apartment at 22 Beekman Place on April 10.

KANSAS CITY, April 21 (AP). -- Clarence Sparger and John Langdon, sought by the government for bank robbery and automobile theft, were arrested today after a gun fight near this city in which Sparger and a Federal officer were wounded. Department of Justice men refused to name the agent.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 21. -- Pepper Constable, captain of Princeton's football team last Fall, today led the Tiger Rugby fifteen to a 22-8 victory over the Long Island University team on Bedford Field.

With sugar and coffee futures stronger other staples were moderately weaker in light trading yesterday on the commodity markets. Most price changes were of minor proportions. On the cash markets, wheat, corn and cotton rose, while rye, oats, lard, butter, eggs, wool-tops, rubber and silk declined.

The Alleghany Corporation is to contest a decision of the Federal Court in St. Louis disapproving a contract under which the Missouri Pacific Railroad transferred $3,200,000 to the holding company as part payment for terminal properties and real estate. O.P. Van Sweringen, president of the corporation, discloses in his pamphlet report for 1935.

ALBANY, April 21 (AP). -- Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, in an address today at the induction of Governor Lehman as the nation's "first credit-union Governor," declared that "in the very nature of the changes which have come over civilization, the people must dominate not only our political but our economic life."

A drop of a quarter cent an ounce in the price of silver quoted here by Hardy Harman; bullion brokers, and an increase of 1-16d an ounce in London yesterday brought the local quotation again under the dollar equivalent of the price in London.

Fellowships and scholarships with a total value of almost $130,000 have been awarded by Columbia University to 107 students for the academic year 1936-37, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of the university, following action by the university council. Twenty-three alternates also were named.
Combining all their resources, the four art projects of the WPA will hold something like a large lawn party for children on Saturday afternoon, May 2, in Central Park.

Newspaper readers in the smaller cities of the country are demanding more national news in relation to local news than ever before, according to an address made yesterday by John L. Stewart, a Pennsylvania publisher, at the first session of the fiftieth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- The Federal Government and officials of Tennessee were called upon today by the American Federation of Hosiery Workers to provide protection for strikers in the hosiery industry in that State.
Housing deals by operators featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

It took considerable brawn and finally a loud single by the muscular Hank Leiber in the last half of the ninth for the Giants to pin down the Phillies at the Polo Grounds yesterday and square the series at a victory apiece.

Women interested in the drive for funds for the restoration of Stratford Hall, the historic home of the Lee family of Virginia, gave parties at the luncheon and entertainment in behalf of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation held yesterday in the Garden Room of the Park Lane. Southern dishes were features of the luncheon.

Mr. and Mrs. George C. Scott of Plainfield, N.J., gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Sir William and Lady Firth of London. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. George C. Scott Jr., Kenneth Firth, David Scott, Charles Phillips of London and George Collinet of Paris.

MADISON, Wis., April 21. -- Harry A Stuhldreher, one of Notre Dame's famed Four Horsemen, was appointed athletic director and football coach at the University of Wisconsin today. The Board of Regents approved the appointment of the Villanova mentor after the athletic board had recommended his selection unanimously from a field of fifty candidates.
NEWARK, N. J., April 21. -- The Bears registered their fifth consecutive victory today by drubbing the Buffalo Bisons, 10 to 5, in the third and final game of their series.
TRENTON, April 21. -- One seat as United States Senator and fourteen as Representatives in Congress are being sought by eighty-five candidates in the New Jersey primaries on May 19.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts yesterday obtained a rate 0.16 per cent plus a premium of $5 for a new issue of $2,086,300 of seven-month notes, dated April 22, awarding the issue to the First Boston corporation. The sale attracted several other bids, the second highest being tendered by the Bankers Trust Company of 0.17 plus a premium of $17.

The share market moved irresolutely during most of yesterday and was saved from a lower closing by a half-hearted rally in the final hour. It was another occasion on which the final averages did not quite tell the story. Owing to the fact that leading stocks were the principal beneficiaries in the late buying, movement, as the lower-priced issues suffered from neglect, the averages showed a gain on the day.

A whole generation of America's youth is being ruthlessly brushed aside, its productive ability and energies lying dormant. Industry is unable to absorb the millions of unemployed youth. The colleged-trained man finds that his education is of negligible value in the struggle for existence.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP). -- Daughters of the American Revolution were advised today by the dean of their Past Presidents General, Mrs. George Thatcher Guernsey of Kansas, to change their ways if they wished to win young members.

For all of Casey Stengel's masterminding the Dodgers could do nothing with the troublesome Bees yesterday and as darkness descended upon Ebbets Field the teams were locked in a bitter struggle, neither able to make any headway. So when a twelfth-inning Brooklyn rally was snuffed out and the clubs were still deadlocked at 6 -- 6, there was nothing for Umpire Beans Reardon to do except call a halt.

ROME, April 21. -- Pastry cooks from every province of Italy vied today to determine who could create the most elaborate confections and win first place in the Fascist party's newly instituted "Olympics of Work."

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- From a delegation of nearly 200 striking East Coast seamen who said they spoke for 3,200 more, two surprised Cabinet officers today received firsthand information on living conditions aboard American flag ships and heard the group assert that safety at sea was but a meaningless term as long as such conditions continued.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21. -- Seven-year-old Samuel Mydosh, the youngest of four children in one family who suffer from cataracts, was operated on here today in St. Michael's Hospital for the second time within three days for the removal of the growths.

LONDON, April 21. -- The severe epidemic of measles at present sweeping Great Britain has invaded the royal family. The Princess Royal and her younger son, the Honorable Gerald Lascelles, 11 years old, are both stricken. A bulletin issued at Harewood House today said the complaint was taking its normal course.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- President Roosevelt attended the funeral of Louis McHenry Howe, his secretary, and left late tonight for the burial at Fall River, Mass.

Cowboys and cooks, bricklayers and musicians, will vie for artistic laurels with professional painters and sculptors when the twentieth anniversary exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists is opened to the public Saturday morning in Grand Central Palace after a reception for artists on the preceding evening.

LONDON, April 21. -- A cheerful air pervaded the London Stock Exchange today as traders awaited the budget report. British funds continued strong, the war loan gaining, German securities were in demand in the foreign section.

In the Senate Monday there was a debate in the original sense of the word: a wrangle, a quarrel. Mr. HASTINGS was the chief Republican wrangler; Mr. ROBINSON head wrangler for the Democrats. Other figures came into the delightful scene, but none could equal these masters of polished argument.
Frankness was in the air and as a result the members of the Grand Street Boys Association last night heard remarks usually confined to closed meetings of the Board of Estimate.

PARIS, April 21. --The newspaper Excelsior reports Germany has begun building a line of steel and concrete fortifications in the remilitarized Rhineland along the Netherland, Belgian and French frontiers.

In the Senate Monday there was a debate in the original sense of the word: a wrangle, a quarrel. Mr. HASTINGS was the chief Republican wrangler; Mr. ROBINSON head wrangler for the Democrats. Other figures came into the delightful scene, but none could equal these masters of polished argument.
Frankness was in the air and as a result the members of the Grand Street Boys Association last night heard remarks usually confined to closed meetings of the Board of Estimate.

PARIS, April 21. --The newspaper Excelsior reports Germany has begun building a line of steel and concrete fortifications in the remilitarized Rhineland along the Netherland, Belgian and French frontiers.

Cowboys and cooks, bricklayers and musicians, will vie for artistic laurels with professional painters and sculptors when the twentieth anniversary exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists is opened to the public Saturday morning in Grand Central Palace after a reception for artists on the preceding evening.

LONDON, April 21. -- A cheerful air pervaded the London Stock Exchange today as traders awaited the budget report. British funds continued strong, the war loan gaining, German securities were in demand in the foreign section.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Declaring that recovery in the United States was menaced by fear of inflation, Professor Edwin V. Hemmerer of Princeton University called, in a speech here today, for a "nationwide ground swell of opposition to further inflationary measures, an opposition which will result in the prompt repeal of the radical monetary and banking legislation now upon our statute books."

Before me lies a clipping from today's Rotogravure Section of THE TIMES depicting Lewis J. Gorin Jr., Princeton, '36. The accompanying text states that this young man is "the head of the organization of students of American colleges who wish to receive immediate payment of a $1,000 bonus as the men who will fight in America's next wars." Verily, patriotism at a price!

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- "Well-distributed" rises in industrial employment and payrolls in March accounted for an increase of about 225,000 jobs and $10,000,000 in weekly payrolls, Secretary Perkins announced today. Sixty-six of the ninety manufacturing industries covered by the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed employment gains over February and eleven of sixteen non-manufacturing industries also showed upturns.

ALBANY, April 21. -- The Senate voted today to kill a bill to put into effect the constitutional change approved by the electorate last Fall to provide for five-sixths jury verdicts in Civil cases and defeated three other bills dealing with changes in the law on personal-injury suits.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- That weird setback the Yanks suffered yesterday had a salutary effect on the McCarthymen. They downed the Athletics today, 7 to 6, but not without complications which menaced a five-run Yankee lead in the ninth inning.

Three British police officials arrived yesterday from England on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to study American criminology, especially the methods of criminal identification and police communications. They are Lieut. Col. Frank Brook, Inspector of Constabulary for England and Wales; John Maxwell, Chief Constable of the Manchester City Police, and R.M. Howe, Deputy Assistant Commissioner of the Criminal Investigation Department at New Scotland Yard, known generally as the "C.I.D."
A variety of office and store leases in various parts of the city was reported yesterday.

John W. Pole, who had power to close the Harriman National Bank as Federal Controller of the Currency in 1932, testified yesterday in the Supreme Court here that he was kept from closing it nine months before the banking moratorium of 1933 by "assurances from the New York Clearing House that the depositors would be protected against loss."

Overproduction of cotton fabrics, which has forced prices down and resulted in mills operating at a loss, was condemned by speakers at the annual dinner at the Hotel New Yorker last night of the Textile Fabrics Association, comprised of many of the leading converters in the industry.

Groping hands against the darkened skyline of New York, symbolizing the need for help among 400,000 families and as many more individuals in the city, beckoned yesterday to the 600 business, civic and welfare leaders who attended the formal opening of the drive by the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for $1,500,000 to support private family welfare agencies.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 21. -- Miss Martha A. McDowell of New York gave a luncheon today for Mrs. Pembroke Donegan, the Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan and the Rev. Ambrose H. Beavin.

For some time the representatives of the railroads and of railway labor conferred on the question of a "dismissal wage." The conferences eventually reached a deadlock. The difference was over the amount of compensation to be paid to workers who are displaced as a result of railway consolidations.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Townsend plan leaders were charged today with knowingly distorting the records of the Senate Finance Committee and the House Committee on Ways and Means as a part of their campaign to "sell" the Townsend $200-a-month old-age pension plan to the country.

John Quinn, veteran keeper of the hoofed animals at the Bronx Zoo, was in a serious condition at Fordham Hospital last night as the result of a sudden attack by one of his charges, a zebra, yesterday morning. The keeper, who is 65 years old, has been at the park for thirty years and is expected soon to retire.

Jascha Heifetz gave his last individual recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, although his final appearance will take place next Wednesday, when he will be the soloist at Arturo Toscanini's farewell performance with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- A picture of the financial operations made by the New Deal was revealed today with publication of the particulars of hearings before the House Ways and Means Committee on the administration's new Tax Bill.

TRENTON, April 21. -- Unemployed men and women took over the seats of Assemblymen in the State House here today in protest of the failure of the members of the House and Senate to approve measures to supply funds for relief before adjourning earlier in the day.

MOOSE RIVER, N.S., Wednesday, April 22. -- Rescue workers in the Moose River gold mine in which Dr. D.E. Robertson and Charles Alfred Scadding have been trapped for nine days reported early this morning that they believed they were within twelve feet of a clear shaft leading to the prison chamber.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 21 (AP). -- Time Supply, star campaigner of Frank Carreaud, was outrun today in his first start at Arlington Downs by Headliner, 3-year-old colt of the Three D's Stock Farm, in the Mirabeau Lamer Purse.

The Barnard School baseball team scored its second straight victory yesterday when it defeated the Collegiate School nine, 16 to 8, at Carroll Field. The victors scored in every inning with the biggest rally coming in the second frame, when seven runs crossed the plate.

The Ferro Enamel Corporation declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of 20 cents on the common stock, payable June 20 to stock of record June 10 with the provision that, if the sale of 15,250 shares of common stock on Saturday is successful, the dividend shall be 25 cents.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- George Lansbury, who resigned his leadership of the British Labor party because he differed with his associates on the question of sanctions against Italy, made a plea tonight that the United States and Great Britain lead an international movement for an economic conference to discuss "a square deal" for all nations in so far as the world's natural resources are concerned.

Father DUFFY'S statue is to stand at the north end of Times Square. It is hard to think of any public monument bathed in a brighter glare than the blaze of white electrics and red neons that will encompass the effigy of the well-loved priest Father DUFFY'S fame is widest as the war chaplain of the old Sixty-ninth.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21. -- A drive to end racketeering conditions in Eastern markets, particularly in those of New York City, was started today with Mayor La Guardia promising support to California growers and shippers of fruits and vegetables.

When Judge John J. Freschi suspended sentence on John Fiorenza in General Sessions on May 18, 1935, on his plea of guilty to stealing an automobile, he had received a report on the youth from Irving W. Halpern, chief probation officer of General Sessions.

CLEVELAND, April 21. -- Old Guard leaders assumed command of Republican affairs today when Senator Frederick C. Steiwer of Oregon was unanimously selected by the committee on arrangements to be the keynote speaker at the national convention in June.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Scattered rains which fell over part of the eastern half of Kansas led to fairly general selling of wheat today at the opening of the Board of Trade, and all futures dropped around 1 cent a bushel under yesterday's finish.

The Republican party was urged last night by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt to seek the aid of Democrats in electing a President, preserving democratic government and stopping the New Deal. Colonel Roosevelt spoke at the National Republican Club in accepting election as its president for a third consecutive term.

Nominees of the First National Bank remained the largest holders of Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad capital stock on Feb. 1, the list of the twenty largest stockholders of the road on that date shows. Hank Co. held 167,825 shares, unchanged from a year previously, and Gerdes Co. 61,900 shares, against 87,482.
BALTIMORE, April 22 (AP). -- Laurie Myllykangas pitched Montreal to an 11-to-1 victory over Baltimore today. He allowed nine hits and fanned five of the Birds.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Marcia Tugwell, 12-year-old daughter of Rexford G. Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, and two of her chums have opened a dog laundry at which they offer to wash dogs at prices varying with the size of the animal.

Irving Brenner, who conducts an insurance business at 16 Court Street, Brooklyn, caused a commotion yesterday outside the grand jury room when he demanded why he had been subpoenaed as a witness in Hiram C. Todd's investigation of the bribery and police brutality phases of the murder of Sam Drukman for which three men have been convicted.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Charges that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's policy from the beginning had been to create a holding company for the monopolistic control of the telephone business in this country were presented today to the Federal Communications Commission as the conclusions of the special investigators who have been conducting for it the inquiry ordered by Congress.
ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP). -- The Browns raised their batting averages and won their second game of the season today, drubbing the world champion Tigers, 12 to 4.
PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- Pennsylvania hit timely and took advantage of the wildness of rival hurlers to rout Drexel Institute on the latter's field today, 20 to 8.

A campaign for $250,000 to support the four affiliated agencies of the Queens Welfare Committee was opened last night at a dinner attended by more than 250 residents of the borough at the Queens Elks Club, in Elmhurst.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 22. -- Former Representative Franklin W. Fort, who is contending with Governor Hoffman for delegate-at-large from New Jersey to the Republican National Convention, opened his primary campaign here tonight by an attack on the Governor's handling of the Hauptmann case as an impeachment of the "integrity of the courts."

Research in the coming decade and a half will help solve the farm problem, add many new metal alloys to the thousands now in use and bring drastic changes in the tools used for working metals, J.H. Van Deventer, editor of Iron Age, told 300 delegates attending the thirty-eighth annual convention of the National Metal Trades Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

LONDON, April 14. -- Endeavour II, now under construction at Gosport, with which T.O.M. Sopwith may again challenge for the America's Cup, will not be ready for launching until the middle of June. She will therefore be absent from the opening regattas.
MOOSE RIVER, N.S., Thursday, April 22. -- Jack Simpson and George Morrell were the first men to break through to Robertson and Scadding.

The crabapple tree, which figures in several of Shakespeare's works, served as a means of tribute yesterday as seven of the species were planted in Shakespeare Garden, Central Park, on the eve of the 372d anniversary of the poet's birth.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The general level of retail food prices declined fractionally in the two weeks to April 7, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1923-25 average as 100, was 78.9, compared with 79 two weeks before and 81.2 a year ago.

ROME, April 22. -- The Italian troops on the Ogaden front after last week's Gianagobo battle continued to advance rapidly into Ethiopian territory. Today's official bulletin says they are still pushing forward all along the line and in some places have reached positions almost 100 miles from the points of departure, while the Libyan division has occupied Ducun in the Dacata Valley.
PARIS, April 22. -- Reports of concentrations of German military and semi-military detachments near the Austrian frontier were published in the newspaper Liberte here this afternoon.
All the city's future school buildings will be designed to permit the use of roofs for playground purposes, according to a policy adopted at a meeting of the Board of Education last night.

If, as has been suggested, Britain's policy in the Ethiopian crisis has been to demonstrate the futility of the League of Nations as now functioning, at the same time becoming the militant champion of world opinion, she has done very well to date. We may assume that despite her difficulties she has a purpose and a policy for the future.

SAGINAW, Mich., April 22. -- At a luncheon given here today by business men of Saginaw for officials of the General Motors Corporation, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the corporation, voiced his belief that General Motors will set a new production record of 2,000,000 motor vehicles this year and that recovery will carry over into 1937.

More than 500 members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, meeting in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, applauded a report of its committee on freedom of the press, recommending that all citizens whose private papers were seized by the Black committee of the United States Senate demand criminal prosecutions of and civil damages from "all involved in the odious affair."

John Fiorenza, confessed strangler of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, was sped yesterday through a succession of dramatic events that began with the police headquarters line-up and terminated with his imprisonment in the Tombs.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- John H. Fahey, head of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, added his voice today to the chorus of administration leaders approving the Wagner Slum-Clearance and Low-Cost Housing Bill.

BERLIN, April 22. -- There is no substantial evidence here to justify French fears regarding any immediate German intentions toward Austria, and telephone conversations with Vienna have brought the information that all is as quiet there as could be expected in Austria's permanently precarious situation.
Students in the nation's high schools and colleges raised their voices yesterday in a prayer for peace.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., April 22. -- Mrs. Myrta Morgan Hanford, former chairman of the city affairs committee of the Women's National Republican Club, of which she was a founder, died here yesterday in the Grasslands Hospital, where she had been a patient since Friday.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

After a husband and wife, who had separated, became reconciled, they were inadvertently separated from their two children for thirty hours until 6 o'clock last night. The family was finally united at the Shelter of the Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, 105 Schermerhorn Street.
NEWARK, April 22. -- The Newark Bears made it six in a row today with a 10-to-7 victory in the opener of a four-game series with the Rochester Red Wings.

With France's general elections only three days away, the franc suffered yesterday, a fresh attack of weakness in the foreign-exchange market, opening the prospect of an early renewal of gold exports from Paris to this market. The pound sterling, to which the franc is being pegged by the operations of the British Exchange Equalization Fund, also weakened, and the decline of these two major currencies carried down the exchanges of other leading countries.
BERLIN, April 22. -- The Boerse for all practical purposes was entirely inactive today.
JERUSALEM, April 22 (AP). -- Reports received by the Jewish Telegraph Agency tonight said that eight Arabs had been killed and fifty-eight others wounded in scattered outbreaks during the day.
The Bristol-Myers Company has declared the usual extra dividend of 10 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock.

Former Mayor James J. Walker, making his first radio speech since the day of his return to the United States, devoted it last night to a eulogy of the late Charles F. Murphy, for twenty-two years leader of Tammany Hall. Mr. Walker spoke from station WOR in connection with ceremonies on Saturday that will mark the twelfth anniversary of Mr. Murphy's death.

IT is the fond belief of President Ford Frick of the National League that he has cleared up one of his major problems. He had the ball players of his league puzzled when he threatened them with a $10 fine for fraternizing with players on rival clubs and then slapped $25 fines on Bartell of the Giants and Mungo of the Dodgers for fighting.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 22. -- The Citizens Commission on Reorganization of the Westchester County government, to which the Board of Supervisors on Monday passed the responsibility for drafting a new charter, returned the matter to the County Board today and curtly refused to hold further joint hearings.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., April 22. -- L.W. Baldwin, president of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, speaking here today at the annual convention of the American Society of Civil Engineers, deplored any movement for government ownership of railroads.
In the center of a rush of construction activity on the site of the new Randall's Island stadium, 140 Park Department gardeners were busily at work yesterday making lawn.

Coach Hubert Glendon sent Columbia's varsity and junior varsity crews on a time trial over the one-and-three-quarter-mile course yesterday on the Harlem River in preparation for the traditional Childs Cup Regatta with Princeton and Pennsylvania here on Saturday. No times were announced for the test over rough water, but the jayvees again gave a sterling performance, trailing the varsity by only one length.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- A proposal for a broad investigation by Congress of the anthracite industry is being prepared by the United Mine Workers of America.

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 22. -- Standing with bowed head before a flower-strewn open grave in Oak Cemetery, President Roosevelt today paid his last silent tribute to Louis McHenry Howe, former secretary and political adviser.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP). -- The galloping Longhorns from Texas, favored to carve the name of the Lone Star State in Penn relays annals for the first time, reached Franklin Field today for the forty-second renewal of the classic carnival Friday and Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The report of the Ways and Means Committee majority on the new tax measure, as presented to the House today, quotes the President's message requesting more revenue and states its own conception of what is to be accomplished. It taken goes on to explain the bill thus:

Production of steel ingots this week is only fractionally higher at 68 per cent of capacity, and the recent sharp rise appears to have been checked, according to the magazine Iron Age, issued yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP). -- The directors of the Gulf Oil Corporation of Pennsylvania shortened the organization's name today to Gulf Oil Corporation. The company will remain a Pennsylvania corporation. The directors said the action was taken because the corporation operated in more than thirty States.

It was impossible that the annual convention of newspaper publishers should ignore recent official activities in Washington and elsewhere affecting the integrity and independence of the press. Some of the things done have been startling and scandalous. The facts have been carefully collected and studied by the publishers.

THE scene is one of the most primitive cities on earth. Lions roar as the sun goes down, and jackals roam the streets. Hemmed in and hated by tens of thousands of wild tribesmen who are convinced that any one who is white is an enemy, a large company of the most high-pressure news-gatherers of the world attempt to report a war.

EDINBURGH, April 22 (Canadian Press) . -- Celtic won the Scottish Football League championship when the Glasgow Rangers, winners of the Scottish Cup, were held to a 1-1 draw by Heart of Midlothian at Tynecastle Park today. With one game to play before the season ends the Celts have 64 points while the Rangers with two fixtures left have 59.

The directors of the World's Fair elected Grover Whalen chairman of the board and voted to add the Mayor and three other city officials and one State and one Federal representative to the board at a meeting yesterday in the Empire State Club.

MONTREAL, April 22 (AP). -- Eddie Shore, the Boston Bruins' star defense man, and Elwin (Doc) Romnes, center of the Chicago Black Hawks, were awarded two of the National Hockey League's coveted trophies today.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Assets of 14,123 banks in the United States insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as of Dec. 31 last amounted to $50,917,563,000, while those of the 768 insured banks in New York State totaled $15,486,338,000, it was announced today.

By a 7-to-5 majority, a "jury" of twelve thoroughbred trainers yesterday picked Joseph E. Widener's Brevity, future-book choice, to capture the Kentucky Derby and its purse of more than $40,000 on May 2.
HAVERFORD, Pa., April 22. -- A five-run rally in the fifth inning gave Haverford College an 8-to-5 baseball victory over Stevens Tech on the winner's diamond today.

ADDIS ABABA, April 22. -- A serious insurrection among the Northern Ethiopian armies was reported unofficially in Addis Ababa today as Crown Prince Asfaou Wassen returned to the palace to resume his place as his father's deputy in the capital.
Mrs. Natalie J. Van Vieck has been elected a director of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company to succeed her mother, Mrs. Elinore I. Johnson, retired.

STOCKHOLM, April 22. -- The board of directors of the Swedish Match Company today called an extraordinary general meeting of shareholders for April 27. The only point to be discussed is a new issue of 1,100,000 B shares with a value of 27,500,000 Swedish kronor (approximately $5,500,000), thus increasing the company's share capitalization from 90,000,000 to 117,500,000 kronor.

BERLIN, April 22. -- The German Olympics Committee, having disposed successfully of the threat in various countries to participation in the games, has now gone in whole-heartedly for support of the National Socialist regime's propaganda campaign in connection with them.

Eighteen of the twenty member banks of the New York Clearing House Association voted their readiness at the time of the banking moratorium to protect the depositors of the insolvent Harriman National Bank as a fellow member, according to testimony given yesterday in the Supreme Court here by Mortimer N. Buckner, who presided at a Clearing House meeting on March 11, 1933, when the vote was taken.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 22 (AP). -- Dogaway and Fast Express, two Milky Way Farms entries, finished an easy one-two in the $2,500 added Juvenile Stakes at Arlington Downs today before a crowd of 5,000. Heelfly, a Three-D horse, placed third.
