Governor and Mrs. Lehman head the list of patrons for the annual military ball of the New York University chapter of Scabbard and Blade, national honorary military fraternity, at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night. More than 1,000 persons are expected to attend.

After prices of cotton had risen about a half cent a pound since March contracts went off the board a month ago, the first indication that the 200,000 bales of May held by the producers' pool were available to shorts appeared yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 22. -- Policemen and officers who are alleged to have been connected with the shooting and killing of Hiram Rosado and Elias Beauchamp at police headquarters after their assassination of Police Chief E. Francis Riggs on Feb. 23 were indicted today for murder by the insular grand jury, which reported to Judge Pablo Berga after an investigation of almost two months.

The tone of the stock market was improved considerably yesterday, although trading continued to be mainly professional in character. Moderate improvement early culminated in a brisk rally in the last half hour which carried the list to the day's best levels at the closing.

Two young armed thugs by means of a ruse gained the time necessary to escape from the Fashion Center Building at 525 Seventh Avenue at 2:20 P.M. yesterday after a payroll robbery which netted them $1,469.

The headquarters of the Horticultural Society of New York on the sixteenth floor of 598 Madison Avenue were transformed yesterday into a picturesque bower featuring early Spring flowers. The two-day exhibition is the sixth annual narcissus show of the Westbury Horticultural Society and is being held in this city for the first time.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Total exports from this country to Italy from January through March of this year were valued at $18,719,391, compared with $19,985,913 in the corresponding period last year, detailed figures of the Department of Commerce revealed today. This was a reduction of $1,266,522.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, who conceived the proposal to pay a pension of $200 a month to all over 60 years of age, was subpoenaed today by the Special House Committee, which is investigating his plan and directed to appear May 5.
Manhattan College's undefeated varsity nine stretched its string to four straight yesterday, beating C.C.N.Y. by a 9-to-6 score at the Lewisohn Stadium after a hectic struggle.

Eleven persons suffered shock and minor injuries, two remaining in Bellevue Hospital afterward, when a cable snapped in a descending passenger elevator in the twelve-story Manufacturers Trust Company Building, at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, at 12:30 P.M. yesterday.

BERLIN, April 22. -- Nordic paganism's strongest allies, the commanders of the Hitler Special Guards, devote the front page of their widely distributed weekly organ, the Black Corps, to an article instructing the pagans in the way they must go if they expect to avoid suppression in the interests of the State.
LONDON, April 22. -- The budget held a comparatively slight effect on prices on the London Stock Exchange today.

Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio revoked yesterday the licenses of four men charged with driving while intoxicated, among other traffic offenses. A fine of $102 was paid by one of them to avoid a term of seven days, while another chose to serve thirty-nine days rather than pay fines totaling $220.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 22. -- The Dominion Provincial Loan Council plan, proposed by the Dominion Government to salvage the credit of the Western Canadian provinces in return for control over their future expenditures, apparently is to be dropped. It is no longer practical politics.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday it had decided that for "a reasonable time" after the admittance to trading of securities stamped as assenting to a plan of reorganization under Section 77 or 77b of the Bankruptcy Act no reports of the number of assenting shares would be required of a corporation if the corporation objected to giving such information.
Latest reports on the playwrights-managers situation:

ROME, April 22. -- An additional war appropriation of 1,440,500,000 lire was published in Italy's Official Gazette today. The appropriation brings the total of the war funds thus far, as published in the Gazette, to 10,065,000,000 lire.
ITHCA, N.Y., April 22. -- Syracuse took advantage of the wildness of three Cornell pitchers and loose infield play to score an 8-to-3 victory in a chilly game today.

War never settled anything, war can never be paid for and war must be doomed by the cooperation of peoples in all lands determined to end it, George Lansbury, resigned leader of the British Labor party, declared last night before more than 2,000 persons at Carnegie Hall.

The submarine wrestlers from the New York Athletic Club continued unbeaten in soft-ball water polo last night for the fourteenth consecutive year as they climaxed their season with a relatively easy 25-to-9 victory over the Queens Central Y.N.C.A. for the national championship.
ALBANY, April 22 (AP). -- Albany blanked Buffalo, 2 to 0, at Hawkins Stadium today in a close game marked by a pitching duel between Bob Burke, Albany southpaw, and Bill Harris.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- In preparation for their drive to shove the new Tax Bill quickly through the House, the majority members of the Ways and Means Committee today filed formal recommendations for passage of the measure as introduced yesterday, but indicated at the same time that they had no intention of providing now the full amount of additional revenue sought by President Roosevelt.
Four radio programs were awarded citations as the most outstanding of the past year by the Women's National Radio Committee at its second annual "awards" luncheon at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

The New York County American Legion's entire Committee on Americanism, it became known yesterday, is prepared to resign in a body next Monday night unless it receives permission to continue distributing a booklet which has been attacked from within the ranks as "red" and praised by outsiders as "liberal."

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 22. -- Army won from Lehigh on the diamond today, 7 to 4. The visitors tied the count at 4 -- 4 in the seventh, Pennauchi's scorching triple scoring two runners. That blow drove Hines, the Cadets' startnig pitcher, from the mound.

Always in command of the situation after obtaining a cluster of four runs in the second inning, Columbia, behind Captain Johnny DeBettencourt's pitching, opened its Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League schedule with a 7-to-3-victory over Princeton at Baker Field yesterday.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the applications of fourteen corporations to list their securities on the Exchange. The issues of two companies had previously been dealt in on the New York Curb Exchange, two on out-of-town Exchanges and one over-the-counter.
Business improvement has accelerated since the beginning of March, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday.

ALBANY, April 22. -- An air of mystery was attached today to a second amendment to a key bill in a series urged by Governor Lehman and Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, to strike at racketeers through the State Income Tax Law.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The deadlock over budget appropriations was broken today when the Senate adopted the report of the joint legislative Budget Conference Committee containing the compromise terms agreed on yesterday by the representatives of the Democratic-controlled Senate and the Republican-controlled Assembly.

Returning to the form he displayed in the South, big George Earnshaw yesterday thrilled a gathering of 2,000 fans at Ebbets Field by blanking the Bees with five scattered hits while the Dodgers gathered as many runs on ten blows for a 5-0 triumph to climb out of the National League cellar once more.

In the story of the burning of five tenement houses in the Bronx there is a point that cannot escape any reader. It was repeated four times in the course of THE TIMES report. These buildings were old-law tenements, with rickety fire-escapes, wooden staircases -- in other words, they were fire traps.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 23. -- Charges purporting to be based on police information that the Russian Embassy maintains a "perfect spy network organization for preparing for war against Japan" are made in the newspaper Hochi today.

JERUSALEM, April 22. -- Tension still permeates the air throughout Palestine in the wake of the recent Arab attacks on Jews, and wild rumors are causing a panicky atmosphere everywhere. The blasting of rocks, any one running in the street or a child blowing a toy whistle is sufficient to create a state of alarm.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission dealing with data reported under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 by corporations with the request that it be withheld from publication as confidential and the treatment of such requests by the commission, have been re-written to cover annual reports now required, as well as original applications for registration of securities on exchanges.

Twenty-four hours after his arrival here Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion of the world, decided yesterday that the business of meeting Joe Louis in their fifteen-round bout at the Yankee Stadium on June 18 was too serious to permit of any sight-seeing. Accordingly, he canceled his plans for a trip to French Lick and a chance to witness the Kentucky Derby at Louisville on May 2.

Oliver Tucker, now 30 years old, who was married in 1923, when he was 16, to the former Mrs. William Simpson, now 59 years old, was paroled in West Side Court yesterday after a hearing before Magistrate Burke on a disorderly conduct charge made by his wife.

With as masterful a pitching performance as has been witnessed on any college diamond here, George Robinson, 20-year-old Fordham junior, twirled the Maroon nine to a 10-0, no-hit triumph over Upsala yesterday at Fordham Field.

Most futures were higher in light trading on the commodity markets yesterday. Sugar, coffee and hides were slightly lower. On the cash markets the grains, cotton, wooltops and cocoa advanced, while eggs, tins and quicksilver eased.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Two cruises of naval vessels, one to Europe and the other to Latin-American ports, were announced today by the Navy Department.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Political conditions in Germany and Russia are such that this country should not deport nationals of these two countries living in the United States, Senator Copeland said today in urging the enactment of the Kerr-Coolidge bill now before the Senate.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Some Democrats in the House stood up and cheered today after Representative Mitchell of Illinois, the only Negro ever to sit in the House as a Democrat, assailed the Republican party.

DOVER, Del., April 22. -- Delaware Republicans in State convention this afternoon elected nine delegates to the national convention, selected a new State committee and adopted a platform critical of the Roosevelt administration.

With the date of his retirement from the army near, Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commanding the Second Corps Area, was guest at a farewell dinner given at Governors Island last night by the Military Intelligence Reserve Society of New York.

CHICAGO, April 22. -- While receipts of hogs were somewhat in excess of trade expectations here today, prices were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher, with the top of $11 moving up 10 cents to equal the highest level since the middle of February.

CLEVELAND, April 22. -- Representative B.H. Snell of New York, minority House leader, a conservative and one of the most consistent opponents of the New Deal, was selected today to be permanent chairman of the Republican National Convention in June.

HITLER'S birthday and the birthday of Rome happened to come within twenty-four hours of each other. Celebration of the two anniversaries practically coincided, and in the process a good deal of history was scrambled on both sides of the Alps.

BERLIN, April 22. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Germany's new Supreme War Lord, today honored Colonel-General Hans von Seeckt, the creator of the Reichswehr and the man who caused .the collapse of the Hitler-Ludendorff revolt in 1923.

LONDON, April 22. -- The possibility of a long series of crushing budgets dawned upon the British public today as it studied the implications of yesterday's grim statement by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

TRENTON, N.J., April 22. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman sent out requests tonight to the leaders of the Legislature asking them to convene again as quickly as possible to do something definite about relief.

Plans mapped by the juvenile aid bureau of the Police Department for stamping out criminal habits among boys and girls will be pushed more vigorously in the future by the police, Commissioner Valentine said yesterday.

The alphabet has its ineptitudes, according to the Society of Independent Artists, who were busy yesterday hanging the paintings for their twentieth anniversary exhibition in the alphabetical order of the artists' names.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- An attempt by utility interests to compel the government to produce a secret note written by President Roosevelt to Secretary Ickes outlining the power policy to be followed by PWA was defeated in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today.

Exploiting the theory that there is nothing like blasting the enemy with plenty of shells, even if some of them miss their mark, the Giants peppered the Phillies with sixteen hits of varying lengths at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

ALBANY, April 22. -- Cemetery corporations which acquire additional property not used for burials may be required to pay taxes on their holdings, the Court of Appeals has ruled in the case of the Springfield (L.I.) Cemetery Society against the City of New York.

Despite its leadership in technical efficiency of aircraft and its clear1 supremacy in commercial air transport, the United States is in danger of being overtaken in the aviation race by other world powers.

Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, conferred here yesterday with committees of the International Seamen's Union and the seamen who are attempting to tie up Atlantic shipping by encouraging strikes of working crews.

Jerome D. Barnum, publisher of The Syracuse (N.Y.) Post-Standard, opened the discussion of freedom of the press yesterday morning at the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 22. -- Night Sprite, cast-off of Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable, turned six furlongs at Havre de Grace today in 1:12 to win the featured Hampton Roads Purse.

Reorganization of the Chicago North Western Railway may be delayed by the railroad pension and social security laws and by the pending tax bill, Fred W. Sargent, president, said yesterday. The two laws would cost the company $3,000,000 annually by 1938, he estimated.

Detailed plans for a vehicular tunnel connecting the Battery and Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, are expected to be completed some time next week and submitted to Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate, according to John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

WARSAW, April 22. -- Premier Marjan Zyndram Koscialkowski "recovered from his chill" and left this afternoon for Budapest to pay a state visit to Premier Julius Goemboes that was unexpectedly postponed Sunday after confiscation of the semi-official newspaper Gazeta Polska and a dramatic talk with foes within the regime who launched a furious attack on the government because of widespread rioting.

PARIS, April 22. -- Once more the Bourse today was under the influ ence of wild of rumors and suffered a sudden attack of nervousness. Throughout the first part of the session especially there was a quick selling wave which was laid to ex-aggregated impressions of the international situation and uncertainty regarding the outcome of the French elections.

Selection of Senator Frederick C. Steiwer of Oregon for temporary chairman of the Republican National Convention by the committee of arrangements at Cleveland Tuesday was interpreted here yesterday as preparing the way for Mr. Steiwer to become a "dark horse" candidate for the Presidential nomination.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harold Chalifoux were guests at a luncheon given at the Casino today by Dr. and Mrs. Guy Hinsdale. Miss Marion King entertained with luncheon in compliment to Mrs. E. Boyd Morrow and Miss Edith McHenry.

There is shining kinship between these resiliently poised Easter lilies which a friend has had sent as a gift directly from Bermuda and the vision above the rain-swept city at night of a silvery searchlight ray from some ship in New York Harbor that, wheeling in a vast arc through the canopy of mist, cleaves its delicate tissue keenly as the blade of Excalibur cutting a veil of white silk.

At last the intolerable suspense is over. The Republicans have picked their keynoter. This musical metaphor has crowded out the humdrum title of temporary chairman. The tropical exuberance of some keynoters has given the word an almost comic aspect, but the choice of the temporary chairman of a national convention when there is a contest for the nomination is regarded as a grave matter.

Retention of governmental protection of individualism, and the setting up of a "civil service, 1936 model," which would make a career of public office holding, were urged last night by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University. He spoke at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore concluding the annual three-day business meeting of sales executives of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, attended by 850 company representatives from the United States and Canada.
BOSTON, April 22 (AP). -- Making all except one of their six hits count, the Red Sox handed Buck Newsom his first defeat of the season today as they downed the Senators, 4 to 3.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, sponsor of the Residence Law which was passed by the Municipal Assembly over Mayor La Guardia's veto, denied yesterday a suggestion by Alderman Thomas J. Curran that the Mayor had suspended operation of the law as the result of a "deal."

GENEVA, April 22. -- The League of Nations Secretariat issued today a long document giving detailed figures on trade with Italy last November, December and January by sanctionist and non-sanctionist countries. With information already reported this document shows how and where Italy received various commodities after sanctions began and how sanctions have been changing trade channels.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 22. -- Spinach must take a back seat to escarole, kale and parsley in vitamin A value, according to a report today of the committee on science of the New Jersey Dental Society, at the opening session of the society's sixty-sixth convention at the Hotel Ambassador here. The convention will continue tomorrow.

CHICAGO, April 22. -- Continued dry weather over the greater part of the Winter wheat belt and a forecast of higher temperatures in that section started today a buying movement which lifted prices in leading United States markets around 2 cents a bushel above yesterday's final quotations, with the May delivery on the Board of Trade here reaching the highest mark since early January.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP). -- The fate of the administration's Commodity Exchange Bill was thrown into new uncertainty today when Senator Norris of Nebraska announced at a hearing of the Senate Agriculture Committee that several Senators and Representatives had told him that it could not be passed at this session unless cotton was included within its scope.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 16. -- That poetry hath charms to soothe the savage tax collector is proved in the case of a taxpayer who dispatched to R.W. Chenoweth, Commissioner of Taxation in the State of Victoria, Australia, a humorous jingle that won for him not only an answer in like vein but his requested extension of time to pay his taxes.

As a result of a flood of entries received from out-of-town drivers during the past few days, Commodore William T. Crawford Sr. of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association announced last night at a meeting of the organization at the Hotel Lexington that a record field would compete in the Albany-to-New York marathon on May 10.

In a meeting devoted exclusively to the discussion of advertising problems, the American Newspaper Publishers Association, at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon, unanimously adopted the following resolutions:

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan, predicting that the Kings County grand jury will indict five persons tomorrow for the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, caused the arrest yesterday of another suspect.
U. S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

BARTOW, Fla., April 22. -- The singing of "America" and the reading of a quotation from the American Constitution opened each meeting of the Modern Democrats, the Tampa organization whose three leaders were kidnapped and flogged on Nov. 30, causing the death of Joseph A. Shoemaker, its president.

Yankee, the America's Cup class yacht of Gerard B. Lambert, which is making her way back to this country after her Summer of racing with the English sloops last year, reported by radio yesterday that she was 1,245 miles from Boston, where she is heading to fit out for racing with Harold S. Vanderbilt's cup defender Rainbow the coming season.
MOOSE RIVER, Thursday, April 23. -- The two men entombed for ten days in the Moose River gold mine were brought to the surface early today.

Mrs. Olga Kilenyi Mead, widow of the architect, William Rutherford Mead of McKim, Mead White, who died in her apartment in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel on April 10, last, bequeathed her entire estate to the trustees of Amherst College, Amherst, Mass.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22. -- Lou Walker's effective pitching and Larry Kelley's timely batting were features in Yale's 4-2 defeat of Providence College today. Walker allowed Providence only five hits.

Hirsch Jacobs, the trainer, who for the past three years has saddled more winners than any other man, added another triple to his string at Jamaica yesterday, with Kawagoe, Pretty Busy and Miss Trophy. All of the horses carried the colors of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Whether "unsound in principle," as the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee style the new Tax Bill, or a legislative besom to sweep away "the inequity between large and small shareholders" in business (the words of the majority report), the measure has been supervised by conservative Democrats.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 22 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley said tonight the government "is going to get out of business as soon as it possibly can."

The art of Jean-Louis Forain famous French artist who died in 1931, is considerably in evidence here at the moment. The exhibition of his paintings at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, previously reported in these columns, will continue until May 2.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- A price of $5,000 was put today on the head of Alvin Karpis, rated as "Public Enemy No. 1" by Attorney General Cummings.

Admonitions to motorists and pedestrians alike were in evidence along Fifth Avenue yesterday in the form of axioms and limericks from the pen of Borough President Samuel Levy in the interest of safety on the streets of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, President-elect of Cuba, praised the good neighbor policy of President Roosevelt and Pan-Americanism at a press conference today on the occasion of his official visit to the capital.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The Senate today passed the Brownell bill extending for another year New York City's power of emergency taxation for unemployment relief, as well as three other major measures affecting the city. Altogether the Senators acted favorably on 165 bills, killed one and prepared to devote a full working day tomorrow to cleaning up the remainder of the current calendar.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Fear of another disastrous drought and an official report of sharply increased cash farm income during the first quarter of this year caused conflicting reactions today in government circles.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 22. -- Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, the national tennis champion, went down in defeat today in the Mason-Dixon championship at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

LONDON, April 22. - Britain's war debt to the United States was injected into tonight's budget debate in the House of Commons when members asked whether the government was doing anything to reach a settlement.

With a lusty and energetic performance of Otto Nicolai's opera-comique, "The Merry Wives of Windsor," in the English version of Henry E. Krehbiel, the opera department of the Juilliard School of Music opened the series of four presentations of that production to he given at the school's auditorium this week as the final offering of its season.

Again we hear Charity's challenge sounded for this community. Former Governor SMITH has put it in an imperative sentence, "Come on, New York." At least $1,500,000 must be raised to support private welfare agencies. With all our public relief, for the administration of which a more sensible and prudent program is being presented, there will be a continuing need for that virtue which is put above faith and hope.

BERLIN, April 22. -- German university students lost by a decree issued today their last hope of even limited personal freedom during at least half of their university course. The decree, issued by the chief of the National Socialist Student League, provides that all students must spend three semesters in National Socialist student homes, where they will be drilled and trained in the fundamentals of the Nazi viewpoints.

BERLIN, April 22. -- The German Foreign Ministry's semi-official organ, Diplomatische Korrespondenz, issued today the first of a series of articles taking issue with the British Blue Book [containing documents that recount the events leading up to Germany's reoccupation of the Rhineland].

Sir William Firth, British industrialist, accompanied by Lady Firth and their son, Kenneth Firth, will be among the passengers sailing tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen for Europe. Others on the ship will include:

Backed by the fine pitching of Jim Young, who struck out fifteen batsmen in going the distance, Poly Prep topped Princeton Prop's nine, 6 -- 5, in an Eastern Private Schools League struggle on Poly's diamond in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, yesterday.

On March 3 the President sent his message to Congress proposing three new taxes. One was a new processing tax on farm products, one was a so-called "windfall" tax to get back the former impounded processing taxes returned to processors by court order, and the third was a proposal for a complete revolution in our methods of taxing corporations.

The American Society of Painters, Sculptors and Gravers, whose membership includes a number of outstanding artists, has declined to participate in the international biennial art exhibition in Venice this Summer because no rent will be paid for paintings shown in the exhibition.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange fell further into the doldrums yesterday, but at the same time, exhibited a better undertone than during the first two days of the week. With pressure lifted from those sections which proved most vulnerable earlier in the week, the market did little more than mark time in the slowest trading of the month.

MARGATE, England, April 22. -- With but two more rounds remaining in the international chess tournament of the Kent County Chess Association's annual Easter congress, the deadlock for first place continues between Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba and Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia.

Operations of the Gulf Oil Corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries in 1935 resulted in a net profit of $10,551,720 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, abandonments, interest, Federal taxes and other charges, it was announced yesterday.

Activity increased in the ready-to- wear markets this week, but the business placed was regarded as only preliminary to heavy volume during the next week to ten days, Reports from retailers continued to indicate a slower pace of trading, which was expected to quicken materially with the arrival of warmer weather.

CINCINNATI, April 22 (AP). -- Calvin Chapman, utility outfielder, came to bat as a pinch hitter in the eighth inning today and stretched a long outfield drive into a home run that provided the Reds with the margin for a 7-6 victory over the Cardinals.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 22. -- Mrs. John R. Williams and her granddaughter, Miss Nancy Leiter, have left for Washington by motor. Last evening Miss Leiter entertained at dinner in the Colonial Room for Miss Polly Ingalls, Miss Ellen Bates and Mrs. Williams.

Because the committee representing insurance company and saving banks and headed by John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, has been so determined in its opposition to the Van Sweringen plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific, the announcement that it would present its own plan within a few days was greeted yesterday with interest in Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The Supreme Court was asked today to reverse the decision of the New York Court of Appeals invalidating the minimum-wage law for women and children. Assertions that the law was a proper exercise of the police powers of the State and did not contravene the Fourteenth Amendment by abridging the privileges and immunities of citizens were made in a brief filed by John J. Bennett Jr., Attorney General of New York.

Playing its best game of the season, the St. John's University baseball team scored its third straight victory in four days when it downed the Panzer College nine of East Orange, 7 to 2, at Dexter Park yesterday.

John Torrio, who abdicated from the rank of public enemy No. 1 in Chicago eleven years ago to make way for Al Capone, was arrested in White Plains yesterday on a warrant charging violation of internal revenue laws.

Twenty representatives of Pennsylvania city and State organizations, meeting yesterday at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia, adopted a resolution approving the "consumers protection label" as a symbol marking decently made coats and suits, it was announced here yesterday by the National Garment Label Council of New York, which sponsored the meeting.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- President Roosevelt returned to Washington after attending the burial of his Secretary, Louis McHenry Howe, at Fall River, Mass.

Every tourist returning to the United States through New York with a gallon of liquor in his baggage will be subject in the future to the State beverage tax, and the thousands who have brought in liquor since repeal face a retroactive levy, it was learned yesterday.

The largest public offering of securities of an industrial corporation since 1929 will be made today by fifty-four underwriters headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Edward B. Smith Co., involving $90,000,000 of new securities of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

PITTSBURGH, April 22. -- Pro posed consolidation of Methodism throughout the world, a restatement of the church's attitude on temperance and recommendations for the solution of world economic problems featured today's business session of the Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

A 798-pound mako shark was caught in Bimini waters yesterday by Norton Conway of this city, according to a message received by Orton G. Dale Jr., vice president of the Salt Water Anglers of America, from Mrs. Oliver C. Grinnell.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- In announcing today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had received bids placing a total premium of $1,540,623 on $17,460,000 of equipment trust certificates of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and thirty-six issues of 4 per cent municipal, county and district securities aggregating $4,364,200, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, expressed the belief that the result of the public offering indicated steady improvement in railroad credit and a receptive market.

The Metropolitan Opera's Spring season, which will open on Monday evening, May 11, with a performance of "Carmen," will introduce a number of new singers, bring back several artists who have been absent for several years and will include members of the regular company, Edward Johnson, the general manager, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The Union Pacific Railroad Company received today exemption from the holding-company provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 from the Securities and Exchange Commission, which found that the railroad was only incidentally a holding company had did not derive, directly or indirectly, any material part of its income from its subsidiary company, the Southern Wyoming Utilities Company, the principal business of which is that of a public utility company.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 23 (AP). -- J. Millard Hayes, Albany pitcher, walked eight men, but allowed only six hits, to give the Senators a 4-3 triumph over Buffalo today. All the hits off Hayes were made in the first four innings. It was Albany's third victory in a row and its second straight over the Bisons.

The Engineers Public Service Company will divest itself of control of the El Paso Natural Gas Company after it has exercised next week its option of $25 a share to acquire common shares of that company held under an escrow agreement, according to an announcement made yesterday.

THIS may wind up in the files at Scotland Yard where the British agents keep the records and cabinet portraits of persons dangerous to the peace or prestige of the realm. Even so, the golfers named for the United States Walker Cup team of 1936 that will waylay the Britishers at Pine Valley in early September look something like this:

After receiving successive reverses from Columbia and Temple without him as the starting pitcher, New York University's baseball team called upon Frank Fee again yesterday and he quelled Rutgers, 13 to 8, at Ohio Field to pull Coach Bill McCarthy's charges from the doldrums of their two-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP). -- Marion Zioncheck, young Washington Democrat of the House, came off second best today in a skirmish over the capital's traffic laws, involving a dozen policemen backed by one police court judge.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23. -- Two former Cabinet officers, Bainbridge Colby, Democrat, and Ogden L. Mills, Republican, predicted at a luncheon of Republican women here today that the New Deal would be repudiated at the November election if the Republicans nominated a strong candidate and backed him with a platform committed to the principles of the American system of government.
BERLIN, April 23. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet today, activity appearing only in certain specialties.

The seamen's strike committee undertook yesterday the compilation of affidavits by men who have observed conditions at sea and will submit them to Secretary of Commerce Roper in support of their charges that equipment of many American ships is defective; that living quarters for crews are inadequate, and that inexperienced men have been sent to sea in strikers' places.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation has discontinued its loop operation of buses around Gramercy Park, it was disclosed yesterday. The company is still using the streets abutting the park, however, for through operation of buses on its Lexington Avenue line.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Howell B. Erminger entertained with dinner for their daughter, Miss Bertha Erminger, and her guests tonight in the Colonnades Room at the Greenbriar.

EVANSTON, Ill., April 23. -- A meter which measures the electric voltage of nervous "shocks" in humans was demonstrated tonight to scientists arriving for the convention of the Midwestern Psychological Association.

Support for the proposed legislation which would permit owners to modernize antiquated buildings without having assessments increased accordingly was urged by speakers at a luncheon under auspices of the First Avenue Association at Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place, First Avenue at Forty-ninth Street, yesterday which was attended by representatives of more than twenty civic and taxpayers' organizations.

LONDON, April 23. -- Foremost among the questions that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden is now formulating to send to Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany for further elucidation of his peace proposals of April 1 is an inquiry as to the exact meaning of the Fuehrer's statement concerning colonies.

A proposal to divide the League of Nation into "regional leagues established on the basis of equality" was presented yesterday by Renzo Sawada, Japanese Consul General in New York, on the eve of his departure for Tokyo. Mr. Sawada addressed the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents as their guest of honor at luncheon in the Hotel Lombardy, 111 East Fifty-sixth Street.

A headlong dive by a mounted patrolman from the back of a galloping horse resulted in the capture early last night of one of two thugs who, a few minutes earlier, had made an unsuccessful attempt to hold up a patron in the washroom of Silver's Cafeteria, 562 Seventh Avenue, between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and a vice president of the American Federation of Labor, sent a letter yesterday to John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers and chairman of the committee for industrial organization, offering to contribute $100,000 to a $500,000 fund to be devoted to the organization of 400,000 steel workers.

The resources of seventy-eight community trusts in the United States and Canada in 1935 increased to $45,137,146 from $40,818,000 in 1934, according to a national year-end survey of community foundations published yesterday by the New York Community Trust, 111 Broadway.

Work on the last section of the West Side improvement from 129th to Dyckman Street will get under way this Summer, Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday. By the Fall of next year, he said, the New York Central Railroad tracks would be covered from Seventy-second to Dyckman Streets and a new express parkway would be opened linking the express highway with the Henry Hudson Parkway.
Vanguard will bring out in May the first novel in several years from the pen of M.P. Shiel. The title is "Invisible Voices."

BERLIN, April 23. -- Travelers returning from Poland are bringing back reports of the condition of Jews in that country which, in conjunction with reports of pogroms and persecution in the larger cities, present a pitiable state of affairs.
PARIS, April 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
BOSTON, April 23 (AP). -- Leo Norris and George Watkins connected for homers and between them drove in all of the runs that gave the Phillies a 5-3 triumph over the revamped Bees today.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 23. -- The 10-year-old son of an Allentown department store executive broke a kidnapper's bonds today, and tonight an Akron, Ohio, man was in jail, charged with kidnapping, as a crudely planned and executed extortion plot was swiftly thwarted by police.

Sweet revenge for the rough treatment by Colonel Bill Terry and his Giants at the opening Polo Grounds series came to Casey Stengel's band and the Flatbush fans among the 18,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Dodgers passed their rivals in the tenth to win a thriller, 4 -- 3.
Apartment and business properties changed hands in the urban realty deals reported yesterday.
MOOSE RIVER, N.S., April 23. -- Fresh air and hospital treatment tonight speeded recovery of two men dramatically rescued from a gold mine after a horrifying ten-day entombment.

Walter Dette reports that examination of the stomach contents of trout taken on the Beaverkill this week showed an abundance of stone fly nymphs. He says an imitation of this nymph is being used as a lure to good avail and believes it should be effective for some time to come.

More than 500 persons at the United States Customs semi-annual auction of unclaimed goods, faced a variety of goods and merchandise yesterday when the session opened at 10 o'clock in the Appraiser's Stores at 201 Varick Street.

CAIRO, April 23. -- Baron Everhard von Stohrer, the German Minister to Egypt, and his automobile mechanic were found today by a British Royal Air Force plane after five days' search by land and air over the desert.

No great power is more conciliatory in its present European foreign policy than Soviet Russia. Its recent prompt and cordial support of the request of the Turkish Republic to be allowed to fortify the Dardanelles -- forbidden by the Treaty of Lausanne of 1923 -- is a complete reversal of the traditional Czarist insistence on the "freedom of the Straits," which repeatedly endangered the peace of Europe during the nineteenth century.

The French franc fell further yesterday to 6.58 1/4 cents, a price which should permit exports of gold from Paris to New York, and closed at 6.58 1/2 cents, off 1/8 point. Although the franc fell below the gold point, as it is now calculated, no engagements of gold in Paris were reported and transactions continued relatively small.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23. -- Ralph M. Jones, vice president of the Utica Knitting Company, was re-elected president of the Underwear Institute at the annual meeting in the Commercial Museum today. Vice president Benjamin Russell of the Russell Manufacturing Company was also re-elected, as was Oscar W. Gridley, treasurer.

It will be a long time before citizens of New Jersey recover something of the pride they once had in the State. The Governor's strange interference with the course of justice was followed by an extraordinary display of legislative futility. Weeks ago Governor HOFFMAN put before the Legislature the necessity of providing funds for relief. Shifty expedients would no longer do.

John Torrio, former Chicago gang boss, now rated as New York's Public Enemy No. 2, was held in $100,000 bail by United States Commissioner Isaac Platt yesterday on a charge of conspiring to defraud the government of 2250,000 in liquor taxes between Dec. 11, 1933, and last March 28.

The statement of the country's foreign trade in March, published by the Commerce Department Tuesday, showed again a surplus for the month of merchandise imports over exports. In February, when the excess of imports was $10,191,000, it was remarked that this was the first import-surplus month since last July and the first of such adverse balances to occur in February since 1926.

Mrs. Robert R. Livingston sat on a bale of excelsior in a stately living room stripped of its appointments yesterday afternoon and told of her departure from the old red brick home at 11 Washington Square North which was built by her grandfather, Thomas Suffern, and has been in continuous possession of her family for 103 years.
PARIS, April 23. -- A copy of the questions Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain is going to put to Germany has been received here and, it is stated, has given satisfaction to the Quai d'Orsay.

Untold obstacles appeared before the State Tax Commission yesterday in its announced determination to levy a tax of $1 a gallon on all liquor brought in from foreign ports by returning tourists and other travelers. Customs lawyers pronounced the tax unconstitutional and declared that many protests had been received from their clients, with the implication that the tourist "importers" would fight the levy through court action.

MARGATE, England, April 23. -- Gaining an additional half point as a result of his play with G. Stahlberg of Stockholm in the eighth and semi-final round today, Jose R. Capablanca of Havana assumed the lead temporarily in the international tournament of the Kent County Chess Association's annual congress at the Grand Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Secretary Hull today disavowed any political implications in the fact that President Roosevelt is serving as honorary president and Secretaries Swanson, Dern and himself as honorary vice presidents of the American Olympic Committee.

Miss Cornelia R. Trowbridge, 67 years old, a sister of James R. Trowbridge, president of the Franklin Savings Bank, plunged six stories to her death yesterday morning from her room on the eighth floor of the Women's University Club, 106 East Fifty-first Street, near Park Avenue.

ALBANY, April 23. -- The fashionable Goldens Bridge Hounds Club has paid $8,000 to the State Conservation Department because forty deer were killed out of season. The deer were killed when the club's fox-hunting pack preferred to chase them instead of Reynard.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, will open today the largest WPA sewing shop in New York City on the third and sixth floors of the Old Siegel-Cooper Building at 45 West Eighteenth Street. The shop, occupying 65,000 square feet of floor space and equipped with 880 electrically operated sewing machines, will employ 3,000 women in two daily work periods.

Midtown stores continued to be in active demand yesterday, according to reports on commercial rentals received from brokers in that district. New tenants were found for a number of buildings along Broadway. Among the leases were several made by clothing and jewelry firms.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 23. -- A plea for better selection of college students, higher tuition fees, and more excellence in training to counteract "factory methods" in American colleges, which he said were producing "second-raters and half-educated panhandlers and boondogglers," was made today by Dr. William P. Few, president of Duke University, before a University of Chattanooga semi-centennial celebration audience.

Plans for a new association for the defense of principles of religious liberty were discussed and a tentative organization was effected yesterday at a meeting of a group of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders at the Empire State Club in the Empire State Building.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics routed Wes Ferrell today and behind the three-hit pitching of Harry Kelley walloped the Boston Red Sex, 9 to 1, for their second victory of the season.

Domestic corporate bonds on the New York Stock Exchange were subjected to another wave of selling yesterday, and prices suffered the sharpest declines since March 13. While the higher grade investment issues, including Treasury loans, held steady to firm in quiet trading, the more speculative corporate issues again were influenced by the weakness in junior securities and yielded easily on a moderate turnover.

Highly effective relief work by the left-handed Ted Kleinhans stemmed a sixth-inning Washington rally at the Stadium yesterday and the Yankees went on to down Bucky Harris's Senators, 10 -- 6. Thus, for the first time this year, the McCarthymen found themselves above the .500 mark, with better hopes for the future.
MEXICO, D.F., April 23 (AP). -- Persons arriving here tonight by airplane from Nicaragua reported a revolt had broken out in Honduras and that bloody fighting was going on.

The Chase National Bank, as plaintiff in a foreclosure suit, yesterday bid in for $776,000 the eighteen-story office building at 505 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of Forty-second Street. The action was against the Park Avenue Operating Company, Inc., and others for about $1,140,253 due, with taxes, , totaling about $18,413.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Senator Robinson on prospects for adjournment of Congress, began preparation of the speech he will deliver in New York Saturday, and requested appropriations of Congress totaling $460,800,000 for the Social Security and Old-Age Pension systems.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP). -- In the first open communication between candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination, Senator William E. Borah today asked Colonel Frank Knox if he approved efforts the Idahoan said were being made to persuade convention delegates from Illinois to "disregard the wishes of the people."
The United States will not participate in the international art exhibition in Venice, Italy, this Summer as had been planned, it was learned yesterday.

The presidents of the leading Eastern railroads decided yesterday to reduce their passenger fares on June 2 to 2 cents a mile for coaches and 3 cents a mile for Pullman cars as required by an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission issued on Feb. 28.

Affording a "positive program" instead of "negative drifting," the revised Ellenbogen bill for a "little Federal Trade Commission" in the textile industry will have the major effects of leveling off potential ever-production and stabilizing market conditions, Peter Van Horn, president of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., said yesterday at a special meeting of rayon and silk manufacturers called to consider the bill at the Hotel Astor.
Building plans filed yesterday included an $85,000 apartment house and a $50,000 parochial school for the Bronx. Details of the projects were as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Edwin S. Smith, a member of the National Labor Relations Board, urged the La Follette subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today to investigate "anti-Red hysteria" as part of the movement for suppression of civil rights and of the freedom of labor to organize.

The Hamburg-American liner New York will arrive today from Hamburg, Southampton, Cherbourg and Cobh. Her passengers include Lord Horder, physician-in-ordinary to King Edward VIII of England, who is coming here to read scientific papers before several medical societies.

NEWARK, N.J., April 23. -- The Bears climbed into first place in the International League today when they defeated Rochester, 3 to 0, while Montreal was losing to Baltimore. It was Newark's seventh straight victory.

BARTOW, Fla., April 23. -- How Tampa policemen forced him into an automobile in front of police headquarters and delivered him to the gang which administered a flogging and tarring and feathering was told in court today by Eugene F. Poulnot, one of three victims.

MOSCOW, April 23. -- Soviet realism in world affairs is showing itself in obvious, though not openly avowed, lukewarmness toward the application of sanctions against Italy unless there is to be complete assurance that effective sanctions will be applied against any aggressor in the future -- with Germany, of course, specifically in mind.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 23. -- For intelligence and loyalty to his 2-year-old mistress, Rex, a police dog, received a medal tonight at a testimonial dinner given at a downtown hotel by the Rochester Anti-Vivisection Society.

While there were indications in Broadway circles that the playwrights and managers might yet get together and compromise their differences over the form of a new play-producing contract, a majority group of managers, represented by the League of New York Theatres, made public yesterday the terms of the alternative contract which they have drawn up and pledged themselves to use in protest against the present minimum basic agreement of the Dramatists Guild.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 23. -- Of the seventy amateur musicians competing for places on the program of the twelfth annual Westchester Music Festival, Miss Sophie Pratt Bostelmann, 20 years old, of Hastings-on-Hudson, was selected as the instrumentalist and Mrs. Helen Wagner Sniffin of White Plains as the singer, judges announced this afternoon.

GORDON SINCLAIR is the John O'Hara, the James M. Cain, the Walter Winchell of the travel book writers. He seems to write by nature on the rocket principle with a kick in every line. His "Khyber Caravan" (Farrar Rinehart, $3) is one of the easiest to read and most amusing books of the Spring.

The Salvation Army was praised last night as an agency doing "valiant work" in curbing the "spirit of dependency" fostered in many persons by the depression, at a dinner given at the Hotel Plaza. The speaker was Henry W. Taft, attorney and member of the dinner committee.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- A bill to provide complete independence and sovereignty for Puerto Rico was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland, chairman of the Committee of Territories and Insular Affairs.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23. -- Evidence that there exists in the living body a system of automatic time-clocks, which are wound up by heredity at the beginning and inexorably determine the life-span of the individual, was presented here today before the annual meeting of the American Philosophical Society, the oldest scientific body in America, founded in 1727 by Benjamin Franklin.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Put together the legislative records of Republican Keynoter Steiwer and Permanent Chairman Snell, and the outcome will be political scrambled eggs. Throw the Cleveland platform into the pot, and there will be an explosion.

ADDIS ABABA, April 23. -- Ethiopian patrols announced today that the Italian troops were nowhere near the Robi River. It seems the invaders have penetrated no further than Ras Kabada's province of Ephrata, fifty miles south of Dessye, if that far. No fighting was reported between here and Dessye.

The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday that the first quarter of this year had been the most profitable first quarter in its history and that it had been surpassed only by the last quarter of last year. The directors declared a dividend of $1.50 a share on its common stock, the largest distribution ever ordered for one quarter.

BALTIMORE, April 23 (AP). -- The Orioles combined Joe Bivin's pitching and some healthy hitting today to beat the Royals, 7 -- 5. The victory was Bivin's second in as many starts. He allowed only seven hits, but one of them was Seeds's homer in the first with one on.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The names of underwriters and the total of securities written by each were given today in an amendment filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation to its registration statement for the issuance of $65,000,00 of 4 1/2 per cent series bonds and $45,000,000 of serial bonds. The list follows:

In your editions of April 21 and 22 there were published dispatches from Managua, Nicaragua, and San Jose, Costa Rica, respectively, informing of certain invasions of revolutionary forces into the territory of the republic of Honduras.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution adopted today strongly phrased resolutions for the defense of this country from military invasion and for the preservation of the Constitution from amendments now which would result in a change in the form of government.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Early administration moves to simplify the pending tax measure and increase the yield were forecast at the Capitol today as the House began consideration of the bill presented by its Ways and Means Committee.

Formal declaration of interest payments at the rate of $4.75 a $1,000 bond, in settlement of the two oldest unpaid coupons, will be announced today by the Autonomous Institute for the Amortization of the Public Debt of the Republic of Chile on thirteen direct and guaranteed external loans of the republic, outstanding in the principal amount of more than $200,000,000.

Dr. Clyde Fisher, head of the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History, announced yesterday that, after photographing the solar eclipse in Russia next June, he plans to cross the Ural Mountains to visit the meteor craters in Siberia formed in 1908 by the greatest fall of meteoric bodies in recent years.

Three young men, one of them a taxicab driver, were held in Queens early this morning on charges of sending a letter to a furniture dealer threatening to kidnap his 12-year-old son unless he paid them $800.

GENEVA, April 23. -- "Cause for anxiety" was seen today in Latin American proposals for a Pan-American League of Nations by Hans Oersted of Denmark, spokesman for the employers' group in the governing body of the International Labor Office.

LONDON, April 23. -- Jack Petersen retained his BritiSh and Empire heavyweight championship tonight by outpointing Jock McAvoy in a fifteen-round bout. McAvoy, weighing 178, spotted Petersen twelve pounds.

The stock market suffered yesterday its widest decline of the year when increased offerings in most sections of the list sent leading issues down 1 to 4 points -- three down 6 1/2, 8 and 13 3/4 points. The climax was reached at 2:30 o'clock, and in the remaining half hour the market steadied as the selling pressure was relaxed.

Following is the text of the amended resolution on freedom of the press, attacking the Black lobby investigating committee and the Federal Communications Commission for the seizure of private papers of publishers and other citizens, as adopted yesterday by the American Newspaper Publishers Association in convention at the Waldorf-Astoria:

A marital quarrel ended violently yesterday morning for Randolph J. Kruger, 36 years old, a real estate broker, when he was stabbed seven times by his wife, Loretta, 32, in the bedroom of their home at 1,415 East Thirty-fourth Street, in the Flatbush district of Brooklyn.

Lower prices for anthracite coal, butter and steers more than offset advances in the grains and flour, and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined 0.5 point to 123.9 on Tuesday from 124.4 the Tuesday previous.

The annual competition for the coveted George D. Pratt Medal of Achievement for Professional Gardeners developed into a keen race between two men yesterday at the closing session of the sixth annual narcissus show of the Westbury Horticultural Society.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- A plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific System, drawn up by the protective committee for holders of first and refunding mortgage bonds, of which John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, is chairman, and which would reduce the capital structure of the new company $144,036,643 under that fixed by the Van Sweringen proposal, was submitted late today at the reorganization hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Members of the Stock Exchange were inclined to attribute a considerable part of the weakness of yesterday's stock market to the belated realization by brokers and their customers that the Federal Reserve Board's margin regulations effective on next Friday would virtually double the Exchange's present minimum margin requirements.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 23. -- In the Century Purse, feature today at Havre de Grace, Colonel E.R. Bradley's green-and-white silks were carried to victory for the first time this Spring. The victory was scored by the Preakness candidate, Bow and Arrow.
An order prohibiting homework in the men's and boys' outer clothing industry was issued yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 23. -- Under the title "No More Leagues of Nations," El Mercurio editorially maintained today that there was absolutely no basis of truth in the rumor circulating in South American republics that the coming Pan-American conference at Buenos Aires might lead to the creation of some sort of Pan-American League of Nations.

Newspaper publishers were urged yesterday to fight any efforts of governmental officials or advertisers to restrict the freedom of radio broadcasting, on the ground that freedom of the air as well as freedom of the press is essential to the maintenance of American liberty and democracy.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 22, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,482,000,000, a decrease of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $5,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Wholesale prices increased in the week ended on April 18, offsetting the losses in March, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average as 100, rose to 79.7, compared with 79.5 the week before and 80.3 a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23. -- With every prospect of a lightning-fast track and many new records, the forty-second annual University of Pennsylvania Relay Carnival gets under way on Franklin Field tomorrow afternoon.
CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP). -- The Indians returned to first place in the American League standing today by blasting six runs behind Johnny Allen's hurling to defeat the White Sox, 6 to 0.
TORONTO, April 23. -- In a special dispatch from its Montreal correspondent, The Financial Post, in its issue for April 25, says:

LONDON, April 23. -- Winston Churchill deeply stirred the House of Commons today with new revelations of the extent of German rearmament and with the solemn prophecy that the next four years would decide the future of Europe.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP). -- Larry French won a southpaw hurling duel with Fred Birkofer today, the Cubs gaining a 2 -- 1 decision over Pittsburgh. French set the Pirates down with six hits for his second victory of the season.
Centralization of power in government was attacked yesterday by Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago newspaper publisher, during a luncheon address in the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue.

The unsympathetic attitude of many New York policemen toward boys is an important contributing factor to juvenile delinquency, it was charged last night by boys who took part in a forum meeting on "Why We Get Into Trouble" at the Red Cross Building, 321 Lexington Avenue. Nearly 100 boys, some of them former inmates of reformatories and all of them members of various boys' organizations, participated.

Without doubt the fencer who will be watched with the keenest interest in the women's national foils championship a the Fencers Club tonight is Mrs. Bela de Tuscan, young wife of Detroit's only fencing master and the most improved contender on this season's strips.

Misses' coats and suits with an increase of 42.7 per cent led sales gains last month in local department stores, according to the departmental analysis issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Improved sales over March, 1935, were reported for fifty-two out of sixty-six departments. Inventories during the month were lower in twenty-five departments.

ANGORA, Turkey, April 23. -- Although the answers to the Turkish note from all signatories of the Straits convention, notably Italy, have not yet reached Angora, the generally sympathetic tone of the replies thus far received and the favorable foreign press comment regarding the motives actuating Turkey have created the impression here that serious objection will not be encountered to proposals for modification of the convention.

CINCINNATI, April 23 (AP). -- Billy Myers, Reds' shortstop, whose error enabled St. Louis to tie the score in the eighth inning, redeemed himself in the tenth today by hitting a home run with Gilly Campbell on base, thus leading Cincinnati to an 8-to-6 victory over the Cardinals.
A new issue of $600,000 of notes of Everett, Mass., will be offered for sale on next Wednesday. They will be dated April 29, and become payable on Nov. 12.

The Brooklyn Edison Company, Inc., filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission an application for permission to issue $55,000,000 aggregate principal amount of 3 1/4 per cent mortgage bonds due in 1971, to refund $55,007,000 of outstanding 5 per cent general mortgage bonds.

Miss Cornelia Meigs, Assistant Professor of English Composition at Bryn Mawr College, received a check for $300 for her prize-winning children's story "Fox and Geese" at a tea given yesterday at the Hotel Chatham. More than 150 authors, editors, librarians and others active in the children's book world were present.
ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP). -- The Browns bowed humbly to the Tigers today, 10 to 0, after twice routing the world champions.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Representatives of the building industry today opposed the financing provisions of the Wagner slum-clearance and low-cost-housing bill before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor. They advocated that capital grants from the Federal Government be stopped, and warned against government competition with private industry.

Indictment of John Florence, the 24-year-old ex-convict and upholsterer's helper who has confessed the slaying of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, will be asked of the New York County grand jury today, District Attorney William C. Dodge announced yesterday.

Ellis H. Parker Jr., son of the widely known Burlington County, N.J., detective, and four other men were indicted yesterday by the Kings County grand jury in Brooklyn. They were jointly charged with kidnapping Paul H. Wendel, disbarred Trenton lawyer, and with second degree assault on him.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Robert E. Clements, one of the founders of the Townsend $200-a-month old-age pension plan, admitted to the special House committee today that in a little more than two years he received in salaries, dividends and expenses more than $77,000 as a direct result of his connection with the movement.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company denied at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission charges of special investigators that the company had made millions of dollars for itself at the expense of its associated companies.

ALBANY, April 23. -- Speeding ahead in the hope of clearing the decks for final adjournment by the end of next week, the Senate passed seventy-seven bills today, including measures tightening the laws on drunken driving, changing utility statutes and creating a Long Island Rapid Transit Authority which would be permitted to take over and operate the entire Long Island system.

Dr. George Vincent, former president of the Rockefeller Foundation; Raymond Rubicam, chairman of the board of Young Rubicam; Thomas H. Beck, president of Crowell Publishing Company, and Clarence Francis, president of General Foods Corporation, will be speakers at the annual convention of the American Association of Advertising Agents at the Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., on April 30 to May 2.
WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Dr. Miguel Gomez, President-elect of Cuba, concluded his visit to Washington this evening after being entertained as guest of honor at a tea at the White House.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Between brief conferences today with Congressional leaders, including Senator Robinson, the majority leader, and the Cabinet, President Roosevelt began preparing the speech he is scheduled to deliver in New York City on Saturday night before the National Democratic Club.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The determination of the administration to curb the functions and activities of holding companies, first given concrete expression in the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Act of 1935, which is now under attack in the courts, was further emphasized today by the attitude of House tax leaders toward a provision in the new revenue bill aimed directly at holding company pyramids.
LONDON, April 23. -- Margaret Rawlings tonight repeated her New York success as Mrs. O'Shea, the role she created in the late Elsie Schauffler's "Parnell." Wyndam Goldie was in the name part.

Although trading in the wool goods markets was quiet last week, sentiment turned more optimistic, as prices continued to hold strongly after three to four weeks of inactivity, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

CHICAGO, April 23. -- Prices of hogs were generally steady in the early trading today, with weights under 230 pounds in fair demand. As soon as the urgent orders were filled, however, the market turned easy, and final sales were 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight lower, with weights over 250 pounds weakest.

Toscanini conducted his last Thursday concert with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday evening in Carnegie Hall. Very appropriately, the program was the one he presented when he made his debut with this organization ten years ago, on Jan. 14, 1926. Only the order of the compositions was changed.

Futures, generally, were lower yesterday in the local commodity markets in sympathy with the weakness in stocks. Coffee and silk were particularly weak. On the cash markets wheat, cotton and wool tops rose, while declines appeared in the other grains, lard, tins, cocoa, Santos coffee, rubber and silk.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 23. -- Ellis H. Parker denied flatly today that he had any knowledge of the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel.

Who has forgotten the dire prophecies made last January when AAA was declared to be unconstitutional? Some members of Congress described that event as a national calamity and freely predicted that the bottom would fall out of the market for agricultural products, with a consequent tremendous loss of farm income.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, April 23. -- This Warwickshire town today honored its greatest son, William Shakespeare, with a birthday celebration that lacked nothing of warm-hearted enthusiasm for having become traditional.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The country's major cities are preparing to care for at least 500,000 employable jobless without Federal aid during the next fiscal year, Sherwood L. Reeder, assistant director of the United States Conference of Mayors, announced here today.

Five men, including a physician, it was revealed in District Attorney Dodge's office yesterday, have been arrested in the last three days in an investigation of alleged fraudulent practices in workmen's compensation insurance claims. Other arrests are expected.

THE NEW YORK TIMES on April 17 published a dispatch from St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, which would indicate that I have crossed swords with Dr. Ernest Gruening, Director of the Division of Territories and Island Possessions.

A Republican and a Democratic member of the House Ways and Means Committee debated the new corporation surplus tax program last night in the weekly program of America's Town Meeting of the Air. Representative Allen T. Treadway of Massachusetts, ranking Republican member, said the bill would undermine the whole business structure, but Representative Frank H. Buck of California, an administration spokesman, declared it was a bulwark for small business.

Following the temporary recession of the preceding week, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday resumed their upward movement, the total for twenty-two leading cities reaching $6,207,962,000, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was 33.3 per cent above the total of $4,658,605,000 a year earlier and $1,134,977,000 more than the week before.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas for the week ended April 18 showed a decrease of 12 per cent under the corresponding week last year, it was reported yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The decline reflects the effect of the earlier date of Easter this year, the comparative week last year being the one immediately preceding Easter.

Let the memory drift back to 1906 when 1,100 men lost their lives in the Courrieres coal-mine catastrophe in France, and to the explosion which in 1907 killed 358 men in the Monongah mine in West Virginia, and it is evident that the Moose River disaster is not of historic importance to the mining engineer.

Passenger traffic on the Interborough Rapid Transit System increased 14,500,909 during the nine months ended on March 31, compared with the number of riders in the corresponding period of the preceding fiscal year, according to Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, in his current report, filed with the Federal court.

Just back from California, Max Gordon reveals casually that he is the owner of "The Aunt of England," the Cosmo Hamilton-Anthony Gibbs play which Haidee Wright acted last season in London. He is not rushing it to Broadway, though.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 23. -- The winning streak of Miss Eunice Dean came to an end today on the clay courts of the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

With the drought in Oklahoma relieved only slightly by Tuesday's light showers, prices for cotton of the new crop recovered yesterday 1 to 5 points on the Cotton Exchange here. Near deliveries continued to advance under aggressive trade price-fixing operations in advance of notices on next Tuesday, the May selling at 11.59 cents a pound and the July at 11.30, the highest quotation recorded since Dec. 9.
JERUSALEM, April 23. -- After a week of serious racial disturbances, Palestine was fearful tonight of possible future disorders.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., in its first annual report since that for 1931, discloses a net profit for the fiscal year ended on Dec. 28, 1935, of $3,153,167, after all charges, including depreciation, Federal taxes and interest but before a special inventory reserve of $2,500,000.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, speaking tonight at Constitution Hall, urged the Daughters of the American Revolution to "insist upon the wider use of fingerprinting, especially of those entrusted with public welfare."

TRENTON, N.J., April 23. -- In answer to the State-wide demand for immediate action on the relief question and with its chamber still occupied tonight by a group of unemployed holding a burlesque session, the New Jersey Assembly will meet tomorrow morning.
ALBANY, April 23. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today urging action at this session to remove the stigma of illegitimacy from children born out of wedlock.

After more than two months of negotiations, during which there had been a deadlock on all points at issue, indications last night pointed to a new agreement between the joint conference of anthracite operators and representatives of the United Mine Workers.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 23 (AP). -- Mayor La Guardia of New York City, in a speech here today before the conference of Mayors, characterized the Bonneville Dam as providing another step toward "liberating the people of this country from the clutches and control and monopoly of public utility companies."
Numerous housing deals in Brooklyn and Queens were reported yesterday.

Speaking on "The Newspaper of Tomorrow," Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Graduate School of Journalism of Columbia University told more than 1,000 of the country's leading newspaper publishers, editors, business executives and their guests last night that the press must remain firmly on guard to make certain that the newspaper of tomorrow remains just as free and independent an institution as that of today.

MEXICO, D.F., April 23. -- Five thousand Catholics who had journeyed here in special trains from Vera Cruz to petition President Lazaro Cardenas to bring about the opening of the legal number of churches and the functioning there of the number of priests authorized by law, paraded peacefully before the National Palace this morning.

JERUSALEM, April 23. -- Although there have been no major disorders in Palestine in the past two days high tension still prevails. The police are taking every precaution in Jerusalem, where, it is strongly rumored, thousands of Arabs are coming tomorrow from surrounding villages at the invitation of Haj Amin el Husseini, who is Mufti of Jerusalem and president of the Moslem Supreme Council, supposedly for Moslem Sabbath prayers at the Mosque of Omar.

The American I.G. Chemical Company declared yesterday extra dividends of $1 a share on the common stock and 10 cents a share on the Class B common, in addition to the regular payments of $1 a share on the common and 10 cents a share on the B stock.

The Treasury continued this week to make large disbursements out of funds previously acquired, with the effect of raising member-bank reserves $109,000,000 and lifting the excess of reserves over requirements $90,000,000 to a total of $2,640,000,000, according to the weekly Federal Reserve report of Wednesday, published yesterday.

ALBANY, April 23. -- Efforts to obtain enactment of a law providing free bus transportation for pupils of parochial schools such as those in public institutions now have were renewed in the Legislature today with introduction of a new bill.

The word is coming into high favor again. It is reappearing in political writings and speeches. There it serves as a substitute for thought, or definition, just as MACAULAY said that a long word of Greek derivation often did. "Reactionary" frequently occurs as a form of epithet, a convenient kind of condemnation applied to a man or a political party.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway plans to effect a saving of $196,000 in interest charges annually by the sale of $40,362,000 of 3 1/2 per cent Series D sinking-fund refunding and improvement mortgage bonds. Application for authorization of the financing is to be filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission within a few days.

BERLIN, April 23. -- The National Socialist regime will dedicate tomorrow with appropriate ceremonies three newly built "castles of the National Socialist order," which, despite the medieval connotation of their name, really represent a new type of school, namely, a school for political leadership.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Deficiency appropriations of $195,800,000 for the Social Security Board for the current and coming fiscal years as well as an appropriation of $265,000,000 for the Old Age Reserve Account to be set up during 1937 under the same law have been asked by President Roosevelt.

For the energy and resourcefulness displayed in the Titterton case there is praise enough to go around. This will hold as between Police Commissioner VALENTINE'S men and the District Attorney's office, and within the Police Department as between the straight detective work and the scientific research.

An additional indictment, charging compulsory prostitution on ninety counts, against Charles (Lucky) Lucania and twelve co-defendants in the city's vice ring was handed up yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook by the extraordinary grand jury investigating racketeering in New York County.

MOOSE RIVER, N.S., April 23. -- I was the first man to reach and the first man to speak to Dr. D.E. Robertson and Alfred Scadding after digging through the rock to the 150-foot level of the Magill Mine, where they were caught.
