The good impression Seabiscuitt created by finishing ahead of Hollyrood last Saturday was pretty well dissipated yesterday at Jamaica when he brought up third in a field of four after a six-furlong dash which was further preparation for the Kentucky Derby or whatever other engagements the season holds for this Wheatley Stable color bearer.

Confronted with the prospect that the new Federal Reserve margin regulations governing banks, effective on next Friday, would compel brokers and their customers to maintain maximum margins at all times, regardless of a declining market, officials of the New York Stock Exchange prepared yesterday to increase that market's minimum margin requirements.

CHICAGO, April 23. -- The spirit of NRA continues to march on within the governmental agencies through attempts to control distribution of goods and profits, Wilson Compton secretary and manager of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, declared today at the annual meeting of the group.
LONDON, April 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP). -- A spokesman for the Grain Futures Administration proposed today a conciliatory amendment to the Commodity Exchange Bill in an effort to break a Senate deadlock over the measure.

Scoring nine runs in the first inning, Jamaica High School's baseball team conquered Flushing yesterday, 10 to 8, for its third straight triumph of the season. Seven singles and five errors marked the opening drive in the Queens Division P.S.A.L. game at Flushing.

ROME, April 23. -- Today's war bulletin indicates Italian troops on the southern Ethiopian front have almost finished taking up positions for a big battle designed to put them in possession of Sasa Baneh and Daggah Bur, thus opening the way to Harar.

Morris Shappes, a teacher of English for the last eight years at City College, reported to be a member of the Communist party, was notified yesterday by Professor Charles Francis Horne, head of the English Department, that his name had not been included in the list of recommendations to the Board of Higher Education for reappointment.

TOKYO, April 24. -- The "unification" of Japan's foreign policy was carried a stage further today when the Cabinet sanctioned informal weekly conferences on foreign affairs between the Foreign, War and Navy Ministers.

Federal Judge John C. Knox reserved decision yesterday on motions to dismiss four suits aggregating $4,225,807 against the Chase National Bank as a branch of the treasury of the Philippine Islands. The suits asserted that the money was national bank assets illegally transferred to the War Department, which disposed of them through the Chase Bank.

With the situation between the managers and playwrights approaching what Broadway believes to be a climax, two more of the large film-producers have gone on record opposing the terms of the present Dramatists Guild contract.
BOSTON, April 24 (AP). -- Danny MacFayden held the Philies to six hits while striking out seven today to give the Bees a 4-1 victory and an even break in the two game series.

It is increasingly clear that, in the eyes of many of its advocates, the proposed tax on undistributed corporation profits is more important as a "reform" than as a revenue measure. The Treasury, indeed, has not even attempted to estimate what revenue it will bring in as at present drawn.

Marvels of growing science of criminal detection through laboratory analyses were described to the Teachers Chemistry Club by E.P. Coffey, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation laboratory, at a meeting in Rockefeller Center last night.

ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP). -- The tremendous clouting and sparkling fielding of the Tigers were so outstanding today in the world champions' 9-to-3 defeat of the Browns that Beau Bell's ninth-inning home run for the home team received scant notice.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Wheat prices fluctuated in an erratic manner again today on the Board of Trade. They sold off after a firm opening, only to rally around 1 1/2 cents a bushel from the inside level and closed with net gains of 5/8 to 7/8 cent, the May leading.

I am always amused at the personality studies made by psychologists, and the report on John Fiorenza is a gem. I know a dozen professional men and women who fit that picture exactly. Many newspaper people I know must be crazy too. Apparently what passes for genius in literary men and women is abnormality -- or subnormality -- in less educated persons.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP). -- In a statement from his campaign headquarters here tonight Colonel Frank Knox, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, urged that the national government "take the postoffice out of politics."

HAVANA, April 24. -- Seven students charged with forming an illegal university students' committee and promoting an island-wide strike among students to obstruct the opening of Havana University, set for May 10 were acquitted at their trial today.

Finding that The Associated Press had engaged in unfair labor practices under the Wagner Labor Act, Dean Charles E. Clark of Yale Law School, trial examiner for the Labor Relations Board, recommended yesterday that the news service be required to reinstate Morris Watson in its employ and to negotiate with the American Newspaper Guild as representative of its editorial employes.

Directors of the Seaboard Oil Company of Delaware voted yesterday to declare a quarterly dividend of 25 cents, placing the stock on an annual basis of $1. The company previously had paid 15 cents quarterly and an extra of 10 cents.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $27,602,463, representing one State and fifty-nine lesser political divisions. The revised total of offerings made this week is $22,391,555, and the weekly average for the year to date is $23,674,876.

The marketing of $90,000,000 of securities of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company on Thursday lifted the new bond financing of this week to $159,718,910 from the $41,068,000 offered last week. A. year ago this week $112,310,000 in new bonds was placed on the market.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP). -- A surprise move in the Senate to offer independence to Puerto Rico received administration backing today after a spokesman for the Puerto Rican Liberal party had denounced the plan as a "hold-up" to "obtain a popular mandate for continuation of American rule."

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP). -- Representative Hancock, Republican, of New York, said today that he would introduce a "very timely" amendment to the Constitution to "repeal the immunity of Congressmen from arrest, except for treason, felony and breach of the peace."
Urban realty trading reported yesterday was light, the deals including West Side dwellings and Brooklyn properties.

BERLIN, April 24. -- All exchange students and other German students going abroad to study must now undergo in advance special training in the principles of National Socialism and the attitude they are to adopt toward foreign friends and acquaintances.

BERLIN, April 24. -- Prices on the Boerse showed some signs of weakness today because of realizing sales, although activity, as usual, was strictly limited. The market continues to retain its purely official character and to be ignored largely by the business community.

Following continuation of Thursday's severe selling pressure in the first hour yesterday, the share market steadied somewhat and moved to an irregular closing. Rallying tendencies were by no means impressive, but a few issues were enabled to make recoveries of a point or two.
Seven Manhattan parcels were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. One scheduled sale was adjourned. The results were as follows:

College rowing in New York will have its biggest day of the year this morning when Columbia, Princeton and Pennsylvania meet for the historic Childs Cup on the Harlem River. A crowd of 20,000 is expected to witness the four-race regatta, which will commence at 10 o'clock and be climaxed at 11:30 with the varsity event.

Dorade, most famous of all small deep-sea yachts, is going to leave the Atlantic Ocean, over which her fame has spread for seven years. She was sold yesterday by her brother owners, Olin J. Stephens 2d, and Roderick Stephens Jr., to James Flood of San Francisco.

TRENTON, N.J., April 24. -- The emergency tax session of the New Jersey Assembly called to "sit until the relief problem is solved" failed to materialize this morning, less than twelve hours after it was ordered, thus delaying until Monday night at least any official action on the emergency involving 270,000 needy persons.

It is perhaps in a way just an "average" sort of show, this twentieth annual exhibition Of the Society of Independent Artists, which opened with a reception last evening at the Grand Central Palace (fourth floor), to continue through May 17.

After holding around the high levels of the week for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased slightly in final dealings to close with losses of 1 to 3 points. Active mill price-fixing absorbed a quantity of May contracts around 11.60 cents a pound, but it was generally believed that contracts came from private sources and not from the producers' pool.

Local groups of sportsmen throughout the State, with the cooperation of landowners, have an opportunity to do much toward the conservation of wild life by encouraging zones of brush along streams in their localities, officials of the State Conservation Department have announced.

The 225-page pamphlet report of the Diamond Match Company for 1935 devotes considerable space to objections to the disclosures of data required by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange and hints at a constitutional test of a decision of the SEC last October that the company make public figures on sales and cost of sales.

ROME, April 24. -- A strong plea was made today in Italian quarters for reform of the League of Nations. It is admitted that the League "can be very useful," but it was submitted that it was not a panacea for all evils.

BERLIN, April 24. -- The German Economist, the periodical that is generally regarded as the mouthpiece of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, advanced today a demand for an economy dictator with authority and power to control and coordinate the finances of the government and the National Socialist party and their "associated" but usually compulsory associations in order to safeguard the necessary funds for continued rearmament.

While special promotional events staged by local stores drew a good response on several days of the week, the general activity was under that expected with the betterment of weather conditions, retail executives here reported yesterday. The average sales volume of department stores here was estimated as showing a decrease of about 7 to 8 per cent under the corresponding week last year.

In the Oval Restaurant of the Ritz-Carlton last night a "Lucky Number Dance" was given for the benefit of the Louise Eltinge Memorial Fund. During the supper hour a special entertainment program enlisted Rosita and Fontana in exhibition dances, Miss Lilian Sharp in several songs and Miss Kathryn Jordan in a specialty balloon dance.

LONDON, April 24. -- President Roosevelt's projected visit to Canada was hailed here today as an occasion to remind the world that for more than a century there has been unbroken peace between the United States and the British Empire and an unbroken amity between American Republic and Dominion of Canada, with "nothing but friendly intercourse over 3,000 miles of unfortified frontier."

The home of Sherwood Eddy, author and lecturer, was sold at foreclosure yesterday together with the homes of two other families residing in the Sunnyside Gardens community of Queens. The foreclosure sales took place on the steps of the Queens County Court House in Long Island City.

The Columbia interfraternity ball will be held tonight at the Hotel Plaza under the auspices of Pamphratria, the association of fraternities. More than 100 members of the clubs and their guests are expected to attend the dance, the last off-campus social event of the academic year.

BALTIMORE, April 24. -- This city and the famous valleys outside it that have been associated with the horse for so many years were ready tonight for tomorrow's renewal of one of the most famous races in the world, the forty-third running of the Maryland Hunt Cup, generally regarded as the most sought after prize in amateur timber racing.

The Knickerbocker Greys, crack junior cadet corps, were reviewed by Lieut. Gen. Robert Lee Bullard, retired, at their fifty-fifth anniversary annual Spring review and reception, held yesterday for 500 admiring veterans, families and first moves at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

On the ground that discoveries in chemical science are being made so rapidly that they cannot be displayed in a museum unless it has large capacity and an adequate maintenance fund, the American Chemical Society applied in the Supreme Court yesterday for permission to turn over a trust fund of $26,000 to the Chemists Club of New York for the benefit of its library.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 24. -- With the scene illuminated by a brilliant April sun, television outdoors was demonstrated this afternoon in a mile broadcast, with members of the local Fire Department as the actors.
The New York Stock Exchange yesterday announced the proposed dissolution of six member partnerships, and the proposed formation of seven new partnerships.

Hale, hearty and keen, though born in the first year of the Civil War, Professor Edwin R.A. Seligman will celebrate the seventy-fifth anniversary of his birth today. In a ten-minute interview last night in his apartment at the Carlyle, 35 East Seventy-sixth Street, the world-famous economist talked as optimistically about the future as a young man just on the threshold of his career.
In Topics of The Times, April 17, there was an article on pre-war Russia. This is particularly significant today when most of the facts about the old regime are obscured in embryonic criticism.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Bullocks, Inc., Los Angeles, in an amendment to its registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of $5,000,000 of secured 4 per cent bonds and 40,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock gave the offering date as next Wednesday and the offering prices of bonds as follows:

Governor Lehman's message in approbation of the three Livingston bills in behalf of the deaf and the hard of hearing carried with it the hopes of many citizens of this State who know the limitations imposed by these handicaps.

LOUISVILLE, April 24 (AP). -- A Kentucky Derby costume rehearsal is booked at Churchill Downs tomorrow, with Brevity, Coldstream, He Did and Bien Joli scampering seven furlongs. Thirteen Derby eligibles' owners flung their pets into the Sophomores Purse entry box and crowded the secondary event into the spotlight along with the inaugural feature, the $5,000 added Clark Handicap.

At a "peace-aviation" luncheon, given in honor of Miss Ruth R. Nichols, the flier, by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday, the most sustained applause, except that for Miss Nichols herself, greeted statements by fliers and other speakers that the best insurance against future war for the United States was a big and fully prepared air force.

Most futures rallied yesterday on the local commodity markets from their sharp declines of the previous day. Silk and metals were fairly steady. On the cash markets wheat, oats, lard, eggs, rubber and cocoa advanced, while corn, rye, cotton, tins and silk declined.
CLEVELAND, April 24 (AP). -- Two home runs and three Chicago errors in one inning presented the Indians with a 6-to-2 victory over the White Sox today in the concluding game of their series.

I would appreciate comment from your readers about the Olympic basketball committee's plan to have the United States squad engage in a series of double-headers with two Eastern college quintets before it sails on July 15 for the competition in Germany.

Atop a trio of smooth-leaping bay geldings, the New York Police Department team took the lead in the three-phase low-score military jumping competition as the two-day horse show sponsored by the Brooklyn Elks, Lodge 22, opened last night at Edwin R. Teevan's Riding Academy.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Earnings of Montgomery Ward Co. in the first quarter of 1936 were at least as good as a year ago and sales volume was up slightly despite floods and cold weather, Sewell L. Avery, president and chairman of the board of Montgomery Ward Co., said at the annual stockholders' meeting today.

Two more pages off the calendar and Summer will be back in town. Since the night spots, like the man in the new straw kelly, invariably rush the season, preparations are already under way to be open and ready to greet him. Cooling systems are receiving preliminary whirls, storm windows are being taken down from roofs and announcements are being made.

Fifteen hundred City College students signed petitions yesterday protesting the dismissal of Morris Schappes as a tutor of English at the end of this semester. Protest meetings also were held yesterday by 200 members of the college chapter of the American Students Union and 300 former students of Mr. Schappes.

PITTSBURGH, April 24. -- A sharp attack on those who seek to undermine the Constitution and replace it with a new form of government was made here tonight by James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York.

Mr. R.M. McCABE, improver of old reliable Dr. TOWNSEND and author of that perfect parody and reduction to the absurd, The Perpetual Prosperity Plan, is the last man upon whom the curse of humorlessness seemed likely to fall; but he has had a momentary attack which must take its place with fears of the brave and follies of the wise.

Owing to the failure of the company to pay more than eight quarterly dividends on the preferred stock, holders of those shares of the Engineers Public Service Company of record of April 23 will be entitled, as a class, to elect seven of the fifteen directors to be chosen at the annual meeting in Wilmington on May 18.

PARIS, April 24. -- A motion picture taken by a spectator served as the principal evidence in court today when two members of the Royalist crowd that attacked Leon Blum, the Socialist leader, were sentenced to jail.

Twenty-two corporations, indicted more than two years ago for conducting a monopoly in the saltwater fish market in violation of the anti-trust laws, were fined a total of $12,000 when they entered pleas of nolo contendere yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack.

LONDON, April 24. -- Moved by a suspicion that the Baldwin government may give away some British territory to Germany for the sake of peace, a group of diehard backbench Tory members of the House of Commons organized themselves today into a committee to oppose any such action.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Charles Hemendinger, 56 years old, an acting sergeant of detectives who was to have been a grand jury witness in the bribery phase of the investigation into Samuel Drukman's murder, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the mouth.

Gold amounting to $7,115,000 was engaged in Paris yesterday for shipment to the United States as the French franc on the last full business day before Sunday's elections continued to sell below the gold-import point. In addition to the gold engaged in Paris, banks here purchased $840,000 gold in England, and $200,000 in India for shipment here, making total engagements for the day of $8,155,000.

New York's major league baseball clubs should establish some sort of daily information system at important points throughout the city to advise fans of late developments, such as cancellations, double-headers, This system could take the form of placards being placed in corner-store windows and on buses and subway cars.

Supreme Court Justice Francis Martin, presiding justice of the Appellate Division, First Department, was called on yesterday by the State Board of Parole to substantiate charges made by him against the board or else make a public retraction.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Hogs weighing under 230 pounds were in fairly good demand here today at steady prices, but the call for heavier kinds was relatively slow, with heavy butchers off around 10 cents a hundred weight at the close. The top price was unchanged from yesterday at $11, while the day's average price was steady at $10.65.

Supreme Court Justice McCook yesterday afternoon set May 11 for the trial of Charles Lucania and twelve other men on charges of compulsory prostitution. They were held in an aggregate bail of $1,175,000, Lucania's being the highest, $350,000.

Parliamentary government in France is certainly not discredited if one may judge by the number of people who would like to be in Parliament. For the elections to the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow the average is eight candidates for every seat.

Miss Janice Lifson of the Women's Swimming Association retained her metropolitan senior A.A.U. diving championship and Wallace Spence of the New York A.C. became the metropolitan senior 300-yard medley titleholder last night in a meet at the Downtown A.C.
DENVILLE, N.J., April 24. -- When all others fail the villages of Denville and Rainbow Lakes in need, they may look for time of protection to four Mountain Lakes high school boys.

DALLAS, Texas, April 24. -- An appeal for the cotton industry to organize on the same basis as the wool growers, with contributions from all branches of the industry for a common promotional and educational campaign on behalf of utilization of the staple, was made today by Charles K. Everett, manager of the new uses section of the Cotton Textile Institute, at the opening session of the American Cotton Shippers Association.

American newspaper publishers were urged yesterday to buy newsprint as much as possible from American or European paper mills, in order to save themselves from threatened price control by Canadian manufacturers in coalition with the Canadian Government, at yesterday's final session of the fiftieth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Although endorsing the objectives of the Wagner Slum Clearance and Low Cost Housing Bill, Peter Grimm of New York, formerly a special assistant to Secretary Morgenthau to analyze and coordinate Federal housing programs, today appeared before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor to oppose the financing provisions of the bill and to present an alternative slum-clearance program.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- "An Afternoon in Provence" will be given at Woodstock Barn, the Villanova studio of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Oakley, on May 12 by the occupational therapy committee of the Devon Horse Show Country Fair.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP). -- Declaring Senator Vandenberg "one of the major eligibles," the Republican State convention today instructed its delegation to the national convention to present his name and act according to its "best judgment."

Researches into early Mexican history, undertaken as part of a ten-year program under the joint auspices of the American Museum of Natural History and the Mexican Government, have revealed that as early as 100 B.C. a well-developed civilization similar to that of the Pueblo Indians of today existed, Dr. George C. Vaillant, associate curator of Mexican archaeology at the museum, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Payrolls, factory employment, industrial production and retail trade showed substantial increases from February to March, while the output of minerals declined, the Federal Reserve Board announced in its monthly business review today.

Outstanding personalities of the newspaper profession were featured in the entertainment program at the annual Front Page Ball given last night by the New York Newspaper Women's Club at the Hotel Astor.

The crowning of a new champion, always an exciting event in any sport, kept a large gallery interested throughout the women's national foils championship at the Fencers Club last night as Mrs. Bela de Tuscan of Detroit won her first title from a small but select field.
Many unusual baseball records have appeared in your columns of letters, but here is one achievement of note that probably few persons recall.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Democratic leaders in the Senate are planning to submit an amendment designed to mitigate the political effects of the Vandenberg resolution which calls for the names of all who received benefit payments of more than $10,000 from the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- A trade agreement between the United States and Guatemala providing for reciprocal tariff benefits was signed at Guatemala City today, according to an announcement by the State Department.

With the United States championship at stake, in addition to liberal cash prizes and custody of the Frank J. Marshall Trophy, sixteen of the best chess players in this country will start a tournament of fifteen rounds in the grill at the Hotel Astor at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

An adaptation by the cotton industry, including growers, shippers and manufacturers, of the promotional campaign undertaken by the wool industry was recommended yesterday by C. K. Everett, manager of the New Uses Section of the Cotton-Textile Industry, at the annual convention of the American Cotton Shippers Association at the Adolphus Hotel, Dallas, Texas.

The 480 relief workers who were withdrawn on Thursday from the paving project at the ferry terminal at St. George, S.I., may return to work Monday. Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, called them away as the result of a dispute between WPA officials and Andrew Hudson, Deputy Commissioner of Plant and Structures, as to the best method for conducting the work.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The "good neighbor" policy advocated by President Roosevelt in many speeches, and reiterated in the message which he read before the last opening session of Congress, took active form today in the organization of a Good Neighbor League.

PIERRE, S.D., April 24. -- In an opinion declaring that the need for a free press was "more urgent in this country today than ever it has been before," the South Dakota Supreme Court today reversed the convictions of two newspaper men on charges of contempt of court for criticisms published in an editorial in 1932.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 24. -- Rafael Martinez Nadal, President of the Puerto Rican Senate and head of the majority coalition, today assailed as a betrayal of the people of Puerto Rico the bill introduced in the United States Senate yesterday by Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland giving them a chance to vote for independence.

Mrs. Mary Wiggen, 32 years old, of 1 St. Paul Court, Brooklyn, was shot and critically wounded at about 2 o'clock this morning when the car which her husband, Charles V. Wiggen, was driving failed to stop when it was hailed by Nassau County detectives in another car in Little Neck, L.I.

MARGATE, England, April 24. -- Salo Flohr of Prague today won the international tournament at the second annual Easter congress of the Kent County Chess Association, concluded after a session of ten days at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville.

In a recent address at Cambridge University, Sir Austen Chamberlain is reported to have condemned the pro-German party that has arisen in Great Britain -- the "poor Germany" faction who talk of the harshness of the Versailles treaty. Sir Austen asked: "Would there have been a less rigorous peace to the beaten party if Germany had won?"

Collecting seventeen hits, the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School nine crushed St. Peter's High of Staten Island, 19 -- 5, in a Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. clash at Sisco Park, Port Richmond, yesterday. The triumph was the third in a row in the tournament for Loughlin.
ROME, April 24. -- Today's war bulletin shows Italian troops in movement on both the northern and southern fronts in Ethiopia.

In a garden setting of blossoming trees, southern smilax, apple blossoms and dogwood, the Blossom Ball was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza in behalf of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital of Columbia University.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- Jesse Owens of Ohio State, a vivid streak of scarlet flashing across the somber gray background of Franklin Field this afternoon, came catapulting from seventh to second place to set the stage for a brilliant Buckeye victory in the sprint medley championship that featured the opening day of the forty-second annual Penn Relay Carnival.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP). -- Behind the seven-hit pitching of Lonnie Warneke, the Chicago Cubs took their second straight victory from the Pittsburgh Pirates today, 6 -- 1.

Casey Stengel and his Dodgers left them laughing when they said goodbye to Ebbets Field yesterday on the eve of their first extended journey. While the first ladies' day crowd in the annals of the present Brooklyn playground hooted and jeered the enemy and cheered their idols, the Flatbush youngsters and oldsters made it two straight over the Giants, 8 -- 2, and climbed into the rarefied atmosphere of the first division.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP). -- The Red Sox again fell before the Athletics, 3 to 1, today. The Mackmen scored all their runs in the opening inning, when they chased Johnny Marcum to cover.
Gains were reported yesterday by the committee in charge of the Atlantic seamen's strike, but passenger and freight ships left on schedule.

LONDON, April 24. -- Because each year more than 1,000 boys and girls are killed in road accidents in Britain, a government committee composed of education and transport authorities has recommended that no child under 7 years of age be allowed on any highway or country lane unless accompanied by some one competent to serve as a protector.

Lincoln Ellsworth announced yesterday that he has presented to the Smithsonian Institution his plane, the Polar Star, which carried him and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon across 2,200 miles of Antarctica and enabled him to claim 350,000 square miles of land for the United States.

Few persons outside of the small -- but constantly growing! -- world of garden enthusiasts realize that among flowers there is a never-ceasing competition for popular favor. First one and then another captures the public imagination.

Federal Judge Inch in Brooklyn reserved yesterday decision on an application of a committee of preferred stockholders of the Bush Terminal Buildings Company for rehearing of a motion granted last month to dismiss the Bush Terminal Company from reorganization proceedings and from a suit in equity brought against it.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Testimony indicating that the new board of directors controlling the Townsend pension organization was "hand-picked" by Dr. Francis E. Townsend and his brother, Walter Townsend, was given before the Special House Investigating Committee today by Robert E. Clements, co-founder of the Townsend plan.

A jury before Supreme Court Justice McCook awarded $85,000 yesterday to William S. Hart, former film actor and producer of Western films, in his $500,000 suit against the United Artists Corporation. Mr. Hart charged that the company failed to exploit properly his last film, "Tumbleweeds," and that Joseph M. Schenck and the late Hiram Abrams, executives of the defendant corporation, conspired to force him out of business as an independent producer in 1925.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Corporation in an amendment to its registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for issuance of $45,000,000 of rapid transit collateral trust serials bonds due serially on May 1, 1937, to May 1, 1951, and $65,000,000 of rapid transit collateral trust bonds 4 1/2 per cent series due on May 1, 1966, gave the prices at which the securities would be offered.

Many pastors will tomorrow preach on the topic "The Good Shepherd," that parable being the "Gospel for the Day" as set forth in the ritualistic calendar to be read in the churches. Many other clergymen will discuss the emergency peace campaign launched in this city Wednesday evening at a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall and to be waged in some 300 cities of the country.

An attack that reminded about 4,000 chilled observers of gayer times with Yankee baseball clubs snowed under the Senators yesterday at the Stadium. It was the second straight over the hapless crew of Bucky Harris, and the third victory in a row for New York.

The annual festival of the English Folk Dance Society of America, in which more than 400 dancers will participate, will be held this afternoon in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. Mrs. Arthur O. Choate is chairman of the festival committee.

The Adult Education Project of the Board of Education, carried on in cooperation with the WPA, was swamped with applicants yesterday at its headquarters, 257 West Fortieth Street, as a result of an advertising campaign launched the day before on elevated, subway, trolley car and bus lines.
LONDON, April 24. -- King Edward today again revealed his personal interest in his subjects.

Although brokers without exception welcomed the rulings of the Stock Exchange yesterday after the close of the market on margin requirements, considerable mystery and confusion surround the entire situation. It had been expected that the Exchange would be compelled to increase the minimum margin requirements to conform to the new Federal Reserve regulations.

LONDON, April 24. -- Crown Prince Farouk, 16-year-old heir to the throne of Egypt -- or Emir es Said (Prince of Upper Egypt), to give him his official title -- arrived in England aboard a British warship in October of last year to complete his education.

JERUSALEM, April 24. -- Contrary to expectations there were no disturbances today. At the invitation of Arab leaders, villagers came for noon prayers in the Mosque of Omar, but the worshipers dispersed peacefully.

ADDIS ABABA, April 24. -- At intervals of two hours this morning two Caproni bombers of the Italian Air Force flew over this city. They approached along the Dessye road and returned over Mount Entoto along the road leading to Fiche, about fifty miles north in the basin of the Blue Nile.

An eight-State alarm was sent out yesterday for Ellis H. Parker Jr., who was indicted Thursday by the Kings County grand jury with four other men on charges of kidnapping and second-degree assault in connection with the abduction of Paul H. Wendel, disbarred Trenton (N.J.) lawyer.

Many dinner parties contributed to an attendance of several hundred persons at the Spring dinner dance held last night at Sherry's for the benefit of the social service and occupational therapy departments of the Reconstruction Hospital Unit of the Post-Graduate Hospital.

The first ten railroads to report for March showed a net operating income of $8,892,000, against $9,032,000 in March, 1935, a decrease of .56 per cent, and against $10,866,000 in March, 1934, a decrease of 17.3 per cent. This was a reversal of a trend followed in recent months. Higher expenses and lower coal loadings contributed to the result.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 24. -- Rear Admiral David F. Sellers, Superintendent of the Naval Academy, will present medals at dress parade Wednesday to twenty midshipmen who have qualified as first-class gun pointers.

There was a day when there were two kinds of women -- those who married and those who "had to teach." Any one could detect to which group women they met belonged, even when their gloves concealed possible wedding rings. The married women were stout and contented and did not all dress with an eye to the latest fashion.

What is a yacht? That question, though it may seem to some too broad to answer, really is defined. The word has been misused to such an extent recently, however, that it should be cleared up, even if in the process some self-styled yachtsmen may find themselves boatmen.

The postoffice at the navy yard in Brooklyn, which had served thousands of employes at the yard for thirty-three years, has been ordered discontinued, it was revealed yesterday by navy yard officials.

It was not until prices of many of the speculative domestic corporate obligations had dropped to new low levels for the move during the first hour yesterday that the decline in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was checked. After that, moderate recovery movements developed and extended over a fairly broad list for the rest of the day.
In answer to the letter of Helen Alfred, secretary of the National Public Housing Conference, appearing in your paper April 23, permit me to correct some of the statements therein contained.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 24. -- Ray Ellinwood, the University of Chicago's great sophomore middle-distance Olympic hope, gave a brilliant last-minute performance today to prevent a pair of field-event stars, Sam Francis of Nebraska and Alton Terry of Hardin-Simmons, from stealing all the first-day glory in the twenty-seventh annual Drake relays.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Secretary Ickes said yesterday that he would "consider" reallocating for a bridge the $58,000,000 that the PWA has agreed to advance to New York City in loans and grants for a tunnel under the East River.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- A new silver substance which promises to provide medicine with a veritable "silver sword" for destruction of the invading armies of man's invisible bacterial enemies was described for the first time before the annual meeting of the American Philosophical Society here today.

Granville and Teufel, the former not a stake winner and the latter a maiden, will run coupled today in the $10,000-added Wood Memorial at Jamaica, and it is almost a certainty that the entry will be favored in a field of eight Kentucky Derby eligibles.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, April 24. -- What may be considered the first step toward an Italian march on Addis Ababa was taken early this morning when an Eritrean column occupied without opposition Warra Hailu, about thirty-five miles south of Dessye on the Imperial Highway and about 125 miles in a straight line from the capital.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 24. -- For the first time in the long weeks of the Eastern field trial season the sun shone all day as the annual meeting of the Sport and Conservation League got under way today. Two stakes were completed in the competition which will be concluded Sunday.

IT was my friend from the University on the phone. "Hello," I said, "what do you know about Noah Webster?" "Noah Webster?" came the faint reply, "Noah Webster? Why, not much. He wrote a dictionary about a hundred years ago. And he didn't make a speech on the Seventh of March."

THE ball clubs are just warming to their work in the big league pennants races and it's too early to take the current standings as a reliable guide to future operations. Some that are up will go down a few notches and some that are down will be moving up shortly.

An advisory committee consisting of representatives from the home economics, magazine, industry, department store, women's clubs and extension groups to aid in the coordination of efforts to further consumer education was appointed at a conference held yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker under the auspices of the Textiles Education Bureau.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- A slight cold confined President Roosevelt to the residential quarters of the White House today, causing cancellation of routine appointments but giving him an opportunity for uninterrupted work on the speech he is scheduled to make tomorrow night in New York at a dinner given by the National Democratic Club.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- By unanimous consent the Senate passed today the administration amendments to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 extending indefinitely trading in unlisted securities on registered Securities Exchanges, subject to the decision of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and also setting up new regulations for trading in over-the-counter securities.

Criticism of the Federal Social Security Act, both for its operative failures and for its alleged basic fallacy, was voiced yesterday at the ninth annual national conference of the American Association for Social Security being held at the Hotel Astor.

Skiing, which claims the most devotees of any Winter sport, enjoyed a phenomenal development during the past season that, without a doubt, has been unprecedented in the annals of sportdom. Formerly an infant activity in this country, skiing has made such a sweeping step forward that it is now "The King of Winter Delights" in the United States.

Assurance has been given to Jews in America by the High Commissioner of Palestine that he would not "put a premium upon violence" by yielding to any unjust demands of the Arabs, Dr. Stephen S. Wise said yesterday. He said continued admittance of immigrants to Palestine was guaranteed.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 24. -- King Fuad is desperately ill, and his death is declared to be only a matter of hours. Since his serious illness of more than a year ago his health had been precarious, but in the past few weeks it again took a turn for the worse.
Under Mayor La Guardia's direction, arrangements were completed yesterday for the expenditure of $16,000 from the city's Welfare Special Fund for social welfare and educational purposes.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

Residents of New York City and about 320 cities, towns and villages in New York State will observe daylight-saving time from tomorrow at 2 A.M. until Sunday, Sept. 27, at 2 A.M., it was announced yesterday by the Merchants' Association of New York, a leading advocate of the summertime movement.

By permitting the proposed national housing program to be "stymied" for another year because of petty bickerings, personal ambitions and departmental interference the Roosevelt administration has jeopardized the program for restoring millions of men now on relief to private jobs, Professor Raymond Moley, editor of Today, declared last night at a dinner given by the directors of the National Association of Manufacturers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

NEWARK, N.J., April 24. -- A legislative program that would place the administration of relief in the hands of municipalities with State assistance was announced today at the close of a five-hour conference of leaders of the Republican majority in both the State Assembly and Senate at the Essex Club here.

One bandit was shot and killed, seven others were captured and thirteen escaped yesterday in a series of nine hold-ups and two other robberies throughout the city. The day's loot, including three payrolls, aggregated more than $4,000.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- Any threat by this country to adopt a policy of trade embargoes in time of war was pictured tonight by Allen W. Dulles of New York, as influencing the peace time trade of the United States disadvantageously and, perhaps, seriously affecting our economic relations with many of our best customer-nations.

Puerto Rico, whose complete independence is now proposed in a bill before the Senate, has nearly doubled in population during its thirty-seven years as part of the United States. This is a tribute to the success of the measures introduced during this period to improve health, schools and sanitation.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 24. -- Three times within a stroke of yielding the second set and averting the loss of the third by the same thin margin at one juncture, Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta defeated Harold Surface of Kansas City, Mo., today to gain the final round of the Mason-Dixon championship at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

For successive days the foreign dispatches have told of official inquiries sent by the British Government to the German. They have not all been formulated as yet, or at least not published. But the gist of them has been made clear. The British Foreign Office desires to know what HITLER proposes to do about many things affecting the peace of Europe.

The Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31, a net income of $4,919,393 after all deductions, equal to $9.19 a share on 534,875 shares of capital stock, comparing with $5,308,710, or $9.92 a share on the shares then outstanding.

Charles S. McCain, former chairman of the Chase National Bank, revealed on the witness stand in the Supreme Court here yesterday that he kept the insolvent Harriman National Bank open until the moratorium of 1933 on guarantees from other banks for the protection of the Harriman's depositors, which were "entirely implicit."

PARIS, April 24. -- Belgium will defend her soil but does not wish to become entangled in European controversies, former Premier Henri Jaspar declared last night in explaining the present Belgian policies in a lecture given under the auspices of the Foreign Policy Center.

The regular New York County grand jury speedily voted a first-degree murder indictment yesterday against John Fiorenza, 24 years old, confessed strangler of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, 34, in her home at 22 Beekman Place on Good Friday. The bill will be handed up to Judge Koenig in General Sessions on Monday.

George Holtzer's letter, "Youth Seeks a Place," illustrates the sad trend in our country. This is just another case of making the hustler who is not afraid of hard work, and has the initiative to provide for himself and his dependents, take on the load of supporting in ease the higher educated sapling.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Taking issue on behalf of the "rank and file" of World War veterans with M.A. Harlan, national commander of the Disabled Veterans, who recently told President Roosevelt that there was no organized demand among them for monthly payments to all who suffered. The National Tribune, headed by Colonel Rice W. Means, has announced its intention to "fight" for pensions for all veterans, including those of the World War.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, April 24 (AP). -- The presence of a revolt in Honduras was admitted by the government today when it claimed victory in two engagements, one with the use of airplanes.

ST. PAUL, April 24 (AP). -- The State Supreme Court today ruled Minnesota's corporate excess tax law of 1879 invalid, affirming a District Court order handed down in a test case instituted by Bemis Brothers Bag Company of St. Louis and S.H. Clausin Co., Minneapolis wholesale jewelers.

BERLIN, April 24. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler today gave amnesty to all these critics of his regime sentenced to less than six months' imprisonment on the condition that they do not again come into conflict with the law within three years.

BALTIMORE, April 24 (AP). -- Heavy hitting which drove across three Montreal runs in the eighth inning today gave the Royals a 5-3 triumph over the Orioles, dropping the birds to fourth place in the International League. The only homer of the game came off the bat of Woodey Abernathy.

PITTSBURGH, April 24. -- A fortune of more than $2,300,000 earned by Addison H. Gibson, a farm boy who struggled through poverty to wealth and success in the oil industry, goes to the poor and needy under the terms of his will.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP). -- Ali Baba, Turkish wrestler, became a new claimant to the world's heavyweight wrestling championship tonight by pinning Dick Shikat in 46 minutes 40 seconds. The match was held at Olympia Sports Arena.

Gold medals and silver cups emblematic of city championships were awarded yesterday by Borough President Samuel Levy to the captains of four roller-skating hockey teams who won the distinction in a city-wide competition sponsored by the Police Department Crime Prevention Bureau and conducted with the aid of the WPA.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told New York University students yesterday that this country had come to a period when changes had to be made in the economic and social philosophy. Until these changes are made, she added, violent discussion and sometimes violence without discussion might take place.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Because of a slight cold, President Roosevelt remained in the residential quarters of the White House today, but he received representatives of the Good Neighbor League, who notified him of the formation of an organization to support his "good neighbor" policy.
Violet was the predominant color last night at the annual military ball of the New York University Chapter of Scabbard and Blade at the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 1,000 persons were present.
Federal warrants for two men wanted as material witnesses in the government's case against John Torrio, gang leader, were issued yesterday by United States Commissioner Isaac Platt.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Federal Reserve Board issued today a brief interpretation of Section 3 (e) of Regulation U covering the extension of loans by banks for the purpose of purchasing or carrying securities on national securities exchanges, dealing in this instance with the transfer of loans.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP). -- The Bureau of Mines recommended today that the oil industry produce a daily average of 2,826,300 barrels during May.

In the opinion of Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, it was learned yesterday, the Municipal Assembly had no legal right to enact the Lyons Residence Bill, operation of which has been suspended by Mayor La Guardia.

EGER, Czechoslovakia, April 24. -- Konrad Henlein, who is popularly called the "Czechoslovak Hitler" and who is head of the Sudeten German party, which obtained 66 per cent of the German vote in Czechoslovakia in the last elections, today explained to your correspondent the aims of his movement.

HALIFAX, N.S., April 24. -- Special medical equipment for treatment of Alfred Scadding, one of the two survivors of ten days' imprisonment in the Moose River gold mine, was rushed tonight to Halifax, where the men are patients in a hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- A new angle to the suits of four power companies to enjoin PWA Administrator Ickes from allocating funds to construct municipally owned lighting plants developed in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today when evidence was submitted that officials of PWA had advised the town of Hominy, Okla., to withdraw its application for such funds and to continue using the service furnished by the Oklahoma Utilities Company.

Lord Horder, physician-in-ordinary to King Edward VIII, one of the leading liberal scientists of England and an active protagonist of wise living, suggested on his arrival here yesterday that the life span of the modern human being was long enough, that the wiser task of science was to enhance life, rather than prolong it.

In a decision yesterday Judge Clarence G. Galston, in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, held that the seizure of the Norwegian steamship Reidun by Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs of the Port of New York, was illegal and that a libel action brought by the government for the forfeiture of the vessel was without basis.
NEWARK, N.J., April 24. -- The Bears made it eight victories in a row today with an easy 13-to-3 victory over the Rochester Red Wings.

PARIS, April 24. -- With the reception to Claude Farrere, who took the seat of the late Foreign Minister Louis Barthou, the scholarly calm of the French Academy seemed to waken yesterday to echoes of the political campaign outside.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today recommending a $30,000,000 unemployment relief bond issue and an additional appropriation of $10,000,000 for relief out of general funds.

Henry Levine Co. of Brooklyn, builders and contractors, have reassembled the old DeRonde estate at Teaneck Road and Route 4, Teaneck, for improvement with dwellings on quarter-acre plots. Part of the tract was acquired from Captain DeRonde, the transfer being the first in more than 100 years.

MADRID, April 24. -- After the municipal band played the "Internationale," Mayor Pedro Rico of Madrid tonight welcomed back to Spain 121 Socialist and Communist revolutionists who fled to the Soviet Union after the collapse of the Marxist rebellion in October, 1934.

FORT WORTH, Texas, April 24 (AP). -- Puzzling angles confronted police tonight in their effort to explain the death of a baseball player's wife whose body was found in her fire-swept apartment a few hours after she was pursued in an automobile.

Methods for the teaching of reading now currently in use in many schools were criticized last night as contributing to language disabilities which curtail mental development and create emotional disturbances. This condemnation came from Dr. Samuel T. Orton, Professor of Neurology and Neuro-pathology of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, one of the leading neurologists of the country.

With many retail merchants enlarging their budgets for second and third quarter commitments, buying this week in various divisions of the wholesale markets was close to the best weekly record of the year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Republicans, aided by one lone Democrat, Representative Lamneck of Ohio, directed a sharp attack upon President Roosevelt's revenue program today as the House wearily rode out five hours more of general debate on the Tax Bill submitted by its Ways and Means Committee.

Artur Rodzinski, who will conduct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next Spring, is sailing today on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia to conduct concerts at the Salzburg Festival. Others sailing for Mediterranean ports include Nathan Milstein, Russian violinist; Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Block.
Modern Library has issued a complete and unabridged one-volume edition of Henry James's "The Portrait of a Lady." This is the first novel by James to be included in the series.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning will complete on May 11 fifteen years as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York and on May 12 he will be 70 years old. A diocesan observance has been arranged by a committee headed by the Right Rev. Arthur S. Lloyd and the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishops.

THE growing vogue of outdoor sports among city dwellers -- encouraged in this case by a program of bridle path improvement -- has brought about a revival of almost "boom" proportions in horseback riding in the five boroughs of New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 25. -- The first annual tournament of Boys' Clubs that have been organized by the Westchester County Recreation Commission was held today at the County Center. Mrs. Eugene Meyer, commission chairman, said that the eight clubs created since Jan. 1, had been so successful that next Winter the commission would seek to establish one in every village and in every ward of the cities in Westchester County.

While Mrs. Margaret Wiggen remained in a serious condition in the Flushing Hospital after being shot in the head by a Nassau County detective early yesterday, District Attorney Martin W. Littleton Jr. of Nassau promised in Mineola to make a thorough investigation of the shooting.

AMONG the finest exhibits at the leading Eastern daffodil shows this Spring have been displays shipped by air mail from the great bulb fields in the Pacific Northwest, where the new American industry of bulb growing has reached its most imposing proportions.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee, a Democrat of Mississippi, today maintained that Congress possessed the power to give a measure of relief to debt-ridden corporations as provided in the $803,000,000 House bill revising the corporate income tax structure.

AFTER Stravinsky, Malipiero is the next to be honored by a stormy reception in Italy's current music chronicles. The occasion was the Italian premiere of his three-act opera, "L'Orfeide," given at the Teatro La Fenice, under the auspices of the local Gruppo Universitario Fascista, as a feature of the congress of Italian universities held here under the name of "Lictorials of Culture and Art."

Frank Appel, right-handed pitching star of St. Peter's College of Jersey City, entered baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday when he pitched a no-hit game as the Peacocks overwhelmed Seth Low College, 18 to 1, at Lincoln Park in Jersey City.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 25 (AP). -- Marynell, little 5-year-old brown mare, won the $10,000 added Centennial Exposition Handicap at Arlington Downs today, defeating the highly regarded Time Supply before 20,000 fans. Time Supply finished fourth but gained the show position when Rushaway was disqualified for bumping Frank Carreaud's Ace in the drive.

WITH banishment of fur coats to mothproof vaults, and relegation of storm windows to dim attics, vacation schemes are shouldering out mere workaday plans and economical resolves. Warm sunshine and bursting buds set the mind dreaming of lazy days at near-by lakes, of new scenes, with their challenge of strangeness.
To my mind it is much too early to say that the League of Nations "has proven a colossal failure," as William J. O'Malley Jr. states in your issue of April 21.

As a result of the great increase in interest in the training of thoroughbred dogs in obedience and the success attending the tests conducted at various dog shows during the last two years, the Obedience Test Club of New York has been organized.

THE radio booms nightly with the deeper thoughts, the more persuasive tones of statesmen. Bridge foursomes tend to drift away from the game into discussions of how strong Landon looks, calculations of how many farm States Roosevelt can carry with AAA checks appearing as soil conservation benefits.

Veterans of the New York Anti-Vivisection Society's semi-annual animal hero days held another reunion in the South Garden of the Hotel Astor yesterday. It was a cheery occasion as usual, and pleased scores of children besides providing medals, ribbons and statuettes for pets and owners.

The Grace liner Santa Paula sailed on schedule at noon yesterday despite a walkout of forty-seven members of her crew on the previous day. Replacements were made and the ship departed without incident, as a detail of pickets paraded back and forth in front of the dock at West Twenty-first Street.
Pennsylvania's varsity crew, making its first appearance of the season, rowed off with the historic Childs Cup yesterday by beating both Princeton and Columbia over the Harlem River course.

Time was when the term public enemy had only one meaning: a nation waging war against us; but now we have public enemies within our own confines, a host of them set up in a tabulated hierarchy. The modern usage of the term seems to have begun back in the late Nineteen Twenties when Alphonse (Scarface) Capone was at the top of Chicago's gangland.

THE final match of the Grand National team-of-four tournament, postponed from April 5, will be played this afternoon and tonight at Crockford's Club. The other events of the Grand National tournament were completed by April 4, but the team-of-four finalists, after the semi-final matches were over, decided that it would be more pleasant to have a short vacation before contesting for the championship.

The new Tax Bill, to be officially known, if enacted into law, as the Revenue Act of 1936, emerged last Tuesday from the House. Tax subcommittee; it was speedily adopted by a majority vote of the Ways and Means Committee and is now the subject of heated debates on the floor of the House of Representatives.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 25. -- Finishing with 50 straight targets, J. White annexed the registered skeet event of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Twenty-six gunners competed. R.R. Bogie took the second trophy on a shoot-off.

A resolution protesting the treatment of Jewish people and "bloody pogroms" in Poland was presented yesterday afternoon to an attache of the Polish Consulate, 151 East Sixty-seventh Street, by a delegation representing the recently organized Peoples Committee Against Polish Pogroms.

AT the centennial celebration in 1932 of Lewis Carroll, Columbia University had a sweet old English lady guest -- Mrs. Hargreaves -- the original Alice-in-Wonderland, who sixty-odd years before had inspired Carroll to write his beloved tale, which made of the shy, quiet, Oxford don an international benefactor.

ITS issuance timed for the Texas Centennial, this is a historic romance of the struggle of Texas for freedom from the yoke of Mexico. In its pages the author has delineated with apparent verisimilitude several of the leaders of the revolution of 1835-36, among them Sam Houston, Stephen F. Austin, James Bowie, William Barrett Travis, Ben Milam, James W. Fannin and Davy Crockett.

STRATFORD, Conn., April 25. -- Two more world records were added today to the string in the amphibian classifications which are being attempted here with the world's largest plane of the type, the twin Hornet-powered Sikorsky S-43.

WITH no less than nine Norwegian authors represented on the New York book-lists of the past two or three years, the American reading public is indirectly reflecting increasing interest in the vital literary production of this far northern country.

TWO emigrant trains, one of thirty-two wagons from Ohio and Indiana under command of Norman Brasfield and the other twenty-two wagons strong from the South in charge of John Remington of Missouri, journeying across the Continental Divide to the California gold fields in 1855, combined for protection against Indian attack and elected Brasfield captain.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- The University of Pennsylvania has decided to give greater recognition to the particular interests of its women students. As a result, it announces a revised curriculum which will be offered to students of the College of Liberal Arts for Women at the opening of the Fall term.

TRENTON, N.J., April 25. -- New Jersey's emergency relief crisis, which resulted this week in a group of unemployed men and women invading the Assembly Chamber at the State House here with the announced intention of remaining there day and night until the Legislature made funds available, is not an unexpected development.

THIS book, says its author, grew out of her work with adolescent girls, which furnished her with the material for her previous volume, "Understanding the Adolescent Girl," a work noteworthy in its field because of Mrs. Elliott's wide knowledge of the girl of that age, her keen insight into the problems of adolescence, their implications and consequences, and the sensitiveness, sympathy and practicality with which she came to firm grips with them.

The jacket labels this novel "A tempestuous romance of the South Seas." Tempestuous is the word for it. With a high-handed disregard for plausibility, the author tosses together an astounding bunch of adventures -- romantic, exotic, with a touch of the criminal and the revolutionary -- for a beautiful, red-haired, young heroine.

A brand-new unit in the United States Power Squadrons and located inland from the Atlantic seaboard is now being formed, probably as a fore-runner of other Great Lakes branches of this national organization of skippers. Leonard Thompson of Detroit, secretary also of the American Power Boat Association and a member of the Detroit Y.C., is the prime-mover of the new U.S.P.S. chapter in Detroit.

FOR several years graduates of liberal arts colleges have found it difficult to obtain teaching posts in public high schools. Increased requirements of "units" or "hours" in the technical study of education made by State departments are met easily by graduates of State teachers' colleges, but often are discouraging barriers to college students.

When the Gray Man walks on East Island there is trouble brewing. That is the legend believed by all the Negroes and more than half believed by some of the whites. On the night that Benton Clay is murdered the Gray Man is seen by two persons. Benton Clay is a rich Northerner who has made his home on this island off the Carolina coast.

J.F. Fogarty, president of the North American Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that the balance available for common stock after preferred dividends and all prior deductions was $12,458,385, equal to $1.45 a share, for the twelve months ended on March 31.

SOME thirty Japanese artists resident in America are represented by either paintings or sculpture in the current show at the A.C.A. Gallery. Most of them are young. Some have been quite obviously influenced by the American scene, while others have looked upon French modernism.
PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Twelve men will receive the medal awards of the Franklin Institute for 1936 at special exercises on May 20.
With Moe Siegel keeping the St. John's University hits well scattered, City College chalked up a 12-to-6 victory over the Redmen at Dexter Park yesterday.

DEVOTEES of that Bible of gypsy lore. Borrow's "Lavengro" and "The Romany Rye" will revel in this book for the double reason that it adds rich treasure to that already assembled in this and other Romany scriptures and also, and especially, because it is written by the grandson of that gypsy tinker and philosopher.

Your reviewer, Alfred Kazin, thinks that in book "What God Means to Me" I have defended the idealistic position as against the materialistic. I am sorry to be in a controversy with so well-armed an antagonist as Mr. Kazin, but I think it proper that I should state what my book about God means to me.

Although 9,865 relief cases were closed in March, the home relief rolls for that month showed a net increase of 5,565, it was reported yesterday by Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the ERB. Of the cases closed 3,514 found private employment.

ROME, April 25. -- A few hundred persons, many of them foreign journalists, who motored down this morning into the heart of what once was the Pontine marshes, caught a different view of Premier Benito Mussolini from the one that has been made familiar to the world.

NOT the scientists but the Stakhanovs who master their trade revise technical standards and thus exploit technology to the utmost." It is Stalin speaking. The workers in Moscow industrial laboratories respond with cheers.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- Although warmer weather was needed urgently last week, the larger department stores managed to record sales gains of as high as 12 per cent over the like 1935 period. The peak increases were recorded by outlying groups, which staged heavily advertised special sales, while sales in the Loop averaged around 8 per cent.

TOKYO, April 25. -- The Japanese commercial mission to Central American countries has met complete failure, reports the newspaper Yomiuri, which states that the mission was dissolved at Port au Prince, Haiti, without having concluded a single contract or agreement.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25 (AP). -- Even after spotting five rivals the two hurdles events, Harvard's well-balanced track and field forces retained their Greater Boston intercollegiate title today by piling up 68 points in the other 14 events at the Stadium.

Long before you come to the end of this story you will wonder how Kay Cleaver Strahan is ever going to unscramble the mess in which she has involved her characters. What with people being murdered all over the place, disappearing cadavers and plain and fancy lying by almost everybody concerned, the reader who fancies himself as an amateur sleuth will find very few definitely known facts upon which to base his deductions.

FOR centuries the stage has had its hardy perennials. Aristophanes, Shakespeare, Goldsmith and Sheridan and the others have been welcomed with undiminished enthusiasm in revival after revival. But not until recent years has the screen developed its own group of repeat numbers, thereby approaching dramatic maturity.

PROFESSOR BUCK tokes his title from Shelley's "Hellas" and uses it to describe the literary and philosophical achievements of the nineteenth century, from Rousseau to Hardy. It is a useful book in many ways: as a runover merely of the personalities of the great romantics, as a comparison and evaluation of their attitudes toward life, as a springboard of ideas that catapults us into contemporary living.

The bench and bar of Westchester County paid tribute last night, at the annual dinner of the Westchester County Bar Association in the Hotel Biltmore, to Justice J. Addison Young of New Rochelle, who is about to retire from the Appellate Division, Second Department, because of the constitutional age limit of 70 years.

A NEW road providing direct connection between Glacier National Park in Montana and Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, Canada, is to be opened in July, it is announced. The highway will permit American cars moving northward to enter Canada through the International Peace Park.

One of the greatest faults of the novice fresh-water angler, and a common failing of experienced men as well, is the tendency to rely soley on the bait or artificial lure to do the job of catching fish.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 25. -- A joint concert by the Williams and Vassar Glee Clubs was presented in Chapin Hall here tonight. After the concert the 140 singers in the combined groups, with a large number of Williams undergraduates and students from the neighboring Bennington College, participated in a dance at the Garfield Club.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 25. -- Miss Elizabeth Hyland won the championship for the second successive year in the annual riding meet of the Greenwich Academy at the indoor ring of the Round Hill Stables today. The reserve went to Miss Betty Harris.

HAMLIN GARLAND, blooming out as a psychic researcher after his long and successful career as novelist, essayist, literary memoirist, observer and critic of his times, has certainly saved up a surprise to spring upon his public in the very evening of his life.

SUBSTITUTING bicycles for skis and toboggans, knickers and "culottes" for woolen suits and windproof parkas, and their own pedaling power for the ready-made momentum of ice-covered slopes, a trainload of metropolitan sports seekers will head northward today to replace Winter's vanished army of snow enthusiasts.

STOCKHOLM. -- Tension, sharply accentuated by the recent discussions of defense, marks the present session of the Swedish Riksdag. Though the defense issue looms as the most formidable problem in the whole program before adjournment in June, the Social Democrats reject the suggestion that a crisis impends of the sort that might result in a change of Cabinets.

DETROIT, April 25 (AP). -- Howard Hughes, holder of two airplane speed records, said today that a new engine being constructed for him will give his racer a speed of more than 400 miles an hour at 20,000 feet.

The annual tour of city gardens under the auspices of the Anne Brown Alumnae Association will be held on May 5 for the benefit of the Anne Brown Free Nursery School, 524 West Forty-second Street, where children of pre-school age are given care and training and classes are held for mothers.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24. -- Two years of turmoil and conflict on the Can Francisco waterfront came to a halt, if not an end, this week when both sides signed an agreement promising to abide by the terms of the 1934 award and to accept the decisions of the arbitrator on all disputed issues.

SINCE Dorothy Bows, an employe of a Washington dry-cleaning establishment, established a new musical high on a recent Major Bowes's amateur hour, the broadcasters have been delving deep in the records of music to see who, if any one, previously reached the amazing point on the musical scale of D, an octave and a note above high C.

ST. LOUIS, April 25. -- Unseasonable weather this week has been a deterrent in many lines in the Eighth Federal Reserve District. The demand for Spring goods has been slowed down and retail sales show the effect generally. Department stores are running about 6 per cent ahead of last year and orders for wholesale houses have been spotty.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25. -- The discovery this week of secret society relics in Whig Hall on the Princeton University campus recalls the colorful history and secret initiations of the Whig-Cliosophic societies, America's oldest debating associations.
SOPHIE KERR can be depended upon for pleasantly readable light fiction, with a casually convincing air of reality. In "There's Only One" she takes a novel and interesting slant on the mother complex.

THE trails are drying out. This report, brought back by early venturers into the wilds that surround New York, has stirred anew the Spring unrest in the breasts of thousands of city-bound nature lovers, and from now on each week-end will see an ever-increasing army setting forth for the hills and the woods.

In his first political speech in New York City since his inauguration, President Franklin D. Roosevelt expounded last night a campaign-year philosophy of "higher wages for workers, more income for farmers, more goods produced, more and better food eaten, fewer unemployed and lower taxes."
Between Feb. 5 and April 17 the world witnessed the gratifying spectacle of the leading world powers declaring for the Open Door after they had blocked the Open Door for seventeen years.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- A forecast of showers in the Southwest over the week-end restricted bullish operations in the wheat market today and the new-crop months dropped 1 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel below yesterday's final prices and closed within a fraction of the bottom.

SHIP model making is one of the delightful leisure-hour pastimes. As a hobby it has advantages over mere collecting, or the making of most other things. With a very small outlay of money for material one can either get results fairly quickly or spend the spare time of years in endeavoring to achieve perfection; some even say that a ship model should never be completely finished.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Necessity for an attack on the problems of land speculation, exorbitant fees and prices charged by contractors and manufacturers of building material attendant upon government housing projects, and pressure exerted by higher income groups seeking to benefit by low rental, was cited by witnesses favorable to the Wagner $78,000,000 housing program, appearing today before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor.

With her 4-year-old son in her arms, Mrs. Augusta Radetsky, 36 years old, of 34 Post Avenue, jumped in front of a downtown train at the Broadway and 168th Street station of the I.R.T. at 9:20 o'clock yesterday morning.
MADRID, April 24. -- Fear of civil war in Spain is rising with each concession that Premier Manuel Azana and his liberal republican followers make to their increasingly Marxist allies.

Two young men were injured, probably fatally, last night when an automobile in which they were riding and which, according to the police, had been stolen from a parking place on Ninety-eighth Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, ran into a lamppost at the southwest corner of Fifty-eight Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Followers of the share market were kept on the anxious seat last week in an endeavor to puzzle out an answer to the question whether the long advance of prices of securities really has overdone the improvement in business, or whether the week's sharp decline was merely a setback to which any bull market is entitled.

THE antiquarian's knowledge of household furnishings of other eras is proving an invaluable aid in picturing early social backgrounds. Such service is now part of every historical celebration. An extensive exhibition at the Newark Museum in commemoration of Newark's incorporation as a city a century ago is, to a large extent, the result of assistance from collectors, who contributed authenticated old household articles, shop equipment, prints and other documents of the early days.

HALIFAX, N.S., April 25 (Canadian Press). -- A "glass boot" developed in Cincinnati and flown to Halifax was being used today for treatment of Charles Alfred Scadding, whose feet are in serious condition after his long entombment in the Moose River gold mine.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP). -- Amendments intended to tighten up the Federal control of commodity exchanges were approved today by a Senate Agricultural subcommittee, but members at the same time conceded that differences among Senators from cotton States had the bill at a standstill. Some of the amendments were proposed by Secretary Wallace; others were to meet protests of operators on exchanges.

LEWIS in the three essays in this book, and Spender in his recently published volume "The Destructive Element." are both concerned with fusing psychoanalysis and Marxism. Why? Very probably because these poets have become aware that a poetry of ideas, even of Marxian ideas, is a contradiction in terms.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 25. -- Confidence was expressed today in government quarters here that resumption of payments on the coupons of Chile's foreign debt issued in dollars, which was started in New York yesterday by the J. Henry Schroder Trust Company in accordance with the law enacted for Gustavo Ross, Minister of Finance, will prove successful in spite of the opposition of many groups.

This ambitious international biographical reference book sets out to cover "all periods and schools from the earliest times to 1935." Prodigious labor has obviously been expended in checking data. The Index lists more than 27,000 artists, about 8,000 of whom are contemporary.

THE curing of facial defects by surgical methods, the rebuilding of the human face nearer to the heart's desire, is not, Dr. Maltz explains, a recent discovery of surgical science, but was practiced with skill and success by Hindu surgeons more than 2,000 years ago.
I was interested in Mr. Livingston Welch's review of Dr. Henry C. McComas's book, "Ghosts I Have Talked With," that appeared in your issue of Feb. 16.

MEDFORD, Mass., April 25. -- An overwhelming sentiment against the Teachers Oath Law among the student bodies of Massachusetts colleges is indicated in the early returns of a poll being conducted by undergraduate newspapers, with the cooperation of The Tufts Weekly, student journal of Tufts College.

ONE of the things that the increased leisure alleged to be materializing for everybody is expected to do is to interest all manner of people in their ancestors and inspire them with the desire to find out who they were and what they did -- matters in which the big majority of Americans have not heretofore shown much concern.

"Golden Tales of the Far West" is a recent and important addition to the admirable collections of regional stories that Mrs. Becker has edited; as her foreword says, "No one can understand our history, especially the history of our last frontiers, without its romance."

THE cool, competent, rapier-like wit that makes possible the true comedy of manners has become both rare and difficult.
