For great wit stands a bit aside from life; it seldom can choose as its vehicle that favored child of the twentieth century, the novel, which by its very nature must plunge without reserve into the turbulent cross-currents of living.

BERLIN, April 25. -- The Marienburg, ancient castle on the East Prussian-Polish frontier and once upon a time the headquarters of Teutonic knights, conquerors of the Baltic East, is being converted into a headquarters of the "National Socialist Order" for training future rulers of the Third Reich.

WHAT is a seed? It is a tiny fertilized and mature capsule instinct with the forces of life. It is imprisoned life waiting for release into some new form of plant creation. It is a promise of growth, flower and fruitfulness.

John Fiorenza, 24 years old, who was indicted by a New York County grand jury on Friday for the murder of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, 34, in her home at 22 Beekman Place on Good Friday, will be arraigned in the Court of General Sessions next Tuesday, District Attorney William C. Dodge said yesterday.

MORE than a thousand men and women from all walks of life have been attending Public Forum lectures in Sprinfield, Mass., where a new idea in adult education has been evolved that is already spreading to other cities throughout the country.

MR. LUNDBERG'S book about America's richest newspaper publisher is described on the jacket as "the unauthorized biography." It will have to divide that distinction with the volume which Messrs. Carlson and Bates have put together, for the internal evidence would suggest that the "Lord of San Simeon" was not consulted as to what should and should not be published.

RICHMOND, April 25. -- All five reporting wholesale lines in the Fifth district did more business in March than in the corresponding month last year, the Richmond bank reports. For the first quarter all five lines gained, but the largest spread was 7 per cent for dry goods.

IN the impulsive epilogue to the published version of "Idiot's Delight" Robert E. Sherwood puts in a good word for good will: "Let me here express the conviction that those who shrug and say 'War is inevitable' are false prophets. I believe that the world is populated largely by decent people, and decent people don't want war." Mr. Sherwood had hardly made that humane observation before Irwin Shaw did something toward proving it.

The existence of a vice ring operated by Negro men in this and other cities, with white women as victims, was disclosed here yesterday the Federal authorities. With the arraignment of two men and four women, it was also charged that raiders had seized a vicious "manual" which prescribed methods of procurement and of enforcing the continued service of the women.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25. -- The first results of Harvard University's new policy of granting younger faculty members leaves of absence with full salary for independent research were revealed today. Ten young scholars have taken advantage of the plan started a year ago by Dr. James B. Conant, president.

IN the vast work of private relief no effort is deemed of more importance than lending a helping hand to youth and the needy child. This effort is emphasized by the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, which inaugurates today its parish drive for funds.

In the Tennessee Valley Authority's program of building dams for flood control and for the benefit of navigation, it was found that to maintain these dams erosion control would have to be initiated to prevent the reservoirs from filling with silt.

IN speed and efficiency the commercial airplanes of the United States are far superior to those of other countries. Nearly every nation on earth is either buying the products of American factories or trying to imitate them. Upward of forty world records are held here.

A girl who wouldn't be "jammed into a smooth narrow mold and turned out like a flabby jar of jelly" wasn't slated for a humdrum life. Gail Kincaid wanted to "tear the heart out of living and feel it throbbing in my hand." Life throbs meant romance to pretty young Gail.

An application was made yesterday in Surrogate's Court for issuance of letters of administration on the "goods, chattels and credits" of Antonio Scotti, Metropolitan Opera star, who died in Naples, Italy, last Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- A bill authorizing flood control projects to cost about $320,000,000, with another $100,000,000 in land costs and damages to be borne by State or local governments, will be reported to the Senate Monday, the Commerce Committee decided today.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The receivers for the Seaboard Air Line Railway have been taken to task by the Treasury Department for failure to make payments of past-due interest on old government loans to the road while at the same time paying similar private obligations.

THIS romantic novelette has a vaguely charming setting in a Louisiana swamp-forest, three characters equally vague and charming, and a story that is by contrast sharp and clear. By the terms of a will such as more often turns up in a movie, Paulina Charlesworth's great fortune is contingent on her making an annual monthly visit to Pontehartrain, La.

BOSTON'S "pop" concerts, described by the broadcasters as "an institution almost as old as the Boston Symphony Orchestra and quite as much a 'hub' at tradition as Boston baked beans," will be broacast on Saturday nights from 8:30 to 9:30 o'clock through the coast-to-coast facilities of WJZ's hook-up, beginning May 9.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Following is the text of the treaty between the United States and Panama covering all phases of relations between the two countries and which is now being considered in executive sessions by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

LAWRENCE, L.I., April 25. -- Onny Melmo, 86-year-old domestic who never sewed a stitch in her life and is not a good cook, but who is proud of having been born in Connaught, Ireland, the stronghold of the O'Connors before it was divided up into counties like Mayo, Sligo, Roscommon and Galway, was inclined to believe today she had achieved some after-a-fashion fame.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 25. -- In pageantry, including a procession of delegates from 250 universities and colleges and in academic cap and gown, the University of Chattanooga was saluted today on its birthday at the close of its semi-centennial celebration.
JERUSALEM, April 25. -- Arab disorders were reported in various parts of Palestine today, although in general the country was declared to be orderly.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area during the week fell below expectations, despite more favorable weather conditions. The special sales promotions launched by some stores drew good consumer response, but the average volume of leading department stores here was estimated as running about 7 to 8 per cent under the same period last year. Retail automobile sales continued to mount.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Pennsylvania lost a free-hitting game to the Penn Athletic Club nine in the Frankford Stadium today, 13 -- 11. George Jeffers was hammered for fifteen hits, Schaefer leading the way with four, including a pair of two-baggers.

The drive to raise books for distribution among the hospitals and charitable institutions of the city, started last week by the Book-Sharing Week committee, will be continued throughout the coming week, it was announced yesterday by Lewis E. Lawes, warden of Sing Sing prison, and Mrs. Sherman Post Haight, co-chairman of the campaign committee.

Textile High's baseball team, defending City P.S.A.L. champion, checked a late rally by Seward to beat the East Siders, 6 -- 5, in a Lower Manhattan-Richmond League contest at the Parade Grounds yesterday. Trailing by 6 -- 2 in the fourth, Seward counted twice in the fifth and three times in the seventh to fall just one run short of tying the score.

After running rampant in the first half, the Long Island University rugby team was held scoreless thereafter by a hard-fighting Pilgrims Rugby Club at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The margin was 27 to 0.

I enjoy opera a great deal, and I have heard almost every one of the broadcasts this season. I listen for the music and I dislike very much having the opera disrupted by the sudden intrusion of a sound-equipment man or a stagehand, who gives out a lot of trivial information wholly out of place during the broadcast.

The actual experience of retail stores with some branded lines of main-floor merchandise disproves the view that on these goods the set retail prices provide insufficient mark-up for the stores, according to a communication addressed to the business editor by Emanuel J. Weil, sales manager of the Van Raalte Company.

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 25. -- Preparations for the handling of the world's largest airship, the Hindenburg, when it arrives from Germany at the naval air station here on its first crossing of the North Atlantic early next month, are about complete, Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, commanding officer of the station, said today.
WE have been brought of late into signally renewed contact with the four great pioneering Post-Impressionists.

L.F. Sanman, a Class A gunner, won the trapshooting championship of the New York A.C. at Travers Island yesterday by breaking 196 out of a possible 200 targets. T.H. Lewis finished second with 194. Then came P. Garino, who had 192.

THE next regular season of the Metropolitan Opera Association should begin on Monday evening, Dec. 21. At least that is the tentative date. Since subscriptions are being received for a fourteen-week season, the opera will run until March 27.

UNRULY, even delinquent, children have been transformed into well-behaved members of the community solely through remedial instruction in reading, in a unique project undertaken during the past year by the Westchester County Children's Association.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP). -- Halting their losing streak after four straight, the Senators defeated Philadelphia today, 10 to 3. It was the third consecutive victory the Senators have scored over the Athletics this year without a loss.

THE thesis of Dean Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, in this book is it hat a nation founded, as is ours, on the principles of liberty and equality, is fated for trouble because those two principles are mutually antagonistic and can work in harmony only by compromise.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., April 25. -- The second annual Spring manoeuvres of the Knickerbocker Greys, junior cadet corps, was held here today. One hundred and twenty-five of the young cadets, nearly all members of prominent families, took part.

Blasting away at the offerings of three hurlers, Manhattan College's unbeaten nine crushed the previously undefeated Columbus Council baseball team, 17 -- 9, at the Parade Grounds in Brooklyn yesterday.

SAMUEL ADAMS helped to break the bonds that united Colonial America to England; George Washington fought to make that independence a fact, and Noah Webster wrote and lectured in the interest of unity and nationalism. The orators, soldiers and statesmen of the Revolutionary period have long been heralded by historians, but the scientists and scholars of our formative years have been more or less neglected.

MIAMI, Fla., April 25 (AP). -- Attorneys for Jane Thurston, daughter and co-worker of Howard Thurston, magician, who died at Miami Beach April 13, today filed a caveat in probate court here seeking to prevent the filing of any will which might be presented as having been signed by her father.
PARIS, April 25. -- Seldom has an election been held in the midst of such confusion of ideas, doctrines and personalities as that which will be held in France tomorrow.

SUSAN ERTZ'S latest novel, "Woman Alive," is a fantasy of the future that makes such recent Wellsiana as "Things to Come" seem pale and thin. For, in contrast to Wells's distant and mechanical fictions, her people of the future possess a notable warmth and a stalwart individuality.

From the perspective of its one hundredth convention, the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs will look back Friday upon thirty-three years of its history, to mark the milestone with a program of reminiscence and prophecy. Mrs. William Foster Rowland, president, will officiate at the proceedings in the Hotel Astor.
Mr. Benson divides his monograph into two parts, the first devoted to John Marin himself, the second to the art that has brought him fame in this country.

TORONTO, Ont., April 25. -- Because of $35 gold and the resulting increase in the value of ore reserves, leading Ontario mines have expanded their tonnage capacity by 25 per cent in the last four years.

NEW ORLEANS. PERIQUE tobacco plants are beginning to shoot their green leaves through the rich soil of Louisiana. The Cajun farmers, French-speaking descendants of the exiled Acadians about whom Longfellow sang in "Evangeline," regard the crops without enthusiasm.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, following a conference with Luis N. Morones, vice president of the Pan-American Federation of Labor, who was recently expelled from Mexico, yesterday issued a statement in which he said in part:

ASIDE from its intrinsic merit, "Man With a Bull Tongue Plow" had the asset of sheer novelty. These unconventional sonnets, written by a Kentuckian who actually works the soil, had a primitive, virile quality very much out of the ordinary.

HERBERT GEORGE WELLS probably will be grieved to hear that his world of 2036 is meeting with no more approval, and in some quarters with considerably less, than our world of 1936. Ever since "Things To Come" moved into the Rivoli we have been hearing complaints.

MIDLETOWN, N.Y., April 25. -- Gowidas Billious Ben today won the featured event on the second day of the annual field trial meeting of the Sport and Conservation League, which will be concluded tomorrow with the running of the open all-age stake.

POINTING to the freedom of the press as a "precious inheritance." Arming S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, declared "that freedom must be extended to radio" in an address at the recent luncheon of the Women's National Radio Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Temple University has elected as May Queen Miss R. Virginia Bagans, senior non-sorority girl, over a wide field of candidates on the basis of popularity, personality and scholarship.

THE gaillardia has always been an excellent perennial plant, and one which thrives in almost any situation. Poor soil, drought and even neglect never seem to interfere with its blooming. The flowering period is a long one, starting in June and continuing steadily through Summer and Fall.

OMAHA, April 23. -- There is anxious talk about the weather again in the Corn Belt. The hope held out in the heavy snowfall of January and early February for a return to normal precipitation has not been realized. The past two months have been so dry that the excess of precipitation accumulated during the Winter has been wiped out and deficiencies are now recorded.

AMONG the most assiduously collected art objects of the eighteenth century a special place must be conceded to Lady Hamilton. At one time or another four or five of the most discerning connoisseurs owned her, and when the beauty was by sedate auction transferred it was always to move into the richer gallery of a more resplendent collector.

TRENTON, N.J., April 25. -- The unemployed who took over New Jersey's Assembly chamber last Tuesday and have remained in session night and day ever since informed the Governor today that their move was an "insurrection," that they were actually "invaders" and that as Governor he should do something about it.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 25. -- Yale and M.I.T. opened New England's rowing season on Lake Quinsigamond today, the Elis gaining a clean sweep, all three of its crews winning with ease. Yale showed superiority throughout, with the final results never in doubt.

This little volume is the third in a series the Renaissance Society of the University of Chicago has been publishing; a series that began in 1934 with the appearance of James Johnson Sweeney's "Plastic Redirections in Twentieth Century Painting," followed by Edward F. Rothschild's "The Meaning of Unintelligibility in Modern Art."

The future of more than $4,000,000,000 of investments of insurance companies, mutual savings banks and other fiduciary institutions is regarded, in Wall Street, as tied up with the controversy over reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, which took definite form last week.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- A hastily called press conference by Governor Blanton Winship of Puerto Rico failed today to reveal the Governor's attitude toward the Tydings Independence Bill, but he gave to newspaper men a glowing picture of improved conditions in the island from economic, social and political standpoints.

WARSAW, April 25. -- Poland's capital was delighted with the magnificent reception Premier Marjan Zyndram Koscialkowski received in Budapest, hailing the age-long Polish-Hungarian friendship as one of the most gratifying factors in European politics.

DAPHNE DU MAURIER has a brilliant heritage. Her grandfather was George du Maurier, the creator of Trilby, and her father, as every one must know by now because of her recent biography of him, was the celebrated actor, Sir Gerald du Maurier.

THERE were 14,806 pilots and 7,205 aircraft holding active Department of Commerce licenses on April 1, 1936, according to a tabulation last week by the Bureau of Air Commerce. On April 1, 1935, there were 13,886 licensed pilots and 6,855 licensed aircraft.

ALBANY, April 25. -- Establishment of a State-wide system of district infirmaries for treatment of indigent persons having chronic diseases was recommended today by the State Board of Social Welfare in its annual report to the Legislature.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24. -- With labor difficulties on the San Francisco water front ended, conditions are rapidly returning to normal. All shipping is moving freely and so far as cargo handling is concerned no further disturbance is expected.

Social welfare projects of which the objective is improvement in the status of dependent, delinquent, transient and defective children, will hold the attention of the New Jersey division of the American Association of University Women on Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Franklin Field has been chosen as the scene of President Roosevelt's acceptance of renomination, James A. Farley, Democratic chairman, announced tonight. The ceremonies will take place at an outdoor demonstration the night of June 27 at the athletic grounds of the University of Pennsylvania.

A 30,000-ACRE game preserve is in the process of development near Natural Bridge, Va. Situated in Augusta County, in the northern end of the Natural Bridge division of the George Washington National Forest, this tract has been set aside by Presidential proclamation as the laboratory of a national experiment in wild-life propagation.

ALTHOUGH there is a certain opinion, backed by excellent medical authority, that profound thought and added cares do not of themselves induce thinning locks and premature grayness, there is little in baseball to support this encouraging belief.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 25. -- Manhattan College freshman crews scored a clean sweep against Hun School on Lake Carnegie today.

With the running of the Wood Memorial yesterday there are no more hurdles for the Kentucky Derby eligibles before the sixty-second running of that famous horse race on Saturday at Churchill Downs. The test is at a mile and a quarter, carries $40,000 in added money, and is one of the oldest races of its kind in the West, dating back to 1875.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 25. -- For the third successive time Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and Gene Mako of Los Angeles defeated Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, and John Van Ryn of Philadelphia, the national champions, today in the final round of the Mason-Dixon doubles championship at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

It was only three years ago that Texas legally declared Stephen F. Austin The Father of Texas, ninety-seven years after his death. How much he merited the title, at what cost of health, money and personal ambition he sacrificed himself to further his dreams for Texas, are made clear in this biography.

Two important sets of early eightenth century dining chairs, numbering thirteen pieces in all, brought together a $2,275 purchase at the last session yesterday of an auction of valuable English and French period furniture, tapestries and rugs from the Madeleine Scheuer, William Mitchell and other estates at the Anderson Galleries.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, which left Southampton on April 15 for the Clyde to undergo her trials, will be in charge of chief pilot Captain Duncan Cameron, assisted by Captain John Liguria Murchie, also a Clyde pilot.

WASHINGTON. -- The defense budget of the nation has reached a new peace-time peak; despite our "good neighbor" policy and our announced intention of keeping out of war, the United States is keeping pace with a rearming world.

The largest single gifts, $5,000 and $2,500, to the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army have come from public utilities, it was disclosed by Chalmers Wood, chairman of the appeal, when he made public a list of contributions yesterday.

IN the seven short stories collected under the group-title "The World Over" Edith Wharton, in spite of some minor lapses, proves that her reputation as a master of this form of literary art remains for the most part unimpaired.

After a twenty-minute chase in the area from Ninth to Twelfth Avenue between Fifty-seventh and Fifty-ninth Streets, during which two radio car policemen fired twelve shots at them, four unidentified young men, riding in a stolen automobile, eluded their pursuers shortly before 10:30 o'clock last night, abandoning the car at Fifty-fourth Street and Ninth Avenue.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 25. -- A painting, once the property of Thomas Jefferson, and recently bequeathed to the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation by Miss Mary K. Chapman, a greatniece of James Madison, has been identified as an important work by the Spanish and Neapolitan master, Jose Ribera.

THE wanderlust that assails most people in the Spring is in a way responsible for new baggage and equipment designed to fill the needs of the weekend traveler. A dressy, party box suitcase is intended for those clothes one is particularly anxious to keep smooth and fresh.

The Colombian Bondholders Committees for the Republic of Colombia are preparing to call upon the trustees and fiscal agents to take steps provided for in the trust indentures in the event of defaults, by declaring the bonds due and payable in full, and, if payments are not made, to take foreclosure proceedings, Lawrence E. de S. Hoover, executive secretary of the committees, announced yesterday.

ANY who pursue music with the help and guidance of Sir Walford Davies are likely sooner or later to catch up with a good deal of it. The book is considerably different from the elementary or even the more advanced manuals of "appreciation."

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With a number of events on the calendar for the remainder of April, the round of activies for this week will open with a kickers' handicap eighteen-hole medal golf tournament, to be played over the picturesque Pine Needles course this afternoon.

Reminiscent of Saturday trading in midsummer, the share market idled through the two-hour session yesterday. Stocks fluctuated within narrow limits and closed steady at generally higher levels. The volume on the Stock Exchange was 536,000 shares, the smallest since Sept. 28, and compared with 809,000 the Saturday before.

EARLE S. BALCH of Putnam's, who returned recently from his annual trip to England and the Continent, is all excited about "The Lordless," by Eleanor C. Kneen, a first novel of fifteenth century Europe for which he secured the American rights while he was in London.

MOSCOW, April 25. -- The tenth anniversary of the founding of the Blood Transfusion Institute was marked yesterday by the publication of statistics showing the development of the enormous extent of its work over much of the Soviet Union.

MR. THOMAS BURKE here serves you up the historic tale of the murder of the gambler William Weare by the provincial sporting blade, John Thurtell, that took place over a hundred years ago in England all Elstree, which gave a new word, gigmanity, to the language, which Borrow mentions in "Lavengro," and which Edmund Pearson has, I believe, celebrated in one of his yarns.

The national lacrosse tournament which Miss Martha Butler, president of the New York association, is arranging for the week-end of May 8, 9 and 10 at the Riverdale School in Fieldston at 252d Street and Broadway will be the culmination of an unusually active season.

The Diavolo colt, Teufel, which never before had won a race, was first by a nose yesterday at Jamaica before a record crowd of 20,000 persons which turned out to see seven formidable candidates for the Kentucky Derby try their speed in the $14.275 Wood Memorial. It was the thirteenth start of Teufel's career.
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 25. -- Stanford's Indians scored a surprisingly one-sided track victory over the University of California today, 75 3/8 to 55 5/8, before 10,000 fans.

The legend is that exactly 2,689 years ago last Tuesday, on the festival of the shepherd goddess Pales, Romulus, a martial man, marked out the site of Rome. Last week the Italians simultaneously celebrated the legendary act of Romulus and the wholly factual accomplishments of another martial man -- Pietro Badoglio, supreme commander in Ethiopia, who is pressing down toward Addis Ababa and triumph.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 25. -- John Hamilton, campaign manager for Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, declared in an address here today that the percentage of child labor in the Southern States has not been reduced

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- In May the opening of two Federal reclamation projects in Oregon to homesteading will in a small way revive an aspect of the old frontier, where land from the public domain was to be had for the asking.

AVON, N.Y., April 25 (AP). -- Once famous for its curative mineral waters, this little Livingston County village is seeking to regain the place it held among the nation's spas. The movement is sponsored by Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth of Geneseo and State Senator Joe R. Hanley of Perry.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Consultation, rather than definite arrangements for the defense of the approaches to the Panama Canal Zone in event of aggression, is provided for in the new treaty between Panama and the United States. The latter drops its role of guardian of the former, an uncorrected text of the treaty, kept secret by the State Department and Senate Foreign Relations Committee, revealed today.

THE turbulent waters of the Missouri River are being brought under control for navigation by United States Army engineers, backed by emergency funds. From the Fort Peck Dam on the arid northeastern plains of Montana to where the river joins the Mississippi just above St. Louis, construction actively proceeds.

There seems to be a belief in other European capitals that the Berlin regime stands in rather constant need of "victories." In other words, there is a feeling among Germany's neighbors that Hitler will try to continue heroic measures to show the populace of the Reich what a great fellow he is and what he can do for the country as long as it votes 99 per cent for him.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25. -- Harvard University asserted its independence of the Federal Government today and, in a statement issued by Jerome D. Greene, secretary to the Harvard Corporation and director of the tercentenary exercises, snubbed the United States Senate's efforts to constitute itself part of the tercentenary reception committee.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The week of April 27 to May 2 is Garden Week in Virginia -- a true festival of flowers. Many famous gardens will be thrown open to the public. Those easily accessible from Hot Springs are in Lexington, Charlottesville, Staunton, James River (South Side), Lynchburg, Harrisonburg and Roanoke.

Dr. Paul F. Sarubbi, Alderman from the First district, Manhattan, for whom a bench warrant as a material witness had been issued, surrendered yesterday and submitted to three hours questioning about some of the affairs of John Torrio, who has been characterized as this city's Public Enemy No. 2.

DES MOINES, April 25. -- Glenn Cunningham, veteran of the American foot-racing wars, and Don Lash, welterweight Indiana University speedster who may some day take Cunningham's place as ruler of the middle distances, gave America's Olympic hopes a boost today by racing to new American records in the twenty-seventh annual Drake relays.

Mr. LA GUARDIA in Portland, Ore., made a brave attempt the other day to appraise married happiness in kilowatts, but the thing cannot be done. He was addressing the conference of Mayors and he argued that cheap electric power means fewer divorces.

The recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES by F.L. Adams, titled "Disorders at Sea Laid to Red Tape," is interesting as indicating one of the stagnant spots in relation to the development of American commerce, so much so that it is unfortunate that he has brought out one premise that is entirely erroneous.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 25. -- Before sailing for Peru John L. Merrill, president of the Pan-American Society, declared yesterday that his six weeks' tour of Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina and Chile had given him the impression that cordiality was growing among the American peoples and sentiment was steadily crystallizing in favor of collective unity for mutual help in peace.

PASSING in review the season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra which terminates today, it transpired that the organization gave 122 concerts over a period of thirty weeks. There were 110 subscription concerts in Carnegie Hall, a series of Saturday' morning children's concerts in the same auditorium, three out-of-town concerts, one pension-fund concert and a concert in which the orchestra participated for the Carnegie centennial celebration.

BOSTON, April 25. -- Department store trade during the last fortnight has been down substantially from the pre-Easter peak. Protracted cold weather has been a retarding factor. Most wholesale lines are active. The demand for men's clothing is reported as particularly satisfactory.

PARIS, April 25. -- On the eve of the elections the Bourse showed today surprising firmness and even strength in the department of public funds. Bank stocks, too, were strong and, although business was restricted, the internal market remained satisfactory.

BERLIN, April 25. -- The propaganda commission for the Olympics has announced a program of five conducted tours in various parts of Germany for Olympic guests. The idea has been borrowed from the Soviet Intourist propaganda tours in Russia.

A UNIFIED front is expected to result from the annual meeting of the Screen Writers Guild to be held during the coming week. Writers are displaying a fortitude not hitherto evident and, with a fusion between the more and the less conservative members as a result of recent meetings, there is considerable optimism over the eventual outcome of the war with producers.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland called the bluff of the Puerto Rican agitators when he introduced Thursday a bill providing for the complete independence of their island, in the opinion of most people here who are in close touch with the situation.

THOUGH I shall presently have to find considerable fault with it, this is by no means an uninteresting book. The author gives evidence of knowing postwar Europe at first hand, of possessing an observant and sometimes witty mind, and of knowing how to write.

THE well-established tradition that a policeman's lot is full of a number of things is adequately borne out by the author in this highly readable book. For here are recorded the experiences of a government patrol officer in Papua and Northeastern New Guinea, where head-hunting, cannibalism and similar diversions are more or less rampant.

THE Italo-Ethiopian war incites a small, secretly affiliated group of pacifists, plotting in England, to force an end to hostilities by aiming a deadly blow at the efficient transport of Italian troops, supplies, munitions into Abyssinia via the Suez Canal.

The University of Pennsylvania scored its second triumph in as many days by beating Columbia's netmen, 8 -- 1, on the South Field courts at Columbia yesterday. The Lions' lone victory came in the singles, with Schwartzman being extended to beat Albert, 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

It is getting to be quite the thing for detectives in mystery fiction to make friends with brilliant amateurs, and if ever a detective needed such a friend it is Inspector Arnold of Scotland Yard. To Arnold is assigned the task of finding out who killed the man whose headless body is found in a milk can.

CINCINNATI, April 25 (AP). -- Eugene Schott held the league champion Cubs in check today and the Reds bagged a 5-to-3 victory. Following a double conquest of the Cardinals the triumph enabled Cincinnati to tighten its hold on second place.

When the Social Security Bill was before Congress Senator CLARK introduced a series of amendments to permit exemptions from the old-age payroll taxes of companies that had private old-age pension plans "not less favorable" to those to be benefited by them than the Government's plan.

Students at Hunter College have earned almost $77,000 since the beginning of the academic year in September, according to figures released yesterday by Mrs. Harriet L. Loewenstein, director of the Bureau of Occupations. Approximately one-fourth of the student population has been placed by the bureau in part-time positions outside college or in work under relief funds.

A recent letter in these columns from Marion Meyer Drew, relating to the alleged dastardly plot of women-folk to take over, usurp and otherwise dominate spheres hitherto held by mere man, might be replied to (chauvinistically, perhaps) that it would have been well had Harriet Beecher Stowe never been born to write "Uncle Tom's Cabin."

Your remarks on the drivel that is served up during the intermissions at the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts has brought such an avalanche of letters that the one I intended to write has never been missed. I can now only add my voice to the others that approved the criticism.

CLEVELAND, April 25. -- Republican leaders, by their two-day meeting here this week, created an impression of impartiality toward the party's rival candidacies for the Presidential nomination. This impartiality, on the face of things, extended also to sectional groups and to disparate viewpoints that tested Republicans might bring to the national convention to be held here next June.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Once more there is active discussion of the relations and methods of the government with the press. And once more it may be well to report that, in the observation of this correspondent, great clouds of smoke are issuing from a very small fire.

The seamen who recently held up the steamship California several days in San Francisco in an effort to obtain better wages are classed as strikers by Secretary PERKINS, as mutineers by Secretary ROPER. On the President Garfield there was unquestionably a mutiny when an officer was assaulted -- a mutiny which the master quelled by taking proper disciplinary action.

Differences between near and distant deliveries were widened further on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, May going to a premium of 121 points over October and the list ending 3 points higher to 6 lower than on Friday.

Three New Yorkers and a Los Angeles player were returned victors in the first round of the United States chess championship yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Astor grill before a large gathering of chess enthusiasts.

ATLANTIC CITY. -- Golf, horseback riding and trout fishing hold the interest of sportsmen visiting Atlantic City this Spring. Hundreds of men and women here for recreation are found daily at the golf courses at Linwood, Seaview, Northfield, Brigantine and Somers Point, all within a few minutes by automobile from the resort. A number of the clubs have planned Spring tournaments.

OBERLIN, Ohio. STUDENT thought at Oberlin College is keyed to a high political pitch in anticipation of the quadrennial mock convention, to be held on the evenings of May 8 and 9. This will be the nineteenth of such conventions, held in Presidential campaign years, the custom having begun in 1860 and continued without interruption except for 1912.

Several committees of prominent young women are assisting with plans for a celebration to mark the opening of the new Polo Bar at the Hotel Westbury on Thursday afternoon as a benefit for the Police Athletic League of the Juvenile Aid Bureau. The party will advance the work of the bureau in providing wholesome recreation for thousands of underprivileged children.

FROM "Mrs. Wiggs of the Cabbage Patch" to "February Hill" this story of poor people blessed because they are pure in heart has been told over and over again. Radclyffe Hall's contribution is no very notable addition to the genre.

New Utrecht went into a first-place tie with Abraham Lincoln High for the Section I leadership of the Brooklyn-Queens Division of the P.S.A.L. championship handball tournament by blanking Thomas Jefferson, 5 -- 0, on the James Madison High courts yesterday.

The engagement of $11,130,000 of gold in Paris for shipments here was announced yesterday as the flight of capital from France increased on the eve of today's parliamentary elections. Added to the $7,115,000 gold that had been taken on Friday, yesterday's engagements brought the total for the two days to $18,245,000.

I read with much interest your comments under date of Sunday, April 5, on the intermission broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera Association during the Saturday matinees. I recall very distinctly the interview with Mr. Melchior to which you refer, and, as a listener at the time, I thought it quite interesting.

AN elaborate new lighting system at the Rhode Island State Airport, supplemented by other equipment recently installed, has made that port New England's finest flying field and one of the most completely equipped in the East.
The annual call to students to "strike" for peace last Wednesday found the desire to cut classes for this purpose all but extinguished among the city's high school pupils.

The use of child labor was condemned as "folly and injustice" in a declaration of principles adopted by the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church of the United States of America, after a two-day meeting at the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue.

BOSTON, April 25. -- The Yankees invaded Fenway Park for the initial skirmish of a two-game series today and retreated from the ball park in the Back Bay section still seeking their first victory over Robert Moses Grove in two seasons.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Virginia Gold Cup Racing Committee has announced the following officials for the races to be run next Saturday: Stewards: A.S. Craven, Greenwood, Va.; F. Wallis Armstrong, Mooresville, N.J.; W. Wallace Lanahan, Baltimore.
HAMBURG, N.J., April 25. -- Victor R. Clouse, 24 years old, was arrested today charged with running down and killing his 2-year-old nephew and then speeding away from the accident.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were fewer than in any week in several months. Not only were the calls smaller in number, but they did not include any large amount of bonds. The notices were chiefly for small blocks of municipal bonds, mostly for redemption in May.

James A. (Buck) Freeman, veteran St. John's University basketball and baseball coach, will not hold the positions at the school at the close of this term, it was announced last night. Acceptance of Freeman's resignation from both jobs was made at the last regular meeting of the board of athletic control, held last Tuesday, the results of which were first made known last night.

MOSCOW, April 25. -- For the first two months of this year, the latest for which statistics are available, the Soviet Union has shipped no manganese to Germany, although last year the Soviet supplied Germany with large quantities.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25. -- Paced by Captain Harry Wilson's five goals, a hard-hitting Army four handed the Princeton polo team a 10-2 defeat today on Devereux Field in the Tigers' opening contest of the season.
I The text of the address of President Roosevelt last night the annual Jefferson Day dinner of the National Democratic Club at the Hotel Commodore follows:

Headed by Lord Horder of England, physician-in-ordinary to King Edward VIII, an impressive list of speakers will be heard tomorrow during the thirtieth annual meeting of the Women's Medical Society of New York State. Sessions and clinics will be held at the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

GLYNDON, Md., April 25. -- One of the great prizes of American amateur racing came home to Maryland today when Inshore scored a smashing victory in the forty-third running of the Maryland Hunt Cup event. It came right home, in fact, for Inshore is the property of J.W.Y. Martin, and it is through Mr. Martin's grounds that this great timber race is run.

Four firemen were Injured yesterday at 9 A.M. when the hose truck in which they were riding was in a collision with an Ocean Avenue trolley car at Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn. The firemen were on their way to a fire at East Sixteenth Street and Emmons Avenue, Brooklyn, in which a woman and two patrolmen were burned.

If lovers were not desperately stupid about discovering the state of the beloved one's heart, many burning romances would never be written. "In Lilac Time" is one of them. It is founded on the good old thesis that love is blind.

Two men arrested after an attempted hold-up of a Brooklyn jewelry store Friday admitted yesterdays, according to the police, that they were implicated in the $11,300 hold-up of the Nanuet National Bank at Nanuet, N.Y., March 20. A man was shot and two women were kidnapped in the robbers' escape from Nanuet.

Although their competitive career is only seven months old, the New York Police Department's well-trained bay geldings stalked off with the premier honors last night in the three-phase, low-score, military jumping competition, feature of the two-day horse show, sponsored by the Brooklyn Elks, Lodge 22, at Edwin R. Teevan's Riding Academy.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, April 25 (AP). -- The Presidential secretariat stated tonight that rebel uprisings had been crushed at Santa Barbara, Olancho and EL Paraiso. As a result, it was declared, the whole nation was now absolutely peaceful and all commercial and agricultural activities were being carried on in a normal manner.

THREE thousand years ago there emerged out of the mists of the Mediterranean a vision of loveliest womanhood. Over land and sea she moved, hither and thither, serene in shine or storm, and all who looked upon her were silenced by her changeless beauty. Nor has the memory of that wonder faded from men's minds.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Discovery of a "window" in the Milky Way, through which man is able for the first time to look through the vast clouds of chaos into the great beyond on the other side of the universe, was reported here today before the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Philosophical Society by Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory.

THE very announcement of a fine novel from modern Iceland has a curious and stimulating effect upon the imagination. It is a little like hearing that a great symphony has just come from Alaska, or a stupendous mural from Tasmania.
Ramsey Conklin and his tattered brood were glad to breathe the free air of their greening hill in Pomona at sundown yesterday after almost getting to see New York and the big circus.

THERE are about Old John the same qualities of kindliness and contentment which made Marie Etts's "Mr. Penny" such a lovable and memorable figure. Old John lived at Tir Aulin in a thatched cottage overlooking the sea, and behind him towered the Irish mountains, "the two grandest sights any man could wish for."

ALBANY, April 25. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the bill of Assemblyman Stewart, Republican, of Clinton, which would have provided an eight-hour workday for all employes in State prisons, reformatories and State hospitals for the criminal insane.
CLEVELAND, April 25 (AP). -- Cleveland was forced to share first place in the American League with the Red Sox when the Browns defeated the Indians, 6 to 3, today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 25. -- Although he drove two home runs and a triple, Dick Baldwin, Lafayette pitched, lost a ten-inning contest with the Naval Academy today, 9 to 8. Baldwin allowed fourteen safeties, including a home run, a triple and two doubles.

ROME, Sunday, April 26. -- Italian war correspondents reported today that forty airplanes, dropping tons of bombs on Ethiopian defense works at Sasa Baneh and other points on the southeastern front, had caused the defending forces to swing out in desperate but unsuccessful attempts to check the Italian advance.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Conspicuous among the features of the Pennsylvania primary campaign which will end Tuesday in the election of delegates to the national conventions and nomination of candidates for Congress and State offices, is the drive which the Democrats are making to poll more votes than their rivals in this, one of the last strongholds of Republicanism.

HIROHITO, Emperor of Japan, will be 35 years old next Wednesday. Supreme ruler of 66,000,000 Japanese and 30,000,000 Koreans, protector of 30,000,000 Manchurians, he is the least known of all the world's rulers. The paradoxes of the East seem to meet in his position, at once all powerful and circumscribed by etiquette and tradition.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Surprise was expressed among Senators today when it was reported that Harvard University "resented" passage of a resolution by the Senate yesterday stating that the United States Government and its people "unite with Harvard" in celebrating its 300th anniversary.

In the face of protests by twelve business organizations, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine approved yesterday the request of the United Labor May Day Committee for a joint march of Communists, Socialists, trade unionists and members of unemployed groups through the midtown section on Friday.

Days of Kentucky colonels may be numbered by reason of the recent abrogation of their commissions but there are no such hardships and loss of face in store for the New York yachtsmen who have during recent weeks been receiving grotesque, multi-colored diplomas giving them the rank of admiral from the sly comic, Dr. Seuss.

LET this morning's first bulletin creep out into the Springtime sun, unfold itself and report the founding of a new triumvirate of theatrical producers. And, if it is names you want, the three are Ben Hecht, Charles MacArthur and Leland Hayward.

Recuperating from the shock brought on by the double setback at the hands of the Dodgers, the Giants regained their winning stride at the expense of the Bees yesterday at the Polo Grounds, coasting in with an 11-5 victory, much to the satisfaction of some 10,000 chilled observers.
Credit must be given to the President of the United States for his selection of people from whom he obtains commentary that places in ridicule bankers, newspaper editors and old men.

DETAILED analysis of the Verona primitives in the Cannon collection, recently presented to the Museum of Historic Art by Frank Jewett Mather Jr. of Princeton, reveals the extent and significance of the benefaction. "The collection consists of fifty-five pictures, of which thirty-four are of the Veronese school," explains Mr. Mather, "the most complete and important group in America and, perhaps, only surpassed at London, Milan and Verona itself.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, April 2. -- Once more the Flying Camel will spread its wings on the shores of the Mediterranean as the emblem of the Levant Fair, which opens at Tel Aviv on April 30. Now an institution in this modern young city, this exposition bids fair to surpass any of the many thus far held here.

The relief program of the Roosevelt administration forestalled a revolution in the country and continued governmental expenditures have prevented the "wiping out of the small bourgeoisie," delegates were told yesterday at the opening of the national convention of the Socialist Labor party in the Cornish Arms Hotel.

The six-car Roosevelt special pulled into Pennsylvania Station at 7:29 o'clock last night. Aside from considerable police activity on the upper level, the arrival was quiet and slightly ahead of schedule. Rather than be delayed at the hotel, the Presidential party chose to remain aboard for several minutes.

WHEN people in mystery stories withhold information from the police, their reasons for so doing are often downright silly. But in this story the reasons are perfectly logical. For the persons who withhold the information are, in any case, almost sure to be suspected of the murder, and the evidence that they fail to give would almost certainly convict at least one of them.

The permanent outdoor flower show assembled at the Gardens of the Nations in Rockefeller Center will be ablaze with Spring blossoms for the opening tomorrow of the three-day Spring Flower Festival to be conducted for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 25. -- A bulletin late this evening reported that King Fuad, who is very ill, had had a fairly quiet day, that the hemorrhage from which he was suffering had stopped and that his condition was stationary. The previous bulletin, issued shortly after noon, had declared that the King had spent a comparatively calm night, that his fever was stationary, but that general and circulatory weakness were considerably aggravated.

THE TIMES last Sunday quoted an editorial from The St. Louis Post-Dispatch entitled "Massachusetts and Virginia," in which it is stated that Faneuil Hall is "the cradle of American liberty and is so accounted in the imperishable entablature of fact."

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- After Governor George H. Earle had made public his tax plan for the raising of unemployment relief funds there was somewhat less certainty this week among legislators that the forthcoming special session of the General Assembly would be a short one.

HAVANA, April 25. -- A gun fight within a block of police headquarters of Guanaboca, across the bay from Havana, resulted today in three known deaths, and in the belief that two other men had been slain in reprisal.
BERLIN, April 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
If yachtsmen weren't such an optimistic breed they might conclude that the Spring's cold weather is going to last all Summer and start laying in new heating stoves for their cabins.

LONDON, April 25, -- One of the finest sailing ships, the Finnish four-masted barque Herzogin Cecilie, 3,111 tons, which had just won the annual grain race from Australia for the eighth time, is now lying fast on the rocks of the Devon coast, badly holed and being pounded to pieces by heavy seas.

IT may be esteemed no slight task to cover, in one volume, a span of 5,000 years. Professor Anthony's is, however, a special field -- the art of mosaic -- so that he finds it possible to survey this vast field, and in a manner commendably thorough, without recourse to small type.

More than 5,000 musicians employed on the WPA music units will take part in local and Statewide Spring music festivals throughout the country during National Music Week, May 3-10, it was announced yesterday. Practically all of the programs, the announcement disclosed, will be devoted largely to the works of American composers.

An eight-run drive in the seventh inning gave the Wagner College nine a 12-5 triumph over the New Jersey State Teachers College of Trenton yesterday at Sisco Park, Port Richmond, S.I. Going the route, Fred Schnackenberg hurled the Hilltoppers to their third straight victory, allowing only six hits.

Employing a new plan of financial aid, Columbia graduates, through the alumni fund committee, this year will assume the support of definite educational activities previously maintained by budget appropriations from the general revenues of the university.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 25. -- Lanky Leon Carter of Lexington, Ky., smiling broadly, pocketed the $6,625 winner's share of the $7,500 added Philadelphia Handicap, annexed today by his one and only horse, Black Gift, a rank outsider.

IT has been a good season on Broadway, the road and in the coffers of the Stage Relief Fund, the records of which show twenty Sunday night benefits. This total includes "Love on the Dole," scheduled for this evening.

Experiments to determine whether or not young school children enjoy music that has an educational value were conducted yesterday at Lincoln School, Columbia University, by members of the Junior Program Department of the National Music League.

Everybody hates taxes, especially higher taxes. Like war, they seem to be a scourge that is always with us. Last week saw a new tax bill launched in the American Congress; it also witnessed higher income taxes in Great Britain. There was a great difference between the two.
AMHERST, Mass., April 25. -- Army defeated Amherst, 8 -- 4, today on Stromberg's home run with the bases loaded in the sixth inning. It was the West Pointers' first appearance on an Amherst diamond.

THIS being the second annual National Dance Week, a program of special events has been arranged for the dance section of the Music Library, 121 East Fifty-eighth Street, as follows: Monday Lucile Marsh will speak on "The American Dance."

LONDON, April 25 (Canadian Press). -- The extra touch of finesse that so often marks the difference between first and second-division English football league teams gave Arsenal supporters plenty to enthuse over today.

Representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission at noon yesterday served on White, Weld Co. an order to show cause why the firm, eleven partners and two former partners, should not be suspended or expelled from membership in the New York Stock Exchange, the New York Curb Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade for alleged manipulation of the common stock of the A.O. Smith Corporation on the Curb Exchange.

The story of the Tattered Brigade, the plucky, oddly assorted band of backwoodsmen and aristocrats who harried and nagged the British to distraction through the Carolina lowlands during the latter days of the Revolution, is told with spirit in this account of the adventures of one young soldier.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25. -- The Bears won their ninth consecutive game and tightened their grip on first place in the International League today with a 15-to-7 victory in a free-hitting match with Rochester.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25. -- The Harvard and Princeton Rugby teams divided a double-header at Soldiers Field today. The Harvard first team beat the Tiger firsts, 5 to 3, while Princeton's seconds won the "junior varsity" struggle, 8 to 0.

LOCAL history for the highway tourist is being written in the form of brief stories and set up by the side of the road so that he who drives may read. Each marker narrates briefly and concisely something significant and interesting about the spot in which it is placed. When a New York State "book" of markers is completed in 1937 there will be 5,500 "chapters," each written at the roadside in buff and blue.

Frank Cumiskey, Swiss Turn Verein of Hudson County star, gave an impressive series of performances in retaining his all-around Metropolitan A.A.U. senior gymnastic championship at the forty-fifth annual title meet held last night at Sokol Hall, Manhattan.

Only nature appears to be fighting Ethiopia's battles now, for the latest news from the front indicates that the Italian troops are moving on Addis Ababa with no resistance except what they encounter from the rough and muddy roads. Even correspondents in the Ethiopian capital, who have been optimistic about Haile 'Selassie's chances of delaying the Italian advance, now admit that Marshal Badoglio's soldiers will oe in the city within a few days.

Although New York builders have a reputation for tearing down buildings and replacing them with new structures more rapidly than those in almost any other city, more than three-quarters of the occupied residential area of Manhattan compromises homes and tenements at least thirty-five years old, according to a report made public yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on City Planning.

A CONCERT this afternoon and a concert Wednesday night, instituted especially in his honor, and Arturo Toscanini ends his term of eleven years as conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. This will probably be his last public appearance in America.

LONDON, April 25 (AP). -- A sharp, chilling wind cut short a practice session by America's Curtis Cup women golfers today at Sandy Lodge, near here, where on Monday the invaders will play an informal series of four-ball matches paired with British stars.

Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd had under scrutiny yesterday several bank accounts of Charles Hemendinger, acting detective sergeant who committed suicide Friday afternoon after he had been summoned to testify before the extraordinary grand jury in Brooklyn in its investigation of alleged bribery in the murder of Samuel Drukman.
ADDIS ABABA, April 25. -- Two three-engined Caproni bombers flew over Addis Ababa this morning soon after an air-raid alarm had been given.

WITH the coming of Spring auto tourists are once again streaming into the capital and putting up at the government's tourist camp, which lies along the Potomac River, within sight of the Capitol and the Washington Monument.

STIFF-NECKED: As the last stage of a trip from Africa via Jersey City to the Madison Square Garden Circus, a ten-foot giraffe was taken by truck last week to the entrance to the Holland Vehicular Tunnel -- but the critter wouldn't bend its neck, and there wasn't room for it with neck extended.
THE West Coast as well as New York is planning a world's fair in 1939. The San Francisco Bay cities are preparing for the largest "bridge party" ever known and expect more than 20,000,000 visitors.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The death of Louis McHenry Howe, chief secretary to the President and his political mentor for more than twenty-five years, created a vacancy in the intimate staff assisting Mr. Roosevelt which cannot possibly be filled in the same manner as before.
After four months, of comparative quiet, importers and customs department officials again were embroiled in sharp conflict last week over the department's literal enforcement of customs regulations.

A minimum of formal addresses and a maximum of conferences for discussion of problems of youth will characterize the program of the fourteenth biennial of the Y.W.C.A., opening Wednesday afternoon at Colorado Springs. Over the week-end staff members from headquarters at 600 Lexington Avenue and fifteen delegates from New York are on their way westward for the event, led by Mrs. Cleveland Earl Dodge, metropolitan president.

A pronounced upswing in the purchase of women's Summer apparel and accessories is expected here beginning this week with the arrival of a large number of out-of-town buyers. The resident buying offices look for a steady gain in the number of arrivals until well into May, in the belief that the retail Summer season will be one of the most active in years.

Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday that real estate tax payments up to Friday night totaled $90,579,689.39, or almost $20,000,000 more than had been paid into the city treasury on the same date last year.

HOLLYWOOD. THE extraordinary special gala premiere, which lay in Hollywood's cedar chest during the depression years because of the fear of riots by unemployed in protest against such ostentation, has been but recently revived.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 25. -- The department of ceramics of Rutgers University opened its fourth ceramic exposition this week to display until next Saturday products of seventy-five industrial companies from eight States.

IN the beautiful little volume written by Campbell Dodgson, bearing the copyright of M. Knoedler Co., and illustrated with Forain's works in reproduction, the British author calls Forain "Draughtsman, Lithographer, Etcher."

The University of Cincinnati Glee Club, under the direction of Sherwood Kains, was heard in a concert last night at the Town Hall. The organization, consisting of some eighty voices, included both the Men's Glee Club and the Girls' Glee Club of the college.

BERLIN, April 24. -- Along the historic half-mile of Unter den Linden between the Schloss and Brandenburg Gate and along a further half-mile where the broad highway runs through the Tiergarten toward Charlottenburg, crowds stood from a dozen to a score deep last Monday, impressed with the military spectacle before them.

Outside of the usually inactive staples, there was nothing to record in yesterday's commodity future markets but slight losses in quiet trading. In the cash markets, wheat, cotton and standard tin rose, while corn declined.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- After successful early trout fishing with with the heavier lures, fly fishermen in the Berkshires are looking forward to several important opening dates relating to their sport. These include May 1, when all State forest streams may be fished; the May 15 opening of the private waters of the Alford Brook Club, the lifting on May 30 of the ban on Onota Lake and its tributaries and the Deerfield River.

Dr. Frederick A. Stock, who for more than thirty years was conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, will direct a symphony orchestra of approximately 150 musicians at an all-star benefit, sponsored by the Committee for the Relief and Liberation of Victims of Persecution in Europe, on Sunday evening, May 3, at Madison Square Garden.

ANNETTE KELLERMANN, post-war "Diving Venus," star of the silent motion pictures "Neptune's Daughter" and "A Daughter of the Gods," introducer of the one-piece bathing suit, has come back to America (home of the lubritorium, the Chinamat, the motorcade, ) from her native Australia, bringing with her something new in etymology, impossible as that may sound.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, was asked in a telegram today by Chairman Ramspeck of the House Civil Service Committee if he would urge House Republican leaders to withdraw their objection to his bill to place all postmasters under civil service.

ROCHESTER, April 25 (AP). -- With a new instrument he calls a vibrometer, George W. Jacobus, 24-year-old inventor, has obtained pictures of street car vibrations, building oscillations and the almost imperceptible movements caused by a roomful of workers.

EVEN in the year which saw NRA outlawed, the New Deal apparently was not the most engrossing subject of public discussion in these United States. As a topic for harangues, the international situation outclassed it by more than two to one, if figures just obtained by the Federal Office of Education from 200 public forums in all parts of the country are generally applicable.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission in an amendment to its registration statement that its $30,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, series H, will be offered to the public on April 28 at 102 3/4 per cent of par, exclusive of accrued interest.

NEW JERSEY'S high school students in the future will be required to take organized courses in automobile driving and highway safety. The adoption of this plan, which will go into effect with the opening of school next September, marks New Jersey as one of the first States to make such courses compulsory.

PARIS. THE Spring holidays offer the Paris coutures an excuse to create little collections for their favorite private clients to wear in or out of town. These miniature collections are worth consideration, for they contain more than a hint of the trends to be revealed in the forthcoming mid-season showings.

With retail distribution showing substantial gains over sales in the corresponding period last year in most of the Federal Reserve districts, business in general maintained a fairly steady pace last week. Protracted cold weather held down buying to some extent in various sections, particularly in New England and the Midwest; but, where weather conditions were more favorable, the movement of Spring merchandise stocks was active.

This week, with the Tax Bill presumably out of the way, the House is scheduled to debate the proposed appropriations for relief. The extent of these appropriations must depend upon the extent and probable duration of our unemployment problem, but that problem is still surrounded by uncertainty.

MOSCOW, April 25. -- The Communist party put its foot down hard today on the theory that a superman can be created through the application of a substance reported designed to regenerate human mental processes.

WITH THE NORTHERN ARMY, Below Dessye, Ethiopia (by Military Airplane to Asmara, Eritrea), April 25. -- There is a lessening in, the necessity for caution by the Italian military censorship-as strict as any in the history of warfare-because of the recent Ethiopian defeats.

CINCINNATI, April 25. -- The Constitution, social security and international peace will be subjects of intensive discussion at the biennial convention of the National League of Women Voters here this week. More than 800 delegates will open the five-day meeting Monday.

LARCHMONT N.Y., April 25. -- Gunwale roosting, which is the art of sitting out on the furthest windward part of a floating object to keep it upright, was engaged in to the extreme this afternoon aboard the dinghies that sailed in the races at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

The proposal of President Roosevelt, embodied in the bill now before the House, to tax corporate reserves in place of corporate income has brought home to the country, the importance of that part of the nation's industry carried on in corporate form.

OF all the commodities whose use has received official sanction tobacco has had perhaps the most troublesome and interesting history. Long before the apocryphal tale of the dousing administered to Walter Raleigh by his alarmed servant, and for centuries after, its cultivation and applications have been attended by the sharpest controversy.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Underwriters are soon to know whether the Securities and Exchange Commission, under authority granted to it by Section 9 (a) (6) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, will issue rules dealing with the pegging, fixing or stabilizing of the prices of securities which are being distributed.
PITTSBURGH, April 23. -- For the first time since the formation of the present Republican party more than eighty years ago, the Democrats have attained the majority enrollment rank in this city.
The address Governor Lehman at the Jefferson dinner of the National Democratic Club at the Hotel Commodore follows:

EVEN the first-season gardener can select beautiful climbing vines at a nursery or from a catalogue which will surely thrive and cover an unsightly spot or make an arresting point of beauty over an archway, pergola, or porch trellis.

Debutantes headed by Miss Edith Bouvier Beale are taking an active interest in the plans for the Spring Fever fashion show to be held in conjunction with a luncheon for the benefit of the Prosperity Shop Wednesday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

Arthur E. Morgan, president of Antioch College and chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, declared yesterday that continuation of the patronage system would "absolutely kill government." He urged establishment of a universal merit system that would wipe out patronage and be superior to what remained of "perfunctory" civil service.

Long Island University lost its initial major athletic encounter with New York University yesterday, bowing to the Violet baseball team on Ohio Field by 7 to 2. The eight-game winning streak of the Blackbirds was broken mainly by the superb pitching of Mike Stelmach. A crowd of more than a thousand saw the engagement.
GENEVA, April 24. -- The week events leave the League of Nation holdings its positions against the heaviest attacks yet made on them but it has failed in its efforts to advance.

FIGHTING ships of our navy of early days will be brought to Washington and moored permanently in the Potomac River, near the probable site of the new Navy Department building, if a project approved by President Roosevelt is carried out.

The Albany Y.C., which because of its convenient location is used as a stopping-off place and mail port by hundreds of New Yorkers on cruises to Lake Champlain and the Thousand Islands, recently adopted a unique new policy. The membership limit has been set at 100 active yachtsmen, exclusive of honorary and life members, and special rates will obtain for them on gasoline, oil and other commodities sold at the club.

WASHINGTON. -- Registering a 9 per cent increase in 1935, the 4-H clubs seem to be setting the pace for club membership gains throughout the country. According to figures recently compiled, close to a million rural boys and girls are now enrolled in 4-H clubs in nearly 3,000 counties throughout the United States.

President Roosevelt will be reelected in November, in the opinion of New York University seniors. Results of the annual poll of graduating students at the university's Washington Square College, conducted by the "Album" school yearbook, were announced yesterday.

Initiation of 124 students in Teachers College, Columbia University, into five professional and honorary fraternities of the college, was announced yesterday by Margaret E. Sober, executive secretary of student organizations. Invitations to honorary membership also were extended to three persons prominent in educational circles.

PARIS, April 23. -- Molyneux's midseason collection, a forerunner of the forthcoming openings, develops his previous typical silhouette trends, with wide but soft shoulder treatments and short skirts.

ALBANY, N. Y., April 25 (AP). -- Ken Ash allowed Albany only Six hits today and Buffalo won, 6 to 3. It was the Bisons' only victory of the four-game series and enabled them to break a six-game losing streak.

WITH ITALIAN NORTHERN ARMY, DESSYE, Ethiopia, April 25. -- A large force of Eritrean and white Italian troops from Gondar this morning occupied Bahar Dar, the point where Lake Tana empties into the Blue Nile.
WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Industrial activity in the week ended on April 18 continued the upward trend that began late in March, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

Hubert Viard, second captain of the Normandie, has been appointed master of the steamship Antilles, which the French Line operates in its West Indian and South American service. His place on the Normandie will be taken by Captain Herve Le Huede, who has served on the ship as security officer, and Lieutenant Joseph Cailloce will become security officer.

PARLIAMENTARY rule in France has a bad reputation both at home and abroad, and yet today, when a new Chamber of Deputies is being elected, every adult male citizen -- for the Frenchwoman is still without right of franchise -- will go gallantly to the polling booth with the eternal hope that this time there will be a change for the better.

A Spring festival concert and dance will be given by the People's Chorus of New York on the night of May 7 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The program will include groups of Spring songs sung by the 400 men and women members of the chorus, piano selections by Frank Sheridan and individual dances in costume by Carola Goya.

DURING her visit to this city, Dr. Fanny Geissmar happened one day to make a call on Miss Dorothy Lawton, music librarian of the circulation department of the New York Public Library. The Countess Mercati, who has been a prime mover in all activities concerned with the improvement and building up of the music library of the circulation department of the New York Public Library, was also present when Dr. Geissmar made this particular call.
KAMPA DZONG, Tibet, April 12 (By Wireless to Calcutta and Air Mail via London). -- Our whole party is now encamped at Kampa Dzong, having marched 100 miles from Gangtok.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 25. -- The Brooklyn College baseball team tallied six runs in the last two innings to upset the Seton Hall College nine at Setonia Field today. The final score was 9 -- 3.

The scientific care given to the horses of the city's mounted police was cited as a demonstration of kindness to animals in a statement yesterday by Sydney H. Coleman, executive vice president of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, 50 Madison Avenue.
ST. LOUIS, April 25 (AP). -- Four hurlers failed to stop an eleven-hit Pittsburgh attack today and the Cardinals lost the first of a three-game series to the Pirates, 12 to 5.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP). -- A ruling on Robert A. Taft's suit to collect $1.07 in gold from the United States was asked today of the Supreme Court.

Of all the conventions of women's organizations crowding the Spring calendar, the annual council meeting of the General Federation opening tomorrow at Miami will influence the largest number of units and the widest range of program topics. Several hundred advance registrations indicate that the sessions at the Miami-Biltmore Hotel will be more than usually animated.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- "Amazing inaccuracies" in the Munitions Committee's report to the Senate were alleged in an open letter to the chairman of that body, Senator Nye made public today by H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders of New York City.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 24. -- Senator William E. Borah is to come into the State of Ohio next week for a "swing around the circle," speaking in Cleveland, Columbus, Zanesville and probably a couple of other places.

LOUISVILLE, April 25. -- Backed down to 2-5 favoritism, Brevity, Joseph E. Widener's Kentucky Derby hope, whipped the tar out of a field of Derby colts in the secondary feature of the Churchill Downs opening card today.

Nearly 500 German paintings are here catalogued, arranged chronologically according to artist and school. Brief biographies and bibliographies have been furnished in connection with each item included. In choosing the works to be reproduced preference was given to less familiar or hitherto unpublished works.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25. -- With about 3,300 men loading and unloading cargoes, San Francisco's waterfront has become a busy place again after the labor-dispute stoppages that cost the city's business interests an estimated loss of more than a hundred thousand dollars a day.

The annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital will take place Wednesday at the Plaza under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of the hospital. There will be tables for cards for those who do not care for dancing.

Retail business responded satisfactorily in sections having favorable weather last week, but less reordering of Spring merchandise was evident in the wholesale markets here as attention swung to Summer lines, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

There are two Scriptural references to the staying of the sun in its daily course, or as we would say, "daylight-saving." One was on the day of JOSHUA'S battle with the Amorites. The account as it is written reads:

With expanding credit sales at retail spurring the turnover of higher unit cost merchandise ranging from furniture and electrical appliances to furs and jewelry, the question has again come up whether lower mark-ups on such products would not result in further sales gains and larger profits for the stores, despite a cut in the mark-up.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 25 (AP). -- Eleazar Lopez Contreras, the army officer who rose to the rank of general under the late dictator, Juan Vicente Gomez, was elected President today by a vote of 132 to 1 by Congress. He will assume the office Wednesday.

GENEVA, April 25. -- Transportation by automobile trucks now employs almost as many workers as the railroads, Harold B. Butler, director of the International Labor Organization, told the governing body at its meeting in Geneva yesterday.

BUDAPEST, April 25. -- The official communique regarding the conversations here between the Polish and Hungarian Premiers stated that close friendship and cooperation prevailed. The two Premiers agree that such cooperation is based on community of interests and that the century-old cordiality must be continued in the interests of general peace.

THAT old-time barnyard pastime of horseshoe pitching is making good in the big city -- and in a big way. As the mild weather brings the horseshoe pitchers of New York out of hibernation, they are finding more and finer facilities than ever before.

Young matrons and debutantes of this season and former years have organized several committees to arrange a benefit hay ride and gingham dance to open the new Jardin d'Ete of Le Coq Rouge on the night of May 12. Net proceeds from the entertainment will be contributed to the Bellevue Hospital occupation committee of the New York City visiting committee.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Fewer and better treaties, adopted only after the most careful consideration, were urged on the Pan-American Conference tonight at the annual dinner of the American Society of International Law.

LONDON, April 24. -- An impressive announcement on British foreign policy has just come not from the Foreign Office but from the Chancellor of the Exchequer. The principal meaning for the British people of the budget introduced Tuesday may be expressed by saying that Chancellor Adolf Hitler has raised the British income tax.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Whether Governor Horner can consolidate the gains made in his primary-day victory is a matter of conjecture until the State Democratic convention puts his strength and strategy to the test. At a conference of the Governor with his chief lieutenants held last Sunday in French Lick, Ind., it was resolved to make no compromise with the regular party organization which Mayor Kelly of Chicago led to defeat.

DENVER, April 24. -- More than 500 indigents have been refused admittance to Colorado since last Saturday when Governor Edward C. Johnson issued a proclamation declaring martial law along a 365-mile strip of the State's southern border.

Harvard increased its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by defeating Columbia in both games of a double-header yesterday before 1,000 spectators at Baker Field. The scores were 6 to 3 and 10 to 1.
