The three girls and two boys who will represent New York City's 1,500,000 public school children at the annual Parents Day exercises in Central Park on May 10 were received last week by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, in his office at 500 Park Avenue.

Reporting general improvement in practically all sections, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, in its current monthly report made public yesterday, forecasts a steady rate of manufacturing activity for the next several months.

WITH the average temperature steadily rising, and a real "hot spell" probably just around the corner, some of the routine garden work which has been delayed by rains and cold must now be hastened. First on the list in many gardens is likely to be the completion of the division and replanting of perennials.
BERLIN, April 25 (AP). -- The government disclosed today an amnesty for Protestant and Catholic clergymen who have been arrested for displeasing the Nazi administration.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 25. -- Upsala College won its first game of the season after five starts today, defeating the University of Newark, 14 to 3, with Captain Red Thulin leading the hitters. Six errors by the visitors aided the Vikings. The seventh inning saw the home team make seven runs on five hits and two errors. Thulin accounted for two of his four hits in this frame as the Vikings batted around.

A NEW claim to distinction has come to the University of Alaska, America's most northerly institution of higher learning -- situated on an ice-cap, as it were. According to Dr. Charles m. Bunnell, first and only president, "every member of last year's graduating class at the university helped in putting herself, or himself, through college, and every member had a position awaiting him on receiving a diploma."

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Once more a scarlet jersey streaked across the swift-moving picture of the forty-second annual Penn Relay Carnival today in an eye-catching splash of color as Charlie Beetham of Ohio State unfurled the outstanding performance of the Franklin Field classic.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Social activities have a prominent place in the program of the council meeting of the General Federation of Women's Clubs opening at the Miami Biltmore Hotel tomorrow to continue through Friday.
VIENNA, April 25. -- Prince Ernst Ruediger yon Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor and leader of the Heimwehr, called a meeting today of all Heimwehr district commanders.

Jock, the gray pony of Sandringham, who has grown white in the service of his well-loved master, tells here of his years as the shooting pony of the late King George. Quite simply, as would a child, he rejoices in his knowledge of himself as the King's favorite, although he generously allows Arabian Night, the chestnut pony from London, second place in his master's affections.

Ellis Parker Jr., son of the widely known Mount Holly, N.J., detective, under indictment with four other men, two of whom are in custody, for the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, remained a fugitive yesterday as District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn intimated that other New Jersey officials might be involved in the crime.

PROVIDENCE, April 25. -- The Holy Cross baseball team scored a 6-to-2 victory over Providence College today, driving Collins from the box in the sixth inning after scoring three runs on two hits, two walks, a hit batsman, and a sacrifice.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 25. -- Champion Sturdy Max, English setter owned by the Maridor Kennels of Springfield, Mass., and handled by Charles Palmer, carried off the best in show laurels at the close of the tenth annual exhibition of the Springfield Kennel Club tonight in the Springfield Auditorium.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25. -- Dr. Harold Tobin of the Department of Political Science at Dartmouth College declared here today that democracy must either learn the processes of government "or give way to those forces which can learn and apply these processes."

BRYN MAWR, Pa., April 25. -- Miss Theresa Helburn, Bryn Mawr '08, who has been executive director, casting director and a member of the board of managers of the Theatre Guild of New York since 1920, will portray the part of Queen Elizabeth in the Bryn Mawr May Day celebration on May 8 and 9.

With a plea for tolerance and a promise that "there is no finality in the act or in our plans for its administration," John G. Winant, chairman of the Federal Social Security Board, defended the Social Security Act yesterday and said that its effects in form of payments to the aged unemployed would be felt as early as 1937.

Pittsburgh's loss may be New York's gain in the world of motor boat racing. There seems every likelihood, according to President George W. Sutton Jr. of the American Power Boat Association, that the national outboard championships may be alloted to New York as the result of the unexpected reassignment of dates made necessary by the floods at Pittsburgh along the Allegheny River.
THE Associated American Artists, Inc., opened a new permanent headquarters last week at 420 Madison Avenue. The galleries are spacious and the prints by members of this group appear to advantage.

UNDER date of March 17, 1892, THE NEW YORK TIMES ran a story with the heading: "Tariff-Reform Champion -- Nebraska Furnishes a Fine Democratic Fighter." There had been a notable tariff debate the previous day at the Capitol in Washington, and an unknown Congressman, making what was in effect his maiden speech, had talked himself into prominence.

A NEW claim to distinction has come to the University of Alaska, America's most northerly institution of higher learning -- situated on an ice-cap, as it were. According to Dr. Charles m. Bunnell, first and only president, "every member of last year's graduating class at the university helped in putting herself, or himself, through college, and every member had a position awaiting him on receiving a diploma."

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Once more a scarlet jersey streaked across the swift-moving picture of the forty-second annual Penn Relay Carnival today in an eye-catching splash of color as Charlie Beetham of Ohio State unfurled the outstanding performance of the Franklin Field classic.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Social activities have a prominent place in the program of the council meeting of the General Federation of Women's Clubs opening at the Miami Biltmore Hotel tomorrow to continue through Friday.
VIENNA, April 25. -- Prince Ernst Ruediger yon Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor and leader of the Heimwehr, called a meeting today of all Heimwehr district commanders.

Jock, the gray pony of Sandringham, who has grown white in the service of his well-loved master, tells here of his years as the shooting pony of the late King George. Quite simply, as would a child, he rejoices in his knowledge of himself as the King's favorite, although he generously allows Arabian Night, the chestnut pony from London, second place in his master's affections.

Spanish period furniture, decorations, rugs, damasks, brocades, embroideries and other textiles, together with Spanish primitives and paintings of other schools and a French Gothic tapestry, the collection of Don Luis Ruiz of Madrid, Spain, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Saturday afternoon.

ON the floor of a huge hangar at Bridgeport, Conn., is the outline in white paint of a flying boat capable of carrying forty-eight passengers, surrounded with every luxury and comfort, to Europe in twenty-four hours.

OTTAWA, April 23. -- Canada which, under the regime of R.B. Bennett, seemed disposed to seek recovery by means of a "new deal" patterned closely on President Roosevelt's, is now adopting other and more orthodox means under the guidance of Prime Minister Mackenzie King.

ARUBICUND fellow with proportions that would make him easily adaptable to the job of stand-in for Walter Connolly, or, if need be, for our own politically minded Joe McGoldrick, hurried through town last week on his way to visit the Ould Sod.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- The doctrine of economic self-sufficiency, advanced in some quarters as a means of keeping the nations observing it out of war, was attacked tonight by Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, as one that not only leads to dictatorship and imperialism, but carries a perpetual threat of armed conflict.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa. -- The Union Government has been following with interest the claims recently put forward by the Soviet Union that Russia will, in the near future, be able to surpass the output of the Rand gold mines and thus take first place in world gold production.

AMONG the principal activities of Europe during the last century were the development of parliamentary government, the vast increase of industrial productivity, the consequent raising of the standard of living. This kind of progress is much less conspicuous today. The attention of Europe -- even of the stock exchanges, even of the average man -- is turned chiefly to the activities of diplomats, which have assumed transcendent importance.

NATIONALISM and internationalism -- about these two poles the affairs of the modern world revolve. Not only is internationalism of more and more importance; it is the inevitable and indispensable complement of that form of nationalist activity called economic imperialism.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 25. -- Felix M. Warburg of New York tonight urged generous giving to the relief program of the New England Conference of Jewish Communal Agencies.

HENRY MORGENTHAU Sr. is to celebrate today his eightieth birthday in the bosom of his family at his Summer home at Purchase. His family is a large one. There are his son, Henry Morgenthau Jr.; three daughters and twelve grandchildren as well as his sons-in-law and his daughter-in-law.

Mayor La Guardia predicted last night that political machines would go out of existence in this country within ten years. He spoke at a dinner of the Blackstone Council of the Civil Service Forum, composed of employes of the law department, in honor of Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
A special meeting of the Board , of Education will be held tomorrow for considering school sites and contracts for school construction as well as other building items.

Behind the scenes of unrest in Palestine, of Egyptian riots and nationalist uprisings in Syria, important events are shaping themselves in the Near East. The dream of a union of Arabic-speaking nations, leading perhaps to an Arabic confederation or even empire, is nearer realization now than at any other time in the past.

The undefeated Fordham University nine pounded the offerings of four Rutgers hurlers for seventeen hits to down the Scarlet team, 17 to 12, at Fordham Field yesterday. A crowd of 1,500 shivering fans saw the Rams register their eighth successive victory.

The recently published theory that the earth may have been hit by a small planet coincides with some rather concrete evidence which I have observed in Summers spent at Rockport, Mass. There we find archaic sedementary granite rocks, which normally would lie deepest beneath the earth's surface, not merely forced up into lofty promontories, but showing that they have been heaved skyward by some tremendous shattering blow.

HELD back in some districts by unseasonably cold weather, retail trade nevertheless marked up gains in other sections of from 5 to 15 per cent in the week. New England was the principal area affected by weather conditions, while in this territory heavy State tax payments and the decline in the stock market were probably major influences in retarding trade activity.

Streamers of ticker tape and sheets of colored paper were thrown from lofty windows in lower Broadway yesterday afternoon as several thousand spectators watched seventy-five members of the Old Guard of the City of New York celebrate the 110th anniversary of the organization by ceremonies including a parade from City Hall to South Ferry.

Charging that repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is rapidly being nullified through excessive and unreasonable taxation, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, president of the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild, yesterday charged that New York State is one of the worst offenders.

The pamphlet report of the International Paper Company for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net loss of $2,840,898, compared with a loss of $3,009,717 in 1934. With an increase of 8 per cent in the physical volume of business and a slight rise in average selling prices, there was a substantial increase in gross sales, but this was offset almost entirely by higher expenses due to the larger volume, Richard J. Cullen, president, said.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 25. -- Dartmouth's fourth-inning rally, which produced three runs on singles by Ray Ratajczak and Junie Allen and a two-bagger by Frigard, defeated Yale, 3 -- 1, today as the Elis opened the Intercollegiate Baseball League season.

With a total of more than 1,600 buyers registered during the first week, general activity at the American Toy Fair at the Hotel McAlpin and the Toy Center was reported the best since 1929 by H.D. Clarke, manager of the fair. He estimated orders placed ran 15 to 20 per cent ahead of the initial week of the fair last year.

In the limited space allotted to books of this kind, it is imperative to grasp at generalizations and avoid the details of issues that are so highly controversial. The conclusion I referred to in the Crandon case was based on the following: "In view of the above findings, your commission [appointed by the A.S.P.R.] submit that the Margery mediumship is a clever and entertaining performance, but unworthy of any serious consideration by your society."
BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP). -- Baltimore scored two runs in the ninth today to defeat Montreal, 5 to 4, in the series final.

THE season's prints stop at nothing. They are on a rampage. When it comes to subject-matter, they cannot be daunted. They call upon the barnyard and the jungle, on the Alps and the tropics. No matter how foreign to fabrics some of the themes are, they seem to "belong" when made into clever conventional designs.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 25. -- Chief Justice Roger B. Taney should be rated second only to John Marshall in the constitutional law of this nation, said Felix Frankfurter, Harvard law professor, last night in the second of the series of Weil lectures on citizenship which are being delivered at the University of North Carolina.

Cardinal Hayes told the more than 500 members of the Ladies of Catholic Charity at their thirty-fourth annual conference in the Hotel St. Regis yesterday afternoon that they and their works were a benediction to the Archdiocese of New York.

THE international opera season at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London, will open tomorrow night with a performance of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" and will continue until June 12, when it will be followed by a season of Russian ballets.

In support of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee campaign for a minimum of $1,500,000 to support private family welfare agencies, the clergyman's committee of the organization will ask 1,500 churches and synagogues in New York City to observe May 9 and 10 as Family Welfare Sabbath.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Dodger hopes of going higher in the first division on their first long flight were punctured scarcely two hours away from Brooklyn today. Before the five-hit hurling of Joe Bowman, the Stengeleers went down, 3 -- 1, and back into the lower brackets white the Phils moved into a four-way tie for third place.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Italy's successful use of poison gas in the war against the Ethiopians has caused Prime Minister Baldwin of Great Britain to voice an old apprehension -- the fear that whole city populations might be killed in a future conflict by gases dropped in bombs or shot from guns.

A steady to firm undertone ruled throughout the bond market yesterday in the two-hour period. While trading was the slowest on the New York Stock Exchange for a half-day trading session since Sept. 28, 1935, the trend was toward slightly better prices in all the major groups.

WALDWICK, N.J., April 25. -- A 21-year-old boy who drove a milk truck and once gave fifty cents and a ride on the milk truck to an old "hobo," was on his way to a silver mine and possible fortune tonight in the manner of the best Horatio Alger stories.

The marked interest in the future of control over production and imports of sugar has been particularly emphasized in the recent introduction of a number of separate bills in the Senate and the House to replace the existing Jones-Costigan act, which is considered invalid as a result of the United States Supreme Court's decision on the AAA.

THREE years ago Owen W. Matthews 3d, Eagle Scout, of Troop 83, Portland, Ore., went to the world Jamboree at Godollo, Hungary. There he mingled with 30,000 fellow-Scouts from forty-six different lands; and there he began an experience which has won for him a $5,000 college scholarship.

Thirty-two East Side children, trundled by proud mothers, sisters and elder brothers, competed for prizes in costumes and pulchritude yesterday afternoon as the Madison Square Boys' Club, 312 East Thirtieth Street, opened its observance of Boys' and Girls' Week with a baby parade.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 25. -- Princeton and Cornell divided an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header today, the Ithacans bowing, 3 to 1, in the second battle after winning the first, 6 to 2.

Henry Hewitt, 58 years old, had a streak of luck yesterday. He won on all of the first five races at Jamaica; he collected more than $1,700 in cash and except for an error -- a liquid error -- he also would have won on the sixth race. But with that race his luck ended and at a late hour he was sleeping peacefully in jail.

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 25. -- Mrs. Sol M. Stroock of Ossining will open her home on Wednesday for a meeting and tea for committee chairmen organizing an exhibition of antiques and fine arts to be held at Ophir Hall, the country estate of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid at Purchase, from, May 16 to May 31 for the benefit of the Westchester County Children's Association.

Last week's demonstrations against war by college students in various parts of the country were not so large and impressive as had been predicted, but were certainly significant. After making due allowance for the mass psychology, and ebullient spirits of undergraduates, the total effect remains undisputed.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP). -- Marvin Owen's tenth-inning single with the bases filled gave the Tigers an 8 -- 6 victory over the White Sox before 5,000 fans today.

VARIETY, it appears, is not only the spice of life but also the spice of broadcasting. For variety is the keynote in three out of four of the radio shows cited by the Women's National Radio Committee as outstanding programs of the year.

MADISON. ONE hundred years old this Spring, the Wisconsin State Library is the pioneer book-lending institution of the Northwest. It was created by the act of Congress that established the Wisconsin Territory. The act was approved on April 20, 1836, by President Andrew Jackson.

EVERY one who has driven much beyond metropolitan boundaries has been delayed and annoyed by needless red-and-green signal lights. It is not uncommon for a motorist to be stopped by a red light at some rural or suburban intersection and wait impatiently for green while no cars pass in front of him.

LIKE a leit-motif the complaint, "art without qualification," runs through this stimulating if not completely satisfying little book by one of the British critics. Thus it is that Mr. Furst characterizes the effort of those who seek "absolute" values and rank "art," looked upon as a kind of precious detached phenomenon, above the purpose to which all great creative effort must necessarily be dedicated.
PARIS, April 24. -- Nothing more need be expected from Sunday's general election in France than that there will be a new Chamber of Deputies.

TOKYO, April 25. -- Japan entertains no thought of taking action on account of frontier disputes with the Soviet Union unless "others launch aggression upon us," Hachiro Arita said today in his first statement of policy as Foreign Minister at a reception given to foreign correspondents.

This is the new and revised edition of an important book on modern art first published about eight years ago and now widely known in the art world. The present is substantially the text of the last three impressions of the first edition, but Mr. Wilenski has added an epilogue and made a few alterations of detail.

On almost every page of this book one stumbles over diamonds of fabulous value, and where such diamonds are crimes of violence may be expected. Chief among the jewels with which the story deals are two huge stones from the Russian crown jewels.

MOSCOW, April 25. -- The possibility that Klementy Voroshiloff, Soviet Defense Commissar, and General Sadao Araki, former Japanese War Minister, may exchange good-will visits to Tokyo and Moscow with the object of strengthening peace is the surprising development of a banquet given at the Japanese Embassy here yesterday in honor of the newly arrived Japanese military attache.

TOKYO, April 25. -- The fear that the Tokyo government has entertained for some time that a major incident on the borders of Manchukuo might precipitate a war between Soviet Russia and Japan, is spreading among the general populace of Japan.

THE importance to the car owner of proper balancing in his automobile was described last week by S.T. Foresman of the Chrysler Corporation in a paper presented at the production meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers in this city.

ONE of the proudest boasts and most alluring of Fire Island charms has passed. That elongated stretch of sand dunes, fingering for dozens of miles between the Atlantic Ocean and the Great South Bay, Summer refuge of literary and stage people, as well as of more prosaic yearners after the primitive, has gone modern.

Credit executives are planning a complete revision of credit extension technique, if the proposed tax on undivided corporation surpluses is passed, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by association heads and credit men. The National Association of Credit Men is studying the tax program very carefully and will make recommendations and suggestions to members as to the "harmful effects" of the bill on credit granting, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the group, said yesterday.

That elongated stretch of sand dunes, fingering for dozens of miles between the Atlantic Ocean and the Great South Bay, Summer refuge of literary and stage people, as well as of more prosaic yearners after the primitive, has gone modern.

Credit executives are planning a complete revision of credit extension technique, if the proposed tax on undivided corporation surpluses is passed, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by association heads and credit men. The National Association of Credit Men is studying the tax program very carefully and will make recommendations and suggestions to members as to the "harmful effects" of the bill on credit granting, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the group, said yesterday.

One hundred models of the French liner Normandie, selected from 2,000 entries in a contest sponsored by the Model Builders Guild of Hempstead, N.Y., will be exhibited for two weeks, starting tomorrow, at La Maison Francaise in Rockefeller City.

The first missionary band turned out in New York by the WPA Music Project made its debut yesterday on Pier 58, North River, foot of West Sixteenth Street, when Sister Frances Jolly of Anoka, Minn., a lay sister of the Church Army of the Protestant Episcopal Church, sailed on the American Shipper for Liberia, West Africa.
PARIS, April 25 (By Wireless). -Fashion observers have just had an advance view of collections for Fall and Summer that soon will be shown at several houses.

ROME, April 24. -- Italy's conquest of Ethiopia is now considered to be so nearly accomplished that the people's thoughts already are reaching forward to exploitation of the vast territories they believe are to come under Italian rule.
EUROPE'S newest and second highest Alpine road, the Austrian Glocknerstrasse, which lay all Winter long under huge snowdrifts, again is open to tourists in Tyrol.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP). -- Jimmy Caras, young Wilmington (Del.) cue star, retained his world pocket billiards championship tonight against the challenge of the veteran Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, winning, 750 to 743, in a five-block match.

Some of us were present almost at the birth of Mr. Hinnissy and Mr. Dooley. In dingy newspaper offices of the infant Nineties a discoverer, choking as best he could his own merriment, would read aloud Mr. DUNNE'S first pieces in The Chicago Post. Cenacles of Dooleyites were quickly formed.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP). -- A contention that "industries ought to be self-supporting or quit" was advanced today by New York City in a brief filed with the Supreme Court in support of the State's minimum wage law for women and children.
Paddles digging deep, two young adventurers pushed off in a seventeen-foot canoe from the foot of West Forty-second Street yesterday morning, bound for Nome, Alaska, by way of inland waters.

IN her previous book, "Connecticut Trilogy," which helped to commemorate Connecticut's tri-centenary, Marguerite Allis demonstrated her ability to write that kind of book with success. "English Prelude" belongs to the same literary genre, but it is more ambitious, spreads over more territory, and its preparation demanded work on unfamiliar ground.

PROFESSOR SANTAYANA'S sensational achievement lends a topical interest to the lecture on "Novels Not by Novelists," recently delivered by the Marquess of Crewe before the Royal Society of Literature. For the purpose of his address he defined a novelist as "a person whose main business is the writing of novels and who is not specially conspicuous in any other occupation of life."

In a suit filed in Federal court yesterday, based on an agreement between President Roosevelt and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, the United States Government demanded that the Chase National Bank surrender all deposits made by corporations organized under eight pre-Soviet regimes.

LAURENCE STALLINGS'S tales of the baked, bitten and bedeviled lives led by the foreign correspondents in Ethiopia were racy and illuminating; they came by cable when that war was young. Mr. Chaplin's addenda, published some months after the last entry in his diary, have an unavoidable and rather unfortunate air of the twice-told.

The City College lacross team offered unexpectedly stubborn opposition to the Johns Hopkins University ten, one of the foremost college aggregations in the country, before bowing by 14-8 yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium.
President Roosevelt's trip to New York for his speech yesterday marked the beginning of a campaign season which will mean a considerable amount of travel.

The stock of United States cotton in the world at the end of March, including government financed holdings, was approximately 11,179,000 bales, against 12,604,000 bales a year before, according to figures compiled by the New York Cotton Exchange.

The question of taxing corporation reserves has been the cause of much acrimonious discussion. It has been described by its opponents as a tax on foresight and on economy. We are told that prudent management is justified in accumulating a fairly large sum to be held for distribution to its stockholders and to cover possible losses during periods of financial stress.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 26. -- The soft-ball game with which Sidney Wood undermined Ellsworth Vines's blasting attack at Seabright in 1930 proved the undoing of Vines's prototype of the tennis courts today as Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta scored a thrilling uphill victory over Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., in the final of the Mason-Dixon championship.

NEW ORLEANS, April 26. -- Trading improved considerably last week on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange. The rise was laid to trade buying, price-fixing by spinners, more or less hedging against freer purchases of spots and buying of near positions and transferring to new crop months at widening differences in liquidating the May position, the first notice day for which is at hand.

Patience and perseverance in the face of present-day confusion is the greatest service that man can render, the Rev. Dr. James J. Henry said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP). -- Vic Sorrell, veteran member of the Detroit mound staff, held Chicago to five hits today and the champion Tigers defeated the White Sox, 6 -- 4, before 15,000 fans. It was Detroit's fourth straight victory.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- With chief Congressional interest still focused on the administration tax program, major attention will shift this week to the Senate, whose Finance Committee will lay the groundwork for what is expected to be a drastic revision of the measure.
LONDON, April 24. -- Although the budget message contained some mild shocks, especially the increase in the income tax, it is already being forgotten.

An extraordinary concentration of extra policemen and radio cars in the Bronx failed to bring about the capture of the "alcoholic pyromaniac" who for the last two and a half years has terrorized the tenement dwellers of that borough. The police reported yesterday, however, that it had prevented two fires, seemingly incendiary in origin, from doing any damage.

Two plucky members of the CCC Service Company stationed at Fort Wood, Bedloe's Island, who rescued a girl from the icy waters of New York Harbor in January, were rewarded for their valor yesterday afternoon with decorations and citations from President Roosevelt.

With all of the important Kentucky Derby prep races finished, formidable eligibles for that $40,000 added test next Saturday have been reduced to a dozen. Dominating the lot is Joseph E. Widener's Brevity, one of the shortest-priced future book favorites in many years. He is held at 8 to 5.

The Kennebec Fish and Game Association of Maine is sponsoring a Chinook Salmon Derby this Spring, awarding prizes to anglers who catch the largest specimens in Great Pond, Salmon Lake and McGrath Pond, three of the Belgrade chain of fishing waters.

Seniors at City College prefer to avoid middle-class discussions, it was indicated yesterday in a poll by their 1936 yearbook. Asked to select the "best dresser" among their classmates, most of the students refused to vote, writing "too bourgeois" on their ballots.

With a southwest gale raging across the North Atlantic ship lane, two freighters, the St. Quentin and the Ivanhoe, of British and Norwegian registry, respectively, were reported in distress last night, with the liners Pilsudski and Washington speeding to the rescue.
Purchase of a Fifth Avenue building by the famous Corning Glass Works and sales of Greenwich Village houses by old estates featured announcements of realty transactions in the city over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, despite a reduction of $700,000,000 in March, amounted to $2,300,000,000 at the end of that month and were sufficient to provide a basis for the expansion of bank credit far beyond present or prospective needs, the Federal Reserve Board announced today in its monthly bulletin.

NEWARK, N.J., April 26. -- The Newark Bears' winning streak was halted after ten consecutive victories today when they lost the second game of their double-header to the Montreal Royals, 5 to 3, after taking the opener, 7 to 4.

Lord Horder, personal physician of King Edward VIII and chairman of the Anti-Noise League of England, discussed a "noiseless nation" in a radio address last night under the sponsorship of the League for Less Noise. He said New York seemed less noisy than when he was here last, "but it is noisy enough."

THE countryside in Maryland's Worthington and Green Spring Valleys is unusually soft in April. Trees are in new green and rolling hillsides wander right up to the doorsills of the white-stooped houses of Baltimore. A few miles out of the city the country looks as though it had never really made any serious attempt to keep up with the succeeding generations.

Besides being "an essential of our salvation," the exercise of Christian charity is "the nearest to a God-like thing a mere mortal can do," the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The American Federation of Labor will follow its traditions and "adhere to a nonpartisan policy" in the 1936 campaign, William Green and Frank Morrison, president and secretary, respectively, asserted in a letter sent today to 109 national and international unions and all affiliated organizations.

ST. LOUIS, April 26. -- Although held to a 2-2 tie in the first game of their National Challenge Cup final series with the St. Louis Shamrocks before a crowd of 15,000 at Walsh Memorial Stadium tonight, the Philadelphia German-Americans became favored to win the United States soccer championship, since the second and final match will be played at Philadelphia next Sunday.

Passage by the Assembly of a concurrent resolution which would remove from the State Constitution the prohibition against the imposition of tolls on the State Barge Canal is defended by W. Kenneth Hayes, vice chairman of the Association of Railroads of New York State, in a statement issued for publication today.

Declines were the rule on local commodity futures markets last week with the exception of sugar and some of the metals, with the volume higher only in coffee. In the cash markets only cotton and corn were stronger, while declines appeared in wheat, rye, flour, lard, butter, hides, rubber, silk, tins, quicksilver, Santos coffee and cocoa.

A strike of barbers in all shops in Brooklyn, except the Brownsville section, was called for 8 A.M. today by the Journeymen Barbers International Union of America, Local 217, yesterday. The union expects 10,000 men in 3,500 barber shops to respond.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- Breaking out early with a highly potent collection of extra-base hits, the Dodgers shuttled themselves back into the first division today, transferring the Phillies below the .500 mark. A Sunday crowd of 5,000 saw Brooklyn drive Sylvester Johnson and Orville Jorgens away to win, 10 to 7.
Following a slight advance in March, industrial activity showed further improvement in the first two weeks of April, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Two men were injured, one of them seriously, when the automobile in which they were riding crashed through a granite safety wall at Broadway and 135th Street at 5:15 A.M. yesterday and plunged to the Interborough subway tracks in an open cut twenty feet below the street level.

THOMAS D. THACHER -- Mr. Thacher, chairman of the commission, is a member of the law firm of Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, a firm of which his father was one of the founders. He was graduated from Yale University in 1904 and from Yale Law School in 1906.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 26 (AP). -- Toronto defeated Albany in both games of today's double-header, 7 -- 2, 1 -- 0.

Asserting that Uncle Sam had been indulging in an orgy of borrowing and spending, Senator Arthur Capper of Kansas declared yesterday that pay day was approaching for the people of this country and that expenditures of the Federal Government must be reduced.

BERLIN, April 24. -- Business sentiment here this week has been better. Stimulated by increases in dividends and abnormally low money rates, leading stocks by the middle of the week had reached the highest level since July, 1935.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 26 (AP). -- A two-base hit by Rookie Hub Geary in the seventeenth inning drove in two runs and gave Buffalo a 10-to-9 victory over Syracuse today in one of the longest International League games on record.
BALTIMORE, April 26 (AP). -- Baltimore and Rochester today split a double-header, the Orioles taking the first game, 10 to 7, then losing, 13 to 8. The box scores:

LONDON, April 25. -- The decline of almost 6,500,000 in the note circulation of the Bank of England in the week ended on Wednesday represented a normal contraction following the large expansion which preceded the Easter holidays. Nevertheless, the general trend of circulation still is upward and the total is 22,260,000 greater than a year ago.

The Catholic Poetry Society of America, which has twenty-one chapters in the United States and Canada, celebrated its fifth anniversary yesterday with a solemn high mass of thanksgiving at St. Leo's Church, 9-11 East Twenty-eighth Street, and a breakfast at the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street.
TRENTON, N.J., April 26. -- When the New Jersey Legislature convenes tomorrow night to take up the problem of relief taxation it will be greeted by hundreds, perhaps thousands, of the unemployed.

The arrest of John Fiorenza as the murderer of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton emphasizes the need for more adequate social facilities for the treatment of known psychopaths, the protective and correctional section of the Welfare Council declared yesterday.

1. The city of New York as now existing shall continue with the boundaries and with the powers, rights and property and subject to the obligations and liabilities which exist at the time of the adoption of this charter.

For outstanding acts of heroism and for risking their lives beyond the call of duty in 1935, ten firemen have won the valor medals awarded annually by the Fire Department, it was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

Mrs. William Francis Gibbs heads a group of women in charge of the plans for the Spring luncheon to be held tomorrow at La Maisonette Russe in the St. Regis under the auspices of the Women's Auxiliary Board of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Clearing Spring weather brought an increase in residential construction in March throughout the country, announcements by both the Federal Housing Administration and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 26. -- Thoroughly alarmed by the Tydings Independence Bill, the business community, through the Chamber of Commerce, today urged Washington authorities to take no action on the plebiscite measure until fullest opportunity has been given to those of all shades of opinion to voice their views at a public hearing.

The open-hand cash distribution plan inaugurated by Henry Hewitt at the Jamaica track after he had won about $1,800 on the first five races Saturday appeared yesterday to have been inspired by a philosophy of fatalism.

ADDIS ABABA, April 26. -- The armies of Dedjasmatch Moshesha, Governor of Kambuta, and Ras Makonnen, Governor of Western Wallaga, are entering Addis Ababa. Both were in action recently at Antalo, near Amba Aradam.

Amid ceremony that would have done credit to an America's Cup yacht, the New York A.C. launched The Olympic yesterday at Travers Island. No yacht, but a lean, smooth-skinned racing shell, The Olympic nevertheless may see the sea before the Summer is out, providing her crew of national senior champion oarsmen win an Atlantic crossing to the Olympic Games.

A large Flushing housing property taken in foreclosure by the Lawyers Mortgage Company under the supervision of the State Superintendent of Insurance has been sold to an operator through the State Mortgage Commission, the mortgage company and a committee of certificate holders.

Mrs. Ely Culbertson, Waldemar von Zedtwitz, Sam Fry Jr. and A. Mitchell Barnes won the Grand National contract bridge team-of-four championship of the United States Bridge Association last night at Crockford's, 14 East Sixty-second Street, after a grueling struggle.

Headed by the Apostolic Delegate to the United States, the Most Rev. Amleto G. Cicognani, clergy and members of religious orders of the diocese of Brooklyn joined yesterday with the Vincentian priests of St. John's University in the celebration of the feast of the translation of the relics of St. Vincent de Paul, founder and patron of the order which bears his name.

PARIS, April 24. -- Trading on the Bourse was characterized again this week by dullness. The kind of truce concluded in Geneva and lasting until May 11, concerning the disagreement between Great Britain and France on the attitude to adopt toward Italy, has put this question into the background so far as the stock market is concerned.

MILLER'S SIDING (Half Mile North of Canaan, Conn., on N.Y., N.H. H.R.R.), April 26. -- The clock was turned ahead one hour today but 222 New Yorkers rolled back the calendar more than a quarter of a century to relive the days of Little Ol' New York when Maggie Cline was making the welkin ring with the strains of "Throw Him Down, McCloskey." The 222 went bicycling.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The twenty-fourth annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States will open tomorrow, with recent evidence indicating that it will be the most critical of New Deal policies since President Roosevelt took office.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 26. -- More than 50,000 gallons of high grade illicit alcohol destined to become bootleg liquor, cleverly concealed under a tank of kerosene, were seized here early this morning on an oil tanker.

John W. Aiken, 40-year-old hardwood finisher of 25 Marlboro Street, Chelsea, Mass., was nominated for the Presidency by the Socialist Labor party yesterday at its convention at the Cornish Arms Hotel, 311 West Twenty-third Street.

BERLIN, April 24. -- Current trade press analyses of United States business are favorable, but emphasis is laid on the backwardness of the building industry and the apparent anomaly of rapidly improving production indices side by side with heavy unemployment.
JERUSALEM, April 26. -- As sporadic acts of violence by Arabs continued in Palestine today, all police officials in the country were ordered to deal severely with all breaches of the peace.

With prices of old-crop cotton sustained by the large government holdings and those of the new crop weakened by more favorable crop weather and declines in the security markets, prices for future deliveries of cotton changed irregularly last week.

ROME, April 26. -- The Ogaden front, where a battle is in progress for possession of Sasa Baneh, has been the scene of the most serious fighting of the East African campaign. The Italians are making progress, but the resistance they are encountering is shown in the relatively high casualty figures.

Atlantic shipping operators said yesterday the only hope of settlement of the labor difficulties that have arisen over the recent signing of a new wage agreement with the spokesmen of their crews lay with in the membership of the International Seamen's Union.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., April 26. -- President Roosevelt came again to his mother's home near here for a brief visit today following the speech in New York City last night which marked his first appearance at a political gathering there since he entered the White House in 1933.

Award of twenty-two research fellowships, valued at $65,000, to research specialists and graduate students of universities throughout the country was announced yesterday by the Social Science Research Council, 230 Park Avenue. Two of the awards went to Columbia University men.

Charges that the relief agencies have come under the influence of Communists and other subversive groups to such an extent that World War veterans are threatened by discrimination were voiced yesterday by Borough President George U. Harvey at the Americanization Day ceremonies of the Queens Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

We are hearing a great deal about the Dutch elm disease and its ravages around New York City. At the same time we hear but a very little about the verticilium wilt, a fungus disease which is both prevalent and destructive.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP). -- While Buck Newsom allowed Philadelphia seven scattered hits, Washington pounded a trio of Athletic pitchers for thirteen hits today to defeat the Mackmen, 11 to 3.

Information received yesterday morning by District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County on the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel was considered by him to be of such importance that he ordered a police guard to protect a woman witness against any persons who might seek to prevent her testimony before the grand jury or at prospective trials.

ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean, back in stride again, won a hurling duel from Bill Swift of Pittsburgh today as the Cardinals tied up their series with the Pirates with a typical tenth-inning punch that netted them a 3-to-2 victory before 5,500 fans.

KALGAN, China, April 26. -- Although the permanent Japanese civilian population in Chahar Province has increased by fewer than 200 in the past year, there are hundreds of Japanese civilians traveling in the province on survey and investigating projects for the South Manchuria Railway and other Japanese concerns, according to an official spokesman of the Chahar provisional government.

Militant support of Speaker Irving M. Ives for twenty-seven bills of the anti-crime program, which are pending in the Assembly, was asked yesterday by Governor Lehman in a letter to the Speaker, made public here.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- An increase in disturbing influences, both current and in prospect, particularly those governing wheat crop prospects in the United States and other countries, makes grain traders decidedly uneasy. All indications point to smaller production of Winter wheat unless there are copious, well-scattered rains over the entire Winter wheat country at once, as well as over the Spring wheat sections in the Northwest within the next few weeks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26. -- The Franco-American Review, a quarterly journal devoted to the cultural and historical relations of France and America, will be published in June. The magazine will be a cooperative effort by a group of prominent Americans and Frenchmen.

Professor Thorndike Saville has been appointed dean of the College of Engineering of New York University, and Professor John Musser has been named dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Science, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Traders who were short of May oats took advantage of all weak spots here last week to cover and cash interests that had May sold transferred their commitments to July. The close was at net losses of 3/4 cent a bushel on the May, 5/8 cent on the July and 7/8 cent on the December.

LONDON, April 24. -- Now that the severe budget message has been left behind, the stock markets are developing greater activity, with the public distinctly inclined to return after an absence unduly prolonged by the uncertainties of the European situation.

The Brooklyn Citizens' Patriotic May Day Celebration, established in 1920 to offset the annual Socialist and Communist May Day parade, was held yesterday afternoon in the Music Grove of Prospect Park. Student peace efforts and President Roosevelt's policies were assailed.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 26. -- The noon bulletin on the condition of King Fuad said the infection in his mouth has not increased in the past twenty-four hours and that his general condition was unchanged. Actually, he is slightly improved, but still is critically ill and required another blood transfusion last night.

The greatest demonstration this writer has ever seen in a concert auditorium was tendered Arturo Toscanini when he finished his program with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.
In your editorial on the Illinois primary you state that Senator Borah "is entitled to a little exultation" because of the primary vote of April 14.

Swordsmen of the East repulsed the strongest challenge ever to come from fencers of the various sections of the country yesterday as six foilsmen qualified for the national championships in the tests conducted by the Amateur Fencers League of America on the strips of the New York A.C.

A permanent committee for social justice, empowered to fight for the five-day week, slum clearance and social security legislation, was set up yesterday by the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America.

The House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York, convening today at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria as the opening event of the 130th annual meeting of the society, will be called upon to consider the proposal of its committee on economics that physicians organize to combat the new influence of hospitals in fields formerly held exclusively by private doctors.

A general improvement in business conditions throughout the country was reported yesterday by Postmaster General James A. Farley in an address at the fifteenth annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society of the New York Postoffice, held at the Hotel Astor.

VIENNA, April 26. -- Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, the Vice Chancellor, launched a political bombshell this afternoon before 12,000 uniformed and armed Heimwehr members at Horn, Lower Austria. Breaking his two-month silence since Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg announced Austria would introduce conscription, Prince Starhemberg, to the wild enthusiasm of his Fascist audience, declared the Heimwehr "will never be disarmed except over my dead body."

PARIS, Monday, April 27. -- Out of the inextricable tangle of yesterday's general election in France, with its enormous number of candidates, its intricate party divisions and its lack of clear issues clearly expressed, there has come a well-indicated swing of the electorate toward the Left, but the results are still inconclusive.

A plea for the support of Summer camps for children who otherwise would play in the streets was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon at Riverside Baptist Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 26. -- Celebrating his eightieth birthday today, Henry Morgenthau Sr., financier and former Ambassador to Turkey, received congratulatory messages from many friends, including President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Professor Albert Einstein; cut a birthday cake at a family dinner and told an interviewer he really felt sorry for the Republicans in the coming Presidential campaign.

MOSCOW, April 26. -- Great interest was shown in foreign diplomatic circles in the visit of high officers of the general staffs of Estonia and Latvia who will arrive here tomorrow for a stay of several days, probably including May Day, when the Soviet will display once more its progress in mechanized military equipment.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26. -- Harvard University notified Vice President John N. Garner tonight that it "is honored" by the Senate's action in designating the university's tercentenary as the tercentenary also of higher education in this country.

The arrival in the wholesale markets here last week of a substantial number of out-of-town buyers resulted in stimulating the demand for all types of Summer merchandise in the apparel division. Orders for dresses increased, with most of the interest centered on the Summer types; particularly chiffons for street wear and the washable lines for spectator sportswear.

CINCINNATI, April 26 (AP). -- The Cubs, behind the four-hit pitching of Tex Carleton, scored a shutout over the Cincinnati Reds today, 5 to 0. A crowd of 21,500 saw the Reds' first Sunday game of the season at home.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Since first issuing United States Savings Bonds, the so-called "baby bonds," on March 1, 1935, the Treasury has made cash sales of them in the amount of $310,081,930, representing a maturity value of $413,442,574, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

The New York unit of the Women's Overseas Service League held yesterday its first memorial service for its thirty members who have died since the war. The service, which began at 4 P.M., was held in St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street.

Two members of a family of five, the youngest of which was 69 years old, were suffocated last night and the three others were burned seriously, when a fire, which started in the basement of their four-story residence at 64 Rutland Road, Brooklyn, swept the building before the occupants were awakened.

Postmaster General James A. Farley took his children to the circus yesterday and refused to be perturbed by a report that the elephants put on their best performance of the waning season for his special benefit.

Klarna Pinska and her dance group gave a debut recital last night at the Guild Theatre before an audience of fair size and large enthusiasm. Though this was technically a debut for Miss Pinska, she has appeared over a period of years with the Denishawn company, and can under no circumstances be considered a beginner.

Columbia University announced faculty appointments and promotions yesterday, including the appointment of Dr. Nolan D.C., Lewis of Washington, D.C., as Professor of Neurology in the Columbia Medical School and as an associate director of the Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,806,636,200. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Under the Illinois Primary Law the Presidential preference vote of the State at large is advisory to the delegates at large, that of the districts to the district delegates. In the recent primary Colonel KNOX carried the State; in more than half the districts, if Mr. BORAH'S friends in the State are correct in their mathematics, the Senator was the victor.

The present drive for a new charter for New York City gained its momentum as a result of the legislative investigation of the city conducted by the committee of which Samuel Seabury was counsel. Mr. Seabury made proposals for a new charter, in his report to the Legislature, which were ignored by that body.

PITTSBURGH, April 26. -- Formation of a new steel-producing company through a merger of the West Leechburg Steel and the Allegheny Steel Companies, non-competing independents, has been suggested to the stockholders of the two concerns, it was announced here today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Aldrich gave a luncheon in the Colonial Room today for Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Fleming and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas K. Smith. Others entertaining there were Mrs. R.O. Kennedy and Mr. and Mrs. A.L. Grennell.

NEW HAVEN, April 25. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.5, which compares with 82.6 the week before, 82.6 two weeks before, 82.5 three weeks before and 82.6 four weeks before.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Jack Schiller, 21, a first-year medical student at the University of Chicago, was found stabbed to death tonight in his dormitory apartment. Police said they believed he killed himself.
The Brendin Publishing Company, 26 Maiden Lane, London, has issued a small edition of a new volume of poems by Marianne Moore, entitled "The Pangolin and Other Verse."

Group exhibitions dominate the new attractions in the New York art galleries as April turns to May More than a score of shows are on the roster, a number of them presenting points of special interest for the gallery-goer.
PITTSBURGH, April 26. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 72 per cent of capacity, up 4 points in the week and 8 points in three weeks.
Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founder of the Chinese Republic, was ranked as "one of the world's great leaders" yesterday afternoon by Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College.

Swimming in an effortless manner, 21-year-old Miss Erna Kompa successfully defended her Metropolitan senior 100-yard back-stroke championship at the benefit A.A.U. competition for women in the 25-yard pool of the Women's Swimming Association yesterday.

LONDON, April 26 (AP). -- The first big-scale move by the Ethiopian Government to remedy its weakness in military aviation has been launched here by Dr. Azaj Warqneh Martin, Ethiopian Minister to Great Britain. Dr. Martin has appealed for a private loan of $5,000,000 at 2 per cent from 100,000 subscribers to buy an air fleet.

Whom do unsound corporation taxes chiefly hurt? Obviously those who are most dependent on the corporations for their income. It is a popular notion, of which politicians frequently take advantage, that these are the stockholders. But even the most casual examination shows that the greatest beneficiary is labor.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is seeking to raise $1,500,000 to help private family welfare agencies cover their extraordinary budgets, received $232,632 after the first four full days of solicitation, Laurence M. Marks, chairman, announced yesterday.

The proposed frame of city government submitted by the Thacher commission for public discussion is built largely on existing foundations. It retains, as the very keystone of the arch, New York's unique contribution to the science of municipal government, the Board of Estimate.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP). -- William Green came to Chicago tonight to press a campaign of throwing "the entire strength of organized labor" behind the Wagner Low-Cost Housing Bill pending in the Senate.

The State Omnibus Social Security Bill was endorsed yesterday by Harold Riegelman, chairman of the Legislative Advisory Committee of the New York Republican County Committee. The bill has been held up for some time in the Republican-controlled Rules Committee of the Assembly.

LONDON, April 24. -- Wall Street's acute spasm of weakness on Thursday had, as it is viewed here, some explanation in the fact that it followed a period of prolonged buoyancy in which the rising trend of industrial activity entirely obscured the less direct, but still menacing, influence of developments abroad.

A sweeping investigation of the Sanitation Department by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, was demanded yesterday by Louis Waldman, counsel for Victor H. Abbott, former District Superintendent in charge of snow removal work. Mr. Abbott was recently dismissed by Commissioner Thomas W. Hammond.
ALBANY, April 26. -- Leaders will throw the legislative machinery into high gear tomorrow night in an effort to bring about final adjournment by the latter part of the week.

Once more the President has left the political prophets high and dry. They had confidently predicted that his speech before the Democratic Club in this city on Saturday evening would be a rouser. He was to challenge and belittle his Republican opponents. He was to utter fiery watchwords for his own party in this campaign.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Corn recently gained friends and, while there was an advance here early last week, profit-taking caused a reaction, with the May closing unchanged at 63 5/8 cents a bushel, while July was 7/8 cent lower at 62 cents, and September 1 1/8 cents lower at 60 3/4 cents.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 26. -- In one of the best judged stakes of the Eastern season, High Island Jack led his field today to capture the open all-age stake at the annual field trial meeting of the Sport and Conservation League. It was the concluding number and the most important event of the three-day program.

Edward Roesler of Laidlaw Co., a member of the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange who was not renominated on the official ticket a fortnight ago, confirmed last night reports that his name had been placed in independent nomination by a petition signed by more than forty members of the Exchange.
HORNELL, N.Y., April 26. -- Death today separated permanently two brothers, whose hermit-like existence in the hills near here had been divided by a chalkline for sixty-two years.

A prediction that the next twenty-five years would witness the greatest movement toward the reunion of Protestantism since the Reformation was made in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Light hogs sold at $11 a hundredweight on last Monday and also on the last three days of the five-day week. This price has been made several times since Feb. 10. The average price of hogs here last week was $10.65, or 5 cents more than the previous week.

CINCINNATI, April 26. -- Officers of thirty-six State organizations, vanguard of 800 delegates, will be here by tomorrow morning for the all-day conferences to precede the opening Tuesday of the biennial convention of the League of Women Voters.

When Cyrano de Bergerac opens this evening, PERCY HAMMOND will not be there. The critic of The Herald Tribune is dead. Those who have been taking his presence for granted in aisle seats well forward will have a strange feeling that tonight's premiere is incomplete; and it will be some months before an opening without his presence seems normal.
Seven second-round games were completed yesterday in the United States chess championship play before an enthusiastic crowd in the Grill Room of the Hotel Astor.

Under the authorization of Chapter 867, Laws of 1934, the Mayor on January 12, 1935, appointed as the New York City Charter Revision Commission: Thomas D. Thacher, chairman. S. John Block, Mrs. William P. Earle Jr., Frederick L. Hackenburg, Charles E. Hughes Jr., Joseph D. McGoldrick, Charles G. Meyer, Thomas I. Parkinson and Joseph M. Proskauer.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26. -- Insignia for competition in Winter sports have been granted to 262 athletes at Yale by the board of control of the Athletic Association of the university on recommendation of the Undergraduate Athletic Association.

A few hours after Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, had sent a cable telling of the recent outbreak in Palestine and asking for a special $150,000 fund to meet urgent needs, a drive for the money was started last night at a meeting of all the Zionist groups in the Hotel Astor.

DALLAS, Texas, April 26. -- Robert Mayer of Dallas was elected yesterday president of the American Cotton Shippers Association, succeeding Morris E. Berney of Fort Worth. Selection of the city for the next convention will be determined by a mail ballot of members of the association.

MADRID, April 26. -- With the Monarchist and Conservative parties abstaining almost everywhere, Spain held today an election who designate 473 special electors who will meet with an equal number of parliamentary Deputies May 10 to choose the republic's second President.

PLAY in your own back yard," said Mother one Summer afternoon a long time ago, "and you won't get hurt." The little boy had gone across the street to play with Victor the day before; both he and Victor had fallen from the railing of Victor's front porch, and a good deal of screaming, limping and rubbing with liniment had ensued.

Governor LEHMAN'S message calling for another $10,000,000 relief appropriation now and another $30,000,000 relief bond issue to be voted on next Fall comes as a shock, and a disturbing one. It is not pleasant to learn that home relief expenditures have risen so sharply lately, in the face of recovery, that the pending budgetary appropriation must be doubled.

MIAMI, Fla., April 26. -- In a serenely social atmosphere marked by nothing more official than a Sunday afternoon tea, delegates to the annual council meeting of the General Federation of Women's Clubs poured in here today from all parts of the country, preparatory to a far more serious program, opening tomorrow.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 26. -- After recording two impressive victories over the various jumps on the outside course during the morning session, the striking aged chestnut mare Rule Britannia, owned by Miss Fredericka Fry of Cos Cob, Conn., fared equally well when shown under saddle this afternoon to take the hunter championship in the Hutchinson Horse Show.

A typical family of four persons with an annual income of $2,500, while paying no Federal or New York State income taxes, pays indirect taxes of $183 a year, or about $3.50 out of a weekly income of $48, the Guaranty Trust Company calculates in a study of the tax drain on low incomes in the current issue of its publication, The Guaranty Survey.

With representatives of the Dramatists Guild and the League of New York Theatres attempting to bridge the differences between the play-producing contracts proffered by the two groups, a settlement within a week was predicted yesterday by one prominent producer-playwright.

BERLIN, April 26. -- The conversion of the entire German nation into a semi-military organization subject to semi-military discipline has taken another big forward stride with the creation of a whole system of honor and disciplinary courts for the German Labor Front, which comprises virtually the entire non-agrarian working populace, both employers and employes.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Senator Davis of Pennsylvania, who proclaims that in his early days he "delighted to sing and upon occasion could do something with the clarinet" and who knew the stage favorites of the gay Nineties, assailed today what he referred to as the diversion of "American money to spread communistic propaganda in this country, through the theatre or otherwise."

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- A major drive to prevent the nomination of Governor Landon is under way among Republican leaders, with the first open move made by some of the party chieftains at Cleveland last week.

A one-week canvass of the 370 parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York in behalf of its charities will start today. The goal is $1,500,000. There will be 25,000 volunteer workers. At each mass in all the churches yesterday a personal message from Cardinal Hayes was read to the 1,250,000 under his spiritual jurisdiction.

Though its case load has continued to decrease in recent years, because of unemployment and the fact that poor litigants resort to the small claims courts in increasing numbers, the Legal Aid Society expects an increase in the number of cases it handles as employment improves, it is disclosed by the sixtieth annual report of the society, made public yesterday.

Harsh words are again being exchanged between the generations. It may be the late Spring bringing an unusual number of heavy colds. It may be the recent anti-war demonstrations, which so often produce frayed tempers.

For the first quarter of this year, the Monsanto Chemical Company has reported a consolidated net profit of $1,071,691 after all charges, including taxes. After deductions for minority interest and subsidiary preferred dividend requirements, there was $1,032,852 applicable to the common stock, or $1.03 a share on 999,123 shares outstanding.
CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP). -- The Indians swept into undisputed possession of first place in the American League by outlasting the Browns in a sixteen-inning marathon today, 8 -- 7.

The annual Spring shoot of the Atlantic Indians, an organization with members throughout the Eastern States, brought sixty-four gunners to the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The feature was a class event at 100 targets.
We are told that 9,000,000 new voters will cast their first ballot for President in the Fall elections. The youth of today is an important element in the political world.

Special details of police have been assigned to guard 175 naval cadets and five officers of the German cruiser Emden from Communist and anti-Nazi demonstrations on their visit to New York today and tomorrow.

There is a force in the world today that is radically and militantly evil and is determined to go forward, the Rev. Andrew R. Osborn of Edmonton, Alberta, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons will display bridal costumes of the past as well as those of the present day when the fashion showing entitled "Brides of Two Centuries" will be repeated during the luncheon hour Friday in the Trianon Room and Garden of the Ambassador.

The offer of the Chilean Government to pay interest on its own long-term dollar obligations and those guaranteed by it at the rate of $4.75 on each $1,000 bond was characterized last night by the Chilean bondholders' committee as "another example of the irresponsible attitude of a foreign debtor toward rights and privileges of American investors."

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP). -- Paul A. Walker, Commissioner of Communications, said today that telephone rate slashes resulting in savings to subscribers of more than $3,000,000 annually had been made since the FCC started its investigation into the far-flung American Telephone and Telegraph Company last Fall.

A new charter for the City of New York, to be submitted to the voters at the general election this Fall, was made public yesterday by the New York City Charter Revision Commission. The document, representing the work of a year and a half on the part of the nine members of the commission, will be the subject of public hearings, and possible revisions, between now and midsummer.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 26. -- Colonists entertained at the casino today before the final match in the sixteenth annual Mason and Dixon championship tennis tournament played by Bryan Grant Jr. and Donald Budge. Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Berwind Jr. gave a luncheon for Miss Mary F. Clay.

Nearly 3,000 members and friends of 145 Anglo-American lodges and orders assembled yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine for a special service in honor of St. George, Great Britain's patron saint, received cabled greetings from King Edward and heard a plea for closer cooperation between the British and American people.

PARIS, April 24. -- The report of the Bank of France for April 17 shows a fresh increase of 426,000,000 francs in bills discounted, while loans against securities and bonds decreased only 39,000,000 francs from a week before. Circulation, however, decreased 880,000,000 francs, of which 493,000,000 went to swell private deposits.
BOSTON, April 26. -- The Yankees spotted the Red Sox six runs in the first inning and then conquered Tom Yawkey's minions with a blistering fire of base hits in Fenway Park today.

More than 10,000 retailers situated in various sections of the country, who are planning to observe National Cotton Week, June 1 to 6, have received an "Idea Book" of practical suggestions for profitable participation in the event, it was announced yesterday by the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc.

" Belief may be no more than an opinion, but faith is trust," said the Rev. Dr. Walton H. Greever, Secretary of the United Lutheran Church in America, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Lutheran Church of Our Savior's Atonement, Bennett Avenue and 189th Street.

A diversified program is being prepared for the Spring fete and bazaar of St. James Church, which will take place on May 7 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The fete is for the benefit of domestic and foreign missions in which the young people of the church are interested.

Sigismond Stojowski, the Polish pianist, who has not appeared in recital in New York for several years, gave a concert at the Town Hall last night for the benefit of the Polish Institute of Arts and Letters. Appropriately enough, the program was devoted to two great Polish musicians -- Chopin and Paderewski.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, which is seeking $3,500,000 in this country to aid the Jews of Germany and other European lands, published a statement yesterday clarifying its position toward Palestine, Poland and the newly formed Council for German Jewry.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 26. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman declared here tonight that New Jersey "is confronted with the urgent necessity of raising about $30,000,000." That amount, he said, is needed "to take care of relief and to make a start in reducing the tax burdens on real estate."

BERLIN, April 26. -- Two political developments outside of Germany will influence German official action in the next few weeks. One is, of course, the French elections; the other is the series of questions regarding German intentions that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain, on behalf of the powers still adhering to the Locarno treaty, will address to the Wilhelmstrasse this week.

Traffic stopped, amateur photographers had a field day and elderly gentlemen peered over their newspapers and out of the windows of the Metropolitan Club yesterday afternoon as the Knickerbocker Greys, smartly uniformed junior cadet corps, marched from the Seventh Regiment Armory down Fifth Avenue to St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

The experience of the share market last week was that nervousness was intensified rather than diminished after more than a fortnight of indecisive trading. Professionals, who are never averse to pressing an advantage whether on the side of the advance or the decline, found it easier to depress prices than to rally them, so that the market was on the defensive most of the week.

I am a member of the so-called "lost generation," born during the World War and come to maturity during the great depression. I am a member of that generation which indulges in peace strikes, which has produced such organizations as the Veterans of Future Wars, which is able to pronounce the word "communism" without hissing the last syllable.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, preached at confirmation services yesterday at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street.

The completely renovated historic Gracie Mansion, in Carl Schurz Park, Eighty-eighth Street and East River, will be opened to the public next Saturday and will remain open every day thereafter except Mondays from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., the Department of Parks announced yesterday.
The Fifteenth Assembly District Republicans turned to the stage last night to lampoon the New Deal.

Women interested in the Mount Ivy Camp of the Art Workshop will meet this morning at the home of Mrs. Morgan Wing Jr., 1,136 Fifth Avenue, to discuss plans for the opening on July 3 of this creative art camp for girls, near Suffern, N.Y.

TRENTON, N.J., April 27. -- After a two-hour public hearing this afternoon, the Senate Judiciary Committee said it would decide in conference whether to report the Assembly bill to restrict issuance of injunctions by the Court of Chancery in labor disputes.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27. -- Joe Bowers, 40 years old, a mail robber, was killed today in an attempt to escape from the Alcatraz Island Federal prison. It was the first attempt to flee from the "escapeless" fortress since Alcatraz ceased to be an army disciplinary barracks.

Several young matrons and dbutantes of this and recent seasons will act as manikins in the fashion show to be presented at the luncheon and card party for the benefit of the :New York Diet Kitchen Association on May 5 at the formal opening of the Park Lane Gardens.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Justice Jennings Bailey in District of Columbia Supreme Court today sustained the constitutionality of the processing tax on Philippine coconut oil and refused to order a distribution of a $26,000,000 fund which has accumulated from the levy collected from 200 soap manufacturers.

" Work out for yourselves," the President asked the Young Democrats at Baltimore, "what would happen if all "the boys and all the girls of 14 and "15 and 16 and 17 who are now working "in industry found it possible to "stay in school until they were at least "18 years old.

The New York State Waterways Association charged the railroads of the State yesterday with having issued "misleading and incorrect" statements in a campaign to abolish free-toll transportation of freight on the State canal system.

LOUISVILLE, April 27. -- With the arrival today of five racers from the East, there are twenty eligibles for the sixty-second Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs preparing for the running of the $40,000 added mile-and-a-quarter test on Saturday. Teufel, Granville, Merry Pete, Gold Seeker and Ned Reigh detrained from the Cincinnati Limited and all were reported in excellent shape.

A drive to eradicate old foundations in Queens on which buildings formerly stood or were to have been built was begun yesterday by the Highway Bureau in cooperation with the borough office of the Health Department and the Police Department.
A crowd of men and women cheered a policeman yesterday as he rushed up the stairs of a five-story tenement to save a woman from jumping from the roof to the sidewalk, more than 100 feet below.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The Senate adopted without a record vote today the Vandenberg resolution calling on Secretary Wallace to supply a list of beneficiaries under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of more than $10,000 a year.

Brooklyn's boys and girls week began in earnest yesterday with the selection of Winifred Wells, 16-year-old high school student of 692 Lexington Avenue, as Miss Brooklyn, and the descent of thousands of youngsters on the borough's industrial and professional world.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Two leaders of opposing political parties in Puerto Rico agreed here today that the Independence Bill introduced last week by Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland was unsuitable. They both held that the plan would ruin Puerto Rico economically before the island had any opportunity to benefit from independence.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Protesting that no one group could re-employ the millions now on relief and declaring that it was "useless to blame any one for unemployment," the board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States decided today to make a special survey of the possibilities of re-employment throughout the nation.
BARTOW, Fla., April 27. -- A curtain behind which threats, violence and political chicanery held sway in Tampa was partly pulled aside today as the flogging trial went into its third week.

Jamaica High came through with its fourth straight victory and remained the only unbeaten baseball team in the race for the Queens P.S.A.L. championship by halting Grover Cleveland, 8 -- 2, at the Jamaica Stadium yesterday.

The National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor, brought its season of six evening concerts to a close at Carnegie Hall last night. Winifred Cecil, the soprano, was the assisting artist; she sang two Wagner excerpts -- "Elsa's Traum" from "Lohengrin" and "Dich, Theure Halle" from "Tannhaeuser."

The proposed new city charter was critically received yesterday by politicians and reformers alike. Officeholders declared that it went too far and would make a dictator out of the Mayor. Reformers called it a step in the right direction, but indicated that they believed the city's governmental structure needed a more drastic overhauling.
