The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of 96,000 shares of 5 1/4 per cent convertible preferred stock and 192,000 additional shares of common stock of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company. Stockholders will vote at a special meeting today on a reclassification of the company's stock to provide for a new issue of preferred shares.

Use of new and more thorough methods of research to shed light on such things as the factors which bring about prosperity and depression are among the long-range aims of the United States Department of Commerce, Ernest G. Draper, Assistant Secretary of the department, said in an address to the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., at its regular luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- A large number of American citizens are reduced to such economic extremity that they eat 20 per cent of the canned dog food produced in the country, Senator Dickinson charged in the Senate today.

ALBANY, April 27. -- Spurred by Governor Lehman's letter to Speaker Ives, demanding enactment of the rest of the anti-crime bills, the Republican Assembly tonight passed two of the key measures in the Executive's program, both sponsored by Senator Buckley.

Wall Street is still more or less in a state of perplexity over what constitutes a new loan by banks to brokers under the Federal Reserve Board's Regulation U that will become effective on Friday. Last week's ruling by the board in the matter still left the question unanswered for many.

Domestic corporation bonds declined sharply yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange in sympathy with the break in stocks. The combined average for the three major corporate groups was 0.40 point lower on the day, with the public utility issues in the van with a drop of 0.63 point.
Awards for meritorious work by students at the free art schools of the National Academy of Design, Amsterdam Avenue and 109th Street, were made last night at the annual commencement exercises.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Denial of the right to bargain for employment according to an individual's estimate of his own mental and physical capacity would make some free men and women wards of the State, counsel for Joseph Tipaldo, New York laundry owner, asserted today in a brief opposing the New York State Minimum Wage Law.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Administration officials are understood to be perturbed about reports from various parts of the country indicating the extent to which State and local relief costs are rising under the government's work-relief program.

Frederick L. Bauer, former lame newsdealer at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, whose customers included the late Theodore Roosevelt and Jacob Riis, received ,the Henry Pomeroy Davison Memorial prize last night at Institute Day exercises of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, 400 First Avenue.

Last evening it was the double bill, as renowned a conjunction as the founders themselves, which went into the repertory at the Majestic. Name them as "Trial by Jury" and "H.M.S. Pinafore," third in the offerings of Mr. Chartock's Savoy season. An audience that pretty well filled the house -- the Queen's navy being popular everywhere -- was on hand to greet them, and evener one had a good time.

The share market suffered its widest decline since July 26, 1934, yesterday, eclipsing last Thursday's break, which had been the most severe since the bull market began more than thirteen months ago. Yesterday leading stocks were depressed 1 to more than 9 points.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 27. -- Bow and Arrow, the 3-year-old bay gelded son of Whichone and Beaming Over, which won so cleverly in his outing last week, came back today in the Sudbrook Purse, fourth and feature number on the program, and made it two in a row.

CINCINNATI, April 27. -- The failure of Congress to vote on the Ramspeck bill to place under civil service first, second and third class postmasters was denounced and its passage at this session demanded in a statement by the National League of Women Voters today on the eve of its biennial convention.

Eighteen men and one woman were arrested yesterday in an alleged State-wide racket, through which the New York Telephone Company, a restaurant chain and the three subway systems in this city were defrauded last year alone of about $400,000 through the use of metal slugs in coin boxes.

Sunday's voting in France for a new Parliament was, as most political observers predicted, inconclusive. Apparently less than one-third of the total membership of the Chamber of Deputies was elected. This results from the peculiar method of conducting a general election in France.

In recognition of her forty years' service to New York City and of her "pioneering" work in advancing the cause of the woman doctor. Dr. Anna Williams, former assistant director of the research laboratories of the New York City Department of Health, received last night a testimonial scroll presented by the Women's Medical Society of New York State.

BERLIN, April 27. -- Colonel-General Hermann Goering in effect superseded Dr. Hjalmar Schacht today as dictator of the economic and financial policies of the Third Reich when Chancellor Adolf Hitler appointed him a sort of special commissar to deal with all problems involving "raw materials and foreign exchange."

The heavily scented eleventh-floor roof terrace in Rockefeller Center was humming with activity yesterday for the Spring opening of the Gardens of the Nations, augmented by a Daffodil Show and a Spring Flower Festival, the latter following a French Riviera tradition hundreds of years old.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 27 (AP). -- Hundreds of excited students rushed from University of Nebraska class rooms today to find two members of the faculty wounded, one fatally, after three shots rang out on the campus.

Many dinners were given last night in the Russian Eagle of the Sherry-Netherland in connection with the Spring dance held there under the patronage of the Grand Duke Dmitri for the benefit of the League of Young Russia. The dance was arranged by a committee under the direction of Princess Serge Troubetzkoy and Princess Dolly Obolensky.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, April 27. -- The program of the ceremonies honoring the 550th anniversary of Heidelberg University in June, just published, indicates that the spokesmen for the political regime now in power will have the major role.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Beginning next Monday the Treasury will increase its weekly sales of bills from $50,000,000 to $100,000,000 to provide funds for payment of the soldiers' bonus and to maintain a "comfortable cash balance" regarded as necessary because of unsettled world conditions.

Charges of communism in the Federal theatre protect here, made public Sunday in Washington by Senator Davis of Pennsylvania, were denied yesterday by Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national director of the stage program, and received without comment by Philip W. Barber, regional director for this city.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Attention was focused today upon the fact that the Works Progress Administration is financing the building or improving of 600 municipal golf courses throughout the country when it was announced that Bobby Jones, the famous Atlanta golfer, had offered his services as an expert adviser in connection with the projects.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- An atom gun shooting atomic projectiles at speeds of 15,000 miles a second with energies of 11,000,000 volts was announced here today at the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences by Professor Ernest O. Lawrence and Dr. J.M. Cork of the University of California.

The minutes of directors' meetings of nine banks were examined by the government in the Supreme Court here yesterday. All nine are defendants in a government equity suit before Justice Bernard L. Shientag, involving $2,000,000 still needed by the Federal receiver of the closed Harriman National Bank to pay the depositors in full.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- James P. Warburg, former financial adviser to the Treasury Department, declared tonight that the Federal budget should be balanced by broadening the base of the income tax "so that governmental economy will become popular and governmental extravagance unpopular."

The colors of Mrs. Payne Whitney were first and third in the Victorian Handicap at six furlongs, feature at Jamaica yesterday, when her Chicle gelding, Plat Eye, one of the best local sprinters, got home a length and a half before Paul A. Shaw's Gov. Sholtz with Mrs. Whitney's Black Buddy third in the field of seven.

Most futures declined yesterday on the local commodity Exchanges. Sugar futures were an exception. On the cash markets eggs and tin rose, while losses appeared in all the grains, cotton, lard, rubber and butter.

Lawrence Levy of 2,800 Bailey Avenue, the Bronx, a self-confessed robber, was so proud of his success as a bootlegger during the last four years of prohibition that he talked himself into an income tax inquiry while he was testifying yesterday in Federal court.

Sale at auction of collateral securing bank loans of the United States Electric Power Corporation, which now aggregate more than $12,000,000 including interest in arrears, will be announced today by the Chase National Bank, the Guaranty Trust Company and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

More actual writing of orders for Summer merchandise is expected this week, with the arrival of additional buyers here and the completion of the inspection of the new lines, reports here yesterday indicated. Mail orders yesterday showed some improvement over last week, particularly from stores in the South and Middle West, which have already obtained consumer action on Summer garments.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- Although outhit, Pennsylvania came through with a 4-to-3 victory over Dartmouth on Franklin Field today to gain second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

CHICAGO, April 27. -- Moving into this sector of the baseball front, which has been a Waterloo for the Dodgers since the Cubs halted their 1930 pennant drive, Field Marshal Casey Stengel today went into a state of deep concentration on the problem of preventing history from repeating itself.

John F. Krepps, White Plains banker, likes to fish for trout in a stream. The week-ends usually find him on a winding brook in Westchester or Putnam. Occasionally, in the Spring, he will try for perch in one of the Croton lakes, but as a rule he is not partial to lake fishing in the early stages of the season.
MOSCOW, April 27. -- A proposal for a tax on divorces, to be doubled for each divorce after the first, is included in the new marriage law being drafted by the Commission for Framing Laws.

LONDON, April 27. -- Sir Thomas Beecham opened the London international opera season in Covent Garden tonight with "Die Meistersinger." The audience, which thus celebrated the commencement of the annual social round, was held to be as representative as any of past years.

CLEVELAND, April 27 (AP). -- George Blaeholder's seven-hit pitching and Bruce Campbell's homer in the seventh inning gave the Indians a 2-1 victory over the Browns today and kept the Indians at the top of the American League.

Mrs. Anna Sage, 44 years old, who is said to have betrayed the notorious bandit John Dillinger to Federal agents, who shot him down in Chicago as he was leaving a moving picture theatre, arrived early yesterday morning at Jersey City with eighty other deportees in a special train and was taken to Ellis Island.

Low fares and improved equipment increased passenger movement on the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad in 1935, the report of the company for that year discloses. In the West, the rate of 2 cents a mile for coaches and 3 cents a mile for Pullman cars recently ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission in the East, has prevailed since Dec. 1, 1933.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP). -- The Federal Reserve Board pursued today a policy which it said was designed to curb the flow of credit for speculation, while permitting free movement of funds for business enterprises.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 28. -- A long step toward insuring peace along the Russo-Japanese and Russo-Manchukuoan frontiers was taken yesterday when Ambassador Constantin Yureneff of Russia and Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita reached an agreement that will enable frontier commissions to be appointed for the eastern sector, extending from Lake Khanka to the Korean border.

A banking group composed of Kidder, Peabody Co., W.E. Hutton Co., G.M.-P. Murphy Co. and Field, Glore Co. today will offer 54,702 shares of common stock of the General Time Instruments Corporation at $23.50 a share. The stock represents shares from among 75,644 that were not subscribed by stockholders under the rights offered to them by the company on April 15.

The new municipal North River pier, under construction at the foot of West Fiftieth Street for occupancy by ships of the Cunard White Star Line, will be ready to receive the Queen Mary on her maiden voyage June 1, it was announced yesterday by Public Works Administrator Harold L. Ickes.

Teach children to think and civilization will be transformed in one generation, Dr. Rollo G. Reynolds, principal of Horace Mann School, said yesterday afternoon. He spoke at the second of three panel meetings sponsored by the Public Education Association.

After congratulating the detective division on the solution of the Titterton murder case and several other recent cases, Police Commissioner Valentine told the executives of the division yesterday that he was still not entirely satisfied with the discipline of the division. He ordered them to weed out incompetents and keep a sharp eye out for promising talent among the ranks of the uniformed force.

CHICAGO, April 27. -- Receipts of hogs exceeded the estimates today and were above trade requirements and prices dropped 10 to 30 cents a hundredweight, with the better grade of light weights showing the least loss. Arrivals were 19,000 head, the largest total since Jan. 30.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., which recently changed its name from Consolidated Gas Company, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $32,563,785 for the twelve months ended on March 31, after all deductions except minority interests in affiliated companies' common stocks.

Sears, Roebuck Co. should make substantially better profits this year than last "if the country doesn't go into a nose dive," General R.E. Wood, president, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting here.
CHICAGO, April 27. -- Horton Smith, lanky Chicago professional who would have settled for a $2,000 slice of the Winter golf prize money, grabbed the biggest bankroll of them all -- $7,048.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP). -- E. Ralph Jones of Norfolk, Va., formerly a cotton merchant, told the Senate Agriculture Committee today that big cotton trading firms dominated the Bureau of Economics of the Department of Agriculture.

TRENTON, N.J., April 27. -- If New Jersey's two dominant political leaders, Governor Harold G. Hoffman, titular chief of the Re publicans, and Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic head, were to take a vacation of two weeks perhaps the State's critical unemployment relief situation could be solved.

The Brooklyn division of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee started its campaign to obtain $150,000, Brooklyn's share of the $1,500,000 quota of the campaign, last night at a dinner at the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn. More than 500 workers gathered to hear campaign chairmen and division leaders outline the necessity for the fund.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 27. -- Definite provision against amalgamation of the government-owned Canadian National Railways and the privately owned Canadian Pacific Railway, or even unified management and control, is made in Bill 21, introduced today in Parliament by C.D. Howe, Minister of Railways, for reorganization of the Canadian National's management and replacement of the present board of three trustees by seven directors.

Governor LANDON'S backers for the Presidential nomination are surprised, and perhaps a little alarmed, by the evidence that some other candidates and several Republican managers are attempting to form a combination against him. That always happens when one man in the race seems to have taken a strong lead.

CINCINNATI, April 27. -- With two gone in the last of the tenth and Long Lonnie Warneke on the mound, Ernie Lombardi doubled and Tommy Thevenow singled today to give the Reds a 5-4 victory over the Cubs.

The background of the battle over the life of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, executed slayer of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., came to the fore again yesterday as District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn continued his investigation into the kidnapping and false confession of Paul H. Wendel.

MARFA, Texas, April 27. -- More than 3,000 men and officers are encamped on the plains at near-by Fort D.A. Russell preparatory to the first manoeuvres since 1927 of the entire First Cavalry Division, the army's only cavalry division.

The United States Bureau of Fisheries was branded as a "racket" last night by Jay N. Darling, acting president of General Wildlife Federation, at a meeting of the officers and trustees of the American Wildlife Institute at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Physicians on full-time employment as public servants who engage in private practice for profit were condemned yesterday by the House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York, meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in connection with the 130th annual convention of the society.

Despite generally favorable news from trade and industry, the stock market suffered yesterday its widest decline since July 26, 1934. Representative stocks dropped from 1 to 9 points on the Stock Exchange. Trading totaled 2,303,000 shares, the largest volume of any day since March 13.

NORTHWOOD, England, April 27. -- Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, golf's youngest and newest sensation, and Miss Joyce Wethered, long regarded as the game's foremost feminine player, stole the show today in a series of exhibition charity foursome matches featuring members of the American Curtis Cup team and British stars.

Pedro Montanez, the Puerto Rican lightweight sensation, added one more triumph to his impressive list by defeating Aldo Spoldi, game little Italian battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.
Noisy bus loads of children thronged into Madison Square Garden yesterday morning for a special two-hour performance of the circus.

CHICAGO, April 27. -- General rains over the Winter wheat belt in the Southwest, ranging up to three inches in the Texas Panhandle, according to trade reports, started general selling of wheat futures today on the Board of Trade and prices closed 2 7/8 to 3 7/8 cents a bushel lower.

As a successor to its stimulatingly controversial exhibition of "Cubist and Abstract Art," the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will open privately today and to the public tomorrow a show devoted entirely to illustration. It occupies all of the galleries on four floors and is held under the direction of Monroe Wheeler, a specialist in de luxe editions and one of the founders of the publishing house of Harrison of Paris.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Senator Dickinson told the Senate that the annual production of canned dog food had been estimated at 500,000,000 cans with a retail value of $40,000,000. He said L.J. Becker, former secretary of the National Dog Food Manufacturers Association, had figured that 20 per cent of the output, or about 100,000,000 pounds, was eaten by people.
Isaac I. Kashdan, New York State champion, won two games in the U.S. chess championship last night at the Hotel Astor and took undisputed possession of first place with three victories to his credit.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 27. -- Seventeen thousand Kentucky colonels and admirals whose status has been in question since Attorney General B.M. Vincent recently held they were not entitled to office were ordered restored to good standing today by Acting Governor James E. Wise.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on April 22 shows a decrease for the week of $13,000,000 in total loans and investments, increases of $191,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, $27,000,000 in time deposits and $132,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and a decrease of $108,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

Joe Jacobs, manager of Max Schmeling, announced yesterday that he had selected the Napanoch Country Club at Napanoch, N.Y., as the training site for the German heavyweight, who will meet Joe Louis here on June 18.

The Yankees will be called on to repel the first threat of the American League's Western clubs today when the Indians start a three-game series at the Bronx Stadium The visitors are in first place this morning, have been getting fine pitching so far and strong hitting from Averill, Trosky and Campbell, all above the .350 mark.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Having denied applications that the information be treated as confidential, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today certain data filed by several corporations under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 27. -- The Westchester Commission on Government, headed by Carl H. Pforzheimer, submitted this afternoon to the Board of Supervisors a final draft of its recommendations in bill form, with a request that it be forwarded immediately to the Legislature for approval.

An offering of $30,000,000 of Pacific Gas and Electric Company first and refunding mortgage series H 3 3/4 per cent bonds, due 1961, is being made today, at a price of 102 3/4 and accrued interest, by a nationwide underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The $2,766,186,167 volume of security transactions on national securities exchanges in March, while at a comparatively high level, represented a decrease of 4.6 per cent from the value of sales in February, the Securities and Exchange Commission made known today.

BERLIN, April 27. -- The Boerse opened the week generally firm and livelier than usual. It was stimulated by favorable business news, including the announcement that employment last month increased 740,866, which is 160,000 more than the decrease in registered unemployment.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- House Republicans, seeking to make "campaign material" out of the administration's tax bill met tonight in the House chamber to discuss the general provisions of the "unworkable" tax bill.

NEWARK, N.J., April 27. -- The Bears concluded a successful home stay today with a sparkling display of hitting and recorded an easy 12-to-3 victory over Montreal. The Bruins won eleven games out of thirteen on the home diamond.

Action on the booklet, "Americanism -- What Is It?" put out by the committee on Americanism of the New York County Committee of the American Legion to the chagrin of many Legionnaires who term it communistic, was postponed by the county committee at a meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- One of Senator Borah's most uncomfortable thoughts these days is that, in stopping Colonel Knox and -- if he can -- Governor Landon, he may be paving the way for the nomination of Senator Dickinson of Iowa by the Republican National Convention at Cleveland.

Three firemen were injured, mostly by smoke, in a four-alarm fire last night that rolled great waves of tar smoke from two four-story buildings of an abandoned brewery at 3,560 Third Avenue between 168th and 169th Streets, the Bronx.

Six hours after the directors had called the first duelists to the strips, six epee wielders, led by the defending champion, Lieutenant Thomas J. Sands of the Fencers Club and West Point, qualified for the final round robin of the national championship early this morning on the strips of the New York A.C. Tomorrow evening they will clash for the crown.

Figures made public yesterday by the WPA revealed that 80,000 school children of a total of 763,065 examined here by experts at work on a WPA project have been found with potential Impairments of hearing in one or both ears. The examinations cover a period from January, 1934, to March 1, 1936.

Having snapped L.I.U.'s winning streak on Saturday the New York University nine went over to Manhattan Field yesterday intent upon handing the same treatment to the unbeaten Manhattan College outfit, but the Violet had not reckoned with burly Pete Blumette, the Jasper southpaw ace.

A gift of $3,000,000 from the General Education Board, founded by John D. Rockefeller, to the Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, to erect a new twelve-story hospital building adjacent to the Rockefeller Institute, was announced yesterday by Harry Pelham Robbins, president of the institution.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The Supreme Court warned "multiplying" legislative agencies today that their conclusions of facts, as well as of law, must be subject to scrutiny of the courts if constitutional rights of liberty and property have been invaded.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 27. -- Formally and dressily, with speech and song, several hundred officials and members inaugurated the seventeenth council meeting of the General Federation of Women's Clubs in the main dining room of the Miami-Biltmore Hotel here tonight, but informal activities that had urged the majority to early rising had already written a good day's work into the record preliminary to the evening ceremony.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 27. -- Young American composers had majority representation on the program of chamber music which was played at the opening concert of the Eastman School Festival of American Music tonight. The concert was in Kilbourn Hall, which was taxed to capacity.
The State of Mississippi has invited bankers to submit bids on May 14 for a new issue of $9,850,000 of State highway notes. Further details will be announced later.

The Council of the Dramatists Guild paused long enough in its contract difficulties yesterday to award the Roi Cooper Megrue Prize. The winner; "Boy Meets Girl," the authors of which, Samuel and Bella Spewack, will be enriched by $500. The prize is given each year to that play which in the opinion of the council dismisses an audience in a happier frame of mind than it held at 8:50 and at 2:50.

Dr. JAMES M. KIERAN, lately president of Hunter College, was by native ability, temperament and opportunity a teacher, and out of his experience as such prepared to be a teacher of teachers. He did not have to learn from EMERSON that there is no teaching until the student is brought into the same "state and principle" with the teacher.

The proposed tax on surplus earnings of corporations is unsound, and will retard the growth of industry, injure labor and jeopardize financial security, according to a report issued yesterday by the special committee on fiscal policies of government to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

DESSYE, April 27. -- The Italian vanguard, marching on Addis Ababa, had a brief encounter 100 miles south of Dessye with a group of Ethiopian irregulars, who were swiftly dispersed with several casualties. The advance motorized column which left here yesterday is pressing steadily toward the capital.

ROME, April 27. -- No official bulletin on the Ethiopian war was published today. From this fact the impression was gathered that the opposing armies on the Ogaden front, where a battle for the possession of Sasa Baneh has been going on for almost a fortnight, are recruiting their strength for a decisive clash.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP). -- The Supreme Court affirmed today a decree by the Southern New York Federal District Court holding that the International Business Machines Corporation of New York City had violated the anti-trust laws.

LOUISVILLE, April 27. -- The Rockhome Stable's Dora May qualified handsomely for her engagement in the Kentucky Oaks when she led home five other eligibles for that stake and two non-eligibles in the Eastern Parkway Purse at Churchill Downs today.

Senator Tydings's bill to permit the people of Puerto Rico to vote on independence presents two questions, namely, the economic and financial welfare of the people of the island, and, in a way, the national security of the United States.

Judge SEABURY'S support of the new charter, however qualified, should bring comfort to members of the committee which drafted it. To him, more than to any other man living, the city owes the exposure of the evil forces which so long corrupted local government. It was understandable that he should seek in radical changes in the charter the cure for a disease so deep-seated.

Mr. Hampden is saying farewell to "Cyrano" of the long beak and grandiloquent literary style. Since he first staged Rostand's romantic drama in 1923 he has revived it in New York three times, and now he has set it up for its last Gotham showing at the New Amsterdam, where a large audience applauded it last evening.
THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine had an article by R.L. Martin depicting the passing of the salesmen. This was, I am sure, pleasing to the old-time salesman.

ST. LOUIS, April 27. -- With Freddy Fitzsimmons, who was left behind in New York nursing a heavy cold, remaining as the lone serious convalescent, Colonel Bill Terry marshaled his forces on the west bank of the Mississippi tonight, prepared for his first clash of the season with the Cardinals tomorrow.

VIENNA, April 27. -- The first Fascist election on the corporative principle held in Austria occurred yesterday in Vorarlberg Province, when a strictly limited electorate was invited to vote on certain names as future village representatives in the corporative Peasant and Forest Council.

ALBANY, April 27. -- In the face of opposition from most of the Democrats from the City of New York, the Senate tonight passed a bill by Senator Samuel Mandelbaum, Democrat, to amend the Multiple Dwelling Law by providing for the demolition of buildings which constitute nuisances, which are vacant or abandoned and a fire hazard, which are dangerous to human life or are detrimental to the health of occupants of adjoining buildings.

Rudolph Metz, member of the banking firm of Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., who died June 8, 1933, left an estate appraised yesterday at $2,077,264 gross and $1,869,620 net, of which $1,163,137 was in securities. The stocks included 6,637 shares of Cooperstown Corporation worth $657,155, and 2,474 shares of Standard Utilities, valued at $244,939.

Wireless messages received last night in New York reported a yacht in distress about five miles off the coast of Cuba and some twenty miles west-southwest of Bahia Honda. The vessel reported her name as Jane II.

The International Seamen's Union reiterated its disapproval of the current strike of Atlantic Coast seamen yesterday morning when its suit to prevent the provisional strike committee from representing the walkout as one for which the union was sponsor, was opened before Supreme Court Justice William Harmon Black.

Offering will be made to the public today by a banking group headed by Hayden, Stone Co., Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co., Inc., of $110,000,000 of Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation rapid transit collateral-trust bonds.

A visit to the circus last night completed the first lap of a whirlwind trip to New York by 169 naval cadets and five officers from the German cruiser Emden. Anticipated Communist and anti-Nazi demonstrations failed to materialize, and the policemen detailed to watch over the group had little to do.

ALBANY, April 27. -- Governor Lehman's main Budget Bill, with reducing amendments agreed upon by the conference committee, was passed tonight by both houses of the Legislature, ending a six-week deadlock.
New York City will spend up to $7,000,000 on the 1939 World's Fair in Flushing Meadows, according to legislation sent to Albany last night after its approval by the Board of Estimate.
France's run-off election to be held next Sunday is for the selection of Deputies in those constituencies in which no candidate received a clear majority on last Sunday's first ballot.

A committee of bondholders reported to Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad officers yesterday that they had offered to sell one-third of the common stock of the line to the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad. The results were negative, it was reported.

Artificial barriers to commerce, still existing between American republics, must be removed to assure peaceful relations between the nations of the Western Hemisphere, Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, declared last night in an address at the Case de las Espanas of Columbia University, 435 West 117th Street.

A consolidated net income of $5,856,265 was reported yesterday for 1935 by the Cities Service Company and subsidiaries, after all taxes, charges for depletion and depreciation, underlying preferred dividends accrued and paid or undeclared, and minority interests.

The police here were endeavoring yesterday to clear up the disappearance of Mrs. Hazel Margery Archibald Draper, 42 years old, wife of Eben S. Draper, son of the late Governor of Massachusetts, who left the Four Winds Sanitarium at Katonah, N.Y., on April 19, and was traced to this city.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 27. -Mr. and Mrs. Everett Colby of West Orange, N.J., entertained at luncheon in the Colonial loom of the Homestead today for Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Philip McKim GarFison and Archibald G. Thacher,

Two men in a small coupe plunged over a ten-foot embankment at West End Avenue and Sixty-third Street at 2:30 P.M. yesterday and landed in the freight yard of the New York Central Railroad, ten or twelve feet below, barely scratched.

A general strike of barbers which would tie up barber shops throughout the city employing approximately 25,000 men was threatened yesterday by officials of the Journeymen Barbers International Union. The strike called in Brooklyn for yesterday morning went into effect but without any marked success.

Net profits of McKesson Robbins, Inc., for the quarter ended on March 31 amounted to $551,006 after Federal taxes, minority interest and other deductions. After allowing for dividend requirements on 533,000 shares of new $3 preferred stock, the profit was equal to 12 cents each on 1,282,983 shares of common stock.

In a few editorial paragraphs you have condensed the real problem of Puerto Rico to its economic aspect, and besides you have shown to us the real spirit of the United States, friendly and with a real understanding of our situation.

Any one who puts forward the idea that unless private enterprise toes the mark and relieves unemployment distress, the government can take over the job and do it well, must be suspected of trying to sell our people a nice pot of gold bricks at the end of a lovely Spring rainbow.

WARSAW, April 27. -- Foreign exchange control and an embargo on gold exports were decreed this morning by President Ignacy Moscicki. The zloty is still technically on the gold standard, and the government strongly denies all rumors of devaluation, but in fact Polish currency has joined the group of controlled currencies, like the mark and lira.

City College seniors in the distribution of annual class honors omitted to vote for a best-dressed man. Most of the boys thought such a distinction was "too bourgeois," and said so on their ballots. This was an error. It indicates that the City College class of 1936 does not keep up with the foreign news.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., April 27. -- President Roosevelt tonight concluded at 10:20 o'clock a two-day holiday at Hyde Park House, his mother's home overlooking the Hudson River. He boarded a special train that was to carry him to Washington overnight and retired immediately.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

HAVANA, April 27. -- Dr. Carlos Marquez Sterling, 39-year-old son of the late Ambassador to Washington and a member of the Liberal party, tonight was proclaimed President of the House of Representatives, ending a three-week deadlock that had held up all legislative matters in the new Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP). -- The Supreme Court indicated today that it would rule against the government in its efforts to bar Arthur W. Cutten, Chicago trader, from the nation's grain markets for two years.

Awaiting a clearer interpretation of the French elections before making commitments, traders in foreign exchange here eschewed operations yesterday and trading was virtually at a standstill. Although the franc closed at the gold-transfer point, a rally at mid-day prevented engagement of any of the metal for shipment to this country.

The Federal art project of the WPA in the New York area had in its employ at the close of business last Friday 2,139 persons, well over a third of the total engaged on the Federal art project throughout the country, according to figures disclosed yesterday by Mrs. Audrey McMahon, who administers the local area and is assistant to the national director of the project.
BALTIMORE, April 27 (AP). -- Baltimore made nine runs in the first inning of its game with Rochester today and its resulting victory moved the Orioles into second place. The score was 14 to 6.

STOCKHOLM, April 27. -- An issue of 1,100,000 Class B shares, representing $26,000,000, was unanimously voted today by the shareholders of the Svenska Taendstickbolaget (Swedish Match Company) at their extraordinary general at Joenkoeping.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 27 (AP). -- Holding the Bisons scoreless until the ninth, the Syracuse Chiefs recorded a 7-to-4 victory over Buffalo today.
ADDIS ABABA, April 27. -- A warning that the Italians would bomb and "destroy" Addis Ababa if their advance on the capital should be resisted was made today in leaflets dropped from an airplane.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 27. -- King Fuad is sinking rapidly and all hope has been given up.

TRENTON, April 27. -- With the galleries and the floors crowded to capacity and a thousand more in the street outside the State House, the New Jersey Legislature met tonight to take care of the relief problem.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- An appeal for cooperation by government and industry, capital and labor toward a rebuilding of the economic structure of the country was sounded tonight by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Company, at a dinner given by the American section of the International Chamber of Commerce, of which he is chairman.

PARIS, April 27. -- Less than 30 per cent of the total membership of the new Chamber of Deputies was elected yesterday, and although there is much speculation as to what next Sunday's ballot will produce, it is as yet impossible to say on which side the majority will finally lie.

The firm of Hugh W. Long Co., with offices at 44 Wall Street, has been formed. Associated with Mr. Long, who has withdrawn as a general partner in Fenner Beane, are Ernest J. Lewis of Los Angeles, Calif., and Thomas E. Chalker of this city.

The election of thirty-nine New York University students to the Caducean Society, honor organization for pre-medical men students at Washington Square College, was announced yesterday by Professor William C. MacTavish, faculty adviser and head of the Department of Chemistry.

RICHMOND, Va., April 27. -- Stockholders of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation met here today to act on a proposal to retire some 90,000 shares of 7 per cent preference stock held in the treasury as an investment but adjourned until May 18 without taking action.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 27. -- The holders of the outdoor and indoor world's records for the high jump are included among the six entrants for that event at the third annual Princeton invitation track meet to be held in Palmer Stadium on June 13, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics at Princeton.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday a net profit for the quarter ended March 31, 1936, of $52,464,174, equal to $1.17 a share on the average common shares outstanding during the period. This is the largest earnings for any first quarter since 1929 and the third best March quarter in the history of the corporation.
LONDON, April 27. -- Prices were firm today, but business was small on the Stock Exchange here. British Government issues moved upward on a moderate amount of buying.
CHICAGO, April 27 (AP). -- The prohibition of major league game broadcasts into minor league territory will be demanded tomorrow of Kenesaw Mountain Landis, Commissioner of Baseball.

Prices of cotton on the Cotton Exchange fell 6 to 11 points yesterday as a result of selling induced by additional moisture in the Southwest and weakness in outside markets and of completion of operations preliminary to first May notices this morning.

With a decline of $17,800,242 for March, due mainly to the continued reduction in the volume of acceptances representing goods stored in domestic warehouses, the volume of bankers' acceptances on March 31 stood at $359,004,507, against $376,804,749 a month before and $465,860,016 on March 31, 1935, according to the survey of the American Acceptance Council.

Some 5,000 persons crowded outside yesterday afternoon when services were held for Charles Hemendinger, acting detective sergeant, at the Kirschenbaum Funeral Home, 345 Kosciusko Street, Brooklyn. Hemendinger shot himself at his Edgemere (Queens) bungalow last Friday.

ADDIS ABABA, April 27. -- It seems probable that the Italian advance from Dessye will in fact be resisted, as the Ethiopian Government has asserted for the past week. There are now said to be 10,000 troops between the Italians and Addis Ababa.

Funeral services for Dr. James M. Kieran, president emeritus of Hunter College, who died on Saturday at his home, 575 Park Avenue, at the age of 72, will be held with a solemn requiem mass this morning at 10 o'clock at the Church of St. Vincent Ferret, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

The "advisability of considering the promising character of the coat and suit outlook in granting credit for the Fall season" was cited yesterday by representatives of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., at a conference with executives of banks active in the garment area, held at the Garment Centre Capitol Club.

Advertising agencies here were encouraged yesterday by reports from Toronto that they would be put on an equal basis with Canadian agencies when the new contract with publishers goes into effect. Definite news regarding developments will come out at the meeting of Canadian newspaper publishers here next week.

LONDON, April 27. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced in the House of Commons today that he had requested Charles N.D. Dixey, chairman of Lloyd's, the underwriters, to "sift to the bottom" allegations that there had been a leaking in budget secrets.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard refused yesterday to reduce the $100,000 bail under which John Torrio, gang leader, is being held for trial on a charge of defrauding the government of $250,000 in revenues through a liquor company he controlled.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP). -- A declaration by President Roosevelt that flood control and water conservation must be "dealt with on a national basis" today was delivered before the National Rivers and Harbors Congress, along with contrasting suggestions for flood control by two Federal agencies.

The Federal housing experiment has demonstrated that housing remains essentially a local problem, requiring local initiative and responsibility, according to the annual report of the State Board of Housing, presented last night to the Legislature at Albany.

Although the number of buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was slightly under the figures for the preceding week, the total continued above the thousand mark. This high registration was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Additional applications for permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of securities of foreign issuers or American shares representing foreign shares were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A "merchandising" of railway passenger service which resulted in an increase of about 21 per cent in passenger revenues in 1935 is described by W.A. Harriman, chairman of the board of the Union Pacific Railroad, in the report for last year, issued yesterday.

General rains over Texas, reported by fifty-five stations, caused a further loss in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Pressure was heaviest on new-crop deliveries, which ended with a decline of 6 points, compared with a 3-point loss on the May position.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 28. -- The "little phantom" burglar of Nassau County has opened his 1936 season. Within the last twenty-four hours, the police said today, he had robbed ten homes in Mineola and Williston Park.
I noted in THE NEW YORK TIMES some remarks by Lord Horder of a complimentary nature about the noise in New York.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 (AP). -- O. Otto Moore, Denver lawyer, told a Congressional subcommittee here today that Robert E. Clements when secretary-treasurer of the Townsend Old Age Pension movement once said:

The amounts allocated to educational purposes in the budgets of New York City and other governmental units should increase every year, Mayor La Guardia declared last night in welcoming to the city the delegates to the Association for Childhood Education, which opened its forty-third annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Sherwin Williams Company has declared a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock and an initial quarterly dividend of $1.25 on the new preferred. Holders of deposit receipts for the new preferred stock as of record May 15 will also receive the dividend, the company announced. Similar dividends were paid on the common stock in the three previous quarters.
CINCINNATI, April 28 (AP). -- Ray Benge held the Reds hitless for five innings today and pitched the Bees to a 5-to-2 victory.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard was asked yesterday to urge the opposing preferred stockholders to carry their appeal against the reorganization plan of the New York Railways Corporation to the United States Supreme Court as soon as possible.

Cardinal Hayes yesterday endorsed the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is seeking to raise a fund of $1,500,000 to meet the extraordinary budgets of recognized private family welfare agencies in this city. He sent a message to the committee appealing to the people of New York to give their moral and financial support to the campaign.

Approximately eighty-five races will be sailed on Long Island Sound the coming Summer by the Interclub sloops. The schedule was partly announced last night at the Spring dinner of the class in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, and another active year of racing was assured.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

Earnings of the International Business Machines Corporation, including foreign subsidiaries, for the first three months of this year amounted to $1,889,921 after all charges, including estimated Federal taxes. This is equivalent to $2.56 a share on 738,934 no-par capital shares outstanding.

LOUISVILLE, April 28. -- Pre-Kentucky Derby predictions were pretty thoroughly knocked about, if not fully shattered, at Churchill Downs today when the favored Brevity turned in an indifferent work, Ned Reigh was withdrawn from the race because of fever and Grand Slam capped the climax by suffering defeat in the Derby Trial run as the feature today.

WOODMERE, L.I., April 28. -- Detectives of the Woodmere Precinct of the Nassau County Police arrested five boys, all but one under 16 years old, and charged them with thirty burglaries in the Rockaway Branch villages since last October.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 28 (AP). -- While asserting there did not seem to be any immediate prospect of severe inflation in this country, Leonard P. Ayres, outlined tonight what he called "three important guiding rules" for bank management during a period of inflation.

While industry is confronted with many problems, the most serious of which is heavy taxation, Grant R. Lohnes, president of the National Association of Cost Accountants, declared here last night that he was optimistic about the future "because we all know that business is showing improvement."

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- A pledge has been given industrial leaders that no revival of NRA is planned as a result of a WPA investigation into the technological causes of unemployment, and as a result of this promise business is giving whole-hearted support to the study, a confidential report to Harry L. Hopkins revealed today.

A report advocating the use of public funds to provide adequate housing for families of low income, but criticizing the housing program as suggested in the Wagner-Ellenbogen bills now before Congress, was submitted yesterday to President Roosevelt by the Committee for Economic Recovery.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 28. -- Playing errorless ball, Princeton's varsity baseball team downed an alumni nine, 4 -- 2, on University Field today.

The number of cases of measles reported last week was the highest since the start of the current epidemic, according to the Department of Health's weekly summary of vital statistics. Cases totaled 2,284, compared with 1,857 the week before and 1,585 for the same week last year.
Seemingly indifferent to the seriousness of the proceeding, John Fiorenza, 24 years old, was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions yesterday for the murder of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton.

BOSTON, Wednesday, April 29. -- Governor Landon of Kansas piled up a large majority early today with tabulation of the Republican Presidential preference vote in the Massachusetts primary about two-thirds complete.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Following is the text of the address made by Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, at the general session of the National Chamber of Commerce today:

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Farley today expressed belief that the rule by which a two-thirds vote is required for nomination will be abrogated at the coming Democratic convention.

Erection of a new building for St. Luke's Home for Aged Women in Amsterdam Avenue, opposite the entrance to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, is planned for an indefinite future date. The home's purchase of the site, comprising the block front between 111th and ll2th Streets, was announced yesterday.
LONDON, April 28. -- The House of Commons will grant King Edward's request for 40,000 yearly for a possible future Queen, but it will not begin to pay the money until he marries.

The body of Jacob Horowitz, 10- month-old baby believed to have been kidnapped and drowned by a demented woman last January, was found in the East River at about 5 P.M. yesterday, near the foot of Market Street.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP). -- A $1,000,000,000 navigation and flood control program, embracing the Congressionally abandoned Florida ship canal, was asked of the Federal Government today by the National Rivers and Harbors Congress.

Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black agreed yesterday to serve as mediator in an attempt to end the strike of Atlantic Coast seamen which has been in effect the last six weeks in protest against the wage contract signed by the International Seamen's Union with their employer lines.

Miss Mary Hirsch, daughter of Max Hirsch and the first woman to be granted a trainer's license by the Jockey Club, scored, an impressive double at Jamaica yesterday when she saddled the winners of both divisions of the Tester Purse, six-furlong dashes run as the first and third races on the card.

The courage shown by the physically handicapped who have been receiving training in the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled should put to shame young men and women who in possession of sound bodies and good minds yield to difficulties that might with half the effort be overcome.

Harry J. Anslinger, chief of the United States Bureau of Narcotics, and Mrs. Anslinger are among the passengers sailing today for the Channel ports on the President Harding of the United States Lines. Others sailing are Dr. James A. Brussel, Percy G. Kemp, Captain Arthur Lee, Mrs. Hugh Millard, Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Bint, Mr. and Mrs. R.B. Fahnestock, T.R. Charlesworth and Charles M. Ward.

ALBANY, April 28. -- Three bills providing optional forms for modernizing county governments in line with the Fearon constitutional amendment approved last Fall were passed today by the Senate without a dissenting vote.

Vincent Astor's yacht Nourmahal returned to New York yesterday from a cruise in the Pacific, bringing eight birds and two animals for the Staten Island Zoological Society. The bulk of specimens taken in the Galapagos Islands, including some fish, was left in Bermuda on the way north, as a gift to the government aquarium there.

Up to lunch time yesterday Abraham Gordon, who drives a wagon for the Snow White Laundry, would have said there wasn't a milder mannered horse than old Pete. It was not until after his midday meal that Pete reared up and tried to climb into a taxicab by way of the roof.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The Supreme Court began hearing arguments today in the test case involving the New York Minimum Wage Law, affecting 1,500,000 women workers in that State and thousands more in at least seven other States.

Charging that the steamship Morro Castle, which was destroyed by fire off the New Jersey coast on Sept. 8, 1934, with the loss of many lives, was insufficiently manned, with incompetent mates and crew, Mrs. Mathilda H. Willmott, widow of Robert R. Willmott, captain of the vessel who died on board a day prior to the fire, filed suit yesterday in the United States District Court, in Brooklyn, for $200,000 damages.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a net profit of $3,376,304 for the first quarter of this year, equal to 94 cents a share on the 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, on which there is an accumulation of unpaid dividends. This is the best report made by the company for this period since the first quarter of 1931.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 28. -- The Nassau County April grand jury handed up a presentment this afternoon declaring accidental the shooting of Mrs. Marguerite Weggin, 32 years old, of 1 St. Paul's Court, Brooklyn, by two Nassau County detectives early last Saturday morning at Little Neck, L.I.

ALBANY, April 28. -- At the request of Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd, Assemblyman Brownell, New York Republican, today introduced a bill to aid the prosecutor in obtaining the testimony of missing witnesses in connection with alleged bribery growing out of the Drukman murder case.

The concert of the Dessoff Choirs at the Town Hall last night was scheduled as a farewell to Margarete Dessoff, their conductor. But Miss Dessoff, owing to injuries she received in an automobile accident, was unable to appear on the podium in her formal departure, and Paul Boepple, who is to direct the choirs next season, was the guest conductor.

Senator VANDENBERG'S resolution demanding publication of the names of all farmers who, for not farming, received $10,000 or more from the Government, finally passed the Senate. It was hard for the Democrats to agree to it, but harder still for them to vote it down as Senators willing to suppress information which the public is entitled to have.

O. Davis Keep, manager of Franklin W. Fort's campaign for delegate at large to the Republican National Convention, challenged Governor Harold G. Hoffman to reveal publicly whether Ellis Parker Jr. had been removed from the State payroll.

LIFE, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" -- the Declaration of Independence reads. The common earlier phrase, it has been pointed out, had been that men had rights to life, liberty and property. The change slipped into the Declaration was made in a spirit of liberalism, and let pass as a measure of political expediency. Now the word "property," some voices rise to warn, should again be included in the phrase.

CINCINNATI, April 28. -- New and repeal legislation for the elimination of the spoils system and the substitution for patronage appointments of a trained and qualified personnel in the government service will be demanded of Congress under a "reform program" adopted today by the National League of Women Voters.

It is always pleasant to see old friends turning up, playing their old parts and unchanged by time and fate. Every two years of the Thirties Senator GEORGE FEARON and Mayor ROLAND MARVIN of Syracuse are mentioned as likely candidates-for the Republican nomination for Governor.

GENEVA, April 28. -- China advanced today in her long struggle to get back on the Council of the League of Nations and obtain permanent status there. The committee on the Council's composition agreed to recommend adding, provisionally for three years, a fifteenth seat, with the understanding that it would go to China and that she would thereafter have a semi- permanent position in the Council.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 28. -- King Fuad of Egypt died this afternoon of a heart attack that followed a tenacious four-day fight against a gangrenous infection in the throat. He was 68 years old.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 28. -- Traditional interests of women were the pivot from which the program of the General Federation of Women's Clubs swung widely today, encompassing foreign hostilities and domestic complexities alike.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Trading in wheat slowed down materially today, with operators disposed to do little on either side of the market pending further developments in the crop situation in the Southwest. No additional rains of consequence were reported overnight, and in some quarters there was a belief the enthusiastic selling of yesterday, coupled with the general liquidation by longs, had materially strengthened the technical situation.

As a guest of the Brooklyn Kiwanis Club yesterday at the Towers Hotel, the newly elected boy Borough President of Brooklyn, who will assume the duties of that office for a whole day tomorrow, arose from his seat at the speaker's table and flushed with all the modesty of his 15 years.

A warning against what it called a new attempt on the part of a Niagara-Hudson subsidiary to encroach upon the State's rights to water power at Niagara Falls was sounded yesterday by the Power Authority in its annual report to the Legislature.

Inquiries to sixteen universities reported from Germany as having accepted invitations to attend the 550th anniversary of Heidelberg University in June revealed yesterday that at least five of the universities listed had not officially accepted the invitations.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The Chicago Illinois Midland Railway made application today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $5,500,000 of 20-year 4 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds, Series A; $1,500,000 of 6 per cent income non-cumulative debentures and $2,400,000 par of additional capital stock.

ALBANY, April 28. -- An attempt by Senator Dunnigan, Democratic leader, to secure immediate adoption of his concurrent resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution to prepare the way for pari-mutuel betting at racetracks was blocked in the Senate today by Senator Twomey, Brooklyn Democrat.

BARTOW, Fla., April 28. -- How the Tampa police were dominated by R.G. Tittsworth as their chief and how investigations of previous floggings in that city always were "met by a wall" of police silence were dramatically blurted out today by Lieutenant J.L. Eddings at the trial of the seven former policemen, including the former chief as an accessory.
BUENOS AIRES, April 28. -- President Agustin P. Justo this afternoon accepted the resignation of Leopoldo Melo as Minister of the Interior.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 29. -- President Roosevelt, facing only the nominal opposition of Continue,{ on Page 'Two I Continued ]From Page One i Colonel Henry Breckin'ridge of New .York, ran away with the Demo[cratie Presidential preference balloting in yesterday's Pennsylvania primary election.

At the Essex Troop Armory in Newark tonight, the Spring circuit will be inaugurated by the opening session of the sixteenth annual Newark Horse Show, which will continue through Saturday night and will include a matinee on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- A memorandum submitted to Secretary Roper today charged to ship owners disregard of the shipping laws to the peril of passengers and crew, inadequate lifeboat and other safety equipment, dangerous engine-room conditions and inhuman treatment of crews both in hours and living conditions.

The New York State Sportsman, official organ of the State Conservation Council, discusses in its current issue a plan for the establishment of special trout streams to be set aside for the use of anglers willing to pay an extra seasonal fee.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Prices of hogs declined 25 to 35 cents a hundredweight here today with the lowest level reached near the close when the top price was $10.45 compared with early sales at $10.60. Receipts of 16,000 head were the largest for a Tuesday since Jan. 28 and much in excess of trade requirements.

Although the ruling on last Friday by governors of the Stock Exchange that member firms might use their own capital to carry customers' accounts was credited with obviating the issuance of a few margin calls this week, many conservative brokers regret that the Exchange was forced by the Federal Reserve Board to abandon its long-standing custom that accounts must be "self-financing."

Characterizing as "inaccuracies and misstatements" certain assertions contained in the annual report of the State Tax Commission relating to the proposed tax limitation amendment to the State Constitution, William J. Demorest, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, has written to State Tax Commissioner Mark Graves asking that the disputed assertions receive "public correction."

ALBANY, April 28. -- Because of employers' unfamiliarity with the requirements of the new State Unemployment Insurance Law and a temporary shortage of informed personnel to answer questions regarding it. Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews today announced that fifteen days' extension of time would be given to employers in which to pay contributions for the first quarter of 1936.

VIENNA, April 28. -- After a long delay during which the whole underground press of Austria, both Socialist and Nazi, unremittingly attacked the government and demanded revelation of the truth about the scandal attaching to the collapse of the Austrian Phoenix Life Insurance Company because of the misuse of policy holders' funds the government lifted the curtain tonight in a communique.

ALRANY, April 28. -- New complications arose today over Governor Lehman's proposal for a new bond issue of $30,000,000 and an additional appropriation of $10,000,000 out of the general fund to finance unemployment relief until Feb. 1.

The Board of Aldermen voted yesterday to authorize the issuance of $203,000 in special revenue bonds to pay salaries and expenses of experts working on the revaluation of utility properties in the city.

Building plans filed yesterday included a $135,000 apartment house for a Bronx site and a $100,000 church for a Brooklyn corner. Four apartments are planned for a four- story dwelling at 36 East Sixty-fifth Street recently bought by Dorimar, Inc.; Doris R. Marks, president. Numerous dwelling projects were submitted in Queens.

Manhattan College's undefeated diamond forces rode roughshod over the St. John's University nine yesterday to register their seventh straight triumph of the season, 22 to 9, before a crowd of 1,000 at Manhattan Field.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 28 (AP). -- Toronto overcame Albany's early lead today and made a clean sweep of the three-game series by scoring a 10 to 4 victory.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Before an audience of more than 2,000 business men, Lewis H. Brown, president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, today accepted in the name of organized business President Roosevelt's challenge that it take up the slack of unemployment and put men back to work.

JERUSALEM, April 28. -- Arab demonstrators in Nazareth today stoned the police, who were forced to fire, wounding one demonstrator. Four British constables were injured by stones. Several persons were arrested.
A recent dispatch from your correspondent Frederick T. Birchall headed "Hitler Made Supreme War Lord" re-. quires some linguistic explanation.

The entire music collection of the late Sophie Breslau, Metropolitan Opera contralto and concert artist, including more than a score of manuscripts from the pens of such composers as Rachmaninoff, Tchaikovsky, Sibelius and MacDowell, has been acquired by the Brooklyn Public Library.
LONDON, April 28. -- Viscount Allenby, the conqueror of Jerusalem, today aligned himself with pacifists such as H.G. Wells in advocating a world State and a world police force to keep peace.

BERLIN, April 28. -- Following the appointment of Colonel-General Hermann Goering to supersede him as the dictator of German financial and economic policies, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht ended his vacation at Badenweiler, near the Swiss frontier, today and is hurrying back so Berlin to confer with "his new boss," as General Goering is called in international financial circles.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- With the immediate aim of speeding consideration of his Anti-Chain Store Bill, Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, called upon the Senate today to hasten its labors so that Congress might adjourn before the national political conventions in June.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct his farewell concert with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall tonight. A post-season concert was arranged at Mr. Toscanini's request and the proceeds of tonight's performance will go to the orchestra's pension fund, the personnel of Carnegie Hall and unemployed musicians.

William A. Brady and the Grace George who is Mrs. Brady are starting back to New York tomorrow, arriving Monday. They have been in Hollywood, Mr. Brady disposing of plays to the movies and picking up others to offer New York and Miss George trying to find something for next season.

BERLIN, April 28. -- Direct, uncamouflaged State control of all German sport was established today by a decree whereby the sport dictator, Hans von Tschammer und Osten, becomes a civil servant in the Reich Ministry of the Interior, under the orders of Dr. Wilhelm Frick.

All Winter long the city and the State have been bickering over appropriations for the New York World's Fair. It has been largely a case of "After you, Alphonse." At last they seem to have patched up their differences. The city is ready to spend $7,000,000 on land, fill, sewers and exhibits, with the understanding that the State will spend $4,125,000 on roads and other facilities.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP). -- Paced by homers by Goslin and Greenberg, the champion Detroit Tigers jumped on three Washington pitchers today and ran away with an 8-to-1 triumph over the Senators.

With the Baltimore Ohio and lines under its control dissenting, the heads of other Eastern railroads announced yesterday that they would make a court fight on the Interstate Commerce Commission's recent order for a passenger fare reduction, and simultaneously disclosed that they would put these reductions into effect under protest.

The pamphlet report of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., for 1935, issued yesterday, showed that current assets on Dec. 31 were $245,792,616 and current liabilities, $58,933,784, compared with $238,236,596 and $54,088,125, respectively, at the close of 1934.

PITTSBURGH, April 28 (AP) -- The Phillies knocked Cy Blanton, Pirate hurler, from the mound and continued a seventeen-hit assault on two other pitchers to win, 9 to 7, today. It was the fourth time Blanton had been forced from the game this season.

LONDON, April 28. -- The handsome young new King of Egypt, who as Prince Faruk has been attending the Royal Military Academy at Woolwich since last Autumn, will leave London for Cairo on Thursday. He will travel to Marseilles, where he will board a steamer for Alexandria.

If Federal finances are not adjusted, either by reducing expenditures or imposing additional taxation, national bankruptcy threatens, Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, warned the Insurance Brokers Association of New York, Inc., at a luncheon following their annual meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

Parents should blame themselves rather than their children for the youngsters' misbehavior and thus find a more effective method of correcting misconduct, in the opinion of Mrs. Paul B. Welles, president of the National Federation of Day Nurseries.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 28. -- Robert V. Fleming, president of the American Bankers Association, at the opening session of its executive council here today, said it was the council's largest meeting, with 421 members and others registered.

Arguments began yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack on a petition by the $700,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company system to dismiss proceedings seeking its reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

An injunction prohibiting the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel and the Wivel Restaurant in West Fifty-fourth Street, from serving Bacardi coctails containing other than the rum manufactured by the Compania Ron Bacardi was issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John L. Walsh.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,932,700 barrels, compared to 2,935,200 in the previous week, a decrease of 2,500, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A gain of 11,350 barrels in Kansas and a decline of 12,600 in Oklahoma were the important changes.

The quarterly meeting of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church got under way yesterday at the Church Mission House, 281 Fourth Avenue. The twenty-seven Bishops, ministers and laymen attending will continue in session today and tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP). -- Asserting that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had received $180,000,000 in excess profits from long-distance business, an investigator for the Federal Communications Commission said today that this phase of operation had "been relatively free from regulation."

ALBANY, April 28. -- The City Council of Long Beach had no authority to contract with John V. Schaefer to serve as City Engineer and to vote him compensation other than that attached to his office, the Court of Appeals held today in dismissing the complaint in his action for $50,577.46 salary. The court also reversed the Appellate Division's confirmation of a referee's report in favor of Mr. Schaefer.
Charley Ruffing arrived with a bang yesterday at the Stadium and took a fall out of the league-leading Indians.

Miss Anna Glenn Butler heads a group of debutantes who are aiding in the plans for the gala children's party and fashion revue of the latest costumes for juveniles to be held tomorrow afternoon in the Park Lane Gardens in behalf of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- World economic recovery cannot be attained without an international agreement stabilizing currencies on a gold basis and adoption of the most-favored-nation principle by leading commercial countries, James A. Farrell of New York declared today at a round-table discussion of foreign trade problems at the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Speeded unscathed through the amending stages by the available but unused force of the great Democratic majority, the new Tax Bill stood tonight on the brink of apparently certain passage in the House, with the final vote set as the first order of business tomorrow.

Senator DICKINSON thinks that Americans have been consuming large quantities of dog food because the AAA scarcity program has pushed the price of human food beyond the reach of many people. But if this explains the large sales in animal food it is odd that the American people was not reduced to similar straits on earlier occasions.
BOSTON, April 28 (AP). -- The Red Sex wrecking crew went to work on four White Sox pitchers today and blasted out an 11-8 victory in the first game against a Western team this season.

Bob Zimmerman twirled a no-hit contest as the Bryant High School baseball team took second place in the Queens P.S.A.L. championship by conquering Far Rockaway High, 3 -- 1, at Electrics Oval yesterday.

Little resiliency was displayed by stocks yesterday following the sharp decline on the day before. The trading pace continued active, transactions on the Stock Exchange amounting to 2,231,000 shares, against 2,303,000 on Monday. The market opened irregular, declined throughout the forenoon except for a feeble rally in the late morning, steadied somewhat in the afternoon, and closed irregular.

PARIS, April 28. -- The Normandie will not surrender the blue ribbon of the Atlantic to the Queen Mary without a struggle. If the French liner loses the title this season, her power will be increased and she will make an effort to regain the honors, it is declared.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Within the space of five hours, Representative Zioncheek got married today, cooked Irish stew for newspaper men and offered to meet the table-tennis champion of America.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Use of the mails was denied the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., and the Golden Stakes Contest and subsidiaries in orders signed tonight by Postmaster General Farley following hearings before the Postoffice Department some weeks ago on charges of violating the postal fraud and lottery statutes.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The price on the head of Alvin Karpis went up to $7,000 today as the postoffice inspection service disclosed an undercover search for the man now rated as "Public Enemy No. 1."

The foreign exchange market continued dull yesterday. The French franc was steady within a narrow range and closed unchanged from the previous day at 6.58 1/2 cents. No further engagements of gold in France for shipment here were reported, and there was, it appeared to bankers, little need for the British Exchange Equalization Fund to support the French currency.

WASHINGTON, April 28, -- Plans for prompt handling of the cashing of the soldiers' bonus were completed today by Postmaster General Farley and Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans' Affairs, national leaders of the veterans' organizations, and officials of the Treasury Department.

ROME, April 28. -- The proclamation of Victor Emmanuel III as Emperor of Ethiopia, which is expected to follow soon after the entry of Italian troops into Addis Ababa, has been brought within a measurable distance by the extraordinarily rapid advance of two Italian columns from Dessye and Warra Hailu.

Bruno Richard Hauptmann, who was executed for the murder of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr., had no partner in the kidnapping, it was indicated in a report on Hauptmann's finances forwarded yesterday by Hugh McQuillan, New York agent, to Elmer Irey, head of the intelligence unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue in Washington.

TRENTON, April 28. -- A plan that would put Governor Harold G. Hoffman and a Republican board of four in control of New Jersey's relief administration will be placed before the State Legislature for action tomorrow.

Plainclothes patrolmen of Commissioner Valentine's confidential staff raided yesterday the Lovejoy Bridge Studio, a well-known contract-bridge club, at 853 Seventh Avenue, near Fifty-fifth Street, in their first interference in the operation of such an establishment since contract bridge became the vogue, almost ten years ago.

The five-story brick office building at 169 Main Street, White Plains, has been sold to the Elmcroft Corporation of 2,804 Third Avenue by the Title and mortgage Rehabilitation and Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department. The building is the former home office of the Westchester Title and Trust Company, in liquidation.
It has remained for Mr. Roosevelt to translate into actuality a truly prophetic vision of the future foreseen by Thomas Jefferson.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- A vista of virtually unlimited possibilities for productive expansion of industry with re-employment of millions now idle was opened up to the members of a round-table session of business men here today by Dr. F.R. Weidlein, director of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research of Pittsburgh, who described the success of applied science in discovering new commercial products and wider uses for old ones.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- WPA is so costly and so wasteful, PWA is so slow and the administration is so definitely opposed to a reversion to the direct dole in advance of an election that persons honestly seeking a solution of the problem of relief are calling more insistently for an efficient reexamination of the whole subject.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Congress will be asked by the administration for legislation authorizing the Navy Department to lay down two battleships next year, if any other powers begin such construction. The bill is being drafted in the House Naval Committee, in consultation with President Roosevelt.

A syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,500,000 of State of Louisiana 4 1/4 per cent highway, Series P. bonds on a bid of 107.819. They will be dated April 15, 1936, and will mature on April 15, 1940 to 1961.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- President Roosevelt returned from Hyde Park, signed entrance papers for the Georgia primaries and expressed a belief that the two-thirds rule would be abrogated at the Democratic National Convention.

Business failures in the retail division throughout the country in the week ended April 23 dropped below the average registered so far this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. However, they totaled 124, as compared with 101 in the previous week.

DENVER, April 28. -- Preparatory to the fourteenth biennial convention of the Young Women's Christian Association, which opens tomorrow in Colorado Springs, Mrs. James Rae Arneill of Denver arranged today a luncheon honoring Mrs. John H. Finley of New York. Other leaders prominent in the association's work were present.
At the Spring meeting of the New York Conference of the United Lutheran Synod of New York last night steps were taken to organize Lutheran laymen into a New York Conference Brotherhood.

In his first speech as a candidate for election as a delegate at large to the Republican National Convention, Governor Harold G. Hoffman last night charged Franklin W.
