Fort, his opponent, with attempting to make a political issue of the Lindbergh case and defended his course in granting a reprieve to Bruno Richard Hauptmann, executed for the murder of the Lindbergh child.

A Summer drive for $10,000 to aid destitute musicians was announced yesterday by Mrs. Vincent Astor, acting president of the Musicians Emergency Fund, at the Spring luncheon meeting of the Women's Auxiliary Board of the fund at the Hotel St. Regis.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The first report of a monthly study of manufacturers' and wholesalers' sales and collections on accounts receivable, undertaken jointly by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce and the National Association of Credit Men, and made public today, disclosed that total sales of 582 reporting manufacturers in the principal industries increased 13 per cent in dollar volume for March, this year, compared with March, 1935.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP). -- In a twenty-six-word statement Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, today warned all major and minor league baseball clubs not to make any additional commitments for radio broadcasts of games.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The Roosevelt administration, through Secretary Roper, offering the support and cooperation of the government, called on leaders in industry and trade today to carry out a ten-point re-employment program presented before the formal opening session of the annual convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States this morning.
PERHAPS the gentleman had a just complaint. In any event, his monologue was enlightening and ran as follows, to wit and viz.:

The Texas Corporation intends to call by Oct. 1 the remaining $60,000,000 of its 5 per cent debentures due on Oct. 1, 1944, in order to get a lower rate of interest on its money, T. Rieber, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
The Kansans' New York committee for Landon, of which Brock Pemberton is chairman, will open headquarters today at the Murray Hill Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28. -- President Roosevelt was endorsed for re-election today by the annual convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers, which has more than 60,000 members in eighteen States.

Quite as perfunctorily as though paying the butcher, a woman opened an ordinary black purse yesterday morning and before the astounded eyes of two clerks in the Federal Building counted out $100,000 cash as bail for her notorious husband, Johnny Torrio.

PARIS, April 28. -- After some hesitancy Edouard Herriot, who for the first time in his Parliamentary history failed to obtain a majority on the first ballot from his Lyon constituency last Sunday, decided tonight to maintain his candidacy in the second voting next Sunday.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 28. -- A general shake-up of the Princeton varsity crew, which brought Larry Fenninger from the jayvees to stroke the first eight, was made by Gordon Sikes before today's practice, the first formal workout for the oarsmen since their defeat by Pennsylvania on %he Harlem Saturday.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., purchased yesterday $17,366,087 of 3 1/2 per cent bonds of Chicago Park District at par. With the exception of sales in 1935 by the city of Chicago and the Chicago Board of Education, the price obtained by the Park District for its bonds marks the highest figure obtained for many years by any major taxing body in Cook County.

BARCELONA, Spain, April 28. -- Miguel Badia, former chief of the Catalan Generalidad, or regional government, and his brother Jose were shot and killed here this afternoon as they were leaving their home. The police say that the gunmen who shot them down were members of the F.A.I., or Iberian Anarchist Federation.

The seventh exhibition in the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon. The work will be shown to the public, beginning today, until May 17. The hours are 12 o'clock noon to 6 P.M. every day of the week except Monday, when the galleries are closed.

Adolph Austin, part owner of the Pine Tree Restaurant, at 106 West Thirty-eighth Street, appeared before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday on a charge of criminal contempt. He was accused of failing to submit all his books and records to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.
John Wexley, author of the stage successes "The Last Mile" and "They Shall Not Die," has written a novel, as yet untitled. It will be published later in the year by Random House.

Intelligent censorship of advertising is a growing reality, Edward H. Gardner, executive secretary of the advisory committee on advertising of the Proprietary Association, told members of the New York Advertising Women, Inc., at a luncheon at the Hotel Iroquois yesterday.

The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada continued to be the largest holder of American Telephone and Telegraph stock on March 14, 1936, with 124,550 shares, a decrease of 2,000 from Dee. 15, 1934, according to figures filed with the State Department of Public Utilities.

Two men trapped by smoke and flames in a burning building at 306 Fulton Street, near Johnson Street in the downtown section of Brooklyn, escaped by walking along a narrow ledge on the third floor to an adjoining structure while several thousand workers from nearby office buildings paused on their way home at about 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon to watch.

Miss Genie Chester gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 400 East Fifty-seventh Street, for chairmen of committees working for the success of the luncheon, fashion show and card party for the benefit of the New York Diet Kitchen Association to be held Tuesday at the formal opening of the gardens of the Park Lane.

Commodity futures continued depressed yesterday with the exception of coffee and silk, which were strong. Trading was on a moderate scale. On the cash markets wheat and corn advanced, while cotton, lard, rubber and tin declined.

Ali Baba's claim to the heavyweight wrestling championship of the world will not be recognized in this State, the Athletic Commission decided yesterday. The Kurd grappler, who defeated Dick Shikat in Detroit last week, was named No. 1 challenger, however, and he will encounter Shikat in a championship struggle at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday night.

A promise by Ellis Parker Jr. to have him appointed to the New Jersey State police was given by Harry Weiss as his motive for helping to kidnap Paul H. Wendel, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan said last night when the fugitive, arrested in Youngstown, Ohio, returned to Brooklyn.
BERLIN, April 28. -- The Boerse was strong at the opening today, but closed weak without establishing a price tendency. The market was limited and spotty.

TOKYO, April 28. -- Soviet Ambassador Konstantin K. Yureneff, in an interview last evening with Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kensuke Horinouchi, requested that Japan take measures to control the White Russians in Manchukuo, whom he accused of plotting to disturb Russo-Japanese relations.

MAIDSTONE, England, April 28. -- Final informal practice over, the American women Curtis Cup golfers tonight headed for Gleneagles, Scotland, where they will settle down to serious preparations for defense of the trophy there May 6 against a British side.

Inspector George F. Spencer, head of the eastern division of the Pennsylvania Railroad police, who has guarded kings, presidents and merchant princes for more than thirty-two years, will retire from the job on May 9, railroad officials announced yesterday.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The National Industrial Conference Board, in its monthly report made public yesterday, showed that the number of unemployed workers in March, 1936, was 9,649,000, a decrease of 201,000, or 2 per cent, from the preceding month, and a decrease of 390,000, or 3.9 per cent, below March, 1935.

General approval of the proposed new city charter was expressed yesterday by the Citizens Union, while the Citizens Budget Commission amplified its earlier views and recommended two amendments to meet criticism of the new proposals.

Workmen struggled with heavy filing cabinets, desks and chairs yesterday and vans rumbled through the streets continually, transferring office and factory equipment and household goods to new addresses.

While the market for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday did not show any widespread rallying power, the severe pressure which characterized trading on Monday was lifted in most groups and the market generally turned irregular with declines outnumbering gains.

Not all is harmony and cooperation behind the scenes in Nazi Germany. The appointment yesterday of HERMANN GOERING, instead of Dr. HJALMAR SCHACHT, as "economic dictator" is one of those telltale revelations of discord and conflict which not even the severe censorship and the mesmerism of Dr. GOEBBELS'S brilliant showmanship have succeeded in concealing.

Fourth among the great diamond finds of history and until Monday the largest uncut stone in the world, the famous Jonker diamond, said by experts to be unequaled in purity and potential beauty, is now in pieces.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- An important advance in the art of ruling lines for the spectroscope, man's winged Pegasus on which he rides at will among stars and atoms, was reported here today before the National Academy of Sciences by Professor R.W. Wood of Johns Hopkins University.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Adding to the rising tide of Republican criticism of administration policies and activities, Senator Barbour called on the Senate today to undertake an investigation of the Resettlement Administration and announced that he would continue to press for action of that nature.

Samuel Reshevsky, undefeated in the last three international tournaments in which he was the victor -- at Syracuse, Margate and Great Yarmouth -- last night lost his adjourned game from the third round of the United States chess championship at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, April 28. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were generally dull today, largely because of the setback in Wall Street yesterday, although some improvement in prices was shown in the afternoon. British funds were dull, lacking support. Foreign securities were quiet pending a clearer outlook of the French situation.

Sands Gallagher, Inc., won the first corned-beef-and-cabbage contest in the history of the Madison Square Boys Club at 312 East Thirtieth Street yesterday, Two years ago, it was gefuelte fish; last year, spaghetti. Whether the 1937 competition will involve far young dan or fried chicken, Harlem style, has not yet been determined.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- A drop of 18 per cent in motor vehicle fatalities throughout the country during March resulted in a reduction of the mortality rate for the first quarter of 1936 to levels 9 per cent below the same period last year, according to figures made public today by the National Safety Council.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 28. -- Goldey F., chestnut daughter of Tall Timber -- Naharanna, which sold last August at the Saratoga yearling sales for $150, scored today in the twenty-fourth running of the $2,500 added, four-and-one-half-furlong Aberdeen Stakes for 2-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes today endorsed the Tydings bill which would allow the people of Puerto Rico to vote on their own independence. He remarked that if they should decide they did not want complete independence, the question of statehood could be discussed later.

The Medical Society of the State of New York, with a membership of 12,000 physicians, voted through its house of delegates at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday to oppose the further spread of lay influence in the management of the hospitals of the State.

Twenty years ago a boy of 14 and a sprightly miss of 8 paid a visit to the circus at the old Madison Square Garden. They heard the band play and wonderingly ran sensitive fingers over the elephants, horses, camels and giraffes -- but they did not see the multitudinous attractions because they were blind.

Approval given by stockholders of the Swedish Match Company at a special meeting in Joenkoeping, Sweden, on Monday, to the issuance of 1,100,000 Class B shares, means that the final chapter in the inter-company settlements between former Kreuger enterprises will be written in the United States, possibly in the next few weeks.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $9,995,649 for the twelve months ended on March 31, after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 3 cents each on 33,673,325 common shares.

The directors of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad decided yesterday to ask the Federal court in Denver for an extension of ninety days of the time in which the company was ordered to file a plan of reorganization. L.W. Baldwin, president of the Missouri Pacific, joint owner with the Western Pacific of the Rio Grande, made the announcement.

The East repulsed the challenge of Western swordsmen for the second time in three days as six saber wielders entered the final round robin pool in quest of the national crown last night on the strips of the New York Athletic Club.

The New York County grand jury will begin an investigation next week into fraudulent practices by racketeers in using fictitious names and addresses to place misleading classified advertisements in newspapers. The investigation was ordered yesterday by District Attorney William C. Dodge.

Total sales of reporting wholesale firms in this district showed an increase of 10.3 per cent in March, as compared with the same month last year, according to the review issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gain was smaller than in the preceding two months.
In the President's New York speech he solemnly declared: "Reduction of costs of manufacture does not mean more purchasing power and more goods consumed. It means just the opposite."

Public offering will be made today of 111,464 shares of 4 1/2 per cent preferred stock of $100 par value of the Central Illinois Light Company through an underwriting group headed by Bonbright Co., Inc., and including the First Boston Corporation, E.W. Clark Co., Blyth Co., Inc., and the Central Republic Company.

The Prophet Ezekiel, denouncing the land wherein the tribes of Israel were held captive, asserted 570 years before the birth of Christ that there would be "no more a prince of the land of Egypt." That was in the time of Apries, a Pharaoh of one of the final Egyptian dynasties.

An increased volume of orders for Summer apparel and accessories was placed this week, but the activity has yet to reach its peak, manufacturers here said yesterday. The expectation is that buying will increase sharply within the next week or so, inasmuch as many stores will need representative assortments of Summer lines before the middle of next month.

LONDON, April 29. -- While the British Government is watching the Austrian situation anxiously, there was no unusual concern in Whitehall today over sensational reports of troop movements along the Austro-German frontier.

ALBANY, April 29. -- The Assembly passed and sent to the Governor today the Dunnigan bill creating a codification committee for New York City, composed of the Mayor, the Corporation Counsel, the Aldermanic President and the Controller, who would recodify New York City ordinances and departmental regulations.

TRENTON, Thursday, April 30. -- Both houses of the New Jersey Legislature, called together to provide relief for the State's 270,000 unemployed, passed a measure just before last midnight turning over the State Relief Administration machinery to a board of five Republicans, one of whom is Governor Harold G. Hoffman.

MIAMI, Fla., April 29. -- After seventeen years and a series of disheartening experiences, the ardor of the General Federation of Women's Clubs for United States membership in the League of Nations appeared today to have sunk even beyond apathy, into active opposition.
Arturo Toscanini brought to an end last night, amid ovation after ovation, his career at the head of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 29. -- Ninety persons were arrested today in various parts of the country in connection with an alleged plot to march on Budapest on May Day, Friday. The conspirators were members of a group of Hungarian Nazis named from their badge the "Sickle and Cross" organization.

Your correspondent who states the case for youth has acquired a clear style and a knack at exposition. That is a good beginning for any young man. It is creditable to his intelligence that he dislikes war, depressions, unemployment, jingoism, Hearsts, Coughlins, Longs and Townsends.

Sparks flew from hoofs clattering on the sidewalk fronting Carnegie Hall last night as mounted patrolmen strove to restrain ten times as many persons as could be accommodated as standees at Arturo Toscanini's farewell concert.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29. -- The number of probable starters for the sixty-second Kentucky Derby, to be run Saturday, jumped to fifteen today with the E.R. Bradley pair having their final heavy workout in such unexpected fashion that both are to go to the post for fear the wrong one will be left in the barn.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- President Roosevelt called upon Secretary Swanson, who is ill in the Naval Hospital; had luncheon with Under-Secretary of State Phillips and conferred with Postmaster General Farley and Governor Brann of Maine.
QUEBEC, Que., April 29 (Canadian Press). -- An attempt to reorganize Price Brothers Co. failed at a meeting today of shareholders and creditors.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee has raised $347,838 toward its goal of $1,500,000 in its drive for funds for family welfare agencies, it was announced yesterday at the first report meeting since the campaign opened officially on April 21. The meeting was at the Hotel Biltmore, with chairmen of the principal canvassing committees in attendance.

ALBANY, April 29. -- Attorney General Bennett reiterated today his assurances that contributions to the State unemployment insurance fund, falling due shortly, would be returned to employers if the law were invalidated by the United States Supreme Court.

More jobs await June graduates of American colleges and professional schools than at any time since 1931, according to Robert F. Moore, secretary of appointments at Columbia University, who reported yesterday that many business and industrial organizations were faced with "an alarming gap" in their personnel forces as a result of depression economies.

Forty dollars will be the top price for tickets to the heavyweight bout between Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, and Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion of the world. Mike Jacobs, secretary of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, which is promoting the battle at the Yankee Stadium on June 18, made the fact known yesterday when he announced the scale for the contest, which does not involve the championship held by James J. Braddock.
Money market remained stationary so far as business and rate fluctuations were concerned. Demand was light and quotations unchanged.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- Officials of the Federal Communications Commission disclosed today that they had requested an additional $400,000 from Congress to continue their many-sided investigation of the $5,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 29. -- In view of the fact that Egypt was officially mourning today the death of King Fuad, the entire country was retaining a surprisingly normal atmosphere, with every one going about his business as usual.

The widespread impression that the railroads have been standing still while other forms of transportation have been making rapid technical advances receives no support from the annual report published today of the Union Pacific Railroad. W.A. HARRIMAN, chairman of the board, describes the introduction of six new streamlined trains, two of which are in service and four of which will be placed in service in May and June.

Presidential preference primaries, the preferences expressed in which bind no delegates, may seem like curious toys. At least they indicate a praiseworthy industry and patience on the part of such voters as take the trouble to play. In Massachusetts the friends of Governor LANDON had been busy, but their activity cannot explain his easy and fat majority over the other candidates on whom votes were scattered.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Ferguson of 1,088 Fifth Avenue gave a dinner last night at Sherry's to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their marriage. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Roy W. Howard, Mr. and Mrs. Frazier Hunt, Mr. and Mrs. Miles W. Vaughn, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Ruland, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Coyle, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Beatty, Mr. and Mrs. Norris Huse, Mr. and Mrs. William Stafford.

ADDIS ABABA, April 29. -- There is no news here today of a further Italian advance toward this capital. Judged by latest reports the Italian motorized column traveling on the Imperial Road from Dessye still has to overcome Shoa Meda and the mountains of Jibwasha.

Weakness on the Paris Bourse, further selling of stocks here and beneficial rains in the Mississippi Valley sent cotton lower on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. At one time July sold within a point of 11 cents a pound, with new crop months off 10 points, but in the last hour trade price-fixing steadied the list, which closed with losses of 2 to 5 points on the day.

Doris Dudley, young actress and the daughter of Bide Dudley, former dramatic critic and a current radio commentator, shot and painfully wounded herself a few minutes after 8 o'clock last night in what the police describe as an attempt to commit suicide.

The Rev. Wilfrid Parsons will retire as editor of America, national Catholic weekly published by Jesuits, after serving twelve years, with the issue of May 9. He will be succeeded by the Rev. Dr. Francis Talbot, who has been associate editor for the last thirteen years.
TORONTO, Ont., April 29. -- The Toronto Globe will say tomorrow in a special dispatch from its Ottawa correspondent:

JERUSALEM, April 29. -- Sixteen Arabs were wounded, two of them seriously, by the police here tonight when several hundred tried to conduct a demonstration near the government offices at the Damascus Gate. Several policemen also were wounded.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29. -- Taking advantage of the wildness of two pitchers, Harvard's crack varsity baseball team hammered out a 13-3 triumph over Boston University at Soldiers Field today.

In reply to H.R. Byers's letter I would like to ask him if he has been sleeping so soundly that he has not heard of "platitudes and cliches -- flag-waving and heroic attitudes -- 'Red' scares and patriotism" being broadcast before? Mr. Byers seems to be stripping illusions that have been nude a long time.

COLORADO SPRINGS, April 29. -- Closer study of public affairs and increasing costs of government were submitted today as topics for discussion before the 1,500 delegates of the national Y. W.C.A. convention here.

The atrocious act of vandalism which followed Arturo Toscanini's concluding concert with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall put an abrupt and a shocking end to a demonstration which in the normal course of events would have been greater than the one of last Sunday afternoon when Mr. Toscanini conducted in the same place.

The annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital was held last night at the Plaza under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of the hospital. During the evening there were divertissements by Armand Tokatyan; Dean Goodelle and Jean Farris, dancers; Tex Rickard; Marie Cavan of the Chicago Opera Company, and Harry McNaughton, who contributed their services.

Two masked men who broke into De Witt Clinton High School at Mosholu Parkway and Sedgwick Avenue early yesterday, bound and gagged the watchman, broke open a metal cabinet and smashed about fifteen windows in the executive offices.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- Both critics and friends of the New Deal expressed satisfaction today over the results of yesterday's primary election in Pennsylvania, as incomplete returns continued to indicate that President Roosevelt would have a total vote in the Democratic Presidential preference balloting exceeding 700,000, as against 40,000 or more for his opponent, Colonel Henry Breckinridge.

The Brooklyn College nine found the pitching of Phil Kadis very much to its liking and pounded out eighteen hits to score an 18-2 triumph over Seth Low at Manhattan Beach yesterday. The triumph was the fourth in seven starts for the Kingsmen.

CINCINNATI, April 29. -- In complete agreement, delegates to the fifth biennial convention of the National League of Women Voters today adopted half of the proposed 1936-38 program of work and applauded the nominations of officers headed by Miss Marguerite M. Wells, whose re-election as president, and election of all other nominees, is assured.

An exhibition of the Tibetan colection obtained by the Cutting-Vernay expedition to Tibet will be held from May 11-16 at the showrooms of Arthur S. Vernay, Inc., 19 East Fifty-fourth Street, as a benefit for the Professional Children's School, of which Mrs. Franklin Robinson is president.

Traffic this month on the Northern Pacific Railway exceeded the total for April, 1935, although the gain, on an annual basis, was not as sharp as it was in March, according to Charles Donnelly, president. He said that more rain was necessary for the Spring wheat crop in the Northwest, although moisture was sufficient for sowing.
NEWARK, N.J., April 29. -- With the largest entry in the sixteen years of its existence, the Newark Horse Show opened tonight in the Essex Troop Armory to continue through Saturday.

Any time Representative WARREN of North Carolina is tired of his present job he can have a fine position as plebiscite expert with one of the big European dictators. Mr. WARREN was presiding in the House on Tuesday when the new Tax Bill was up for amendments.

Several States on the Eastern seaboard are displaying growing concern over the decline of the striped bass. At least two, Rhode Island and Connecticut, are planning to do something about it. That is good news, for the striped bass is among the best of our food fishes, and ranks high as a game species.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, Va., April 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Chalifoux entertained at luncheon today at the Greenbrier Casino for Miss Jean Hinsdale and Mrs. Paul F. Donnelly.

In preparation for the going into effect tomorrow of Regulation U, governing banks' loans on securities, brokers have been shifting their, loans in the last few days, segregating in separate loans collateral that can be left untouched for some time and, in some cases, increasing their borrowings.

ROME, April 29. -- Today's official war bulletin dismisses the fighting on the southern front in Ethiopia with the simple statement that there is great activity by patrols and that Libyan troops have routed enemy detachments in the Sullul Valley.

Special attention to intelligent advertising, "not for the day, or the week, but for years ahead," was urged by W.S. Allison, general manager of the Quality Bakers of America, at the closing session yesterday of the organization's silver jubilee general conference at the Park Central Hotel.

Dr. James R. Joy, known as "The Bishop-Maker" of the Methodist Episcopal Church, announced yesterday his decision not to stand for re-election chairman of the editorial board of the National Methodist Christian Advocate and as editor of The New York Methodist Christian Advocate.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Estimating that 12,184,000 persons were without normal work in industry in March, with seasonal gains between January and March about normal, creating 559,000 new jobs, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that the lengthening of hours was a partial cause of the lack of greater employment.

Anne Nichols's and Alford Van Ronkel's "Pre-Honeymoon" has been creeping toward town since March 19, and here -- tonight at the Lyceum -- it finally is. Much has happened during the tryout, including a change of title (it used to be "Her Week-End") and almost as complete a change of cast.

No widespread under-nutrition that is likely to affect the general health of the American people has developed as a result of the depression, Dr. James S. McLester, president of the American Medical Association, said yesterday before the general session of the 130th annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York.

BALTIMORE, April 29 (AP). -- Pimlico's sixteen-day Spring race meeting got away to a good start today amid the cheers from a crowd of 10,000 fans, who watched Breckenridge Long's Legume gain a length victory in the Whetstone Point, feature race of the inaugural program.

The death of King FUAD I last Tuesday may have important political results for Egypt and increase the difficulties of Anglo-Egyptian relations. A regency, nearly always a weak instrumentality, must govern for more than a year -- until the new King FAROUK I becomes 18.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, tonight told 650 Chicago business executives that the real development of government regulation of finance was only beginning and that the commission faces "not the gentle task of polishing and refining but the stern work of continued building."

A sharp decline in the Swiss franc, in the face of continued steadiness in the French franc and firmness in the pound sterling, was the outstanding development in the foreign exchange market yesterday. The Swiss currency dropped to 32.45 1/4 cents and closed at 32.47 cents, off 11 points net.

The fleet Sandy Bill, now owned by Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs, gave another exhibition of his speed at Jamaica yesterday by easily winning the featured Panetian Handicap at six furlongs. The 6-year-old son of Wise Counsellor led the field a merry pace all the way to defeat Jokester by three lengths, with En Masse third, a length and a half further back.

PARIS, April 29. -- After two days of hesitation the Bourse today fell a victim to its revised conviction that next Sunday's ballot would confirm the victory of the Left political parties. To the nervousness thereby produced was added the further alarm over events in Austria.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as plaintiff and trustee, yesterday bought in at auction the fifteen-story Hyde Park Hotel at 998 Madison Avenue, northwest corner of Seventy-seventh Street, on a bid of $550,000. The building was put up for sale by Thomas F. Burchill, auctioneer, in a foreclosure action against the 25 East Seventy-seventh Street Company, Inc.

A banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and including Kuhn, Loeb Co., Edward B. Smith Co. and seven other firms will offer publicly today a new issue of $40,362,000 of refunding and improvement mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series D, of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company.
TRENTON, N.J., April 29. -- Governor Hoffman refused today the request of California for the extradition of Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt in a message to Governor Frank F. Merriam.

LONDON, April 29. -- Predicting that the Queen Mary would be "a most profitable ship," Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard White Star Company, told shareholders today that her recent trials had justified all her owners' expectations.
LONDON, April 29. -- The House of Commons will be asked tomorrow to appropriate an additional 10,000,000 for the navy's expansion during the present budget year, which ends March 31, 1937.

ARTURO TOSCANINI ended last night his career as conductor in America. The demonstrations which have attended his final appearances with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra have probably been without a parallel in the annals of New York's concert halls.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- A summary of reports of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations for March, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed that sales had predominated as in the preceding month.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 29. -- Students of the University of Puerto Rico favor an immediate declaration of a republic. With the island's one-star flag flying from a tower commanding the campus, the students held a two-hour session today on the call of Francisco Ponsa, president of the senior class, to determine the students' position in the situation created by the proposed independence plebiscite.

Isaac I. Kashdan, New York State champion, only one of sixteen competitors with a clean slate, adjourned his fourth-round game in the United States title chess tournament in a definitely superior position last night, yielding the lead for the time being to George Nelson Treysman, who defeated Harold Morton of Boston and increased his score to 3 1/2 points.

Mayor La Guardia will present his views on the new city charter at the first public hearing on the proposed draft, to be held at City Hall on Thursday, May 7, Thomas D. Thacher, chairman of the Charter Commission, announced yesterday.

After little debate worthy of the name, conducted for the most part before an indifferent chamber whose seats were less than one-quarter filled, the House yesterday sent to the Senate, by a vote of 267 to 93, one of the worst tax bills ever passed in its history.

A crowd estimated by the police at more than 10,000 was attracted yesterday by thick clouds of acrid smoke that blanketed a section of the midtown area south of Fifty-ninth Street, caused twelve firemen to be overcome and disrupted bus service on Seventh Avenue for about an hour.

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 29. -- Through a special tax drive against suspected evaders of miscellaneous internal revenue taxes more than $10,000,000 has been found due to the Treasury, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 2O. -- For two days Mickey and Minnie Mouse have been the subject of legal argument before the Federal Trade Marks Commissioner as to whether the names of these famous film stars may be used by an Australian company that manufactures radio sets.
Mayor La Guardia signed Alderman Murray W. Stand's anti-noise ordinance at City Hall yesterday in the presence of prominent figures in the noise abatement movement.
LONDON, April 29. -- Business in most departments of the London Stock Exchange was quiet today, with prices irregular. British Government stocks weakened generally.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 29. -- The American Bankers Association has added 484 members since Sept. 1 last, E.N. Van Horne, president of the Continental National Bank of Lincoln, Neb., said today in reporting to the executive council of the association for the membership committee.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Wrigley Field remains an unhealthy spot for the Dodgers. Professor Stengel is beginning to believe that his players see signs all over the walls, invisible to every one else, which read: "You can't win here."
George Vetzigian bought from the Skillman Homes Corporation an English type house at 45-53 189th Street, Flushing, planned by Sterling M. Palm, architect.

Fordham decisively maintained its superiority over City College in their long baseball rivalry and continued undefeated for the current campaign by recording a 20-to-2 triumph at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday for its ninth success of the season.

H.R. Byers, in your issue of April 27, has joined the army of recrimination in the endless conflict between the generations. After pronouncing himself sick to death of platitudes and cliches and other political and economic odds and ends of hypocrisy and ambition, he adds: "And all the other paraphernalia which are our unsavory heritage.

NEWARK, April 29. -- In a statement replying to Governor Hoffman's radio address of Tuesday night, former Representative Franklin W. Fort, who is opposing the Governor for delegate at large to the National Republican Convention, denied making a political issue of the Lindbergh case.

ALBANY, April 29. -- The New York City Charter provision that the Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity shall have authority to fix rates for hydrant service for water supplied by private water companies was declared unconstitutional today in a decision by Justice Francis Bergan of the Supreme Court.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 29. -- A seven-run splurge in the third inning, in which two balls went over the right field wall for home runs, gave Lehigh University a 9-7 victory over Rutgers in a Middle Three contest today.

KINGSTON, N. Y., April 29. -- Father Divine, Harlem preacher, who intends to make Ulster County a promised land, is negotiating for the purchase of the Kingston Airport, just outside the city limits, so that he and his "angels" can fly to their heavenly colony.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Taking advantage of every opportunity to make capital of political debate and embarrassing the Democratic side with filibuster tactics, the Republicans unloosed in the House today the bitterest partisan debate of the session.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The fundamental question of constitutional law involved in the so-called New York minimum wage case is whether the fixing of the price of labor in a purely private industry, not affected by a public interest, comes within the police power of the State.

An agreement to end the current strike of Atlantic Coast seamen and clear the way for the return of the men to their ships was reached yesterday afternoon by spokesmen of the International Seamen's Union and the strikers committee, headed by Joseph Curran, formerly of the Panama Pacific liner California.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- A flood of proposed amendments to the Anti-Chain-Store Bill prevented its expected passage in the Senate today.

With the upward trend of ingot production accelerated by a strong and diversified demand for practically all forms of steel following a temporary halt last week, output this week rose 1 point to 69 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly summary by Iron Age.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The virtues and defects of the Social Security Act were analyzed in considerable detail today by M.B. Folsom, treasurer of the Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, N. Y., before the industrial relations round-table of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

VIENNA, April 29. -- Officials said tonight that four infantry battalions, two artillery battalions and one armored-car unit were engaging in Alpine manoeuvres not far from the German border. The total number of men in the manoeuvres was reported to be 1,450.

A scramble on the part of distillers to originate acceptable cocktails and identify the drinks with their brand names is looked for in the liquor trade as a result of Supreme Court Justice Walsh's order Tuesday, prohibiting several local hotels from serving Bacardi cocktails made with other rum.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Prices of hogs showed little change today from yesterday's levels, although the demand was relatively slow. A decline of 1/2 cent in the best fresh pork loins to 21 1/2 cents a pound had some effect on the market. The top price declined 5 cents to $10.55 a hundredweight, while the day's average was steady at $10.15.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The heavy vote given to Governor Landon in Pennsylvania and Massachusetts, where voters wrote in his name on the ballots despite the fact he was not a formal candidate, indicated that the Kansan has a much wider popular appeal than has been generally believed, in the view of Washington political observers.

The army today will take leave of one of its most distinguished and best-loved officers, Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commanding the Second Corps Area, who, having reached the mandatory retirement age of 64, will be officially retired at simple ceremonies at Governors Island.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and France is nearing completion and the pact may be signed next Monday. It is expected to be concluded by May 15 at the latest.

HUNTSVILE, Ala., April 29 (AP). -- A menacing crowd of 400 to 500 was dispersed with tear gas today by harassed National Guardsmen after a preliminary hearing for Walter Miller, young Negro charged with the murder of and assault on Vivian Woodward, 19, a white girl.
ST. LOUIS, April 29. -- The Giants made a tremendous effort today to vindicate Colonel Bill Terry's judgment in having traded Roy Parmelee to the Cardinals last Winter.

ALBANY, April 29. -- Assailing the present open betting law in sharp terms as clearly in violation of the Constitution, Democratic Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan asked Attorney General Bennett today for a formal opinion and threatened to instigate a test case himself.

PARIS, April 29. -- The probability that a strong and united Left majority will be formed in the Chamber of Deputies as a result of next Sunday's second ballot was confirmed today by the strict application among the three Left parties of their agreement not to oppose each other but to switch their votes to the candidate with the best chance of winning against the Right.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission voted yesterday to transfer approximately 4,000 employes of the city hospitals under permanent civil service classification. At present the employes, all in the non-competitive group, may be dismissed without notice or explanation.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, April 30. -- Japanese reports today said Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic expert of the British Government, had protested at Tientsin to Consul General Shigeru Kawagoe, the Japanese Ambassador-designate, against Japanese smuggling, which is blighting British business in North China.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Showing fresh irritation at being taken to task by the administration, organized business, as represented by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, applauded enthusiastically today as several leaders charged that government taxation and financial policies were retarding recovery and asserted that private business enterprise had done more than its share to end the depression.

Manhattan's usually potent bats were comparatively silent yesterday, but big Ray Volpi stepped into the breach with a magnificent two-hit performance against Long Island University, enabling the undefeated Jaspers to register their eighth straight triumph of the season by a 3-to-0 score at Manhattan Field.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 29. -- When an attorney for the Home Owners Loan Corporation objected before Supreme Court Justice Bleakley to a court cost item of $10 on the ground that it would prove a burden to persons to whom mortgage loans had been granted, Justice Bleakley commented the HOLC had "a lot of nerve" in view of large deficiency judgments it had obtained in foreclosing mortgages.

Magistrate Anthony F. Burke decided in West Side Court yesterday to let the Court of Special Sessions judge whether bridge teachers who conduct duplicate tournaments for a card fee are guilty of maintaining a gambling establishment.

The Commander of the Second Corps with headquarters at Governors Island is always regarded as something more than an army officer. He is expected to be a sort of unofficial ambassador to the City of New York. It is his duty to maintain cordial relations with the municipal authorities.

I am a young man of 25 years who has been reading with interest, but not approbation, the condemnations from the pens of other young people launched at our present older generation. I have found, to my disappointment, little of serious value for curing society's evils.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Further rains in Kansas and Nebraska and a forecast for unsettled weather increased pressure on the wheat market today and prices dropped more than 1 cent a bushel to the lowest level of the current movement.

Statistics show that Protestant churches are "running downhill," Charles J. McCollough, private secretary to Roger W. Babson and vice president of Babson's statistical organization, reported yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Association of Statisticians of American Religious Bodies at the Parkside Hotel, 18 Gramercy Park South.

Leaders of 125 organizations, with an aserted membership throughout the nation of 1,000,000 women, moved yesterday to weld their groups into an interfaith front against the spread of fascism in this country.
LONDON, April 29. -- The mystery of the missing Mrs. Hazel Draper was cleared up today when the Georgic docked at Tilbury.

Several young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons acted as manikins in the fashion revue, he Spring Fever Fashion Show, yesterday in conjunction with a luncheon in the Trianon and the Embassy Rooms of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Prosperity Shop.

ALBANY, April 29. -- Governor Lehman's social security program, designed to put the State in line with the Federal Social Security Act, was killed by the Republican majority in the Assembly today. This resulted from defeat of a motion to take the Dunnigan Social Security Bill, already passed unanimously by the Senate, from the Committee on Rules for debate and final action on the floor.

BERLIN, April 29. -- Amid general Perturbation in financial and official quarters, Colonel-General Hermann Goering, the new economic dictator, and Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economic Minister, tried today to ascertain whether they could work together without impairing Dr. Schacht's pride and authority to such an extent as to force him from office.

Better timing of fashions in accord with consumer demand will give the consumer merchandise when she is in the market for it, improve retail profits and enable manufacturers to plan production intelligently, speakers said yesterday at a triangular discussion of the timing of fashions held by the Fashion Group at the Hotel Biltmore.
PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP). -- Driving their old team-mate, Roy Mahaffey, off the hill and banging Mike Meola for four runs in the seventh, the Athletics beat the Browns, 7 to 4, today.

Relentless selling weakened stock prices further yesterday. Rallies were feeble and short-lived, and were generally taken advantage of as opportunities for further liquidation. Leading issues lost 1 to 6 points, carrying THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks down 2.20 points on the day and 7.55 points on the month, erasing all but 0.60 point of the gain built up thus far this year.

The third annual exhibition of work by New York artists who have participated in the Washington Square open-air art exhibitions will be held at the International Art Center, 310 Riverside Drive, opening with a reception on Sunday from 4 to 6 o'clock in the afternoon, and to the public on Monday.
ALBANY, April 29. -- The Senate passed today, after considerable debate, two bills that would have the effect of restoring next year the salary cuts imposed on New York City teachers in 1932.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP). -- Pitcher Bucky Walter lost control after intentionally passing two men to fill the bases in the eleventh inning today and hit Gus Suhr with a pitched ball, forcing home the run that gave Pittsburgh a 10-9 victory over Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The administration's fiscal and taxation policies were subjected today to the most vigorous attacks heard during the three days the Chamber of Commerce of the United States has been in session, as a prominent Chicago banker and a Wisconsin manufacturer denounced its activities in both fields.

On the slender left arm of Vernon Gomez the Yanks rode to their second victory in as many games over the Indians yesterday at the Stadium, and slapped the Tribe from its lofty perch at the head of the American League. Cleveland now is in third place.

BOSTON, April 29. -- Complete returns from a primary that drew a Presidential preference from but a small percentage of Massachusetts voters today gave Governor Landon of Kansas a heavy endorsement in the Republican "write-in" balloting.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Secretary Roper called on the Department of Justice and the Treasury Department today to aid him in an investigation of charges that the government has been "lax in its inspecting activities involving lifesaving apparatus and crew efficiency on American merchant vessels."

Nine men arrested at a hospital charity ball in the Hotel Commodore during a raid by Police Inspector Charles L. Neidig's men early yesterday morning were held in $500 bail each by Magistrate Louis Brodsky in Yorkville Court later in the day for hearing Saturday on charges of operating gambling devices.

Flashing a powerful attack behind the excellent pitching by Cornelius Nicholas, the James Monroe High nine crushed the High School of Commerce, 15 -- 0, in their Upper Manhattan-Bronx P.S.A.L. contest yesterday at Monroe Field. The victory was the second in as many circuit starts.

The decline in bond prices continued over a broad front yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. With the exception of United States Government loans, which held within narrow trading limits, virtually all groups were subjected to selling pressure with many of the better grade issues joining with the speculative bonds in the decline.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The administration has virtually abandoned its efforts to obtain Senate ratification of the recently signed treaty with Panama at the present session of Congress, it was learned today. The treaty has been before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for several weeks.

ST. LOUIS, April 29 (AP). -- The annual report of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis states that the bank had net earnings of $235,288 in 1935, against $139,996 in 1934. After payment of dividends there was a net deficit of $899, against $101,013.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Elmer Rice, Broadway playwright, is the central figure in a test case in which the Supreme Court today was asked to decide whether New York State can retroactively collect income taxes on copyrights and patents.

WHEN the mail piles up in thick bundles there comes the thought that the late Walter Camp of football fame once treated a serious problem in a judicious way. It must have been along in the early General Grant period that the seven Nesser brothers of the professional gridiron were in the thick of a bitter football battle.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Discovery of the existence of a cosmic ray ceiling at a height of ten and three-quarter miles above sea level, was announced here today by the National Geographic Society in its first official report on the scientific results of the stratosphere flight on Nov. 11, 1935.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- Resentment at what he described as insinuations that his conduct of the Senate Agriculture Committee's cotton-trading investigation had been unfair was expressed today by Senator Smith of South Carolina, chairman of the committee.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, has been nominated for president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, it was announced yesterday. Nomination is tantamount to election.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 29. -- Henry T. Bush and C. Ray Phillips, receivers for the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company (Mokani), were directed today by Chancellor Wolcott to accept the supplemented offer of settlement submitted by the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- A program calling for an expenditure of $360,000,000 over a period of ten years for construction of navigation and power dams in the Tennessee Valley was discussed by President Roosevelt today with Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the TVA.
Renewals of more than 3,000,000 drivers' licenses, which expire at midnight May 31, will begin throughout the State tomorrow, Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, announced yesterday.

A Broadway clothier was accused yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook of having acted as the "pay-off man" for Louis (Lepke) Buckhouse and Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, who were described as the two leading industrial racketeers of the city.
ADDIS ABABA, April 29. -- Emperor Haile Selassie has communicated to your correspondent an appeal in which he says:

Ellis Parker Jr., son of the well-known New Jersey detective, was accused yesterday by District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan not only of directing Paul H. Wendel's kidnapping, but also of providing the "props" with which he and his gang of would-be "G-men" carried out the plot which delayed Bruno Richard Hauptmann's execution.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- Al Simmons smashed a home run in the ninth inning today to spoil Pete Appleton's hopes of becoming the first pitcher to hurl a one-hit game this season, but the 31-year-old "rookie" nevertheless turned in his third victory for Washington, 7 to 3.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The administration's $803,000,000 tax bill, designed to meet part of the increasing Federal budgetary requirements, chiefly through additional exactions on corporations and their stockholders, was passed by the House today by a vote of 267 to 93.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- An issue of $4,907,000 City of New York 4 per cent Rapid Transit subway serial bonds is among forty-two issues of securities of municipalities, counties and school districts of an aggregate face value of $9,097,100 on which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will open bids at noon May 12.

The twelve-story Pictorial Reviewm Building at 222 West Thirty-ninth Street, where eight lofts of more than 12,000 square feet each were' vacant two weeks ago, is now fullyi rented, Huberth Huberth, Inc., the managing agent, reported yesterday.

New York City police are planning for the largest May Day demonstration in years tomorrow and are taking every precaution against any disorder. Days off have been canceled for all members of the force and, in addition to the regular patrol squads, two squads will be held on reserve in every station house from 8 o'clock tonight until noon Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Asserting that added tax burdens and potential competition with private industry were involved, representatives of real estate interests opposed the Wagner bill for slum clearance and low-cost housing at a hearing today before the Senate Committee on Education and Finance.

Yale pitching and Columbia fielding proved an unbeatable combination in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game yesterday at Baker Field. At least it was unbeatable as far as the Elis were concerned. The Lions contrived to set a new circuit mark in errors -- nine of them -- and this made it relatively simple for the New Havenites to win 14 to 7.

VIENNA, April 29. -- Nervous tension in Austria is constantly growing despite the outward calm of her coordinated press. Behind it is the frequently denied but nevertheless real conflict between the Heimwehr Fascists and the clericals.

Announcement was made yesterday that entries for the newest of polo competitions, the recently formed Eastern League, would close next Wednesday, and there is every indication at present of the success of this venture in its first season.

A tie-up of the anthracite coal industry, affecting 106,000 miners, chiefly in Pennsylvania, loomed yesterday as representatives of the United Mine Workers and operators, who have been holding sessions in this city for more than two months, were unable to break the deadlock in their negotiations for a new agreement.

ALBANY, April 29. -- A bill to permit the New York City Tunnel Authority to build a bridge over the East River, as well as to dig a vehicular tunnel under it, was advanced to the order of third reading in the Senate today. The measure was offered by Senator Desmond of Orange who has held that a bridge would cost $24,000,000 against $58,000,000, the estimated cost of a tunnel.

BOSTON, April 29 (AP). -- The Red Sox, waging an uphill battle most of the game, regained first place today by topping the White Sox, 8 -- 7, before 10,000 fans. Rick Ferrell's single with one out and the bases filled in the ninth brought in Rog Cramer with the winning run.

Mrs. Hazel Margery Archibald Draper, wife of Eben S. Draper of Hopedale, Mass., who has been missing since April 19, was reported yesterday as alive and "perfectly well" in London, having traveled there as a stowaway aboard the Georgic.

Two former champions regained their laurels and another successfully defended his crown in the national fencing championships last night on the strips of the New York Athletic Club. A large crowd in the banner-bedecked gymnasium saw the trio from the Fencers Club, Lieutenant Gustave Heiss, Norman Armitage and Hugh V. Alessandroni, win with epee, saber and foil respectively.

Pointing out that only three first-floor departments, hosiery, toilet goods and gloves exceed notions in dollar volume and profit returns, Thomas W. MacLeod, vice president of Stern Brothers, yesterday suggested to notion manufacturers methods by which both producers and retailers could further increase their sales.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The statement that pending legislation affecting price-making would be unenforceable and would "Volsteadize the anti-trust laws and Federal Trade Commission Act" was made by Gilbert H. Montague of New York, authority on trade association law, in an address before a round-table today in connection with the convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

The successful newspaper of the future will give more attention to news articles of educational value and less space to crime and "slush," in the opinion of Dr. Garry C. Myers, head of the department of parent education in Cleveland College, Western Reserve University.

NEWMARKET, England, April 29 (AP). -- Lord Astor's Pay Up, brown son of Fairway -- Book Debt, captured the 128th running of the Two Thousand Guineas, first of the season's turf classics for 3-year-olds today.

HAVANA, Thursday, April 30. -- The Cuban Senate shortly after midnight unanimously resolved to call upon President Miguel Mariano Gomez "to exhaust all the means at his command definitely to solve acts of bloodshed that newspapers report are shrouded in mystery and that are occurring with continuous frequency, and to secure the punishment of the guilty."

Federal Judge John C. Knox signed preliminary injunctions yesterday preventing Postmaster General James A. Farley from enforcing his order of last Tuesday denying use of the mails to the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, headed by Mrs. Oliver Harriman, and to the Golden Stakes Advertising Corporation, of which Alfred E. Smith Jr. is vice president and general counsel.
ALBANY, April 29. -- The bill offered by Miss Jane Todd to bar hasty marriages was defeated today in the Senate by a vote on strictly party lines.

The Duquesne Power Company advised the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that it was "impossible at this time to estimate with any degree of accuracy the amount of loss either of gross revenue or damage to property" suffered by the company during the recent floods of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers in Pennsylvania.

Standard Brands, Inc., and subsidiary companies reported yesterday for the three months ended on March 31 a net income of $3,793,542 applicable to the parent company after expenses, minority interests, Federal taxes and other charges but before profit and loss items.
Five Atlantic liners will arrive today from Europe with 2,400 passengers.

The Bronx was the center of brisk real estate activity yesterday when deals were announced involving a block front sale by Harvard University and contracts on various housing properties in which operators and investors figured.

Cooperation between architects and builders and the scientists who are developing new building materials was urged by Dr. Edward Ray Weidlein, director of the Mellon Institute for Industrial Research, in a talk on "Building Materials of Tomorrow" at the fifteenth annual luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

BARTOW, Fla., April 29. -- The flogging spirit flared into the open in Judge Dewell's court room today where seven former Tampa policemen, including the ex-chief of police, are on trial in the flogging of three men, one of whom later died from his wounds.

Albert H. Stursberg, partner In W. Stursberg, Schell Co., factor for woolen mills, who died on July 14, 1933, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,019,840 gross and $876,040 net. Most of the estate consisted of property inherited from William Stursberg, an uncle, who was head of the firm, and his father, Julius A. Stursberg, which was worth $740,608.

The trading in futures on the local commodity markets yesterday developed irregularity. The market was more active. Rubber, cocoa, wool top and copper futures were stronger, while other staples declined. On the cash markets corn and rubber gained, while wheat, rye, oats, cotton, hides, butter and tin declined.

The city of Detroit awarded yesterday a new issue of $18,720,000 of refunding bonds to a nation-wide banking syndicate headed by Edward B. Smith Co. at a net interest cost of 3.77 per cent. The group paid 100.0048 for $12,870,000 as 4s, due on June 1, 1937 to 1956, and $5,850,000 as 3 1/2s, maturing from 1957 to 1962.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack reserved decision yesterday on a petition by the Associated Gas and Electric Company to dismiss a reorganization proceeding instituted by a group of creditors. Hearings in the litigation will be resumed Monday.

MEXICO, D.F., April 29. -- The United States is prompted by ulterior motives in the convocation of a Pan-American peace conference this Summer, because there is no danger of a war between any Pan-American countries, says Vicente Lombardo Toledano, general secretary of the Mexican Confederation of Labor, in the newspaper Universal today.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Annual reports by corporations under the Securities Act of 1934 which were made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that Philip D. Wagoner, president, general manager and a director of the Underwood Elliot, Fisher Company received in 1935 remuneration of $100,480 and that Matthew S. Eylar, vice president, drew $30,000.

BOSTON, April 30. -- Chandler Hovey today confirmed a consistent report of the last few days that he had purchased from Frederick H. Prince the yacht Weetamoe, twice unsuccessful candidate for defense of the America's Cup.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.
TOKYO, April 30. -- Japanese accustomed to read between the lines scanned thoughtfully today the following words in a statement Tsuneo Matsudaira, Lord Privy Seal, made on the Emperor's birthday:
LONDON, April 30 (AP). -- Workers of Britain, France and Spain tonight prepared for huge May Day demonstrations calling for a united labor front to smash fascism and prevent war.

As part of a refunding operation for The Hartford Times, Inc., formal offering will be made today of the unsubscribed remainder of an issue of fifteen-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures, due 1951, by Hemphill, Noyes Co. The debentures are priced at par.

Within the last four weeks Park Commissioner Robert Moses wrote a letter to the World's Fair Committee of the Board of Estimate expressing the opinion that "because of weaknesses which have become apparent in the World's Fair management" the proposed exposition may not be held until 1940, it was disclosed yesterday.
A schedule of minimum medical fees for treatment of workmen's compensation cases in the metropolitan district was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

The American Olympic fencing committee named both men's and women's teams for the international competition at Berlin after a three-hour session at the New York Athletic Club last night. Eighteen men and four alternates, together with three women and one substitute, will compose the squad as announced by Leon M. Schoonmaker, chairman of the group.

Thirty-one cloth sponging and shrinking corporations, two unions and the Textile Refinishers Association were enjoined yesterday by consent from violating the antitrust laws. The injunction was signed by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack on application by John Harlan Amen, special assistant to the Attorney General.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $24,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent Series D bonds of the Cincinnati Union Terminal Company by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Kuhn, Loeb Co. The bonds, dated May 1, 1936, and due May 1, 1971, will be priced at 102 1/2 and accrued interest, to yield about 3.37 per cent.

WINCHESTER, Va., April 30. -- Against a background of millions of pinkish-white apple blossoms and in the fragrance of Spring, the Shenandoah Valley paid its annual tribute to King Apple today with parade and pageantry. The events surpassed in scenic beauty and solemnity any of the previous celebrations held in honor of the fruit that nature presented to this community for its chief means of livelihood.
TEL AVIV, April 30. -- Contrary to rumors that the Levant Fair might be postponed because of the troubled situation in the country, it was opened by the High Commissioner today as scheduled.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- A movement to simplify the $803,000,000 Tax Bill, passed yesterday by the House, and to add about $190,000,000 to its annual yield for the next two years, took definite form in the Senate Finance Committee today following a plea by Secretary Morgenthau for enactment of the full revenue program outlined by President Roosevelt in his message of March 3.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Government installation of airway aids at a cost of $14,000,000, and Federal policing of air traffic to make air safety "bullet-proof," was urged today by Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, before the House Postoffice Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- Twenty-eight New York City corporations in the lumber trade today asked the Supreme Court to find that steamship lines and numerous labor unions had formed an illegal conspiracy to block their shipping through the Port of New York.

Microphone, a 7-year-old son of Flying Ebony, winner of the Kentucky Derby in 1925, scored his fifth straight triumph yesterday when he was an easy victor in the Cedarhurst Purse at a mile and seventy yards, feature of the day at Jamaica.

ALBANY, April 30. -- The Assembly today unanimously passed the bill of Assemblyman Stone, Onondaga Republican, providing that all contributions to the unemployment insurance fund shall be held in the State pending determination by the United States Supreme Court of the constitutionality of the law.

Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, senior corps area commander, retired from the army yesterday after almost forty years' service. A thirteen-gun salute from the batteries at Fort Jay sounded the farewell as General Nolan completed his final inspection at Governors Island and boarded a ferry for Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Restoration of economic stability was declared today by Secretary Hull, in a speech before the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, to be the one antidote for the "rising danger of new world catastrophe."

MOSCOW, April 30. -- Long lines of covered field guns and tanks were drawn up tonight in the streets that open into Red Square for the annual Soviet May Day review, regarded as particularly significant this year because of the threatening situation in the Far East.

Labor's employment of May Day as an occasion for the demonstration of its numerical strength will been confined today to a single parade on lower Fifth Avenue as a result of recent efforts to amalgamate left wing labor and Communist sympathizers.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Problems arising under Regulation U, adopted by the Federal Reserve Board and covering the extension of loans by banks for the purchase or carrying of securities on stock exchanges, were discussed today by Charles R. Gay, president, and other representatives of the New York Stock Exchange with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.

Houses doing government business released yesterday contracts for several thousand bales of cotton for delivery in May, which was attributed to the producers' pool, but prices on the Cotton Exchange displayed more resistance than on Wednesday and ended unchanged to only 2 points net lower.
PARIS, April 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- A new form of electrical transmission in which ultra-high frequency radio waves are transmitted through a hollow metal pipe in much the same manner as the human voice travels through a speaking tube, was described here today before a joint meeting of the American Physical Society and the Institute of Radio Engineers.

MIAMI, Fla., April 30. -- By a smoothly executed manoeuvre the General Federation of Women's Clubs today declined to go on record on membership by the United States in the League of Nations. Instead of voting on a resolution submitted yesterday, the measure was remanded to the department of international relations, where it originated, for further study.
Leaders in the United States championship of the National Chess Federation experienced heavy going in fifth-round matches last night at the Hotel Astor before another capacity attendance.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Dayton Power and Light Company today filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 100,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative 4 1/2 per cent preferred stock, stating that the price to the public and names of underwriters, in addition to W.E. Hutton Co., the principal underwriter, would be supplied later in an amendment.

What started out to be a mock burial of "academic freedom" on the campus of City College at noon yesterday ended in a five-hour "sit-down" strike by more than 500 of the 2,000 students who participated in the "funeral services."

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Secretary Ickes warned power companies contesting the administration's municipal power program today that "no projects will be canceled because of court delays." He then accused the Duke Power Company of deliberately delaying an appeal, which it has now made to the Supreme Court, to decide the constitutionality of PWA allotments to municipally owned power plants.

A collection of nineteen surveys by George Washington brought $4,700 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction of autographs, books, and other items from the collections of the late J. Percy Sabin of Summit, N.J., and other owners.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- Representative Marion A. Zioncheck of Washington State speeded himself back into the hands of police again today, this time in near-by Alexandria, Va.

Dividends declared in April, as in previous months this year, compared favorably with those of a year before. To shareholders was voted a total of $172,636,197 by 737 corporations, the largest payment for April since 1934. The amount compared with $235,542,166 for 1,174 companies in the preceding month; $139,366,332 for 705 companies in April, 1935, and $175,667,316 for 627 corporations in April, 1934.

A common prayer for victims of persecution throughout the world will be offered tomorrow and Sunday in Protestant and Catholic churches and Jewish synagogues in the metropolitan area, it is announced by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

NEWARK, N.J., April 30. -- A fanfare of trumpets and individual blasts for the various teams entered signalled the formal opening of military night of the sixteenth annual Newark Horse Show in the Essex Troop Armory this evening.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

A crowd of several thousand office workers in the financial district gathered at Wall and Broad Streets during the noon hour yesterday to watch a celebration on the steps of the Sub-treasury Building by America's Good-Will Union of the 147th anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as the first President of the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Warnings of a possible dictatorship resulting from a fruition in the Roosevelt administration of policies, espoused by both Republican and Democratic parties for many years, were voiced today by speakers at the annual convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
BERLIN, April 30. -- Stocks on the Boerse were strengthened today by rumors of a growing demand for devaluation of the currency. Activity, however, was, as usual, limited.

Charging that "some sinister influences are conceivably attempting to create a bear market in stocks in the face of vastly improving business conditions," Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, predicted last night that net profits of industry for the remainder of this year would show an increase of at least 25 per cent as a result of general production and sales gains of 5 to 10 per cent.

LONDON, April 30. -- Great Britain has not yet hauled down her flag in the conflict with Italy over Ethiopia, it was made plain in the House of Lords yesterday by Earl Stanhope, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs.

CINCINNATI, April 30. -- With enthusiasm and but one dissenting vote, the National League of Women Voters in convention today adopted the recommended addition of classroom freedom of teachers to its 1936-38 program as a "continuing responsibility."

The curious may well wonder why the National Geographic Society should have built the greatest of balloons and sent it up on Nov. 11, 1935, under the auspices of the army, to reach a height of 72,395 feet -- 13.71 miles. What have the atmosphere, cosmic rays, ozone layers and the solar spectrum to do with geography?

Eleven properties in Manhattan were taken over by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Two scheduled sales were adjourned. Many of the properties, which consisted chiefly of tenement buildings, were bought in by savings banks.

PITTSBURGH, April 30. -- Financial circles here understood tonight that details of transferring the Gulf Oil Corporation's interest in the Barco concession in Colombia to the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and the Texas Corporation were completed today at a conference here.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 30. -- Undergraduate members of Princeton's eighteen upper class eating clubs will play host to 534 young women guests at the annual house parties, high-light of the university Spring social season, here tomorrow and Saturday.

The St. John's University tennis team gained its third straight victory by conquering Long Island University, 8 -- 1, at the Queens Community courts yesterday. Myron Sewitch was the lone victor for L. I. U., vanquishing Gordon Peggs, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2.

Loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose in a the last month to a level previously exceeded only in two weeks in the Autumn of 1929, when these banks took over a large volume of loans to security brokers which previously had been extended by other lenders, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports in its monthly review, issued yetserday.

New bond issues offered in April were the largest in amount for any month in more than ten years. The total of $886,087,000 for sixty-three issues, compared with $559,153,000 for seventy-six issues in March. The combined total of $1,445,240,000 for the last two months established a record for such a period in the last decade.

The angling frontiers in New York State broaden today with the opening of the season on pickerel and great northern pike. Sportsmen of the metropolitan area desiring to fish for these species will have to travel some distance, however, as the restrictions in Westchester and Putnam Counties remain in force until July 1.

Plans of the Department of Docks for an extension of the East River m bulkhead line into the fiver between Twenty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets to make possible the construction of a motor highway encountered conflicting views yesterday when sumbitted to a public hearing in the Army Building.

A campaign to improve the Columbus Circle area was begun by the West of Central Park Association yesterday when property owners and their agents, merchants, representatives of banks, schools and institutions in the neighborhood were called together at a luncheon in the Mayflower Hotel, Sixty-first Street and Central Park West, to consider what action should be taken.

A luncheon was given yesterday at the Pierre by the Colonial Dames of America before the annual meeting of the organization at the clubhouse, 421 East Sixty-first Street. James W. Gerard, whose mother, the late Mrs. James W. Gerard, was president of the society from 1904-08, addressed the guests briefly.

The world-wide quest for $1,507,938 in securities stolen in Wall Street in January, 1935, led back to this city yesterday from Paris and Vienna. Two men held in $10,000 bail for transfer to the Texas Federal Court, on charges of having $5,000 in stolen bonds, were reported to be suspected of being members of the international gang that has been trying to dispose of the Bank of the Manhattan Company's securities.

LONDON, April 30. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange rallied well in the afternoon after an early setback because of adverse news from United States and Continental markets. British funds became steadier after the opening sales had been made at overnight quotations.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 30. -- The leader of the extreme Right Iron Guard organization, Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, and his former lieutenant, now his rival, Jon Stelescu, were arrested here last night at the request of a court at Galati, where they were transferred by automobile and jailed.

Although he had been convicted by a General Sessions jury early last February as a participant in a $7,700 hold-up, Salvatore Sanguedolce, 21 years old, a member of the Naval Militia, was freed yesterday by Judge Otto A. Rosalsky. The court set the conviction aside and quashed the indictment against him.

THE most effectively written novel to appear many weeks, and one of the books best worth reading of this year, is Arnold Zweig's "Education Before Verdun" (Viking, $2:50). As Zweig has earlier indicated -- recall his "The Case of Sergeant Grischa" -- the war setting, not that of the new Germany or that of Palestine, brings out his finest work.

ON THE ROAD TO ADDIS ABABA (via field radio at Marina, Ethiopia), April 30. -- The last great drive on Italy's northern front is drawing swiftly to a close as the greatest motorized column in military history pushes steadily southward to the Ethiopian capital.
