BORDEAUX, France, April 30 (AP). -- Dr. Norbert Barthozek, Austrian physician, went on trial today accused of having sterilized several residents of Bordeaux, and his counsel argued that sterilization was no more a crime than tattooing.
Political uncertainties abroad, which caused an unsettlement in the foreign exchange market in favor of the dollar, increased the flow of gold to the United States in April.

Judge Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, signed yesterday an order dismissing reorganization proceedings under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Law of the Bush Terminal Company and also dismissing a suit in equity pending against the company.
ALBANY, April 30. -- Governor Lehman issued a proclamation today setting aside the week of May 17-23 as Foreign Trade Week.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 30. -- Hugh Lynn's deep drive into center field in the eleventh inning sent Bob Nevitt across the plate with a run that gave Princeton a 5-4 victory over Pennsylvania in a closely contested Eastern League game on University Field today.

The break in grain and flour prices, with lower quotations for hogs, steers and beef, has sent The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to the lowest level since July 16, the index declining on Tuesday to 123.1 per cent of the 1913 average from 123.9 on the Tuesday previous and 126.6 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Harry Bridges, the Australian-born labor leader who played such a part in the San Francisco waterfront strike of 1934, and his radical associates were blamed today by Roger D. Lapham, president of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company, for the unrest among steamship workers.
TOKYO, April 30. -- A Manchukuoan-German commercial agreement has been signed at the Tokyo Foreign Office.

BERLIN, April 30. -- Germany's annual labor celebration tomorrow will be held with the slogan "lets enjoy life and make merry." It is to begin at dawn and a huge torchlight parade will keep it going after dark. The police hour, meaning the time when cafes, restaurants and beer halls must close, has been lifted for three successive nights.

LONDON, April 30. -- Thirty-eight new warships, including two battleships of about 35,000 tons each, will be begun this year as the first installment of the navy's share in Britain's 300,000,000 rearmament program.

Today would have marked the time limit for employers to pay their first contribution to New York State's new Unemployment Insurance Act, but because of the unfamiliarity of employers with the requirements of the new law and a temporary shortage of informed personnel to answer questions about it, Industrial Commissioner ELMER F. ANDREWS has extended the time to midnight, May 15.

Revival of the recent strike of the building service union, affecting some 40,000 men, was threatened yesterday when the Realty Advisory Board sent a letter to affiliated realty owners charging that the wage award handed down in Washington by Ferdinand A. Silcox, chief forester of the United States, was unfair and invalid in parts and advising them to take action to protect themselves against it.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Carinthia, leaving today for Liverpool via Glasgow and Belfast, includes Mrs. Clifford Atkinson, Mrs. Walter N. Vail, Mrs. Robert B. Ogden, Miss Jennie Hedgecock, Mrs. T.C. Moorehouse, Mr. and Mrs. B.S. Colburn, Mrs. Fred C. Whitney and Miss Vera Kemp.
Interest charges for both call and time loans last month were unchanged for the sixth consecutive month.

The prospect of an early settlement of the strike of Atlantic Coast seamen, which has been under way six weeks, was dissipated yesterday afternoon when the executive board of the International Seamen's Union rejected a proposal to submit the new Atlantic wage contract to a poll of union members.

The City Stores Company and subsidiaries report net profit for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, 1936, after Federal taxes, depreciation, amortization and minority, interest, of $303,337, equal to 25 cents a share on the outstanding common stock. This compares with net loss of $524,328 for the preceding year.

ADDIS ABABA, April 30. -- Emperor Haile Selassie returned suddenly today to his apparently doomed capital, while high officials and natives fled in panic against the approach of the Italian northern army.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30. -- With the Kentucky Derby's sixty-second running two days away, the unusual condition prevails that the favorite, Joseph E. Widener's Brevity, is a longer price today than he was a week ago. The track is deep in mud, and no one appears to like the Florida Derby winner in that kind of footing. But Trainer Pete Coyne believes he can run in it.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Robinson-Patman "Anti-Chain Store" Bill was passed by the Senate today without a roll-call. Threatened opposition collapsed when various amendments were accepted and sent to conference. The bill is intended to bar either award or acceptance of pride discriminations.

It was not quite a civilized incident that marred the last moments of ARTURO TOSCANINI'S farewell appearance in Carnegie Hall. But there is no need of taking the affair of the wild camera man too tragically. Perhaps when TOSCANINI, in the years to come, lets his thoughts go back to America, that flashlight assault by a reckless photographer will help the great artist remember us a bit more vividly.

The New York alumni group of Lawrenceville School gathered at the Downtown Athletic Club at luncheon yesterday to pay honor to the remarkable young polo team which represented the school this year. In the indoor tournament held in New York in March, the team defeated Culver Military Academy of Indiana for the schoolboy title for the second year in a row.

BOSTON, April 30 (AP). -- The battering Red Sox, with eighteen hits and a dozen passes, made a clean sweep of the three-game Chicago series today by pounding four White Sox pitchers for a wild 16-4 victory. The visitors turned in a triple play in the eighth.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30. -- The quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church will open here tomorrow with 616 ministerial and lay delegates and thirty-six Bishops attending a communion service and organization meeting.
CLEVELAND, April 30 (AP). -- The Republic Steel Corporation announced today plans for expenditure of $1,250,000 for improvements on plants and mines at twelve cities.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Chicago Western Indiana Railroad filed today an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $24,462,000 of first and refunding mortgage, Series D, 4 1/4 per cent sinking fund bonds to replace a like amount of Series A, B and C, 5 1/2 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds.

Although the underlying trend in bond prices yesterday continued toward moderately lower levels, goodsized recoveries were scattered throughout the list of domestic corporate issues with the result that the market, as a whole, showed a highly mixed undertone at the close.

Saying it with frequent hits, the Yankees yesterday taught their former teammate, Johnny Allen, that to vow is easy but to carry out such an expression of determination is quite difficult. In short, the Cleveland hurler's Spring training camp promise to beat the McCarthymen is still unfulfilled.

PARIS, April 30. -- Maurice Thorez, secretary-general of the Communist party, said today a new government, inclined further to the Left than at present, would have Communist support if it would carry out the minimum program of the Popular Front.

Salaries of executives in 1935, bonus payments and stock options, if any were outstanding, of more than a score of listed companies were disclosed yesterday in annual earnings reports filed with the New York Stock Exchange in compliance with the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
ALBANY, April 30. -- The Democratic Senate put through Governor Lehman's program for financing unemployment relief today and incidentally took sharp issue with the Republican Assembly.

For some weeks the question of relief for the unemployed has been sadly muddled in New Jersey. Available funds were exhausted, and the Governor called upon the Legislature to lay new taxes in order to obtain the $3,000,000 a month required. But personal and party controversies have thus far prevented the raising of the money needed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP). -- The Athletics defeated the Browns, 12 to 8, today, the victory giving Philadelphia three games of the series. A cluster of four runs in the fourth inning and five in the sixth won for the Mackmen.

The Spanish naval schoolship Juan Sebastian de Elcano arrived yesterday morning on her way home to Cadiz from a cruise around the world. The vessel is a four-masted schooner and carries twenty-three cadets and 224 officers and men. Captain Cristobal Gonzeles Aller y Aceval is in command.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- The grain markets fluctuated today in an erratic manner within moderate price limits. It was first notice day of intention to deliver cash grain on May contracts and brought about heavy evening up on the Board of Trade.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 30. -- The American Association of Advertising Agencies elected officers today at its annual convention here.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- An increase of $709,475 in the provision for taxes prevented the Commonwealth Edison Company from making a much better showing in the first quarter of 1936 than in the same period of 1935, James Simpson, chairman, reported today.

CONCORD, N.H., April 30. -- Governor H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, who has been mentioned as a possible Republican nominee for vice president, and Robert A. Taft, Ohio's "favorite-son" candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, today called for the adoption of a "constructive, forward-looking" platform at the Cleveland convention, and urged a system of moderate old-age pensions.

Playing the role of an interested spectator, Bobby Jones, former monarch of the golf world, yesterday visited the new Split Rock course, built by the Works Progress Administration, and the Pelham Bay course, which has been reconstructed by the same organization.

Results of the vote of Columbia College seniors for their permanent class officers, for class marshals at graduation and for annual prize awards were announced yesterday. Next year's under-class officers and members of the undergraduate student council also were named.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 30. -- Climaxing a busy two weeks in which the Citizens Commission on Reorganization of the Westchester County Government fought desperately to put its final charter draft into shape for consideration by the Legislature before it adjourned, the Westchester Board of Supervisors late this afternoon rejected the commission's charter by a vote of 31 to 8.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- President Roosevelt stood firm today in his determination to permit no Federal expenditures except those provided for in the ordinary and relief budgets by not accepting the proposal of a House bloc to earmark for PWA projects $700,000,000, or nearly half, of the pending work-relief appropriations.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 30. -- Speaking before the American Association of Physical Anthropologists at Yale University tonight on the subject, "What Is an American?" Dr. E. A. Hooton, Professor of Anthropology at Harvard University, declared there was no anthropological justification for anti-Semitism, or preferment of Nordic and "Aryan" stocks.

The reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System were increased again in the week ended on Wednesday by disbursements by the Treasury out of balances previously accumulated at the Reserve Banks. The report of the Federal Reserve System for the week, published yesterday, showed an increase of $64,000,000 in member-bank reserves and a rise of $50,000,000 in the excess of these reserves over legal requirements to a total excess of $2,690,000,000.

Asserting that economic isolation is impossible of attainment, Colonel H. Murray Jacoby, economist and one-time Ambassador at Large under the Hoover administration, called upon the nation to face the fact and adjust itself to earn the benefits and not just the misery resulting from inter-trade developments abroad.

May I congratulate you on the publication Sunday of the full text of the important new treaty between the United States and Panama now being discussed in executive session by the Senate? Since your Washington correspondent reports that the Senate desires the opinion of the public concerning the instrument, it would be well for those interested in a further development of the happily growing inter-American fellowship to make known their approval of this pact.

Retail package deliveries, in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase of 17 per cent for the week ended April 25 as against the corresponding week a year ago, it was announced yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure compares with a decrease of 12 per cent for the previous, week.

This week's decline in the stock market brought the "averages" to a figure more than 13 points below that of April 6, when the highest average prices of the upward movement which began somewhat more than a year ago were reached. This decline is the largest that has occurred in the occasional reactions of the prolonged upward movement.

Thousands of pupils of Professor George Lyman Kittredge, soon to retire after almost a half century teaching at Harvard, must have welcomed, as I did, the timely article about him that appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of April 19 and your editorial of the same date.

Harry Weiss, held in $50,000 bail as one of the alleged kidnappers of Paul H. Wendel, attempted suicide yesterday in the Brooklyn City Prison. Making a noose out of his necktie, which he tied to a bar in his cell, he tried to hang himself. He was cut down by guards.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- J.H. Case, for many years chairman and Federal Reserve agent of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has tendered his resignation from these posts and as a Class C director, and the resignation has been accepted, the governors of the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

ST. LOUIS, April 30. -- The grand offensive machinery of the Giants thundered on the west bank of the Mississippi today as the forces of Colonel Bill Terry peppered Paul Dean for eleven hits. But either the boys were firing blank cartridges or their shots were falling wide of their mark.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 30. -- Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons announced in the House of Representatives today that the government was leasing the Newnes shale oil field in New South Wales to subsidize petrol production up to a maximum of 10,000,000 gallons annually and was spending 250,000 to facilitate the search for oil by approved companies in Australia and in New Guinea, where the prospects are considered more favorable than formerly.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- A summary of tke budget situation, as reflected in prospective deficits, presenteg to the enate Finance Committee today by ecretary Morgenthau, read a follows:

The mistakes of the Republican leaders, making ready for the Presidential campaign, have been plentiful, but beneath everything there has been a basic strategy, which the recent primary vote in Massachusetts has helped to evolve. That strategy was to nominate a Middle Westerner, near the heart of the agricultural belt, who would be acceptable to the populous States of the East.

The Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday made known on its billboards at the Broadway house that its 1936-37 regular season will begin on Dec. 21, Monday evening, and continue for fourteen weeks, terminating on March 27, 1937.

The American Metal Company has declared a dividend of $4 a share on the preferred stock on account of accumulations. A similar amount was declared three months ago. Payment of this dividend will reduce the arrearages to $16.50 a share.

ALBANY, April 30. -- Democratic Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan called on the Racing Commission today to investigate the stand of John G. Cavanagh, veteran ringmaster, in opposition to the proposed pari-mutuel amendment to the State Constitution.

PITTSBURGH, April 30. -- Continued industrial expansion and substantially heavier freight shipments last week caused the index of business activity in the Pittsburgh district to reach the highest level in nearly six years, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

The threatened strike of 106,000 anthracite miners, most of them in Pennsylvania, was averted last night upon intervention of Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor. Through Edward F. McGrady, assistant secretary, she prevailed upon the joint conference of miners and operators to extend the old agreement of the industry to permit continuance of negotiations.

A daring but unsuccessful attempt to hold up the cashier at Jack Dempsey's Restaurant, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, was made yesterday afternoon. The man who is accused of the hold-up, who described himself as John A. Downing, 47 years old, of 56 East 177th Street, the Bronx, was captured outside the restaurant, on Fiftieth Street, by two patrolmen as he was fleeing with a strongbox containing $145.40.

Sterling, Grace Co. has been formed, with offices at 111 Broadway. The partners are Duncan Sterling, member of the New York Stock Exchange, Duncan Sterling Jr. and Oliver R. Grace. Mr. Sterling and his son were formerly partners in the dissolved Stock Exchange firm of Frank Sterling.

OTTAWA, April 30 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada decreased $1,919,175 and by chartered banks increased $2,493,488 in the week ended yesterday, said the weekly report issued today. The statement follows:

A threat that the Bronx Terminal Market may soon be vacated again, as it has been twice before, unless the city administration acts to improve business conditions there, was voiced yesterday at a meeting of the Bronx Terminal Market Merchants Association, attended by seventy-five merchants, Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. and Deputy Commissioner Carl W. Kimball.

Controller Frank J. Taylor will introduce in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly today a local law to save taxpayers about $2,000,000 a year on local improvements by separating salary costs from the cost of the improvements.

The franc continued firm yesterday in the face of continued uncertainty over the consequences for France's financial policy inasmuch as further gains by the Left political parties are expected at next Sunday's run-off elections. It closed at 6.58 5/8 cents, a gain of 1/8 point over the previous day.
Richmond Hill High registered a Queens division P.S.A.L. victory yesterday, Bill Wichers blanking Flushing, 3 to 0, at Memorial Field, Flushing.

As the market rallied yesterday afternoon, rumors went about the Street of a possible change in or postponement of Regulation U of the Federal Reserve Board governing bank loans on securities, which will become effective today. There were reports of meetings between Federal Reserve officials, bankers and officers of the Stock Exchange.

TORONTO, April 30 (AP). -- Francis (Bots) Nekola held Newark to three hits today as the Maple Leafs scored a 2 -- 0 victory over the league leaders before an opening day crowd of 6,500. Threatening weather kept down the attendance. The victory was Toronto's fifth straight.

The National City Bank extended credit totaling more than $23,000,000 to 56,459 persons during eighteen months of operation under the modernization credit plan of the Federal Housing Administration, Thomas G. Grace, the State director, announced yesterday.
BOGOTA, N.J., April 30. -- Four men, one with a submachine gun, stole $19,818.61 at noon today from the Bogota National Bank and escaped in a dark sedan driven by a fifth member of the gang.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- The champion Cubs came literally out of a fog to win a thrilling eleven-inning battle with the luckless Dodgers today, 2-1, nullifying the second good Brooklyn pitching performance in two days and sending Casey Stengel's men away to St. Louis feeling that a victory in Wrigley Field is a rare prize not to be had.

LOS ANGELES, April 30 (AP). -- Pierre Tomlinson, who said he had known Dr. Francis E. Townsend for twenty-seven years, testified at a Congressional investigation today that Dr. Townsend was unable to pay his gas and light bills at the time he started his old-age pension movement.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- Offerings of hogs were smaller today and with a fair demand prices were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, with weights under 210 pounds showing the most strength. Heavy butcher hogs and sows were unchanged, the decline in lard acting as a drag.
The Exchange has advised member firms that they may not absorb any part of the service charge of $1 for each draft with securities attached which was started by New York banks on April 20.
The Rev. Dr. William Adams Brown will retire from the faculty of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, when its season closes, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- Misfortune cracked down on the Tigers again today, this time putting Manager Mickey Cochrane out of the line-up for several days with an injured foot.

J. Herbert Case, who retired yesterday as chairman, Federal Reserve agent and Class C director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will become today a general partner in the investment banking firm of R.W. Pressprich Co.

Brokers' loans, as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, rose $20,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $1,056,000,000, according to the condition statement of these banks issued yesterday.

Price movements were somewhat mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. The volume of trading generally was light. On the cash markets wheat, corn and silk rose, while cotton, rye, lard, butter and rubber declined.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 29, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,473,000,000, a decrease of $9,000,000 compared with the preceding week, and an increase of $5,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Real estate tax collections for the current year are almost $40,000,000 in excess of the taxes collected on the same date a year ago despite the fact that the 1936 real estate levy is $15,824,045.56 below that of a year ago, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced last night.

The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church announced yesterday at the end of a three-day quarterly meeting at the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue, that its campaign to avert a threatened missionary crisis had gone over the top 150 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- Breakfast every morning with Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and an icebox left unlocked at night "if they are young-looking" were promised today by the First Lady for the seven Alabama girl textile workers to be her White House guests all next week.
The dollar on the local foreign! exchange market, based on quota-] tions for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP). -- A home run by Bill Brubaker, subbing at third base, sent Pittsburgh on to a 6-to-5 triumph today over Philadelphia.
ADDIS ABABA, Friday, May 1. -- The Italians this morning occupied Debra Brehan, about seventy-five miles northeast of Addis Ababa, along a level road.

Semi-conscious and suffering from shock, Mrs. Marjorie Smith, 29-year-old mother of two children and wife of Harry Smith, salesman, was discovered about 7:30 o'clock last night lying in a closet of the Smiths' four-room apartment at 25 Vermilyea Avenue, near Dyckman Street.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States declared today that "in formulating and adopting resolutions a prime duty of the chamber is to furnish to business definite leadership, guidance and inspiration in the direction of developing practices which contribute to the increase of our national economic and social well-being."
Mayor La Guardia's Charter Commission has submitted a new city charter which the voters will never adopt. It wilt satisfy neither the taxpayers nor the politicians.

ROME, April 30. -- While the main Italian column advancing from Dessye was reported to have reached Cundi, about seventy-seven miles from Addis Ababa, General Rodolfo Graziani on the Ogaden front delivered a smashing blow to Has Nasibu's army, the last of six Ethiopian forces that took the field against Italy.

As the author of "Abie's Irish Rose" in 1922, Anne Nichols did more to discredit drama criticism than Dr. Sirovich. It behooves the scholarly profession, therefore, to proceed warily against "Pre-Honeymoon," which Miss Nichols has written in collaboration with Alford Van Ronkel, and which she caused to be exhibited at the Lyceum last evening.
CINCINNATI, April 30 (AP). -- Behind the five-hit pitching of Danny MacFayden, a former Red, the Bees defeated Cincinnati, 3 to 1, today to sweep the two-game series.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- The honking of automobile horns except "when reasonably necessary for the prevention of accidents" will be forbidden in Philadelphia by an anti-noise ordinance drafted by the County Medical Society and passed today by the City Council. Mayor Wilson is expected to approve it within the next two weeks.

The rally in share prices during the final hour yesterday was generally hailed as long overdue, but at any rate it arrested the decline and enabled the market to close higher for the first time this week. With leading issues up 1 to 6 points, THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks gained 2.10 points on the day, against a loss of 2.20 the day before, so that Wednesday's losses were virtually erased.

Sights and sounds of the frontier West filled a good part of the Pennsylvania Station a few minutes before 8 o'clock last night when the Texas Centennial Special with a delegation of 100, headed by the Governor of the State, pulled in as cowboy yells were sent up by about 500 native sons and city officials.

MONTREAL, April 30 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals won their home opening game today when Leon Chagnon pitched the International League pennant holders to an 8-6 victory over Albany for his third victory this season. The former Giant needed hitting help from his mates, who combined their blows for four runs in the fifth inning and three in the seventh.

The government suit accusing three of the leading motion picture groups of conspiracy to monopolize the industry was ended yesterday afternoon when Federal Judge John C. Knox signed an order sanctioning a stipulation whereby the producers promised that they would refrain from committing the acts charged.

TRENTON, N.J., April 30. -- In a letter to Howell Johnson, secretary of the Workers Alliance of New Jersey, Governor Harold G. Hoffman declared today that he could not, under the law, divert any more money from other State funds to relief.

BERLIN, April 30. -- The future of German exports, involving the fate of the German currency and the position of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, was left in the balance tonight after a meeting of the Reich Economic Chamber.

Those who will may rejoice with Governor LANDON in that "splendid Republican victory" won at the Massachusetts primary. Feeling hearts will mourn for the unexplained and unpardonable defeat of BEN BOICE, the gasoline station man of New Ashford. A small town in Berkshire County, but there are those who love it.
BALTIMORE, April 30. -- Mrs. A.S. Bowman's Genie Palatine, ridden by E. de Camillis, scored a well-deserved victory in the Equitable Purse, feature race today at Pimlico.
HANOVER, N.H., April 30. -- Dissolution of all national fraternity connections at Dartmouth was recommended to President Hopkins today by the Committee for the Survey of Social Life.
The country is "all set for a period of good sound business," Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday in issuing its report for the March quarter.

MOSCOW, April 30. -- Moscow's May Day tomorrow will be the gayest since the founding of the Soviet Union. More and more in recent years its character of a political demonstration has receded, or rather has come to be expressed more subtly and more cleverly, and it has progressively assumed an air of carnival.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- House consideration of the $3,000,000,000 Frazier-Lemke bill for farm mortgage refinancing was made certain today when signatures to a petition to discharge the Rules Committee reached the required total of 218.

Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, President-elect of Cuba, sailed for home yesterday on the United Fruit liner Peten, accompanied by a party of nine. From the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria a police escort of ten detectives under Captain Thomas Dugan of the alien squad accompanied him to the ship, where a large detail of policemen, detectives and Department of Justice agents was on hand.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 30. -- King Fuad, first King of an independent Egypt in modern times, was laid to rest today with a fitting Moslem ceremony at Al Rifai Mosque, where lie the forefathers of the Mohammed Aly dynasty.

PARIS, April 30. -- Pershing Hall, headquarters of the American Legion in France, was in a state of siege today. Late tonight four members of the Paris Post, who had resisted policemen with eviction orders all day, remained in control of the premises.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Adoption of resolutions declaring the administration's taxation program an attempt "to regulate the management of corporations" and denouncing the Social Security Act as an invasion of the rights and responsibilities of private industry closed the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States tonight.

Boston (Mass.) sold yesterday a new issue of $3,000,000 of notes to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Hemphill, Noyes Co., on a 1.20 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $35. The notes, which are dated May 4, and become payable on Nov. 6, were reoffered on a 0.80 per cent basis. Salomon Brothers Hutzler submitted the second highest bid of 1.28 interest basis, plus $13.
CHICAGO, April 30. -- A telegraph "grapevine," linking forty Chicago hotels in a new system designed to guard innkeepers against fraud, was pronounced a success today.

GENEVA, April 30. -- Public movies for children like public libraries were foreseen today by Dr. Edgar Dale of the Payne Fund of New York, who spoke as a movie expert to the League of Nations Child Welfare Committee.

The Washington of the United States Lines arrived at 12:05 this morning, more than twelve hours late due to high seas and to answering distress calls from other ships. Among the 703 passengers were Douglas Fairbanks and his wife, the former Lady Sylvia Ashley.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., April 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Scheepers gave a garden party this afternoon at Paradou, their place on the North Hempstead Turnpike, to more than 1,000 persons, several hundred of whom were members of the Garden Club of America and the Horticultural Society of New York.

Bank clearings declined in the last week of the month from the total of the preceding week. The aggregate for twenty-two leading cities in the United States for the week ended on Wednesday, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,152,120,000, compared with $6,011,214,000 for the same week of last year, a decrease of 14.3 per cent.

Purchase of a Washington Heights plot for improvement with an apartment building and deals involving various housing properties on the upper West Side and in Harlem featured Manhattan realty trading yesterday.
PARIS, April 30. -- More than 10, 000,000 Frenchmen voted ten different ways last Sunday, according to their choice and in the full exercise of their political liberty.

J.P. Morgan Co. and the National City Bank, fiscal agents for the government of the Argentine nation, announced yesterday that $486,521 would be available for the purchase of Argentine external 6 per cent bonds, issue of 1925, at flat prices below par until June 1.

Despite declines in security values since 1929, two trust funds set up by the will of the late Angler B. Duke for his two sons are now worth in principal and invested income twice their value at Mr. Duke's death, it was disclosed in an accounting filed yesterday in Surrogates' Court.
LONDON, April 30. -- Sir Herbert Austin, British motor manufacturer, has given 250,000 to the Cavendish Laboratory of Experimental Physics at Cambridge University.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 30. -- A free and untrammeled press, the more honestly critical the better, was urged here tonight as one of the best safeguards of the nation by Raymond Moley, appearing as a kind of unofficial spokesman for the Democratic administration at the annual dinner of the Whig-Clio Halls, Princeton's old and now united societies of debate.

BARTOW, Fla., April 30. -- The Tampa flogging trial, which has seen many pauses since the case was first called in that city on March 24, recessed today until Monday after a pointed hint from Judge Dewell that his patience with wordy objections and court-room oratory was about exhausted, and that from now on the case must be speeded up.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- Colonel Joseph I. McMullen, veteran officer in the Judge Advocate General's office, was convicted tonight of accepting compensation illegally from a private firm.
ALBANY, April 30. -- The Senate concurred today in the Assembly amendments to the bill reducing jury exemptions and sent the measure to Governor Lehman.

Last year in this city 608 persons were arrested on manslaughter charges in connection with automobile accidents. Only thirteen of the 608 were convicted, and only five of those convicted ever saw the inside of a prison. Juries simply will not find a man guilty on this charge, even when, as in all these cases, criminal negligence is alleged.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Wholesale prices softened slightly in the week ended on April 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average as 100, fell to 79.6, compared with 79.7 the week before and 80.3 on April 27, 1935.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The largest peacetime navy appropriation bill in history was reported by the Appropriations Committee to the House today, which began consideration of the measure, with passage planned for next week.

William Slockbower, wanted as a material witness in the government's case against John Torrio, described as the city's Public Enemy No. 2, surrendered yesterday to Isaac Platt, United States Commissioner.

A plan for settling the two-year mortgage strike of home owners in Sunnyside, Queens, was suggested yesterday in a letter sent to the owners by the Sunnyside Bondholders Protective Committee, of which Lawson Purdy is chairman.

ALBANY, April 30. -- The two houses of the Legislature passed today and sent to Governor Lehman for expected approval a series of measures empowering and establishing official State and city cooperation and financial aid for the World's Fair of 1939.

An increase of nearly a billion dollars in the operating expenses of railroads throughout the country would result from pending legislation sponsored by the twenty-one railroad unions, according to R.V. Fletcher, vice president and general counsel of the Association of American Railroads.
The story of Oscar Wilde's tour of the United States in 1882, "Oscar Wilde Discovers America," by Lloyd Lewis and Henry Justin Smith, will be published by Harcourt Brace on May 21.
LONDON, April 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

MAMARONECK, N.Y., April 30. -- Two young musicians, driving from Richmond, Va., to Dartmouth College without sleep or rest, swerved off the Boston Post Road at Delancey Avenue here at 6 o'clock this morning and knocked down a fire-signal standard, a letter box, an electric light pole and a metal sign.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 30 (AP). -- Baltimore scored a 5-3 victory over the Bisons in the opening game of the local season today. Two homers by Oscar Roettger and Roy Spencer. providing three runs, decided the issue.
LONDON, April 30. -- King Farouk, 16-year-old sovereign of Egypt, was received by King Edward today before the former left for Cairo to take over the throne of his father, the late King Fuad.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Finding that streamline trains are reclaiming "considerable passenger traffic" taken away by airplanes and motor transport, the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to issue $3,950,000 of equipment trust certificates so that it may add cars of that type.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 30. -- German students who come to this country with "certificates of political responsibility" are not desired at Williams College, President Tyler Dennett said tonight, disclosing that the institution's system of exchange scholarships would lapse in June.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 30. -- The fourth concert in the Eastman School Festival was given tonight in the Eastman Theatre by the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, Howard Hanson conducting.

" To My Husband" yesterday set back its opening date from May 16 to June 1, with rehearsals scheduled to begin between May 7 and 11. For testing purposes it will go to the Boulevard Theatre, Jackson Heights, the week of May 25. Gerald Kent has been added to a cast which already included Lenore Ulric and King Calder. . . .

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Uncertainty over the future of a secretly drafted bill which would virtually displace Rexford G. Tugwell's Resettlement Administration with a new and permanent corporation arose today in the wake of a White House conference.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- Paul A. Walker, communications commissioner, made a qualified prediction today that the commission's investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company might bring slashes in long-distance phone rates.

MONTREAL, May 1 (AP). -- Laurie Myllykangas recorded his fourth straight victory today as Montreal took its second game in a row from Albany, 5 -- 2. Both Albany runs came in the first inning when Catcher George Savino hit a homer after Smead Jolley had doubled.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1. -- Professor George Lyman Kittredge, a colorful figure who came to be an institution at Harvard University in the past half century, passed into the ranks of Harvard's retired scholars today.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway plans to spend $6,350,000 this year on deferred maintenance, additions and betterments, said a report issued yesterday by the committee for the company's first and refunding 4 per cent bonds and secured 4 1/2 per cent bonds.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 1. -- Dancing followed dinner tonight at the Greenbrier, climaxing the second day of the convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

Mrs. Edith Weed Bishop, daughter of a Connecticut banker, and estranged wife of Henry A. Bishop Jr., a broker, was sentenced to one to three years in the State Prison for Women at Bedford Hills by Judge Allen in General Sessions yesterday. She had pleaded guilty to stealing two antique tea sets, valued at $400, she had received on memoranda a year ago from the Robert Ensko Corporation at 682 Lexington Avenue.

The marketing of $110,000,000 of Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit securities, the largest block of securities to be floated so far under the Securities Act of 1933, lifted the total of new bond offerings this week to $237,315,000, making the week the second most active of the year to date.
LONDON, May 1. -- The Royal Academy's private view today, officially inaugurating the London season, was marked by the usual throngs of artists, statesmen and celebrities.

The Panama Pacific liner California, which was withdrawn from service for a single round trip six weeks ago as the result of a strike of her crew, is scheduled to sail at 11 A.M. today for the Panama Canal and the Pacific Coast.

He is the smallest regular on the team, one of the youngest and, beyond peradventure, the noisiest, with a piping tenor that is never stilled. But right now he is the biggest unit in a Yankee machine that is hitting on all six and rushing uphill at down-grade speed.
Mayor La Guardia reviewed the 369th Infantry Regiment of the New York National Guard last night in the regiment's armory, Fifth Avenue at 142nd Street.
Purchases of apartment houses to be remodeled featured the Brooklyn realty turnover reported yesterday.

Just what class-angle did the proletarian editors and news writers impart to New Jersey's recent Army of Un-Occupation? This was one of the names assumed by the unemployed men and women who camped for more than a week in the chamber of the lower house at Trenton.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP). -- The doctor whom Alvin Karpis kid napped in making his escape to the Midwest after shooting his way out of an Atlantic City hotel in January, 1935, was "relieved" tonight to hear the No. 1 bad man of the country had been captured.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 1. -- Four of the country's leading golfers -- Bobby Jones, Lawson Little, Horton Smith and Jimmy Thomson -- played an informal round on the Baltusrol Golf Club course today while camera men took pictures of their various shots and interrupted the play frequently.

If the Pennsylvania Railroad reduced the rent it is charging the Long Island Railroad for the use of Pennsylvania Station there would be no need for an increase in commutation rates, E.E. Williamson, transit expert, told Public Service Commissioner George R. Lunn and Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley yesterday at the twenty-fourth hearing on the application of the Long Island for an increase in commutation fares.

In your issue of April 27, where you report the activities of the Brooklyn citizens' patriotic May Day committee, you quote me as being opposed to the "demonstration on behalf of peace last Wednesday by the students of Brooklyn College." Your quotation is correct in every respect, but I do not want to have it believed that I am opposed to any demonstration on behalf of peace.

Mayor La Guardia proposed the use of the present court house of the Appellate Division, at Madison Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, as a municipal art center in an impromptu address yesterday at the 100th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs in the Hotel Astor.

Dun's index number of average commodity prices as of May 1, the first of the monthly numbers to be published, shows very slight fractional decline during April. The present index number is 1 5/8 per cent below that of a year ago; otherwise it is the highest May average since 1930.

The proposed tax on undistributed corporation profits is not the first measure of its kind ever to be discussed in Congress. Similar proposals have made their appearance in the past, and it is interesting to look at one of them which came nearest to success.

As a member of the great inarticulate, bipartisan group of Federal tax victims, I wish to commend your editorial "Tariff Subsidies" and its deserved and constructive criticism of the administration's eleventh-hour attempt to emasculate Senator Vandenberg's resolution for publicity respecting the beneficiaries of AAA gratuities.

MEXICO, D.F., May 1. -- Mexicans celebrated May Day by staging the greatest parade ever seen in this city. About 60,000 workmen and field laborers, men and women, filed through the principal avenues to the national palace, where Minister of Interior Barbo Gonzalez, acting for President Cardenas, watched them march past.

A moderate recovery movement developed yesterday among domestic corporation bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. There was a market decrease in the volume of trading, but this was considered to reflect a drying up of the recent liquidation rather than any spirited demand by investors.

CHATTANOOGA, May 1. -- Mumbling "I let him in the front door -- he said I'd left him -- said he'd come for me," Mrs. Eula Mae McConnell, 23-year-old mother of twins, died at Erlanger Hospital early this afternoon, the victim of a brutal beating which has mystified police.

To celebrate their causes as political and economic dissenters, Communists and Socialists of various gradations of revolutionary tendencies paraded yesterday for more than seven hours through the streets of midtown Manhattan, marking the fiftieth anniversary of May Day demonstrations.

By order of Mayor La Guardia, Johnny Torrio, so-called Public Enemy No. 2 of New York City, is to be arrested on a vagrancy charge if found in the city, though the courts have released him in bail totaling $104,000.

ROME, May 1. -- While the attention of all Italians is concentrated on East Africa, many newspapers are seriously disturbed by reports reaching Rome from Great Britain of an alleged recrudescence of the sanctionist campaign.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe approved yesterday an agreement for the continuation of the business of H.R. Mallinson Co., Inc., until Aug. 4 as a preliminary to a permanent reorganization plan which is expected to be evolved by that time.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 1. -- Mayor George J. Zimmermann of Buffalo was indicted today on charges that he made a pre-election "deal" to eliminate his most dangerous opponent by promising jobs in violation of the State law.

OTTAWA, May 1. -- The first budget of the new Canadian Government, presented today by Finance Minister Dunning, added several important concessions to those already given to American exporters by the recent Canadian-American trade treaty. It also imposed, chiefly by countervailing duties, new imposts which will nullify in a few respects the advantages of that treaty to the United States.

What this country now needs is "a clear definition of fair competition," according to Donald R. Richberg, former head of the NRA, addressing yesterday the closing session of a series of public hearings on pending legislation conducted here by the commerce committee of the American Bar Association.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- A warning on behalf of small business that the proposed tax on undistributed corporate profits would "freeze" the American corporate structure, preventing little companies from ever becoming large ones, was followed today by indications of a split among the Democratic forces of the Senate Finance Committee over President Roosevelt's tax program.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- President Roosevelt today ordered Robert Fechner, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, to conduct a publicity campaign to bring the corps to full strength, and extended the period of enlistment from April 30 to May 15.

DETROIT, May 1. -- Department of Justice agents and the State police forces of Michigan and Ohio joined tonight in a widening manhunt for five gunmen who scooped up $50,000 in a swift hold-up of a branch of the Detroit Bank and escaped with the largest such loot ever taken here.

Leasehold transactions yesterday included a lease of the five-story building at 16 East Fifty-seventh Street to the Valentine Gallery of Modern Art. The building, which has been the home of Frederick Keppel Sons in recent years, will be altered while Valentine Dudensing, president of the Valentine Gallery, is in Europ.

There is a difference of expert opinion as to the proper division of functions between the elective Controller and the appointive Treasurer in the new set-up suggested by the charter commission. The size of the proposed tax reserve has also been called in question, and doubts have been expressed regarding the precise extent of the authority which the City Planning Commission should exercise over appropriations for capital improvements.

Child Health Day, ushering in a period of health examinations in the schools of New York City, was celebrated yesterday morning as 150 children assembled on the steps of the new Department of Health Building, 125 Worth Street, and were reminded that health must be considered even before education.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the admission of Mrs. Margaret A.C. Riter as a special partner of Riter Co. and the retirement of Edward B. Condon from Condon, Proctor Co. and Percy Bullard from Filor, Bullard Smyth.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 1. -- Dr. Clark Wissler of Yale University said this afternoon at the annual meeting of the American Association of Physical Anthropologists that in his investigation of population profiles for American Indians the birth rate is now forty-eight per thousand, one of the highest in the world, and that the death rate, the peak of which was reached about 1890, has been steadily declining.
A fine of $250 for contempt of court was imposed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook on Adolph Austin, part owner of the Pine Tree Restaurant at 106 West Thirty-eighth Street.

TORONTO, May 1 (AP). -- Newark evened the series by beating the Maple Leafs, 4 -- 3, today. Whitey Wistert of Toronto allowed the Betrs seven hits, but his wildness proved costly. In the seventh inning he was removed in favor of George Murray.

One of the many sweet mysteries of this particular field of entertainment is why one week which follows another may be so different in the munificence of its offerings. This past week, for instance, has been as comparatively lacking in reportable events as the pages of a hermit's diary.

W.S. Beaver of Berwyn, Pa., regained the amateur doubles championship of America at clay targets over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The 1934 winner took the title with a total of 90 out of a possible 50 pairs.
PITTSBURGH, May 1 (AP). -- The Bees beat the Pirates today, 6 -- 4, aided by two long home runs by Gene Moore and seven innings of fine hurling by Wayne Osborne. Osborne was relieved in the eighth.

J.P. Morgan Co. is preparing a memorandum based on the testimony brought out at the recent hearings of the Senate Munitions Committee that will refute the insinuation that the United States was moved to enter the World War because of the financial and commercial interests involved.

Support of the members of the Women's National Republican Club in the fight to preserve the freedom of the press in the United States was asked last night by Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune. Colonel McCormick spoke at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and France was said by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to be in the final stage, as he received at his press conference a delegation of the Foreign Correspondents Association of New York, headed by Bernard Moloney, president of the association.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., May 1. -- Mrs. Carl H. Donner of Baltusrol, holder of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association closed championship, today won that association's opening one-day tournament of the 1936 season when she scored an 87 on the rugged Green Brook Country Club course.

NEWTON, Mass., May 1. -- A revamped Boston College baseball team won its first game in four starts by scoring a 5-2 decision over St. John's of Brooklyn at the Eagle's diamond on University Heights today.

John R. Crews, Brooklyn leader, was elected vice chairman of the executive committee of the Republican State Committee at a meeting Thursday night at the Metropolitan Club. The session lasted until early yesterday morning. Miss Natalie Couch of Rockland County also was elected vice chairman.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 1. -- Villanova bunched five of its nine hits in the third inning to score all its runs in a 6-to-1 victory over Cornell today. It was Villanova's seventh triumph of the season.

LOUISVILLE, May 1. -- Fifteen colt, two fillies and two geldings were named overnight for the $40,000 added Kentucky Derby, which will have its sixty-second running at Churchill Downs tomorrow before an expected crowd of 60,000 persons. If all nineteen start the race will gross $50,150.

Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the State Racing Commission, yesterday gave out a letter which he had written to State Senator John J. Dunnigan, who is sponsoring the pari-mutuel bill in the legislature with the support of the commission.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Flying down from New York, Amelia Earhart appeared today before Senator Copeland's air safety committee to testify in behalf of air pilots and the "humble inventors" of navigation aids, and to disagree with public opinion reflecting upon the integrity of the men in the air service.

The Society of Illustrators opened its thirty-second annual exhibition last evening with a reception in the Mezzanine Galleries of the R.C.A. Building, Rockefeller Center. The show contains 160 items, selected from more than 500 paintings, water-colors, etchings, pieces of sculpture and masks submitted to the jury by 275 members of the organization.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP). -- Pitcher Eldon Auker won his own ball game today, singling in the sixth to score Ray Hayworth with the run that clinched a 4-to-3 victory for the Tigers over the Athletics in the opener of a two-game series.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 1. -- The long-debated refunding agreement for paying on easier terms the nearly $3,000,000 defaulted portion of the $5,000,000 of county bonded debt was approved today by the Atlantic County Board of Freeholders.

TOKYO, May 1. -- Lieut. Gen. Kanichiro Tashiro has been appointed commander of the Japanese garrison in North China. He is the first lieutenant general to be named to this post, the importance of which has been increased by an imperial order providing that its occupant shall in the future be of a rank to which appointment is made directly by the Emperor.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The Union Pacific Railroad Company has called for redemption on July 1 its $26,835,000 of forty-year 4 1/2 per cent bonds at 102 1/2 and accrued interest. Payment will be made at the office of the company here.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Discovery of the existence within the hearts of atoms of a hitherto unknown cosmic force forty times greater than electricity, in fact the very force which holds the universe together and without which it would evaporate into a cloud of hydrogen gas, was reported here today before the American Physical Society by physicists of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court decided unanimously yesterday that Park Commissioner Robert Moses had authority to order the destruction of the Central Park Casino building. It reversed a decision by Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew restraining him from interfering with the building or its surroundings.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The legal battle in which the government is seeking to recover $3,089,261 in additional taxes and penalties from Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury, approached its conclusion today when briefs were filed with the Board of Tax Appeals by representatives of both sides.
MOSCOW, May 1. -- True to its practice in recent years, the Soviet Government used the May Day parade today to show foreign eyes some developments in its military establishment.

BERLIN, May 1. -- Germany's millions of workers celebrated May Day today in the now familiar fashion -- to the tramp of marching feet with mass singing, the music of countless bands and listening to speeches by their Fuehrer, by Colonel-General Hermann Goering and by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels with loud-speakers spreading them so all might hear.
BALTIMORE, May 1. -- The red, white and blue colors of Miss Ethel Hill were carried to victory by Deliberate in the Hill Top Purse, six-furlong feature today at Pimlico.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor for the last twelve years of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, Washington, D.C., known as "The Church of the Presidents," will begin his pastorate tomorrow at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, now know as "The Church in Rockefeller Center."

CINCINNATI, May 1. -- Expansion of Federal power to meet expanding national needs as fulfillment and not violation of the intention of the founding fathers, was declared today to be the most important of all the "emerging issues" presented for discussion at the concluding session of the National League of Women Voters convention.

THE TIMES article "Germany Opening Leaders' Schools" describes the attempts of the Nazis to build up a school for political leadership. The three schools just opened are depicted as a unique method in training the future leaders of Germany.

Regulation U, governing bank loans on registered stocks, went into effect yesterday. Comparatively few brokers' loans were made under the new rules because brokers had prepared in advance by increasing their loans before the regulation went into effect.

Eight men and a woman, previously arrested as members of a "little stock exchange" which dealt exclusively in stolen securities, were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges growing out of the theft of more than $2,000,000 worth from two banks.
A new biography of Queen Victoria, by Edith Sitwell, is to be published by Houghton Mifflin this Fall.
ALBANY, May 1. -- Governor Lehman demanded today in a special message to the Legislature a reapportioning of legislative and Congressional districts before the end of the current session.
James A. Ten Eyck, Syracuse's 84-year-old rowing coach, was honored by 200 admirers last night at a dinner tendered by the Syracuse University Club of New York at the Hotel New Yorker.

George Washington Hill, president of the American Tobacco Company, received in 1935 a salary of $212,199 and a bonus of $92,199, the annual report of the company, filed with the New York Stock Exchange in compliance with the Securities Exchange Act, disclosed yesterday. Mr. Hill got $120,000 in 1933 and $187,126 in 1934, according to reports of the Treasury Department.

R.C. Williams Co., Inc., wholesale distributors of grocery products, this month will observe the 125th anniversary of the organization of the business in this city. More than 400 Royal Scarlet Stores, privately owned, are enrolled under a voluntary plan put into effect by the company in 1929 to offer the advantages of mass buying and the exchange of mutually beneficial marketing data.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Despite a prediction by Speaker Byrns that the Frazier-Lemke $3,000,000,000 inflationary Farm Mortgage Bill would be defeated when it is called up on May 11 under a discharge petition signed by 218 members, other leaders on both sides asserted their belief tonight that "nothing but adjournment before that date" can forestall its passage in the House.
HWAIKING, Honan Province, China, May 1 (AP). -- Frightful famine conditions brought millions of Chinese peasants today to a choice between banditry and stoical waiting for death from starvation.
NEWMARKET, England, May 1 (AP). -- Tide-Way, brown daughter of Fairway -- Drift and owned by Lord Derby, ran off with the One Thousand Guineas, at one mile for 3-year-old fillies, today.

An authentic collection of historic bridal costumes was displayed at a May Day luncheon and fashion show held yesterday in the Garden and Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Entitled "Brides of Two Centuries," the event was in aid of two music funds -- the Lewisohn Stadium Concert Fund and Les Anciens Etudes du Conservatoire de Paris, the latter being established for worthy French artists of advanced years.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

CHEVY CHASE, Md., May 1. -- Another chapter will be added to the rivalry of the country's ranking doubles tennis teams tomorrow when Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn, the national champions, meet Donald Budge and Gene Mako in the final of the Chevy Chase Club invitation tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- President Roosevelt has approved plans for him to go to Philadelphia immediately after the Democratic National Convention to receive notification of his expected nomination for a second term as President, it was learned today.
CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP). -- Lee Grissom, lefthander, making his first start for the Reds, pitched Cincinnati to a 4-to-3 victory over Philadelphia today with the aid of some timely hitting.

A consolidated net income of $2,032,951 was reported yesterday by the Engineers Public Service Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, after all prior deductions, against $964,768 in the preceding twelve months. Annual preferred dividend requirements are $2,323,537.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- President Roosevelt approved a drive to increase enrollment in the CCC, agreed to a plan to go to Philadelphia immediately after his renomination to accept the honor officially, and stated at his press conference that he hoped for food and drug and ship subsidy legislation at this session of Congress.

The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the smallest for a month since last September but the largest for an April since 1933. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 39,616,438 shares, compared with 51,025,148 in March and 22,408,195 shares in the corresponding month in 1935.

Seven men and three women, members of the "arsenal gang" captured March 16 in a raid by detectives at a rooming house owned by one of the women defendants at 322 West Ninetieth Street, were found guilty yesterday in General Sessions of possessing one of the two machine guns seized in the place. It was the first conviction in this city under the recently enacted machine gun law.

Texas, "the country's economic frontier," is leading the nation out of the depression, Governor James V. Allred of the Lone Star State declared yesterday. The young Governor, here to publicize the Texas Centennial, urged New York bankers to increase their investments in "the land of unparalleled opportunity."

Stocks closed steady at irregularly higher levels yesterday, thus adding a little to the ground gained in the sharp recovery on the day before. Price movements were narrow most of the day, and the trading pace was greatly diminished. The volume on the Stock Exchange totaled 1,162,000 shares -- the smallest for a full day since April 17 -- compared with transactions of 2,309,000 on Thursday.

Murray Bleefeld, sought as a leader in the plot to kidnap Paul H. Wendel, disbarred Trenton lawyer, was arrested in Albany yesterday and was brought to Brooklyn late last night. He made a detailed confession of the facts and circumstances surrounding Wendel's detention, according to District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn.

Isaac Irving Kashdan of this city, New York State champion and one of America's foremost internationalists, seized the lead for the United States championship of the National Chess Federation at the Hotel Astor last night when he defeated Arnold S. Denker in their adjourned game from the fourth round after sixty moves.

A Spring Saturday morning is the sorrowful time when a fair share of this corner is given over to the obituaries of departing warriors. Come evening, six of them will fight their last battles and then depart into history, Cain's or the restlessness that precedes Summer stock in the rural theatres.
Results of operations in the first three months of this year were announced yesterday by four oil companies.

VIENNA, May 1. -- May 1, which is a national holiday under the present Austrian regime, passed quietly throughout the country. In Vienna there were several parades, but bad weather considerably reduced the attendance and marching of the patriotic organizations.

A number of noted figures in the world of music are listed among the passengers departing for Europe today on the French liner Champlain. They include Pierre Monteux, former conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, who will conduct the San Francisco Symphony next year; Otto Klemperer, German conductor; Miss Madeleine Monnier, French cellist, and Adolfo Betti, violinist.
The annual senior ball of the New York University College of Engineering was held last night in the Cascades Room of the Hotel Biltmore. More than 750 persons attended the affair.

LONDON, May 1. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin went today to Albert Hall to address a great demonstration of the Primrose League. Conservative organization founded to perpetuate the ideals of Disraeli.
ST. PAUL, May 1 (AP). -- The capture of Alvin Karpis in New Orleans tonight ended a man-hunt as extensive as that of his predecessor as "Public Enemy No. 1," John Dillinger.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1. -- In a notable competition, the brown gelding Woodfellow tonight captured the $250 hunter stake, leading event of the third session of the sixteenth annual Newark Horse Show in the Essex Troop Armory.

Dispatches from Europe in advance of the political demonstrations on the first of May gave this year a singular impression of restraint nearly everywhere. In Germany HITLER could not, of course, permit any of the old cries and demands which came from trade union and Communist workers. They have all been silenced temporarily.
NEW ORLEANS, May 1. -- Alvin Karpis, No. 1 bad man of the United States, was captured tonight without resistance by officers led by J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

CHICAGO, May 1. -- Weakness in Winnipeg and Liverpool and reports of additional rains in Eastern Kansas and Nebraska had a depressing effect on wheat markets in the United States today, and closing prices on the Board of Trade here were at net losses of 7/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel, with May leading.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

An initial appropriation of $308,020 to start actual work on the World's Fair site in Flushing Meadows was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate, following quickly upon the Legislature's approval of four enabling bills in Albany last Thursday.

While Ely Culbertson was expressing concern to Mayor La Guardia over the raid on the Lovejoy Bridge Studio last Tuesday in which Miss Mildred Lovejoy and Mrs. Adelaide Neuwirth were arrested for keeping a gambling house, the police paid an informal visit to the Crockford Club, 14 East Sixty-second Street, of which Culbertson is the founder and honorary president.
TOKYO, May 1 (AP). -- An extraordinary session of the Diet opened today, its principal task to approve the biggest budget in Japan's history, including the largest army and navy estimates.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP). -- The Senators inundated the Browns under a deluge of base hits in the first three innings today and scored by 17 to 1.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 1. -- Mrs. Jessie Gibson Haas, 45 years old, of 412 Saxon Woods Road, this city, wife of Louis G. Haas, private secretary to Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt, pleaded not guilty in county court this afternoon to four indictments charging grand larceny.
Houses in Brooklyn and Queens formed the bulk of projects for which building plans were filed yesterday. Details of the plans for the proposed structures follow:

New municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $10,697,363, representing sixty-three municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $31,327,463 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $24,100,014.

Department stores do not make wide use of the special services newspapers provide, according to the conclusion drawn by The Journal of Retailing of the New York University School of Retailing from a survey of 282 department stores in 123 cities. Of the total queried, sixty-nine replies were received.

TEN years ago a group of Minnesota farmers decided that they were paying too much for gas and oil. They raised $500 in capital and went into business for themselves. Today the Freeborn County Cooperative Oil Company is the largest distributor of petroleum products in the locality. It has accumulated assets totaling $125,000. It has paid back to consumer-members $250,000 in dividends.
BERLIN, May 1. -- The Boerse was closed today in observance of May Day.

In the inaugural matches of the Long Island interclub series, held by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Queens Valley Golf Club yesterday, the players from Women's National Golf and Tennis Club scored 8 points to 3 1/2 each for the Nassau Country Club and Piping Rock to top the Class A field.

TATUNG, Shansi Province, China, May 1. -- The Japanese contention that Communist agitators and propagandists are invading this area in large numbers apparently is not true. Drastic counter-measures have been adopted by Chinese authorities, who suspect the Japanese intention is to use these charges as a basis for new demands.

The Golden Hill Chorus, under the direction of Channing Lefebvre, gave its Spring concert last night in Carnegie Hall. William Towson Taylor, baritone, was the guest artist, and Grace Roberts the accompanist. The chorus is composed of 160 singers, most of whom are women employed in business in lower Manhattan.

With the selling price of May contracts above the average quotation for spot cotton in the South, pool brokers supplied the spot month on the Cotton Exchange yesterday to all buyers at 11.51 cents a point. Absence of rain in Oklahoma and an improvement in the stock market influenced sentiment and a recovery left the list with gains of 4 to 12 points.

Two recent groups of malicious crimes were believed to have been solved yesterday when a short, stocky little man with near-sighted eyes and a surprisingly placid expression admitted that he had set three of five fires which kept Bronx firemen on the run early April 19, and also that he had stabbed three young men in Bronx Park in the last two weeks.

Arthur G. Kuney, 50 years old, president of the defunct Commonwealth Bond Corporation at 74 Trinity Place, who lived at 112 East Fifty-fourth Street, was sentenced to Sing Sing for three to six years by Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday. A term of two to four years was imposed on Edward A. Sauter, 53, of 382 Eighth Street, Brooklyn, who was secretary and treasurer of the company.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 1. -- Repeal and its alleged results of "intolerable liquor conditions, of gambling and other vices," were brought to the attention of the general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in reports filed at the opening session here today.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Hearn Department Stores, Inc., of New York City filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for issuance of 45,000 shares of $50-par value 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock and 500,000 shares of $5-par value common stock, making a total of $4,750,000 par value, under a re-capitalization plan, and to increase working capital necessary for purchases of merchandise requiring increased funds at peak seasons.

Two little books, a hundred poems of which the longest is short, are the whole published works of ALFRED HOUSMAN in verse. Everything that came from him was mature, faultless, or mighty near it. The words are of the simplest. Long thought and consummate art might have left us cold if he had not been under the influence of "continuous excitement," as he said of the writing of "The Shropshire Lad."

While more seasonable weather conditions reacted favorably on nearly all branches of trade this week, the outstanding gain was in the wholesale markets, where the volume of buying was the best for the period since 1931, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

After many months of unrelenting pressure, inflationists in the House of Representatives have at last succeeded in mustering enough strength to force a vote on the long-pending Frazier-Lemke bill. This measure has been bottled up in the Rules Committee during the last two sessions.

GENEVA, May 1. -- A fairly complete report for February on sanctions, issued by the League of Nations today, shows Italy at the end of that month had lost $16,517,000, old gold value, from her gold reserve, instead of $5,813,000, as stated in previous reports.

Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Pelham Darlington gave a dinner last night at their home in Fanwood, N.J., for the Rev. and Mrs. Gilbert S.B. Darlington, Mr. and Mrs. John Moody, Mrs. Walter H. Close, Miss Dorothea Darlington and Captain Herbert B. Taylor.

JERUSALEM, May 1. -- A 14year-old Arab youth was killed and another Arab succumbed to his injuries as the result of police firing into a crowd of about 2,000 Arabs marching in a demonstration at Haifa today. Fifteen others were injured and sent to hospitals.

The Blue Ridge Corporation, an investment trust, will report today net assets on March 31 of $45,938,986, equivalent to $106.45 a share of preference stock, and after allowing for this stock at $55 a share and accrued dividends, to $2.95 a share of common stock.

ALBANY, May 1. -- Charging that the Roosevelt administration was taxing New York and other Eastern States to build up political machines in the West and South Senator George R. Fearon introduced a resolution in the Upper House today to memorialize Congress for a "more equitable" distribution of Federal tax receipts.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 1 (AP). -- Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation, told advertising agency representatives here today that both business and politics "have got to know more about economics in the coming years."

LANSING, Mich., May 1 (AP). -- Howard C. Lawrence, chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, said tonight that Senator Vandenberg had authorized the presentation of his name for the Presidential nomination at the Republican National Convention.
ALBANY, May 1. -- Governor Lehman issued a proclamation today setting aside the week of May 2 to 9 as "Boys and Girls' Week." He wrote:

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- New charges that publication of salary lists of persons who received more than $15,000 annually aided racketeers and underworld characters were made in the House today by Representative Bacon of Westbury, L.I., who read a letter from a Washington firm in which a list was offered to "high type" clients for $50.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 1. -- Unless relatives can be located, the Yonkers Lawyers Association will pay for the burial of Dr. Samuel Whitney Dunscomb Jr., authority on bankruptcy law, attorney, Doctor of Philosophy, author and once a member of many legal and scientific organizations.

The value of the collateral securing the Alleghany Corporation's $31,466,000 of convertible 5 per cent bonds of 1944 was appraised yesterday at 164 per cent of their face value and the value of the collateral behind the corporation's $21,938,000 of 5s of 1949 was set at 142 per cent of their face value by the Guaranty Trust Company, trustee for Alleghany bond issues.

MUNICH, May 1. -- It was an account in a Neu-Ulm newspaper of the funeral of a functionary "overtaken by death in the service of the fatherland" that led to the revelation of an air crash a week ago in which eleven persons were killed. Mention of the disaster by the press or over the radio had been suppressed, in conformance with Nazi policy, "in the interests of air-mindedness."

Governor LEHMAN addressed to the Legislature yesterday a renewed plea for reapportionment. As every one knows by this time, reapportionment of both Congressional and legislative districts is long overdue. It is also well understood that the reasons for the delay are exclusively political.

A group of labor unions and the Old Guard of the Socialist party celebrated May Day yesterday with a rally and open-air festival at the Polo Grounds that attracted a crowd estimated by the police at 45,000.
ADDIS ABABA, May 1. -- Citizens of Addis Ababa were preparing tonight to make a last stand against the advancing Italian columns which were slowly pressing down toward this capital.

Aided by more favorable weather conditions, retail trade in the metropolitan area made a better showing during the week. Executives here estimated the gain at about 3 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Apparel and accessories met a better consumer demand, while there was some increase in the buying of home furnishings for warm-weather use.

BOSTON, May 1 (AP). -- Invincible Lefty Grove turned in his fourth brilliant victory of the season today when the league-leading Red Sox blanked the Indians, 6 -- 0, before a ladies' day crowd of 20,000.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman, of the Securities and Exchange Commission until Sept. 20 last, when he resigned, has become special adviser to Paramount Pictures, Inc., the directors of the company announced yesterday.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Annual reports filed by corporations with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, showed that Joseph Wilshire, president and director of Standard Brands, Inc., and subsidiaries, received in 1935 remuneration of $152,689; Paul W. Fleischmann, vice president of the company and subsidiaries, $60,029, and Hugo A. Oswald, secretary and treasurer, $60,740.
Tottenville High scored its sixth straight triumph yesterday by downing the Textile nine, 16 -- 6, at Mount Loretto Field, S.I. The game was a Lower Manhattan-Richmond Division P.S.A.L. contest.

The Appellate Division decided yesterday that the City of New York has no power to tax the Chrysler Building property on land owned by Cooper Union. The court acted under a decision by the Court of Appeals more than thirty years ago when an earlier assessment of the land was stricken from tax roils.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1. -- Paced by the brilliant three-hit pitching of Ambrose Murray, Brown crushed Columbia, 10 to 0, today for the Bruins' sixth triumph in seven games. The fine hurling of the star southpaw, coupled with sensational fielding by Brokaw and Elrod, held the Lions completely in check and only thirty batters faced Murray. He did not issue a pass.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1, -- The opening gun of another Harvard rowing season will sound tomorrow when the varsity shells of Harvard, M.I.T. and Princeton start from Cottage Farm Bridge. Princeton and M.I.T. already have raced, but the Crimson will get its first taste of victory or defeat in the Compton Cup Regatta on the Charles River.

LONDON, May 1. -- Emperor Haile Selassie's British advisers are reported here to have been instrumental in persuading him to make Ethiopia's new temporary capital at Gore, in the unoccupied country west of Addis Ababa.

BOSTON, May 1. -- What the latest America's Cup defender's masts will be like was disclosed today when the sections of the new steel "sticks" for Harold S. Vanderbilt's defender Rainbow and Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee were laid out in the spar shed of the Lawley Shipyard in Neponset, on Dorchester Bay.
