CHICAGO, May 1. -- Little change was shown in the market for hogs here today, although the top was off 5 cents a hundredweight from yesterday at $10.60. The day's average was unchanged at $10.20. Offerings were small. Most sales were at $9.85 to $10.45.

IT has rained on many a Derby Day since, but they had fine weather for it back in 1875 when the news that came from Churchill Downs, in a few mild paragraphs, was that Price McGrath's chestnut colt, Aristides, had won the first running of the Kentucky Derby from a field of fifteen starters.

Irregular price movements were still in evidence on the local commodity markets yesterday. Rubber, cocoa and cottonseed oil were firmer, and sugar, coffee, silk and hides easier. The trading was light. On the cash markets, cotton, lard, oats, cocoa and tin rose, and wheat, corn and hides declined.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 1. -Ex-President Solorzano had lived in San Francisco since leaving Nicaragua until last year, when he moved to Costa Rica. He was elected President for the 1925-29 term, but had served only a little more than a year when he and Vice President Sacasa were ousted by General Emiliano Chamorro, Conservative, early in 1926.
BEAUFORT, N.C., May 1. -- North Carolina's first State park was formally opened today at old Fort Macon on the eastern tip of Bogue Island, adjacent to Beaufort Inlet.

Contract for alterations to the offices and showrooms in 110-14 E. 24th St. and 315-21 4th Av. has been awarded by the Jacob Ruppert Realty Corp., owners, to the Robert E. Orr Co., according to Brown's Letters, Inc., construction reports. Plans for the changes, estimated to cost about $50,000, have been prepared by Frank S. Parker, architect.

ROME, May 1. -- General Rodolfo Graziani, pressing with characteristic speed and vigor the advantage gained by his victories at Sasa Baneh and Bullaleh, has occupied Daggah Bur. This is believed to remove the last obstacle barring his way to Jijiga and Harar.

Louis Silver, 45 years old, of 860 South Eleventh Street, Newark, N.J., general manager of the Empire State Brewery in Brooklyn, and said by the police to be a former associate of Johnny Torrio, former Chicago racketeer, was shot and seriously wounded last night at Broadway and Sixty-first Street.

My valued friends and former associates in the Pennsylvania Railroad Company were much too modest when they chose to celebrate the ninetieth anniversary of the charter of that organization on April 13, 1936.

" What is a yacht?" is the question posed by "A.D." in a letter last week, and then by some curious, grotesque, haphazard philology, he proceeds to arrive at a devious answering that makes motor boatmen laugh at him, not with him.

Realty deals announced yesterday indicated a continuance of the good demand for housing properties in Manhattan that has marked recent trading. The day's activity covered a wide area and included transactions in the Chelsea and Yorkville sections, in Harlem and on Washington Heights.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The largest peace-time Naval Supply Bill ever put forward, carrying $531,068,707 in new funds and conditional authorization for the construction of two new superbattleships, was passed by the House today after it crushed by a 212-to-73-vote a move to strike out the capital-ship clause.

I have been a close student and follower of our great game of baseball for more than fifty years and that is going back into the past -- plenty. Consequently, when I read John Kieran's column on "All in a Family" recently I was deeply interested because I remember all the players he mentioned.

LONDON, May 1. -- The London Stock Exchange operated today in a brighter atmosphere, largely the result of yesterday's rally in Wall Street, but business remained small owing to the end of the account. British funds were steadier. In the foreign department French issues strengthened and the German group went lower.
Several housing and industrial deals in Queens were reported yesterday.
ROCHESTER, May 1 (AP). -- Bob Weiland shaded Hy Vandenberg in a brilliant pitching duel today as the Red Wings inaugurated their home season with a 1-0 decision over Syracuse.

ST. LOUIS, May 1. -- Casey Stengel shifted his batting order today, resorted to the extreme of putting Big Babe Phelps in right field in place of Oscar Eckhardt in an effort to add punch, and succeeded only in seeing his young men punched dizzy by fourteen Cardinal base hits, while Dizzy Dean held the Dodgers to three to shut them out, 12 -- 0.

New York University's annual varsity show entitled "Bric-a-Brac," attracted an audience of more than 1,000 undergraduates and friends of the university last night at the Manhattan Opera House, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

PARIS, May 1. -- The siege of Pershing Hall continued throughout the day without decisive action. While the four volunteers who are holding the fort against eviction remained in possession tonight, their comrades who had gathered outside decided to make no attempt to force their way past the doors guarded by the police.

Recommendations that news photographers who "violate standards of decency and courtesy" be ostracized by the newspapers and that their names be submitted to the public by the police were made yesterday in a letter to Police Commissioner Valentine by Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia School of Journalism.

A common prayer for victims of persecution throughout the world will be offered today in synagogues, and tomorrow in churches. In many churches in this city and throughout the United States there will be sung tomorrow compositions by Charles Henry Doersam, warden of the American Guild of Organists.

The Board of Estimate instructed Corporation Counsel Windels yesterday to begin immediate court action to test the validity of the perpetual franchise under which the New York and Queens Transit Corporation operates its street car line from Flushing and College Point, Queens, to Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Greenwood County, S.C., today entered the legal controversy over the right of the government to finance publicly owned hydroelectric plants in competition with private enterprise, asking the Supreme Court to dismiss an appeal filed by the Duke Power Company attacking the constitutionality of PWA loans for such plants.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 1. -- Senator Daniel O. Hastings, sharp critic of the New Deal, is reported to be scheduled to retire to private life because he has been refused a renomination by the du Pont forces which elevated him politically six years ago.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to unlisted trading Acme Wire Company voting trust certificates for the common stock, terminating on May 1, 1939. Certificates under the voting trust agreement ended yesterday have been removed from trading.

TRENTON, N.J., May 1. -- The bills adopted by the Legislature Wednesday night to abolish the State Emergency Relief Administration and convert the present State House Commission into the State Financial Assistance Commission to disburse relief funds have not yet been signed by Governor Hoffman.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 1. -More than any other amateur performance seen in Princeton for several years, the production of Henrik Ibsen's "Peer Gynt" in McCarter Theatre this evening by the Princeton Theatre Intime and the Finch School dramatic department deserved to be called drama.

Short casts: Carl W. Shattuck, secretary of the New Jersey State Federation of Sportsmen's Club, points out that Connecticut and Rhode Island are not the only Eastern States that have sponsored legislation for protection of the striped bass.

Arturo Toscanini, whose avoidance of press interviews is well known, departed from this custom yesterday and issued a statement in which he expressed deep gratitude for his association with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, its board of directors and the music public.

Between 6,000 and 7,000 miners who went on strike in more than half a dozen anthracite collieries in Pennsylvania because they were uninformed of the truce arranged Thursday night by operators and union's representatives negotiating for a new contract here, were ordered back to work yesterday by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 1. -- The Housatonic River a few miles above this city took on mid-season rowing flavor today. Yale's boat-house above Derby was alive with shells and only a stubborn upstream breeze bothered the oarsmen of the Elis, Pennsylvania and Columbia as they went through final workouts for tomorrow's Derby day, of which the Blackwell Cup race for the varsities is the feature.

Reporting for the first time to the New York Stock Exchange on the assents to the reorganization of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, George H. Houston, president, announced yesterday that holders of 32.2 per cent of first mortgage 5 per cent bonds, 40.9 per cent of 6 per cent consolidated mortgage bonds, 35.7 per cent of preferred stock and 15.7 per cent of the common stock had approved the plan.

In view of business in sight, the J.G. Brill Company should have no difficulty in obtaining banking accommodation, Charles J. Hardy, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. The company is controlled by the American Car and Foundry Company.

The Jamaica Handicap at six furlongs, with $4,000 added, will be revived at Jamaica today after a lapse of three years and will bring together two of to the outstanding sprinters in the country in Pat Kenebel kamp's King Saxon and George D. Widener's Sation, among others to a field of nine.

MACFUD, Ethiopia, on the Road to Addis Ababa, May 1. -- New light was thrown on Emperor Haile Selassie's movement today when thirty chieftains presented themselves at this important encampment with their followers to submit to the Italians.

In one of the best exhibitions of speed that New York racegoers have been treated to in a long time, George D. Widener's Sation captured the revived Jamaica Handicap at Jamaica yesterday and thrilled a crowd of 15,000 spectators as he finished four lengths in front of victor Emanuel's Miss Merriment, with the Greentree Stable's Plat Eye third in a field of seven.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- There is no particular harm in the present pastime of interpreting Pennsylvania's primary election results in the light of next November unless the interpreters take themselves too seriously. In that case, November may bring disappointments.

TORONTO, Ont., May 2. -- With the reopening of the Summer flying season in Canada within three weeks, the greatest activity in prospecting and mining development in Canadian mining history is expected by government and airways officials.

Mrs. Estelle M. Sternberger, executive director of World Peace-ways, warned 500 members of the Women's American ORT at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor against letting peace become "a commodity for export only."

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today by the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway for authority to extend for two years the maturity of a $5,000,000 note due on Aug. 1 to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

LONDON, May 2. -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia suddenly fled his stricken country today with the Italian invaders almost at the gates of his capital and with a revolt of local chieftains barring his escape to the western provinces.

ANOTHER milestone has been passed in the spectacular development of modern Palestine. Jerusalem is about to have an up-to-date and adequate water supply system. Thus the Holy City will enter upon a new phase of its varied life -- a phase that promises an acceleration of progress at an unprecedented pace.

TRADITION says that Dick Whittington's cat played a leading part in making its owner Lord Mayor of London. From the same source springs the story that it was the prophecy of a street phrenologist that helped make Herbert Morrison chairman of the London County Council, an office of more importance, though decorated with less gold braid, than that of Lord Mayor.

The Carnegie Corporation has awarded scholarships in New York University's Graduate Department of the Fine Arts to 103 teachers of art and museum staff members in the New York area, according to announcement yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university.

Citing the ancient but substantial Bowne house in Flushing as an example of durable construction which might wisely be followed by present-day builders, John Halleran, Flushing realty broker, declares that a good house is an asset for the owner, the person holding the mortgage, the broker and also for the neighborhood.

To the accompaniment of a thirteen-gun salute and the ruffle of drums, Major Gen. Frank Moss McCoy assumed command yesterday morning of the Second Corps Area, succeeding Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, who retired on Thursday at the age of 64.
Real estate tax collections for the first-payment period this year totaled $209,411,121.64, a sum $21,094,830 in excess of similar payments in 1935, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, May 2 (AP). -- A project for the distribution of 4,000,000 acres of land among Paraguayan peasants was approved today by President Rafael Franco of Paraguay, said dispatches from Asuncion tonight.

LOUISVILLE, May 2. -- Bold Venture's victory in the Kentucky Derby today was due to three things in the opinion of Max Hirsch, the man who saddled the Morton L. Schwartz's 3-year-old. He was a fit horse, Ira (Babe) Hanford rode an intelligent race and (Hirsch smiled as he said this) Mrs. Hirsch was seeing her first Derby.

DURING election time in France there are always huge pilgrimages into Paris. The boulevards leading to the Place de la Bastile, long the rallying place of revolutionary France, are filled with marchers: men with berets and neck scarfs typical of workers: women with shawls and clochepaille hats.

Accurate deductions concerning human driving weaknesses will be sought by Harvard University at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, beginning tomorrow. More than 25,000 automobile drivers will be used as laboratory material in the survey, which will employ new scientific equipment, and is expected to continue for two months.

THE action of this exciting adventure novel begins without preamble, and with immediate sustained hold upon one's interest, in the ancient Cambodian city of Angkor, where a party of round-the-world tourists have halted their itinerary to view the famous ruins of the Buddhist temples.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Relief projects for airport development are now being approved at the rate of more than one a day, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, reported today. The number of such projects for which relief funds have been allocated increased from 410 to 461 between Feb. 15 and March 31.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 2. -- Miss Marie Bohan of 1,545 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx, a senior, has been elected May Queen of the College of New Rochelle. She will hold court on Mission Day, May 9, on the campus. Miss Bohan was also adjudged the most beautiful senior by her classmates.
The Southern Women's National Democratic Organization, intent on raising a political war chest for the Fall election, opened a drive yesterday for old gold, silver or any other precious metal.

Due to an unusually heavy schedule of meetings, little time has been alloted to social activities in the five-day program of the sixteenth annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, opening tomorrow at the Jefferson Hotel in Richmond, Va.
AT last the chess masters have come to Times Square. In the Astor grill, where usually saxophones moan and corks pop, bishops now glide, pawns queen and mates threaten in the night.

THE woodsfolk of modern Norway, as they appear in this picturesque novel, are the spiritual inheritors of the Angle and the Saxon. They are a primitive, traditional people, melancholy and grim of nature as the bleak moors and endless forests can make them.

TARPON are beginning to run again in Florida waters, and anglers from many parts of the United States are arriving to join natives in what salt-water fishermen generally regard as the most exciting season of all.

KANSAS CITY, May 2. -- J. Edgar Hoover took a "cage" for Alvin Karpis with him when he went to New Orleans to arrest the outlaw. The "cage" was the fourteen-passenger plane used to fly karpis to St. Paul today after the arrest of the notorious criminal.

AGAINST CANCER: The Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, founded in New York in 1884 as the first special cancer hospital in the country, received last week a gift of $3,000,000 from the General Education Board, a Rockefeller charity.

Plans for the national lacrosse tournament at Riverdale School, 252d Street and Riverdale Avenue, next week-end are pretty well completed, and all that is needed now, according to Miss Martha Butler, president of the New York association and organizer of the tournament, is "a little really good luck with the weather."

MORNING-GLORIES are glories-of-the-morning -- all that the name indicates. But few plants are so persistent and farmers do not appreciate them in the wild state. Cutting is no discouragement. From underground roots they pop up somewhere else, and live on as peacefully as if they believed they added to the enjoyment of a farmer's life!

FLYING down to Rio" for a change of air or "flying up to New York" to take in a Broadway show is now such a common occurrence that occasionally one misses a friend for a fortnight, and on meeting him again he nonchalantly remarks: "Since I last saw you two weeks ago I have been to New York and back."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 2. -- National Music Week will be celebrated in Westchester County with a variety of musical entertainment. Its observance will start tomorrow with a concert at 3:30 P.M. in the Wood Auditorium, Mount Vernon, under the direction of the music division of the Works Progress Administration.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2. -- All kinds of business showed a tendency to improve during the past week on the Pacific Coast. The stock markets were, of course, weak in sympathy with the big board in New York. Bonds were also very quiet, although offerings of new issues were well taken.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Senator Vandenberg reiterated to newspaper men today that "I have not sought" the Republican Presidential nomination and "shall not do so."

AVON, Conn., May 2. -- The lambing season got in the way of plans for a sheep-shearing contest on the grounds of Avon Old Farm School here today, but the contest was held anyway -- to the manifest discomfort of some of the participants, human as well as animal.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 2. -- Navy, defeated by Columbia two weeks ago, came back into the high circles of college rowing today when it won from Cornell in three of four races rowed in rough water on the Severn. The Ithacans scored a decisive victory in the first contest, the race between the 150-pounders.

ALTHOUGH trade reports were somewhat spotty for the week, there was improvement in sections which had previously been backward. This was particularly true of the New England area. In the Middle West gains ran about 10 per cent over a year ago.

TRANSATLANTIC flying is here -- not just the daring hops of some trail-blazing pioneer, but, for this Summer at least, regular scheduled travel through the skies above the stormy North Atlantic, skies which have the reputation for carrying more bad storms in a twelvemonth than any other corresponding region over the earth's surface.

THE reader's first impression, from this book, is of its author's deep love for Alaska. It is, evidently, his own country, and what he feels for it is a passionate localized patriotism. And the reader's attention is held next by Mr. Hellenthal's complete and bitter dissatisfaction with what the United States Government has done in the Alaskan Peninsula.
SEA ISLAND, Ga. As the Summer season replaces that of Winter here and on the neighboring resort island on St. Simons, golf and shooting tournaments have become the center of sports interest.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- To the State from which Calvin Coolidge went to the Presidency, Governor Landon of Kansas owes the strongest certification of the nation-wide appeal of his candidacy he has yet received. Massachusetts Republicans, although they numbered less than a fourth of their voting eligibles, gave him a 10-to-1 lead over other Republicans considered for the party's Presidential nomination by writing in Mr. Landon's name in the State preferential primaries this week.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 2. -- The American flag alone will fly over Puerto Rican public buildings, Acting Governor Jose Padin asserted today, calling attention to the fact that as a result of the Tydings Plebiscite Bill some individuals had acted as though the bill already had become a law in full effect.

THE twelfth annual Westchester Music Festival will be held under the direction of Hugh Ross, this Friday and Saturday nights, at the County Center, White Plains. At the first concert the festival chorus of 500 will be assisted by Ruggiero Ricci, violinist.

CLEVELAND, May 1. -- When you motor to Cleveland this Summer for the Republican Convention, or the Great Lakes Exposition, or the American Legion doings, please remember that whenever you desire to make a left turn you must pull way over to the right, stop, and wait for the light or the semaphore to turn.

FLOWER borders are often enhanced by a low edging of annuals, either using one variety for a continuous ribbon effect, or combining a number of varieties. This latter practice of planting a mixed "bouquet" of small annuals of softly blended colors and prettily contrasting forms often produces a very pleasing effect.

THE curious thing about ruddy, silver haired Fred Stone is that after fifty years in the show business, thirty-five of them along Broadway, he still retains the unmistakable accent and idiom of the prairie.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Ushering in a schedule of early season convention activities, this resort, during the coming weeks, will entertain more than 100,000 members of various organizations listed to meet here.

Persistency throughout two long sessions of the sixth round at the Hotel Astor enabled Isaac I. Kashdan. New York State champion, to maintain his hold on first place in the United States title chess tournament yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Retail trade was a little slower in the week just ended, while wholesale dry goods houses reported a sharp upturn in sales. The larger department stores showed a gain of around 10 per cent for the week, compared with last year.

FOR the ninth time since 1900 Bryn Mawr College next Friday and Saturday will hold its quadrennial celebration of May Day in the Elizabethan manner. Once again on its campus greenswards white oxen will draw the flower-bedecked Maypole, and "Queen Elizabeth" will view the antics of country folk, acrobats and actors in sixteenth century plays.

SOME confusion must exist in the minds of those who have been following the recent fortunes of the first edition of the earliest English translation of "The Swiss Family Robinson." This scarce book has made no fewer than five public appearances in the salesrooms here and in London within two months, beginning with the one sold at the American Art Anderson Galleries March 12.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- The largest amount of building here is reported for April within four years permits having been issued for 773 operations to cost $3,700,000. Five new school buildings will cost nearly $2,000,000. May opens with no cessation in requests for permits.

In a setting of Spring flowers a luncheon, fashion show and card party in behalf of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will be held on Tuesday at the formal opening of the Park Lane Gardens of the Park Lane. The latest costumes and millinery for Spring and Summer will be displayed by a group of young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons.

A SELECTIVE exhibition of prints by three outstanding French sculptors, Rodin, Maillol and Despiau, has been assembled and arranged by Curator Carl O. Schniewind in the Print Gallery of the Brooklyn Museum. The prints reveal an aspect of these artists less well known in this country than their sculpture.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- The investment banking firm of Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. of New York urged the Supreme Court today to refuse to pass on an appeal brought by a Swiss corporation, Uebersee Finanz-Korporation Aktien Gesellschaft, in its effort to keep the United States from seizing its gold in this country, valued a $1,250,000.

MR. JOHNSON, planning his Spring season of opera at the Metropolitan, has remarked that he will attempt certain revivals, such as that of Gluck's "Orfeo"; at least a novelty, in the instance of Richard Hageman's "Caponsacchi"; a production in English of Smetana's "Bartered Bride," which is a delightful opera, but that he will place his faith principally upon opera of the traditional repertory.

ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP). -- Two California psychiatrists reported to the American Association on Mental Deficiency today that 23,166 persons have been sterilized so far in twenty-eight States legalizing such procedure for the feeble-minded.

The Panama-Pacific liner California, which had sailed at 11:08 o'clock yesterday morning on her first trip after a six-week lay-up due to labor troubles, turned around outside this port and returned to New York harbor early this morning. She reached her pier at 3 A.M.

BECAUSE a succession of droughts and sand-storms had ruined his grazing land in the Mesa Grande country, turning it into a desert, Brand Falconer decided to abandon the ranch and take his finely bred horses and cattle and all he possessed down into Mexico to the big ranch called the Hacienda Encantada which had been left to him by an older brother.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 2. -- Walter (Shanty) Fuchs was victorious in a pitchers' duel with Stretch Kirley on Weston Field today, enabling Williams to down Vermont, 2 -- 1.

CAIRO, May 1. -- The passing of Fuad I, the first King of modern Egypt, closed a stormy reign marked by repeated clashes between a strong-willed monarch, the British authorities who put him on his throne and leaders of a rapidly rising nationalist movement.

Manhattan College's fourth annual Campus Day exercises are expected to attract a crowd of more than 1,500 this afternoon. An elaborate program has been arranged by the class of 1937 under the direction of William J. Myhan, general chairman.

WHEN the Republican delegates meet in June to select a Presidential candidate, they will have before them a list of possibilities who, if they could be blended into one, would undoubtedly make one of the greatest Presidents this country has ever seen, but who, taken individually, have as yet failed to arouse the nation.

The annual Spring fete and bazaar of St. James Church, which will be held on Thursday in the main ballroom of the Plaza, has received a large advance patronage from many members of society who have taken tables and boxes. Entertainment, both for children and their elders, is planned for the event, which will benefit the children's missionary work of the church.

BERLIN, May 2. -- Col. Gen. Hermann Goering agreed in the course of a talk with Dr. Hjalmar Schacht today to use only a small corps of adjutants as a connecting link with Ministries and departments under his new office as commissar in charge of raw materials and foreign exchange problems.

Several prominent clubwomen and a motion-picture executive will speak at the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the board of the Evelyn Goldsmith Home for Crippled Children on Wednesday at 2:30 P.M. at the Hotel Biltmore. The president, Miss Evelyn M. Goldsmith, will preside.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 2. -- Twenty-nine nationally prominent figures have already accepted invitations to participate in the first annual Princeton-Harvard-Yale conference on public affairs, to be held here on Friday and Saturday, it was announced today by Joseph L. Broderick, Princeton junior, who is chairman of the executive committee.

MINISTER for thirty years at the Temple Emanu-el in New York and famous Jewish scholar and priest, Rabbi Gustave Gottheil not only "left his mark upon the religious life of his day," as this book points out, but was, in the words of Rabbi I.S. Moses, "a welcome and respected spokesman of Jew and Judaism whenever and wherever an official word needed speaking."

GRADUATION is synonymous with Spring. All over the country girls blossom into white. Youth carols its class song, orates, receives its diplomas. On such a conspicuous occasion girls must look their best.
WHENEVER a resume of past activities is undertaken and the list of sets put aside for particular commendation examined one is struck by the predominance of chamber music albums in the accumulation.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Evacuation of Addis Ababa and the sacking of the city by a mob amid scenes of death and destruction were reported to the State Department today in a series of cryptic but highly descriptive messages from Cornelius Van H. Engert, the United States Minister Resident.
PARIS, May 2 (AP). -- The French Foreign Office received a message today from Addis Ababa which reported the palace of Emperor Halle Selassie had been pillaged.

The Yankees made a couple of costly mistakes yesterday and snapped their winning streak at five straight while a crowd of 24,000 looked on gloomily. What is more, the Yanks earned the questionable distinction of being the team against which the White Sox snapped out of the doldrums after dropping eight in a row.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Spring weather has turned the Poconos, playgrounds of Pennsylvania, into a bower of buds and early Spring flowers and the entire resort area is preparing for an active season. All of the larger hotels are open, and many guests are enjoying the trout fishing.

DURING the celebration of the thirteenth National Music Week, which starts today, many of the mass activities throughout the country will be devoted to the furtherance of American music, which is the keynote of this far-flung observance.
Joseph Hiestand, a Hillsboro (Ohio) farmer, successfully defended the amateur trapshooting championship of America at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 2. -- Many visitors have been lured to the Berkshire Hills by Summer weather. At the St. Lawrence Inn, Lenox, are Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Walker, Mr. and Mrs. C. Maury Jones, and Miss Shirley R. Jones of New York, and Mr. and Mrs. Melville D. Truesdale of Greenwich, Conn.

A PERSISTENTLY reminiscent spirit haunts the twentieth annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists at the Grand Central Palace (on through May 17). Many of the older men, some of whom had not shown there for years, sent pictures, while to a group of American artists no longer living informal memorial honors have been paid.

Supreme Court Justice James T. Hallinan urged more than 1,200 mothers at the seventeenth anniversary luncheon of the Queensboro Federation of Mothers Clubs yesterday in Manhattan to "teach our children a love of America" and to spread that sentiment particularly among foreign-born families seeking citizenship.

A general policy of barring families that can afford more expensive quarters from the three model housing projects erected in New York with Federal financing has been decided upon by the New York State Board of Housing, and the building owners have been directed to replace such tenants with families of low income, it was learned yesterday.

HE was a dirty, unkempt little boy, this lad who had been born in 1854 in the town of Weidenau, in Silesia, then part of the Austrian Empire. But he had a fine, clear voice, and choir boys were then eagerly sought after for the Benedictine Monastery of St. Paul, in Carinthia, where Father Gregor, uncle of Adolf Lorenz, was capitular.

The most general rainfall in Oklahoma so far this season, with five stations reporting one to more than two inches, eased prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Pressure on new crops, which had lifted on Friday, was resumed and the list ended unchanged to 8 points lower on the day.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Attention of the Hot Springs colony will be temporarily diverted from gardens and flowers to golf next Saturday, when the Southern Conference championship opens on the Cascades course.
J.P. Morgan Co. issued yesterday the following statement regarding accounts of a memorandum, prepared by the banking house, on the Nye Senate committee's munitions investigation.

Holding its annual reunion and luncheon for the first time on the college grounds, the Class of 1904 of Hunter College met yesterday in Gillet Hall in the new Bronx buildings at Navy Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard to hear Dr. Eugene A. Colligan describe the undergraduates as "a student body that seems to thrive on adversity."

IT was an inspirational thought, no doubt, that prompted Herschel L. Bricker to bring into being this invaluable manual on theatre-craft in all its phases. Symposiac, provocative in the most modern manner, it calls to the platform certain luminaries of the American stage and gives them free rein in expressing ideas most dear to their hearts.

PICTURESQUE and often amusing records of life in the Civil War epoch and the period that followed it are the plaster parlor ornaments known as Rogers groups. Like Currier Ives prints, they have a pleasant realism; even if they do not seem to be great art, they have sentimental associations and their antiquarian value is increasing.

THE PSYCHOLOGY OF DEALING WITH PEOPLE. By Wendell White. 255 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $2.50. THIS book attempts to analyze such problems as peculiarities of behavior, preventing wrongdoing, presenting our ideas in an unoffensive manner, repression and providing wholesome compensation. It is written in a manner quite understandable to the layman and is designed to aid him in the most important task of life -- dealing with people.

KENT, Conn., May 2. -- Manhattan crews rowed against three Kent rivals on the upper course of the Housatonic today, the major race between the Jasper 150-pound varsity and Kent's first crew resulting in a dead heat.

DR. CHARLES G. ABBOT, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, for years has been measuring the solar constant, meaning the amount of heat given off by the sun every day. For the sun pulsates. In fact it is a variable star.

ROME, May 1. -- Foreign correspondents who were invited unexpectedly to a luncheon with Premier Benito Mussolini at an inn in Littoria recently, immediately after he had dedicated the new Pontine town of Aprilia, found him in an exceptionally good mood.

Turned green from the rays of a near-Summer sun, the Sheep Meadow, on the west side of Central Park, between Sixty-sixth and Sixty-eighth Streets, took on the aspect of a gigantic kaleidoscope yesterday afternoon as almost 25,000 children -- and not a few adults -- crowded together to witness a May festival presented jointly by the four Federal arts projects of the WPA.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Two kidnappers were left at the top of the government's list of wanted men today as Alvin Karpis was landed in St. Paul for a kidnapping trial.

The pending tax bill would have the effect of placing the growing retail organization at a distinct disadvantage, and its major provisions, governing the distribution of surplus, merit the same criticism from a retail standpoint as from that of manufacturers, according to Myron Finke, partner in Klein, Hinds Finke, accountants of this city.

The work mapped out by the recently organized Emergency Peace Campaign is so admirable that one hesitates to criticize, and the following suggestions are offered in a spirit of cooperation. The purpose to keep the United States from going to war and to achieve world peace would surely be strengthened if the methods included an immediate and vigorous opposition to the appalling increase in appropriations for militarism.

WITH this book a new publishing house presents itself to American readers. Its purpose, it announces, in entering a field which some of those established therein believe to be already too crowded for comfort, is to publish books "possessing social significance as well as literary merit.

Efforts of the United States liner Washington to reach the belabored British freighter St. Quentin during an Atlantic storm last Sunday night cost the line many thousands of dollars. The ship steamed under pressure for fifteen hours and was only twenty-five miles from the freighter when word came that she was safe and able to navigate.

A proposed new charter for New York City, submitted for inspection last Monday by the Charter Revision Commission, drew the immediate fire of present office-holders and evoked sighs of disappointment from civic-minded citizens who had hoped that the document would present a radically different form of government from the one under which the city now operates.

WASHINGTON. THE Bureau of Home Economics, in two investigations, will try to find a practical answer to questions on the tongue of many an American housewife. First, what quantities of vitamins are needed in the diet of the average healthy person, and second, what types of household refrigeration and equipment are most efficient?

PARIS, May 2. -- Members of Paris Post 1, American Legion, won in a French court today their fight for Pershing Hall. The Civil Tribunal of the Seine ruled that the building corporation, which had been pressing for eviction, acted without authority in closing the premises and ordered that the building be kept open.

When the Legislature of the State of New York enacted the law imposing a tax of $1 a gallon on alcoholic beverages imported into the State for consumption by the importer, it overlooked the following provision of the Constitution of the United States (Article I, Section 10):

The Cuban Telephone Company, controlled by the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday for 1935 a consolidated net loss of $525,509 after charges and taxes, compared with a net deficit of $1,112,141 in 1934. Operating revenues were $2,457,753, against $1,557,319.

Anticipated as one of the most important events on the organization's calendar, the annual meeting of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women will bring hundreds of members to Delmonico's at Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street tomorrow afternoon.

After being told that the games seized in the arrest of nine men at the Commodore Hotel early last Wednesday were being operated purely for the purpose of charity, Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in Yorkville Court yesterday reserved decision on gambling charges against the nine.
The Canadian freighter Canadian Planter sank in Nantucket Sound about 2 o'clock this morning (E. D.T.), after it had been in collision with the British freighter City of Auckland in a dense fog.

From 66 to 80 per cent of the recovery in the United States "must be attributed to the stimulating spending of the Federal government" and the business expansion this policy has induced apart from other recovery forces, Dr. Gerhard Colm, public economist, and Dr. Fritz Lewhann, financial economist, calculate in a joint research on the immediate effects of the program, a report of which was made public yesterday.

VIENNA -- The German swoop on the Rhineland has left Austria and Czechoslovakia with the feelings of patients in a dentist's waiting-room. Statements that Germany now has no further ambitions in Europe do not reassure those who live next door to her; like the farewell appearances of popular favorites, they are thought not to be utterly final.

AN old fight over the status of contract bridge -- game of skill versus chance -- was revived last week when police raided a bridge club, interrupting a five-table duplicate game, on the ground that the club was a "gambling house."

HOYA CARNOSA, the waxplant, years ago a familiar dweller in window gardens, is regaining its popularity. Ease of culture and charm of appearance both recommend it. Its climbing habit makes it particularly valuable when the window-sill garden is designed as a single picture -- vines tumbling from high-fastened brackets, low plants on the sill, and such climbers as this at the side to blend the scene into a unified composition.

ROBINSON MacLEAN served four months last Summer in Ethiopia as correspondent for The Toronto Evening Telegram, and he had made this book out of the sheaf of pictures by typewriter and camera that he brought back with him.

CHRISTINA STEAD'S lavish imagination has not dulled since it produced "The Salzburg Tales." It still defies the conventional patterns of fiction and gently eases reviewers toward their graves. For we are forced to praise in Miss Stead's work everything that we would ridicule as stilted, overambitious and pretentious in a less gifted writer.

MISSIONARIES accompanied the Spanish conquerors to South America. Missionaries went forth valorously from the centers of conquest into the tropical wilderness and the mountains -- explorers, settlers, teachers, martyrs -- and long after the acquisitive hopes of the first adventurers had been disappointed, missionaries continued, for almost three centuries, their jungle crusade.

ARTURO TOSCANINI has made his farewell, but the Philo harmonic-Symphony Orchestra goes on. According to Arthur Judson, the manager, renewals of subscriptions for next season have been coming in at a rate that equals those received last year at this time.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- John Strawbridge's Coq Bruyere, in a stirring rally, won the twenty-fifth running of the Harston Cup at the Spring meet of the Whitemarsh Valley Hunt Club at Broad Axe today before a crowd of 3,000.

DERBY, Conn., May 2. -- Pennsylvania and Columbia shared the honors today in one of the best-rowed regattas that Yale's Derby course has ever seen. Four smashing, brilliant races ended with Pennsylvania's superb sprint crew still undefeated, conquerer of Yale and Columbia in that order for the Blackwell Cup in the varsity race.

THE hunt race meet, one of the most colorful of sports, is moving up from the Mid-South along with the Spring. Yesterday, over the smooth green hills of Virginia hunting country, the Warrenton Gold Cup was run. The week before saw the running of the Maryland Hunt Cup event.

While prices on Summer apparel and accessories will be unchanged or slightly lower than last year, next month will see an uptrend in quotations that should mark the beginning of a substantial price rise for the second half of the year. The preliminary Fall lines of women's apparel, particularly coats and furs, will reflect the uptrend, but the indications are that the increases will affect reorders chiefly.

A palatial dog hospital where ailing pets may enjoy all the comforts of a wealthy owner's home is planned in the two four-story buildings at 142-44 East Fifty-seventh Street. The New York Veterinary Hospital has leased a ground-floor shop and the two upper floors.

TWENTY buffalo are now on a long journey by railway and steamer from Wainwright, Alberta, to Berlin, Germany, where breeding experiments will be conducted in an effort to save the European bison from extinction. Candian buffalo have in the past traveled long distances to zoological gardens in the United States, and across the seas to points as distant as Australia, but no mass migration comparable to the present one has ever before been undertaken.

ALTHOUGH any playwright capable of the unexpected feat of selling Jane Austen to Hollywood might be regarded with suspicion as a potential "uplifter" of the screen, Helen Jerome -- whose stage play "pride and Prejudice" was recently photographed in its entirety by an MGM camera and sound crew, as a guide for future picture adapters -- is the least stuffy of tone-raisers.

Marguerite de Angeli catches the authentic note in writing of the everyday doings of boys and girls. Ted and Nina, who, in a companion volume, went to the grocery store on an errand for their mother, are now shown amusing themselves on a rainy Spring Saturday.
A DEMOCRAT: "What am I, Democrat or Republican? I don't know."

WARRENTON, Va., May 2 (AP). -- Ghost Dancer, owned by Carleton H. Palmer, took the Virginia Gold Cup race of four miles over Limber today before a crowd of approximately 20,000. His time was 7 minutes 34 seconds. Noel Laing, gentleman rider who has piloted many winners, was up as Ghost Dancer romped home.

Many notable trophies will be in competition at the fifty-second specialty show of the American Foxterrier Club, which is to be given at The Brook, in Summit, N.J., on Friday, May 22. The chief trophy is the Grand Challenge Cup for best of breed. This is a perpetual prize, the dog winning it twice during a year being the champion fox terrier.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 2. -Episodes in the intellectual, social and artistic development of human knowledge through twenty-four centuries marked the Guest Day program with which Wellesley College celebrated today the achievements of its president, Dr. Ellen Fitz Pendleton.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, May 2. -- The Zeppelin Hindenburg's four Diesel engines, two of which were out of commission on the dirigible's return from South America, have been reinstalled after a thorough examination. Final preparations are now being made for the Hindenburg to depart for Lakehurst, N.J., Wednesday afternoon with sixty passengers.

CARLSBAD, Czechoslovakia, May 1. -- The recent appeal by Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party to the League of Nations against an ordinance issued by Minister of War Franz Matchnik, under which firms seeking War Office contracts must employ Czechs as technicians and workers to a percentage equivalent to the Czech percentage of the country's population is one of several indications of increased activity on the part of the party.

ROME, May 2. -- Vague rumors have been in circulation in Rome for some days of an alleged plot to reconstitute Italian Freemasonry, which in common with all secret societies has been declared illegal under Italian law.

NEW ORLEANS, May 2. -- Federal agents who participated in the coup in which Alvin Karpis and two companions were captured here said today that a search of the apartment where the outlaw lived for about a month had yielded "plenty."

Close-hauled and heeling well over in a spanking breeze, 300 model yachts owned by young racing enthusiasts whipped across Conservatory Lake in Central Park yesterday afternoon in the twelfth annual sailboat regatta conducted by the Department of Parks under sponsorship of Bloomingdale's.

MOSCOW, May 2. -- All Soviet Russia gave itself up to pleasure today by dancing in the streets, visiting friends or picknicking in the country. For this post-May Day holiday is the one day in the year on which the ordinary citizen can forget industry and politics and simply enjoy himself.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 2. -- Three Princeton crews and one Cornell eight triumphed over oarsmen from Pennsylvania and Rutgers in a series of four races held over the Henley distance on Lake Carnegie today.

Favored by warm weather, retail trade in the metropolitan area showed improvement last week. The increase over a year ago, while not large, being estimated at about 3 per cent, was held the forerunner of active consumer purchasing of Summer merchandise.

Plans are going forward for the garden bazaar and card party for the benefit of Save-a-Life Farm, which has been arranged by a group of women headed by Miss Frances Coleman for the afternoon of May 12 at Sherry's. Mrs. Richard L. Farrelly gave a luncheon yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza for Miss Coleman and her aides, at which arrangements for the benefit were discussed.

WITH the rush of Spring planting somewhat abated, there is a chance now to devote some attention to the general fixing up of the home place -- those little touches which result in what the professional gardeners call "finish."

The seventeenth annual Girl Scout conference for the Hendrik Hudson Region (New York and New Jersey) will be held May 7-9 at the Jamestown Hotel, in Jamestown, N. Y. Mrs. Ralph G. Wright of New Brunswick, N.J., chairman of the regional committee, will preside.

The end of April and the beginning of May regularly bring to our national capital warm weather and the annual convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. Of the two, the man in the White House usually prefers the weather.

A dinner dance entitled "A Night in Capri" will be held tomorrow night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador to aid the welfare work of La Margherita Society, a non-political, non-sectarian organization which conducts Red Cross work and child and maternal welfare work, maintains Summer camps for needy children and engages in disease-prevention campaigns.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Treasury wound up April with receipts still on the increase, but with a deficit growing toward $3,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Their batting attack clicking again, the Washington Senators jumped on three St. Louis pitchers today and pounded out a 9-4 victory over the Browns.

SELECTED canvases by more than a dozen French painters of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries are being shown until May 13 at the Valentine Gallery. Cezanne is represented by a large, partly completed portrait of Mme. Cezanne and by a small "Fleurs"; Degas by one of his innumerable ballet scenes; Forain by a loosely and satirically brushed "Au Promenoir."
This department owes an apology to Mr. V. Benedicto of Holguin, Cuba.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Official advices to the Commerce Department today revealed that, far from suffering a shortage of essential war-time materials due to sanctions and other trade restrictions, Italy had built up a big surplus.

Mrs. Victor Harris, who heads the group in charge of the sale of boxes and seats in behalf of the Dalton School Scholarship Fund at the concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra under the direction of Leopold Stokowski on May 17 at Madison Square Garden, will give a reception on Wednesday afternoon at the York Club for her associates and the patronesses.

FROM Trouville and English Channel Summer resorts to the Bosporus, from the Dalmatian coast to Venice's Lido, preparations for the warm vacation days are under way. For human nature, the world over, turns to blue water and sandy beaches when the sun's rays grow warm.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 2. -- Are college students "just girls" or are they responsible young women?

THE bells of Bruges and the lace-makers of Malines, the art galleries of Antwerp, birthplace of Rubens and Van Dyck, the parks and gay cafes of Brussels are sights and sounds for the traveler crossing from Dover or Harwich to Belgium for a tour of that country's cities and resorts.

The Manhattan College baseball team registered its ninth consecutive triumph of the season by turning back St. Francis College of Brooklyn at Manhattan Field yesterday. Behind the southpaw slants of Pete Blumette, who let the visitors off with only three hits, the Jaspers had little difficulty defeating their rivals by a score of 11 to 1.

The American Commercial Alcohol Corporation for the three months ended on March 31 had a net income of $310,149 after provision for Federal income tax and other charges, Russell R. Brown, president, reported yesterday. This compared with income of $284,125 in the same quarter of 1935.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Branding the "strategy" of the Townsend organization to start a motor caravan from Los Angeles to Washington Tuesday "another cruel hoax upon aged and infirm persons," Chairman Bell of the special House committee investigating old-age pension organizations declared today that it was clear that the manoeuvre was arranged chiefly to obtain personal benefits for the sponsors.

CARPETING the earth in spots where lack of light or water or the presence of tree roots makes the growing of ordinary plants difficult has ceased to be impossible to the gardener. Indeed, such a situation offers opportunity for the use of many delightful plants which otherwise would be disregarded.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The Municipal Convention Hall here is undergoing a transformation in preparation for the seventh annual Atlantic City Horse Show. When the thousands of visitors enter the main hall on the evening of May 12, they will find spread before them a complete "outdoor" course, with turf, shrubbery, water jumps, stile gates, fences and walls.

Arrangements were completed last week for the opening of the elimination round in the Constitution contest for the best teaching plans and articles submitted by high school teachers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, which is being conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A GREEK temple on a Syrian hill surrounded by shady courts and Pompeiian mosaics amid the ruins of an emperor's palace are paradoxes in a present-day village of the Druses, high up in the Hauran Mountains, east of Beirut, Syria.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 1. -- The retail department store sales in Kansas City for the month of April showed about the usual seasonal gain of 7 per cent over March, but it averaged 9 per cent over a year ago. Wholesale trade averaged 11 per cent over a year ago.

TORONTO, May 2 (Canadian Press). -- The validity of the Ontario Government's legislation canceling certain contracts for electric power from Quebec will be put to the test on Monday, when the first of several actions against the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario will come to trial before Chief Justice Hugh E. Rose in non-jury assizes.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- At least a score of Senators will battle against passage of the near record $531,068,707 Naval Appropriations Bill, even at the cost of delaying the adjournment of Congress, Senator Nye declared today.

UPHOLDING the right of Antoine Lavoisier to the sobriquet by which he is so generally known, Douglas McKie of the faculty of University College, London -- for the book is of British origin -- establishes here with careful and conclusive scholarship the high place which the French chemist holds in the history of science.

The Oratorio Society of New York, under Albert Stoessel's direction, gave its sixth and final concert of the season last night in the concert hall of the Juilliard Graduate School. To add variety to the proceedings, the program was not confined to choral numbers, but included also vocal and instrumental offerings by guest artists.

Edward Monahan, 21 years old, of 502 Harding Park, the Bronx, was killed early yesterday morning, and three of his companions were injured, when the automobile in which they were riding hit a trolley pole at Soundview and Gildersleeve Avenues, in the Clason Point section.

ALTHOUGH its climax is a murder, Mrs. Belloc Lowndes emphasizes her desire that her new novel, "The Second Key," shall be regarded primarily as a study of jealousy. That passion, of course, has been the motive behind many a murder, and as in several other of her recent books.

MODERN abstraction (nee School of Paris) continues to lure a surprising number of our American artists. For months we have encountered widespread evidence of this fact, and the most recent derivations are to be seen in the ground-floor room of the Municipal Art Committee's Temporary Gallery at 62 West Fifty-third Street.

The widely held opinion that the earth is round is now confirmed by a handsome aerial photograph in today's picture section of THE TIMES. At the top of the picture we see the white line of the earth's curvature deviating from the black line which represents the true horizontal.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2. -- Riding a slashing round on the black gelding Round Up, Captain John W. Wofford of the West Point Horse Show team tonight captured the individual military championship as the sixteenth annual Newark Horse Show came to a close in the Essex Troop Armory.

A charge that the resolution endorsing Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas for the Presidential nomination adopted by the New York Young Republican Club at a recent meeting was put through by use of the "steam roller" was made yesterday by George J. Abrams in a letter to Paul W. Williams, president of the club.

LONDON, May 1. -- The British people have suffered many disillusionments since 1918 and the end is not in sight. The latest but not the least of the long series has been the so-called defense budget of Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, which has called millions of the hardest pressed taxpayers on earth to dig still deeper into their pockets to pay for rearmament.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 (AP). -- President Roosevelt, Governor Landon of Kansas and Herbert Hoover wil get the first Far Western test of their strength as Presidential candidates next Tuesday in California's primary.

PARIS, April 30. -- League of Nations bracelets are a timely jewelry novelty. From each link of the chain a bangle is suspended; these are tiny flags reproduced in precious or semi-precious stones or enamel.
Commodity features were generally lower yesterday in quiet trading. In the cash market, eggs were higher, while corn, rye, flour and rubber were lower.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were slightly more numerous than in the preceding week. The calls, most of which were for future months, also were larger. These, too, included many entire issues of outstanding bonds and were more diversified than a week ago.

HOLLYWOOD. IF Clifford Odets isn't careful he may become a fabulous figure in Hollywood. He is probably too competent a craftsman ever to be rated as a genius by the cinema, but, after only a few weeks, there is talk about him. He says startling things and is mildly startled by the place.
MOSCOW, May 1. -- Quiet, suspicious watchfulness has taken the place of the recent raids and counter-attacks along the Far Eastern borders of the Soviet and Outer Mongolia.

The first organization meeting of the newly formed music and arts committee of the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries will take the form of a conference tea on Thursday at the exposition headquarters, 247 Park Avenue. The committee will plan a special showing by women artists with a music representation at the fifteenth annual Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries, to be held the week of May 23 at Grand Central Palace.

TRENTON, N.J., May 2. -- New Jersey's Republican voters will have an opportunity at the primary elections on May 19 to pass judgment on Governor Hoffman's administration, particularly his intervention in the Lindbergh kidnapping case after Bruno Richard Hauptmann had been convicted and sentenced to death.

Steadily rising retail sales figures, which stimulated buying for current and future needs in the leading wholesale markets, featured the trend of business activity in most of the Federal Reserve districts last week. Reports from various sections of the country of broad building construction programs gave further evidence of improved conditions.

PARIS. MOLYNEUX'S midseason collection is always in advance of the other Paris openings. Designed primarily for private clients, it is made up almost entirely of clothes to be worn in the more or less immediate future.
Joseph C. Hyman, secretary of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, explained yesterday a point in a committee statement published on April 27.

OWEN P. WHITE offers one more lively collection of his sketches and tall tales from Texas, that seem perennially calculated to stir the residents of the Lone Star State to sputtering fury. In deference to the Centennial Year, he has devoted himself almost wholly to extolling the glories of a past to which, as he infers, the present way of life in Texas presents a sorry contrast.
ALBANY, May 2. -- Governor Lehman today signed two bills in his anti-crime program.

HANOVER, N.H., May 2. -- Captain Ted Olson of Dartmouth saved the Green from an embarrassing situation today by getting up from a sickbed to pitch his team to a 9-3 victory over the Yale nine in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

Virtually all the foreign exhibitors and judges who will participate in the international stamp exhibition opening next Saturday in the Grand Central Palace have arrived in New York or will be here early this week. They include many of the world's leading collectors and stamp experts.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2. -- Heading a procession of the "big fellows" out of San Francisco Bay Friday was the Canadian Pacific steamship Empress of Britain, which had just completed her fifth visit to this port with a full complement of round-the-world tourists.

Paddy, the border terrier mascot of the Humane Society of New York, will be present in full dress clothes, complete with top hat, to greet guests at the gala dinner and supper party on Thursday, marking the formal opening for the season of the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

An advisory council of fashion merchandising will be formed by the Fashion Originators Guild of America to direct its efforts primarily toward the solution of those style problems which cause uncertainty and confusion, it was announced yesterday by Maurice Rentner, chairman of the Guild.

NO lover of mushrooms, whether as gourmet or botanist, could wish for more comprehensive and authentic information about them than he will find in this admirable handbook by Louis C.C. Kreiger, who has been their devoted student for many years, and as specialist in mycology serves the New York State Museum.

CHICAGO, May 2 (AP). -- The Prohibition party in national convention next week will renew its bid for national support as the pioneer champion of "liberalism" in American politics, its chairman, Edward Blake, said today.

THE sociologists who hold that inventions are inevitable in a mechanical age like ours and that we do too much honor to individual heroes of science will find some confirmation of their theory in last week's scientific developments.

Mayor La Guardia has written to Senator David E. Doyle, chairman of the State Senate's Committee on Cities, asking his support for the Baldwin-Hill bill relieving cities throughout the State from certain mandatory salary legislation.

A report from Jerusalem, made public yesterday by the United Palestine Appeal, announced that $10,337,000 had been spent in Palestine from Oct. 1, 1932, to March 31, 1936, by the Palestine Foundation Fund, the Jewish National Fund and the German Settlement Bureau of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Drought has taken a heavy toll of the Winter wheat crop in the Southwest for the fourth consecutive year, even though this season's prospective harvest, based on the condition which prevails today, is the best since the record yield of 1931.

A glowing tribute to the character and artistry of Arturo Toscanini, retired conductor of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, was expressed last night by Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, in a radio address broadcast from San Francisco over a coast-to-coast network of the National Broadcasting Company.

BOSTON, May 2 (AP). -- The Indians left Boston tonight for Washington under medical injunction to take every precaution against contagion from the spinal meningitis afflicting Bruce Campbell, right fielder. They will be allowed to play the Senators tomorrow.

BERLIN, May 2. -- The government news service announced tonight that Chancellor Adolf Hitler had relieved Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler of all his duties as a conductor in Germany next season. The announcement also stated that Dr. Furtwaengler would not conduct abroad and would appear only as guest conductor at the Baireuth festival until the following season, when he will resume his career in Germany and abroad.

INSTEAD of the thunder of horses' hoofs, the amplifiers behind the silver screen may soon emit the romantic roar of motors and the red-blooded rattle of fenders. In desperation because of the competition furnished by the Class B and C product from the major lots, independent makers of Westerns are endeavoring to interest motor car manufacturers in cinematic rescues of heroines about to suffer a fate worse than death.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Senator Hastings of Delaware, outspoken Republican critic of the New Deal, announced today that he would not be a candidate for re-election to the Senate this Fall. It was reported in Wilmington yesterday that he would retire to private life because the du Pont forces had refused to support him for renomination.

RECENT queries put by teachers' organizations to Governor Landon of Kansas as to his attitude toward public education have focused attention upon the present school situation in his State. Between the conflicting claims of political opponents and adherents, what are the facts as to Kansas schools?

IT was an uneventful week until we received that letter from Mr. Auletta. One reading, then a second and a third, and we had recovered from the inertia which envelops us every May. Mr. Auletta does not like long movie programs. He thinks there should be a time limit, under stricture of a city ordinance if need be, curtailing any downtown or neighborhood theatre bill to a period of three hours or less.

POSTAGE stamps from every country in the world and from practically every well-known collection will he displayed in the third international stamp exhibition to be held in this country, which opens next Saturday afternoon in the Grand Central Palace and continues through Sunday, May 17.

TUCSON, Ariz., May 2. -- A Roosevelt critic was floored by a swung fist, factions created turbulent scenes and police had to be called in to maintain order today as Arizona Democrats moved through a stormy State convertion, only to adjourn in disagreement.

While visiting buyers continued to concentrate operations on Summer merchandise, Fall staples began to draw interest, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyer. Most departments enjoyed consistent activity during the week.

BERLIN, May 2. -- The Appellate Court at Hamm in the Ruhr, which has been sentencing alleged traitors to the regime to penal servitude in batches of ninety to 100 at a time, has just sentenced another batch to terms ranging from eight months to one and three-quarters years.

A lethargy reminiscent of mid-Summer sessions ruled bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Prices drifted aimlessly within narrow limits on the smallest turnover for a two-hour period since Aug. 31, 1935. Total transactions amounted to only $3,619,300, compared with $4,731,400 on Saturday a week ago.
Suppose we analyze Mr. Roosevelt's economic philosophy as revealed in his New York speech. He said:

A description of the chief features of Addis Ababa was written yesterday by Albert W. Wilson, an Associated Press correspondent, who has just returned from Addis Ababa, and was sent out by that agency. He gave the following information:

James V. Martin of Hempstead, L.I., designer of the Martin bomber, filed suit in Federal court yesterday asking triple damages totaling $15,000,000 against the Curtiss-Wright Export Corporation, and the Curtiss Airplane and Motor Company, Inc.

Francis H. Brownell, chairman of the American Smelting and Refining Company, received $100,000 last year, exclusive of his remuneration from affiliated companies not controlled by American Smelting, according to the company's annual report filed with the New York Stock Exchange in compliance with the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

More than 5,000 children and their parents in Central Park yesterday saw a modern but faithfully accurate re-enactment of the city's earliest historical episode, the purchase of Manhattan Island from the Manna-Matin Indians, commemorating the 310th anniversary of the event.
Much has been said about the National Labor Relations Act by employers, union officials and government labor mediators, but strangely little has come from the employe, whose welfare it most concerns.

LONDON, May 2. -- After a five-hour conference at the Foreign Office which must have been one of the saddest of his career, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden spoke to his constituents at Leamington tonight as if the whole seven months' conflict between Italy and the League of Nations were already a matter of history.

WHEN we study the art of the European theatre in the generation before the war we find it conditioned by men and women not strictly in the inner coterie of the theatre at all. Nothing in the whole record of the theatre is more interesting than the influence that was exercised on the theatre by artists whose contacts with its profession were of the sketchiest.

Mr. Morgenthau's statement, presented last Thursday to the Senate Finance Committee in behalf of the new Tax Bill, is not merely an attempt to justify the particular kind of taxation sought to be enacted; it is as well historical of the events to which the present urgency for additional revenue is mainly attributed.

AN exceptionally large orchestra, consisting of the Philharmonic-Symphony and additional musicians, who will bring the total number of players to more than 150, will perform in Madison Square Garden tonight for the benefit of "victims of Nazi and Fascist persecution."
ROME, May 2. -- Premier Mussolini called the Italian Supreme Naval Commission for Defense into conference today as his columns in Northern Ethiopia prepared to occupy Addis Ababa.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 2. -- Unless the Board of Education at its meeting Tuesday night agrees to continue the fourth, fifth and sixth grades at the Huguenot School, parents of the children in these grades will keep their youngsters home.

In your recent editorial "What Is 'Unemployment'?" you suggest that if employment be limited to those between the ages of 18 and 65, as suggested by the President, it would make room for "only a third of the existing unemployed, according to the prevailing estimate of unemployment."

A new engineering and consulting firm in the yachting field has been organized by William Edgar John, executive secretary and assistant treasurer of the American Power Boat Association, with offices at 424 Madison Avenue.

The forty-second annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs will draw more than 1,000 women to Atlantic City on Wednesday, when a well-balanced program of lectures on education, government and international affairs, panel discussions, teas, dinners and entertainment will begin and continue until Saturday, at Haddon Hall.
FORTY years ago Mr. Thompson embarked upon an unusual experiment. He adopted a maker of history as a "major interest" within his mind. He shared his life with Sir Walter Ralegh.

A GIGANTIC bonfire of drift-wood gathered from the shores of Jackson Lake in Grand Teton National Park, Wyo., recently marked the virtual completion by the CCC of the clearing of worthless timber from the 7,234 acres surrounding this body of water, high in the Rockies.

HARTFORD, a town of individualists that contains a kind of Left Bank of Puritanism where the expatriate spirit survives and men go naturally from the mortalities of the life insurance business to the immortalities of art, produced Dudley Vaill Taicott, sculptor of the modern school, excellent writer, and owner of a fabulous Norwegian ship.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 2. -- Pennsylvania won its fourth Eastern Intercollegiate League victory in six starts today, beating Cornell, 8 -- 6, on Bob Effinger's ninth-inning triple at Hey Field today.

The curtain is falling on the last act of the Italo-Ethiopian War, and Premier Mussolini has his victory. In the brief space of seven months his armies have accomplished what non-Italian military experts the world over had called the impossible. They have driven a wedge 300 miles into the heart of a mountainous and forbidding land and they have destroyed virtually all of the organized defense that stood in their path.

THIS year, despite the war in Ethiopia, Italy is keeping open house to visitors. Florence, always popular with the traveler, opens to the public one of its beauty spots, the Boboli Gardens, for several open-air performances of "La Tancia," a seventeenth century peasant comedy.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- For the second time within a few months the office of Chairman O'Connor of the House Rules Committee was reported today to have been entered forcibly last night.

Chancellor SCHUSCHNIGG'S optimistic May Day speech cannot hide the fact that dictatorship works badly in Austria. After three years of the authoritarian regime established by Chancellor DOLLFUSS, the dangers of civil war, of intervention from the north and of armed "protection" from the south increase.

GENEVA, May 1. -- The proposed Pan-American conference so far has aroused much less fear and hope here than it would have a few years ago. Officially the League Secretariat regards the meeting with a favorable eye, while the specialists are following closely every move with a particular desire to see whether the conference will be helpful or harmful to the League.

Continued penetration of Latin-American markets by German manufacturers, trading with so-called compensation marks, is assuming far more serious proportions than is generally realized, Joseph D. Bohan, chairman of the foreign-trade section of the Proprietary Association and export manager for Fletcher's Castoria, said here yesterday on his return from a trip to Brazil.

BERLIN, May 2. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler was understood today to have taken personal charge of the conflict centering on Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, in an effort to smooth it over without breaking up his official family and thereby openly revealing the difficulties of his regime.

Three groups sponsoring contests for prize money, in which the public already has invested thousands of dollars, lost the first round in their fight for legal sanction in the United States District Court yesterday afternoon.

ONE of the fascinations of foreign travel is that delightful sensation of buying things and paying fares and fees in currencies that make prices lower. During the last few years the exchange situation has been such that American tourists have been largely deprived of this satisfaction, but this year it appears that at least a part of the old thrill is to be restored.

VACATIONISTS who visit the national parks this Summer will find wider and smoother trails than ever before, leading to hitherto inaccessible wonders of nature, scenes of beauty and curiosities of history and science.

Medals were awarded yesterday to 1,180 child artists, whose drawings were selected from more than 11,000 entries in Wanamaker's twenty-fourth annual drawing competition for school children. Pupils of more than 500 public, private and parochial schools were entered.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., May 2. -- Nine times within a stroke of winning the third set, Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn, the national champions, passed up their opportunity to stage a comeback against Donald Budge and Gene Mako today, and for the fourth successive time the Californians carried off the decision over their rivals for the Davis Cup doubles assignment.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 2. -- The high-geared Holy Cross baseball team had little trouble in disposing of Columbia today, 18 to 1, in their annual game.

ON the conservation front at this season the Boy Scouts are active in tree planting. Within the past five years they have put into the ground millions of seedlings throughout the country, and they have engaged in other forms of forest care as well.
BOSTON, May 1 -- While the victory of Governor Landon on Tuesday occasioned no astonishment, in itself, the magnitude of his sweep fame as a surprise.

THE suggestion that "all stop" signals be substituted for the usual red-and-green lights at dangerous but not heavily traveled intersections, originally put forward in The Automotive Daily News by its publisher, George M. Slocum, was printed here last Sunday.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 2. -- Preliminary arrangements for experimental flying by British and American airplanes over the North Atlantic this summer are being made by Canadian and Newfoundland Governments, which agreed at Washington some months ago to participate with Imperial and Pan-American Airways in starting a transatlantic service.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., May 2. -- Walter Hagen paired with Alex Ednie, Shelter Rock professional, to defeat Pete Cassella of the home club and Pat Circelli of Rockwood Hall in an eighteen-hole exhibition match today on the links of the Southern Parkway Country Club.

THE three-cents-a-day plan of hospital care, inaugurated for the middle-class worker in the metropolitan area, will be a year old on Thursday. It is considered a vigorous one-year-old, for more than 80,000 persons have enrolled under it.

Completion of operating returns for March gave the statistical record of how the floods in Pennsylvania and New England in that month cut into the earnings of the railroads. The floods affected the railroads adversely in two ways -- by actual damage and by preventing the flow of revenue-bearing traffic.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Broad criticisms of the pending Tax Bill were placed before the Senate Finance Committee today by several spokesmen for business, Professor Fred Rogers Fairchild of Yale University urging that all revision of the Federal tax structure be deferred until it could be made part of a definite plan to balance the budget.

POETRY -- or verse, if you prefer -- is having a phenomenal run these days. The gentle brook of genuine poetry that flows steadily in all seasons is suddenly swollen out of its banks by a flood of rhyme from sources heretofore arid, and the crest of the flood seems still a long way upstream.

ST. PAUL, May 2. -- Heavily shackled and surrounded by a cordon of machine gunners, Alvin Karpis, the nation's No. 1 desperado, was brought back to St. Paul by airplane today to face trial on kidnapping charges.

A high-power ultra-short-wave experimental station, based on the "static-less" radio system perfected by Major. Edwin H. Armstrong, Professor of Electrical Engineering of Columbia University, and recently demonstrated in New York by him, will come into being late this Summer in this area if the Federal Communications Commission approves the construction plans.

"Be ever patriotic and live by the Constitution," Cardinal Hayes declared yesterday in an address to more than 2,500 persons of Irish birth or ancestry, gathered at St. Patrick's Cathedral for a pontificial mass in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Ancient Order of Hibernians in America.

RICHMOND, May 2. -- A shortage of labor in many parts of the Fifth District is reported by the Richmond Bank, which says the improvement in employment conditions for the six weeks ended April 15 was the best for any similar period since the beginning of the depression.

TO go through the steps in which "Bury the Dead" was conceived, written and finally produced is to reconstruct a nightmare.
