Since all plays exposed in New York seem to emerge from the same, or nearly similar, nightmares, to examine this particular one in detail would result only in another eyewitness description of the assorted bogymen that lie in wait on the side streets off Broadway between Fortieth and Fiftieth Streets.

THE cosmic rays are recognized as such by their effects. They have a way of wrecking atoms in gases (air, for example) and even of penetrating deep into matter and hurling out positrons. From streaks left on photographs by flying chips of atoms, from clicks heard in a counter whenever a ray enters, the physicist infers what he can.

MAY DAY still is moving day in these quarters and the Keppel Galleries have gone further down their street (to No. 71) and hung their new walls with Gauguin's highly decorative prints in black and white and in color -- a fitting tailpiece to the big mural that is going to Boston from the Marie Harriman Galleries.

TO a drama critic who had been feverishly pulling stray words out of his sleeves and the wastepaper basket at midnight nothing was more discouraging than a glance at The Herald Tribune the next morning. There, under the cool by-line of Percy Hammond, the story of last night's disturbance in the theatre was crisply recorded in a few daintily chosen words that hummed with irony.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Although approaching a voluntary agreement with most railroads on methods of protecting employes who are thrown out of work by consolidations, union spokesmen indicated today that they would press for enactment of a bill requiring other roads to provide similar protection.

ALREADY supreme in world-record performance, the United States is entering the third year of a definitely directed campaign to win and hold this international recognition. Technical experts in aviation declare the equipment has been produced in our factories which soon will advance America's flying colors beyond the forty-four world records now held in classified aircraft performances, officially recognized.
PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP). -- Johnny Tising, erstwhile American Association strikeout king, combined careful nine-hit pitching with timely Pirate hitting to score a 6-1 victory over the Bees today.

WHILE listening to a revue, "Spread It Abroad," which is the most pointed and the wittiest revue that has lately been seen in London, I was led to ask myself what it is that gives to a work of art or to an entertainment an international circulation.

Two detectives from Brooklyn headquarters frustrated a kidnapping last night in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn after two gunmen had pounced upon their victim and had him pinned to the floor of their automobile.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Maryland, California and South Dakota will hold their primaries next week, with the electors of the State first named making their decision on Monday.

LOUISVILLE, May 2. -- Surviving a terrific smash at the start in which Granville and Brevity were the chief sufferers, Bold Venture today won the sixty-second Kentucky Derby before 70,000 persons, the largest crowd to pack Churchill Downs in many years.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 2. -- John Mason and C. Leslie (Bunny) Fletcher Jr., Narragansett Bay dinghy skippers, carried Brown's colors to victory in the invitation regatta sponsored by the Brown Yacht Club today. The home pair amassed 130 points in six races to defeat Williams by 17 points.

SAFETY councils endeavoring to reduce the number of traffic accidents in their communities could take a lesson from the experiences we have encountered in promoting what is generally considered the most dangerous of sports.

Regular two-and-one-half-day travel to Europe, faster than any heretofore possible, will be offered this season on the new German airship Hindenburg. The rate has been fixed at $400 for the one-way passage by the German Zeppelin Company, of which the Hamburg American Line-North German Lloyd are the American agents.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (2P). -- Plans to draw the nation's police radio stations into a network that would give almost instantaneous communication to any part of the country will be taken up soon by the Federal Communications Commission.
While considerable space has already been given in your pages to the interesting theories of Dr. Hess and Mr. Fisk, I believe there is still something to be said on the subject.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 2. -- Princeton's hard-riding polo four defeated the Yale quartet, 5 to 4. in a hard-fought battle on Phipps Field today.

Ten months ago Emperor Haile Selassie was wildly acclaimed at Addis Ababa when, in a fighting speech before his chieftains, he pledged to shed his own blood if necessary in leading Ethiopia in the defense of her independence.

WITH the advent of May, the beaches and other playgrounds of Virginia's tidewater country are springing into activity. Already many of the waterfront cottages -- among them some new ones -- have been opened for the season, and the hotels are filling up.

BOSTON, May 2 (AP). -- The Indians ended their four-game losing streak and Boston's string of four victories today, defeating the Red Sox, 7 to 3. Rallying in the eighth, Cleveland battered five Boston hurlers for six runs in the last two innings.

NEXT Wednesday will be the eightieth birthday of Sigmund Freud, the stoop-shouldered Viennese doctor with the piercing brown eyes, father of psychoanalysis, the "science of the soul," to which many in this puzzled generation have turned for the solution of their manifold problems.

The 250th anniversary of the granting of the Dongan Charter to New York City will be commemorated Thursday at 1 P.M. at City Hall with ceremonies in the Aldermanic Chamber, it was announced yesterday by Stanley Howe, Mayor La Guardia's secretary.

AMHERST, Mass., May 2. -- Amherst took her first Little Three game today, trouncing Wesleyan, 12 -- 7. Wesleyan tallied first on two singles and an error in the opening frame. The Lord Jeffs came back in their half, with an error, two hits, a double steal and an infield out to register three runs.

The assessed value of adjacent land on Sixth Avenue, between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-eighth Streets, has risen more than 56 per cent in the ten years since the Interborough elevated structure north of Fifty-third Street was removed, according to a preliminary survey made by the Board of Transportation with the aid of WPA workers.
The annual meeting of the Travelers Aid Society will take place on Wednesday night at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

RECENT magnetic bombardments and freak "noise" outbursts blamed on sun-spots have afforded the Bureau of Standards opportunity to collect more data relative to a mysterious blotting out of certain radio waves.

A sharp decline on Monday, the widest since July 26, 1934; irregularity on Tuesday, further losses on Wednesday, a technical rally on Thursday and Friday and a do-nothing market yesterday is the chronology of stocks in a week that has experienced the greatest losses of the year thus far.
BALTIMORE, May 2. -- Jockey Bobby Merritt and the Howe Stable's Cycle won first honors today as 15,000 racegoers -- the largest crowd of the Spring season, witnessed the events at Pimlico.

HERE, done into English by two admirable American poets, with a capital, if unnecessary, apologia by Miss Millay in form of preface, are the "Flowers of Evil," by one who for the past thirty years has dominated, more or less admittedly, the entire realm of French poetry.

THAT Mr. Coleman has visited lands and breathed air from which great poets drew inspiration is quite evident. Yet, in spite of such experiences, his reactions to life and beauty have no sharp originality. His pages are full of literary phrases that have long been echoes.

THERE are two fights up ahead and the bright prospect is that they will not be clinching arguments. McLarnin, Canzoneri, Schmeling and Louis are not the type to hold everything. They let go with both barrels at the start and keep firing in open order.

The controversy over the right to the designation as "the world's largest ship" was renewed yesterday when the Cunard White Star Line issued a statement citing a point in favor of the claim of the new Queen Mary to the title.

TWENTY years ago a young man, J.E. Williamson by name, photographer and reporter on the staff of a Norfolk newspaper, The Virginia Pilot, was seized with the desire to go exploring. He was not so much moved by a desire to discover things as he was to report on them -- especially to photograph them.

WITH the completion of the new bridge across the Tampaon River, twelve miles south of Valles, all bridges between Laredo and Mexico City on the Pan American Highway are now completed, it is announced by William Harrison Furlong, United States representative of the National Highway Direction of Mexico, with headquarters in San Antonio, Texas.

FLOWERS contribute much to the beauty of graduation festivities. They are the only color notes in the chorus of white which celebrates the last day of the school year. (Only a few schools and colleges permit the use of pastel shades for gowns.)

ON Nov. 11, 1935, the Explorer II, biggest balloon ever made, rose to a height of 72,395 feet under the auspices of the National Geographic Society and the United States Army. Captains Albert W. Stevens (pilot) and Orvil Anderson (observer) had no intention of making a world's record. Theirs was a scientific mission. Yet the higher they floated the better for science.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The new $1,500,000,000 relief bill in its final form provides only for a continued WPA program, it was revealed as the House Appropriations Committee ended work on the measure today. No money is set aside for Secretary Ickes's PWA or Rexford G. Tugwell's Resettlement Administration.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 2. -- The Navy reached Berry and Kadany, Temple pitchers, for an even dozen hits today to win a hard-fought game of baseball, 6 to 5. Temple batsmen registered only half this number against Joe Eliot.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 2 (AP). -- The Baltimore Orioles turned the tables on the Bisons in their second consecutive extra-inning whirl today by gaining a 5-4 decision in thirteen innings.

In his first speech in the East since his selection as temporary chairman of the Republican National Convention, Senator Frederick Steiwer of Oregon declared last night for the liquidation of the Works Progress Administration and the turning over of responsibility for the administration of relief to the States and local agencies.

CINCINNATI, May 2 (AP). -- Bucky Walter, the infielder who turned pitcher, held Cincinnati to seven hits in seven and two-thirds innings today and batted in the winning run to give Philadelphia a 4-3 victory and even the two-game series.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- The Summer sailing series of the Nassau Yacht Club will open on Friday afternoon when the Star Class race will be featured. The Nassau Polo Association opens its season the same afternoon with a game on the Eastern Parade, three teams competing.
TOKYO. -- The military earthquake is sufficiently in the past to enable one to measure its results.

Backing its excellent pitching with a strong attack, the James Monroe High School nine continued its unbeaten pace in the upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the P.S.A.L. championship race by routing Morris, 10 -- 3, yesterday on the winners' diamond.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 2. -- After a four-month recess Congress will convene again tomorrow in an atmosphere of considerable tension as a result of the withdrawal of immunity to the Deputies following the declaration of a state of siege in the November revolt.

To read the addresses on race delivered last week by Professor FRANZ BOAS of Columbia University and Professor EARNEST A. HOOTON of Harvard, the one before the National Academy of Sciences and the other before the American Association of Physical Anthropologists, is to give thanks that this is a democracy in which an anthropologist need not restrict himself to an innocuous study of savages.

Johnny Morris, junior right-hander, who has to his credit a one-hit victory over Panzer, was highly effective against Brooklyn College yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium as he pitched the C.C.N.Y. nine to a 14-3 triumph.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- Yale's better-balanced track team subdued Pennsylvania on Franklin Field today, 73 to 62, for the fourth straight year. The Red and Blue excelled in the running events and hurdles but could not cope with the Elis in the field events.

BACK in the Seventies, in the far Northwest, a boy of 17 fell heir to a ranch, thousands of cattle and the title of "Uncle" -- always reserved in the cow country for a ranch owner. He was beloved by his punchers and shared their work and hardships on trail and round-up.

VISITORS to the national capital this Spring will find a city vastly changed as the result of an ambitious program of national park development within the District of Columbia, and in near-by Maryland and Virginia.

IF there is any logic at all to account for the popularity of a book -- and one sometimes doubts it this new novel by Gelett Burgess should reach a very wide audience. It is at least three different kinds of story rolled into one.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 2. -- One Hungarian and seventeen American photographers have received merit awards for prints submitted for inclusion in the fourth annual Princeton photographic exhibition, which will be opened in McCormick Hall tomorrow.

NEXT Thursday the door of "Old Merchant's House" at 29 East Fourth Street will swing open to the public as a historical showplace, under the auspices of the Historic Landmark Society. It was just a century ago that this same door first opened to receive the family of the owner-builder, Seabury Tredwell, New York merchant.

THE great Boulder Dam is finished and for many people has become an old tale. But Lake Mead -- the largest man-made lake in the world -- which the dam has made possible, has become a center of attraction, for the thousands of visitors who come weekly to see the dam would not consider their visit complete unless they had explored this most unusual body of water.

ST. LOUIS, May 2. -- With the advent of real Spring weather, business generally showed a decided pick-up in the Eighth Federal Reserve District this week. Retail stores report heavy Spring buying. Sales in department stores are at least 7 per cent ahead of those in the same period last year.
TWO new-model trailers, the York Cruiser Senior and Junior, have been put on display here at 10 Central Park West by the Split Coach Motor Corporation of York, Pa. The Senior model is pictured above.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Earnest A. Hooton, Harvard University Professor of Anthropology, told a conference on the alien in America tonight that "there is no Aryan race," and that he was eager "to disassociate the findings of science from the acts of human injustice which masquerade as racial movements or racial hygiene."

TO see the television parade forming in two of the country's leading radio laboratories, specializing in that branch of research, is to catch a glimpse of the future. Sitting there in the semi-darkened room in front of a radio set, the spectator may well imagine he is in his own living room several years hence watching a home-movie performance flashing through the air.

THE automobile industry is decentralizing its operations. Instead of concentrating production in a few plants, thus necessitating the crowding of tens of thousands of workers into congested urban centers, it is spreading out its manufacturing activities.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., May 12. -- The national convention of the Young Women's Christian Association was told today by Mrs. Frederick Paist of Wayne, Pa., president of the national board, that the association was ready to incorporate sex education in its study program.

Outstanding achievement by a trade association during the last three years was hailed during the week by the presentation in Washington by Secretary Roper of the award of the American Trade Association Executives to the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

Mayor and Mrs. La Guardia will attend this morning the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, at the entrance to Rockefeller Center, to hear the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo preach his first sermon as the pastor-elect.

A CHANGING emphasis is noted in the high school curriculum as shown by the pupil enrollment in the several subjects of instruction in New York State secondary schools. High school practice, however, still lags behind our philosophy of education for adolescent needs in a social democracy.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Clarification of the existing rights of neutrals was urged by Secretary Hull in a list of topics transmitted by this government today to the preparatory commission for the Inter-American Conference, to be held in Buenos Aires.

Harry Bernstein, accused of seriously wounding Louis Silver, reputed associate of Johnny Torrio, alleged racketeer, was held yesterday by Magistrate William A. Farrell in Felony Court without bail for examination Friday on a charge of felonious assault.

Despite the refusal of the New York State Court of Appeals to amend its previous decision holding Section 2 of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Law unconstitutional, drug interests here declared yesterday that they will push their efforts to carry the fight to the United States Supreme Court.
CAIRO, May 2. -- The delicate question of the regency is overshadowing every other interest in Egyptian politics to such an extent one would hardly know that parliamentary elections were held today.

THIS book is a master key to the news of 1935. It is skillfully designed to enable any one to locate practically everything that has appeared in the papers during the year. Through this index domestic and foreign news of all sorts can be traced, as well as editorials, book reviews, magazine articles and all the infinite categories of material published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

DESPITE the injury to his wrist in the recent plane accident at Port of Spain, Trinidad, Jose Iturbi, the pianist, was only an hour in Buenos Aires before he was on the podium conducting a rehearsal of the Colon Orchestra for his first concert.

CHICAGO, May 1. -- Mayor Edward J. Kelly, who pitted Dr. Herman N. Bundesen against Governor Henry Horner in the recent primary fight, only to see his candidate snowed under by down-State ballots, at last has broken his silence by an admission that he accepts the party's verdict and will support the entire Democratic ticket.

CINCINNATI, May 2. -- Inspired by the discussions and conclusions of the biennial convention sessions, delegates and members of the National League of Women Voters today are on their way home to launch a whirlwind campaign in support of their No. 1 project, "qualified personnel in government service."

THIS is National Music Week, and David Sarnoff, chairman of the committee, will so declare during WJZ's hour broadcast at 2 o'clock this afternoon. This matinee concert presenting Gladys Swarthout, soprano, and Mario Chamlee, tenor, will be devoted to the aims of America's Spring festival of melody.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 2. -- Middlebury defeated Army at baseball today, 8 to 7. The Vermonters took kindly to both Army pitchers and connected for some timely hitting, especially in the fifth inning, when five hard blows, one of them a double by Lins with two men on, netted four tallies.

Skimming and sloshing, bumping, twisting and hydroplaning down the Hudson River next Sunday morning will be a hundred or more men and at least one woman, contestants in the opening event of the motor boat racing season.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The text of the formal statement relative to the administration's tax policy that was made on Thursday by Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury Department before the Senate Finance Committee follows:

Two employes of the Hotel Capitol, on Eighth Avenue between Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets, were injured at about 10:20 o'clock last night when a service elevator, running between the first and fifth floors adjoining the five-story extension, got out of control at the third floor and crashed into cross-girders at the top of the shaft.

The annual tea dance of the College of the Sacred Heart, Manhattanville, will be held next Saturday afternoon in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise money for the college's endowment fund. Miss Marion Moran heads the dance committee. Assisting her are the Misses Betty Rafter, Joan Willett, Margaret Lambert, Joan Schmid, Rosemary Lussier, Mary Beth Tobin, Sara Brady and Rita McLoughlin.

DR. TUCKER has invariably declined to repeat himself in his writings. No two of his works are alike in subject or treatment; but in his 1930 book, "The Gift of Genius," there occurred a passage in which one can spot the germ from which the present historical novel would appear to have originated.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Establishment of consumer information divisions, similar to those in New York and New Jersey, is being considered by departments of agriculture in sixteen additional Eastern States.

IN producing Bronislava Nijinska's original version of "Les Noces," the de Basil Ballet Russe has contributed to the season one of its most distinguished events. "Contributed" is perhaps the exact word to be used, for it is inconceivable that such a ballet will ever prove popular at the box-office.
Following is the text of the address last night to the Queens County Republican Committee by Senator Frederick Steiwer:

ROME, May 2. -- Even though word was received here this evening that Emperor Haile Selassie was fleeing from Ethiopia, usually well-informed quarters continued to say the Italian occupation of Addis Ababa was unlikely to occur for another week or more.

BERLIN, May 1. -- The most important happening in Germany since the remilitarization of the Rhineland in defiance of the Locarno treaty has been the appointment of Herman Goering, Premier of Prussia, as boss over Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers completed a sweep of the two-game series with the Athletics today, winning a free-hitting contest, 8 to 7.

Democratic leaders and orators are maintaining that the degree of recovery already attained is entirely the work of their own hands. It must be wholly credited to the New Deal. It should result in a glad and overwhelming vote for its continuance under President ROOSEVELT.

Wallabout Market's new railroad freight terminal, giving Brooklyn's produce market a direct link with the trunk line railroad network of the country, was formally dedicated yesterday morning. Municipal officials and market men acclaimed the new facilities as a forward step that will result in a savings of $1,000,000 or more a year to the housewives of New York City.

CONFRONTED with "thousands of contemporary picture-books,'' Monroe Wheeler wisely decided to restrict items included in the current show at the Museum of Modern Art to such as involve the work of painters and sculptors who turn only now and then to projects of illustration.

CHARMING gifts are displayed in the shops for the Spring bride who will want to make her new home look bright and cheery when she returns from her honeymoon some time during the Summer. Some of the household things a bride enjoys purchasing for herself; but there are many others that, while practical, possess beauty and charm which make them suitable as presents.

LONDON, May 2 (Canadian Press). -- Closing struggles in the English Football League today saw Manchester United and Charlton Athletic gain promotion from the Second Division, and Coventry City and Chesterfield, third leaguers, move into the Second Division berths vacated by relegation of Port Vale and Hull City.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- In a new search for gold, the United States Geological Survey will turn its attention this Spring and Summer to one of the most famous gold camps in the world, the Cripple Creek district in Colorado, which once swarmed with prospectors.

BOSTON, Mass., May 2. -- New England business is showing general improvement. Retail trade increased this week and there has been further activity in some of the principal industrial lines in this area. The effects of the March floods have been entirely wiped out, except for the rehabilitation and repair work now going on at a brisk rate.
CHICAGO, May 2. -- Bent on doing something in the interest of science, the Giants made a noble effort today to win an extra-inning ball game from the Cubs. It is a feat rarely if ever accomplished.

FOUR centuries ago a bold and hardy soldier, 60 years of age, stockily built and lacking one eye, reached the Aconcagua valley in central Chile after a journey of 2,082 miles from Cuzo in Peru. This was the Adelantado, Don Diego de Almagro, Pizarro's great rival.

AIR transport recently proved a boon to Philadelphia's babies when thousands of paper milk bottles, air expressed from Detroit in one night, reached that city in time for the morning milk delivery. The bottles, made by an almost human machine which takes flat cardboard, parrafins it, makes it into bottles and fills them with milk, are normally received in regular shipments from Wrightstown, N.J.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Wheat prices were on the down grade today on the Chicago Board of Trade as a result of further rains over the more eastern sections of the grain belt, easiness in Liverpool and a break in Winnipeg to the season's lowest level.
Three women suffered shock and thirty or more families were driven from their homes yesterday when sewer gas exploded under Hudson and Essex Streets in Jersey City.
The average Frenchman likes to speak his own mind. He has definite social and political ideas and he stands up for them. Unlike Nazi Germany, which has only one party, France has more than a dozen.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Organized business and the Roosevelt administration met at the crossroads this week. The intersection was just a block from the White House, where stands the national headquarters of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

SAN FRANCISCO. WHAT is thought to be the largest collection of automobile name plates in the world can be seen here in San Francisco. Owned by Ernest Ingold, an automobile dealer, and William Ryan, a motor executive, the collection constitutes a roll-call of early American automobiles.

VIENNA, May 2. -- It was learned tonight that the Austrian Government had addressed an aide-memoire to the great European powers and also to the members of the Little Entente outlining the details of its conscription plans.

This delightful little volume, measuring four and a quarter by four inches, bids fair to share the popularity of Little Black Sambo and other miniature nursery classics. Both text and illustrations have an engaging humor and there is real wit in the drawings of the tiger, so magnificently proceeding through the jungle, so ignominiously tricked by the bland Percival.

OMAHA, May 1 -- Senator George W. Norris, trying to beat a retreat from public life, became the object of major attention the same as when he was resisting the effort of his foes to put him out. Will he or will he not yield to the importunities to enter as a candidate for a fifth term in the Senate?

About two-thirds of the city's public schools are creating anti-social character through "autocratic instructions" and failure to treat students as personalities, Professor William H. Kilpatrick of Teachers College, Columbia, declared yesterday.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico. -- Introduction of the Tydings bill at Washington to provide for a plebiscite on Puerto Rican independence in November, 1937, complicates the pending trial of Pedro Albizu Campos, president of the Nationalist party, and eight others charged with conspiracy to overthrow the United States Government in the island.
Since the Dutch West India Company was authorized in 1656 to set up for New Amsterdam a form of government like that of Amsterdam, Holland, this city on the Hudson has had many charters.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- President Roosevelt embarked today for a week-end cruise down the Potomac River aboard his new official yacht, also named the Potomac. It was the first time he had stepped aboard the deck of the converted Coast Guard cutter since he terminated his fishing cruise in the South Atlantic early last month.

AFTER you've talked to Hal B. Wallis for a while, you begin to realize that the life of a production chief for a major film studio is not all beer and skittles. In Mr. Wallis's own case -- he is associate executive in charge of production for Warner Brothers -he doesn't like beer, and there just isn't time for skittles.

AMERICAN travelers soon will be received at a new legation in Helsingfors. Ground has been purchased and plans completed for a building to house the United States Minister and his staff, in the same neighborhood with other foreign Ministries.

TORONTO, May 2 (Canadian Press). -- Leroy Herrmann, righthander, brought to the Toronto Leafs from the Cincinnati Reds, pitched a ten-inning no-hit, no-run game today and turned back the league-leading Newark Bears, 1 -- 0, in the final game of the series.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2. -- Under blue and shining skies, in the cool of an afternoon the heat of which was further tempered by a flurry of rain earlier in the day, high officials, national and State, including diplomats, Governors and Cabinet officers, and representatives of all ranks of official and unofficial society East, West, North and South, met today at Churchill Downs.

Round and round the base paths on their home field yesterday romped Fordham's unbeaten baseball forces to register a 21-to-2 triumph over their old and neighboring rival, New York University, for the tenth Maroon success of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Preparing to start a ten-year program for increasing the number of army officers, the War Department completed plans today for calling 1,000 young reserve officers to a year of active service beginning in July.

THIS volume throws light on the spiritual revolution which accompanied the political and economic upheavals after the great war. The disintegration of the social structure of which we read, was world-wide. The United States was swept by an inflationary experimentality.

The fifteen-odd points offered by Secretary Roper and Mr. Brown as a solution of our unemployment problem at the meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce substitute fifteen very difficult problems for one equally difficult. What the country needs is a firm farewell to generalities and theories, and a direct, practical approach to the problem.

ALTHOUGH a story of the French Foreign Legion, this novel is largely void of the customary heroics, perils, villainies and whatnot characteristic of the breed. But the suppression of these familiars is not balanced by the use of fresher, more ingenious and exciting stuff, while the tale is further handicapped by an absence of closely knit plot complexities.

The New York Stock Exchange has received notice from the Commercial Credit Company of a proposed increase in the company's authorized capital stock by $25,000,000 of $100 par cumulative convertible preferred.

WASHINGTON. -- With the Commonwealth government of the Philippines an uncertain infant six months old, and with the Washington naval treaty of 1922 a broken veteran doddering to its end, the problem of Pacific fortifications and naval bases is again receiving the attention of military and naval exports and government officials.

THE annual showing of city gardens, held under the auspices of the Anne Brown Alumnae Association for the benefit of its free Nursery School, will be prefaced by an exhibition of photographs of city gardens and penthouse terraces tomorrow afternoon at the Ehrich-Newhouse Gallery, Madison Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

PARIS, May 2. -- Neither the internal nor external policy of France is likely to be altered very greatly as a result of the elections to be held tomorrow, even though, as is expected, the Left parties win a handsome majority.

MISS ROTHERY does not call the Finns a nation of kulaks, but one suspects that their Russian neighbors would apply to them this same name that they reserve for such of their own citizens as cannot kill the yen for a little landed property.

In the slowest trading since last Summer, stock prices moved indecisively during the two-hour trading period yesterday. Followers of the market were disposed to await the outcome of the French "run-off" elections today, for a clearer view on the future of the franc, and the possible decision tomorrow by the United States Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the Guffey act, the little NRA of the coal industry.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Industrial output in April was well above that in March, although usually at this time of year there is little change, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly business review.

LONDON, May 2. -- The British Government has reason to expect that Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy will take advantage of the expected entry of Italian troops into Addis Ababa to proclaim the annexation of the Ethiopian Empire.

IN "Sinbad's Book of Pirates" Captain Dingle has collected tales of the buccaneers who sailed the Spanish Main, the Indian Ocean and the China Sea. Among them are Pierre le Grand, Blackbeard, Henry Morgan, De Soto, Lolonois and Mary Reed.

Proprietary medicines lead the list of all industries in the ratio of advertising expenditures to net sales, according to the 1934-35 survey of national advertising budgets completed yesterday by the Advertising Research Committee of the Association of National Advertisers, Inc.

SYDNEY. NEW ZEALAND'S Government has received an order from Germany for the eye-teeth of red deer. Payment offered is about 30 cents for a pair of any size or shape, but preferably for discolored cuspids of the adult animal.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 2. -- Rutgers University will hold its 170th anniversary commencement of the colleges for men at the Rutgers gymnasium on Saturday, June 13, according to an announcement today by Robert C. Clothier, president of the university.
A project in the Americanization of foreign-born adults started years ago by the Board of Education now has nearly 10,000 citizens in the making every year.

Penthouse, back yard and country gardens in the metropolitan area will be open to visitors during the annual garden days of the School Nature League, to be held May 12-26. Governor and Mrs. Lehman head a group of patrons and patronesses for the garden days, which are arranged to stimulate interest in the activities of the league, an organization that has conducted pioneer work for nature study among city children since 1917.

SHALLOTTE, N.C., May 2 (AP). -- Representative Zioncheck, whose fast driving twice before brought him under charges, ran afoul of the law again today, but was allowed to continue his honeymoon trip after being detained several hours.

THERE was a time, shortly after the war, when we heard much of "tired radicals." Today, according to Professor T.V. Smith, the liberals also are tired. As regarded radicals, to be sure, the fatigue was mainly limited to America.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- In publishing another volume of "Foreign Relations of the United States," State Department historians have carried to 1920 their exhumation of the diplomatic correspondence exchanged between Washington and foreign capitals.

Included in a mathematics exhibit that was opened this week at Teachers College, Columbia University, is a letter from George Washington to Nicholas Pike, a Yankee schoolmaster, that throws new light upon Washington's modesty.

MACHINE wheels are not the only things that revolve at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In the School of Architecture, $10,000 of the Chandler Fund has been set in motion. It will revolve year after year, it is hoped, with the acquisitiveness of the snowball.

Mayor La Guardia last night "publicly begged" the Assembly to put aside partisan considerations and adopt Governor Lehman's Social Security Bill before the Legislature adjourns. The Senate already has adopted the bill unanimously.

THE first dance congress and festival, sponsored by a committee of eighty-three dancers and others well known in the dance world, will be held in the Theresa L. Kaufman Auditorium of the Y.M.H.A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, throughout the week of May 18.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 2. -- Five meet records and one Princeton mark fell today in Palmer Stadium as the Cornell track team rolled up an 81 1-2-to-53 2-3 victory over the Tiger track squad.

ISTANBUL, May 2. -- Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdu Aras has gone to Athens, from where, together with Premier John Metaxas of Greece, he will go to Belgrade for the meeting of the council of the Balkan Entente Monday.

Practical experience in public administration will be introduced in Columbia College next year to "offset the artificial studies of the classroom." according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Joseph D. McGoldrick, head of the college department of government, and Dr. Luther Gulick, Eaton Professor of Municipal Administration.

MR. BEKKER'S book is not a history of opera in the elder and conventional sense. He takes the history of opera as read -- in the parliamentary sense -- as something known in its general outlines and understood in its setting in musical history.

MAY, the loveliest month of the year, is something like fifty times as flowery as April. And I see on looking over my old notebooks of many previous Springs that more birds arrive around my home in the first fifteen days of May than in all April, though April has twice as many birds as March.

THE art of the essay is a peculiarly English art; it is a form which seems to have a perennial appeal for both writers and public. What with Belloc, Chesterton, Desmond MacCarthy, Rose Macaulay and other literary notables going in for the form, the art may be said to be in a very thriving state.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 2. -- A 36-to-1 shot, W.G. Clysdale's Allen Z., captured the Narragansett Handicap, a $5,000 added sprint for 3-year-olds and upward, today in the feature event of New England's Spring racing opening at Narragansett Park.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 2. -- The first of a series of gardens to be opened to the public in tours sponsored by the Westchester County Children's Association will be Mrs. Louise Beebe Wilder's rock garden in Bronxville. It will be on view next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Municipal securities would not be affected by enactment of the bill to continue trading in unlisted securities which recently passed the Senate and is pending before the House, according to Chairman Fletcher of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.
PARIS, May 2. -- Out of the second ballot in the French general election, which will be held tomorrow, it is now conceded by every party that the Left majority will emerge the victor.

IT wasn't a dog at all, the critter that made away with several of Amos Brand's young lambs, snatching two of them at a time on each of three successive early mornings from the high-fenced little pasture where he had herded them preparatory to shipping them to a dealer who had ordered the thirty.

ALTHOUGH there is no preface to this volume of short stories -- explaining its genesis and whose dubious inspiration it was -- the title is a sufficient clue to its contents. Briefly, "Not Long for This World" is a collection of twenty-two macabre tales by an assortment of British authors.

Accused of shooting and fatally wounding his cousin because the latter called him "skinny," Vincent Comerford, 17 years old, of 326 East 117th Street, was held without bail in Felony Court yesterday on charges of suspicion of homicide and violation of the Sullivan law.

HAVANA, May 2. -- Heeding a unanimous resolution of Congress demanding that recent mysterious "acts of bloodshed" in and around Havana be cleared up and those guilty be brought to justice, Col. Fulgencio Batista, chief of staff of the army, initiated investigations today.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- President Roosevelt in his Jefferson Day speech said that the national income had risen from $35,000,000,000 in 1932 to $65,000,000 in 1936. Estimates of national income for this year, made by twenty public and private statistical services, range from $50,000,000,000 to $70,000,000,000, leaving an average of $60,000,000,000, which, on informal estimates from various government bureaus, the President adjusted to $65,000,000,000 as the probable 1936 total.

The names of sixty-three undergraduates who will pledge for thirteen City College fraternities at the end of a six-week trial period were announced yesterday by Mortimer Cohen, newly elected chancellor of the Inter-Fraternity Council. Herbert Raskin was named secretary-treasurer of the council.

Higher educational standards, wider educational opportunities for women and international understanding form the trilogy of program topics for the New York State division of the American Association of University Women at its two-day biennial conference at Saratoga Springs this week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 2. -- The statement that the rate of body growth and final adult size over the earth is related to the intensity of climatic stimulation under which population masses live was made by Dr. C.A. Mills of the University of Cincinnati at the closing session of the American Anthropological Association meeting at Yale today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- With golfing under way on the fresh green turf, plans are being made to start the third Summer of play for the Berkshire County Four Ball League. An organization meeting has been called for this week, at which the schedule will be drawn up.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Government attorneys said tonight they believed that the Supreme Court had reached an agreement on the question of constitutionality of the 1934 Municipal Bankruptcy Act, a New Deal law.

IN the thirteen of its existence, approximately 1,000 students from the United States have been enrolled in the American School of Fine Arts in the Chateau at Fontainebleau. The school was sponsored by the French Government and is under its patronage -- a gesture of appreciation toward this country after the World War.
ATHENS, May 2. -- Tewfik Rushdu Aras, the Turkish Foreign Minister, arrived here today and conferred at length with Premier John Metaxas. He was also received by King George.
BUENOS AIRES, May 2. -- Fighting men who lost their freedom in the long "War of the Chaco" between Paraguay and Bolivia started for their homelands tonight.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 2. -- The first English performances of "Fuente Ovejuna." or "The Sheep Well." by Lope de Vega, were given by the Experimental Theatre of Vassar College last night and tonight. The translation, by John Garrett Underhill, had an elaborate and colorful setting by Harold Kopel.

ALL the writing tribe may look with envious eyes at Gordon Sinclair's running assignment. For seven years his paper, The Toronto Star, has been sending him hither and yon across the face of the earth to any sort of remote, alluring place where either spot news or good stories seemed ready to blossom.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- The cost of dozens of research projects and other scientific studies in progress in nearly every part of the country is being underwritten by the American Philosophical Society.

PLATINUM Changed to Gold" read the headlines last week. The physicist had been facing the possibility with dread. Not because he objected to changing anything into gold, even on the smallest and most expensive scale, but because the public would leap to the conclusion that the Treasury's hoard of billions in gold was worth no more than so much lead.

William Daingerfield Bristol, 27-year-old playwright of 140 West Fifty-seventh Street, died at 10:30 o'clock last night in the Roosevelt Hospital after taking an overdose of a sleeping potion at a hotel at 120 West Forty-fourth Street, where he had registered the night before.

TOKYO, May 2. -- The British Ambassador, Sir Robert Henry Clive, was Foreign Minister Hachiro Hirota today and drew the government's attention to the enormous amount of smuggling going on in North China through the area under the Japanese Army's control.

THIS choice collection of aphoristic gems is well named. Jade has a mystic allure and is susceptible of high polish. So these short, cryptic poems and prose poems of the best of Chinese philosophy of recent date have been tooled and polished until they shine with fascinating luster.

Manhattan College retained the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championship at Ohio Field yesterday but had to do some vigorous sprinting in the homestretch to do it. Columbia started off with such a brisk rush that the Jaspers spent a very nervous and uncomfortable afternoon, the Lions staying either right at their heels or a bit ahead of them for most of the way.

BY his brilliant and fruitful work during the seven years he has been president of the University of Chicago, Robert Maynard Hutchins has won the eager attention of all who are interested in the problems and possibilities of our higher education, and so this collection of twenty-four of his public addresses on various occasions should be welcomed by every one who from any standpoint is concerned in educational affairs.
BROOKLINE, Mass., May 2. -- Staging a ninth inning rally to tally three runs, St. John's University of Brooklyn recorded a 6 to 5 triumph over Northeastern University on the latter's diamond today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2. -- Rowing in the darkness with a searchlight on a police boat to mark the finish line, Princeton's varsity crew defeated its Harvard and M.I.T. rivals tonight to retain the Compton Cup.
The unemployment problem has created much discussion on the asserted uselessness of the man or woman past 50. But is this a fair appraisal?

MUSHROOMS are a feature of the May menu. Their delicate flavor blends admirably with that of Spring chicken; they supplement the popular vegetable dinner and often make a whole meal in themselves. Once a luxury, the cultivated mushroom is now sold at a price that commends itself to the housekeeper who must watch the pennies and buy wisely.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Polo looms large on the Summer sports calendar at White Sulphur Springs, and the Greenbrier Polo Club already is busy with plans to make this a memorable season. It has issued invitations to various polo associations to hold the 1936 inter-circuit and intra-circuit tournaments here in August.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Half a hundred men were named by Secretary Perkins today to work out a method for ending silicosis, a disease for which no cure has yet been found.

THE most recent issue of the Index of Twentieth Century Artists, published by the College Art Association, is devoted entirely to sculptors. There are five of them in this issue, which is the belated March number -- Alexander Archipenko, George Grey Bernard, Alfeo Faggi, Elie Nadelman and Heinz Warneke.

MIAMI, Fla., May 2. -- The cruise ship S.S. Florida, carrying 100 executives and members of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, steamed south from Miami last night. Today and tomorrow will be spent in Havana, the first port in a West Indies jaunt that will occupy two weeks and set a precedent in the organization for mass travel to other shores.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 2. -- Miss Patricia Nixon of Rochester climaxed the twelve events of the annual Rosemary Hall horse show at the Round Hill Club stables today by winning the championship of the upper school, traditional highest honor, with a fine exhibition of horsemanship.

BERLIN, May 2. -- Prices on the Boerse were mixed again today, failing to establish any definite tendency. Heavy industrials showed strength, Mansfeld gaining 1 1/4 points and Vereinigtestahl 5/8. Potashes weakened, Aschesleben losing 1/2 point.

AMERICA'S sundown seaboard again awaits the annual trek of tourists. From the uplands of British Columbia to the Mexican border, from the crags of the Rocky Mountains to the breakers of the Pacific, stretches an expanse of scenic grandeur as large as half a dozen European countries.

SIXTEEN etchings and drypoints by Rembrandt are on view (until May 11) at the gallery of M.A. McDonald, 665 Fifth Avenue. Mr. McDonald, whose thirty-five years' experience in the handling of prints has made him an authority in the field, calls these "the finest impressions of the most important and unique subjects that have come into my hands for sale."

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Evidence intended to show the existence of mighty rivers of electricity flowing in circular paths around the earth's magnetic poles was presented here today before the meeting of the American Geophysical Union by Dr. A.G. McNish of the Department of Terrestial Magnetism, Carnegie Institution of Washington.

The library from Ophir Hall, Purchase, N.Y., residence of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, comprising largely handsomely bound sets of works by eminent writers, biographies, histories, and general literature, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons.

BACK in the days when radio was younger than it is now, it was thought that the possibility of nation speaking direct to nation over the air held out the prospect of better international understanding, but now that European radio is expanding from its original national basis, and nation is at last speaking direct to nation, the net result so far seems to be a gathering flurry of propaganda charges.

In an effort to lay the basis on which the supply and type of housing in the future may be adjusted to the demand, the Mayor's Committee on City Planning has just completed a survey of the rentals paid in 1,838,876 occupied family units in New York.

Debate and mature consideration have become so unfashionable that even the greatest deliberative assembly in the world passed the Robinson "anti-chain-store" bill on Thursday after only two days of discussion. If the bill becomes law, however, it may have an important effect on our economic life -- and perhaps not exactly the effect the Senate intended.

A 50-year-old butcher successfully prevented two young thugs from stealing his Saturday receipts last night in his store on the east side of Amsterdam Avenue between Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets, but in doing so was critically wounded. The robbers escaped.

The National Americanization League, a patriotic organization, invaded Union Square yesterday and staged a sort of reactionary sequel to the May Day demonstrations by stumping all afternoon on the virtues of Americanism before a crowd of some 300 persons.

Sooner or later all metropolitan yachts and most of their sister ships from ports along the Atlantic seaboard visit City Island and like it. It is a sort of yachting Cafe de la Paix where the pleasure craft pass in review and every one sees his friends.

THOUGH deemed a banner season, the Broadway semester that ends this month will provide something less than a smash finish, at least as far as new plays are concerned. Whereas May of last year brought forth ten shows (eight new plays, a revue and a revival), its not so merry counterpart in 1936 promises a total of eight.

RUDYARD KIPLING'S estate of 155,228 is believed to be the second largest fortune left by a British author. The list is headed by Hall Caine, who left 250,000. Next come, in recent days, Stanley Weyman's 100,000, Thomas Hardy's 91,000 and John Galsworthy's 88,000.

ANOTHER book about Germany's "Supreme War Lord," to give him his latest title, is announced for publication on May 12 by Covici, Friede. The author is Rudolf Olden, former political editor of the Berliner Tageblatt, who now holds an appointment at Oxford.

AT this season of the year even the inexperienced gardener can keep up with the practical enthusiast by planting certain Summer tubers -- such as begonias, gloxinias and caladiums. Those mysterious cultural warnings, which perhaps have deterred the amateur in the past, lose their terror when he learns how few and simple are the rules.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee announced yesterday that, on the basis of reports from offices abroad, all remaining Jewish actors, singers and concert artists were deprived of employment in Germany in 1935 and 1,000 of 6,000 physicians remaining had emigrated.

ST. LOUIS, May 2. -- This morning Dodger and Cardinal officials conferred for three hours without reaching a decision on a proposed deal that would send Joe Stripp to St. Louis and bring an outfielder, possibly Ed Morgan, to Brooklyn.

The capture of Addis Ababa, capital of Ethiopia, by the Italians would not ordinarily mean the end of the war if this colonial campaign could be judged by similar conquests. Addis Ababa is merely the point where the only railway from the outside world comes to an end, but as the railway has not been used for military purposes its control is not important to the Ethiopian cause.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- The Sugartown Horse Show, which opened this morning on the estate of Joseph B. Ryan near Paoli, was the starting event in hunting and racing circles of five shows for May.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 2. -- A declaration of unflinching war against the "liquor traffic," a plea for moderation in the discussion of social problems, approval of the proposed merger of the three larger Methodist branches and appeals for greater evangelism and for world peace marked the Episcopal address of the Board of Bishops delivered today at the general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., May 2 (Canadian Press). -- A.B. Hayes, radio operator of the British freighter St. Quentin, was acclaimed here today as the damaged craft limped into port and master and crew told of their desperate struggle to keep afloat in mountainous seas.

HANOVER, N.H., May 2. -- The Dartmouth track team triumphed over Holy Cross today by 69 2-3 to 65 1-3. The outstanding performance was provided in the 440-yard dash when John Hoffstetter of Dartmouth broke his own record of 0:48 by one-fifth of a second.

Secretary MORGENTHAU told a committee of Congress last week that the Government now estimates its deficit for the current fiscal year at the enormous sum of $5,966,000,000. Never before, in a peacetime year, has the deficit approached this figure or, in fact, amounted to as much as $4,000,000,000.

THE winning compositions by contemporary American composers in the contest instituted by the Westminster Choir School last Spring will be performed at a festival of American music to be held May 18, 19 and 20 in Princeton, N.J.

The City Planning Commission in the charter proposal drafted by the Charter Revision Commission will, if established, prevent waste and reckless expenditures and give the city what it has never had before, long range planning, Thomas D. Thacher, chairman of the charter commission, declared last night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2. -- Harvard's nine today continued its march toward the Eastern intercollegiate championship by taking its second game from Princeton, thus making it five victories in a row in league competition. Whereas the Crimson won, 9 to 2, at Nassau, today it was 13 to 8 in a game in which Harvard did a lot of free hitting against Shorty Morris and Dick Bell.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan announced yesterday that he was ready to present evidence to the grand jury this week against Ellis Parker Sr. as the guiding genius behind the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, whose last-minute entry into the Lindbergh case delayed the execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann.

If the members of the House of Representatives who last Friday voted for the "Revenue Act of 1936" could be credited with a complete understanding of the bill's contents, the adoption of one of the last minute amendments might reasonably indicate that they had deliberately tried to add to the unworkability of the instrument.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 2. -- A resolution based on opposition to peace parades and similar student demonstrations, and urging more instruction in government was adopted unanimously today by the Reserve Officers Association of New York State.

TICKETS are growing longer and timetables thicker at railroad depots. Buses roar westward with baggage bulging under flapping canvas. With increasing frequency big planes rise from Newark Airport and turn whirring propellers toward the setting sun.

WASHINGTON. AMERICANS are planting too few flowers for perfume, according to Federal horticulturists. Many plant flower beds for color and decorative masses, and many plant kitchen and herb gardens for utility, but only here and there is there an amateur gardener who plants flowers for their fragrance.
LACLEDE, Mo., May 2 (AP). -- General John J. Pershing warned today against "insidious propaganda that there are better forms of government than that of the United States."

LONDON. THERE has recently been completed at Elstree by a new company called Concordia Films, and under conditions of considerable secrecy, a film which is said to represent a new theory of production.

LONDON, May 2. -- Describing how President Roosevelt's supporters have been "greatly encouraged" by the voting in State Presidential preference primary elections thus far held The Times says editorially:

LOS ANGELES, May 2 (AP). -- A weird death plot, in which the woman victim was drowned after being bound and thrust into a den of rattlesnakes, was charged to her husband tonight by the District Attorney's office.

Here is a story with the Springtime quality that we associate with the early troubadours. Vernon Ives has made a new and spirited translation of a little-known twelfth century Provencal romance, which recounts the doughty deeds of Sir Jaufry of Normandy, one of the youngest of the knights of the Round Table.

Two Broadway pioneers who still are active in the widely separated fields of acting and manufacturing paused yesterday to roll back the scroll of years a half-century or more as they gazed at the midtown crowds hurrying along a thoroughfare which has changed vastly since first they cast their fortunes with it sixty-three years ago.

An accelerating flight from the franc on the eve of today's "run-off" elections in France was disclosed yesterday by the announcement that an additional $13,065,000 gold had been engaged in Paris for shipment here, thus lifting to $21,870,000 the engagements of the last two days.
The Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial has contributed $50,000 to the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, it was announced yesterday by Chalmers Wood, chairman of the fund-raising campaign.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 3 (2P). -- A bitter battle over liberalization of the Prohibition party and a proposal to change its name loomed today as the first delegates arrived here for the opening Tuesday of the National Prohibition Convention.

CAIRO, May 3. -- Although the election returns are incomplete, the Wafd, as expected, has a strong lead, with 118 seats against 27 for the other parties. Eighty-seven constituencies are still to be heard from, but the Wafd expects to win 190 to 200 of the 232 seats in the Chamber of Deputies.
BOSTON, May 3 (AP). -- The highriding Red Sox, paced by the Ferrell brother combination of Pitcher Wes and Catcher Rick, shut out the world champion Tigers, 6 to 0, in the rain today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- Outclassing the defending champion St. Louis Shamrocks, 3 to 0, before 12,000 fans on the Rifle Club grounds today the Philadelphia German-Americans won their first national soccer crown and became the first all-amateur team ever to achieve top honors in the U.S. Football Association's annual cup series.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Two-thirds of the 1,001 delegates to the Republican National Convention have been selected, with 103 instructed for or endorsing Governor Landon of Kansas, 78 for Colonel Knox, 21 for Senator Borah and 38 for Senator Vandenberg.

MEXICO, D.F., May 3. -- By a score of 5 to 4, Mexico's squad which will figure in the next Olympic Games in the polo section, today beat the Field Artillery School team representing the Eighth Corps Area of the United States Army and sponsored by Major General Frank Parker.

Nicholas Mavrikes, 19-year-old violinist, gave a recital for the benefit of the Junior League of the National Home for Jewish Children at Denver and the Young Folks' League for Aid to Hebrew Infants yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Phillip Blackman, baritone, was the assisting artist, and Pierre Luboshutz provided the accompaniments.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, May 3. -- A British destroyer stood by today as Emperor Haile Selassie and his party arrived from Addis Ababa. It was indicated in high quarters that he planned to travel on the warship to Aden, Arabia, and there transfer to a liner bound for England.

Plans for modernizing the roof garden atop the Hotel Astor in Times Square at a cost of more than $50,000 were announced yesterday by Frederick A. Muschenheim, president of the Hotel Astor Corpora[ion. As part of $600,000 project for rehabilitating the hotel started last Fall, the roof will be converted into an air-cooled area resembling a garden on the Italian Riviera.
Fordham and Manhattan continued to set the pace in metropolitan intercollegiate baseball during the week. They remain undefeated with ten and nine victories respectively.

Headed by Theresa Helburn of the Theatre Guild and sponsored by seven motion picture companies, a "Bureau of New Plays" announced yesterday a campaign to discover and finance new playwrights among college students and recent graduates.

A study of income arising in nine basic industries of the country in the years 1919 to 1934, which is published today by the National Bureau of Economic Research, shows that, measured in current dollars both income produced and paid out declined in most industries.

The Department of Parks will open thirteen new playgrounds today, increasing to 149 the total added to the department's recreational system since January, 1934. There were 108 playgrounds in the park system prior to the present administration.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- Lard had spells of activity here last week, caused by liberal selling by speculative holders to take profits and by buying by shorts, which at times led to sharp advances. There was nothing in the movement of hogs or prices to attract special attention.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP). -- After pitching three good relief innings Mike Kowalik, young Chicago right-hander, weakened in the twelfth today and the Phillies reached him for four hits and three runs to take the opening game of the series from the Cubs, 8 to 5.

In considering the relations of industrial management with the public and with labor too frequently there is overlooked the great change that has occurred in the background and attitude of management. A new conception of service to customers has taken a rightful place in the functioning of all departments of an enterprise.

ADDIS ABABA, May 3 (By The Associated Press and Other American Correspondents Collaborating in Use of Limited Wireless Facilities). -- Fire, pillaging, murder and anarchy raged in governmentless Addis Ababa today. An American woman was killed by a bullet from marauders as she slept.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 3. -- Between intermittent showers, thunder and lightning, Mrs. Gordon Wright's famous aged bay gelding Sonny captured his seventh jumping championship of the year when he annexed the rosette in the sixth annual Harrison Horse Show in the Kentucky Riding Academy's ring today.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- European political and financial uncertainties, coupled with the effects of the devalued dollar, brought $1,741, 000,000 of foreign gold into the United States last year, according to the annual analysis by the Department of Commerce of the United States's balance of international payments for 1935, made public today.

Considerably more proficient in frequently smacking timely hits of various dimensions to virtually every corner of the ball park, the Yankees climbed back into the winning column yesterday as the Browns invaded the Stadium for the opener of a three-game series.

The WPA Music Project's six-day festival of American music opened with a concert by the New York Civic Orchestra last night at the Manhattan Theatre. Three conductors wielded the baton at this inaugural event. They were Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, national director of the Federal Music Project; Howard Hanson, director of the Eastman Conservatory of Music in Rochester, and Phillip James, head of the Music Department of New York University.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Matters directly affecting the budget will provide the chief interest in both branches of Congress this week, with the Senate Finance Committee working on revision of the Tax Bill, while House leaders prepare for passage of the Second Deficiency Bill carrying President Roosevelt's request for $1,500,000,000 for relief.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 3. -- Mrs. Madeline C. McGlone of the Bronx tonight carried off the highest honors in the second annual specialty show of the Boston Terrier Club of Westchester held in the County Center.

Hyman Batkin, president of the Universal Folding Box Company, is leaving the Bush Terminal in Brooklyn for larger quarters in Hoboken where he has purchased the one and two-story factory occupying the block front on the east side of Monroe Street, from Twelfth to Thirteenth Streets.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has accepted an invitation of the French Government to arrange a retrospective exhibition of American art tom be held in the Museum of the Jeu de Paume, Paris, coincidentally with the World's Fair in that city during the Summer of 1937.
Louis Silver, 45 years old, reputed associate of Johnny Torrio, Public Enemy No. 2 of this city, died yesterday morning in Roosevelt Hospital of bullet wounds in the chest and abdomen.

BERLIN, May 3. -- A command issued by Chancellor Adolf Hitler after the intervention of Field Marshal Werner van Blomberg, the War Minister, has calmed the storm raging for the past week around Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the Economies Minister, and the latest "Schacht crisis" is believed today to have ended in something like a draw.

GAETANO SALVEMINI resigned his chair of history at the University of Florence in November, 1925, a few months after he had been put on trial for clandestinely compiling and distributing a pamphlet, vilifying the King of Italy and doing (or not doing) certain other things. Early in 1927 he arrived in the United States an exile.

American labor stood firmly opposed to the principles of ironbound dictatorship and ready to aid its victims, Mayor La Guardia and labor leaders declared last night before almost 18,000 persons at Madison Square Garden.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., May 3. -- A wide investigation was begun late today to discover the identity of a man whose head, cut off while he was still alive and conscious, was found floating in a pond hear here.

The prospective deficit for the current fiscal year, charging the entire veterans' bonus to the year, reaches the enormous sum of $5,966,000,000. The estimated deficit for the next fiscal year is $2,675,000,000. It would not be difficult to show that not all the expenditures that help to produce these deficits are necessary.

A total of 2,958,100,000 passengers used the rapid transit lines, surface street railways, Hudson tubes and bus lines reporting to the Transit Commission during the year ended Dec. 31, 1935, according to figures made public by the commission yesterday.
Many a piece of legislation of importance to the general public is frequently lost sight of because it is thought to be "technical" and therefore something that concerns only the specialists.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 3 (AP). -- A secret questioning of Alvin Karpis, "Public Enemy No. 1," was continued today by Federal agents determined to draw from the gangster a list of those who aided his long flight from the law.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- Liquidation by tired holders last week carried wheat prices down to around the lowest of the season in the current downturn, with Winnipeg at the lowest level of the season. While this softening of prices permitted shorts to cover recent sales, there was comparatively little of what is called good buying support.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 3 (AP). -- Rochester outbatted Baltimore to capture a 13-9 decision today. The Wings clinched the game in the fifth when Hugh Poland, sent in to bat for the league's leading hitter, Lou Bush, smashed a home run over the right-field fence with the bases loaded.

Increased purchases of rolling stock reflect an expectation of a greater volume of railway traffic, according to the Association of American Railroads. The association reported that the Class I carriers had 13,562 freight cars on order on April 1, against 482 the year before.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP). -- In a new move to bring the Civilian Conservation Corps back to its authorized strength of 350,000, Robert Fechner, the director, today directed State enrollment officers to disregard previous quotas and accept any qualified boy from a relief family.
Greta Garbo, film actress, returned yesterday on the motor ship Gripsholm of the Swedish American Line after a year's visit in her native Sweden.

After May 1 the American college campus ceases to be a danger zone and a sore spot, as they say on the maps of troubled Europe, and reverts to its traditional Arcadian charm. The student body puts aside its demonstrations and protests and turns to yearbooks and class days.

MADRID, May 3. -- Parliamentary elections were held today in Cuenca and Granada, where the Conservative victories of Feb. 16 had been annulled on the ground that they were fraudulent. No disorders were reported by the Ministry of the Interior, and no official returns were available.

The late Elsie Schauffler's "Parnell," which made a ninety-eight-performance visit earlier this season, returns again this evening. It will play this time at the Forty-eighth Street, and in its leading roles will be Dennis King and Edith Barrett instead of George Curzon and Margaret Rawlings.

The blocking by the Republican-controlled Assembly of the State social security legislation was characterized yesterday as "the worst kind of partisanship" by United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, in a speech over WHN.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 3. -- A reception and tea marked the opening of the eighteenth annual exhibition of the Greenwich Society of Artists in the art gallery of the Greenwich Library this afternoon at 4 o'clock. The exhibition of work by members of the society and New York artists will be on view to the public commencing tomorrow and continuing through May 7.

ROME, May 3. -- An urgent appeal has been received in Rome from the French Government asking that Italian troops occupy Addis Ababa with as little delay as possible to re-establish order and protect the lives and property of European residents.

The siege of Pershing Hall by its owning corporation and by the police, and the holding of the fort by four members of the American Legion, Paris Post, who refuse to permit that post to be evicted, is a tragic situation, but one, nevertheless, possessed of a salutary phase.

With a substantial number of buyers visiting the wholesale markets here last week, there was an active demand for all types of Summer merchandise, particularly dresses. Reorders for merchandise for current selling were fairly heavy in some departments, reflecting the steady rise in consumer demand with the advent of more favorable weather conditions in most sections.
St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street, celebrated yesterday the 131st anniversary of its founding.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- Livestock prices were highest in the first two days of last week and lowest at the close, establishing fair declines, although supplies were ample for all trade requirements and a demand was rather indifferent. The top price for hogs was $10.85 a hundredweight, made on Monday, and the low point was $10.55 on Wednesday.

Mrs. Margaret Wiggen, wife of a Brooklyn department store buyer, died at Flushing Hospital in Queens at 5:15 P.M. yesterday of a bullet wound. She was shot by a Nassau County detective in a hold-up scare near Little Neck, L.I., on April 25.

BOSTON, May 3. -- Six Republican members of the House of Representatives made public tonight vouchers showing State payments for taxi rides to Boston hotels, burlesque theatres, a wedding and to New Bedford, Springfield and Pittsfield.

Thomas M. Carhart, '38, of Watervliet, N.Y., won the sixty- seventh annual Grady Memorial Oratorical Contest at Manhattan College yesterday. The speaking competition was a feature of the fourth annual Campus Day exercises, which attracted a crowd of more than 2,500 to the Riverdale institution.

A new feat in the highly skilled craft of bridge building was performed yesterday when the colossal lift span of the Triborough Bridge connecting East 125th Street with Randall's Island, completely assembled and weighing more than 4,000,000 pounds, was floated out into the center of the Harlem River and hoisted into position in the bridge.

In spite of some uncertainties which have arisen in the last month, there seems to be no reason to revise hopeful views of the Spring and Summer business prospects, the National City Bank says in the current issue of its monthly bulletin.

The first of a series of chain letters sent out by the National Women's Pro-Roosevelt League was mailed yesterday to Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, from the league's headquarters at 21 East Seventy-sixth Street. Letters requesting each recipient to send similar letters to five other women will be sent throughout the United States.

LONDON, May 3. -- With Great Britain's League of Nations policy in ruins, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and his colleagues coolly began today to prepare for a retreat from Geneva in coming months and for ultimate revision of the League covenant.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Registrations statements under the Securities Act of 1933 involving $583,000,000 became effective in March, a new high record for a month, bringing the aggregate of effective statements for the first quarter of 1936 to $1,071,000,000.

The Kings County grand jury investigating the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel is expected to hear today the testimony of Murray Bleefeld, who has told District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan that Ellis Parker Sr., Chief of Burlington County detectives, was the instigator of the crime.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 3. -- "I want to take nothing from Bold Venture, which ran like a fine colt, but I wish to say that I am satisfied to have Brevity take him on any time, at any distance," was the declaration today of Joseph E. Widener at his Elmendorf Farm.

Women headed by Mrs. Sherman Post Haight have arranged a card party for May 19 at the Plaza in behalf of the memorial and patriotic program sponsored by the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association at Roosevelt House, the birthplace and boyhood home of the late President Roosevelt.

Politics was described as Public Enemy No. 1 yesterday by J. Edgar Hoover, director, Bureau of Investigation, Department of Justice, in an interview here. Mr. Hoover arrived in New York by airplane from St. Paul, where he delivered Alvin Karpis, known as Public Enemy No. 1, to the Federal authorities for trial on kidnapping charges.

A LONG in June or July it may be necessary to consult the medical journals for dope on the baseball races. The Giants had so many hospital cases in the first couple of weeks that Gaffer Terry had to hobble out to first base himself on his unsteady underpinning and put chance acquaintances at various points on the Polo Grounds greensward.

For the second time since the outbreak of recent labor troubles a voyage of the Panama Pacific liner California was canceled yesterday after the ship, with 250 passengers, returned to her pier at the foot of West Twenty-first Street at 3 A.M. The ship was forced to put back when the port engine went out of commission off Barnegat Light at 4:30 Saturday afternoon.

HAVANA, May 3. -- Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, the President-elect, returned with his family this afternoon from the United States, where he had been vacationing since the middle of March. A crowd of 2,500 persons greeted him near the dock.

Recent freshman students at Fordham University have been found mentally and scholastically inferior to first-year students of other years, it was said yesterday by the Rev. Charles 5. Deans, dean of Fordham College.

MOSCOW, May 3. -- The total eclipse of the sun that will sweep across the Soviet Union June 19 will be the most widely observed and studied of any in history, Dr. Donald H. Menzel of Harvard University said today on his arrival with Mrs. Menzel and seven other members of the Harvard-Massachusetts Institution of Technology Expedition.

JERUSALEM, May 3. -- The predictions that the general Arab strike in Palestine would be over in a few days have proved false. Today is the twelfth day of the complete strike throughout the country except at Haifa, where it is being observed only half-heartedly.

Jesus told His disciples to forget their illusions of grandeur and not to expect any earthly reward for having established Him in His glory, the Rev. A. Wismar of St. Matthew's Lutheran Church, Convent Avenue and West 145th Street, told his congregation yesterday morning.

NEW HAVEN, May 2. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.2, which compares with 82.5 the week before, 82.6 two weeks before, 82.5 three weeks before and 82.5 four weeks before.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., May (AP). -- The British freighter City of Auckland started for New York late today carrying the crew of the Canadian freighter Canadian Planter, with which she was in collision at about 1:30 this morning near here in Buzzards Bay.

James G. Conway, president of the New York Towboat Exchange, attacked yesterday the Dock Department's proposal to extend the East River bulkhead lines into the river between Twenty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets as dangerous to navigation and a potential cause of flood conditions similar to those which existed last Winter in Hartford and Pittsburgh.
One way to start the season right is to go fishing with a boy. Better yet, go fishing with four boys. It's four times as much fun.

Friends and colleagues of Percy Hammond, late drama critic of The Herald Tribune, joined in eulogizing him last evening over Station WOR. The speakers were Burns Mantle and John Mason Brown, drama critics for The Daily News and Post, respectively, and Grantland Rice, sports writer. Mr. Hammond died April 25 at the age of 63.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP). -- A five-run uprising in the ninth, climaxed by Zeke Bonura's homer into the left-field stands, gave the White Box an 8-to-4 victory over the Athletics today before 12,000 fans.

An independent committee of Protestant Episcopal clergymen and laymen has issued an appeal for active support by that denomination of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.
