An official of the federation said last night that several Protestant Episcopal churches had been members for forty years without taking more than a nominal part in the program.
ROME, May 3. -- At least 400,000 of the 500,000 Italian soldiers and workmen in East Africa will remain there as settlers, Premier Mussolini indicated today in a speech to a peasants group.

PITTSBURGH, May 3. -- Today's official communique concerning the Dodger movement on the Western front showed the situation still unchanged. Casey Stengel's troops made one briefly successful foray through the Pirate defenses, but when their leader, Van Lingle Mungo, was shot down late in the engagement they collapsed into a fifth straight defeat.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP). -- Led by Manager Frankie Frisch, the first-place Cardinals turned back the Bees, 6 to 2, today, for their sixth straight triumph in the opener of a three-game series. The contest was played under lowering skies before 7,500 fans.

The Reynolds Spring Company reports for the quarter ended on March 31 net earning of $139,806 after all charges, including provision for Federal income tax, equal to 96 cents a share on outstanding stock. April shipments will exceed by 15 per cent the best previous month in the company's history, C.G. Munn, president, said.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- A grimly determined band, led by Cornelius Van H. Engert, United States Minister Resident in Addis Ababa, and encouraged by Mrs. Engert, tonight was holding the American Legation there, whence more than a dozen persons, mostly women and children, had been evacuated.

Public prayer was offered yesterday throughout the city "on behalf of the persecuted and the refugees of the world." This was at the request of the American Christian Committee for German Refugees, of which the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman is chairman; the Committee for the Relief and Liberation of Victims of Persecution in Europe, Matthew Woll, chairman, and the New York Board of Jewish Ministers, Rabbi Samuel J. Levinson, chairman.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 3. -- The Balkan Entente will assemble for its first meeting tomorrow. The Greek Premier, John Metaxas, and the Turkish Foreign Minister, Tewfik Rushdu Aras, with their delegations, arrived this afternoon and were met at the station by Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and the Ministers of the Balkan Entente States.

Stores throughout the country are planning to cooperate in the promotion of National "Swim for Health Week," sponsored by the National Knitted Outerwear Association and the National Association of Amusement Parks, Pools and Beaches, according to the committee.

In spite of several developments tending to depress prices last week, quotations in the cotton futures market showed only a moderate recession. At the close on Saturday on the New York Cotton Exchange the losses ranged from 7 to 18 points.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP). -- A proposal that the resettlement administration or some other governmental agency acquire control of the cotton-picking machine invented by the Rust Brothers of Memphis, Tenn., is now in negotiation between the inventors and government officials.

ON THE ROAD TO ADDIS ABABA, May 3. -- It is now possible to say what the world doubtless guessed some days ago, namely, that Marshal Pietro Badoglio and his general staff are with this motorized column, which is pushing steadily toward Addis Ababa.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,806,696,200. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest bearing discount bills.

Senator Frederick Steiwer of Oregon, who will be temporary chairman of the Republican National Convention, returned to Washington yesterday noon, after his speech before the Queens County Republican Committee at Jamaica Saturday night.

Steps were taken last night at a meeting in the Hotel Astor of representatives of local and national organizations of dancing teachers to fight alleged unfair competition on the part of WPA and NYA workers.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has received a testimonial of honor from the American Institute of Architects for the restoration of Colonial Williamsburg, "the symbol of an early American culture," it was announced yesterday by Stephen F. Voorhees, president of the institute.

BERLIN, May 1. -- Berlin's security markets on the whole this week were under the influence of a departmental shuffle whereby supreme responsibility in the Reich's domains of raw materials and foreign exchange was in form transferred to Colonel-Gen. Hermann Goering.

The argument over evolution "weakened the Christian church because it gave many persons the idea that Christianity is only a system of doctrines and dogmas," said the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, yesterday morning in his sermon, "Religion Is Over-Defended."

Mayor La Guardia and Mrs. La Guardia were among the worshipers yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, when the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo began his pastorate. Dr. Sizoo was called to the church two months ago from Washington, D.C., where he had been pastor of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, known as "The Church of the Presidents."

CHICAGO, May 4 (AP). -- The eighty-sixth annual report of the Illinois Central Railroad Company disclosed today that the total net income of the system for 1935 was $7,529,256, a decrease of 48 per cent compared with the 1934 figure. After deduction of fixed and other charges there was a deficit in 1935 of $9,932,399, compared with a deficit of $2,964,646 in the preceding year.

Lightning damaged property in widely separated parts of the city yesterday during thunderstorms that began shortly after noon and continued intermittently for several hours. The accompanying rains, which were at times a mild drizzle and at others a heavy downpour, drove to shelter thousands of persons who had gone to the city beaches for the day.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 3 (AP). -- Although they reeled off a triple play and outhit the Bisons, the league-leading Newark Bears suffered another setback in the opening game of their series today as the locals put over the winning run with none out in the ninth to gain a 10-9 verdict.

Grudging gifts to the poor do not constitute charity, the Rev. Joseph Tytheridge warned yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, rebuking persons who ignore the Catholic Charities appeal or willfully evade calls from workers.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP). -- Lightning, flames and firemen staged a spectacular exhibition today in the steeple tip of the old Postoffice Department Building 300 feet above Pennsylvania Avenue.

PARIS, May 2. -- The first results of the elections, which were marked by unexpected gains by the Communists, startled both the country and the Bourse. On Wednesday the Stock Exchange was panicky, and if the authorities had not intervened before closing, quotations would have been even lower.

ALBANY, May 3. -- Governor Lehman announced today the signing of three more bills in his anticrime program as the legislators began returning to the Capitol in the hope of reaching final adjournment before the end of the coming week.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said that "one must look hopefully forward to a new appreciation of cultural idealism, as an antidote to the present day vogue of spiritual and intellectual depression," when he addressed a congregation at St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bouwerie yesterday.

The wearniness of sin was emphasized by the Rev. Wesley G. Huber, pastor of the Lincoln Square Baptist Church, Worcester, Mass., in his sermon yesterday morning at Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street. "Most men of today are old at 40, when life ought to begin," he said.

Barring special weakness in the Swiss franc and Polish zloty, fluctuations in the other foreign exchanges last week were narrow and unimportant. Business was typical of that of the last several weeks, chiefly for routine requirements.

Out of the fog two miles south by east of Ambrose Lightship, where a fleet of eight fishing boats rode at anchor, the inbound Bull liner Angelina, a 414-footer of 4,772 tons, slid suddenly into sight just before 2 P.M. yesterday and sheared off the stern of the 65-foot MJR III, out of Sheepshead Bay.
TOKYO, Monday, May 4. -- Empeter Hirohito this morning opened a session of the Diet that his subjects will watch with unusual anxiety.

CINCINNATI, May 3. -- Finding his charges embroiled in another extra-inning battle, their third on a trip already frought with plenty of disaster, Colonel Bill Terry decided to take matters in his own brawny hands today.

Detective James F. Carberry, an investigator in the office of the Police Commissioner, spent his day off yesterday catching a chicken hawk in Brooklyn Heights and solving the month-old mystery of who stole the fresh-killed chickens from his favorite Sunday dining place.
Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, announced yesterday that contributions to the committee's fund had reached a total of $406,344.
YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, May 3. -- Artificial recreation of a chemical which may be the common ancestor of blood and of chlorophyll, the green coloring matter of plants, is announced at Antioch College.

The devotion to the cause of youth manifested by Associate Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals took precedence over his services as jurist, philanthropist and religious leader at a dinner in his honor last night at the Hotel Astor.

The prices of commodity futures generally drifted lower in quiet trading last week. In the cash markets cocoa, eggs, tin and silk were higher, while all the grains, butter, lard, cotton, print cloths, rubber and hides weakened.

Forty "grants-in-aid" totaling $23,650 to professors and others throughout the country, including one abroad, for the support of research in the social sciences were announced yesterday by the Social Science Research Council, 230 Park Avenue.

William Casin, 17 years old, of 30 Marsher Place, Princes Bay, S.I., was killed and John Donnell, 16, of 6,565 Amboy Road, Princes Bay, was injured critically about 7 o'clock yesterday morning when they were struck by an automobile in Eltingville, S.I.

DETROIT, May 3. -- William J. Cameron, who is regarded as speaking for Henry Ford, declared tonight on a radio network that the nation could expect that, "regardless of the adversities they have met," President Roosevelt's policies of the past would be his policies for the future.
ESSEX, Conn., May 3. -- Twenty-nine sailing dinghies from seven States competed today in the Essex Yacht Club's Spring regatta, in which the Roosevelt Trophy was the foremost stake.

It was obviously the speech of a disappointed man which the British Foreign Secretary made to his constituents on Saturday. He had to face, and to admit, a pretty complete defeat of British diplomacy and British policy. Decisive events had occurred, he said, which they must henceforth deal with in a spirit of realism, taking to heart the lessons which they teach.

With only one of the eight matches, but an important one, unfinished in the seventh round of the United States title chess tournament yesterday, the lead passed to Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., the Pacific Coast champion.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 3. -- A warning against trying to make church property yield a rental income through development as a business enterprise is contained in the report of Bishop Francis McConnell of the New York area to the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in session here.

The founding of the first American chapter of the Ancient Order of Hibernians and the memory of its members who defended old St. Patrick's Cathedral, Prince and Mulberry Streets, against Know Nothing mobs in 1844, were commemorated yesterday at special exercises at St. James Church, James Street and New Bowery, and at the old Cathedral.

Since the art scion got under way in October, few if any weeks have produced less than twenty new exhibitions. The present week is no exception and included on the roster are two large annual group shows. One of these is the Fourteenth Spring Exhibition of the Salons of America, which opens on Wednesday and continues until May 23, at the American Art-Anderson Galleries, always a large and diversified event.
A new name has been found at last for that branch of the Police Department which, if it operated at ideal efficiency, would make all other branches unnecessary, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, May 2. -- A money market exists only for day-to-day loans, which cost 4 per cent, with the longer-term loans being given only by the Bank of France. The bank's return for April 24 shows a new increase in bills discounted of almost 400,000,000 francs, while the total of loans on securities and government bonds declined only 100,000,000 francs.

The May appeal for donations of articles suitable for resale at Everybody's Thrift Shop will be inaugurated Wednesday afternoon with a reception to be known as "A Party With a String Attached to It," which will be given by Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell at her home, 161 East Sixty-fourth Street.

Theatrical Protective Union Local 1, which exercises jurisdiction over the stagehands in Manhattan, Bronx and Staten Island, celebrated its golden anniversary last night at the Hotel Astor. The organization was founded April 26, 1886. About 3,000 people were present, more than half of whom were members of Local 1.

LONDON, May 3. -- The following radiogram was received in London through official channels today from four British correspondents in Addis Ababa -- G.L. Steer, representing The Times of London and THE NEW YORK TIMES, and the correspondents of The Daily Telegraph, Reuters and the Exchange Telegraph Company -- who because of the closing of the Ethiopian Government radio station had been unable to send any messages by that means:

Largely because the prices of United States cotton have not been supported by a government loan above market levels this season, the cotton has sold more nearly on a competitive basis with foreign growths in world markets, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

GENEVA, May 3. -- The news of the departure of Emperor Haile Selassie caused such dismay here that it could not be believed. Unlike the prospect of the fall of Addis Ababa, it was not expected. On second thought some take it more philosophically as being, perhaps, the wisest and least dangerous move to the Negus.

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday the award of the Theodore N. Vail medal in bronze to three employes in recognition of "unusual devotion" to duty. The awards are made annually in memory of the late president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company by every company in the Bell system.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, May 3. -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, bareheaded, haggard and dejected, stepped off his train here today after his flight from Addis Ababa. He received a royal salute from a triple line of French colonial soldiers and then was received as a guest by the Governor.

NEW ORLEANS, May 3 (AP). -- Questioned by Federal agents, the attractive red-haired girl friend of Alvin Karpis was believed to have "talked" today. But there was no word coming from the inquisitors concerning what they obtained from the woman of mystery.

PITTSBURGH, May 3. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 71 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the previous week, the estimate for which was revised downward from 72 per cent. The rate in the last fortnight was three-eighths above that in January and almost one-third better than in the last quarter of 1935.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 3. -- Arriving at the Greenbrier today were many persons trekking north from the Kentucky Derby, among them Morton L. Schwartz, owner of Bold Venture, this year's Derby winner, and Mrs. Schwartz.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 3. -- Athletic insignia will be given to 150 Army representatives in Winter sports, it was announced today by Major L.D. Worsham, graduate manager of athletics. Ten of the awards listed are major letters, the others including minor letters, monograms, class numerals and managerial recognition.

The New Singers, Lan Adomian conducting, presented a program of contemporary music in their Spring concert at the New School for Social Research last night. The assisting artists were Joseph Posner, baritone; Hester Sondergaard, narrator; Alex North and Jerome Moross, pianists; Sam Prizant, percussion, and Jack Scherr, accordion.

George Dock Jr., public relations adviser to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in Washington in the last two and one-half years, has resigned to take a position in the New York office of Doremus Co., financial advertising agency, on June 1, according to an announcement.

Shipments of hosiery into consumption totaled 10,420,286 dozen pairs of all types in March, it was announced today by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. This figure, the association states, represents a gain of 652,050 dozen pairs, or 6.7 per cent, over shipments in March, 1935, and more than a seasonal increase of 1,758,218 dozen pairs, or 20.3 per cent, over shipments in the preceding month.

After the Hindenburg, world's largest airship, sails from Friedrichshafen, Germany, the day after tomorrow on the first of ten scheduled trips to the United States, she will be in communication by radio through the office of Naval Communications in New York until she is within 500 miles of our coast.
PARIS, Monday, May 4. -- With the Communists bringing the total of their seats to seventy-one, the Left parties swept to a conclusive victory yesterday in the second ballot of the French elections.

ROME, May 3 (AP). -- General Pirzo Biroli's Eritrean Askaris were perched on hills within long artillery range of Addis Ababa tonight waiting for white troops of Marshal Pietro Badoglio's main Continued on Page Eleven.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Picric acid, a common antiseptic, was suggested today by the Public Health Service as a possible preventive of sleeping sickness and infantile paralysis.

There is a memory of General MCCOY as the young aide whom General WOOD ordered to give to the great throng in Havana the signal that the United States was recognizing the new Republic of Cuba -- as he did by lowering the United States flag over the palace on the day of Cuban independence.

Catholic action aims toward the realization of social justice and the spreading of tolerance among people of all faiths, John J. Bennett, State Attorney General, said yesterday in an address at the twelfth annual communion breakfast of the United States Custom House Holy Name Society at the Hotel Astor.

While reading in the Old Testament I came across the story of Rahab -- how she hid the spies sent by Joshua, and how that great general sent special agents and saved not only her life but the lives of all her people, at the taking of Jericho. Joshua honored the promise made by the spies -- three thousand or more years ago -- and did it handsomely.

Senator STEIWER of Oregon, who is to be temporary chairman of the Republican National Convention in June, gave an advance specimen of his quality in his speech before the Republicans of the Borough of Queens. It was a forthright and vigorous utterance. Without ranting or excess, the Senator attacked the Democratic Administration at its most vulnerable points.

Pelted by hail stones and drenched by a thunder shower, Charles Eschenbach of Rockville Center, L.I., and the New York A.C., raced to the National A.A.U. 30,000-meter walking championship yesterday at Oakwood Heights, S.I.

Two fires, apparently of incendiary origin, were discovered yesterday in the Bronx, one of them in a tenement house in the Morrisania section, where in the last three weeks ten other fires have been recorded as the work of an "alcoholic pyromaniac" who has eluded capture.

Home relief was the topic night at the Civic Repertory, where the New Theatre League presided over two angry forty-minute sermons. "Ten Million Others," by David Danzig, and "From Little Acorns,' by William Hauptman and Joseph Samuelson, were the plays, and though they differed in mood they agreed in substance -- Fourteenth Street is bitter about home relief.

KATOWICE, Poland, May 3. --The fifteenth anniversary of the third and final Upper Silesian rising following a post-war plebiscite was celebrated here today with great pomp. The rising, which started with the sudden occupation of several cities by well-armed and well-trained Polish forces on May 3, 1921, greatly influenced the League of Nations Council decision on the disputed territory's division between Poland and Germany.

PARIS, May 3. -- A graphic picture of the situation at Addis Ababa was given today in laconic radiograms received by the French Foreign Ministry from Paul Bodard, French Minister at the Ethiopian capital. One of the last of these read:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 3 (AP). -- Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York, chairman of the House Immigration, Naturalization and Deportation Committee, declared here tonight that while the Hitler government refused to meet its obligations to American bondholders, it spent almost $32,000,000 to spread propaganda against the Jewish race in the United States.

As an interested but uninformed observer of the New York scene, I seek a little clarity in regard to your article of April 27 about the Knickerbocker Greys. Was it a United States cadet corps of boys, aged 8 and 9, that marched down Fifth Avenue or one of Mr. Mussolini's regiments with their gas masks left behind?

A festival of flowers and fashions will be held under the auspices of the New York Chapter of Kenwood Alumnae during the luncheon hour at the formal opening of Chatham Walk on May 16 for the benefit of the work for the blind at the Sacred Heart Convent in Albany.

The fourteen-story Hotel Gregorian at 40-44 West Thirty-fifth Street was sold by the Braker Memorial Home, E. Clifford Potter, president, to Hyman Portnof in a transaction announced over the week-end. The buyer controls a number of hotels here, including the Murray Hill, the Wolcott, the Stratford and the Grand Union.

More than 2,000 veterans of the Spanish-American War and members of other veterans' and patriotic societies paraded up Fifth Avenue in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday to exercises in commemoration of the thirty-eighth anniversary of the Battle of Manila.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 3 (AP). -- Toronto hit freely to win the first game from Albany in today's double-header, 6 to 1, and then the teams battled to a 3-3 tie in the second game, which was called on account of rain, with two out in the seventh inning.

BERLIN, May 1. -- Experts here agree that the mark's nominal gold parity need never be abandoned involuntarily if only the new plan and rationing of debt payments are retained. This is all the more true because exports promise to develop satisfactorily.
MONTREAL, May 3 (AP). -- With Henry Johnson pitching one-hit ball in the second game, Montreal took both sides of a double-header from Syracuse today, both by scores of 2 -- 0.

CLEVELAND, May 3 (AP). -- The iron and steel industry, the magazine Steel said today, continues to exhibit a surprising degree of vitality "despite the unsettling factors of an approaching national political campaign, impending tax legislation and the stock market break."
MONTREAL, May 3 (AP). -- With Henry Johnson pitching one-hit ball in the second game, Montreal took both sides of a double-header from Syracuse today, both by scores of 2 -- 0.

CLEVELAND, May 3 (AP). -- The iron and steel industry, the magazine Steel said today, continues to exhibit a surprising degree of vitality "despite the unsettling factors of an approaching national political campaign, impending tax legislation and the stock market break."

For three years 50-year-old Paul Rother, a carpenter, trudged the streets in Hudson County, N.J., daily and visited employment office after employment office in an unsuccessful search for a job. Today, five minutes after he was hired and put to work, he dropped dead.
Brief biographical sketches of the winners of Pulitzer prize awards in letters and journalism follow:

Two years of junior college competition will be equivalent to one year in senior college varsity competition, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has ruled in its latest move to standardize eligibility regulations, The Associated Press reports.
TORONTO, May 4 (AP). -- Two errors, both by Keith Molesworth, Baltimore shortstop, gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 4-3 decision over the Orioles in twelve innings today.

The Panama Pacific liner California lay at her pier at West Twenty-first Street yesterday while arrangements were made for the unloading of her 2,700 tons of freight and the transfer of the baggage of the 250 passengers who were aboard her when she was forced by engine trouble to return to port early Sunday morning.

RICHMOND, Va., May 4. -- Overcrowded urban housing makes the construction of nearly 10,000,000 new or modernized low-cost houses and the rebuilding of many American cities inevitable, speakers today told the opening session of the National Planning Conference.

Nine charitable organizations receive bequests totaling $56,000 in the will of Albert Stieglitz, partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Halle Stieglitz, filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday. The will names the widow, Hannah Stieglitz, of 330 Park Avenue, as principal beneficiary.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 4. -- The honor of opening the season with a victory fell today to the lot of Harvey W. Shaffer of Meadow Brook, an amateur with three strokes to put to use, and Henry Ciuci, dapper young Fresh Meadow professional.

LONDON, May 4. -- The election success of the French parties of the Left, which profess fidelity to the principles of the League of Nations, comes too late, it is thought in Lotion, to back the British policy of resistance to Italian aggression against Ethiopia.
BERLIN, May 4. -- There is unrestrained satisfaction in private and more restrained gratification in public throughout Germany over developments of what one newspaper calls a "dramatic week-end."

The executive committee of the State Chamber of Commerce, headed by Richard W. Lawrence, made public yesterday excerpts from a report it will make to the chamber on Thursday on its recent survey of the activities of Communists and other radicals in this country.

Prospects for an agreement between anthracite operators and miners, who have been deadlocked for twelve weeks, appeared brighter at midnight last night when the joint conference of representatives of the owners and the United Mine Workers adjourned to reconvene at 11 A.M. today.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The Supreme Court failed again today to rule on the constitutionality of the Guffey Coal Act. This means that the decision will be delayed for another two weeks at least.

LONDON, May 4. -- Both Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today that the British Government would consider changes in the League of Nations covenant as a result of the unsuccessful application of sanctions against Italy.
BERLIN, May 4 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company and chairman of the Kansas City Southern Railway, was shown to be among the highest paid of railway officials in reports filed with Washington agencies and made public yesterday.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, April 24. -- Now that the Italians are poised to launch the last drive of their African campaign from this most central town of Ethiopia, the extremely important question arises of the future of the native population.

Five newly completed buildings that will house a modern, sanitary market where formerly a maze of pushcarts cluttered Park Avenue, from 111th to 116th Street, were opened yesterday morning by Mayor La Guardia. The Mayor said that as long as he held office only the "small merchant doing business at his own stand" would be tolerated there and "politicians and speculators in rotten food" would be barred.

BERLIN, May 4. -- Germany's establishment of a "demilitarized zone" five kilometers deep along the frontiers of France, Belgium and Czechoslovakia, in order to prevent border incidents through accident or individual negligence, was officially confirmed today.

BASLE, May 4. -- Funds of the Bank for International Settlements were fairly steady in April, the bank's monthly statement issued tonight showing a total on April 20 of 65,197,255 Swiss francs, a'decline of about 9,000,000. This was mostly in central bank deposits for their own account,

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Regulations which after June 1 will cover the growing trust department activities of national banks were made public today by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System. They contain a list of factors to which the board will give special consideration in passing upon applications for permission to exercise fiduciary powers, and emphasize the responsibilities and duties of the directors of banks to which such authority is granted.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 4. -- The Women's National Golf and Tennis Club team continued its march toward the Long Island sectional title by winning all five of its matches in the second of the interclub series of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

Religious persecution has ended in Mexico and apparently is a live issue only in the United States, four representatives of the Confederation of Workers of Mexico, here on a good-will tour, asserted yesterday.
BALTIMORE, May 4. -- Maryland Democrats, by a better than five-to-one ratio, assured President Roosevelt today of the State's 16 votes in the national convention.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, May 4 (By Wireless). -- The Zeppelin Hindenburg, her motors overhauled, tested and reinstalled, is ready to depart on schedule Wednesday on her first flight across the North Atlantic. Passengers, thrilled with anticipation, are beginning to arrive, and the provisioning of the giant airship is proceeding.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 4. -- William H.H., Childs, a son of Eversley Childs, a director of the Long Island Lighting Company and the Bon Ami Company, shot and wounded himself fatally today in his home here at 49 Beverly Road. According to the police, Mr. Childs was despondent over ill health.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- "If President Roosevelt is re-elected I don't know what will become of us," said John E. Zimmermann, president of the United Gas Improvement Company, in response to a stockholder's question after adjournment of the company's annual meeting today.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

A banking group composed of Edward B. Smith Co., the First Boston Corporation and the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $865,000 of public improvement, public works and relief bonds of Schenectady County, N.Y., on a bid of 100.059 for 2.10s.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Major Gen. Johnson Hagood, commanding the Sixth Army Corps Area at Chicago, was ordered home tonight to await retirement -- at his own request -- after serving only one full day in what he said his friends called his "vindication" command.
LONDON, May 4. -- The government will appoint a special judicial tribunal to investigate alleged leakages of budget secrets which cost Lloyd's, the underwriters, at least 100,000 a fortnight ago.
IT was Charley O'Leary, the veteran coach of the St. Louis Browns, who said "Have you seen Ali Baba, the Terrible Turk?" and then moved off, leaving a bystander to enlarge on the topic.

Princeton University's Palmer Stadium has been selected as the site for the forty-eighth annual junior and senior National A.A.U. track and field championships on Friday and Saturday, July 3 and 4. This was made known yesterday by Major Patrick J. Walsh, chairman of the National A.A.U. championship track committee.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- Captain Arthur B. Cook, commander of the aircraft carrier Lexington, was selected today to direct the navy's drive to lift its air force to a par with any naval air armada in the world.

ALBANY, May 4. -- Governor Lehman tonight sent a special message to the Senate and Assembly, earnestly pleading for favorable action on his social security program, which had passed the Senate by unanimous vote but has been buried in the Rules Committee of the Republican controlled Assembly.

LONDON, May 4. -- Leonard P. Rees, secretary of the British Chess Federation, today released the entry list of foreign competitors in the international chess masters' tournament to be held at Nottingham during August.

Numerous salaries were reported in the annual statements of companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Exchange, made available here yesterday, while a few companies filed only confidential information concerning salaries.
Any one who has unused books can do a good turn in getting rid of them by sending them to the Hospital Reading Society, which has headquarters in room 420 at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

The list of the steamship Santa Clara of the Grace Line, due today from Chile, Peru and Ecuador, includes Dr. Pablo W. Sanchez Cerro, brother of the late President of Peru; Harold Kingsmill, Oskar Schroder. Mrs. Kenneth Johnston, Ralph Jenkins, Mrs. Hilda Watkins, Miss Edwina Watkins and Leo Gluck.

The Majestic Theatre's Gilbert and Sullivan troupe is spending this week with the choral enterprises of "Iolanthe." Spending it quite profitably, what is more, and singing expertly through what is not one of the masters' easiest fables. Sometimes individuals among the local Savoyards are prone to antic vices, but "Iolanthe" is remarkably free of them, and, besides, they never bob up in the ensemble.
Reuben Fine and Samuel Reshevsky of this city, outstanding American chess experts, were victors in the eighth round of the United States championship tournament at the Hotel Astor last night.

Six special awards for outstanding service and thirty-three varsity letters were presented to members of the women's field hockey, basketball, swimming, fencing and tennis teams of New York University last night at the twelfth annual dinner of the N.Y.U. Women's Athletic Association at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Although the United States Government had virtually ordered CorneliUs %;'an 1. Engert, Minister Resident at Addis Ababa, to evacuate the United States Legation, the Minister notified the State Deparment late tonight that he was willing to do so only if there were no alternative.

The General Motors Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on its common stock. Since there are 43,500,000 shares outstanding, the distributions amount to $54,375,000.
LONDON, May 4 (by Wireless). -- Anthony Eden, young British Foreign Secretary, said on Saturday afternoon that nobody could envy him his job. With this remark everybody agreed.

ROME, May 4. -- Premier Benito Mussolini this afternoon made his first appearance in the Chamber of Deputies since the great Italian victories in the East African campaign. He was received as a conquering hero.

A gift of $30,000 from the Consolidated Edison Company carried forward yesterday the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee to raise a minimum of $1,500,000 in this city for the aid of private welfare agencies. The gift, together with two anonymous individual contributions of $10,000, headed a list of additions to the fund, made public by Laurence M. Marks, the committee's chairman.

Using a left-hand punch to good advantage, Charles Aiden of the Salem-Crescent A.C. outpointed Jack Babian, unattached, in the 160-pound special battle on the amateur boxing card at the New York Athletic Club last night. The show was the closing one of the Winged Foot organization's indoor season.

Advertising volume continued to climb back to the level of mid-1931 during April, according to preliminary estimates here yesterday. It still lags behind the general rise in business activity and profits, but apparently advertisers are steadily enlarging budgets and consistent gains this year are expected.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The administration was faced with new difficulties today as a House group began to put pressure on conservative members to gain pledges of votes to bring out the $3,000,000,000 Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Bill and another group completed a petition to force a Democratic caucus with the idea of earmarking for public works a large part of the $1,500,000,000 relief fund.

Some interesting contrasts were provided by yesterday's financial news. A Stock Exchange seat sold at $100,000, the lowest price since June 21, 1935, and only $4,000 above the level prevailing when the Securities and Exchange Commission assumed jurisdiction over the nation's markets on July 1, 1934.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 4 (AP). -- Opening its tercentenary celebration, Rhode Island today reenacted two famous events of its history. It recalled its Declaration of Independence 160 years ago today, two months ahead of the united colonies, and it received from Governor Curley of Massachusetts a resolution of the General Court of that State revoking the banishment edict pronounced 301 years ago by the Massachusetts Bay Colony against Roger Williams founder of Rhode Island.

Two armed robbers, posing as representatives of loan companies, held up two women in the home of one of them. Mrs. Benjamin Ratner, 1,259 East Twenty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning and escaped with $3,000 in jewelry and silver and $50 in cash.

LONDON, May 4. -- Emperor Haile Selassie and his family set sail aboard the British cruiser Enterprise tonight on their way to Jerusalem. They boarded the warship this afternoon at Jibuti, French Somaliland, as a result of a friendly arrangement between the British and French Governments.

Mrs. Henry S. Pascal was elected president of the United Parents Associations of New York City at a meeting of the delegate assembly of that organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night. Mrs. Pascal, who has been serving as chairman of the committee on legislation of the organization, will succeed Mrs. Robert V. Russell, the president for the last two years.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 4. -- The Balkan Entente conference opened here this morning under the presidency of the Turkish Foreign Minister, Tewfik Rushdu Aras.
The previous winners of the Pulitzer prizes in letter, and their prize-winning works, are listed below.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The two series of Treasury bills offered last Friday were heavily oversubscribed, Secretary Morgenthau announced today. Whereas tenders of about $100,000,000 had been invited, applications reached $188,517,000, of which $100,126,000 was accepted.

Encouraged by a world tour that showed "amazing" growth of the birth-control movement, Margaret Sanger, president of the National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control, said here yesterday that birth control may become a national political issue if the pending Federal bill allowing birth control education is not passed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 (AP). -- That none of the offenses which resulted in the suspension of three jockeys in Saturday's renewal of the Kentucky Derby affected the ultimate result of the race was expressed by the Churchill Downs stewards in a statement today.

With serviettes tucked under their chins, bespeaking the earnestness of their devotion to food, Les Amis d'Eseoffier, recently formed society of gourmets, sat down to their first dinner last night in the Hotel New Yorker.

BOSTON, May 4. -- The fog blanket which has sent one steamer ashore, another to the bottom in a collision, and has badly disrupted coastwise shipping for two days, resulted in another shipwreck and a spectacular rescue off Cape Cod at dawn today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 4. -- The harnessing for the first time of a considerable amount of the vast stores of energy locked up within the hearts of atoms, for possible use in the treatment of disease, was announced here today before the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the American Society for Clinical Investigation.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- A compromise ship subsidy bill, intended to break the deadlock which threatens action at this session, was introduced today by Senator Guffey.
Contribution No. 4,000 to the campaign of the Republican National Finance Committee for New York City in its pre-convention appeal for funds was announced yesterday by Robert H. Thayer, its chairman.

Sammy Nichols of California used a flying tackle and body hold to defeat Hans Schacht of Germany in the main wrestling bout at the New York Coliseum last night before 2,500. In the early stages Nichols came close to pressing the German's shoulders to the mat twice, but it was not until 22:48 that he did it.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Following are the texts of messages received by the State Department today over Naval Radio from Cornelius Van H. Engert, United States Minister Resident in Addis Ababa. The hours mentioned are Addis Ababa time, which is about six hours ahead of Eastern daylight saving time.

Pursuant to an order signed yesterday by Judge Robert P. Patterson, the plan of reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation will be put into effect today, according to an announcement by the reorganization committee, composed of Stuart Hedden, Bernard Benson, George S. Armstrong and A.J. Fink.
ST. LOUIS, May 4 (AP). -- The winning streak of the Cardinals was snapped at six today as the Bees, with a four-run seventh inning, opened the series with a 7-6 victory.

AKRON, Ohio, May 4 (AP). -- Rubber-manufacturing companies here today announced increases averaging 10 per cent in the prices of automobile tires. Their spokesmen confirmed a report that the dealer-discount schedule of Nov. 1, 1934, had been restored by an agreement reached at conferences over the week-end.

ALBANY, May 4 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, WPA Administrator, allocated $481,240.92 today for work relief projects, which he said would assure continuance of work for 1,214 men and 91 women now on WPA rolls for a grand total of 121 months.

LONDON, May 4. -- Charges of "most discreditable and alarming deficiencies" in Great Britain's Mediterranean fleet were made by Winston Churchill today during a debate in the House of Commons on the new naval building program.

Unclaimed loot, the possessions of unidentified dead persons, and other goods which annually fall into the hands of the Police Department were sold yesterday at public auction. More than $5,000 was obtained for the city.

Arrangements were made yesterday for the sale of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange at $100,000. This price is $30,000 less than that of the last previous transaction and the lowest since June 21, 1935, when one sold at $99,000.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 4. -- Three teams tied for first place today in the opening pro-amateur tournament of the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association 1936 season. They were the duos of John Hoctor and Bobby Wilkinson of Locust Grove; John Kinder and J.H. Ackerman of Plainfield, and Maurice O'Connor, holder of the State P.G.A. title, and Mike Cestone, New Jersey public links champion, from Branch Brook.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Organized business, speaking through the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, again attacked President Roosevelt's tax program at the hearing on the new Revenue Bill today before the Senate Finance Committee.

ALBANY, May 4. -- The Senate approved at its session tonight three Buckley hills tightening the Income Tax Law so that it could be used more effectively against racketeers. The bills were recommended by Governor Lehman at the suggestion of Special Prosecutor Dewey.

County Judge Franklin Taylor of Brooklyn denounced yesterday as a "whitewash" the Nassau County authorities' handling of the case of Mrs. Marguerite Wiggen, Queens housewife, who was fatally shot by two Nassau police officers in the mistaken notion that she was a fleeing bandit.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A bill authorizing the sale of the Port Newark Army Supply Base to the city of Newark for $2,000,000 passed the House by unanimous consent today along with a number of other bills of relatively little national importance.

The phrase "towering art" probably has a very personal meaning for Jack Earle, "the world's tallest man, featured with Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey combined circus," who is a current exhibitor at the Delphic Studios. Earle, who is reported to overtop the partitions at the Delphic in an awe-inspiring manner, is represented by six canvases and a plaster head of an African bushman type.

Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Microphone, one of the most consistent racers in this section, continued his winning streak yesterday by taking the Canter Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth, feature at Jamaica. It was his fifth consecutive victory at the course and his sixth in a row, the streak having been started at Hialeah Park.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Bruce Barton is merely to make a survey of Republican National Committee publicity and suggest ways to improve it. This was announced today. He will not, as the hard-boiled publicity agents at the Democratic National Committee had been led to believe, direct against them the rattling musketry of the rival barrage of typewriters.

The completed French elections give fresh point to the saying that the more you change political conditions in France, the more they remain the same. There was, indeed, a marked shifting within the groups making up what is loosely called the Left. One lost to another, or gained from a third, while the Communists picked up seats rather promiscuously.

The Port of New York Authority is contemplating the sale of about $17,500,000 of general and refunding bonds to the public within two or three weeks, Frank C. Ferguson, chairman, announced yesterday. Details of the financing are expected to be available in a few days.

ABOARD THE AMERICAN EXPORT LINER EXETER, May 4. -- Fighting wildly to throw herself overboard, an Italian woman stowaway was transferred at 10 o'clock tonight in a tossing lifeboat to this vessel from the Exochorda of the same line, bound for New York.

PARIS, May 4. -- The election results and the sweeping victory of the Left produced today great irregularity and nervousness on the Bourse, which was not, however, excessive. French securities fell 5 and 10 per cent and Bank of France shares dropped 445 francs.

During the Winter the sort of business manipulations that Broadway regards as smart terminated the profitable and creditable run of the late Elsie Schauffler's "Parnell." Now it has been resumed at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, where it was restaged last evening with Dennis King and Edith Barrett in the central roles.

Hardly had the Pulitzer prize awards in letters and Journalism been announced last night than there arose criticism of the selections in the fields of the drama and the novel, which for several years have been fruitful of controversy.

A special panel of 200 talesmen Was drawn yesterday for the trial next Monday of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and twelve other men on an indictment of ninety count charging compulsory prostitution. A blue ribbon jury of twelve members and two alternates will be picked.

The seat sale for the Metropolitan Opera's Spring season, which will be launched next Monday evening with a performance of "Carmen," began yesterday in encouraging fashion, according to Earle R. Lewis, box-office treasurer.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 4. -- Science is on the trail of a mysterious substance, produced in the front part of the stomach, which is vitally necessary to avoid pernicious anemia, Dr. George R. Minor of the Harvard Medical School told the annual meeting of the American Gastroenterological Association here today.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on April 29 shows increases for the week of $12,000,000 in total loans and investments, $68,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $71,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $62,000,000 in time deposits, and a decrease of $81,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

LONDON, May 4. -- The stock market here received news of the French elections with unexpected calmness today. British Government issues improved slightly on scattered buying orders, while French Government loans were quiet and steady all day.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Despite the strong support for President Roosevelt given by some large unions within the American Federation of Labor, the executive council, which opens its quarterly meeting here tomorrow, will reaffirm its nonpartisan political policy, it was indicated today.

A suit to stop the presentation of the film, "The Great Ziegfeld," was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday on the ground that a pictured romance between "Little Egypt" and Sandow, the strong man, on the Midway of the Chicago World's Fair of 1893 libeled "Little Egypt."

Two New York corporations engaged in the manufacture of explosives in plants in New Jersey and Pennsylvania and two of their officers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in connection with an alleged plot to ship aerial bombs to Bolivia during the Gran Chaco boundary line war.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Consolidation of all law enforcement agencies in the Treasury Department, excepting the Bureau of Narcotics, into one agency to be known as the Treasury Agency Service, was recommended today by the House Ways and Means Committee, in favorably reporting an administration measure.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 4. -- A collection containing first editions of nearly all the writings of John Milton and many important works of contemporary and later criticism has been acquired by the Princeton University Library, James Thayer Gerould, librarian, announced today.

Commodity futures were generally lower in the markets here yesterday in quiet trading. Coffee and sugar finished slightly higher. In the cash market, rye was higher and wheat, corn, tin, silk and rubber were lower.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- A waitress, a stenographer, and a dressmaker from New York, and a textile worker from Alabama have unpacked their bags in the Lincoln Room of the White House. And in the other guest rooms of the Presidential mansion eleven more women wage-earners from the North and the South will sleep between governmental sheets and breakfast upon Federal fare until next Saturday.

Many parties were given last night in connection with the Night in Capri dinner dance in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Proceeds of the event, which took place under the auspices of La Margherita Society, will be added to the benevolence fund of that organization.

The purchase of the stock of the South American Gulf Oil Company from the Gulf Oil Corporation was completed yesterday by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and the Texas Corporation, according to an announcement by the purchasers. South American Gulf owns 79 per cent of the stock of the Colombia Petroleum Company, which owns the Barco concession in Colombia.

UNION CITY, N.J., May 4. -- Detectives searched here today for a bandit who escaped after he entered a third-floor apartment and robbed a woman of $100, but missed $3,000 worth of jewelry he sought. The woman, Mrs. Edith Heineman, 53 years old, of 90 Palisade Avenue, was making up a bank deposit for her husband, a salesman for a New York grocery concern, when the robbery was committed.

ALBANY, May 4. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Brownell bill extending for one year, or until July 1, 1937, the power of New York City to impose emergency taxes, including the sales tax, for unemployment relief.
JIBUTI, French Somaliland, May 4. -- Ethiopia's fleeing Emperor Haile Selassie and his family left Africa today on the British Cruiser Enterprise for refuge in Palestine.

Jackson E. Reynolds, president of the First National Bank, testified in the Supreme Court here yesterday that there was a general willingness among the Clearing House banks to make good the losses of depositors in the Harriman Bank after it closed during the 1933 moratorium, but that the willingness was not due to "any legal or moral responsibility."

Warning that the price structure of business is going to come up for examination as never before, Dr. Willard L. Thorp, director of economic research of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., advised individual manufacturers to go over their price methods carefully and see if they can change voluntarily the features which they may later be compelled to change by legislation.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 4. -- St. Lawrence, behind the effective pitching of Paczkowski, defeated Syracuse today, 13 -- 3, ending a six-game winning streak run up by the Orange.

Reflecting the stimulating effect of warm weather upon retail trade last week, mail orders received in the wholesale markets here yesterday were substantial and indications were that the week would be featured by increased buying activity.

The first of a series of scientific tests to measure the varied reactions of automobile drivers brought hundreds yesterday to the demonstration conducted by Harvard University experts at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 4. -- Celebrating his birthday, A.T. Watson, yachtsman and poloist, entertained today with luncheon at the Greenbrier Casino for Mr. and Mrs. M.C. Eaton, Mr. and Mrs. John Searle, and Mr. and Mrs. J.C. Chilcott.
CHICAGO, May 4. -- About 800 buyers registered today, for the mid-season furniture market and officials predicted attendance and sales volume far larger than last year.
Grover A. Whalen was placed in direct charge yesterday of the organization and activities of the forthcoming world's fair at Flushing Meadows Park.
Correspondents decry the assignment of wages as an unethical collection procedure in the case of delinquent furniture accounts. They lack knowledge of their subject.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- An additional list of annual reports by corporations under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, containing remuneration received by officers and directors for 1935, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Every now and then Mr. GEORGE H. MOSES, sometime a Senator in Congress from New Hampshire, wistfully revisits Washington. The voice heard no more in the Senate chamber is not denied to reporters. New Hampshire Republicans are committed, perhaps not too firmly, to the candidacy of Colonel KNOX.

Dick Shikat will defend his world's heavyweight wrestling championship against Ali Baba in a finish contest at Madison Square Garden tonight. The bout will be the second meeting between the pair, Ali Baba having defeated the titleholder in Detroit two weeks ago.

The annual report of the New England Power Association for 1935 shows a consolidated net income of $4,765,336 after all deductions, equal after annual dividend requirements on 656,458 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock and 19,447 shares of $2 preferred stock to 84 cents a share on 932,609 shares of common stock, comparing with $5,162,868, or $1.27 a share, in 1934.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that collateral borrowings of its members at the close of business on April 30 amounted to $1,063,950,736, an increase of $67,056,718 compared with the March 31 total of $996,894,018.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 4. -- When Congress reopened its sessions here today among the first proposals put before it was one by President Getulio Vargas for nationalizing all the foreign banking and insurance companies established here.

Net earnings of the Coca-Cola Company for the quarter ended on March 31 amounted to $2,660,067 after Federal taxes, dividend requirements on the Class A stock and other charges. This is equivalent to 65 cents a share on 4,000,000 no-par common shares.
CINCINNATI, May 4. -- A blight of some sort or other seems to have settled upon the fortunes of Carl Hubbell, ace left-hander, who appears to be utterly stumped to find the proper answer.

LONDON, May 4. -- News from British official sources in Addis Ababa today indicated the city was quietier, although indiscriminate firing was still going on and the center of the city was nothing but a mass of blackened ruins.

At the end of the long road that leads to the capital of Ethiopia the Italian troops have found a defenseless city in a state of anarchy, its Government in flight, its population rioting, its chief buildings reduced to smoldering ruins. These things testify to the completeness of the military victory.
Public hearings on the proposed city charter will begin on Thursday afternoon at 2:30 when Mayor La Guardia will appear before the Charter Revision Commission at City Hall.

John S. Sumner, executive secretary of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice, hit back yesterday at Federal judges and city magistrates who do not see eye to eye with him on what makes a book an "obscene publication."

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange continued in the doldrums, dealers showing little disposition to participate in the day's activities. As a result pivotal issues drifted within comparatively narrow limits. Prices generally moved in mixed trends with the undertone holding firm.

Reversing the ruling of a lower court, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals granted yesterday to Kuhn, Loeb Co. and their attorneys, Cravath, de Gersdorff, Swaine Wood, fees for their work in connection with the reorganization of the Paramount Publix Corporation.

ROME, May 4. -- A reliable source reported tonight that an advance guard of Askari (native) and Italian troops under the command of General Alessandro Pirzio-Biroli had entered the outskirts of Addis Ababa late this afternoon.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 4 (AP). -- Demands for expansion of the Prohibition party program to include support of the Townsend Plan and Father Coughlin's Union for Social Justice confronted the party leaders tonight as they prepared for the opening of their national convention tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- Hammering Pete Appleton for thirteen hits, the Indians defeated Washington, 6 -- 3, today for their second straight victory over the Senators.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Without a dissenting vote, the Senate passed today the Wheeler bill to amend the Federal Trade Commission Act to provide control over "unfair or deceptive acts and practices in commerce." The commission already has authority over "unfair methods of competition." The measure was sent to the House.

The victory of the parties of the Left in Sunday's "run-off" election in France lent fresh impetus to the flight from the franc yesterday, and a total of $19,540,000 gold was engaged in Paris for shipment here. This lifted to $59,655,000 the gold lost by France to the United States in the last ten days.
The most interesting news in salt water fishing comes from Jones Beach, where the first striped bass and the first kingfish of the young season were taken in the surf over the week-end.

In discussing the "unjust enrichment" of food producers who have retrieved processing taxes collected under the AAA, your editorial of April 25 suggested that, although the producers had already recouped, "the Supreme Court makes them a handsome present. Still, it is the Supreme Court that provided the windfall.

Total bail for eight men and a woman accused of having stolen $1,500,000 worth of United States Treasury notes from two New York banks was reduced yesterday from $326,500, which had been fixed by a Federal commissioner, to $154,000 when the suspects pleaded not guilty to indictments before Federal Judge William Bondy.

Dr. GEORGE J. RYAN'S term as member of the Board of Education is about to expire. He has served the city in that capacity for eighteen years and for a good part of that period as President of the Board, thus surpassing in length of service every predecessor in that important office.

The market value of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined from $51,667,867,515 on April 1 to $47,774,402,524 on May 1, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange, a net loss of $3,893,000,000, despite an increase of 7,000,000 shares in the total listed on the Exchange.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend tonight had sharp words for the House committee which tomorrow will open its questioning of the co-founder of the old age pension plan.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- Major Eastern railroads which have objected to an Interstate Commerce Commission order slashing passenger fares filed new rates today in conformity with the order, but served notice they would challenge it in the courts.

MELVILLE, L.I., May 4. -- Roy Edgar Appleman, regional historian of the Federal National Park Service, expressed, interest today in the Walt Whitman birthplace at Huntington as a possible national shrine to the poet.

TRENTON, N.J., May 4. -- A joint committee of six Republican Senators and six Republican Assemblymen was appointed tonight to frame a program for the permanent financing of emergency relief that will be acceptable to the Legislature.

Veiled in secrecy to the latest possible moment, the annual announcement of the Pulitzer Prize awards in letters and journalism was made last night at the annual dinner of the alumni of the Columbia University School of Journalism, at the Hotel Commodore.

PARIS, May 4. -- Within the next few weeks France will have her first experience of a Socialist government, as a result of yesterday's election. As the largest single party in the new Chamber of Deputies, the Socialist party will have the duty to try to form a government.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- The demand for hogs was relatively slow here today with prices steady to 10 cents a hundred weight lower. Final sales were at the low levels of the day and since the middle of March. A Spring pig crop of 37,900,000 head, compared with 30,400,000 last year, was indicated in an estimate by a local statistician.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (AP). -- Appeals for a large turnout of voters mingled tonight with overwhelming victory predictions as campaigns wound up for tomorrow's Presidential primary in which three Democratic and two Republican convention slates face voters.

Helen, a 2 1/2-year-old forest-bred lioness in the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, gave birth yesterday morning to four cubs. A litter of this size was said by Captain Ronald Cheyne-Stout, director of park zoos, to be a rarity in captive animal circles.
Ed (Strangler) Lewis, veteran grappler from Glendale, Calif., last night threw Hans Steinke of Germany in the feature finish wrestling bout at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory before 4,500 persons.

BARTOW, Fla., May 4. -- Repeated questions by the defense suggested today that two of the policemen named in the raid and subsequent floggings and tar and featherings of Nov. 30 have for some reason received immunity from indictment with the seven Tampa policemen, including the former chief, who now are on trial here.

Additional moisture in Oklahoma over Sunday and lower prices in Liverpool as a result of the elections in France brought a slight decline yesterday in prices on the Cotton Exchange. The net changes ranged from a gain of 1 point to a loss of 8 points.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 4. -- The State Legislature, called into special session tonight primarily to provide funds for unemployment relief purposes, received from Governor Earle a schedule of proposed new taxes to produce an estimated $80,650,000 to meet the commonwealth's financial needs until the 1937 session.

Not content with becoming a producer, Sidney Kingsley will be a competitive one. He announced yesterday three productions he will make next season, and at the very top of the list is a new, untitled play about Napoleon by Ferdinand Bruckner.

RICHMOND, Va., May 4. -- Three hundred Junior Leaguers came to Richmond today for the annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, which will hold sessions through Friday. Members are present from all parts of the United States, Canada, Hawaii and from Mexico City.

NAPLES, May 4. -- Miss Frances Marion Miller of New York was married here today to Captain Don Luciano del Balzo, member of a distinguished Neapolitan family. The bride arrived a short time ago from America for the wedding, accompanied by her mother.
BALTIMORE, May 4 (AP). -- Star Porter, carrying the silks of Major Hal Parr, won the Sparrows Point, six-furlong claiming handicap feature at Pimlico today.

BERLIN, May 4. -- The Boerse opened weak throughout the list, but the movement was checked by the customary official influences. The tendency to caution and a certain degree of pessimism on the market, however, is receiving, general official support and care simply is being taken not to let it get out of hand or come to the attention of the general public.

BOSTON, May 4. -- Sea-scarred but whole, Yankee, proud conqueror of the western ocean, ended her second Atlantic crossing at the Lawley yard in Neponset at 6:15 o'clock tonight. The famous Class J sloop, owned by Gerard B. Lambert, came up the harbor amid a noisy din of saluting, a year and eight days from the date on which she began her European venture last April.

One room of the Carroll Carstairs Gallery at 11 East Fifty-seventh Street has been converted into a Stable Royal, wherein may be seen, until May 23, six horses by Herbert Haseltine, the well-known American sculptor, whose last previous one-man show (at Knoedler's in 1934) consisted of beautiful animal portraits that had been presented by Marshall Field to the Field Museum in Chicago.

Razing of the Central Park Casino will begin today. William C. Chanler, Assistant Corporation Counsel, notified the Park Department yesterday that the last legal moves in the two-year fight over the restaurant had been completed and that its demolition could be undertaken at once.

LONDON, May 5. -- London, which generally has taken none too kindly to Eugene O'Neill's bitter realism, was surprised and delighted tonight by Lord Longford's Dublin Gate company in its production of Eugene O'Neill's "Ah, Wilderness!" at the Westminster.

Five radio cars sped to Forty-second Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue at about 10 o'clock last night to disperse a crowd of 500 persons who had gathered around a police patrol wagon as three pickets were arrested in front of the Times Square Theatre, a double-feature movie house at 219 West Forty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Four additional corporations have filed with the SEC under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of securities.

GLENEAGLES, Scotland, May 4. -- A thoroughly chilled and disappointed group were America's Curtis Cup golfers after today's single round of practice over this bitter cold Perthshire course, where they meet the British Wednesday in defense of the cup.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Prices of wheat declined around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade as the result of private reports indicating scattered showers to heavy rains in parts of Southwestern Kansas, combined with uneasines over the French situation and relative declines in Liverpool.

American civilization has changed from agricultural to industrial, from horse-and-buggy to automobile, and from small-town to sophisticated, but Americans still love steak and corned beef and cabbage more than anything else.

Something of the old New York that is gone lives again at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets, in a new series of exhibitions which will be opened to the public tomorrow, after an invitation preview this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- President Roosevelt received the award of the Cuban Grand Cross of Honor and Merit from the Red Cross of Cuba, and nominated Captain Arthur B. Cooke to become Chief of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics.
LONDON, May 4. -- The British Cabinet assembled for a special session today, confronted by an Italian fait accompli -- virtual domination of Ethiopia.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- James M. Beck, former Solicitor General and member of Congress, left nearly all of his estate in trust for his widow, Mrs. Lilla Mitchell Beck, by his will probated today. The estate is valued in excess of $200,000.

Stocks opened weak yesterday under a heavy accumulation of selling orders, rallied mildly at midday, improved moderately in the afternoon and closed irregularly higher. Trading was the slowest for a full day since March 31, the turnover being 1,071,000 shares, compared with 1,162,000 last Friday.

Among the novels on the Random House list for Fall are "Absalom, Absalom!" by William Faulkner, and "Moscow Skies," by Maurice Hindus. Mr. Hindus, better known as a historian of modern Russia, has been working on his novel for the last five years.
ALBANY, May 4. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Stephens Bill which provided for a loosening of restrictions on savings bank trustees. He signed another group of Stephens banking bills.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Moving to correct administrative difficulties that have recently beset the Virgin Islands, the Senate approved today a permanent form of government for the 22,000 inhabitants of the former Danish possession, and sent it to the House.

GENEVA, May 4. -- Japan or her territories led the world in per capita consumption or all narcotics, according to tables for 1934 in the annual report of the Permanent Central Opium Board of the League of Nations.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 (AP). -- Alcohol was given as an unseen and unreported cause of many deaths among chronic drinkers in a study reported to the American Psychiatric Association today by Dr. V.G. Urse, assistant psychiatrist of the Cook County Psychopathic Hospital, Chicago.

A Federal inquiry into the collision of the Bull Line freighter Angelina and the fishing boat MJR III was ordered yesterday as the police sought in vain for one of the fishing boat's passengers who has been missing since the accident.

Stony Wold Sanatorium will be the beneficiary of a card party and fashion show to be held this afternoon at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League under the auspices of Auxiliary No. 6 of the sanatorium.

TRENTON, May 4. -- Assemblyman Basil Bruno, Republican, of Monmouth County, introduced in the House tonight a bill appropriating $1,000 as a reward for the capture of Ellis Parker Jr., who is under indictment in Brooklyn on a charge of kidnapping and torturing Paul H. Wendel.

ALBANY May 4 (AP). -- New York State's Milk Control Law was attacked as opening the way to "price chiseling" and stanchly defended as a "safeguard" for consumers and producers at a hearing held today to consider proposed changes in the milk price structure.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4. -- After a tense two-hour debate over charges and denials of discrimination against the Negro members of the church, delegates to the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church today adopted by a vote of 470 to 83 the plan for the union of their church with the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, and the Methodist Protestant Church.

Izzy Jannazzo, East Side welterweight, side tracked the championship aspirations of Billy Celebron of Rockford, Ill., at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. The New York battler, piling up a good early lead, scored a decisive triumph over the Middle Westerner in a ten-round fray that was witnessed by a crowd of 3,000 persons.

PARIS, May 4 (AP). -- Armed trucks from the French and British Legations in riot-torn Addis Ababa went out on the streets tonight in search of dead and wounded, the French Minister advised his government by wireless.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, provided a twenty-five foot rug yesterday to be laid on the marble floor for student demonstrators in the Lincoln corridor outside his office in the main building. About 200 undergraduates convened there at the noon hour to resume the passive sit-down protest begun last Thursday against the "practical firing" of Morris U. Schappes a tutor in the English department.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 4 (AP). -- Larry Barton's home run over the right field fence, scoring Poland ahead of him in the fourth, gave Rochester a 3-to-2 victory over Albany today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- A plan for creation of a monetary authority to stabilize the value of the currency was advanced today by Senator Borah as one means of removing "the injustice to agriculture."

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The Essex Razor Blade Corporation of Elizabeth, N.J., today was allowed a Supreme Court hearing on its claim that a razor blade it made and sold did not infringe one patented by the Gillette Safety Razor Company.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Presented by its sponsors as the first authentic factual and philosophical document dealing with the widespread defaults in municipal and district obligations in the last few years, the Securities and Exchange Commission transmitted to Congress today the first section of a voluminous report which, when completed, will cover almost every phase of defaults, reorganizations and protective committees in all types of domestic and foreign securities.

MADRID, May 4. -- Three churches, one convent and four Catholic schools were burning tonight and thirty persons had been treated for burns, bullet wounds, knife slashes and other injuries suffered in rioting in Madrid's Communist quarters.

TOKYO, May 4. -- Reports implying that the smuggling into North China is being encouraged by Japanese as a means of pressure on China were categorically repudiated today by Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita in replying to representations by Ambassador Sir Robert Clive of Britain.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 4. -- After six years, during which it has been compelled to remain in the background, the Wafd has again won control of the government, through Saturday's parliamentary elections.

The Catholic War Veterans, Inc., has voted former Governor Alfred E. Smith the "outstanding Catholic layman in the United States" and has awarded him the organization's Medal of the Order of St. Sebastian, according to an announcement last night.

Assailing "real estate manipulators" for blocking an understanding of city planning, Mayor La Guardia formally opened yesterday an exhibit arranged by his Committee on City Planning to acquaint the public with its aims and methods.

For some three years a committee of both houses of Parliament has been collecting materials for and preparing the manuscript of a history of Parliament from SIMON DE MONTFORT'S national assembly of 1265 till the passage of the Representation of the People Act in 1918.

School children should be allowed to see the seamy side of life, Dr. James R. McGaughy of Teachers College said yesterday afternoon at the last of a series of three panel meetings of which he has been the chairman. The meetings, sponsored by the Public Education Association, were held at different schools.

TRENTON, N.J., May 4. -- Laborers on a PWA paving project made possible by funds allocated by the Roosevelt Administration obligingly "ceased firing" with their compressed-air drills today so Republican women attending a luncheon at the Hotel Hildebrecht here might hear speakers criticize the Democratic New Deal.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 4 (AP). -- The Newark Bears blanked Buffalo, 7 to 0, today and squared the series.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The dole was called "wasteful" and "an outrageous way of treating the unemployed" by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA head, today in a speech intended as a reply to Senator Steiwer, Senator Vandenberg and others who have advocated a return to direct relief.

ROME, May 5. -- To an enormous crowd in the Piazza Venezia in Rome, to throngs gathered around loud-speakers in every village square in Italy and to countless Italians listening at radios throughout the world Premier Benito Mussolini this evening announced the triumphal entry of the Italian Armies into Addis Ababa.

ADDIS ABABA, May 5. -- Ethiopia's era of independence, which had lasted since biblical times, ended at 4 o'clock this afternoon [10 A.M. in New York] when the Italians occupied Addis Ababa. The newer empire founded by Menelik received its quietus at the same time, and a new epoch in the history of this ancient country begins.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The expected questioning of Dr. Francis E. Townsend about the financing and manifold activities of his $200-a-month old-age pension plan was deferred today when the special House committee investigating the movement suddenly adjourned the hearings until May 19.

NORTH MERRICK, L.I., May 5. -- Angry citizens, booing, shouting and hissing, and heedless of the hammering of the chairman's gavel, broke up a town meeting at the high school here tonight at which school trustees were to be nominated for the election tomorrow.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, May 5. -- The recent simultaneous official visit to Moscow of Estonian, Latvian and Lithuanian general-staff chiefs as guests of the Russian general staff has attracted considerable attention in diplomatic circles in the Baltic area.

The Duchess of Leeds, Sir Gordon and Lady Ley, Sir Robert Kindersley, director of the Bank of England, with Lady Kindersley, and Mr. and Mrs. Clarence C. Pell are among the persons due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

One of the objectives for this year of the National Federation of Music Clubs will be "the introduction of better music and more of it into screen shorts and news reels," Mrs. E.H. Cahill, chairman of the national motion picture committee of the organization, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- J.G. White Co. today obtained exemption from the holding-company provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 from the Securities and Exchange Commission on the ground that they derived no material part of their income from a public utility subsidiary whose principal business as such was within the United States.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Representatives of many of the country's major furniture and department stores, attending the Spring mid-season furniture market here, are making larger immediate commitments than at any Spring showing in six years, it was reported today as the first two days' buyer registrations broke all mid-season records and sales showed approximately 40 per cent increase over last year's Spring show.

MOSCOW, May 5 (AP). -- A reliable indication that the Soviet Union will hold out for preservation of the League of Nations despite events in Ethiopia was given tonight in the government's French language newspaper, Journal de Moscou.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 5. -- A resolution proposing that no new Bishops be elected to fill any of the seven vacancies that will occur during the conference and a report from the World Service Commission stating that income for the church's foreign and domestic activities dropped more than 50 per cent in the last quadrennium were placed today before the delegates of the Methodist Episcopal Church in general conference here.
