TOKYO, Wednesday, May 6. -- Japan, "in her solicitude for peace in East Asia, cannot remain indifferent" to large Soviet troop concentrations in the Far East, Hachiro Arita, new Foreign Minister, told the House of Peers today.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP). -- Timely hitting today brought Cleveland a 6-4 triumph over Washington -- the Indians' third consecutive victory over the Senators.

GENEVA, May 5. -- League of Nations quarters received Premier Benito Mussolini's announcement to the Italian people tonight that Ethiopia is Italian as about the best thing he could have said to help the League keep sanctions in force.

BERLIN, May 5. -- It is said in official quarters here today that the questionnaire regarding Germany's international intentions, which was under preparation in London before matters of greater urgency supervened, is not now expected before the end of this week, if then.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation in the first three months of this year sold nearly 18,000,000 pounds of copper more than in the corresponding period last year and at a higher price, Stephen Birch, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

Bills have been passed by the State Senate providing for the reporting of children with deafness or impaired hearing by physicians and others, adequate educational provisions and annual scientific hearing tests.

After about twenty young women had identified him as the youth who had robbed them in a series of holdups in women's rest rooms in office buildings in the midtown and financial districts of the city, Stanley Schleifer, 18 years old, was held in a total of $15,000 bail for the grand jury in the Felony Court yesterday.

The George Washington High School nine scored its fourth straight victory yesterday and supplanted James Monroe High as league leader in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division of the P.S.A.L. Washington beat Evander Childs, 7 -- 1, at Dyckman Oval.

The threatened strike of more than 105,000 miners in the anthracite fields of Pennsylvania was definitely averted when the joint conference of operators and miners' representatives, which has been in session here for twelve weeks, announced at 2 A.M. today that it had reached an agreement on all important points.

DES MOINES, May 5. -- The State Supreme Court today wiped out grand jury charges against thirty-one defendants of participating in graft and official corruption extending "into the State House." This followed by only a day the awarding of a Pulitzer prize for meritorious service to The Cedar Rapids Gazette, whose campaign helped to bring about the indictment of the men.

The fourteenth annual exhibition of Salons of America, Inc., opened with a reception last evening in the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, 30 West Fifty-seventh Street. The work, which consists of oils, water-colors, drawings, prints and sculpture, will be on public view beginning today until May 23.
MONTREAL, May 5 (Canadian Press). -- Bob Seeds provided the punch today that gave Montreal a 9-8 decision over Syracuse in the twelfth inning.

" 1935," scheduled to open tonight at the Biltmore as the second of the Living Newspaper's productions, has been postponed until next Tuesday night. At a dress rehearsal last evening it was found to run an hour and a half, or half an hour too long.

Captain William D. Perry, master of the Bull Line freighter Angelina, admitted that his ship was traveling at fourteen knots in a heavy fog Sunday afternoon when she crashed into the fishing boat MJR III off the Ambrose Lightship.

PITTSBURGH, May 5. -- Benching the injured Ben Geraghty and shaking the line-up from top to bottom proved no panacea for the ills that have assailed the Dodgers on their most disastrous Western tour in several seasons. Tonight Professor Casey Stengel took his scoreless wonders to Cincinnati with the record of having lost six straight games, four of them by shutouts, in the inhospitable West.
ROME, May 5 (AP). -- Rough plans for the transformation of the vast African domain of Ethiopia from a native empire to an Italian possession already were being discussed tonight.

Ali Baba won the heavyweight wrestling championship of the world last night. The Armenian grappler gained the crown by tossing the defending titleholder, Dick Shikat of Germany, with a body slam in 53 minutes 37 seconds of a one-fall finish contest at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Partial agreement on a modified low-cost housing plan, which forecast completion of a program for presentation to Congress at this session, was announced by President Roosevelt at a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP). -- Compensation of more than $269,250 in 1935 to W.R. Sheehan, vice president of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, was listed today in the company's annual report to the Securities Exchange Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5. -An uninstructed delegation headed by Earl Warren, friend of former President Hoover, had a sharp edge over a delegate slate pledged to Covernor Landon in Republican returns from forty of California's fifty-eight counties.
The Works Progress Administration began looking for new quarters yesterday after getting "120 days' notice" from its present landlord, the Port of New York Authority.

Police of the Vanderveer Park Precinct, Brooklyn, made public yesterday the text of a note they said had been written by Mrs. Margaret Reynolds, 38 years old, of 861 East Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, before she was found seated in her automobile, dead from carbon-monoxide fumes, shortly after midnight.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

CEDARHURST, L.I., May 5. -- A three-day celebration held to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the founding of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Hewlett closed tonight with a dinner at the Rockaway Hunting Club in Cedarhurst. About 250 persons attended.

When announcement was made of his appointment as head of the Department of Commerce for the study of Negro problems his name appeared in some of the dispatches from Washington as "EUGENE K. JONES." But to those who know his splendid work for a quarter of a century as the administrative secretary of the National Urban League, for the urbanized Negro, he is "KINCKLE JONES."

BOSTON, May 5 (AP). -- Bob (Lefty) Grove gave the Boston Red Sox a clean sweep in the abbreviated series with the Detroit Tigers today by blanking the world champions, 2 -- 0, before a crowd of 16,100. It was the mighty southpaw's fifth straight victory and his third shutout of the season.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5. -- A total of 176 athletic awards has been granted to Princeton students for participation as players or managers on sixteen Winter sports teams, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics at the university.

CINCINNATI, May 5. -- The cumulative misfortunes of the Giants on this harrowing tour of the West practically touched rock bottom today as the forces of Colonel Bill Terry dropped the concluding game of their series with the Reds, 5 to 2.

Many persons of prominence in society who are interested in the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre at 16 West Forty-sixth Street met yesterday afternoon at a tea given by Mrs. Reginald de Koven at her home, 1,025 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The Associated Press pressed its fight today against "news piracy" by radio stations by asking the Supreme Court to continue an injunction granted by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals against Station KVOS at Bellingham, Wash.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 5 (AP) -- In one of the season's most interesting pitching duels Buffalo defeated the Newark Bears today, 1 to 0. Greg Mulleavy drove a home run over the left center field wall with two out in the eighth for the only run. It was the second straight shut-out of the series and gave the Bisons two out of three. Newark won yesterday by 7 to 0.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 5. -- The nationalization of banks is not contemplated by the administration, your correspondent learned today on good authority.

Tumultuous cheers of a throng estimated at 400,000 gathered in the great Piazza Venezia in Rome to hear Premier Benito Mussolini announce from the balcony of the palace the close of the campaign in Ethiopia traveled across the Atlantic yesterday as listeners here twisted their dials in the hope of picking up Il Duce's voice.

PROVIDENCE, May 5 (AP). -- Rhode Island's unemployment insurance plan went into effect today when Governor Green signed the bill passed by the Legislature last week, and named a three-man commission to administer it.

As part of the observance of the "Spring Renaissance" at the John Wanamaker store, marking the opening of the new "accessory floor" in the North Building, a "green walk" was featured yesterday, giving a seasonal touch to Wanamaker Place.

Charges of being common gamblers, made against nine men arrested on April 29, when plainclothes patrolmen from the staff of Inspector Charles L. Neidig, commander of the fourth division, raided the east ballroom of the Hotel Commodore, were dismissed last night by Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in Night court.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, May 5. -- Finland's hope of being host at the Olympic Games in 1950 soared today with a report from Rome that Italy has now definitely relinquished its claim to arrange the games until 1944, owing to the political situation.

JERUSALEM, May 5. -- Although the Arab general strike in Palestine is continuing, there are increasing signs of dissatisfaction among shopkeepers, laborers and chauffeurs. Arab youth is agitating most energetically for continuance of the strike.

LONDON, May 5. -- Premier Benito Mussolini, in an interview today with Ward Price, special correspondent of The London Daily Mail, renounced "any further colonial ambitions" and extended the hand of friendship to Great Britain.
GLEN COVE, L.I., May 5. -Four bells which some day might have formed a carillon atop the Glen Cove Presbyterian Church have "gradually" disappeared. They weighed 500 pounds each.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The administration's $1,500,000,000 Relief Appropriation Bill, which will be taken up in the House Thursday, was further endangered today when a House bloc, seeking to force earmarking of $700,000,000 of the fund for strictly PWA projects, filed a petition for a Democratic caucus tomorrow or Thursday night.

The share market showed advancing tendencies yesterday until the final hour, when profit-taking reduced the day's gains measurably. The closing was generally higher than that of Monday, with a few issues making wide gains. The volume of business, however, was little more than on Monday; yesterday's total on the Stock Exchange was 1,174,000 shares, compared with 1,071,000 the day before.

ALBANY, May 5. -- The Baldwin bill to repeal mandatory State imposition of specific salaries and specific positions on the municipalities of the State was hailed by civic organizations today at a public hearing and assailed by organized labor.

Earnings of the Hudson Motor Car Company and subsidiaries of $592,827 in the first quarter of 1936 were the largest for that period in six years, and, with the exception of the last three months of 1935, were higher than in any other quarter since 1930, the company announced yesterday.
ROME, May 5 (AP). -- Victorious Italian forces in Addis Ababa moved promptly tonight to give assistance to besieged foreign legations.
Residential and business properties were included in the Bronx and Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

ROCHESTER, May 5 (AP). -- Lake Ontario's waters are at their lowest level since records were started in 1860, and the lake is showing the widest expanse of beach in many years. Cottage piers used for boat landings in previous years are now high and dry.

A sharp drop last week in the city's birth rate was reported yesterday by the Department of Health. Live births totaled 1,644, for a rate of 11.6 per thousand of population. The preceding week there were 1,843 births -- a rate of 13.1 -- while for the same week a year ago the total was 2,038 and the rate 14.6.

The 1,456 bond issues listed on the New York Exchange, aggregating $44,222,956,661 par value on May 1, had a total market value of $41,524,856,027, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. On April 1, there were 1,462 issues, aggregating $44,255,014,146 par value, which had a market value of $41,807,142,328.

President BUTLER cannot be accused, like ARTURO TOSCANINI, of failing to recognize the penalties which attach to eminence in a democracy. He has readily subscribed to the basic American doctrine that reporters and newspaper camera men must live.

LONDON, May 5 (Canadian Press). -- The touring Indian team, making its debut on English soil this year, encountered a snag when Worcestershire defeated the visitors by three wickets in their three-day match concluded today. Yorkshire, champion county, pitted against Marylebone, won by a clear-cut margin of eight wickets at Lord's.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5. -- On the basis of incomplete returns from widely scattered sections of California, the Warren uninstructed Republican delegation to the national convention was winning over the Landon-Hearst-Merriam group on today's Presidential primary ballot.

The committee of striking seamen attempted yesterday to prove that officials of the seamen's unions have been overfriendly toward steamship lines with which they are supposed to negotiate wage agreements. The efforts of the committee, made during the hearing of a suit before Supreme Court Justice William Harmon Black, developed such confusion that Justice Black was obliged to warn a witness, counsel and the audience.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 6. -- Conferences among Lieut. Gen. Seishiro Itagaki, chief of staff of the Kwantung army; Colonel Sakanishi, chief of the first section of the same general staff, and the general staff in Tokyo, have resulted in an agreement regarding increase of Japanese arms in Manchukuo.

Commissioner MOSES may be nothing but an ephemerid, the "passing creature of a day," as Justice CAREW called him, but while he lives he rules. As one lawsuit after another is ultimately decided in his favor, he is rapidly becoming de jure the sovereign that he has long been de facto.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, May 5 (By Wireless). -- Pope Pius XI has decided that the passenger saloon of the giant Zeppelin Hindenburg is a place of diginity and of history and that the great airship is so steady that sacrificial wine will not be spilled.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Expanding receipts of hogs here today and at other Western markets resulted in a decline of 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight. A good part of the run was sold at the full decline. An early top of $10.35, 20 cents under Monday's level, was paid for several loads, but the late top was around $10.20.

Until yesterday the veteran Pat Malone was, more or less, a question mark on Joe McCarthy's pitching staff. But yesterday, against the Browns at the Stadium, he had an answer and in his first official start of the campaign completely vindicated the Yankee manager's belief in him.

ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP). -- The basic structure of insanity has been found in thirteen physical factors, according to statements made today before the American Psychiatric Association by Drs. Isidore Finkelman of Northwestern Medical School and Daniel Haffron of the Elgin State Hospital.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 5. -- Many illnesses can frequently be traced to a specific food sensitiveness in the patient, according to Dr. Walter Alvarez of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn. Dr. Alvarez described a long list of such instances before the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the American Gastro-Enterological Association in the Hotel Claridge, here, today.

While visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday were less than in the preceding week, the total was slightly above the figures for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
BUENOS AIRES, May 5. -- President Rafael Franco of Paraguay has signed a decree permitting the entry of 100 Japanese families into the country, according to dispatches from Asuncion.

While 500 persons were gathered at a dinner at the Astor last night in honor of Lord Horder, president of the Anti-Noise League of Great Britain, tests conducted under auspices of the dinner committee revealed that many sections of the city were still "obnoxiously" noisy. The League for Less Noise, which gave the dinner, conducted the tests as part of its drive "to make New Yorkers noise-conscious."

The Social Security Act provided that the Federal Government would make certain grants-in-aid to States giving pensions to the needy aged, the needy blind, for dependent children and other purposes if the State laws conformed with certain minimum requirements.

Legislation to remedy defects in the personal property law, now being used by racketeers, called "payroll ghosts," in the installment credit business, was recommended yesterday at a conference of officials and others in a campaign District Attorney William C. Dodge has opened against the abuses.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 5. -- President Roosevelt and the New Deal were denounced tonight before 600 delegates to the Republican State Convention by former Senator Hiram Bingham, keynote chairman, who, it is expected, will be named tomorrow as one of the nineteen uninstructed and unpledged delegates whom Connecticut will send to the Cleveland convention.

Two new witnesses in the Paul H. Wendel case, who later went before the Kings County grand jury, told District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan yesterday that Ellis Parker Sr. as well as his son, Ellis Parker Jr., was concerned in the affair.
In his address at the Jefferson Day dinner, Mr. Roosevelt made this statement:

Two items in the news from Washington tell an interesting story. First comes the announcement that registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 have set a new high record -- reaching a total of $583,000,000 in March and of $1,071,000,000 for the first quarter of the year.

The typical man or woman who uses mechanical means of going about his business in New York did just about as much riding last year as the year before. The number of fares collected rose slightly, but so, presumably, did the population, with the result that the number of rides per capita actually dipped a trifle.

Robert E. Sherwood, who won the Pulitzer Prize for drama, recommended yesterday that in the future the awarding of that prize should be placed in the hands of the Drama Critics Circle. He said that he was happy to receive the award, but that he would have refused it had the committee not removed the rule that barred prize winners of other years from the competition.

ALBANY, May 5. -- Governor Lehman today reiterated his demand, embodied in a special message sent to the Legislature last night, that his Social Security Bill be brought out of the Assembly Rules Committee for a record vote before the Legislative session comes to a close.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Members of the Baltic Society from all sections of the country will be guests of General Pershing at a dinner on May 30 at the Army and Navy Club in observance of their sailing on the steamer Baltic on May 28, 1917, as the first army personnel to go to France after our entry into the World War and as the nucleus of A.E.F. headquarters in France.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 5 (AP). -- Dr. D. Leigh Colvin of New York told the Prohibition party's national convention in his keynote address today that repeal had led to "the alcoholizing of vast numbers of women."

PARIS, May 5. -- The agitation that stirred the Bourse yesterday calmed down somewhat today. The market was irregular, with domestic securities weak and the international list strong, but the outlook on the future today seemed to show some evidence of being more sane than it was yesterday, with traders showing some appreciation of the fact that politics is not everything.

LONDON, May 5. -- "We have in our present King a man who has had more direct and intimate associations and friendship with our common people than any monarch since the days of Charles II," said Frederick W. Pethwick-Lawrence, Laborite, in a tribute to Edward VIII in the House of Commons tonight, speaking on the King's civil list, which is to be 410,000, against his father's 470,000.

From the procession of notorieties figures are always dropping out. They have their hour. Then they are little heard of or heard no more. To how many memories does the death of MILO RENO yesterday recall the troubles of the Iowa farmers in '32 and '33? Nature had been too bountiful.

The 1935 act by the New Jersey Legislature which exempted children under 16 from prosecution for statutory crime in any but juvenile courts was held unconstitutional yesterday by Judge Robert V. Kinkead in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, Jersey City.

Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, 1,267 Sixth Avenue, announced yesterday the settlement of the strike in the New York music-publishing industry, which started March 30, and the signing of a two-year contract with the Music Publishers Protective Association, granting the union's demands for a closed shop, minimum wages and hours and a basic price list for arrangers doing piece work.

A broad recovery movement spread throughout the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange with the second grade and speculative corporate loans leading the advance. The trading pace was stepped up considerably, total transactions amounting to $9,758,700, compared with $7,434,300 on Monday.

BELGRADE, May 5. -- The Balkan Entente conference was unable to finish its agenda tonight within the proposed time limit and will therefore hold a final session tomorrow. As Dr. Kamil Krofta, the Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, will then be in Belgrade, the two interlocking circles of the Balkan and Little Ententes will for a few hours be concentric.

Mrs. Jane Collins Belknap, widow of Frank L. Belknap, Chicago patent attorney, left an estate appraised yesterday at $558,275 gross and $488,891 net. She died April 10, 1934, on her arrival here from Europe. The estate included stocks and bonds worth $202,200, of which $163,233 was in Liberty bonds.

TRENTON, May 5 (AP). -- The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey decided today to consolidate its many parishes into five convocations with a view to making the groups better acquainted with their problems and with each other.

BARTOW, Fla., May 5. -- Evidence was presented in court here today that Officers Bridges and Crosby held Eugene F. Poulnot in the automobile which took him from police headquarters on the night of Nov. 30, when Poulnot and two others were flogged, tarred and feathered.

One of the reasons why brokers are disposed to take a more favorable view toward the stock market than they were a week ago is the manner in which the market is reacting to good and bad news. While the recent recession was under way, favorable news failed to check the decline, and unfavorable news was sure to bring out heavy selling.

A plan of readjustment for the secured debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company, registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission on April 6, will be announced today jointly by the two American protective committees for the debentures, headed respectively by Grayson M.-P.

Business failures in the wholesale, retail and construction groups in the United States in the week ended April 30 were below their average for the first eighteen weeks of this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

LONDON, May 5. -- J.B. Priestley's farcical tragedy, "Bees on the Boat Deck," in which Ralph Richardson and Laurence Olivier made a joint debut as actor-managers at the Lyric tonight, is as stimulating and original as its title. The Times reviewer calls it "New as paint, bold as brass, manufactured to no formula and indebted to no one, unless a little to Aristophanes and the author of 'Heartbreak House.'"

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP). -- Rival Democratic camps, viewing Maryland's primary in terms of the November general election, read both victory and defeat tonight in President Roosevelt's 5 1/2-to-1 majority over Colonel Henry Breckinridge.

The largest offering of common stock for the financing of additions and improvements to be made since the enactment of the Securities Law of 1933 will be made today by the Continental Can Company, Inc., through the mailing to stockholders of warrants for the purchase of 177,679 common shares at $60 a share in the ratio of one new share for each fifteen shares held.

Representative business and professional men along the West Side joined yesterday in a campaign to increase hospital facilities in that area under the direction of the West Side Hospital campaign committee.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 5. -- The Duke University baseball team scored its thirteenth triumph of the season today, halting a Princeton ninth-inning rally to win on University Field, 6-4.

The Women's Missionary Auxiliary of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York raised $110,100 for missionary work during 1935, it was announced yesterday in the annual report of the president. This was a marked increase over the sum collected during 1934, and the year in general was described as one of advance.

Fifty-nine students and four members of the faculty were elected to membership in the Columbia University chapter of Sigma Xi, Dr. Marston T. Bogert, Professor of Chemistry and president of the chapter, announced yesterday. The fraternity was established fifty years ago as an honorary science research society.

The field day committees of the Bond Club of New York have drawn freely upon the New Deal alphabet in making their plans for entertainment at the club's annual outing to be held at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club on June 5.

The New York Diet Kitchen Association was the beneficiary of a luncheon, fashion show and card party held yesterday in a setting of Spring flowers at the formal opening of the Park Lane Gardens of the Park Lane. Mrs. William H. Button Jr. had charge of the fashion show, a feature of the entertainment, in which several young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons acted as manikins.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Full information on the steps that were taken to defend the American Legation at Addis Ababa, together with an explanation of why the legation was left "practically defenseless and virtually unarmed," will be demanded from the Secretary of State in a resolution to be introduced in the House tomorrow by Representative Edith N. Rogers of Massachusetts.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,918,450 barrels, compared with 2,932,700 in the preceding week, a decrease of 14,250, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A decline of 25,100 barrels in the daily average of Oklahoma was the most important change.

RICHMOND, Va., May 5. -- Need for local planning has become more urgent since the Supreme Court invalidated part of the AAA, the National Planning Conference was told today by Bushrod W. Allin of the AAA. He declared that the principal effect of the decision had been to acelerate the development of long-time aspects of the national agricultural policy.

GLENEAGLES, Scotland, May 5. -- Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old Minneapolis schoolgirl, was telling fortunes from her teacup at the luncheon table today, and if the sturdily built, auburn-haired youngster is as good a prophet as she is a golfer, the British women will fail to gain their first victory in the international match with the United States team for the Curtis Cup tomorrow.
KHARTUM, The Sudan, Egypt, May 5. -- Fears for foreign lives and property in Western Ethiopia following the Addis Ababa disorder have resulted in an appeal to the Sudan Government for protection.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The National Resources Committee, of which Secretary Ickes is chairman, recommended in a report to the President, maple public today, the immediate creation by this Congress of a Federal corporate power agency similar to the Tennessee Valley Authority, to control the power possible of generation at the Bonneville and Grand Coulee Dams in the Columbia River.
Thirty-five WPA workmen began yesterday to demolish a gaunt, forlorn-looking building just west of the East Drive opposite Seventy-first Street in Central Park.

A shapeless victory parade surged through Mulberry Street last night as Little Italy celebrated the fall of Addis Ababa, and outside the Circulo Mario Morgantini at 354 East 116th Street 2,500 persons paid tribute to the victorious Black-shirts in a spontaneous demonstration that required a special detail of thirty-five patrolmen.

To prevent monopolistic control of the taxicab business on city piers by large fleet operators, Dock Commissioner John McKenzie issued an executive order yesterday barring all taxciabs from the interior of the piers.
MADISON, N.J., May 5. -- After tying the score on Fernando Marcial's triple with the bases filled in the ninth, the Drew nine went on to defeat Wagner in the tenth today, 4 to 3.
ALBANY, May 5. -- Governor Lehman announced the veto of five bills today.
WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The re-election of President Roosevelt was advocated today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who coupled it with a plea for a new and strong NRA.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 5 (AP). -- Scattered returns from twelve Congressional districts of Indiana indicated early tonight that voters in today's primary election favored renomination of all Representatives running for re-election.

ROME, May 5. -- The first news of the fall of the Ethiopian capital reached Rome today through London, to which Sir Sidney Barton, British Minister to Addis Ababa, had reported the arrival of the Italian troops. Rome immediately was thrown into great excitement, heightened later by the call to the adunata.
ALEXANDERIA, Egypt, May 5. -- Emperor Haile Selassie is relatively a poor man for one of his rank, now that he has fled into exile, his former American adviser said today.

The adverse effect of floods in the East is reflected in a compilation of the earnings of 140 Class I railroads for March, issued yesterday by the Association of American Railroads. The figures show that net operating income of the Eastern lines in March fell 28.1 per cent from the same month of 1935, although the Western lines reported an increase of 60.2 per cent and the Southern lines one of 21.3 per cent.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- Major Gen. Johnson Hagood issued general orders today relinquishing command of the Sixth Corps area and the Second Field Army, a command which he assumed only Saturday, and issued a statement asserting that President Roosevelt in a personal interview had requested him "not to retire at this time."

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, May 5 (Reuters). -- Most of the Ethiopian leaders on the Ogaden front accompanied Ras Nasibu, commander of the Ethiopian Southern Army, and General Wehib Pasha, his Turkish military adviser, when they arrived here last night by train from Diredawa, Ethiopia.

Louis Waldman, head of the right-wing group of the Socialist party in New York State, announced last night that his supporters were prepared to leave the party and form a new political organization, if this proved necessary, in their contest with Norman Thomas, left-wing leader.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Attorneys for Al Capone said today that they would immediately seek his release from Alcatraz Island prison on a newly raised technical point. Government representatives will oppose the move.

The Grand Lodge of Masons of the State of New York went on record as opposed to the religious and racial persecution which has caused distress in many European countries, at the opening of the 155th annual convention of the lodge yesterday at the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

ALBANY, May 5. -- By a vote of 135 to 9 the Assembly today passed the bill of Assemblyman Brownell, Republican, of New York, which is designed to aid Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor, to compel missing witnesses to appear in connection with the bribery charges growing out of the Drukman murder case.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Robert E. Lee and Thomas J. (Stonewall) Jackson will have places in company with George Washington, U.S. Grant and W.T. Sherman on memorial stamps soon to be issued by the Postoffice Department commemorating America's great military and naval leaders.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Only one steamship operating company in the United States has sufficient free resources to build a modern vessel such as the Manhattan, Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania said today in explaining the compromise Ship Subsidy Bill which he introduced in the Senate yesterday.

Jockey Johnny Gilbert rode three winners for the fourth racing day in succession and the fifth time during the meeting at Jamaica yesterday. He captured the opener with Mrs. L.J. Schaefer's Chirac, 6-1 shot: the fifth event aboard William Zakoor's Fumble, 3-1, and the nightcap on B.G. Guth's Phrixus, 9-10 favorite.

Plans for the further extension of self-regulation of advertising in the drug industry will be discussed at a special conference to be held in connection with the fifty-fourth annual convention of the Proprietary Association at the Hotel Biltmore on May 13, 14 and 15, it was announced yesterday by Charles P. Tyrrell, secretary-treasurer of the organization.

Gold medals will be presented tonight to J.P. Morgan, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, Mrs. Harrison Eustis and William Edwin Hall at the annual dinner of the National Institute of Social Sciences at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 5. -- The officers elected at the annual school meetings in the rural districts of Riverhead town tonight and the amount of the budgets adopted follow:

The third day of the Federal Music Project's festival of American music was featured yesterday afternoon by the playing of nineteenth and twentieth century symphonic music by the New York Festival Orchestra, under the direction of Jacques Gordon.

LONDON, May 5. -- The reign of terror that had gripped Addis Ababa since Saturday was ended today when the first detachments of the Italian Army marched as conquerors into the ruins of what used to be the capital of the Ethiopian Empire.

District Attorney William C. Dodge revealed yesterday that he had not dropped the investigation he started two years ago of reported violations of the Criminal Anarchy Law in New York County, but he admitted he had as yet not been able to obtain evidence for grand jury action.

LYNBROOK, L.I., May 5. -- The return of Charles D. Vosburgh as superintendent of schools was indicated in the election of school trustees in the high school tonight. Mr. Vosburgh, superintendent for the past thirty-two years, was discharged a month ago and the position of supervising principal was created which went to Harold W. McCormick of Copiague, with the proviso that he also act as superintendent.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The United States Legation in Addis Ababa was being guarded by Italian troops tonight after four occupants had beaten off an attack by hostile natives in a brisk clash that lasted five minutes.

Philately as a hobby is passe, according to a poll of the 700 members of the City College House Plan, extracurricular center. A negligible number of the undergraduates expressed an interest in collecting stamps, it was revealed yesterday by Mortimer Karpp, director of the house plan.

Johnny Morro, 131 3/4, Fordham veteran, came from behind to earn a draw against Sammy Angott, 132 1/2, Pittsburgh lightweight, in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night. A crowd of 4,500 witnessed the bout, which was replete with action from start to finish.

C. Blackburn Miller, president of the Salt Water Anglers of America, who has just returned from a trip to Florida, reports encouraging progress in the campaign to induce boatmen and anglers to conserve the game resources of Southern waters, notably the sailfish.

The State of Colorado will be in the market on May 16 with a new issue of $10,000,000 of State highway fund anticipation warrants. The warrants will mature in 1939 to 1954. The notice for bids specifies that the warrants are to be sold at par with bidders naming the interest rate.

The fresh air and sunshine that he forsook when he neglected to keep up his alimony payments now are part of Benjamin Harned's official daily routine, even though he resides in the alimony jail at Long Island City.

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP). -- In the Windsor Hills, sixth and feature race on the program presented at Pimlico today, top honors went to Walter M. Jeffords's good-looking Jean Bart, bay son of Man o' War -- Escunia. He was coupled in the betting with Giant Killer.

In an order signed yesterday by Martin T. Manton, presiding judge of the United States Circuit Court, Albert Goldman, postmaster of New York, was restrained from carrying out portions of the fraud orders signed by Postmaster General Farley against the Golden Stakes Advertising Corporation, of which Alfred E. Smith Jr. is an officer, and the National Conference for Legalizing Lotteries, headed by Mrs. Oliver Harriman.

Max Greenberg, who is 55 years old and deals in used clothing, journeyed to the Bronx yesterday in pursuit of his trade, and won distinction in an unexpected way. Shouting his offer of "I cash clothes!" he became the first man to be arrested under the Noise Abatement Law in the Bronx.
To mark the fact that it now leads the larger cities in reducing traffic accidents, New York will stage a safe-driving demonstration on Saturday afternoon, with the Police Department as sponsor.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa, May 5. -- The British Government would meet strong opposition from South Africa if it attempted to abandon sanctions or to weaken the League of Nations, it was indicated here today. Leading South African newspapers unanimously urged that the British Commonwealth of nations support the League in its time of trial.

While the small ballroom in the Hotel Pennsylvania was filled with smoke from tobacco last night, there was not a single cigarette or pipe in sight. The occasion marked the launching of a campaign, under the auspices of the Cigar Progress Board, among manufacturers, jobbers and salesmen to make the men of America "cigar conscious."
WATERVILLE, Me., May 5 (AP). -- Kennebec River Valley authorities tonight sought a man who attacked and strangled Mary Proulx.

NEWARK, N.J., May 5. -- United States Senator William E. Borah will come to New Jersey May 14 to press his fight for the Republican Presidential nomination. He will open his campaign in this State for a delegation pledged to him in an address in the Krueger Auditorium here, it was announced today by Russell C. Gates, New Jersey campaign manager for the Idaho Senator.
ROME, May 5. -- The text of Premier Benito Mussolini's address at the victory celebration in Rome today follows:

By midafternoon yesterday nearly 1,000 persons had taken the six tests for automobile driving reactions on scientific machines in the New York Museum of Science and Industry in the RCA Building. Rockefeller Center. The demonstration, which opened Monday, is under the auspices of the Harvard Bureau of Street Traffic Research and the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company.

Cardinal Hayes threw his spiritual and financial support behind the Citizens Family Welfare Committee yesterday in its effort to raise $1,500,000 to finance the work of private welfare agencies in this city. He sent a personal contribution of $750.

Federal Judge John M. Woolsey directed Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, yesterday to conduct an investigation to determine whether Ralph A. Freundlich, president of the doll-manufacturing corporation that bears his name, had obstructed justice by filing a false accounting in an infringement suit brought against him because of his sale of "Betty Boop" dolls.

I had occasion recently to go to the Yorkville section of Manhattan. I was amazed to see how this part of our city has deteriorated. I saw an old school building on Seventy-seventh Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues, abandoned.

The flight of capital from the franc was undiminished yesterday. If anything, it was increased as a result of the nervousness over the victory of the "Leftist" parties at the French elections on Sunday. There was evidence of strong support of the franc by the British Equalization Fund and indications that the American Stabilization Fund was active in behalf of the French currency.

A devotion to the game of policy that had led her to keep a record of all the winning numbers for the last sixteen years finally got Mary Johnson, 41-year-old Negro, into a certain amount of trouble yesterday. She will have to stand trial as a player, in Bronx Special Sessions, when that court has a place for her on its already crowded calendar.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 5. -- Miss Sylva Annenberg, New York State champion for the past two years, today negotiated the scenic route of the North Shore Country Club course in 79 strokes, one under women's par, to win the opening one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

The late Robert E. Simon, realty operator, philanthropist and friend of education, was eulogized yesterday in the lobby of Carnegie Hall, which he bought and preserved for community use, following the unveiling of a bronze bust of the benefactor that occupies a niche opposite the bust of Andrew Carnegie.

More than one dispatch from London has reported a common feeling of shame in Great Britain. This is partly a strong nationalistic sentiment in reverse. It is mortification over the failure of a major British policy and the lowering of British prestige. Only a short time ago the international repute of Great Britain was at its height.

Laurence A. Steinhardt, American Minister to Sweden, and Mrs. Steinhardt gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mrs. Rickard J. Sandler, whose husband is Swedish Minister of Foreign Affairs. Mrs. Sandier is staying in this city for a short time before proceeding on her tour of the United States.

ALBANY, May 5. -- John Sloan was renamed today as a member of the State Racing Commission as it was learned that Attorney General Bennett would give a formal opinion tomorrow on the legality of the present Open Betting Law.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., May 5. -- Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas built up a steadily growing lead over Senator William E. Borah for South Dakota's eight Presidential delegates to the Republican National Convention as returns were tabulated tonight from nearly a third of the State's precincts in today's primary.
NEWTON, N.J., May 5. -- The seventh annual reunion of the Octogenarians of Sussex County was held here today at the Cochran House. Sixty-five men and women of eighty years or older were present.

RICHMOND, Va., May 5. -- Delegates to the sixteenth annual conference of Junior Leagues of America decided today that member leagues might participate to a limited degree in legislative and controversial matters. This reverses the "hands-off" policy adopted at the Toronto conference in 1934.

C.R. Gray, president, and F.W. Charske, chairman of the executive committee of the Union Pacific Railroad, each received a salary of $60,000 in 1935, the company's report for that year to the Interstate Commerce Commission shows.

OTTAWA, May 5. -- The Canadian Government is anxiously awaiting news from Washington that the Canadian whisky distillers have settled their differences with the United States Treasury and that a serious threat to the Canadian-American trade treaty has been removed.
ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP) -- Danny MacFayden held the Cardinals in almost complete subjection today, allowed only three hits and Boston was victorious, 1 to 0.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Another list of annual reports by corporations under the Securities Exchange let of 1934, containing remuneration received by officers and directors in 1935, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A sharp recovery in the stock market, trade covering of May obligations and little moisture in dry sections still left unrelieved in the western belt exerted a steadying influence on prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Best quotations of the session were reached in closing dealings when the list ended unchanged to 9 points higher than on Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Whether army or navy planes should fly out to meet the enemy in the event of war in the Pacific has caused a new flare-up between the two services.

Representatives of property which William J. Pedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, estimated to be valued at $100,000,000 appeared before License Commissioner Moss yesterday to urge refusal of a permit for a motion picture theatre at the rear of a plot on the west side of Park Avenue, between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Private estimates of the Winter wheat crop showing a prospective yield of 486,000,000 bushels, or 51,000,000 less than was forecast a month ago and 7,000,000 less than the government's April 1 returns, had a bullish effect today on the prices of the deferred deliveries on the Board of Trade, and while there was a small dip at one time the close was 1/4 to 1/2 cent a bushel higher.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The United States Government will delay decision with respect to such diplomatic questions as recognition of the Italian regime in Ethiopia until after Great Britain and other countries more directly interested have received an opportunity to determine their policies, according to indications today in official circles.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP). -- Bill Lee, last year's leading percentage pitcher in the National League, turned in his third straight victory today as the Cubs crowded all their activity into two innings for a 5-to-4 series-splitting victory over Philadelphia. The victory sent Chicago into first place, a half game ahead of the Cards and Pirates, tied for second.

State Tax Commissioner Mark Graves said a few days ago that 25,000 more persons had paid a New York State income tax this year than in 1935. It would be interesting to know how many more residents of the State of New York paid a State income tax than paid a Federal tax.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 5. -- More than 135 elementary school children will be "called out" on strike here this morning in protest against their being transferred to other schools.

The remaining unsold lots in Rugby Garden in Teaneck and Bergenfield, N.J., have been purchased by Thomas Moffa, Inc., builders and operators, of 344 East 149th Street, the Bronx. Plans are now being drawn for the erection of approximately 100 houses and ground will be broken within ten days, it was announced yesterday.

TRENTON, May 5. -- Several programs for the permanent financing of emergency relief, based largely on the proposal of Senator Charles E. Loizeaux of Union County, were considered today by a joint committee of twelve Republican legislators.

Mayor La Guardia has sent an emergency message to Governor Lehman asking that the Legislature pass the Desmond bill permitting the Queens Midtown Tunnel Authority to build either a tunnel or bridge from East Thirty-Eighth Street, Manhattan, to Queens, it was learned yesterday.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 5. (AP). -- Scoring five runs in a wild sixth inning, the Rochester Red Wings gained a 7-4 verdict over the Albany Senators today. The triumph ran the Wings' streak to four.

Frank Appel shut out the Newark University nine with eight scattered hits and enabled the St. Peter's College team to score an easy 9-0 triumph at Lincoln Park, Jersey City, yesterday. Appel bore down when there were men on the bases and had little trouble registering his third victory of the year.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Carl G. Bachmann, campaign manager for Senator Borah, charged in a speech over the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight that the opposition within the Republican party to the nomination of Senator Borah for the Presidency comes from individuals and groups who have "selfish interests" at stake which they know Senator Borah as President would not permit them to exploit.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

The recent death of William R. George of the George Junior Republic calls to mind that after the Good Government Clubs in New York (1894) with 10,000 members had elected Mayor Strong, immediately all hands were after jobs. They kept asking "What is there for us in this?"

Uncle Robert made public yesterday the program for his ninth annual celebration of "Parents' Day" next Sunday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park. A crowd of 40,000 school children and their parents are expected to take part in the program of patriotic music, drill and speeches. In case of rain the exercises will be postponed to May 17.

There has been a large subscription for the Spring song festival and dance to be given by members of the People's Chorus of New York in behalf of that organization tomorrow night in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The Senate Finance Committee was told today by Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, that the proposed tax on undistributed corporate income would not only weaken and possibly "impoverish" the country's industrial and commercial enterprise, but also work in direct opposition to President Roosevelt's aim for social security.

A further retort by County Judge Franklin Taylor of Brooklyn to District Attorney Martin W. Littleton Jr. of Nassau County was made yesterday concerning the case of Mrs. Marguerite Wiggen, Queens housewife, who was fatally shot in Nassau County by county detectives who mistook her for a bandit.
MOSCOW, May 5. -- Negotiations will begin shortly in London between the Soviet Union and Great Britain looking toward a joint agreement for naval limitation, it was announced officially here tonight.

PARIS, May 5. -- Although five members of Premier Albert Sarraut's Cabinet were defeated in the election and the parties that it represents were the biggest losers, the Cabinet will conform with the usual custom, it was decided today, and remain in office until the end of the month.

First to finish of the twelve players with adjourned games, Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., successfully defended his hold on first place in the United States championship of the National Chess Federation last night when he defeated Samuel Factor of Chicago, Illinois State champion, in fifty moves.

LONDON, May 5. -- The visiting Golden Gloves boxing team from New York went down in defeat, 7 bouts to 4, before a picked aggregation of London amateurs tonight, but not before the Americans had put up a series of battles that made a capacity crowd howl itself hoarse with excitement.

William C. Potter, president of the Guaranty Trust Company, was questioned in the Supreme Court yesterday as the center of resistance among the nine Clearing House banks that the government now is suing in equity for $2,000,000 still needed to pay the depositors of the closed Harriman National Bank.

BERLIN, May 5. -- The Boerse under the usual official influences, continued today its slow downward course, which is apparently intended as a variety of the demonstration against talk of devaluation. At the opening the drop threatened to turn into a plunge, but the movement was quickly checked by government agents, who then went on with the process of letting the market down slowly.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The Brooklyn Edison Company, Inc., filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement for the issuance Of $55,000,000 of thirty-five-year consolidated mortgage bonds, 3 1/4 per cent series of 1936, due on May 15, 1971.
Jerome Lewine, its first president, was honored by the members of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., at a reception in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night, with Floyd Y. Keeler, now president, presiding.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $3,715,057 for the twelve months ended on March 31 after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.40 a share on 1,791,408 average no-par common shares outstanding.
VIENNA, May 6. -- All liberal circles in Austria and Czechoslovakia, the country of his birth, united today in a tribute to Dr. Sigmund Freud on his eightieth birthday.

Thousands of homes and many streets in the residential Woodlawn Heights district of the Bronx were plunged into darkness from 9:11 o'clock until shortly after 10 last night as the result of a power failure, caused, according to the police, by a short circuit in a feed line at 236th Street and Katonah Avenue.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 6 (AP). -- J.T. Taylor's Planetoid stamped herself as probably the best 2-year-old Charlie Kurtsinger ever rode when that veteran piloted her to her third consecutive victory in the Jeanne D'Arc Stakes today at Narragansett Park.

BELGRADE, May 6. -- The Balkan Entente conference was concluded this afternoon with the issuance of a colorless communique saying the delegates had discussed all the questions before them in the friendliest spirit and had reached conclusions that served the security of the Balkan States and the interests of universal peace.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Although Governor Landon emerged from the California primaries with his slate of convention delegates defeated, his managers feel that he has gained through what they regard as the elimination of William Randolph Hearst as a factor.

The former Waldorf-Astoria Hotel building at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street was so obsolete between 1925 and 1929 that it was worthless as a hotel property, according to a plea made before the Appellate Division yesterday, when the court heard an appeal by the Waldorf-Astoria Realty Corporation from the dismissal by Supreme Court Justice John Ford of suits brought to review the assessments for those years.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A long-awaited NRA-Commerce Department survey on the effect of the Bituminous Code today criticized efforts of the Recovery Administration to solve the crucial North-South wage differential dispute as "weak, vacillating and futile."

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP). -- Two errors in the ninth inning, one of them on Relief Pitcher Curt Davis's throw to first base when no one was covering the bag, gave the Cardinals a 3-to-2 victory today over Philadelphia.

BERLIN, May 6. -- Bernhard Rust, Reich Education Minister, decreed today that, beginning next year, English shall be the first foreign language taught in all German high schools except some humanistic gymnasiums, where the dead languages continue to enjoy preference.

" Enrolled Agent" takes me statistically to task for criticizing the unbalancing wage and hour demands of the President and organized labor, in that I chose to group the latter's 6,700,000 members with the total population -- nearer 130,000,000 than 123,000,000 as stated by Agent -- rather than confining them to the 38,476,000 gainfully employed.

A scheduled sale of the Oliver Cromwell apartment hotel at 12-18 West Seventy-Second Street was adjourned yesterday to May 20, pending consideration of a reorganization plan submitted by a minority group of bondholders. The foreclosure action was brought by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, against Howard V. Williams, the 14 West Seventy-second Street Corporation and others for $1,901,686 due, with taxes, , totaling about $375,164.

ROME, May 6 (AP). -- A dispatch received today from the headquarters of Marshal Pietro Badoglio at Addis Ababa said several groups of pillagers in the Ethiopian capital had been "rapidly eliminated" by Italian troops protecting the French and United States Legations.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey had been apprised that some one was being held prisoner, during the period in which Paul H. Wendel says that he was tortured into making a false confession of the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., William F.X. Geoghan, District Attorney of Kings County, asserted yesterday.
J. P. Morgan told his recipe for success last night in these words:

A breeze that might have done an old salt's heart good whipped sailboats across a 100-foot pond at the Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School in Brooklyn yesterday, but provided rough going for the more modern nautical models, the steam and electric boats.

TAIYUAN, Shansi, May 6. --Shansi Provincial officials declared today the Communist crisis was virtually ended, the Reds having been forced into mountainous, sparsely populated regions where they are unable to obtain sufficient food and supplies.

All the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's controlling interest in the Reading Company has been pledged for loans or as collateral for notes, the report of the B. O. for 1935 to the Interstate Commerce Commission discloses. The B. O. paid $71,240,603 for 42.2 per cent control of the Reading.

Unable to regain the composure befitting world champions after plunging into an open switch with Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe at the throttle in the first inning, the Tigers traveled a bumpy road in their season's Stadium debut yesterday to the complete satisfaction of more than 19,000 Yankee fans.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, the distinguished Polish pianist, has signed a contract to appear in a leading role in a sound film to be made in London. The pianist's American manager, George Engles, revealed yesterday that he had received a cable in which the facts of the agreement were disclosed.

Strenuous objections raised yesterday by stage hands' officials of Theatrical Protective Union Local 1 resulted in canceling the Federal Theatre Project's agreement to rent the Longacre Theatre on West Forty-eighth Street from May 11 to June 28.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 6. -- The Construction Division of the Federal Resettlement Administration was rushing work on the model industrial town it is building four miles southeast of Hightstown today so that the first unit of thirty-five houses might be finished and that many families moved in from New York by June 15.

United Drug, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a net profit of $392,153 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges, exclusive of a non-recurring profit of $837,002 from the sale of stock of the Boots Pure Drug Company, an English concern.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Cornelius Van H. Engert, United States Minister Resident to Ethiopia, reported to the State Department today that all Americans in Addis Ababa were safe with the exception of one American woman who could not be located.
DANDRIDGE, Tenn., May 6. -- Tennesseans were picking $5 bills from willow trees and cornstalks along the French Broad River near here today. The money apparently was deposited by recent high waters.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 6. -- Four successive singles in the last half of the ninth netted two runs and enabled Upsala to subdue C.C.H.Y. today, 7 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A tentative agreement on payments for dismissal to be made to railroad workers who may be severed from their occupations by consolidation of railroads has been made here as a result of negotiations by committees of railway managements and of the twenty-one standard railway labor unions.

PARIS, May 6. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's speech yesterday and claim that Ethiopia henceforth would be "Italian territory" has brought from Paris a sharper toned diplomatic note than almost any other that has been addressed to Rome since the Ethiopian campaign began.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 6 (AP). -- The United States Naval Air Station, America's first great terminal for giant dirigibles, was the center of renewed activity tonight as it made final preparations for greeting the Hindenburg.

ADDIS ABABA, May 5 (Delayed). -- Occupation of this capital today came at the end of a triumphal march in the truest sense. Every important service in the Italian Army had its representation as the troops swept slowly and steadily down from Dessye in by far the greatest motorized column ever organized.
The Atlas Powder Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents and the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP). -- Treasury officials said tonight they were prepared to defend the dollar against virtually any turn the perplexing European monetary situation might take.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP). -- The International Business Machines Corporation, New York, reported today to the Securities and Exchange Commission that in 1935 it paid its president, Thomas J. Watson, $303,813, compared with $365,358 in 1934, the largest salary paid to an industrialist in that year, according to the commissions records.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A gigantic network of sound will carry President Roosevelt's voice to outdoor mass meetings in all parts of the country when he formally accepts renomination next month and the Democratic National Committee will profit thereby to the tune of half a million dollars, if present plans come to fruition.

Already ominous repercussions are heard from MUSSOLINI'S victory over the efforts at collective security. Nazi Germany rejoices in the hope that no longer need there be fear of effective sanctions against a treaty-breaker. Britain and France suddenly become watchful of their "rights" in their respective spheres of influence in Ethiopia, delimited by the tripartite treaty of 1906 without Ethiopia's consent.

ST. LOUIS, May 6. -- A new scientific aid to detection of criminals of the future was indicated here today with the disclosure that the identity of a person may be revealed by the way he breathes almost as surely as by his fingerprints, his handwriting or his photograph.

BERWYN, Pa., May 6. -- Edward B. Smith Jr.'s Exford, capably ridden by George Strawbridge, won the three-and-a-half-mile timber course event at the opening of the Radnor Hunt Club Spring meet near here today before a crowd of 3,500 spectators. With the victory also went the Happy Hollow Plate.
The city of Bay City, Mich., will be in the market on June 3 with a new issue of $660,000 of school refunding bonds.

RICHMOND, Va., May 6. -- The burden of replenishing the nation's population cannot be thrown permanently on the most underprivileged groups and on those isolated from the main current of urban cultural development, the National Planning Conference was told today by Frank Lorimer, director of the committee on population problems of the National Resources Committee.

In the House of Representatives they have refused to appropriate $3,067,000 for monuments to BETSY ROSS and the signers of the Declaration of Independence. The memorial to the lady who made the first American flag would have cost a mere $5,000.

Your editorial "A House of Courage" referring to the splendid work accomplished by the physically handicapped in the New York Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, and the award of the Davison and Ellsworth prizes -- "to those who by their courage have done most to further the ideals of the institute" -- is an inspiration to all who suffer from physical handicaps.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6. -- Columbia put up a stubborn game against Penn today, but could not shake off its Eastern Intercollegiate League losing streak and the Red and Blue won, 6 to 5, and tightened its grip on second place. By the defeat the Lions dropped into a last-place tie with Cornell.

California illustrates, as New York had previously done, the power of the regular party organization in a primary fight. The Republican State Committee, largely composed of left-overs friendly to Mr. HOOVER, had made arrangements to elect uninstructed delegates to the Cleveland convention.

BARTOW, Fla., May 6. -- Testimony that R.G. Tittsworth, at that time chief of police in Tampa and now one of seven defendants on the trial in the kidnapping of one of three victims of the fatal Shoemaker flogging of last Nov. 30, attempted to shield the accused policemen under him was presented in court here today.
A good demand for dwellings on the East Side was indicated in transactions announced by brokers yesterday. Most of the homes were taken on lease.
Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. yesterday declared in an opinion that betting was illegal on the New York race tracks, but the sport and betting went on as usual at the Jamaica course.

The women's chorus of the New York Madrigal Society appeared in concert last night at the Town Hall for the benefit of the society's educational fund. The choral forces were assisted by Hanna Lefkowitz, pianist; Daniel Harris, baritone, and the New York Symphonette.

The city is prepared to start a $75,000,000 building program if the Wagner Housing Bill is enacted into law, Mayor La Guardia told 300 persons yesterday at a luncheon preceding the laying of the cornerstone of a new East Harlem health center. He did not give any details of the projects.

Although activity in the steel industry appears to have passed the seasonal peak for Spring, no precipitate drop in the rate of operations is in prospect, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by Iron Age. The rate for this week is 68 per cent of capacity, 1 point lower than last week, the magazine says.

The U.S.S. Illinois, familiar to almost a generation of New Yorkers as the barnlike floating armory at the foot of West Ninety-sixth Street, will "put to sea" again within the next few weeks, it became known yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 6. -- With a splendid incoming nine of 36, Miss Grace Amory, the youthful star from the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club gained the chief honors today in the season's inaugural tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6. -- Boxing relations have been severed between Harvard and Yale in their first athletic break since 1894. It came as an aftermath of the protested decision in the March 7 match at New Haven, where the cumulative method of scoring was used for judging bouts.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP). -- The Indians' extra-base batting shelled the Athletics into a 7-to-1 defeat in the opening game of a series today for the Tribe's fifth straight victory.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Minor changes in the Navy Department Appropriation Bill brought its total down to $529,125,806, as it was reported to the Senate today by the Appropriations Committee. As passed by the House, it carried an appropriation of $531,068,707.

ALBANY, May 6. -- Governor Lehman will go on the air tomorrow evening to make a second appeal to the public for support of his social security program, so far blocked by Republican legislators. Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth will use the same stations for a reply to the Governor on Friday evening in which he will defend the Republican opposition.

UTICA, N.Y., May 6. -- The Right Rev. Dr. Edward H. Coley of Utica was elected Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Central New York this afternoon on the fourth ballot. He succeeds Bishop Charles Fiske, retired.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 6. -- Society, convicted a year ago of neglecting its youth, was exonerated here tonight because it had shown improvement during the one-year probation. The verdict was announced to 300 persons at the annual dinner of the Council of Social Agencies in the Hotel Suburban here by Common Pleas Judge Daniel J. Brennan.

The legal efforts of the International Seamen's Union to curb the activities of a group of its members who have been on strike in Atlantic Coast ports for the last two months were transferred yesterday to the Federal Trade Commission.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 6. -- All Egypt was en fete today in welcoming home the 16-year-old King Farouk. Almost from dawn the streets of Alexandria and Cairo and railroad stations between the two cities were filled with throngs eager to catch a glimpse and extend a hearty welcome to the young monarch.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had stricken from the list McCrory Stores Corporation old 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, old no-par value common stock; old Class B common stock, and fifteen-year 5 1/2 per cent gold debentures, due on Dec. 15, 1941.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 6. -- Duke University's nine continued its winning ways today, this time at the expense of Army, the Blue Devils being on the long end of a 16-to-4 score at the finish of a heavy hitting engagement on The Plains diamond.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, in praising the work of the Children's Village, a juvenile correctional institution near Dobbs Ferry, expressed her "firm belief in the principle of 'give me the child before it is 7 and I will answer for the rest of its life.'"

TOKYO, Thursday, May 7. -- In a secret session of the Diet last night General Count Juichi Terauchi, War Minister, disclosed all that the army intends to reveal for the time being concerning the inner history of the February mutiny. He answered questions in a straightforward, soldierly manner, which made a good personal impression.

PITTSBURGH, May 6. -- In an encounter of skill and chance which they appeared to have definitely won as late as the seventh inning and practically lost in the ninth, the Giants finally managed to put a bold front on their affairs today.
IT was Somnolent James Crowley, clothed in a rich brown creation with hat and tie to match, who strolled in and said ingratiatingly:
FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, May 6 (AP). -- Germany's giant new airship, the Hindenburg, rose easily and lightly from her moorings at 9:30 tonight and pointed her nose for the English Channel.

ON BOARD THE ZEPPELIN HINDENBURG, May 6. With fifty-one passengers, including nine women besides myself, and a crew of fifty-six, much mail and some freight, the Zeppelin Hindenburg was drawn out from her great hangar at Friedrichshafen, Germany, shortly after 9 P.M. [4 P.M. New York time] and at 9:30 had begun her flight to the United States.
Scientists have stated that during the Glacial Age (about fifty thousand years ago) this section of our country was covered to a tremendous depth with ice moving relentlessly to the sea.

Little Freddie Marcella came sliding home in a whirl of dust, Umpire Lou Ferry's thumb jerked skyward and Fordham's ten-game winning streak came to an end yesterday at the Ram field. Marcella was called out in the final play of the contest as Long Island University toppled the hitherto unbeaten Maroon, 6 to 5.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP). -- Following a decision today by the United States Court of Claims, the Supreme Court will be asked to rule on the right of the Federal Government to collect income tax on the profits from the sale of tax-exempt First Liberty Loan gold bonds.

LONDON, May 6. -- The British Government insists that the "League of Nations must go on," but will demand a careful and thorough stock-taking by all its members as the result of its failure in Ethiopia, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden announced today.

BERLIN, May 6. -- The Boerse continued to fall slowly today, reacting steadily under government influence against the recent discussion of devaluation, which was reported to have pushed up the market. Stocks showed an average drop of 1 to 2 points.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and France, which is expected to improve materially the volume of commerce between the two countries, was signed at the State Department today by Secretary Cordell Hull and Andre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- A write-down of $14,500,000 in the assets of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and a segregation of so-called intangibles was approved today by directors of the company. The financial adjustments were announced by George A Ranney.

New challengers for supremacy in the 3-year-old division were shown yesterday at Jamaica when Mrs. Payne Whitney's Brush Hook was brought out for his seasonal debut in a test that also saw Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Gean Canach and others as competitors.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6. -- Women's influence in education was one of the principal subjects of discussion tonight at the opening here of the forty-second annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs.

CINCINNATI, May 6. -- "All things," quota Professor Casey Stengel happily tonight, "must come to an end." Meaning, of course, that his Dodgers snapped their losing streak at six games today by defeating the Reds, 5 -- 2, behind the excellent pitching of George Earnshaw.

Concrete evidence of the determination of public officials and business leaders to speed construction of the World's Fair of 1939 was provided yesterday when the Park Department advertised for bids for a $2,254,000 grading contract five days after the Board of Estimate had authorized an appropriation for the work.

A total of 119 entries has been received for the Albany-to-New York motor boat marathon on Sunday, Commodore Charles F. Chapman, race referee, announced last night at the meeting of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association at the Hotel Lexington. It was freely predicted that 150 would be included in the fleet.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Immediate withdrawal of American sovereignty from Puerto Rico and the payment of a substantial indemnity to the government its people might establish to compensate for the low state to which the rule of the United States is said to have brought it would be provided in a bill introduced in the House today by Representative Vito Marcantonio of New York.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 6. -- On instructions from their parents, between 200 and 250 of the 367 pupils at Huguenot School, an elementary public school, here, stayed home today in protest of the failure of the Board of Education to change its ruling closing the upper three grades of the school.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, appeared today before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce and urged favorable action on the bill for continuation of trading in unlisted securities upon the Exchanges, the registration of over-the-counter brokers and dealers and other regulatory purposes.

CHICAGO, May 6 (AP). -- Tex Carleton picked up where he left off in his role of Boston jinx as the Cubs defeated the Bees today, 8 to 6, but needed a lot of pitching and batting help to achieve the decision.

SAN FRANSISCO0 May 6 (AP). -- Almost complete Presidential primary returns give a clear-cut victory to an uninstructed Republican delegation over a slate pledged to Governor Landon, and an overwhelming majority for President Roosevelt's personally selected ticket as opposed to two other Democratic groups.

Miss Anne Morgan who was reelected president of the American Women's Association for the ninth consecutive year on Tuesday at a meeting of the board of governors, presided last night at a governor's dinner held in the clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6. -- Dr. A.R. Baldwin of Saranac, N.Y., received the George M. Kober Medal for outstanding medical achievement at the concluding sessions of the fifty-first annual meeting of the Association of American Physicians here today.
Several leases for expansion were included in the business rentals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Personal objections of Senator Copeland will probably block Senate confirmation of John J. Kelly as United States Marshal for New York, a post he is now filling under a recess appointment. The Senator has filed his formal objections with the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee, which is considering the appointment.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ROME, May 6. -- "We shall go straight ahead." This sentence, which has been the badge that Premier Benito Mussolini has exhibited in public throughout the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, continues more than ever to guide his actions in his present hour of triumph.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Praised by members on both sides of the aisle as a measure that would result in more efficient law enforcement, the House today passed by unanimous consent a bill authorizing consolidation of all Treasury Department enforcement agencies, except the Narcotics Division, into a single unit to be known as the Treasury Agency Service.

Prices of Commodity futures were generally higher yesterday in comparatively quiet trading. A feature was the strength in sugar futures. The May contract reaching 2.95 cents a pound, the best price for any future month since May, 1928. In the cash market, corn, rye, oats and silk were higher, while wheat, lard and rubber were lower.
ALBANY, May 6. -- Payment of 50 per cent of the increased State franchise tax on incorporated business must be made on May 15, State officials said today.

Dr. Harry W. Laidler, new State chairman of the Socialist party, issued a statement yesterday deploring the announced intention of the party's Old Guard faction, defeated in the recent State primary, to form a separate Social-Democratic party.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Newton D. Baker was re-elected president and Dr. Charles E. Clark, dean of the Yale Law School was elected vice president and chairman of a newly created ways and means committee at the annual meeting here today of the American Judicature Society.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

In the Social Security Act Congress provided for a plan under which the States were to build up reserves to be paid out as unemployment insurance. So convinced was Congress of the necessity of these reserves that it refused to grant a tax credit to any State unemployment insurance plan proposing to pay out benefits before accumulating a reserve for two years.
BOSTON, May 6 (AP). -- The Red Sox turned back the Browns, 7 -- 4, today, with Johnny Marcum going the route for the first time as a member of the Boston clan.

Plans to set up a night club in the all-night bar and restaurant in the Bronx Terminal Market, the only resort in the city with an all-night liquor license, have been blocked by Mayor La Guardia, it developed yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 6. -- Amherst held Yale scoreless for eleven innings and finally won today's game, 1 -- 0.

Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., drew a short game lasting only sixteen moves with Isaac I. Kashdan of New York in the ninth round last night to maintain his lead in the United States title chess tournament.

Stocks continued to improve moderately in quiet trading yesterday, with the closing steady and slightly higher. The day's leaders, which included several of the steel and mining issues, were up from fractions to 2 1/2 points. Transactions on the Stock Exchange aggregated 1,131,000 shares, against 1,174,000 the day before.

The Bronx continued as a center of real estate buying activity yesterday when plots were purchased by builders for improvement with apartment houses and multi-family structures were disposed of by operators. The trading included the sale of a large factory to a concern that will employ 200 workers.
