Under the lead of July contracts, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday, ending with gains of 1 to 7 points. May held within a limit of 2 points, the narrowest range so far this season, as mills fixed prices or transferred obligations to later months.

Gleanings from notebook and mailbag: Bill Gates of White Plains caught a white perch in Lake Mahopac, Putnam County, the other day that weighed two pounds five ounces. . . . It reminded the old-timers of the fine pan-fishing they used to enjoy in some of the Putham and Westchester lakes in former days. . . .

LONDON, May 6. -- Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, flatly rejected today a proposal now being made by leading internationalists in this country to give discontented nations like Germany a share in governing colonial mandates.

LONDON, May 6. -- The Foreign Office announced today that Dr. Andre John Mesnard Melly, leader of a British ambulance unit in North Ethiopia, died peacefully at the British Legation in Addis Ababa last night.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 6. -- The Treasury of Nebraska, the only debtless State in the nation, had a balance of $21,123,935 today.

The Southern Pacific Company contributed $97,555 as its share of the support of the Association of American Railroads in 1935, the company's report for that year to the Interstate Commerce Commission discloses.

SENECA FALLS, N.Y., May 6 (AP). -- Samuel Keighkley, 87, retired farmer, burned to death in his homo this morning. His wife had gone shopping, leaving Mr. Keighkley asleep in the living room near a stove. Neighbors discovered the house in flames and called firemen.
LONDON, May 6. -- Following are extracts from Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's speech in the House of Commons today on the Ethiopian situation:

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 6. -- Restoration of historic Williamsburg to its Colonial appearance through the philanthropy of John D. Rockefeller Jr. was achieved without one piece of property being purchased from speculators, it was revealed today to members attending the sixty-eighth convention of the American Institute of Architects by Vernon M. Geddy, assistant to the president of Colonial Williamsburg, Inc.

Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, for thirty-five years a teacher in the city's schools, was appointed and sworn in yesterday as a member of the Board of Education by Mayor La Guardia. She succeeds Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the board for fourteen years, whose term expired Tuesday.

Jack Dempsey, restaurateur and former boxing champion, has leased an apartment of eleven rooms and four baths in the San Remo, 145 Central Park West, at Seventy-fourth Street. The rental was arranged by the Real Estate Bureau of the State Banking Department.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 6. -- President Roosevelt's adversaries are prone to forget what they said and what they felt a few years ago in regard to "the very policies they so emphatically denounce now," Postmaster General Farley declared here tonight in an address to Connecticut Democratic leaders.

Bullish influences again reigned yesterday in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Further recoveries extended over a broad list of domestic corporate issues as trading reflected returning confidence among most traders. Both high-grade and the more speculative issues in the domestic section shared in the advance.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Spending drives by Congressional blocs, amounting in one case to a revolt against the administration, had developed to a point today where they threatened to override President Roosevelt's demand for economy and increase Federal expenditures by at least $1,000,000,000.
ALBANY, May 6. -- Behind closed doors the Senate Judiciary Committee today defeated the bill of Senator Byrne, Democrat of Albany, providing for ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment.

The pamphlet report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $939,526 for the year, equal to $1.22 each on 770,566 combined preferred shares, compared with an income of $156,746, or 20 cents a preferred share, for 1934.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The House Appropriations Committee has cut $75,000,000 from the President's requested $1,500,000,000 for relief for the fiscal year 1937, it was learned today as leaders tightened their lines for a three-cornered battle when the Secondary Deficiency Appropriation Bill, carrying almost $2,500,000,000, is introduced and comes up for debate tomorrow.

GLENEAGLES, Scotland, May 6. -- The United States women's golf team retained the Curtis Cup today by the narrow margin of a one-yard putt on the last green which lipped the cup but just would not drop for a British victory on the hole.

A home run by Thomas Cronin in the sixth enabled the St. Peter's High team to defeat Tottenville, 3 to 2, yesterday at Goodhue Oval, New Brighton, S.I. The defeat ended the six-game winning streak of Tottenville. In another Staten Island contest Williamsburgh Vocational lost to McKee Vocational at Thompson Stadium, 10 to 9.

The thirtieth quadrennial session of the General Conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Church opened yesterday at Rockland Palace, 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, with more than 5,000 Negroes in attendance from the United States, South Africa, West Africa, the West Indies and South America.

Establishment of a joint commission of operators and miners for stabilization of the anthracite industry has been agreed upon by the joint conference representing both factors which has been meeting here for the past twelve weeks in efforts to reach a new agreement for the industry.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 6 (AP). -- The Newark Bears squared the four-game series with the Bisons by battering their way to a 9-to-3 verdict in the final contest today.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- Covering by shorts and spreading operations furnished a good part of today's trade in wheat on the Board of Trade. Scattered buying of the new crop months, based on reports of high temperatures and dust storms in parts of Kansas and Nebraska, lifted prices rather sharply after a small dip early, with the distant deliveries closing 5/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel higher.

Membership in the Roman Catholic Church in the United States increased in 1935 by 212,136, according to the Official Catholic Directory published by P.J. Kenedy Sons of this city, the 1936 annual edition of which appeared yesterday.

Many textile fabrics and products could be materially improved in strength, finish and wearability if dealers and consumers were willing to pay a slight premium for the extra time and cost of better drying during their manufacture, speakers said yesterday at the conference on textile drying problems held under the auspices of the United States Institute for Textile Research at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 6. -- A birth control memorial was fried today with the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which is in session here. The memorial, said to be the first dealing with birth control ever to come before the governing body, asks endorsement of "the principles of birth control legislation now pending in Congress," which would permit physicians, hospitals and clinics to receive through the mails contraceptive appliances and information.

The festival of American music sponsored by the Federal Music Project yesterday afternoon entered its fourth day at the Manhattan Theatre with a concert devoted to a procession of songs, harpsichord and piano compositions dating from the Revolutionary period to the present day.

The list of the Italian liner Rex, due today from Mediterranean ports, includes Mr. and Mrs. Woods Bliss, Colonel Lynn Chu, Henri B. Rainville, for twenty-five years Speaker of the Canadian House of Parliament, with Mrs. Rainville; Henry Gerard-Rainville, concert violinist; Count and Countess Contini Bonacossi, Baroness Von Nagerl, Count G. D'Attimis, Ignacio Molina and Mr. and Mrs. Davis English.

DETROIT, May 6 (AP). -- Resounding ovations and a capacity crowd greeted the world premiere of "The Dybbuk" in English tonight when the Detroit Civic Opera presented it for the first time in the United States.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., May 6 (AP). -- Possibility that the final outcome of yesterday's primary test between Senator Borah and Governor Landon may await the official canvass developed today as late returns showed the Kansan holding only a slight edge.
TRENTON, May 6. -- Commissioner William J. Ellis of the State Institutions Department was advised today that New Jersey has been found eligible for Federal old-age assistance.

Sales in the men's wear and affiliated industries will be "good" for at least another six months, according to a survey covering the wholesale branch of the industry, it was announced, last night by Harry J. Delaney, vice president of Meinhard, Greef Co., at a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

A capacity gathering attended last night the formal opening for the season of the Pierre Roof, a Summer restaurant overlooking Central Park from the forty-second floor of the Hotel Pierre. The rendezvous has been redecorated to represent a trellis-enclosed garden with privet hedges and window boxes lining the side walls.

Percy H. Johnston, president of the Chemical Bank, testified yesterday in the Supreme Court that ten directors of his bank had pledged their willingness in March, 1933, to pay $40,000 each out of their private pockets, if necessary, provided all the other Clearing House banks would join similarly in an attempt to make up the deposit losses of the insolvent Harriman Bank to "keep it out of the newspapers."

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The establishment by Eastern railroads of a free store-door pick-up and delivery service for less-than-carload freight, regardless of the distance of hauls, was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission over the combined opposition of organized shippers and truckers and the government of New York City.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP). -- The National Retail Credit Association, the National Consumer Credit Reporting Corporation, four credit reporting bureaus and five individuals pleaded guilty today to criminal contempt of an anti-trust injunction issued by Federal District Judge Charles B. Davis in 1933.

Your recent editorial article "Probation and Parole" should attract attention among criminologists, for its inspiration was the Welfare Council's urge for adequate psychopathic clinics and its claim that the suspended sentence and the promise to reform were really a high order of social protection.

Federal Judge William Bondy ordered yesterday the return of a quantity of business records and correspondence, seized on Saturday by Federal authorities, on which they were relying heavily to build up their case against John Torrio, former Chicago gangster who is accused of having defrauded the government through the misuse of revenue stamps.
SHANGHAI, May 6. -- After one of the periodical lulls, Chino-Japanese relations seem to be again growing tense in both the north and the south.

This week has seen the beginning of recovery in retail trade from the post-Easter decline in volume, reports in both wholesale and retail circles here yesterday indicated. Retailers here expressed the view that sales this month will show the start of the upward curve in volume that will reach a climax in June and July.

LONDON, May 6. -- The British Government heard today a voice from the political wilderness saying in effect, "I told you so." It was the well-remembered voice of Sir Samuel Hoare, making one of his few speeches since he was driven from the Foreign Secretaryship and his first since the Italian conquest of Ethiopia became a fact.

Dock Commissioner John McKenzie, who issued an order on Tuesday barring all taxicabs from city-owned piers, was not worried yesterday over the apparent disregard of the new regulation on piers along the North River.

Changes in the rules governing the awarding of the Pulitzer prizes in letters and journalism were announced yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism, secretary of the advisory board that recommends to the Columbia trustees candidates for the awards.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Prestige is so delicately based a thing, especially in politics, that even politicians in the most commanding situations cannot retain it against a succession of adversities, however minor in themselves. The moment prestige is lost or seriously questioned, defeat becomes the possibility it was not the moment before.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Health insurance and a new Federal law to set wage and hour standards are to be among the next pillars erected by the Roosevelt administration to support the New Deal's social security and labor program, Senator Wagner told a mass meeting arranged by the convention of the Women's Trade Union League tonight.

Challenging the right of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., to act on behalf of United States holders of defaulted Colombian bonds in efforts to effect a settlement with the Colombian Government, the Bondholders Committees for the Republic of Colombia, which have been obtaining deposits of bonds for three years, have addressed a communication to the council stating that, if necessary, legal action would be taken to restrain its activities.

Foreseeing years of continued exchange difficulty before Italy recovers from the heavy expenses of the Ethiopian war, exporters will continue to demand cash in New York on shipments to that country, they said yesterday at the round-table discussion of export credit problems held at the Hotel Pennsylvania under auspices of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- In a statement which administration spokesmen admitted was perhaps the most rational indictment yet laid against the proposed undistributed corporate profits tax, George O. May, senior partner of Price, Waterhouse Co., accountants, and a war-time adviser to the Treasury, told the Senate Finance Committee today that the pending measure was unsound, unworkable and unnecessary.
The "three-cents-a-day" plan of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, which affords hospital care to its subscribers when needed, started its second year of operation yesterday.

Opening the prosecution at the mail-fraud trial of four former officers of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company, the government accused them yesterday of a "monumental betrayal of trust" that led to considerable losses to holders of the company's $81,000,000 mortgage bonds.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 6. -- Cornell won its third game in ten starts by defeating the University of Rochester, 5 -- 1, today. The Yellow Jackets committed eight misplays behind Wes Van Grafland's four-hit hurling. Ernie Downer got a triple and Jack Batten a double for Cornell.

Declaring that witnesses at Congressional hearings had been subjected to the mental torture of an inquisitorial examination into their private affairs, the New York Board of Trade sent a protest yesterday to the chairmen of all committees of Congress.

Opening the prosecution at the mail-fraud trial of four former officers of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company, the government accused them yesterday of a "monumental betrayal of trust" that led to considerable losses to holders of the company's $81,000,000 mortgage bonds.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 6. -- Cornell won its third game in ten starts by defeating the University of Rochester, 5 -- 1, today. The Yellow Jackets committed eight misplays behind Wes Van Grafland's four-hit hurling. Ernie Downer got a triple and Jack Batten a double for Cornell.

Declaring that witnesses at Congressional hearings had been subjected to the mental torture of an inquisitorial examination into their private affairs, the New York Board of Trade sent a protest yesterday to the chairmen of all committees of Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- In a statement which administration spokesmen admitted was perhaps the most rational indictment yet laid against the proposed undistributed corporate profits tax, George O. May, senior partner of Price, Waterhouse Co., accountants, and a war-time adviser to the Treasury, told the Senate Finance Committee today that the pending measure was unsound, unworkable and unnecessary.

Plans to organize a nation-wide "home-sewing" campaign were discussed yesterday by piece goods buyers of department and specialty stores and resident buying office representatives at a meeting held at the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 6. -- Georgetown collected thirteen hits today to defeat the Naval Academy nine, 12 to 8. Up to the fifth inning, the Middies only put one runner as far as second. In that session, Nicketakis's wildness enabled them to tally four runs.
PITTSBURGH, May 6. -- It is either "Good night mother!" or "Good-bye, broadcasting!" for John Charles Thomas, the baritone.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad's efforts to recapture passenger business resulted in increases of 12.9 per cent in the number of passengers carried and 3.4 per cent in passenger revenue in 1935, Ralph Budd, president, told stockholders in his annual report today.

Debate will begin in the House of Representatives today on the Administration's Relief Bill. This measure calls for an appropriation of $1,500,000,000 to be used for relief of unemployment during the twelve months beginning next July. The President is opposed to "earmarking" any substantial part of this sum for large construction projects under the auspices of PWA.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 6. -- John Morris held the New York University's batsmen to seven scattered hits on University Field today to turn in a 5-1 victory for Princeton. It was the fifth triumph of the season for the Nassau team.

CONSIDERABLE material for the argument that "crime and justice" is at present in America the name of a game, in which the final score largely depends on who has the luck, the cop or the robber, is supplied by Sheldon Glueck, Professor of Criminology at Harvard Law School, in his "Crime and Justice" (Little, Brown, $3).

Today's statement of the Bank of France, which will give the position of that institution as of last Friday, is expected to show a loss of gold amounting to about $75,000,000, which would be the largest since the week ended on April 3, when the current run of gold losses began to show up in the bank's statement.

Isidor J. Kresel will appear as attorney for Charles C. Wright, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, at hearings beginning next Monday on the alleged manipulation of the stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange.

A blind honor graduate in law, who worked his way through school by tuning pianos and tutoring other students, was one of 198 law graduates to be admitted to the bar yesterday in a ceremony in the Appellate Division chambers in Brooklyn.

A plan to sell about $25,000,000 of convertible debentures to its stockholders has been abandoned by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, Sosthenes Behn, president, announced yesterday in a statement accompanying the pamphlet report for 1935.

The Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities is always at this season under the necessity of reminding the public that the Federation has to support alone the agencies (twenty-five in number) that carry on practically every type of philanthropic endeavor. Which is to say that its budget is not provided for by "The Federation for "the Support of Jewish Philanthropic "Societies of New York City."

LONDON, May 6. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were brighter today, largely because of more encouraging news from Wall Street and the Continent. Renewed demand sprang up for British Government securities.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 6. -- Nineteen Connecticut delegates to the Republican National Convention at Cleveland were selected here today, at the Republican State Convention. The delegates will go uninstructed and unpledged and, although Governor Landon is favored by some of the delegates as a Presidential nominee, others prefer Senator Vandenberg and Senator Steiwer.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 6. -- The auctioneer's hammer will resound tomorrow in Northampton at the first Presidential souvenir auction, which will put household articles once used by a President into the hands of hundreds of persons who are coming from all over the country to buy some article in memory of Calvin Coolidge.

ADDIS ABABA, May 6 (AP). -- Brigands still held partial control today of the business section and some outlying districts of this Ethiopian capital, now a shambles after looting, pillaging and burning.
Money market remained at a standstill in the matter of business and quotations. The demand for funds was light, at prevailing charges.

To his already crowded schedule for next season George Abbott has added a new musical show -- the first that he will ever have presented. Its authors will be Richard Rodgers, Lorenz Hart and Mr. Abbott, the trio who wrote the current "On Your Toes," and Mr. Abbott, of course, will stage it.

Manhattan College accounted for its tenth straight victory by subduing a stubborn Brooklyn College nine, 9 to 5, yesterday at Manhattan Beach, spending a few uneasy moments before being able to clinch matters and remain among the unbeaten.

Ginette Marboeuf-Hoyet, who won a contest over 2,999 other little girls in Paris because she looked the most like Shirley Temple, arrived yesterday on the French liner Paris en route to Hollywood, where she will meet the real Shirley and be the guest of the Fox Film Company.
ALBANY, May 6. -- Governor Lehman signed today two bills designed to improve methods in the appointment of lunacy commissions. In a memorandum of approval he wrote:
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 6 (AP). -- The Prohibition party in national convention late today overwhelmingly voted down a proposal to change its name to the "Commonweal party."

PHILADELPHIA, May 6. -- Mrs. Justine Constance Perot Emerson, a du Pont heiress who risked forfeiture of her inheritance by marrying in defiance of a wish expressed in her mother's will, is not to suffer financially as a result. Judge Charles Klein in Orphans Court today nullified Mrs. Eleanor du Pont Taney's testamentary recommendation that her daughter be penalized.
MONTREAL, May 6 (Canadian Press). -- Shareholders of Canadian Pacific Railway approved a resolution today authorizing issuance of $65,000,000 of further capital stock of a par value of $25 a share.

LONDON, May 6. -- David Lloyd George delivered a slashing attack on munitions makers today when he testified before the Royal Commission which is inquiring into the private manufacture of arms in Britain.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The statement of George O. May, senior partner of Price, Waterhouse Co. of New York, to the Senate Finance committee, today, was as follows:

BALTIMORE, May 6. -- Elwood Sachsenmaier's Roman Soldier, 4-year-old black son of Cohort -- Miamba and an eligible for the Dixie Handicap, captured the Class A division of the graded handicaps, feature event today at Pimlico.

CLEVELAND, May 6. -- Resumption of the long struggle for control of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Company is expected to follow a special meeting of stockholders which has been called for May 27 to vote on amending the articles of incorporation.

GENEVA, May 7. -- The British Government's attitude in the House of Commons leaves League of Nations quarters discouraged, but with a good many officials still incredulous that sanctions against Italy will really be lifted soon, least of all during the coming Council session.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, May 7. -- An Estonian court-martial today began the trial of 155 Fascists accused of complicity in the unsuccessful revolt of Dec. 8 designed to overthrow the present political regime. The defendants belong to all social classes ranging from generals, diplomats and barristers to taxi drivers and farmers.

PARIS, May 7. -- A radio message received by the Air Ministry tonight reported that the Graf Zegpelin, returning from South America, was in difficulty and was asking permission to fly over France en route to her base at Friedrichshafen.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 7 (AP). -- Buffalo humbled Albany, 9 to 2, today and extended the consecutive losing streak of the visitors to twelve games. Johnny Wilson restricted his foes to four hits and was robbed of a shutout only by Smead Jolley's homer.

PITTSBURGH, May 7. -- Business activity in the Pittsburgh district declined slightly last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's index of general business, in which allowance has been made for the usual seasonal changes and for long-term growth, stood at 86.3 last week, three-tenths of a point lower than in the preceding week.

As an ex-member of the Knickerbocker Greys, I would like to reply to a communication which was printed in your paper. The correspondent has gone woefully wide of the mark in her understanding of the purpose of the Greys, and her questions are based upon these misconceptions.

BOSTON, May 7. -- Frederic E. Snow Jr., youngest son of a prominent Boston lawyer, was married yesterday to Edna Pettinati of Medford. The couple eloped to Harrison, N.Y., and this morning Frederic Snow's brother, William Snow, received a post card reading:

Dr. Charles Norris, for eighteen years chief medical examiner of New York City, who died on Sept. 11, left an estate appraised yesterday at $491,600 gross and $438,236 net, the bulk of which was in securities worth $413,429. The largest holdings were $62,100 in city of Philadelphia bonds, 2,850 shares United Gas and Improvement Company stock worth $27,737, and 3,300 shares Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company valued at $23,100.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway paid $19,462 in 1935 as a gratuity to Mrs. Helen Bernet, widow of J.J. Bernet, former president of the company, the report of the company for last year to the Interstate Commerce Commission discloses. Mr. Bernet, who was president also of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) and the Pere Marquette Railways, died last July.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, May 7. -- When Emperor Haile Selassie left Ethiopia with older chiefs, several young Ethiopian Government officials, to mark their disgust, took their rifles and declared they were going out to lead a last stand against the Italians.

BARTOW, Fla., May 7. -- The two men who survived the Tampa floggings of Nov. 30, Eugene F. Poulnot and Dr. Sam J. Rogers, were in effect on trial today before the six-man jury which is hearing evidence against seven discharged Tampa policemen charged with the kidnapping of Mr. Poulnot.

ROME, May 7. -- Outright annexation of Ethiopia will be decided upon at a meeting of the Fascist Grand Council at 10 o'clock Saturday evening and confirmed at a Cabinet council a half-hour later. It will be announced immediately afterward, probably by Premier Benito Mussolini in a speech from the balcony outside his offices in the Palazzo Venezia.

Principally through Bill Dickey's two homers, some effective relief hurling by Ted Kleinhans and Joe DiMaggio's spectacular ninth-inning throw to home, the Yankees safely sailed into Victory Harbor again at the Stadium yesterday to sweep the two-game series with the Tigers.

LONDON, May 7. -- The Netherlands freighter Alphard was sunk in the North Sea tonight when it collided with the Hamburg-American liner New York, but all twenty-six members of the Alphard's crew were saved.

Early American and English portrait mezzotints and stipple and line engravings removed from Ophir Hall, Purchase, N. Y., residence of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, together with etchings and engravings, including property of the estate of William Mitchell and other properties, brought $12,555 last night at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 7. -- Chile will make no move for the reform of the League of Nations at the Council meeting Monday, according to well-informed circles, which base their view on the fact that the Chilean Cabinet will be altered soon.
PARIS, May 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

TOPEKA, Kan., May 7. -- Governor Landon, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, charged tonight that the Roosevelt administration "had made the worst record ever made in the history of the United States in bringing this country out of a depression."

At a meeting of the new board of directors of Universal Pictures, Inc., held yesterday at the general offices of the company, R.H. Cochrane was elected president, J. Cheever Cowdin was elected chairman of the board, Charles R. Rogers executive vice president, Willard S. McKay vice president and secretary and Charles B. Paine treasurer.

Montgomery Ward Co. yesterday announced that sales in April, amounting to $30,402,667 represented the largest volume of business transacted in that month in its history. The dollar volume exceeded the previous record of $35,571,012 in April, 1935, by 18.9 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A House appropriations subcommittee has handed J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, another mystery to solve -- why his Federal Bureau of Investigation bought eighty-six new cars when it did not have the money to pay for them.

Unchecked by Wednesday's advance in the rediscount rate of the Bank of France to 6 per cent, the flight of capital from the franc continued strong yesterday. An additional $17,500,000 of gold was engaged in Paris for shipment here, making a total of $114,300,000 French gold taken for United States account since April 24.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 7. -- Architects can render their greatest service by "directing their efforts toward the small house of moderate cost for occupancy by the wage-earners and salaried workers in our urban communities," President Roosevelt told the American Institute of Architects today through a message read by Stephen F. Voorhees of New York, institute president, to the convention here.

PITTSBURGH, May 7. -- After more than a week and a half of severe buffeting in the West, the Giants finally straightened out today. They straightened out in the sixth inning when, at a very tense moment, the Pirates clouted them for a cluster of five runs that stretched Colonel Bill Terry's stalwarts out on the green of Forbes Field.

Possibly, as Albert Ulmann suggests in his letter to THE TIMES, Manhattan has at least two architectural relics of its Dutch occupation. To me it seems a question of whether we are to regard the tombstone of Petrus Stuyvesant as -- and here I am again quoting Professor Shepherd, not repeating myself -- an "architectural relic."

CHICAGO, May 7. -- Radio and aeronautical instrument engineers have perfected a robot pilot which not only stabilizes airplanes while they are in flight but lands them without the aid of a human pilot. The landing is done by means of a curved radio "glide path" beam which guides the planes in safe and precise descents regardless of clouds or fog.

PARIS, May 7. -- Despite reassuring statements by Finance Minister Marcel Regnier and the bankers and political experts with whom he has been in consultation, a serious flight of capital has begun in France.
Housing and business properties changed hands in the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.

Permission to complete speedily the replacement of the city's trolley lines with buses was requested yesterday by the New York Railways Corporation, which is being reorganized under the Bankruptcy Act, in a show-cause suit intended to cut through impeding litigation.

A two-year agreement assuring peace in the anthracite industry was signed last night by representatives of operators and miners after another day of discussion at the Hotel Vanderbilt. The agreement signed last night is dated as of April 30.
Upsets which damaged the chances of two of the foremost contestants marked play in the tenth round of the United States championship of the National Chess Federation at the Hotel Astor last night.
All preparations had been completed last night for the handling of the Hindenburg at Lakehurst.

In his Hartford speech Wednesday night Chairman FARLEY was at his most withering in decrying Republican chances of success this year. He left them no consolation whatever, staking his political reputation on the prediction that President ROOSEVELT will have a larger majority in 1936 than he had in 1932.

The Zeppelin Hindenburg will leave Monday night with a full passenger list, fifty-one persons in all, among them Mrs. Harriet O. Hague, 86 years old. Eleven of those on board will be making a return trip.

HAVANA, May 7. -- Dr. Evelio Luis Barrena, who was commissioned by the government to arrange for reopening Havana University, was shot and slightly wounded this morning while he was on his way to the university.

Advertising men should study the economics of the distribution field, as in this field lie most of our current problems, Paul Cornell of Geyer, Cornell Newell and recently elected chairman of the board of the American Association of Advertising Agents, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York.
Operators figured prominently in the purchase of apartment houses in the Bronx yesterday when deals also were announced involving the erection of new multi-family buildings.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 7. -- Although the Little Entente Foreign Ministers will remain in Belgrade until tomorrow for economic negotiations on behalf of their respective States, the political conference ended this afternoon and a communique was issued this evening.

ALBANY, May 7. -- Governor Lehman went on the air tonight and summed up his case for the social security legislation which he has sponsored. He declared that failure of the Republican Assembly to concur with the Democratic Senate in a favorable vote on the measure would be nothing short of a public calamity.

Announcing its endorsement of a bill in Congress fixing a duty of 8 cents a pound on oysters and oyster products, the Middle Atlantic Fisheries Association yesterday said the measure aimed at halting the rapid invasion of the American market by Japanese interests.

LONDON, May 7. -- Happy as a busload of schoolgirls over the fact they saved the Curtis Cup for two more years, America's women golfers spent most of the day en route to St. Annes-on-the-Sea for several days of rest before tackling their next big enterprise -- the women's British championship -- at Southport, starting May 15.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- President Roosevelt endorsed enthusiastically today plans laid before him for the use of more than $20,000,000 in building and endowing a post-graduate medical school and hospital in New York City.

The bluefish are in the surf at Oregon Inlet, N.C. Bradley Martin of this city spent a couple of days there early this week and landed a nice mess of fish, weighing up to eight pounds. Two channel bass also were beached. Martin hooked his blues on a white Japanese feather, rigged especially for surf casting by a New York tackle dealer.

LACONA, N.Y., May 7 (AP). -- Charles M. Salisbury, 78-year-old president of the Lacona National Bank, was shot and killed today by one of two youthful robbers, who escaped. The gunmen, who entered the bank announcing: "This is a stick-up," fled without taking any money.

The National Labor Relations Board announced through its regional office here yesterday that editorial employes of the New York office of The Associated Press would have an opportunity to decide in a secret ballot whether they wish to be represented in collective bargaining by the American Newspaper Guild.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted reached the lowest.
ALBANY, May 7. -- The Senate passed two bills today aimed at restoration of about $17,000,000 in pay cuts to New York City firemen, policemen and other city employes.

Money market was quiet, business being small and quotations unchanged for all classifications. Discussion continued on the question of raising the rate for demand loans due to increased clerical work resulting from the new regulations. Lenders were of the opinion that a hardening might be expected shortly.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Foreign diplomatic representatives in Addis Ababa have been informed by Marshal Pietro Badoglio, Italian commander, in a circular letter that, pending further developments regarding the cessation of hostilities and the new status of Ethiopia, the chiefs of foreign missions and members of their legations will enjoy their usual prerogatives for representing the interests of their countries and for protecting their nationals.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A State Department explanation of the steps taken to guard American lives and property in the legation at Addis Ababa was assured tonight when Chairman McReynolds of the House Foreign Affairs Committee agreed to hold a hearing next Tuesday on the resolution of Representative Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts calling for such information.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who in the Appellate Division last week won a ruling that he had authority to raze the Central Park Casino building and use the site for a children's playground, faced another injunction proceeding in the Supreme Court yesterday because he is constructing a playground and a wading pool for children in Stuyvesant Square.

A resolution disapproving many of the changes proposed in the Bankruptcy Act was adopted yesterday by the bankruptcy law committee of the Federal Bar Association and forwarded to the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives in Washington.
ST. LOUIS, May 7 (AP). -- Trailing by a run in the eighth, the Cardinals utilized two singles, an error, a walk, a sacrifice and a long fly to score twice and defeat Philadelphia today, 3 to 2.

Jersey justice of late has not exactly been basking in the admiration of the world, but it now handsomely redeems itself. Compared with recent proceedings in and about Trenton the people of the Oranges and Maplewood have every reason to be proud of their law and order machinery.
LONDON, May 7. -- Great Britain's retreat from Geneva gained momentum today as more and more of the government's supporters urged abandonment of sanctions and reform of the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Welcomed by President Roosevelt and addressed informally by Chief Justice Hughes, members of the American Law Institute opened today their annual meeting here for intensive discussion of their restatement of law.

The People's Chorus of New York, under the direction of Lorenzo Camilieri, celebrated its twentieth anniversary last night with a Spring Song Festival in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. A large, responsive assemblage greeted the concert and also the assisting artists of the evening, Frank Sheridan, pianist, and Carola Goya, Spanish dancer, both distinguished in their arts.

An investor has bought the five- story building containing fifty-six apartments at 2,027 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, from Pitkin Estates, Inc., Morris Dlugasch, president. The house is on a plot 150 by 100 feet and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $106,000.

After negotiations which have lasted many months, the United States and France have signed a new trade treaty. Its terms will not be made public until Wednesday of next week, but it is known that the agreement will come into effect on June 15 and that it will remain in force until July 1, 1937, and indefinitely thereafter, subject to termination by either country on six months' notice.

Long Island University sports awards will be presented this evening at the annual L.I.U. athletic dinner at the Hotel Capitol. Letter awards total 108 while additional prizes for meritorious endeavour are to be given.

Building plans filed yesterday included two apartment projects for Bronx corners and proposed construction of forty-two dwellings in Rego Park, Queens, to cost $168,000. Details of the plans were as follows:

A cheap diamond ring, said to have been pledged in a transaction involving $200, led yesterday to the arrest of Miss Mary Berd, 36-year-old secretary of Rabbi Zeida Schmellner. His arrival in this country from Rumania in 1925 was the occasion for a reception by the Mayor.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 7. -- A proposal intended to broaden the grounds on which Methodist Episcopal ministers may perform the marriage ceremony for a divorced person was rejected today by the State of the Church Committee of the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in session here.

After deliberating two hours a jury before Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, returned a verdict for $115,000 yesterday in favor of Miss Tess Gardella, an actress known as "Aunt Jemima." The defendants were the National Broadcasting Company, General Foods, Inc., and Log Cabin Products, Inc., a subsidiary of General Foods.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Militarist domination of Japan would have fallen of its own weight years ago except for the encouragement given to it by ever-mounting military expenditures by the United States, Senator Nye told the Senate today while speaking against the pending $529,125,806 Navy Department Appropriation Bill. Mr. Nye was seeking to have stricken from the bill the $115,000,000 for construction of new vessels.

When the President first suggested the revolution in corporate income taxes on March 3, the principal reason he gave for that tax was the need to raise $620,000,000 "permanent" additional annual revenue by it. When the House Ways and Means Committee had framed a tentative measure, spokesmen for the Treasury estimated that it would yield this additional amount.
Coming and going:

Running within four-fifths of a second of his own track record, King Saxon, pet of C.H. (Pat) Knebelkamp, yesterday won the featured Dunboyne Handicap at Jamaica in what was his third start and first victory of the season. Under 126 pounds, the 5-year-old finished the six furlongs in 1:11 1-5 after hard urging from Charlie Landolt.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 7. -- Homely household possessions of a former citizen of this city, things which could be duplicated in thousands of homes throughout the country, were sold at auction today in the gymnasium of Smith Agricultural School, and people came from many States to bid on them.

RICHMOND, Va., May 7. -- Members of the Association of Junior Leagues will be allowed the right to publish papers in the League's magazine on controversial questions, provided, it is stated, that such views do not constitute the opinion of the entire membership, league delegates decided today at a session held in Williamsburg.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The People's Gas Light and Coke Company of Chicago has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of $22,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series D, due on June 1, 1961.
BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP). -- The favorite players suffered a heavy blow today at Pimlico in the Eutaw Purse, feature offering, when Billy Bee, 3-to-5 choice, finished fifth.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A statement of expenditures and receipts by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation from its establishment on Feb. 2, 1932, until April 30, this year, shows that repayments last month were $75,355,694 and that there had been a continuous reduction of loans to banks, these institutions having repaid $15,283,562 of previous loans, cutting the total outstanding down to $277,883,063.

Randalls Island, as mysterious a place to native New Yorkers as Tahiti or the Isle of Bali, was formally shown to members of the American Olympic Committee and to sports writers yesterday. They were given a view for the first time of the huge $1,000,000 construction project under way there and all were quite amazed at the progress made in the building of the stadium.

RYE, N.Y., May 7. -- Mrs. Jonathan Thorne, metropolitan champion, joined Miss Sylva Annenberg and Miss Grace Amory in the winning ranks of the one-day tournaments when she negotiated the Westchester Country Club course in 79 today to take the low gross of the first Westchester-Fairfield event.
THE TIMES is to be commended on its editorial "Money for Investment," in which an analysis is made of the factors responsible for so little new financing of productive enterprise.
LONDON, May 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

City College honored 406 of its athletic representatives yesterday with letters and numerals as part of the eighty-ninth Charter Day exercises, which were held to commemorate the founding of the college. This, incidentally, was the largest number of awards ever to be given for a program of athletics in its history.

The Museum of Modern Art, which has outgrown its present quarters at 11 West Fifty-third Street, has bought a large plot diagonally opposite for an indicated cost of $215,250, records filed yesterday revealed. Alfred H. Barr Jr., director of the museum, said that while it eventually must have a new building, "nothing definite" had been decided.

Long training in the terminology of chart students enabled some traders in board rooms quickly to label yesterday's decline as a "secondary reaction." Other chart students, equally versed in the mysteries of stock-market charts, decided that the sell-off represented the "resumption of the downward trend."

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Decision on the constitutionality of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law was asked in the Supreme Court today when two interests defeated in the recent ruling by the State Court of Appeals sustaining the statute filed appeals.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 7 (AP). -- Newark made it five consecutive victories over the Red Wings by romping off with the opening game of the series here today, 17 to 4.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had been notified by the Andes Copper Mining Company of a proposed reduction in capital represented by outstanding capital stock from $83,369,425 to $71,647,580, and of a change in the value from no-par to $20 a share.

BERLIN, May 7. -- The Boerse made a strong recovery today, with gains up to two or three points frequent and the entire list benefiting. Financial commentators attributed the upturn to technical reasons following the recent downward trend and to favorable business and dividend news, but presumably the rumors about the struggle over the future economic policy involving the position of Hjalmar Schacht, head of the Reichsbank, contributed to the buoyancy.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- Hogs sold at steady prices here today in the early trading, but weakness developed later and prices at the end were 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight off, with some sales regarded as 25 cents lower compared with the early high.

Joseph Curran, leader of the seamen's strike in New York, told a group of students last night in South Hall, Columbia University, that the largest number of seamen strikers ever assembled in New York at one place would picket the sailing of the Grace liner Santa Rosa tomorrow at noon.

OTTAWA, May 7 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government decreased $397,504, and by chartered banks increased $7,410,654 in the week ended yesterday, the bank reported today. The statement follows:
The number of relief clients supported by the Emergency Relief Bureau is now greater in number than at any time this year, a report made public by the ERB yesterday revealed.

"This is not a La Guardia charter," the Mayor declared at yesterday's hearing in City Hall. Of course not. It was never intended to be. The Mayor could have secured such a charter, if he had wanted one, by the simple expedient of appointing to the commission men who shared his precise views on municipal government and economics.

Charter Day, commemorating the eighty-ninth anniversary of the founding of the City College as a free institution of higher learning, was celebrated yesterday morning with the annual exercises in the Great Hall. More than 2,500 students, dismissed from classes for the occasion, and members of the faculty, who entered the auditorium in academic procession, attended the ceremonies.
Mayor La Guardia was the chief speaker yesterday at a ceremony in City Hall commemorating the 250th anniversary of the granting of the city's first charter by Governor Thomas Dongan.

ON BOARD THE ZEPPELIN HINDENBURG, May 7. -- The super-Zeppelin Hindenburg will reach New York on her way to Lakehurst, N.J., between 4 and 6 o'clock Saturday morning, if her present remarkable speed across the North Atlantic can be maintained.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP). -- The Tennessee Valley Authority was disclosed today to have told the House Appropriations Committee that its Tennessee River basin program ultimately is expected to cost $479,150,000.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday that on May 16 he would promote six lieutenants to the rank of captain, thirty-nine firemen to lieutenancies and would name thirty new firemen. This is the first general departmental promotion since last December, when nineteen lieutenants were raised to the rank of captain.

WESTONBIRT, Gloucestershire, England, May 7. -- Great Britain's polo fortunes were looking up tonight with the addition of the hard-riding Gerald Balding, the world's second highest ranking player, to the squad which will attempt to wrest the International Cup from the United States at the Hurlingham Club, London, next month.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7. -- Nerveshattered William Mahan, the scar-faced ex-convict accused of engineering the $200,000 George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping, was arrested here today and sped by plane to the abduction scene at Tacoma, Wash.

VIENNA, May 7. -- Before a vast audience comprising statesmen, professors, psychiatrists and psychoanalysts from all parts of Central Europe, the Vienna Psychiatric Association tonight celebrated Dr. Sigmund Freud's eightieth birthday. The celebration was held in the hall of the Vienna Medical Society.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The loss of prestige suffered by the League of Nations through Premier Mussolini's conquest of Ethiopia is reacting to give sudden impetus to the movement for a Pan-American League of Nations.

ON BOARD THE ZEPPELIN HINDENBURG, May 7. -- As this giant new German dirigible raced over the North Atlantic today, Dr. Hugo Eckener, her commander, voiced the belief that she might reach New York early Saturday.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey intimated strongly yesterday that he would not permit the extradition of any suspects from that State in the investigation in Brooklyn of the alleged kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, who declares that he was tortured into making a false confession of the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

The Jamaica and Tottenville High School baseball teams continued their unbeaten strides in the race for the city P.S.A.L. championship by winning their respective circuit contests yesterday. The former gained its sixth successive victory in the Queens group by halting John Adams, 6 -- 2, at Dexter Park, while Tottenville topped Port Richmond, 4 -- 3, at Aquehonda Field, Staten Island, for its fourth straight triumph in the lower Manhattan-Richmond loop.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, May 7. -- Amy Johnson Mollison landed here at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon local time [10:30 A.M. New York time], breaking all records for the England-Cape Town flight. Her time of 3 days 6 hours 26 minutes lowered the record set by Flight Lieutenant Tommy Rose last February by 11 hours 9 minutes.

JERUSALEM, May 7. -- The troubled situation in Palestine instead of subsiding now is becoming more serious. Despite the High Commissioner's warning Arab leaders at a general conference representing all Arab towns in the country here today unanimously decided on civil disobedience by all Arabs in Palestine.

The twelfth annual Westchester County Music Festival, under the direction of Hugh Ross, will start tonight at the County Center in White Plains. The festival will open with the singing of Bach's chorale, "Glory Now to Thee Be Given," by a chorus of 500.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A week of constant bombardment by business and industry against President Roosevelt's new tax program apparently was beginning today to have effect upon the Senate Finance Committee, and indications were developing fast that the administration will have the fight of the year if it holds out for the plan, particularly the proposed new corporate levy based solely on undistributed profits.
Two grand little "old men" of boxing will struggle tonight in the ring of Madison Square Garden in one of the game's most attractive matches.
LONDON, May 7 (AP). -- The British Government today presented a four-point proposal for uniform international regulation of the arms traffic to the Royal Arms Commission.

Price movements in the local commodity futures markets were mixed yesterday. Coffee, hides and cottonseed oil advanced, while rubber, silk and metals sagged and other staples were steady. On the cash markets corn, rye and silk advanced, while wheat, lard, tin and rubber declined.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Further evidence of the close scrutiny that the Securities and Exchange Commission is keeping on market operations to detect unlawful manipulative practices was supplied today when it issued an order calling upon Thomas F. Gagen to show cause why he should not be suspended or expelled from the Boston Stock Exchange for alleged activities in the capital stock of the East Boston Company on the Boston board.
DETROIT, May 7 (AP). -- The National Hockey League acted today to build up and preserve the French-Canadian make-up of one of its Montreal teams, the Canadiens.
ALBANY, May 7. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's radio address tonight:

There was no enthusiasm yesterday in the share market on the side of the advance. Following an irregular and dull opening, many professionals who had bought stocks earlier in the week were disposed to sell or to remain on the sidelines for the moment.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase of 6 per cent for the week ended May 2, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure is sharply under the rise of 17 per cent noted in packages handled for the preceding week.

Speaking at a dinner at the University Club. 1 West Fifty-fourth Street, last night, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine declared: "I hope it will be possible to have a Boy Scout unit or Scout troop in every part of New York City."

The choice of a successor to Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, who will retire on June 30, has narrowed down to two men, General Dennis E. Nolan, who retired last week from active army service as commander of the Second Corps Area, and "a prominent engineer," whose identity has not been disclosed, according to information obtained yesterday at the office of the WPA, 111 Eighth Avenue.

Twelve patrolmen of the East 104th Street Station were questioned yesterday by James M. Fitzsimmons, Assistant District Attorney, in an investigation of charges by Anna Zenko, 16 years old, of 432 East Seventy-seventh Street, that they attacked her at various places in East Harlem between April 17 and four days ago.
Robert P. Tristram Coffin, who won this year's Pulitzer Prize for his volume of verse, "Strange Holiness," has written a novel, "John Dawn," which Macmillan will publish in September.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 7. -- Gay Edward ran to a brilliant victory in the mile and 70 yard feature of today's program at Narragansett Park.

BERLIN, May 7. -- The British questionnaire whereby it is hoped to elucidate Chancellor Adolf Hitler's proposals for a new settlement of European questions following his repudiation of the Locarno treaty, was handed in to the Wilhelmstrasse by Sir Eric Phipps today.

Suggestions for planks to be included in the Republican platform for the coming national campaign will be discussed at a series of daily meetings to be held in the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street from May 11 to May 14, inclusive, Perry Osborn, chairman of a joint committee of five Republican organizations, announced yesterday.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 7 (AP). -- The Prohibition party put the first ticket in the 1936 Presidential race today, nominating Dr. D. Leigh Colvin of New York City for President and then drafting Sergeant Alvin C. York of Tennessee, World War hero, for Vice President.

Bank clearings in the United States in the first week of this month advanced to the highest level since the week ended on March 18, when they exceeded $7,000,000,000. The total for the twenty-two principal centers for the week ended on Wednesday was $6,671,348,000, against $6,242,917,000 a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

TOKYO, Friday, May 8. -- A fiery speech in which Tadao Saito, Minseito member, attacked the army for interfering in political matters, was thunderously cheered in the House of Representatives of the Diet last night.
CINCINNATI, May 7. -- Casey Stengel put his Dodgers aboard an early train tonight for the long haul to Boston with a winning streak of two games in their possession.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 7. -- With an entry of nearly 700 -- 200 more than a year ago -- the New Haven Horse Show Association opened its twelfth annual exhibition today in the New Haven Arena with many outstanding horses competing for the ribbons and trophies.

The Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria was formally opened for the Summer season last night with a dinner and supper dance for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York. Acting as a living reminder of the work being done by the beneficiary through its free clinic at 313 East Fifty-eighth Street, Paddy, border terrier mascot of the society, a featured attraction at the party as he received the guests at the door.

Approximately 97 per cent of all the park districts in the Chicago area superseded by the Chicago Park District have definitely assented to the central organization's refunding offer, according to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., refunding agents.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 7. -- The Manufacturers Association of New Jersey called on the Legislature and Governor Hoffman today to bring suit in the United States Supreme Court to force the "complete withdrawal by the Federal Government and its agencies from every phase of interference, regulation or control in the field of industrial production and employment relations."

F.G. Awalt, who was Acting Federal Controller of the Currency in 1933, came from Washington on the midnight train to take the witness stand in the Supreme Court here yesterday expressly to contradict testimony given the previous day by Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A second Deficiency Bill, carrying total appropriations of $2,364,229,712.53, including an appropriation of $1,425,000,000 for relief in the fiscal year 1937, was introduced today into a House prepared for battle. The sum allowed for relief is $75,000,000 less than the President's budget request.

Two armed men entered the bedroom of Mrs. Daniel G. Millstein, 30-year-old wife of a clothing manufacturer, as she was preparing for bed at 11 o'clock last night in her home at 5 Girard Street, Manhattan Beach, and took jewelry valued at $4,500. They escaped in an automobile.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP). -- The Indians defeated the Athletics, 4 -- 3, today, sweeping the two-game series and recording their sixth straight victory.

MOST of the fight fans are picking James Archibald McLarnin over Antonio Canzoneri in their approaching encounter. There's a reasonable ring to their statements and perhaps straw-ballots show something more than which way the wind is blowing.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 7. -- The "strike" will continue tomorrow, it was decided this afternoon at an informal meeting of the protest committee of the Huguenot Parent-Teacher Association at the home of Mrs. Kathryn Goldsmith, president, 28 Le Count Place, here.
BUDAPEST, May 7. -- Three saber encounters ending with combatants seriously wounded and several new challenges were today's developments in Hungary's growing wave of dueling.

The Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, a finance company, declared yesterday a 20 per cent common-stock dividend, payable by June 1, to holders of common stock of record of May 18. At the same time it declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of 90 cents a share on its common stock, after giving effect to the stock dividend, this cash dividend being payable on July 1 to stockholders of record of June 5.

The twenty-third annual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America opened with a varnishing day reception last night in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The work goes on public view this morning and will continue to be shown until the end of the month.

For an hour and fifteen minutes yesterday afternoon Mayor La Guardia stood before the nine members of the New York City Charter Revision Commission, whom he had appointed, and picked flaws in their recently published proposed new charter for the city.

Continuing its efforts to divert bond business to its own trading floor, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that before executing off the Exchange orders for active listed bonds, in lots of nine bonds or less, members must seek a market on the Exchange by actually sending the orders to the floor.

Since modern women are "emancipated" and have equal rights with men, they must also support their husbands if they have the means and the husbands are in need, Justice Jacob Panken of the Domestic Relations Court ruled yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 7. -- Harry Campbell, last of the Barker-Karpis gang, who was captured at dawn in his Toledo, Ohio, flat, was rushed here by plane this morning to face trial for participation in the $200,000 kidnapping of Edward G. Bremer, wealthy St. Paul banker.
Value of Dollar in Exchange I The dollar on the local foreigl exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

CALDWELL, N.J., May 7. -- Preparation of a bill to permit bankers to keep real estate for an unlimited time was authorized today at the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the New Jersey Savings Banks Association at the Greenbrook Country Club, North Caldwell.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP). -- Making it two in a row over Washington, the White Sox today handed the Senators an 11-to-6 beating that chalked up their fifth straight defeat.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 6 as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,477,000,000, an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $6,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Freedom of speech over the radio in the United States can remain unrestricted only "by its use and not its abuse," Lenox R. Lohr, president, and M. H. Aylesworth, former president and now vice chairman of the board of the National Broadcasting Company, declared yesterday in a combined statement at the tenth annual meeting of the company's advisory council in Radio City.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP). -- A double by Billy Herman, his second in two innings and his fourteenth of the season, drove home Stan Hack with the run that gave the Cubs a victory over the Bees, 9 to 8, in ten innings today.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Wholesale prices were easier in the week ended on May 2, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, is now 79.1, compared with 79.6 a week ago and 80.1 on May 4, 1935.

More than $64,000,000 of wholly owned mortgages, sold by title and mortgage companies now under control of the State Insurance Department, had been liquidated as of March 31 through amortizations, full satisfactions or HOLC refunding, according to a report made public yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- Weakness in other markets and a weather map which held out hopes of fairly good rains in the Southwest led today to general selling of wheat on the Board of Trade and prices declined 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel, with May leading.

The 150th anniversary of the Friends Seminary, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, was held yesterday afternoon. A stone hitching post and a stone carriage step, which originally were part of the William Penn home in Philadelphia, were given to the institution.

The wool goods markets were more active this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Duplicate orders for men's wear suitings for Fall were placed in encouraging volume, with the result that unfilled orders on the books of mills are much larger than they were two or three weeks ago, the report states.

A huge python, 26 feet long and 24 1/4 inches in circumference, was shown here yesterday at a preview of the first snake exposition, which will be opened to the public today at the Grand Central Palace.

ADDIS ABABA, May 7 (AP). -- Italian troops began pouring supplies into this city tonight over the French-owned Jibuti-Addis Ababa railroad to bring relief to residents reduced to the barest necessities.

As the date for Mothers Day comes around every year, the question comes to me very forcibly not only what the sons and daughters owe to their mothers, but what the mothers have done to merit the tribute of Mothers Day.

LONDON, May 7. -- Sir Sidney Barton, the British Minister in Addis Ababa, received two warm messages of congratulations today. The first, from King Edward, applauded the Minister and his staff and the legation guard for their "excellent services" during the recent critical days.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- In two swift and bloodless raids Justice Department agents operating more than half the width of the nation apart today arrested William Mahan and Harry Campbell and wiped the list of unapprehended public enemies almost clean.

Present world unrest is not entirely the result of economic and political changes but is caused primarily by an "unsettlement of culture," in the opinion of George Nauman Shuster, managing editor of The Commonweal.

LONDON, May 7. -- Operations were quiet today on the London Stock Exchange with completion of the settlement, although the undertone remained firm. Trading became more active near the close, when oil shares were strongly supported in anticipation of coming dividends.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange reflected an atmosphere of uncertainty as prices backed and filled within comparatively narrow limits. Many of the speculative favorites were subjected to renewed selling pressure.
John Sloan, recently reappointed to the six-year term on the State Racing Commission, yesterday called for unity of action among all interested in racing for the betterment of the sport.

The appointment to the Board of Education of one who knows the schools from the inside has much to be said for it and the more that the appointee has had so long an experience as a teacher. Mrs. LINDLOF having retired after thirty-five years of teaching has now an opportunity to render a superior though "superannuated" service that none from the outside can immediately offer.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 7. -- Rallying in the last three innings, the Rutgers nine defeated Hampden-Sydney, 8 -- 7, today in a twilight game. Trailing by two runs in the final frame, the Scarlet fell on Birch Douglass, relief pitcher, for three runs.

PARIS, May 7. -- French hopes that Premier Mussolini would prove accommodating in his acceptance of less than absolute possession of Ethiopia were dimmed today when it was learned from Rome that his reception of yesterday's French note, citing France's treaty rights in Ethiopia and inquiring about his intentions there, had not been favorable.
MEXICO, D.F., May 7. -- Mgr. Pascual Diaz, Archbishop of Mexico, who is ill here, received extreme unction this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- President Roosevelt bestowed the Congressional Medal of Honor upon Samuel I. Parker of Atlanta, presented the annual Gorgas Memorial Institute essay prize to Helen Mae Collentine of Milwaukee, discussed plans for the Pan-American Hospital in New York City with Dr. Joseph J. Eller and signed fifty minor bills, mostly for private relief or lesser public works projects.

A 24-year-old youth took over the presidency of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday morning. Then he "got the gong." But so did a whole lot of others. It was the signal for the start of the trading session.

BOSTON, May 7 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx's seventh and eighth home runs of the season, each of which came with a runner on base, enabled the Red Sox to conclude their home stay today with a 9-to-6 victory over the Browns.

The J. Paul Getty interests of California, which for several weeks had been seeking proxies for the annual meeting of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, failed yesterday to obtain a greater voice in the management of the company. The final tabulation showed that about 4,100,000 shares had been voted in favor of the management, headed by William F. Humphrey, compared with about 952,000 for the Getty interests.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Regulation of the American air transportation services should be transferred from the Department of Commerce to the Interstate Commerce Commission, there to be regulated in the same way as are the land transportation services, David L. Bencke, president of the Airlines Pilots Association, told the House Postoffice Committee today.

The proposed Federal tax on surplus earnings of corporations was described as a menace to industrial recovery, business stability, employment and national welfare in general by speakers yesterday at the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Leo Trencher, a partner in G. S. Seligmann, sold his membership in the New York Stock Exchange last Monday at $100,000, it was announced yesterday. He has proposed the transfer of the membership to Frederick P. Tompkins, who will become an associate broker in the firm of Jacquelin De Coppet.

ONE day in December, 1846, H. M. S. Rattlesnake, an old and leaky 28-gun vessel, sailed from England. Six months later, after touching South America, South Africa and Mauritius, the ship reached what is now called Tasmania, to begin in earnest the labors for which it had been dispatched -- the exploration of Australian waters in and about the Great Barrier Reef, with side-trips across the Coral Sea to the Louisiade Archipelago.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- Seven members of the United States Army post at Hawaii, who traveled 5,000 miles to compete in the tryouts for the nation's Olympic boxing team, were eliminated tonight as the trials got under way.

LYNDHURST, N.J., May 7. -- Florence Sylvester, 17-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Sylvester of 315 Willow Avenue, Lyndhurst, is the best center fielder in the Lyndhurst High School, but she had to turn in her uniform today because the school principal banned her playing with the boys' team as "undignified."
Five years ago the city condemned property needed for the construction of Grand Central Parkway. The proceedings were before Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP). -- The General Printing Ink Corporation of New York has filed confidentially with the Securities and Exchange Commission the names of its three officers who received the higest salaries in 1935. The amounts were given as $56,576, $51,910 and $49,240.

As keynoter of the Connecticut Republican State Convention former Senator BINGHAM had to shudder professionally. Dark days may be ahead. If the New Dealers aren't kicked out they will try to "usurp the constitutional power of the courts"; and "this might lead to revolution and civil war."

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Four States were listed by Federal officials today as having no Public debts. They were Florida, Ohio, Wisconsin and Nebraska. Nebraska's State Treasurer yesterday reported a surplus of $21,123,935.

The reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $26,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday and the excess of these reserves over legal requirements increased $10,000,000 to $2,700,000,000, a new high level in the recovery from the low point of $2,310,000,000 to which excess reserves were reduced in March.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The bright red flag of the Soviet Union flew for more than an hour early today from one of the eighty-foot poles in front of the $11,500,000 marble home of the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP). -- The Department of Commerce reported today that a substantial upturn in the heavy goods industries was leading the way in helping business in the United States to move "forward over a broad front this Spring."

In connection with an announcement that it had filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an issue of $85,000,000 of twenty-five-year 3 per cent debentures, maturing on June 1, 1961, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced yesterday that for 1935 it had consolidated net earnings, after all charges, reserves and taxes, of $62,863,192, equal to $2.43 a share on the capital stock.

Business space rentals reported yesterday included a lease of the entire third floor in 498 Seventh Avenue for early Fall occupancy to the Duplan Silk Corporation, now at Broadway and Forty-first Street. The lease, which was negotiated by Butts Molloy, Inc., as sole broker, gives the lessees 25 per cent more space than they now occupy.

A further recovery occurred yesterday in prices on the New York Cotton Exchange, with new crops gaining as much as 11 points, compared with a 2-point improvement in May. Pool liquidation in the near month exceeded 5,000 bales at the highest quotations of the week.

Net profit of the Commercial Solvents Corporation in the first quarter of this year was $617,778 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges, according to a report issued yesterday. This was equivalent to 23 cents each on 2,636,636 shares of no-par common stock.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The proposal covering the manufacture of and international traffic in arms that was made by the British Government today was viewed here as merely a restatement along general lines of the position Britain has previously taken on this subject in the general disarmament conference at Geneva.

Bankers have been invited to submit bids on May 15 for a new issue of $1,285,000 of general improvement bonds of Middlesex County. N.J. The bonds, dated May 15, 1936, will mature on May 15, 1937 to 1949. Bidders are asked to name the rate of interest.

LONDON, May 7. -- Advance information has been received in London of Premier Bonito Mussolini's plan for organizing the conquered Ethiopian Empire. According to these apparently authentic advices the intention of the Italian Government now is to follow as closely as possible the British model in India.

A nominal bid of $1,000 was made by the Dry Dock Savings Institution in taking over the ten-story building at 207 to 219 West Forty- first Street through to 214 West Forty-second Street at an auction sale conducted in 18 Vesey Street yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Testimony of witnesses at the hearing conducted by the subcommittee of the House Committee on Appropriations on the Second Deficiency Bill was made public today, and revealed the magnitude of the task confronting the Social Security Board.

A new approach to practical eugenics, in which emphasis is laid on a good home environment in the early years of childhood as being at least equal in importance to heredity, was the subject of roundtable conferences at the annual meeting of the American Eugenics Society at the Delmonico Hotel yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 7 (AP). -- The start of another industrial revolution, sensed through study of higher types of feeble-minded who are the first to be affected, was reported to the American Psychiatric Association here today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 7. -- Ninety members of the Yale junior class were elected today to the six senior societies in the picturesque tap day exercises at which members of the class gather in the Harkness College Court and the new members of the societies are chosen by a slap between the shoulders by present members.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Treasury estimates of revenue, which yesterday suffered their most recent black eye at the hands of George O. May, senior partner of Price, Waterhouse Co., have long been a thorn in the side of committees of Congress, the Opposition and business in general.

The other day we were talking to a man who had moved here several years ago from a mid-Western city. He remarked that in the brief period of his residence in the East he had derived more enjoyment from fishing than in twenty-five years of angling experience in his native State.

J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, who recently won a victory over the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States Supreme Court, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on fifteen counts of mail fraud growing out of his sale of $800,000 in certificates of a series of trusts.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 8. -- Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, commandant of the naval air station here, made a plea tonight in a nationwide broadcast for the United States seriously to undertake a program of airship development.

PITTSBURGH, May 8. -- Vacations with pay for wage earners as well as salaried employes will be granted by the United States Steel Corporation and subsidiaries, including the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, which operates in this territory.
The undefeated filly Goldey F., and the fleet King Saxon loom as the favorites on the double feature getaway program at Jamaica today.

The Boys High nine gained its fifth victory in as many league starts and tightened its hold on first place in Section A of the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. by conquering Alexander Hamilton, 5 -- 2, yesterday at Commercial Field.

America's third international stamp show will open this morning at 9 o'clock in the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street. The committee in charge announced yesterday that Postmaster General Farley would open the exhibition officially.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- Prices of hogs were on the down grade today, with losses of 15 to 25 cents a hundred weight recorded. Most sales today were 50 to 60 cents under those of a week ago, while underweights have dropped 75 to 85 cents. The day's average of $9.65 was off 15 cents from yesterday's close and at the lowest level since Jan. 6, the day the processing tax was eliminated.
