Widespread literacy is the chief reason for the change from the play-writing of Shakespeare and his day to modern dramatic authorship, Daniel Frohman, dean of American theatrical producers, declared yesterday afternoon in an address from the stage of the Lyceum Theatre at the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the Actors Fund of America of which he is president.

Our Dr. COPELAND'S election to the Senate in 1922 was in the nature of a surprise party. Time has vindicated the judgment of the electors. Who else of the togate gods is in closer and more continual communication with his constituents? And as the years tread on each other's kibes who climbs more steadily the steeps of power?

What price glory? The first phase of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict is over. Italy has gained her objective for the present at the irreparable expenditure in lives and sorrow to say nothing of the vast sums of money she has spent. The League of Nations has been defied and possibly disrupted.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 8. -- The Westchester music festival was presented for the twelfth year at the County Center tonight before an audience of more than 2,000. Representing the entire county was a chorus of 500 voices and two musicians, a singer and an instrumentalist selected by competition from the county at large. Hugh Ross conducted.

Plans filed in this city by architects yesterday include projects for a tenement house in Manhattan and numerous small dwellings in Brooklyn. Alterations to various Manhattan structures also are provided for in other plans.

The salary of S.T. Bledsoe, president and chairman of the executive committee of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, was increased on an annual basis from $57,000 to $60,000 in March, 1935, the report of the company to the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed yesterday.
With the Cedarhurst Grand National as the feature, the Spring meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association will be held today over the grounds of the Rockaway Hunting Club, Cedarhurst, L.I.

BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP). -- Four upsets in a row left in a befuddled condition most of the 8,000 turf fans who witnessed the program at Pimlico today. One of the surprises occurred in the featured Brooklandwood Purse, when the winner turned up in Mrs. T. Stevenson's Tempestuous, 4-year-old chestnut gelded son of Sickle-Equinoctial.

ROME, May 8. -- Now that the European situation is claiming a East African campaign is over the larger measure of Italian attention. An effort apparently will be made to heal the wounds left by sanctions.
City College opened its dual-meet track campaign yesterday by overwhelming the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute team of Troy, 77 to 49, in their annual engagement at the Lewisohn Stadium.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 8. -- The will of Zenas M. Crane, paper manufacturer of Dalton, filed in probate court today, contained public bequests totaling $675,000 and specific cash legacies of $670,000 to individuals. Judge Arthur H. Robinson appointed as special administrator the Pittsfield Third National Bank and Trust Company, which filed a bond of $5,000,000.

Leading banks here reached yesterday an informal agreement to increase call and time money rates by one-quarter of 1 per cent next week. The change, which will be the first shift in money-market rates since Oct. 30 last, is expected to be put into effect on Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- A new survey of the approaches of New York Harbor, extending seaward to the 1,000-fathom curve or continental shelft, is to be made this Summer by the Coast and Geodetic Survey, that agency announced today.

Apropos of the Yankee-St. Louis base-hitting slugfest of May 3, which was won by the New Yorkers, 14 -- 5, the crediting of the game to Pitcher Murphy has, strange as it may seem to you, planted within my mind the seed of incertitude

SARATOGA SPRING, N.Y., May 8. -- The New York State branches of the American Association of University Women gave evidence at a luncheon here today that the Alpha and Omega of their widely divergent programs were the scholarships and fellowships financed both locally and nationally.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The administration's $529,125,806 navy supply bill was approved by the Senate today without a roll-call and sent to conference with the House, which had passed it with an appropriation of $531,068,707.

Park zoo circles are considerably agitated just now by a hot discussion on the subject of science versus nature. The controversy revolves around four cubs born Monday in the Prospect Park Zoo to a lioness named Helen.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 5. -- Members of the American Institute of Architects ended their three-day convention here today with the award of a testimonial of honor to John D. Rockefeller Jr. for the restoration of Colonial Williamsburg as a "symbol of early American culture."

Sales of automobiles by the General Motors Corporation last month exceeded the pre-depression peak of 1928 and 1929 and established a new record volume for any month in the corporation's history, it was announced yesterday.
ADDIS ABABA, May 8. -- Ras Seyoum, the "black fox of Ethiopia'' and long Italy's most redoubtable enemy in the days when the Tembien area seemed almost unconquerable, submitted to the Italians today.

Among those sailing for Europe today on the Rex of the Italian Line are Charles du Bois, United States Consul General at Naples; Baron and Baroness V. Lomonaco, Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Thalmann, David Lichtenstein, Mr. and Mrs. Hunt Stromberg, Mme. Regina Khayatt Bey, G.S.B. Acheson, Julius Hallgarten and Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Gunther.

Overshadowed by more important details in the reports of the recent final American Olympia wrestling tryouts at Lehigh University were several sidelights which seem worthy of mention even at this late date. Hence this letter concerning some of the contestants, who waged splendid bids, but who, rather unfortunately, did not land berths on this country's squad of fourteen men in that sport.

Persons interested in gambling are advised to "study your dice" by Dr. Aaron Bakst of the Department of Mathematics in Teachers College, Columbia University, who has just finished a survey of the "mathematical probability" of winning at games of chance.

Once again the season is up to paradoxical tricks. Yesterday the thermometer said it was mid-July and yet the calendar persisted in calling it early May. Tonight, Leon and Eddie of the Fifty-second Street filling station will offer their new "Spring Festival," with little Ells Logan, James Alvin, Marion Joyce and others taking part.

So many of the organizations of the men and women of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York have expressed the desire to participate in the religious service in celebration of the fifteenth anniversary of the Right Rev. William T. Manning as Bishop of the diocese it has been decided to permit them to attend.
As the new giant Zeppelin nears its goal, scoring another victory for German genius and German enterprise, one cannot help reflecting how it is HITLER and his associates who made it all possible.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 8. -- The birth control memorial before the general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church was reported out by a subcommittee today for non-concurrence on the ground that it was "artfully drawn" and deceptive in asserting that other church bodies had approved it.

Ever since the SEC took action against White, Weld Co. in connection with its trading in the stock of the A.O. Smith Corporation, the financial interest has been hearing rumors of impending actions against other brokerage firms for alleged activity in a prominent stock issue.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

PHILADELPHIA, May 8. -- The strongest Davis Cup team to invade the United States since the trophy was lost to France in 1927 is scheduled to reach here Sunday, and Philadelphia is in the throes of a tennis revival that already has come close to setting an advance-sale record for tennis in the United States.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The Keeshin Transcontinental Freight Lines, Inc., have arranged to provide collection and delivery of less-than-carload freight through joint rates with the Baltimore Ohio and its controlled carriers, the Reading Company, the Central of New Jersey and the Alton Railway, J.L. Keeshin, president of the trucking company, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The Senate today adopted a resolution by Senator Barbour requesting Rexford G. Tugwell to report on the advisability of continuing the Resettlement Administration, and also upon m its effects on labor, taxation, real estate values and the securing of tenants.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Bitter rivalry for the privilege of attempting to organize the steel workers of the nation developed today between the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization of which John L. Lewis is chairman.

A joint lesson for motorists and drivers of city operated vehicles will be given this afternoon when the Police Department will sponsor a safe-driving demonstration along the Harlem River Speedway and Riverside Drive.
BERLIN, May 8. -- The German courts are now busy with a peculiar conflict between two Nordic pagan leaders, each of whom contends that the other libeled him by calling him an atheist.

James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., announced yesterday a plan for the consolidation of all present preferred stocks into a new $4.50 cumulative preferred issue bearing common stock purchase warrants and for the offering to holders of common stock rights to buy additional common shares, the proceeds to be used eventually to retire the new preferred shares.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- President Roosevelt revealed at his press conference that he had undertaken a search for jobs for unemployed by expansion of needed industries and had consulted with Owen D. Young, Walter P. Chrysler and others about it.

Rumors of an impending deal between the Giants and the Phillies whereby the New Yorkers would pass along to the Philadelphia club Sam Leslie, Harry Gumbert and $50,000 in cash for Curt Davis and Dolph Camilli were officially denied yesterday by Secretary Eddie Brannick.

The superiority of the English variety of women's lacrosse was clearly demonstrated in the very first game of the fourth annual national tournament on the playing field of the Riverdale Country School yesterday. In the opener, the English players, who have been coaching in this country all Spring, combined with four United States recruits to rout the New York team, 19 to 1.

A reply answering the complaints made by the Federal Trade Commission has been filed by the Fashion Originators Guild of America, it was announced yesterday by Albert M. Post, executive director of the guild.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $53,908,123, representing three States and 104 municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $11,815,363 for this week. The weekly average for 1936 is $23,453,453.
" The national vice of England " wrote Thomas Babington Macaulay, "is hypocrisy."

BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 8. -- Brightly attired and very lively "ghosts" of Robin Hood, the Fair Maid Marian, hundreds of sixteenth century English villagers and a fair sprinkling of lords and ladies from the court of Good Queen Bess reveled on the rolling acres of Bryn Mawr College today in a colorful revival of an Elizabethan May Day.

The annual report of the El Paso Natural Gas Company for 1935 shows net income of $419,043 after all deductions, comparing to $333,349 for the previous year. Sales of gas in El Paso were 25 per cent above those of 1934, and gross revenues were 16 per cent higher.

Since Count Zeppelin began to carry passengers in crude small craft, around the turn of the century, no single passenger has been lost in commercial airship service and about 800,000 have been carried, including those on short-sightseeing hops here and abroad.

The text of the radio address made here last night by Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth, chairman of the Assembly Committee on Public Relief and Welfare, replying to Governor Lehman's address on social security, was as follows :

NOROTON, Conn., May 8. -- The Westchester Country Club gave evidence today that it again will be a strong contender for the district and metropolitan honors it annexed last year as play in the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team-match series opened at the Wee Burn Club.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- A compromise tax plan, designed to meet the volume of complaint against President Roosevelt's proposed levy on undistributed corporate profits, yet embodying the principle, at least for an "experimental" period, is expected to be submitted to the Senate Finance Committee when it reconvenes in executive session Monday to begin revision of the Tax Bill.

There is a movement on among the children and parents of Washington Avenue, in the Bronx, to get Minnie Candela, who is 10 years old, a medal or something. They would like to make her the Queen of Washington Avenue, for a start.

It is useless to entertain hopes for a better and more secure future for the nations of the world based on a reorganization of the League of Nations, by putting teeth into the covenant or other similar remedies. There is nothing wrong with the covenant in its present form.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP). -- In a weird, comic ball game in which nine pitchers paraded to the mound, the Cardinals defeated the Cubs, 11 -- 9, today and replaced Chicago in first place in the National League.
CAIRO, May 8. -- An Egyptian Parliament, elected and convened with unprecedented haste, met this afternoon and named a Council of Regency to act until 16-year-old King Farouk is eligible to reign.

The Maternity Center Association deserves to be especially remembered on Mother's Day in the Bellevue-Yorkville district of this city because of what it has done to help save the lives of expectant mothers. If the good care that has made possible the low record of deaths were extended to the entire city and to the whole country, the death rate from causes incident to childbirth would be reduced by one-half or two-thirds.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8. -- Under the hottest sun that the rowing season has yet seen, the oarsmen of Syracuse, Navy and Princeton went through their final workouts today for tomorrow's regatta. This will be the first competition of the season for Syracuse, which has been handicapped by flood damage at home and was forced to cancel its first race on April 24.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe approved yesterday a plan for the reorganization of the Schulte Real Estate Company, Inc., under the Bankruptcy Act. It was said the object of the plan was to reduce fixed charges and that new working capital would not be required for its consummation.

Whatever may be the final reputation of OSWALD SPENGLER, whatever the fate of his philosophy and his predictions, no one can deny the encyclopedic range of his knowledge, the power and brilliance of his prose, the imaginative sweep of his theories and his Weltanschauung.

Warm southerly winds and the rays of a benign sun brought to blossom the city's first annual crop of shirt sleeves yesterday as the outer vestments of thousands of New Yorkers surrendered to the year's first heat wave.

LONDON, May 8. -- E.A. Chapman-Andrews, British Consul at Harar, has reported serious disorders occurred there before the Italian occupation today. Mr. Andrews, who has a guard of forty British Somaliland policemen, telegraphed that he had been doing his utmost to help the Ethiopian Government keep order until the arrival of Italian troops.

Old crop months advanced while new crop deliveries declined on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. The market ended with a gain of 2 to a loss of 4 points. Rains in both Texas and Oklahoma influenced operations in the distant positions but recessions were limited because of covering operations in the spot month and a sharp advance in sterling exchange.

ON BOARD THE ZEPPELIN HINDENBURG, May 8. -- Racing along with a following wind, the super-Zeppelin Hindenburg will be over New York City between 2 and 3 o'clock [3 A.M. and 4 A.M. daylight-saving time] Saturday morning, Captain Ernst Lehmann announced today.

Plans for the picketing of the Grace liner Santa Rosa today by seamen who have been on strike in New York and other Atlantic ports for the last eight weeks were extended last night to include two non-seamen groups.

The report of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company for 1935, issued yesterday, showed net earnings of $973,135 after depletion, depreciation, leases canceled and surrendered and other charges. This equaled 32 cents a share on 2,999,000 shares of $1 par capital stock, excluding 1,000 held by the company.

New bond financing this week amounted to only $5,638,750, the smallest total for a similar period since the week ended on Feb. 15, 1935, when new placements were $5,537,000. This week's total compares with $237,315,000 last week and $9,461,000 in the corresponding period last year.

Promotional campaigns to reawaken consumer interest in better type wines are due to be launched here immediately after details of the French trade agreement signed in Washington Wednesday are made public, wine dealers and agency executives agreed yesterday.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was almost at a standstill at times and prices, except those of French Government loans, fluctuated within extremely narrow limits. The turnover of $7,351,700 was the smallest for a five-hour session since Sept. 23 last year, and compared with sales of $9,566,900 on Thursday.

GENEVA, May 8. -- Definite but unofficial word reached Geneva tonight from the Ethiopian delegation in Paris that Mariam Ayeleu Wolde was coming to the League of Nations Council session opening Monday prepared to contest the expected Italian claim that he has no right to sit because Ethiopia is now Italian and that no other government remains there.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- En route from Washington to his home in El Paso, Marvin A. Harlan, national commander of the Disabled American Veterans of the World War, declared here that the organization would not support pension legislation to pay World War veterans without regard to their disability.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 8. -- A United States marine plane flown by Captain Hayne D. Boyden forced down yesterday a private plane owned and flown by Marciso and Horacio Basso, Nationalists, they complained in newspapers today.
The work and direct relief rolls of New York City, now at the peak total of 421,893 cases, could be cut by at least 80,000, it was estimated yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator.

The officers and crew of the Hindenburg will be the guests tomorrow night of the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce at a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Julius P. Meyer, president of the board, will act as toastmaster at the dinner, at which 1,500 persons are expected.

Family Welfare Sabbath will be observed in about 1,500 synagogues and churches, the former today and the latter tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, pastor of St. James Lutheran Church, speaking as chairman of the clergymen's committee of the Citizens' Family Welfare Committee.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 8. -- M.J. Bartell's Bubblesome scored his first victory of the season when he captured the Fort Adams Claiming Stakes at a mile and a sixteenth for 3-year-olds and upward with a length to spare over the Wheatley Stable's Faust at Narragansett Park today.

Ever looking to the far places, as did his Norsemen ancestors, Dr. Hugo Eckener, commander of the Hindenburg, in three decades has made his name virtually synonymous with the progress of airship construction and flying. Now, nearing the age of 70, he can look back on a long series of achievements that have taken him through the skies of four continents and brought him acclaim and honors from a dozen nations.

LONDON, May 8. -- Owing to nervousness regarding the franc and renewed weakness in Wall Street, the London Stock Market opened quietly today, although prices became firmer in the afternoon. British funds continued firm and German issues rose in the foreign list, which otherwise was quiet.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- Uncle Sam's 1936 team of fighting men -- the youths who will carry the Stars and Stripes in Berlin next Summer -- took definite form tonight as sixteen boxers swept through the Olympic semi-final trials.

After a forty-five minute wrangle over a proposal to appropriate $750,000 for revenue-producing improvements in the city parks and the selection of an operating staff, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to issue that amount in special revenue bonds.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP). -- Religion has a "great contribution" to make to psychiatry, or mental healing, said Dr. William S. Sadler of Chicago before the American Psychiatric Association's closing session today.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Housekeeping paused at the White House today for an hour when three of the most important members of the staff made their debut on the air right after the breakfast dishes had been washed.

The foreign exchange market floundered in confusion yesterday as the flight from the franc gathered momentum. With the approach of the week-end, fears of a possible gold embargo increased, but simultaneously it was disclosed that bear speculators against the franc were facing a possible severe squeeze next week, when, it is estimated, some 300,000,000 francs, sold for forward delivery over the past few months, will have to be covered.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Winston Guest, pole player, asked the District of Columbia Supreme Court today to require Secretary Perkins and Daniel W. MacCormack, Commissioner of Immigration, to declare him an American citizen. He explained that he has political ambitions that are affected by his citizenship status.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 8. -- A central committee of more than forty-five national patriotic societies with a total membership of more than 500,000 persons was organized on a permanent basis at the Hotel Gramatan here this afternoon.

BALBOA, C.Z., May 8. -- Leading the vanguard of the United States fleet, the Argonne, flagship of the base force with Rear Admiral W. T. Cluverius, arrived today and anchored in the inner harbor of Balboa, where ninety-three of the 150 ships will be berthed.

In the main ballroom of Sherry's last night the Tip Top Ball was given under the auspices of Auxiliary No. 5 of the Stony Wold Sanatorium, an institution at Lake Kushaqua in the Adirondacks providing care and treatment for girls and women afflicted with tuberculosis.

JERUSALEM, May 8. -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, an exile from his conquered land, landed at Haifa today from the British cruiser Enterprise, becoming a private citizen as he stepped on the quay.

Miss Audrey X. Anderton gave a farewell dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Marion Kingsland, who sailed later on the Berengaria. The other guests included Miss Jane Robb Murdoch, Miss Hildegarde Graham, Robert D.L. Gardiner, George H Hobson, Bronson Trevor, Henry O. H. Frelinghuysen and Bearns Smith.

Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth of Livingston County, as spokesman for the Republican majority in the Assembly at Albany, delivered a radio address last night in reply to Governor Lehman, who, on Thursday evening, in a State-wide radio talk, pleaded for passage of his Social Security Bill, which has been voted down twice in the lower house.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Convicted last week on charges of violating the anti-lobbying laws, Colonel Joseph L. McMullen, former chief of the Patents Section of the Judge Advocate General's Department of the army, was sentenced by District Supreme Court Justice Daniel W. O'Donoghue today to serve six months in prison and to pay a $1,000 fine.

The real estate market in Manhattan yesterday was noticeable for the variety of buildings that figured in selling and leasing contracts. The properties traded included dwellings, apartments, a hotel, a warehouse and a bank building.
Store and office quarters in various parts of the city add suburbs were listed among the business rentals yesterday.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Saturday, May 9. -- A worn-out champion of the North Atlantic, the United States Navy's last dirigible, the Los Angeles, gave up her berth in her hangar here last night to make room for the new German Zeppelin Hindenburg, which announced by radio this morning that she would be landing here at dawn.

Tentative plans for the proposed vehicular tunnel between the Battery and Brooklyn were submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday by the Board of Transportation, whose report was referred to the Committee of the Whole for future consideration. The plans call for construction of a twin-tube tunnel, to cost $60,309,000, and also a bridge over the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, to cost $2,300,000.

ALBANY, May 8. -- Senate Democrats today killed the Republican proposal for creation of a State Department of Justice. Meanwhile the Assembly passed a bill to establish the three-platoon system for fireman in New York City, which provides for eight-hour shifts instead of the present twelve.

A balanced budget is indispensable in the government program of recovery, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors, Federal Reserve System, said last night in an address at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

SAN JOSE, C.R., May 8. -- Leon Cortes was inaugurated President of Costa Rica in the Hall of Congress at noon today before a throng including foreign diplomatic representatives. He received an ovation.
Villanova tallied twice in the tenth inning to turn back Long Island University's nine, 5 to 3, at Dexter Park yesterday.

The Hindenburg, bearing the serial number LZ-129, is the largest rigid airship ever built. With a length of 811 feet and a diameter of 135.7 feet, she exceeds in gas capacity the Akron and Macon of the United States Navy, the largest previous ships, by about 250,000 cubic feet with a total capacity of 7,063,000.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Arms, ammunition and implements of war valued at $350,940.70 were exported from the United States during April to The Netherlands and the Netherland East Indies, according to a report issued today by Secretary Hull.

The exhibition of contemporary art arranged as a benefit for the Little Red School House in Bleecker Street opens to the public today at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. There was a preview for patrons last evening. The patron list is headed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mayor La Guardia.

In connection with the forty-sixth renewal of the Preakness at Pimlico on Saturday, May 16. some account of the origin of this important racing fixture and a sketch of its sponsor, the Maryland Jockey Club, may be of interest to your readers.

RICHMOND, Va., May 8. -- Decisions that Junior Leagues could not lobby or endorse candidates for office or by any use of their name or funds back any movement pertaining to religious or racial beliefs but might participate in legislative or controversial matters in a restricted way were made today at the closing session of the annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- House leaders, having practically finished with the Relief and Second Deficiency Bill, will turn their attention over the week-end to the Frazier-Lemke $3,000,000,000 Farm Mortgage Bill, which will come up automatically Monday under a discharge petition.

With a background of the sea and training for a naval career, Captain Ernst August Lehmann, actual master of the Hindenburg under the general direction of Dr. Hugo Eckener, transferred his allegiance to the air just before the World War. He has since been in command of airships, both military and commercial, including the Graf Zeppelin on most of her 100 scheduled trips made between Germany and Brazil.

OTTAWA, May 8. -- The reduction of the gasoline tariff by 1 1/4 cents per gallon in the budget presented in the Canadian Parliament last week has apparently modified the plans of United States oil companies with regard to the Canadian market.

So dull was yesterday's share market that the occasion might have been a day in mid-Summer with the news, marketwise, either superficial or lacking entirely. Instead, the Spring day witnessed the gold-bloc currencies in a death struggle against devaluation, and the biggest tax and relief bills in this nation's history being debated in Congress.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construetions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile 2Brokers Association, Inc,

WARSAW, May 8. -- The president of the Bank of Poland, Colonel Adam Koc, resigned today. He had asked to be relieved of his duties immediately after exchange control was decreed a fortnight ago and he repeated his request today following the import control decree, which came into force this morning.
" Abdul the Damned," an English-made film released by Columbia Pictures, opens this morning at the Rialto. Fritz Kortner has the title role, assisted by Nils Asther and Adrienne Ames.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- Soaking rains which effectively broke the long drought in the dust bowl in Kansas and Oklahoma, and fairly liberal precipitation over a large part of the former State and Nebraska, gave wheat bulls a body blow today and started a liquidating movement which carried prices of wheat off 1 5/8 to 3 1/6 cents a bushel from Thursday's finish before the decline was checked.
A complete roster of the fifty-four officers and members of the crew of the airship Hindenburg, with their various duties, was made public yesterday by the Hamburg-American Line. It follows:

I read with great interest your Washington correspondent's dispatch of May 5 wherein he states that Representative Edith N. Rogers of Massachusetts intends to question the Secretary of State regarding the unpreparedness of the American Legation at Addis Ababa. May I commend Mrs. Rogers?
LONDON, May 8. -- The British League of Nations Union reaffirmed its policy of sanctions against Italy and the principle of collective security at a crowded meeting in Albert Hall tonight.

ST. PAUL, May 8. -- Reports that additional arrests were imminent in the William Hamm and Edward G. Bremer kidnappings were circulated today as Federal authorities held secret conferences similar to those which preceded the arrest yesterday of Harry Campbell, Barker-Karpis gangster.

Quite generous in giving transportation to first base, but stingy in permitting the tabulation of runs against them, the Athletics got off on the right foot in their 1936 New York debut yesterday to the disappointment of 10,000 Yankee fans at the Stadium.

Parades, pageants and meetings will mark the city-wide observance tomorrow of Mother's Day. The full and varied programs arranged indicate a largely increased interest on the part of the public in the celebration over previous years.

A man learning to drive his automobile and a friend who was teaching him were killed instantly about 8:30 o'clock last night when their car was in collision with another at Prospect Avenue and Grote Street, the Bronx.

Few of the passengers of an airplane realize the responsibility thrown on the pilot during the crucial moment of landing, especially at night or in a fog. Once he has picked up the radio beacon of an airport he must keep a vigilant eye on at least seven purely navigational instruments which indicate air speed, altitude, rate of descent, position relatively to the radio beam and the like.
The Federal Theatre Project added another bright feather to its cap last night when one of its units, the Yiddish Intimate Theatre, presented its first revue, "We Live and Laugh," at the Public.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 8. -- Lewis Cass Ledyard Jr., attorney of Manhattan and Syosset, L.I., who died May 1, left an estate valued at more than $4,000,000 in his will filed for probate today in Nassau County Surrogate's Court.

Jimmy McLarnin weighed 143 pounds and Tony Canzoneri 136 1/2 for their bout in Madison Square Garden last night. The fight was scheduled for ten rounds, with Arthur Donovan the referee, and Charley Devlin and Charley Lynch the judges.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP). -- The Senators came out of a deep slump today and battered out a 12-9 victory over the league-leading Red Sox. Washington beat the Sox at their own game -- slugging -- outhitting Joe Cronin's boys, 17 -- 10.

CIHCINNATI, May 8. -- Archie M. Andrews of New York, former chairman of the board of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, today lost in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals his fight to have declared valid certain contracts which he held with the motor concern.

LONDON, May 8. -- Searching questions which go to the very roots of Europe's fears were published officially in London and Berlin today as the British Government's answer to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's peace proposals of a few weeks ago.

ADDIS ABABA, May 7 (Delayed). -- Normal conditions are being gradually restored here after the four days of terror that succeeded Emperor Haile Selassie's flight. It will be months, however, before ruined merchants can rebuild and restock their stores and residents can construct new houses.

The ruling of the State Board of Housing against use of so-called model apartments except by families of limited incomes will apply not only to the three large private projects financed with Federal loans but also to all other limited-dividend housing here, it was learned yesterday.

Generally the Society of Independent Artists has nothing more serious to worry about than its annual deficit, but this week a disaster threatened to close their twentieth anniversary exhibition, now in progress in Grand Central Palace.

THE first big swing on the major league front ended on Thursday as the Western clubs of the American League waved a weary farewell to Eastern parks and the Eastern clubs of the National League bid a groaning good-bye to their overboisterous hosts in the West.

Four itinerant musicians were warned yesterday by Magistrate Abeles in Yorkville Court not to play on the streets because "the law is against you." At the same time, however, the magistrate expressed his liking for street music and revealed that he was out of sympathy with Mayor La Guardia's ban on organ grinders and other outdoor players.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 8. -- With a score of 75, only four strokes over the par of the Siwanoy Country Club course, Miss Rosalie Knapp and Eddie Driggs Jr. today won the qualifying medal in the annual New York State mixed foursomes championship by the margin of two strokes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8. -- Sending of a candy "bomb" to Governor Curley and The Lampoon's red flag flying at the Supreme Court Building in Washington will be considered at Tuesday's meeting of the Harvard College administrative board.

MOSCOW, May 8. -- The vanguard of 3,000 members of Russia's new "leisure class," the wives of the more highly paid directors and technicians of industry, began assembling in Moscow today for a Kremlin conference that will form what might be called the Soviet Women's Aid Society.
WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The House consumed three-quarters of an hour today while reading the Relief Appropriation Bill in discussion of the question of naming dams after living men.

Senator TYDINGS'S bill for Puerto Rican independence has not been received with much enthusiasm in that community. The extreme Nationalist party of ALBIZU CAMPOS professes to welcome it, but the opinions voiced thus far by other groups have not been favorable.

The State's evidence had been submitted yesterday in the General Sessions trial of three fake labor union officials who tried to extort $10,000 from officials of Stanley Patterson, Inc., electrical manufacturers at 150 Varick Street, when the defendants unexpectedly pleaded guilty to attempted grand larceny.

Further losses in grains, livestock and products and in the textile group depressed The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices to the lowest level since Dec. 31, 1934. The index stood at 121.5 on May 5, a drop of 1.6 points from the 123.1 on previous Tuesday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8. -- Harvard, Yale and Princeton opened today a new extracurricular collegiate activity with a tri-university round-table conference on the economic problems of government. The sessions will last two days.

" Mother's Day" will be celebrated today in the synagogues and tomorrow in churches of virtually every faith. Perhaps there is no day in the religious calendar which is coming to be so universally observed. There will be sermons on "Mother," hymns about "Mother," and in the Roman Catholic and high Episcopal churches special honor will be paid to the Blessed Virgin Mary, Mother of Jesus Christ.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Persons seeking service on protective committees for securities of railroads in reorganization must show not only that "nothing objectionable is intended" but that there is need for such a committee and that they are qualified to serve, the Interstate Commerce Commission's Bureau of Finance held today.

Thank you for your editorial on the Ethiopian situation. The entry of the Italian Army after the flight of the Emperor, the disorder in Addis Ababa, and the looting of the palace, was like the letting down of the curtain after an ugly, wanton mass tragedy.
Annoyed over Mayor La Guardia's statement that they constituted a union, the Borough Presidents used yesterday's Board of Estimate meeting as a forum to express their irritation over the union label.

Despite sundry rumors of its continuance, Mr. Gordon's production of "Pride and Prejudice" will depart from the Plymouth Theatre after tonight's performance. Derived by Helen Jerome from the Jane Austen novel, the play opened Nov. 5 at the Music Box, and moved to its last station a month later.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A search for jobs for the unemployed by expansion of industries for the products of which there is an obvious demand if prices and purchasing power can be brought within the proper relation has been undertaken by President Roosevelt in a series of conferences with industrial leaders numbered among recent callers at the White House.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey said last night that the tip on which Ellis Parker Jr. entered upon the course that eventuated in the alleged kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel emanated from Wendel himself.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., May 8. -Mrs. Carl H. Donnor repeated her victory of last Friday when she annexed the women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament today at the Essex Fells Country Club. The Baltusrol star, who is expected to be one of the eastern threats in the women's national championship at Canoe Brook later this season, put together two 41s for an excellent 82.

PARIS, May 8. -- Measures to check the fear of French possessing classes at the prospect of the Popular Front's coming to power failed so signally that Premier Albert Sarraut tonight called on Leon Blum, Socialist leader, to make a reassuring public statement.

Four men accused of holding up the Nanuet National Bank of Nanuet. Rockland County, face possible death sentences if convicted of a five-count indictment voted yesterday by a Federal grand jury at the request of John C. Walsh, Assistant United States Attorney.

Most commodity futures declined yesterday on the commodity markets here. Wool tops and crude rubber futures were somewhat firmer. Trading generally was quiet. On the cash markets, wheat and flour sold at new low prices for the year and rye, oats, lard, print cloths and wooltops declined. Cotton, corn, butter and standard tin advanced.

A radio program, with speeches by Dr. Hugo Eckener and passengers and piano and vocal selections, was broadcast last night from the Hindenburg while the airship was traveling ninety miles an hour at an altitude of 1,000 feet.
Check exchanges at the nation's principal clearing houses in April totaled $26,990,579,535, a decline of 6.4 per cent from the turnover in March, but 8.9 per cent larger than in April last year.
LONDON, May 8. -- Following is the text of the British questionnaire to Germany embodied in a dispatch, from Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to Ambassador Sir Eric Phipps in Berlin:

Commissioner MOSES has again been summoned to court, this time on a plea by Beth Israel Hospital that he be enjoined from completing the construction of a playground and wading pool for children on Stuyvesant Square. It is charged that a playground at this particular spot would seriously disturb the patients in the hospital, and in other similar institutions in the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in the registration statement that it has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $85,000,000 of twenty-five-year 3 per cent debentures outlined at some length what it felt to be the uncertainty faced by business because of rapidly increasing taxes and referred specifically to the "current threat" to eliminate entirely the deductions of intercorporate dividends.

Fred C. Kelly's study of the Commercial Solvents Corporation, entitled "One Thing Leads to Another," will he published by Houghton Mifflin later in the month. A group of photographs by Margaret Bourke-White will serve as illustrations.

Retail and wholesale trade were slower this week, due to seasonal factors and unfavorable weather, while recessions in a number of divisions halted the advancing rate of industrial operations, which had been in progress for nearly four months, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

" The American Mother of 1936," Mrs. James Richard Smith, 53 years old, of Claremont, Calif. (population more than 1,000), who would like to have had twelve children but thinks her six is "pretty good, considering the small family income," arrived in New York yesterday for the first time.

The Philippine Railway Company has been notified that the Commonwealth of the Philippines is prepared to consider the purchase of bonds and stock of the company, provided that it is able to buy at one time enough to give it, with bonds already held, substantially more than a majority of the securities outstanding.

Successfully completing a record flight from Europe, the Zeppelin Hindenburg glided majestically over New York City at 4:55 o'clock this morning, Eastern daylight-saving time, heading for Lakehurst, N.J., her landing point. She was then 60 hours 15 minutes out of Friedrichshafen, Germany, her starting point.

PARIS, May 8. -- After opening weak today the Bourse reacted to some extent from yesterday's exaggerated pessimism. Here and there were discerned evidences of strong intervention in the market, perhaps from the outside, to prevent the panicky feelings from spreading and becoming disastrous.

Maintaining its reputation for originality and humor, the junior class of Hunter College, under the leadership of Bernice Friedman, captured first place in the twentieth annual "Sing," which was held at Mecca Auditorium yesterday afternoon.
BERLIN, May 8. -- The British memorandum asking for Germany's views on peace was printed textually in German newspapers, both evening and morning.

Anticipating the May 15 deadline for the filing of applications for permanent registration of foreign securities in accordance with the rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York stock Exchange yesterday made public the list of foreign securities for which no application has yet been filed, and which will be suspended from dealings on May 16 unless such applications are received prior to that date.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 8. -- Saboyon, 7-year-old chestnut mare, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Gerard S. Smith of Brooklyn, tonight won the championship among the polo mounts shown at the twelfth annual New Haven Horse Show in progress at the New Haven Arena.

For the first time, if memory serves, a presidential candidate has, before the National Convention meets, submitted to a long interview reported over the radio. It was a novel venture for Governor LANDON, but perhaps not so bold as it might appear. An effort was made to give his talk an air of spontaneity, but undoubtedly the questions had all been laid before him in advance and he had carefully written out his answers.
ADDIS ABABA, May 8. -- An Italian detachment was en route by rail tonight to aid the army under General Rodolfo Graziani to complete the conquest of Southern Ethiopia.

Organization of Health Research, Inc., a non-profit making organization that will cooperate with the city health program and render effective aid to the Health Department's laboratory research activities was announced yesterday by Health Commissioner John L. Rice.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Supreme Court Justices, high officials of the present and past administrations and members of the bench and bar from all parts of the country to the number of more than 500 attended the annual dinner of the American Law Institute tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The $2. 364,229,712 Second Deficiency Appropriation Bill, carrying $1,425,000,000 for relief for the fiscal year 1937, was driven through all attempts to amend it in ways opposed by the House leaders today and advanced to the stage of final passage, assured for Monday.

To the unparalleled distinction he holds as the first boxer in history to regain the world's lightweight championship, Tony Canzoneri last night added recognition as one of the greatest little fighters for his weight and inches the ring has ever known.
Nearly $2,000,000 in funds may have passed through the hands of Miss Mary Berd, 36-year-old secretary of Rabbi Zeida Schmellner, District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn said yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 8 (AP). -- Bob Weiland, ace of the Rochester pitching staff, scored his fifth victory of the season today as he pitched the Red Wings to an 8-1 triumph over the Newark Bears. It was the first time that Rochester has beaten the Bears this season.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8. -- The varsity crews of Harvard, Columbia and M.I.T, will engage in a triangular regatta on the Charles River tomorrow.

Fulfilling expectations based on the difference in material in the adjourned position, Samuel Reshevsky of this city, one-time prodigy, defeated Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., in their match adjourned from Thursday's tenth round of the United States chess championship at the Hotel Astor last night.

Rising temperatures spurred retail trade in the metropolitan area during the week, marking the period as probably the best since Easter. On a day-by-day basis average sales volume of leading department stores here were estimated as ranging around 10 per cent greater than for the corresponding week last year.

MOSCOW, May 8. -- As a result of the visit of the chiefs of staff of three Baltic States, the last of whom left Moscow yesterday, the Soviet Union is generally believed to have strengthened its western defenses morally even if no definite agreements have been reached.

In an effort to broaden the foreign exchange market here and to attract business from London, the world center, the foreign exchange brokers of this city will put into effect on next Friday a new system of commissions and trading rules, modeled on those in force in the British market.

JERUSALEM, May 8 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Emergency measures were invoked today to preserve order following the decision of 150 Arab leaders to launch a campaign of civil disobedience, including a rigid boycott of everything Jewish.

YEARS ago a project was on foot to include in one of the larger museums of the country a section of illustrated books as important in the matter of size and esthetic value as the section of prints. Whether that went through or not, something of a similar kind is certain to go through, in not one but many of our museums, as public taste and desire grow up to it.

TO the everlasting credit of the group of artists from the Midwest whose paintings comprise the current exhibition at the A.C.A. Gallery (through May 16), let it be said that there are no imitations of Benton, Curry and Wood; and, second, that there has been no attempt to glorify the "American Scene" from without.

An account of a year's standing with Ed Vaughn and his Villanova team-mates was squared by Fordham's nine on the latter's field yesterday, but the Rams had to squelch a desperate last-inning rally by the Pennsylvanians in order to accomplish the objective.

EDNA FERBER'S "Show Boat" is considered an American institution, like the nautical theatre it celebrates. It has reached every recess of the land in all conceivable forms except television. It sold widely as a novel. The operetta by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d ran for eighteen months on Broadway in 1926-1927, eight months on tour, another eight in revival, played everywhere in stock, was filmed silently and did two years in radio disguises.

BERLIN, May 9. -- The upward movement on the Boerse that set in with considerable strength on Thursday and raised the average level of stock prices more than 3 points continued today, although profit-taking near the finish shaded the day's best prices.

HENRIETTA BUCKMASTER'S new novel is a story of pre-war and post-war Vienna, of the cruel smashing of its aristocratic fashions and traditions, and of the spiritual rebirth of Count Paul von Holenberg as a citizen of a democracy.

BORN in South Africa, 25 years old, and a successful playwright; so much we are told of Noel Langley. His first novel, as it seems to be, inside and outside of the cover, is dedicated to the Lunts with a dedication that Shakespeare used in his "Rape of Lucrece" for the young Earl of Southampton.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 9. -- Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of the Chieftains gave a buffet supper this evening for the judges for the sixth annual Lawridge Horse Show to be held tomorrow on the estate of Mrs. Robert Law here. Mrs. Gimbel is general chairman of the executive committee for the horse show which will benefit the United Hospital of Port Chester and the Greenwich milk fund.

WOMEN drivers, as a friend of ours remarked the other day, are not unpredictable. "My policy," he said, "always has been to expect them to do the one thing you would least expect of a normal driver." Reasonably close study of screen heroines leads us to the same general conclusion.

Coming from behind in the final event, a well-balanced squad from Bishop Loughlin High School captured the team title in the first novice track and field championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Manhattan Field yesterday.

LONDON, May 9. -- An appeal to President Roosevelt to take action in connection with the Italo-Ethiopian war was cabled from London today by the well-known feminist, Sylvia Pankhurst, and R.C. Hawkin.

THOSE who have read his autobiography know Toller the man. A young, idealistic German Jew, he went to the great war, where in the agony of mass killing he heard his fellow creatures shriek out their lives, their bodies shredded on barbed-wire entanglements.

LISTENERS in England believe some of Ethiopia's attempts to broadcast have been deliberately jammed. A mysterious Morse code signal on a slow rasping note has on several occasions wiped out the Ethiopian waves and made reception unintelligible.

The viewpoint of a militant progressive in school affairs, as well as the experience of a professional teacher with particular understanding of younger children, will be brought to the Board of Education through the appointment of Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof.

SINCE the publication of "The Exile," which was Pearl Buck's biography of her mother, many readers have express the wish to know more about the author's father, who appears in "The Exile" as a somewhat shadowy and austere character.

BOSTON, May 9. -- Freddy Lindstrom's leaping catch of a long liner driven to center field by the old Brooklyn captain, Al Lopez, today ended a tense ball game, relieved the pressure on Professor Casey Stengel and gave the Dodgers a 2-0 victory over the Bees in the opener of the three-game series.

A junior committee has been organized to assist at the Tibetan exhibition to be held this week, beginning tomorrow, at the showrooms of Arthur S. Vernay, Inc., 19 East Fifty-fourth Street, for the benefit of the Professional Children's School.

When the driver of the automobile in which he was riding lost control of the machine after it had struck and killed a man and had crashed into a parked car, Patrolman Miles Coen, 38 years old, of 121 Beach Ninety-second Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens, attached to the West Sixty-eighth Street Station, was injured seriously at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon on Cross-Bay Boulevard at North Channel Bridge, Howard Beach.

THOROUGH and thoughtful yet dramatic, this biography of the Mongol conqueror -- the unknown superman of Asia -- achieves its purpose. In this sense Mr. Fox has written a perfect book -- the best modern and intelligible account of Genghis Khan that has appeared.
The heroes of sports at Fordham University who have carried the Maroon banner on athletic fields during the past year moved, one by one, to the rostrum last night and received their reward.

LIVELY, brittle, modern as tomorrow's newspaper, this first novel is the highly amusing story of a girl who was the only dependable member of an entirely irresponsible family. Deborah Martin's father married four times, his first wife being also his fourth.

DR. CLINDENING, a Pickwick enthusiast, has collected a great deal of odd knowledge in his small book, which should delight all genuine fellow-Pickwickians in this, Pickwick's centenary year. A genuine Pickwickian, it must be explained, is one who goes on reading the "Pickwick Paper" while the rest of the world is absorbed in works of contemporary genius.

Alfred II. Landon appears at the moment the probable Cleveland nominee, though there are plenty of possibilities ahead which might wreck his craft. If the Governor is named, however, he will owe his success not to Landon-instructed delegates but to the several hundred "uninstructed" delegates -- delegates uninstructed because the party bosses wanted them uninstructed.

Last August Congress passed the Social Security Act, a measure close to the heart of President Roosevelt. Intended to avoid infringements of the rights of the States, the law authorized Federal grants to States which provide by approved methods for their needy aged, blind, dependent children and unemployed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 9 (AP). -- Attorneys retained directly or indirectly by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, who frequent night clubs "with the hopes that they may hear a composition played upon which they can base a case and obtain a fee, and then take the witness stand to prove the alleged violation," were censured in a decision by Judge Frederick H. Bryant of the Northern New York Federal District Court today.

ARMED with his famous green umbrella -- and a formidable weapon it is -- the Baron Franz Maximilian Karagos von Kaz, sojourning temporarily in Mexico, is engaged to guard a wealthy Japanese importer who is about to depart for his home m Honolulu.
SOON the butterflies will appear in Northern gardens. Some will be migrants which have traveled long distances, crossing seas and mountains, buffeting winds or fluttering before them.

CEDARHURST, L.I., May 9. -- Mrs. Frank M. Gould's aged gelding, Daniel Soot, one of the best of the cross-country performers, today scored his second consecutive victory in the Cedarhurst Grand National Handicap Steeplechase, feature event of the Spring meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association.

Thirty students from the United States and Canada have received scholarships and fellowships in the New York University Graduate School of Liberal Arts upon the recommendation of Dean John Musser, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary.
ASHEVILLE, N. C. -- Mountain hikes to some of the highest peaks east of the Rockies are attracting an unusual number of enthusiasts visiting in this section.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):
A small army of biologists, chemists, ichthyologists, parasitologists and botanists will invade the lower Hudson region next month to engage in an undertaking that stirs the layman's imagination.

LUCILLE RACINE, 5-year-old pianist, the newest musical prodigy discovered on Major Bowes's amateur hour, possesses that rare power -- the ability to determine absolute pitch. After running nimbly through Beethoven's "Minuet in G" last Sunday, she perched atop a big concert grand piano in Radio City's largest studio and called off single notes and tones to the amazement of an astonished audience both in and outside of the studio.

SPRING flower shows, big and not so big, continue to interest gardeners in the metropolitan district. Most important of them this week is the Long Island Flower Show, which will be held on Wednesday from 3 P.M. to 10 P.M. and on Thursday from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., at the Crescent Athletic Club, Huntington, L.I.

James Monroe High School went into a deadlock with George Washington for first place in the Bronx P.S.A.L. race by subduing Evander, 8 -- 3, at Monroe in one of the leading scholastic baseball games played yesterday. Both Monroe and Washington have won four tests and lost one in the circuit race.

Launched at the Nevins shipyard in City Island yesterday were the first two of the New York Yacht Club 32-foot class of racing sloops, which will be the largest class that has been built under that burgee in thirty-two years.

PARIS, May 9. -- Leon Blum, who seems new to view as unavoidable his becoming the next Premier of France, will set forth tomorrow his program before the executive council of the Socialist party and no doubt he will receive enthusiastic approbation. During the past week his direction of the situation has been reassuring, even to his adversaries.

Much has been heard recently of the virtues of world trade. Will this propaganda translate itself into positive action when the time comes? Already nationalistic voices are whispering higher tariffs, cheaper dollars. And, one asks, why not? What virtue lies in trade that we should hesitate to block it?

FOR nineteen years a committee of British engineers, partly subsidized by the government, has been studying the ravages wrought by sea water on timber and metals. Recently the official report on these researches was published.

SAN FRANCISCO. May 8. -- Deviated from her usual Winter assignment of cruises to the West Indies and making her debut in the world-cruise field, the Reliance, 20,000-ton Hamburg-American liner, put into this harbor today.
LONDON, May 9. -- The openings of the opera season at Covent Garden, the Royal Academy at Burlington House and the royal tournament at Olympia announce that the London season has commenced.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9. -- In an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header on University Field today the Dartmouth and Princeton baseball teams broke even. Both games went extra innings. The score in each instance was 5 -- 4, with Dartmouth taking the opening fray and Princeton the nightcap.
OMAHA, May 8. -- The farm event of the week in the Corn Belt was the appearance of Secretary Wallace at Lincoln for a series of farm conferences and speeches on the Soil-Conservation Act.

PLANS for a bureau of copyrights within the National Association of Broadcasters, submitted by James W. Baldwin, managing director, as the ultimate solution of the broadcasters' music copyright problem, was accepted at a recent meeting of the NAB directors.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- Holding the Senators to seven scattered hits as his mates pounded the Washington pitchers heavily, Rube Walberg won his first game of the year today, pitching the Red Sox to a 9-to-5 triumph before 15,000 fans.

A proposal that President Roosevelt call a conference of nations looking toward the establishment of a "United States of the World" in the interests of peace was made yesterday at a peace conference of many organizations held at the Central Y.W.C.A., Lexington Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Preparations were made today by Secretary Ickes for an immediate cut of 25 per cent in the PWA administrative staff of 10,000 persons. He ordered that all executives submit at once a list of one-fourth of their employes who could be dropped.

THE present year contains the 250th anniversary of the birth, and the 200th of the death, of a man whose name is mentioned more often in our time than any other name of his generation. The noblest princes and Prime Ministers, the huaghtiest empire-builders and world-wreckers of the period between 1686 and 1736 appear less in print today than humble Daniel Gabriel Fahrenheit.

Skeptical about the ability of the present competitive industrial system to solve the unemployment problem in the face of technological advances, Ordway Tead, editor of economic books for Harper Brothers and president of the Society for the Advancement of Management, yesterday expressed the opinion that government measures must be more fully relied upon to send the jobless back to work.

THE newly established feud between the police and the bridge clubs smoldered during the second week of its life. The case which started it all, when a squadron of police arrested the proprietresses of the Lovejoy Bridge Studios on the charge of maintaining a gambling house, awaited its trial at Special Sessions a few weeks from now.

As a benefit for the Professional Children's School of New York, the Tibetan collection of temple banners, embroideries, metal work, pottery and other objects collected for the American Museum of Natural History by the Cutting-Vernay expedition to Lhasa and Shigates in 1935, will be placed on exhibition tomorrow in the galleries of Arthur S. Vernay, 19 East Fifty-fourth Street, and remain on view until Saturday.

TO keep city children "off the streets," and to restore to them some of the means of self-expression available to country youngsters, Oakland, Calif., has been experimenting with a Tom Thumb Club which indulges its small members in the natural desire to "make something."

TODAY being Mother's Day, many mothers of Boy Scouts throughout the nation will be honored by a special Scout award. This takes the form of a pin, denoting in miniature the rank of their sons in the movement. For Scout leaders' wives there are pins duplicating the badge of their husbands' office.

Automobile tourists who are planning a trip to Mexico will find the new Pan-American Highway, which is scheduled to open officially next month, "as fine as many roads in the United States" and the trip a "fascinating blend of the primitive and modern."

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- Motivated doubtless by a desire to get an even closer view of the odd workings of his careening baseball machine, Colonel Bill Terry put himself back into the line-up of his Giants today.

ST. LOUIS, May 8. -- Missouri Democrats, holding their most harmonious convention in history in Joplin, proved this week that they are still willing to carry out the orders of Tom J. Pendergast, Kansas City leader, and that there is no hint here of defection from the Roosevelt administration.

A HUMAN tragedy has brought the Indian people to a realization of the possible effects of a dowry custom they have followed for ages. Recently four grown-up girls, daughters of an impoverished Hindu of Calcutta, entered upon a suicide pact; three of them succeeded in doing away with themselves.

Prospective exhibitors at the tenth annual show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club to be held at Giralda Farms, Madison, N.J., on Saturday. May 23, have until Thursday to get their entries to the superintendent, the Foley Organization.

DALLAS, May 9. -- Generous rains have fallen over the Eleventh Federal Reserve District during the last few days, and business of all kinds is greatly encouraged thereby. These rains end a drought that threatened to assume damaging proportions.

The City College baseball team overdid the hospitality angle in its annual battle with N.Y.U. at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The Beavers handed the Violet the game with a generous gesture in the fourth inning, and then repented too late to do anything about it.

CLEVELAND, May 9 (AP). -- Senator Borah asserted in a radio address here tonight that a segment of the Republican leadership was fostering a monopolistic system which brings "a scanty, meager living for the vast majority and almost incalculable wealth for the few."
BERLIN, May 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of May 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Temple, with its superior strength in the field events and fair support from runners and hurdlers, topped New York University's track and field team in impressive fashion yesterday at Ohio Field. The score was 78 1-3 to 56 2-3.

SPRING weather is bringing the amateur out again to archery ranges in the parks of the city and the State. Lovers of the long bow and the fletched arrow have increased steadily in numbers in recent years, and more and more of them are turning to the delights of making their own equipment.

OPERA, composers of special promise will soon have an opportunity to out their works with a full orchestra and soloists. For, recognizing the importance of preparing its young musicians for operatic orchestras as well as symphonic ones, the National Orchestral Association is amplifying its course of training this Spring by giving rehearsals in operatic music.

ST. ANNES-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 9 (AP). -- Taking advantage of a handicap of four strokes each, the American and British women's Curtis Cup golfers today defeated a team of men, 5 to 3, in foursome competition over the Royal Lytham-St. Annes course.

TALK will not be cheap this year, the politicians are discovering as they seek time on the air for the national political campaign. Radio costs have risen since the New Deal staged its triumphant verbal bombardment in 1932. Size of the networks has increased, too.

"It is high time that a halt was called in the pursuit of self-sufficiency, according to which each country would endeavor to be its own supplier of goods of every description," Dannie Heineman, managing director, and Vicomte Van de Vyvere, chairman of the Societe Financiere de Transports et d'Entreprises Industrielles, or Sofina, of Belgium, say in their annual report for 1935.

TEXAS is celebrating her centennial this year, the anniversary of her emergence upon the international scene as a free republic, of the Alamo and San Jacinto, the centenary of a thousand memories sacred to her people.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The House leadership and the farm bloc inflationists oiled up their heavy guns tonight in anticipation of the fight looming when the Frazier-Lemke $3,000,000,000 Farm Mortgage Bill is called up Monday.

NEW DEAL efforts to achieve "truth in securities" offered for sale are matched by new regulations to insure "truth in distilled spirits." Rums, whiskies, brandies, applejacks, cordials and liqueurs are defined, and what may and may not be said of them in labels, advertisements and broadcasts is specified with such particularity that the rules run to 14,000 words.

PERENNIALS can be grown from seed almost as easily as annuals. It is a far less expensive way of adding to one's collection of perennials than purchasing plants two years or more old. Patience is, of course, required, since the plants will not bloom until the second season.

THE gardener who is interested in perennials is ever on the lookout for a new plant or a disregarded variety to add to his collection. The charm of a perennial garden lies not only in old-fashioned material but in the occasional odd plant of striking color or habit of growth.

JERUSALEM, May 9. -- In his first public statement since fleeing from Ethiopia, Emperor Haile Selassie said today that it was with a "saddened heart" that he had decided not to pursue an "unequal war" any longer.

Erection of 12,000 seats on the Mall in Central Park was completed yesterday in preparation for the ninth annual celebration at 2 o'clock this afternoon of Parents Day, arranged by Uncle Robert of the Uncle Robert Foundation. Mayor La Guardia heads the list of speakers for the ceremonies.
MEMPHIS, Tenn, May 9 (AP). -- Dave Sweatman, 71 years old, hitched himself to a wagon and pulled his family and belongings the 435 miles from Tulsa to Memphis.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE is one small group in the wonder city that is more frantic than any other. It consists of the lads who make the trailers, those unbelievable concoctions designed to lure customers with adjectives and promises. A fist crashes into the faces of the audience and words scream, "A Smashing Sensation."

AUTOMOBILE production is being held at the highest level since the Summer of 1929. April assemblies are estimated to have been in excess of 500,000 cars and trucks, thus topping the mark attained in the same month a year ago.
ATLANTA, May 9 (AP). -- Governor Talmadge today won a five-to-one State Supreme Court decision on the first point of his financial "dictatorship" to reach that body.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be one of the speakers on Tuesday at a luncheon at First Houses, East Third Street and Avenue A, at which fifty prominent New York women will hear details of the new rehousing program outlined in a bill recently introduced by United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, Mrs. Mary K. Simkovitch, president of the National Public Housing Conference, will be hostess and chairman.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 9. -- From the coast of Europe at Flushing, Holland, to America in 55 hours 15 minutes; from the line of Southampton and Cherbourg to New York in 52 hours 45 minutes; from Friedrichshafen in South Germany to New York in 60 hours 15 minutes.

THE long international arm of short-wave radio and the remarkable facility with which it reaches out across the world to perform lightning-like service was recently demonstrated from Addis Ababa when it became necessary to resort to long distance to overcome a short distance.

LONG RIVER, the Algonquin Indian called the Connecticut, and the white settlers did not change into something too new and strange for recognition its Algonquin syllables -- Quinnitau-gukt. Mr. Verrill sees in the river and the river valley and their history the veritable heart of the colonial and early Republic days of New England.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- It may be accepted with assurance that James M. Landis will remain as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, instead of returning to Harvard, and that as a general proposition the commission's policies will continue along the lines already charted by that body.

A conference of elementary school teachers and administrators will be held Friday night and Saturday morning at Teachers College, Columbia University, 120th Street near Broadway, to consider the questions "How Shall the Public Schools Be Changed?" and "What Factors Need to Be Considered in Changing the Public Schools?"

Thousands of New Yorkers in all five boroughs saw a splendid spectacle at dawn yesterday when the Hindenburg, 60 hours 15 minutes out of Friedrichshafen, Germany, rode in majesty above the city's towers.

Floor coverings of the texture types have attained "spectacular prominence" in the home furnishings picture, according to a survey of style and color trends in the American-loomed wool pile rug and carpet industry, prepared for the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers by its style trend council.

ON a little piece of paper Anita Louise may have had folded up in her handbag when she hurried aboard the Berengaria Friday night were detailed instructions in the delivery of a few well-chosen football cheers.

BALTIMORE, May 9. -- J.W.Y. Martin's Dark Hope stepped out in top form today to equal the track record and win the historic $10,000 added Dixie Handicap by a length and a half from the Brookmeade Stable's Good Goods, the favorite. A crowd of 20,000 attended a Pimlico.

ON Tuesday it will have been fifty years since the Berkshire Industrial Farm at Canaan, N.Y., was founded to help wayward boys. At that time it was the fashion to herd truants and runaways, lads who lied, stole and misbehaved, into reformatories and jails, where they mingled with hardened criminals and were sped on their way toward a criminal career.

TENGKYI DZONG, Tibet, April 21 (by Air Mail to London). -- Napoleon's aphorism that an army marches on its stomach can be applied well enough to a climbing expedition to Mount Everest, and Tibet is a country in which Massena himself would have been hard put to it to feed his men.

HOBBYISTS going abroad may observe the activities of their overseas contemporaries this Summer at a leisure-time exhibition to be held in the picturesque medieval town of Ystad, just two hours' run from Malmo.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was urged yesterday by Frank V. Kelly, Democratic leader of Kings County, to tell the President he will receive a greater plurality than ever before from Brooklyn voters next Fall.

Samuel Reshevsky and Albert C. Simonson of New York, two of the youngest players in the United States chess tournament, triumphed in their eleventh-round matches at the Hotel Astor yesterday and went into a tie for the lead, each with a score of 8 -- 3.

The modern type of airship, with rigid frame, is the brainchild of Count von Zeppelin, a retired German army officer who began building balloons in 1898. During the World War German dirigibles made a sensational impression, although they had little military effect, by their bombing raids on England.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The voice of public opinion has apparently made itself heard in Washington on so prosaic a thing as a Tax Bill. It came in strong and clear this week, resounding through all the confusion that has surrounded this confusing question since President Roosevelt made his demand for new taxes March 3.
The following table shows some important dividend meetings set for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

TOKYO, May 9. -- A death sentence was passed today on Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa, a 47-year-old military instructor and self-styled patriot, for the murder last August of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzau Nagata, director of the Military Affairs Bureau in the War Office.

BERLIN, May 8. -- Germany's colonial ambitions, contrary to expectations, do not figure in the British questionnaire presented to Wilhelmstrasse on Thursday and under consideration now. Nevertheless, they are bound to arise in the diplomatic debate which the questionnaire will initiate, although for reasons of their own German official quarters would prefer to have the Rhineland and Austrian questions out of the way before getting into further complications.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 9. -- Quadruplets -- a girl and three boys, weighing less than four pounds each -- were born here today to the 36-year-old wife of a $20-a-week laborer who only two weeks ago obtained a job after a long period of unemployment.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 9. -- The Hindenburg set not only a new record for the transatlantic crossing by airship but gave promise of still greater achievements. A cheek of the engines' logs revealed that at no time during the flight were the engines opened to their full power.

OTTAWA, May 9 (Canadian Press). -- The sudden spurt of warm weather will cause a wailing ghost to stroll again in Lover's Walk, the slope beside the Parliament Buildings. Tom Reid, British Columbia Liberal, known as "The Piper of the Hill," who practices on his bagpipes in his room every night after supper, will again take to the great outdoors and play in the moonlight.

ROME, May 9. -- Decrees of the Italian Government read by Premier Mussolini, annexing Ethiopia to Italy and proclaiming the King as Emperor and Marshal Pietro Badoglio as Viceroy of the conquered territory follow:

The annual meeting of the Board of Education will be held on Tuesday at 4 P.M. for the election of officers. Henry C. Turner, senior Fusion member, is expected to be chosen president. A vice president also will be elected.

Dr. SIGMUND FREUD celebrated his eightieth birthday the other day, whereupon the psychological and medical organs of the world surveyed his accomplishments and appraised him as a scientist. It cannot be said that his views are generally accepted, and this because of the glibness with which they explain in a quackish terminology everything from belief in religion to stylistic peculiarities of Greek and Gothic architecture.

A NAVY scouting squadron made an extended flight to Tucson from San Diego the other day for the purpose of obtaining fuel and oil consumption data. The trip over was without incident. The return trip was started at about 9:30 in the morning.

WHEN the crimson Korean chrysanthemum Mercury came into notice, two or three seasons ago, chrysanthemums became a leading topic in horticultural publications. Since then new crosses, with improvement along many lines, notably earliness of bloom, have continued to interest gardeners in this handsome Autumn perennial.

THANKS to the inventor, there are several homely objects in the shops that are designed to make the annual chore of putting away Winter clothes less of a bugbear than it used to be. A good-sized pile of camphored woolens can be stored easily in a tarpaper box, so constructed that there are no apertures through which moths may creep when it is closed.

Business conditions were spotty in some sections of the country last week, with the rising level of retail distributive totals being checked to some extent, according to reports from the various Federal Reserve districts. The volume of purchasing, however, was well ahead of that during the corresponding period last year, with many districts reporting substantial gains over last week's figures.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 9. -- The Greenwich Garden Club will hold a plant market from Monday to Saturday at the home of Mrs. William F. Hencken on Dublin Road. The Hortulus Club also will have a table, where table accessories, vases and match boxes will be displayed.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9. -- Two of the smaller craft of the United States Navy took their objectives tonight on the smooth mirror of Carnegie Lake when the Naval Academy's junior varsity and varsity eight-oared shells completely dominated their races against Princeton and Syracuse and won clean cut, handsome victories.

Working in collaboration with John J. Floherty, whose ubiquitous camera is focused on nearly every aspect of present-day life, the authors present a graphic record of a garage man's day at a busy corner filling station. Nearly every conceivable type of automobile, and its passengers, are included in the stream of traffic which flows past, and is described for children of the picture-book age.
