CEDARHURST, L.I., May 9. -- One of the largest and most representative crowds that ever gathered on the South Shore for a turf event assembled today from many parts of the East for the Spring meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association at the Rockaway Hunting Club, after a score of luncheons in country homes in the neighboring Summer colonies.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Inspection of the books of furriers, manufacturing jewelers, sporting goods and cosmetic manufacturers and other groups subject to special Federal taxes shows that $10,000,000 is due to the Treasury, according to a recent report on the operations of the Miscellaneous Tax Project.

DISCONCERTINGLY, Eleanor Mercein -- otherwise and better known as Mrs. Kelly -- has made her own apt comment on this volume of picturesque tales. In her foreword she confesses that they were devised for entertainment only, on the theory that fiction, to a large degree, is an instinctive escape from reality.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Following refusal of the House to earmark part of the $1,425,000,000 relief funds for the Public Works Administration, Representative Beiter, Democrat of New York, leader of the defeated PWA bloc, charged that "un-American" tactics had been employed by the Democratic leadership in sidetracking his earmarking proposal without a House vote on a ruling that such an amendment was not "germane."

ONE point has not been sufficiently emphasized concerning the Metropolitan Opera's Spring season, Edward Johnson observed last week. The use of the world "experiment" has caused the oversight, he maintained.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 9. -- Safely berthed in the snugly fitting navy hangar here after a nip and tuck tussle at the mooring mast, the record-breaking dirigible Hindenburg was being made ready tonight for her homeward flight Monday at midnight.

George William Lewis, director of aeronautical research of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, Washington, D.C., has received the 1936 Daniel Guggenheim Medal for "outstanding success in the direction of aeronautical research and for the development of original equipment and methods," it was announced yesterday by Alfred D. Flinn, secretary of the award board.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9. -- State rights do not include the privilege of individual States to obstruct the development of the economic security of the people of the nation, as a whole, John Dickinson, Assistant Attorney General of the United States, said today in addressing the constitutional forum of the first annual Harvard-Yale-Princeton round-table conference on government.

WITH the huge Hindenburg making her first of ten scheduled round trips over the North Atlantic, with passengers, mail and freight; with hot meals prepared on electric stoves and the radio an ever-present source of guidance and contact with an earth-bound world, a letter of Thomas Jefferson's, a copy of which recently was obtained by Major Lester D. Gardner, indefatigable secretary of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, has exceptional interest.

The threat of a coalition of liberal and left-wing forces to defeat Franklin D. Roosevelt in the November election collapsed yesterday with the announcement by Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, that no national Farmer-Labor ticket would be put in the field this year.

RICHMOND, May 9. -- Some slowing down in retail and wholesale trade was noted in the Fifth District this week, but volume still remains satisfactory in comparison with a year ago. April statistics are not available, but preliminary figures show a gain for retail trade which was good, yet not up to the pace set in the three previous months.

Sped by breezes that have been scarce the last two days, 200 sleek-lined model yachts, each a qualifying boat from its respective borough, careened across Conservatory Lake in Central Park yesterday afternoon in the finals of the Park Department's city-wide regatta.

ANNAPOLIS, May 9. -- June week at the Naval Academy will start on Saturday, May 30, with athletic events and a naval historic pageant. It will conclude with the graduation exercises on Wednesday, June 4.

OBERLIN, Ohio, May 9. -- John G. Winant was nominated on the seventh ballot with 515 votes as the standard bearer of the mock Republican party at the nineteenth Oberlin mock convention before a throng of 3,000 in a big tent on the campus.

A PLACE TO LAND: In a speech in Washington last week, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt laid down the most important prerequisite for entering politics: "It is a grand thing to go into public service, but not until you have some other business or profession to go back to when you are thrown out of office."

THE desperate extremities to which the imminence of prohibition repeal pressed the organized bootleg racket is again pictured in this naive but sprightly novel, apparently the author's first. Its unhackneyed setting is a fishing hamlet on the southwestern shore of Narragansett Bay, which for years past has been the secure base for rum-running by a notorious gang czar.
TORONTO, May 9 (AP). -- After beating Syracuse, 5 -- 3, in the first game of a double bill today, Toronto was held to a 3-3 tie in the second, which was called at the end of the eighth by agreement.

MISS STERNBERGER, who is executive director of World Peaceways, and has therefore had ample opportunity for the collection of the extensive and representative quantity of ideas about the causes of war and the preservation of peace that composes her book, divides the volume into two parts.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- Week-end evening-up by shorts in the wheat market today more than offset further scattered liquidation and reports of additional good rains over the hard Winter wheat belt. The close on the Board of Trade was at the top, with net gains of 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel, the May leading.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- The Senate Lobby Committee reasserted its right today to examine the telegrams of William Randolph Hearst, the publisher, in filing an answer to his appeal from the decision of the District of Columbia Supreme Court which refused to interfere with the committee.

The feud between the Taplin and the Van Sweringen interests, both of Cleveland, is expected to flare anew on May 27, when corporate steps affecting the control of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway are to be submitted to the company's stockholders for consideration.
ALBANY, May 9. -- Governor Lehman formally ended the battle of the budget today when he signed two budget bills embodying the cuts of about $15,000,000, imposed by the Republicans, in his program.

GENEVA, May 9. -- In advance of Monday's meeting of the League of Nations Council representatives of seven smaller European States conferred today on the Italo-Ethiopian situation. The Foreign Ministers of the Netherlands, Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Finland met in the morning and Salvador de Madariaga of Spain and the representative of Switzerland joined them in the afternoon.

Hurrying messenger boys and appropriate decorative schemes behind the plate-glass windows of florist's, confectioner's, and other shops reminded the New Yorker yesterday that the eve of Mother's Day had arrived. A number of organizations meeting yesterday marked the day in their programs, while others will hold special observances today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8. -- Action by members of the Board of Education indicates that persons who have charged repeatedly that communism has invaded Philadelphia public schools finally will have their complaints investigated.

Every waterway has an ideal course for the annual Spring shakedown cruise. A close-to-shore voyage is best. No one wants to venture great distances on a Saturday or Sunday in May. The boat is ready for the season, to be sure; the painting is done, the fitting out completed; only a few new gadgets needed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 9. -- Sharp criticism of those who demand for this country "a planned economy that is both alien and godless" was expressed today by Bishop Adna W. Leonard of Pittsburgh at the morning devotional service of the general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church here.

One of the tests of a satisfactory revenue bill is its smoothness of administration. Despite the imposition of high rates, our present system of income taxes is functioning tolerably well. Apart from certain arbitrary restrictive features in respect to deductions from income, complications now present are mostly traceable to rulings which seek to promote equality and justice in the law's application.

AFTER more than thirty years of intensive work concerned with the complete restoration of the famous Manuscrit du Roi, Dr. Jean Baptiste Beck is now busily engaged in Philadelphia on his two volumes, devoted to this thirteenth century collection of Troubadour music, which are to appear shortly in print.

Hearings are now being held in Washington on the Wagner Housing Bill, and divergent views are being presented. One frequently hears the question, "What's the matter with housing? We need houses -- why haven't we got them? Money in vast sums has been appropriated --why isn't it being spent to build houses?"

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, which has been roaming the country on its transcontinental tour since April 13, will finish its six-week trek with a gala concert next Sunday night in Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Dalton School, with Leopold Stokowski conducting.

With more than 1,500,000 chauffeurs and private operators in the five boroughs of the city, only 57,126 had renewed their licenses to drive at the close of business on Friday, it was reported yesterday by Motor Vehicle Commissioner Charles A. Harnett.

Shut out of only one of the fifteen events, Brooklyn College amassed the imposing total of 68 points yesterday at Pershing Field, Jersey City, as Lou Oshin's athletes romped to their third straight metropolitan intercollegiate Class B track and field championship.

Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, 1932 Olympic back-stroke champion and America's leading hope in this Summer's back-stroke event in Berlin, will make her first Eastern appearance in a couple of seasons at the handicap meet at the Women's Swimming Association next Friday night.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 9. -- Rutgers won the Middle Three track championship today by defeating Lehigh, 85 to 41, on Neilson Field. The Scarlet thereby became the first team to win the mythical title four years in a row.

While reorders poured in on Summer lines last week, retailers also made Fall commitments on furs, men's clothing, blankets and other staples, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Seventeen registered entries for the Bermuda race have been received by Herbert L. Stone, chairman of the race committee of the Cruising Club of America, and from inquiries and communications he had yesterday there seemed a likelihood of close to fifty starters in the contest that is to get under way at Newport on June 22.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 9. -- Choral music by Wagner, Haydn and Chadwick was featured this evening at the concluding performance of the twelfth annual Westchester Music Festival. It was held in the County Center and box office sales for the evening were more than 3,500.

ONE of the most interesting of the literary prizes for which English authors are eligible is of foreign institution The Femina Vie Heureuse Prize is presented annually by a French magazine for the best work of imagination in English published during the year by an author whose writing has not hitherto received sufficient recognition.

The Senate has passed the Robinson-Patman "anti-chain store" bill, and the House now has under consideration a similar measure, designed to give the independent "cracker-barrel" merchant an opportunity to survive against the competition of the highly organized chain grocery, drygoods and drug stores and the big mail-order houses.

Streaking about Long Island Sound yesterday afternoon was the newest and largest "crash" boat of the United States Navy. It had been successfully tested by the designers and builders, the Luders Marine Construction Company of Stamford, Conn., with a navy trial board consisting of Commander Joseph Kiernan, representing the Bureau of Construction and Repair, and Commander R. Velz of the New York Inspection Office.

A COLLECTION of wax seals portraying in faithful detail the art of an English family of heraldic designers over a span of more the six centuries has come to light in Akron. The property of Leo F. Herrington, the collection has been in the United States for sixty-five years, but not until recently has Mr. Herrington exhibited it, even to his close friends.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9. -- A spectacular rally by Yale, with two out in the ninth inning, produced three runs, wiped out a two-run deficit and furnished a 7-6 victory over Columbia today. The triumph kept Yale in the running for the Eastern Intercollegiate League title, but sank Columbia hopelessly in the race.

DERBY, Conn., May 9. -- Four evenly contested crew races were rowed on the Housatonic today. The Yale third eight defeated Rutgers by three lengths, with the Yale fourth eight struggling a length behind Rutgers for third place in the only varsity heavyweight event scheduled.

A GIRL friend of ours reports an odd experience that befell her in Hollywood, where odd things are likely to happen to any one. Last Summer, when she had a hankering for a mummer's life, she registered at the Central Casting Bureau, which is a clearing house for all extras, from ex-lady Macbeths to knife-throwers.
ATHENS, Greece, May 9. -- Twelve were killed and more than 100 wounded, it was reported from Saloniki, as the army and police strove to restore order in the Macedonian capital today.

The person who wrote the blurb which appears on the jacket of this book should have read the story more carefully. The first paragraph of that blurb contains a statement that is not borne out by the facts as they are related. Some detective stories are really worth a blurb writer's close attention, and this is one of them.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 9. -- The Hindenburg brought to America among its passengers a British navigator who had failed in an attempt to cross the Atlantic in a lighter-than-air craft more than a quarter of a century ago, and a spirited German Countess who was sure her cabin had been designed by a misogynist.

Governor and Mrs. Lehman evidenced their interest in the effort of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee to raise $1,500,000 by sending a joint contribution of $1,000 yesterday to Laurence M. Marks, the committee's chairman.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9. -- Seven more young graduates of various colleges, chosen for their promise of notable contribution to knowledge, have been appointed to the Society of Fellows, known as "the scholar's paradise," at Harvard University, President J.B. Conant announced tonight.

"WE live to learn" in war as in peace. Lessons have been drawn from the Italian campaign in Ethiopia that the world will undoubtedly -- and unfortunately -- adapt in future wars. There would be few persons today so optimistic as to believe that Europe will not see another war in the near or distant future.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 9. -- Dr. James Grover McDonald, former High Commissioner of the League of Nations for Refugees from Germany, was extolled as "one of the world's outstanding contributors to the cause of international understanding" as the Gottheil medal, given annually to the American who has in the previous year done the most for Jewry, was awarded in absentia to him here tonight.

Captain Robert Bartlett, veteran skipper of northern waters, will sail the motor schooner Morrissey north again this Summer to provide three months of strenuous outdoor life for a group of boys and make some collections for museums. The 100-foot vessel, which has sailed about 225,000 miles, will be on her twelfth trip when she puts out from McWilliams Shipyard, West Brighton, S. I., on June 20.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 9 (AP). -- Political observers watched today for some official interpretation to clear up the situation caused by the necessity for electing a United States Senator to succeed Park Trammell, who died at Washington last night.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Golfers today are following the Southern Conference golf championship on the Cascades course. Washington and Lee are favored to win, having defeated Boston, Georgetown and Boston Universities recently on this course.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The Social Security Board expects to have 11,765 employes on its payroll during the fiscal year 1937, with 3,750 in Washington, according to statements filed with the House Committee on Appropriations.

FAR the most important revival of the present Italian season, since Casella's restoration of the lost Muzio Clementi symphonies, was the first hearing in Italy, after two centuries of oblivion, of Giovanni Platti's "Miserere," for soli, chorus and orchestra, brought to light by Fausto Torrefranca and transcribed and conducted by Bernardino Molinari in a recent concert at the Augusteo.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The deadlock in the Senate Finance Committee may delay for several weeks actual consideration of the administration bill to tax undistributed surpluses of corporations, according to informed circles today. The committee is so hopelessly divided on the issues presented by the measure passed by the House that it may take some time to reconcile the diverging points of view.

Out of a group of 430 exorbitantly paid Representatives there were but thirty or forty present in the Capitol last week when the administration's hopper was grinding out like sausages a string of far-reaching enactments. And yet some complacent people smile and say: "It can't happen here!" Can't happen? It is happening right before our eyes.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 9. -- Miss Madeline Goddard, '38, captured two events to feature the annual sports day at Vassar College today. Competitions were held in track, golf, lacrosse, baseball and archery.

Gardening apparel, baskets and garden implements will be offered for sale at booths at the garden bazaar and card party for the benefit of Save-a-Life Farm on Tuesday afternoon at Sherry's. In addition, there will be a herb booth presided over by a group of younger members of society who will display potted and dried herbs and seeds from the Cherry Meadows Gardens in Framingham Centre, Mass.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 9. -- Two famous veterans of more than a hundred flights across the Atlantic told something of their latest venture this morning just after the Hindenburg had been safely berthed.

DUBLIN, May 9. -- This was a big day in the history of Dublin as a port when the first direct transatlantic service between Dublin and New York was inaugurated with the sailing of the Anchor Line's 17,000-ton liner California for New York.

ALTHOUGH a garden in the city may seem impracticable, it is much easier than it used to be to achieve one, now that seed stores and other stores with garden departments have competent advisers to give advice and reliable information to the beginner.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The seventh floor of WPA headquarters here was taken over about noon today by thirty-five New York City crippled men and women, all members of the "League for Physically Handicapped," who refused to leave until Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, heard their plea for Federal aid.

THE automobile manufacturing industry believes that, in the government's reciprocal trade agreement program, the way to recapture languishing foreign markets has been found. The experts and observers of the Automobile Manufacturers Association say that statistics now available show its beneficial effect upon exports to virtually all the twelve countries with which the United States has concluded treaties.

TOKYO, May 9. -- In the Diet, where the muzzle of martial law is absent, members continue to challenge and criticize the claims of the fighting services. Representative Hisashi also Labor member, referred today to an army pamphlet entitled "The Principles of National Defense," which admits that security ultimately depends on good living conditions.

IF the Emperor Napoleon, who once remarked that Robespierre's was a case that had been often judged but never pleaded could come back to earth just in time to read Mr. Thompson's wonderfully comprehensive two-volume life of the tribune of the Terror, he might return to Paradise satisfied on the subject of one great historical enigma.

Reciprocity in spirit as well as in treaties is necessary if the United States is to improve upon its economic relations with Latin-American countries, James S. Carson, former chairman of the Council on Inter-American Relations, Inc., and member of the committee arranging events for the celebration of Foreign Trade Week here next week, pointed out yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Reversing the traditional position the American Institute of Law today recommended modification of existing law to permit publication of defamatory statements, if true, or "where the circumstances are such as to induce a correct or reasonable belief that facts exist which affect a sufficiently important public interest."

THE first bulletin of the season issued by the New York Division of Highways notes that numerous macadam roads throughout the State were more severely damaged by frost last Winter than for many years past and that weather conditions have prevented repairs in many sections.

FEW events in recent years have caused quite so much excitement here as the award of the first National Prize of Literature to Gregorio Lopez y Fuentes for his rich and sensitive novel, "El Indio" ("The Indian"). This wa.s ahiefly due to the fact mqtt,t the prize ran a long and -.tormy course before it finally came to rest on the substantial shoulders of L,opez y Fuentes.

Firm prices, heavy buying and good attendance were the three points most impressive to furniture manufacturers who attended midseason showings last week, they reported on returning here yesterday. Producers, salesmen and furniture buyers who looked over new goods offered at Jamestown, N.Y., Chicago and Grand Rapids all agreed that price uncertainty had been wiped out by the good response obtained at these exhibits.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 9. -- The defeat of the defending champions, Charley Shelden and Mrs. A.U. Rodney, featured the second round of the annual New York State mixed foursomes golf championship at the Siwanoy Country Club today.
DETROIT, May 9 (AP). -- The Tigers ended their losing streak at the expense of Oral Hildebrand today, climbing back into the first division with a 4-3 victory over the Indians.

Howard M. Breslin of New York City received the principal student honors in Manhattan College's annual senior poll, the results of which were announced last week by the editorial board of the Manhattanite, yearbook of the graduating class.

ON four feet instead of two, over a 2,000-mile network of bridle trails that wind through six States, New Englanders and visitors in the great "down East" vacation area will rediscover this season vast stretches of country that until lately have been known only to a few farmers and woodsmen and to the chipmunk, the squirrel and the deer.

WITH the take-off of the Hindenburg, largest rigid airship ever built, from Friedrichshafen field on Wednesday, the debate between the advocates of lighter-than-air and those of heavier-than-air vehicles for ocean travel, long maintained was reopened.

THIS book, with its amusing drawings, and its endpapers, which must surely have come straight from the advertising pages of old files of Harper's Monthly and The Youth's Companion of blessed memory, belongs on the shelf with such excellent period pieces as "Down Street With Edith," "Danny's Country Store" and "Day Before Yesterday."
With a crowd of 2,500 on hand, Brooklyn College crushed the St. Francis nine, 13 -- 1, on the Manhattan Beach diamond yesterday.

DESFITE a lengthly professional exile and the fact that he is the life and soul of Jock Whitney's Technicolor and Pioneer Pictures, Robert Edmond Jones, Hollywood's Paganini of the color scale, still considers himself primarily a craftsman of the stage.
Lou Gehrig's powerful bat pointed the Yanks in the right direction yesterday at the Stadium, where 26,000 fans enjoyed the spectacle of a rousing New York triumph over the hapless Athletics.

Behind the masterful pitching of Ray Volpi, sophomore star, the Manhattan College baseball team turned back the New York A.C. nine at Manhattan Field yesterday, 7 to 1. The triumph was the eleventh in succession for the Jaspers, undefeated this season.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Senator Borah declined to be a delegate from Idaho to the Republican National Convention so as to be free to decide his course in the Presidential campaign, it became known today. If the platform and the nominee are dictated by the "corporations and big interests in the East," as he contends has been the case in the past, he will not support the ticket but content himself with his Senatorial candidacy.

The share market suffered from comparative neglect during the half-day session yesterday. Prices were steady and fractionally higher, a handful of issues closing with gains of 1 to 3 points. Trading on the Stock Exchange amounted to but 341,000 shares, the lightest since June 29, 1935; the Saturday before, the total was 401,000.
The position of Canada on the North American Continent is one that in some, perhaps, not, too far-distant time may offer a serious problem to the English-speaking world.

OUT of the World War came the commercial process for making ammonia synthetically; out of the Ethiopian conflict has come the first practical method for making synthetic wool. Perhaps this newest achievement of chemistry may mean more to Italy in the long run than the defeat of Haile Selassie.

Pounding Frank Appel for six runs in the fifth inning on five hits, two errors and two walks, Long Island University defeated St. Peter's College at Lincoln Park, Jersey City, yesterday, 7 to 5, for its tenth baseball victory in thirteen starts this season.

A protest against proposed encroachment upon harbor waters that serve as lanes of commerce was made yesterday by Eugene F. Moran, president of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company and chairman of harbor and piers committee of the Maritime Association.
THE newly organized Artists Gallery, Inc., will open next October at 33 West Eighth Street, according to an announcement received from Hugh Stix. The prospectus reads in part as follows:

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP). -- The Cardinals, who took the league lead away from the Cubs yesterday, dropped the National League champions still another notch to third place today by beating them again in ten innings. The score was 4 to 2.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 9. -- From Kensington Gardens to the home of the Little Lost Boys in Never-Never Land, an audience of nearly 3,000 persons followed the adventures of the immortal Peter Pan in the outdoor adaptation of Sir James Barrie's work, given this afternoon as the annual May Day celebration at Mount Holyoke College.

ORDINARILY the fourth edition of a book is expected to be little more than the third, the second, or the first, which at the publisher's request -- to extract a few more shekels from a reluctant public -- the author has slightly dolled up with the addition of another chapter or two, the corrections of a few errors, or the insertions of a few recently dated footnotes.

VIENNA, May 9. -- Not even the sensational events in Ethiopia have been able to deflect the eyes of Central European statesmen this week from the conferences of the Balkan Entente and Little Entente in Belgrade. Indeed, the gravity of the problems on the agenda of each was only emphasized by Italy's capture of Addis Ababa.

MADRID, April 10, 1936. THE chief novelty of the Madrid season was the world premiere of Sergel Prokofieff's G minor violin concerto, performed in the composer's presence by the Madrid Symphony Orchestra under Enrique Arbos, with Robert Soetens soloist.

ROME, May 8. -- The flight of Emperor Haile Selassie, the occupation of Addis Ababa and Mussolini's announcement that the East African war is over bring to an end one of the most difficult colonial campaigns in history. The Italians are now in possession of half of what was once the empire of the Lion of Judah and the whole of Ethiopia lies open and defenseless.

Captain T. Murray Smith, a British veteran of the World War and a big-game hunter from Kenya Colony, East Africa, a lean, bronzed man, arrived last week from Durban on the City of New York of the American-South African line.

TACOMA, Wash., May 9. -- William Mahan was sentenced today to serve sixty years in McNeil Island penitentiary on a plea of guilty to the $200,000 kidnapping of George Weyerhaeuser, 9-year-old lumber fortune heir.

Terminating a journey which i took her as far as the Pacific Coast Mrs. Arthur Brin of Mlnne apolis will arrive in New York tot / day for a series of conferences i with executives of the National Council of Jewish Women, of which she is president.

Here is a story of murder with voodoo trimmings on an island off the coast of South Carolina. When the story opens the slaughter has already begun, but it is not ended. The scene is to be strewn with corpses before the murderer meets his just deserts in the final chapter.
ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP). -- The Browns ran their string of consecutive defeats up to an even dozen today by dropping a series opener to the White Sox, 7 to 3. The Browns used four pitchers.

SANDWICHED in between formal obeisances to Ira Gershwin and Vincente Minnelli for their respective contributions to the "Follies," this line appears in the Winter Garden program: "Sketches by David Freedman."
HENRYETTA, Okla., May 9 (AP). -- A boy of 12 was honored today as a modern Paul Revere without a horse, who saved dozens from a tornado.

GENEVA, May 9. -- Pictures showing the effects of mustard gas on young Ethiopians, evidence that Italian airplanes literally rained gas by spraying apparatus in a decisive battle and figures showing that sanctions were steadily accumulating pressure were circulated by the League of Nations to members tonight.

LONDON, May 8. -- The British Government is now engaged in a desperate quest of a foreign policy. I former policy was among the casualties of the Ethiopian war in which Britain's greatest venture in "collective security" failed. The government declined on Wednesday to tell the Commons what kind of policy it was looking for but asked that it be trusted to pursue the search diligently.

Sixty-nine undergraduates at City College are enrolled in first, second and third year honors work, it was announced by Dr. Morton Gottsehall, dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences. The honors students, selected from the juniors and seniors of high scholastic standing, pursue an intensive course in specialized study under the personal guidance of special instructors, in addition to the regular course.

Industry faces a serious shortage of trained workers and of housing facilities for employes, according to George F. Trundle Jr., president of the Trundle Engineering Company of Cleveland, using data from a survey prepared by his concern.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- Mrs. Wallace Powell, a housewife, received neighborly commendation today for saving the life of a goldfish with needle and thread.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 9 (AP). -- Continuing on a prolonged spree of extra-base hitting, Buffalo defeated Albany today by a score of 20 to 8, making it thirteen consecutive setbacks for the visiting team.

LONDON, May 9. -- The price of gold here was lower today at 140s 2 1/2d a fine ounce, and 414,000 was sold. Silver also was lower at 20 1/8d an ounce for spot and 20 3/6d for forward delivery. Credit was plentiful at one-half of 1 per cent. Discounts were steady.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Industrial activity appeared to be leveling off in the week ended on May 2, after having advanced in late April to the year's highest point, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly business review.

PARIS, May 7. -- There are plenty of style points to remember this season. In the evening, Schiaparelli wants you to wear your curls pushed back from a crepe fetter, like those Recamier bandeaux we favored around 1909. Her fete champetre evening dresses of striped muslin are reminiscent of the same epoch.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 9. -- A return to the social and economic principles advocated by George Washington and other Colonial patriots was asked today by members of the General Court of the Patriotic Societies of America, representing national patriotic societies with a membership of more than a half million.

On the ground that it would be a paradox to hold a conference on municipal government in a nation where local self-government has been "obliterated," Mayor La Guardia formally declined an invitation yesterday to attend a congress of the International Union of Local Authorities to be held in Berlin on June 7.

The concentration of striking seamen and their sympathizers on the Grace liner Santa Rosa yesterday failed to delay the departure of the ship at noon from her West Twenty-first Street pier. Police officials in charge of a detail at the pier estimated that between 350 and 400 strikers and sympathizers from two groups, who had announced their picketing intentions on Friday, walked up and down in front of the pier under close police scrutiny.

After a three-mile chase through Brooklyn streets, four robber suspects eluded two patrolmen in a commandeered taxicab early yesterday. In the chase one of the patrolmen was thrown to the street, sustaining minor injuries. No shots were fired.

THAT perennial pest, the tent caterpillar, is again on the rampage. The fight against it, however, is by no means hopeless; in fact, according to experiment station authorities, tent caterpillars can, without great trouble, be eradicated from home grounds and even in whole communities if cooperative action is taken.

WESTONBIRT, Gloucestershire, England, May 9 (AP). -- California's Eric Pedley led the American polo team, which will defend the Westchester Cup in the international matches at Hurlingham next month, to an 11 to-8 victory over the powerful thirty-two-goal Beaufort Club combination today.
The Negus: It is very good of you to consent to see me. I am passing through Jerusalem on my way to Geneva. Perhaps you know the object of my journey ?

CAIRO, Egypt, May 9. -- Events continue to move fast in Egyptian politics. Following the opening of Parliament yesterday afternoon and the appointment of a Council of Regency late yesterday evening, the Cabinet of Premier Aly Maher Pasha resigend this morning and Nahas Pasha, president of the Wafd or Nationalist party, was charged this afternoon by the Regency to form a new government. Its composition will be announced tomorrow.

As a result of the victory of the Popular Front of Radical Socialists, Socialists and Communists in the recent French elections, the Bank of France is facing one of the most serious crises in its history of 136 years. Menaced by the flight from the franc, the bank is being attacked also as a modern Bastile, "a stronghold of resistance to popular sovereignty."

GREENWICH, Conn., May 9. -- The annual pet show of the Greenwich Country Day School, held on the school grounds today, attracted a large gathering, including many socially prominent women. Entries in the show totaling 189, eclipsed those of former years by a large margin.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 9. --Puritanism is a serious, high-minded belief in the right of the individual with no dictator, spiritual or political, over any of us, Professor Walter Prichard Eaton of the Department of Drama at Yale University said here today in a talk on "The Puritan Strain in American Literature."

DEBUT AT 75: It is almost fifty years since Poland's foremost patriot, Ignace Jan Paderewski, made his brilliant debut as a pianist in Vienna. At that time his nation was divided among Russia, Germany and the Austro-Hungarian monarchy. When the World War broke out he fought for an independent Poland.

Italy's triumph in Ethiopia comletes four centuries of a territorial transition that now embraces the whole of the once-Dark Continent of Africa with its 12,000,000 square miles and about 150,000,000 inhabitants. Omitting the single and comparatively unimportant exception of Liberia -- a Negro republic on the Atlantic seaboard -- the whole of Africa has been brought under the dominion of white men of European origin.

SWIFT'S weapon in demolishing an opponent was satire which proved as long in duration as it was broad in spirit. Despite its grotesque character it was subtly effective and his adversary usually died of shame, a literary death, to be sure.

Our neighbor The Sun has made an instructive survey of unemployment on its own account. In view of the estimates that have hitherto prevailed, its results are astonishingly favorable. For all forms of work in the United States, excepting agriculture, domestic service and professional service, it estimates unemployment at 3,085,000.

Thousands of enthusiastic stamp collectors and dealers, many of them from distant parts of the world, swarmed through three floors of Grand Central Palace yesterday morning at the opening of the Third International Philatelic Exhibition.

Even the House of Lords do move. After the trial by a jury of his peers of Lord DE CLIFFORD, a young gentleman a little careless in the use of automobiles, there was much talk about the anomaly and uselessness of this survival in procedure. The House passed a resolution against it.

A VISIT to the more desolate parts of the depressed areas in the north of England offers a tragic contrast to the comparative prosperity of London and the serene and thriving south, and provides a spectacle of idle resources, wasted labor, penury and despair which may be guaranteed to haunt the memory of the observer long afterward.

The Republican National Committee's new tabloid publication, On Our Way, which purports to depict the weaknesses of the Roosevelt administration and at the same time aid in the solicitation of campaign funds, has found little circulation in New York. Very few copies have found their way into the clubhouses, although the headquarters in each of the five counties have received their allotments.

Communists, either individually or in groups, will not be admitted into the new political party to be formed by the Old Guard wing of the Socialist party, according to Louis Waldman, former State chairman.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- Pitcher Frank Smith held Pennsylvania to four hits today as Penn State easily defeated the Red and Blue on Franklin Field, 16 to 6.

THIS week William T. Manning will celebrate two anniversaries. Fifteen years ago tomorrow he was elected Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, and seventy years ago on Tuesday he was born in Northampton, England.
AMSTERDAM, May 9. -- William Mengelberg conductor of the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, is criticized in an open letter for his appearance with the Frankfort-am-Main Orchestra.

For several weeks the uncertainties of the European political and financial situation have cast a long shadow over our own speculative markets. Doubtless other influences have also affected the movements of commodities, bonds and stocks. But it is impossible to ignore the close attention paid by American investors to such factors as the Left victory in France and the possible devaluation of the franc.

Writing to The Times of London, its chief American correspondent undertakes to make an impartial survey of American opinion for and against President ROOSEVELT. He points out that there is violent and bitter opposition to him by many who heartily supported him during his first year in the Presidency.

LYNCHBURG, Va., May 9. -- In the outdoor theatre of Randolph-Macon Woman's College, students of the Greek department presented this afternoon the twenty-first in a series of Greek plays in the original, given at the institution.

The fine play of Miss Jane Adair, former All-America star and present coach in Chicago, whose clearheaded work in the second home position was a material aid to the English team's 6-0 victory over the Boston twelve, featured the morning games in the women's national lacrosse tournament yesterday.

The paper on underfeeding read by Dr. James McLester to the New York Medical Association seems to be typical of recent investigations in this field. It is time that some one stated the background of such research.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 9. -- Mrs. J.B. Taylor of Schenectady was elected today to succeed Mrs. Emerson D. Fite of Poughkeepsie as president of the New York State Division of the American Association of University Women at the biennial conference here. She is a former president of her local branch and also headed the Eastern New York Smith College Alumnae Association.

WHETHER or not "Idiot's Delight" is the best American play of the year is a matter of opinion, but certainly it is a creditable play. Every one agrees to that with enthusiasm. After it opened in mid-March with the Lunts galumphing through a robust Theatre Guild production, most of the newspaper reviews were tumultuous; and business at the Shubert has been terrific, as the theatre gentry say.
KEMPTON PARK, England, May 9. -- England learned about Omaha today.

THE problem of discussing controversial subjects in the classroom has been attacked in the Millburn (N.J.) High School. For almost five years the principal, R.J. Bretnall, has encouraged pupils to express their opinions on anything from school politics to the nation's foreign policy.

An anachronistic and doubtless a startling motif will be injected into Fifth Avenue traffic on Tuesday evening when several horse-drawn rustic hay wagons will proceed leisurely down the avenue from Seventy-ninth Street, bearing a throng of younger members of society bound for a charity dance.

Vassar College at Poughkeepsie will be the scene of an all-day forum on Wednesday of four regions of the League of Women Voters, supplementary to the recent biennial at Cincinnati. The county leagues of Schenectady, Orange, Dutchess, Westchester, Albany and Columbia, as well as New York, will have representatives present. Legislation of the present and the future will be the topic.

Four thousand students are expected to enroll in the twenty-first annual Summer session of Hunter College, which will be held from July 6 to Aug. 14, according to an announcement yesterday by Broderick Cohen, director of the evening and extension sessions.

Book Review -- "President Hutchins Speaks" -- reminds one that there are other voices besides that of the titular head of the nation. And since his addresses are concerned with the higher education, there are other important topics besides that of politics. And in the passage cited there is a thesis as fundamental to politics as to education, religion or culture, or any essential aspect of life. This is the passage:

THE supercilious lions that guard the entrance to the New York Public Library drew new attention recently when art lovers discovered that the pedestals had been covered with library notices and posters. The head of the monument restoration group in the Park Department was the first to tell the library officials about the "artistic error."

LAKELAND, Fla., May 8. -- Florida's citrus industry, shaken by periodic internal ructions in recent years, is ,ready for another experiment. It is a marketing agreement signed by a majority of growers and shippers, and became effective tonight in accordance with an order issued by Secretary Wallace.

HAVANA, May 9. -- Major Carmelo Gonzalez Arias, chief of the naval post at Cienfuegos, and his orderly, Ramon Lacido, were gravely wounded this morning when a package containing a bomb on the desk of the major exploded.

ALBANY, May 9. -- Manufacturers of paper milk containers represented by a committee including New York City milk dealers today sent a protest to Peter G. Ten Eyck, State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, against a hearing which he is to conduct Thursday on New York City milk prices.

There is food for thought in the recent discussion in THE TIMES between Stephen Bell and Whidden Graham respecting the use of the word "capital" by Professor John H. Williams in his address before the Academy of Political Science. Is it true, as Mr. Graham holds, that bills of exchange are not properly to be termed capital and that there is no such thing as an international flow of capital?

IN order to prevent the possibility of disease infection it is wise to paint any pruning wound that is more than two inches in diameter. Shellac, white lead and red lead paints are good, but perhaps the best wound dressings are the various asphaltum paints now available for this particular purpose.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, May 9. -- After a sham running battle of 3,000 miles lasting from April 27 until 5 o'clock this morning, the United States fleet is anchored here and in the Bay of Panama under the guns of the fortified islands guarding the canal's approaches.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9. -- Harvard's track and field forces successfully defended their Heptagonal Games championship before 2,500 spectators in the Harvard Stadium today.

COMTESSE DE CHAMBRUN has written a biography of Shakespeare that belongs with the curiosities of literature. What we know of Shakespeare's life has been summarized by Professor J.W. Mackail in less than eight octavo pages.

WHEN the Dance Guild holds its second annual meeting on Wednesday night at the Y.M.H.A., it will bring to a close the first year's work of a courageous and much-needed organization. Because of its lack of financial means (a sadly familiar phrase!), its activities are less well known than they deserve to be.
Foreign Minister Eden advises his countrymen to draw the lessons from the Ethiopian affair. Every one, indeed, may do that. Here are some of them as they appear to a lay observer:

Administration predictions of a balanced budget and a satisfactory economic outlook are "flights of the imagination," a group of economists and business men was told yesterday by Ralph W. Robey, Professor of Banking at Columbia University.

MARY ELIZABETH TODD is well fitted for the writing of a book of this sort, for she is not only an athlete and sportswoman of fine standing but also one of the country's leading women sports writers. And she has here made the first outline and comprehensive story of women in sports and in daring and courageous pursuits and achievements that has yet been attempted.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- A new NRA and a less powerful Supreme Court were two of the chief demands made today in resolutions by the Women's Trade Union League.
NEW MARKET, Va., May 9 (AP). -- In an effort to establish a women's record for midget planes, Miss Helen Richey of McKeesport, Pa., attained today an altitude unofficially estimated at 18,000 feet.

BESIDES the exhibitions commented upon above, other large group shows are now current. The twenty-third annual of the Allied Artists of America opened with a private view Thursday night and to the public Friday, in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building.

Although rainfall over Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas was the heaviest in several months, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved yesterday within the narrowest range of the year to end 3 points higher to 4 points lower than on Friday.

THE Broadway eye, which finds the country view tolerable, glows now with the light of Summer stages. Out there they are already planning great events, and this may be set down as one of them: Lawrence Langner's season at Westport will begin on June 29, with Eva Le Gallienne heading the cast of a Restoration comedy.

The Belmont Park Spring meeting, which is expected to see the 3-year-old championship definitely settled by the running of the Withers and Belmont Stakes, will get under way tomorrow and run until June 6. This makes the session the longest of the Spring meetings in New York, and the stake program makes it the most important in the country.

HAVING told us in "Land of the Free" that, farmers and industrial workers and white-collar folk alike, we are wage slaves or on the brink of becoming so. Herbert Agar (this time in conjunction with Allen Tate has assembled a notable group of publicists who deliver the same sable message, each from his peculiar point of view -- two and twenty black-birds made into a pie.

NEWARK, N. J., May 9 (AP). -- William S. Conklin, Governor Harold G. Hoffman's publicity secretary, denounced tonight as a "flood of scurrilous propaganda" the campaign being waged against the Governor for election as delegate at large to the Republican national convention.

The rift in Tammany has been widened by the opposition of Senator Royal S. Copeland to confirmation of President Roosevelt's appointment of John J. Kelly, leader of the Twenty-second Assembly District, as United States Marshal for the Southern District of New York, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON. -- The dearth of able men in British politics at the present time is a well-known fact. The best part of a generation was lost in the World War, when the resistance of the masses of the nation to military conscription led to the slaughter of the chosen elements as volunteers.

AS so often happens, warm weather following abundant rains is quickening plant development. This results in vigorous but "soft" growth, which is likely to suffer unduly in the operation of transplanting, whether plants are merely moved about in one's own garden or are received from a nursery.
BALTIMORE, May 8. -- Where the balloting was heaviest in the spotty Maryland primaries last Monday, President Roosevelt received the votes in numbers that should please himself and Mr. Farley.

"Public Welfare -- a Responsibility of Government -- the Concern of All," will be discussed by the New Jersey League of Women Voters as the theme of its sixteenth annual convention in Asbury Park Thursday and Friday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9. -- A fresh chapter in Columbia's modern rowing history was concluded in glory late today as three Blue and White crews swept the Charles, the first time that the oarsmen from Morningside Heights have carried off all the honors in a regatta in several years.

Fleet King Saxon and undefeated Goldey F., made favorites in yesterday's stake events at Jamaica, charged home in front before 15,000 persons who once more jammed the Metropolitan Jockey Club's facilities to the straining point. Both victories were popular on an afternoon which saw form hold up remarkably well, even though the prices of three favorites were odds-on.

MOSCOW, May 9. -- A firmer step in British policy, which often has been criticized here as wavering, was seen in Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's questionnaire to Germany. Although it leaves untouched some points the Soviet considers of prime importance, its reference to the problem of Eastern security has won a favorable reception here.

Passage by the Senate of the Robinson-Patman-Borah-Van Nuys bills, including the amendments offered on the floor and accepted by the Senate, has resulted in "confusion twice confounded" on these measures, which seek to prevent price discrimination, according to Irving C. Fox, counsel of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Leading by only 3 -- 0 at the end of the first period, Princeton's rugby team put on pressure in the second half to score an 18-0 victory over the French Rugby Club yesterday at Central Park. The triumph was the sixth in seven starts for the Tigers and their second ever the French.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 (AP). -- A raging fire forced forty sports writers and telegraphers to flee from the lofty Harvard Stadium press box today.

MISS CHRANE'S book should appeal to many who dislike those poets of the modern school who use disturbing meters and express disturbing ideas. In this, her first publication since she graduated from college, there is nothing to offend.
ROCHESTER, May 9 (AP). -- The Red Wings made it two in a row over Newark by capturing a 6-to-3 decision today.

Cypress, pine and eucalyptus trees planted in Palestine as a Mother's Day tribute to many American Jewish women constitute one of the projects through which Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, is assisting in the reforestation of the Holy Land.

MR. BENCHLEY is waiting for the meteors. Citizens who have not been tipped off that it was the last war that ended civilization may want to wait with him. And I can think of no better way to pass the time between than in reading his new book.

Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth, a leader of the forces blocking enactment of Governor Lehman's Social Security Bill, was condemned yesterday by William Hodson, City Commissioner of Public Welfare, for "facing both ways" on security legislation.

The proposed bill to tax corporate surpluses would delay further the revival of the capital-goods industries, which have been lagging in their recovery, according to a telegram sent to Senator Pat Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, by the American Institute of Steel Construction.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May, 9. -- Winners of speech contests for the three upper classes of Rutgers University were announced today by Richard C. Reager, Assistant Professor of Public Speaking and coach of debate. The Bussing and O'Grady extemporaneous speaking contest for seniors was won by William H. Schmidt, Cliffside Park, who receives $30.
The passage of the Social Security Bill by the State Legislature would save city taxpayers more than $8,000,000 annually, according to William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare.

THE Spring thaw in the publishing world appears to have released some uncommonly good literary-floes from the back- regions of Nordic climes. From Iceland has come Gudmundsson's stormy, passionate novel, "Morning of Life"; from Norway, Gulbranssen's finely tempered, atmospheric "Beyond Sing the Woods," and now comes another vigorous novel about modern Iceland.
MEXICO, D.F., May 9. -- Another day has passed without a solution for the strike of National Railways workers, scheduled to begin May 17 unless some way out is found meanwhile.

Although capturing only one event, Boys High School's versatile band of athletes flashed considerable strength to carry off the team prize in the city P.S.A.L. senior high schools novice outdoor track and field championships yesterday at the General George W. Wingate Athletic Field in Brooklyn.

If would-be explorers wistfully believe that the spaciousness of Elizabethan days is forever lost, that the world is to be seen henceforth only from too-well-beaten tracks, here are cheering words from one of the most notable explorers of his time.

WORLD tours will encompass wide swings this Summer, making available to the traveler almost every form of diversion. Paths are being charted beyond the ordinary lanes of travel which offer new opportunities to the amateur explorer.

AT the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be opened this week -- to remain on view all Summer -- an exhibition which makes all comers, so to speak, eyewitnesses of something we are apt to be a hit hazy about: the prodigious impression produced on his contemporaries in Europe by Dr. Benjamin Franklin, Printer. of Philadelphia.

Early American and English period furniture, American and English silver, English porcelains and other decorations, comprising property from the collections of Miss Ella Parsons of Philadelphia and Cornelius U. S. Edmond, removed from Green Oak Farm, Flushing, L. I., from the estate of R. K. Richards and from other owners, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday and Friday afternoons.

VINELAND, N.J., May 9. -- Women are more severe in their judgment of the personalities of other women than men are, Dr. E. Lowell Kelly of Connecticut State College declared in a paper read here today at the seventh annual meeting of the Association of Consulting Psychologists.

UNIONS have come to the forecastle and picketing to the pier-heads, and once against the American merchant marine is opening a new era. The latest act in our roaring maritime drama started recently with charges of insubordination and lack of discipline among crews, and countercharges by members of the seamen's union against ship operators and the government's inspection service.

ENGINEERS of the War Department will soon decide the fate of a project for the erection of another great span across the Hudson River between Tarrytown and Nyack, designed to ease motor traffic in this part of the metropolitan area.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 9. -- President Roosevelt is first choice for re-election in the opinion of Rutgers University seniors, according to a poll of the graduating class conducted by The Targum, undergraduate newspaper, which published the results today.

AFTER a three years' test, Helen Keller's alma mater, Perkins Institution for the Blind at Watertown in Massachusetts, reports striking results from a process of training that develops ear-sense on the fingertips of young deaf-blind-mutes and enables them to speak with their tongues.

Before a crowd of more than 700, who saw the game as part of the sub-freshmen day exercises, the Pratt Institute nine reached two Wagner College pitchers for fourteen hits and won, 11 to 9, yesterday at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, S.I.

The banana farm was new and small, a tiny clearing on the edge of the vast Honduran jungle, but it represented the achievement of a lifelong ambition to Tio Lorenzo and an enthralling future to Benito and Lola, who stood fingering the banana "bits" with wonder and interest.

BOSTON, May 8. -- Governor Curley at last "sees the path of duty clearly defined." He will not run for a second term. He would "'not be justified'" in standing in the way of three Democratic State officials, "all capable men," who aspire to the Governorship.

Miss Sarah Elkus, director of the day classes in English and citizenship in New York City, which she founded twenty-one years ago for the instruction of non-English-speaking foreign women, was honored yesterday by a group of about 250 friends and colleagues at a testimonial luncheon at the Hotel Pierre.

THIS book is a shining illustration of the fact that all rules about writing are made to be broken. It is subtitled, "An Interpretation of Sacajawea, the Indian Girl That Accompanied Lewis and Clark." Obviously it deals with a character drawn from history and the word "interpretation" warns us that the author has supplemented or replaced historical fact with her own inventions.
It seems to me that the legislators are busying themselves with certain details in the conduct of chain stores and missing the crux of the matter.

ALBANY, May 9. -- Governor Lehman's determined stand for his social security program and his insistence on a new test of strength over the Social Security Bill in the Republican Assembly, where it has suffered two defeats already, have made it certain that the legislative session this year will close, as it opened, on a note of bitter partisan belligerency.

ATLANTIC CITY. -- Thousands of visitors from all sections of the country are already here to attend the seventh annual Atlantic City Horse Show, which opens in the municipal convention hall on Tuesday and continues through Saturday.

VATICAN CITY, May 9. -- Four million and eighty thousand dollars was the total contribution made by all countries of the world to the Vatican's missionary work during 1935, it was announced today to Pope Plus by Cardinal Fumasoni Biondi, Prefect of the Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith.

Unless a greater degree of traffic safety is achieved and maintained, it may become necessary to limit the number of automobiles licensed each year, Mayor F.H. La Guardia declared yesterday at the review of the safety parade of more than 2,000 motor vehicles arranged by the Police Department.

IN popular understanding, until this year, hay was hay, just as in freight classifications "pigs is pigs." But under standards recently fixed and promulgated by the Secretary of Agriculture hay has become complicated. It has been separated into nine different groups, each group has been broken down into classes and each class into several grades, making the dictionary definition -- "grass cut and cured for fodder" -- almost inadequate.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 9. -- William Woodward's Gallant Prince ran a courageous race to win the $5,000 added King Philip Handicap before 35,000 at Narragansett Park today.

WITH synthetic Chinese films being concocted by several studios, Douglas MacLean, former star and in recent years a Paramount producer, within the next few weeks will throw on the screen the first native Chinese endeavor to be released generally.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 9. -- Dr. Tyler W. Dennett has the Hey. Dr. Henry Lefavour, former president of Simmons College, as his guest at the president's house, Williamstown. In honor of the Williams trustees Dr. Dennett had a luncheon party of eighteen today, including Clark Williams, William P. Sidley, John C. Wilson and Harry P. Dewey, who are at Williams Inn.

Ginette Marboeuf-Hoyet, 5 1/2-year-old French youngster who recently arrived in this country after being selected from among 3,000 girls in France as the child most resembling Shirley Temple, Hollywood's juvenile actress, gave a group oil New York children some hints on healthful eating yesterday. She mentioned spinach.

TIME was, and not so very long long ago either, when the seeker after amusement could find legitimate play in virtually and center of population larger than village, for there were stock companies everywhere and countless touring companies of varying degrees of excellence.

PARIS, May 8. -- "Peace by disarmament" is going to be the slogan of the Left parties which have won the elections in France and the beginning of their foreign policy. How far they will get is another matter.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Although Governor Landon of Kansas, with 139 delegates instructed or endorsed for him, holds a commanding lead for the Republican nomination for President the balance of power in the convention at Cleveland on June 8 will rest with the uninstructed delegates, mainly from the large Eastern and Pacific Coast States.

Net income of the New Jersey Zinc Company in the first quarter of this year amounted to $1,074,179, after taxes, depreciation, depletion, contingencies and other charges. This is equal to 55 cents each on $1,963,264 shares of $25-par stock. In the corresponding quarter of 1935, the net income was $1,060,889, or 54 cents a share.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 9. -- Holy Cross took a close game from Colgate today, 2 to 1. The game was twice interrupted by rain.

GENEVA, May 9. -- The League of Nations Council meets in regular session Monday facing another crossroads, this time under the presidency of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain for the first time. It must be graver than previous ones for the League itself and therefore for its members.

PROVENCE lies smiling and beautiful, "old and gay" and unconquerably itself, in its clear golden light; and there is no other land like it in all the world. Countless tourists visit it; a number of foreigners live in it; several people have written books about it.

IT was a grand fight by two great little fellows, that Canzoneri-McLarnin affair. Perhaps the battlers were all that the historians and surviving citizens say of them. Even so, the modern era has produced some fighters who take rank with the best of them in the pugilistic Hall of Fame.

RETAIL gains last week were reduced in some sections of the country, while other areas reported larger increases as a result of warm weather. Sports and Summer lines and accessories have jumped into strong demand.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Any end to the United States embargo on shipments of war materials to belligerents in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict will be decided by President Roosevelt "on a basis of fact" and not upon any action taken by the League of Nations or other governments, an authoritative source reported today.

Educational and social activities of the Eastern Federation of Delphian chapters will be merged on Tuesday in the Spring rally of the organization, to be held at the Hotel Roosevelt under the leadership of Mrs. Charles J. Snyder of New York, president.

More than 500 women, representing many fields of endeavor, are expected to attend the eighteenth annual convention of the New Jersey Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs Friday, Saturday and Sunday at the Berkeley-Carteret Hotel in Asbury Park.

FOR some years the Kappa Delta Pi society has made it a practice at its annual dinner to have a scholar of eminence deliver a lecture that shall be an incentive to more thoughtful living. The talk last year, by John Finley, scholar, educator and editor, is now brought out, as all these lectures are, in book form.

PITTSBURGH, May 9 (AP). -- Cy Blanton held the Reds to a pair of scratch hits in four innings today after the Pirates staged a five-run assault in the fifth to overcome an early lead and Pittsburgh won its second successive game from Cincinnati, 10 -- 6.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9. -- Winners of contests staged by the junior department of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs were announced today by the committee chairmen at the ninth annual convention.

PARIS, May 9. -- The question of France's participation in the Olympic Games in Berlin this Summer was raised again in the Council of Ministers this afternoon, but was left undecided. The matter will probably be left over for the incoming Leftist government, which, it is believed, will be ill disposed to support the games.

Murder in a publishing house -- a most respectable London establishment -- provides Albert Campion with another opportunity to show his ability as a detective. His efforts are devoted to clearing the name of Michael Wedgwood, who is accused of murdering his cousin, Paul Brande.

Universal faith in the "fundamental truths" of religion was urged yesterday afternoon by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College, as an essential factor in the solution of present-day problems.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- A plan for complete reorganization of the American Bar Association was announced today by President William L. Ransom of New York, at the close of a special four-day meeting of the association's executive committee.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- Mrs. Lillian Guild, 50-year-old widow and manager of a gift shop in the Stevens Hotel, was found brutally murdered this morning beside the bed in her room at the Y.W. C.A. Hotel, 830 South Michigan Avenue.

SANTO DOMINGO has had more fantastic vicissitudes than almost any other land, and nowhere has opera bouffe so quickly changed into bloody butchery. Columbus first sighted it in 1492, and it soon became the theatre of hideous cruelties, for the Spaniards decimated the natives by brutality and overwork

THE last interview given out by Henri Barbusse on art -- perhaps his last public utterance on any topic -- was published by the Soviet magazine October. It is now made available in the Art Front for May, in an English translation by Samuel Putnam.

The East River Drive from Grand Street to Sixtieth Street, a stretch of about three and one-half miles, will cost the city $26,890,000, or $7,682,000 a mile exclusive of "consequential damages" to adjacent property, according to estimates contained in a detailed report on the project made public yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.

AS a result of an invitation extended to the Budapest University Chorus by the Yale Glee Club during its tour of Europe four years ago, the Hungarian choral unit, which is one of the oldest musical bodies in the world, will visit the United States next February.

Blue eyes and red hair are the outstanding characteristics of the ideal girl, according to the members of the senior class at St. John's College, who expressed their opinion in a class poll, conducted by the college yearbook, the Vincentian, and announced yesterday.

OTTAWA, May 8. -- The budget brought down in the Canadian Parliament last week by Finance Minister Charles A. Dunning was remarkable for several reasons. It definitely showed that in an age of economic nationalism there is in the saddle in Canada a government which believes in freer trade.

American antiques will be on view at Ophir Hall, the home of the late, Mrs. Whitelaw Reid at Purchase, N.Y., for the benefit of the Westchester County Children's Association, from next Saturday through May 31, according to an announcement yesterday by the sponsors.

IN a recent article in The Sphere, reprinted here in The Taxi Weekly, Charles Graves describes the taxicab driver's lot in London. Apparently it is not so unhappy as that of a Gilbert and Sullivan policeman. Nor, it would seem, as that of a New York hackman.
ROME, May 9. -- The rebirth of an empire ruled by Italy was announced tonight by Premier Benito Mussolini.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 9. -- Harold L. Davis, writer of the Pulitzer Prize novel for 1935, will not accept the all-expense visit to New York at the request of his publisher. He has not stirred from the Summer resort hotel near Lebanon where he was told Tuesday morning of his success.

THIS is the second of what Mr. Wells calls "a film" to emerge between boards. The first, "Things to Come," made curiously stilted and hollow reading, although imaginative technical direction has constructed an engrossing motion picture upon its framework.

SUGARING-OFF is over for the year and the new crop of maple sugar is now coming to market. It will go not only to the pantry shelves of New Yorkers but to restaurant, grocers, candy manufacturers and even to tobacco companies, for this tree sugar is used to flavor certain blends of tobacco.

THIS is the second of what Mr. Wells calls "a film" to emerge between boards. The first, "Things to Come," made curiously stilted and hollow reading, although imaginative technical direction has constructed an engrossing motion picture upon its framework.

SUGARING-OFF is over for the year and the new crop of maple sugar is now coming to market. It will go not only to the pantry shelves of New Yorkers but to restaurant, grocers, candy manufacturers and even to tobacco companies, for this tree sugar is used to flavor certain blends of tobacco.

For the first year since 1930, the steel industry operated "in the black" in 1935, showing a net profit of $62,961,961, against a net loss of $14,703,536 in 1934, according to a compilation of the reports of 127 companies, representing more than 90 per cent of the invested capital in the industry, prepared by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Immediate promotions for Minister Resident Cornelius van H. Engert and Vice Consuls William C. Cramp and Robert L. Hunter, who held the United States Legation at Addis Ababa throughout the rioting that marked the collapse of the Ethiopian Government, was announced today by President Roosevelt in a message to Mr. Engert.

RELICS of the Civil War, long in private possession, have recently been lent for display to the museum under construction for the Spottsylvania and Fredericksburg County Battle Fields Memorial National Military Park. The first collector of these trophies was George H. Stuart, chairman of the United States Christian Commission, a humanitarian organization founded to care for Civil War wounded; the collection now belongs to his grandson, Edward T. Stuart of Ardmore, Pa.

With all branches of the drug and allied industries determined to curb predatory price-cutting on branded lines, a marked increase in the consignment method of distribution, whereby wholesalers serve solely as the sales agents for the manufacturers, was predicted here yesterday.

Repeating his Hartford prediction that President Roosevelt would be elected by greater popular and electoral majorities than he received in 1932, Postmaster General James A. Farley gave specific reasons last night why he believed that Pennsylvania, never carried by a Democratic nominee for President since the Civil War, would be in the Democratic column at the November election.

IT would be hard to find a deadlier indictment of civilization in its present phase than this story -- covering the better part of 700 pages without one superfluous word -- of the twenty-odd hopeless years of an English girl's life in London and its neighborhood.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9. -- The Harvard nine today continued on its unbeaten way toward the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship when it beat Cornell, 9 to 5. It was the Crimson's sixth straight.

The Summer opening of the newly decorated roof garden of the St. Regis will take place on the night of May 19, when a party will be held there for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund. Mrs. Vincent Astor, chairman of the fund, also is executive head of the benefit.

Under the auspices of the New York Chapter of Kenwood Alumnae of the Sacred Heart Convent a festival of flowers and fashions will be held during the luncheon hour on Saturday at the formal opening of Chatham Walk. Augmenting the scenic effect supplied at the walk by the willow trees, boxwood hedges and rustic fence, Spring flowers will be banked against the walls and the tables will be shaded by brightly colored umbrellas.

The Anvil Chorus, Brooklyn lampooning organization, last night took its annual satirical fling at public officials and public events at a stunt dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria attended by 1,200 persons, many of them prominent in national, State and city official life.

Artur Bodanzky, conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, declined to return to San Francisco this Fall to conduct Wagner's "Ring" cycle for the second time because of the failure of the San Francisco Opera Association to provide facilities for a full Wagnerian orchestra, the conductor's representative, Berthold Neuer, has announced.

The annual junior promenade of Hunter College was held last night in the Gold Room of the Hotel Savoy Plaza, where more than 100 juniors and their escorts danced to the music of Peter Van Steeden's Orchestra.

Ethiopia -- Formerly (until last week) an empire, the last native sovereignty in Africa; area, 350,000 square miles; population, uncertain but probably about 10,000,000; produces cattle, cotton, sugar cane, salt; has various mineral deposits, extent undetermined; the forests abound in valuable trees, including rubber.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Visitors will assemble from Hot Springs, Asheville and the environs of White Sulphur Springs on Sunday afternoon to witness the exhibition tennis matches on the clay courts of the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

Again stimulated by warm weather, retail trade in the metropolitan area made a notably good showing last week. The increase over the corresponding week last year for leading department stores was estimated at around 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- President Roosevelt remained in town tonight, instead of starting on his usual week-end cruise on the Potomac River, in order to attend the annual dinner of the National Press Club. He spent two hours at this dinner, watching skits that were parodies on political and official life.

A gold box, only three and a quarter inches long, was sold for $1,000 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. It was part of the art property of the E.F. Bonaventure Company which was sold by the galleries Friday and yesterday.

TWENTY-FIVE dollars per citizen per month to start within eighteen months. That was the promise which led 54 per cent of the voters of the Far Western Canadian Province of Alberta to sweep William C. Aberhart last August from the principal's desk in a Calgary high school into power and prestige as Premier of the world's first Social Credit government.

Health Commissioner John L. Rice has written to Park Commissioner Robert Moses suggesting bicycle paths be set aside wherever possible in the parks, according to an announcement made public yesterday by the office of the health commissioner.

With the Summer season already giving evidence of opening favorably at retail, plans for developing added trade stimulus with the payment next month to veterans of some $2,000,000,000 are receiving careful consideration from retail sales promotion and merchandising executives.

The first annual Band and Drum Corps competition of the New York department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars was held yesterday afternoon and evening at the 102d Combat Engineers Armory, 168th Street, west of Broadway.

MADRID, May 9. -- Manuel Azana, four times Premier of the second Spanish Republic, will be elected its second President tomorrow to succeed Niceto Alcala Zamora, who was removed from office last month.

The United States liner Washington sailed Wednesday, starting her fourth year of operation as a transatlantic liner. In her three years she has carried 46,907 passengers and, like her sister ship, the Manhattan, has been one of the most popular ships on the Atlantic.

THE principal musical offering of this week in New York will be the local premiere of the opera, or "lyric drama" in three acts with prologue, by Lodovico Rocca after the famous play of Sholom Ansky (Rappaport of Vitebsk), "The Dybbuk."

ST. LOUIS. May 9. -- The steady gains by steel plants and other heavy industries in the Eighth Federal Reserve District is regarded as one of the most encouraging signs of a substantial business betterment. Orders for railway equipment have been received in sizable proportions, supplementing good commitments for structural steel.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 9. -- The American Medical Association, largest body of organized medicine in the world, with a membership of more than 100,000 American physi cians and surgeons, will hold its eighty-eighth annual session here next week, from Monday morning through Friday, May 15.

With two deaths attributed to the high temperatures reported in the metropolitan area, New York passed yesterday through the second day of this year's first heat wave. A maximum temperature of 89.9 degrees, 2.6 degrees higher than on Friday, was recorded at 6:10 P.M. by the United States Weather Bureau.

PARIS, May 7. -- The first midseason openings show each couturier developing his or her individual silhouette, shown at the last season, rather than launching any sensational new lines. Sleeves remain large at the top, shoulders are wide and high, sometimes they are so high that they hide the neck.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- A $2,000,000 loan to the Boston Maine Railroad from the Public Works Administration was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The money will be used for repairs to roadway estimated to cost $2,500,000.

License Commissioner Paul Moss, it was announced yesterday, has denied an application made by Robert W. Goelet for a permit for a motion-picture theatre at Fifty-third Street and Park Avenue. The commissioner denied the application without opinion.

Stock market sentiment was not much changed during the week just completed. That trading was cautious was attested by the fact that the turnover on the Stock Exchange was but slightly more than 5,000,000 shares, the smallest since the final week in June, 1935.
