SELDOM have Spring crowds on Fifth Avenue seemed gayer than this year, for a new note -- as fresh as Spring flowers -- is apparent. Fashion has accepted bright gloves, and myriad colored gloves are seen at every turn.

The Socialists and Communists of France, allied with the Radical Socialists in the "Popular Front," last Sunday clinched their victory in the elections for the new Parliament. In anticipation and in consequence of that victory the franc, long under pressure as the world's principal remaining gold-standard currency, suffered another run. The Bank of France statement for the week ended May 1 showed a loss of gold worth 1,169,000,000 francs (about $77,000,000).

WARSAW, May 8. -- The first anniversary of Marshal Pilsudski's death, May 12, happens to be the tenth anniversary of his march on Warsaw, which made him for nine years Poland's virtual dictator. It has been an eventful year since the nation took his body to the royal crypt in Wawel Cathedral at Cracow to rest among those of kings.

Undergraduates of Barnard College have contributed nearly $500 to the building fund campaign, it was announced yesterday by Miss Jane Craighead, the chairman. The money was raised by student activities during the Spring semester and it is expected that the contributions will reach $600 by June 2, the end of the academic year.

The most confirmed reader of mystery stories will find in this novel something entirely new, so far as we are aware, in crime fiction. It will appeal, we fear, to comparatively few, for it breaks away from the standard patterns to such an extent that it is difficult to classify.

THE long-standing controversy at the University of Pittsburgh involving liberalism, academic freedom and professorial tenure reached a new stage last week with the election of two trustees by the alumni. The candidates who won were regarded as "regular," or in other words, friendly to the university administration.

Brief contacts with the sessions of the women's division of the WPA in Washington last week so impressed Representative Mary T. Norton of New Jersey with the scope of the projects that she has requested a resume of the activities, State by State, for presentation to Congress.

LOUISVILLE, May 9 (AP). -- Murph, a black gelding owned by the Milky Way Farms, came from behind in the stretch to win the thirty-fifth running of the Bashford Manor Stakes for 2-year-olds at Churchill Downs today.
ROME, May 9. -- General Rodolfo Graziani marched into Harar at the head of his troops at 12:35 yesterday afternoon while thirty-five fighting planes filled the sky with the roar of their engines.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 9. -- Army won from Yale in a hard-riding polo contest today by a score of 11 to 6. A burst of speed by the cadets in the first chukker stood them in good stead, as the Elis' play improved thereafter and the Blue riders fought their rivals on even terms until the end.

ARE styles in Congressmen's wives changing? Mrs. Blumpus is decidedly pleased to think they are. Mrs. Blumpus, in case you may have forgotten, is the wife of the Hon. Augustine Blumpus, M. C., of the great Midland State of Paw-Paw. Since she came here in the last year of the Coolidge administration, life for a Congressional lady has become gayer, less stilted, more stimulating.

Drawn by the screams of a 14-year-old girl to a lonely spot on the Third Avenue Elevated Railway bridge over the Harlem River, Detective Edward Gunsett of the Bronx Main Office Division shot and killed one of two men he found with the girl at about 10 o'clock last night, and seriously wounded the other.

Announcement has just been made that an entertainment entitled the Queen Mary Supper Dance and Fashion Show will be held in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria on June 4 as part of the welcome ceremonial to the new liner Queen Mary, which is due in New York June 1 on her maiden voyage.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, yesterday withdrew his application to the Supreme Court asking its approval of the offer of the Eetna Casualty and Surety Company for the purchase of the title plants of the New York Title Insurance Company and the Lawyers Title Corporation and the stock of the Home Title Guaranty Company.

Forty-seven judges were announced last week for the elimination round of the seventy-five senior high schools, preparatory and diocesan schools of New York City entered in the Constitution Contest being conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES for high school teachers.

Thomas W. Lamont's tribute to his former teacher, Professor George Lyman Kittredge of Harvard University, and his statement in support of the educational value of Latin come as a timely, heartening message and an inspiration to those of us who have devoted the greater part of our lives to the study and teaching of the classical languages Mr. Lament must have observed that the classical tradition is rapidly passing out of the American curriculum.
Passengers on the Hindenburg, flown from Lakehurst to Newark on Douglas planes of American Airlines, the first of which reached Newark at 9:05 A.M. yesterday, quickly scattered to their hotels.

IN "The New Acoustics" Dr. McLachlan undertakes to provide "scientists, engineers and general reader" with a simple, non-mathematical account of acoustical developments since the outbreak of the great war. But while he avoids the Scylla of mathematics he plunges straight into the Charybdis of engineering jargon.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- Four days of Summer temperatures gave retail trade a much needed tonic and sales totals gained sharply over those of the week preceding. By comparison with the like 1935 week, the margin of increase was in excess of 10 per cent.

Except for the continued decline in French dollar loans to the lowest levels of the year, trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was featureless and typical of a two-hour session in mid-Summer. Prices of domestic corporation and United States Government bonds recorded only nominal changes in the smallest trading for a Saturday since Aug. 31, 1935.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- Red Cross services in disaster relief, in health, in the field of social service and in first aid and life saving will be the themes of the general sessions of the annual convention meeting here from Monday to Thursday. Preparations have been made to register 3,000 delegates.

An action to displace Chase Mellen Jr. as Republican leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District, North, has been started in Supreme Court by Joseph Pabian, former leader of the district, it became known yesterday. Mr. Mellen was formerly New York County Republican chairman.

FIFTEEN years ago when I was a small boy in short pants, living a carefree existence in the Tenth Georgia Congressional District, my one supreme ambition in life was to grow up to be the straight man for the Congressman from the neighboring Eighth Georgia district.

The Federal Music Project's festival, held in connection with the celebration of National Music Week, ended last night at the Manhattan Theatre with a performance of "Il Trovatore," sung in English by a cast of sixty-one Negro students, who were supervised by Miss Minto Cato.

THEY'RE off! The chase to the country is on. The dogwood beckons. Those who have country houses are opening them. Those who have not, week-end with those who have. Crowds in railway stations grow bigger at the commuting hour. The black serpent that winds out of town over the highway roads lengthens each day.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 9. -- While the silver Hindenburg snuggled quietly in its great hangar here today, men, women and children to whom Zeppelins were no longer the fabulous aircraft they were a score of years ago filed along roped-off aisles with restrained and polite curiosity.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- A huge camera, equipped with a newly designed astrographic lens, will be used to photograph the sun's corona during the total eclipse at Ak Bulak, U.S.S.R., June 19, by the expedition of the National Geographic Society and National Bureau of Standards.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9. -- Having given a series of remarkable performances through four consecutive events, the chestnut mare, Margie McNeil, was awarded first money of $150 at the conclusion of the working hunter stake, one of the most interesting competitions of the twelfth annual New Haven horse show, which was concluded tonight in the New Haven Arena.

COLLEGE students are carrying their anti-war activities beyond campus "strikes" this year. Four hundred undergraduates are to give up their whole vacation this Summer to organized work for peace. In groups of four or five each, under adult leaders, they are to be stationed in a hundred rural communities in thirty States as part of an emergency peace campaign initiated by the American Friends Service Committee.

Mussolini has announced that all of Ethiopia is to belong to Italy. With the flight of Haile Selassie and the capture of Addis Ababa, the last real obstacles to the realization of this program have been overcome. The remainder of the country will not be so much "conquered" as "occupied."

WHEREVER men's thoughts run to healing works and the succor of the suffering, honor will be rendered to Florence Nightingale on Tuesday, her birthday. History knows her as "the lady of the lamp," who, born in 1820 of well-to-do English parents, journeyed on an errand of mercy to the horrors of primitive war hospitals in the Crimea.

POSSIBLY no other small group of plants gets more national publicity at this season than the Japanese cherry -- and when the Japanese cherry bursts into bloom it is definitely established in the minds of many that Spring has come to stay.

Capacity bookings are assured the new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary on her first six transatlantic crossings this year, it was announced yesterday by the line. The ship is scheduled to make fourteen round trips during her first seven months.

IN November of the year 1847 a youthful assistant surgeon attached to a British naval vessel on a survey mission along the Australian coast discovered that he had also become attached to a young lady living at New Town, just outside Sydney.

Mayor La Guardia warned magistrates to deal more stringently with unlicensed pushcart peddlers who compete with established taxpaying markets yesterday morning when he cut a red, white and blue ribbon, formally opening the new $48,000 Bronx Terminal Retail Market at 150th and Exterior Streets, the Bronx.

THE new metal and wicker furniture for penthouse terrace or country porch is both individual and adaptable. The designs are more graceful than ever before; they combine simplicity of shape with added comfort and convenience and meet structural needs with increased ingenuity.

Announcement has just been made that an entertainment entitled the Queen Mary Supper Dance and Fashion Show will be held in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria on June 4 as part of the welcome ceremonial to the new liner Queen Mary, which is due in New York June 1 on her maiden voyage.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 (AP). -- Paul Derringer, hurling his first game since his suspension for failing to slide home in a game against the Giants, held the Pirates to three scattered hits today to give the Cincinnati Reds a 6-0 victory.

NEW ORLEANS, May 10. -- The volume of trading in contracts for cotton for future delivery increased here last week. Less belligerent aspects of affairs in Europe, firmness of prices of spot cotton and the strength of the near months, particularly July, gave a more confident tone to the market.

One man was killed and another wounded critically at 1:45 o'clock this morning at 192d Street and Fort George Avenue, in the Inwood section of upper Manhattan, by an unidentified man who escaped, leaving his victims lying in the street.
The Davison Fund, Inc., established by John D. Rockefeller Jr., has contributed $25,000 to the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, Laurence M. Marks, chairman, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Prices of hogs here declined 50 to 60 cents a hundredweight for most of the offerings last week, and aged underweight stock lost 75 to 85 cents. Prices for cattle dropped to the lowest level in fifteen months, as quoted by leading livestock authorities, and all cattle, except calves, showed plain quality.

Activity looking toward the redemption of bonds before maturity was substantially curtailed last week when announcements declined to about half the number for the preceding week. Not only were the calls less numerous (and there were but few entire issues among them) but the size of the payments involved was smaller.

Belmont Park's twenty-four-day Spring meeting, which will decide the 3-year-old championship with the running of the Withers and Belmont Stakes, will get under way today with one of the most famous sprinting tests in the country as the feature of a seven-race program.

The Fire Department of Onset, Mass., up near the head of Buzzards Bay where Cape Cod begins, had to struggle along as best it could yesterday. It is one of those typical Down East volunteer brigades and has only two paid men. One of them, the second in rank, which gives him the title of Assistant Chief Clayton Bishop, had a week-end furlough because of an important engagement on the Hudson.

Edgar R. Patterson, who is forming a new firm for the distribution of decorative upholstery and drapery fabrics, has leased the entire fifth floor in the sixteen-story Wellsworth Building, 70 West Fortieth Street. He was formerly president of Johnson Faulkner, with which company he was associated for more than twenty-six years.
Cotton moved against the general commodity price trend last week. Saturday's closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 3 to 20 points.
Warnings against commercialization of "Mother's Day" and the tendency of many modern mothers to neglect their children were sounded by members of the clergy of this city yesterday in their sermons.

LONDON, May 8. -- France's political affairs and her financial situation again are the dominating factors in London's markets. It cannot be said that there is any real alarm in the City over the dramatic swing on the other side of the Channel from Right to Left.

The value of American cooperation in the establishment of a regular transatantic airship service was emphasized last night by Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador, at the dinner of welcome at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in honor of Dr. Hugo Eckener, Captain Ernst Lebmann and other officers of the Hindenburg.

Loyalty to church and nation as a means of combating radicalism was urged yesterday by the Very Rev. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. He spoke at the fifth annual communion breakfast of the Department of Sanitation Holy Name Society of Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond at the Hotel Astor.

GENEVA, May 10. -- In a pleasant world beside a blue lake and amid luxuriant greenery, which knows nothing of poison gas and never saw a tank such as those that rolled over and extinguished the independent Ethiopian Empire, the ninety-second Council of the League of Nations will meet tomorrow.

More than $4,000,000,000 a year is expended for the salaries of Federal, local and State employes, it is estimated in a study made public yesterday by the National Civil Service Reform League. This represents approximately 38 per cent of the taxes collected, it declared, adding that nearly one-tenth of all those gainfully employed in the United States are employed at the expense of the taxpayer.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The estimated population of the United States on July 1, 1935, was 127,521,000, as compared with the official Federal census figures of 122,755,046 on April 1, 1930, an increase of 3.9 per cent, according to figures made public today by William L. Austin, Director of the Bureau of the Census.

The notes of a bugle sounding "taps" echoed and re-echoed about the interior of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine last night in requiem for Florence Nightingale and the trained nurses who have died serving humanity in peace and in war.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The bitter struggle that has been waged over the inflationary Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Refinancing Bill for almost two years will be settled in the House this week, at least for this session.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- A new feature in the lard trade here at the close of last week was the buying of September lard by commission houses which were selling September wheat at the same time. The orders were said to have come from the East and some said they were for foreign account.

About 7,000 persons filled St. Patrick's Cathedral last night to hear "The Triumph of St. Patrick," an oratorio composed by Pietro Yon, organist at the cathedral. The performance was given in the presence and under the patronage of Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York.

One of the most important ancient Greek sculptured gravestones outside the series in the National Museum in Athens has been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and will be placed on exhibition this morning in the room of recent accessions. It dates from the end of the fifth century or the beginning of the fourth century B.C.

Senator WAGNER'S Housing Bill has now run the gauntlet of public hearings and is again under discussion among the higher powers at Washington. It is an immense advance over previous measures. Its sponsors seem to know better what they want, and in many respects what they want is more within the realm of what is practicable and wise.

Oh, please! Will some one save us from clinics? I know we ought to be grateful. In fact we ought to bow our heads in reverence to those institutions which minister to us now that our incomes no longer admit of expensive medication or surgery.

BARTOW, Fla., May 10. -- An unanswerable question to persons in this part of the country is why the mere flogging and tar and feathering of three men, one of them so severely that he died, should attract such widespread attention in the United States.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10. -The election of the 1936-1937 Interclub Committee of Princeton University was announced here today by Howard Menand Jr., '36, of Menands, N.Y., retiring president. Composed of the presidents of Princeton's eighteen upperclass eating clubs, the committee is charged with the supervision of the annual "bickering" period and of all club matters.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 10. -- Repeating her impressive victory in the saddle championship at New Haven yesterday, the chestnut mare Trouble Maker today captured the division title in the final competition of the sixth annual Lawridge Horse Show.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,856,720,200. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest bearing discount bills:
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 10 (AP). -The Buffalo Bisons fattened their batting averages today at the expense of the Albany Senators, taking both halves of the double encounter, 12 to 5 and 10 to 6.

A.J. McCarthy, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company in charge of operations, made public yesterday a letter to Dock Commissioner John McKenzie, asking the withdrawal of the new Dock Department regulation prohibiting taxicabs on city piers.

That powerful Yankee hitting combination, Joe DiMaggio and Bill Dickey, was functioning in accustomed style yesterday at the Stadium, and the McCarthymen easily defeated the hapless Athletics before the season's largest gathering in the Bronx ball yard.

PARIS, May 9. -- Hoarding of gold or foreign bank notes in France and exports of capital, both of which have increased and are spreading more and more widely among the general public since the national elections, are regarded here as reflecting two distinct sentiments.

LONDON, May 10. -- Plans to establish a political "Left theatre" as the first Socialist theatre in Great Britain, with a permanent playhouse and company in London, was discussed tonight at a conference of 400 trade union and other labor delegates.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 10. -- The second twenty-four hours in the life of the Passaic quadruplets ended auspiciously. They received their names and plans were under way tonight to have the State of New Jersey so far recognize their birth as to supply funds for their care.
CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP). -- The magazine Steel said today that demand for steel was subsiding slowly, with automobile and railroad requirements still leading in a broad and active market.
Happy-days-are-here-again note:

Gains were registered by most of the commodity futures markets last week. Rubber, cottonseed oil and a majority of the metals were exceptions. The close was dull and quotations were below the mid-week top prices in most instances. In the cash markets, corn, rye, cotton, hides and cocoa advanced, while wheat, oats, flour, raw sugar, lard, print cloths, wool tops, rubber, silk and tin declined.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 10. -Dr. Bolivar Lang Falconer, retired senior United States Civil Service Examiner, will start the first leg of an around-the-world commercial air lines flight when he leaves here tomorrow on the Hindenburg.

While the nation paid homage to its mothers, more than 20,000 children and their parents gathered on the Mall in Central Park yesterday afternoon to honor the fathers as well at the ninth annual Parents' Day celebration conducted under the auspices of Uncle Robert.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 10. -Already the holder of a new record for the westward crossing of the North Atlantic, the new German dirigible Hindenburg, which was the object of 75,000 pairs of admiring eyes here today, will seek new honors when she leaves tomorrow night for Germany with fifty passengers and two tons of freight and mail.

The eightieth anniversary of the founding of Congregation Baith Israel Anshei Emes at 236 Kane Street, Brooklyn, was celebrated at a dinner last night at the Hotel St. George attended by more than 100 members and guests. The latter included Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of the Free Synagogue, Manhattan, and Presiding Justice Edward Lazansky of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. Harold L. Turk, president of the congregation, was toastmaster.

GENEVA, May 10. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's annexation of Ethiopia as the foundation for the Empire of Italy and the decree giving the King of Italy the title of Emperor of Ethiopia have raised here a new angle in the non-recognition problem.

TOKYO, Monday, May 11. -- Publication of industrial information that hitherto had been treated as commercial news, will become a crime of espionage under a general mobilization secrets bill that the Hirota government is preparing to introduce.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May'' 10. -With the opening of regular north transatlantic airship service, the Luftschiffbau Zeppelin, Friedrichshafen, has printed a twelve-page booklet entitled "General Regulations for Passengers and Luggage Carried by Airship," of which a copy was obtained here today.

A "marked revival" of interest in the city's private hospitals and the rapid development of a coordinated city-wide hospital program were noted by Mayor La Guardia in a statement issued yesterday in connection with the observance tomorrow of "Hospital Day."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 10. -- The election of Bishops was the center of interest here today as the 600 ministerial and lay delegates to the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church awaited the counting tomorrow of the first ballot.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, for the last twelve years pastor of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church in Washington, D.C., known as "the Church of the Presidents," was installed yesterday afternoon as pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP). -Lefty Grove got a taste of his own medicine today as Washington knocked him off the mound, ended his five game winning streak, and shut out Boston, 4 to 0. About 25,000 fans saw the Red Sox pushed out of first place in the American League.

ATHENS, May 10. -- Representatives of striking workers in Saloniki expect tonight that the government will agree to their demands, which call for the resignations of George Rhallis, Governor General of Macedonia, and General Dakon, commandant of the gendarmerie.

LONDON, May 8. -- Italy's conquest of Ethiopia produced no strong reactions in London's financial circles. This immediate situation cannot, however, thrust aside the undercurrent of uneasiness caused by the contemplation of European politics and what moves will next develop.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, May 10. -The requirements of the United States Navy call for increasing the capacity of the Panama Canal by building a third set of locks, Admiral Joseph M. Reeves, commander of the fleet, said today in an interview on the flagship Pennsylvania.
Repercussions of the Left victory in the recent French elections resulted in a highly irregular market for the foreign exchanges here last week.

The 1936 baseball campaign at Travers Island, Pelham, was launched yesterday as the New York A.C. nine shut out St. John's University of Brooklyn, 4 -- 0. Jim Burns, the Winged Foot right-hander, set back the Redman with three safeties.

DETROIT, May 10 (AP). -- The Cleveland Indians scored twice in the fifteenth inning on a walk, a triple and a single to break up the longest game played here this season, and won by 9 to 7 today to even the series with the champion Detroit Tigers.

The National Republican Club, Women's National Republican Club, New York Young Republican Club, National Republican Builders and the Young Women's Republican Club of New York will begin today a series of hearings on planks in the platform to be adopted by the National Convention.

MEXICO, D.F., May 10. -- Mexico's polo squad, slated for participation in the Olympic Games, today won its second encounter from a team representing the Eighth Corps Area of the United States Army, 4 -- 1. The Mexicans downed the United States quartet last Sunday, 5 -- 4.

DETROIT, May 10 (AP). -- The introduction of new models in November instead of January, the Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today, has eliminated the usual wide fluctuations of employment during Spring months in motor assembly plants.
LAKEHURST, N.J., May 10.--To America's No. 1 lighter-than-air-minded town the local debut of the Hindenburg may have been a social success but it was a financial fiasco to the extent of $4,000.

Sweeping changes, both legislative and administrative, to promote the safety of life at sea, are urged by the National Council on Safety at Sea in a "progress report" made public yesterday by Walter Parker, chairman, and Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman.

TORONTO, Ont., May 9. -- A series of unusual diamond drill holes on the property of Macleod-Cockshutt Mines, Ltd., in the Little Long Lac area in Northern Ontario has revived great interest in this district. On the strength of the reports of the drilling, usually reliable mining Journals and mining authorities are predicting important developments.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 10. -- The three-day strike of more than 300 children attending the Huguenot School here was declared off today. The truce followed a meeting of the Huguenot Parent-Teacher Association, and the parents announced all the children would be back in school tomorrow.

LONDON, May 10. -- Albert Bein's "Little Ol' Boy" rather shocked critics at the Arts Theatre last night, some even questioning the correctness of the portrayal of a reform school in the American Middle West. The London Times says:

More than 5,000 youngsters, members of junior naval and military organizations in New York City, marched yesterday afternoon in Prospect Park to celebrate Mother's Day. The parade, the second of its kind, was under the auspices of the Association of Junior Military and Naval Organizations of Greater New York, with Colonel Ward H. Lasker in command.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 10. -- A treaty of friendship between Egypt and Saudi Arabia has been signed in Cairo and published simultaneously in Cairo and Mecca. The signing of the treaty was one of the last official acts of Aly Maher Pasha in his capacity as Minister of Foreign Affairs.

ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., May 10. -- Sarah Levi, 14 years old, of 1,600 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, was injured seriously about 6 o'clock this evening in a headlong fall from the top of the Palisades to a ledge forty feet below. She was taken to Englewood Hospital.

The Rev. William Popcke, pastor of the Zion Lutheran Church, 339 East Eighty-fourth Street, asserted in his sermon yesterday morning that it was a "divine spirit that chose Dr. Hugo Eckener to be here with us today to celebrate Mother's Day and to assure the American mothers that Germany is devoted to peace."

ALBANY, May 10. -- An increase in the number of deaths in the State from heart disease, pneumonia and influenza caused the least favorable mortality record for March in four years, the State Health Department's division of statistics reported today.

The good works of Jesus were praised as the most important events in world history yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Joseph Fort Newton, co-rector of St. James's Church, Philadelphia, preaching at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at Tenth Street.

NEW HAVEN, May 9. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81.6, which compares with 82.2 the week before, 82.5 two weeks before, 82.6 three weeks before and 82.5 four weeks before.

The candidacy of Goveimor All r. Landon of Kansas for the Republican nomination for President has a strong appeal to the women of the East, Mrs. Lawrence Morris of Pelham [anor declared yesterday at the headquarters of the Landon-forPresident Committee sponsored by former Kansans at the Murray Hill Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Ninety per cent of the enormous electric utility industry in the United States -- an industry which serves 25,000,000 customers and has an annual gross income of some $2,000,000,000 and a book value of about $13,000,000,000 -- is controlled by fifty-seven systems, directly or through subsidiaries, a survey made public today by the Federal Power Commission revealed.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine made public yesterday the names of twenty-two members of the force whose bravery during 1935 won them departmental decorations. Two of the three departmental medal awards were posthumous -those to Captain Richard McHale and Patrolman James M. J. Killion.

A season of grand opera at popular prices will be launched at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight with a performance of "Carmen." In the leading roles will be Bruna Castagna as Carmen, Natalie Bodanskaya as Micaela, Armand Tokatyan as Don Jose and Carlo Morelli as Escamillo. Gennaro Papi will conduct.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 10 (AP). -In the most magnificent pitching performance ever recorded in International League history here, Ray Starr pitched the Chiefs to a double victory over Toronto today, 9-0 and 3-0.
Informed readers must have appreciated, as I did, your editorial "Probation and Parole."

PARIS, May 10.--Amid almost frenzied applause by his Socialist supporters, Leon Blum today assumed leadership of the democratic majority in France in terms that implied that leadership would be not far removed from the dictatorial.

PROVIDENCE, May 10 (AP). -Harold I. June, chief pilot on two Byrd Antarctic expeditions, and Lincoln Ellsworth, Arctic flier-explorer, are planning a joint expedition to the South Pole to discover what they believe to be the last uncharted continent, 600,000 square miles, never seen by man.

MOSCOW, May 10. -- Accusations that local trade union leaders were interfering with the voluntary efforts of wives of industrial executives to improve living conditions among the workers were a feature of the opening meeting at the Kremlin today of the first All-Union Conference of Engineers' Wives.

The United Aircraft Corporation reports for the quarter ended on March 31 a net profit of $350,952, which is equivalent to 16 cents each on 2,109,561 shares of capital stock which will be outstanding when all exchanges for common stock of the United Aircraft and Transport Corporation have been effected.

Back comes Alla Nazimova tonight in "Ghosts," wherein she has toured extensively since her forty-four Manhattan performances earlier this season. The Golden is the place, and the prices again are popular -- a $1.65 top. McKay Morris and Harry Ellerbe continue in the two principal supporting roles.

ADDIS ABABA, May 10. -Premier Mussolini's radio speech last night proclaiming Ethiopia as part of the Italian Empire aroused enthusiasm almost too deep for expression among officers and soldiers in this land who listened beside every available radio set.

It is hard not to sympathize with Magistrate ABELES in the Yorkville Court when he sympathizes with the outlawed street musicians. He discharged four of them the other day because the law was against them, but he took occasion to differ sharply with Mayor LA GUARDIA'S policy in refusing licenses to all outdoor players, whether hand-organ soloists or German quartets.
A plan for the reorganization of the League of Nations was outlined in a formal statement made public here yesterday by the League of Nations Association of the United States.

The thoughts of thousands, even from beyond those of his own household of faith, will mount today to Morningside Heights to greet Bishop MANNING in observance of the double anniversary which he is enjoying -- the fifteenth of his election as Bishop and the seventieth of his birth.

ALBANY, May 10. -- The Republicans in the Assembly entered what is probably the final week of the legislative session planning to stage a last-ditch battle against Governor Lehman's eight-point social security program. Adjournment of the 1936 session by Wednesday is likely.
ALBANY, May 10. -- Attorney General Bennett renewed today in his annual report his recommendation that all legal work of the State Government be centralized in the Department of Law.

S. John Block, the one Socialist member of the Charter Revision Commission, issued a statement yesterday explaining his reasons for supporting the draft made public recently by the commission. The commission had announced that it was unanimous in agreeing on the proposal.

The Kill van Kull between Bayonne, N.J., and the north shore of Staten Island, with a nine-mile tide in its channel racing to even more treacherous waters, was crossed by a swimmer yesterday morning for the first time in many years.

With his wife looking on from the shore, John Fives, 26-year-old truck driver, of 331 East Eight-eight Street, Brooklyn, was drowned in Mill Basin, Jamaica Bay, near the Floyd Bennett Airport, shortly before 7 o'clock last night.

The action of the Republican leaders of the Assembly in opposing the Social Security Bill, sponsored by Governor Lehman, was attacked yesterday by Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican Representative from the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, and W. Kingsland Macy, former Republican State Chairman, who recently led an unsuccessful attempt to elect Borah-pledged delegates to the Republican National Convention.

Your editorial summary of how Commissioner Goldwater "put an end to these evil conditions" in our municipal hospitals prompts the following reminder of a more recent step by him and the Municipal Civil Service Commission, which promises to make it impossible for these evil hospital conditions to return.

BERLIN, May 8. -- The domestic industrial situation has improved. This week not only witnessed satisfactory declarations of dividends but it brought forth also a report showing that bankruptcies in April numbered 181, compared with 233 in April, 1935.

That revue which Henry Souvaine has been ever so busily assembling got around to the Vanderbilt Theatre last night, there to parade under the name of "Spring Tonic" before a houseful of friends of the City and Country School.
STEPPING cautiously out of the line of fire, the following return of tennis service is offered in court:

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 10. -Age conquered youth today in the opening of the yachting season at the Larchmont Yacht Club when the seven-year-old six-meter yacht Totem, cleverly handled by Bill Luders, defeated six others in the class, including J. Seward Johnson's new Mood, which made her first appearance, and Herman Whiton's Indian Scout, which made her racing bow in the international contests in Bermuda last month.

An attack along new lines against the so-called "bankruptcy closing-out" linen stores n the Fifth Avenue section will be launched by the Fifth Avenue Association, Inc., according to William J. Pedrick, president of the organization. Recent developments of a disturbing nature have aroused members of the association to the menace of the stores, Mr. Pedrick states in a special bulletin.

ALBANY, May 10.--State records of the past five years for a month's incorporations were broken during April when 127 new concerns outside of New York City accounted for a capitalization of $10,142,550. For the whole State, the total was 1,580, or eighteen more than in April, 1935, Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, reported today.

BERLIN, May 10. -- Annexation of Ethiopia by Italy on the eve another gathering of the Council of the League of Nations impressed German political opinion as a tragicomic, yet not unexpected, sequel to what is called bungling European statesmanship and diplomacy.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 10. -- After six years in the background the Wafd again stepped into power today, with Mustafa Nahas Pasha, its president, at the helm of the Egyptian Government.

KANSAS CITY, May 10. -- A veritable new Pandora's box of diseases resulting from hypersensitiveness to heat, cold or slight effort, and simple methods of relief for these sufferers, who have hitherto gone mostly unrelieved because the factors bringing about their ailments had been unknown, were demonstrated here today at the scientific exhibit of the American Medical Association on the eve of the opening of the association's eighty-seventh annual session.

A gift of securities with a present market value of more than $1,000,000 to provide additional fellowships in science and art was announced yesterday by former United States Senator and Mrs. Simon Guggenheim. The gift was made to the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, established in 1925 by Mr. and Mrs. Guggenheim in memory of their son, who died on April 26, 1922.

VIENNA, May 10. -- Disorderly conduct by the Heimwehr on the occasion of a parade by the Clerical Freiheitsbund today illuminated the differences between the Heimwehr (Fascist) and Schuschnigg Clericals, partners in the Austrian dictatorship.

Even the most indulgent minds resent some forms of atheism, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The largest army and navy appropriation bills ever to be approved by Congress in a peacetime year have now been passed by both houses and await only a conference agreement and the President's signature before becoming law. They call for an expenditure of $900,000,000 for national defense.

The appointment of Harold L. Cross, Henry F. Pringle and Howard P. Jones as professors on the faculty of the School of Journalism at Columbia University was announced yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman.

The pamphlet report of the General Motors Corporation, to be issued today, shows that net income for the first quarter of this year, as announced in the preliminary report, was $52,464,174, which was equal to $1.17 a share on the common stock. This compared with $31,510,371, or 68 cents a share, in the corresponding period of last year.
Henry K. Astwood, George A. Flett and C. John Swan are with Amott, Baker Co., Inc., as sales representatives.

Let it not be denied that the Italian Dictator is entitled to his day of triumph, however short it may prove to be. He has dared greatly, faced continuous and complicated difficulties, run enormous risks, and worked for the end he held steadily in view with extraordinary and feverish energy.

ROME, May 10. -- Italy is still ringing with excitement and enthusiasm after the proclamation made yesterday by Premier Benito Mussolini of the annexation of Ethiopia and the return of Rome to the status of capital of an empire.

BOSTON, May 10. -- Battling through twelve innings of error-spotted baseball, the Bees today emerged triumphant over both the Dodgers and the Sunday Curfew Law, beating the Stengeleers by 5-4 and the legal barrier by three minutes.

The first parachute jump of Winifred Bayer, 16-year-old student at Jamaica High School, Queens, landed her late yesterday afternoon in the cockpit of her airplane -- a leap of a few inches -- when she and the pilot discovered as she was braced on the wing that the parachute had opened prematurely.
NEWFOUNDLAND, N.J., May 10. -- Three city "slickers" from Paterson disturbed the normal quietude of Newfoundland's Sunday twilight hours tonight.

"We are no longer trying to build "a new world. We are struggling "desperately to save this one." This remark by President BENES of Czechoslovakia, one of the ablest and most pacific of European statesmen, aptly suggests the acute apprehension felt by the Little Entente States, which just closed their conference in Belgrade.

HAVANA, May 10. -- Navy Lieutenant Antonio Menendez Pelaez, who made a solo flight in the single-engined plane Fourth of Sep-tem from Havana to Seville, Spain, last January returned this afternoon aboard the steamship Cristobal Colon. He was wildly acclaimed.

No indication has yet appeared of the downward movement which in some quarters was inferred from the recent reaction on the Stock Exchange. Although a receding tendency in business activity after March or April would not be unusual under any circumstances, last week's returns of steel production and general business showed little change from the high level previously maintained.

The city's foreign trade zone now being established at Staten Island will increase the commerce of the Port of New York and the entire country, Mayor La Guardia predicted in a letter, made public yesterday, to the organizations sponsoring the local observance of "Foreign Trade Week" from May 17 to 23.

Intimating that many of the ills of the world would be remedied if the zeal of the Communists were transferred to Christianity, Stewart Dien, national vice president of the Young People's Christian Union, spoke yesterday morning on "Let Us Try to Get Back" at the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP). -- Promised that they would have an opportunity to present their case to Harry L. Hopkins tomorrow, thirty-five members of the League of the Physically Handicapped tonight left Works Progress Administration headquarters, where they had encamped for twenty-four hours, to stay in lodgings provided by the WPA.
MONTREAL, May 10 (AP). -- Baltimore ended Montreal's winning streak today, defeating the International League leaders in both ends of a double-header, 7 -- 1 and 7 -- 5, before a crowd of 21,000.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10.--Shelterock Merry Sovereign, fine looking airedale terrier belonging to S.M. Stewart of Montclair, captured the best-in-show prize in the fourth annual exhibition staged under the auspices of the Trenton Kennel Club on the grounds of the 112th Field Artillery today.

The feast of St. Joan of Arc, a religious and patriotic French holiday, was celebrated here yesterday morning at the French Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent de Paul, Twenty-third Street near Sixth Avenue. The solemn high mass was attended by Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General, with the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, representing Cardinal Hayes.

The Rev. Charles C. Webber, assistant director of field work at Union Theological Seminary and an instructor in the seminary's department of church and community, called upon youth yesterday to abolish capitalism and establish "a planned and planning social economy" in the United States.
Your editorial "Moses and the Park" is very much to the point. It has occurred to a good many of us that the removal of the Casino for the purpose of providing a playground was unwise.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 10 (AP). -- Driving Marvin Duke to cover in the fourth inning, the Rochester Red Wings shoved six runs across the plate and defeated the Newark Bears today, 9 to 4.

BERLIN, May 8. -- The Ethiopian problem receded into the background this week and market interest centered about the crisis of the French franc and the political outlook in Paris. The result was a new feeling of insecurity, which the Boerse first felt in the selling of stocks.
Realty men at the Senate hearings on the Wagner bill charged that unsanitary living conditions in the slums were not the result of the houses themselves, but of the tenants who lived in them.

A three-story brick Colonial dwelling containing eight rooms at the northwest corner of Avondale and Morningside Roads, Ridgewood, N.J., was sold by George W. Peterson, builder, to Frederick W. Reichard. The Realty Exchange of Ridgewood acted as broker in the transaction.
The French liner Normandie is due to arrive today from Havre via Southampton after being laid up at her home port since last October.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Senator Couzens, independent Republican of Michigan, may become the Democratic nominee for the Senate and also run on an independent Republican ticket. He has been suggested by some prominent Democrats of Michigan as their choice following increasing opposition among the Old Guard and industrial leaders in Michigan to his re-nomination by the Republican party.

MADRID, May 10. -- A Presidential convention today carried out all the formalities required by the Constitution to elect Manuel Azana Chief Executive of the Spanish Republic. There was no contest, as Mr. Azana was the only formally announced candidate.

Democracy can survive only if it is "maintained by people of character and unselfish service," the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

JOHN L. SPIVAK'S "Europe Under the Terror" (Simon Schuster, $2.50), the Book Union selection for May, is an assortment of informal essays on Italy, Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Austria. It is a clever attempt to pick out the threads of fear, misery and venality in the texture of Central Europe today, not with a scholar's fine point but with the blunt stub of a partisan.

LONDON, May 10. -- Herbert Morrison arrived home tonight from the United States convinced that Americans have "a real friendship" for the British. Mr. Morrison said, however, that the United States was at least fifty years behind Britain in housing.

FRANKFORT, May 10. -- Upon her return from her maiden flight across the North Atlantic the Hindenburg will land at her new home, the "Airdrome and Zeppelin Port Rhine-Main" at Frankfort, which henceforth will be the terminus of transatlantic Zeppelin services to North and South America.

Gaining a point a piece in the twelfth round yesterday afternoon, Samuel Reshevsky of the Marshall Club and Albert C. Simonson of the Manhattan Club, with totals of 9 -- 3, remained tied for first place in the United States title chess tournament at the Hotel Astor.

One museum opening and many shows in the galleries are on the calendar of events for the current week. Mid-May finds scant letup in the pace of a season that has set a new high for the number and variety of exhibitions.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 10. -Certain changes in the structure of the League of Nations to "make it more effective and give more authority to the Kellogg Pact," were urged here tonight in an address by Clark M. Eichelberger, national director of the League of Nations Association.

From the outset of Mayor La Guardia's administration, there has been on his part a singular solicitude toward the taxicab drivers of the city. None of us recalls with relish how he let them run wild in their strike, up to the point of a public scandal.

Action on the mille advertising bill by the New York State Legislature is expected this week, as the proposal has been reported out of the Assembly Rules Committee. Despite the success of the 1935-36 campaign, which ended April 1, the appropriation has been reported cut from $400,000 to $250,000.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Corn attracted the attention of operators on the Board of Trade here last week and the market gained strength because of the light stocks here. The recent liberal receipts have been picked up and moved eastward and into consumers' hands.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, laid the cornerstone of the new edifice of the Good Shepherd Church, Isham Street and Broadway, yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was witnessed by a crowd that police estimated at 5,000.

PARIS, May 9. -- The report of the Bank of France for May 1 showed important fluctuations which were due in part to the fact that the return was made up on the day after the end-of-the month expansion. It is abnormal, however, for bills discounted to have risen again by 500,000,000 francs, as they usually decrease upon collection of month-end maturities.
Deals involving houses in Harlem featured selling and leasing contracts reported in the city over the week-end.

Tallyho days will return to New York briefly this morning and a whip will crack along Fifth Avenue as a coach-and-four sets out to break the quarter-century-old coaching record from New York to the Atlantic City Horse Show.

Dr Hugo Eckener, commodore of the dirigible Hindenburg, paid a brief visit yesterday afternoon to Grand Central Palace, where the Third International Philatelic Exhibition is in progress. He delivered personally 1,040 first flight covers (stamped envelopes) that were part of the mail cargo on the recently completed air voyage from Germany.

PARIS, May 10. -- No meeting of the League of Nations Council has ever opened in such alarming and even humiliating circumstances as confront tomorrow's meeting at Geneva. One way or another it seems likely to be a decisive meeting.

Remarkable improvement in the American brand of play during the last two years was the main feature of the fourth women's national lacrosse tournament, which ended at the Riverdale Country School yesterday after three days of round robin team competition.

Acclaiming the Italian victory in Ethiopia, more than 16,000 Americans of Italian birth or descent gathered at a Victory Ball and celebration in Madison Square Garden last night. Frank Prina, chairman of the Committee of One Thousand which arranged the affair, estimated that it would raise between $20,000 and $25,000 for the benefit of the Italian Red Cross and other war relief agencies.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP). -- The Cardinals defeated the Cubs, 5 to 1, today in a five-inning game curtailed by rain to sweep the three-game series and more firmly entrench themselves in first place.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 10. -The following list of passengers who plan to fly to Germany on the Hindenburg was released here today. It was explained that the list would be subject to change. It was announced that fifty would sail, but the names of only thirty-six were made known. The list follows:

PITTSBURGH, May 10. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 70 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the rate of the preceding two weeks. Tonnage output is almost 30 per cent above the rate in either the first quarter of this year or the last quarter of last year.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 10. -- Countess Palfry, who motored from Hot Springs to the Greenbrier here, was the weekend guest of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Mills, who have been here since returning from the Kentucky Derby.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Petitions signed by 55,000 citizens protesting against the methods pursued by the Senate Lobby Committee and the Federal Trade Commission with respect to seizure of private telegrams were sent today to Vice President Garner by the American Liberty League for spreading on the Senate's records.

Admirers of Governor CURLEY in these parts should no be perturbed by dispatches from Boston that represent him as "carrying two pistols." He waggishly pretends that he is guarding himself against the Republican leaders: "I wouldn't put it beyond them to go to any depth."

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- A lot of pent-up emotion welled in the Giants today, burst a safety valve and the result was a severe scalding for the Phillies, who certainly were not looking for any such mishap to mar a pleasant Sabbath afternoon for an enthusiastic gathering of 13,000.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Prices of wheat dropped precipitiously last week following a break in the drought over the Winter crop sections of the Southwest, the largest producing section of hard Winter wheat in the country.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Senator Byrd, in a letter written to Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury last Friday and made public today, listed eleven large corporations that, he said, would have paid no taxes at all on their 1934 earnings and dividend distribution if the Revenue Bill now pending in Congress had been in effect.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 10 -- A secret espionage center of the German' Gestapo, the secret State police, which, it is believed, has led to the arrest in Germany of large numbers of relatives and friends of emigres from that country, has been discovered by the police here.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 10 -- Miss Sylva Annenberg today wrote another chapter to her story of success in New York State golf when she and Mark J. Stuart won the mixed foursomes title at the Siwanoy Country Club.

Stimulated by more favorable weather last week, the various wholesale markets here experienced a rather active period, with all types of Summer apparel in good demand. Cotton played an important part in the substantial dress business reported.

The country that was pleased with "To Have and to Hold" was a happier country than this United States of today. MARY JOHNSTON'S own Virginia mountains and waters, her earlier Virginians created after deep historical studies, her sense of character and drama, gave quality and charm to her books.

Proof of God's goodness and mercy lies in the fact that He makes the "minimum requirement for entering heaven" so easy, the Rev. William O'Connor declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

BERLIN, May 11. -- Trading on the Boerse was quieter but continued its tendency of consistent strength and its character as a devaluation market. Official influences were set at work to check a buoyant tendency and apparently were able to keep it well in hand but unable to reverse it.

The National City Bank of New York will announce today a reduction of interest from 6 per cent to 4 per cent a year on new loans in its personal credit department (formerly personal loan department) of not more than twelve months maturity.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- A decidedly bullish construction was placed by the grain trade on the government's crop report, which was issued today after the close of business on the Board of Trade, as it showed a prospective Winter wheat crop of only 464,000,000 bushels.

Trading, cautious in the extreme, characterized the security markets yesterday. The turnover on the Stock Exchange aggregated but 677,000 shares, the smallest for a full day since June 10, 1935. Stocks closed generally lower after opening with fractional gains; during most of the day prices were confined to narrow trading ranges.

The Snider Packing Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on March 31 a net profit of $630,244 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $3 each on the 210,000 no par capital shares outstanding. In the preceding fiscal year the net profit was $591,627, or $2.82 a share.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 11. -- Leaving a handful of wistful earthlings gazing upward at her silky grace, the new German dirigible Hindenburg took off at 11:27 o'clock tonight for Frankfort, Germany. Her commanding officers were hopeful of completing the homeward leg of their first round-trip flight in record time.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 11. -- An 87-year-old grandmother stepped firmly to the first step of the gangway of the Hindenburg at 10:55 o'clock here tonight and became the first of forty-eight passengers to board the airship for the eastward flight. Ten of her fellow-travelers had come over with the new dirigible.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Loans disbursed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in March amounted to $17,692,656, while repayments on former loans reached $57,905,403, according to the month ly report of the corporation transmitted today to Congress.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 11 (AP). -- Political quiet prevailed tonight on the eve of Ohio's most important Presidential primary in sixteen years.

The French superliner Normandie, largest and speediest passenger vessel in service, arrived from Havre via Southampton yesterday on her first voyage in 1936, making the run of 2,944 miles from Bishop Rock to the Ambrose Channel Lightship in 103 hours at an average speed of 28.57 knots.

William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, declared last night that defeat of the Social Security Bill, now held up in the State Assembly, would be "stark tragedy" for more than 100,000 persons, the old and young, the sick and blind. Mr. Hodson spoke from radio station WOR in reply to a speech by Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth against the bill last Friday evening.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor today replied to John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, who attacked the council's policy last week in connection with the proposed plans for organization of the steel industry.

Civic groups and other interests supporting or opposing municipal acts for "selfish or political reasons," or without sufficient study, were criticized yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in an address at the twenty-fifth anniversary luncheon of the Broadway Association in the Hotel Astor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- Peppering five of Bill Terry's pitchers for a total of sixteen hits, the Phillies showered the Giants with five home runs today in a forceful demonstration that sheer power is infinitely superior to the finest of intellects.
VATICAN CITY, May 11. -- Pope Pius made a vigorous attack on communism today in reply to an address by the Primate of Hungary, Cardinal Seredi, in introducing Hungarian pilgrims.
Events moved rapidly yesterday for Marcia Hamilton, 19 years old, a small town miss who got lost in the big city.

The failure of Lawson Little, double winner of the American and British amateur golf championships, to qualify, featured the far-flung play yesterday in the sectional qualifying rounds for the national open championship.

TRENTON, N.J., May 11. -- Shortly after a petition was presented here to Governor Hoffman asking that Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf be retained as head of the State Police, the Assembly passed a bill making it mandatory that Colonel Schwarzkopf be retained until such time as the Senate might approve a new appointee.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The $2,364,229,712 Deficiency Appropriation Bill carrying $1,425,000,000 for relief during the fiscal year 1937 was passed in the House today by a vote of 341 to 38, all but a handful of the Republicans saying aye on the final test.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Department store sales in April were 8 per cent higher than in the corresponding month last year, and for the first four months of the year exceeded the corresponding period of 1935 by 9 per cent, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

LOS ANGELES, May 11. -- Announcing drastic changes in the Townsend Old Age Revolving Pension Plan set-up in Southern California, Dr. Francis E. Townsend today indicated a new method of handling contributions by which employes will receive a fixed salary and will not receive a commission from gross receipts as in the past.

The Robinson-Patmann bill -- commonly called the "Anti-Chain Store Bill" -- has finally passed the Senate and now awaits action by the House. I have tried to discover the reason for this amendment to the Clayton anti-trust law without much success. Ostensibly it is to help small business enterprises.

ADDIS ABABA, May 10 (delayed). -- The Abuna Cyril, Patriarch of the Ethiopian Coptic Church, told your correspondent in an interview that religious life in this conquered country would go on as usual.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 11. -- Miss Elizabeth Chadbourne of New York, daughter of the late Dr. Paul Ansel Chadbourne, fifth president of Williams College, is visiting Miss Susan Hopkins in Williamstown. Mrs. John Hopkins Denison of Santa Barbara, Calif., is spending a few days at her place, Camerina, which adjoins that of Miss Hopkins.

One of the season's better shows came back to town last evening, to set up a late Spring shop at the Golden Theatre. It was Ibsen's "Ghosts," revived courageously earlier in the year by Nazimova, with herself, McKay Morris and Harry Ellerbe in the leading roles.

Further beneficial rainfall in dry areas west of the Mississippi River created some pressure on new crop deliveries on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but a sharp recovery in final dealings left the list unchanged to 2 points lower than on Saturday.
BALTIMORE, May 11. -- This Preakness week will be crowded with social events culminating in the Preakness ball on Friday night before the day of the race at old Pimlico.
CHICAGO, May 11. -- The text of President Roosevelt's letter today to the national convention of the American Red Cross read as follows:

The Caruso American Memorial Foundation, Inc., applied in the Supreme Court yesterday for permission to transfer its assets, consisting of $13,894 in cash and about $20,000 in securities, to the Juilliard School of Music because the resources of the foundation are insufficient to enable it to maintain an organization to carry out the purposes for which it was founded.
ROME, May 11. -- King Victor Emmanuel may be crowned Emperor of Ethiopia in the Holy City of Aksum, an official source disclosed tonight.

The second of the Federal Theatre's Living Newspaper shows will go on tonight at the Biltmore Theatre. It is "1935," and is, as the name suggests, a review of last year. The Hauptmann trial, the murder of "Dutch" Schultz, flight of the China Clipper, baseball games, , are among its incidents.

The House of Representatives voted yesterday to begin consideration of a bill whose real purpose, in the eyes of many members, is an inflation of the currency. It is to be brought before the House in the guise of a farm bill, since it provides for the refinancing of existing farm indebtedness. But for many members this is less important than the means by which the refinancing is to be undertaken.

In what he termed his second public address in two years, Sinclair Lewis prophesied last night that no form of radio broadcast, television included, ever would threaten the demand for good books. Mr. Lewis spoke on "Enemies of of the Book" at the thirty-sixth annual dinner of the American Booksellers Association, which concluded a two-day convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Jamaica High School baseball team scored its seventh straight league victory yesterday when it defeated the Richmond Hill nine, 11 to 8, at Jamaica Stadium in a Queens Division P.S.A.L. contest. Tom Kelly was credited with his fifth triumph of the campaign.

BOSTON, May 11. -- Summer came back to Boston today, but there was Winter in the harassed soul of Casey Stengel as he took his error-ridden Dodgers toward Brooklyn tonight with nothing more pleasant in prospect than the task of repelling an invasion by Frankie Frisch's Gashouse Gang.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--Whether the flight of the Hindenburg will again swing naval opinion in favor of the construction and operation of dirigibles by United States defense forces was a question on which naval officers reserved judgment today.

A meeting of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference, composed of American and foreign-flag ship lines in the Atlantic trade, has been called for 11:30 A.M. today to consider a protest against the order of Dock Commissioner John McKenzie barring taxicabs from the city piers.

DEDHAM, Mass., May 11 (AP). -- Judge Joseph R. McCoole took under advisement today a motion to dismiss a bill in equity brought by John J. Powers of Braintree, seeking removal of fourteen officials of the New England Gas and Electric Company including Howard C. Hopson of New Jersey, John I. Mange of Plandome, N.Y., and Daniel Starch, Sanford Magee and Ralph Jennison, all of New York.

ROME, May 11.--Proceedings at Geneva are being watched here with interest but not with any apprehension. Much indignation has been caused by the manoeuvres of Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, to permit Wolde Mariam Ayeleu, representative of "a non-existent State," as Ethiopia is called here, to sit at the council table.

After more than ten hours of stubborn denial Patrolman Edward J. Bradley of the Wadsworth Avenue precinct confessed late yesterday afternoon that he killed Morris Sperber, cab driver, and seriously wounded Robert Fischer, a friend, in a brawl over a $225 loan.

Your editorial "Alarm in South-Eastern Europe" concludes with these words which set minds thinking in other directions than political boundaries and fears: "European statesmen must choose between some form of real collective security and war; there is no third alternative." You make us think of what I may call "morality-boundaries."

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- A comma was the basis for a $300,000 appeal to the Supreme Court today by the Irving Trust Company of New York, which contended that the punctuation mark in an Ohio Federal court order seventeen years ago entitled it to protection for its $300,000 deposit in the Guardian Trust Company, Cleveland bank which closed in 1933.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 11. -- New Jersey's quadruplets -- Frances, Frank, Felix and Ferdinand -- spent a normal day in their incubators in St. Mary's Hospital here today, but they were the innocent cause of more excitement than Passaic had known in many years.

Not for many years on the opening day of the Belmont Park races has society made so gay and festive an event of the pre-race luncheon at the Turf and Field Club and not in several seasons has it been warm enough for the al fresco feature that gave yesterday's opening a Spring-like touch.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Urging business men to "discourage all efforts to create unjustifiable political friction," Secretary of Commerce Roper in a radio address tonight called for cooperation with the government and a realization that the object of this administration is to "assure the perpetuity of our American system."

The first of a series of public hearings to learn Republican voters' opinions on matters of national import as a guide for recommendations to the platform committee at the Cleveland convention was held yesterday afternoon and another in the evening at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today sent to the Senate the nomination of Arthur S. Tuttle as State Director of the Public Works Administration for New York.

Visitors to the international stamp show in Grand Central Palace devoted their attention yesterday chiefly to looking at and studying the rarities in stamps from all parts of the world. Activity continued, however, around the windows of the branch philatelic postoffice on the ground floor, where the special exhibition souvenir sheets and other United States commemoratives are on sale.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 11. -- The women's team from the Gedney Farm Golf Club assumed the lead in the Westchester interclub matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today. Gedney Farm's players, called upon to face two opponents, defeated Quaker Ridge, 3 to 2, and shut out the Grassy Sprain team, 5 to 0.
The vanguard of the weakfish run has arrived in Peconic Bay.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Attorney General Cummings said today of A. Mitchell Palmer's death "He was a great lawyer, a distinguished public servant and an outstanding citizen. He was my friend of many years' standing and his death brings to me a deep sense of personal loss and sorrow."

With three of his alleged lieutenants pleading guilty before the morning session had ended, Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, described in court as the vice over-lord of the city, went on trial for compulsory prostitution yesterday. Nine co-defendants faced Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook with him, after the pleas of the three others had been accepted.

Singing Wood and Sation fought it out to finish as named in the forty-third Toboggan Handicap as Belmont Park opened its Spring meeting yesterday before 10,000 persons, including many distinguished men and women widely known in society and on the turf.

Coming on the heels of his four hits yesterday, the Philadelphia Moore's homer in the first was Johnny's fifth straight safety of the series. But in the third the streak ended when Jim Ripple chased clear to the center field bleachers to make the catch.

A crowd of more than 100 men chased a Negro bootblack six blocks in Washington Heights about 7 o'clock last night after he had hit a man over the head with a bottle in a dispute after they had collided while walking on the sidewalk of West 181st Street.
A jury of teachers was advocated yesterday by Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, as a means of ridding the city school system of incompetent teachers.

Life insurance underwriters meeting here yesterday for the opening of a national "week" were told by Surrogate Leone D. Howell of Nassau County that inflationary measures like the Frazier-Lemke bill would destroy the security benefits of insurance.

GENEVA, May 11. -- At the very outset of its meeting today the League of Nations Council was brought somewhat disconcertingly face to face with the realities of the Ethiopian situation and forced to take a position that will be of importance in subsequent deliberations.

BASLE, May 11. -- Rearmament, political tension, rising taxes and the general lack of international agreement even on economic and financial problems now capable of solution -- these have threatened the business recovery that is trying to break through.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP). -- A man and a woman quit confidential positions under Mayor S. Davis Wilson today, declaring they would have no part in the proposed transactions for the city's purchase of the Philadelphia transit system. They are Florence Greaves, a lawyer, for whom Mayor Wilson created the $3,500 position of confidential secretary, and Ralph Jones, his technical consultant in the reorganization proceedings for the transit company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 11. -- Slumping in the witness chair during cross-examination this afternoon in the trial of a Supreme Court damage suit, Frederick A. Church, 58 years old, for the last eight years general superintendent of Playland, was pronounced dead a few minutes later at White Plains Hospital.

The opening of the Spring season of popular-priced opera last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was very auspicious. The house was packed and sold out, with an audience which had a brilliant appearance in the boxes and in some places on the floor.

The formation of the Carlton M. Higbie Corporation to do an underwriting and general investment business in the Buhl Building, Detroit, was announced yesterday by Carlton M. Higbie, recently retired partner in the Detroit Stock Exchange firm of Alison Co. Duncan J. McNabb will be vice president and treasurer and E.J. Garvey, secretary.

THE 764 pages of the two new books on Adolf Hitler leave the puzzle still unsolved. It is all very well to say that Der Fuehrer's soul lies in his breath, that his heart pumps on his tongue, that the "barrenness of his soul is as nothing compared to the emptiness of his mind," as Rudolf Olden, author of "Hitler" (Covici, Friede, $3), believes.

ALBANY, May 11. -- A legislative investigation of justices of the Supreme Court and of the Appellate Division was threatened by John J. Dunnigan, President pro tem of the Senate, in a debate which ended just before midnight on a bill by Senator Byrne, Albany Democrat, to prevent the courts from modifying plans of reorganization proposed by the State Mortgage Commission except with the consent of the commission.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on May 6 shows increases for the week of $102,000,000 in total loans and investments, $42,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $29,000,000 in time deposits, $60,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks and $26,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of foreign banks.

Among the nine Manhattan properties bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday was the fifteen-story Peter Stuyvesant apartment house at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and Eleventh Street, taken over by the State Mortgage Commission on a $1,000 bid.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 11. -- Only 1,000 pounds of foodstuffs were put on board the Hindenburg this afternoon, since the airliner was provisioned in Germany for a round trip. The items are typical American edibles intended to please the American taste, Chief Steward Heinrich Kubis explained.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 11. -- With her red cream coach, the Valiant, bringing back to the motor-thronged highways the more colorful mode of transportation of an older generation, Mrs. Florence Evans Dibble tooled along the highway into Beachwood tonight, successfully completing the first half of her effort at breaking the coach record between New York and Atlantic City.

"Old Merchant's House" at 29 East Fourth Street, built a century ago by Seabury Tredwell, New York merchant, was opened to the public yesterday as a permanent historical museum by the Historic Landmark Society.

ST. PAUL, May 11 (AP). -- The Federal Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, ruled unconstitutional today one farm relief measure sponsored by Senator L.J. Frazier and Representative William Lemke, as the House in Washington voted to consider another.

Miss Anne Cutler heads a group of younger members of society who are assisting in the series of city garden tours for the benefit of the Anne Brown Alumnae Free Nursery School, the second of which will be held Thursday afternoon.

PARIS, May 11. -- Following Leon Blum's speech yesterday, the situ ation on the Bourse today was completely reversed. French securities took a quick leap forward, rentes and franc exchange recovered strongly and Bank of France shares regained no less than 960 francs of its last week's losses.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- A letter from President Roosevelt describing the American Red Cross as "truly a brotherhood of service," and praising "America's Legion of Mercy" for cooperation in efforts to "lessen the human suffering created by unemployment and the depression," was read today before the organization's annual convention.

Rent paid by the Western Union Telegraph Company under leases to three telegraph companies that exist merely for the purpose of collecting dividends is taxable as profits, even though the stockholder of the companies are virtually in the position of having to pay double income taxes, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- A program of development for the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, calling for the eventual investment of $3,500,000 in exhibits, research and endowment, was outlined today by Effingham B. Morris, the president, at a meeting of scientists, educators and civic leaders.

Beth Israel Hospital and other institutions facing Stuyvesant Square won yesterday on their plea to Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins for an injunction restraining Park Commissioner Robert Moses from continuing with the construction of children's playgrounds in Stuyvesant Square.

ST. LOUIS, May 11 (AP). -- A barrage of 22 hits, eight for extra bases, enabled the White Sox to sweep their series with St. Louis today, 19 -- 6, and sent the Browns to the showers smarting under their thirteenth straight defeat.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- Petey Sarron of Birmingham Ala., swarmed all over Freddie Miller tonight to win the world's featherweight boxing crown by decision after fifteen furious rounds at Griffith Stadium. Miller weighed 126 and Sarron 125 1/2.

The future of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society is entirely dependent on the support which it will receive from the public, since 75 per cent of the sum expended for its maintenance must be derived from the sale of seats. This was the concluding comment of the report of the society's president, Marshall Field, at the annual meeting at Steinway Hall yesterday afternoon.

Showing that he, too, could knit one, purl one with the best of the nation's feminine needle-wielders, 16-year-old David Sanderson of Winona, Miss., carried off the fourteenth prize in the National Knitting Contest, the winners of which were chosen by fashion experts yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The various charitable organizations which benefit by the proceeds of sales at the Bargain Box will be aided by a bundle tea and reception to be given tomorrow by Mrs. Stephen H. Philbin at her home, 174 East Seventieth Street. Guests have been requested to bring packages of useful articles suitable for resale later at the shop at 1,175 Third Avenue.

Eastbound passengers for the airship Hindenburg began reaching Lakehurst by airplane yesterday afternoon. American Airlines, operating a shuttle service to the dirigible with fourteen-passenger Douglas planes, had booked reservations for thirty-two of the forty- eight passengers for the airship's homeward voyage.

Group insurance will be made available to all members of the personnel of R.H. Macy Co. with two or more years of service through arrangements with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, it was announced yesterday to the executive staff by Percy S. Straus, president of the store.

With numerous publications, particularly magazines, starting to step up advertising rates again as circulation increases, national advertisers are beginning to offer resistance to the higher schedules, according to comment here yesterday. One of the leading weeklies has just sent out notices of an increase effective the first of next year and numerous other magazines have either announced, or will announce shortly, rate rises.

The large exhibition devoted to "Benjamin Franklin and His Circle" opened with an invitation preview yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum, where it will remain through the Summer, closing Sept. 13. It opens to the public today.
