Ali Baba successfully defended his recently acquired world's heavyweight wrestling crown at the New York Coliseum last night by tossing Ernest yon Heffner of Germany in a finish contest.
Properties in three States were included in the realty transactions reported yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11. -- Princeton University's unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps, composed of nearly 400 undergraduates, passed in review before Major Gen. Frank McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area, this afternoon on the old polo field adjoining Palmer Stadium.
In an editorial in Foreign Service, the official publication of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, the following statement is made:

Possibility of a strike of 100,000 woolen and worsted workers throughout the country to enforce demands for a 20 per cent wage increase and a third-five-hour week were revealed here yesterday when the United Textile Workers of America announced strike mobilization plans.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 11. -- Thirteen steps, ten rubber-cushioned and the bottom three all-metal, make up the slightly curved gangway on which passengers entered the super-Zeppelin Hindenburg to sail for Germany tonight.

Invitations have been received here for the marriage of Miss Valerie Stirling Prochnik, daughter of Edgar L.G. Prochnik, Austrian Minister to the United States, and Mrs. Prochnik, to Jean Raymond de Sibour, son of Viscount and Viscountess J. Henri de Sibour, on the afternoon of June 1 in St. Matthew's Church, Washington, D.C.

The estate of Joseph Leblang, cut-rate theatre ticket agency head, who died April 17, 1931, was appraised yesterday by Deputy Tax Commissioner Jacob Manicoff at $5,161,451, but debts and expenses reduced the net estate to $2,331,956. Most of it was in securities worth $2,545,103.

Tart criticism of Mayor La Guardia's views on borough government was voiced last night by Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn, usually one of the Mayor's stanchest supporters. Mr. Ingersoll spoke before the New York City Charter Revision Commission at the first borough hearing, held last night in the Supreme Court Building in the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn.

LONDON, May 11 (AP). -- Announcement was made today that combined army, navy and air force manoeuvres to test the defenses of Great Britain's Mediterranean station of Malta would start tomorrow and continue through Wednesday night.
JUST think of it. Connie Mack, the tall, thin, gentle dean of the diamond, is "rising 74" and still going strong in the hurly-burly of baseball. The man is a marvel in a mild and genial way.

LONDON, May 11. -- The stock market here was quiet today but the undertone was firm. British Government issues improved on renewed investment demand. Aircrafts, building shares and electrical equipment led the way among British industrials.

KANSAS CITY, May 11. -- Purification of a kidney extract which is believed to contain a powerful new hormone and which has relieved some intractable human cases of severe kidney disease and associated high blood pressure was reported here today at the annual scientific session of the Association for the Study of Internal Secretion by Dr. Benjamin Jablons of Jewish Memorial Hospital, New York City.

Price movements were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, copper and wool-top futures advanced and rubber, silk, hides and cottonseed-oil futures declined. On the cash markets eggs and Straits tin were higher, while declines were registered in wheat, corn, rye, oats, cotton, butter, lard, printcloths, silk and rubber.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- With the assurance that President Roosevelt would give any constructive suggestions for relieving the condition of the physically handicapped his "personal consideration and study," the delegation of New York cripples left here tonight to return to their homes at government expense.

BERLIN, May 11. -- The German Labor Office announced today that the number of registered unemployed had decreased another 174,000 during April, leaving a total of 1,763,000 still to be absorbed before the National Socialist scheme of liquidating all unemployment is achieved.

The suit brought in behalf of 682 subscribers to stock of the Schulte-United 1 Cent to $1 Stores, Inc., charging fraud and deceit in the sale of the stock, was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Valente on the ground that the plaintiffs had failed to prove their charges.

In a campaign to change the United States tariff law so that no American museum will again be forced to pay duty on importations of abstract art, the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, offered yesterday at the thirty-first annual meeting of the American Association of Museums a proposed amendment to the present law.

PARIS, May 11. -- Mrs. Henry Symes Lehr, widow of Harry Lehr, society leader in New York early in the century, will be married here on May 23 to John Graham Beresford, Lord Decies, Irish peer, according to an announcement made today.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The capture of Thomas H. Robinson Jr., long sought as the kidnapper of Mrs. Alice Speed Stoll of Louisville, was announced tonight by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Bureau of Investigation. The arrest was made tonight in Glendale, Calif.,

Brevity, Joseph E. Widener's beaten favorite in the Kentucky Derby, has been established the future book choice for the Belmont Stakes on June 6, according to prices posted yesterday. Brevity is held at 2-1 for the mile and a half 3-year-old test.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 11 (AP). -- The Bisons repulsed Syracuse today, 9 to 7. Pitcher Lefty Jacobs entered in the seventh inning with the score tied and two on to retire three consecutive batsmen. McGowan drove a homer, double and two singles to make it 14 safeties in his last twenty-one tries, ten of them for extra bases.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 11. -- Scoring a clean sweep against Nassau and Inwood, the Huntington Country Club assured itself of the championship in Class B, Section 2, of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Long Island tournament today at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- President Roosevelt received Dr. Hugo Eckener and Ambassador Luther; discussed with Senators McNary, Schwellenbach and Bone the means of marketing power from the Grand Coulee and Bonneville Dams, and gave assurance to a group of physically handicapped from New York that their plea for WPA jobs would receive his personal consideration.

It will not come altogether as a surprise that there are victims of allergy whose particular danger is conversation. When exposed to after-dinner speakers, whether professional or social, they suffer. Slight variations in heat, cold or fatigue will produce this condition. It is known as physical allergy, to be distinguished from plain allergy.

Among the numerous building projects filed yesterday were a $50,000 church rectory for East Twenty-first Street, Manhattan; two Bronx apartment houses to cost a total of $370,000, a $25,000 baby health center for Brooklyn and two dwelling groups for Queens to cost a total of $85,500.

Fifteen years ago yesterday the Right Rev. William T. Manning was consecrated Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, the largest, wealthiest and perhaps the most influential in the entire communion. Seventy years ago Bishop Manning was born in Northampton, England.
LONDON, May 11. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin indicated today that he was not in the least impressed with the glories of the new Roman Empire in Africa.

ALBANY, May 11. -- Governor Lehman made a dramatic appearance before the Senate and Assembly in joint session tonight, demanding again that the Assembly Rules Committee report and the Assembly take favorable action on his eight-point Social Security Bill, twice killed by the Republican lower house.
ALBANY, May 11. -- New York City magistrates received the power to punish for contempt of court under the Buckley bill signed today by Governor Lehman.

BARTOW, Fla., May 11. -- Manuel A. Menendez, police stenographer to former Police Chief R.G. Tittsworth of Tampa, one of the seven defendants in the flogging trial here, stood on his constitutional rights today and refused to testify as a State witness on the ground that his testimony might incriminate himself.
Thrilling play marked the opening of competition yesterday in the twenty-first annual tennis tournament of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, L.I.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- A Winter wheat crop of 463,708,000 bushels was forecast today by the Federal crop reporting board on the basis of May 1 crop conditions equaling 67 per cent of normal. The estimate today was nearly 30,000,000 bushels less than was forecast a month ago and reflected inroads made by drought during the month.
Andre de Laboulaye, French Ambassador to the United States, accompanied by Mme. de Laboulaye and their daughter, will sail tonight for Europe on the French liner Normandie.

JERUSALEM, May 11. -- Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope broadcast on the radio tonight an explanation of the recent increase in the Palestine garrison. He said the rise of lawlessness in the last few weeks necessitated greater mobility for the military forces to enable them to deal more rapidly with the situation should renewed disturbances occur.
Irving Eldridge, East Side lightweight, dropped twice in early rounds, rallied to outpoint Al Casimini of Corona before 3,000 persons in the main ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Palace last night.

In unusually heavy balloting members of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday re-elected Charles R. Gay as president for one year, and Benjamin H. Brinton as treasurer. They were unopposed candidates. Nine of the ten men nominated on the official slate for membership on the governing committee for four-year terms were re-elected.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- Decision was reached at a White House conference today to consolidate provisions in various Columbia River power bills and report a composite measure which would be flexible enough to adopt as the basis for a national power policy for Federal dams constructed in the future.

It is reported from Berlin that HITLER will take his time about answering the queries addressed to him by the British Government, if, indeed, he ever replies to them at all. Yet they are very much to the point. They are a direct and necessary response to the proposals which HITLER himself made to Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Administration leaders on the Senate Finance Committee were forced to move swiftly today to prevent substantial alteration or possible deletion of the House's version of President Roosevelt's corporation profits tax proposal until Treasury experts could answer the volumes of protests leveled at the measure during the recent public hearings.

Although sentiment in Wall Street is dependent to a great extent upon the trend of prices on the Stock Exchange, it is almost equally dependent on the volume of trading; for the latter affects employment in the financial district, the profits of Stock Exchange firms, and the value of one of their most important assets -- the memberships that they hold in the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The parallel between the plight of the administration's present corporate surplus tax bill and its inheritance tax measure of 1935 is now almost exact. And, unless the President insists upon the corporate tax in the present form, it will go the way of the inheritance levies which he abandoned when the Senate Finance Committee revolted against them.

MOSCOW, May 11. -- The movement of the Soviet's leisured women -- the wives of better-paid industrial executives who do not need to work for wages -- to improve cultural conditions among workers is taking the same course into which the Stakhanoff efficiency movement was guided last Fall when the government began welding it into a nation-wide system for increasing industrial production.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Filings under the Securities Act of 1933 today included the registration by the John Irving Shoe Corporation of Boston for the issuance of 24,000 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock, $25 par value; 24,000 detachable common stock purchase warrants and 46,500 shares of $1-par value common stock of which 24,000 are to be reserved for the exercise of warrants.

NEWARK, N.J., May 11. -- In a hearing involving one-half of a $1,000,000 trust fund left by Charles Barsotti, late publisher of Il Progreso Italo-Americano, New York Italian daily, Frederick W. Gahrmann of Jamaica, L.I., testified today that Milford F. Gahrmann of New Rochelle, brought up by him as his son since the age of 2 years, was not his son but a waif taken into his home.

The salaries of most officers of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad were increased in 1935, it is disclosed in its report for that year to the Interstate Commerce Commission, made public yesterday. The salaries of the three highest officers remained unchanged.

Ospreys and humming birds, ducks and cuckoos and myriads of brilliantly colored warblers have been paying a Spring visit to Central Park and other open spaces in the metropolitan area, the National Association of Audubon Societies reported yesterday.
ALBANY, May 11. -- Following is the text of the special message delivered by Governor Lehman in person at a joint session of the Senate and Assembly tonight:

A spending cycle of long duration, "that will doubtless provide a solution for the entire unemployment problem," was predicted here yesterday by J.M. Mathes, head of the advertising agency that bears his name, following an extensive checkup on the industrial research work in the country's most important laboratories.

LONDON, May 11.--Leslie Thomas, stock broker son of the Colonial Secretary, J.H. Thomas, today admitted having taken out thousands of pounds of last-minute insurance with Lloyd's last month against rises in the income tax and tea duty.

Samuel Reshevsky and Albert C. Simonson, each with a score of 10 -- 3, remained tied for the lead after last night's matches in the United States title chess tournament. Eight games in the thirteenth round were contested and four played to a decision.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 11.--Jim Dante, a freckle-faced New Jersey professional, making the second attempt in his career to qualify for the national open golf championship, led a field of 196 candidates home in today's metropolitan district test over the Inwood and Seawane courses.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Pointing the way toward lower counsel fees in railroad reorganization cases, the Interstate Commerce Commission today reduced from $75,000 to $25,000 the maximum charge for legal work in the gold-clause case by lawyers for trustees of the St. Louis, Iron Mountain Southern Railway's River and Gulf Division mortgage.

The Federal Theatre Project has taken the Adelphi Theatre at 145-57 West Fifty-third Street, and will begin rehearsals immediately for the production there of "The Dance of Death," a satirical play in verse by W.H. Auden, which will open on Tuesday, May 19.

ROME, May 11. -- While Geneva is discussing what should be done about sanctions, Marshal Pietro Badoglio is systematically carrying out the occupation of the country for whose benefit they were originally imposed.

Taking off on her return to Germany from Lakehurst at 11:27 o'clock last night, with a forty-five-hour record from coast to coast as the goal of her commander, the Zeppelin Hindenburg flew over New York with her searchlight waving in farewell at 12:06 o'clock this morning as she sped toward Frankfort, Germany, her home port.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- Prices of hogs continued on the down grade here today, the top dropping 30 cents a hundredweight from Friday to $9.80, while the day's average was down 25 cents at $9.40. For eighteen days prices have been working irregularly lower and are down $1.20 to $1.25 from April 24, the last time hogs sold at $11.

Ground will be broken at Cicero and Castle Hill Avenues, in the East Bronx, Saturday, on the first house of the Castle Hill Gardens development, a large single-house project, approved by the Federal Housing Administration, which its developers, Alderman Charles Keegan and Thomas McEvily, say ultimately will include more than 1,000 houses and occupy about twenty city blocks in the area bounded by Castle Hill, Pugsley, Lacombe and Turnbull Avenues.

An increase of $2 or $3 a ton in the price of finished steel products for delivery in the third quarter of this year was predicted yesterday by steel company executives. The increase will be announced near the end of this month, it was believed.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Consideration was given by the State Department last August to sending a warship to the Red Sea to act as a naval radio relay station with Addis Ababa, but the plan was abandoned to avoid criticism at home and possible international friction.

MADRID, May 11. -- Republican Spain revived much of the monarchy's pomp and splendor this afternoon in inaugurating her new President, Hanuel Azana, in the Cortes building. Less than two years ago he was a prisoner on a warship in Barcelona Harbor on a charge of having conspired to overthrow the government then in power.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Opening headquarters here today, representatives of Labor's Non-Partisan League called on President Roosevelt at the White House, informed him of the formation of the union organization to work for his re-election, and stated that 30,000 union officials in the various States had authorized the use of their names as sponsors for the league.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- Remuneration of $100,000 in both 1935 and 1934 to J.W. Van Dyke as chairman of the Atlantic Refining Company of Philadelphia was shown today in the company's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The North River waterfront from Twentieth to Twenty-third Street became a battleground last night when a squad of about sixty policemen waded into a crowd of striking seamen who insisted upon maintaining a picket line in front of the Chelsea piers of the International Mercantile Marine Company.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's 1936-37 production schedule will consist of from forty-four to fifty-two feature-length pictures and 194 short subjects, it was announced here yesterday coincident with the opening of the company's annual sales convention at the Palmer House in Chicago.

Some weeks ago the Legislature adopted, and Governor LEHMAN signed, a measure making a significant change in the penal system of the State. Although a part of his crime program, the Neustein bill, discussed in a letter to the editor on this page yesterday, has not received the public attention it deserves.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 11 (AP). -- Hundreds of unemployed men and women, many of them in shirt sleeves, shouted their demand to the special session of the Legislature tonight for $121,000,000 for food, clothing and rent.

In the opinion of some of its supporters, the proposed corporation tax solely on undistributed profits is desirable, not primarily because it means "equality of taxation" as among stockholders but because it would prevent corporations from "saving excessively." This is the point emphasized by Professor TUGWELL in his book, "The Industrial Discipline," published in 1933.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- While the members of the Australian team rested the United States Davis Cup tennis players indulged in their first formal workout at the Merion Cricket Club today for the American Zone final to be played at Germantown May 30, 31 and June 1.

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County made his fifth appearance yesterday before the extraordinary grand jury which is now investigating charges of bribery and police brutality in the Drukman murder case. William W. Kleinman, an assistant on his staff, was also called before the grand jury.

MANTOLOKING, N.J., May 11. -- Mrs. Margaret Van N. Storer, wife of David Storer, a Philadelphia broker and well-known yachtsman, was in a serious condition tonight in Beach Boroughs Hospital at Point Pleasant following an early morning attempt to kill herself by slashing her wrists with a razor blade.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11. -- Four stars, two of them record holders, are listed for the quarter-mile event in the third annual Princeton invitation track meet on June 13, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics at the university.
The government's estimate of condition, acreage and indicated yield for Winter wheat compares as follows with similar estimates of April 1, 1936, and May 1, 1935:

Joseph Curran, chairman of the provisional committee of striking Atlantic Coast seamen, submitted yesterday a series of proposals to the National Committee on Safety at Sea for the improvement of conditions in American shipping, particularly with respect to working and living conditions of seamen.

The Republican county chairmen of the five counties in New York City urged last night in a telegram to Speaker Irving M. Ives that the Social Security Bill, sponsored by Governor Lehman, be reported out of the Rules Committee of the Assembly, where it has been held up, and passed by the Assembly.
For the second time since the electric chair was substituted for the gallows in New York State in 1889, a group of six men yesterday was delivered to Sing Sing to be put to death in the same week.
BALTIMORE, May 11 (AP). -- The Bomar Stable's Grand Slam proved he was nearing Preakness form by turning in an impressive workout on the Pimlico course today.

Hot weather at the week-end cut into the initial stocks of Summer merchandise of retailers in many sections and mail reorders in the wholesale markets here yesterday were more numerous than a week ago. The number of buyers to be here this week will also show a substantial increase, according to the resident buying offices.

KANSAS CITY, May 11. -- The insurance principle in the provision of medical care for persons of moderate income was described in a report today to the house of delegates of the American Medical Association by the association's Bureau of Medical Economics as "reasonable in theory," but with a warning that its "application introduces many dangers that should not be overlooked."

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Triumphing over the Democratic leadership, the inflation bloc in the House today mustered 220 votes to the conservatives' 153, and thus discharged the Rules Committee from further consideration of the Frazier-Lemke bill appropriating $3,000,000,000 for farm mortgage relief.

VILNA, Poland, May 11. -- A funeral roll-call, preceded by military music by the massed bands of the Vilna garrison, tonight opened the ceremonies commemorating the first anniversary of Marshal Josef Pilsudski's death. Tomorrow the late dictator's heart will be buried at the foot of his mother's grave in the military cemetery at Rossa.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- After receipt of a formal warning that the supremacy of the United States in aeronautical research is "threatened" by four foreign nations, government officials today planned accelerated activity in this field.

Murray Patrick won the heavyweight championship of the Catholic Youth Association at Madison Square Garden last night. The son of the manager of the New York Rangers' hockey team gained the crown by defeating Bill Gould, courageous and clever Bronx battler, in what turned out to be the feature bout of the C.Y.A.'s second annual boxing tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Passage of the Pettengill Bill, which would eliminate the existing long-and-short-haul clause in the Interstate Commerce Act, was urged today before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee by representatives of the Association of American Railroads.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 11. -- The first ballot for the election of three Bishops at the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, counted today, resulted in the casting of 546 effective votes for a total of 142 persons, with fifty-one getting five or more votes and sixty-three one vote each.

PARIS, May 11. -- In further proof of the importance Leon Blum, Socialist leader, who is to be France's next Premier, attaches to getting Communists into his government, he and the Socialist executive committee today sent another letter to the Communist leaders offering participation.

Judge ROSALSKY first sat upon the bench of General Sessions by appointment. He had been an active Republican politician. He was defeated, if we remember rightly, as a Republican candidate for a place on that court. He was only a little over 30 when Governor HIGGINS gave him the post in which he has served with such distinction and such satisfaction to the public for nearly a generation.

A public offering by means of a prospectus of 50,000 shares of cumulative preference stock of the Domestic Finance Corporation will be made today by Hammons Co., Inc., the concern announced yesterday. The shares, which are part of the 96,848 registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, are priced at $28 each.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- A last-ditch fight by the American Trucking Associations, Inc., against unrestricted store-door-collection-and-delivery service by Eastern railroads, as authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission, was forecast today by that organization.

A committee representing independent wholesale fish dealers yesterday protested the alleged action of the Fulton Street Fishmongers Association forbidding them the use of Piers 17 and 18, East River and access to the fishing boats docking there.

This is the happy and proud sobriquet by which the nurses who have completed the post-graduate courses under the auspices of the Florence Nightingale International Foundation speak of themselves as they keep in touch with one another in the nearly half-hundred countries through which they are scattered.

The State of Kentucky has invited bankers to submit bids on May 29 for two new issues of bonds, aggregating $5,465,000. The financing consists of an issue of $4,240,000 of bonds of Bridge Project No. 1 and $1,225,000 of bonds of Bridge Project No. 2.
Four persons were killed in the metropolitan area yesterday in traffic accidents and several others were injured, one seriously.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 11. -- Felix Spatola's Wise Prince, making his second start of the meeting, won the Pawtucket Handicap at six furlongs for 3-year-olds and up in the fast time of 1:10 4-5 at Narragansett Park today.

Thirty-eight more Brooklyn skippers will have formal induction into the ranks of trained navigators, tried and true, at a dinner and initiation of the Brooklyn unit of the United States Power Squadrons tonight. In a proclamation in the name of "H.R.H. Neptune-Rex" but actually signed by Commander Charles J. Kappelmann, the Brooklyn members have been summoned to greet the newcomers at the Tally-Ho Casino, Kimball Street and Avenue U.

RICHMOND, Va., May 11. -- The American Library Association's convention at its opening session today voted to request Federal aid following a plea for extension of library service to 45,000,000 persons now without it.
DETROIT, May 11 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers climbed back into the first division in the American League today by defeating the Cleveland Indians, 8 -- 3.

The franc rallied sharply yesterday in response to the declaration of Leon Blum, head of the Socialist Party in the Chamber of Deputies, that devaluation would be strongly resisted. The pronouncement, which amounted to a restatement of socialist policy, induced heavy short-covering with a resultant rise in the franc to 6.60 3/8 cents, the highest since April 7.

Although the number of passengers carried by the New York Central Railroad decreased by almost 2.5 per cent in 1935, passenger revenue increased slightly, according to the report for the year issued yesterday by F.E. Williamson, president.

The proposal to tax the undistributed profits of corporations is in itself wrong in principle and dangerous to the economic future of the country, but, considered in the light of recently adopted legislation which is adverse to the formation of capital, the proposal becomes ominous in the extreme, according to Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank.

The annual competitions for the American Academy in Rome fellowships are being held this week. An exhibition composed of competitive designs submitted in the fields of painting, sculpture, architecture and landscape architecture opened yesterday at the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries, to remain current until Saturday.

Raymond Ariola, 27 years old, a former legal aide on the staff of Thomas E. Dewey in his extraordinary Supreme Court investigation of racketeering; Dr. Leo A. Ariola, 26, a brother, and Saul A. Schwartz, 26, also an attorney, were arraigned in Special Sessions yesterday on two "informations" accusing them of ambulance chasing.
CALLANDER, Ont., May 11. -- The Keys quadruplets of Waco, Texas, and Hollis, Okla., presented to the Dionne quintuplets today four-year scholarships at Baylor University in Texas, which they attend.

ALBANY, May 11. -- Factory employment rose 0.6 per cent in New York State from the middle of March to mid-April, while payrolls fell 0.7 per cent, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported today. Usually in that period there are decreases of 0.8 per cent and 1.8 per cent.

Legal aid for the poor in the municipal courts and the small claims courts of New York City has been made a WPA project, and twenty-four unemployed lawyers have been assigned to the various courts, it was announced yesterday.

The April term of the Queens grand jury yesterday handed up a presentment to County Judge Charles S. Colden of Queens criticizing the county Democratic organization for "vicious practice" in dispensing jobs.

For a brief period at noon yesterday the legal mechanism of Yorkville Court was transferred to the soft turf beneath a large sycamore tree in Central Park. There Magistrate Peter A. Abeles, surrounded by court clerks, stenographers, witnesses and a crowd of the curious witnessed a partial reenactment of the alleged running down of a small child by a horseman two weeks ago.

At times speeding as much as seventy miles an hour with the help of tail-winds, the Zeppelin Hindenburg was far out over the Atlantic last night on her 3,900-mile journey from Lakehurst, N.J., to Frankfort, Germany, with forty-eight passengers and about two tons of mail and express cargo.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Wednesday, May 13 (AP). -- Halting returns early today from West Virginia Presidential primaries showed President Roosevelt polling a greater vote in his Democratic contest than was cast for Senator Borah in the Republican Presidential preference contest.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 12. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener's name crept back into Nazi newspapers today, and district party leaders here announced that they intended to present a silver cup to him when the Zeppelin Hindenburg returns from her inaugural North American flight.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Politics will use music in a new way at the Cleveland and Philadelphia conventions if plans of the Republican and Democratic National Committees are carried out.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was above the figures for the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES . The arrivals for the week numbered 745, as against 691 in the previous week and 623 in the same period last year.

GENEVA, May 12. -- Obeying a peremptory order from Rome. Baron Pompeo Aloisi, with the entire Italian delegation to the League of Nations Council meeting, made a dramatic exit from Geneva this afternoon. Within an hour after their departure the Council adopted the following resolution:

The execution of trade buying orders at the opening of the Cotton Exchange yesterday established a new high level on May contracts, which enabled houses doing government business to release between 10,000 and 15,000 bales, the largest distribution in a single day.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Here is the new corporate undistributed profits tax schedule submitted today by the Treasury to the Senate Finance Committee:

Apartment house corners in Riverside Drive, Broadway and St. Nicholas and Third Avenues were among the nine Manhattan parcels bought in at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. A Ninth Avenue garage block front and a Bowery loft structure also were included.
About forty stockholders of the Delaware Hudson Company gathered yesterday in the offices of the company for their annual meeting.

Following a special meeting of the reconstituted board of directors of American Type Founders, Inc., formerly the American Type Founders Company, Thomas R. Jones, president, announced yesterday that preparations were being made for the delivery of new securities, to be issued under the reorganization plan, to creditors and stockholders of the company.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., May 12. -- Burgess Joseph J. Lukasik today announced the horsewhip for "jaywalkers" as another of the punitive measures he has established in the near-by mining town of Du Pont.

The American Legion of Kings County, through its commander, James M. Clark, attacked yesterday a ruling of officials at Fort Hamilton that military firing squads would not be provided during the Summer for funerals of World War veterans unless the veterans had died of wounds or illnesses contracted during the war.

CAMP NO. 3, Mount Everest, Tibet, May 12 (by Wireless via Calcutta). -- The main body of the 1936 British Mount Everest Expedition is now at Camp No. 3, which has been established at a new site, not far from the foot of the North colslopes, at a height of about 21,500 feet.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 12. -- Jeffrey Plate, member of the Garden City Country Club, today led a small field in the one-day amateur tournament of the Long Island Golf Association by scoring 77 on the Brookville Country Club course.

In keeping with its intention to present programs of unusual quality the Philharmonic-Symphony Society announced yesterday that Artur Rodzinski would direct at least three important works during his directorship of the orchestra next season.

JERUSALEM, May 12. -- Emperor Hale Selassie decided today to leave soon for London for a short stay and then to proceed to Geneva to plead the case of Ethiopia before the session of the League of Nations Council opening on June 15.

As an aftermath of the recent court-martial of Captain Ralph E. Fleischer of Fort Slocum, near New Rochelle, N.Y., the War Department has ordered the transfer of many officers at the post, it was learned yesterday.

MADRID, Wednesday, May 13. -- Santiago Casares Quiroga, close friend of President Manuel Azana and energetic Minister of the Interior in the last Cabinet, announced at 2 o'clock this morning the formation of a new government. His ministerial list follows:

MONTREAL, May 12 (Canadian Press). -- The Montreal Royals won the opener of their three-game series with Newark today, 3 -- 2, in spite of Ernie Koy's homer for the Bears with one on base and two out in the ninth. Montreal's first-place margin over Newark went to two full games.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 12. -- Two white Bishops were elected today by the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, meeting here. They are the Rev. Dr. Wilbur E. Hammaker of Youngstown, Ohio, and the Rev. Dr. Charles W. Flint, chancellor of Syracuse University.
Far from the land of windmills and dikes, an old Holland atmosphere descended upon Forty-second Street yesterday afternoon with the formal opening of the Tudor City Tulip Gardens.

The erection of a new $2,500,000 structure to house Lebanon Hospital will begin toward the end of next month, it was announced last night at the annual commencement exercises of the Lebanon Hospital School of Nursing.

Settlement of the dispute that has been going on for two months between the Dramatists Guild and the League of New York Theatres over the terms of a mutually acceptable minimum basic agreement covering the production of plays was virtually assured yesterday with the ratification by members of the league of a compromise agreement negotiated by representatives of the two groups.

The member lines of the Atlantic Passenger Conference agreed unanimously yesterday to protest to mayor La Guardia and Dock Commissioner John McKenzie against the new city regulation barring concessionaire taxicabs from the city-owned piers.

MEXICO, D.F., May 12. -- The State of Puebla section of the Regional Federation of Mexican Workmen and Agricultural Laborers will stage a parade of 30,000 here tomorrow as a protest against decisions of the national revolutionary party subsequent to the recent primaries in the State.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP). -- Bill Brubaker and Charley Lucas pulled the Pirates out of the ruck today, but the visitors were forced to share a 6-6 tie with the Bees. Darkness and an approaching thunderstorm halted the game after ten innings.

Business failures in the manufacturing, wholesale, retail and commercial service groups in the week ended May 7 dropped below their m average for the first nineteen weeks of this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Following reputed assurances from President Roosevelt that he would accept a compromise on his proposed tax on undistributed corporate profits, Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee today submitted a tentative plan which he hoped might form the basis for an early agreement within the committee and guarantee quick passage of a bill by the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12. -- Under a warm sun, members of the Australian Davis Cup team engaged in their first workout at the Germantown Cricket Club courts today in preparation for the American zone cup final with the United States, beginning May 30.

WASMTNGTON, May 12. -- Temporary flood control to permit immediate rehabilitation work in Eastern areas which suffered from the Spring floods was placed by President Roosevelt today on the list of legislation which he hoped Congress could act upon before adjournment.
Chain store sales in April made the best showing thus far this year, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc., and Hammons Co., Inc.

Big Chief Sanooke, 339 3/4, Oklahoma, threw Ernst Von Heffner, 228, Germany, in 19:37 of their bout last night at the St. Nicholas (Palace before a crowd of 2,500 fans. The winner used a pick-up and body slam to end the bout.

Voters in eleven New Jersey municipalies having the commission form of government, including Montclair, Nutley, Ridgefield Park, Long Branch and Atlantic City, went to the polls yesterday is elect new governing boards. Reports of the elections follow:

James V. Martin, aviation expert, who in his time has sued many corporations and individuals, began an action yesterday in Federal court for $90,000,000 against practically the entire aviation industry.

The last of the kidnappers is in the hands of the Department of Justice's able G-men. The Federal slate of public enemies has been wiped clean. Within the space of ten days Washington has announced the capture of three big outlaws, beginning with ALVIN KARPIS, our distinguished No. 1.

Casey Stengel won two decisions over Frankie Frisch's league-leading Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday but the 7,500 fans missed the second contest. They saw the Dodgers assail Dizzy Dean for thirteen hits to win, 5 -- 2, while Ed Brandt was holding the Gas-House Gang to four, and they observed Frisch losing two arguments with Umpire Beans Reardon.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 12 (AP). -- The Bisons won their sixth straight game today, defeating Syracuse, 10 to 8, in a home-run-studded slugging match.

Charles Mattmann of Trinity and Walter Meserole of Lincoln reached the final round of the twenty-first annual tournament for the championship of the Athletic Association of Private Schools yesterday on the hard courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills.

ALBANY, May 12. -- With a statement that receipts from the New York personal income tax to date amounted to $73,496,169, Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, announced today the opening of a drive against delinquent income taxpayers.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- The "heartfelt gratitude" of Pennsylvania to the American Red Cross for its "magnificent response" last March in the flood disaster was voiced here tonight by Governor George H. Earle.

Mayor La Guardia and Victor F. Ridder, WPA administrator, returned from Washington late yesterday with the question of Mr. Ridder's successor still unsettled after a conference with Harry L. Hopkins, Federal WPA administrator.
The Chase National Bank and associates will offer today the $4,907,000 of New York City 4 percent rapid transit subway bonds, for which they made yesterday the highest bid at the RFC's auction.
DETROIT, May 12 (AP). -- Victor Sorrell held the Boston Red Sox to three hits today as the champion Detroit Tigers repulsed the first Eastern team to invade Navin Field this season, 5 to 0.

BERLIN, May 12. -- The Brotherhood Council of the Confessional Church has been summoned to meet tomorrow to consider ways of halting the paralysis affecting the Confessional Synods. The trouble is again appearing between pastors and local Nazi party functionaires in various parts of Germany.

TOKYO, May 12. -- Explaining in a secret Diet session yesterday evening the reasons causing Japan's armament expenditures to rise, Admiral Osami Nagano, the Navy Minister, pleaded the United States naval expansion policy as a cause compelling the Japanese Navy to follow suit.

Neisner Bros., Inc., reconsidered the declaration of a quarterly dividend of 25 cents declared on May 11 and will pay 37 1/2 cents, payable June 15 to stock of record May 29. This places the stock on an annual rate of $1.50 against $1 previously.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12. -- With an excellent entry, the Atlantic City Horse Show opened tonight at the Auditorium, the officials being forced by additional classes and the number of exhibitors to extend the event from four days to five.

TRENTON, May 12. -- As had been expected by political observers, there will be no action by the Legislature on the financing of emergency relief in New Jersey until after the primary elections next Tuesday.

Two judges of the Court of General Sessions and two Supreme Court justices were endorsed for re-election last night by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at its annual meeting at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- Prices of wheat were persistently on the downgrade today after having opened fractionally higher than yesterday's last quotations as a result of a bullish construction placed on the government report issued late yesterday.

PROBABLY even Bob Jones was chagrined at the setback suffered by one of his business associates. As for many others who are interested in the strange game called golf, you could have knocked them down with a niblick yesterday when they learned that W. Lawson Little had failed to qualify for the open golf championship.

A plan to save at least $4,000,000 in the city's annual police and fire protection bills was outlined yesterday by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., speaking at a luncheon meeting of the Lions Club of New York at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The fight on the $1,500,000,000 work-relief portion of the Second Deficiency Bill opened vigorously in the Senate today. Two substitute measures and an added appropriation of $700,000,000 for public works were proposed.

LONDON, May 12. -- Today's debate in the House of Lords on collective security, and rival motions, submitted in the House of Commons on the advisability otherwise of continuing sanctions against Italy, have revealed a split among the government's supporters in both houses.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12. -- A substantial upturn in business during the past year was reported by delegates to two large conventions here today.
KANSAS CITY, May 12 (AP). -- Lord Horder of London, physician to King Edward VIII, proposed a new interpretation of disease today to the American Medical Association.

A somewhat better tone prevailed in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange on a moderate increase in trading. The improvement extended over a fairly broad list, including foreign dollar loans as well as domestic issues. Total transactions were $7,068,300, compared with $6,714,500 on Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- A charge that Germany has consistently tried to mislead the Mixed Claims Commission regarding the Reich's attitude toward sabotage in the United States during the World War, and particularly in the Black Tom and Kingsland explosions, was made by representatives of this country today as they sought to reopen suits involving $40,000,000 arising from the two cases.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- A compromise on ship-subsidy legislation was declared a possibility at the present session by Chairman Copeland of the Commerce Committee today after reaching a working arrangement with Senator Guffey, author of the chief rival of the Copeland bill.

The Board of Elections announced yesterday that it had received a communication from the New York City Charter Revision Commission announcing the commission's decision to submit the proposed new charter, and a separate question on election of the City Council by proportional representation, to the people at the general election in November.

Greenwich Village artists are going ahead with their plans for a Spring exhibition on the sidewalks around Washington Square, despite the withdrawal of the Artists Aid Committee, sponsors of the semi-annual shows, it was announced yesterday by Brandon Barbour, 146 Macdougal Street.

From a room that had once been part of a slum, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt sent forth yesterday an appeal to every woman who "has an interest in her own children and in the future of our country," to concern herself with better housing.

A survey of the outlaw strike of seaman which has been going on in New York and other Atlantic Coast ports for the last two months indicates the existence of what appears to be potentially a highly inflammable situation.

Notice has been received by the New York Stock Exchange from the Container Corporation of America of the proposed increase in authorized common stock to 1,250,000 shares and the creation of 200,000 shares of $50 par preferred stock, convertible or with warrants.

The French franc resumed its downward trend yesterday as the sustaining effects of short-covering, which had lifted it strongly on Monday, began to wear off. The exchange dropped to 6.58 5/8 cents and closed at 6.59 5/8 cents, off 5/8 point on the day. As the franc declined, sterling advanced 1 3/8 cents to $4.97 3/4.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- President Roosevelt sent the London Naval treaty to the Senate, revealed at his press conference that he desired legislation at this session of Congress on flood relief and a Federal power rate policy, and discussed New York's World's Fair plans with Grover Whalen and Representative Bloom.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- J. Edgar Hoover said today that Thomas H. Robinson Jr. had not only admitted kidnapping Mrs. Stoll but had told Federal agents that his first plan was to kidnap C.C. Stoll, father-in-law of his victim.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 12. -- A home run by Carl Miller in the ninth inning gave Rutgers a 10-to-6 victory over Princeton today. With the bases full, two out and the score tied at 6-all, the Scarlet sophomore cracked the ball over the center field fence for a homer.

New cases of diphtheria in the city totaled 63 last week, the largest number for any week this year, the Department of Health reported yesterday. For the corresponding period last year only 29 cases were reported.

LEON BLUM expects soon to be occupying that Castle Dangerous, the French Premiership. He is the leader of the largest Socialist party in France, but has been hastening to assure French business and finance that he contemplates no disturbing policy, much less one revolutionary.

DUBLIN, May 12. -- The most spectacular item of the government's fifth budget, introduced by Sean MacEntee, the Minister of Finance, in the Assembly this evening, was a big employment program for the Free State costing 2,500,000.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Following is the State Department's analysis of the new French trade agreement:

The American Academy in Rome announced yesterday afternoon the winners of its annual competitions in sculpture, architecture and landscape architecture. The winner of the competition in painting was not announced as the jury needed 'more time to come to a decision.

The times require not only a revision but a revolution in museum philosophy, Edward S. Robinson, Professor of Psychology and chairman of the Division of General Graduate Studies at Yale University, told delegates to the thirty-first annual meeting of the American Association of Museums yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 12. -- With a decrease of $16,500,000 last year from 1934, fire losses in the United States were the lowest since 1916, according to Robert S. Moulton of Boston, chairman of the Fire Records Committee of the National Fire Prevention Association.
For his recent flight across Antarctica, Lincoln Ellsworth, Arctic and Antarctic explorer, received the medal of the Explorers Club at a dinner last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Five to six years must elapse before raw cotton exports become a big factor in Brazilian export trade, J.D. Bohan, chairman of the foreign trade section of the Proprietary Association, said yesterday before the Export Managers' Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday that their earnings in the quarter ended on March 31 amounted to $2,255,139 after ordinary taxes, depreciation, depletion and minority interest but before Federal income taxes. For the corresponding quarter of 1935 they showed a net profit of $622,150 after Federal taxes and other deductions.

Asked to name psychological factors most often responsible for automobile accidents, 142 of the nation's leading psychologists emphasized inattention, 118 also specified lack of judgment, 106 recklessness, 94 thoughtlessness, 81 love of speed, 87 slow wits and 61 excitement.

DEVILS LAKE, N.D., May 12 (AP). -- Postmaster General James A. Farley said today that the people knew "the work of recovery is only half done," and predicted they would give to President Roosevelt full opportunity to complete it by "the greatest endorsement received by any of our Chief Executives since the birth of parties in this country."

Battle lines for the sharp fight expected when the Actors Equity Association chooses ten members of its council and four replacements were drawn tighter yesterday as the "regular" and "independent" forces set forth opposing claims. The election will be held at the annual meeting on May 25 at the Hotel Astor.

The new trade treaty between France and the United States is in several ways the most important trade agreement negotiated by Secretary HULL -- a fine vindication of the reciprocal tariff policy of the Roosevelt Administration. It will not affect so large a volume of trade as the treaty concluded with Canada last November.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Five more applications for permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of foreign securities, or American shares representing foreign issues, have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was announced today.

George B. Elliott, president of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad, received a salary of $22,500 in 1935, according to the report of the company for that year to the Interstate Commerce Commission. Lyman Delano, chairman and executive vice president, received $27,000, and C. McD. Davis, vice president, $18,000.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The Narragansett Electric Company has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Act of 1935 for exemption from filing a declaration for a proposed issue and sale of $34,000,000 of three-year notes, with interest of not more than 3 per cent, to be used as collateral in obtaining bank loans to retire outstanding bonds.

VATICAN CITY, May 12. -- State interference with religion in Russia and Germany was decried today by Pope Pius in a speech to delegates from various parts of the world at the opening of an international Catholic press exhibition.

Short casts: Ray Benson relays word that fishermen trolling from rowboats and outboards are making nice catches of striped bass in the Niantic River, Connecticut. . . . A party of three landed thirteen fish one day last week. . . . The biggest striper taken so far weighed fourteen pounds. . . .

The National Executive Committee of the Socialist party has restored the charter of the New York State Socialist party, suspended last December, Jack Altman, city executive secretary, announced yesterday. The restored charter has been vested in the State Committee elected at the recent State convention in Buffalo.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 12 (AP). -- F.J. Conley's My Blaze got up in a driving finish to nose out C.A. Peck's Bartering Kate, the odds-on favorite, in the Lions Club Purse, today's principal attraction at Churchill Downs.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 12 (AP). -- Thomas H. Robinson Sr. said the flying of his son from California to Louisville today by Department of Justice agents was a "display of showmanship."

Under the lofty Gothic arches of the recently completed nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, more than 3,000 ministerial and lay friends of the Right Rev. William T. Manning paid honor to him late yesterday afternoon at a service of thanksgiving.

ALBANY, May 12. -- Following up his charges at last night's session of serious irregularities by justices of the Supreme Court and the Appellate Division in connection with the reorganization of mortgages, John J. Dunnigan, president pro tem of the Senate, caused a resolution to be introduced today providing for a legislative investigation.

A voluntary association of industry on a city-wide scale, with business concerns pledging themselves to expand payrolls 1 per cent each month for seven months, was proposed yesterday by the WPA as a means of taking 175,000 relief workers off its rolls.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Following is an analysis of American trade with France:

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace said today that farmers had a choice "between an improved income and a moderate amount of imports on the one hand, and a low income and practically no imports on the ether hand."

BALTIMORE, May 12. -- The Wheatley Stable's Teufel worked a mile in the sparkling time of 1:39 today and served notice he is rounding into top form for the forty-sixth running of the historic Preakness Stakes.

VILNA, Poland, May 12. -- A gravestone with these simple words, "A mother and her son's heart," closed the mausoleum where Marshal Josef Pilsudski's heart and his mother's body were laid to rest today in the little wayside Rossa Cemetery amid 200 Polish soldiers killed in battles for the liberation of Vilna in 1919.

Mayor La Guardia, who on Monday night attended "Carmen," the opening performance of the Metropolitan popular season, yesterday sent a telegram of congratulations to Edward Johnson, the Metropolitan's general manager. The telegram read:

The jury was completed at 8:08 o'clock last evening for the trial of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and nine other men accused of compulsory prostitution. Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook immediately announced that the taking of evidence would begin today.

Governor LEHMAN'S appeal to the Legislature completely exposed the lack of either substance or consistency in the Republican opposition to his "eight-point" social security measure. Mr. WADSWORTH, as, in his own words, "spokesman for the Republican Assembly," called the methods proposed in the Security Assistance Bill "decidedly experimental"; yet he introduced and with his Republican colleagues voted for a bill practically identical with the old-age pension section of the measure he is opposing.

A contingent of 125 members of the Knickerbocker Greys, New York cadet battalion, held a special review in honor of Major Kenneth M. Gibson of the Seventh Regiment and his staff yesterday afternoon on the sun deck of the French liner Normandie, docked at the foot of West Forty-eighth Street.

ALBANY, May 12. -- With final adjournment of the Legislature fixed for 3 P.M. tomorrow, Governor Lehman's bill embodying his eight-point social security program, twice defeated in the Republican controlled Assembly, tonight is awaiting its third and final test in that branch.

Lou Camps, 129 1/2, Bronx feather-weight, continued along the victory trail by outpointing Pete Mascia, 137, Brooklyn, in the headline bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 5,000 watched the Bronxite register his tenth straight victory.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 12. -- Syracuse made it two straight in the annual baseball series with Colgate today, beating the visitors, 13 to 12, in eleven innings.

A feature of the stamp collecting hobby as exemplified yesterday in the international stamp exhibition in the Grand Central Palace is the growing tendency toward specialized collections of individual designs. Some collect only stamps showing animals, others take birds, other maps, while Theresa M. Clark shows a nice lot depicting the fashions in many parts of the world.
TORONTO, May 12 (Canadian Press). -- Albany made it two straight over Toronto by taking an 11-7 victory in the second game of their series today.

Recognition of the basic factor which has made for American technical achievement in the air has been fittingly given by the award to Dr. GEORGE W. LEWIS, director of research of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, of the 1936 Daniel Guggenheim Medal.

BERLIN, May 12. -- In a speech before 1,200 tax officials at Eisenach, Dr. Fritz Reinhardt, Secretary of State in the Finance Ministry, admitted today that despite all increases in revenue yields the national budget was still unbalanced and the Reich's debt was still growing.

Seeking to recover $25,000,000 for depositors of the First National Bank of Detroit, which was closed in 1933, B.C. Schram, its receiver, filed thirty suits yesterday in Federal court here against New York stockholders in the Detroit Bankers Company, a holding company accused of illegally controlling twenty-five banks and trust companies in Michigan.

The Republican symposium on proposed planks for the party's platform, being held at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, under the auspices of five Republican organizations, accepted yesterday afternoon a plank on money and banking from "a prominent Democrat." Arthur A. Ballantine and Miss Maude Wetmore directed the discussion of finance.

It is abundantly evident that, despite the great mileage of new construction in the last five years, main roads still lag seriously behind the traffic demands. The design and condition of the chief transcontinental highways, in their Eastern sections at any rate, are entirely inadequate.

Captain Robert A. Bartlett, veteran Arctic explorer, announced yesterday that preparations for this year's northern cruise of his schooner, the Morrissey, were virtually completed. He is now enrolling the group of boys who will sail with him as vacationists, paying for the trip, but signed on to do various tasks as members of the crew.

LONDON, May 12. -- The resignation of Colonial Secretary J.H. Thomas from the Cabinet is felt to be imminent today as a result of the unprecedented furor here over the alleged leakage of budget secrets.

BERLIN, May 12. -- The Boerse was under official pressure today and at the opening showed signs of the weakness much desired in official circles. This phase did not last long, however, and the usual characteristic of the market listening nervously for devaluation rumors reappeared.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- States, municipalities and local entities carrying out WPA projects under the Relief Appropriation Bill now before Congress will be required to put up larger contributions than heretofore to have the projects approved, it was revealed today in a confidential order sent by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA chief, to forty-eight State administrators under his immediate control.

One job in every ten, says the National Civil Service Reform League, is a job with the Government. It is an industry in which "recovery" has been carried far, and in which comparative prosperity is assured for generations to come. Yet an "emergency" persists, here as elsewhere, only it is an emergency in the field of administration rather than economics.

One of the most unwilling of Ellis Island's many involuntary guests, Mrs. Potter Palmer, former wife of the wealthy Chicagoan, left the detention rooms of the immigration station on the first boat yesterday and returned to her apartment in the Hotel Berkshire.

ATHENS, May 12. -- Premier John Metaxas late tonight reached an agreement with tobacco employers granting five to eight per cent salary increases and providing minimum men's wage of $6 a week. Employers representatives signed under protest after strong governmental pressure.

Nathan W. Levitan, 57 years old, a furniture dealer, of 563 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, pleaded not guilty in Special Sessions yesterday after his arrest on charges that he had placed false and misleading advertisements in two newspapers. He was released in $500 bail and James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, said he would be called for trial on June 4.

RICHMOND, Va., May 12. -- The present-day mental generation demands hard books, Miss May Wood Wiggington of Denver, assistant librarian, told delegates to the convention of the American Library Association, opening here today.
Mayor La Guardia charged in a speech last night that abuses had developed in the administration of medical relief and that "doctors are collecting patients from the relief rolls."

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 12. -- Well-informed circles explained this afternoon Chile's attitude concerning League of Nations sanctions against Italy following the delivery of a note today to the League Secretary-General by the Chilean delegate, Manuel Rivas Vicuna.

ADDIS ABABA, May 11 (Delayed). -- The Italians made an important decision affecting the economic life of Ethiopia today by decreeing the liquidation of the Central Bank of Ethiopia, which has been run by British and French interests under the direction of Emperor Haile Selassie.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 11 (AP). -- Richard W. Leche, a young lawyer, took the helm of Louisiana's ship of state today and charted for himself a far-reaching program.

The campaign for safety in the streets of New York has brought out an array of beautiful sentiments. But this city, like most other big cities, has not realized the intent of signals, which is to tell those who see them exactly what they may and may not do without doubt or hesitation

Seeking to file a protest against police tactics during the dispersal of striking seamen Monday night at the Chelsea piers of the International Mercantile Marine Company, about 150 of the strikers marched to City Hall yesterday from their headquarters at 164 Eleventh Avenue.
ALBANY, May 12. -- With the Legislative session near final adjournment, thirty-two measures in Governor Lehman's sixty-point anticrime program have already become law.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP). -- The Reds opened their invasion of the East today with a 6-to-4 triumph over the Phillies, sending the locals into the National League cellar.

With George N. Treysman crowding them and Reuben Fine not far behind, Samuel Reshevsky and Albert C. Simonson were still in the lead by the slimmest of margins last night at the close of play in the National Chess Federation's tournament at the Hotel Astor.

Edition time having come around again, the news hawks and actors of the WPA have released the second issue of The Living Newspaper, "1935," which was staged amid blare and searchlights at the Biltmore last evening. As the title indicates, it is a quick "once over -- and lightly" of the year that collapsed under the weight of its own blunders nearly five months ago.

A tribute to the late Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, for twenty-five years president of the American Museum of Natural History, opened the report made by his successor, F. Trubee Davison, at the Spring meeting of the board of trustees at the institution last night.

An eight-point program for peace, written by Albert J. Passage of 24 Chester Street, Mount Vernon, has been adjudged the best of 1,500 1,000-word essays submitted in a nation-wide contest conducted by the League of Political Education in cooperation with the National Peace Conference, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 12. -- Business was slack on the London Stock Exchange today and prices in all departments eased because of the absence of buyers. British Government issues were adversely affected by the disappointing result of the New Zealand loan, 34 per cent of the 4,000,000 offering of 3 per cents being reported left with the underwriters.

WASHINGTON, Nay 12. -- The Chase National Bank of New York and associates today bid $1,109.30 for each $1,000 face value of an issue of $4,907,000 New York City 4 per cent Rapid Transit Subway serial bonds offered at auction by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Marty Cogan, Samuel J. Tilden High School's star twirler, pitched his mates to a no-hit, no-run victory over Manual Training High School in a Section B, Brooklyn P.S.A.L. battle at the Parade Grounds yesterday. The score was 6 -- 0.

The theory that diet plays the major role in preventing dental decay, which has been accepted by many dentists, was discounted yesterday at the opening session of the sixty-eighth annual convention of the Dental Society of the State of New York at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Holdings of Dutch interests in stock of the Illinois Central Railroad continued to increase in 1935, according to the report of the company for that year to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The interest of the Union Pacific Railroad did not change, although the holdings of the Oregon Short Line, a unit of Union Pacific, were consolidated with those of the parent company.

Erwin S. Dayan, 22 years old, of 2,011 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on a Special Sessions warrant on a charge that he conspired to defraud the public in selling cotton goods in his Fifth Avenue Linen Corner, at 417 Fifth Avenue, under the pretense that they were linen.

Most commodity futures declined in dull trading on the local commodity markets yesterday. Cottonseed oil and wooltop futures were slightly higher. On the cash markets, oats and tins advanced, while declines appeared in corn, rye, lard, wheat, flour and silk.

The pending National Textile Act, which, if enacted, would set up a "little Federal Trade Commission" for the textile industry, has a "fair chance" of passage, according to Peter Van Horn, president of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.

H.B. LeQuatte, president of Churchill-Hall, Inc., was yesterday re-elected president of the Advertising Club of New York, at the organization's annual meeting. This will be his second term as the head of the club.

IRVINGTON, N.J., May 12. -- Thirteen-year-old Harold McGuiness returned to his home tonight as the police conducted a wide search for him and admitted that "just for fun" he had run away from home and then sent a note demanding $20,000 ransom to his uncle.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 12. -- Princeton is leading the Middle Atlantic Division of the Eastern Inter-collegiate Golf Association, with Dartmouth and Yale tied for first place in the New England district after the completion of the intra-sectional round-robin matches, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, executive secretary of the league.

WASMINGTON, May 12. -- That the Pettengill bill, which has passed the House and which would repeal the long-and-short-haul clause in the Interstate Commerce Act, faces hard sledding in the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce was indicated today at a hearing before that committee.

Kept in the running by a couple of circuit clouts, a trick they seemed to have picked up in Philadelphia the previous day, the Giants outfoxed the Cubs in the opening clash of their three-game series at the Polo Grounds yesterday in a manner that was not exactly cricket, but certainly very fine baseball in the opinion of a crowd of 10,000.

The share market continued yesterday to exhibit indifference toward the domestic and foreign news of the day. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was only 599,000 shares, setting a new record for dullness in the period since June 3, last. The market failed to hold its early advantage and prices receded slightly during the final hour, closing irregular.

The Fusion forces assumed official control of the Board of Education yesterday with the election of Henry C. Turner and James Marshall, first and second appointees of Mayor La Guardia, as president and vice president, respectively, and the seating of Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, fifth Fusion member in a body of seven.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Following is the description of the Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Relief Bill which was prepared last night by the Farm Credit Administration and mailed to each member of the House at the request of Majority Leader Bankhead and Representative Jones of Texas, chairman of the Agriculture Committee, and which aroused ire in the House today:

I do not make the slightest pretense to being qualified to determine what should have been done with the Casino or its site. I am satisfied from my own close observations that never before has so much intelligence been manifest in the administration and conduct of the parks.
Housing and business properties were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, May 13. -- Senator Borah, bidding for Ohio's Republican Presidential delegation, fell steadily behind Robert A. Taft of Cincinnati, a "favorite son" candidate, in returns early today from yesterday's primary.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., May 12, -- With Thomas Hitchcock Jr. taking part in his first full match of the 1936 campaign, the White quartet of Robert Lehman, Dr. John Richards, Captain Nick Craw and the ten-goal star routed G.H. (Pete) Bostwick's Blue riders, 15 to 7, on the J.S. Phipps estate today.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,961,700 barrels, compared with 2,925,700 in the preceding week, an increase of 36,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 20,600 barrels in the daily average output of California was the most important change.

ST. LOUIS, May 12. -- Roaring out of the East in the American League lead, the Yanks-caught up with the Browns at Sportsman's Park today before a gathering of about 700 fans and silently went into reverse.

ALBANY, May 12. -- After sharp debate today the Senate passed the Desmond bill to permit construction of a tunnel or a bridge from Manhattan to Queens in the midtown area. The vote, 39 to 9, cut across party lines.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12. -- Behind the sirens of motorcycle police, Mrs. Florence Evans Dibble of Newburyport, Mass., drove her coach, the Valiant, into this city this afternoon. She was well ahead of the time set at 12 hours and 18 minutes in 1910 by Paul Sorg, holder of the record for the coach run between the Holland House and Atlantic City.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 12. -- The automobile adventures of Representative Marion Zioncheck of Washington State continued here yesterday.

New York's sense of humor was tested along Fifth Avenue last night when two wagonloads of hay riders got under way at Seventy-ninth Street and traversed a hectic course of a mile or so, strewing wisps all over passing automobiles along the way.

John L. Keeshin of Chicago, who started business in 1912 with a horse-drawn wagon and is now the head of a motor freight transportation system extending from New York to St. Paul and Kansas City, took the stand at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday to urge approval of the application to extend his system into New England.

ABOARD THE ZEPPELIN HINDENBURG, En Route to Germany, May 12 (AP). -- Dr. Hugo Eckener, after predicting a forty-hour flight by the Zeppelin Hindenburg from Lakehurst, N.J., to the English Channel, hit today at critics of arrangements at Lakehurst to handle the giant airliner.

The Long Island University nine pounded out a 10-3 decision over the University of Newark team at Dexter Park yesterday. Seven of the nine Long Island hits went for extra bases in the hard-hitting contest.
ROME, May 12. -- Italy's resignation from the League of Nations is generally regarded here as the logical and indeed almost necessary sequel of Baron Pompeo Aloisi's withdrawal from Geneva today.

WASHINGTON, May l2. -- An invitation to President Roosevelt to establish a Summer White House at Atlantic City, combined with the offer of a selection of suitable houses, was made to the President today by a delegation from that city which visited the White House, escorted by Senator Moore.

Standing before an audience composed chiefly of manufacturers and distributors who are endeavoring to stabilize conditions in the drug industry, Miss Frances Kneitel, attorney for the National Independent Pharmacists, Inc., declared here yesterday that price-fixing is "economic insanity ."

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Mill Pond got up in the last few strides of a driving finish to capture the thirty-ninth running of the Bouquet Claiming Stakes, a test for 2-year-olds at four and a half furlongs through the Widener course that featured the racing at Belmont Park yesterday.

Encouraged by the smoothness with which the advance in the call-money rate from three-quarters of 1 per cent to 1 per cent was put into effect on Monday, a few bankers are talking about a further advance. Although this rate affects only a relatively small amount of loans, it exerts an influence, indirectly, upon the earning power of the banks in other directions.

KANSAS CITY, May 12. -- Dr. J. Tate Mason, president-elect of the American Medical Associaition, who is fighting a losing battle for life at a Seattle Hospital following a major operation, was inaugurated in absentia here tonight as official head of Americana medicine.

Mrs. M. Duke Biddle gave a musicale, preceded by a small dinner, last night at her home, 1,009 Fifth Avenue. The artists were Prince Alex Obolensky, baritone, and the Obolensky Chanters; Miss Helen Gilliland, soprano, and Vladimir Heifetz and Franklin Cannon, pianists. Mrs. Duke was assisted in receiving by Mrs. Enos W. Curtin and Mrs. A. De Vere Du Chene.

The WPA's Federal Theatre Project takes its bow this evening as the producer of one-act plays. The One-Act Experimental Unit of that bureau has borrowed Daly's Sixty-third Street Theatre, and for four nights will offer there the following: Moliere's "The Miser," Shaw's "The Great Catherine" and Emjo Basshe's "Snickering Horses."

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- President Roosevelt entertained today at tea the members of the monetary mission from China who have been conferring with Treasury officials here. Also present were Secretary Morgenthau and Alfred Sze, Chinese Ambassador.

PASADENA, Calif., May 12. -- An alert soda clerk, who suspected a customer of masquerading as a woman, apparently put Federal agents on the trail of Thomas H. Robinson Jr., who was captured in Glendale last night and taken by airplane to Louisville today to face a possible death penalty for the Stoll kidnapping.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- William C. Bullitt plans to give serious consideration to resigning as Ambassador to the Soviet Union upon his return here next month for a leave of absence, according to indications today in authoritative circles.

E.H.H. Simmons, president of the New York Stock Exchange from 1924 until 1930, was re-elected vice president yesterday at a special meeting of the governing committee. He became vice president in May, 1935, at the suggestion of Charles R. Gay, who was re-elected president on Monday.

Mrs. Walter Ewing Hope heads a group of women who will give a reception the afternoon of May 25 in the library of the Central Branch of the Young Women's Christian Association, 610 Lexington Avenue, for Mrs. Henry P. Davison and Mrs. William Fellowes Morgan, who returned recently from Cape Colony, South Africa, where she passed the Winter with her sister, Mrs. J. Bryant Lindley in Claremont.
PARIS, May 12. -- French veterans today addressed a solemn appeal to German veterans to join them in an effort to reconcile their peoples.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 12. -- Miss Sylva Annenberg, New York State champion, continued her winning streak by taking low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association second one-day tournament at the Rockwood Hall Country Club today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 12 (AP). -- Rochester and Baltimore divided a double-header this afternoon. The Orioles won the opener, a thirteen-inning struggle, 5 to 4, but bowed to the wizardry of Bob Weiland, who scored his sixth victory of the season in winning the nightcap, 1 to 0.

BARTOW, Fla., May 12. -- The State rested its case today in the first of the Tampa flogging trials and Pat Whitaker, head of the defense counsel for six former Tampa policemen and their chief, said he would present a motion for a directed verdict of acquittal.

Plans for the World's Fair to be held here in 1939 and 1940 were laid before President Roosevelt in Washington yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, who was accompanied on his visit to the White House by Representative Sol Bloom, New York City Democrat.

Yesterday afternoon the Whitney Museum of American Art opened a Summer exhibition composed of oils, water-colors, drawings, prints and sculpture from its permanent collection. It fills all of the galleries on the first and second floors. The show will remain on until Oct. 1, except that for five weeks (Aug. 1 to Sept. 8) the museum will be closed.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Reductions in rates of duty and other concessions affecting American export products, with an aggregate value on the basis of 1935 trade of $24,500,000, were among the outstanding features of the reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and France, which was published simultaneously tonight here and in Paris.

An 18-year-old boy earning $13 a week, it was brought out yesterday, was in charge of assigning first mortgage certificates to the 17,000 persons who invested their money with the Westchester Title and Mortgage Company before it failed in 1933 with $81,000,000 in mortgage bonds outstanding.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- There are several reasons for Senator Vandenberg's correct assumption in the Senate today that the administration and the Democratic majority in Congress will not at this time accept any substitute for their relief policy, however sound. Most of the reasons are political, which arouses only formal indignation on the part of Mr. Vandenberg.
