HACKENSACK, N.J., May 12. -- Two convicted felons, one already sentenced and the other about to be sentenced, escaped from the detention room of the Bergen County circuit court here at 10 o'clock this morning.

SIAN, Shensi Province, China, May 12. -- Although about 26,000 Communists went from this province into Shansi in March, the successful campaign by government forces has now reduced these Red forces to less than 10,000 who have now re-entered Shensi.
Bill Meyer, a pinch-hitter, singled in the ninth to drive in Eddie Blaskowitz with the winning tally as Wagner College beat Panzer, 11 to 10, yesterday at Sisco Park, Port Richmond, S.I.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 12. -- Thomas H. Robinson Jr. moped in a detention cell here late today as the government planned to demand his life under the Lindbergh kidnapping law for the abduction of Mrs. Berry V. Stoll twenty months ago.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 12. -- Frances, Frank, Felix and Ferdinand Kasper, the Passaic quadruplets, ended their first seventy-two hours of life late today with an impressive advisory hoard to handle their "business" matters.

A special luncheon featured by a fashion show of Summer beach apparel was held yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Bide-a-Wee Home for Animals. Mrs. Edward P.C. L. Cumming acted as master of ceremonies, and manikins in the fashion revue were Mrs. Alan Jackson, Mrs. Carleton Young, the Misses Marianna Ward, Julie Gillespie, Marjorie McPherson and Aurelie Murchison.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The House jumped into swift and acrimonious debate on the Frazier-Lemke $3,000,000,000 Farm Mortgage Relief Bill today, with the measure termed everything from a "fantastic monetary scheme" to a non-inflationary savior of debt-ridden farmers.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 12. -- Bankers from all sections were arriving at the Hotel Traymore tonight for the opening tomorrow of the sixteenth annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. The association represents 14,000,000 persons having $10,000,000,000 on deposit in the banks, according to Myron F. Converse, president of the Worcester (Mass.) Five Cents Savings Bank.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 12 (AP). -- The Araho Stable's Jackie D. got away to a bad start in the four-and--a-half-furlong fifth race at Narragansett today, but sprinted with the strength that he displayed in his previous two starts here to win by two lengths from the Bristol Stable's Legion, the favorite.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- Hog prices continue on the downgrade. A further recession in the price of fresh pork loins resulted today in a drop of 10 to 25 cents, with sales of light lights regarded as showing greater losses.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 12. -- Frances, Frank, Felix and Ferdinand Kasper, the Passaic quadruplets, ended their first seventy-two hours of life late today with an impressive advisory hoard to handle their "business" matters.

A special luncheon featured by a fashion show of Summer beach apparel was held yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Bide-a-Wee Home for Animals. Mrs. Edward P.C. L. Cumming acted as master of ceremonies, and manikins in the fashion revue were Mrs. Alan Jackson, Mrs. Carleton Young, the Misses Marianna Ward, Julie Gillespie, Marjorie McPherson and Aurelie Murchison.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The House jumped into swift and acrimonious debate on the Frazier-Lemke $3,000,000,000 Farm Mortgage Relief Bill today, with the measure termed everything from a "fantastic monetary scheme" to a non-inflationary savior of debt-ridden farmers.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Investigation by a special board of the Passamaquoddy and Florida Ship Canal projects with a view to pressing these projects was proposed in a resolution introduced in the Senate today by Senator Robinson, majority leader.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Opposition to the appearance of William D. Mitchell to plead the American cause in the renewed controversy over the $40,000,000 Black Tom and Kingsland explosion claims was circumvented when Secretary Hull today officially named the former Attorney General as counsel for the American Government.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 13 (AP). -- State police wounded and captured a second suspect in the $13,000 robbery of the Pine Bush National Bank today as a third man took his life to avoid arrest after a gun battle with troopers near Otisville.

Herbert Hoover, former President, visited the international stamp show yesterday in Grand Central Palace and spent nearly an hour inspecting the signatures of his Presidential predecessors on the "franked" envelopes in the collection of Edward Stern of this city.

Support for the policy underlying the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act will provide the keynote of the second annual celebration of Foreign Trade Week, starting Sunday, according to James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council and of the foreign trade committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

The American Acceptance Council, founded seventeen years ago to help develop an American bill market, is to be dissolved and its fact-finding and educational functions are to be taken over by the American Bankers Association, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of representatives of leading banks held in the Federal Reserve Bank.

The application of the Standard Oil Company (Kentucky) to list 2,604,801 outstanding shares of $10 par common stock on the New York Curb Exchange was approved by the board of governors yesterday. The stock has been admitted to unlisted trading for many years.
CHICAGO, May 13. -- A national mobilization against traffic toll was urged by speakers before the American Red Cross convention today.

Two groups of transportation executives declared their disapproval yesterday of the Wheeler-Crosser bill, which is intended to strengthen the control of the Interstate Commerce Commission over the merger and abandonment of rail facilities and dictate the policies of the railroads with respect to the care of employes discharged because of such changes.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Chief Justice Alfred A. Wheat ruled today that confidential correspondence between President Roosevelt and Secretary Ickes could not be introduced as evidence in the District of Columbia Supreme Court.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 13. -- Andrew H. Dykes, New York lumber man, said today that the lumber industry must settle its internal disputes quickly, cut distribution costs and concentrate on serving the public, or lose more and more business to substitute products.

John J. Meehan Jr. has resigned from Ivor B. Clark, Inc., to open a realty and mortgage brokerage business at 12 W. 37th St. Mr. Meehan joined the Clark organization in January, 1934, as a mortgage solicitor. Previously he was with the Bank for Savings and the New York Title and Mortgage Co.

A brooding gray sky lit by lightning provided a backdrop in Somerville, N.J., late yesterday afternoon for George Creely, middle-aged utility worker, as, single-handed, he stood on the lid of a sixty-foot tank filled with 110,000 gallons of gasoline and beat out blue flame spurting from a six-foot crack where a bolt had struck.
BERLIN, May 13. -- Official pressure on the Boerse resulted finally today in the desired drop in prices. Activity, however, was strictly limited.

A short, sharp command from Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania in the Fall of 1933 was sufficient to drive out of business the several men then operating chains of disorderly houses and to leave the field open to Lucania, according to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey in an opening address yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a blue ribbon jury.

The Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Corporation, says in the fifth intermediate report and account, covering 1935, that with respect to pending settlements between former Kreuger companies it can say no more at this time but it expects in the near future to be able to present the matter to the court and creditors for consideration.

Conditions and entry blanks for the New York Athletic Club's annual Block Island races, which this year will be held on July 11, were sent out yesterday by F.W. Horenburger, chairman of the race committee of that organization's yachting department.
Flats and dwellings in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn proved attractive in sales and leases of urban realty reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- An investigation of the steamship President Roosevelt today on the basis of charges by striking seamen that she was "improperly manned" was regarded as inconclusive by Commerce Department officials having jurisdiction in the matter.

Because of a delay in the arrival of the musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, as well as the scenery, the performance of Lodovico Rocca's operatic version of "The Dybbuk" was postponed last night at Carnegie Hall. The performance will be given tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Representatives of all the railroads in the United States appeared today before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee and urged passage of the Pettengill bill repealing the long-and-short-haul clause in the Interstate Commerce Law.

According to the Amsterdam newspaper Her Volk, Heinrich Mann, exiled from Germany, has become a citizen of Czechoslovakia. Knopf will publish Mr. Mann's new novel, "The Youth of Henry IV," in the Fall.

Tonight's opening is up at the Masque Theatre, where Gaston Valcourt's "A Private Affair" will open under the aegis of Albert Bannister. Oscar Shaw is the star and Helen Raymond and Betty Linley are featured; the company also includes Florence Britton, Nelly Malcolm, George Graham, A.J. Herbert, Audree Corday and Charles Campbell.

National advertising is the power behind Main Street, the generator which gives that composite of American life its tremendous energy and activity, H.B. LeQuatte, president of Churchill-Hall, Inc., and recently re-elected president of the Advertising Club of New York, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin.
LONDON, May 13 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for April:
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The House, by a decisive vote of 235 to 142, rejected the $3,000,000,000 Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Relief Bill today.

Due to the aggressive retail promotions, consumer purchases of outdoor sports apparel have been increasing heavily and play no small part in the sales gains noted by the stores. Reorders on this merchandise reaching manufacturers have been heavy, with continued marked activity seen for the period directly ahead.

MANILA, P.I., May 13 (AP). -- Thousands of Filipinos shouted "Godspeed, hurry back" today as High Commissioner Frank Murphy and his party sailed for the United States. President Manuel Quezon and several Cabinet officials will accompany Mr. Murphy as far as Shanghai.
The intemperance of a former clerk in the Yonkers Postoffice accused of stealing money from the mails was attributed yesterday to his wife's membership in the Women's Christian Temperance Union.

While this committee joins with a recent editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES in praising Commissioner of Hospitals S.S. Goldwater for his good work in eliminating politics from his department, it feels that the praise for this work, too often given, has tended to divert attention from his failure to win urgently necessary enlargements of hospitals.

Professor Edwin W. Kemmerer of Princeton University and Professor Walter Spahr of the Economists National Committee on Monetary Relations have submitted a proposed plank on money and banking to the joint committee on a Republican platform which has conducted a series of hearings at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Reports that Great Britain was negotiating with the United States for an increase of her destroyer tonnage under the London Naval treaty of 1930 were denied at the State Department today.

Declaring that only 25 per cent of the population is now getting regular dental care, Dr. Harlan H. Horner, Assistant Commissioner for Higher Education, told 1,500 dentists yesterday that the extension of dental care to all persons in need of it represents the "most important and far-reaching challenge" to dentistry.

President ROOSEVELT has sent to the Senate the naval treaty recently signed at London and hearings on it are to be held at once. Considering the readiness with which members of Congress ordinarily express opinions on matters of foreign policy, there has been very little comment thus far on the new agreement.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- In an open letter to Postmaster General Farley Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee charged today that Republican campaign literature had been mutilated while in the mails.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Senate passed today with several amendments the bill adopted by the House last January to modify procedural provisions of the Bankruptcy Act of 1934. The changes, which would apply to Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act of 1898, are of a technical nature and are intended to correct minor inequities which have resulted in actual administration of the 1934 enactment.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Owens-Illinois Glass Company of Toledo, in a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for issuance of 63,300 common shares, $25 par value, said that, subject to modifications due to changing conditions, it and its subsidiaries contemplated engaging within two or three years in a $12,500,000 program of expansion and improvement of existing facilities.
LONDON, May 13. -- Great Britain has asked the United States and Japan for permission to exceed the destroyer tonnage limit in the 1930 three-power naval treaty.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Vivian McGrath, the player who uses two hands on the backhand, has a slight infection of the index finger of his right hand and will be unable to practice with the Australian Davis Cup tennis team for three or four days.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Claims of the Treasury Department against Canadian distillers for customs duties on liquor smuggled into the United States during prohibition days have been settled. Substantial payments of duties are understood to have been made, but the amounts were not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Eight Senators today petitioned the subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee, which is considering the Deficiency Bill containing the $1,425,000,000 appropriation for direct relief, for some provision to continue the activities of the Rural Resettlement Administration.

" Mickey" Saitoo, a 5-year-old Japanese child, was one of the hits of the first annual international fair held last night at the Heckscher Foundation for Children, Fifth Avenue at 104th Street. The fair and entertainment program were planned as an expression of what each nation contributes to recreation work in this city, and children of almost every national background were represented.

PARIS, May 13. -- With the announcement by the Radical Socialist party tonight of its willingness to participate in a Popular Front government, Leon Blum, Socialist leader, is virtually ready to form his Cabinet.

A syndicate agreement between the Cord Corporation and Morris Markin, president of the Checker Cab Manufacturing Corporation, for investing in the stock of Checker Cab has been extended for five years from last Aug. 10, according to a notice filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Checker Cab.

A resolution praising Charles R. Gay for his work in behalf of the New York Stock Exchange in his first year as its president was adopted yesterday by the governing committee of the Exchange. Mr. Gay was re-elected without opposition last Monday.

Three tall buildings in the Garment Center and a Brooklyn skyscraper were bought in at foreclosure yesterday by the Manufacturers Trust Company, as trustee, in an action against the Bricken Properties Corporation and others.

Lightning struck several times in the Bronx on buildings, trees and electric light poles, but no injuries or appreciable damage was reported. A 40-foot flagpole on the Wakefield police station, a three-story building at 229th Street and White Plains Avenue, was splintered by a bolt and some of the fragments dropped into the street.
ALBANY, May 13. -- Following is a tabulation showing the principal measures passed and defeated during the 1936 session of the Legislature:

Increasing public concern over the cost of government, a conservative trend in public opinion in the last two years, strong opposition to any increases in taxes on business concerns and to the fixing of prices of farm products and an increasing opposition to the redistribution of wealth by taxation were reported yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Charles Edison on New Jersey grade-crossings elimination projects, discussed the Civil Service with Chester A. Arthur Jr. and appointed Harry M. Hickey as collector of internal revenue at Albany.
The United States Gypsum Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 50 cents, placing the common stock on a $2 annual basis, against $1 heretofore.

Mayor La Guardia favors the Desmond amendment to the Queens Midtown Tunnel Bill in the Legislature as a strategic move to eliminate a controversial phase of the vehicular tunnel project to be built from Thirty-eighth Street to Long Island City.

An exhibition of the creative work and treasured possessions of persons 70 years old and older, designed to demonstrate the extent to which they contribute to the esthetic life of the community, will be held at the University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street, for one week, beginning next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- An estimate by Farm Administration officials that upward of 4,500,000 farmers would participate in the soil-conservation program was challenged today by Secretary Wallace. He thought the number of cooperating producers would not exceed 3,500,000, the maximum participation in any one year under the old AAA programs.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 13 (AP). -- Paul H. Roberts, acting director of the Federal Shelterbelt project, estimated today that 75 to 80 per cent of the trees planted have survived.

LONDON, May 13. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin announced today that the British Government had accepted "under all reserve" a copy of the Italian decree annexing Ethiopia and proclaiming Victor Emmanuel the new Emperor.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange appointed yesterday its standing subcommittees for the year. Most of the changes resulted from the retirement of Edward Roesler and George P. Smith as members of the governing committee.

The Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway discarded 446 freight cars in 1935, according to the report for 1935 by C.T. O'Neal, president, issued yesterday. This, following the scrapping of 1,872 freight cars in 1934, reduced the total owned to 4,483.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- An oversold condition was disclosed today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade when short covering developed on uneasiness over the foreign political situation and a marked let-up in the heavy liquidation that was a large factor yesterday.
VALETTA, Malta, May 13. -- Although the war in Ethiopia has ended, the situation here is as tense as ever. Defense precautions are noticeably keener.

In connection with the issuance of its report for the first quarter showing earnings of $1,248,029, or about 9 cents a share on the 15,000,000 shares of capital stock, the Packard Motor Car Company announced yesterday that its directors had declared a dividend of 15 cents a share on the capital stock, payable July 1, to stock of record June 6.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 13 (AP). -- Thirteen delegates listed as supporting Governor Landon for the Republican Presidential nomination led tonight in scattered returns from West Virginia's Presidential preference primary. The State has sixteen delegate votes.

DETROIT, May 13 (AP). -- With Third Baseman Bill Werber driving in all of their runs with his first homer of the season, the Boston Red Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 3 to 1, today for their third victory in four starts against the world champions this year.

Red Rain C.V. Whitney Pennant colt, that many considered last year's juvenile champion, was beaten by a head at Belmont yesterday at the end of the fastest mile thus far of the meeting in a test that was his seasonal debut of 1936. Picking up five lengths in the stretch run, Red Rain was just short of victory as Mrs. Dodge Sloan's Delphinium flashed first past the judges in 1:36 3-5.
Architects filed plans yesterday for several alteration jobs in Manhattan, two new Bronx dwellings and various projects in Brooklyn and Queens.

The operation of the Val-Kill Furniture Shop, in which Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has taken a leading part for nine years, has been turned over to Otto Berg, the firm's chief cabinet maker, according to an announcement made yesterday by Miss Nancy Cook, one of the four partners in the enterprise.

Stock prices were better yesterday but the trading pace was even slower than on the dull days immediately preceding. Followers of the share market paid close attention to the action taken on the inflationary Frazier-Lemke bill for refinancing farm mortgages with new currency and to Senator Harrison's statement that the Senate Finance Committee's revision of the Tax Bill might be completed some time next week.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 13. -- Showing splendidly in a fine class, the chestnut mare Winning Ways from the Terre Haute Farm of Bethel, Conn., owned by Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kaiser, was one of the principal victors tonight on the second day of the annual Atlantic City Horse Show.

Brokers who are concerned over the increased trading in American stocks in London are wondering whether this development has been caused by Regulation U of the Federal Reserve Board, prescribing maximum loan values for banks here in lending on security collateral.

ALBANY, May 13. -- Despite an apparent lack of warmth for his issues, Mayor La Guardia achieved considerable success in putting through the Legislature measures favored by him, according to a check-up tonight.

I was interested to see in Saturday's issue of your paper upon Page 14 a letter signed "Thomas Judson," dated Washington, D.C., May 6, 1936. So far as I know there is no other one bearing my name; naturally I wonder about this letter, which I did not write.

McALESTER, Okla., May 13 (AP). -- Twenty-four convicts escaped from the State Penitentiary today, used a foreman as a shield, then killed him and dumped his body from an automobile, while ten of their band were being shot down by guards.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP). -- The Phillies scored three runs in the seventh today to come from be hind and defeat, the Cincinnati Reds, 9 to 7.
MONTREAL, May 13 (AP). -- Newark evened the count in its three-game series with Montreal today, pushing over a run in the ninth inning to take a 6-to-5 decision.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

Judge Clarence G. Galston in Brooklyn Federal court, signed an order yesterday extending to May 26 the time for the Brooklyn Academy of Music to file a plan for reorganization. The academy filed a petition under Section 77-b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act on April 22, 1935.

While the heavy run of weakfish into Peconic Bay probably will not develop for another week or ten days, bookings of charter boats are being made at the various ports for this week-end. That the forerunners of the schools that swarm into the bay each Spring have arrived was established several days ago with the first catches on rod and reel.
BERLIN, May 13. -- The League Council's failure to act to lessen the tension in the Italo-Ethiopian crisis is deplored here.

Defeating Alexander Kevitz, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, in the fourteenth and semifinal round, Samuel Reshevsky of the Marshall Chess Club, former Western champion and one-time prodigy, gained sole possession of the lead last night in the National Chess Federation's championship at the Hotel Astor.

RICHMOND, Va., May 13. -- Raising of funds to initiate mandamus proceedings in New Jersey to compel the directors of the Sloss-Sheffield Steel and Iron Company to permit an independent audit of the company's books was begun today by George S. Kemp and John Stewart Bryan in a communication addressed to holders of the company's preferred stock.

Captain Ronald Cheyne-Stout, director of park zoos, displayed proudly to visitors at his office yesterday an object that at first sight appeared to be some sort of mammoth chestnut burr. Unlike a burr, however, it started violently when prodded.

LONDON, May 13. -- Now that a Franco-American trade treaty eliminating high tariff barriers has been concluded, it is expected the attention of Washington will be directed to London. Thus far, however, Secretary Hull has not given instructions for negotiations to commence.

CLEVELAND, May 13 (AP). -- A new radio device with which the village blacksmith can diagnose trouble in an automobile engine as accurately as only scientists could do it heretofore was described here today by H.J. Schrader of the Radio Corporation of America.

The administration proposal to tax undistributed earnings of corporations was declared "reasonable" in an address at the Hotel Astor last night before the Economic Club by Oliver M.W. Sprague, Professor of Banking and Finance at Harvard, former adviser to the Bank of England and later to the United States Treasury.

THE title may draw more dust than readers. It is "Humor in the Old Deep South" (Macmillan, $5) -- one of these titles which seem to ask nothing more than a little shelf-room in the larger libraries. But this is a case when such modesty amounts to a betrayal, for this book is good. The editor, Arthur Palmer Hudson, is a scholar with personality and a temperament, and an unfinicky interest in the old South.

Governor Lehman, in a letter written in Albany, moved yesterday to determine whether the State should reopen the case of Mrs. Margaret Wiggen, Brooklyn woman who was shot and fatally wounded by one of two Nassau County detectives who pursued an automobile in which she was riding with her husband.

May contracts on the Cotton Exchange ended unchanged again yesterday, but later months gained as much as 7 points. Pool brokers continued to reduce obligations in the spot month, while houses with foreign connections bought October in sufficient volume to carry that month to a premium over both December and January.

WESTONBIRT, England, May 13. -- Seeking the strongest possible combination, Britain's polo authorities reached out today and recruited the Rajah Hanut Singh, eight-goal Indian star, for duty against the United States in the Westchester Cup matches next month.

LONDON, May 13. -- A story of a 15,100 house that the Colonial Secretary, J.H. Thomas, accepted as an advance payment for the writing of a book was told today before the official inquiry into an alleged leakage of Cabinet secrets.
RICHMOND, Va., May 13. -- America's distinct contribution to civilization is the free public library, President Roosevelt told the American Library Association's conference in a message today.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- The right of a court of equity to limit free competition through the setting of minimum prices in an industry was denied in an opinion handed down today by the Illinois Appellate Court. The ruling upset the price fixing injunction issued in July on behalf of the Cleaning and Dyeing Plant Owners Association of Chicago.

The City of New York formally opened its attack yesterday on the Long Island Railroad's application for an increase in commutation rates at the twenty-sixth joint hearing under the auspices of the Public Service and State Transit Commissions.

CANONSBURG, Pa., May 13 (AP). -- The country's biggest steel union voted today to start an organization drive in the industry under its own direction, but along the industrial union plan advocated by John L. Lewis.

Receipt of the entry of a thirty-one-man team from the University of Southern California for the annual I.C.A.A.A.A. track and field championship meet to be held in Philadelphia May 29-30 was announced yesterday by James A. Taylor at the organization's offices here

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The spirit of good-will was said by William Phillips, Under-Secretary of State, in a radio broadcast tonight, still to be alive among nations, not-withstanding some discouraging signs.

STANLEY BALDWIN is not exactly dazzled by the new empire which MUSSOLINI has set up in Africa; and others may agree with the British Prime Minister. "I would not myself be in a hurry to take literally," said Mr. BALDWIN, "every statement that is made in a moment of enthusiasm."

The Bank of France reported last Thursday decrease in its gold reserve amounting to $77,100,000. This was the weekly period immediately following the French elections. Markets assumed the outgo of gold to indicate both hoarding of gold at home and export of capital to foreign markets.

This year's legislative session at Albany was the longest in twenty-five years. It was also one of the stormiest. Its outstanding accomplishment was the passage of a series of bills, recommended by Governor LEHMAN, designed to strengthen the hands of law-enforcement officials throughout the State and to make the administration of justice more swift and sure.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 13. -- Joe Louis, the reigning sensation in the heavyweight ranks, celebrated his twenty-second birthday today in the presence of about sixty guests, including James J. Braddock, heavyweight champion of the world, whom Joe hopes to meet for the title before the year is out, and other ring celebrities.

HADDONFIELD, N.J., May 13. -- more than 100 caddies were on strike today at the Woodcrest Country Club and the Tavistock Golf Club here for increased fees and use of the course for their own playing on Mondays. State police were assigned to guard both clubs, but the pickets were entirely peaceful.

Both domestic manufacturers and foreign traders were occupied analyzing particular rate changes and concessions in the French trade agreement yesterday. As a result, most of the criticism and praise of the treaty was confined largely to generalities.

COLUMBUS, May 13. -- Forty-seven of Ohio's fifty-two delegates to the Republican National Convention had been apportioned tonight to a "favorite son" candidate, Robert A. Taft, Cincinnati lawyer, and five to Senator Borah of Idaho.

Museums throughout the country are borrowing art for special exhibitions at such a rate that to continue the present pace will eventually dry up all sources of material, Henry Marceau, assistant director of the Pennsylvania Museum of Art, warned the delegates at the thirty-first annual meeting of the American Association of Museums yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum.

ALBANY, Thursday, May 14. -- After having buried for this session Governor Lehman's eight-point social security program and passed the Wadsworth Old-Age Pension Bill, the Legislature at 4 o'clock this morning was debating reapportionment, but final adjournment seemed a matter of only an hour or so.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 13. -- Harvard today scored its second rugby victory this Spring over Yale, winning 5 -- 0. Joe Kennedy, outstanding in the Crimson attack throughout, made the solitary try midway in the opening period on a three-quarter movement and Don Meiklejohn, stand-off half, converted neatly to complete the scoring.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, May 13. -- The fleet will begin a movement at midnight Friday to an unknown destination in the Pacific off the Panama Canal for a week of secret manoeuvres which will Carry the entire force across the Equator.

LOUISVILLE, May 13. -- Thomas H. Robinson Jr. pleaded guilty in Federal court here late today to the kidnapping of Mrs. Berry V. Stoll and was sentenced to life imprisonment. His case was completed less than forty-eight hours after his capture in Glendale, Calif.

I. D.S. Meister, Inc., and Nathan Wilson, operators, have bought from the Glen Ridge Trust Company, as trustee for the Frank Slocum estate, a 194-acre tract in Millington, N.J. The property had been a Slocum holding for about twenty-five years.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Six trustees were named today by Federal Judge George A. Welsh to manage the affairs of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company. They are:

The Board of Estimate, as set up in the proposed new charter, should be a compact, efficient, representative and sensitive agency for administration of the city's business, former Judge Thomas D. Thacher told members of the New York Board of Trade yesterday at their monthly luncheon meeting in the Hotel Commodore.
A program of school building construction totaling $25,250,000 for inclusion in the city's capital outlay budget for 1936 was approved by the Board of Education yesterday.

VIENNA, Thursday, May 14. -- After a night of feverish excitement an official announcement was issued at 4 o'clock this morning declaring, "Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor, has resigned from the government in consequence of differences of opinion on matters of principle with Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg."

The Keys of the city of Waco, Texas, were presented yesterday morning to New York. There were four in the bunch -- Mona, Mary, Leota and Roberta, the quadruplets who are "Ambassadresses Extraordinary" for the scores of centennial celebrations now being held in Texas.

A flat prohibition on the use of armed guards, spies or labor blacklists has been sent to State and District WPA Administrators by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, he announced yesterday in Washington.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Charles E. Stuart resigned today as vice president of the Export-Import Bank, effective on May 31, in order to return to private business. His successor has not been named.

James Roosevelt, son of the President, with his wife, and Robert P. Skinner, former United States Ambassador to Turkey, with Mrs. Skinner, are among the persons due today from Europe on the Manhattan of the United States Lines.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Senate passed a bill today to change the name of the Department of the Interior to the "Department of Conservation," and sent the measure, which has been pending for nearly a year, to the House. As approved by the Senate, the proposal had little resemblance to the measure championed by Secretary Ickes.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- With Congressional action nearly completed on the peace-time record Navy Appropriation Bill, Admiral William H. Standley, acting Secretary of the Navy, said today the navy was ready to start immediately construction of a $10,000,000 floating drydock as part of the Hawaiian Islands' defense line.

Production of steel ingots has declined only a half point this week to 67 1/2 per cent of capacity, and demand for steel remains unusually stable, said the weekly summary of Iron Age, issued yesterday. Mill backlogs are sufficiently large to prevent any sharp decline in output for at least another month, the magazine added.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced that it had issued an order refusing to permit the registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by International Investors Fund System, Inc., of Scranton, Pa., to become effective after the registrant, following a hearing, had asked that stop-order proceedings be dismissed.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, announced today the appointment of the following special committee to study the possibilities of expanding private employment, in accordance with a resolution adopted at the chamber's recent meeting:

Resorting to a new weapon in his investigation of the Wendel kidnapping case, William F.X. Geoghan, District Attorney of Kings County, began an effort yesterday to force the appearance before the Kings County grand jury of Mrs. Anna Bading, secretary to Ellis Parker Sr., county detective of Burlington County, N.J.

Father Paul Schulte, the Roman Catholic priest who made the trip here on the Hindenburg and celebrated mass in her lounge during the westward flight over the Atlantic, is arranging a trip by airplane this Summer to Hudson Bay, Chesterfield Inlet and the McKenzie River in the interest of the society, M.I.V.A., of which he was the founder.

COLUMBUS, May 13. -- A statement that the church had the right to speak out on social and economic problems but that the Methodist Episcopal Church would resist all efforts to correct economic evils through a Fascist or Communist dictatorship was adopted by the Committee on State of the Church today.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Twenty-five to thirty judges of the Circuit and Superior Courts in Chicago plan to withdraw in a body from the Chicago Bar Association because the association has charged nearly that many with unseemly political activity.

BERLIN, May 13. -- Besides observing strict neutrality in the growing Anglo-Italian tension, Chancellor Adolf Hitler has also decreed what amounts to a domestic truce between rival factions in order to present to the world the picture of a strong united Germany worthy of being courted as an ally and able to take care of her own interests if need be.

An investment of $1,800,000 in the Standard Carloading Company by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Pere Marquette Railway, which C. O. controls, was disclosed yesterday in their reports for 1935 to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 13. -- Representative Marion Zioncheck turned himself and his bride over to the marines today, with Colonel James T. Moore personally conducting the honeymooners from these shores to the near-by Virgin Islands.

Jack Selig, alias Jack Riskin, was arrested on a charge of stealing an automobile. Yesterday, while he was still marveling at the generosity of the detectives who went out of their way to obtain his dismissal in magistrate's court on that charge, he was arrested again for illegal Possession of $7,500 worth of the jewelry stolen from Mrs. C.F. Zittel, wife of the publisher of Zit's Weekly, on Dec. 12, 1930.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13. -- Harvard's varsity baseball team, Eastern Intercollegiate League leader, won its ninth straight game today, defeating Brown, 9 -- 8, in a see-saw battle at Soldiers Field.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 13. -- Latest bulletins concerning the Kasper quadruplets at St. Mary's Hospital here, where the babies were born Saturday afternoon, show weight gains for all except one of the children. Frances has regained the half an ounce she lost immediately after birth, Felix has put on one ounce, Ferdinand has regained a half-ounce of the one and a half he lost, and only Frank remained the same.

Gluck's "Orpheus and Euridice" will be revived May 22, Friday evening, as a feature of the second week of the Metropolitan's popular season, the association announced yesterday. The opera will be pantomimed by members of the American Ballet ensemble with the vocal soloists, chorus and orchestra occupying the pit.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 (AP). -- A night club patron's attempt to light a cigarette from a dancer's torch started a roaring fire in the Club Shamrock here early today, resulting in the deaths of four persons and injuries to twelve others.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. D.T. Richardson entertained today with luncheon in the Casino Terrace at the Greenbrier. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. T.W. Gregory Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig Mosle, Mr. and Mrs. A.W. Snyder, Mr. and Mrs. John Loomis Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Pleasants, Mr. and Mrs. P.G. Morris, John Dennison and John Clark.

Is the Italian Dictator about to essay the role of mystery man of Europe? He appears at the moment to wish to leave everybody guessing at his intentions. His delegates to Geneva he abruptly ordered to quit and go home. Theirs not to reason why. They said that they did not know why they had been recalled or what it meant.

Medical leaders made no effort yesterday to hide their anger at Mayor La Guardia's public charge that abuses were cropping up in the administration of medical relief and that physicians were "collecting patients from the relief rolls."

Mayor John G. Meister and members of the Town Council of Weehawken, N.J., held their bimonthly caucus 3,000 feet above the City Hall yesterday afternoon. The officials were taken aloft from Newark Airport in a transport plane as the guests of a transcontinental airline.

In the first ceremony of its kind Dr. Alexis Carrel, physician; Jonas Lie, artist, and Dr. Walter Damrosch, musician, received last night the awards of merit of the National Institute of Immigrant Welfare at a dinner of the institute at the Hotel Biltmore.

A firm undertone prevailed throughout the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. While trading remained dull and featureless, the course of least resistance was toward moderately higher levels in most of the major groups. The sales volume again reflected the indifference of traders, transactions amounting to $7,182,800, as compared to $7,068,300 on Tuesday.

Harmony prevailed last night at the meeting of the Democratic County Committee of Queens, held in the Jamaica High School Auditorium. The business of the meeting, consisting principally of the adoption of rules and the election of officers, was carried on without a dissenting vote.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $22,185,580, after all deductions, including provision for gas revenue in dispute, but excluding subsidiary preferred dividends.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 13. -- Miss Ruth Adel won the Long Island women's one-day golf event today with a gross score of 85, giving her a one-stroke margin over Miss Rosalie Knapp, president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 13. -- Sal Di Buono and Phil Duey, the home team, put together a best-ball score of 67 to win the opening pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association today on the rain-drenched course of the Bonnie Briar Country Club.

DETROIT, May 13. -- Francis P. Garvan, president of the Farm Chemurgic Council, told members at today's session that oil interests, dominated by the Standard of New Jersey, are eager to dispose of nearly $1,000,000,000 worth of foreign oil, after which the Standard has planned with German interests to organize a monopoly for the hydrogenation of coal, which is the extraction of oil from coal.

MEXICO, D.F., May 13. -- Twenty thousand men, women and children, all members of the Mexican Federation of Workers, paraded here today after an overnight journey from Puebla. The march was in protest against the candidacy of General Avila Camacho, the Under-Secretary of War, for the Governorship of that State.

ALBANY, May 13. -- The order of the Public Service Commission reducing the charge of the New York Telephone Company on hand sets or "French telephones" from 25 to 15 cents a month was declared illegal today by the Appellate Division, Third Department.

BARTOW, Fla., May 13. -- Counsel for the six former Tampa policemen and their former chief on trial here in the first of the Tampa flogging cases argued all of today for a directed verdict of acquittal for the defendants, "jointly, separately and severally." The argument will continue tomorrow.

As a part of the refunding operation of Chicago Park District and subsequent thereto, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., have purchased $32,131,299 of Chicago Park District 3 1/2 and 4 per cent bonds. It is expected that public offering of these bonds will be made within ten days.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 13. -- Social security legislation was the center of discussion and of concern here today in speeches opening the sixteenth annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks in the Hotel Traymore.

BALTIMORE, May 13 (AP). -- Pimlico officials, keen for a fast field in the $25,000 added Preakness stakes on Saturday, were elated by a report from New York today that Hal Price Headley would enter his Hollyrood. The High Cloud colt was highly favored last Winter but was withdrawn from the Kentucky Derby.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- The decline in the hog market which has been under way for nearly three weeks was halted today. Aggressive buying, credited to all interests, left at the close prices steady to as much as 25 cents a hundredweight higher, compared with Tuesday's levels.

While shipments of men's and women's wear woolens and worsteds for the first quarter of this year were equal to those of 1935, the backlog of unfinished orders for both types of fabrics was much larger at the end of the quarter than at the corresponding period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

DETROIT, May 13. -- Three former Detroit bankers were found guilty today by a Federal jury of eleven women and one man of criminal violation of the National Banking Law. Those convicted, all connected with the Peoples Wayne County Bank, are: John R. Dodde, former president, Donald N. Sweeny, former executive vice president, and Edwin J. Eckert, former vice president.

A resolution to permit women to serve as vestrymen in the churches of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York was lost by a narrow margin yesterday at the second and last day's session of the 153d convention of the diocese, which was held in Synod House in the close of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

By wisely yielding to the mounting volume of criticism against a corporation tax solely on undistributed profits, the Administration has cleared the air. The Senate Finance Committee is now free to draft an act which need do no more than embody the "general philosophy" of a tax on undistributed profits.

Alfred E. Smith has not decided whether he will "take his walk" away from the Democratic party before, during or after the Philadelphia convention, it was said definitely yetserday in informed quarters, in response to reports that the former Governor already had decided not to attend the convention.

Seeking to prevent a change of control of the Equitable Mortgage and Title Guarantee Company through the sale of its stock, Walter E. Ernst, trustee in reorganization for the Madison Mortgage Corporation, filed an injunction suit yesterday in Federal Court against the Manhattan Company and seven other defendants.

ROME, May 13. -- No indication, either official or unofficial, has yet been given as to the policy Italy intends to follow in the immediate future on the League of Nations. The reason for this silence is probably that Premier Mussolini has not yet made up his mind.

With water flowing into the depressed area at the lower end of the old reservoir site in Central Park to form a small new lake, the rehabilitation of the thirty-two-acre tract, which has been a barren waste for six years, is rapidly nearing completion.

ABOARD THE ZEPPELIN HINDENBURG, En Route to Germany, May 13. -- This giant airship flew thirty miles north of London tonight instead of passing over the British capital, to avoid the possibility of any political complications.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told representatives of three Columbia newspapers yesterday at an informal press conference in Russell Hall, Teachers College, that she did not expect to take any part in the pre-election campaign of the President.

A committee appointed by Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia has invited forty artists to represent New York City and State in the First National Exhibition of American Art, to be opened on May 18 on the mezzanine floor of the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

John G. Neeser, president of the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Company, who died April 14, 1935, left an estate appraised yesterday at $261,436 gross and $247,155 net, which included securities valued at $251,581. He held 209 shares of the warehouse stock valued at $21,004.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Walter Pach, artist, author and lecturer, will speak on "Academic Art" this evening at 9 o'clock at the Uptown Gallery of the Continental Club, under the Forum Division of the Adult Education Project of the Board of Education.

RENO, May 13. -- Mrs. Gloria Debevoise Spreckels ended her eight months' marriage to Adolph B. Spreckels here today when she obtained a divorce on grounds of extreme cruelty. At the request of Mrs. Spreckels's counsel, Judge B.F. Curler cleared the court room and the testimony was heard in secret.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- A war time Tax Bill intended to scale down profits to a point below peacetime levels was turned over today to the Senate Finance Committee by a subcommittee.

The Transit Commission announced yesterday that it had denied the application of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway for a reduction of its train service between its terminal at the Harlem River and 133d Street and Port Chester.

Price movements on the local commodity futures markets were mixed yesterday. Hides, rubber, silk and cottonseed oil futures were stronger while sugar and coffee eased. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, lard, wool tops and rubber advanced, while oats, butter, eggs and silk were lower.

SYRACUSE, May 13. -- Election of Chancellor Flint of Syracuse University to be a Bishop of the Methodis Church yesterday took practically every member of the university board of trustees and faculty by surprise today, but various developments later resulted in something of a clarification of the situation.

Expertly treated, Verdi's "Rigoletto" can on occasion become one of the most harrowingly intense operas of the Italian school. It permits of no half-way measures, and when performed with the absence of dramatic force that marked last night's presentation at the Metropolitan, it easily dwindles down into little more than a boring congeries of solos and ensembles.
PHILLIPS, Wis., May 13. -- Overheard in a CCC camp:

A picture by Rob Godfrey, a 25-year-old artist, who had to ride several nights in the subway the Winter before last because he did not have a place to sleep, has been bought by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Two figures, excellent examples of the work that has won for George Grey Barnard a place among the world's foremost sculptors, have been destroyed by the casual kicks of vandals, it was revealed yesterday.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 13. -- If the press and the public must classify criminals according to number, "Public Rat No. 1" or No. 2 rather than "Public Enemy No. 1" or No. 2 should be the form, according to J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Bureau of Investigation, Department of Justice, who urged the "debunking of the falacious idea of romance in crime" in an address here today.

Fifty-eight King's Crowns, the highest recognition accorded to Columbia College students for non-athletic activities outside the classroom, have been awarded for work with the varsity show, glee club, debating team, band, chess team, orchestra and undergraduate publications.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 13 (AP). -- The human "carrier" of the common cold, the agency probably responsible for epidemics of colds, has been found in the victims of chronic sinus trouble.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 13. -- New York University won from Army on the diamond today, 11 to 8, the game terminating at the end of the eighth because of darkness.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 13. -- Running without blinkers for the second time in his racing career, J.L. Robert's Tugboat Frank scored his second consecutive victory at Narragansett Park today when he won the Providence Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth for 3-year-olds by two lengths from C. V. Whitney's Piccolo.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- A legal battle arising out of the attempt of two States to levy on the estate of Dr. John T. Dorrance was brought today to the Supreme Court.

MEDIA, Pa., May 13. -- James Cox Brady Jr.'s filly Crooning Water displayed good jumping ability and staying qualities in winning the Corinthian Plate, a two-mile race over brush, at the opening of the Rose Tree Hunt Spring race meet today.

Favorite Sons are an abomination unto Mr. BORAH. Their iniquity is not personal but vicarious. Like the Uninstructed Delegation, they are a devilish device of the Old Guard to keep the Republican people from flocking to their natural shepherd from Idaho to be safe from the wolf of monopoly.

The labor trouble in the American Merchant Marine which has come to the surface in the outlaw' strike of seamen in Atlantic and Gulf ports has been brewing for years. In 1921 a seaman's strike was broken and the International Seamen's Union of America, which is affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, was greatly weakened.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Creation of an impartial commission to visit Mexico and investigate conflicting claims of rival labor organizations was suggested today by spokesmen for the two organizations who are here to explain their respective viewpoints to the American Federation of Labor.

Calling together representatives of leading advertising agencies, the advisory committee on advertising of the Proprietary Association, at a meeting in the Hotel Biltmore yesterday afternoon, discussed plans for the expansion of the program to control copy in the packaged medicine and allied industries.

Preliminary returns indicate that gross revenues and net operating income of United States railroads in April reached high levels for the year and surpassed the $34,600,000 reported for April, 1935. Flood conditions of March ceased to exert much influence in April.

The sum of $20,000 to complete a guarantee fund of $75,000 is still needed to make possible the nineteenth season of concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium, which is scheduled to start on Wednesday evening, June 24, under the direction of Jose Iturbi, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the Stadium Concerts Committee, announced yesterday.

Eighty-one awards of letters and class numerals to the members of the New York University basketball, indoor track, swimming, fencing, indoor tennis and wrestling teams, in addition to the cheer leaders, were announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon.

The United States liner President Roosevelt, carrying 275 passengers and 4,676 sacks of mail, was held at her Hudson River pier an hour and fifteen minutes yesterday afternoon while Federal inspectors examined the credentials of her crew of 201. The examination was undertaken in response to protests by striking seamen that men unqualified to go to sea had been hired as strike-breakers.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 13. -- The annual Spring flower show of the Scarsdale Garden Club was held today at the Children's House of the Hitchcock Memorial Church here. There were about 100 exhibits of Spring flowers and flower arrangements.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday the recommendation of the committee on stock list to list Consumers Power Company $55,709,000 of first-mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series of 1936, due Nov. 1, 1970, and Engineers Public Service Company 2,344,022 shares of $1 par value common stock.
ST. LOUIS, May 13. -- The Yanks encountered more of that unexpected stubbornness from the Browns today but rode out the storm and held their slim lead in the American League standing.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP). -- Waite Hoyt yielded one hit and gave only one base on balls in six innings of relief pitching today, but it was that hit and walk that gave the Bees a 4 to 3 decision over the Pirates in ten innings. It was the second ten-inning game played by the two teams in as many days, yesterday's contest ending in a 6-6 draw.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The drive for a compromise on President Roosevelt's proposed tax on undistributed corporate profits was intensified today with the disclosure by Secretary Morgenthau that under the pending plan about half of the larger corporations of the country would have obtained substantial tax reductions on the basis of their 1934 income and dividend distributions, the last year for which the Treasury has complete figures.

JERUSALEM, May 13. -- Two Jews, Reuben Klapholtz and Alter Cohen, were shot to death by Arabs in the Old City of Jerusalem today, one as he left his home and the other as he passed an Arab cafe. The assassins are still unapprehended.

St. Joseph's Home for the Aged of the Little Sisters of the Poor, 135 West 106th Street, celebrated yesterday the fiftieth anniversary of the admission into the order of Sister Simeone de la Pentecote, who made her vows at La Tour. St. Pern, Brittany, France, in 1886.

The police launched an offensive last night to wipe out questionable "studios" for private dancing instruction, located principally in the West-Seventies but scattered in the district from West Fourteenth to West Eighty-sixth Street.

Value of Dollar in Exchange } The dollar on the local foreign: exchange market, based on quota-I tions for the French franc on the l dates indicated, compares as fol- I lows (quotations are in cents):

New York City's plans for a free trade zone on Staten Island moved forward yesterday when the Sinking Fund Commission authorized an issue of $875,000 in corporate stock to finance pier improvements within the zone.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The successful Democratic rebellion in the Senate Finance Committee against the Treasury's corporate surplus tax proposals tends to obscure the fact that the revolt was wholly against plan and not against objective.

Hole and all, the lowly doughnut came into its own yesterday afternoon as its history -- including its part in the fine art of dunking -- was discussed at a "doughnut fry" in honor of Major Helen Purviance of the Salvation Army, who mixed, shaped and fried the first doughnuts for the American Army in France in August, 1917.

Net profit of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., for the first three months of this year was $8,386,787, after expenses, interest, provision for taxes, depreciation, depletion and other charges, says the quarterly statement to be made public today.

BERLIN, May 13. -- Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels has issued an order forbidding the German press to print criticism of a new play on the morning after the opening night. The same prohibition applies to musical criticism.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Leaders who will control the Republican National Convention were declared by Senator Borah today to care nothing about "constitutional integrity," and to be "hypocritical and intellectually dishonest."

Many properties covered by the guaranteed mortgage certificates issued by the Westchester Title and Trust Company before it collapsed in 1933 were in arears in taxes from two to three years, according to testimony given yesterday. This was brought out at the mail fraud trial of four former officers or directors of the company before a jury and Federal Judge Patterson.

The efforts of bearish speculators to cover their short positions were responsible yesterday for another rally in the French franc which carried it well above the gold-import point to 6.60 cents, 3/8 point above Tuesday's final price. Accompanying the lifting of pressure on the franc, there was a decline in sterling, which lately has been buoyed up by the flight of capital from France to London.

GENEVA, May 13. -- The League of Nations Council adjourned this evening after having passed an hour in public session clearing its calendar of minor items covering its organizational and public welfare activities.

A letter to Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, urging that high qualifications be set for a director of civics teaching in the public schools was made public yesterday by the National Self Government Committee, Inc., of which Richard Welling is chairman.

Final returns of Tuesday's balloting for boards of commissioners in eleven New Jersey municipalities were announced yesterday, as the successful candidates prepared to organize next Tuesday. In many cases, the candidate receiving the greatest number of votes will be elected Mayor By the board.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Leaders who will control the Republican National Convention were declared by Senator Borah today to care nothing about "constitutional integrity," and to be "hypocritical and intellectually dishonest."

Many properties covered by the guaranteed mortgage certificates issued by the Westchester Title and Trust Company before it collapsed in 1933 were in arears in taxes from two to three years, according to testimony given yesterday. This was brought out at the mail fraud trial of four former officers or directors of the company before a jury and Federal Judge Patterson.

The efforts of bearish speculators to cover their short positions were responsible yesterday for another rally in the French franc which carried it well above the gold-import point to 6.60 cents, 3/8 point above Tuesday's final price. Accompanying the lifting of pressure on the franc, there was a decline in sterling, which lately has been buoyed up by the flight of capital from France to London.

John Knox Cowperthwaite gave a dinner last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for his fiancee, Miss Victoria M.P. Brady. The other guests included Mr. and Mrs. James Cox Brady, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Moseley Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Philip W. Smith, the Misses Genevieve G. Brady, Sheila Potter, Flora B. Garvan and Virginia Hoyt; Horace Morehead, James S. Jones, Morgan Cowperthwaite Jr. and Gilbert Lea of Philadelphia.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 13. -- Mrs. Lucy Viscusi, 40 years old, of 24 Spring Street, this city, was arrested today charged with attempting to poison a family of ten, her neighbors, by putting poison in their milk.

ST. LOUIS, May 14. -- The sensational Joe DiMaggio set the pace at Sportsman's Park today in a fifteen-hit attack that gave the Yankees their second victory in the three games played against the Browns. The count was 6 to 1. A crowd of about 1,500 watched the rout of the Browns.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- "The Plough That Broke the Plains," a vivid motion picture portrayal of soil erosion in the West, directed for the Resettlement Administration by Pare Lorentz, is having its troubles getting distributed commercially, it has developed here.

Although the Long Island Railroad's rental agreement for the use of Pennsylvania Station is based on the number of cars entering and leaving the terminal, Richard H. Burton, engineer-accountant for the State Transit Commission, testified yesterday to several glaring errors in the check-up of the cars.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., May 14. -- With Thomas Hitchcock Jr. turning in another fine exhibition of polo, his White quartet defeated Earle W. Hopping's Blue riders, 10 to 7, in one of the two Meadow Brook members' polo matches contested on the J.S. Phipps estate today.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- J. Edgar Hoover stated today that $51,374.47 of Weyerhaeuser ransom money, or money taken in exchange for the "hot" money, had been recovered since the arrest of William Mahan in San Francisco last week.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 14. -- District Attorney Martin W. Littleton of Nassau County was awaiting a message from Governor Lehman tonight as to when it will be convenient for the Governor to meet Mr. Littleton to discuss the latter's report on the fatal shooting of Mrs. Marguerite Wiggen of Brooklyn by two Nassau County detectives on April 25.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP). -- Howardi i Hughes motion picture producer [ land holder of air-speed records, j !took off at 2:05 P. M. (Eastern standard time), today on an attempted lunch-to-dinner airplane dash to Los .Angeles.
BERLIN, May 14. -- Prices on the Boerse were strong again today.

The share market shook off its lethargy yesterday and, to the accompaniment of the heaviest trading since April 30, leading stocks rose 1 to 7 points. For one thing, the advance demonstrated that "inflation" is not a prime requisite for higher stock prices.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The WPA program is costing the government and local entities $80 a month per person, as compared to a direct relief cost of $33, the Works Progress Administration revealed today.

Renewed confidence was reflected in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as constructive forces dominated almost all sections of the market. Trading volume was the largest this month for a five-hour period, and the net advance in the price average for combined domestic corporation issues of 0.41 point was the widest upswing since Jan. 23, when the group rose 0.45 point.

PARIS, May 14. -- On the ground that their presence in the Cabinet would be more of a disadvantage than otherwise in that it would offer a pretext to "enemies of the people" to spread panic, the Communist leaders today definitely declined the invitation of Leon Blum, Socialist chief, to cooperate in his coming Cabinet.
ST. THOMAS, V.I., May 14 (AP). -- Representative Marion Zioncheck, who found only trouble and disorder in Puerto Rico, by contrast found the Virgin Islands "heaven" today.

The evidence moved closer yesterday toward Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, on trial with nine other men before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a blue ribbon jury on charges of compulsory prostitution.

In a letter filed with the Board of Estimate yesterday Robert Moses, executive officer of the Triborough Bridge Authority, announced that the Authority had decided to grant a permit for the operation of buses on the bridge to the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

BOSTON, May 14 (AP). -- The Pirates, in a lusty eighth-inning rally, scored all of the runs needed for a 5-2 victory over the Bees today before a chilled crowd of 2,000. Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis and Ford Frick, National League president, were among the spectators.

A nine-story cooperative apartment house for professors at City College is to be erected at Hamilton Terrace and 141st Street, a block from the college. The building, which will be ready for occupancy in September, 1937, will cost about $600,000.

LONDON, May 14. -- The Colonial Secretary, J.H. Thomas, was named for the first time before the official inquiry today as the man alleged to have betrayed Cabinet secrets on the eve of the release of the budget last month.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The suggestion of Assistant Superintendent of Schools John L. Tildsley which appeared in THE TIMES of May 12 is timely and presents a serious question of school administration. He suggests that a charge of unfitness of a teacher should be tried by a jury of teachers. This plan is intended to replace the existing trial method by which such charges are tried by the Board of Superintendents.

A suit asking an examination before trial was asked in Federal Court yesterday by Mrs. Mabel S. Billiard Rudkin against Emil Winter, chairman of the board of directors of the Pittsburgh Steel Company. She implied bad faith in a deal whereby he allegedly persuaded her to sell stock for less than its value.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Secretary Ickes added a new note to the controversy which has surrounded the administration's $1,425,000,000 relief apropriation today when he declared in his press conference that the PWA could continue with its organization intact for the time being if the House provided $75,000,000 for PWA heavy construction.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 14. -- Capturing the Marlborough Blenheim $1,000 jumper stake with a dashing performance, Clipped Wings, a bay mare from the Fort Myer (Va.) string, scored the outstanding triumph of the third day of the Atlantic City horse show tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The House Naval Affairs Committee, following a visit of some members to the Hindenburg at Lakehurst, adopted unanimously today a resolution suggesting that the Navy Department, after study, recommission the Los Angeles, now used as a ground training ship.

A consolidated net income of $13,230,489 was reported yesterday by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, equal, after preferred dividends, to 54 cents a share on the outstanding common stock, compared with $9,370,082, or 21 cents a share, in the preceding year.
LONDON, May 14. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange generally were quiet today and British funds were inclined to ease. German issues were lower in the foreign market.

While legislative experimentation may temporarily retard the progress of American business, great opportunities for expansion lie ahead of the present cycle of readjustments, Frank A. Blair, president of the Proprietary Association, declared yesterday at the association's fifty-fourth annual convention at the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed in April was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 576,762 bales of lint and 61,450 of linters, compared with 548,913 and 60,811 in the preceding month and 468,402 and 69,341 in April of last year.

ROME, May 14. -- The Chamber of Deputies this afternoon, amid scenes of great enthusiasm, unanimously approved the bill presented by Premier Benito Mussolini annexing Ethiopia and proclaiming King Victor Emmanuel Emperor. A second bill also presented by Mussolini, appointing Marshal Pietro Badoglio Viceroy of Ethiopia, also passed without a dissenting vote.

Pirouetting with all the dignity of their advanced years, eighteen residents at the Home for the Aged and Infirm Hebrews of New York put on a rollicking musical revue yesterday afternoon that brought memories of days gone by to a delighted audience of 250 aged folk.

LONDON, May 14. -- The liner Queen Mary sailed from Southampton this evening on her final trial run and her first trip under the Cunard White Star house flag. Six hundred distinguished guests, including several Cabinet Ministers, were aboard for a twenty-four hour cruise of 470 miles.

Senator William E. Borah of Idaho declined last night to go on the air from Newark over a nationwide radio hook-up in what was scheduled to be his last major address of the pre-convention campaign when he learned that the National Broadcasting Company would grant him only a half hour over its WJZ network.
A home run by Andrew Costarino over the left-field fence in the tenth inning enabled St. John's Prep to turn back St. Augustine's, 4 -- 2, in a Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. game at Carey Field yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., May 14. -- A declaration that wealth should be taxed to provide library facilities for the 45,000,000 Americans now without access to books because libraries are a defense against dictators and demagogues, was made today by Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, speaking to the American Library Association.

Trumpery, from the C.V. Whitney stable, became the first bearer of the Eton blue and brown silks to capture the Hollis Claiming Stakes, which had its twenty-second running yesterday at Belmont Park. He was first by a head at the end of six furlongs down the Widener chute.

VATICAN CITY, May 14 (AP). -- The Vatican plans large-scale missionary work in Ethiopia, now that peace is at hand. No definite plan has been prepared, however. The missionary work will be left to the various religious organizations even now carrying it on in Ethiopia.

The General Motors Corporation reduced its holdings of reacquired common stock from 730,522 shares to 573,989 shares as of March 31 through distribution of its treasury stock to the General Motors Management Corporation under the General Motors management compensation plan, according to a report made by the company to the New York Stock Exchange.

In his speech at Washington Jan. 25 Governor SMITH asked: "What hap-"pens to the disciples of JEFFERSON "and JACKSON and CLEVELAND" when a resolution approving Mr. ROOSEVELT'S Administration is read at the Philadelphia convention? This was the answer:

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 14. -- An unexpected call to arms yesterday of the Republican Militia at a meeting presided over by General Julio Schwarzenberg has caused a stir in political circles here. The revival of the militia's activities is considered by Opposition leaders to be a political move in support of the formation of a Right Wing group of parties backing President Arturo Alessandri's administration.

The gain in bank clearings this year from the 1935 figures was extended in the week ended on Wednesday, the total for which, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,219,359,000, compared with $4,723,368,000 for the corresponding week last year, an increase of 10.5 per cent.
CHICAGO, May 14 (AP). -- Failing to hold a 10-to-1 lead that they had built going into the fourth inning, the White Sox, nevertheless, defeated the Senators. 13 to 12, today.

The city of Toronto, Ont., will be in the market on next Wednesday, with $6,144,000 of various purpose bonds, the sale to be made on competitive bidding. The bonds will be dated June 1, and will consist of $2,872,000 of 2s, maturing from 1937 to 1941; $2,283,000 of 2 1/2s, due 1937 to 1946, and $989,000 as 3s, due in 1937 to 1956.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The House leadership under Speaker Byrns earned the good-will of most responsible persons in politics and industry yesterday in functioning effectively against the Frazier-Lemke Inflation Bill. Since this leadership has been critically rated as too soft in dealing with the radical fringe, and too compliant in carrying out the wishes of the Executive, its smooth performance in this instance is worth noting.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Favorable crop comments from Winter and Spring wheat areas, with easiness in Liverpool and a lessening of the uneasiness regarding the foreign political situation resulted in an early break in prices on the Board of Trade today. The May sold off as much as 1 1/2 cents a bushel from Wednesday's finish to a new low level since Sept. 3.

BALTIMORE, May 14 (AP). -- Labeled as the horse to beat, Morton L. Schwartz's Bold Venture, winner of the Kentucky Derby, arrived today at Pimlico, where two days hence he will seek to complete the American turf's "double" by winning the forty-eighth running of the $25,000 added Preakness.

Methods of exterminating the tent caterpillars that have caused extensive damage on Staten Island were discussed at City Hall yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, C. Walter Collins of the entomology bureau of the Federal Department of Agriculture and Allyn R. Jennings, City Park Director.

Widespread improvement in the durable goods industries caused a substantial increase in The Annalist index of business activity last month. The preliminary figure rose to 93.0 from 88.4 for March and 87.8 for February, the low for the year to date.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES published a letter, "The Taxpayer Pays Anyway," by Abraham Goldfeld, vice chairman of the Housing Section of the Welfare Council.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced sharply yesterday, particularly the October position, which gained 16 points and sold at a premium over other new crop deliveries. The list closed around the top with gains of 3 to 16 points.

BERLIN, May 14. -- The Hitler regime continues to put forth every effort to present to the City of Lon don and the foreign commercial world generally a serene and prosperous countenance. The nervous truce on economic policy continues with Dr. Hjalmar Schacht still in control, at least for the time being.

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 16 per cent for the week ended May 9, as against the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The rise, reflecting the gain in retail trade last week, compares with an increase of 6 per cent for the previous week.
MONTREAL, May 14 (AP). -- Newark defeated Montreal, 7 -- 3, today to take the three-game series with the Royals, two games to one.

LONDON, May 14. -- Great Britain's approach to the United States and Japan regarding destroyer tonnage is an attempt to bring the world's destroyer fleets back to their correct relative strengths without invoking the escalator clause of the London Treaty of 1930.

Presidential primaries, now so common, have not worked as well as was hoped by the reformers who got them made compulsory by law. This is especially true of the Presidential preference party vote. It is binding upon nobody, and is often only an idle political gesture. But one thing is to be said for its operation this year.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 14 (AP). -- State police seeking two of the band of five bandits who robbed the Pine Bush National Bank, pressed their hunt over a wide New York-New Jersey border area tonight.
Purchase of a midtown business building by an investor and various deals for housing properties were the items of chief interest in realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

JERUSALEM, May 14. -- After twenty-five days of chaos, panic, arson and terrorism there is not yet the slightest indication of a return to normalcy. To the contrary the tension is increasing and acts of terrorism are mounting with the result that every one is panicky.
" Speed," a Metro film with James Stewart, Wendy Barrie and Una Merkel, opens this morning at the Capitol.

In its first appearance since the highly successful "Murder in the Cathedral," the Popular Price unit of the WPA bobs up tonight at the Manhattan Theatre in "Class of '29." This is the item by Orrie Lashin and Milo Hastings about which there was a little flurry a while back -- a sort of Red scare.

MOSCOW, May 14. -- A diary found near the body of a Soviet flier disclosed today that he had lived for forty-five days after his plane had crashed on barren Chukhotsk Peninsula near Bering Strait, only to succumb to cold and starvation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 14. -- After adopting a statement denouncing the liquor traffic and proposing a pledge-signing campaign in all Methodist Episcopal churches, the committee on temperance, prohibition and public morals today failed to agree on a resolution to have the Bishops and all ministerial and lay delegates at the general conference sign a total abstinence pledge in a public ceremony here.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 14. -- One hundred and thirty-four aspirants for the women's British golf championship, including nine Americans, wound up their practice today in perfect weather and settled down to wait for the thirty-six-hole qualifying round to be played tomorrow and Saturday.

BOSTON, May 14 (AP). -- The best features of all the tested methods of selecting players for the 1936 all-star game, which will be played at the Boston National League park on July 7, were combined today by the moguls of major league baseball.

LONDON, May 14. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin announced today that his government would try to re-form the League of Nations so drastically that the United States, Germany and Japan could be persuaded to join it.
ALBANY, May 14. -- The 1936 session of the Legislature adjourned at 7:14 o'clock this morning after an all-night session and the weary members began moving toward their homes.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Faced with revolt in their own ranks and with virtually solid opposition among the Republicans, administration leaders in the Senate found themselves today with their backs to the wall in their fight to save even the principle of President Roosevelt's proposed tax on undistributed corporate profits.
