A contribution of $3,000 from the Friedsam Foundation, Inc., to the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army was announced last night by Chalmers Wood, chairman.

VIENNA, May 14. -- This correspondent has just seen Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, leader of the Heimwehr, who was forced out of his position as Vice Chancellor last night, leave for Rome from Vienna's South Station. He received a warm send-off from several thousand supporters.

The retirement of William Joyce, chief engineer of the American Merchant liner American Farmer and a sailor for forty-seven years, was announced yesterday by the International Mercantile Marine Company, owner of the line. He will sail for Southampton today on the American Trader, and will make his home there with his wife and daughter.

A plan to establish a world sugar market in New York reached an active stage yesterday when a special committee, appointed by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, held an organization meeting for preliminary work.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange rket, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Price movements continued mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Coffee and hide futures were lower, while rubber and cottonseed oil advanced. Trading generally was at a good pace. On the cash markets cotton, rye, Rio coffee, butter, lard and rubber advanced, while declines appeared in wheat, corn, oats, flour, eggs, silk and cocoa.
LONDON, May 14 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
Charles Mattmann, stalwart 17-year-old Forest Hills junior, won the tennis championship of the Athletic Association of Private Schools for Trinity yesterday.

Three separate proceedings yesterday started the machinery for a final triangular settlement of all intercorporate claims among the three principal companies once dominated by Ivar Kreuger, who committed suicide in Paris on March 12, 1932.

To promote, protect and police the performing rights of serious music in this country, leading American composers effected an organization last night, to be known as the American Grand Rights Association, Inc.

Action withdrawing the "red cards" which were issued against the B. Forman Company, Rochester, and the Rike-Kumler Company, Dayton, is being taken by the Fashion Originators Guild of America, and these stores are rejoining the guild, it was learned here yesterday.

The Automobile Manufacturers Association will petition delegates to the Republican National Convention to include a plank in the party's platform calling for the endorsement and continuance of reciprocal trade agreements and the most-favored-nation principle, it was disclosed yesterday afternoon by Edgar W. Smith, vice president of General Motors Export Corporation.

The charter proposed by the New York City Charter Revision Commission should be scrapped, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx told the members of the commission at a public hearing held last night in the Bronx County Court House.

NEWARK, N.J., May 14. -- Launching a bitter attack on the present leadership of the Republican party, Senator William E. Borah of Idaho declared here tonight that the defeat of the Social Security Bill by the New York State Republican Assembly was typical of its folly.

TOPEKA, Kan. May 14 (AP). -- Governor Landon announced today that a special legislative session would be held, probably in July, to propose a constitutional amendment for Kansas's participation in major phases of the Federal social security program. The amendment will be submitted to the voters in the November election.

Supreme Court Justice John MacCrate in Brooklyn yesterday sustained the so-called "subordination agreement" which the New York Stock Exchange requires be filed with it when any part of the purchase price of a Stock Exchange seat is supplied by another person.
ALBANY, May 14. -- Amid the tension and disorder which marked the end of the session, the Legislature voted a broad legislative inquiry into communism in the schools as practically its last act.

R.P. Clayberger of Calkins Holden has been re-elected president of the National Better Business Bureaus, Inc., it was announced here yesterday. Other officers elected are: Vice president, Major I. E. Lambert, attorney; treasurer, John L. Anderson of McCann-Erickson, and secretary, Warren Agry of Good Housekeeping.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Prospects for an early campaign to organize unions in the iron and steel industry under the joint auspices of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers and the Committee for Industrial Organization appeared bright today, according to officials of the CIO.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

DETROIT, May 14 (AP). -- Robert Moses Grove, left-handed ace of the Boston pitching staff, stopped the Tigers with five hits for the second time this season as the Red Sox won today, 3 to 1, and took the series, two games to one.

With more than 3,000 blooms and a display of a number of new and striking varieties, the annual tulip show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society opened yesterday afternoon at 598 Madison Avenue. The exhibition, which is under the auspices of the Horticultural Society of New York, was planned originally for next week, but the warm weather necessitated an earlier showing.

TORONTO, May 14 (AP). -- Albany, which came here after fifteen successive losses, made it four victories in a row over the Maple Leafs by wining both ends of today's doubleheader by scores of 6 -- 4 and 2 -- 0. Harry Matuzak went the distance for the Senators in the opener. Bob Burke, Albany southpaw, was never in difficulty in the afterpiece.
CHICAGO, May 14. -- A promise is a promise to W. Lawson Little Jr., the newest businessman-golfer, so he will pass up the British open at Hoylake next month, much as he would like to play in it.

ALBANY, May 14. -- Two measures to establish the Palisades Interstate Park Commission as an interstate "authority" apart from the State park system were defeated in the Assembly before adjournment today after sharp debate.
ALBANY, May 14. -- The drive to legalize pari-mutuel machines at the New York race tracks went down to a final defeat early this morning as the 1936 session of the Legislature came to an end.

The annual garden party of the New York Zoological Society was held yesterday at the Zoological Park in the Bronx. Fifteen of the patronesses, headed by Mrs. John Sloane, chairman of the ladies' auxiliary of the society, received the guests.

HONOLULU, May 14. -- The submarine S -- 4, symbol of disaster and hope, will end her career in 1,000 fathoms of water west of Oahu tomorrow. Her usefulness to the navy ended, the vessel that in December, 1927, carried forty men to death off the coast of Massachusetts win be towed far to sea from Pearl Harbor for her last dive.
LONDON, May 14. -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's speech in Albert Hall today to 7,000 women members of Conservative party associations:

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard reserved decision yesterday on requests for attorneys' fees aggregating $337,000 in the reorganization proceedings of the Susquehanna Silk Mills. In the company's equity receivership $158,000 had been allowed to the attorneys.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 14. -- The danger that investors may become speculators because of continuing low yields on securities was expressed here today by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Senator Wheeler of Montana charged the Association of American Railways and the managements of the country's great trunk lines had engaged in "cheap propaganda" to bring about the repeal of the long-and-short-haul clause in the Interstate Commerce Act before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today.

Dr. Milton Thomashefsky, Brooklyn ear, nose and throat specialist, who was shot five years ago by his nurse who then shot and killed herself, died at 5:30 P.M., yesterday at the Half Moon Hotel in Coney Island, where he had been living in a semi-paralyzed state since the shooting. He was 39 years old.

Messages were exchanged yesterday between Governor Blanton Winship at San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Washington officials at the opening of the first exhibition of commercial and industrial products of that island at 67 Broad Street.

The realty firm of Hickernell-Romeyn, Inc., has been formed, with Mrs. Jane Smith Romeyn as president and Mrs. Bobbe Hickernell as vice president. The office is in a remodeled house leased from the Girl Scouts at 134 East 56th St., between Park and Lexington Avs. Mrs. Hickernell was with Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc., for five years.

The dissolution of the American Acceptance Council will not have any important effect upon the bill market in this country, bankers and bill dealers said yesterday. The council, through its seventeen years of educational work, has helped to establish the use of acceptances and while conditions of depressed trade and low money rates have contracted the volume of bill business the need for such an institution as the council is past, it was said.

A banking group headed by Speyer Co., Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., Hayden, Stone Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $17,500,000 of general and refunding 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due May 1, 1976, of the Port of New York Authority.

The franc continued to recover yesterday under the stimulus of short covering and reached 6.60 1/2 cents, the best price since April 1. It closed at 6.60 1/4 cents, up 1/4 point, while future contracts improved to a discount of 38 3/4 points below the spot rate, 3 1/4 points narrower than on Wednesday.

TRENTON, May 14. -- Unless the Court of Pardons commutes his sentence to life imprisonment, Jacob Ciemiengo, who will not be 17 years old until July 16, must die in the electric chair for murder, the Court of Errors and Appeals today having refused to set aside his conviction and order a new trial.

Charles P. Graddick, superintendent of the air mail service, speaking yesterday at the Third International Philatelic Exposition at the Grand Central Palace, prophesied that within five years transatlantic air mail would be "commonplace."

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The Senate Finance Committee late today reached virtual agreement to levy a flat 15 per cent tax on corporation income, but bogged down on the question of how or whether to write into the revenue bill a levy on undistributed corporate earnings.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP). -- Moving to give law enforcement agencies a powerful new weapon in their fight on crime, the Communications Commission today shifted its allocation of wave bands to provide frequencies for a country-wide police radio network.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 14. -- Reacting to recent emotional outbursts, which came to a climax yesterday in the school strike disorders, Puerto Rico gave indications today that it was seriously considering the outcome if the present course continued unchecked.

A steady demand for men's wear Fall suitings was reported yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Prices during the week were steady and in some quarters showed a hardening tendency. Buyers, the report states, apparently have given up seeking low prices and are now paying the prices quoted by the mills.

MOSCOW, May 14. -- With ten picked experts, representing the cream of talent from five of the leading chess-playing countries of Europe, and one from Cuba entered for a competition which will last for a period of four weeks in this city and Leningrad, the international masters congress, sponsored by the U.S.S.R. Chess Federation, convened today.

The defeat of the Frazier-Lemke bill in the House of Representatives is one of the most reassuring developments of the present session. Ostensibly this was a bill to provide farm relief, through the refinancing of farm mortgages; but its real significance was that it proposed to meet the demand of the inflationists for a new currency issue of $3,000,000,000.
Victor J. Sudman, president of the Black Diamond Line, returned on the United States liner Manhattan yesterday after making a tour of the company's foreign offices and agencies.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 14 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government increased $5,498,994, and those b chartered banks declined $11,462,235 in the week ended yesterday, said the report issued today. The statement follows:
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Secretary Morgenthau was considering today plans for the June 15 Treasury finance when $686,616,400 in 1 1/8 per cent notes will be retired.

There was no fighting at Ebbets Field yesterday. There wasn't even a contest. Despite the pugnacity displayed on Tuesday by Manager Casey Stengel, his Dodgers were like lambs before the roaring attack of the league-leading Gas House Gang from St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Composite wholesale prices softened in the week ended on May 9 under the influence of declines in the cost of farm products and foods, the Bureau of Labor Statistics made known today. The index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was off to 78.6, compared with 79.1 the preceding week and 79.9 a year ago.

Steamship operators will welcome a thorough investigation of the alleged practice of issuing false certificates to men posing as seamen on American ships, according to A.J. McCarthy, vice president in charge of operations of the International Mercantile Marine Company.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- In a brief citing the Railroad Retirement and Social Security Acts as adding to the expense burdens under which the railroads operate, R.V. Fletcher, general counsel of the Association of American Railroads, today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to continue indefinitely the emergency freight surcharges.
The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that fully listed companies had reported the following changes in holdings of reacquired stocks and bonds:

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld yesterday the National Labor Relations Board, declining to dismiss the board's application for an order enforcing its ruling against the Friedman-Harry Marks Clothing Company which has an office here and a factory in Richmond, Va.

PARIS, May 14 (AP). -- The statement of the Bank of France disclosed today that there was a drain of 2,739,000,000 francs in gold, about $181,689,000, in the week ended on May 8. This loss, the heaviest of the year, followed a Leftist triumph in the Chamber of Deputies election.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14. -- The Rutgers baseball team today defeated Princeton, 4 -- 2, for its second conquest of the Tigers this week. The other triumph, coming by the score of 10 -- 6, was recorded in New Brunswick on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Exports from the United States to South America and Oceania declined slightly in March, compared with March, 1935, but shipment to all other geographical divisions increased, the Department of Commerce reported today on the basis of statistics corrected to May 12. Imports increased from all major geographical divisions except South America and Africa.

The pamphlet report of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, released for publication today, shows current assets on Dec. 31 of $641,470,025 and current liabilities of $216,132,547, compared to $608,939,709 and $201,774,363, respectively, at the close of 1934.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Fairly active buying of hogs by local butchers on the steadiness in fresh pork lifted the price of hogs as much as 10 cents a hundredweight in the early trading, but as soon as the demand let up an easier undertone developed which wiped out the gain and some sales late in the day were regarded as slightly lower.

The second of two massive panels of sculptural glass designed by Attilio Piccirilli is to be officially installed today at Rockefeller Center. It is to be placed over the main entrance to the International Building. The first panel, over the entrance to the Palazzo d'Italia, was installed last Fall.

LONDON, May 14. -- There is good reason to believe that banks and insurance companies in the City of London have been warned from high official quarters to abstain from giving fresh credits to Germany and to recall discreetly wherever possible money from that country as a new and severe financial breakdown is anticipated.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

As a tribute to his work as president of the New York Furniture Exchange, Rudolf Braun was given a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night, which was attended by more than 250 representatives of the manufacturing and distribution branches of the industry.

The rise of the stock market yesterday was accompanied by rumors that the Federal Reserve Board would soon announce more liberal margin rules. Since the margin requirements that recently became effective have been regarded in Wall Street as a factor restricting trading and the rise of the market, traders were heartened by the rumor.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag, who heard a suit by Maison Prunier, conducting Prunier's restaurant in Paris, with a branch in London, granted yesterday a temporary injunction restraining Prunier's Restaurant and Cafe, Inc., of 121 East Fifty-second Street, from operating as the Prunier de Paris, Inc., or from representing in any way that it is connected with the restaurants operated by the plaintiff in Europe.

An unemployed clothing worker cannot be compelled to try to find a job selling diamonds, writing a book or playing the violin before a court will require his wife to support him if she is able, Justice Panken of the Domestic Relations Court ruled yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., May 14. -- Here are some of the points made by former President Hoover in his speech tonight:

BERLIN, May 14. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler today received Sir Eric Phipps, the British Ambassador, in the presence of Baron Constantin von Neurath, Foreign Minister, for a discussion of the British questionnaire recently submitted to the Foreign Office regarding the true meaning of Hitler's peace proposals.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will report the London naval treaty to the Senate tomorrow with a view to asking its ratification early next week, according to plans made today by administration leaders.

Count and Countess Giuseppe Cippico gave a dinner last night in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. The guests were seated at a table with a centerpiece of a miniature Mexican sunken garden containing a lake, small cactus and rubber plants, and statuettes brought from Mexico recently by Count Cippico.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., May 14. -- Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill, one of the most consistently steady players in the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association, today won the second one-day event with a low gross score of 92 for the Woodway Country Club links.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- The prepared text of former President Hoover's address tonight before the Republican women of Pennsylvania was as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The El Paso Natural Gas Company of El Paso, Texas, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $7,500,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series A, 4 1/2 per cent, due June 1, 1951, and $3,750,000 of 4 3/4 per cent convertible debentures due June 1, 1946, the proceeds to be used chiefly for refunding higher-interest-bearing obligations, amounting to about $8,500,000.

Alfred E. Smith Jr., son of the former Governor, has made a complaint to District Attorney William C. Dodge that he was blackmailed for $10,000 in cash and $10,000 in promissory notes by a young woman and three men. The complaint will be investigated by the New York County grand jury on Monday, when evidence will be submitted by Assistant District Attorneys Harold W. Hastings and John J. Sullivan.

BALBOA, C.Z., May 14. -- Admiral Joseph M. Reeves, on the battleship Pennsylvania, will leave the Panama Canal early Saturday morning, leading the United States fleet to the equator, where 32,000 "pollywogs" will be changed to "shellbacks" and he will make good his desire to make the fleet "seagoing."

BERLIN, May 14. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener upon his arrival in Frankfort this morning found the Propaganda Ministry's boycott on the use of his name in the press or the radio to be only partly effective. He received from Governor Jacob Sprengler of Hesse a silver cup presented by the city of Frankfort. The cup bore the inscription: "To the leader of the dirigible Hindenburg in commemoration of its landing at the new Frankfort airport."

Showing more optimism than members of last year's senior class in the Columbia School of Engineering, who predicted they would have an annual salary of $3,330 five years after graduation, seniors this year, in answering the poll conducted by "The Engineer," school annual, estimated they would be earning $4,700 by 1941.

Lester Cohen's first book since his novel "Sweepings," published ten years ago, will be issued by Covici, Friede late in June under the title "Two Worlds." It is a picture of how men live in the modern world under fascism, communism and capitalism.

NEWARK, N.J., May 14. -- Three men are being held at Police headquarters here under warrants obtained by the Nutley police charging participation in the hold-up of an Erie Railroad train in Nutley on April 17, when $958 was stolen.

Mayor La Guardia accepted the honorary chairmanship of a committee formed last night at a dinner at the Hotel Delmonico to sponsor and aid the Summer concerts, which for the last six years have been presented in the city parks by Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince and his orchestra.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 13 as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,475,000,000 a decrease of $2,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $10,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Officials of the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee reported a marked increase in the contributions received during the week toward the $1,500,000 sought for family welfare this year. The present total is $774,731, Lawrence Marks, chairman of the committee, said at a meeting in the Hotel Biltmore.

Profiting by a serious oversight by his opponent in their adjourned game from the fourteenth round, in which it was supposed there were excellent chances for a draw, Albert C. Simonson, youthful member of the Manhattan Chess Club, added one point to his score in the National Chess Federation's championship at the Hotel Astor last night.

PITTSBURGH, May 14. -- Business activity in the Pittsburgh district showed further marked gains last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's index of general business stood above 87 per cent of normal last week, a new peak in the recovery period and the highest level since the end of October, 1930. This index was 65 a year ago and 49 in the corresponding week of 1933.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 14 (AP). -- Walloping John Berly, a former team-mate, for eight hits, Rochester defeated Baltimore today, 7 to 4. Crabtree hit a home run over the right-field wall in the first inning for Rochester.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt took tea at Mt. Vernon as guests of the State regents of the Mt. Vernon Ladies' Association, received a group representing twenty Indian tribes, and entertained the Washington newspaper corps at an "at home" this evening.

If it were not such a grim piece of business, the fate of the Stoll kidnapper might be described in the lilting lines of the old nursery chant: He was captured in California on Monday, landed by plane in Louisville, Ky., on Tuesday, sentenced to life by a Federal judge and started for Atlanta on Wednesday, and such is the end of THOMAS H. ROBINSON Jr.

Edgar L. Eckert, 54 years old, assistant treasurer and director of Rogers Peet Company, men's clothing retailers, was found strangled in a men's washroom of the Independent Subway station at Forty-second Street and Eighth Avenue, at 2:40 A.M. yesterday.

Thirty-seven artists and models whose intention was to bivouac in the office of the WPA Art Project, 6 East Thirty-ninth Street, until work was given them, defied police orders to leave the building at closing time, were physically ejected and arrested on charges of disorderly conduct.
BARRE, Vt., May 14 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley told delegates to the Vermont Democratic Convention today, "There is no longer any such thing as rock-ribbed Republican territory."

ANTLERS, Okla., May 14 (AP). -- Two Oklahoma penitentiary guards and a farmer, kidnapped as hostages, were released near here tonight by fugitive convicts, four of whom were being trailed closely by a posse of officers, who said they were only "ten minutes" behind their quarries.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Samaria, leaving today for Liverpool via Glasgow and Belfast, includes Mrs. Marion R. Dudley, W. Sanders Davies, Mrs. J.D. Chapman, Mr. and Mrs. F.H. Kendrick, E. Foster-Cooper, George Noble, Mr. and Mrs. E.H. Earp, Kenneth J. Ridgway and Richard Hayward, film producer.

GENEVA, May 14. -- As long as sanctions continue and no longer, an arrangement for mutual armed assistance among Great Britain and other Mediterranean powers against any attack by Italy will also continue, it became clear today.
CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP). -- Gordon (Dusty) Rhodes held Cleveland to three scattered hits today as the Athletics trounced the third-place Indians, 4 to 0.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Cooperation of citizens who unite in the American Red Cross to carry on welfare work is building a public sentiment which will eventually divorce welfare activity from political influence and party alignment, said Albert D. Lasker, Chicago advertising executive, in an address today before delegates to the Red Cross convention at their final session.
ALBANY, May 14. -- Pointing to violations of the State Milk Law, Peter G. Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Agriculture, warned today that he would take "drastic action" if these violations continued.

That an ill wind blows some good was proved by the Fordham baseball team yesterday. With a miniature gale blowing across Fordham Field, making virtually every catch unpredictable, the Maroon nine scored a 6-to-4 triumph over Brooklyn College before 1,000 chilled fans.

MOSCOW, May 14. -- Charges of embezzlement of more than 5,000,000 rubles in social insurance funds during the past three years were brought today against nineteen former executives of the Ukrainian Trade Union Council, all of whom have been ousted.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- Herbert Hoover called upon the Republican party tonight to draw up a platform at Cleveland next month composed of "fighting words," backed by "a determination to restore American liberty and to revitalize American life."

BOSTON, May 14. -- Patrick J. Duane, 74-year-old special District Court justice, indignant at Governor Curley's purpose to retire aging judges, challenged the Governor tonight to meet him in physical combat in the auditorium of the House of Representatives.

The world economic situation remained uncertain in March, according to the monthly review of foreign conditions in The Annalist, issued today. Industrial activity outside of the United States and Canada showed little change. International trade persisted at the levels that have prevailed since last November. Commodity stocks held their ground. Commodity prices continued weak, however, in part because of sanctions and the uncertain European political situation.

Mrs. Hazel Margery Archibald Draper, wife of Eben S. Draper, son of the late Governor of Massachusetts, returned yesterday as a cabin passenger on the Cunard White Star liner Georgic. She stowed away on the Georgic in New York April 20 after escaping from the Four Winds Sanatorium at Katonah, N.Y., the previous day.
The first New York performance of the opera "The Dybbuk," the music by Lodovico Rocca, after the play of Sholom Ansky, was given last night in Carnegie Hall with the conductor and cast above listed.

The United States Foil Company, which controls the Reynolds Metals Company and the Reynolds Corporation, will announce that its net assets on Dec. 31, 1935, were equal to approximately $23.32 a share on the common stock, after allowing for Federal taxes on unrealized appreciation on investments.

State prison terms were imposed in General Sessions yesterday on seven men and two women members of the "arsenal gang" for possessing a machine gun. They were seized in a raid last March 16 in a West Ninetieth Street boardinghouse which they used as a hideout. Sentence on the tenth member of the gang, another woman, was put off until May 28.

Another class of racing yachts appeared on the horizon yesterday with the announcement that one had been formed and twenty craft underwritten which may take the place of the famous Interclubs, now ten years old, and also may become an international division.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP). -- The German-American Mixed Claims Commission had before it tonight official Austrian documents which the United States contends definitely establish Germany's wartime sabotage guilt.

BOSTON, May 14. -- Two bar associations joined with numerous prominent lawyers and laymen today in denouncing Governor Curley's proposal to compel elderly judges of the Massachusetts courts to submit to mental and physical examinations with the threat of removal held over those failing to measure up to qualifications which he and the Executive Council may see fit to establish.

The heavy influx of gold from foreign countries, seasonal retirement of currency from circulation and continued but smaller Treasury disbursements combined to lift reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System $79,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday and to expand the excess of reserves over requirements $70,000,000 to a new high level on the present movement of $2,770,000,000.

KANSAS CITY, May 14. -- A dramatic attack on the use of "twilight sleep" for painless childbirth was made here today by several of the country's leading obstetricians at a symposium in the section on obstetrics and gynecology at the annual session of the American Medical Association.

Whatever doubts Carl Hubbell might have harbored as to whether his teammates were really his supporters were dispelled at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the Giants, scoring sufficiently behind the southpaw ace for the first time in his last four starts, recorded their second straight success over the Cubs.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The House refused today to accept the Senate's elimination of the $26,500,000 appropriation for mail contract payments to steamship companies from the $975,112,000 Treasury-Postoffice Supply Bill. Senate action on the appropriation is now necessary.
Vacation days are just around the corner. And that reminds us:

Fighting side by side against the rank-and-file strike of seamen are the shipowners and the leaders of the International Seamen's Union of America, an A.F. of L. affiliate, which has outlawed the strike and is supplying men to replace strikers.

SEATTLE, May 14. -- One hundred and eleven passengers of the steamer North Sea and thirty members of the crew were taken off the ship today when it appeared to be foundering in Alaskan waters, but were put back on board tonight when the situation improved.

Pedro Montanez, hard-hitting young lightweight contender from Puerto Rico, will make his initial appearance in Madison Square Garden tonight when he faces Leonard Del Genio, rugged Harlem battler, in the feature ten-round bout.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 14 (AP). -- The Bisons routed Syracuse, 14 to 8 and 17 to 4, in a double-header today to make a clean sweep of the four-game series. The victories extended the Herd's winning streak to eight games, during which it has scored 101 runs.

MIAMI, May 14 (AP). -- Mrs. Sarah Wyman, Miami widow, won a $175,000 judgment today against Edward L. Newhouse Jr., of New York, for breach of promise and seduction. The 42-year-old Mrs. Wyman had asked $500,000 damages.
The Cavan Gaelic football team and the Limerick hurling fifteen, each champion of Ireland, arrived in this country yesterday aboard the Manhattan of the United States Lines.

The New York Stock Exchange will suspend from dealings today forty bond and note issues of thirty foreign companies and governments which have failed to apply for the registration of these issues in accordance with the rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mayor La Guardia was authorized by the Board of Estimate yesterday to issue a temporary permit covering the Summer months that would allow the Triborough Bridge Authority to approve the use of New York Omnibus Company buses on the Triborough Bridge.

Seven home runs were hit as Seward Park upset the league-leading Tottenville High nine, 11 -- 9, in a lower Manhattan-Richmond P.S.A.L. battle at the Prospect Park Parade Grounds yesterday. Despite the reversal, Tottenville held first place.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 15. -- The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks closed its sixteenth annual conference here today in the Hotel Traymore by electing officers and adopting resolutions, including one which protested against "corporate refunding operations which fail to give the holders of called bonds a reasonable opportunity to restore their investment by the purchase of the refunding bonds at the prices at which they are offered to the public."

Christian Nissen, who will sail one of the German yachts coming to this country for the Bermuda race and the following contest from Bermuda to Germany, arrived herb yesterday and gave to Herbert L. Stone, chairman of the Cruising Club of America race committee, the list of ten European yachts that either are on their way or are to be shipped by steamship for the events.

Among the inward-moving throngs at the railroad stations, bus terminals and piers there are tens of thousands in the course of every year who find themselves in need of some such friendly guidance or further help as the Travelers Aid Society is organized and maintained to give.

The Dalton School, whose work with children is well known, will open its annual exhibition of pupils' work this afternoon. It will continue until May 22, the school being open tomorrow for the benefit of those who find it impossible to attend on other days.

BOSTON, May 15 (AP). -- The Bees gave Leroy Parmelee an unexpected stinging today while trouncing the pace-setting Cardinals, 7 -- 5. The visiting righthander was found for ten hits and all except one of the Boston runs.

DENVER, May 15 (AP). -- Michael Edward O'Brien, the "forgotten artist" of Denver, is dead, but the announcement was delayed for days. He died Tuesday at Denver General Hospital, listed only as "Michael O'Brien, hodcarrier, 82."

ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP). -- Every man on the Washington team except Pitcher Buck Newsom got at least one hit as the Senators defeated the Browns, 10-5, today. Not a little credit for the victory goes to Newsom, however, for he fanned eleven batsmen.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 15. -- Charging the State Republican leadership with ineptitude that has brought about a succession of defeats for twenty years, George H. Sibley called tonight for the retirement of Charles D. Hilles as national committeeman from New York.

The French franc weakened again yesterday as the sustaining effects of short-covering began to wear off. It dropped to 6.59 5/8 cents and closed at 6.59 3/4 cents, off 1/2 point. At these quotations, however, it was still more than a point above the price at which gold is shipped here from Paris.

The ferry system on San Francisco Bay, controlled by the Southern Pacific Company through a $10,000,000 investment, incurred a net loss of $431,702 in 1935, against a net income of $600,057 in 1934, according to the final instalment of the Southern Pacific's report for last year.

Following the defeat of the Desmond bill in the last Legislature, which would have given the Queens Midtown Tunnel Authority the alternative of building a bridge over the East River at Thirty-eighth Street, Borough President Samuel C. Levy of Manhattan said yesterday that he would seek Federal funds for the bridge.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotat. ions for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Two daring bold-up men, moving with the precision of trained actors, robbed a gem dealer of $10,000 worth of mounted and loose diamonds in the lobby of the apartment house in which he lives at 145 West Fifty-fifth Street early yesterday morning.

MOSCOW, May 15. -- After five drawn games in the first round yesterday, two more matches ended similarly today in the second round of the international chess masters' tournament. Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba and Dr. Emanuel Lasker of England, two former world champions, figured in the even encounters, with Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia and A. Lilienthal of Hungary, respectively.

While the national gain over last year of about 2.5 per cent in retail advertising linage for the first four months of this year compares with a rise of 9 per cent in dollar sales volume of department stores for the same period, this development is to be regarded as normal, comment in retail advertising circles here yesterday indicated.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- State Senator G. Mason Owlett of Tioga County was agreed upon tonight at a caucus of State Republican leaders to succeed former Senator David A. Reed as the party's National Committeeman from Pennsylvania.

If it were customary to run up some sort of flag to signify the opening of the suburban night-spot season this coming week would certainly be the time for doing it. Four of the pastoral flock, including the bellwether of them all, Ben Marden's Riviera at Fort Lee, N.J., will begin their seasonal activities with appropriate ceremonies, and the outdoor race will be on.

Dr. Blanche Colton Williams, biographer of George Eliot and head of the English Department at Hunter College, will entertain the members of her staff this afternoon at a tea to be held in the White and Gold Room of the Hotel Plaza.

KANSAS CITY, May 15. -- Experimental clues to the origin of such prevalent fatal conditions as coronary thrombosis and similar degenerative diseases of middle life and old age, the underlying causes of which have been elusive, were reported today before the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Medical Association by Dr. Gregory Shwartzman of the laboratories of Mount Sinai Hospital, New York City.

Joseph Curran, young and militant disciple of Harry Bridges, radical Pacific Coast labor leader, is the key man of the rank-and-file strike of seamen here. He told this reporter in an interview why the strikers are fighting their own union leaders as well as the ship-owners.

SHANGHAI, May 15. -- The first enlargement of the Japanese garrison in North China, whose ultimate strength has not been revealed, was made today when four special trains took an initial contingent of 1,700 reinforcements to Tientsin. They had been landed from transports at Tangku.

BALTIMORE, May 15. -- More than 4,000 persons, hundreds of whom are prominent in society and club circles of New York, Philadelphia, Washington and other cities, were guests at the Preakness ball tonight, before Maryland's notable Spring racing event tomorrow at Pimlico.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., May 15. -- W. Stanton Barbour of Siwanoy, medalist and winner of the Morris County invitation golf tournament last year, was defeated in the opening round of match play in the 1936 renewal of that event today, losing by 1 up on the eighteenth green in a close match with Henry Picoli of the Garden City Golf Club.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 15. -- For the second time in two weeks Mrs. A. L. Felling, a new member of the association, won low net honors today at the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament at the Shackamaxon Country Club.

BALTIMORE, May 15. -- A field of fourteen, from which several scratches are expected, has been named for the forty-sixth running of the $25,000 added Preakness Stakes, Maryland's greatest horse race, which will be renewed at Pimlico tomorrow before an anticipated crowd of 50,000.

IT was Manager Charley Grimm of the Cubs, heading for Philadelphia, who said, "Never mind the Fancy Dans in the field or the guys who hit with two out and none on. Give me the hitters who bring the runs in. Ott, Berger, Medwick -- those are the hitters a pitcher hates to see come up there. Get a pencil and paper and figure it out some day."

Beaten in the Illinois primary, Mayor KELLY of Chicago and National Committeeman PAT NASH, masters of the Cook County machine, took their medicine in public nearly three weeks ago. The Democratic State Convention, remarkably rich in Kelly-Nash delegates, was held at Springfield last week.

While prices on the Cotton Exchange held yesterday within a narrower range and ended 2 points higher to 2 points lower than on Thursday, the undertone continued to display decided firmness under a broader interest on the part of both foreign and domestic consumers.
The following are some of the inspirational and religious books that lave been published recently:

It is unnecessary to take an alarmist view of the German economic and financial situation in order to appreciate the problems with which that country is confronted. It has long been known that the improvement of business and the increase of employment under the Hitler Government have been brought about primarily by the German rearmament program and that rearmament has been financed by heavy borrowing.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 15. -Tied until today for team honors in Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association, Yale made a 9-0 sweep in its play-off with Dartmouth and tomorrow faces Princeton for the circuit championship.

August Heckscher, 87-year-old philanthropist and real estate owner, must continue to pay $15,000 a year to Frieda Hempel, former opera star, for the rest of her life under an agreement made May 11, 1928, under a decision yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 15. -- Led by Mrs. Jonathan Thorne, the metropolitan champion, the formidable Innis Arden Golf Club team of Greenwich, Conn., today vanquished the Gedney Farm aggregation, 4 1/2 to 1/2, in the Westchester interclub matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

Thanks to Al Smith's relief pitching and a sparkling double play that ended the game, Hal Schumacher and the Giants subdued the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but their 2-to-0 advantage was strongly endangered for a few minutes in the concluding frame.

Alexander Printz, chairman of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board, Inc., wired yesterday to Senator Pope of Idaho, protesting against the bill, sponsored by the Senator, which places a 3 per cent tax on all furs and articles of which fur is the component material of chief value.

The salt-water fishing horizon broadens this week-end with the first concentration of anglers at Peconic Bay. Although the initial catches of weakfish on rod and reel were recorded only a week ago, indications are that the ports on the famous bay in Eastern Long Island will do a rushing business.

LONDON, May 15. -- Soviet Russia has thrown a new element of discord into the world naval situation by refusing to regulate or limit her navy in the Far East except by a specific agreement with Japan.

Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, announced yesterday plans for the retirement of the $25,000,000 of capital notes, sold by the company to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in 1933, through the sale to shareholders of new preferred stock convertible into common stock.

No doubt many physicians read the letter signed "Ah, Depression" with feelings similar to those of the motorist who offered a weary-looking hitchhiker a ride, only to be spurned because his car was not equipped with a radio.

Having nurtured for almost three years an ambition to effect reprisals for being beaten unconscious with a lead pipe, being hit on the eye and suffering a hold-up in her disorderly house, a woman who said she was Mrs. Joan Martin had her inning yesterday on the stand before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a blue ribbon jury.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Moving further and further away from President Roosevelt's proposal to raise the bulk of needed new revenue from a tax on undistributed corporate profits, the Senate Finance Committee tonight was veering toward a program calling for an increase in income taxes for individuals and corporations and a moderate levy on the undivided income of the latter.

Further improvement in retail sales in the metropolitan area was noted during the week. Estimates indicated leading department stores here had sales averaging about 15 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year. While the lower temperatures were somewhat of a factor during the week, consumer demand for Summer apparel and accessories, particularly sports apparel, was well maintained.

The finish of this year's Maryland Hunt Cup event was of deep interest to me because it furnished another example of the truism that blood in horse and man will tell. The winner, Inshore, is full of Domino sprinting blood, but he gallantly stayed the long four miles over hill and dale, splendidly ridden by young Henry W. Frost Jr.

Bayuk Cigars, Inc., has notified the Stock Exchange that the directors decided on May 12 not to make, until further notice, the proposed offering of additional common stock to stockholders. A listing application had been made. The decision does not affect the proposed four-for-one stock split-up.

Laverne Fator, retired jockey, who was regarded as one of the greatest riders of his day, died at 12:01 o'clock this morning in the Jamaica Hospital, Queens, of injuries he suffered yesterday when he fell from a second-floor window of the hospital while awaiting an operation for appendicitis.

BERLIN, May 15. -- Prices were strong today in almost every department of the Boerse. Heavy industrial shares rose moderately on rather heavy trading, Stahlverein gaining 3/4 point. Potash stocks showed some weakness in contrast to the rest of the market, Salzdetfurth receding 1 1/4 points.

Every now and then J.C. Nugent sits down and writes a play, and shortly thereafter he and other members of the family fill the roles and they put it on. Very often with considerable effect. Let the main news this morning be to the effect that Mr. Nugent has been at his typewriter again, the result to be shown on May 30 at Skowhegan, Me.

The State Transit Commission has started a court action to force the Long Island Railroad to charge its passengers the two-cent-a-mile rate in conformity with the Interstate Commerce Commission ruling, which becomes effective June 2, it was disclosed yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., May 15. -- The New Jersey Fair Trade Act of 1935 was held unconstitutional in an opinion filed in Trenton today by Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein. He ruled the law deprived retailers of "their property and liberty of contracts without due process of law."

LONDON, May 15. -- The tribunal investigating the alleged leakage of Cabinet secrets heard today the story of a mysterious visit paid to J.H. Thomas, the Colonial Secretary, on the eve of the revelation of the budget by his race course friend, Sir Alfred Butt, who took out 7,800 of last-minute insurance against a rise in the income tax.

In regard to the case of Hauter, who allegedly ran down a little girl on the bridle path, may I say that for the last five years that I have ridden in Central Park I have been beset on each and every ride by every sort of difficulty, due to inadequate policing of the bridle path.
ALBANY, May 15. -- Governor Lehman signed three bills today throwing the State's financial support as well as its complete cooperation with New York City behind the 1939 World's Fair project.

The Storch Leasing Corporation of New York resold to the Noah Realty Holding Corporation of Newark the four four-story, twenty-family brick flats at 122, 130, 132 and 136 Corbin Avenue, Jersey City. The buildings, assessed at $54,000 each, were sold subject to four mortgages totaling $240,500.

This is the season when the art schools look back over a year of endeavor and select the most representative and best work by students for display. One or two of these exhibitions have already been held; several are current, others are shortly to open.

With only three of the sixteen contestants left with chances of gaining first place and only half a point separating the first two from the third, the fifteenth and final round of the United States championship conducted under the auspices of the National Chess Federation will be contested at the Hotel Astor this afternoon and evening.

Although drawing a bye yesterday, the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club team virtually in assured of the Class A championship in the women's Long Island interclub golf tournament as a result of the matches played at the Pomonok Country Club.

Price movements were uneven again on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with trading fairly brisk. Coffees and rubber were firmer, while cottonseed oil and sugar declined slightly. On the cash markets antimony declined, while gains appeared in wheat, corn, rye, cotton, wooltops, rubber and cocoa.

Holders of 1,350,000 outstanding participating preference shares of the International Match Corporation of $35 par value, whether deposited or not with the Adams protective committee, will share in the triangular intercompany settlement proposed for the former Kreuger companies, a study of the proceedings indicates.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15. -Four crews worked out on the Charles River and the basin today in preparation for the race tomorrow afternoon, which in the general opinion of rowing followers will decide the unofficial sprint championship of the college rowing season.

ROME, May 15. -- News of Guatemala's resignation from the League of Nations is prominently displayed in the Italian press. It is regarded as further evidence of the revolt of Central and South America against Geneva and their tendency to cut adrift from European affairs and group themselves into a Pan-American league.

The slow but persistent advance in high-grade investment vehicles continued yesterday as the principal feature of bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The broad improvement developed without any expansion in the trading pace, sales, in fact, declining to $9,348,100, compared with $10,963,700 on Thursday.

Old acquaintances of Central Park along its middle reaches are beginning to smile again. A small lake is being born along one edge of the site of the old south reservoir. Two acres are not thirty-two acres, which was the surface area of that lovely body of water before it was drained and turned into an abomination of desolation.

BERLIN, May 15. -- In a speech before the World Economic Society, Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk, the Finance Minister, again gave voice today to Germany's demand for colonies as one means of easing her strained raw material and foreign exchange situation.

Three of the four traffic violators ordered by Magistrate Anthony J. Burke to take the driving tests in the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center were sentenced by him yesterday in Traffic Court, 300 Mulberry Street.
BOSTON, May 15. -- Governor Curley backed down today from plans previously announced to force judges over 70 to submit to mental and physical examinations to determine their fitness. Mr. Curley said:

Pleas for price stabilization and the elimination of cutthroat tactics in competition, which will result in a fair profit for manufacturers and distributors of drugs and allied products, were made by speakers yesterday at the closing session of the fifty-fourth annual convention of the Proprietary Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

Howard S. Palmer, one of the trustees in bankruptcy of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, was receiving salary at the annual rate of $14,000 on Dec. 31 last, compared to $36,000 on Jan. 1, 1935, as president of the company, according to its report to the Interstate Commerce Commission, made public yesterday.

For the second consecutive week new bond financing this week has consisted entirely of tax-exempt securities. The total is $26,386,000 for nine loans. This compares with only $5,638,750 in new bonds, also State and municipal, placed on the market last week, and with $10,139,000 marketed a year ago this week.
Professor Felix Frankfurter of the Harvard Law School took the legal profession to task yesterday for failure to measure up to its responsibilities in modern society.

NEWARK, N.J., May 15. -- With the aid of information by customs officials the beverage tax division of the New Jersey Tax Department has in the past two weeks sent bills to more than 1,000 New Jersey residents for tax on liquor brought in from abroad, principally on ships from Cuba, Bermuda and other points in the Carribean.

A price war in branded liquors that started in lower Manhattan early yesterday had spread into three boroughs of the city last night. While retailers, wholesalers and distillers vainly sought to check the competition, consumers in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn crowded retail establishments to purchase imported champagnes which ordinarily sell at $2.50 for $1.98, and domestic whiskies in the $1 to $1.19-a-pint class for 69 to 79 cents.

LONDON, May 15. -- Field Marshal Viscount Allenby of Megiddo will be buried in Westminster Abbey Tuesday. His last resting place will be beside Field Marshal Lord Plumer in the Warriors Chapel near the tomb of the Unknown Warrior.

The writer, who is the older brother of Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, has read with interest the letter of Bruce S. Old of Cambridge, Mass., which was published in a recent issue of THE TIMES. Mr. Old advocates that Bryan should be selected to play in the singles against Australia in the Davis Cup matches.
CLEVELAND, May 15 (AP). -- The Indians turned their siege guns on the Red Sox today, blasted Johnny Marcum out of the box in the third and went on to a 7-to-2 victory.

Lord Horder, physician in ordinary to King Edward VIII, who has been attending medical meetings in the United States, will depart for home today on the Cunard White Star liner Georgic. This liner, which leaves for Cobh, Southampton, Havre and London, will also have on board a group of American physicians who will make a tour of foreign clinics in connection with graduate medical work.

As one of the two Princeton representatives in the C.H.Y.P. Intercollegiate Chess League tournament during the Winter of 1894 and as a joint donor with L. Walter Stephens, Princeton, '10, in 1925 of a cup for the new league formation, the H.Y.P.D., I have kept up an intermittent interest in chess, especially intercollegiate chess, during the past four decades.
JERUSALEM, May 15. -- In a clash today between Arab demonstrators and police at Jaffa one Arab was killed and fifteen were injured, two critically.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- President Roosevelt outlined a tentative relief program under which the Works Progress Administration would be the controlling agency with the Public Works Administration and the Resettlement Administration continuing in curtailed form.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- A Ladies' Day gathering of 16,000, of whom 10,000 were women guests of the management, saw the White Sox trample the Yankees at Comiskey Park today in a slugfest that held four home runs in a collection of twenty-four hits of varying power and different distances struck by both teams.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The Pettengill bill which would repeal the "long and short haul" clause in the Interstate Commerce Act appeared today to have no chance of passage at this session of Congress. The case of the railroads and the brotherhoods that have favored the bill before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce practically was completed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- Nineteen-year-old David G. Nichols of Garden City, L.I., won the applause of a group of scientists today with a paper on the habits of mice he has been observing for several years.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP). -- While nearing practical use from a technical standpoint, television was reported by Communications Commission officials today to have run into a maze of difficult "economic problems."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15. -Predicting that history will reveal President Roosevelt not only as a humanitarian but as the defender of the American form of government, Attorney General Cummings declared in a keynote address at the Connecticut Democratic Convention tonight that for all practical purposes the election is over now.

RICHMOND, Va., May 15. -- The American Library Association Conference today reached a wide range of problems, embracing the library's contribution in combating crime, plans for extending library service and for Latin-American library scholarships, and tributes to men writers of children's books.

Every American who is aware of the unique service which the Johns Hopkins University has rendered to the advancement of learning in this country will be grieved to learn of the financial difficulties which now threaten the successful maintenance of its most essential activities.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase reviewed the Reserve Officers Training Corps of New York University yesterday at its annual military field day held at Ohio Field, University Heights. More thn 3,000 watched the student soldiers participate in competitive events following the review.

The sixty-second convention of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania defeated a resolution for the establishment of a free city college in Queens County. So great a majority voted against the measure that no count of hands was necessary.

Since the economy of scarcity hasn't yet been applied to fiction, the piece in The Fortnightly by the Marquess of CREWE, "Novels Not by Novelists," must have been inspired by antiquarian interest. SHELLEY'S boyish romances "Zastrozzi" and "St. Irvyne" are in a vein that has long seemed burlesque:

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $26,179,172, representing two States and fifty-three municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $45,616,123 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $24,561,587.

The grand award of the third international philatelic exhibition, which is being held this week at the Grand Central Palace, was won by Raymond T. Lapham of New York for his collection of Postmasters, it was announced last night.

Another display of dazzling speed is promised with the forty-third running of the Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park today. With the Fashion Stakes and International Steeplechase Handicap as supporting features, more than 20,000 race-goers are expected.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott, speaking yesterday at ceremonies marking the promotion of forty-eight members of the Fire Department and the swearing in of thirty new firemen, protested against the Civil Service preference which is given to war veterans under the laws of the State.

The brisk advance in share prices on Thursday was not pursued yesterday. Until well into the afternoon, the market moved hesitantly, slightly lower on the average, then ruled firm in mid-afternoon, and closed irregularly higher as the buying movement spent itself before the end of the final hour.

The jury is still unable to decide which artist in the Prix de Rome competition shall receive the painting award this year. The three other awards were announced according to schedule last Tuesday. They went to Harrison Gibbs (sculpture), Richard Ayers (architecture) and Robert S. Kitchen (landscape architecture).

I would like to call attention to the Tebeau brothers, who were not mentioned in John Kieran's recent column about brother combinations in baseball. They were Pat (Oliver) and George (White Wings) Tebeau, and their home was in St. Louis.

ALBANY, May 15. -- Flying to Albany late today, District Attorney Martin W. Littleton Jr. of Nassau County gave Governor Lehman a complete report of the fatal shooting last month of Mrs. Margaret Wiggen by two Nassau County detectives.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Backed by the assurance of American delegates to the London Naval Conference that there was nothing in it inimical to the interests of this country, the London Naval Treaty of 1936 was favorably reported to the Senate by the Foreign Relations Committee today.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 15. -- An almost faultlessly played 75, which easily was the best score ever put up here in women's competition, gave Mrs. Frank Goldthwaite of Fort Worth, Texas, the lead in the first qualifying round of the women's British golf championship today.

The teachings of Pope Pius XI and of Pope Leo XIII in favor of lower interest and profits and higher wages meet the "genuine needs of our industrial system today," and their encyclicals put the church on record in support of the movement for abolishing evils of child labor, more than 500 leading Catholic laymen were told last night at the Center Club, 120 Central Park South.
For the second successive day the Brooklyn College nine lost a lead and wound up on the short end of the score, bowing to Panzer, 9 -- 7, at the Manhattan Beach diamond yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Senator Borah is out to defeat Governor Landon for the Republican nomination for President, according to definite reports here today. He is said to be willing to join with former President Hoover and the others to fight the Kansas Governor at the Cleveland convention.

The report of the Federal Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows net income of $1,506,028 after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.36 a share on 524,903 shares of $15 par common stock.

There has been much talk lately about the indifference of the American public to the serious plight of the share-croppers in the South. It is a ray of hope that such a subject can become a topic for discussion.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 15. -- N.Y.U. won a hectic game from Rutgers today, 7 to 6. Mike Stelmach pitched airtight ball for six innings, showed signs of weakening in the seventh and retired under a barrage of hits in the eighth, which netted the Scarlet five runs.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, urged yesterday that a joint body of representatives of government, labor, ship owners and private citizens be convened immediately to undertake a thorough investigation of conditions in the American merchant marine, particularly those affecting safety and working conditions.

Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, Olympic and national back-stroke champion from the Women's Swimming Association, made her first Eastern appearance in several seasons at her home club pool last night, and although she failed to win the 100-meter handicap back-stroke event, she gave plenty of proof that she is fast getting back into top form by going the Olympic distance in 1:16.4.
TOKYO, May 15. -- Jusha Tsumura, a member of the House of Peers, today publicly apologized for having insulted army and navy officers by a "slip of the tongue" in debate yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- Federal District Judge Charles E. Woodward signed an order today approving settlement and dismissal of the $150,000,000 suit brought in New York by receivers of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company against the Columbia Oil and Gas Company and the Columbia Gas and Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Thomas H. Gammack, executive assistant to James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, retired today to return to private business in New York City. Mr. Landis said his services had been of "inestimable value" in solving problems which the commission had faced in effective administration of the acts under which it operates.

Public park tennis, which is rapidly becoming the cradle of our New York City college and high school teams as well as the recreation spot for thousands of workers, is taking a decided step in the wrong direction.

A concert in memory of Alexander Glazunoff, the Russian composer, was given by the newly formed Glazunoff Association last night at Steinway Hall. The program, consisting entirely of works by Glazunoff, was in line with the chief aim of the organization, namely, to stimulate interest in the propaganda of his musical creations.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Adjournment of Congress by Saturday, June 6, three days before the Republican National Convention meets at Cleveland, was hopefully predicted in the Senate today by Senator Robinson, Democratic floor leader.

With the watch and gold medallion believed to have been stolen from Edgar L. Eckert, 54 years old, assistant treasurer of the Rogers Peet Company, as clues, the police yesterday pressed the search for the person or persons who strangled the executive in a washroom of the Independent Subway at Forty-second Street and Eighth Avenue.

VIENNA, May 15. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg formally assumed command of the Fatherland Front, the only legal political organization, tonight at an assembly of its officials in its headquarters in the center of Vienna.

Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, will begin the celebration of its one-hundredth anniversary this evening at 8 o'clock with a choral festival in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, just behind the seminary buildings.

An elderly woman with gray hair who once played roles with Richard Mansfield told a jury in Federal court yesterday that she was the owner of five patents covering inventions for improving the interior construction of sleeping cars.

LONDON, May 15. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet today, but the price undertone was firm as a result of yesterday's recovery in Wall Street. British Government securities were steady, although little business was done.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- Wheat firmed quickly after a fractional recession at the start of business on the Board of Trade today, and, while the close was somewhat below the top, net gains were 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel, with May and July showing the most strength, due to spreading operations and covering by shorts.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 15 (AP). -Senator Charles L. McNary, Republican leader in the upper house of Congress, gained a big lead over two opponents carrying the banners of the Townsend Pension Plan in primary election returns tonight from one-ninth of the State's precincts.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 15. -- With the issuance by Governor Blanton H. Winship today of the order to all insular officials that the American flag must not be desecrated Puerto Ricans realize that the Governor means by his assertion that he intends to preserve law and order.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a list of additional filings for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets received by it since April 6. In some instances the applications supplement earlier ones, giving additional data.

WARSAW, May 15. -- General Felicjan Slawoj Skladkowski, First Under-Secretary of State and quartermaster-general of the Polish Army, tonight was appointed Prime Minister and Minister of the Interior to succeed Marjan Zyndram Koscialkowski, who resigned this afternoon.

Plans for groups of dwellings in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens were filed yesterday, in addition to a $180,000 apartment house project. for rBooklyn and a $50,000 factory for Queens. Details of the plans were as follows:

Governor LEHMAN'S Commission on Unemployment Relief, headed by ALLEN WARDWELL, some months ago reached the sensible conclusion that it was time to begin transferring the administration of relief to a permanent State agency. The Department of Social Welfare was, obviously, the one to take over this work.

Michael De Santis, the artist, who gained a reputation on Morningside Heights for his portraits of past and present Columbia professors as recently as 1934, died destitute at 11:50 P.M. on Thursday in Bellevue Hospital. He was 43 years old. Fellow-artists, likewise impoverished, will hold a sale today of his paintings to obtain the money for funeral expenses.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- James Jacobs, 40, an Indianapolis bootlegger, confessed to Federal agents today that he drove the alcohol-running automobile in the chase early yesterday morning when Agent John R. Foster was shot and killed.

One would like very much to know just what Messrs. Young, Chrysler, Baruch, et al., told the President about business conditions, especially with respect to capital goods. There is not much doubt about what business men as a class would have told him.

Reversing the trend of the week preceding, retail sales this week moved ahead at the most lively pace since Easter, the estimated gain for the country as a whole being 6 to 10 per cent over the volume in the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

MOSCOW, May 15. -- The Moscow subway had its first birthday today, and the city gave a party in honor of the anniversary of its going into commercial operation. Inasmuch as one day is all too brief for any good Russian party, the celebration will continue through tomorrow with an evening entertainment, including fireworks, for subway workers and their friends in the Park of Culture and Rest.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Plans for reorganization of Federal relief which would make Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, the practical head of coordidinated operations embracing the Public Works Administration headed by Secretary Ickes, Mr. Hopkins's own Works Progress Administration and the Resettlement Administration, operated by Rexford G. Tugwell, were outlined by President Roosevelt today.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 15 (AP). -Injured earlier in the week when she became caught in the starting gate during a schooling session, Weston W. Adams's Conservative staged a comeback today by winning the Watch Hill Claiming Stakes.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- With the deadline for permanent registration of securities of foreign issuers on the American Exchanges today, additional applications received since the recent announcement by the Securities and Exchange Commission brought the aggregate market value of those for which registration had been sought to approximately $2,920,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP). -- A story of spies, plots and sabotage by secret agents in this country before the United States entered the World War was continued today before the German-American Mixed Claims Commission.
ALBANY, May 15 (AP). -- Employer contributions to New York's unemployment insurance fund are "pouring in by the bushel," it was said tonight at the office of Glenn A. Bowers, executive director.

MOSCOW, May 15. -- United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt left tonight via Paris and London on a leave of absence that will give him forty-five days in the United States. He was accompanied by Vice Consul Carmel Offie, his secretary.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 16. -- The Chinese protest on smuggling, filed with the Japanese Consulate in Nanking, points out, according to the Domei News Agency, that Japan's intervention in North China makes it impossible for the Chinese authorities to control smuggling while extraterritorial rights in the area guarded by the Japanese military enables Koreans and Japanese to practice smuggling with impunity.

BERLIN, May 15. -- All the higher Nazi party functionaries have received an order from Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the party, forbidding them to hold office in any church body or religious organization. This ruling affects party officials everywhere of or above the rank of "community group leader."
DETROIT, May 15 (AP). -- The Athletics came from behind in the seventh inning today as two pinch hitters connected to win a 6-to-5 slugfest from the Tigers.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama cheeks in this nlarket, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc,:

President Roosevelt's adherence to unsound economic theories has resulted in the complete failure of his Administration to solve the unemployment and relief problems, Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, declared last night in an address to members of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club in the clubhouse at 122 East Eighty-third Street.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- The demand for hogs was relatively slow here today and sales were made at weak to 15 cents a hundredweight lower prices. A small lot sold at $9.65 for the best figure of the day while shippers paid up to $9.60, and the practical top for local interests was $9.50.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 15. -- A mustard gas bomb was exploded in the Minneola Theatre, a motion-picture house on Franklin Avenue here, tonight, forcing the 500 patrons to flee and sending eleven of them to the hospital for treatment.

Pedro Montanez kept his string of American victories intact last night by decisively outpointing Leonard Del Genio of Harlem in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden. The Puerto Rican, who had registered fourteen straight triumphs in this country, had little difficulty overcoming the game Del Genio, who was forced to absorb a withering, devastating body attack throughout the struggle.

LONDON, May 15. -- Mrs. Amy Johnson Mollison smashed all records for flights between England and Cape Town when she landed at Croydon at 1:35 P.M. today completing the homeward journey, in 4 days, 16 hours and 16 minutes.

PARIS, May 15. -- Leon Blum, Premier-designate of the French Republic, speaking as a private citizen and still free to express his thoughts without regard for office, used the tribune of the American Club of Paris today to make his first public indication of his policies and hopes.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 15. -- The drama went outdoors at Vassar College tonight. Philaletheis, the dramatic society, combined with faculty and alumnae to produce "Tyl Owleglass" in the amphitheatre overlooking old Vassar Lake.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 15. -- For the third time in four years, Knight Bachelor, owned by Miss Judy King of Atlanta, Ga., tonight carried off the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall $1,000 championship harness horse stake, one of the features of the fourth day of the Atlantic City horse show.

The reorganization managers of the New York Railways Corporation under the plan of readjustment and motorization dated March 19, 1935, have advised assenting holders of securities that at a hearing in the Federal court here next Tuesday at 10:30 A.M. an order finally confirming the plan and authorizing immediate abandonment of the railway franchises will be asked for.

ALBANY, May 15. -- Only 484 of the 1,303 applicants for admission to the bar who took the March examinations passed, it was announced today by John Kirkland Clark of New York, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany, comprising the State Board of Law Examiners.

National Gideon Day will be observed in many churches tomorrow under the sponsorship of the International Gideons, the third Sunday in May each year being set aside by this group of business men. The Gideons were organized in 1899 at Beaver Dam, Wis., for the purpose of placing Bibles in hotel bedrooms and also for personal evangelism.

A. Henry Ross, a lawyer with offices at 185 Montague Street, Brooklyn, and Max D. Krone, a private detective with an office in the Dixie Hotel, in West Forty-third Street, were indicted yesterday by the New York County Grand Jury on the complaint of Alfred E. Smith Jr., involving them in the extortion of about $12,900 from him since 1933.
GENEVA, May 15. -- The League of Nations received today the following cablegram, dated yesterday and signed by Acting Foreign Minister Jose Gonzalez Campo of Guatemala:

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Federal Reserve policy during 1935 was concentrated on contributing to business recovery and the creation of easy-money conditions while, at the same time, giving consideration to the danger of inflation in the rapidly increasing excess reserves of member banks.
Harlem housing properties figured prominently yesterday in Manhattan realty trading, which was confined almost entirely to the selling and leasing of flats and dwellings.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 15. -- The birth control memorial put before the general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church with the endorsement of leading educators and ministers in the church, including Bishop-elect G. Bromley Oxnam, was disapproved today by the Committee on State of the Church.

LONDON, May 15. -- King Edward VIII saw a special performance of the last act of the current Haymarket hit, James Bridie's "Storm in a Teacup," in the drawing room of Lady Cunard's Grosvenor Square house tonight.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 15. -Miss Mildred Helen McAfee, 36, Dean of Women of Oberlin College and a graduate of Vassar, will be the next president of Wellesley College. Miss McAfee will succeed Dr. Ellen Fitz Pendleton, whose retirement is to take effect in June, and will assume her position in the Fall.

As a condition for a loan of $10,000,000 granted to it by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company gave to the bank the right to name the majority of the members of the executive committee, to define the committee's powers and to place an employe in the company responsible only to the executive committee.

BUENOS AIRES, May 15. -- News agencies here have been notified that Brazil has established one of the strictest censorships yet devised in South America to prevent Brazilians from learning what is going on in the outside world.

The Appellate Division refused yesterday to hear the appeal of the eleven tenants of Knickerbocker Village who lost a suit to block their eviction. The court, in upholding the decision of Municipal Court Justice Prince, ruled against their contention that their leases were automatically renewed when the landlord failed to give them notice ninety days before the expiration of their leases, that they were required to sign new leases within thirty days.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- Former Senator Moses of New Hampshire said here today that his latest tabulation showed that 241 of the delegates already elected to the Republican National Convention favored the nomination of Colonel Frank Knox.
