PRINCETON, N.J., May 15. -Seventeen crews took final spins on Lake Carnegie today in preparation for six races to be held tomorrow, including the Carnegie Cup event for the Cornell, Princeton and Yale varsities, and the Goldthwait Cup race for the Harvard, Princeton and Yale 150-pound boats.

SUNNYVALE, Calif., May 15 (AP). -- Two attempts by a mysterious rifleman to shoot down the army dirigible TC-13 resulted today in a move by military authorities to learn the sniper's identity and motive.

Operations of the Columbian Carbon Company and subsidiaries in the first quarter of this year resulted in a net profit of $1,027,011, after depreciation, depletion, taxes and minority interest. This equaled $1.91 a share on 537,586 shares of common stock outstanding.

The annual report of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, which was issued yesterday, took on additional interest this year by reason of the appendix that gave, as required by the Banking Act of 1935, details of the decisions taken by the board and the open market committee at their meetings in the course of the year.

Still suffering from shock as a result of the terrific Cardinal bombardment on Thursday, Casey Stengel's Dodgers fell easy victims to the Pirates in yesterday's opener at Ebbetts Field before a ladies' day crowd of 6,500. The score was 6 -- 2.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced last night that his organization had taken a neutral stand on the issues involved in the current strike of Atlantic Coast seamen and intended to maintain it.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- From behind ten-foot brick walls, and locked doors of rooms in which the windows are high above their heads, sixty girls from 13 to 20 years of age will emerge briefly tomorrow to be the guests of Mrs. Roosevelt at a special garden party for them in the White House grounds.
Here is another story of a little orphan girl with winning ways and a large inheritance, unknown to herself and her compassionate, but poor, young uncle until the final reel.

The Spring season of opera at popular prices in the Metropolitan Opera House had as one of its objectives the performances of certain operas in English. The first of these experiments came off last night with exceptional eclat and enthusiasm on the part of a very large audience.

Ex-President HOOVER'S speech at Philadelphia on Thursday evening, which is to be the last that he will make before the Republican convention meets, was .one of the most vigorous of his series. It was full of the crisp and positive utterances which have come with his new style.

BALTIMORE, May 16. -- Smashing home first in a bitter drive, Bold Venture today won the forty-sixth Preakness Stakes by a nose and in a manner to lift 40,000 persons from their seats for one of the greatest thrills the turf has supplied this or any other season.

PARIS, May 14. -- Jeanne Lanvin is still developing her wide-shouldered, square-topped and big-sleeved line in easy-fitting and swagger coats made with front fullness. She likes white coats and very wide, white belts with dark frocks for all occasions. Summer afternoon frocks are ankle-length and have low, plain decolletages.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Several Southern Berkshire hotels are opening earlier than usual this season because of a "house party" of 1,500 members of the Oxford Group, which is to have headquarters at Stockbridge from May 22 to June 10.

A national committee comprising seventy-two women leaders in civic and philanthropic enterprises, representing widely distant sections of the country, has been formed by Hadassah to coordinate the work of the organization in the Youth Aliyah.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., May 16. -- The opening of a new wing and laboratory and the creation of the position of resident physician were announced today at the sixteenth annual meeting of the board of directors of the Irvington House for children with heart disease.

VIENNA, May 16. -- Austria, for three years a dictatorship without dictators, became overnight this week a typical dictatorship in which power was concentrated in one man. But, contrary to popular expectations abroad, it is not "Austria's strong man," the dashing but unreliable Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, but a reserved scholar of the Jesuit school in Vorarlberg who has become the absolute ruler.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- Senator Borah's candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination will have the support of eighteen or more of Pennsylvania's seventy-five delegates in the early balloting at Cleveland, as a result of unexpected action taken at the delegation's first caucus here today.

NEW coordinated airline schedules for the vacation season this Summer are making it possible for a traveler to leave New York or its vicinity, take in the lakes of Minnesota, visit the Yellowstone, get in a day's fishing or mountain climbing here and there, catch a glimpse of Hollywood and Old Mexico and return to New York all within eight or nine days.

AT a meeting somewhat like this I was recently introduced as a "person who had persuaded the already harassed Federal Government to enter the show business." I disclaim the honor. The people who persuaded the Federal Government to enter the show business were 12,000 unemployed professional theatre people -- actors, designers, stage hands, dramatists, from coast to coast.

BENEATH the apparently mild and ordinary significance of the title of this book one finds a daring, determined and even awe-inspiring search for the ultimate secret of life. Mr. Waddington is an investigator in the laboratory of Experimental Zoology of Cambridge University and a British authority in the science of embryology.
POUGHKEEPSIE, May 16. -- Unlimited leaves of absence from classes and the campus, effective in September, have been granted by the faculty this week to seniors and juniors of Vassar College.
HERE TO STAY: Before an audience of booksellers in New York last week Sinclair Lewis said that writers, publishers and dealers may suffer permanently lower profits, but:

A beginner at bicycling often finds himself fatally attracted to the obstacles he is determined to avoid. So it was with Sally Hamilton when she decided to steer clear of love. Having decided to take a trip round the world to forget a faithless fiance, Sally promptly changed her mind ad buried herself in a little up-State village, where inevitable romance awaited her.

PEIPING, May 16. -- Stoical Chinese watched new files of Japanese troops tramp into northern mainland garrisons tonight. While Nanking protested to Tokyo and foreign diplomats, including the American, studied the possible eonse-! quenees the Chinese saw a double purpose'in a triple-strength Japa-i nese garrison at Peiping and I Tientsin, namely:
DETROIT, May 16 (AP). -- The Tigers snapped their losing streak at three games today by defeating Philadelphia, 5 to 4.

BARTOW, Fla., May 16. -- Former Police Chief R.G. Tittsworth of Tampa and Robert Chappell, former Tampa city employe and special policeman, were acquitted today by a directed verdict in the first of the Tampa flogging trials here.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 15. -- Whether Canadian broadcasting is to be controlled by an independent commission or by the Canadian Government and whether it is to include advertising as in the United States, or ban it as in Great Britain, are problems which have been under discussion for weeks by a Canadian Parliamentary committee.

Business continued to move vigorously toward higher levels in most of the Federal Reserve Districts throughout the country last week, the most significant gains being recorded in retail distribution. Sales mounted sharply in all sections in comparison with the figures for the corresponding period last year.

WITH a sweet and spicy assault, mounds of fresh pineapples are now invading the market stands. Sun-ripened for the Northern palate in the lush valleys of Cuba and Puerto Rico, plucked from low-growing nests of spiked leaves, graded according to size, and shipped away in tropical freighters, they reach New York in greatest number each May.
CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP). -- Professional band directors acclaimed young America's high school bands.

IT is seldom a writer can be found so creatively gifted as to be able to write as a philosopher and poet of what he has observed as a scientist. Donald Culross Peattie, himself one of the chosen few, has said of Maeterlinck: "He is a brilliant example of what I take to be the ultimate truth, that poetry and science are brother and sister.
ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP). -- The Senators closed a two-game series today by handing the Browns their fourth straight defeat, 4 -- 1.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- Better retail demand in the Middle West during the early May warm spell was followed this week by a broad improvement in wholesale dry goods activities. About 50 per cent more buyers were in the local field than a year ago, according to one house, while the average sales gain was from 15 to 18 per cent.

Because of curiosity, despite his 74 years, Fred Meyer, who lives with his wife at 1,521 Rosedale Avenue, the Bronx, found himself under orders yesterday not to go for at walk again unless he is accompanied.

Museum exhibits depicting the history of Long Island, a Colonial reception and tea and a dinner with the eight justices of the Appellate Division of the Second Department as guests will feature the Long Island Tercentenary celebration at the end of the month, the committee announced yesterday.

ROME, May 15. -- It is impossible to tell with any degree of accuracy how much damage has been done to Italy by sanctions. The government has ceased publishing the statistics that alone can throw any light on this subject. One can only make a guess by observing facts that are plain for every one to see.

The list of musical events for the 1936 season at Chautauqua, N.Y., were announced yesterday by Albert Stoessel, the director of musical activities there. Mr. Stoessel has been granted a leave of absence for the Summer to enable him to finish writing his opera and his place will be taken by Georges Barrere, the flutist and conductor.
ST. LOUIS, May 16. -- Aside from the unemployment and relief situation, general conditions in the Eighth Federal Reserve District are particularly encouraging.
DETROIT, May 16. -- Henry Ford, who has built more than 24,000,000 automobiles, rides a bicycle.

Most students are unable to read intelligently when they reach college, Professor Algernon Tassin of Columbia University said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Good Speech Society of New York at the Commodore Hotel. The luncheon was the last feature of the third annual Field Day of the organization.

THE MacDowell Club will hold its fifth annual young artists' contest in October. The object of the contest is to provide a public appearance in this city for gifted young professional artists. It is open to all students not over 30 years old who are studying with private teachers, or private pupils of teachers engaged at music schools or other educational institutions.

IT is six years since the publication of Thomas F. Madigan's "Word Shadows of the Great," a volume laden with facts and figures, but none the less a readable record of the fascinating hobby of autograph collecting. It was Mr. Madigan's first published book, and it proved to be his final fling at the "amenities."

A NEW automatic control of tuning, to facilitate precision that affords maximum fidelity and minimum interference, is being developed in the laboratories, according to Arthur Van Dyck of the Radio Corporation of America in a lecture on "The Evolution of Radio" before the American Institute.

In this attractive picture book the artist has drawn ten new and charming pictures for a rhyme by Olive Wadsworth that has been a favorite with many generations of children. Older readers will notice certain variants from the better known form.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., May 16 (AP). Rutgers University won the track and field championship of the Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Association for the fourth consecutive year today with a total of 38 points. Lehigh had taken an early lead when Walter Crockett and Dudley Healy finished first and second in the finals of the 44-yard dash.

The annual Spring golf tournament of the New York Curb Exchange will be held on Thursday at the Echo Lake Country Club, Westfield, N.J. Members of the Exchange will compete for the New York Curb Exchange Championship Trophy and the President's Cup, as well as for several prizes donated by Curb brokers and the Echo Lake Country Club.

BARCELONA, April 15, 1936. THE Liceu opera season offered forty-eight performances of its usual varied international fare. Its most novel item was the visit of a company from Prague, presenting Dvorak's "Jacobin" (first time in Spain) and Smetana's "Bartered Bride" (second locally), under Karel Nedbal's baton.

Representatives of the clubs in Northern New York Federation who will attend the twenty-ninth annual convention at Watertown Wednesday and Thursday will hear a series of addresses on the second day's program, under the auspices of the American Home department of the State Federation.

ROUEN, France, May 16. -- A Catholic Archbishop, shorn of power because he had failed to prevent a church scandal involving a protege, refused to relinquish his official post tonight pending a personal appeal to Pope Pius.

Those two celebrated islands -- Manhattan and Long -- will be much better connected with the North American mainland and with each other upon completion of three big vehicular projects now far advanced. But even as the steel is riveted and the concrete is poured, there is serious talk of three additional projects which, if they too are translated into engineering actuality, will bind the two islands and Staten Island even more closely together.

LONDON, May 9. -- Reports are beginning to reach England of the unbeatable team that America is going to send to the Berlin Olympics in August -- a team, we hear, which is going to win every track event from 100 to 1,500 meters, including the two relays.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Good Harvest, an outsider in the betting at 10 to 1, sprang a surprise on the crowd of 20,000 spectators at Belmont Park yesterday when he came pounding through the final furlong to capture the forty-third running of the $8,400 Metropolitan Handicap.

FOR 800 years the Sussex village of Thorney, on Thorney Island, near Chichester, England, has been known as a farming community. Domesday Book speaks of it as "Tornei, a manor of thirty-two villeins with eight plows."

ENTERING the crowded field of anthologies -- although they specifically forswear the word -- the editors of The Saturday Evening Post have selected for the honor of reprinting twenty-one stories which appeared in the 1935 issues of their magazine.

M. MARITAIN is never known to venture, except on the rarest occasions (and then with visible trepidation, upon an assertion for which he is unable to find grounds and often actual reference in the works of St. Thomas," an English critic once wrote, and it is with no surprise whatsoever that one finds M. Maritain beginning a comparatively topical discussion with the customary appeal to the authority of the Angelic Doctor.

IT often seems as if island dwellers have a greater affection for their small spot of soil than those who live on the mainland. If this is so, probably it is because they can learn to know every square foot of their microcosmos; they can envision it in its totality, as the person whose habitation is but a tiny fraction of a mighty whole cannot.

LONDON, April 20. BY a fortunate chance there have been produced during the past week three plays which illustrate three of the most prevalent styles of playwriting and are valuable for comparison and critical synthesis.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- The action of May wheat is attracting more attention from the trade, and the possibilities of a sharp decline or advance, depending largely on the reception there will be given to deliveries of No. 2 hard Winter on contracts next week, are said by certain operators to be restricting speculative interest in all futures.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16. -- With an anticipated registration of 10,000 delegates, the National Conference of Social Work will meet here from May 24-May 30, it was announced today by Howard R. Knight, general secretary of the conference.

In the House of Commons the other day Mr. ATLEE, leader of the Opposition, said that the Government "was in the dock." That was before the name of Mr. THOMAS, Secretary of State for the Colonies, had appeared, save in unverified rumor, in connection with the buying of insurance at Lloyd's against an increase of the income tax.

Property of the estates of Walter Leighton Clark, founder and president of the Grand Central Art Galleries, and Eben Howard Gay, financier and art collector, of Boston, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday afternoon.

A TRADE practice conference, at which Robert E. Freer, Commissioner of the Federal Trade Commission, will preside, has been called for the rubber tire industry at the Stevens Hotel, Chicago, June 4. The purpose of the conference, the commission reports, is to give all branches of the industry an opportunity to participate in deliberations "looking to elimination of practices believed to be unfair, wasteful and otherwise harmful to the industry and the public."

LOLLING in the bubble bath that is part of a Spring pickup treatment at a New York salon is something like floating in a cloud. One gets into a tub full to the top with tiny-bubbled, live foam. As the bubbles burst slowly against one's body, they give the effect of a light, relaxing massage.

Dr. Goodwin Watson, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, speaking yesterday at the closing session of a conference of 300 elementary school teachers and administrators from the metropolitan area at the university, urged them to become allied with the labor movement.

With the chains having reached the peak of growth in 1928 and 1929, their record in relation to other systems of distribution refutes the claims of backing the Patman-Utterback "Anti-Chain" Bill that such legislation is necessary to prevent them from destroying small independent retailers and the wholesalers who supply these retailers, according to Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association and Professor of Marketing at Columbia University.

"The Radio Theatre" heard over WABC's network on Monday nights at 9 o'clock finds itself so allied with the screen that it will originate in Hollywood instead of New York after June 1. . . . A new Sunday program, "The Art of Song," will be introduced by WOR at 8 P.M. on May 31 with Alfred Wallenstein conducting, and Mina Hager, lieder singer, as soloist.

MOUNT VERNON, Ohio, May 16 (AP). -- A young stenographer's $25,000 alienation of affections suit against her uncle by marriage, former Senator Clarence C. Dill, and his sister-in-law, charged that they arranged an illegal operation for her, pleadings disclosed here today.

QUAYAQUIL, ECUADOR. FROM a stretch of rough water just off a point on the coast of Ecuador lost Spanish treasure is being actually recovered. Not, however, by man's efforts--for attempts at salvaging have been fruitless--by freakish action of the sea.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 16. -- The General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church today adopted its important reports on prohibition, social and economic problems and world peace with few dissenting votes. Moved by the peace report, the 600 ministerial and lay delegates stood and applauded its adoption and sang "The Star-Spangled Banner."

FOR all her repute as a vacation paradise, France has had a struggle of late to hold her tourist trade. Despite her art treasures, her historic monuments, the variety of her numerous coast and mountain resorts, her picturesque countryside and the refinement of her cuisine, it has become more and more difficult for her to attract her normal quota of recreation seekers.
A survey of reading habits in the city's high schools shows that 71 per cent of the students read chiefly fiction and that reading generally is "cheap, tawdry and desultory."

PARIS, May 16 (AP). -- England's Davis Cup tennis aces, Perry and H.W. (Bunny) Austin, went down to unexpected defeat today as France gained a 7 -- 3 lead at the end of the first day's play in the annual two-day Franco-British team matches.

To supplement the campaign conducted recently for the Community Music Schools two benefit entertainments have been arranged for the near future by a special committee under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Alexander AicLanahan and Mrs. Lawrence Tibbett.

OBERLIN, Ohio, May 16. -- When the news reached the quiet Oberlin campus yesterday that the authorities of Wellesley College had ended their long search for a president by electing Miss Mildred McAfee, young and vivacious dean of women here, there was a surge of excitement throughout the college town.

LONDON, May 16 (By Wireless). -- It has constantly been said that public opinion is the life-blood of the League of Nations. The basis on which the whole movement for peace is founded is that the common people throughout the world desire peace and that they are in this respect inadequately represented by governments and bureaucracies.
CASPER, Wyo., May 15. -- Wyoming this week manoeuvred its politicians into line for the approaching national party conventions.

TICONDEROGA, N.Y., May 16 (AP) -- Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, warned in a speech here today that "we can never relax our vigilance" in the battle for liberty, which "is never finally won."

LATE in December the Morgan Library had an exhibition of illuminated manuscripts and drawings illustrating the Christmas festival, and Professor Kirsopp Lake of Harvard talked on the early history of this fete and explained how it had been transmuted from a pagan into a Christian celebration.

WARSAW, May 16. -- The new Polish Premier, General Felicien Slawoj-Skladkowski, with members of his Cabinet, took the oath of office before President Moscicki today. The Premier took over his office wearing the uniform of a Polish Army general.

The trend toward the control and limitation of trade by restricting imports, which became apparent soon after the end of the World War, generally is not diminishing to any marked degree and even is becoming more pronounced in certain foreign countries, according to executives of companies engaged in international trade.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- More than 40,000 beds will be added to the facilities of American hospitals under the current PWA program. Both Federal and other hospitals will be the beneficiaries. PWA has refused aid to over-hospitalized towns and cities, but has approved many projects for communities that hitherto have lacked adequate hospital facilities, and has undertaken more than 500 hospital projects, including both new construction and the improvement of existing hospitals.
The joint board of the Journeymen Barbers International Union completed plans yesterday for a city wide barber strike, to get under way tomorrow. The union expects 16,000 barbers to respond.

NEW YORK subway builders are at it again, sanguine and undaunted still after their thirty years of prodigious underground toil and trouble. This time they are tackling Sixth Avenue. From Eighth Street to Fifty-third, through the core of Manhattan, they will lay a new four-track trunk line for the Independent system, relieving the Eighth Avenue line of some of its burden of traffic to and from Fort Washington, Brooklyn and Queen.

WITH so many violent doctrines loose in the world it is a comfort for the peace-loving to come across a panacea that doesn't bite. Whatever defects may be found in the move to make us all happier by means of cooperative buying and selling, it at least rests on a faith that human nature is well-meaning and quite sensible.

With forty trade associations combining forces, the second annual observance of National Foreign Trade Week will be started here tonight on a scale more elaborate than any previous joint activity undertaken by the foreign trade community.

Gilbert S. McInerny of Hollis, Queens, will head Manhattan College's Student Council next year. His nomination as president and the selection of other student officers in the general undergraduate elections last week were announced yesterday by Thomas F. Gagan, retiring Student Council president.

SACRIFICE FOR LOVE" is a sentimental but sincerely written novel showing the inner conflicts and strained relationships that develop, almost subconsciously and without intention in an otherwise happy family when one of the children is, in any way, an alien.

Plans for codifying the Federal banking laws to clear up existing contradictions and complexities and to unify the banking reform measures of the last three years are under consideration by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, according to reports in banking circles here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- The resignations of two of Mayor S. Davis Wilson's advisers on transit matters this week gave Philadelphians another opportunity to debate the advantages and drawbacks of the latest proposal for ending the Philadelphia Rapid Transit "headache."

GEORGE PICKEN, whose recent water-colors are being shown (until May 29) at the Marie Harriman Gallery, has somewhat brightened his color and made freer his treatment in this work. But a somber mood, a certain brooding melancholy of spirit persists.

Hereafter, smooth and wire haired fox terriers will not be classified as distinct breeds by the American Kennel Club. The decision of the board of directors of the governing body of dogdom is of the greatest importance to breeders throughout the country, especially to those interested in the smooth variety.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sunday, May 17. -- The Zeppelin Hindenburg took off from the Rhein-Main airport at 5:35 o'clock this Morning [12:35. A.M., Sunday, New York time] on her second flight to Lakehurst, N.J. She departed amid glorious sunshine while a small crowd shouted "Heil!" and sang "Deutschland Ueber Alles."

THIS is a tiny book, but it is weighty with sound, informed thinking, common sense and a high, earnest purpose. Its author has been for thirty years, he says, interested in the subject of why the world does not achieve durable peace and by what means it can reach that goal.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 16 (AP). -- Buffalo extended its winning streak to ten games when Johnny Wilson pitched the Bisons to a 3-to-1 victory over the Rochester Red Wings today. Wilson held the Wings to five scattered hits. Fletcher and Mulleavy led the seven-hit attack with two safeties apiece.

IT is a well-known fact that the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, the National Bureau of Standards, the Air Corps technical section at Wright Field, the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics and the Bureau of Air Commerce each in its own way contributes mightily to the performance of all aircraft.

WATERVILLE, ME. THE project to move Colby College from its 118-year-old location to a new site two miles distant has been actively resumed by the Colby trustees after having been shelved for the past four years because of the depression.

Their president and their legislative program during the next twelve months will be the main concern of delegates to the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs at Jamestown on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

THE Metropolitan Opera House had its fiftieth anniversary two and a half years ago, having been opened in the season of 1883-84. A record of this half century is therefore a little overdue; but the interest and value of this record are not diminished by this fact.

Thundering along once more on a single track, but this time in a far more pleasing direction, the Giants polished off the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday to make a clean sweep of the two-game series and record their sixth straight victory.

LONDON, May 16. -- Lord Decies will preside at a luncheon to be given by the British Sportsman's Club at the Savoy Hotel on Monday, in honor of the American international polo team on their arrival in England.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 16. -- Unusual professional opportunities have been made possible for Summer students of the theatre at Union College, to which the Carnegie Corporation has just granted $12,000, spread in annual payments over three years, to be used in connection with the Mohawk Drama Festival and the Institute of the Theatre.

SEVENTEEN ensemble works of Brahms will be presented at the six concerts of the chamber music festival to be held by the Cleveland String Quartet and guest artists in Cleveland, Ohio, during the last two weeks of this month, starting tomorrow.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 16. -- The Williams nine defeated Wesleyan, 8 -- 3, today. Moseley knocked out a homer and a three-bagger end on each occasion scored Stanley, who was on base. Home made a three-bagger for Wesleyan in the third, scoring O'Leary.

ROME, May 16. -- Italy's 337 Senators this afternoon unanimously approved two bills passed by the Chamber of Deputies Thursday, annexing Ethiopia, proclaiming King Victor Emmanuel Emperor and appointing Marshal Pietro Badoglio the first Viceroy.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Mrs. Roosevelt received and entertained at a White House garden party today the personnel of the National Training School for Girls, including sixty "delinquents" ranging in age from 13 to 20 and their twenty attendants, headed by Dr. Carrie Weaver Smith, superintendent of the institution.

AMONG personal possessions which Emperor Haile Selassie took with him when he fled from Ethiopia, according to news dispatches, was a prized pet python. Reptile fanciers of this country, including many in and around New York City, find such devotion understandable.

IN the preface the authors say that, "curiously enough," this is the first time Longstreet's life has been written. It is not so curious. NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 16. -- By capturing first and third places in the 200-meter race, the final event of their thirty-first annual varsity dual track meet, Yale today defeated Princeton, 67 2-3 to 67 1-3. The margin is the smallest for any victory ever registered by the rivals, although two previous meets were tied.

PROFESSOR GAETANO SALVEMINI is a veteran leader of the anti-Fascist movement and an irreconcilable foe of Mussolini. His new book is not an objective and impartial investigation of a vast and disturbing social phenomenon, but the virulent plea of a man who, outraged in his most sacred feelings, builds up his case against the usurper with the help of whatever evidence he can find.

The watch and gold medallion taken from Edgar Eckert, 54-year-old assistant treasurer of the Rogers Peet Company, Thursday when he was murdered in a subway washroom were recovered yesterday, Commissioner Valentine announced.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 16. -- Newport Council of Boy Scouts hopes to meet its expenses for the year at a ball in the Hotel Viking on May 29 sponsored by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt and members of the naval and Summer colonies.

IN writing this biography Count Corti had the advantage of being able to draw upon material hitherto unavailable in the archives of the imperial house of Austria, the royal and ducal families of Bavaria, the private correspondence of Empress Elizabeth and her husband, Emperor Franz Joseph, in addition to nearly a dozen other private and State archives.

WHAT may be euphemistically described as clashes of temperament have marred many of the great partnerships of history. Cain and Abel somehow Couldn't see eye to eye; and Romulus is on record as having worsted Remus in the conclusive fashion of their time.

ESTABLISHMENT of airplane service across the Pacific has given a new prominence to far-distant islands -- Midway, Wake, Guam, the Philippines and, most distant of all, Macao, the oldest of all permanent foreign settlements on the China coast.

THE first National Dance Congress and Festival will bring the current season to a close with more than the customary fanfare by offering a full week of performances and conferences whose purpose is apparently both to extend the field of the dancer and to unify his attack upon his artistic and economic problems.

RAIN, which falls in the garden on the "just and unjust," is quite as essential for the development of plant enemies -- the fungi -- as for the flowers themselves. The vital part played by water in the development of a fungus, and the resulting disease, was strikingly shown recently by investigations conducted at Cornell University on the control of "black-spot" of roses under glass.

The second clash within a week between striking seamen and police assigned to supervise their picketing activities occurred yesterday morning in Eleventh Avenue opposite the Panama Pacific Line pier at West Twenty-first Street.

The inevitable effects on posterity of the shattering of family morale were cited yesterday by Mrs. Courtlandt D. Barnes, Mrs. Artemus L. Gates and Mrs. Reeve Schley, all former chairmen of the women's division of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, in an appeal to women to support the committee's current drive for 51,500,000.

He thoroughly enjoys them himself and retells them with a gusto and a mischievous humor in both text and drawings that are irresistible.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- George Jeffers's relief pitching helped Pennsylvania defeat Princeton in the annual Alumni Day baseball game on Franklin Field today before a colorful crowd of 8,000. The score was 9 to 8.
MILWAUKEE, May 16 (AP). -- Mrs. Meta Berger charged today that Mayor Daniel Hoan and other leaders have permitted the Socialist party here to go to a "quiet suicide.''

LONDON, May 15. -- While the future of the present sanctions plan of the League of Nations hangs in the balance many are asking what Great Britain intends to do and whether she will eventully accept Premier Benito Mussolini's fair accompli as she did Chancellor Adolf Hitler's.

CHARDONNE, known as the painter of delicate love feelings in a manner where mild realism is combined with searching psychological analysis, has just completed a novel in three volumes,* in which his talent expands to a broad view of society as well as individuals, in a tone of gentle observation, philosophical reflection and restrained pathos.

MRS. MILLIN expresses what may be called the greater European outlook on affairs which is possible in a Africa where whites are aristocrats, where the foreground is an illimitable veldt, where the background is a world, east and west, that revolves around a strategic dominion. Here is a book that reveals a large philosophy of life.

By a vote which fell seven short of the two-thirds necessary to ratify, the United States Senate on March 19, 1920, rejected the Treaty of Versailles, keeping us out of the League of Nations and, incidentally, producing a joke that was soon worn threadbare. The joke: "Half a League onward!"
Two conflicts, each long in the brewing and each heightened by the fact that in an election year Congressmen must be most wary, reached their climaxes last week in Washington.

THIS Spring and Summer motorists driving through the country on holiday jaunts will find construction crews busy on hundreds of highway construction projects as Federal road builders push forward on a gigantic program -- a program that will add many miles of new roads, improve approaches to a number of our larger cities, provide needed bypasses, widen main arteries and better thousands of miles of secondary or feeder roads.

Circuit Court Judge Wilfred H. Jayne took under advisement in Mount Holly, N.J., yesterday the request of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn for the production of Mrs. Anna Bading, secretary of Ellis Parker Sr., Burlington County detective chief, as a witness before the Kings County Grand Jury.

WHEN that clever group of lads in Princeton University announced a month or so ago that they had organized a group of Veterans of Future Wars, they probably had no idea how fast their infant project would grow nor how various would be the reactions of the public.

BERLIN, May 16. -- Responding to greetings from French veterans' societies, seven German veterans' associations have issued an address expressing their esteem for their former opponents on the Western Front and a desire for a Franco-German understanding.

Sixteen national and State executives of the National Society of New England Women were among delegates and visitors who departed last night for Detroit, where the twenty-third annual congress of the organization opens tomorrow. Mrs. Parlan Semple Jr. of Montclair, N.J., president general, will go from Cincinnati, where she has been the guest of the Cincinnati Colony.

While millions of dollars have been spent in recent years in the metropolitan district to provide highways and widened streets, parking facilities in the suburban communities close to New York have been allowed to remain "wholly inadequate" to meet the demands of increasing traffic, the Regional Plan Association declared yesterday.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 16. -- Thirty years ago the handful of citizens of the community which founded the present Oklahoma City gathered in an open pasture to see an oil well spudded. The ceremony was preceded by prayers by a priest, a Methodist minister and a Presbyterian elder, the theme of which was that the community might be blessed with riches from oil.

A funeral service for Arthur Lehman will be held at 3 P.M. today at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street. Rabbis Jonah B. Wise of the Central Synagogue and B. Benedict Glazer of Emanu-El will officiate. Burial will be private and there will be no honorary pallbearers.

THE first few really hot days -- with the temperature soaring toward, or well above, the eighties -- are likely to dampen the ardor of the gardener, but they have no such effect upon weeds. In fact, after even a day or two of hot weather there suddenly appear, as if by magic, thousands of tiny weed seedlings in the soil of borders and garden beds that previously had looked promisingly weed-free.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 16. -- T. Suffern Taller, former metropolitan amateur titleholder, and G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, six-goal polo star and well known as a steeplechase rider, representing the home club, registered a hard-earned 2-and-1 victory over James Knott of Piping Rock and John R. Fell of Meadow Brook as play in the annual invitation best-ball handicap golf tournament got under way at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Activities for the Fall season in Westchester County will be directed in their respective organizations by the leaders whose photographs appear above.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Hostility toward Governor Landon among some followers of Senator Borah is worrying Republicans eager for convention harmony.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- Attorneys for the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, of Akron, Ohio, told the Supreme Court today that the United States Rubber Company of New York City was "seeking to perpetuate the monopoly which it has enjoyed for a number of years" by protesting an adverse lower court ruling in a patent claim against Firestone.

SWISS by-paths are finding a prominent place this season on the lists of vacationists who have tired of trying to see as many places as possible on a single European trip and are now turning to leisurely wanderings.

Baker interested me tremendously, not so much because of the item about the two-thirds rule as in his inference that should President Roosevelt be re-elected next Fall he would seek a third term in 1940. What even a second term of the New Deal would mean few would hazard a guess.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Two leading events of the last week-defeat by the House of the Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Refinancing Bill and the definite change of direction of the corporate tax measure in the Senate Finance Committee -- have been seized upon by a number of political observers as additional signs that the government at Washington has turned to the right beyond the crossroads.

An application of the American Radio Telegraphists Association for membership in the Commercial Telegraphers Association has been temporarily rejected, it was announced yesterday by Frank B. Powers, international president of the commercial group.

MOSCOW, May 15. -- "Let there be gayety" the Soviet regime said, and there was gayety. And of the many changes which have occurred in Soviet life in recent years none shows more graphically than this the advance made toward that human happiness which is the avowed object of the Bolshevist experiment.

The volume of bonds called last week for redemption before maturity was further restricted. Excepting two large public utility retirements, the notices were mostly for small lots of municipal bonds. Redemption dates were almost all for later months. The total for May was slightly changed to $371,061,000, compared with $348,563,000 in April and $96,267,000 in May, 1935, in corresponding weeks.

PARIS, May 16. -- A sensation has been caused throughout the Catholic Church in France by the removal from his high office by the Vatican of Mgr. Andre DuBois de la Villerabel, Archbishop of Rouen and Primate of Normandy.

CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP). -- Leaders predicted today contests over seating of delegates when the convention of the Socialist party of the United States opens here Saturday.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 16. -- Garden club delegates from all parts of the United States and Honolulu will gather here and at West Point next Tuesday to open a four-day session of the Garden Club of America. Mrs. Ernest R. Adee of Tuxedo is chairman of the committee in charge.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- A full dollar has been clipped off the family food bill this Spring. A month's supply of ten basic foods consumed by typical American families costs $22. Last Winter the cost was $23. Last Spring it was $21.50.
OMAHA, Neb., May 15. -- How much of a "taxpayer's paradise" Nebraska may be, as boasted by Governor Cochran, depends to some extent upon the location.

ADDIS ABABA, May 16 (AP). -- A dramatic story of the burning and looting of Aspa Tafari, capital of Chercher Province, 200 miles south of here, was brought to Addis Ababa tonight by nine British missionaries.

GENEVA, May 16. -- The historic Necker house at 9 Rue Calvin, Geneva, built where Francois Boniyard, Byron's "Prisoner of Chillon," lived before being thrown into a dungeon, has become the world's fifth International House for students.

Drastic revision of the United States maritime law to place responsibility for safety conditions at sea directly upon shipping operators is urged in a report submitted by James W. Ryan, admiralty lawyer, of 99 John Street, to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. Mr. Ryan submitted his recommendations as a minority report of the association's admiralty committee.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- Persons 22 years of age led in committing crimes during the first quarter of 1936, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today, adding that the "crime age" had been 19 during the last four years.

Summaries of activities in the various departments will occupy representatives of the first judicial district of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs on Thursday, at their Spring meeting at the Hotel McAlpin. Mrs. Otto Hahn, director of the area, has invited all club women to attend.

ALTHOUGH in the galleries of New York the season has begun -- with reluctance and rather tentatively as yet -- to relax its record pace, our museums are proceeding full steam ahead. For them Summer acts as no deterrent at all.
Stockholders of Carib Syndicate, Ltd., have been called to act on June 12 on increasing authorized capital from 800,000 shares of 25 cents par value to 2,000,000 shares.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 16. -- Needle workers and their families from crowded city slums will gather near here tomorrow 1,000 strong to inspect the model cooperative community which is being erected for their occupancy by the Resettlement Administration.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Under the Social Security Act so much additional work has been given to the Treasury's Division of Research and Statistics that it will necessitate the establishment of a special section. Each year the Secretary of the Treasury must furnish estimates of the appropriations needed as an "annual premium" to provide for the old age annuity benefits.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Tuna fishing has assumed a new prominence here, with the formal opening of the new home of the Atlantic City Tuna Club. Well equipped and with eleven docks for visiting boatmen, the building is located at the entrance to the Inlet on the site of the old Atlantic City Yacht Club.

CREATION of a great international park on both sides of the Rio Grande in Texas and Mexico, plans for which are now maturing, would open for tourists of both countries a region surpassing majesty and picturesqueness.

THE concept of private schools as glorified country clubs is due for a good deal of modification this week when a 2,000-pound copper-covered dome, constructed by boys of the Edgewood School, Greenwich, Conn., will be placed on an observatory which they also built.
HOLLAND, Mich., May 16 (AP). -- Three million brilliant blossoms greeted visitors today at the opening of this Dutch-American community's eighth annual "Tulpen Feest."

EASTON, Pa., May 16. -- Enrollment of 1,000,000 voters, preferably those who will cast their first ballots in November. Is sought by "The League for Political Common Sense," started by a group of voters here under the leadership of Dr. William M. Lewis, president of Lafayette College.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP). -- After six straight defeats the Chicago Cubs turned on the Phillies today to score a 7-3 triumph behind the six-hit pitching of Roy Henshaw.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Dr. George W. Calver, attending physician at the Capitol, who holds the rank of captain although the Navy Department exercises no supervision over him because the 1933 Legislative Appropriation Bill continued his detail "until otherwise provided by law," is the centre of a threatened storm of protest in the House.

THE Little Red Rider of the District of Columbia public schools is rapidly taking a place in discussion of American pedagogy and bids fair to become as well known in certain circles as Little Red Riding Hood, although it is not yet a year old and its death appears imminent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- Pitcher Lou Hall starred as City College gained an uphill victory over Temple University today, 6 to 1. Hall not only held the Owls to six hits, but also hammered out a home run in the eighth inning with two men on base to win his own game.

MANY of the broadleaf shrubs hold their leaves all Winter in the neighborhood of New York City, although they are actually deciduous in regions where the Winters are severe and prolonged. South of Long Island the yews, retinosporas, thuyas and cryptomerias, and a greater variety of glossy-leaved evergreens, may be safely planted.

It was a gala day for the Union-port section of the East Bronx yesterday. War veterans, naval cadets and public and parochial school children marched in gayly colored uniforms behind fife and drum corps. Federal, State and city officials made speeches from a flag-bedecked enclosure at Castle Hill and Cicero Avenues.

Austria's population (6,759,062) is somewhat less than New York City's, and her territory (33,369 sq. mi.) could be fitted comfortably inside of Maine. Yet small as she may be by American standards, her place in European affairs looms large. Behind her domestic troubles of recent years move the chessmen of powerful Continental diplomacy.

NO one is indifferent to the beauty of a garden. Even the passer-by realizes that a few flowers can make the humblest cottage appear bright and gay. Those who have seen thatched cottages in England and France, covered to the eaves with roses and clematis and surrounded with a flower garden, know what a picture even a few well-chosen plants can make.

A TRANSFORMATION of the undergraduate social life at City College has taken place in the past two years through the introduction in modest and modified form of some of the ideas underlying the much-heralded "house plan" now in vogue at Harvard and Yale.

Crews representing the New York Athletic Club swept the river in the regatta with Manhattan College on the Harlem yesterday. In the three races of the program the Winged Foot senior, intermediate and junior eights all came home in front of their respective opponents, the Jasper varsity, 150-pound and freshman combinations.

Bizet's "Carmen" received its second performance of the popular season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan. The presentation, in all respects, merited the same encomiums as the initial one that ushered in the Spring activities at the opera house.

RICHMOND, Va., May 15. -- A movement which may mark an epoch in the social and cultural rehabilitation of the South has been begun at the Southern Policy Conference in Chattanooga, attended by seventy-five economists, teachers, journalists and writers.

IN an effort toward reducing its share of the country's automobile fatalities, California is starting an intensive move against traffic violators on a class of thoroughfares little suspected by the average driver of yielding the highest fatal accident percentage.

Recent easing in commodity prices has been carefully watched by chain merchandising executives. At this time, however, the belief is that the decline largely represents the uncertainty due to the prospective devaluation of the French franc, and that with this uncertainty removed in the near future, levels would stabilize, if not move to higher levels.

DR. CLENDENING again demonstrates in this book his notable faculty for the clear, simple and readable statement for lay reading of medical developments and findings. It is a remarkably concise and compact survey of its field, a sort of handbook of nutrition for every one, the author having permitted himself the use of hardly a single word in excess of the simplest and most concise expression of facts.

MOSCOW, May 16. -- Jose R. Capablance of Cuba, Dr. Emanuel Lasker of England and the two Russians, M. Botwinnik and V. Ragosin, were winners today in the third round of the International Chess Masters tournament. All five matches on the schedule were played to a conclusion.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- April gains in industry were largely retained in the first nine days of May, the Department of Commerce reported today in noting that little change occurred in the week ended on May 9.

ONCE upon a time -- and this is no fairy tale -- a motorist drove from Cleveland to New York and spent only $1 for gasoline. That trip, the "first long-distance horseless carriage journey ever made in America," was taken in May of 1899 by Alexander Winton, early automobile manufacturer.

HOULTON, Me. -- It is again planting time for potatoes in Aroostook County, Me. Every one of the 6,714 farmers of Aroostook has been-busily engaged for weeks in oiling and repairing his machinery, hauling fertilizer, going to town day after day to sell the remainder of his last crop or to see his banker about financing this year's crop.

TOPEKA, Ran., May 16. -- Although Governor Landon has received many invitations to address organizations in the East, he has chosen for his fourth appearance in the national spotlight the little town of Attica, in Southwest Kansas, tomorrow night.

MINNESOTA, the Gopher State, has declared war on the gopher, offering a bounty for its extermination. This little animal with its yellow and black stripes was a familiar sight to the pioneers. It stood upright, curiously watching the passing men, but ready to drop and scurry off at the first alarming sign.

The Riverdale Country Day School for Girls held its first Greek festival yesterday on the school grounds with more than fifty students, in Greek costumes, taking part in dances, pantomine and athletic contests which included a chariot race with teams of girls acting as steeds.

AS Chancellor of the Exchequer, Neville Chamberlain has shocked the British public into realization of what rearmament means by raising the income tax in his budget for this year. He might easily have met the increased expenditure by loans, as many expected he would do. But it was characteristic of him to refuse to conceal the cost in that way and to state bluntly that armament expenses would go up and stay up for years.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Secretary Ickes reopened his fight tonight to put all government conservation agencies under his control. In a nation-wide radio speech over a National Broadcasting Company chain he urged passage by the House of a bill already passed by the Senate changing the name of the Department of the Interior to Department of Conservation.

THE American Medical Association met at Kansas City last week. Before its fifteen scientific sections some 300 technical papers were read. Their revelations were probably of more direct concern to the public than the mathematical disquisitions on atoms and cosmic rays of the physicists at their gatherings.

BALTIMORE, May 16. -- George Kenyon of New York engaged in a fierce struggle with a hotel thief in his room on the ninth floor of the Southern Hotel early today while Mrs. Kenyon called the night clerk in the lobby for help.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 16. -- Holy Cross added Harvard as its eleventh straight victim today, defeating the Crimson, 15 to 4, before a crowd of 5,000 persons.

NO longer is it necessary to join the navy to see the world. Just be an athlete and -- this is the catch -- if you are good enough you can come pretty close to seeing whatever parts of the globe you wish.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Fauquier-Loudoun Polo Club has begun its 1936 season, is practicing regularly and has announced match games each week at the Marshall Field on Saturdays and the Phipps Field on Sundays. This club in the past has made good records in matches with the army team from Fort Meyer and with other opponents.

Headed by four players with handicaps of one stroke each, the annual Spring handicap list of the Metropolitan Golf Association has been released, a sure harbinger of the fact that the season is on in full blast.

Last week's debate in the House of Representatives did not go far toward solving the most difficult question with which the country is confronted at this time -- the relief problem. The House had before it an Administration bill appropriating an additional $1,425,000,000 for "work relief" during the twelve months beginning next July.

On the eve of being taken back into private industry to work out a certain idea originated and presented by myself, I feel constrained to set down at least one of many thoughts occurring to me after seven months' work on a WPA project.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 16. -- Disagreement with the action of the Republican-controlled Assembly in blocking passage of Governor Lehman's Social Security Bill was expressed by Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo in a speech made after his re-election as president of the Association of New York State Young Republicans Clubs at its convention here today.

Glimpses of the Olympic Games are to be televised twice a day directly from the stadium in Berlin. So, at least, reads the program of the energetic Germans. Can it be that they have outstripped the rest of the world and that we are at last to behold distant events as if they were occurring in our own living rooms?

Rapidly growing realization that the Summer period offers greater opportunity for increased volume than industry is aware of has caused numerous national advertisers to plan expanded advertising and sales drives during the coming season, according to comment here yesterday by manufacturing and agency executives.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 16. -- The platform adopted by the convention of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs here today was as follows:

IF it's horror we have it," said Mr. Arthur Mayer cheerfully. We were interviewing the eminent trader in terror in his charmingly fitted, almost feminine, headquarters above the Rialto Theatre marquee. The marquee reads "Dracula's Daughter, the Vampire Woman Whose Kiss Means Death, Whose Eyes Spell Doom."

While his younger brother searched at home for "play money" to be used as treasure in a game of "pirates" they were about to play, 12-year-old Erick Grawin Jr. was found hanged yesterday afternoon from an abandoned barge at College Point, Queens.

Any one observing carefully the whole procedure of Congress on the bill to tax corporation surpluses might conclude that the House of Representatives had almost taken pains to show to the country how inferior it is to the Senate. The Constitution, of course, puts the responsibility of originating bills for revenue solely upon the House.

A.J. McCarthy, vice president in charge of operations of the International Mercantile Marine Company and chairman of the New York Shipping Association, is the dominant figure among the ship-owners who are fighting the rank-and-file strike of seamen.

Columbia drew out of a tie for last place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League yesterday, taking a double-header from Dartmouth at Baker Field. A home run in the last inning by Al Barabas, with two on, enabled the Lions to take the opener, 5 to 3, while two big scoring innings gave them the record tussle, 5 -- 2.

IT would be an injudicious flattery to say that Shaw's plays have grown better in recent times; they haven't; and other playwrights, who have learned from him how adult ideas may be discussed in the theatre, have been surpassing him by the simple device of presenting, in their plays, credible women.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area again scored substantial gains last week. Estimates placed sales of leading department stores here at about 15 per cent larger than for the corresponding week last year, on a day-by-day basis. For the first half of the month, it was indicated that local department stores would have an increase of from 12 to 13 per cent over the 1935 period.

MIAMI, Fla., May 16. -- Former Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter, who has been appearing at his old office in the Federal Building daily in disregard of his impeachment by the United States Senate, deviated from the custom today.

Six shots fired at him from a fleeing car was the reprisal visited on him for failing to meet a $10,000 demand of the vice industry, David Marcus, a booker, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a blue ribbon jury.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 16. -- With the planting of a golden oak near Pendleten Hall, newest building on the Wellesley campus, the youngest class this afternoon celebrated the oldest of college traditions. The spade was the original implement used in the first Tree Day ceremony fifty-nine years ago to a day.

OTHER than to say that it deals with young love, it would be pretty hard to define the theme of "The Lemon Farm." Mr. Boyd, in a nebulous sort of way, is writing about the conflict between two codes of living, but his story is so very personal in its application that those who like a clean-cut moral will scarcely derive much comfort from it.
ROME, May 16. -- Premier Benito Mussolini expressed "best wishes for the continuance and success of your work" to Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria today.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The International Harvester Company, instead of following the example of other corporations which have held up hearings into complaints of alleged violation of the National Labor Relations Act through injunctive proceedings, is now engaged in laying the groundwork for Supreme Court adjudication of the most fundamental question and issues raised by the labor act.

Various suggestions are being advanced for the reform of the League of Nations covenant. My own conviction is that no change is called for at this time, but rather an honest and fearless application of its present provisions, especially the authorization to use force to punish aggression.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 16. -- The Republic Steel Corporation will share with the A.O. Smith Corporation of Milwaukee a $2,450,000 pipe-line order for the Texas-Empire Pipe Line Company for a line between Kansas City, Mo., and Chicago. This is the first large pipe-line order placed in Youngstown in several years.

AS an acorn is planted for the sake of posterity, so the benefits of a subscription to certain literary enterprises are sometimes mainly derived by a subsequent generation. It may be assumed that every member of the present Cabinet will feel it his duty to enter his name on the subscription list for the "History of Parliament," of which the first volume will be published by H.M. Stationery Office next August.

ALBANY, May 16. -- The dominant issue in the Fall campaign for the election of Assemblymen will be the refusal "of the Republican majority in the Assembly to pass the Dunnigan-Steingut bill carrying out Governor Lehman's eight-point social security program," Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn informed the Democratic minority today.

Antonio Barcelo, leader of the Liberal party and Senator of Puerto Rico, repeated a customary phrase of his when, protesting against the Plebiscite Bill which was recently introduced in Washington by Senator Millard E. Tydings, he said: "Independence, even if we die of hunger!"

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- Colonial facades will take on the guise of haciendas and backyards will become patios in the 1600 block of Latimer Street on June 1. Members of several philanthropic and artistic groups will combine talents to make "The Lark in Latimer Street of 1936" a Mexican fiesta.
Larry Burger, Long Island University ace, shut out the Brooklyn College nine at Dexter Park yesterday, as his teammates pounded two hurlers to win, 10--0.

HERBERT CAROLAN is a young business man in San Francisco who has found so much interest and pleasure` the business and vacation journeys he has made from that city by automobile that he has been moved to share them with readers and so has written this book about them.

"A VERITABLE giant, with quiet and gravely impressive mien, with thick, gray hair and florid face. * * * Spectacles large and insistent; sober frock coat. A nose more depressed than that of Michael Angelo after the mallet blow of Torrigiano * * *."
PORTLAND, Ore., May 16 (AP). -- Townsendite candidates took a beating on the Republican side of the Oregon primary election but gained a foothold in the Democratic contests.

IT has been a practice of this sabbatical department during the past few years to observe at the conclusion of each theatrical season the extent to which Hollywood and its proverbial moguls have dabbled in Broadway's affairs during the preceding months of activity.

Although City Island has an average width of only three or four blocks, and although there are only 230 acres of it, its two harbors, west and east, cater to entirely different yachting clienteles. Recently, a description was offered of the western anchorage on Eastchester Bay, in front of the several yacht clubs, where almost every boat is a power cruiser and most of them not more than fifty feet long.

Nearly 90 per cent of the 85,659 persons who have contributed to the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army are members of employe groups of corporations and firms, it was announced last night by Chalmers Wood, chairman of the drive.

PROFESSOR SHELDON GLUECK of Harvard University, the author of several important works on the subject of criminology, has written another excellent book, "Crime and Justice." In reading it, one is immediately impressed with the author's painstaking and scholarly research.

ANY one inclined to despair of our modern civilization and feel that in all the centuries we have made absolutely no progress should take up his Shakespeare and read that scene in "The Merchant of Venice" which reveals our ancestors as regarding the mistakes and disabilities of the blind as material for mirth.
Week end realizing lowered prices 1 to 6 points on the Cotton Exchange, yesterday. July rose 13 points for the week and October 16 points, however.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 16. -- The Navy was overwhelmed by Washington and Lee, 17 to 6, today. Although the losers had a slight batting edge on the visitors, five errors contributed to their defeat.

Charles P. Graddick, superintendent of the Air Mail Service of the Postoffice Department, said last night that the official postal viewpoint had not been altered by the transatlantic flight of the Zeppelin Hindenburg on the question of the eventual superiority of the airplane over the airship for transatlantic air mail service.

HAVERFORD, Pa., May 16.--A Republican would be elected President in the coming election if Haverford College students were the sole voters. Their annual news questionnaire, conducted last week, indicated a 2-to-1 vote for any Republican over President Roosevelt.

PARIS, May 14. -- As the midseason openings came to an end they forecast some silhouette changes and confirmed many trends already noted. Lanvin and Mainbocher both show a predilection for asymmetrical effects in coats and dresses, which were wrapped way over to the left side and outlined with a contrasting fold, or with fur trimming.

AN atmosphere of right-wing academism always pervades the exhibitions of the Allied Artists of America, Inc. It is much in evidence this year, the occasion being the group's twenty-third annual showing in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building (on through the remainder of the month).

A. Henry Ross, Brooklyn lawyer, who was indicted Friday with Max D. Krone, a private detective, on a charge of having extorted $12,000 from Alfred E. Smith Jr., surrendered yesterday morning in the District Attorney's office.

Despite improved business conditions, the number of employable adults receiving public unemployment relief in this city, through the Works Progress Administration and the Emergency Relief Bureau, increased 57 per cent between July 31, 1935, and May 1 of this year.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Assured today by Treasury experts that their proposed increases in individual and corporation income taxes, coupled with a moderate rate on undistributed corporate profits, would produce the permanent new revenue required to repair the budget, a majority of the Senate Finance Committee appeared determined to scrap the revenue plan suggested by President Roosevelt and substitute their own.
Union Theological Seminary began the celebration of its 100th anniversary last night with a choral festival in the Riverside Church. One thousand adults and 500 children filled the church with song.

A NEW step in music education was inaugurated in Prague a short time ago by the Czechoslovak Government. Taking up where the Anglo-Americans left off, the Czechs recently established an International Society for Musical Education at Prague, and the first congress has just taken place.

BERLIN, May 16. -- The extent of Germany's naval armament officially was revealed today when the Marine Verordnungsblatt published a complete list of warships of the German Navy in service and still building on April 1 this year.

THERE was talk of the Preakness, the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes and the three horses that were triple winners on that circuit in their days -- Sir Barton, Gallant Fox and Omaha. Then some one spoke up and said that the Epsom Derby was still the high-hat, top-hole turf event of the year.

ALTHOUGH there is much that is fine, perceptive and intelligent in "The Weather in the Streets," a brief and unadorned summary of its plot would hardly serve to recommend it. For Rosamond Lehmann has chosen a trifling fable, a bread-and-butter story of the romancers.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- An immediate outlay of $6,000,000 to promote air safety in the United States and Alaska by providing additional aids to navigation was recommended today by the Business Advisory Council to the Commerce Department.

UNLIKE that of the policeman, the lot of a trained nurse doing "Private Duty," is an extremely happy one, judging at least from the picture of it given by Faith Baldwin's new novel Carolyn Cutler, her heroine, young and, of course, extremely pretty, proves irresistibly charming to almost every man with whom she comes in contact, is extremely popular at dances, and triumphs over the rich girl who is her rival.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 16. -- Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Good Goods turned the tables today on J.W.Y. Martin's Dark Hope for last Saturday's defeat in the Dixie Handicap by taking the Governors Handicap, a mile and an eighth for 3-year-olds at Narragansett Park today.

SOU'WESTER SAILS" will please the reader who loves a sea story for the sake of reading about outdoor adventure; in addition it will be highly satisfyying to the young yachtsman who has had some experience and will therefore appreciate the book's authentic details of seamanship.

THEY have been saying that Mr. Cohan (George M.) has not been going daily to the ball games, which in itself is news. Well, then, Mr. Cohan must be doing something with his time, and rumor offers a reason: nothing less than a revue, and an old-fashioned Cohan revue, at that.

THIS is perhaps the most serious and certainly the most consequential novel Honore Morrow has given us. Whether it is at the same time the most successful artistically is rather doubtful. The task which she set herself in telling this story of the dawn of the American Revolution presented enormous difficulties; and not the least of them, oddly enough, is the element of time.

Announcement was made yesterday by the Associated Merchandising Corporation that it will expand its buying for Au Printemps, one of the largest department stores in Paris. The representative of the Paris office of the A.M.C. is now in this country in connection with the purchasing.

PEIPING, China, May 15. -- "We cannot agree with the principles and policies of Nanking and the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] but are willing to cooperate with anybody entertaining the same ideas as ourselves," declared Yin Ju-keng, chief of the East Hopei Autonomous Council at Tungchow, his capital, today.

Four new scholarships, with a total value of $3,200, have been founded by the Very Rev. Aloysius J. Hogan, president of Fordham University, and will be granted to students entering the freshman class in September, it was announced yesterday at the office of the dean of studies.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 16. -- Annual prizes and awards at New Jersey College for Women were announced today by Dean Margaret T. Corwin at the final chapel service of the year. The presentation marked a precedent, since all honors are usually made public at Class Day exercises in June.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- West Philadelphia Catholic High in a stirring rally regained the Stotesbury Cup today, beating Hun School of Princeton by a quarter length on the Schuylkill today. North Catholic was third and Roman Catholic High last.

A RADIO tube designed to generate currents set the "ether" in vibration is called an oscillator, a radically new type of which has been introduced by the RCA tube research division. It produces powerful but tiny radio waves, and the engineers report it opens new vistas in the micro-wave spectrum, which includes television.

JERRARD TICKELL is a newcomer, deserving of a cordial welcome. Irish by birth and widely traveled, he is endowed with a dexterous knack of conveying sophistication with a civilized courtesy and tenderness with a restrained simplicity and yet retaining virility of style.

To assist the United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps a ball will be given on Saturday at the Plaza under the patronage of many persons prominent in social and civic life. The executive committee is headed by Goodhue Livingston Jr., whose assistants are Robert P. MacFadden, Llewellyn G. Ross, John O. Conway, Arthur F. Brownley, Robert L. Debevoise, Alexander Schmidt and Lieut. Commander J. Allen Haines, U.S.N.R.

Publication of the Franco-American reciprocal trade treaty has again called attention to the important breaches that are being made in the high wall erected in 1930 by the Hawley-Smoot Tariff Act. In about two years treaties have been negotiated with thirteen countries with which the United States transacts about a third of its international trade, countries to which in 1935 the United States exported goods valued at $733,200,000.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 16. -- Taking a commanding lead when ready, C.V. Whitney's Two Bob, capably handled by the veteran Sonny Workman, made a show of her opposition in winning the sixty-second running of the $5,000 added Kentucky Oaks at Churchill Downs today.

WESTONBIRT, England, May 16 (AP). -- America's polo squad completed the first stage of its preliminary training for the forth coming international matches today and prepared to move on to London for final drills.

SO far as this writer knows, Arturo Toscanini gave the press but one or two interviews during the whole time that he was conducting in America. He was extremely averse to that sort of thing, which was a pity, because such a musician could have given us invaluable information as well as opinion upon many pertinent subjects.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 15. -- Managements of both political parties in Ohio were disappointed at the result of the primary on Tuesday, although in a major sense the outcome conformed to organization patterns. The general staffs were aggrieved because Father Coughlin's National Union for Social Justice exercised far too much influence.

A woman whom the police described as Grace Adinolfi, wife of Eddie Adinolfi, who is serving sixty years in Sing Sings as a participant in the kidnapping in 1932 of Charles Rosenthal, young broker, was held with a male companion by the police yesterday on assault and robbery charges after they had held up a small restaurant on the West Side and then lost the loot.

MRS. LUM holds a mirror up to nature in Japan, Korea, China and the Philippines without reflecting much more than a flat, polished surface will reveal. In her sketches of the ancient rites, folklore and art, there is an occasional glint of sunlight, but these rare flashes are merely emphasis on the lack of modeling and contrast in most of the writing.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Announcement by the White House today that President Roosevelt had signed the joint Congressional resolution authorizing the United States to participate in the forthcoming Pan-American Peace Conference at Buenos Aires, sponsored by the President, cleared away the last technicality necessary to carry out the project.

Older readers who know George Macdonald's "The Light Princess and Other Fairy Tales," will recall a story in the book, which, under the title "The Carasoyn." gave a delightful account of the little boy who turned the brook through his house and thus made the acquaintance of the Fairy Queen and all her court when the Fairy Fleet came to anchor in his bedroom.

DIANA PATRICK writes light fiction in serious vein. The title of her latest novel is taken from the verse, "What shall we steer by, having no chart but the deliberate fraud of the heart?" So naturally there is an abundance of heart interest in her story.

MEXICO, D.F., May 16. -- Hope has been virtually abandoned, after a week of conferences between Mexican National Railway officials and workers' delegates, of averting the strike called for Monday at 5 P.M.

CLEARWATER, Fla., May 16 (AP). Donald Roebling said today his four-ton "mercy tank" swam a lake and plunged through thickets with an ease which convinced him it could carry on effective relief work in isolated storm areas.

UNSETTLED weather made reports on retail trade a little more spotty in the week and yet sizable gains over a year ago were apparently achieved in many sections of the country. The average increase was probably around 12 per cent.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 15. -- Apparently established more strongly than ever as the Republican leader in Connecticut, J. Henry Roraback, electric utilities operator, was named this week for his fifth four-year term on the Republican National Committee, of which he is third vice chairman.

Strutting proudly, Ophelia demonstrated her fine points before the judges of the Bronx Girl Scout pet show at the 105th Field Artillery Armory yesterday afternoon and carried off the blue ribbon for being the most unusual pet in the show. Ophelia is a lady bug.

SOMETIMES we wonder just how important the movie stars are. Offhand, there does not seem to be any denying their hold on producer, exhibitor and spectator. Clark Gable is box office; Arthur Treacher is not. Jean Harlow will bring them in; Helen Broderick may be taken or left alone.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., May 16. -- Jarvis (Chubby) Hicks of Sea-wane, playing in his first tournament of the season, won the seventeenth annual Morris County Golf Club invitation event today, defeating Sayre (Pat) MacLeod, home club star, 7 and 5.
A NOVELIST may change his mind. Sinclair Lewis apparently has done just that in regard to radio's effect on the sale of books.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., May 16. -- New Jersey's best-ball amateur golf champions, Mike Cestone and Pat Mucci of Branch Brook, had to play forty-five holes today to win two eighteen-hole matches in defense of their title. After battling through twenty-six holes to win their morning match, the defenders defeated Bobby Wilkinson and Bill Donahue, 1 up in nineteen holes, in the afternoon to enter the semifinals.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 16. -- The names of the ten students chosen to receive Upson Memorial Scholarships -- an award of about $400 a year for four years at Rutgers University -- were announced today by Dr. Fraser Metzger, dean of men and chairman of the faculty scholarship committee.

TORONTO, May 16. -- The Canadian metal mining industry is producing $1,000,000 of new wealth each working day and is providing an annual payroll of more than $88,000,000 to roughly 73,000 workers. Metal mining alone employs 34,000 workers, who receive $51,000,000 annually in wages, or an average of $1,500.

UNEXPECTED production may be mounted and performed on short notice at the Metropolitan Opera during its current Spring season. For example, Edward Johnson and his colleagues in the directorate are thinking about a work by Franz von Suppe or Jacques Offenbach.

With Monte Carlo for a setting, Mr. Frost has produced an international spy story that might have come from the pen of Oppenheim himself. His hero is Anthony Hamilton, an American Secret Service agent, and opposed to Hamilton is a group of plotters whose aim is to stir up another European war so that Japan may have a free hand to pursue her aims in Asia and elsewhere.
TRENTON, May 16 -- New Jersey's primary elections, to be held next Tuesday, will command nation-wide attention for three reasons in particular.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 15. -- Kentucky's State Government this month starts upon a brand new experiment in operation, with all direct property taxes and all sales taxes, as far as they apply to the necessities of life, abolished. Their place is taken by taxes on luxuries, personal and corporate incomes.
