A garden party will be given by members of the committee of management of the Studio Club of the Young Women's Christian Association Wednesday afternoon on the roof of the clubhouse, 210 East Seventy-seventh Street. There will be a musical program and tea will be served.

BERLIN, May 16. -- Prospects for early action on a wider scale for the resettlement of Europe along the lines envisaged in Chancellor Adolf Hitler's peace plan of March 31 are not viewed as promising in German quarters.

JUANITA HARRISON is an American colored woman who in eight years lived in twenty-two different countries, and who, with insatiable desire for knowledge, indomitable sportsmanship and all-conquering friendliness of spirit -- as well as energy and competence -- worked her way around the world.

Patrolman John Carney of the East Sixty-seventh Street station had seen the woman pottering over rubbish on his beat before, but she seemed particularly bedraggled and forlorn yesterday at about 1:15 P.M. He walked over to her, in front of the St. Vincent Ferrer Church at Sixty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue, and took her to the station house.

LONDON, May 16. -- Britain will have lasting memorials to King George in a statue to be erected in the heart of the empire beside Westminster Abbey and in playing fields with memorial gateways throughout the country. They were announced tonight after a meeting of the memorial committee with the Archbishop of Canterbury presiding.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- A permanent National Resources Board, to replace the emergency organization set up a year ago by President Roosevelt, would be established as a regular agency of the government by an amendment the Senate Commerce Committee decided today to offer as an addition to the Omnibus Flood Control Bill when it comes up for consideration Tuesday.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- This was Jimmy Dykes Day at Comiskey Park and it was celebrated with minute, attention to all the traditional details. The White Sox leader was presented with a humidor and 1,000 cigars in an elaborate pictorial tableau at the home plate by Cook County Assessor John S. Clark, and then the Yankees promptly proceeded to steal the show.

Three more members of the Police Department were dismissed by Commissioner Valentine yesterday, two for intoxication and one on several charges which included drinking. These dismissals brought to 107 the total since Mr. Valentine took over the office on Sept. 25, 1934.

The New York Shipbuilding Corporation reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a profit of $39,031 after ordinary taxes, interest and depreciation, but before Federal taxes. In the corresponding quarter of 1935 there was a net loss of $160,543.

A FEW weeks ago Mr. Waldemar Kaempffert, writing on the Science Page of THE TIMES, reported that Dr. A.C. Fieldner of the Bureau of Mines had recommended the use of a chemical known as calodorant to add a warning odor to escaping gas. Calodorant, Mr. Kaempffert explained, is "a compound derived from petroleum and, compared with which, the emission of a skunk is a delicate and pleasant perfume."

WHEN Mrs. Penny goes to Jarrold Park, nominally as housekeeper but really to spy out the land for Detective Lieutenant Kirk Larrabee, she is already aware that each of Jerome Jarrold's four former wives had died within a year or two of her marriage and that his fifth wife is ill, but even so she is not fully prepared for the situation that confronts her.

AN undercurrent of stealthy danger pervades Peking, due to the surreptitious entrance into the city of many thousand Northern peasants, in reality the army of the bandit war lord, General Wu Lo Feng. The movement made in conjunction with Japanese militarists aims to create an incident which will not only enrich Wu's coffers but greatly increase Japan's prestige in China.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- Shipping interests fired a new broadside before the Interstate Commerce Commission today against a proposal by Class 1 railroads to continue emergency freight surcharges indefinitely. The railroads estimate that the surcharges, which are due to expire on July 1, provide additional yearly income of $104,500,000.

LATE Spring and Summer are the sesames which unlock for the visitor the delightful treasureland of New York's State parks. When the lengthening sun begins to warm the waters of ocean and lake, when mountain trails and forest burgeon with the season's new life, the Winter-weary urbanite turns from his habitat of stone and steel and bustle for fresher, quieter surroundings.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The War Department has found that foreign nations bought 14 per cent more bombardment planes during the last two years than they had been buying before.

TWO etchers are represented in the New York exhibitions this month whose lives have followed almost opposite directions, whose art shows little in common, one of whom has often been brought before the American public, while the other is practically unknown to that public.

ONE does not have to go beyond the title, "Fiasco in Ethiopia," to discover what Wynant Davis Hubbard thinks of Italy's military excursion into North Africa. Or, at least, what he did think of it when three months ago he abandoned his role of war correspondent at the front and came home.

IF Leslie (Romeo) Howard had been as late for the balcony scene as he was on a recent morning for his interview with this punctual department, he would certainly have missed Norma (Juliet) Shearer's passionate avowal to the moon, and the MGM version of William Shakespeare's sweet tragedy might never have been accomplished.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 16 (AP). -- With the qualifying limit 174, all the members of America's Curtis Cup squad made the grade with strokes to spare today in the women's British golf championship, but the distinction of giving Miss Bridget Newell her closest run rested with three other Britons.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- A novel way in which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation can transfer some of its investments in banks by financing small individual stockholders was disclosed here today by Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, in an interview.

Outscored in first places, eight to six, in its dual meet with St. John's University at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, City College's varsity track and field team nevertheless garnered enough second and third positions to down the Redmen by a 68 -- 58 score.

For the twenty-seventh annual occasion, the longest and toughest cruiser race on Eastern waters will be conducted this season by the New York A.C. Yachting Department. As usual, it will be the familiar 100-nautical-mile thrash, seventy miles of it on the Sound and thirty in rougher, off-shore going, to Block Island's west harbor.
BERLIN, May 16. -- Friedrich Wilhelm, Germany's former Crown Prince, is still smarting under the reception given here to his enthusiastic congratulations to Premier Mussolini.

Many delegates from the metropolitan area are expected to take part in the forty-fifth annual convention of the Daughters of the Revolution, to be held at Haddon Hall in Atlantic City from Tuesday through Friday. Miss Charlotte C. Aycrigg of Ridgewood, N.J., president of the organization, will preside at all sessions.

WITH the first of the airship Hindenburg's ten scheduled round trips of the season behind her, not only safely but with a record for dirigible speed in both directions across the North Atlantic, the question of the American attitude toward commercial dirigibles again comes to the fore.
BEAUTIFUL fourth century statuette of the goddess Artemis was among the important finds made by the American archaeologists excavating in the Athenian agora during recent weeks.
EVANSTON, Ill., May 16. -- An artificial "eye," designed to enable the blind to read ordinary books, magazines and newspapers, was demonstrated tonight at Northwestern University.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- "Unto Joseph Gonnelli, Philadelphia, $5,000 absolutely," read a clause in the will of Frederick McOwen, president of the Cambria Mining Company, who died last month.

AT the top of the Boy Scout organization stands the National Council, composed of men who are outstanding in their communities. As business executives and professional workers, they represent many sides of American life, brought together to further the scouting program for boys.

RARE and fine antique furnishings reveal their merits best when placed in worthy settings; generally they are by the public detached from their proper surroundings. Museums provide suitable backgrounds -- the Metropolitan Museum in its American Wing, for example -- and some private collections are housed with equal dignity.

TULSA, Okla., May 16. -- Excessive taxation of the products of industry was assailed today by William A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, as "one of the most troublesome factors affecting industry today."

THREE of the four annual Prix de Rome awards were announced on Tuesday. These have been given to Harrison Gibbs (sculpture), Richard Ayers (architecture) and Robert S. Kitchen (landscape architecture). The jury's report on the painting award was delayed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 16 (AP). -- Rex Mays of California again proved his mastery over the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today, at least for twenty-five miles, by winning the pole position for the second consecutive time for the 500-mile automobile race to be run May 30.

Scoring all its points in the running events, Brooklyn Tech's track team captured the Brooklyn-Queens interscholastic meet conducted by the Department of Parks yesterday at Victory Field, Glendale, L.I.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- Rare works written by Arabic scholars centuries ago and revealing Islamic medical lore, theology and jurisprudence have been discovered during the cataloguing of the collection of Oriental manuscripts placed on deposit in the library of Princeton University by Robert Garrett, '97, of Baltimore.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Events at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club this week include a match play golf tournament on Friday and Saturday for the Ohio Gold Cup. The National Freight Traffic Golf Association will also hold its annual championship this week-end over the Old White course.

Applying fully to railroad reports for the first time since their framing, the regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission have made available for investors in the last few weeks information concerning finance and operations of the railroads that previously never had been included in statements to stockholders.

A RADIO show staged in the "flying studio of the Zeppelin Hindenburg's big gas bag floating over the Atlantic calls for the same tricks of showmanship as used in the thickly padded studios secluded within a soundproof shell of steel and concrete at Radio City.

Mr. Adams's latest story is a trifling little number. It reads like one of those old-fashioned farce comedies in which, after a number of absurd complications involving an assortment of odd-type characters, true love conquers all.
Frank Munns, 35 years old, of 160 East 108th Street, died in Harlem Hospital yesterday morning of a fractured skull and internal injuries suffered in an automobile accident a short time before.

Sixty new women's ensembles for Summer were displayed yesterday afternoon at the twenty-fifth annual luncheon, fashion show and bridge of the Women's Democratic Club of the City of New York at the Hotel Commodore.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 16. -- Andover had an easy time winning the fifty-first annual Harvard interscholastic Class A track games in the Harvard Stadium today. The triumph was Andover's tenth since the meet's inception.

VERY satisfactory progress in shaking down the transpacific service with the big flying boats of the clipper ship class was reported last week by Colonel Clarence M. Young, former Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Air, who directs the Pacific division for Pan American Airways.

Two doctors, a visitor and a patient are done to death in Monmouth Memorial Hospital in Chicago before Inspector Bondurant, the peppermint-eating detective, fathoms the mystery. Dr. Paul Ravel, who fancies himself as a detective, tries his best to help the inspector and is much annoyed when the latter refuses to take him seriously.
VIENNA, May 16. -- Heimwehr ! circles disclosed tonight that provincial units were massing guns in/ their barracks. "
TORONTO, May 16 (AP). -- Toronto and Montreal today divided a double bill, the Maple Leafs taking the first game, 7 -- 1, and dropping the second, 4 -- 2.

FRANKFORT-ON-THE-MAIN, Germany, Sunday, May 17. -- The Zeppelin Hindenburg, held here for hours by ill winds, was taken from her hangar at 5:30 this morning. The water ballast was released and the Hindenburg started to float up, and one minute later all her motors roared and she nosed into the wind.

NO place is too small to have its water garden. And no form of gardening is easier and more satisfying for the undecided and border-line garden lover than the growing of water lilies. Along in midsummer, when weeds get out of hand and the thermometer climbs, one turns happily to the contemplation of pools.

Man is earth's child and its ruler -- the recipient of its vital forces and also their treasurer. There are times when calm reason tells him that his own life must share the mortality of the Earth which produced it, that his spirit is a flash of light that must be extinguished when the structure through which it shone is in ashes.

Ever since Senator Borah admitted that he was willing to become the Republican candidate for the Presidency politicians have been asking: If he doesn't get the nomination will he bolt? Mr. Borah has not given an unequivocal answer to the question. Last week he came close to it. Addressing a Newark audience he said:
FOR many reasons May is the favorite "garden-visiting" month. Such visiting has spread extensively in recent years; it is one of the most effective methods of gaining genuine horticultural education.

WITH Victor's May release a couple of album nets that unquestionably are to be found on the shelves of all serious collectors are retired. New recordings of the Brahms Symphony No. 1, C minor, Op. 68, and Second piano concerto, B flat, Op. 83, are now available in albums M-301 and 305 respectively.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 16. -- A Vassar College alumna came back to carry off the honors at the Vassar horse show today at Greenvale Farms. Miss Harriet Behrend of Erie, Pa., with Oddity's Omega, won the hunter championship and gained the reserve with Dorando.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- During the fiscal year beginning July 1, the Treasury expects to print about 825 tons of currency paper. Contracts for the year's supply of the distinctive paper used for printed currency were awarded this week. The current appropriation calls for the expenditure of about $600,000.

The existence of "pain, suffering and hardship" in a civilized country like the United States was decried by Mayor La Guardia yesterday morning in an address at the formal dedication of the Dr. Gertrude B. Kelly Playground on Seventeenth Street, west of Eighth Avenue.

In New Brunswick there are several runs of Atlantic salmon and the seasons vary on different rivers. For instance, on the Miramichi the much discussed and maligned mended kelt run of fish, which has wintered under the ice, starts on the downstream migration shortly after the ice goes out in the early Spring.

New York University has awarded twenty-four scholarships to graduate students in the Department of Fine Arts for the semester just closing, Harold O. Voorhis, University secretary, announced yesterday.

WHEN I first went to Moscow in the Summer of 1921 the city was in a shocking state of dilapidation. I had seen Riga two years earlier, after it had undergone several days of shell-fire from Bermont's army, but save for the great quantity of glass which still littered the streets of the Latvian capital its appearance was far more normal than that of Moscow in 1921.

William F. Carey, builder and contractor, was named yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to succeed Colonel Thomas W. Hammond as head of the city's much-criticized Sanitation Department. He will take office as soon as his private affairs will permit.

PATERSON, N.J., May 16. -- Spurred by the removal of silk manufacturing and dyeing plants to other cities, a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce will place before Mayor John V. Hinchliffe the recommendation that a permanent city commission be named to obtain new industries and create conditions which will retain the industries now in the city.

McALESTER, Okla., May 16 (AP). -- Capture of two convicts, which leaves only three at large, release of an Indian hostage and official denunciation of prison guards for throwing down their guns were developments today of Wednesday's break by twenty-four prisoners at the Oklahoma penitentiary.

MEDIA, Pa., May 16. -- Arthur Hagen's Dock Light, a heavy favorite, won the Rose Tree Plate, a two-and-a-half-mile brush event, at the close of the Rose Tree Spring Hunts meet today before a crowd of 10,000. Morris Dixon piloted the winner over the difficult course, with James Simpson Jr.'s Gifted finishing second and Miss Page Lewis's Spartan Lad third.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- At the very time when Japan is doubling its armed forces in North China, the United States informally today repledged itself to observance of the Nine-Power treaty, which guarantees the integrity of China.

After a mock trial in which he was charged with incompetence and conduct unbecoming a gentleman, Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, was found guilty last night by a jury of about 1,000 students who paid 25 cents each for the privilege of sitting in judgment, and voted enthusiastically for his expulsion.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will act as manikins in a chapeau revue entitled the Band Box Fashion Show on Thursday afternoon at the Trouville for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop. The revue will include a showing of the latest hats suitable for wear during the cocktail hour.

THE National Orchestral Association, with Leon Barzin as musical director, will give its concerts next season on Monday evenings, Oct. 26, Nov. 16, Dec. 14, Feb. 22, March 22 and May 3. Admission is restricted to members of the association, who contribute from one dollar to $5,000 yearly to support its work of training young musicans in ensemble playing.

Romance, adventure and mystery, told chiefly by means of casual conversation, make "Dotted Line Honeymoon" easy to read. There are no fine points to miss and the story skips along rapidly. It picks up its heroine in a big Middle Western hotel where she works as a public stenographer.

ROME.--The prohibitive price of gasoline, which is sold everywhere in Italy at $1.35 a gallon owing to the necessity of curtailing private consumption at home for the benefit of military operations in Africa, is said to have forced the Fiat Company, the largest manufacturer of Italian cars, to produce a "baby" automobile that will use only as much gasoline as a motor cycle.

PARIS, May 15. -- France's first Socialist government, under the leadership of Leon Blum, does not seem likely to be as "revolutionary" as its opponents have sought to paint it. Indeed, many of the difficulties that lie in store for it probably will come from the fact that it will not be revolutionary enough to satisfy the eighty Communists on whose support it must, in part, depend, and even the Socialists themselves.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 16. -- By defeating Cornell today, 4-1, Yale leaped ahead toward third place in the Intercollegiate Baseball League. Lou Walker, who allowed the visitors but five singles, only two of which were bunched for the Cornell run, was in rare pitching form for the winners.

A large committee of patrons and patronesses and several Texas organizations in New York are cooperating in plans for the Texas Centennial Blue Bonnet Ball to be held on Saturday at the Biltmore. The event will be held for the benefit of the Texas Students' Scholarship Fund and for the furtherance of the Texas Centennial Exposition.

The New York Long Branch Railroad reported yesterday for 1935 a net income of $280,225, against one of $280,000 in 1934. The company is controlled by the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the Pennsylvania Railroad and its income is derived from Joint facility rents.

Discussion of the war debts due to the United States has been revived -- in Paris, in London and in Washington -- by a statement of LEON BLUM, leader of the Socialist party and probable next Premier of France. He deplored "the dramatic misunderstanding" existing between his country and our own, concerning this long-vexed question, and expressed the hope "that this misunderstanding can be effaced."

A GENTLE narrative of plain people, "Give Us This Day" pursues a leisurely course, guiding its simple hero's footsteps over the last thirty-five years from boyhood to the grave. Mr. Zara views the little world he has created with a mild and reflective eye, finding it, apparently, much of a piece with the greater world outside.

RICHMOND, Va., May 16. -- Lytton Strachey's biographical methods were "the worst influence of our generation" on literature, Dr. Douglas S. Freeman of Richmond, biographer of Robert E. Lee and 1935 Pulitzer Prize winner, asserted at the closing session of the American Library Association today.

Liquor retailers continued yesterday the price war which drove prices down from 5 to 20 per cent the day before. They made further cuts at the opening of business and their places were packed with customers until the close of business.

H.L. DAVIS, whose "Honey in the Horn" (Harper), a story of Oregon pioneers, has received the Pulitzer award for the best American novel of 1935, is a new writer. His prize-winning novel was his first; hitherto he had published only short stories and sketches.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 16. -- Champion Nunsoe Duc de la Terrace of Blakeen, the magnificent white poodle owned by the Blakeen Kennels of Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Katonah, N.Y., was handled by her in the ring this afternoon and was awarded the title of best in show at the thirty-third annual exhibition of the Ladies Kennel Association of America, held on the Mineola Fair Grounds.

Almost a fifth of the money needed for the funeral expenses of Michael De Santis, impoverished portrait painter who died on Thursday, was raised yesterday by the sale of thirteen of his pictures. They were sold at the Toran Decorative Art Studios, 289 Fourth Avenue, where De Santis formerly worked.

ASK an American about to make his first tour of Switzerland to enumerate some of the things that he expects to find most interesting in that country and he is likely to include in the list the Matterhorn, Chillon and the Lion of Lucerne.

Marmaduke M. Mizzle, the adventurous Mincing Lane caraway seed merchant who has not been heard from since August, 1934, is alive and well in the big monastery at Shigatse, Tibet, which houses 3,500 lamas.

The Charity Organization Society, which cares for destitute families in their own homes, will be the beneficiary of a large luncheon and a fashion competition entitled the "Calling All Models Style Revue" on Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

WHEN the chairman of the Department of Drama at Yale writes a book on "Film and Theatre" the natural expectation is that he will defend the stage. No one in the theatre likes to admit that the screen is getting on.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 16. -- Mrs. Fanny Starkey Crane, widow of Albert Crane, Stamford philanthropist and herself donor of the Crane Memorial Chapel at Tufts College, died today at her home, Rock Acres, Strawberry Hill, after being stricken yesterday.

The United States chess championship, held by Frank J. Marshall since 1909, last night went to Samuel Reshevsky, a member of the Marshall Chess Club who came here from Poland fifteen years ago as a child prodigy, Reshevsky triumphed in tournament play over fifteen rivals.

This volume would seem to be the result of crossing the fairy and flower rhyme, popular in the nineteenth century, with the modern idea of scientific picture books for children. On the left hand page are flower pictures, labeled with both the common and the name, on the right hand page the flowers are represented as fairy being.

MADISON, Wis., May 16. -- With the aid of new equipment which hurls protons, or, "electrical bullets," at a velocity of 15,000 miles a second, three University of Wisconsin scientists have begun a series of experiments on atom smashing.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 16. -- The Democratic party of Connecticut abandoned factional strife in the State convention this afternoon and instructed delegates to the national convention to elect David E. Fitzgerald of this city national committeeman.
ALBANY, May 16 (AP). -- Modern "happy hunting grounds," which may offer what the Indian once dreamed of, are being prepared in ten New York State areas, the Conservation Department said today.

BLUE RIDGE SUMMIT, Pa., May 16 (AP) -- A group of Pennsylvania Republicans gathered in this picturesque mountain place tonight to talk over State and national poltics, and fishing, with former President Hoover.

PARIS, May 16 (AP). -- French Socialists, led by the prospective Premier, Leon Blum, tonight scanned lists of Cabinet candidates in which the names of past government leaders were mentioned prominently.

Construction of low-priced homes under the terms of the Federal Housing Administration's insured single mortgage system will not destroy the market for more expensive houses or interfere with existing property values, according to W.D. Flanders, Deputy Federal Housing Administrator.

Voting trustees held the largest amount of common and preferred shares of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad in April, 1935, according to the company's report for last year to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The twenty largest stockholders, with their holdings, were:

TALK of the possible Republican Presidential nominee usually gets around to Arthur H. Vandenberg, junior Senator from Michigan. Whether the discussion starts with Governor Landon, Senator Botch, Colonel Knox or any of the other possibilities, some one is sure to ask: "What about Vandenberg?"

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 16. -- A new American college will be opened Oct. 1 in Mexico City, Dr. Adrienne C. Gobert, member of the faculty of Sarah Lawrence College, has announced. She is the founder of the new college, which will bear her name.

ALBANY, May 16 (AP). -- Albany defeated Baltimore, 2 to 1, in ten innings today when Jack Peerson singled to score Howard McFarland, who ran for Smead Jolley after the latter had doubled. Peerson's single was made off John Berly who replaced Bill Lohrman.

The Spring season of opera in the Metropolitan, conceived as an experiment to be judged by its practical results, has opened auspiciously. Two of the performances of the opening week had a vitality and interest far above past averages of performances of opera at popular prices, and have proved very appealing to big audiences.
PARIS, May 16. -- Socialists in Europe are planning a sports exhibition at Barcelona, Spain, this Summer. They hope it will rival the Olympic games in Berlin.
THE twenty-ninth Bethlehem (Pa.) Bach Festival will take place next Friday afternoon and evening, the 22d, and Saturday afternoon, the 23d, in Parker Memorial Chapel of Lehigh University.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Large crowds are expected here this week for the celebration of Holland Tulip Week in America which began yesterday and continues through May 24. On the shores of Sunset Lake, near the Boardwalk, has been set up a huge windmill, which is surrounded by acres of gayly tinted tulips, tended by maidens in typical Netherlands attire.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The Colony Tennis Tournament will be played on the Casino courts commencing Wednesday and continuing through Saturday. There will be men's and women's doubles, singles and mixed doubles.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- A special House investigating committee today recommended passage of legislation to regulate chain-store and other quantity buying.

LONDON, -- Two nations, Japan and Italy, have recently gone to war to obtain colonies; and a third, Germany, has made her demand for colonies one of the conditions of a European agreement for the maintenance of peace. All three support their claims to colonies by pointing to their lack of raw materials.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- Sea travel this year will be larger than in any year since the depression began, Charles Krebs, general passenger manager of the Gdynia America Line in New York, declared here today. He is visiting all the Pacific Coast offices and agents of the Gdynia America Line, for which the East Asiatic Company, Inc., is general agent on this coast.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- Conditions were somewhat spotty in the retail division last week on the Pacific Coast. A really brisk trade was reported in household goods of all kinds, including groceries, appliances and furniture. A few non-staple items were slower than a week ago, but still showing a margin of gain over figures of last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- Conditions were somewhat spotty in the retail division last week on the Pacific Coast. A really brisk trade was reported in household goods of all kinds, including groceries, appliances and furniture. A few non-staple items were slower than a week ago, but still showing a margin of gain over figures of last year.

IN the little old New York of 100 years ago, there met nine old-fashioned men. Five of them were laymen, four were ministers and all were equally serious in aspect. Solemnly they began their business with prayer, and with the same solemnity they separated when the business was over.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 16. -- An antique and decorative arts exhibition, containing treasures of three centuries valued at more than $2,000,000, was opened this afternoon at Ophir Hall, estate of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid. The exhibition will continue through May 31 and is for the benefit of the Westchester County Children's Association.

To push the new Hunter College building campaign, more than 300 alumnae at their annual Spring meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday unanimously adopted resolutions urging the erection of a building on Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, the site of the structure that burned in February.

JOHANNESBURG. -- The budget of the Union of South Africa reflects what is described as "the wave of prosperity upon which the country is still riding to the envy of the world." A financial year begun with a surplus of 705,000 ($3,750,000) has ended with a surplus of 3,000,000 ($14,820,000).

ITHACA, N.Y., May 16. -- Cornell's track team won its dual meet with Pennsylvania today by one of the greatest margins in this series, 104 to 31. The Ithacans broke two meet records in capturing thirteen of the fifteen events, scoring sweeps in four of them.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 16 (AP). -- Pinch-hitter Bill Baker's single in the ninth enabled Newark to tie the count and Roy Schalk's double in the eleventh scored Hershberger to beat Syracuse today, 3 to 2.

Opportunity for a full explanation and thorough discussion of the proposed new city charter will be presented at two gatherings this week in the city and in Brooklyn. Members of the Women's City Club, League of Women Voters and A.W.A. have joined forces for a mass meeting Wednesday night in the A.W.A. clubhouse at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.
SOUTHPORT, England, May 16. -- It has been left to two reserves in the recent Anglo-American Curtis Cup match to show their compatriots how to qualify for the women's British golf championship.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 16. -- Fordham defeated Army, 27 to 11, today in a heavy-hitting, loosely played game. Five thousand spectators watched the Rams bombard four pitchers, and saw the cadets put up a weird defense in the field.

Emergency relief in New Jersey has been cut to a subsistence dole over wide areas of the State since the municipalities took over the financing and administration of relief a month ago, when the State stopped supplying funds for relief purposes because the Legislature had failed to pass a revenue measure.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- The powerful Mercersburg team swept to its nineteenth championship in the fortieth annual Princeton University interscholastic track and field meet in Palmer Stadium today, registering 31 points to 22 1/2 for Hill, the runner-up.

MANILA. -- The Philippine Commonwealth Government has now completed six months of existence. Its balance sheet is still speculative to a degree, some things having been definitely accomplished and some problems having been raised for the future.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The social and economic consequences of the depression and droughts that plagued this country after 1929 may never be accurately measured. But a part of the story of the period can be pieced together from solid rows of figures recently issued by the Census Bureau in comparing population estimates of July 1, 1935, with the census of 1930.

Under the auspices of the School Nature League a garden tour of estates on Long Island will be held Tuesday. There will be opened to the public the gardens at Manor Hoarse, the estate of Mrs. John T. Pratt in Glen Cove, L.I., and the Tiffany Foundation in Oyster Bay.

Retailers reported good business last week, but in the wholesale markets here activity slowed down generally, with increased volume in only a few departments, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

WE had some notion that Irene Dunne could tell us a lot of show boat lore. Her grandfather used to build them on the Ohio River, and odd paragraphs here and there in the dossier of the actress with the voice that matches her golden hair, compiled by those earnest gentlemen who write such things for the cinema studios, indicated that a show boat audience had been Miss Dunne's first public.

THE "mail-order divorce" racket, as a phase of America's foreign relations, is on its way out. Solicitation of business for quick and easy "divorce mills" in foreign lands, or "giving information," or even "inviting inquiry" about how they operate, is likely to be made one of the more serious "misuse-of-the-mails" offenses before the present session of Congress breaks up.

THIS erratic season, which tarried behind schedule, has now come on with such a rush that it is upsetting the calculations of the managers of flower shows. The Tulip Show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, staged this year at the rooms of the Horticultural Society of New York, was originally announced for May 20 and May 21, but had to be put ahead to May 14 and 15.

MOSCOW, May 16 (AP). -- A new incident on the Manchukuoan border, Soviet advices said today, broke the quiet on the Far Eastern frontiers that Russia insisted on as a prerequisite to an investigation with Japan of boundary disputes.

The Metropolitan popular season last night offered the second presentation of Verdi's "Rigoletto." Like the first performance last Wednesday night, the cast was the same with the exception of two changes. Nicholas Massue, a French-Canadian tenor, made his initial bow to the large audience in the role of the duke.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 16. -- Miss Jean Russell of New York, representing the riders of the secondary school, today defeated the best of the college riders to win the championship class in the annual Marymount College horse show, the concluding feature of the undergraduate sports day activities.

The franc and other gold-bloc currencies weakened further yesterday, but dealings in the foreign exchanges were dull and quiet. The French currency fell to 6.59 1/8 cents and closed at 6.59 3-16 cents, off 9-16 point from the previous day but up 13-16 point from a week ago.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- A decision on whether to pass on the constitutionality of PWA loans for publicly owned hydroelectric projects was believed by some observers tonight to have been reached this afternoon by the Supreme Court.

TOMORROW in New York City one of the nation's most flourishing industries celebrates ten years of increasing prosperity. Dealers in steel and stocks may sigh nostalgically for the bustling days of 1926 as they thumb their reddened ledgers. But tomorrow's celebrators -- the purveyors of adult education -- can point to a clear 50 per cent gain in business during the generally disastrous decade.

One surge of the hitting power for which Professor Casey Stengel had been looking in vain for many days brought his Dodgers their first victory over the Pirates this season when, backed by the shutout pitching of Watson Clark, they won by 3 -- 0 at Ebbet's Field yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16. -- At the end of one of the keenest competitions of the week, Knight Flower, the brown mare owned by Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Fisher of Lexington, Ky., tonight carried off the rosette symbolic of the Traymore $1,000 five-gaited saddle horse championship.

PLANNING the tulip bed, in perspective at least, starts in the Spring, when the tulips are in the full glory of their bloom, and continues in the Summer, when the bulbs are chosen. Placing the bulbs in the ground, in early or mid October, is by no means the most important part of tulip culture.

MR. MOORE, who is vice president and provost of the University of California at Los Angeles, shows in this book a notable faculty for illuminating his subject and making it real and vital, so that the reader sees it as something intimately related to and connected with our own times and environment.

Although trading in stocks last week was the slowest of any week since that ended on June 3, 1935, prices were reasonably firm and closed higher. In bonds, the turnover in the listed market was the smallest since the week ended on Dec. 3, 1932, and new flotations continued far below the 1935 weekly average.

RICHMOND, Ind., May 16. -- An analysis of the actual record of the relations of nations with their colonies in the last century shows they have been expensive luxuries, Grover Clark of New York, consultant on Far Eastern affairs, said at the closing session of the Institute of Foreign Relations at Earlham College tonight.

Thirty-one British students comprise the eleventh annual contingent of Commonwealth Fund Fellows who have been selected by an English committee of award headed by Sir Walter H. Moberly, chairman of the University Grants Committee of the British Government.

Plans for New York City's 1939 World's Fair, which for seven months remained such stuff as dreams are made of, have at last acquired a firm legal and financial foundation. Spurred by developments, authorities are now perfecting the organization necessary to transform 981 acres of Flushing marshes and swamps into a glamorous international city costing $45,000,000 to build.

BALTIMORE, May 16. -- The 750 hospitals affiliated with the Catholic Hospital Association of the United States and Canada are expected to be represented at the convention of the organization here June 15 to 19. More than 600 nuns representing the various Catholic Sisters engaged in hospital work are expected.

Political organizations of both Republican and Democratic young women will hold social events this week to raise funds for their respective groups. Members of the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club will stage a "Republican Danceland" Friday evening at the Lombardy.

A letter went from Germany to Hawaii in five and one-half days. It crossed the Atlantic on the airship Hindenburg and traversed the United States and part of the Pacific by plane. The distance would be more than 8,000 miles, and this piece of air mail made it faster than SAMUEL ADAMS could manage a letter from Boston to New York, what time he was operating his Committees of Correspondence with designs against GEORGE III.

Some hikers (seventy-four of them) stepped down five inches from the curbstone on the northeast corner of Broadway and Sixty-fifth Street yesterday morning and then started the first leg of a 410-mile uphill climb to Dansville, N.Y. There were forty-eight men and twenty-six women.

NOW that we have all got our Summer frocks, or most of them, and have just about decided what we are going to do for our holidays, along come new hats from the ateliers of Paris and New York to give the fillip to our carefully selected clothes.

The purchase by Dr. Gordon Pollock of the town house at 114 East Fifty-fifth Street, near Park Avenue, for remodeling was announced yesterday. The property was sold by Robert C. Morris through Pease Elliman, Inc.
CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP). -- Hal Trosky, abetted by Earl Averill and Jimmy Gleeson, led the Indians in a barrage of eighteen hits today for a 10-to-3 triumph over the Red Sox.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan is being advanced by leading Michigan Republicans as a candidate for Vice President in case Governor Landon is nominated for President.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, May 16. -- Twenty - five thousand people i crowded into this border city toI day, in the greatest demonstration I ever seen on the lower Rio Grande, i to celebrate the return of ocean !commerce to a section that was a !thriving seaport eighty years ago.

Dr. Howard Lee McBain, former Ruggles Professor of Constitutional Law at Columbia University, left his entire estate, valued formally at "more than $10,000," to his widow, Mrs. Agnes Bartlett McBain of 39 Claremont Avenue, according to his will, which was fried for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 10 carried an article, "Housing: Federal or Local Task?" by Peter Grimm. In view of Mr. Grimm's past official position in Washington his remarks attract more consideration than ordinarily would be given to a recognized spokesman for real estate interests, which as a class has consistently opposed all public efforts to abolish slums.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Jules Henry, counselor of the French Embassy and now Charge d'Affaires, has been promoted to the rank of Minister, an official announcement from Paris to the embassy stated today.

AKRON, Ohio, May 16 (AP). -- Harry H. Woodring, Assistant Secretary of War, called anew tonight for a silencing of what he called subversive influences opposing adequate military and naval preparedness.

AT the American Artists School, 131 West Fourteenth Street, classes will continue through the Summer months with a modified schedule. Among the courses is a new type of class, recently organized, for practicing artists and students, held on Wednesday evenings.

THERE are more than 1,000,000 gunners in the United States -- small game hunters, big game hunters and target marksmen -- and a surprising number of them make their own guns. Or, if they do not make them in their entirety, they spend hours improving the work of the makers.

COMPLETELY eliminating the necessity for insulation at the base of radio towers, a "shunt-excited aerial" developed by the Bell Telephone Laboratories is heralded in radio circles as an engineering achievement of importance. It simplifies installation and reduces costs.

A comparison of two sailings during the last week reflected the relative unimportance of size as an indication of a ship's passenger carryings. The French liner Normandie, with a tonnage of 82,000 and a crew of about 1,350 sailed Tuesday with 828 passengers and the following day the Hapag Lloyd ship Hansa, of only 21,000 tons, sailed from a near-by pier with 842 passengers, and a crew of 417.

BERLIN, May 16. -- Stocks on the Boerse today closed the week at firm prices, fixed-interest securities also regaining their strength. Heavy industrials rose, Vereinigte Stahl gaining 1/2 point and Bruderus 2 points. Salzdetfurth rose 5 points and Westregeln 3 in the exceptionally strong potash list.

Quiet trading with minor irregularities in prices characterized the stock market yesterday. During the two-hour period the volume of business on the Stock Exchange amounted to only 370,000 shares, although 29,000 ahead of the Saturday before.

In settings characteristic of decorative art in Europe in the latter part of the seventeenth century, an elaborate party will be given on Tuesday night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis in behalf of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

PUNGENT savor of sea spray, roiling decks, the flap of canvas and the squeak of straining timbers are implied but scarcely mentioned in this diary of a harpooner on a New Bedford whaling vessel in the Eighteen Eighties. To Robert Ferguson, a well-disciplined young Scotsman, life was exciting for its adventures outside the usual, and if he found any romance in his hazardous calling he lets it speak for itself.
MADRID, May 15. -- Is Manuel Azana, who for the last five years has been active in Spanish politics, doomed to become a mere figurehead as President of the Spanish Republic?

WHEN the Spanish Armada was scattered by storm and the English seadogs of the sixteenth century, many of its galleons were left on the Scottish coast. Occasionally in the wreckage brought ashore were iron-banded strongboxes, which now rest in museums.
HOLLYWOOD. WHILE publicity departments are busy concocting glamour for the figures in the cinema's show windows, romance and adventure actually exist in many branches of the business.

THE time may come when man will have need of only a finger with which to press a button. Already much that contributes to civilized living is literally at our fingertips -- from telegraphy to chewing-gum, from the surging horsepower of giant dynamos to the thin trickle of current that can do our Monday wash.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP). -- A two-inning batting bombardment that drove Paul Dean to the showers today proved insufficient for the Bees as they went down to defeat, 7 -- 5, at the hands of the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals.

HARMON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 16. -- The New York Central Railroad's streamlined engine 6516, christened "The Mercury," its latest locomotion product built for high speed at a low operation cost, was demonstrated in the Harmon yards here yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- The red-tipped blades of Cornell, flashing a crimson streak across the last 100 yards of the Lake Carnegie course, today repelled the last despairing challenge of the Princeton boat, won the Carnegie Cup and completed with this flourish a sweep of its triangular regatta with Princeton and Yale.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The War Department Appropriation Bill, providing an unprecedented peacetime sum of $572,500,000 for military and non-military activities, was among a long list announced at the White House today as approved by President Roosevelt.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 16. -- The Ministry of Labor's projects for nationalization of insurance companies and the creation of a reinsurance bank, which were presented to President Getulio Vargas May 7, were more fully explained today.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- There were 6,385,740 persons eligible for Federal work relief jobs in January under stringent rules which made possible the hiring only of employables on relief rolls as of Nov. 1, 1935, the first classified census of eligible relief workers revealed today.

Capablanca never faced a gambit with greater deliberation than that exhibited by youthful contestants in the fourth annual Metropolitan Area Boys Checker Tournament yesterday at the Gramercy Boys Club for laurels in the 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14-year-old classes.

GORDONSVILLE, Va., May 16 (AP). -- A six-and-a-half-hour gun battle which ended late in the night left three persons dead today, one a county Sheriff and the others a 65-year-old Negro and his sister, whose blazing house became their funeral pyre.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 16 (AP). -- Seven men and boys died today when the new automobile in which they were riding crashed into the side of an Erie freight train at the West Austintown crossing. They had just left a wedding.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

The "Crazy Cruise," to be conducted by the Society of Stoopnocracy aboard the steamship State of Delaware on the night of June 4, will be featured by a varied and amusing program of entertainment in keeping with the society's motto of "Charity With Hilarity."

Residents of Gramercy Park objected to the strains of "The Sidewalks of New York" and other melodies as played on a hurdy-gurdy and caused the arrest of a hurdy-gurdy man and his brother, but Magistrate Peter A. Abeles in Yorkville Court, proved himself a sympathetic soul yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 16. -- Yale's golf team won the Eastern collegiate championship with a spectacular victory over Princeton's representatives on the Greenwich Country Club course today. Taking command of the situation with a 2-1 lead over the Tigers in the foursomes matches this morning, the Ells gained the honors for the year by a score of 5 to 4.

FOUR hundred new fish a year for each of the nation's 5,000,000 fishermen -- this is the goal which Federal and State conservation agencies have set to keep up with America's urge for fresh-water fishing.

DALLAS, May 16. -- Business in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District has moved ahead at the most lively pace noted since the week before Easter, and both retailers and wholesalers report merchandise moving readily. Retail sales for the week registered gains ranging from 8 to 15 per cent compared with the volume for the corresponding period last year.

"A French Book to Read All by Yourself" fills a need. The average language textbook is dull and uninviting in appearance, while the picture books made for French children are not always simple enough for the child who is just beginning to read in a foreign language.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 16. -- The Ministry of Labor's projects for nationalization of insurance companies and the creation of a reinsurance bank, which were presented to President Getulio Vargas May 7, were more fully explained today.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- There were 6,385,740 persons eligible for Federal work relief jobs in January under stringent rules which made possible the hiring only of employables on relief rolls as of Nov. 1, 1935, the first classified census of eligible relief workers revealed today.

Capablanca never faced a gambit with greater deliberation than that exhibited by youthful contestants in the fourth annual Metropolitan Area Boys Checker Tournament yesterday at the Gramercy Boys Club for laurels in the 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14-year-old classes.

GORDONSVILLE, Va., May 16 (AP). -- A six-and-a-half-hour gun battle which ended late in the night left three persons dead today, one a county Sheriff and the others a 65-year-old Negro and his sister, whose blazing house became their funeral pyre.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 16 (AP). -- Seven men and boys died today when the new automobile in which they were riding crashed into the side of an Erie freight train at the West Austintown crossing. They had just left a wedding.

THE time may come when man will have need of only a finger with which to press a button. Already much that contributes to civilized living is literally at our fingertips -- from telegraphy to chewing-gum, from the surging horsepower of giant dynamos to the thin trickle of current that can do our Monday wash.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP). -- A two-inning batting bombardment that drove Paul Dean to the showers today proved insufficient for the Bees as they went down to defeat, 7 -- 5, at the hands of the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals.

HARMON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 16. -- The New York Central Railroad's streamlined engine 6516, christened "The Mercury," its latest locomotion product built for high speed at a low operation cost, was demonstrated in the Harmon yards here yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- The red-tipped blades of Cornell, flashing a crimson streak across the last 100 yards of the Lake Carnegie course, today repelled the last despairing challenge of the Princeton boat, won the Carnegie Cup and completed with this flourish a sweep of its triangular regatta with Princeton and Yale.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Prices of live hogs last week were 20 to 50 cents a hundredweight lower than a week ago, with those weighing 260 to 300 pounds off the least. The top price for the week was $9.80, made on Thursday, and on Friday $9.60 was the best figure, although one small lot brought $9.65.

ROSAMOND LEHMANN is a master of dialogue, and no one writing today handles with more beauty and skill the details that give significance to the ordinary materials of life. "The Weather in the Streets" (Reynal Hitchcock, $2.50) is unquestionably her most distinguished achievement. It is an experience so profoundly felt, so movingly and sensitively told, that men and women everywhere will talk about it long after the last page is turned.
Investors continue to lead in the purchase of tenement properties in this city, according to deals of this type announced over the week-end. Some of the buildings acquired will be altered.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Plans for a thorough inquiry into the personnel of the American merchant marine, with a view to recommending legislation that will enhance the safety of American vessels, were announced today by Senator Copeland, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee.

ROUEN, France, May 17. -- In order to avert a likely demonstration of protest, the decision of the Vatican deposing Archbishop Andre DeBois de la Villerabel was not read in the Rouen Cathedral this morning as had been expected.

MOSCOW, May 17. -- A story of tyranny, terror and murder on an icebound Arctic island was unfolded here today at the opening session of the trial of I.D. Simenchuk, former chief of the Wrangel Island polar station, and S.P. Startseff, a subnormal young dog-sled driver, characterized as Simenchuk's dupe.

The Nazi press censorship, not content with instructing editors politically, or regarding what news is to be printed and what not, has taken over dramatic and musical criticism. The new order issued by Propaganda Minister GOEBBELS forbids the publication of any criticism of a new play until noon of the following day.

The second day of the four-day centennial celebration of Union Theological Seminary, which commenced Saturday night with a choral festival in the Riverside Church and will close Tuesday evening with the graduation exercises of the institution, opened yesterday morning with a service in the James Memorial Chapel, Broadway and 120th Street.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 17. -- Voicing their attitude on the tax and budget system of the Federal Government, the forty governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America and the 200 bankers gathered in Spring session in the Hotel Greenbrier adopted today resolutions urging upon the government a policy of curtailed expenditures, a balanced budget and an "honest" revenue act, assuring "adequate taxation on a broad base."

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 17 -- Nearly 900 persons visited today the model industrial homestead project which is being built near here under the direction of the Federal Resettlement Administration. The community is nearing completion, and it is expected that a number of the homesteaders will take occupancy about June 15.

Believers in the independence of the judiciary used to swear by the provision of the old Massachusetts Constitution that all judicial officers "shall "hold their offices during good be"havior, excepting such concerning "whom there is different provision "made in this Constitution: provided, "nevertheless, the Governor, with con"sent of the Council, may remove "them upon the address of both houses "of the Legislature."
Sheed Ward will publish G.K. Chesterton's "Autobiography" in September.

THERE were four men discussing the chances of the Boston Red Sox in the American League race, and then the one who knew more about horses than he did about ball players branched off into a tale of the turf. To take the words out of his mouth:

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 17. -Brookhaven, powerfully built Virginia-bred 7-year-old gelding belonging to Mrs. Samuel C. Register of Glen Cove and shown by John Maloney, was the outstanding performer as the third annual Oaks Hunt horse show was staged on the Rice Farm today.

LONDON, May 15. -- While it is no doubt true to say that Wall Street in the next few months will be swayed principally by domestic events, it probably cannot afford to ignore the possibility of currency upheavals and political events in Europe.

TOKYO, Monday, May 17. -- An important step toward Cabinet control of the army will be announced in an imperial order today. It decrees that the War and Navy Ministers must henceforth be chosen from generals or lieutenant generals and admirals or vice admirals on the active list.

LONDON, May 17. -- The British are struggling to make up their minds how to save Europe and themselves from war. For a nation that distrusts long-range planning and prefers to rely upon eleventh-hour promptings of intuition, this obligation to look ahead imposes an unaccustomed and painful ordeal.

The demand for all types of Summer apparel was active in the wholesale markets here last week. Cotton dresses continued to be heavily ordered, causing delayed deliveries in some instances. Sheer materials, such as dotted Swiss, dimitys and voiles, were among the most popular materials.

The second week of the trial of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and his alleged henchmen for compulsory prostitution before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a blue ribbon jury will get under way at 9:30 o'clock this morning.

BERLIN, May 16. -- A new ordinance has been issued with the purpose of facilitating German exports under the Aski special-account system. A special decree with the same aim for trading with Central and South America is impending.

The International Mercantile Marine Company and its wholly owned American subsidiaries sustained a loss of $1,370,824 last year as against a loss of $2,100,682 in 1934, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

National prosperity will be restored by a revival of world trade, Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, said in an address broadcast over WOR yesterday afternoon on the eve of New York City's celebration of Foreign Trade Week.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Asserting that the depression and the emergency activities of the Federal Government have served to strengthen the hold of the spoils system, the latest publication of the Public Affairs Committee, headed by Raymond Leslie Buell, urges a new drive to place government service on a career basis.

By this time it is quite evident that somebody in Washington will have to take this so-called Spring in hand. Let it be Mr. HOPKINS with WPA, or Mr. ICKES with PWA, or Professor TUGWELL with RRA, but this laissez-faire, cutthroat-and-laryngitis Maytime can't go on.

Overcoming a number of shortcomings, not the least of these being some more rather inept pitching by two members of our younger set, Al Smith and Clydell Castleman, the Giants overpowered Pie Traynor's Pirates before an admiring assemblage of 29,000 at the Polo Grounds yesterday to bag the opening clash of a three-game series by a score of 8 to 6.

Philatelists broke all international stamp show records in their attendance and activities at the Third International Philatelic Exhibition, which closed at 8 o'clock last night at Grand Central Palace, a check of the figures revealed.

DETROIT, May 17 (AP). -- The Tigers scored two runs off Ed Linke in the last of the ninth on a double, two walks and two outfield flies today to win the first of a series from Washington, 8 to 7. The victory sent the Tigers into a tie with the White Sox for fourth place in the American League.

NEWARK, N.J., May 17. -- The study of science has weakened the religious beliefs of the largest percentage of seniors of Newark College of Engineering who answered a recent questionnaire, the results of which were made public today.

A seven-foot pasteboard boat, laden with flowers, was launched in the middle of the Hudson River at 4:50 o'clock yesterday afternoon by members of the Mrs. Ella Bixby Tent 18 of the Daughters of Union Veterans of the Civil War.

A letter from Daniel F. Cohalan, former Supreme Court justice, urging that renomination be withheld from Governor Lehman by the Democratic party, was made public yesterday. Mr. Cohalan wrote to Postmaster General James A. Farley, head of the Democratic State Committee.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 17. -Mrs. Julius Bliss's aged Tupelo walked off with a major share of the honors today in the fourth annual Rockwood Hall Country Club horse show. The big chestnut gelding captured three first places and a third, topping them off by being judged the hunter champion.

A total of $1,825,403,600, or 34 per cent of the $5,345,449,590 of foreign dollar bonds outstanding on Dec. 31, last, was then in default either as to interest or sinking-fund payment or both, according to the second annual report of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., given out for today.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 17. -Three teams representing the home club carried off all of the honors in the Meadow Brook Club's annual invitation best-ball handicap golf tournament which was concluded today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- A glider wing buckled in midair above Pitcairn Field near here this afternoon, sending Thomas Condax, the 25-year-old pilot, plunging 1,000 feet to his death.

TRENTON, N.J., May 17. -Spaulding Frazer, dean of the Law School of the University of Newark, called upon the voters of New Jersey today to oppose the election of Governor Hoffman as a delegate-at-large to the Republican national convention, because of his reputed determination to replace Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf as Superintendent of the State Police Department.

The appeal of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for $1,500,000 to aid private welfare agencies in this city is being carried to 400,000 members of employe groups, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Ticknor 2d, chairman of the employes committee.

A plea for the election and appointment of public officials who will use their office to eliminate the "lasciviousness and immorality" of the burlesque stage and the night clubs was made in a talk yesterday by the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey.

NUREMBERG, Germany, May 17. -- The rapid strides being made toward Germany's self-sufficiency in agricultural products can scarcely escape the attention of any traveler through the Southern Provinces of the Reich in these days when Summer is still on the way.

LONDON, May 17. -- Among the vital issues of foreign policy to come before the specially summoned meeting of the British Cabinet tomorrow will be conversations with Germany on Chancellor Adolf Hitler's peace proposals.

JERUSALEM, May 17. -- In an effort to impress natives with the strength of the British Army, infantry troops, accompanied by tanks, marched through various parts of Palestine today. Machine guns were placed at every strategic point in Jerusalem. Not since the British occupation has the city been patrolled by such strong military forces.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,906,764,200. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest bearing discount bills.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 17. -High-goal polo stars, most of them Meadow Brook Club members, engaged in two matches in this vicinity today and in each instance the final result was an 8-all tie.

An appeal for intelligence and courtesy by policemen in carrying out their duties was made yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine at a memorial service for Jewish members of the department at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

CLEVELAND, May 17 (AP). -- The magazine Steel said today the heavier commitments for structural shapes, steel pipe, sheet and tin plate and increased pig iron shipments had imparted buoyancy to the steel markets. It added that there were prospects for a high rate of production during the Summer in many steel-consuming industries, particularly agricultural equipment and railroad car building.

Samuel Reshevsky, successor to Frank J. Marshall as chess champion of the United States by virtue of his triumph in the tournament concluded at the Hotel Astor Saturday night, received an invitation yesterday to take part in another tournament at San Juan, Puerto Rico, next month.

ABOARD THE ZEPPELIN HINDENBURG, en route America, May 17 (AP). -- The Hindenburg was struck by a heavy rainstorm from the northeast late today, but weathered it in steady fashion. More storms were expected.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- President Roosevelt was accused by Senator Hastings of Delaware tonight of superficial, confused economic thinking and of drawing the "weightiest conclusions" from limited, misleading points of view.

Thirty-five pickets, including four women, most of them striking service employes of the Polyclinic Hospital, were arrested yesterday when they attempted to stage a demonstration in front of 346 West Fifty-first Street, the rear entrance of the hospital.

An income statement of Stone Webster, Inc., for the twelve months ended on March 31 shows total income from subsidiaries of $636,724, compared with $588,485 for the preceding year, and total earnings of $969,568, against $824,422, including for the near-by period $69,434 profit on sales of securities.

Already far gone, the season sees four attractions -- perhaps more -- entering tonight on their final week. The Gilbert and Sullivan fiesta will wind up after a little more than six weeks at the Majestic with "Trial by Jury" and "H.M.S. Pinafore," a double bill which begins a repeat engagement tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A determined drive for adjournment of Congress by June 6, in keeping with the plan announced on Friday by Senator Robinson, is expected to start this week with presentation to the Senate of the $1,500,000,000 relief appropriation and the $800,000,000 Tax Bill.

ROUEN, France, May 17 (AP). -- The Foreign Office stepped into the quarrel of Archibishop Andre DuBois de la Villerabel and the Vatican today with the appointment by the government of an official investigator.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Africa, May 17 (London Times Dispatch). -- Reports from Addis Ababa show that since the Italian occupation more than 1,500 arrests have been made in the city by Italian military authorities. Most of these arrests were alleged to be connected with the looting that followed Emperor Haile Selassie's departure, but trials are summary and the evidence heard by the military tribunals is sketchy.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 17. -- Grant Hyde Code Jr. a 15-year-old high school student and an active member of the Boy Scouts in Brooklyn, was killed instantly here this morning while attempting to board a moving New York, New Haven Hartford train bound for New York City.

LONDON, May 17. -- Overtaken by the speed and completeness of the conquest of Ethiopia, Premier Benito Mussolini can only gradually put substance into his general plan to create a dominion for Italy in Africa on the model of British India.

ROME, May 17. -- A warm welcome was given here this afternoon to Premier Benito Mussolini's two sons, Vittorio and Bruno, and his son-in-law, Count Galeazzo Ciano, on their return after seven months of service with the air force in East Africa. They arrived by air, having flown in a large four-engined plane from Brindisi.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 17. -Services for the consecration of six Bishops were held this afternoon by the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

LONDON, May 17. -- George L. Steer, young South African correspondent of The Times of London and THE NEW YORK TIMES, and three other journalists in Addis Ababa -- Isadore Nebenzahl of the Havas News Agency, Alkeos Angelopoulos, Greek correspondent for Hearst newspapers, and L. de Robillard, French director of the Courrier d'Ethiopie, Ethiopian weekly -- have been expelled by Italian authorities, according to a Reuters dispatch from Addis Ababa.

Between midnight and 4 A.M. yesterday a driver for the Rand Cleaners and Dyers of Brooklyn and his Negro helper, both bound hand and foot, bounced on the floorboards of their enclosed truck as two hold-up men drove to fifteen of the Rand stores on a looting expedition.

Postmaster General Farley defended yesterday the ability of the government to cope with emergencies by the application of fundamental economic laws. He spoke at the forty-first annual memorial service of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Commodity futures generally ended moderately higher last week after considerable backing and filling. Silk, sugar and coffee lost ground slightly. In the cash markets cotton, wool tops, rye, Rio coffee, rubber and tins rose, while wheat, corn, oats, flour, lard, pork, butter, eggs, printcloths, antimony and silk eased.

NEW HAVEN, May 16. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81, which compares with 81.6 the week before, 82.2 two weeks before, 82.5 three weeks before and 82.6 four weeks before.
Mayor La Guardia will open the First National Exhibition of American Art tonight on the mezzanine floor of the International Building in Rockefeller Center.

BERLIN, May 16. -- With the exception of last Tuesday and Wednesday, which days witnessed profit-taking and resultant reactions, the stock market here was firm for the hole week. Heavy buying, part of which was done by foreigners with blocked marks, prevailed and a shortage of stocks caused precipitous rises, gains of 8 to 10 points occurring in favorite issues.

Casey Stengel's Dodgers had 17,000 fans laughing and cheering during the first act of their opening production with the Reds at Ebbets Field yesterday, but when the curtain was rung down in the ninth by the second snappy Cincinnati double play the spectators filed out with dark looks and grumbling words.

Based on registrations already received, upward of 1,500 members of the American Institute of Banking from all parts of the country will attend the institute's thirty-fourth annual convention in Seattle, Wash., from June 8 to 12, the American Bankers Association announced yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 17. -- Five thousand Italians jammed Convention Hall here this afternoon to witness the blessing and presentation of iron rings from Premier Mussolini to Rochester women who had sacrificed their gold wedding rings in order that Italy might have gold.

Consecrated more than seventy-nine years ago, the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, at Lexington Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, closed its doors with a solemn thanksgiving service yesterday at 4 P.M.
Sultry warm weather lured thousands from the city to the beaches and other resorts yesterday, but cooling sea breezes brought out a few lingering topcoats and made bathing an adventure.

The preliminary condensed annual report of the Associated Gas and Electric Company for 1935 shows operating revenues of subsidiaries amounting to $93,215,717, including properties only since dates of acquisition, compared with $83,973,089 for the previous year.

The report of the Missouri-Pacific Railroad for 1935, just issued, shows that one-half of the company's holdings of Texas Pacific Railway common stock, or 114,750 shares, is included in the collateral pledged with J.P. Morgan Co. for a $5,850,000 loan.
A deep purple neckerchief and a surprising frankness almost proved the undoing of a "Broadway sailor" last night, while a brief argument spoiled the evening of a New York contractor.

MEXICO, D.F., May 17. -- Only an eleventh-hour arrangement between the National Railways and the employes can now prevent a general strike over the entire railway system of Mexico. In the absence of an agreement a strike will interrupt all passenger and freight transport at 5 P.M. tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 17 -- Jose Luis Tejada Sorzano was overthrown as President of Bolivia early this morning by a bloodless military coup, which later in the day installed a Chaco War hero, Colonel David Toro, as Provisional President.

Christianity's answer to fascism and communism should not be mere criticism, but positive, militant Christian gospel and example, the Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

PITTSBURGH, May 17. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 70 per cent of capacity, down 1 point in the week and 2 points under the rate in the two preceding weeks, which was the highest since March, 1930.

With the spontaneity, earnestness of purpose and technical address of its singing, the Workmen's Circle Chorus delighted a sizable audience at its second concert of the season, given in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The chorus, consisting of more than 100 mixed voices, is composed of workers in factories, stores and offices, who sing for the sheer love of it and appear at rehearsal after their day's labor is done.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Uncertainty as to American monetary policies was responsible in part for a reduction in European short-term balances held in the United States early in the year, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly review of the financial situation.

LONDON, May 15. -- Imports of gold by Great Britain in April amounted to 17,956,000, compared with 37,491,900 in April, 1935, and in the first four months of this year to 52,808,000, compared with 87,044,000 in the same period of 1935.

VIENNA, May 17. -- Just as it seemed that the Austrian crisis would spend itself along the usual lines -- the fading out of the bitterest enmities through sheer inertia -new storm clouds appeared on the horizon.

A good bill that increases taxes is perhaps a contradiction in terms. But given the necessity for raising more revenue, together with the determination to get nearly all of it from the corporations, and the outline of a tax bill as now put forward by spokesmen for the Senate Finance Committee is a surprisingly sound one.
Taking advantage of a four-goal handicap, the Governors Island poloists turned back Blind Brook Polo Club quartet in the weekly contest at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The London naval treaty, which was approved by the Foreign Relations Committee last week and is expected to be approved by the Senate this week, was said by Senator Walsh of Massachusetts in a statement today to be disappointing in that it is a recession from the expiring naval limitation pacts, inasmuch as it provides for only qualitative and not for quantitative limitations.

CLEVELAND, May 17. -- The S.R.O. pennant flew over League Park today, as the biggest Cleveland crowd of the year, and one of the largest in recent years, saw the Yankees come from behind to triumph after spotting the Indians four runs.

One of the questions arising out of the relief situation in New Jersey is whether a large number of persons who did not deserve relief were carried on the State ERA rolls before that organization turned relief administration over to the municipal authorities on April 15, or whether the municipalities, in reducing relief rolls and expenditures since that date, have refused adequate aid to persons sorely in need of it.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 17. -Delegates to the convention of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs left today for their homes, with the majority satisfied that abandonment of a Presidential preferential poll had put the association in line with the State party organization, leaders of which are opposed to a commitment to any candidate before the national convention.
A recent dispatch from Washington regarding the population growth of the various States in 1930-35, the second paragraph of which began as follows:

The Armenian Church of the Holy Cross was consecrated yesterday morning by Archbishop Karekin Hovsepian, special representative of the Catholicus, head of the Armenian Church. The church was the scene of the murder of Archbishop Tourian, who was killed by factionalists who opposed his policies as he officiated at services on Dec. 24, 1934.

A mammoth concert was given by Leopold Stokowski and the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Madison Square Garden as the climax and end of an 11,000-mile tour in which this leader and his devoted band have dispensed music to audiences as far away as those of the Western Coast.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., May 17. -F. Paul Anderson, thrice winner of the New Jersey amateur golf championship, and Dr. Robert R. Lauckner Jr. of Canoe Brook today dethroned Mike Cestone and Pat Mucci of Branch Brook as the State amateur best-ball champions.

The regimental standard that has been carried since 1920 at all official ceremonies of the 107th Infantry (Seventh Regiment), New York National Guard, was presented to St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, yesterday at the annual church parade of the regiment.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 17. -- A Phi Beta Kappa key has again been voted by Princeton University seniors as more desirable than a varsity athletic letter, it was announced today by Richard O. Jones of Wichita, Kan., chairman of The Nassau Herald, senior class yearbook, which has conducted the annual questionnaire.

The engagement of Rosa Tentoni, young American soprano, and Sydney Rayner, American tenor, for the current Spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Unless the joint conference between the major railroads and the twenty-one standard railway unions strikes unforeseen obstacles, an agreement covering the method of compensating employes displaced by consolidations will probably be completed within twenty-four hours, it was reported tonight.
Faces crowded the windows overlooking oval Seward Park yesterday and fire escapes were heavy with youngsters as the neighborhood helped celebrate the homecoming festival of the Grand Street Boys.

LONDON, May 15. -- One striking effect of the flight of capital from the franc is the return of confidence in sterling. This is finding expression in many ways, but one of the most interesting, as well as perhaps the most unwelcome, of the manifestations is the increasing hoarding of British currency notes in France.

NEW ORLEANS, May 17. -- The cotton market here, after ruling rather quiet most of last week, developed a fair degree of activity as a result of favorable advices from Washington concerning the Smith bill, which it is understood would limit the liquidation of government-controlled cotton to 750,000 bales a year.

The ancient sports of hurling and Gaelic football still are best demonstrated by the Irish from the Irish Free State.
