While a crowd of 40,000 roared approval at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, the champion Limerick hurlers and the champion Cavan footballers downed selected New York teams of transplanted Celts and did it in very convincing fashion.

While Catholics sleep, communistic zeal is lighting torches intended to burn Rome, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared yesterday at high mass. He exhorted the faithful to awaken to the "real danger" that confronts them.

LONDON, May 15. -Except for pronounced activity in a few highly specialized issues which for particular reasons have been having considerable speculative support, the stock markets are having an unusually quiet period. International politics, currency difficulties and dangers abroad have been exerting a widespread influence upon financial and business circles.

According to PLATO, one of the descriptions which SOCRATES gave of his own functions in public life was that of a gadfly. He went around irritating people so as to make them think, and to reconsider their arguments and perhaps alter their convictions or prejudices.

While detectives continued their search for the ex-convict identified in connection with the murder of Edgar Eckert, assistant treasurer of the Rogers Feet Company, members of the police pickpocket squad rounded up seven men in subway and elevated stations early yesterday.

DALLAS, Texas, May 17. -- John G. Hardin, 81, philanthropist, whose first Texas home was an earth dugout on the Red River and whose $5,000,000 fortune grew from a seedling 127-acre plot that cost him $127, is spending his last years giving all his money away.

PARIS, May 16. -- Declarations by Leon Blum, the incoming Premier, with the object of reassuring public opinion, have achieved their end. Tension, with the advent of his pronouncements, immediately relaxed on the foreign exchange market.

The West Side Association of Commerce announced yesterday its opposition to the use of the Marginal Way on West Street for approach and exit ramps for the proposed vehicular tunnel between Manhattan and Brooklyn.

MANILA, May 17 (AP). -- Six lepers terrorized residents of Palawan and small neighboring islands today after having killed four fishermen and having escaped from their colony at Culion Island by stealing a boat.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The American Federation of Labor, in its monthly survey of business, declared today that workers are failing to share equitably in business gains and buying power is lagging in the recovery trend.

NEWARK, N.J., May 17. -- Newark and Albany divided a double-header today before 18,000 fans, the largest crowd at Ruppert Stadium in five years. The Bears won the first game, 9 to 6, and Albany captured the abbreviated nightcap, 6 to 5.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP). -- The Cardinals defeated the Phillies, 10 to 3, today, Dizzy Dean holding the Phils to six hits.
WARDHA, India, May 17 (AP). -- "My lifework is ruined," Mahatma Gandhi said today in discussing, in his retreat here, the results of the recent Lucknow Nationalist Congress.

The wardens and vestry of St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Stret, in an announcement made public yesterday revealed that the resignation of Dr. Karl Reiland, rector of the church for twenty-four years, had been accepted.

BERLIN, May 16. -- Swayed by international influences and renewed talk of devaluation of the mark, the stock market this week again was strong, with quotations on industrial shares reaching heights which, according to the banks, are in no way justified by the financial status and earning potentialities of the corporations.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 17. -- In the presence of a gallery that crowded many deep about the ropes of the huge ring on the lawns of the Seawane Club today, that noble specimen of the Russian wolfhound, Champion Vigow of Romanoff, won the title of best in show at the thirty-fifth annual exhibition of the Long Island Kennel Club.
CHICAGO, May 17 (AP). -- Home runs by Bill Werber and Rick Ferrell gave the Red Sox an 8-to-7 victory and their fourth triumph this year over the White Sox today in the opener of the series.

Traffic-court congestion would be alleviated, and autoists would become better trained in the fundamental rules of the road, were the Police Commissioner to issue the "traffic warning cards" required by Section 42a of Chapter 24, Article 3, of the New York City Code of Ordinances (approved May 31, 1922).

Officials of the Federal, State and city governments and leaders in banking and allied fields of business and in organized charity and philanthropic work attended the funeral service yesterday for Arthur Lehman, banker and brother of Governor Lehman, at Temple l Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-i fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A charge that Federal funds, "principally from New Deal agencies," were being used to finance "a Democratic publicity campaign of unprecedented magnitude" was made today by Henry P. Fletcher, Chairman of the Republican National Committee.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Last week was full of surprises for traders in grains, especially in wheat. At times the market showed fair activity; at others it was dull. The week's range for wheat on the Board of Trade was only 2 to 3 cents a bushel, and the finish was 3/8 to 1 1/3 cents net lower than the week before, the latter on July.

Accusing the 1936 Legislature of "an infamous lack of consideration for the taxpayers of the City of New York," William Church Osborn, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, called upon civic organizations and individuals yesterday to urge Governor Lehman to veto bills which would, if signed, add $36,700,000 to the city's budget for 1937.

CHICAGO, May 17. -Reports from the oats crop are the most promising in several years, but litfie interest has been taken in the cash or speculative markets. Prices are extremely low and most of theI trading in futures on the Board of l Trade is in the way of getting out of the May and into the more deferred deliveries.

AMSTERDAM, May 16. -- French political developments are regarded here with great uneasiness, there being little confidence in Leon Blum's ability to shake off the extreme Left influence which aims at a free spending policy. The financial situation in France is held to be extremely critical and it is fully expected that pressure against the franc will be resumed along with the growing fear that devaluation of the franc, in the long run, is unavoidable.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 17. -The women's British golf championship, in which match play opens tomorrow, is expected to be one of the finest Britain versus the United States sporting contests in years. Representatives of other nations were eliminated in the thirty-sixhole medal play preliminary which was concluded yesterday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 17. -Bolivian Army officers and civilian members of the Socialist party took over the country's government today in a bloodless, shotless coup, forcing President Jose Luis Tejada Sorzano to resign.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP). -- The battered Browns returned to the victory column for the second time in the last nineteen games by hammering an 8-to-5 triumph over the Athletics today in a series-opener before 4,100 fans.
PARIS, May 17 (AP). -- The British holders of the Davis Cup lost to France's Davis Cup players today, but it was only in fun.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 17. -Two ocean-racing yachts, Commodore R.J. Schaefer's Edlu, which won the last sail to Bermuda, and Philip Le Boutillier's Stormy Weather, which captured the transatlantic contest to Norway and the Fastnet race last year, had a tenmile set-to around Long Island Sound today in the special regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Edlu won by 6 minutes 35 seconds.

The sixtieth anniversary of the establishment of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, and the founding of the ethical culture movement as a whole, was observed yesterday morning with special services in the Meeting House of the society, Central Park West at Sixty-fourth Street.

A mysterious biplane answering the description of a machine sought by the customs authorities for smuggling, landed yesterday at Holmes Airport. When a policeman tried to question its unidentified pilot after a chase on foot all around the field, the flier shoved him away, took off and flew toward New England.

The first festival under the auspices of the American Music League was held yesterday at the Yorkville Casino. There were programs in the afternoon and evening with varied vocal and instrumental ensembles taking part. The audiences were large and enthusiastic.

Deaths of all causes in New York City during the first nineteen weeks of the year showed an increase of 1,938 over the same period of 1935. The figures, made public yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, also showed an increase during the nineteen weeks of 615 pneumonia deaths.
HOLLYWOOD, May 17 (AP). -- Film-land was told tonight to allay any fears that television would burst unexpectedly on an unprepared motion-picture industry.

ALBANY, May 17. -- Industrial Commissioner Andrews today released preliminary figures resulting from a survey of all persons registered as job applicants in the adult public employment offices in New York State in February, 1936. These figures reveal significant statistics covering the occupational classification, industrial background, age, sex, color and veteran i status of a large section of the unemployed in the State.

Straw votes taken at various points in the metropolitan area and on the campuses of Yale, Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania indicate the popularity of Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas over all other contenders for the Republican nomination, it was announced yesterday at the Landon-for-President headquarters in the Murray Hill Hotel.

Twelve hundred children will take part in the Catholic schools' music contest festival to be held under the auspices of the Music Education League tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock, in Town Hall. This will be the first time that the Catholic schools of the archdiocese of New York have participated in the music contests of the league.
A Tibetan pageant, "The Devil Dance of Tibet," has been arranged by members of the Junior Museum of the Newark Museum and will be performed on Saturday afternoon at 3 o'clock in the museum garden.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- The Townsend old-age pension plan caravan, which left Los Angeles thirteen days ago with three truck loads of petitions, completed its transcontinental journey today, halting at noon before the Grant Memorial at the foot of Capitol Hill.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 17. -- Many new houses are being added to the North Shore Summer colonies of Glen Cove, the Westburys and Oyster Bay this season, and members of society are leasing and renovating some of the older places in preparation for what apparently will be an active social period.

There seemed to be every indication that the elementary and high schools of the New York area are turning out a generation of learned scientists when the Museum of Natural History opened its Education Hall to the public yesterday for the first day of the eighth annual Children's Science Fair, under the auspices of the American Institute of New York.

United States cotton in all hands in the United States at the end of April was approximately 7,804,000 bales, compared with 9,027,000 on April 30 of last year and 9,850,000 at the close of April two years ago, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

JERUSALEM, May 17. -- A curfew order, forbidding residents of Jerusalem to leave their homes at night, was issued today by Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, the High Commissioner of Palestine, following the killing of three Jews last night at a motion-picture theatre.

The first of a series of pageants to be staged this season by the Folk Festival Council in cooperation with the Department of Parks was held yesterday afternoon on the Long Meadow of Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Ten thousand persons watched the dancers in a program that began at 2 P.M. and lasted until sundown.

Prices of cotton futures continued to show an upward trend last week. On Saturday quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange had advanced 2 to 13 points. The largest gains were in the new-crop months.

According to a bulletin of the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game, location of the best natural pheasant ranges has been discovered to correspond almost invariably with the degree of soil fertility prevailing in various sections.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- A peculiar situation exists in the corn market here. Supplies at the leading markets are the smallest in years. The movement from the country is small, and farmers are busy planting for the coming harvest. The speculative interest is not large, and traders and commission houses which have been long of futures for some time took advantage last week of all hard spots to unload.
Edwin Goodman, Fifth Avenue merchant who opened his first shop on Fifth Avenue nearly thirty-five years ago, is to be guest of honor at a testimonial dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow evening.
With mid-May reached, the number of exhibitions in the local galleries remains at a score or more for the week, with several unusual shows on the calendar.

A week-long celebration in memory of the late Will Rogers will be held in motion picture theatres throughout the nation, beginning next Friday, when the Will Rogers Memorial Hospital at Saranac Lake also will be dedicated to the aid of the ill and needy of the stage and screen.

Last week's foreign exchange market was notable for the hasty covering of "shorts" in the French franc predicated on the statement of Leon Blum, Leftist leader, of "resolute hostility" to devaluation of the franc.

MEXICO, D.F., May 17. -- Mexico's Olympic polo squad gained its third successive victory today over the United States Army team from the Eighth Corps Area by a score of 5 to 4. Play was slow, due to the heavy condition of the field following a heavy rain. The game was halted on one occasion when the ball was lost in the mud.

Among those spidery creatures who "their own web from their own entrails spin" set down the State Milk Control Director. Mr. FEE'S job is to "supervise and regulate the entire milk industry of New York State." It has been made a public utility of sorts, operating under a license system.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Commerce Department officials said tonight they believed the mysterious plane that eluded pursuit after a hasty take-off from Holmes Airport, New York, today was one sought by Federal authorities since last February.

The Knights Templar of the New York area held their ninth annual memorial services yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. More than 1,800 Knights in full regalia of colorful uniforms, plumed hats and swords, attended.

Three major agencies spent $2,061,720 in the six months from Oct. 1, 1935, to April 1, 1936, to aid the settlement in Palestine of Jews from Germany, Poland and other lands, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal.

A series of chain dinners to aid in the re-election of President Roosevelt will be started tonight, with a thousand or more separate dinners planned in New York City, it was announced yesterday by the National Women's Pro-Roosevelt League, with headquarters at 21 East Seventy-sixth Street.

Permit me in the interest of historical accuracy to take exception to the "Racial Clash" type of headline with which you caption the news from Palestine. Were there no Jews in Palestine, or had their numbers not been materially increased since 1919, the situation in that country would have been much what it is, with perhaps the Christian Arabs serving as the casus belli.

MADRID, May 17. -- Twelve Catholic colleges and parochial schools must be closed within ten days, according to a decree of Francisco Barnes, the new Education Minister, that appeared today in the Official Gazette.
The call for the city-wide barber strike, issued by the International Barbers Union, is to go into effect this morning. The union expects the strike to close 10,000 shops.

FORTESCUE, N.J., May 17. -- One man lost his life and twenty-seven were rescued today when the S.K. Parks, a Chesapeake buckeye schooner on a fishing cruise, sank in Delaware Bay off Egg Island Point, two miles off the Jersey shore.

Prime Minister BALDWIN'S speech on the present status of the League of Nations, and on what ought to be done to improve it, was that of a blunt-spoken and honest man with little imagination. He did not attempt to conceal British disappointment with the failure of the League to prevent or stop the war in Ethiopia.

The Order of St. Sebastian, awarded by the Catholic War Veterans, Inc., has been conferred by the national officers of the organization to eight prominent Catholics, including former Governor Alfred E. Smith, it was announced yesterday.

OCEAN GATE, N.J., May 17. -The Thomas A. Mathis Republican Club held its final rally of the primary campaign at the Borough Hall here last night. The program was long, the hall warm and smoke-filled. In the kitchen annex in the rear of the hall Allan Rains broached a second keg.

Mr. Roosevelt's panacea of platitudes at the Jefferson dinner following his gesture of generalities at Baltimore and coupled with his ineffective attempt to pass the buck for unemployment to industry has served to focus the spotlight of a bipartisan, tax-conscious public upon the technical inadequacy and futile failure of New Deal policies.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 17. -- Washington's offer of Puerto Rican independence already is costing American manufacturers millions of dollars through canceled or postponed purchases. The announcement that no action would be taken on the Tydings Independence Bill at this session of Congress is not sufficient to provide assurances for other than current commitments, business men contend.

JERUSALEM, May 18. -- The drastic curfew regulations in Jerusalem were tightened today after violence continued with the slaying of a Christian immigrant from Austria. The government ordered the start of the curfew hour every evening at 7 o'clock instead of 8 o'clock, the Palcor Agency reported.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- A charge that leaders of the Town-send plan movement for $200-a-month pensions for the aged had resorted to "false promotional hokum" in an effort to bolster declining revenues from membership dues and hold in line their followers was made today by Chairman Bell of the House committee which is investigating the movement.

SHAKESPEARE must have been at the gate of the Elysian fields to welcome the faithful pupil who for more than fifty years took his plays to the people. Over England and the United States he strolled with his strollers, bringing those deathless characters, more alive than living men. BEN GREET'S Players; BEN GREET with the Pastoral Plays: for how many millions did they recreate that world of imagination all compact.
Mayor La Guardia opened the First National Exhibition of American Art last night on the mezzanine floor of the International Building in Rockefeller Center.

Calling for the spread of "discriminatory thinking," Morse A. Cartwright, director of the American Association for Adult Education, declared yesterday that with the return to economic "normalcy" it was the business of adult education to unmask the "symbols" of the extreme right proponents, as well as those of the Communist and Fascist left.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP). -- Dr. C.H. Watson, president of the National Safety Council, citing their records of no deaths of passengers and decreases in employes' casualties in 1935, placed the railroads in the van of the safety movement tonight.

Strength in new crop deliveries under the lead of October featured trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended unchanged to 6 points higher than on Saturday. An easier tone developed in Liverpool, but absence of rain in eastern sections of the Cotton Belt where moisture is reported needed attracted buying to an extent that carried October above 10 1/2 cents a pound.

Dissolution of the Stock Exchange firm of Arnold Co. and the formation of a new firm with the same name was announced yesterday. The new firm consists of seven of the ten partners in the old firm. They are Roy W. Arnold, Maurice Goodman, Norman J. Jewel, member of the Exchange; Giuseppe Russo and Benjamin H. Arnold; Samuel Strasbourger and Benjamin F. Goodman, special partners.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- An agreement by the United States to make substantial purchases of silver from China has been reached in a series of conferences between representatives of the two governments, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today.

The first national Dance Congress and Festival to be held in this country got under way yesterday at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Theatre of the Y.M.H.A. at Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street with an organizational meeting in the late afternoon and a joint performance by nine dancers in the evening.
LONDON, May 18. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today took the almost unprecedented step of publicly arraigning a foreign embassy in London from the floor of the House of Commons.

LONDON, May 18.--Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin had one of the unhappiest days of his Premiership today when, on top of his troubles over foreign affairs, he was forced to yield to clamor from all parts of the House of Commons and withdraw the important new Coal Mines Bill which he had hoped would have been passed by evening.

Prices on the commodity markets were mixed in quiet trading yesterday. In the cash market, corn, rye, printcloths and wool tops were higher, while wheat, oats, butter, eggs, tins, silk and rubber were lower.

Coming back in the fine form that made him one of the top flight 3-year-olds last year, Elwood Sachsenmaier's Roman Soldier easily won the Salvadere Handicap at six furlongs, feature at Belmont Park yesterday. This son of Cohort carried top weight of 126 pounds and defeated the fleet Miss Merriment by two lengths, while the latter had a length to spare over Kievex.

ORANGE, N.J., May 18. -- "The Secret Circle and Master Minds," a very secret and vandalistic society of students of Orange High School, has been checked by the suspension of five ringleaders, it was learned here today.

As its answer to the Supreme Court's invalidation of the Guffey Act, the American trade-union movement should immediately start "a labor party for the election of a Congress committed to a constitutional amendment" revoking the court's power to rule Congressional legislation unconstitutional, said Louis Waldman yesterday.

On the final stage of a world cruise covering more than 33,000 miles with calls at twenty-six ports, the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain docked early yesterday at West Nineteenth Street with 370 passengers. Some of the cruise passengers had debarked in California ports and 173 were landed here, leaving the rest to continue to Southampton when the liner sails today.

Many prominent women as well as debutantes of this and recent seasons are taking an active interest in the arrangements for the card party in behalf of the memorial and patriotic program sponsored through Roosevelt House by the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association, this afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
ATTICA, Kan., May 18. -- The address off Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas here tonight to the graduating class of the Attica High School was as follows:

WOODMERE, L.I., May 18. -- Mrs. Herman S. Murray, chairman of the flower show committee of the Lawrence Garden Club, announced today the winners of the annual tulip show held at the home of Mrs. Ethelbert I. Low in Noyes Lane here.

The twelve agencies which placed the largest volume of business with members of the Associated Business Papers were yesterday awarded certificates of recognition by the New York Dotted Line Club, the salesmen's organization of the association, at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--The Supreme Court ruled the Guffey Coal Act unconstitutional in a 6-to-3 decision and held that Secretary Wallace and the Grain Futures Commission were without authority to deprive Arthur Cutten, wheat speculator, of trading privileges on national commodity Exchanges.

In declaring the Guffey Coal Act unconstitutional, the Supreme Court has pronounced judgment on a law which from the very outset was clouded by grave legal doubts. This was the measure concerning which the President said, when he urged Congress to enact it, that there were "not ten but a thousand different legal opinions" on the question of Federal regulation of the bituminous coal industry.

HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., May 18. -- Top-water angling for weakfish in Peconic Bay began in earnest yesterday. Between seventy-five and 100 charter boats sailed from New Suffolk, Greenport, Shinnecock Canal and other ports. Weather conditions were favorable, although in the afternoon a brisk southwest wind kicked up a heavy chop.

MOSCOW, May 18. -- A changing attitude toward criminal suspects, who in the past have been generally assumed to be guilty and convicted on the flimsiest evidence, was shown in a rebuke by the newspaper Izvestia today for the wrongful sentencing of a group of alleged speculators here last Fall.

The American Adult Education Association was organized ten years ago, but though it was founded with no prospect of the coming of a period which would demand extension of education into the upper ranges of age, it may now be said that it was for such a time as this that it was created.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--The defeat of the Guffey Act in the Supreme Court today leaves the score against the government in New Deal cases at 8 to 2. Out of ten New Deal lawsuits decided by the court, the government has won only in the TVA and gold clause cases. The record is as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- Delegates from twenty-two States were warned today that the $384,000,000 Flood Control Bill may be lost in the Senate tomorrow if a provision for local payments toward flood works meets strong opposition.
BOSTON, May 18 (AP). -- The Bees' most persistent nemesis, Tex Carleton, Chicago hurler, enjoyed his usual success today and the Cubs' 7-2 victory put them into a third-place tie with the Pirates.

A gang of carpenters, engaged in erecting a scaffolding around the Criminal Courts Building to strengthen the structure, ignored a command of General Sessions Judge Cornelius F. Collins yesterday to desist, so that the jurors could hear testimony in a trial before him.

Servel, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on April 30 a net profit of $1,381,581 after depreciation, bond interest, Federal taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock the profit is equal to 77 cents each on 1,781,426 shares of $1-par common stock which were outstanding at the close of the company's fiscal year on Oct. 31 last.

The Spring drive of the Health and Police Departments against un-muzzled or unleashed dogs on the city streets brought 284 persons into seven magistrates' courts yesterday. The offenders, summoned by the police and health inspectors, were in most cases fined $1.

Use of the retirement system to rid the schools of incompetent teachers was advocated yesterday by Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, Fusion member of the Board of Education and chairman of the Teachers Retirement Board.
ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, May 18. -- Representative Marion Zioncheck, Democrat, of Washington, who is here with his bride, has given Virgin Islanders something to think about.
ATTICA, Kan., May 18. -- In this town of 700 inhabitants on the Kansas plains, Governor Landon tonight addressed simple words of courage and hope to the youth of America and their elders.

Harry Sherman, 42 years old, who said he lived at the Hotel Wellington in Seventh Avenue, was indicted yesterday by the regular New York County grand jury in the alleged theft of $150,961.75 of the funds of Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union of Greater New York, of which he was president until July, 1934.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Supreme Court's decision on the Guffey Coal Control Law is likely, according to observers of political trends, to be a large factor in the November polling in Pennsylvania, Illinois and West Virginia.

Colonel John C. Robinson, Negro aviator, who was one of the trusted lieutenants of Emperor Haile Selassie before and during the Italian invasion, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. His work of thirteen months in Ethiopia ended by the collapse of the Negus's forces, the 31-year-old flier has returned to become an instructor in aviation at Tuskegee Institute, where he formerly went to college.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- An investigation of charges by various Eastern railroads that three railroad subsidiaries of the Pittsburgh Coal Company were engaging in unlawful practices was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- Research looking to the forecasting of weather two weeks in advance was described today by President Roosevelt as "worth pursuing."
A counterpart of the practical Patsy Grazzianni and his Washington Square hot-dog cafeteria on wheels is Esquipula Martinez, the self-styled Spanish "hamburger king of New Mexico."

BARTOW, Fla., May 18. -- The defense rested today in the first of the Tampa flogging trials after presenting only four witnesses. These challenged the testimony of Eugene F. Poulnot, one of the three flogging victims.

A nation headed in the direction of economic self-containment is also pointed toward State socialism, Henry F. Grady, chief of the division of trade agreements, United States Department of State, warned foreign traders yesterday at the Export-Import Day luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

William B. Leeds, sportsman and son of the late "tin-plate king," plans within ten days to marry Miss Olive Hamilton, in whose rescue from drowning he aided six years ago at Atlantic City. A radio message received yesterday from his yacht, Mona, now at Kingston, Jamaica, revealed his plans to marry.

A price war which liquor men estimated cost local retailers well over $100,000 in a week-end of competitive price slashing appeared to have expired here yesterday. Except for a few stores in the downtown section which were still selling goods below usual prices, most retailers were getting a normal return for their merchandise.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., May 18 (AP). -- The first dead heat in New England horse racing occurred today at Narragansett Park when the judges, despite the use of the electrical photographs, were unable to choose between Mrs. E. E. Russell's Sun Apollo and the Carr brothers' Steelhead in the sixth race at a mile and seventy yards.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 18. -- Mrs. Wait Talcott was hostess to the Great Barrington Garden Club this afternoon at Rollaway Hill, North Egremont. The Rev. Edward Russell Bourne presided, and Miss Doris Brigham of Williamsburg, Mass., discussed "wall gardens."

Union Theological Seminary will confer degrees upon ninety-three graduates tonight at the exercises which will close the seminary's centennial program. The graduating ceremony will follow the alumni meetings during the day.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- The possibility of damage to the Jones Beach State Park as a result of the proposed construction of a jetty across Jones Inlet was raised today at a hearing before the Board of Engineers for rivers and harbors.
Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania glowered yesterday as he heard a woman manager of disorderly houses name him as the man she had been told stood behind the organized vice racket in this city.

Under the pressure of continued flight of capital the franc and other gold-bloc currencies fell further yesterday. The French currency declined to 6.58 7-16 cents, or within 1-16 point of the effective gold-shipping price, and closed at 6.58 1/2 cents, off 11-16 point. Guilders dropped 2 points to 67.59 cents and Swiss francs were off 2 points to 32.35 cents.

For half an hour early this morning about 400 Negroes, rioting on Lenox Avenue between 127th and 133d Streets, in Harlem, after a street meeting of sympathizers with Ethiopia in her struggle against the Italian invasion, battled 110 policemen quickly mobilized in the area.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania arrives today from channel ports. Her passengers include Captain Sir Ian Fraser, a member of the council of the National Institute for the Blind and vice chairman of the British Wireless for the Blind, and Dr. Ernest Whitfield, treasurer of the National Institute for the Blind, who are coming here to study the manufacture of talking books by the American Foundation for the Blind.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 18. -- Patriotism that serves as the cloak for human greed in maintaining high tariff barriers and fomenting a spirit of nationalism among the peoples of the world was denounced tonight at the joint fellowship meeting of Northern and Southern Baptists at the municipal auditorium.

Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, who was one of the defendants in the $5,000,000 suit brought by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, against former directors of the State Title and Mortgage Company for alleged waste of the assets of the company, has paid $30,000 to settle the claim against him.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., May 18. -- Winning by 4 to 1 from Pomonok in its final match, the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club won the women's Long Island interclub Class A team championship in the competition which ended today at the Wheatley Hills golf course.

Augustus J. Lukeman, who succeeded Gutzon Borglum as the sculptor of the Confederate Memorial on Stone Mountain, near Atlanta, Ga., left an estate appraised yesterday at $38,609 when he died on April 3, 1935, but debts and expenses reduced the net estate to $6,887.

Charles Redfield Vose, insurance broker of New York and Litchfield, Conn., was accused before Supreme Court Justice Cotillo and a jury yesterday tricking a second wife into an illegal marriage when the trial of a $250,000 damage suit brought by Mrs. Valerie Huff Vose began.

Forty-three crested Maypoles set on the undulating turf of the Long Meadow in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, attracted 4,500 school girls yesterday afternoon to the largest of the four borough fetes under the sponsorship of the Public Schools Athletic League, 157 East Sixty-seventh Street.
GENEVA, May 18. -- The United States will send a delegation of twenty to the twentieth International Labor Organization conference opening here June 4.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The text of the dissenting minority opinion in the Guffey Act decision was as follows:
NEWARK, May 18. -- Harry Matuzak, rookie right-hander, shut out the Bears with seven hits today, Albany taking the third game of the series by a score of 1 to 0.

BERLIN, May 18. -- The Boerse was decidedly stronger today with an evidently suppressed tendency toward a larger turnover. Heavy industrial shares opened mixed but closed firm near Saturday's levels. Mannesmann lost 1/3 point. Electrical stocks made some advances; utilities rose, silesia gaining 1 1/4; potashes were firm again, Aschesleben gaining 1 7/8 points on a small turnover.

Confronted by the largest group of photographers to greet her here in recent years, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody smilingly stood her ground yesterday at the Grand Central Art Galleries as reporters attempted to get a definite statement as to her plans for the tennis season.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- On the ground that the interstate price-fixing provisions for bituminous coal in the Guffey act were inextricably linked with the wages-and-hours regulations, which were declared to be an invasion of States' rights, a majority of five members of the Supreme Court today threw out the entire act, reserving judgment meanwhile on the validity of price-fixing.

CAMBERRA, Australia, May 18. -- Defense Minister Robert A. Parkhill said today that British aircraft makers would not establish branch factories in Australia so local capital was needed to manufacture airplanes here. Only British machines would be utilized for defense, he stressed, but added that nothing would hinder any manufacturer from establishing an aircraft factory here.

Clutching her gold medal tightly, 15-year-old Dorothy Mischel, winner of the city-wide essay contest conducted in public schools by America's Good-Will Union, stood on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets yesterday and advanced a few theories about attaining and maintaining peace.
There is no comfort for the Flat-bush fans in the news from the front. Yesterday the Dodgers again outhit the Reds, 13 to 11, but, as in the opening contest, were outscored, this time by 9 to 6.

ROUEN, France, May 18 (AP). -- The canons of the Rouen Cathedral, apparently rallying behind Archbishop Andre Debois de la Villerabel in his dispute with the Vatican, served notice on Mgr. Bertin today that they would leave the Joan of Arc services on May 24 if he attempted to take a place in the canons' stall.

Anthony Merlino, fifth vice president of the Journeymen Barbers International Union, predicted last night that 8,000 journeymen barbers would leave their shops this morning in the Times Square area, the upper sections of Broadway and Washington Heights.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- It was during a few hours spent in Chicago while he was en route from the East to his home in Palo Alto, Calif., that former President Hoover issued his answers to questions submitted to him by the press.

RICHMOND, Va., May 18. -- Retirement of all the 7 per cent prior preferred stock of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation held in the company's treasury as an investment and reduction of the corporation's capital liabilities from $35,935,101 to $21,448,001 were approved by stockholders at an adjourned special meeting here today.

The expected has happened in Ethiopia, and without loss of time. Brigandage has broken out in MUSSOLINI'S new dependency, and the native brigands are being shot down in batches. Brigandage always breaks out when a country is overrun by a foreign invader.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP). -- The Cardinals rallied in the seventh and ninth innings today to score seven runs and make it two straight over the Phillies. The score was 11 to 6.

ST. ALBANS, L.I., May 18. -- Steve O'Donnell, veteran steeplechase rider, and Walter Scheiber, former Metropolitan P.G.A. champion, the first pair to finish, left a 67 for the rest of the field to shoot at in the Long Island Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament today at the St. Albans Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Condition of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on May 13 shows a decrease for the week of $77,000,000 in total loans and investments, increases of $79,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $12,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and a decrease of $20,000,000 in time deposits.

Dock Commissioner John McKenzie informed the steamship companies yesterday that any company willing to accept independent taxicabs and fleet cars without discrimination could get a license permitting cabs on municipally owned piers, used by it.
The New York Stock Exchange's committee on stock list yesterday authorized the listing of the following securities:

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on a motion made by Charles M. Travis, attorney for the Associated Gas and Electric Company, for dismissal of reorganization proceedings entered against the company in 1934.
DETROIT, May 18 (AP). -- The Tigers took their second straight game from Washington today, defeating the Senators, 7 to 1, behind the five-hit pitching of General Alvin Crowder.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Congressional comment on the Guffey decision ranged from expressions of gratification, largely from Republicans, to proposals for immediate substitute legislation.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Indiana Natural Gas and Oil Company and its public-utility subsidiary, the Kokomo Gas and Fuel Company, were granted exemption from the holding-company provi sions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which found that both operate entirely within the State of Indiana.

When Mrs. Helen Wills Moody had a pre-view of her first exhibition of paintings yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Art Galleries, she had the pleasure of seeing pasted on two of the frames small green labels marked "Sold."

Jamaica scored one run in the seventh after the bases had been loaded to top Flushing High, 3 -- 2, in a Queens P.S.A.L. tussle at Jamaica Stadium yesterday. The victory was the eighth in nine tournament games for Jamaica, and it served to tighten its grasp on the league lead.

More than three-quarters of the $403,000 sought for pensions for its retired professors as a part of the centennial celebration of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, has been raised by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the seminary, and his co-workers.

Use of water meters in all five boroughs as a means of distributing water charges equitably to all users was declared to be the best method of determining what each user should pay by John E. Eastmond, Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, in an address yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn.

Strength in United States Government loans was the feature in an otherwise routine trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The Federal issues were readily responsive to a demand which carried eleven of the twenty-one long-term obligations to new high levels since their dates of issue.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 18. -- Professor J.H. Baxter, representing the Walker trust, who has been making excavations behind the mosque of Sultan Ahmed, is now engaged in uncovering a new area of mosaic, which is a continuation of the Byzantine floor found last year and is similar to it in character.

C.C.N.Y. came through with some timely hitting yesterday in its meeting with St. John's of Brooklyn to rout the visitors, 13 to 7, and bring to a successful close the Beavers' home stand at Lewisohn Stadium. Fourteen safe blows bounded off the winning bats, Joe Coppo being the victim of the onslaught.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- Commission men dealing in livestock at the Chicago Union Stockyards lost today in the Supreme Court in their effort to collect rates higher than those authorized by Secretary Wallace.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- The price of wheat dipped around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today on scattered selling induced by further moisture in parts of the Southwest and weakness in Liverpool. Closing trades were well toward the top, with May 1/8 cent higher, July 1/4 cent lower and September 1/4 cent higher.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Mrs. William Howard Taft, widow of President Taft, said through her secretary today that she had been greatly annoyed by the publication of an alleged interview with her in Charleston, S.C., several weeks ago.

LONDON, May 18. -- The growing tension in Palestine is being viewed so seriously in London that the Cabinet decided today to appoint a royal commission to investigate Arab and Jewish grievances on the spot.

Under the price-differential provisions of the Robinson-Patman bill, the small distributor will not be able to buy at as low a price as the mass distributor, nor will the latter be barred from obtaining the benefits of savings from quantity purchases, according to the results of a survey made by Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co., accountants and auditors, for the Institute of Distribution, 570 Seventh Avenue, and issued yesterday.

BERLIN, May 18. -- Parallel with the preparation of the German answers to the British questionnaire on the political implications of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's peace proposals, the German Government and business organizations are engaged in a study of Germany's economic demands to be put forward if the third and final period of international negotiations provided in the German peace plan of March 31 is reached.
With the political future of Governor Harold G. Hoffman dependent upon the result of today's primary election in New Jersey, the outlook last night was for a heavy Republican vote.

Producers of bituminous coal said yesterday that the Supreme Court's decision invalidating the Guffey Coal Act had averted rigid government control and "regimentation" of their industry. Just as industry in general welcomed the passing of the NRA a year ago, the producers said, so did the bituminous operators hail the invalidation of the "little NRA," as the Guffey act was called.

VATICAN CITY, May 18 (AP). -- Pope Pius will make two of his oldest friends Cardinals at a secret consistory that he called today for June 15. The secret consistory will be followed by a public one on June 18, when red hats will be bestowed upon the Cardinals-elect.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 18. -- Many champions were toppled to defeat in the first round of the women's British golf championship today, but there are five study Americans left from the Curtis Cup squad of eight to carry the Stars and Stripes in the second round tomorrow.

DETROIT, May 18. -- Former Governor William A. Comstock, who announced a few weeks ago that he had "taken a vacation" from the Democratic party, changed his decision today, and said he would return to the ranks as a "disturber." He declared that if Chairman Farley tried to force a Murphy-Couzens ticket for Governor and Senator on Michigan Democrats he would stir up a primary fight against the ticket by the old-line Democrats.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Extremely light receipts of hogs here today, with a fair shipping demand lifted prices 5 to 10 cents as compared with Friday, the top being up 5 cents at $9.65 a hundredweight, while the day's average of $9.30 also showed a gain of 5 cents.

Curtailed by warm weather that has withered some of the choicest blooms, a two-day tulip arrangement show was opened yesterday in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center. Sixteen of the twenty-two cultural classes originally entered in the competition had to be canceled because the flowers had bloomed and begun to wither nine days ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, MAY 18. -- Organized labor, viewing the Guffey law decision, was discouraged with the possibility of obtaining redress of grievances by law and indicated that a sharper struggle in the economic field was the only recourse left to win its demands for recognition of collective bargaining and the right to form and maintain trade unions.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Some striking sections from the opinions by Justice Sutherland, Chief Justice Hughes and Justice. Cardozo in the Guffey Coal Act decision follow:

The ball club which only a brief ten days ago was careening all over the West and threatening at any moment to sink outright with all on board hung up its eighth victory in a row yesterday as Colonel Bill Terry's astonishing Giants flattened the Pirates for the second successive afternoon at the Polo Grounds.

PARIS, May 18. -- Leon Blum, the Premier-designate, returned to Paris this evening after a few days' rest in the country and immediately there began anew the game of guessing how he will form his Cabinet and what his foreign and financial policies will be.

CLEVELAND, May 18. -- The importance of educating the investor against the risks inherent in the securities markets was stressed today by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and by James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

One of the last public acts of Lord ALLENBY was to pay homage to the memory of Colonel T.E. LAWRENCE ("LAWRENCE of Arabia") by taking the chairmanship of the committee formed to provide a bust of LAWRENCE for a niche in St. Paul's Cathedral and to strike a medal in his honor.

William M. Duncan, president and chairman of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway, received last year $25,000 salary and $480 other compensation, according to the company's report to the Interstate Commerce Commission, made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The majority opinion of the Supreme Court invalidating the Bituminous Coal Conservation Act follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 18. -- Bishop Francis J. McConnell, a liberal leader of the Methodist Episcopal Church, was returned to the Hew York area for a third term of four years by the committee on Episcopacy today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes told a Senate appropriations subcommittee today that "a way out" of the Public Works Administration's financial position might be found in the expansion of the $250,000,000 PWA revolving fund and the relaxation of statutes governing its operation.
CHICAGO, May 18. -- Lefty Grove won a bitter pitching duel from Vernon Kennedy today for his fourth shutout of the season and his seventh victory as the Red Sox outpointed the White Sox, 2 to 0.

Princess Mabel Hohenlohe-Schillingsfurst of 435 East Fifty-second Street was revealed yesterday as one of the victims of the daylight hold-up of the jewelry store of N. Miller, 743 Fifth Avenue, last July 29 when robbers escaped with $100,000 worth of jewelry, including a necklace said to have belonged once to Queen Marie Antoinette.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 18, -- On the eve of the final ceremonies of the 124th annual commencement of Princeton Theological Seminary, the board of trustees late today held their annual meeting and elected a new president.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP). -- Former President Hoover in a statement issued here today regarding the Republican Presidential campaign said: "It should be evident by this time that I am not a candidate."

LONDON, May 18. -- The Italians arrested a warrant officer named Bonner, attached to a British ambulance unit in Ethiopia as he was being rushed to Aden for treatment after having been bitten by a dog, it was learned here tonight.

LONDON, May 18. -- Colonial Secretary J.H. Thomas, who never missed "a good thing" if he could help it, bet 1,000 in May, 1935, that there would be a general election in Britain before the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Following the philosophy that half a loaf is better than no bread, the Senate ratified the London naval treaty, signed less than two months ago, without a dissenting vote today. Debate on the measure, limited principally to faint praise by its backers, took less than two hours.

MOSCOW, May 18. -- Another mysterious death on Wrangel Island came to light at today's session of the trial of I.D. Simenchuk, ousted director of the island's scientific station, on charges of murder, cruelty and inefficiency. This death, which occurred after the alleged murder of Dr. W.R. Wulfson, was that of the wife of S.P. Startseff, the dogsled driver who is accused of killing Dr. Wulfson at Simenchuk's instigation.

Monday at 1:30 P.M. I was coming west from Grand Central and at the corner of Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street, while the traffic light showed green, a policeman permitted six empty cabs to make a right turn, followed by a bus going north on Madison Avenue.

A brief advance of stock market leaders began yesterday when the tickers reported beginning of the reading of the Guffey Act decision by the Supreme Court, but, with traders doubtless mindful of other costly attempts to "ride the news," virtually no following developed, and less than thirty minutes later most of the active stocks had returned below the points whence the rally had started.
The attack of former Judge Daniel F. Cohalan on Governor Lehman was characterized yesterday by Louis Boehm, counsel for the legislative committee on guaranteed mortgages, as ludicrous and amazing.

Three young women, described as telephone operators in midtown hotels, were among the persons questioned yesterday by Assistant District Attorney John J. Sullivan in connection with the case of A. Henry Ross, attorney, and Max D. Krone, a private detective.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 18. -- Against the opposition of the Charter League, the local newspaper and civic groups, the City Council of New Rochelle amended the City Manager Charter tonight to eliminate the nonpartisan election provision.
Recognizing a growing bicycle consciousness on the part of the public, the Park Department announced yesterday plans for the construction of five new bicycle paths in city parks.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The text of Chief Justice Hughes's opinion in the Guffey Act decision, which concurred in part with the majority but also criticized some of its finding, was as follows:

LOUISVILLE, May 18 (AP). -- W. J. Armstrong gave Louisville's amateur riders a lesson in horsemanship as he scored a decisive victory astride Keene Daingerfield's Glint in the third revival of the Gentleman's Cup race at Churchill Downs today.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 18 (AP). -- Miss Berg faces the most formidable opponent of any of the Americans tomorrow morning in the second round of the women's British championship. The Minneapolis youngster will engage Miss Elsie Corlett, runner-up in the English closed tournament last year.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 18. -- Assets of the receivership estate of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., which once had a potential value of $300,000,000, were sold at public auction here today for $4,039,367 and were bought in by Robert G. Starr, New York attorney, for the corporation's reorganization committee.
The Bible was the first book called for yesterday morning when the Bryant Park Open Air Reading Room of the New York Public Library opened for the second Summer.

PITTSBURGH, May 18. -- Conflicting opinions greeted the Supreme Court decision outlawing the Guffey Coal Control Act today, not only as between operators and labor leaders, but among the operators themselves.

Seventeen holders of college and university degrees are numbered among the 224 probationary patrolmen who will be graduated from the Police Academy at exercises at noon today at City Hall. Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine will address the men before they go to take their places in the regular force.
The attack on painless childbirth by members of the medical association meeting in Kansas City calls for some comment by laywomen.

A faint-hearted rally lasted for a brief span of a quarter hour on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon, touched off when news tickers reported that Justice Sutherland had begun reading the decision on the Guffey Coal Act, and in another fifteen minutes quotations of the leaders returned to or below their starting points.
JERUSALEM, May 18. -- Two more deaths were added today to the toll in Arab-Jewish disturbances in Palestine.

Plans for an early reception today of the Hindenburg were abandoned yesterday when wireless dispatches via Radiomarine and Mackay Radio told of a zigzag course and a fight with headwinds. At 4 P.M. the airship was about 1,300 miles east of New York along the 41st parallel.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- A compromise plan for direct Federal subsidies for American vessels engaged in foreign commerce was offered in the Senate today by Senators Copeland, Guffey and Gibson to replace the present ocean mail contracts. These three have kept the question deadlocked in the Senate throughout the session by their conflicting views.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Samuel B. Hill, a representative from Washington State for thirteen years and ranking member of the House Ways and Means Committee, was appointed by President Roosevelt today to be a member of the Board of Tax Appeals for a twelve-year term beginning June 2.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 18. -- Panzer College closed its baseball season with a victory over its traditional rival, Upsala, at Viking Field, today, 8 -- 6. Weinstein hurled the entire game for the winners but Larson of Upsala gave way in the ninth to Schade.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Informal but authoritative word reached the Capitol today that President Roosevelt would insist that Congress pass at this session a tax bill producing the full measure of revenue outlined in his message of March 3 if it required all Summer.

The committee for $40,000,000 of New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway (Gulf Coast Lines) first mortgage bonds and $2,354,000 of 5 per cent income bonds issued yesterday a statement condemning the treatment for these securities proposed in the Van Sweringen plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

An angry crowd of 200 stoned two Internal Revenue agents shortly after 2 P.M. yesterday in the Italian quarter of South Brooklyn, forcing them to retreat into a building they had raided and to barricade themselves until rescued by the police.

PORTLAND, Me., May 18 (AP) --Delegates to the annual congress of the National Society, Sons of the American Revolution, were told today by the president general of the organization that it must fight for an unchanged Federal Constitution.

Federal, State and city authorities in this country and the Royal Mounted in Canada had joined yesterday in the search for the mysterious biplane which landed on Sunday at Holmes Airport and immediately took off again.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- In a divided opinion the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today ruled as unconstitutional the provisions of the Federal Emergency Appropriations Act of 1935 which set up the Resettlement Administration.

PARIS, May 18 (AP). -- Fred Perry and H.W. (Bunny) Austin, Britain's Davis Cup tennis aces, triumphed in doubles today, but France won the annual three-day team matches between the two nations, 16 to 12.

Four followers of Father Divine, Harlem evangelist, are scheduled to appear in magistrate's court Thursday afternoon to answer charges of failing to carry workmen's compensation insurance to cover their employes. Assistant Attorney General Patrick Hughes will represent the Division of Workmen's Compensation of the State Department of Labor, the complainant.

ROCHESTER, May 18. -- A special committee of five editors to study possibilities of a research bureau to analyze all State legislation affecting the press and local government was named today by Clarence T. Leighton, editor of The Oswego Palladium Times and president of the State Society of Newspaper Editors, at its annual meeting here.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Because the Grain Futures Act of 1922 is written in the present and not the past tense, the Supreme Court today defeated the attempt of Secretary Wallace to bar Arthur W. Cutten from trading on the grain markets.

I have a game that I play all by myself. I call it "Find the Light." I assure you it is a nerve-racking sport by daylight or Neon light. Driving any place in New York, excepting Park Avenue, is no job for a nervous person, which I am not.
Aldo Spoldi, Italian lightweight battler, registered a knockout victory over Lou Camps of the Bronx in a scheduled eight-round feature bout before 2,500 fans at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Supreme Court Justice John L. Walsh handed down a decision yesterday in favor of a group of officials of the Firemen's, Oilers and Watertenders Union of the Atlantic and Gulf who had been sued by members on the ground that the union Constitution had been altered illegally.
LONDON, May 18 (AP). -- Two hundred women of high society, including several Anglo-Americans, attended tonight Queen Charlotte's Hospital Ball, the largest event of its kind in the world.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 18. -- The American army of invasion was intact when the first day of the match play stage of the women's British golf championship began, but it is so no longer. What is more, the greatest of the overseas players, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, whom the most perfervid of British patriots would have been glad to see win, was beaten.

BOSTON, May 18. -- Unless the Legislature at its current session enacts a law to retire elderly judges at full pay, Governor Curley will submit an initiative petition to the voters on this issue at the November election.

Theatrical history last evening recorded a new milestone in the combined careers of Walter Hampden and "Cyrano de Bergerac" at the New Amsterdam Theatre. On and off they have been associated since 1923. Before a comfortably filled house the actor-manager gave his 1,000th performance (not consecutive) in the title role.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Bids were opened by the Treasury today for two series of Treasury bills to be dated May 20, 1936, on which an aggregate amount of $100,000,000 was asked and $302,065,000 was applied for. Of this, $100,005,000 was accepted. Details of the two series follow:

ROME, May 18. -- League of Nations sanctions entered their seventh month today, and the Italian press seized the occasion to protest once more against the keeping in existence of measures that it regards as no longer serving any useful purpose and as damaging the economies of all countries.

When he did not comply quickly with an order to give up a $1,214 payroll, David M. Siegel, 38-year-old treasurer of the Williamsburg Knitting Mills, Inc., 20 Bogart Street, Brooklyn, was shot dead shortly after 2 P.M. yesterday by a trembling hold-up man.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 18. -- A three-day festival of American music opened today at the Westminster Choir School in Princeton, at which first performances of twenty-two unpublished works of music by contemporary American composers will be given.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., May 18. -- Byron Nelson, holder of the State open golf championship, was the individual star today in the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament at the Branch Brook Golf Club.
As if to prove itself superior to hot spells, late Spring, the early rural theatre or Life, the local drama this evening will offer two items:

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The joint conference of railroad managers and chiefs of the twenty-one standard railway unions completed a tentative draft of an agreement covering the method of compensating employes displaced by consolidation at a session which ended at 5:30 A.M. today after having begun at 9 A.M. yesterday.
BERLIN, May 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of May 15 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

LONDON, May 18. -- A remarkable account of the manufacture of evidence implicating British firms in the supply of illegal ammunition to Ethiopian forces was included in a statement by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons at question time today.

BOSTON, May 18. -- A threatened "wholesale liquidation" of out-of-date Sunday schools, growing cynicism of youth, invasions of freedom of conscience at home and abroad, and proposed revision of the aims and structure of Unitarianism were questions placed before the convention of the American Unitarian Association and meetings of allied societies here today.

LONDON, May 18.--The Stock Exchange opened the new twenty-one-day account quietly today with prices irregular in most departments. British Government issues were dull, partly owing to a disappointing response to the new Sheffield loan.

BERLIN, May 18. -- Publication of the periodical Judenkenner (Observer of Jews), organ of the Anti-Jewish World Alliance, has been discontinued until after the Olympic Games. The Journal has been published in several languages, it is devoted to spreading anti-Semitism throughout the world and to the creation of a world-wide "front against the Jew wherever he may be found."

An exhibition of Irish industries, including whiskies, linens, hams and tweeds, will be opened this afternoon in the first-class saloon of the California of the Anchor Line at Pier 95, West Fifty-seventh Street. It will be open to the public until a little before noon Saturday when the ship sails again for Dublin.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The death of still another New Deal law at the hands of the Supreme Court was witnessed today by one of the largest crowds that have thronged the magnificent new chamber since the present historic term started, in October.

Why did the Young Republicans of this State in convention at Jamestown feel it necessary to write a party platform? They had two days of organization and oratory. Most of the speeches had to do with questions of leadership and of reform in the management of the Republican party in New York.

Fresh northerly breezes, probably preceded by thunder showers, are expected to dissipate the sweltering heat that hung over New York yesterday, according to the forecaster of the Weather Bureau. At 4:30 P.M. yesterday the mercury rose to 86, one degree short of the record for May 18, set in 1903.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

A local branch of the American Public Health Association was organized last night by New York City members of the national organization meeting in the offices of the Department of Health, 125 Worth Street.

Public offering of $4,350,000 of State of Louisiana highway 41/4, 4 1/2. and 5 per cent bonds will be made today by a banking group composed of the Chase National Bank, the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, Blyth Co., Inc.; the First Boston Corporation, the National Bank of Commerce of New Orleans, Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., and Bacon, Stevenson Co.

The Ludlum Steel Company has offered to Hiland G. Batcheller, president, a contract for five years under which, in return for his exclusive services as general manager, he would receive an annual salary of $48,000 and 600 shares of the company's common stock, to be deliverable to him at the end of each year.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- A reciprocal trade treaty with Finland, the sixteenth to be concluded by the Roosevelt administration under the Trade Agreements Act of 1934, was signed today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Eero Jaarnefelt, the Finnish Minister.

LONDON, May 18. -- Kirsten Flagstad, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, repeated her New York triumphs here tonight in her Covent Garden debut in "Tristan und Isolde," with Fritz Reiner conducting.

MADRID, May 18. -- Sixty-two commissioned and non-commissioned officers of two crack cavalry regiments stationed at Alcala de Hinares, just outside Madrid, were arrested today on charges of insubordination. The War Ministry refused to discuss the matter and censorship suppressed it completely in the press here.

MEXICO, D.F., May 18. -- A general strike of 50,000 workers on the entire system of the National Railways of Mexico became effective at 5 P.M., when Mexican and Red flags were raised over all stations and offices. All entrances to the stations were barred and covered with flags.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey left the dais in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center last night during a dinner to mark the opening of the National Exhibition of American Art, just long enough to deliver a telling blow to the chin of a reporter whose remarks he resented.
MOSCOW, May 18. -- The Soviet chess champion, M. Botwinnik, took the lead today in the international masters tournament when he defeated I. Kan in the fifth round after 41 moves.

Adoption of a "model civil service reform plank," designed to end the spoils system, in the platforms of both the Democratic and Republican parties was urged yesterday by the National Civil Service Reform League. Copies of the proposed plank were sent to Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, and Henry P. Fletcher, Republican National Chairman, by H. Eliot Kaplan, executive director of the league.
The Hardware Club, one of the oldest of lower Manhattan's luncheon organizations, will close its doors on Friday after forty-two years in the same quarters it occupied when organized in 1894.

The winner of the tenth annual high school examination on the League of Nations was announced yesterday as Miss Louise Booth Morley, 17 years old, daughter of Christopher Morley, author and columnist, a student at Hunter College High School. Miss Morley's prize will be a trip to Europe this Summer, including a visit to Geneva and a study there of the League at first hand. Students from 1,248 high schools competed.

Eight persons, including an Assistant District Attorney and a police detective, were indicted in Brooklyn yesterday for conspiring to hamper law enforcement agencies in connection with the Drukman murder case. The indictment, which charges a misdemeanor, also named ten other persons as conspirators, but these were not indicted.
The Prix de Rome in painting was awarded yesterday to Matthew William Boyhan, 20 years old, of 45 Pine Crest Road, Newton Centre, Mass., who competed for the award with forty other young artists.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP). -- Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, lauded the administration's foreign trade program tonight as an economic and social boon and assailed economic nationalism as dangerous.
CAMP NO. 3, MT. EVEREST, Tibet, May 18 (by Wireless via Calcutta). -- P. Wyn Harris and E.G. H. Kempson, with forty-six porters, have made a most successful carry to Camp No. 4, on the North Col.

Testimony by an alleged robber that the police tortured him so badly that he had to undergo a skin-grafting operation resulted yesterday in the acquittal of the prisoner by a jury before County Judge Algeron I. Nova, in Brooklyn.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 19. -- Declaring that a "rapprochement between Britain and Russia would create a major obstacle to Japan's continental policy," the newspaper Nichi Nichi publishes today an outline of the instructions Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita ha given Shigeru Yoshida, Ambassador designate to London.

Mayor La Guardia agreed yesterday to receive a committee of five striking seamen at City Hall and hear their charges of police brutality in the handling of picket lines last week in front of the Chelsea piers of the International Mercantile Marine Company, in Eleventh Avenue.
Comment of the nation's press this morning on the Supreme Court decision invalidating the Guffey Coal Act is generally that of approval. Excerpts from editorials in leading newspapers follow:

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 18. -- Gustavo Ross, Minister of Finance, soon is to return here from London, and, it is understood, will make a special effort to expedite liquidation of the Chilean foreign debt in the United States.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Charles (Chuck) Kocsis and his Michigan mates marched over the Kildeer Coountry Club course today within striking distance of their fifth consecutive Western Conference individual and team golf championships.

THE Giants were in their Polo Grounds coop peeking at the Pirates in batting practice. Even Harry Danning was in uniform. He dresses for baseball every day, although he isn't allowed to play on account of his injured hand that is plastered and taped into what looks like half a snowshoe or one of those long handbaskets used by jai alai players in rapping the ball about the walls of the fronton.

ATTICA, Kan., May 18. -- Prairie farmers for fifty miles around poured into Attica tonight to join its 769 citizens at a high school graduation turned into a national event by the broadcast address of Governor Landon.

The decision on the Guffey act means a saving of $7,000,000 to $10,000,000 annually to the railroads, the Association of American Railroads estimates. Upholding of the act would have meant higher prices for fuel for locomotives.

Children at the age of 10 and 11 develop an extreme dislike to many of the commercial radio programs presented to attract their interest and some of these programs have a "bad effect" upon them, according to a report of the Parent-Teachers Association of the Lincoln School of Columbia University, made public yesterday.

Fifty policemen armed with machine guns and pistols chased two bandits through the maze of a Jersey City railroad freight yard for almost two hours yesterday afternoon. Eventually they captured one suspect in the dark hold of a barge at a neighboring pier, where he put up a savage fight before being subdued.

"MISSIONARY of thrift, stabilizer of society, defender of the integrity of the home, protector of widows and orphans, and harbinger of prosperity, happiness and love." * * * The object of this affecting eloquence was the life insurance agent; the year was 1929.

To this season, which has heard much of the renascence of poetry on our stage, the Federal Theatre Project last night added "The Dance of Death," by that rebellious young Englishman, W.H. Auden. At that pleasant house in Fifty-fourth Street, the Adelphi, the project's poetry unit has joined the several arts of music, dance and acting in theatrical wedlock and made of them a charade at once fluent, bright and irritating.

John Fiorenza, 24-year-old upholsterer's helper, sat impassive yesterday in General Sessions Court before Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. as a jury was chosen to try him for the murder on April 10 of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, writer, in her apartment at 22 Beekman Place.

The Communist party will put before the national convention of the Socialist party in Cleveland next week a formal proposal for a joint Presidential ticket, Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communists, announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 19. -- Compulsory military training, teachers' oath and flag salute laws and vast expenditures by the Federal Government for increasing the size of the army and navy were denounced by the Rev. Dr. Luther Wesley Smith of Syracuse, N.Y., today at the joint fellowship meeting of Northern and Southern Baptists.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Congress received a new proposal to solve the unemployment problem today when Representative Sirovich of New York offered a resolution for a ten-man. Congressional committee to study the practicability of a union between the United States and Canada, with the ultimate view of establishing "the greatest English-speaking nation in the world."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 (AP). -- The State Supreme Court refused today for the third and final time to recommend clemency for Joe Kristy and Alexander Mackay, sentenced to die for the kidnapping and robbery of Prison Board members in an attempt to escape in January, 1935.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 19. -- The Hindenburg's delayed arrival means that she must be gassed and refueled between dawn and dusk if she is to keep to her schedule and start back to Germany tomorrow night. Officers at the air station here today expected no difficulty in landing and launching the big ship in a single day.

SAINT BRIEUC, France, May 19. -- American flags flew from the tower of Treguier Cathedral, the City Hall and many private dwellings here today when a memorial window to Saint Ives, patron saint of lawyers, was presented to the cathedral by the American Bar Association.
PARIS, May 19. -- America's small and none too potent delegation in the French hard court tennis championships got away to an unimpressive start today.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Adoption of a plank by the major parties promising abolition of the spoils system will be sought by the National League of Women Voters, Miss Marguerite M. Wells, president, said today.

Gleanings from notebook and mailbag: The week-end jaunt to Peconic Bay convinced this department of one thing -- any one who uses heavy tackle in top-water angling for weakfish will get mighty little sport out of his trip. . . . When you hear a man speak depreciatively of the fighting qualities of weakfish, it is fairly certain that he uses an outfit that doesn't give the fish a chance.
CHICAGO, May 19. -- Capitalizing on four hits and a brace of errors, the Red Sox today recorded their sixth straight victory over the White Sox, winning 4 to 2.

The share market displayed a heavy tone yesterday. Throughout the day leadership was lacking utterly, and the thinness of the market for many stocks resulted in steady declines. The list closed lower, with many of the more active issues down 1 to more than 3 points.

Once more, and for the last time, Mr. HOOVER declares what "should have been evident by this time," that he is "not a candidate." He has "rigidly prevented" his friends from making any efforts in his behalf. His name has been entered in no primary or State convention. He is opposing no candidates.

More than 1,200 persons, many prominent in commerce and industry, paid tribute last night to Edwin Goodman, Fifth Avenue merchant, who was hailed by speakers as "America's pre-eminent merchant of quality."

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 19. -- By sweeping its triangular match with Century and Grassy Sprain today at the Tamarack Country Club, the formidable team representing the Innis Arden Golf Club of Greenwich, Conn., captured the Class A championship in the Westchester interclub competition of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

The practice of the more sensitive corporate bonds to follow closely the trend in stocks resulted in a broad decline yesterday in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. While sharp declines were restricted to relatively few issues, fractional losses spread over a broad list of the corporate bonds and there was a decline of 0.25 point in the price average for that group.

DUBLIN, May 19. -- President Eamon de Valera's respite for the Free State Senate has expired. He has introduced in the Daft Eireann a decree for the abolition of the Senate which is scheduled for enactment in a few days.

FRANKLIN, N.J., May 19. -- Fire believed to have been caused by lightning destroyed a barn and $10,000 worth of farming equipment tonight at Price's Switch, in Northeastern Sussex County. The farm was owned by James Rickey of Warwick, N.Y., and operated by his son, William. All live stock was saved.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19. -- First performances of thirteen unpublished compositions for piano, viola and 'cello, choral groups and string quartet were given here today at the Westminster Choir School during the second day of the festival of American music.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotation for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
The Emergency Relief Bureau was investigating a case of food poisoning yesterday to determine whether the food had come from supplies being distributed to relief families.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- A list of proposals that, if adopted, would mean the formation of an association or league of nations in North and South America was submitted today by the governing board of the Pan American Union for consideration at the projected Pan-American Peace Conference to be held at Buenos Aires.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 19. -- The printing and stationery firm of William Allen Co. of New York was taken over by the employes here today when Surrogate George A. Slater of Westchester County accepted their bid in preference to a higher offer, so that the wishes of the late owner might be realized.

Forty-three of the 164 cement plants operated by members of the Portland Cement Association completed 1935 without any accidents to workmen severe enough to cause loss of time, it was announced yesterday at the Spring meeting of the association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The American Federation of Labor in its monthly surveys continues to publish comparisons of employment and payrolls with profits and production which are very misleading.
