In the first three months of this year, it finds, business profits were 36 per cent higher than in the corresponding period a year ago, while average wages were only 4.8 per cent higher and employment only 2.4 per cent higher.

LONDON, May 19. -- Lieut. Col. Alberto Mondadori, Italian Military Attache in London, is expected to be recalled soon as a result of the disclosure of his connection with the so-called "dumdum bullet legend."
West Side investment deals featured the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday. Activity on the lower East Side also was listed.

An "acute shortage" of supplies on WPA park projects was reported yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses. Mr. Moses said that Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, had promised to refill the stock of materials but that, in the meantime, reserves were approaching the vanishing point.
Police Commissioner Valentine assured striking seamen yesterday that legal picketing of piers within the port district would be permitted by the police as long as the current strike continues.

BOSTON, May 19. -- The American Unitarian Association at the closing session of its annual convention today voted overwhelmingly to seek the same privileges accorded to Quakers for its conscientious objectors in war and passed a resolution of "repentance" for its acts against pacifist ministers during the World War.
Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley of the Bronx criticized the Emergency Relief Bureau sharply yesterday for permitting aliens to draw relief money while American citizens were destitute.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Eighteen plays by new playwrights have been produced during the five months the WPA theatre project has been in operation and two of these have been purchased for production in the motion pictures or on the legitimate stage, Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, WPA Theatre Director, announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Representative Rayburn, chairman of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, said today that he would ask unanimous consent tomorrow for adoption of the bill to continue unlisted trading privileges to securities on national securities exchanges beyond the present deadline of June 1.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Secretary Ickes testified in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today that unemployment relief, rather than an attempt to "coerce" power companies to lower their rates to consumers, had invariably been the guiding rule of the Public Works Administration in allocating funds to municipalities for construction of publicly owned lighting plants.

Another horse injected himself into contention for 3-year-old honors when John Hay Whitney's Mr. Bones won the thirty-sixth Swift Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park in 1:24 1-5, the second fastest time in the history of this speed test, which goes back to racing at Sheepshead Bay.

Testifying yesterday at the mail fraud trial of four former officers of the Westchester Title and Trust Company, its former treasurer admitted that in 1931 and 1932 the company concealed indebtedness for a few days through dummy loans to show a good condition in year-end statements available to the investing public.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- A recommendation that WPA officials in handling relief funds revert to the system used by the Emergency Relief Administration was made to a subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee by George U. Harvey, President of the Borough of Queens, today.

Five gunmen, four of them Negroes, who were captured in an automobile on the night of April 22 as they were on their way to hold up a gambling house in West Sixty-fifth Street, were sentenced to indeterminate penitentiary terms up to three years each yesterday by Justices Hackenburg, Kernochan and Gresser in Special Sessions.
A dividend of 30 cents a share was declared yesterday by the Kennecott Copper Corporation. On Zfarch 31, 25 cents was paid.

" AM I asking too much," cries James T. Farrell in "A Note on Literary Criticism" (Vanguard, $2.50), "if I ask literary critics to talk sense, and to understand the precise meaning of the 'sense' they do talk?"

Thatcher M. Brown of Brown Brothers Harriman Co. was elected president of the board of directors of the Union Theological Seminary at a meeting yesterday, it was announced last night. He succeeds William Morgan Kingsley, president of the United States Trust Company, who announced the election of his successor at the commencement exercises in James Memorial Chapel.

Surgeon General Thomas Parran Jr. of the United States Public Health Service expressed confidence yesterday that the public health provisions of the Federal Social Security Act would not be declared unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court.

Broadway, accustomed to chicken sandwiches without chicken and safeguarded only by a recent court decision against Bacardi cocktails without Bacardi, found itself facing a parallel problem yesterday -- that of Minsky burlesque without Minskys.

BREMEN, Germany, May 19 (AP). -- The North German Lloyd-Hamburg-American Shipping Lines announced a decrease of capital stock in the proportion of five shares for one today, but the transfer of 35,132,000 marks and 40,000,000 marks, respectively, of their debts into shares to meet heavy losses in 1934 and 1935.

In an address two weeks ago to the American Law Institute, Chief Justice HUGHES referred to divisions in our higher courts. Why should it be expected, he asked, that they would not exist? In sciences and philosophy, as well as in theology, experts of the greatest reputation differed, and it would be strange if judges did not.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 500,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value of the Tom Moore Distillery Company.
Representative Rogers and your correspondent Raymond S. Michael focus the attention for the moment only, alas! on the problem of diplomatic protection to the American citizen abroad.

Formation of the Berkey Gay Acceptance Corporation, which will introduce the methods of automobile financing into the sale of furniture, was announced here yesterday by Frank D. McKay, chairman of the board of the Berkey Gay Furniture Company, who will become head of the acceptance company.

With increasing emphasis on the idea that business should "defend" itself through advertising, institutional copy is expected to be used more widely during the remainder of the year, according to comment here yesterday. Higher taxes, attempts to "regiment" industry by the government and attacks from consumer organizations and other sources regarded as inimical to business are developments concerning which business should make itself vocal through paid advertising, it was said.

Disregarding a heavy shower which fell near the end of exercises yesterday for 224 probationary policemen graduates of the Police Academy, Mayor La Guardia cited the weather as proof of the fact that public life is not all sunshine.

ST. LOUIS, May 19 (AP). -- The Browns, snapping out of an extended slump, clipped short a late Philadelphia rally today and swept their series with the Athletics with an 8-to-4 victory, their sixth of the season.

The police broadcast an alarm last night for four men, one of whom they were sure was wounded, after a hold-up at about 9 o'clock in a basement bakery owned by John Messena at 111 Sanford Street; Brooklyn. The thugs, Who got $30, fled in an automobile.

ALBANY, May 19. -- The Public Service Commission today lost its appeal to the Court of Appeals to enforce an order requiring public utility companies to segregate their capital accounts to show the original cost of properties and to set up straight-line depreciation; also to charge against surplus the price paid for properties over the original cost to the first builder.

Henry Picard, Hershey luminary, who has rapidly forged his way to the top among the golf professionals of the country, has been established as the favorite in the first list of quotations for the United States open championship, to be played at the Baltusrol Golf Club starting June 4.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 19. -- William E. Speers, who polled the highest vote, 7,811, in last Tuesday's record-breaking election, was named Mayor of Montclair for the next four years at the organization meeting of Montclair's new Town Commission today.

Flashing a speedy attack in the final two rounds, Sonny Jones, 142 1/4, Vancouver, B.C., gained a draw against Johnny Clinton, 146 1/4, the West Side, in the six-round feature bout last night at the Coliseum.

The Fire Department of New York City is constantly being called upon to function. It is, I think, needless to point out the efficiency, the bravery, the splendid devotion to duty -- to the point of giving their lives -- that the men of the Fire Department display almost every day.

Francis S. McCaffery of the Consolidated Shipbuilding Company, was elected president of the New York Chapter, National Association of Cost Accountants, at a meeting in the Roger Smith Restaurant last night. Frank Klein of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation and William Keating of Miller, Donaldson Co. were elected first and second vice presidents respectively.

Appeals for the support of the Will Rogers Memorial Hospital at Saranac, N.Y., were made yesterday afternoon by Will Hays, leader of the motion-picture industry, and Jesse Jones, head of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Mr. Hays spoke from New York and Mr. Jones from Washington on a program broadcast over WABC and the Columbia Broadcasting System's network.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area for the thirteen shopping days ended May 15 showed ran increase Of 10.9 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BOSTON, May 19. - Almost unanimous sentiment for a strike to enforce demands that two men be placed in the cab of each Diesel engine operated on the principal New England railroads is being expressed by the more than 3,000 members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, according to union officials.

LONDON, May 19 (AP). -- Chester C. Davis, AAA administrator, returned to London today in a somewhat gloomy and pessimistic mood after six weeks of an agricultural survey in eleven European countries. He will sail for home Thursday aboard the liner Washington.

MEXICO, D.F., May 19. -- Red flags were removed from stations and offices of the National Railways of Mexico today when the 50,000 workers abandoned the strike for wage increases that had begun at 5 P.M. yesterday.
In regard to the article in THE TIMES "Sea Safety Inquiry Ordered by Senate," I wish to state that this investigation will be just another big farce at the American public's expense.

Freddy Lindstrom, one of the stars of the National League for twelve years, suddenly ended his baseball career yesterday by seeking and receiving the consent of the Brooklyn club to place him on the voluntarily retired list.

An Assistant District Attorney allegedly received bribes of $25 for each of several girls arrested in disorderly houses and who subsequently escaped jail, it was testified to yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a blue ribbon jury at the trial of ten men for compulsory prostitution.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The Paraffine Companies, Inc., of San Francisco filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 23,804 shares of 4 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, par value $100 a share, and 23,804 shares of common stock, no-par value.

LONDON, May 19. -- Only two big British warships will be left at Alexandria, protecting the Suez Canal and Egypt, and only two at Gibraltar tomorrow as the result of a continuous shifting of naval units that has been going on recently between the home and the Mediterranean stations.

Continuing its efforts to develop a Diesel engine for automobiles and trucks, as well as work in other fields, the research laboratory of the General Motors Corporation has taken over part of the Cadillac-La Salle plant in West End Detroit because of lack of space in the present research building.

Mayor Frank Hague's ironclad control of Hudson County was demonstrated in the primary yesterday. In the Second Ward, where the Mayor was born, W.H. Smathers, the regular Democratic candidate for United States Senator, received 2,205 votes against 1 for Theron McCampbell, an insurgent.

With an unusually large passenger list for an early-season sailing, the United States liner Manhattan will depart today for Hamburg via other European ports. Her 1,011 passengers include George Messersmith, United States Minister to Austria, and John G. Winant, former Governor of New Hampshire and now chairman of the Social Security Board, who is accompanied by a delegation to the International Labor Conference in Geneva.

Crude oil production in the United States reached a record output last week of 3,008,050 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The previous high record was 2,973,450 barrels daily in the week ended on Aug. 31, 1929. Last week's gain of 46,350 barrels over the 2,961,700 in the previous week was accounted for in part by increases of 22,700 barrels in Oklahoma and 9,400 in Texas.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed May 22 as National Maritime Day, commemorating the sailing of the steamship Savannah from Savannah, Ga., on May 22, 1819, bound on what proved to be the first successful voyage across the ocean under steam power.

A nation - wide banking group, headed by Otis Co., obtained the award yesterday for a new issue of $10,000,000 of State of Colorado, State Highway Fund revenue anticipation warrants, due June 1, 1939 to 1954. The successful bid was 101.2765 for 2 3/4s. Reoffering of the warrants was made immediately after the award at prices to yield from 1.20 to 2.70 per cent, according to maturity.

The second program of the Dance Congress and Festival, which is being held all this week in the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium of the Y.M.H.A., was devoted last night to the folk dance, and the evening proved to be a thoroughly delightful one from beginning to end.

CANBERRA, May 19. -- The loan council consisting of representatives of all the Australian States and presided over by Federal Treasurer Casey today agreed to a loan program for 1936-37 totaling f20,000,000, whereof u2,340,000 is for funding deficits and the remainder for public works and farmers' relief.
Several apartment properties and a large taxpayer on the Concourse were included in the Bronx realty transactions reported yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 19. -- The General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, ended today, will go down in history as the one that passed the plan of union, Bishop Edwin H. Hughes of Washington predicted in his closing address.

WASWINGTON, May 19. -- Administration leaders in the Senate indicated today their determination to fight for retention of the principle of an undivided corporate profits tax in the pending Revenue Bill, despite appearances in official circles that President Roosevelt had lost some of his ardor for the proposal in the face of continuing opposition and reports of revolt within the Senate Finance Committee.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., May 19. -- Either a full-grown whirlwind or an embryo tornado leveled chicken houses, damaged barns and played pranks early last night on at least two farms on Blackwell Mills Road, Hillsborough Township, seven miles south of this place, according to reports that reached here today from the affected area, which is somewhat isolated.

The American Safety Razor Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday that they earned $291,538 in the first quarter of this year, after deducting depreciation, reserves, Federal taxes and other charges. The profit is equivalent to $1.67 each on 174,800 shares of no-par capital stock, excluding shares held in the treasury.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP). -- Lifting the screen of secrecy behind which fleet manoeuvres had been conducted off Panama, the Navy Department announced today that three of its sea fighters had been damaged during the war games. One was in a collision and the two others experienced turbine trouble.

A mass meeting held last night under the auspices of the Teachers Union at Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and Sixteenth Street, launched a campaign for repeal of the Ives loyalty oath law. A resolution condemning the law in strong terms was adopted and the teachers present unanimously pledged themselves to "renewed" efforts to combat "tyranny" in the Schools of this city.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19. -- New Jersey has become the most "commission ridden" State in the nation because of the many departments in the organization of local governments, according to the Princeton Local Government Survey Committee.

About 100 landlords of Harlem and the Bronx, all members of the Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners, Inc., voted unanimously last night "to strike" against enforcement of the Multiple Dwelling Law as it affects the operation of old-law tenements.

HELENA, Mont., May 19 (AP). -Montana Democrats elected a national convention delegation pledged to President Roosevelt at the close of their State convention tonight, and Republicans named an uninstructed group to their party's national meeting.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System reported yesterday for the ten months ended April 30 a consolidated net income of $4,367,841 after taxes, depreciation, charges and minority interests, equal, after ten-month dividend requirements on 249,468 shares of $6 preferred stock, to $4.24 a share on 735,664 no-par common shares, compared to $4,706,949, or $4.70 a share, in the same period of the previous fiscal year.

THE ball game was rained out and it was a bit too wet for a man of his age to go traipsing around the dripping golf links, so Jack Doyle, the Sage of Broadway, sat himself down in a sheltered spot and delivered a monologue on heavyweight matters.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 19. -- Mark Stuart, former metropolitan champion, set the pace today in a practice session for the triangular matches which bring together the Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island teams at the Winged Foot Golf Club tomorrow.

Some increases in salaries in 1935 were reported yesterday by the Missouri Pacific Railroad in its report for last year to the Interstate Commerce Commission. L.W. Baldwin, who was a trustee in bankruptcy of the company until last December, received $36,000 salary in that office, besides $540 other compensation.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Showing a gain of slightly more than 7 per cent over the corresponding period of the 1935 fiscal year, internal revenue collections for the first ten months of the fiscal year 1936, through April 30, amounted to $2,859,869,975, an increase of $195,016,648, the Treasury Department announced today.

Miss Jerry Bergh, chairman, gave a tea yesterday afternoon in the Madison Room of the Biltmore for members of the debutante committee and other girls interested in the success of the Texas Centennial Blue Bonnet Ball on Saturday at that hotel. The proceeds of the ball will be used to further the Texas Centennial Exposition and benefit the Texas Students Scholarship Fund.

The Junior League of Brooklyn closed its season yesterday with a luncheon on the Marine Roof of the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn. Miss Arrietta Smith, newly elected president, presided. Mrs. W. Coverly Fischer and Miss Smith, who attended the recent annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America in Richmond, Va., gave summaries of the conference.

I am a survivor of the steamship Mohawk, and since her sinking with forty-five of my fellow-men I have devoted most of my time to investigation and study of conditions prevailing on American vessels. The results have proved shocking to me and others engaged in this work.
PARIS, May 19 -- Leon Blum, coming Socialist Premier, conferred tonight with Edouard Herriot and offered him the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the new French Cabinet.

Despite criticism of his handling of the Hauptmann case, which Franklin W. Fort, his opponent, made the main issue of his campaign, Governor Harold G. Hoffman was elected a delegate at large to the Republican National Convention in the New Jersey primary election yesterday and retains his leadership of the party in that State.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 19. -- Supported by both Democrats and Republicans, Governor Earle's social security program, including unemployment insurance, old age and mothers' assistance measures, was approved today by the House.

MOSCOW, May 19. -- Another murder was laid to I.D. Simenchuk at today's session of the trial of the Wrangel Island leader. This supposed victim was Hydrologist Vakulenko, who apparently had shot himself to death in remorse over the deaths his unskillful medication had caused among the island's colonists.

Domestic employment has always been highest when import volume was up and declined with any drop in American purchases of foreign goods, Harry Tipper, executive vice president of the National Foreign Trade Association, pointed out in an address before the regular weekly luncheon meeting of the Lions Club of New York at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Operation of the largest high-speed wind tunnel in the world, just completed at Langley Field, Vs., in which air speeds of more than 500 miles an hour can be attained in the eight-foot throat, will be demonstrated tomorrow to more than 300 leaders in aeronautics at the -- annual engineering conference to be held at the field by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 19 (AP). -- Officials of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad announced today the discontinuance of several fare bases coincident with establishment of the new fare schedule on June 2. The new fares provide a cheaper rate than the schedules discontinued, with charges of 2 cents a mile for coach travel and 3 cents a mile for Pullman, exclusive of the Pullman fare.

Apparently seeking to broaden the scope of its inquiry so as to include matters outside the Samuel Drukman murder case, the special grand jury forwarded to Governor Lehman yesterday a document which, it is believed, deals with specific examples of the breakdown of law enforcement in Kings County.
PROVIDENCE, May 19 (AP). -- James A. Farley compared the campaign of 1936 today with that of four years ago and declared: "We hear the same moans of prospective, disaster."

The attempt to establish a voluntary agreement governing hours, operating shifts and wages in the women's seamless hosiery industry has failed, Earl Constantine, managing director of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, made known yesterday.

A steady demand for May contracts as the trade fixed prices held that month steady on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list closed with a gain of 1 point to a loss of 2 points from Monday's levels. It was estimated that the pool released another 10,000 bales of the May.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Sentiment grew in administration circles today in favor of avoiding the issue raised on the constitutionality of the government's entire work relief program by not appealing the decision yesterday of the Federal Court of Appeals here, which specifically outlawed a Resettlement Administration housing project at Bound Brook, N.J.

The winner of the Joe Louis-Max Schmeling fight at the Yankee Stadium June 18 will be recognized as the No. 1 challenger for the world heavyweight championship now held by James J. Braddock. This was definitely decided at a meeting of the State Athletic Commission yesterday, and it is probable that the title fight will be held in New York in September.

A lot of discontent among American seamen is caused by naturalized American skippers of European descent. These skippers try to bring into American-owned ships the cheap, skimpy methods they have been used to. American ships skippered and officered by American-born seamen are the finest ships on the seven seas.

Thirty-six championship games have been arranged by the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association for the coming season, which will open on Decoration Day, F. Fitzmaurice Kelly, secretary, announced yesterday.

OTTAWA, May 19 (Canadian Press). -- Pronounced gains in exports to the United States of leading commodities affected by the Canada-United States trade agreement were made in the four months of 1936, compared with the corresponding period of 1935, W.D. Euler, Minister of Trade and Commerce, said today.
SANTA ANA, Calif., May 19 (AP). -- Mrs. Lydia P. Simpson, wife of Dr. George Gaylord Simpson, curator of the New York Museum of Natural History, was found sane today by a jury here.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Charles (Chuck) Kocsis, 23-year-old star, shot his way back to the Big Ten individual golf championship today, and along with his personal triumph led Michigan to its fifth consecutive team title.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Wednesday, May 20. -- Incomplete returns tabulated early this morning definitely indicated that the Republican faction led by State Senator Winant Van Winkle had defeated all candidates on the Republican slate led by former State Senator Ralph W. Chandless in Bergen County.
DETROIT, May 19. -- The Chrysler Corporation announced tonight an increased wage scale for its shop employes effective June 1.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Facing a committee which he charged was unfriendly, Dr. Francis E. Townsend frankly admitted today that he expected to obtain "millions" in contributions to his old-age pension plan and verified a letter in which he boasted that he had "the world by the tail with a down-hill pull."

Judging by the entry list for the metropolitan open championship, released yesterday by the Metropolitan Golf Association, Henry Picard, tall Hershey professional, will face far sterner opposition at Quaker Ridge, where he will defend his 1935 laurels, than he had a year ago at Lakeville.

HAVANA, May 19. -- Havana took on a festive air tonight as the nation prepared for the inauguration tomorrow of President-elect Miguel Mariano Gomez, the first constitutional President since the downfall of the Machado regime in 1933.

Jeremiah K. Cronin, manager of the mortgage and real estate department of the management division of the Bankers Trust Company, was elected head of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York at the annual meeting of that organization last night in the Hotel Astor.

Hope that an Institute of Forensic Medicine may be established here with the cooperation of the leading universities and the office of the Medical Examiner has been revived by discussions of a subcommittee of the New York Academy of Medicine, it was made known yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 19. -- Unlisted trading in relation to the small Stock Exchanges was the theme today of the executive session at the termination of the two-day convention of the Association of Stock Exchanges here. Considerable interest was evidenced in the amendment to the Securities Exchange Act, now pending in Congress, permitting trading in unlisted securities to be continued after June 1, the present deadline.

CLEVELAND, May 19. -- A pop bottle was heaved on the field at League Park today as Manager Joe McCarthy objected vehemently to Umpire George Moriarty's decisions behind the plate; Ben Chapman was banished from the dugout, home runs clattered over the right field wall and a fist fight was narrowly averted as Tony Lazzeri went to the rescue of Joe DiMaggio, who was handled roughly at second by Bill Knickerbocker on a force play.

Most commodity futures were slightly lower in dull trading yesterday, with little in the news to encourage activity. On the cash markets eggs rose, while wheat, corn, rye, lard and rubber declined and oats, tin and silk sold at new low prices for the year.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- President Roosevelt put on Congress today the responsibility for fixing an adjournment date, while reiterating that relief and taxes are the only subjects on which he insists there be legislation at this session.

The approaching Jeffersonian Day dinner calls upon those who may be summoned to deliver addresses on that occasion not only to familiarize themselves -- which one can be sure they already have done -- with the principles and ideal of government of that eminent man, but also to enunciate them in the very words of the apostle of liberty in whose honor they will be assembled.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, May 18 (delayed). -- The shooting of Ethiopians on flimsy denunciations or on the discovery of arms in their possession continues in Addis Ababa. Forty-five persons were shot Thursday night and twenty-three were led out for execution Saturday morning.

The Municipal Art Committee is responsible for a lion's share of the week's local developments. Having organized and launched the First National Exhibition of American Art at International Building, Rockefeller Center, the committee, headed by Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, now directs attention to its own temporary galleries at 62 West Fifty-third Street, where the eighth exhibition of the season opened yesterday.

Albert H. Morrill, president of the Kroger Grocery and Baking Company, received compensation of $93,718 last year, according to the company's annual report filed with the SEC. C.M. Robertson, vice president and treasurer, received $29,103; H.W. Bracy, branch manager, $66,487; thirteen directors, $18,053; six other employes, each more than $20,000, a total of $180,441.

Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture and Rexford G. Tugwell, his Under-Secretary, came from Washington yesterday to testify in the General Sessions trial of Walter C. Martin on a grand larceny charge.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

John L. Merrill, president of the Pan American Society and president of All America Cables, Inc., returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Maria from a tour of South American countries convinced that Pan Americanism was a strong force in South America today and that those countries expected the forthcoming peace conference in Buenos Aires to result in real cooperation among nations of the Western Hemisphere.

Another edition of "New Faces" came to town last evening to grimace at the late Spring and, if the world is not harsh, at the Summer as well. With some good music and sketches that are not on the intellectual side, the latest of Leonard Sillman's cultural endeavors is a cheerful thing and unpretentious, amiable and bustling with the zest that all new faces provide in the weary month of May.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Members of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers were told today that the Supreme Court decision invalidating the Guffey Coal Act served "further notice" that all industries must solve their own problems without expecting any help from the government.

SANTIAGO, Chile. May 19. -- The promise made by the newly established military junta in Bolivia to respect all international agreements has moved the Chilean Government to consider early recognition of the new government, according to well informed sources.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 19. -- Warren Jr., a Sinclair-bred horse now owned by Warren Wright, won the Valley Handicap, at a mile and 70 yards, the feature of today's card at Narragansett Park.

The Akeley Memorial Hall of African Mammals of the American Museum of Natural History was dedicated yesterday afternoon. The ceremonies were open only to members of the museum. It was the eighth annual members' visiting day and also the anniversary of the birth of the late Carl E. Akeley, explorer, inventor and educator.
LONDON, May 19. -- The web of evidence was drawn more tightly than ever around J.H. Thomas, the Colonial Secretary, today as the budget leakage inquiry swung into its closing stages.

The Department of Health reported yesterday for the eighth successive week an increase in new cases of diphtheria over a year ago. A total of thirty-four new cases occurred last week, compared with twenty-seven for the corresponding period last year.

Captain Sir Ian Fraser, chairman of St. Dunstan's, the British institution that care: for soldiers who lost their sight in the World War, arrived on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania yesterday accompanied by Dr. Ernest Whitfield, member of the executive council of the National Institute for the Blind, to study American production of "talking books."

Gross receipts of the railways for the first quarter of 1936 as shown by the Railway Association's compilation were the largest of any corresponding period since 1931. As compared with the same quarter in 1933, when railroad revenues made their worst showing, the increase in gross receipts was 38 1/4 per cent, while net operating income for the period increased 202 per cent.

The will of Lucy Stella Sehieffelin, daughter of the late Edgar Schieffelin, member of the drug firm of that name, named eleven public and charitable institutions as beneficiaries. Filed In Surrogates' Court yesterday, the will bequeathed one-half of her residuary estate to Troll Rees of 49 West Seventy-fifth Street and the contents of her apartment at that address.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Commission-house liquidation in May wheat on the Board of Trade today and also selling of that delivery against purchases of new crop futures depressed the former as much as 2 cents a bushel below yesterday's last quotation and forced the price to within a fraction of the lowest mark of the current movement.
New York Lodge 1, B'nai B'rith; established last night an annual award to an American organization or institution by presenting to THE NEW YORK TIMES a bronze plaque for "meritorious public service."

Gustav Eder, European welterweight titleholder from Germany, dynamited Al Silva, the previously unbeaten Bronx contender, from the championship picture last night before a capacity crowd of 4,000 persons at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 19. -- A measure being considered by the authorities prohibiting further importations of automobiles and radios for a time, in view of the scarcity of available drafts of foreign currency, is considered to affect seriously United States trade with Chile.

BERLIN, May 19. -- Officially speaking, the Boerse reversed itself today, fixed-interest securities showing strength and most stocks showing weakness at the opening and resistance but little activity at the closing. As fixed-interest securities had been stagnant for months on the Berlin Boerse, the sudden display of strength was regarded as a notable curiosity.
Donald Budge and Gene Mako stand forth as the prospective new United States Davis Cup doubles team.

The hunt for further evidence against Max D. Krone, private detective, and A. Henry Ross, Brooklyn lawyer, in an alleged extortion ring developed divergent leadership yesterday and there was some question as to whether District Attorney William C. Dodge actually was in charge or one of the following assistants: Charles Pilatsky, Harold W. Hastings or John J. Sullivan.

Tests of 2,028 cars by the Automobile Club of New York in the safety lane in Mount Vernon, N.Y., last week showed that 1,202, or 60 per cent, were defective in some "vital" particular, the club announced yesterday.
PARIS, May 19 (AP). -- Former Premier Edouard Herriot urged better commercial relations with the United States today in an effort to heal the war debt "misunderstanding."

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Robert Paul Henneberry is the son of George Francis Henneberry, president of the Henneberry Rotogravure Company of Chicago, and Mrs. Janet Hibbard Henneberry, who were divorced in 1931.

The Zeppelin Hindenburg was nearing the United States coast early this morning on her second west-bound trip from Germany and was expected to land at Lakehurst, N.J., after daybreak, according to a message received by the United States Navy Communications at 2 A.M.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 19. -- Five hundred bankers from Tennessee and Mississippi assembled at conference tables in the Peabody Hotel today looked to the "man behind the plow" to furnish them a suitable market for overflowing bank deposits and bring a permanent prosperity back to the South by land policies to be advocated and encouraged by the bankers themselves.

The six-story Central Mercantile Building, a Sixth Avenue landmark once occupied by the Siegel Cooper Company Department Store, was bid in at a foreclosure auction sale yesterday by the Mutual Life Insurance Company. Leasehold rights to parts of the land under the structure were bought in by two owner estates.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The administration's reciprocal trading program was endorsed today by organized business and the diplomatic corps at a luncheon given by Thomas J. Watson, chairman of the American section of the International Chamber of Commerce, in observance of National Foreign Trade Week.

The decision of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals holding one of REXFORD TUGWELL'S pet projects unconstitutional covers what is in the main familiar ground. The Supreme Court has never taken kindly to the loose delegation of legislative powers, and the Resettlement Administration, according to the majority of the District judges, is another outstanding example of "delegation running riot."
The Hapag Lloyd liner Berlin arrived in port yesterday on her first visit of the year, her officers and crew proud of the success that marked an unusual test of their seamanship en route.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19. -- Princeton oarsmen will gather on the float of the Class of 1887 boathouse tomorrow afternoon to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the first intercollegiate regatta to be held on the then newly made Lake Carnegie.

More than 300 guests attended a buffet luncheon and private view of the work of the students of the New York School of Applied Design for Women, given yesterday by the president, Leon V. Solon, and the trustees of the school at 160 Lexington Avenue.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 19. -- The new Peltier comet, discovered near the North Star last week by an amateur astronomer, gives indications that it will become visible to the naked eye just before sunrise during the latter part of July, according to calculations made at the Harvard College Observatory.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 19. -- So many things happened today during the second round of the women's British golf championship that I had better describe them before going on to the events of the third round.

The Federal public works program will reach its peak in this State late next month or early in July, when 65,000 skilled building craftsmen will be at work on 432 PWA projects, according to a report submitted yesterday to Administrator Harold L. Ickes by Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director, and Colonel M.E. Gilmore, his engineer-inspector.

SEATTLE, Wash., May 19 -- Representative Marion A. Zioncheck's constituency is very much divided over his antics, such as biting a chauffeur, smashing speed laws, insulting Puerto Rican and guzzling soup, a survey today revealed.

WASHINGTON, May 19.--While President Roosevelt was expressing today his desire for continued work looking toward preservation of the Guffey act's objectives, representatives of the government, coal mine workers and operators were canvassing all phases of the problem presented by the Supreme Court decision invalidating the law.

Having had more than a year to think about it, Vinton Freedley has chosen " -- but MILLIONS!" as the title of the new Lindsay-Crouse-Porter musical. Rehearsals begin in mid-August under Mr. Lindsay's direction, for a September tryout at the Colonial, Boston.

A novel treatment of Gluck's classic opera "Orfeo ed Euridice" will be the first experiment in production undertaken by the Metropolitan Opera in the course of its Spring season next Friday evening. Lucrezia Bori, honorary president of the board of the Spring season, declared in an interview yesterday that the manner of production of "Orfeo" will differ from all past interpretations of the work.
I see in your paper that Leon Blum, just before assuming the Premiership of France and still free to speak his mind without regard to the office, said of existing international relations:

Lord Addington of the British House of Lords and Dr. J.E.W. Duys, parliamentary leader of the Socialist party in the Netherlands, were guests of honor last night at a dinner of 250 members of the Oxford Group at the Ambassador Hotel. Twenty-seven members of the group, who recently attended a series of meetings in Denmark, are here for a national assembly to be held in Stockbridge, Mass., May 29 to June 8.

For the second week registrations of visiting buyers in the market showed an increase over the preceding week. The total for the week ended yesterday was also well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 19. -- Jock Whitney and Tommy Hitchcock Jr., members of the open champion Greentree four last year, teamed with Robert Lehman and Dr. John Richards on a Red side to defeat a White team, 10 -- 7, in a members' match on the polo fields of the Phipps estate today.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- California wine growers won their fight to put foreign names on their products when the Senate today adopted an amendment proposed by Senator Johnson and backed by Senator McAdoo. The omnibus Liquor Tax Bill, with the wine and other amendments, was passed without dissent and sent back to the House for concurrence in the changes.

BERLIN, May 19. -- Germany's foreign trade, which improved so rapidly after the introduction of the 1,000,000,000-mark export subsidy last year that German official quarters proclaimed the end of the export crisis and the collapse of the anti-German boycott, has taken a turn for the worse again.

With more than twenty young women of society appearing as manikins in a fashion pageant entitled the "Calling All Models Style Revue," a benefit for the Charity Organization Society was held yesterday during the luncheon hour in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

The French franc declined to its gold-shipping point yesterday, dropping below it momentarily, without occasioning a resumption of engagements of gold for shipment to the United States. The franc closed at its gold point, 6.58 3/8 cents, off 1/8 point from the previous close.

A dinner dance and entertainment, held in settings characteristic of the royal ballrooms of seventeenth-century Europe, marked the formal opening last night of the new Viennese roof garden of the St. Regis. A distinguished gathering attended the celebration, which had been arranged as a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund to assist musicians of genuine talent who are in slender circumstances.
SOUTHPORT, England, May 19 (AP). -- The starting times and pairings in the quarter-final round of the women's British golf championship tomorrow:

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 19. -- In what was described by authorities as a fit of derangement caused by overstudy, Lewis Jack Somers Jr., 19-year-old freshman at Williams College, shot and killed a classmate tonight, wounded another and then committed suicide.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 19. -- Miss Grace Amory of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Montclair Golf Club.
BOSTON, May 19 (AP). -- Wind, dust, rain and the Boston Bees descended upon the Chicago Cubs this afternoon and the 1935 National League pennant winners dropped a 6-to-5 decision.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 19 (AP). -- With a brilliant ninth-inning finish, Buffalo broke the thirteenth game jinx tonight by beating Montreal, 6-5, in its first night game of the International League season. It was the first time the Bisons had succeeded in winning thirteen consecutive games in modern times and it put them in a tie with Newark for the league lead.

The St. John's University track team closed its season by winning its third annual triangular track meet with Brooklyn College and Long Island University at Victory Field yesterday. The Redmen tallied 75 2-3 points. Brooklyn College scored 67, while L.I.U. had only one-third of a point.

Although the seasonal decline in steel and automobile production appears to have started, industrialists feel that the retreat from the recent high levels will not go as far nor last as long as might have been expected in a normal business year.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 19. -- Jock Whitney and Tommy Hitchcock Jr., members of the open champion Greentree four last year, teamed with Robert Lehman and Dr. John Richards on a Red side to defeat a White team, 10 -- 7, in a members' match on the polo fields of the Phipps estate today.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- California wine growers won their fight to put foreign names on their products when the Senate today adopted an amendment proposed by Senator Johnson and backed by Senator McAdoo. The omnibus Liquor Tax Bill, with the wine and other amendments, was passed without dissent and sent back to the House for concurrence in the changes.

NEWARK, N.J., Wednesday, May 20. -- Victory for all Clean Government Republican candidates for public office in the Essex County primary election was assured early this morning on the basis of returns sufficient to make the outcome certain, but the contest for control of the Republican County Committee remained in doubt.

MADRID, May 19. -- With labor conflicts and strikes called by the Marxist trade unions in effect all over Spain, Santiago Casares Quiroga, the new Premier, appealed to the Socialists and Communists to have patience and confidence in his government's intentions to meet all their demands "within reason" as he presented his Cabinet to the Cortes today.

PATERSON, N.J., May 19. -- The Republican organization in Passaic County made a special effort yesterday to pile up a large vote for Governor Harold G. Hoffman as delegate at large. On a recent visit to this county the Governor was promised by Lloyd B. Marsh, Republican leader, that he would lead the ticket when the ballots were counted.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Active competition for the relatively light run of hogs here today lifted prices 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight with practically all interests in the market. Colder weather in the Central West had some effect, although the demand for fresh pork was not as brisk as on Monday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Wednesday, May 20. -- Governor Hoffman was leading Franklin W. Fort by two to one on the basis of the returns counted up to 1:30 o'clock this morning in the Union County Republican primary for delegate at large to the Republican National Convention.

Commendation of Governor Lehman for his record on the civil service and approval for the work of the New York City and State Civil Service Commissions were included in the annual report of the executive committee of the Civil Service Reform Association, which was made public yesterday at the association's fifty-eighth annual luncheon meeting at the Down Town Association, 60 Pine Street.

An attempt to reach an understanding which may result in more unified party leadership than was shown during the session of the Legislature will be made today at a meeting of the executive committee of the Republican State Committee at the National Republican Club.

ROME, May 19. -- The release was announced today of 495 persons serving terms on penal islands for offenses largely of a political nature. No accurate figures are available on the number still confined to these islands, but it is stated in well-informed Italian quarters to be very small.

LONDON, May 19. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet today, but moderate amount of selective buying was in evidence. British Government issues were steadied by the successful result of the Huddersfield municipal loan.

ALBANY, May 19. -- Manning Strewl, sentenced to fifty years imprisonment for the kidnapping of Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr., nephew of Edward J, and Daniel P. O'Connell, Albany County political leaders, is to have a new trial.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 20. -- Japan's southward policy, aiming at development of economic resources in the South Seas, is being put in more concrete form by legislation now before the Diet. It proposes establishment of two special companies for exploitation in the Pacific region.

MOSCOW, May 19. -- Winning his adjourned game from the fourth round against his Russian opponent, V. Ragosin, after sixty-three moves had been made, Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba, former world champion, today tied for first place with M. Botwinnik, the Soviet titleholder, in the international chess masters tournament.
The Charter Revision Commission's plan to abolish an independent Tenement House Department was criticized by several speakers yesterday at another public hearing held by the commission in City Hall.

George F. Mintzer, former Chief Assistant United States Attorney, made public last night a letter he wrote to Daniel F. Cohalan, former Supreme Court justice, in which he criticized the one-time influential Tammany member for questioning the qualities of Governor Lehman for re-election.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- A charge that officers of the $132,000,000 Philadelphia Company for Guaranteeing Mortgages "deliberately plundered" the company before it went into receivership early in 1933 was made today as a Congressional committee opened a hearing into alleged frauds and abuses costing bondholders of this district an estimated $1,000,000,000 in recent years.

TIENTSIN, China, May 19. -- With the arrival today of Lieut. Gen. Kanichiro Tashiro to take over command of the Japanese garrisons in North China from Lieut. Gen. Hayao Tada, Japan has sufficient army officers in this area to command enough troops to handle Hopel and Chahar Provinces in event of an outbreak of a war between Japan and Russia.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Former President Hoover's formal statement of last night taking himself out of the Presidential race is thought by observers here to have weakened the "stop Landon" movement which became more definite after the defeat of the Landon slate in the California primaries.

Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, indicated last night at a hoard meeting at the School of Business and Civic Administration of City College, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, that Morris U. Schappes, tutor in English at City College, whose failure to be recommended for reappointment caused a storm of protests, may be named to the faculty for another year.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- President Roosevelt discussed at his press conference the Supreme Court's invalidation of the Guffey Coal Control Act, intimating that the administration would proceed in its efforts to attain the act's objectives.

Intellectual power remains unimpaired with advancing age, although acumen decreases, according to Irving Lorge, associate in the Institute of Educational Research, Teachers College, Columbia, who spoke yesterday at the tenth anniversary celebration of the American Association for Adult Education in the Hotel Astor.

Although the total number of business failures in the week ended ay 14 was higher, the manufacturing, wholesale and construction groups dropped below their averages for the first twenty weeks of this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Plans for another major unit in the Rockefeller Center development were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings. The new structure will be an office building thirty-two stories in height and estimated to cost $3,500,000.

PARIS, May 19. -- The League of Nations is faced with dissolution unless it can be implemented with force to insure that its decisions will be respected, speakers told the International Diplomatic Academy here today.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Former President Hoover's formal statement of last night taking himself out of the Presidential race is thought by observers here to have weakened the "stop Landon" movement which became more definite after the defeat of the Landon slate in the California primaries.

Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, indicated last night at a hoard meeting at the School of Business and Civic Administration of City College, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, that Morris U. Schappes, tutor in English at City College, whose failure to be recommended for reappointment caused a storm of protests, may be named to the faculty for another year.

DETROIT, May 19 (AP). -- Tommy Bridges returned to form today to hold Washington to four hits and give the Tigers a 4-to-2 victory for a clean sweep of the three-game series with the Senators. He struck out five and walked one batter.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- President Roosevelt discussed at his press conference the Supreme Court's invalidation of the Guffey Coal Control Act, intimating that the administration would proceed in its efforts to attain the act's objectives.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Ralph W. Morrison of Texas, a friend of Vice President Garner, was reported here tonight to be considering submitting to President Roosevelt his resignation as a member of the Federal Reserve Board because of a disagreement as to policies with Marrimer S. Eccles, governor of the board.

ROME, May 19. -- Marshal Pietro Badoglio, Viceroy of Ethiopia, has conferred upon Herbert L. Matthews, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Italian war cross for valor in the East African campaign. He is the first journalist, Italian or foreign, thus honored.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 20 (AP). -- The crash of a plane into a wooded swampland brought death today to Harry P. Williams, aviator and husband of Marguerite Clark, star of the silent screen.

The Public Service Commission sanctioned yesterday the merger of the Astoria Light, Heat and Power Company, the New York and Queens Gas Company and the Standard Gas Company of the City of New York with the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.

GENEVA, May 20. -- "The practice of permitting an unlimited number of visitors to board steamships on sailing days" in the United States and elsewhere was criticized by Stuart J. Fuller of the United States State Department at a meeting of the League of Nations Opium Advisory Committee today.

BOSTON, May 20. -- Ninety-two per cent of the engine drivers, firemen and round-house hostlers employed by the Boston Maine, Maine Central and New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad systems have voted to strike to enforce their union's demand for helpers in the control rooms of Diesel electric locomotives.

A "reshuffling" of African powers and a reapportionment of territories were predicted here yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Ray Phillips of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions at Johannesburg, Natal, South Africa, who said that the change would result in the increased exploitation of the Negro.

HAMBURG, Germany, May 20. (AP). -- Four young hospital orderlies from Brandenburg set sail today in their hand-made yacht, a small craft of 7.3 tonnage and with a 40-foot mast, on a westward crossing of the Atlantic with Bermuda scheduled as the port of call.
LAKEHURST, N.J., May 20. -- The following passenger list for the Hindenburg's eastward flight was made public tonight.
The city faces withdrawal of all State relief funds if the Board ot Aldermen persists in its effort to draw a line between citizens and aliens in relief here, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Hope that Governor Lehman of New York would reconsider his decision not to stand for re-election was expressed by President Roosevelt today soon after Mr. Lehman's announcement that he would not be a candidate was received here.

LONDON, May 20. -- The Times of London will publish tomorrow a letter from Azaj Warqneh C. Martin, the Ethiopian Minister to London, contending that an Ethiopian "regency government" is still in being.
In an attack upon the housekeeping habits of tenement dwellers, Joseph Goldsmith enunciates the theory that personal habits of people cannot be changed by putting them into new buildings.

Business leases reported yesterday included a renewal by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company in the Brady Building, 140 Cedar Street, recently modernized by the Brady Security and Realty Corporation at a reported cost of about $300,000.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during April at 110.9 per cent capacity, on a single shift basis, compared to 108.1 per cent during March this year, and 85.3 per cent during April last year.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, announced yesterday that he had filed with District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan evidence tending to show that May's Department Store, 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and the Caruso Restaurant, Inc., of 226 West Thirty-fourth Street, made illegal political campaign contributions in 1935.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 21 (AP). -- President Roosevelt and a group of Senatorial Progressives held last evening what the Senators described as a three-hour "general chat."

Retail credit collections increased 0.69 per cent during April, according to the index of twenty local key stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The increase marks the thirty-fifth monthly gain during the last three years and compares with a rise in collections of 0.17 per cent in March and 0.13 per cent in April, 1935.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 20. -- Officials of the F.W. Woolworth Company, at the annual meeting here today, announced that although sales receipts in 1935 were nearly $2,000,000 under those in 1934, the total for the first four months of this year was $516,500 more than in the corresponding months of 1935.

Though the hourly wage rates it is paying are already higher than those that prevailed in 1929, the Chrysler Corporation announces a further increase effective June 1. Though this corporation is unusually prosperous, reporting earnings for the first three months of this year higher than for any corresponding period in its history, the situation in regard to the hourly wages it pays is not unique.
Building plans filed by architects yesterday included specifications for a new tenement house on Bennett Avenue to cost $175,000 and a large number of alteration projects.

MEXICO, D.F., May 20. -- The Ministry of the Interior has refused permission for removal of the body of Archbishop Pascual Diaz Barreto, who died last night, from his residence to the cathedral, where it was proposed the body should lie in state until burial on Saturday.

As Governor Lehman studied in Albany yesterday the twenty-four-page communication sent to him on Tuesday by the special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case, both he and Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd continued to withhold the nature of the message.

HANOVER, N.H., May 20. -- Dartmouth's baseball team handed Harvard its first Eastern Intercollegiate League defeat, 8 -- 6, today in a game which saw both Ted Olson and Ed Ingalls, leading pitchers of the circuit, take turns in blowing up.

The departure of three members of the Wightman Cup team for England yesterday was the occasion for the coming here of two members of the Davis Cup squad from the training camp at the Merion Cricket Club, Haverford, Pa.

By way of proving that a deft thrust to a vulnerable spot is frequently as effective as a bludgeoning wallop, Fordham won a light-hitting game from City College at the Ram field yesterday, 4 to 0, a sharp contrast to the Maroons' earlier 20-2 victory over the Beavers.
PARIS, May 20. -- Tomorrow being Ascension Day and a market holiday, the Bourse was inactive today. Although selling orders were not voluminous, prices sagged in most departments.

A truce by which organized liquor dealers hoped to stave off what they predicted would be a prolonged price war "more disastrous in its effects than that which started last week" was in effect among liquor retailers throughout the city last night.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Chairman Morgan and directors of the TVA, and with Wendell L. Willkie, chairman of the Commonwealth and Southern Power Company, on Federal power production; also with Senators Wagner, Norris, Wheeler, La Follette, Shipstead, Minton and Schwellenbach, and received Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

Lanky Bill Lee's long mastery over the Dodgers was smashed in one big inning at Ebbets Field yesterday when they knocked him out in the second, scored six runs, went on to win by 11 to 2 and made one more escape from the cellar. The six tallies were the most scored in any inning and the total was the highest made this season by the Stengeleers.

" One of the world's leading amateur astronomers" is the compliment that Harvard's observatory pays LESLIE C. PELTIER, a draftsman in Delphos, Ohio. He has to his credit not only five comets and a nova but also some 40,000 observations of variable stars, which may be a record for lone astronomer of his type.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- Congestion in May wheat on the Board of Trade became more apparent early, and while there was a small dip early, there was no material pressure on the market. Later when the market in Minneapolis developed independent strength and notices that 110,000 bushels of cash wheat would be delivered on contracts failed to start a liquidating movement, there was a rush of general buying.

Among the speakers at the Inauguration Day dinner of the Lincoln Fellowship Society, to be held on May 25 at the Hotel Lincoln, will be Fletcher Pratt, Henry Steele Commager, Edwin Markham and Thyra Samter Winslow, all of whom have contributed in one way or another to Lincoln literature.
WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The resignation of Ralph W. Morrison of Texas as a member of the Federal Reserve Board was announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 20. -- While Representative Zioncheck of Washington was preparing to return today to Washington his landlady dispossessed him of house and home here.

Five of the private gardens of Greenwich Village were opened to the public yesterday and five more will be opened today. The proceeds from their showing will be used to further the work of Greenwich House Health Center.

A substantial increase in sales in the first quarter of this year lifted the net profit of the Bernard Schwartz Cigar Corporation to $62,281, after depreciation and Federal taxes, from a net profit of $16,550 in the same period a year ago, according to S.T. Gilbert, chairman.
Weren't you a little indifferent as to details concerning the original of the national sobriquet, in the item about "Uncle Sam" Wilson and WPA?

United States Government loans were the center of interest in trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Absorbing about one-fourth of the day's total trading, Federal obligations responded to a broad demand which carried fifteen of the outstanding long-term issues to record high levels since their issuance.
MOSCOW, May 20. -- For the first time since the opening of the international chess masters' congress here a week ago, the ten experts were given a rest today and devoted the time to sightseeing.

At the close of the final session of the American Federation of Arts at its twenty-seventh annual convention, at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, F.A. Whiting, who has been president of the organization since 1930, tendered his resignation.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- Uncle Sam's fighters who will carry the Stars and Stripes into the ring at the Olympic Games in Berlin next August fought it out or first and second places on the team tonight before a cheering crowd of 19,000 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.

Doubt was expressed yesterday among Republican leaders in Trenton that Governor Harold G. Hoffman would be selected as chairman of the New Jersey delegation to the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.

Prices of commodity futures were mixed yesterday in quiet trading. In the cash market wheat, flour, rubber and wool tops were higher, while corn, rye, tin and silk were lower, tin and silk establishing new low prices for the current movement.
LOS ANGELES, May 20 (AP). -- The domestic warfare between Rudy Vallee and Fay Webb Vallee ended in Superior Court today when she won a divorce.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 20 (AP). -- Raced sparingly this year after a successful campaign as a juvenile, Miss Elizabeth Arden's Little Miracle won her second race in four starts as a 3-year-old when she captured the Betsy Williams Stakes at Narrangansett Park today.

BERLIN, May 20. -- The Nazi party's Health Bureau has issued a new slogan: "Eat National Socialist.'' Speaking for the bureau, Dr. Wirtz informed an audience of party "nourishment administrators'' that loyal Germans must now recognize it was no longer their right to eat as they pleased, and that in nourishing themselves they were fulfilling a duty to the nation.

What is said to be the oldest savings bank account in this State has been discovered by WPA workers compiling a city guide book as part of the Federal Writers Project. In 115 years the account has grown from $15 to $3,470.03, solely through interest accretions.
ALBANY, May 20 (AP). -- Syracuse extended its winning streak to three games by beating Albany, 10 to 9, in the first night contest of the season in Albany tonight.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP). -- Merritt (Sugar) Cain pitched the White Sox to their first shut-out victory of the season today, holding the Athletics to seven hits to earn a 4-to-0 decision.

Joseph E. Goldsmith asserts that if tenants of the slums were allowed to live in Fifth Avenue mansions, within six months the houses would have slum appearances. In behalf of our group, we accept this invitation. All he has to do is find the Fifth Avenue apartment and see that the rent is paid, and we will prove that his insinuations arc unfounded.
LONDON, May 20. -- Public inquiry into the leakage of Cabinet secrets ended today after eight days packed with sensations of a kind unknown in Great Britain since the Marconi scandal of 1913.

BALTIMORE, May 20. -- While pledging support to President Roosevelt and declaring that he would be re-elected for "doing something with courage and optimism," the Democratic State Convention called on the Democratic party today to "retain its traditional belief" in the doctrine of States' rights.
ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP). -- The Browns beat the Red Sox today, 12 to 8, garnering the dozen runs from only nine hits but profiting by nine bases on balls.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20. -- The "first" Harvard book, one of the most valuable volumes in the world since it is the only remaining book of the library bequeathed to the college by John Harvard 300 years ago, is on public display for the first time, at the Widener Library of Harvard University.
LONDON, May 20. -- The naval negotiations between Britain and Russia opened at the Admiralty today in a friendly atmosphere, with comparatively little trouble appearing the horizon.

RYE, N.Y., May 20. -- A message of encouragement to women who feel there is no work for them to do or that they are being discriminated against in the matter of employment was given at the Westchester Country Club this afternoon by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt of New Rochelle, 77-year-old suffrage pioneer.

Denunciation of the New Deal by Senator Warren R. Austin of Vermont, State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton and Vice Chairman Virginia Low Bacon, Majority Leader Oswield D. Heck of the Assembly and Mrs. Wilma D. Hoyal, chairman of the Women's Division of the National Committee, featured the annual luncheon of the Westchester County Women's Republican Club, held yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

LONDON, May 20 (AP). -- Hopes of an American victory in the Derby at Epsom Downs next Wednesday were placed strictly up to William Woodward's Boswell and Flares today when the New York banker included his two thoroughbreds, along with twenty-six other 3-year-olds, all colts, in the list of final acceptances.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 20. -- New York State farmers eyed weather predictions gloomily tonight and counted their crop losses in the thousands of dollars as the result of a series of unseasonable frosts, high winds and snowstorms.

The addition of three operas to the repertoire, "Aida," "Pagliacci" and "Traviata"; the debut of Arthur Carron, English tenor, winner of the recent radio audition, and the appearance of Edith Mason as Violetta in "Traviata," will mark the third week of the Metropolitan Opera Spring season, it was announced yesterday.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

About 1,500 teachers, school supervisors and representatives of various educational and community groups paid tribute to Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, newly appointed member of the Board of Education, at a reception and tea yesterday in the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the Kindergarten-6B Teachers Association, of which Mrs. Lindlof is president, in cooperation with the other groups.

Changes to be shown in today's statement of the Bank of France, covering the week ended on last Friday, are likely to be less spectacular than those in recent previous reports. The week in question witnessed the drying up of the drain on the bank's gold, and, presumably, this should have carried with it a relaxation of the demand for currency and of the discounting of domestic bills.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 20. -- Putting together a pair of 41s over the tricky, wind-swept Nassau Country Club Course, Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Women's National captured low gross honors in the Long Island Women's Golf Association one-day tournament today.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- Prices of hogs advanced 5 to 15 cents a hundred weight in the early trading here today, but leading packers refused to follow the advances and as soon as the urgent demand had been satisfied the market reacted and trading in the final rounds was about in line with the finish on Tuesday.

Valerie Elizabeth Huff, San Francisco society girl and former Albertina Rasch dancer, scored a double victory before Supreme Court Justice Cotillo yesterday in her suit for $250,000 damages against Charles Redfield Vose, wealthy insurance broker, for inducing her to marry him in 1932 when he allegedly knew a Mexican divorce obtained from a previous wife was not valid.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 20. -- The German dirigible Hindenburg, which completed one ocean crossing this morning, embarked tonight on her trip back to Frankfort-on-the-Main. Forty-one passengers came over on her and fifty-one were aboard when she left at 11:05 P.M.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Governor Lehman's firmly worded refusal to stand for re-election was accepted in Washington as a major political development. The President was undoubtedly disappointed, for he has been making personal efforts to persuade the Governor to go to the polls with him in New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 20. -- The three-day festival of American music at the Westminster Choir School here closed tonight with first performances of nine more original compositions by contemporary American composers. Thirteen unpublished works for piano, viola and 'cello, choral groups and string quartet were performed yesterday.

A handbag full of rough uncut Russian emeralds, valued at $3,000,000 and said by the importer to be the largest and most valuable gem cargo ever brought here, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain.
We had heard that Doc was getting ready to open his camp this week-end, and so we stopped in at his house the other night to find out how things were going.

The colors of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt were again in front yesterday at Belmont Park when his Gallant Mac, an acquisition from the Audley Farm, came on gamely in the stretch and captured the featured Ben Brush Handicap in 1:51 for the mile and an eighth.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., May 20. -- Max Schmeling, in his third day of preparation for his fifteen-round bout with Joe Louis at the Yankee Stadium next month, had an impressive workout at his training camp today.
LONDON, May 20. -- The late King George's racing cutter, Britannia, which has won more races than any other yacht in the world, will be "buried at sea."

Governor HOFFMAN'S services as an amateur detective, corrector of courts and administrator of super-justice were almost adequately rewarded by his fellow-Republicans. FRANKLIN FORT, who at the eleventh hour became a candidate against him, on the sole issue of his behavior in the Hauptmann case, has polled an enormous vote.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies receives a bequest of $250,000, subject to a reduction if this amount is in excess of 10 per cent of the estate, in the will of Arthur Lehman, banker and brother of Governor Herbert H. Lehman, which was filed for probate yesterday.

" Keep the home fires burning" will be the postoffice's slogan for veterans on the night of June 15. That will be the night mail carriers in this city will deliver bonus bonds to 208,000 ex-service men. The bonds will not be left unless the persons to whom they are addressed are at home to sign receipts.

Prices of investment securities are "very high," Hugh Knowlton, a partner in Kuhn, Loeb Co., said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

The first finance congress of women, supported by a committee from eighteen States, will be held in the Palmer House, Chicago, on June 3 and 4, it was announced yesterday by Miss Catherine Curtis, national director of Women Investors in America, Inc.

Henry Klauber, counsel for John Fiorenza, on trial in General Sessions Court for the murder of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, told the jury in his opening yesterday that "a fiend" had attacked another woman tenant at 22 Beekman Place a few days before Mrs. Titterton was strangled with her own pajameas on April 10.

Declaring that an "unprecedented concentration of reactionary forces is taking place" around the Republican party, Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, declared last night at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden that the "main enemy of the people of America" today and in the coming campaign is the "Republican-Liberty League-Hearst combination."
